Daf 2a

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">Partners who wished to make a partition [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">meḥitza</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>a jointly owned <span class="gemarra-regular">courtyard build </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the wall </span>for the partition <span class="gemarra-regular">in the middle </span>of the courtyard. What is this wall fashioned from? In <span class="gemarra-regular">a place where it is customary to build </span>such a wall with <span class="gemarra-regular">non-chiseled stone </span><span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">g</span><span class="gemarra-italic">evil</span><span class="gemarra-regular">], </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">chiseled stone </span><span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">g</span><span class="gemarra-italic">azit</span><span class="gemarra-regular">], </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">small bricks [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">kefisin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">], </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">large bricks [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">leveinim</span><span class="gemarra-regular">], they must build </span>the wall with that material. <span class="gemarra-regular">Everything is in accordance with the regional </span><span class="gemarra-regular">custom</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
If they build the wall with <span class="gemarra-regular">non-chiseled stone, this </span>partner <span class="gemarra-regular">provide</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> three handbreadths </span>of his portion of the courtyard <span class="gemarra-regular">and that </span>partner <span class="gemarra-regular">provides three handbreadths, </span>since the thickness of such a wall is six handbreadths. If they build the wall with <span class="gemarra-regular">chiseled stone, this </span>partner <span class="gemarra-regular">provides two and a half handbreadths and that </span>partner <span class="gemarra-regular">provides two and a half handbreadths, </span>since such a wall is five handbreadths thick. If they build the wall <span class="gemarra-regular">with small bricks, this </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">provides two handbreadths and that </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">provides two handbreadths, </span>since the thickness of such a wall is four handbreadths. If they build <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span><span class="gemarra-regular">large bricks</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> this </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">provides one and a half handbreadths and that </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">provides one and a half handbreadths, </span>since the thickness of such a wall is three handbreadths. <span class="gemarra-regular">Therefore, if the wall </span>later <span class="gemarra-regular">falls</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the assumption is that <span class="gemarra-regular">the space </span>where the wall stood <span class="gemarra-regular">and the stones belong to both of them, </span>to be divided equally.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And similarly with regard to a garden</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> in <span class="gemarra-regular">a place where it is customary to build a partition </span>in the middle of a garden jointly owned by two people, and one of them wishes to build such a partition, the court <span class="gemarra-regular">obligates </span>his neighbor to join in building the partition. <span class="gemarra-regular">But with regard to </span>an expanse of <span class="gemarra-regular">fields [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">babbika</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> in <span class="gemarra-regular">a place where it is customary not to build a partition </span>between two people’s fields, and one person wishes to build a partition between his field and that of his neighbor, the court <span class="gemarra-regular">does not obligate </span>his neighbor to build such a partition.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, if </span>one person <span class="gemarra-regular">wishes </span>to erect a partition, <span class="gemarra-regular">he must withdraw into his own </span>field <span class="gemarra-regular">and build </span>the partition there. <span class="gemarra-regular">And he makes </span>a border <span class="gemarra-regular">mark on the outer side </span>of the barrier facing his neighbor’s property, indicating that he built the entire structure of his own materials and on his own land. <span class="gemarra-regular">Therefore, if the wall </span>later <span class="gemarra-regular">falls, </span>the assumption is that <span class="gemarra-regular">the space </span>where the wall stood <span class="gemarra-regular">and the stones </span>belong only <span class="gemarra-regular">to him, </span>as is indicated by the mark on the wall.
Nevertheless, in a place where it is not customary to build a partition between two people’s fields, <span class="gemarra-regular">if they made </span>such a partition <span class="gemarra-regular">with the agreement of the two of them, they build it in the middle, </span>i.e., on the property line, <span class="gemarra-regular">and make </span>a border <span class="gemarra-regular">mark on the one </span>side <span class="gemarra-regular">and on the other </span>side. <span class="gemarra-regular">Therefore, if the wall </span>later <span class="gemarra-regular">falls, </span>the assumption is that <span class="gemarra-regular">the space </span>where the wall stood <span class="gemarra-regular">and the stones </span>belong <span class="gemarra-regular">to both of them, </span>to be divided equally.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Sages initially <span class="gemarra-regular">assumed: What </span>is the meaning of the term <span class="gemarra-italic">meḥitza</span> mentioned in the mishna? It means <span class="gemarra-regular">a partition, as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: Consider the case where <span class="gemarra-regular">a partition of [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">meḥitzat</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">vineyar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> which separates the vineyard from a field of grain <span class="gemarra-regular">was breached, </span>resulting, if the situation is not rectified, in the grain and grapes becoming items from which deriving benefit is prohibited due to the prohibition of diverse kinds planted in a vineyard. The owner of the field of grain may <span class="gemarra-regular">say to </span>the owner of the vineyard: <span class="gemarra-regular">Build a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">partitio</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> between the vineyard and the field of grain. If the owner of the vineyard did so, and the partition <span class="gemarra-regular">was breached again, </span>the owner of the field of grain may <span class="gemarra-regular">say to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">hi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">m</span> again: <span class="gemarra-regular">Build a partition. </span>

Daf 2b

If the owner of the vineyard <span class="gemarra-regular">neglecte</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> to make the necessary repairs <span class="gemarra-regular">and did not </span>properly <span class="gemarra-regular">build a partition </span>between the fields, the grain and grapes are <span class="gemarra-regular">rendered forbidde</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> due to the prohibition of diverse kinds planted in a vineyard, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he is liable for the </span>monetary <span class="gemarra-regular">loss. </span>He must compensate the owner of the grain for the damage suffered, as it is the vineyard owner’s fault that deriving benefit from the grain is now prohibited.
According to the understanding that the term <span class="it-text">meḥitza</span> means a partition, one can infer: <span class="gemarra-regular">The reason </span>that they build a wall <span class="gemarra-regular">is that they </span>both <span class="gemarra-regular">wished </span>to make a partition in their jointly owned courtyard. <span class="gemarra-regular">But if they did not </span>both <span class="gemarra-regular">wish </span>to do so, the court <span class="gemarra-regular">does not obligate </span>the reluctant partner to build such a wall, although his neighbor objects to the fact that the partner can see what he is doing in his courtyard. <span class="gemarra-regular">Apparently, </span>it may be concluded that <span class="gemarra-regular">damage </span>caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">sight, </span>that is, the discomfort suffered by someone because he is exposed to the gaze of others while he is in his own private domain, <span class="gemarra-regular">is not called damage.</span>
The Gemara objects to this conclusion: <span class="gemarra-regular">But say </span>that the term <span class="gemarra-italic">meḥitza</span> used in the mishna means <span class="gemarra-regular">a division, as it is written: “And the division of [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">meḥetzat</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] the congregation was” </span>(Numbers 31:43), referring to the half of the spoil that belonged to the entire congregation. According to this interpretation the mishna means: <span class="gemarra-regular">Since they wished </span>to divide the jointly owned courtyard, <span class="gemarra-regular">they build </span>a proper <span class="gemarra-regular">wall </span>in the center even <span class="gemarra-regular">against the will </span>of one of the partners. <span class="gemarra-regular">Apparently, </span>it may be concluded that <span class="gemarra-regular">damage </span>caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">sight is called damage.</span>
The Gemara rejects this line of reasoning: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">so </span>that the term <span class="it-text">meḥitza</span> means a division, the words: <span class="gemarra-regular">Who wished to make a division, </span>are imprecise, as the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">should have said: Who wished to divide. Rather, what </span>is the meaning of the term <span class="it-text">meḥitza</span>? <span class="gemarra-regular">A partition. </span>The Gemara retorts: If so, the words: <span class="gemarra-regular">They build the wall, </span>are imprecise, as the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">should have said: They build it, </span>since the wall and the partition are one and the same. The Gemara responds: <span class="gemarra-regular">Had </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">taught: </span>They build <span class="gemarra-regular">it, I would say that a mere partition of pegs [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">bimseifas</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> would suffice. He therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>that they build an actual <span class="gemarra-regular">wall, </span>all in accordance with the regional custom.
The mishna teaches: Partners who wished to make a partition in a jointly owned courtyard <span class="gemarra-regular">build the wall </span>for the partition <span class="gemarra-regular">in the middle </span>of the courtyard. The Gemara asks: Isn’t it <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious </span>that if they agree to build a wall it should be built in the middle? Why should one of them contribute more than the other?
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>to state this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where one </span>of the partners <span class="gemarra-regular">went ahea</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and convinced the other </span>that they should build a partition. <span class="gemarra-regular">Lest you say </span>that the second <span class="gemarra-regular">can </span>later <span class="gemarra-regular">say to </span>the first when the latter comes to begin construction: <span class="gemarra-regular">When I was persuaded by you </span>to build a partition, it was <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to the airspace</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> I agreed to the erection of a minimal barrier that would result in a loss of open space in the courtyard. <span class="gemarra-regular">But I was not persuaded by you with regard to the use </span>of the courtyard. I did not agree to forfeit any usable space on the ground in my share of the courtyard for the building of a wall. To counter this, the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>that since they agreed to make a partition, they must each contribute a part of the courtyard for the building of the wall.
§ After having determined that the wording of the mishna is unproblematic only if the term <span class="it-text">meḥitza</span> means a wall, it follows that damage caused by sight is not called damage. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And is damage </span>caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">sight </span>in fact <span class="gemarra-regular">not called damage? </span>The Gemara provides <span class="gemarra-regular">a mnemoni</span><span class="gemarra-regular">c</span> for the proofs, which follow, that challenge this assumption: <span class="gemarra-regular">Garden, wall, compels, and they divide, windows, as Rav Naḥman.</span>
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>that which the mishna teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">And similarly with regard to a garden</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> in a place where it is customary to build a partition in the middle of a garden jointly owned by two people, and one of them wishes to build such a partition, the court obligates his neighbor to join in building the partition. This indicates that invading one’s privacy by looking at him while he is in his private domain is called damage.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">A garden is differen</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> with regard to the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> governing invasion of privacy, <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Abba, as Rabbi Abba says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibited for a person to stan</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in another’s field </span>and look at his crop <span class="gemarra-regular">while </span>the grain <span class="gemarra-regular">is standing, </span>because he casts an evil eye upon it and thereby causes him damage, and the same is true for a garden. Since the issue in this case is damage resulting from the evil eye, no proof can be brought with regard to the matter of damage caused by sight.
The Gemara objects: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches: And similarly </span>with regard to a garden, which suggests that a garden and a courtyard are governed by the same rationale. The Gemara answers: The term: And similarly, is stated not with regard to the reason for the obligation to construct a wall, but <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">non-chiseled and chiseled stones.</span> A partition in a garden is built with the same materials used for the building of a wall in a courtyard, in accordance with regional custom.
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a proof from a mishna (5a): In the case of a dividing <span class="gemarra-regular">wall </span>in a jointly owned <span class="gemarra-regular">courtyard that fell</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> if one of the owners wishes to rebuild the wall, the court <span class="gemarra-regular">obligates </span>the other owner <span class="gemarra-regular">to build </span>the wall with him again <span class="gemarra-regular">up to </span>a height of <span class="gemarra-regular">four cubits. </span>This indicates that damage caused by sight is called damage. The Gemara rejects this proof: The case of a wall that <span class="gemarra-regular">fell is different</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span> since a wall had already stood there, the court compels the owners to rebuild it as it was.
The Gemara expresses its astonishment: <span class="gemarra-regular">And he who asked </span>the question, <span class="gemarra-regular">why did he ask it </span>at all? The mishna is clearly referring to a wall that has fallen, which means that the joint owners have already agreed in the past to build a partition between their respective portions. The Gemara answers: He who asked the question maintains that the joint owners can be compelled to build a wall even in a case where a wall had not stood there before, to prevent any invasion of privacy. And the mishna does not address the case of a wall that fell to teach that only in such a case is there an obligation to build a wall. Rather, <span class="gemarra-regular">it was necessary </span>to teach <span class="gemarra-regular">the latter clause</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> which states that even in a case where there had previously been a high wall the court <span class="gemarra-regular">does not obligate him </span>to rebuild it <span class="gemarra-regular">higher than four cubits, </span>because once there is a wall of four cubits there is no further invasion of privacy.
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>an additional proof that damage caused by sight is called damage, from what is taught in a mishna (7b): The residents of a courtyard <span class="gemarra-regular">can compel </span>each inhabitant of that courtyard <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>financially participate in the <span class="gemarra-regular">building of a gatehouse and a door to the </span>jointly owned <span class="gemarra-regular">courtyard, </span>so that the courtyard not be open to the eyes of those standing in the public domain. <span class="gemarra-regular">Learn from it </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">damage </span>caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">sight is called damage. </span>The Gemara answers: This is not a proof to the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in the case of two neighbors, as the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage </span>of being exposed to the gaze <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span>the general <span class="gemarra-regular">public, </span>which has unimpeded sight of what is happening in the courtyard, <span class="gemarra-regular">is different </span>and certainly called damage.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And is </span>exposure to the sight of <span class="gemarra-regular">an individual not </span>considered damage? <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a proof that it is called damage from what is taught in a mishna (11a): <span class="gemarra-regular">One divides a courtyard </span>at the request of one of the co-owners <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>if its area is sufficient so <span class="gemarra-regular">that there will be in it four </span>by four <span class="gemarra-regular">cubits for this one and four </span>by four <span class="gemarra-regular">cubits for that one, </span>that is, the same minimal dimensions for each of the co-owners. This means that <span class="gemarra-regular">if there is enough for this </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">and enough for that </span>one, <span class="gemarra-regular">they do divide </span>the courtyard at the request of one of the owners. <span class="gemarra-regular">What, is it not </span>so that the courtyard must be divided <span class="gemarra-regular">with a wall </span>that will prevent one neighbor from seeing the other? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>perhaps it is divided <span class="gemarra-regular">with a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">mere partition of pegs </span>through which one can still see.
The Gemara further suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>another proof that damage caused by sight is called damage from what is taught in a mishna (22a): One who desires to build a wall opposite <span class="gemarra-regular">the windows </span>of a neighbor’s house must distance the wall <span class="gemarra-regular">four cubits </span>from the windows, <span class="gemarra-regular">whether above, below, or opposite. And </span>a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is taught with regard to </span>that mishna: Concerning the requirement of a distance <span class="gemarra-regular">above, </span>the wall must be high <span class="gemarra-regular">enough so that one cannot peer </span>into the window <span class="gemarra-regular">and see </span>into the window; concerning the requirement of a distance <span class="gemarra-regular">below, </span>the wall must be low <span class="gemarra-regular">so that he will not </span>be able to <span class="gemarra-regular">stand </span>on top of it <span class="gemarra-regular">and see </span>into the window; <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>concerning the requirement of a distance <span class="gemarra-regular">opposite, </span>one must distance the wall from the windows <span class="gemarra-regular">so that it will not darken </span>his neighbor’s house by blocking the light that enters the house through the window. This indicates that there is a concern about the damage caused by exposure to the gaze of others.
The Gemara rejects this argument: The <span class="gemarra-regular">damage </span>of being exposed to the sight of others while <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>one’s own <span class="gemarra-regular">house is different</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as people engage in activities in their homes that they do not want others to see. By contrast, a courtyard is out in the open and it is possible that the residents are indifferent to being observed.
The Gemara challenges this distinction: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a proof, <span class="gemarra-regular">as Rav Naḥman says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel says: </span>If one’s <span class="gemarra-regular">roof is adjacent to another’s courtyard</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he must make a parapet </span>around the roof <span class="gemarra-regular">four cubits high </span>so that he will not be able to see into his neighbor’s courtyard. This indicates that the damage of being exposed to the eyes of others even in a courtyard is called damage. The Gemara refutes this proof: The situation <span class="gemarra-regular">is different there, as the owner of the courtyard can say to the owner of the roof: I </span>make <span class="gemarra-regular">use </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">my </span>courtyard <span class="gemarra-regular">on a regular </span>basis. <span class="gemarra-regular">You, </span>by contrast, <span class="gemarra-regular">do not </span>make <span class="gemarra-regular">use </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">your </span>roof <span class="gemarra-regular">on a regular </span>basis, but only infrequently. Consequently, <span class="gemarra-regular">I do not know when you will go up </span>to the roof, 

Daf 3a

<span class="gemarra-regular">so that I can hide from you </span>at that time and avoid coming under your gaze.
§ The Gemara has so far presented one version of the discussion of the mishna. <span class="gemarra-regular">A different version relates </span>the discussion as follows: The Sages initially <span class="gemarra-regular">assumed: What </span>is the meaning of the term <span class="gemarra-italic">meḥitza</span> mentioned in the mishna? <span class="gemarra-regular">A division, </span>not a partition, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is written: “And the division of [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">meḥetzat</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] the congregation was” </span>(Numbers 31:43). According to this interpretation, the mishna means to say: <span class="gemarra-regular">Since they wished </span>to divide the jointly owned courtyard, <span class="gemarra-regular">they buil</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> a proper <span class="gemarra-regular">wall </span>in the center even <span class="gemarra-regular">against the will </span>of one of the partners. <span class="gemarra-regular">Apparently, </span>it may be concluded that <span class="gemarra-regular">damage </span>caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">sight is called damage.</span>
The Gemara objects to this conclusion: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>why not <span class="gemarra-regular">say: What </span>is the meaning of the term <span class="gemarra-italic">meḥitza</span> mentioned in the mishna? It means <span class="gemarra-regular">a partition. </span>This usage would be <span class="gemarra-regular">as we learned </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: Consider the case where <span class="gemarra-regular">a partition of [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">meḥitzat</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] a vineyard </span>which separates the vineyard from a field of grain <span class="gemarra-regular">was breached, </span>resulting, if the situation is not rectified, in the grain and grapes becoming items from which deriving benefit is prohibited. The owner of the field of grain may <span class="gemarra-regular">say to </span>the owner of the vineyard: <span class="gemarra-regular">Build a partition </span>between the vineyard and the field of grain. If the owner of the vineyard did so, and the partition <span class="gemarra-regular">was breached again, </span>the owner of the field of grain may <span class="gemarra-regular">say to him </span>again: <span class="gemarra-regular">Build a partition. </span>If the owner of the vineyard <span class="gemarra-regular">neglected </span>to make the necessary repairs <span class="gemarra-regular">and did not </span>properly <span class="gemarra-regular">build a partition </span>between the fields, the grain and grapes are <span class="gemarra-regular">rendered forbidden </span>due to the prohibition of diverse kinds planted in a vineyard, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he is liable for the </span>monetary <span class="gemarra-regular">loss.</span>
The Gemara concludes stating the objection: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>according to the understanding that the term <span class="it-text">meḥitza</span> means a partition, one can infer: <span class="gemarra-regular">The reason </span>that they build a wall is <span class="gemarra-regular">that they </span>both <span class="gemarra-regular">wished </span>to make a partition in their jointly owned courtyard. <span class="gemarra-regular">But if they did not </span>both <span class="gemarra-regular">wish </span>to do so, the court <span class="gemarra-regular">does not obligate </span>the reluctant partner to build such a wall, although his neighbor objects to the fact that the partner can see what he is doing in his courtyard. <span class="gemarra-regular">Apparently, </span>it may be concluded that <span class="gemarra-regular">damage </span>caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">sight is not called damage.</span>
The Gemara rejects this argument: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so,</span> the words: <span class="gemarra-regular">They build the wall, </span>are imprecise, as the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">should have said: They build it, </span>since the wall and the partition are one and the same. The Gemara retorts: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, what </span>is the meaning of the term <span class="it-text">meḥitza</span>? <span class="gemarra-regular">A division. If </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">so </span>that the term <span class="it-text">meḥitza</span> means a division, the words: <span class="gemarra-regular">Who wished to make a division, </span>are imprecise, as the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">should have said: Who wished to divide. </span>The Gemara answers: The phrasing of the mishna is <span class="gemarra-regular">as people </span>commonly <span class="gemarra-regular">say: Come, let us make a division. </span>Consequently, the mishna can also be understood as referring to two people who wished to divide a jointly owned area.
The Gemara asks, according to the understanding that <span class="it-text">meḥitza</span> means division: <span class="gemarra-regular">But if damage </span>caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">sight is called damage, why </span>does the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">specifically </span>teach that <span class="gemarra-regular">if they wish, </span>they build a wall? <span class="gemarra-regular">Even if they did not </span>both <span class="gemarra-regular">wish </span>to do so, it should <span class="gemarra-regular">also </span>be possible to compel the reluctant party to build a wall between them. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Asi said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Our mishna </span>is referring to a courtyard <span class="gemarra-regular">that is not subject to the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of division. </span>Joint owners of a courtyard cannot be compelled to divide the courtyard unless each party will receive at least four square cubits of the courtyard. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>therefore, <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>ruling of the mishna applies only in the case <span class="gemarra-regular">where they </span>both <span class="gemarra-regular">wished </span>to divide the courtyard.
The Gemara asks: According to this understanding, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">teaching us? </span>Is he teaching us <span class="gemarra-regular">that when </span>a courtyard <span class="gemarra-regular">is not subject to the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of division, if they </span>nevertheless <span class="gemarra-regular">wished </span>to do so, <span class="gemarra-regular">they divide </span>it? But <span class="gemarra-regular">we </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">learned </span>this in the latter clause of a different mishna (11a): <span class="gemarra-regular">When </span>do they not divide the courtyard because it is not large enough to compel division? <span class="gemarra-regular">When </span>the joint owners <span class="gemarra-regular">do not both wish </span>to divide it. <span class="gemarra-regular">But when both of them wish </span>to divide it, <span class="gemarra-regular">they divide </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>if it is <span class="gemarra-regular">smaller than this, </span>i.e., smaller than four square cubits for each party. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>we had learned this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> only <span class="gemarra-regular">from there, I would say </span>that they divide the courtyard <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>if it is <span class="gemarra-regular">smaller than this by </span>constructing <span class="gemarra-regular">a mere partition of pegs, </span>which does not prevent invasion of privacy. Therefore, the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us here </span>in this mishna that if they wish to divide the courtyard they can be compelled to build a proper <span class="gemarra-regular">wall.</span>
The Gemara asks: If so, <span class="gemarra-regular">let </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">teach this </span>mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">and not teach that </span>other mishna, as this mishna teaches more details than the later one. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">It was necessary for </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> to teach the other mishna to introduce <span class="gemarra-regular">the last clause </span>of that mishna, which states: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>jointly owned <span class="gemarra-regular">sacred writings </span>that are contained in a single scroll <span class="gemarra-regular">should not be divided even if both </span>owners <span class="gemarra-regular">wish </span>to do so.
The Gemara brings <span class="gemarra-regular">a different version </span>of the previous discussion: <span class="gemarra-regular">And if they wished </span>to divide the courtyard, <span class="gemarra-regular">what of it? </span>What forces them to build the wall? If one of the parties does not wish to build a wall, <span class="gemarra-regular">let him retract. Rav Asi said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan said </span>that the mishna is not discussing a case where they merely reached a verbal agreement to divide the courtyard, but rather with a case where each party <span class="gemarra-regular">performed </span>an act of <span class="gemarra-regular">acquisition with </span>the other, confirming their respective commitments. Therefore, neither side can retract.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather than teaching us </span>a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the courtyard <span class="gemarra-regular">is not subject to the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of division, but </span>nevertheless <span class="gemarra-regular">they wished </span>to divide it, <span class="gemarra-regular">let </span>the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teach us </span>a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the courtyard <span class="gemarra-regular">is subject to the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of division, even if they did not </span>both <span class="gemarra-regular">wish </span>to divide it. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Had it taught us </span>only a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the courtyard <span class="gemarra-regular">is subject to the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of division </span>that applies <span class="gemarra-regular">even if they did not </span>both <span class="gemarra-regular">wish </span>to divide it, <span class="gemarra-regular">I would say </span>that in a case where the courtyard <span class="gemarra-regular">is not subject to the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of division </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">even if they </span>both <span class="gemarra-regular">wished </span>to divide it, if one of the parties does not wish to build a proper wall he <span class="gemarra-regular">cannot </span>be compelled to do so. Therefore, the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>that he is compelled to participate.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But how can you say this? Doesn’t the latter clause </span>of the mishna (11a) <span class="gemarra-regular">teach: When </span>do they not divide the courtyard because it is not large enough to compel division? <span class="gemarra-regular">When the </span>joint owners <span class="gemarra-regular">do not both wish </span>to divide it. <span class="gemarra-regular">But when both of them wish </span>to divide it, <span class="gemarra-regular">they divide </span>it even if it is smaller than this. <span class="gemarra-regular">What, </span>is this clause of the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the fact that either one can force the other to build a proper <span class="gemarra-regular">wall? </span>The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>it is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">a mere partition of pegs </span>and not to an actual wall.
The Gemara asks: If so, <span class="gemarra-regular">let </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">teach this </span>mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">and not teach that </span>other mishna, as this mishna teaches more details than the later one. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">It was necessary </span>to teach the other mishna for <span class="gemarra-regular">the last clause </span>of that mishna, which states: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>jointly owned <span class="gemarra-regular">sacred writings </span>that are contained in a single scroll <span class="gemarra-regular">should not be divided even if both </span>owners <span class="gemarra-regular">wish </span>to do so. This concludes the alternative version of the discussion.
The Gemara continues its analysis of the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">To what </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">did you interpret the mishna </span>to be referring? To a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the courtyard <span class="gemarra-regular">is not subject to the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of division. </span>But <span class="gemarra-regular">if there is no </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of division, </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">if they wished </span>to divide the courtyard, <span class="gemarra-regular">what of it; </span>how can either one force the other to build a wall? If the parties no longer want to build a wall, <span class="gemarra-regular">let them retract. Rabbi Asi said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan said: </span>It is referring to a case where each party <span class="gemarra-regular">performed </span>an act of <span class="gemarra-regular">acquisition with </span>the other, confirming their respective commitments. Therefore, neither party can retract.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>even <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>each party <span class="gemarra-regular">performed </span>an act of <span class="gemarra-regular">acquisition with </span>the other, <span class="gemarra-regular">what of it</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> It is merely a verbal acquisition, </span>meaning there was no actual transfer of property, but only a verbal agreement to act in a certain manner in the future and not a true act of acquisition. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">They performed </span>an act of <span class="gemarra-regular">acquisition with </span>the other <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to directions, </span>i.e., not only did they verbally agree to divide the courtyard, they also determined which of them would get which part of the courtyard. Consequently, the acquisition related to actual property, a particular plot of land. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi said: For example, this one walke</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> through his </span>designated portion and <span class="gemarra-regular">performed an act demonstrating ownershi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">p</span> there, <span class="gemarra-regular">and that one walked through his </span>designated portion <span class="gemarra-regular">and performed an act demonstrating ownership </span>there.
§ The mishna teaches: In <span class="gemarra-regular">a place where it is customary to build </span>such a wall with non-chiseled stone [<span class="it-text">g</span><span class="it-text">evil</span>], or chiseled stone [<span class="it-text">g</span><span class="it-text">azit</span>], or small bricks [<span class="it-text">kefisin</span>], or large bricks [<span class="it-text">leveinim</span>], they must build the wall with that material. The Gemara identifies the various building materials: <span class="gemarra-italic">Gevi</span><span class="gemarra-italic">l</span> refers to <span class="gemarra-regular">stones that are not planed. </span><span class="gemarra-italic">Gazi</span><span class="gemarra-italic">t</span> means <span class="gemarra-regular">stones that are planed, as it is written: “All these were of costly stones, according to the measures of chiseled stones </span><span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">gazit</span><span class="gemarra-regular">], </span>sawed with saws, within and without” (I Kings 7:9). This teaches that chiseled stones are those that have been planed and smoothened. <span class="gemarra-italic">Kefisin</span> refers to <span class="gemarra-regular">small bricks. </span><span class="gemarra-italic">Leveinim</span> means <span class="gemarra-regular">large bricks.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba, the son of Rava, said to Rav Ashi: From where </span>do you know <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span><span class="gemarra-italic">gevil</span> refers to <span class="gemarra-regular">stones that are not planed, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and this extra handbreadth </span>that a wall of <span class="it-text">gevil</span> has compared to what a wall of <span class="it-text">gazit</span> has is <span class="gemarra-regular">for the protruding edges? </span>That is, a wall of <span class="it-text">gevil</span> is six handbreadths thick because the stones have not been planed and smoothened, and therefore protrude somewhat outward. <span class="gemarra-regular">Perhaps </span><span class="it-text">gevil</span> refers to planed stones that <span class="gemarra-regular">are half </span>the thickness <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span><span class="gemarra-italic">gazit</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>namely, just two and a half handbreadths, as compared to <span class="it-text">gazit</span>, which is five handbreadths thick; <span class="gemarra-regular">and this extra handbreadth </span>in a wall of <span class="it-text">gevil</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>for the space <span class="gemarra-regular">between the </span>two <span class="gemarra-regular">rows [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">urbei</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> That is, a wall of <span class="it-text">gevil</span> is actually two walls of planed stones that are each two and a half handbreadths thick; and the two walls are separated by one handbreadth, which is later filled in with mortar for added strength.
A proof for this explanation can be brought from <span class="gemarra-regular">what we say, </span>i.e., that <span class="gemarra-italic">kefisin</span> are <span class="gemarra-regular">small bricks, </span>whereas <span class="gemarra-italic">leveinim</span> are <span class="gemarra-regular">large bricks, </span>twice the thickness of small bricks. <span class="gemarra-regular">And this extra handbreadth </span>of thickness that a wall of <span class="it-text">kefisin</span> has compared to what a wall of <span class="it-text">levinim</span> has is for the space <span class="gemarra-regular">between the </span>two <span class="gemarra-regular">rows </span>of small bricks.
Rav Ashi <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: And according to your reasoning, from where do we </span>derive that <span class="gemarra-italic">kefisin</span> are <span class="gemarra-regular">small bricks</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rather, </span>the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">learned this as a tradition. </span>And <span class="gemarra-regular">so</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> too, they learned as a tradition </span>that <span class="gemarra-italic">gevil</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> refers to non-planed stones.</span>
The Gemara presents a different version of the discussion. <span class="gemarra-regular">There are </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">who say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Aḥa, son of Rav Avya, said to Rav Ashi: From where </span>do you know <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kefisin</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> are small bricks, </span>one-half the width of large bricks, <span class="gemarra-regular">and this extra handbreadth </span>of thickness that a wall of <span class="it-text">kefisin</span> has compared to what a wall of <span class="it-text">leveinim</span> has covers the space <span class="gemarra-regular">between the </span>two <span class="gemarra-regular">rows </span>of <span class="it-text">kefisin</span>? <span class="gemarra-regular">Perhaps </span>you should say <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>are <span class="gemarra-italic">kefisin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? Stones that </span>are <span class="gemarra-regular">not planed, and this extra handbreadth </span>of thickness that a wall of <span class="it-text">kefisin</span> has in comparison to what a wall of <span class="it-text">leveinim</span> has <span class="gemarra-regular">is for the protruding edges. </span>And proof for this explanation can be brought from <span class="gemarra-regular">what we say, </span>i.e., that <span class="gemarra-italic">gevil</span> refers to <span class="gemarra-regular">stones that </span>are <span class="gemarra-regular">not planed, </span>whereas <span class="gemarra-italic">gazit</span> means <span class="gemarra-regular">planed stones, and this extra handbreadth </span>of thickness that a wall of <span class="it-text">gevil</span> has compared to what a wall of <span class="it-text">gazit</span> has <span class="gemarra-regular">is for the protruding edges.</span>
Rav Ashi <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: And according to your reasoning, from where do we </span>derive that <span class="gemarra-italic">gevil</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> are stones that </span>are <span class="gemarra-regular">not planed? Rather, </span>the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">learned </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">as a tradition. Here too, they learned as a tradition </span>that <span class="it-text">kefisin</span> are small bricks.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said: Learn from i</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> that the space left <span class="gemarra-regular">between the </span>two <span class="gemarra-regular">rows </span>of a wall <span class="gemarra-regular">is always a handbreadth. </span>The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">This matter </span>applies only when the two rows of the wall are filled in <span class="gemarra-regular">with mortar. But </span>when they are filled in <span class="gemarra-regular">with gravel [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">berikhsa</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> more </span>space <span class="gemarra-regular">is required. And there are </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">who say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">this matter </span>applies only when the two rows of the wall are filled in <span class="gemarra-regular">with gravel. But when mortar </span>is used to fill in the space, <span class="gemarra-regular">not as much </span>space <span class="gemarra-regular">is required, </span>and less than a handbreadth suffices.
§ The Gemara asks: Is this <span class="gemarra-regular">to say that </span>in the case of a wall of <span class="gemarra-regular">chiseled stone, if for every four cubits of height there are five </span>handbreadths <span class="gemarra-regular">of thickness </span>the wall <span class="gemarra-regular">will stand, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">if not it will not stand, </span>as this is the required ratio between a wall’s height and its thickness? <span class="gemarra-regular">But wasn’t there </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">one-cubit-thick wall separating the Holy of Holies from the Sanctuary of the Temple [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">amah</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">teraksin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> separating the Holy of Holies from the Sanctuary, <span class="gemarra-regular">which was thirty cubits high and its thickness was only six handbreadths and </span>nevertheless <span class="gemarra-regular">stood? </span>The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Since there was an extra handbreadt</span><span class="gemarra-regular">h</span> of thickness, it was able to <span class="gemarra-regular">stand </span>even to such a great height.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And what is the reason </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">in the Second Temple they did not fashion an </span><span class="gemarra-italic">amah</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">teraksin</span> to separate between the Holy of Holies and the Sanctuary, as they had done in the First Temple? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">When </span>a partition <span class="gemarra-regular">stands </span>even though it is only six handbreadths thick, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is </span>able to remain standing up to <span class="gemarra-regular">thirty </span>cubits in height. But <span class="gemarra-regular">it will not </span>be able to <span class="gemarra-regular">stand </span>if it is <span class="gemarra-regular">more </span>than that height. The Second Temple was taller than the First Temple, and therefore the partition separating the Holy of Holies from the Sanctuary also had to be higher.
The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">And from where do we </span>derive <span class="gemarra-regular">that</span> the Second Temple <span class="gemarra-regular">was taller </span>than the First Temple? <span class="gemarra-regular">As it is written: “The glory of this latter house shall be greater than that of the former” </span>(Haggai 2:9). <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav and Shmuel </span>disagree about the meaning of this verse, <span class="gemarra-regular">and some say </span>it was <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan and Rabbi Elazar </span>who disagreed as to its meaning. <span class="gemarra-regular">One </span>of them <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>that it means that the Second Temple will be greater <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the size of its <span class="gemarra-regular">structure</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., taller. <span class="gemarra-regular">And one </span>of them <span class="gemarra-regular">said</span>

Daf 3b

that it will be greater <span class="gemarra-regular">in years, </span>meaning that the Second Temple will stand for a longer period of time than the First Temple. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the Gemara comments that <span class="gemarra-regular">this is </span>true <span class="gemarra-regular">and that is </span>true, meaning that the Second Temple was taller than the First Temple and also stood for a longer period of time.
The Gemara asks: If so, if the Second Temple building was taller, then to separate between the Holy of Holies and the Sanctuary in the Second Temple <span class="gemarra-regular">they should have made a wall thirty cubits </span>high <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">made a curtain </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">the rest </span>of the height, the seventy-cubit difference in height between the First and Second Temples. The Gemara answers: This would have been impossible, as <span class="gemarra-regular">even when a thirty-cubit </span>wall that is six handbreadths thick <span class="gemarra-regular">stands, it is due to the ceiling and plaster </span>which attaches it to the ceiling that <span class="gemarra-regular">it stands. </span>But <span class="gemarra-regular">without a ceiling and plaster </span>holding it in place, <span class="gemarra-regular">it does not stand.</span>
The Gemara continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">But they should have made a wall </span>as high <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>can <span class="gemarra-regular">possibly </span>stand by itself, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>then should have <span class="gemarra-regular">made a curtain </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">the rest </span>of the height. <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said: </span>The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">learned </span>as a tradition that the partition separating the Holy of Holies from the Sanctuary should be built <span class="gemarra-regular">either entirely as a wall or entirely as a curtain. </span>It should be built <span class="gemarra-regular">either entirely as a wall, </span>as is learned <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the First <span class="gemarra-regular">Temple, or </span>it should be built <span class="gemarra-regular">entirely as a curtain, </span>as is learned <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">Tabernacle. </span>At no time, however, was there a partition that combined a wall and a curtain.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">A dilemma was raised before </span>the Sages: Do the measurements given in the mishna apply to <span class="gemarra-regular">them, </span>the thickness of the materials themselves, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the plaste</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> with which the materials were coated, <span class="gemarra-regular">or perhaps </span>just to <span class="gemarra-regular">them without their plaster? Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: It is reasonable </span>to say the measurements refer to <span class="gemarra-regular">them and their plaster, as, if </span>it should <span class="gemarra-regular">enter your mind </span>to say they refer to <span class="gemarra-regular">them without their plaster, </span>then the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">should have taught the measurements </span>of the plaster as well. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, isn’t it </span>correct to <span class="gemarra-regular">conclude from here </span>that the measurements refer to <span class="gemarra-regular">them and their plaster? </span>The Gemara rejects this conclusion: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, actually I </span>could <span class="gemarra-regular">say to you </span>that they apply to <span class="gemarra-regular">them without their plaster, and since </span>the plaster <span class="gemarra-regular">does not have </span>the thickness of <span class="gemarra-regular">one handbreadth </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">did not teach </span>such a small measurement.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But doesn’t </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">teach with regard to bricks </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">provides one and a half handbreadths, and that </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">provides one and a half handbreadths? </span>Evidently, the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> lists even an amount less than one handbreadth. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">There </span>mention is made of half-handbreadths because <span class="gemarra-regular">they are fit to be combined </span>into a full handbreadth.
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a solution to the question, from a mishna (<span class="it-text">Eiruvin</span> 13b) in which it is taught: <span class="gemarra-regular">The </span>cross <span class="gemarra-regular">beam</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> which </span>the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">state</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> may be used to render an alleyway fit for one to carry within it on Shabbat, must be <span class="gemarra-regular">wide enough to receive </span>and hold <span class="gemarra-regular">a small brick. And </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">small brick </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">half a large brick, </span>the width <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span>which is <span class="gemarra-regular">three handbreadths. </span>That mishna is referring to a brick without the plaster.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">There, </span>the mishna in <span class="it-text">Eiruvin</span> is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">large bricks </span>that measure three full handbreadths, whereas here the mishna is referring to bricks that measure slightly less than three handbreadths, and the measurement of three handbreadths includes the plaster with which they are coated. The Gemara comments: The language of the mishna there <span class="gemarra-regular">is also precise, as it teaches </span>about a brick <span class="gemarra-regular">of three handbreadths, </span>from which one can conclude <span class="gemarra-regular">by inference that there exists </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">a smaller-</span>sized brick. The Gemara affirms: <span class="gemarra-regular">Learn from here </span>that the mishna there is referring to large bricks.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥisda says: A person may not demolis</span><span class="gemarra-regular">h</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a synagogu</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> until he </span>first <span class="gemarra-regular">builds another synagogue </span>to take its place. <span class="gemarra-regular">There are </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">who say </span>that the reason for this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">due to </span>potential <span class="gemarra-regular">negligence</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> lest he fail to build a new structure after the old one has been razed. <span class="gemarra-regular">And there are </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">who say </span>that the reason for this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">due to </span>the disruption of <span class="gemarra-regular">prayer, </span>for in the meantime there will be nowhere to pray.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is </span>the practical difference <span class="gemarra-regular">between </span>these two explanations? The Gemara answers that <span class="gemarra-regular">there is </span>a difference <span class="gemarra-regular">between them </span>in a situation <span class="gemarra-regular">where there is another synagogue. </span>Even though the community has an alternative place to pray there is still a concern that the new synagogue will never get built. It is related that <span class="gemarra-regular">Mareimar and Mar Zutr</span><span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> demolished and built a summer synagogue in the winter, and, </span>in like manner, <span class="gemarra-regular">they built a winter synagogue in the summer</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> so that the community would never be left without a synagogue.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Ravina said to Rav Ashi: What </span>is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> if <span class="gemarra-regular">money </span>for the construction of a new synagogue <span class="gemarra-regular">has </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">been collected and it rests </span>before us for that purpose? Is it then permitted to demolish the old synagogue before building the new one? Rav Ashi <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>Even if the money has been collected there is still concern that <span class="gemarra-regular">perhaps </span>an opportunity for <span class="gemarra-regular">redeeming captive</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> will present itself, and they will hand over </span>the money for that urgent requirement, and the community will be left without a synagogue.
Ravina continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> if <span class="gemarra-regular">the bricks </span>to be used for the construction of the new synagogue <span class="gemarra-regular">are piled up, the boards are prepared, and the beams are ready? </span>Is it permitted to demolish the old synagogue before building the new one? Rav Ashi <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>Even so, <span class="gemarra-regular">sometimes </span>an opportunity for <span class="gemarra-regular">redeeming captives will present itself, and they will sell </span>the building materials <span class="gemarra-regular">and hand over </span>the proceeds for this purpose. Ravina raises an objection: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, </span>that is, if you are concerned that they will sell the materials to redeem captives, then <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>in a case where <span class="gemarra-regular">they </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">buil</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> the synagogue there should be a concern that they might come to sell the structure for that purpose, and therefore one should never be permitted to destroy an old synagogue. Rav Ashi <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: People do not sell their residences, </span>and certainly not their synagogues.
The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">And we said </span>that an old synagogue must not be razed before its replacement is built <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where cracks are not seen </span>in the old synagogue. <span class="gemarra-regular">But if cracks are see</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> they may </span>first <span class="gemarra-regular">demolish </span>the old synagogue <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">build </span>the new one. <span class="gemarra-regular">This is like </span>the incident involving <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi, </span>who <span class="gemarra-regular">saw cracks in the synagogue </span>in his town <span class="gemarra-regular">of Mata Meḥasya </span>and immediately <span class="gemarra-regular">demolished it. He </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">brought his bed in there, </span>to the building site, so that there should be no delays in the construction, as he himself required shelter from the rain, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he did not remove </span>his bed from there <span class="gemarra-regular">until they </span>finished building the synagogue and even <span class="gemarra-regular">affixed drainpipes </span>to the structure.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">How could Bava ben But</span><span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> have advised Hero</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to raze the Temple </span>and build another in its place, as will be described later? <span class="gemarra-regular">But doesn’t Rav Ḥisda say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a person must not demolish a synagogue unless he </span>first <span class="gemarra-regular">builds another synagogue </span>to take its place? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">If you wish, say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">he saw cracks in </span>the old Temple structure. And <span class="gemarra-regular">if you wish, say </span>that actions taken by <span class="gemarra-regular">the government are different, as </span>the government <span class="gemarra-regular">does not go back </span>on its decisions. Therefore, there is no need to be concerned about negligence, as there is in the case of ordinary people. <span class="gemarra-regular">As Shmuel says: If the government says </span>it will <span class="gemarra-regular">uproot mountains, it will uproot mountains and not retract</span> its word.
§ The Gemara elaborates on the episode involving Bava ben Buta. <span class="gemarra-regular">Herod was a slave in the house of the Hasmoneans. He set his eyes upon a certain young girl </span>from the house of the Hasmoneans. <span class="gemarra-regular">One day that man, </span>Herod, <span class="gemarra-regular">heard a Divine Voic</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that said: Any slave who rebels now will succeed. He rose up </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">killed all his masters, but spared that girl. When that girl saw that he wanted to marry her, she went up to the roof and raised her voice, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">said: Whoever comes and says: I come from the house of the Hasmoneans, is a slave, since only that girl, </span>i.e., I, <span class="gemarra-regular">remained from them. And that girl fell from the roof to the ground </span>and died.
It is related that Herod <span class="gemarra-regular">preserved </span>the girl’s body <span class="gemarra-regular">in honey for seven years </span>to prevent it from decaying. <span class="gemarra-regular">There are </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">who say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">he engaged in necrophilia with her </span>corpse and <span class="gemarra-regular">there are </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">who say he did not engage in necrophilia with her </span>corpse. According to those <span class="gemarra-regular">who say</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he engaged in necrophilia with her </span>corpse, the reason <span class="gemarra-regular">that he preserved her </span>body was <span class="gemarra-regular">to gratify his </span>carnal <span class="gemarra-regular">desires. And </span>according to those <span class="gemarra-regular">who say he did not engage in necrophilia with her </span>corpse, the reason <span class="gemarra-regular">that he preserved her </span>body was <span class="gemarra-regular">so that </span>people <span class="gemarra-regular">would say he married a king’s daughter.</span>
Herod <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>to himself: <span class="gemarra-regular">Who expounds </span>the verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“One from among your brothers you shall set as king over you” </span>(Deuteronomy 17:15) as meaning that he who is appointed as king must come from a Jewish family and cannot be an emancipated slave or a convert? It is <span class="gemarra-regular">the Sages </span>who expound the verse in this manner, insisting that a king must have Jewish roots. <span class="gemarra-regular">He </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">rose up and killed all the Sages, </span>but <span class="gemarra-regular">spared Bava ben Buta in order to take counsel with him. </span>

Daf 4a

Herod <span class="gemarra-regular">placed a garland </span>made <span class="gemarra-regular">of porcupin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> hide <span class="gemarra-regular">on </span>Bava ben Buta’s head, which <span class="gemarra-regular">pricked his eyes out. One day </span>Herod <span class="gemarra-regular">came and sat before him </span>without identifying himself in order to test him. <span class="gemarra-regular">He, </span>Herod, <span class="gemarra-regular">said: See, Master, what this evil slave </span>Herod <span class="gemarra-regular">is doing. </span>Bava ben Buta <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: What should I do to him? </span>Herod <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>The <span class="gemarra-regular">Master should curse him. </span>Bava ben Buta <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>But <span class="gemarra-regular">it is written: “Do not curse the king, not even in your thoughts” </span>(Ecclesiastes 10:20). Herod <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: He is not a king, </span>since he rules illegally. Bava ben Buta <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: And </span>even if <span class="gemarra-regular">he were merely a rich man </span>I would not curse him, as <span class="gemarra-regular">it is written: “And do not curse a rich person in your bedchamber” </span>(Ecclesiastes 10:20). <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>even <span class="gemarra-regular">were he only a leader </span>I would not curse him, as <span class="gemarra-regular">it is written: “And you shall not curse a leader among your people” </span>(Exodus 22:27).
Herod <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>That <span class="it-text">halakha</span> stated <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>“a leader among your people,” that is, to a fit Jew who <span class="gemarra-regular">acts as </span>a member of <span class="gemarra-regular">your people, </span>i.e., in accordance with Torah law, <span class="gemarra-regular">and this one does not do the deeds of your people. </span>Bava ben Buta <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>Nevertheless, <span class="gemarra-regular">I am afraid of him. </span>Herod <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: There is nobody who will go and tell him, since you and I are sitting </span>here alone. Bava ben Buta <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>Nevertheless, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is written: “For a bird of the sky shall carry the sound, and that which has wings shall tell the matter” </span>(Ecclesiastes 10:20).
Herod <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: I am he. Had I known that the Sages were so cautious I would not have killed them. Now, what is that man’s remedy, </span>i.e., what can I do to repent for my sinful actions? Bava ben Buta <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: He </span>who <span class="gemarra-regular">extinguished the light of the world </span>by killing the Torah Sages, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is written: “For the mitzva is a lamp, and the Torah is light” </span>(Proverbs 6:23), <span class="gemarra-regular">should go and occupy himself with the light of the world, </span>the Temple, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is written </span>with regard to the Temple: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And all the nations shall flow [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">venaharu</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] unto it” </span>(Isaiah 2:2), the word <span class="it-text">venaharu</span> alluding to light [<span class="it-text">nehora</span>]. <span class="gemarra-regular">There are </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">who say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>is what <span class="gemarra-regular">he said to him: He </span>who <span class="gemarra-regular">blinded the eye of the world, as it is written </span>in reference to the Sages: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And if </span>it be committed through ignorance <span class="gemarra-regular">by the eyes of the congregation” </span>(Numbers 15:24), <span class="gemarra-regular">should go and occupy himself with the eye of the world, </span>the Temple, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is written: “I will desecrate my Temple, the pride of your strength, the delight of your eyes” </span>(Ezekiel 24:21).
Herod <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: I am afraid of the </span>Roman <span class="gemarra-regular">government, </span>that they will not permit me to make changes in the Temple. Bava ben Buta <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Send a messenger </span>who will <span class="gemarra-regular">travel </span>there for <span class="gemarra-regular">a year, and remain </span>there for another <span class="gemarra-regular">year, and </span>take yet another <span class="gemarra-regular">year </span>to <span class="gemarra-regular">return. In the meantime, you can demolish </span>the Temple <span class="gemarra-regular">and rebuild it. He did so. </span>Eventually, <span class="gemarra-regular">they sent </span>a message <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>Herod from Rome: <span class="gemarra-regular">If you have not </span>yet <span class="gemarra-regular">demolished it, do not demolish it; and if you have </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">demolished it, do not rebuild it; and if you have demolished it and </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">rebuilt it, </span>you shall be counted among <span class="gemarra-regular">those who act wickedly, seeking counsel </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">after they have </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">acted. </span>Even <span class="gemarra-regular">if you are armed </span>and in command of a military force, <span class="gemarra-regular">your book, </span>i.e., your genealogical record, <span class="gemarra-regular">is here. </span>You are <span class="gemarra-regular">neither a king [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">reikha</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> nor the son of a king, </span>but rather <span class="gemarra-regular">Herod the slave who has made himself a freeman [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">kelonya</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is the meaning of the word <span class="gemarra-italic">reikha</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? </span>It denotes <span class="gemarra-regular">royalty, as it is written: “I am today a tender [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">rakh</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] and anointed king” </span>(II Samuel 3:39). <span class="gemarra-regular">And if you wish, say </span>that the meaning of the word is learned <span class="gemarra-regular">from here, </span>from the term describing Joseph after he was appointed viceroy to the king: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And they cried before him, </span><span class="gemarra-italic">Avrekh</span><span class="gemarra-regular">” </span>(Genesis 41:43).
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">say: One who has not seen Herod’s building has never seen a beautiful building in his life. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">With what did he build it? Rabba said: With stones of white and green marble [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">umarmara</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> There are </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">who say </span>that he built it <span class="gemarra-regular">with stones of blue, white, and green marble. </span>Alternate rows of stones <span class="gemarra-regular">sent out an edge </span>a bit <span class="gemarra-regular">and drew in an edge </span>a bit, <span class="gemarra-regular">so that they would </span>better <span class="gemarra-regular">receive </span>and hold <span class="gemarra-regular">the plaster. He considered covering it with gold, </span>but <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis said to him: Leave it, </span>and do not cover it, <span class="gemarra-regular">since it is more beautiful this </span>way, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it looks like the waves of the sea.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And how did Bava ben Buta do this, </span>i.e., give advice to Herod the wicked? <span class="gemarra-regular">But doesn’t Rav Yehuda say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says, and some say </span>it was <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi </span>who says: <span class="gemarra-regular">For what </span>reason <span class="gemarra-regular">was Daniel punished</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Because he offered advic</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to Nebuchadnezzar, as </span>after sharing a harsh prophecy with him, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is stated: “Therefore, O king, let my counsel be acceptable to you, redeem your sins with charity and your iniquities with graciousness to the poor, that there may be a lengthening of your prosperity” </span>(Daniel 4:24). <span class="gemarra-regular">And it is written: “All this came upon King Nebuchadnezzar” </span>(Daniel 4:25). <span class="gemarra-regular">And it is written: “And at the end of twelve months” </span>(Daniel 4:26). Only after a year was the prophecy fulfilled but not before that, apparently because Nebuchadnezzar heeded Daniel’s advice.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">If you wish, say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a slave </span>like Herod <span class="gemarra-regular">is different since he is obligated in the mitzvot, </span>and therefore Bava ben Buta had to help him repent. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if you wish, say the Temple is different, as without </span>the help of <span class="gemarra-regular">the government it would not have been built.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And from where do we </span>derive <span class="gemarra-regular">that Daniel was punished? If we say </span>we know this <span class="gemarra-regular">because it is written: “And Esther called for Hatach, </span>one of the king’s chamberlains, whom he had appointed to attend upon her” (Esther 4:5), <span class="gemarra-regular">and Rav said: Hatach is Daniel. This works out well according to the one who says </span>Daniel was called Hatach because <span class="gemarra-regular">they cut him down [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ḥatakh</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] from his greatness </span>and turned him into a minor attendant. <span class="gemarra-regular">But according</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to the one who says </span>he was called Hatach <span class="gemarra-regular">because all governmental matters were determined [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ḥatakh</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] according to his word, what is there to say? </span>What punishment did he receive? The Gemara answers: His punishment was <span class="gemarra-regular">that they threw him into the den of lions.</span>
§ The mishna teaches: In a place where it is customary to build a wall of non-chiseled stone, or chiseled stone, or small bricks, or large bricks, they must build the partition with that material. <span class="gemarra-regular">Everything is in accordance with the regional custom. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>does the word <span class="gemarra-regular">everything </span>serve <span class="gemarra-regular">to add? </span>The Gemara answers: It serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to add a place where </span><span class="gemarra-regular">it is customary </span>to build a partition <span class="gemarra-regular">out of palm and laurel branches</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> In such a place, the partition is built from those materials.
