The mishna teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">Therefore, if the wall </span>later <span class="gemarra-regular">falls, </span>the assumption is that <span class="gemarra-regular">the space </span>where the wall stood <span class="gemarra-regular">and the stones belong to both of them, </span>to be divided equally. The Gemara questions the need for this ruling: Isn’t it <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious </span>that this is the case, since both neighbors participated in the construction of the wall? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>to teach this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> for a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the entire wall <span class="gemarra-regular">fell into the domain of one of them</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Alternatively, </span>it is necessary in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where one of them </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">cleare</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> all the stones <span class="gemarra-regular">into his </span>own <span class="gemarra-regular">domain. Lest you say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the other </span>party <span class="gemarra-regular">should be </span>governed by the principle that <span class="gemarra-regular">the burden of proof rests upon the claimant, </span>that is, if the other party should have to prove that he had been a partner in the construction of the wall, the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>that they are presumed to have been partners in the building of the wall, and neither requires further proof.
§ The mishna continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">And similarly with regard to a garden, </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">a place where it is customary to build a partition </span>in the middle of a garden jointly owned by two people, and one of them wishes to build such a partition, the court <span class="gemarra-regular">obligates </span>his neighbor to join in building the partition. The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>matter <span class="gemarra-regular">itself </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">difficult. </span>On the one hand, <span class="gemarra-regular">you said: And similarly with regard to a garden, </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">a place where it is customary to build a partition </span>in the middle of a garden jointly owned by two people, and one of them wishes to build such a partition, the court <span class="gemarra-regular">obligates </span>his neighbor to join in building the partition. One can infer <span class="gemarra-regular">that ordinarily, </span>where there is no custom, the court <span class="gemarra-regular">does not obligate him </span>to build a partition.
But <span class="gemarra-regular">say the latter clause </span>of the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>with regard to an expanse of <span class="gemarra-regular">fields, </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">a place where it is customary not to build a partition </span>between two people’s fields, and one person wishes to build a partition between his field and that of his neighbor, the court <span class="gemarra-regular">does not obligate </span>his neighbor to build such a partition. One can infer <span class="gemarra-regular">that ordinarily, </span>where there is no custom, the court <span class="gemarra-regular">obligates him </span>to build a partition. The Gemara explains the difficulty: <span class="gemarra-regular">Now </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">you said </span>by inference that in <span class="gemarra-regular">an ordinary garden </span>the court <span class="gemarra-regular">does not </span>obligate him to build a partition, <span class="gemarra-regular">is it necessary </span>to say that the court does not obligate him to build a partition in <span class="gemarra-regular">an ordinary field? </span>Clearly in a field there is less of a need for a partition, as there is less damage caused by exposure to the gaze of others.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>is what the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is saying: And similarly </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">an ordinary garden, and </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">in a place where it is customary to build a partition in </span>an expanse of <span class="gemarra-regular">fields, </span>the court <span class="gemarra-regular">obligates him </span>to build a partition. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said to him: If so, what </span>is the point of the word: <span class="gemarra-regular">But, </span>mentioned afterward in connection with an expanse of fields, which seems to indicate that the issue of fields had not yet been addressed? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Rava said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>is what the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is teaching: And similarly an ordinary garden is </span>treated <span class="gemarra-regular">like a place where it is customary to build a partition, and </span>therefore the court <span class="gemarra-regular">obligates him </span>to build a partition. <span class="gemarra-regular">But an ordinary </span>expanse of <span class="gemarra-regular">fields is </span>treated <span class="gemarra-regular">like a place where it is customary not </span>to build a partition, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>therefore the court <span class="gemarra-regular">does not obligate him </span>to build one.
§ The mishna teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, if </span>one person <span class="gemarra-regular">wishes </span>to erect a partition, <span class="gemarra-regular">he must withdraw into his own </span>field <span class="gemarra-regular">and build </span>the partition there. <span class="gemarra-regular">And he makes </span>a border <span class="gemarra-regular">mar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">k</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> on the outer side </span>of the barrier facing his neighbor’s property, indicating that he built the entire structure of his own materials and on his own land. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is the meaning of a border <span class="gemarra-regular">mark? Rav Huna said: He bends the edge </span>of the wall <span class="gemarra-regular">toward the outside</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Let him make it on the inside. </span>The Gemara explains: In that case, <span class="gemarra-regular">his neighbor might also make </span>a mark <span class="gemarra-regular">on the outside, </span>that is, on the side facing his own property, <span class="gemarra-regular">and say: </span>The wall <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>both <span class="gemarra-regular">mine and his. </span>The Gemara responds: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, </span>that is, there is a concern about such deception, <span class="gemarra-regular">now also </span>when the person who builds the wall makes a border mark on the outer side of the wall, <span class="gemarra-regular">his neighbor might cut it off and say: </span>The wall <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>both <span class="gemarra-regular">mine and his. </span>The Gemara answers: Such <span class="gemarra-regular">a cut is noticeable </span>and the deception will not work.
<span class="gemarra-regular">There are </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">who say </span>that in answer to the question: What is the meaning of a border mark, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna said: He bends the edge </span>of the wall <span class="gemarra-regular">toward the inside. </span>The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Let him make it on the outside. </span>The Gemara explains: In that case, <span class="gemarra-regular">his neighbor might cut it off and say: </span>The wall <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>both <span class="gemarra-regular">mine and his. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, </span>that is, there is a concern for such deception, <span class="gemarra-regular">now also </span>when the person who builds the wall makes a border mark toward the inside, <span class="gemarra-regular">his neighbor might add </span>a border mark on his own side <span class="gemarra-regular">and say: </span>The wall <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>both <span class="gemarra-regular">mine and his. </span>The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">An addition is noticeable </span>and the deception will not work. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But doesn’t </span>the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teach </span>that he makes the border mark <span class="gemarra-regular">on the outside </span>and not on the inside? The Gemara comments: This is <span class="gemarra-regular">a difficulty.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan said: </span>

Daf 4b

The party who builds the wall <span class="gemarra-regular">should smear i</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> with clay <span class="gemarra-regular">up to a cubi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> at the top of the wall <span class="gemarra-regular">on the outside</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Let him do </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">on the inside. </span>The Gemara explains: In that case, <span class="gemarra-regular">his neighbor might </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">do </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">on the outside, </span>that is, on the side facing his own property, <span class="gemarra-regular">and say: </span>The wall <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>both <span class="gemarra-regular">mine and his. </span>The Gemara responds: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, </span>that is, if there is a concern for such deception, <span class="gemarra-regular">now also </span>when the person who builds the wall smears it with clay on the outside, <span class="gemarra-regular">his neighbor can peel it off and say: </span>The wall <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>both <span class="gemarra-regular">mine and his. </span>The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">Peeling </span>clay <span class="gemarra-regular">is noticeable </span>and the deception will not succeed.
The Gemara asks: If he builds a partition of <span class="gemarra-regular">palm branches, </span>how does he make a border mark? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman said: He directs the tips of the branche</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to the outside</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Let him do </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">to the inside. </span>The Gemara states: If he so directs the branches, <span class="gemarra-regular">his neighbor might also do </span>the same <span class="gemarra-regular">to the outside, </span>that is, to the side facing his own property, <span class="gemarra-regular">and say: </span>The partition <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>both <span class="gemarra-regular">mine and his. </span>The Gemara objects: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, </span>that is, if there is concern for such deception, <span class="gemarra-regular">now also </span>when the one who builds the partition directs the tips of the branches to the outside, the neighbor <span class="gemarra-regular">can cut off </span>the tips <span class="gemarra-regular">and throw </span>them away, <span class="gemarra-regular">and say: </span>The partition <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>both <span class="gemarra-regular">mine and his. </span>The Gemara counsels: <span class="gemarra-regular">He should smear </span>the tips of the palm branches <span class="gemarra-regular">with clay. </span>The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">Now also, the neighbor might come and peel </span>the clay off. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Peeling is noticeable.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said: </span>One who builds a partition of <span class="gemarra-regular">palm branches has no remed</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span> to prove who erected it, <span class="gemarra-regular">except with </span>a written <span class="gemarra-regular">document. </span>The neighbor should draw up a document stating that he has no claim to the space or to the partition, because they belong exclusively to the other neighbor.
§ The mishna teaches: Nevertheless, in a place where it is not customary to build a partition between two people’s fields, <span class="gemarra-regular">if they made </span>such a partition <span class="gemarra-regular">with the agreement of the two of them, </span>they build it in the middle, i.e., on the property line, and make a border mark on the one side and on the other side. Therefore, if the wall later falls, the assumption is that the space where the wall stood and the stones belong to both of them, to be divided equally. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava from Parzika said to Rav Ashi: Neither this one nor that one should make </span>a border mark. Rav Ashi <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: No, </span>this ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">is necessary </span>in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where one of them went ahead and made </span>a border mark <span class="gemarra-regular">for himself, </span>so that <span class="gemarra-regular">if his neighbor does not make </span>one as well, the first one <span class="gemarra-regular">will say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">it is </span>entirely <span class="gemarra-regular">his.</span>
Rava from Parzika asked him: <span class="gemarra-regular">And is the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span> of the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaching us a remedy </span>to be used <span class="gemarra-regular">against a swindler? </span>Rav Ashi <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: But isn’t the former clause </span>of the mishna’s ruling also <span class="gemarra-regular">a remedy </span>to be used <span class="gemarra-regular">against a swindler? </span>That clause teaches that one who builds a wall should make a border mark to indicate that the wall is his.
Rava from Parzika <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Granted, </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">the former clause </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">taught the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> that if one wishes to build a partition between his own field and that of his neighbor, he does so at his own expense and on his own land, <span class="gemarra-regular">and due to </span>the need to teach that <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">taught a remedy </span>to be used against a swindler. <span class="gemarra-regular">But does he teach a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> in <span class="gemarra-regular">the latter clause, </span>so <span class="gemarra-regular">that he </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches a remedy </span>to be used against a swindler? <span class="gemarra-regular">Ravina said: Here, </span>in the latter clause, <span class="gemarra-regular">we are dealing with </span>a barrier made of <span class="gemarra-regular">palm branches. </span>This is <span class="gemarra-regular">to the exclusion </span>of the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Abaye, who said: </span>One who builds a partition of <span class="gemarra-regular">palm branches has no remedy </span>to prove who erected it, <span class="gemarra-regular">except with </span>a written <span class="gemarra-regular">document. He teaches us that </span>a border <span class="gemarra-regular">mark suffices.</span>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who surrounds </span><span class="gemarra-regular">anothe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">on three sides, </span>that is, he owns parcels of land on three sides of the other person’s field, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he built a partition </span>on <span class="gemarra-regular">the first, the second, and the third </span>sides, the court <span class="gemarra-regular">does not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">obligat</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> the neighbor who owns the inner field to contribute to the construction of the partition if he does not wish to do so. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei says: If he arose and built a partition </span>on <span class="gemarra-regular">the fourth </span>side of the field, the court <span class="gemarra-regular">imposes upon </span>the owner of the inner field the responsibility to pay his share for <span class="gemarra-regular">all </span>of the partitions.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel says: </span>The <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei, who says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">if he arose and built a partition </span>on <span class="gemarra-regular">the fourth </span>side of the field, the court <span class="gemarra-regular">imposes upon </span>the owner of the inner field the responsibility to pay his share for <span class="gemarra-regular">all </span>of the partitions. The Gemara comments: It <span class="gemarra-regular">is no different </span>if it was the owner of the <span class="gemarra-regular">surrounded </span>field who <span class="gemarra-regular">arose </span>and built a partition on the fourth side, and it <span class="gemarra-regular">is no different </span>if it was the owner of the <span class="gemarra-regular">surrounding </span>field who <span class="gemarra-regular">arose </span>and built a partition on the fourth side. The <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is the same in both cases.
<span class="gemarra-regular">It was stated </span>that the <span class="it-text">amora’im</span> disagreed with regard to the following point. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna says </span>that when Rabbi Yosei said the court obligates the owner of the inner field to pay his share for <span class="gemarra-regular">all </span>of the partitions, he pays <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with what </span>the other person actually spent when he <span class="gemarra-regular">built the partitions</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> That is, the owner of the inner field must contribute his share according to the cost of the partition his neighbor built. <span class="gemarra-regular">Ḥiyya bar Rav says: </span>He must pay his share for <span class="gemarra-regular">all </span>of the partitions <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with a reduced </span>assessment of the <span class="gemarra-regular">price of reeds</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and no more. The owner of the surrounded field can claim he had no desire for a more substantial partition.
The Gemara attempts to bring a proof from what <span class="gemarra-regular">we learned </span>in the mishna: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who surrounds another on three sides, </span>that is, he owns parcels of land on three sides of the other person’s field, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he built a partition </span>on <span class="gemarra-regular">the first, the second, and the third </span>sides, the court <span class="gemarra-regular">does not obligate </span>the neighbor who owns the inner field to contribute to the construction of the partition. By inference, if he also built a partition on the <span class="gemarra-regular">fourth </span>side of the field, the court <span class="gemarra-regular">does obligate </span>the owner of the inner field to contribute to the building of the partition. The Gemara continues with its proof: <span class="gemarra-regular">Say the latter clause </span>of the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei says: If he arose and built a partition </span>on <span class="gemarra-regular">the fourth </span>side of the field, the court <span class="gemarra-regular">imposes upon </span>the owner of the inner field the responsibility to pay his share for <span class="gemarra-regular">all </span>of the partitions. The first <span class="it-text">tanna</span> and Rabbi Yosei seem to be stating the same ruling.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, according to Rav Huna, who says </span>that the owner of the inner field pays for <span class="gemarra-regular">all </span>of the partitions <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with what </span>the other person actually spent when he <span class="gemarra-regular">built the partitions, this is </span>the difference <span class="gemarra-regular">between the first </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and Rabbi Yosei: The first </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">maintains </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">yes, </span>he pays his share for <span class="gemarra-regular">all </span>of the partitions <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with a reduced </span>assessment of the <span class="gemarra-regular">price of reeds, but not </span>a larger sum in accordance with <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>the other person actually spent when he <span class="gemarra-regular">built the partitions. And Rabbi Yosei maintains </span>that he pays his share for <span class="gemarra-regular">all </span>of the partitions <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with what </span>the other person actually spent when he <span class="gemarra-regular">built the partitions.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">But according to Ḥiyya bar Rav, who says </span>he pays his share for <span class="gemarra-regular">all </span>of the partitions <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with the value of </span>a partition fashioned from <span class="gemarra-regular">inexpensive reeds, what </span>difference <span class="gemarra-regular">is there between the first </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and Rabbi Yosei? If </span>according to the first <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">he does not give him </span>his share for all of the partitions in accordance with <span class="gemarra-regular">a reduced </span>assessment of the <span class="gemarra-regular">price of reeds, what does he give him?</span>
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">If you wish, say there is </span>a practical difference <span class="gemarra-regular">between them </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">the wage of a watchman</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> The first </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> maintains </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">yes, </span>since his field is safeguarded by the partition which surrounds it, the one who built the partition can demand payment of <span class="gemarra-regular">the wage of a watchman. </span>He cannot, however, demand the cost of building the partition, <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>even the other’s share for all of the partitions in accordance with <span class="gemarra-regular">a reduced </span>assessment of the <span class="gemarra-regular">price of reeds. And Rabbi Yosei maintains </span>that he can demand the other’s share for all of the partitions in accordance with <span class="gemarra-regular">a reduced </span>assessment of the <span class="gemarra-regular">price of reeds.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if you wish, say there is </span>a practical difference <span class="gemarra-regular">between them </span>with regard to the partitions built on the <span class="gemarra-regular">first, second, and third </span>sides of the inner field. <span class="gemarra-regular">The first </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> maintains </span>that the owner of the inner field must <span class="gemarra-regular">give to </span>his neighbor money for the partition built on the <span class="gemarra-regular">fourth </span>side, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>required to <span class="gemarra-regular">give him </span>money for the partitions built on the <span class="gemarra-regular">first, second, and third </span>sides. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Yosei maintains </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span>must <span class="gemarra-regular">also give him </span>money <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>the partitions built on <span class="gemarra-regular">the first, the second, and the third </span>sides.
The Gemara suggests another difference between the two opinions: <span class="gemarra-regular">If you wish, say there is </span>a practical difference <span class="gemarra-regular">between them </span>with regard to the issue of whether the partition on the fourth side was built by the owner of the <span class="gemarra-regular">surrounding </span>field <span class="gemarra-regular">or </span>by the owner of the <span class="gemarra-regular">surrounded </span>field. This is <span class="gemarra-regular">because the first </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> maintains </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the reason </span>the owner of the <span class="gemarra-regular">surrounded </span>field must contribute his share of the entire expense is <span class="gemarra-regular">that he arose </span>and built a partition on the fourth side of his field. Therefore, the court <span class="gemarra-regular">imposes upon him </span>the responsibility to pay his share for <span class="gemarra-regular">all </span>of the partitions, because his actions demonstrate that he wants the partition between their fields. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if the owner of the <span class="gemarra-regular">surrounding </span>field <span class="gemarra-regular">arose </span>and built a partition on the fourth side of the field, the owner of the surrounded field <span class="gemarra-regular">must give him only </span>his share of <span class="gemarra-regular">the value of </span>the partition of the <span class="gemarra-regular">fourth </span>side.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Yosei maintains </span>that it is <span class="gemarra-regular">no different </span>if it was the owner of the <span class="gemarra-regular">surrounded </span>field who arose and built a partition on the fourth side, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">no different </span>if it was the owner of the <span class="gemarra-regular">surrounding </span>field who arose and built a partition on the fourth side. <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>either one <span class="gemarra-regular">arose and built a partition </span>on the fourth side, the court <span class="gemarra-regular">imposes upon </span>the owner of the inner field the obligation to pay his share for <span class="gemarra-regular">all </span>of the partitions.
The Gemara reports <span class="gemarra-regular">another version </span>of this last answer: <span class="gemarra-regular">There is </span>a practical difference <span class="gemarra-regular">between them </span>with regard to the issue of whether the partition on the fourth side was built by the owner of the <span class="gemarra-regular">surrounding </span>field <span class="gemarra-regular">or </span>by the owner of the <span class="gemarra-regular">surrounded </span>field. <span class="gemarra-regular">The first </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> maintains </span>that even <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>the owner of the <span class="gemarra-regular">surrounding </span>field <span class="gemarra-regular">built a partition </span>on <span class="gemarra-regular">the fourth </span>side, the owner of the surrounded field <span class="gemarra-regular">also gives him </span>his share of the cost of the partitions. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Yosei maintains </span>that only <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>the owner of the <span class="gemarra-regular">surrounded </span>field <span class="gemarra-regular">arose </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">built a partition </span>on <span class="gemarra-regular">the fourth </span>side <span class="gemarra-regular">does he give </span>the owner of the surrounding field his share of the cost of the partitions. Why is that? <span class="gemarra-regular">Because he reveals that he is pleased </span>with the partitions. <span class="gemarra-regular">But if </span>the owner of the <span class="gemarra-regular">surrounding </span>field <span class="gemarra-regular">built a partition</span> on the fourth side, the owner of the surrounded field <span class="gemarra-regular">does not give him anything, </span>as he can continue to claim that he has no interest in the partitions. 

Daf 5a

It is related that a man named <span class="gemarra-regular">Ronya </span>had a field that <span class="gemarra-regular">was surrounded by </span>fields belonging to <span class="gemarra-regular">Ravina on </span>all <span class="gemarra-regular">four sides. </span>Ravina built partitions around his fields and <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Give me </span>your share of the expense <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with what I </span>actually spent when I <span class="gemarra-regular">built the partitions, </span>i.e., half the cost of the partitions. Ronya <span class="gemarra-regular">did not give </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">to him. </span>Ravina said to him: <span class="gemarra-regular">Give me </span>then at least your share of the expense <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with a reduced </span>assessment of the <span class="gemarra-regular">price of reeds. </span>Ronya <span class="gemarra-regular">did not give </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">to him. </span>Ravina said to him: <span class="gemarra-regular">Give me </span>then at least <span class="gemarra-regular">the wage of a watchman. </span>But <span class="gemarra-regular">he did not give</span> even this <span class="gemarra-regular">to him.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">One day, </span>Ronya <span class="gemarra-regular">was harvesting dates. </span>Ravina <span class="gemarra-regular">said to his sharecropper: Go take a cluster [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">kibbura</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of dates from him. </span>The sharecropper <span class="gemarra-regular">went to bring them, </span>but Ronya <span class="gemarra-regular">raised his voice at him </span>in protest, whereupon Ravina <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: You have revealed that you are pleased </span>with the partitions and the protection that they provide you. Even <span class="gemarra-regular">if it were only a goat </span>that entered your field, <span class="gemarra-regular">wouldn’t </span>the field <span class="gemarra-regular">need safeguarding, </span>to prevent the goat from eating the dates? Ronya <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>If it were <span class="gemarra-regular">only a goat, doesn’t </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">need </span>merely <span class="gemarra-regular">to chase it away [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">le’akhluyei</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> No partition is required. Ravina <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: But wouldn’t you need a man to chase </span>the goat <span class="gemarra-regular">away? </span>Pay me then at least the wage of a watchman.
Ravina <span class="gemarra-regular">came before Rava </span>to adjudicate the matter. Rava <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Ronya: <span class="gemarra-regular">Go appease </span>Ravina <span class="gemarra-regular">with what he </span>expressed his willingness to be <span class="gemarra-regular">appeased with, </span>namely, the wage of a watchman. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if not, I will judge you in accordance with </span>the ruling of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei, </span>and you will be required to pay half the cost of the partition based on what Ravina actually spent on it.
Incidental to that episode, the Gemara relates another encounter between Ravina and Ronya. <span class="gemarra-regular">Ronya </span>once <span class="gemarra-regular">bought land adjoining </span>property belonging to <span class="gemarra-regular">Ravina. Ravina considered removing him due to the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of one </span>whose field <span class="gemarra-regular">borders </span>the field of his neighbor. When land is up for sale, the owners of the adjoining fields have the right of first refusal. If one of the neighbors is willing to match the highest price being offered to the seller, that neighbor has the preemptive right to purchase the property, and if somebody else buys it, that buyer can be removed. Since Ravina owned the adjacent property, he thought that he enjoyed the right of first refusal. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Safra, son of Rav Yeiva, said to Ravina: People say: Four </span>dinars <span class="gemarra-regular">for a large hide [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">tzalla</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> four for a small hide [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">tzelala</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]. </span>Since Ronya also owned land bordering the desired parcel, you cannot remove him even though his plot of land is smaller than yours.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In the case of a dividing <span class="gemarra-regular">wall </span>in a jointly owned <span class="gemarra-regular">courtyard that </span><span class="gemarra-regular">fell</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> if one of the owners wishes to rebuild the wall, the court <span class="gemarra-regular">obligates </span>the other owner <span class="gemarra-regular">to build </span>the wall with him <span class="gemarra-regular">up to </span>a height of <span class="gemarra-regular">four </span><span class="gemarra-regular">cubits</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> If after the wall was built one of the neighbors claims he alone constructed it and the other did not participate in its building, the latter is nevertheless <span class="gemarra-regular">presumed to have </span><span class="gemarra-regular">give</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> his share of the money, <span class="gemarra-regular">unless </span>the claimant <span class="gemarra-regular">brings proof that </span>the other <span class="gemarra-regular">did not give </span>his part.
The court <span class="gemarra-regular">does not obligate </span>the reluctant neighbor to contribute to the building of the wall <span class="gemarra-regular">higher than four cubits</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> But if the reluctant neighbor <span class="gemarra-regular">built another wall close </span>to the wall that had been built higher than four cubits, in order to set a roof over the room that was thereby created, the court <span class="gemarra-regular">imposes upon him </span>the responsibility to pay his share for <span class="gemarra-regular">all </span>of the rebuilt wall, <span class="gemarra-regular">even though he has not </span>yet <span class="gemarra-regular">set a roof over it. </span>Since he has demonstrated his desire to make use of what his neighbor built, he must participate in the cost of its construction. If the builder of the first wall later claims that he did not receive payment from his neighbor, the neighbor <span class="gemarra-regular">is presumed not to have given </span>his share of the money, <span class="gemarra-regular">unless he brings proof that he did </span>in fact <span class="gemarra-regular">give </span>money for the building of the wall.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">Reish Lakish says: </span>If a lender <span class="gemarra-regular">set a time for another </span>to repay the loan that he had extended to him <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>when the debt came due the borrower <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>the lender: <span class="gemarra-regular">I </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">repaid you within the time, he is not deemed </span><span class="gemarra-regular">credible</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as people do not ordinarily repay their debts before they are due. The lender would be happy <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>the borrower <span class="gemarra-regular">would only repay </span>his debt <span class="gemarra-regular">on time. Abaye and Rava </span>disagree with Reish Lakish, <span class="gemarra-regular">as they both say: A person is apt to repay </span>his debt <span class="gemarra-regular">within its time, </span>i.e., before it is due. This is because <span class="gemarra-regular">sometimes he happens to have money </span>and the borrower <span class="gemarra-regular">says </span>to himself: <span class="gemarra-regular">I will go </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">repay </span>my debt

Daf 5b

<span class="gemarra-regular">so that he will not trouble me </span>later by constantly demanding the money.
The Gemara attempts to bring a proof in support of the opinion of Abaye and Rava from what <span class="gemarra-regular">we learned </span>in the mishna (5a): If after the wall was built one of the neighbors claims he alone constructed it and the other did not participate in its building, the latter is nevertheless <span class="gemarra-regular">presumed to have given </span>his share of the money, <span class="gemarra-regular">unless </span>the claimant <span class="gemarra-regular">brings proof that </span>the other <span class="gemarra-regular">did not give </span>his part.
The Gemara clarifies the matter: <span class="gemarra-regular">What are the circumstances </span>of the case under discussion? <span class="gemarra-regular">If we say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">he said to him: I paid you at the time </span>when the payment became due, when the wall was completed, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">he is presumed to have given </span>his part. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, is it not that he said to him: I paid you within the time </span>before the payment became due, while the wall was still under construction? And with regard to such a case the mishna states that he is presumed to have given his share. <span class="gemarra-regular">Apparently,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a person is apt to repay </span>his debt <span class="gemarra-regular">within its time, </span>in accordance with the opinion of Abaye and Rava. The Gemara rejects this proof: <span class="gemarra-regular">Here </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">is different, because the time </span>to pay is upon the completion of <span class="gemarra-regular">each and every row</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Payment does not become due specifically at the completion of the entire wall.
The Gemara further suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a proof in support of the opinion of Reish Lakish from the continuation of the mishna (5a): The court does not obligate the reluctant neighbor to contribute to the building of the wall higher than four cubits. But if the reluctant neighbor built another wall close to the wall that had been built higher than four cubits, in order to set a roof over the room that was thereby created, the court imposes upon him the responsibility to pay his share for all of the rebuilt wall, even though he has not yet set a roof over it. If the builder of the first wall later claims he did not receive payment from his neighbor, the neighbor <span class="gemarra-regular">is presumed not to have given </span>his share of the money, <span class="gemarra-regular">unless he brings proof that he did </span>in fact <span class="gemarra-regular">give </span>money for the building of the wall.
The Gemara clarifies the matter: <span class="gemarra-regular">What are the circumstances </span>of the case under discussion? <span class="gemarra-regular">If we say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">he said to him: I paid you at the time </span>that the payment became due, when the wall was completed, <span class="gemarra-regular">why </span>is he <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>deemed credible? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>is it <span class="gemarra-regular">not that he said to him: I paid you within the time </span>before the payment became due, and therefore he is not deemed credible? <span class="gemarra-regular">Apparently, a person is not apt to repay </span>his debt <span class="gemarra-regular">within its time, </span>in accordance with the opinion of Reish Lakish. The Gemara rejects this proof: <span class="gemarra-regular">Here </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">is different, since </span>the reluctant neighbor <span class="gemarra-regular">says: Who says that the Rabbis will obligate me </span>to pay for this wall? In such a case he certainly does not pay before the payment becomes due.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa and Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, acted </span>in such a case <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye and Rava. Mar bar Rav Ashi acted in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Reish Lakish. </span>The Gemara concludes: <span class="gemarra-regular">And the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Reish Lakis</span><span class="gemarra-regular">h</span> that one is not deemed credible when he says that he repaid a loan before it became due. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>if the debtor dies, the court collects payment <span class="gemarra-regular">even from </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">orphan</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> based on this assumption. <span class="gemarra-regular">And even though the Master said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">one who comes to collect </span>money <span class="gemarra-regular">from the property of orphan</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> cannot collect unless </span>he first takes <span class="gemarra-regular">an oath </span>that he did not already collect the debt from the deceased, here he can collect without taking an oath because there is <span class="gemarra-regular">a presumptio</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">a person is not apt to repay </span>his debt <span class="gemarra-regular">within its time.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">A dilemma was raised before </span>the Sages: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> if the lender stipulated a time with the borrower for repayment of the debt, and <span class="gemarra-regular">he demanded </span>payment of the money <span class="gemarra-regular">after the tim</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> that the payment became due had passed, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the borrower <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: I </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">repaid you within the time </span>before the payment became due? <span class="gemarra-regular">Do we say </span>that even <span class="gemarra-regular">where there is a presumption </span>against someone’s claim, as in this case where there is a presumption that people do not pay their debts before they become due, <span class="gemarra-regular">we say </span>that the borrower can claim: <span class="gemarra-regular">Why would I lie? </span>If one of the litigants could have advanced a claim more advantageous to his cause than the one he actually did, the assumption is that he is telling the truth. Consequently, in this case had the borrower wished to lie, he could have said that he repaid his debt when it became due, and he would have been deemed credible. Therefore, when he claims that he repaid it before it came due he should also be deemed credible. 

Daf 6a

<span class="gemarra-regular">Or perhaps where there is a presumption </span>against a person’s claim, <span class="gemarra-regular">we say </span>that the borrower can claim: <span class="gemarra-regular">Why would I lie? </span>The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a proof from the mishna: If after the wall was built one of the neighbors claims he alone constructed it and the other did not participate in its building, the latter is nevertheless <span class="gemarra-regular">presumed to have given </span>his share of the money, <span class="gemarra-regular">unless </span>the claimant <span class="gemarra-regular">brings proof that </span>the other <span class="gemarra-regular">did not give </span>his share.
The Gemara clarifies the matter: <span class="gemarra-regular">What are the circumstances </span>of the case? <span class="gemarra-regular">If we say that </span>one partner <span class="gemarra-regular">demanded </span>that the other party pay the money <span class="gemarra-regular">after the time </span>that the payment became due, i.e., after the wall was rebuilt, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the other partner <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: I paid you at the time </span>that the payment became due, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious </span>that he is presumed to have given him the money. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, is it not </span>a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he said to him: I paid you within the time, </span>i.e., before the payment became due? <span class="gemarra-regular">Apparently, even where there is a presumption </span>against a person’s claim, <span class="gemarra-regular">we say </span>that the defendant can claim: <span class="gemarra-regular">Why would I lie? </span>The Gemara rejects this proof: <span class="gemarra-regular">Here </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">is different, because the time </span>to pay is upon the completion of <span class="gemarra-regular">each and every row. </span>Therefore, it is as if he said: I paid you at the time that the payment became due.
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>another proof from the continuation of the mishna. The court <span class="gemarra-regular">does not obligate</span> the reluctant neighbor to contribute to the building of the part of the wall that is <span class="gemarra-regular">above four cubits. </span>But if the reluctant neighbor <span class="gemarra-regular">built another wall close to </span>the wall that was built higher than four cubits, in order to set a roof over the room that was thereby created, the court imposes upon him the responsibility to pay his share for all of the rebuilt wall, even though he has not yet set a roof over it. If the builder of the first wall later claims that he did not receive payment from his neighbor, the neighbor is presumed not to have given his share of the money, <span class="gemarra-regular">unless he brings proof that he did </span>in fact <span class="gemarra-regular">give </span>money for the building of the wall.
The Gemara clarifies: <span class="gemarra-regular">What are the circumstances </span>of the case? <span class="gemarra-regular">If we say that </span>one partner <span class="gemarra-regular">demanded </span>that the other party pay the money <span class="gemarra-regular">after the time </span>that the payment became due, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he, </span>the latter, <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: I paid you at the time </span>that the payment became due, <span class="gemarra-regular">why </span>is he <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>deemed credible? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, is it not that he said: I paid you within the time, </span>before the payment became due? And with regard to this case, the mishna states that he is not deemed credible. <span class="gemarra-regular">Apparently, where there is a presumption </span>against a person’s claim, <span class="gemarra-regular">we do not say </span>that the defendant can claim: <span class="gemarra-regular">Why would I lie? </span>The Gemara rejects this proof: <span class="gemarra-regular">Here </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">is different, since </span>the reluctant neighbor <span class="gemarra-regular">says: Who says that the Rabbis will obligate me </span>to pay for this additional part of the wall? In such a case he certainly does not pay before the payment becomes due. The mishna does not provide a proof one way or the other.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Aḥa, son of Rava, said to Rav Ashi: Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a proof from what is taught in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Shevuot</span> 38b): If one said to another: <span class="gemarra-regular">I </span>have <span class="gemarra-regular">one hundred dinars in your possession</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and the other one <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him </span>in the presence of witnesses: <span class="gemarra-regular">Yes, </span>that is so; and <span class="gemarra-regular">the next day </span>the lender <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>the borrower: <span class="gemarra-regular">Give me </span>the money that you owe me, the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>the borrower <span class="gemarra-regular">said: I </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">gave it to you, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt. </span>But if he said: <span class="gemarra-regular">Nothing </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">yours </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">in my possession, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable.</span>
The Gemara clarifies the matter: <span class="gemarra-regular">What, is it not </span>that when he says: <span class="gemarra-regular">I </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">gave it to you, he is saying to him: I repaid you at the time </span>that the payment became due; and when he says: <span class="gemarra-regular">Nothing </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">yours</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in my possession, he is saying to him: I repaid you within the time, </span>before the payment became due? <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>yet, the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>with regard to the latter case that he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable. Apparently, where there is a presumption </span>against a person’s claim, <span class="gemarra-regular">we do not say </span>that the borrower can claim: <span class="gemarra-regular">Why would I lie? </span>The Gemara rejects this proof: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, what </span>does he mean when he says: <span class="gemarra-regular">Nothing </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">yours </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">in my possession? </span>He is saying: <span class="gemarra-regular">There were never such matters; </span>i.e., the purported loan never occurred. <span class="gemarra-regular">As the Master says: Anyone who says: I did not borrow</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is </span>treated <span class="gemarra-regular">as one who says: I did not repay, </span>and since it is known by his own admission that he borrowed money, he is liable to pay.
§ The mishna teaches: But if the reluctant neighbor <span class="gemarra-regular">built another wall close to </span>the wall that was built higher than four cubits, in order to set a roof over the room that was thereby created, the court <span class="gemarra-regular">imposes upon him </span>the responsibility to pay his share for <span class="gemarra-regular">all </span>of the rebuilt wall. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna says: </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">he built </span>another wall <span class="gemarra-regular">close to </span>the first wall that was <span class="gemarra-regular">half </span>the length or the height of the wall that was built higher than four cubits, it is as if <span class="gemarra-regular">he built </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">close to </span>the height and length of <span class="gemarra-regular">the entire </span>wall. Since he can easily add to his wall so that it will be equal in length or height to the wall the neighbor rebuilt, he must therefore pay half the cost of the entire rebuilt wall. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav Naḥman says: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">that which he built close, he built </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">close</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span> with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">that which he did not build close, he did not </span>yet <span class="gemarra-regular">build </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">close. </span>Accordingly, he is required to pay an additional share only for the part of the wall corresponding to the new wall he built.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav Huna concedes with regard to an attachment to the corne</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> of his house that he is not required to pay half the cost of the entire rebuilt wall. If he built the extension of his house in this manner, it is not considered as if he built it close to the entire wall, as it is unlikely that he will add to it. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav Naḥman concedes </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>a case in which he places a heavy <span class="gemarra-regular">beam [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">be’afriza</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> on the wall that can support a roof, <span class="gemarra-regular">or </span>carves into the wall <span class="gemarra-regular">indentations to fix beams in place</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> then even if he has not yet made use of the entire height of the wall, he has demonstrated his desire to do so in the future, and therefore he must pay half the cost of the entire wall.
§ The mishna teaches that if the builder of the first wall later claims that he did not receive payment from his neighbor, the neighbor is presumed not to have given his share of the money, unless he brings proof that he did in fact give money for the building of the wall. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna says: </span>Even if <span class="gemarra-regular">openings in the wall </span>were built on the side facing the reluctant partner and these openings are suited to serve as beam rests, this does <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>create <span class="gemarra-regular">a presumption </span>that the reluctant partner contributed his share to the building of the wall. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>this is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">even if </span>the builder of the wall <span class="gemarra-regular">made sill</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> for these openings. As the builder of the wall can <span class="gemarra-regular">say to </span>his neighbor: <span class="gemarra-regular">I said </span>to myself that <span class="gemarra-regular">when you will appease me </span>and pay me for the construction of the wall, you might want to attach beams to it, and I do <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>want <span class="gemarra-regular">the foundations of my wall to be damaged </span>by your fashioning new openings in it. Therefore, from the outset, I built the wall with these openings.
With regard to the use of a neighbor’s wall, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman says: </span>If one <span class="gemarra-regular">acquired the privilege to </span>place <span class="gemarra-regular">thin beam</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> on his neighbor’s wall, i.e., if one had used the wall in that manner in the past and the owner did not protest, so the one using it can maintain that he had acquired from the owner the right to do so, <span class="gemarra-regular">he has not acquired the privilege to </span>place <span class="gemarra-regular">thick beams </span>there. But if he acquired the privilege <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>place <span class="gemarra-regular">thick beams </span>on the wall, <span class="gemarra-regular">he has acquired the privilege to </span>place <span class="gemarra-regular">thin beams </span>there. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef says: </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">he acquired the privilege to </span>place <span class="gemarra-regular">thin beams, he </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">has acquired the privilege to </span>place <span class="gemarra-regular">thick beams.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">There are </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">who say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman says: </span>If one <span class="gemarra-regular">acquired the privilege to </span>place <span class="gemarra-regular">thin beams </span>on his neighbor’s wall, <span class="gemarra-regular">he has acquired the privilege to </span>place <span class="gemarra-regular">thick beams </span>there; and if he acquired the privilege <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>place <span class="gemarra-regular">thick beams, he has acquired the privilege to </span>place <span class="gemarra-regular">thin beams. </span>This version of Rav Naḥman’s statement accords with the statement of Rav Yosef.
With regard to a similar matter, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman says: </span>If one <span class="gemarra-regular">acquired the privilege to </span>let <span class="gemarra-regular">water dri</span><span class="gemarra-regular">p</span> from his roof into his neighbor’s courtyard, <span class="gemarra-regular">he has acquired the privilege to </span>let the <span class="gemarra-regular">water pour </span>there though a drainpipe. If the neighbor did not protest about the water dripping from the roof into his courtyard, he would certainly allow him to build a drainpipe, which would limit the water to a single place. But if <span class="gemarra-regular">he acquired the privilege to </span>let the <span class="gemarra-regular">water pour </span>through a drainpipe into his neighbor’s courtyard, <span class="gemarra-regular">he has not acquired the privilege </span>to let <span class="gemarra-regular">water drip </span>there from his roof. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav Yosef says: Even </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">he acquired the privilege to </span>let <span class="gemarra-regular">water pour </span>there through a drainpipe, <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">has acquired the privilege to </span>let <span class="gemarra-regular">water drip </span>there from his roof.
<span class="gemarra-regular">There are </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">who say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman said: </span>If one <span class="gemarra-regular">acquired the privilege to </span>let <span class="gemarra-regular">water pou</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> through a drainpipe into his neighbor’s courtyard, <span class="gemarra-regular">he has acquired the privilege to </span>let <span class="gemarra-regular">water drip </span>there from his roof; and <span class="gemarra-regular">if he acquired the privilege to </span>let <span class="gemarra-regular">water drip </span>from his roof into his neighbor’s courtyard, <span class="gemarra-regular">he has acquired the privilege to </span>let <span class="gemarra-regular">water pour </span>there through a drainpipe. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>he has <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>acquired the privilege <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>let water drip from <span class="gemarra-regular">a hut </span>whose roof is composed <span class="gemarra-regular">of willow branche</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> into his neighbor’s courtyard. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef said: </span>He has acquired the privilege to let water drip there <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>from <span class="gemarra-regular">a hut </span>whose roof is composed <span class="gemarra-regular">of willow branches. </span>The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef performed an action, </span>i.e., issued a practical ruling, <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to a hut </span>whose roof is composed <span class="gemarra-regular">of willow branches, </span>allowing the neighbor to let water drip from there after he had acquired the privilege to use a drainpipe.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba bar Avuh says: </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">one rents a room to another</span>

Daf 6b

<span class="gemarra-regular">in a large building </span>with many residences, the renter <span class="gemarra-regular">may make use of the </span>building’s <span class="gemarra-regular">projection</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and of the </span>cavities in its external <span class="gemarra-regular">walls up to </span>a distance of <span class="gemarra-regular">four cubits </span>from his room, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>he may make use <span class="gemarra-regular">of the thickness of the wal</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in a place where it is customar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span> to do so. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>as for making use <span class="gemarra-regular">of the building’s </span>front <span class="gemarra-regular">garden [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">betarbatz</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> he may <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>do so. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav Naḥman himself said: </span>He may make use <span class="gemarra-regular">of even the building’s </span>front <span class="gemarra-regular">garden. But </span>he may <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>use <span class="gemarra-regular">the yard that is at the back of the house. And Rava said: </span>He may use <span class="gemarra-regular">even the yard that is at the back of the house.</span>
Apropos the use of a wall between neighbors, <span class="gemarra-regular">Ravina says: </span>If one’s <span class="gemarra-regular">beam </span>supporting a covering <span class="gemarra-regular">for shad</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> was resting on his neighbor’s wall <span class="gemarra-regular">for up to thirt</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> days, there is no acquired privilege </span>for him to continue using it, since the neighbor can claim that he had assumed that the beam was there only temporarily and for that reason he did not protest. But <span class="gemarra-regular">after thirty days, there is an acquired privilege. And if it was </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">sukka</span> that was being used <span class="gemarra-regular">for the mitzv</span><span class="gemarra-regular">a</span> on the festival of <span class="it-text">Sukkot</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">for up to seven days there is no acquired privilege </span>for him to continue using it, since it is assumed that it is there for the mitzva and that after the Festival it will be removed. But if <span class="gemarra-regular">after seven days </span>the neighbor did not protest, <span class="gemarra-regular">there is an acquired privilege </span>for him to continue using it. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if </span>the one using the beam <span class="gemarra-regular">attached it with clay, there is immediately </span>such <span class="gemarra-regular">an acquired privilege.</span>
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye says: </span>If there were <span class="gemarra-regular">two house</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> on two sides of a public domain</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> this </span>one, the owner of one of the houses, must <span class="gemarra-regular">build a fence for half his roof, and that </span>one, the owner of the other house, must <span class="gemarra-regular">build a fence for half his roof. </span>They must position the fences so that <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>fence <span class="gemarra-regular">is not opposite the other </span>fence, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>each one must <span class="gemarra-regular">add </span>to his fence a little beyond the midway point, so that each one should not be able to see the activity on the other’s roof.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Why </span>discuss <span class="gemarra-regular">specifically </span>the case of two houses on opposite sides of <span class="gemarra-regular">a public domain, </span>considering that the same <span class="it-text">halakha</span> should apply <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>if the two houses are separated by <span class="gemarra-regular">a private domain? </span>The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">It was necessary for </span>Abaye to mention <span class="gemarra-regular">a public domain, lest you say </span>that one neighbor can <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>to the other: <span class="gemarra-regular">Ultimately, you need to conceal </span>yourself <span class="gemarra-regular">from people in the public domain. </span>Since in any event you have to build a fence across your entire roof, you cannot compel me to build a fence on my roof.
To counter this, Abaye <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>that this is not so, because the second homeowner <span class="gemarra-regular">can say to </span>the first in response: <span class="gemarra-regular">The public can see me </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">during the day, </span>when pedestrians pass by, <span class="gemarra-regular">but they cannot see me at night. You, </span>by contrast, <span class="gemarra-regular">can see me both during the day and at night. Alternatively, </span>he can say: <span class="gemarra-regular">The public can see me </span>from the street only <span class="gemarra-regular">when I am standing, </span>but <span class="gemarra-regular">they cannot see me when I am sitting. You, </span>by contrast, <span class="gemarra-regular">can see me both when I am standing and when I am sitting. </span>And furthermore, <span class="gemarra-regular">the public can see me </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">when they look </span>specifically at me, <span class="gemarra-regular">but they cannot see me when they do not look </span>specifically at me, since the average pedestrian does not look up to see what is happening on the roofs. <span class="gemarra-regular">You, </span>by contrast, <span class="gemarra-regular">can see me in any case, </span>because you live opposite me.
<span class="gemarra-regular">The Master, </span>i.e., Abaye, <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>above: <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>one, the owner of one of the houses, must <span class="gemarra-regular">build a fence for half his roof, and that </span>one, the owner of the other house, must <span class="gemarra-regular">build a fence for half his roof. </span>They must position the fences so that <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>fence <span class="gemarra-regular">is not opposite the other </span>fence, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>each one must <span class="gemarra-regular">add </span>to his fence a little beyond the midway point. The Gemara asks: Isn’t it <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious </span>that each one must make a fence for half his roof?
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>in a case where <span class="gemarra-regular">one of them went ahead </span>on his own and <span class="gemarra-regular">constructe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> a fence on half his roof, <span class="gemarra-regular">lest you say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the other can say to him: Take </span>from me compensation for <span class="gemarra-regular">the expenditure [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">uzinka</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and you build the entire </span>fence, and in that way we will not invade one another’s privacy. Therefore, Abaye <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>that the neighbor who built the fence for half his roof <span class="gemarra-regular">can say to him: What is the reason you do not </span>want to <span class="gemarra-regular">build </span>a fence? It is <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>the added weight <span class="gemarra-regular">will damage your house’s foundation. My foundation too will be damaged </span>if I continue to build on my roof.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel says: </span>If one’s <span class="gemarra-regular">roof is adjacent to his neighbor’s courtyard</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he must build a fence </span>on the roof <span class="gemarra-regular">four cubits high, </span>so that he will not be able to see into his neighbor’s courtyard, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>required to build a fence <span class="gemarra-regular">between </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">roof and </span>another <span class="gemarra-regular">roof. And Rav Naḥman him-self says: He is not required to </span>build a fence <span class="gemarra-regular">four cubits </span>high on the roof, <span class="gemarra-regular">but he is required to </span>build <span class="gemarra-regular">a partition </span>that is <span class="gemarra-regular">ten </span>handbreadths high.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">For what </span>purpose, according to Rav Naḥman, does the neighbor have to build such a partition? <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>prevent <span class="gemarra-regular">damage </span>caused by exposure to the <span class="gemarra-regular">sight </span>of others, <span class="gemarra-regular">we require </span>a partition of <span class="gemarra-regular">four cubits. If </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">to catch </span>the neighbor <span class="gemarra-regular">as a thief, </span>i.e., to set a boundary between the two properties so that any trespass will be construed as attempted theft, <span class="gemarra-regular">a mere partition of pegs suffices. </span>And <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>it is to prevent <span class="gemarra-regular">kid goats and lambs </span>from crossing from one roof to the other, a low partition that is high <span class="gemarra-regular">enough so that </span>the goat or lamb <span class="gemarra-regular">will not </span>be able to <span class="gemarra-regular">leap headlong </span>from one roof to the other <span class="gemarra-regular">suffices. </span>The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Actually, </span>it is built <span class="gemarra-regular">to catch </span>the neighbor <span class="gemarra-regular">as a thief. With a partition of pegs he can give an excus</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">he was </span>merely <span class="gemarra-regular">stretching himself</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> but <span class="gemarra-regular">with a partition of ten </span>handbreadths <span class="gemarra-regular">he cannot give </span>such <span class="gemarra-regular">an excuse.</span>
The Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises an objection </span>to the opinion of Rav Naḥman from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">If his courtyard was higher than the other’s roof</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he is not required to attend to it</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> What, is it not </span>teaching <span class="gemarra-regular">that he is not required to attend to it at all, </span>i.e., that he need not build any type of fence? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>it means that <span class="gemarra-regular">he is not required to attend </span>to building a partition <span class="gemarra-regular">of four cubits, but he must attend to </span>building <span class="gemarra-regular">a partition of ten </span>handbreadths, as maintained by Rav Naḥman.
<span class="gemarra-regular">It was stated </span>that <span class="it-text">amora’im</span> disagree about the following case: If there are <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>adjoining <span class="gemarra-regular">courtyards</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> one higher than the other</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rav Huna says </span>that the owner of <span class="gemarra-regular">the lower </span>courtyard <span class="gemarra-regular">builds </span>the wall separating the courtyards <span class="gemarra-regular">from his level and upward, and </span>the owner of <span class="gemarra-regular">the upper </span>courtyard <span class="gemarra-regular">builds </span>the wall <span class="gemarra-regular">from his level and upward. And Rav Ḥisda says: </span>The owner of <span class="gemarra-regular">the upper </span>courtyard <span class="gemarra-regular">assists </span>the owner of the lower courtyard <span class="gemarra-regular">and buil</span><span class="gemarra-regular">ds</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from below, </span>even including that part of the wall which is opposite the lower courtyard.
The Gemara notes that <span class="gemarra-regular">it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav Ḥisda: </span>If there were <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>adjoining <span class="gemarra-regular">courtyards, one higher than the other, </span>the owner of <span class="gemarra-regular">the upper </span>courtyard <span class="gemarra-regular">cannot say: I will build from my level and upward, but </span>rather <span class="gemarra-regular">he assists </span>the owner of the lower courtyard <span class="gemarra-regular">and builds from below. And if his courtyard is higher than the roof of his neighbor, he is not required to attend to it. </span>The owner of the upper courtyard need not build a partition because people do not ordinarily use their roofs.
§ It is related that <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>people <span class="gemarra-regular">were living </span>in a two-story building; <span class="gemarra-regular">one was living in the upper </span>story, <span class="gemarra-regular">and one was living in the lower </span>one. <span class="gemarra-regular">The lower </span>story began to <span class="gemarra-regular">collapse, </span>its walls sinking into the ground to the point that it was no longer fit for dwelling. The owner of <span class="gemarra-regular">the lower </span>story <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>the owner of <span class="gemarra-regular">the upper </span>story: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come and let us </span>demolish the whole building and <span class="gemarra-regular">rebuild it </span>together. The owner of the upper story <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: I am living comfortably </span>and am under no obligation to rebuild your residence. 

Daf 7a

The owner of the lower story <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: I will dismantle </span>the structure <span class="gemarra-regular">and rebuild it. </span>The owner of the upper story <span class="gemarra-regular">said: </span>But then <span class="gemarra-regular">I </span>will <span class="gemarra-regular">have no place to live </span>while you are renovating. The owner of the lower story <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: I will rent a place for you </span>to live for the duration. The owner of the upper story <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: I do not </span>want <span class="gemarra-regular">to bother </span>with moving. The owner of the lower story said to him: But <span class="gemarra-regular">I cannot live </span>in my apartment in this condition, as the walls have sunk into the ground. The owner of the upper story said to him: That is not my problem. <span class="gemarra-regular">Crawl on your stomach to go in, and crawl on your stomach to go out.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥama said: By law, </span>the owner of the upper story <span class="gemarra-regular">can preven</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> his downstairs neighbor from rebuilding. The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">And this statement </span>applies <span class="gemarra-regular">only when the beams </span>supporting the second story <span class="gemarra-regular">have not reached lower than ten </span>handbreadths from the ground. <span class="gemarra-regular">But if </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">beams have reached lower than ten </span>handbreadths from the ground, the owner of the lower story <span class="gemarra-regular">can say to </span>the owner of the upper story: <span class="gemarra-regular">Below ten </span>handbreadths <span class="gemarra-regular">is my domain and </span>my domain <span class="gemarra-regular">is not bound to you </span>to support your residence.
