The Gemara further comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">And this statement, </span>that the owner of the upper story can prevent his downstairs neighbor from rebuilding, applies <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>when <span class="gemarra-regular">they did not stipulate with each other </span>that if the house sinks they will rebuild the house anew. <span class="gemarra-regular">But if they made </span>such <span class="gemarra-regular">a stipulation with each other</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> they must dismantle </span>the house <span class="gemarra-regular">and rebuild it.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And if they made </span>such <span class="gemarra-regular">a stipulation with each other, to what exten</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> must the ceiling of the lower story drop before they implement the stipulation? <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages said before Rabba in the name of Mar Zutra, son of Rav Naḥman, who said in the name of Rav Naḥman: Like that which we learned </span>in a mishna (98b): If one takes upon himself to build a house for another person, without stipulating its dimensions, <span class="gemarra-regular">its height </span>must be equal to the sum of <span class="gemarra-regular">half its length and half its width. Rabba said to them: Did I not tell you not to hang empty pitchers on Rav Naḥman, </span>meaning not to attribute foolish opinions to him? Rather, <span class="gemarra-regular">this is what Rav Naḥman said: As people normally live, </span>and no more. <span class="gemarra-regular">And how much </span>space is that? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, said: </span>The ceiling of the lower story must be high enough <span class="gemarra-regular">so that one could bring in bundles </span>of reeds <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span>the type made in <span class="gemarra-regular">Meḥoz</span><span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and</span> be able to <span class="gemarra-regular">turn around.</span>
It is further related that <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain man built a wall outside the windows of his neighbor</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> The neighbor <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: You are </span>blocking the light with your wall and <span class="gemarra-regular">darkening my </span>house. The one who built the wall <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: I will seal </span>your windows <span class="gemarra-regular">here and make </span>new <span class="gemarra-regular">windows for you </span>in your wall <span class="gemarra-regular">above the wall </span>that I am building. The neighbor <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>By doing so <span class="gemarra-regular">you will damage my wall. </span>The one who built the wall <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: I will demolish your wall until the level of the windows and rebuild it, and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">I will make windows for you in </span>the new part of <span class="gemarra-regular">the building above my wall. </span>The neighbor <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: A wall that is old at the bottom and new at the top will not endure.</span>
The one who built the wall <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: I will demolish </span>the wall <span class="gemarra-regular">until the ground and </span>entirely <span class="gemarra-regular">rebuild it, and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">I will make windows for you in it </span>above my wall. The neighbor <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: One new wal</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in an old house will not endure. </span>The one who built the wall <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: I will demolish your entire house and put windows in the </span>new <span class="gemarra-regular">building </span>that I will erect in its place. The neighbor <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>But in the meantime <span class="gemarra-regular">I will have no place to live. </span>The one who built the wall <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: I will rent a place for you </span>to live. The neighbor <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: I do not </span>want <span class="gemarra-regular">to bother </span>with moving. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥama said: By law, </span>the neighbor <span class="gemarra-regular">can prevent </span>him from building the wall.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>identical to <span class="gemarra-regular">that</span> case; this case is very similar to the previous case of the owner of the upper story who can prevent the owner of the lower story from rebuilding. <span class="gemarra-regular">Why do I </span>need <span class="gemarra-regular">this additional </span>case? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">This teaches us that even if he uses </span>the house <span class="gemarra-regular">only for </span>storing <span class="gemarra-regular">straw and wood, </span>he can still maintain that blocking the light causes him damage and can prevent the neighbor from erecting the wall.
The Gemara further relates: <span class="gemarra-regular">There were two brothers who divided </span>their father’s estate <span class="gemarra-regular">between them. One received a hall [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">aspelida</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> in his share <span class="gemarra-regular">and one received a garden</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span><span class="gemarra-regular">The one who received the garden went and built a wall in front of the opening of the hall. </span>His brother <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: You are </span>blocking the light with your wall and <span class="gemarra-regular">darkening my </span>house. The one who received the garden <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: I am building on my </span>property. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥama said: By right he said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">to him, </span>as it is permitted for him to build there.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Ravina said to Rav Ashi: </span>In <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>way <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">different from that which is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: If <span class="gemarra-regular">two brothers divided </span>their father’s estate between them, <span class="gemarra-regular">one of them taking a vineyar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>the other <span class="gemarra-regular">one taking a grain field, the owner of the vineyard has </span>the right to an area <span class="gemarra-regular">four cubits </span>wide <span class="gemarra-regular">in the grain fiel</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> for the purpose of working the vineyard, <span class="gemarra-regular">since it was on that condition </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">they divided </span>the estate. Why in this case does the owner of the hall not have the right to make use of the light coming in from the garden?
Rav Ashi <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: There, </span>the reason is that <span class="gemarra-regular">they made an assessment with each other </span>with regard to the value of the fields, arranging for compensation if one received more than the other, and they took the work area into account. Ravina asked: <span class="gemarra-regular">But what </span>did they do <span class="gemarra-regular">here? Did they not make an assessment with each other? Are we dealing with fools, that this one took the </span>valuable <span class="gemarra-regular">hall and the </span>other <span class="gemarra-regular">one took </span>the much less valuable <span class="gemarra-regular">garden without making an assessment with each other? Rav Ashi said to him: Although they assessed with each other the value of the bricks, the beams, and the boards</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> they did not assess with each other the value of the airspace. </span>With regard to that, each one retained full rights to his respective airspace.
The Gemara says: <span class="gemarra-regular">And let </span>the one who received the hall <span class="gemarra-regular">say to </span>the other: <span class="gemarra-regular">Initially, you gave me </span>a well-lit <span class="gemarra-regular">hall; now you are making it </span>into <span class="gemarra-regular">a small </span>dark <span class="gemarra-regular">room [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">idrona</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rav Shimi bar Ashi said: He gave him only </span>a place that is called a hall <span class="gemarra-regular">by name</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> that is, a place that is called a hall even though it is no longer used that way.
Rav Ashi continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">Isn’t it taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who says </span>to another: <span class="gemarra-regular">I am selling you a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">beit</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">ko</span><span class="gemarra-italic">r</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">of dirt</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it becomes his even if it is only a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">letekh</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., a half-<span class="it-text">kor</span>, and the sale is not void, <span class="gemarra-regular">because he sold him only </span>a place that is called a <span class="it-text">beit</span> <span class="it-text">kor</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">by name. </span>The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">And this </span>ruling applies only as long as the land he is selling him <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>actually <span class="gemarra-regular">calle</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">beit</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">kor</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>Similarly, if he says to him: <span class="gemarra-regular">I am selling you an orchard, it becomes his even if it lacks pomegranates, because he sold him only </span>a place that is called an orchard <span class="gemarra-regular">by name. </span>The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">And this </span>applies only as long as the land he is selling <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>actually <span class="gemarra-regular">called an orchard. </span>And similarly, if he says to him: <span class="gemarra-regular">I am selling you a vineyard, it becomes his even if it lacks grapevines, because he sold him only </span>a place that is called a vineyard <span class="gemarra-regular">by name. </span>The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">And this</span> applies only as long as the land he is selling <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>actually <span class="gemarra-regular">called a vineyard.</span>
The Gemara rejects this argument: <span class="gemarra-regular">Are these </span>cases <span class="gemarra-regular">comparable? There, the seller can say to the buyer: I sold you </span>only a place that is called that <span class="gemarra-regular">by name; here, </span>the one who received the hall <span class="gemarra-regular">can say to </span>his brother: <span class="gemarra-regular">I took </span>this portion <span class="gemarra-regular">as my share on condition that I would live there the way our fathers lived </span>there, and that you would not change that by blocking the light entering through the windows.
With regard to Rav Ḥama’s ruling that it is permitted for the brother who received the garden to build a wall in front of the hall, <span class="gemarra-regular">they said to him, </span>

Daf 7b

i.e., <span class="gemarra-regular">Mar Yenuka and Mar Kashisha, sons of Rav Ḥisda, </span>said to <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi: The </span>Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">of Neharde’a </span>follow <span class="gemarra-regular">their </span>usual line of <span class="gemarra-regular">reasoning, </span>as Rav Ḥama, who was from Neharde’a, issued his ruling in accordance with the opinion of Shmuel, who was also from that city. <span class="gemarra-regular">As Rav Naḥman says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel says: </span>In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">brothers who divide</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> their father’s estate, <span class="gemarra-regular">they do not have </span>a right-of-<span class="gemarra-regular">way against each other. </span>Although the father would traverse the outer field from the inner field to access the public domain, the brother who received the inner field as an inheritance does not have the right to traverse his brother’s outer field.
Shmuel continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">Nor </span>do they have the right of <span class="gemarra-regular">window</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> against each other, </span>i.e., the right to prevent the other from building a wall facing his windows; <span class="gemarra-regular">nor </span>do they have the right of <span class="gemarra-regular">ladder</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> against each other, </span>i.e., the right to set up a ladder in the other’s property in order to get to his own; <span class="gemarra-regular">nor </span>do they have the right of <span class="gemarra-regular">a water channe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> against each other, </span>i.e., the right to pass a water channel through the other’s property. <span class="gemarra-regular">And be careful with these, since they are established </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakhot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. Rava says: </span>The brothers <span class="gemarra-regular">do have </span>all of the aforementioned rights. Rav Ḥama agrees with Shmuel’s opinion, that each brother can do as he pleases on his own property without the other one preventing him from doing so.
Since Rav Ḥama’s rulings were mentioned, the Gemara cites another halakhic ruling in his name. There was <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain promissory note </span>inherited <span class="gemarra-regular">by orphans </span>from their father, stating that somebody owed them money, <span class="gemarra-regular">against which a receipt was produce</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> by the borrower, stating that the debt was already paid. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥama said: We cannot </span>use the note to <span class="gemarra-regular">collect </span>the debt on behalf of the orphans, <span class="gemarra-regular">nor can we tear it up. </span>The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">We cannot collect </span>with the note because <span class="gemarra-regular">a receipt against it was produced </span>by the borrower; and <span class="gemarra-regular">we cannot tear </span>the note <span class="gemarra-regular">up because perhaps when the orphans grow up they will bring proof </span>that the receipt was forged <span class="gemarra-regular">and undermine it.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Aḥa, son of Rava, said to Ravina: What </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? </span>Ravina <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: In all </span>the cases in this discussion, <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥama, except for </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">the receipt, because we do not presume that the witnesses are liars. </span>Since witnesses signed the receipt, the court trusts that the debt was paid and they tear up the promissory note.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Mar Zutra, son of Rav Mari, said: In this </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">as well, the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥama, </span>because the validity of the receipt is in doubt. <span class="gemarra-regular">As, if it is so </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">it </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">a valid receipt, </span>the borrower <span class="gemarra-regular">should have produced it during their father’s lifetime. And since he did not produce it </span>at the proper time, <span class="gemarra-regular">we learn from this that he </span>may have <span class="gemarra-regular">forged it. </span>Even though this is not an absolute proof, it is sufficient reason not to tear up the promissory note.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> The residents of a courtyard <span class="gemarra-regular">can compel </span>each inhabitant of that courtyard <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>financially participate in the <span class="gemarra-regular">building of a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">gatehous</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and a door to the </span>jointly owned <span class="gemarra-regular">courtyard</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel </span>disagrees and <span class="gemarra-regular">says: Not all courtyards require a gatehouse, </span>and each courtyard must be considered on its own in accordance with its specific needs. Similarly, the residents of a city <span class="gemarra-regular">can compel </span>each inhabitant of that city <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>contribute to the <span class="gemarra-regular">building of a wall, double doors, and a crossbar for the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">city</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel </span>disagrees and <span class="gemarra-regular">says: Not all towns require a wall.</span>
With regard to this latter obligation, the mishna asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">How long </span>must one live <span class="gemarra-regular">in the cit</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to be </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">like </span>one of <span class="gemarra-regular">the people of the city </span>and therefore obligated to contribute to these expenses? <span class="gemarra-regular">Twelve months. </span>But if he <span class="gemarra-regular">bought </span>himself <span class="gemarra-regular">a residence in </span>the city, <span class="gemarra-regular">he is immediately </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">like </span>one of <span class="gemarra-regular">the people of the city.</span>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Is this to say that </span>making <span class="gemarra-regular">a gatehouse is beneficial? But </span>wasn’t there <span class="gemarra-regular">that pious man, with whom </span>the prophet <span class="gemarra-regular">Elija</span><span class="gemarra-regular">h</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">was accustomed to speak, </span>who <span class="gemarra-regular">built a gatehouse, and </span>after-ward Elijah <span class="gemarra-regular">did not speak with him again? </span>The objection to the building of a gatehouse is that the guard who mans it prevents the poor from entering and asking for charity. The Gemara answers: This is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult: This,</span> the case presented in the mishna, is referring to a gatehouse built <span class="gemarra-regular">on the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">insid</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> of the courtyard, in which case the poor can at least reach the courtyard’s entrance and be heard inside the courtyard; <span class="gemarra-regular">that, </span>the story of the pious man and Elijah, involves a gatehouse that was built <span class="gemarra-regular">on the outside </span>of the courtyard, completely blocking the poor’s access to the courtyard’s entrance.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if you wish, say </span>instead that in <span class="gemarra-regular">both </span>cases the gatehouse was built <span class="gemarra-regular">outside </span>the courtyard, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>yet this is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult: </span>In the one case, <span class="gemarra-regular">there is a door </span>to the gatehouse, so that the poor cannot be heard inside the courtyard, while in the other case <span class="gemarra-regular">there is no door. Or if you wish, say </span>that in <span class="gemarra-regular">both </span>cases <span class="gemarra-regular">there is a door, and </span>still this is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult: </span>In the one case, <span class="gemarra-regular">there is a ke</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span> needed to open the door, and the key is not available to the poor people, whereas in the other case, <span class="gemarra-regular">there is no key </span>needed. <span class="gemarra-regular">Or if you wish, say </span>that in <span class="gemarra-regular">both </span>cases <span class="gemarra-regular">there is a key </span>needed, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>even so this is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult: </span>In the one case <span class="gemarra-regular">the key is on the inside, </span>so that the poor cannot reach it, while in the other case of the mishna, <span class="gemarra-regular">the key is on the outside.</span>
§ The mishna teaches that the residents of a courtyard <span class="gemarra-regular">can compel </span>each inhabitant of that courtyard <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>financially participate in the <span class="gemarra-regular">building of a gatehouse and a door to the </span>jointly owned <span class="gemarra-regular">courtyard. It is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: Not all courtyards require a gatehouse. Rather, a courtyard that adjoins the public domain requires a gatehouse </span>to prevent people from peering in. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>a courtyard <span class="gemarra-regular">that does not adjoin the public domain does not require a gatehouse. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>why don’t <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis </span>make this distinction? The Gemara answers: Even if a courtyard does not adjoin the public domain, <span class="gemarra-regular">people in the public domain sometimes are forced </span>toward the courtyard due to crowding in the public domain, <span class="gemarra-regular">and come and enter </span>the courtyard.
§ The mishna teaches that the residents of a city <span class="gemarra-regular">can compel </span>each inhabitant of that city <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>contribute to the <span class="gemarra-regular">building </span>of a wall, double doors, and a crossbar <span class="gemarra-regular">for the city. The Sages taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: The residents of a city <span class="gemarra-regular">can compel </span>each inhabitant of that city <span class="gemarra-regular">to build double doors and a crossbar for the city. And </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rabban</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Shimon ben Gamliel says: Not all cities require a wall. Rather, a city that adjoins the </span>state <span class="gemarra-regular">border requires a wall, whereas </span>a city <span class="gemarra-regular">that does not adjoin the </span>state <span class="gemarra-regular">border does not require a wall. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>why don’t <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis </span>make this distinction? The Gemara answers: Even if a city does not adjoin the border, <span class="gemarra-regular">it sometimes happens that </span>invading <span class="gemarra-regular">troops come </span>into the area. Therefore, it is always good for a city to be protected by a wall.
With regard to this issue, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elaza</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> asked Rabbi Yoḥanan</span><span class="gemarra-regular">:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> When </span>the residents of the city <span class="gemarra-regular">collect </span>money to build a wall, <span class="gemarra-regular">do they collect based on </span>the number of <span class="gemarra-regular">peopl</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> living in each house, <span class="gemarra-regular">or perhaps they collect based on the </span>net <span class="gemarra-regular">worth </span>of each person? Rabbi Yoḥanan <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: They collect based on the </span>net <span class="gemarra-regular">worth </span>of each person, <span class="gemarra-regular">and Elazar, my son, </span>you shall <span class="gemarra-regular">fix nails in this, </span>i.e., this is an established <span class="it-text">halakha</span>, and you must not veer from it.
<span class="gemarra-regular">There are </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">who say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar asked Rabbi Yoḥanan: When they collect </span>money to build a wall, <span class="gemarra-regular">do they collect based on the proximity of the house</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> to the wall, so that those people who live closer to the wall pay more? <span class="gemarra-regular">Or perhaps they collect based on the </span>net <span class="gemarra-regular">worth </span>of each person. Rabbi Yoḥanan <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: They collect based on the proximity of the houses </span>to the wall, <span class="gemarra-regular">and Elazar, my son, </span>you shall <span class="gemarra-regular">fix nails in this.</span>
§ It is related that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda Nesi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">a</span> once <span class="gemarra-regular">imposed </span>payment of the tax for <span class="gemarra-regular">the wall </span>even <span class="gemarra-regular">on the Sages. Reish Lakish said to him: The Sages do not require protection</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as it is written: </span>“How precious are your dear ones to me, O God…<span class="gemarra-regular">If I should count them, they are more in number than the sand” </span>(Psalms 139:17–18). <span class="gemarra-regular">If I should count whom? If we say </span>this is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">the righteous, </span>and the verse is saying <span class="gemarra-regular">that they are greater in number than the </span>grains of <span class="gemarra-regular">sand, </span>this is difficult. <span class="gemarra-regular">Now </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">it is written about all of Israel: “As the sand which is upon the seashore” </span>(Genesis 22:17), can <span class="gemarra-regular">the righteous themselves, </span>who are a part of Israel, <span class="gemarra-regular">be greater in number than the </span>grains of <span class="gemarra-regular">sand? </span>How can they possibly outnumber the grains of sand upon the seashore?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, this </span>is what the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">is saying: </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">I should count the deeds of the righteous, they are greater in number than the </span>grains of <span class="gemarra-regular">sand. And </span>it follows by <span class="gemarra-regular">an </span><span class="gemarra-italic">a</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">fortiori</span> inference: <span class="gemarra-regular">If the </span>grains of <span class="gemarra-regular">sand, which are fewer </span>in number, <span class="gemarra-regular">protect </span>the shore from <span class="gemarra-regular">the sea, </span>barring it from flowing inland (see Jeremiah 5:22), <span class="gemarra-regular">do not all the more so the deeds of the righteous, which are greater </span>in number, <span class="gemarra-regular">protect them? </span>Consequently the Sages do not need additional protection.
<span class="gemarra-regular">When </span>Reish Lakish <span class="gemarra-regular">came before Rabbi Yoḥanan </span>and reported the exchange to him, Rabbi Yoḥanan <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: What is the reason </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">you did not quote this </span>verse <span class="gemarra-regular">to him: “I am a wall and my breasts are like towers” </span>(Song of Songs 8:10), which may be explained as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">“I am a wall</span><span class="gemarra-regular">”;</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> this </span>is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">the Torah. “And my breasts are like towers</span><span class="gemarra-regular">”;</span> 

Daf 8a

<span class="gemarra-regular">these are Torah scholars</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and towers do not require additional protection? The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">And Reish Lakish, </span>who did not cite this verse, <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>in accordance with the way that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava expounded </span>the verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“I am a wall</span><span class="gemarra-regular">”;</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> this </span>is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">the Congregation of Israel</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> “And my breasts are like towers</span><span class="gemarra-regular">”;</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> these are the synagogues and study halls.</span>
It is similarly related that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman bar Rav Ḥisda </span>once <span class="gemarra-regular">im-posed </span>payment of <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>poll <span class="gemarra-regular">tax [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">karga</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> even <span class="gemarra-regular">on the Sages. Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said to him: You have transgressed </span>the words of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Torah, the Prophets, and the Writings.</span>
You have transgressed the words of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Torah, as it is written: “Even when He loves the peoples, all His holy ones are in Your hand” </span>(Deuteronomy 33:3), which is understood to mean that <span class="gemarra-regular">Moses said to the Holy One, Blessed be He: Master of the Universe, even when You hold the </span>other <span class="gemarra-regular">nations dear </span>and grant them dominion over Israel, let <span class="gemarra-regular">“all His holy ones,” </span>meaning the Torah scholars, <span class="gemarra-regular">be </span>exclusively <span class="gemarra-regular">in Your hand </span>and free from the authority of the nations, and therefore be exempt from pay-ing taxes. The continuation of that verse can also be understood as referring to Torah scholars, as it states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And they sit [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">tukku</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] at Your feet, </span>receiving Your words” (Deuteronomy 33:3), and <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef teaches: These are Torah scholars who pound [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">mekhatetim</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] their feet from city to city and from country to country to study Torah; “receiving </span><span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">yissa</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] Your words,” to discuss [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">lissa</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">velitten</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] the utterances of God.</span>
And you have transgressed the words of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Prophets, as it is written: “Though they have hired lovers </span><span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">yitnu</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] among the nations, now I will gather them, and they will begin to be diminished by reason of the burden of kings and princes” </span>(Hosea 8:10). With regard to this verse, <span class="gemarra-regular">Ulla says: </span>Part of <span class="gemarra-regular">this verse is stated in the Aramaic language; </span>the word <span class="it-text">yitnu</span> should be understood here in its Aramaic sense: To learn. And the verse should be interpreted as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">If all </span>of Israel <span class="gemarra-regular">learns </span>Torah, <span class="gemarra-regular">I will gather them </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">now; and if </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">a few of them </span>learn Torah, <span class="gemarra-regular">they will be excused from the burden </span>imposed <span class="gemarra-regular">by kings and princes. </span>This indicates that those who study Torah should not be subject to paying taxes.
And furthermore, you have transgressed the words of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Writings, as it is written: “It shall not be lawful to impose tribute, impost or toll upon them” </span>(Ezra 7:24), i.e., upon the priests and Levites who serve in the Temple. This <span class="it-text">halakha</span> would apply to Torah scholars as well. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav Yehuda says: “Tribute</span><span class="gemarra-regular">”;</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> this </span>is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">the king’s portion, </span>a tax given to the king. <span class="gemarra-regular">“Impost</span><span class="gemarra-regular">”;</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> this </span>is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">the head tax</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> “Toll</span><span class="gemarra-regular">”;</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> this </span>is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">a tax [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">arnona</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> paid with property that was imposed from time to time.
It is related that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa </span>once <span class="gemarra-regular">imposed </span>a tax for <span class="gemarra-regular">the digging of a new </span>cistern even <span class="gemarra-regular">on orphans</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rav Sheisha, son of Rav Idi, said to Rav Pappa: Perhaps </span>they will dig, but in the end <span class="gemarra-regular">they will not draw </span>any <span class="gemarra-regular">water </span>from there, and it will turn out that the money will have been spent for nothing. The rest of the townspeople can relinquish their rights to their money, but orphans who are minors cannot do so. Rav Pappa <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: I shall collect </span>money <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the orphans; <span class="gemarra-regular">if they draw </span>water, <span class="gemarra-regular">they </span>will <span class="gemarra-regular">draw </span>water, <span class="gemarra-regular">and if not, I will return </span>the money <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the orphans.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda says: All </span>of the city’s residents must contribute <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the building and upkeep of <span class="gemarra-regular">the city gates [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">le’aglei</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">gappa</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and for this purpose money is collected <span class="gemarra-regular">even from orphans. But the Sages do not require protection </span>and are therefore exempt from this payment. <span class="gemarra-regular">All </span>of the city’s residents must contribute <span class="gemarra-regular">to the digging of cisterns [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">lekarya</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">patya</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and for this purpose money is collected <span class="gemarra-regular">even from the Sages, </span>since they too need water. The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">And we said </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">only when </span>the people are <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>required to <span class="gemarra-regular">go out en masse [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">be’akhluza</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> and do the actual digging, but are obligated merely to contribute money for that purpose. <span class="gemarra-regular">But if </span>the people are required to <span class="gemarra-regular">go out en masse </span>and actually dig, <span class="gemarra-regular">the Sages </span>are <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>expected to <span class="gemarra-regular">go out </span>with them <span class="gemarra-regular">en masse, </span>but rather they are exempt from such labor.
It is related that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi once <span class="gemarra-regular">opened </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">storehouses </span>to distribute food <span class="gemarra-regular">during years of drought. He said: Masters of Bible, masters of Mishna, masters of Talmud, masters of </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, masters of </span><span class="gemarra-italic">aggada</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> may enter </span>and receive food from me, <span class="gemarra-regular">but ignoramuses should not enter</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rabbi Yonatan ben Amram</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> whom Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi did not know, <span class="gemarra-regular">pushed </span>his way in, <span class="gemarra-regular">and entered, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi, <span class="gemarra-regular">sustain me. </span>Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: My son, have you read </span>the Bible? Rabbi Yonatan ben Amram <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him, </span>out of modesty: <span class="gemarra-regular">No. </span>Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi continued: <span class="gemarra-regular">Have you studied </span>Mishna? Once again, Rabbi Yonatan ben Amram <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: No. </span>Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi then asked him: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, by what </span>merit <span class="gemarra-regular">should I sustain you? </span>Rabbi Yonatan ben Amram <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Sustain me like a dog and like a raven, </span>who are given food even though they have not learned anything. Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi was moved by his words and <span class="gemarra-regular">fed him.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">After </span>Rabbi Yonatan <span class="gemarra-regular">left, Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">sat, and was distressed, and said: Woe is me, that I have given my bread to an ignoramus</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> His son, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon bar Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi, <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Perhaps he was your disciple Yonatan ben Amram, who never in his life wanted to </span>materially <span class="gemarra-regular">benefit from the honor </span>shown to the <span class="gemarra-regular">Torah? They investigated </span>the matter <span class="gemarra-regular">and found </span>that such was the case. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi then <span class="gemarra-regular">said: Let everyone enter</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as there may also be others who hide the fact that they are true Torah scholars.
Commenting on Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi’s opinion, the Gemara notes that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi conformed <span class="gemarra-regular">to his </span>standard line of <span class="gemarra-regular">reasoning, </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">says: Suffering comes to the world only due to ignoramuses. </span>This is <span class="gemarra-regular">like </span>the incident of <span class="gemarra-regular">the crown tax [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">kelila</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that was imposed on </span>the residents of the city of <span class="gemarra-regular">Tiberias. </span>The heads of the city <span class="gemarra-regular">came before Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">and said to him: The Sages should contribute </span>along <span class="gemarra-regular">with us. </span>Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">said to them: No, </span>the Sages are exempt. <span class="gemarra-regular">They said to him: </span>Then <span class="gemarra-regular">we will run away </span>and the entire burden will fall on the Torah scholars. Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">said to them: Run away </span>as you please. <span class="gemarra-regular">Half </span>of the city’s residents <span class="gemarra-regular">ran away. </span>The authorities then <span class="gemarra-regular">waived half </span>the sum that they had initially imposed on the city.
<span class="gemarra-regular">The half </span>of the population that remained in the city then <span class="gemarra-regular">came before Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi, and <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: The Sages should contribute </span>along <span class="gemarra-regular">with us. </span>Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">said to them: No, </span>the Sages are exempt. They said to him: Then <span class="gemarra-regular">we </span>too <span class="gemarra-regular">will run away. </span>Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi said to them: <span class="gemarra-regular">Run away </span>as you please. <span class="gemarra-regular">They all ran away, </span>so that only <span class="gemarra-regular">one launderer was left </span>in the city. The authorities <span class="gemarra-regular">imposed </span>the entire tax <span class="gemarra-regular">on the launderer. The launderer </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">ran away </span>as well. <span class="gemarra-regular">The crown tax was </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">canceled </span>in its entirety. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">said: You see </span>from this <span class="gemarra-regular">that suffering comes to the world only due to ignoramuses, </span>for as soon as they all fled from the city, the crown tax was completely canceled.
§ The mishna teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">And how long </span>must one live <span class="gemarra-regular">in the city to be </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">like </span>one of <span class="gemarra-regular">the people of the city? </span>Twelve months. <span class="gemarra-regular">And we raise a contradiction </span>from what is taught in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a donkey caravan or a camel carava</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that was journeying from place to place, and it lodged inside </span>an idolatrous city, <span class="gemarra-regular">and its </span>members <span class="gemarra-regular">were led astray </span>along <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>the other residents of the city, and they too engaged in idol worship, <span class="gemarra-regular">they, </span>the members of the caravan, are liable to death <span class="gemarra-regular">by stoning </span>like ordinary individual idolaters, <span class="gemarra-regular">and their property escapes </span>destruction, i.e., they are not treated like the residents of an idolatrous city, who are liable to death by the sword and whose property is destroyed.
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">And if </span>the caravan members <span class="gemarra-regular">had remained </span>in that city for <span class="gemarra-regular">thirty days, they </span>are liable to death <span class="gemarra-regular">by the sword and their property is destroyed, </span>just as it is for the rest of the residents of the city. This seems to indicate that once an individual has lived in a city for thirty days, he is already considered one of its residents.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: </span>This is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult. This </span>period, i.e., twelve months, is required in order to be considered one of the <span class="gemarra-regular">members of the city; </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>period, i.e., thirty days, suffices in order to be considered one of the <span class="gemarra-regular">residents of the city. As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">One who is prohibited by a vow from deriving benefit from the people of a </span>particular <span class="gemarra-regular">cit</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibited from deriving benefit from anyone who has stayed there </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">twelve months, </span>but it is permitted for him to derive benefit from anyone who has stayed there for <span class="gemarra-regular">less </span>time <span class="gemarra-regular">than that. </span>By contrast, if he prohibited himself by way of a vow from deriving benefit <span class="gemarra-regular">from the residents of a </span>particular <span class="gemarra-regular">city, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibited from deriving benefit from anyone who has stayed there </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">thirty days, </span>but <span class="gemarra-regular">it is permitted for him to derive benefit from </span>anyone who has stayed there for <span class="gemarra-regular">less </span>time <span class="gemarra-regular">than that.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And do we require </span>that one live in a city for <span class="gemarra-regular">twelve months for all matters? But isn’t it taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: If one lives in city for <span class="gemarra-regular">thirty days, </span>he must contribute <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">charity platte</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> from which food is distributed to the poor. If he lives there for <span class="gemarra-regular">three months, </span>he must contribute <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the charity <span class="gemarra-regular">box. </span>If he lives there for <span class="gemarra-regular">six </span>months, he must contribute <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">clothing </span>fund. If he lives there for <span class="gemarra-regular">nine </span>months, he must contribute <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">burial </span>fund. If he lives there for <span class="gemarra-regular">twelve </span>months, he must contribute <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">columns of the city [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">lepassei</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">ha</span><span class="gemarra-italic">’ir</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., for the construction of a security fence. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Asi said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan said: When we learned twelve months in the mishna, we learned </span>that with regard to contributing <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">columns of the city, </span>money used for protecting and strengthening the city, but not for other matters.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Asi says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: All </span>are required to contribute <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">columns of the city, and </span>money is collected for that purpose <span class="gemarra-regular">even from orphans. But the Sages </span>are <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>required to contribute, <span class="gemarra-regular">since the Sages do not need protection. Rav Pappa said: </span>Money is collected <span class="gemarra-regular">even from orphans for the </span>city <span class="gemarra-regular">wall, for the </span>city <span class="gemarra-regular">horseman, and for the guard [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">uletarzina</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> of the city armory, <span class="gemarra-regular">but the Sages do not require protection. The principle of the matter </span>is: Money is collected <span class="gemarra-regular">even from orphans </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">anything from which they </span>derive <span class="gemarra-regular">benefit.</span>
It is reported that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba imposed </span>a contribution to a certain <span class="gemarra-regular">charity on the orphans of the house of bar Maryon. Abaye said to him: But didn’t Rav Shmuel bar Yehuda teach: One does not impose a charity </span>obligation <span class="gemarra-regular">on orphan</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> even for </span>the sake of <span class="gemarra-regular">redeeming captives, </span>since they are minors and are not obligated in the mitzvot? Rabba <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: I did this to elevate them </span>in standing, i.e., so that people should honor them as generous benefactors; not in order that the poor should benefit.
Incidental to this story, the Gemara relates that <span class="gemarra-regular">Ifera Hurmiz</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the mother of King Shapur, </span>king of Persia, <span class="gemarra-regular">sent a purse [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">arneka</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> full <span class="gemarra-regular">of dinars to Rav Yosef. She said </span>to him: <span class="gemarra-regular">Let </span>the money be used <span class="gemarra-regular">for a great mitzva. Rav Yosef sat and considered </span>the question: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>did Ifera Hurmiz mean when she attached a condition to the gift, saying that it should be used for <span class="gemarra-regular">a great mitzva? Abaye said to him: From what Rav Shmuel bar Yehuda taught, </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">one does not impose a charity </span>obligation <span class="gemarra-regular">on orphans even for </span>the sake of <span class="gemarra-regular">redeeming captives, learn from this</span>

Daf 8b

that <span class="gemarra-regular">redeeming captives is a great mitzva</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said to Rabba bar Mari: </span>Concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">this matter that the Sages stated, that redeeming captives is a great mitzva, from where is </span>it derived? Rabba bar Mari <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: As it is written: “And it shall come to pass, when they say to you: To where shall we depart? Then you shall tell them: So says the Lord: Such as are for death, to death; and such as are for the sword, to the sword; and such as are for famine, to famine; and such as are for captivity, to captivity” </span>(Jeremiah 15:2). <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Yoḥanan says: Whichever </span>punishment <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>written <span class="gemarra-regular">later in this verse is more severe than the one </span>before it.
Rabbi Yoḥanan explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">The sword is worse than death. If you wish, say </span>that this is learned from <span class="gemarra-regular">a verse; if you wish, say </span>instead that it is derived by way of <span class="gemarra-regular">logical reasoning. If you wish, say </span>that this is derived by way of <span class="gemarra-regular">logical reasoning: This </span>punishment, i.e., death by sword, <span class="gemarra-regular">mutilates </span>the body, <span class="gemarra-regular">but that </span>punishment, i.e., natural death, <span class="gemarra-regular">does not mutilate </span>it. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if you wish, say </span>that the fact that the sword is worse than death is learned from <span class="gemarra-regular">a verse: “Precious in the sight of the Lor</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is the death of His pious ones” </span>(Psalms 116:15).
<span class="gemarra-regular">Famine is worse than the sword. If you wish, say </span>that this is derived by way of <span class="gemarra-regular">logical reasoning: This one, </span>who dies of famine, <span class="gemarra-regular">suffers </span>greatly before departing from this world, <span class="gemarra-regular">but that one, </span>who dies by the sword, <span class="gemarra-regular">does not suffer. If you wish, say </span>instead that the fact that famine is worse than the sword is learned from <span class="gemarra-regular">a verse: “More fortunate were the victims of the sword than the victims of famine” </span>(Lamentations 4:9). And <span class="gemarra-regular">captivity is worse than all of them, as it includes all of them, </span>i.e., famine, the sword, and death.
§ In connection with the previous discussion concerning charity distribution, the Gemara cites a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> in which <span class="gemarra-regular">the Sages taught: </span>Money for <span class="gemarra-regular">the charity fun</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is collected by two </span>people <span class="gemarra-regular">and distributed by three </span>people. <span class="gemarra-regular">It is collected by two </span>people <span class="gemarra-regular">because one does not appoint an authority over the community </span>composed <span class="gemarra-regular">of fewer than two </span>people. <span class="gemarra-regular">And it is distributed by three people, like </span>the number of judges needed in cases of <span class="gemarra-regular">monetary law</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> since the distributors determine who receives money and who does not, as well as how much each person receives.
Food for <span class="gemarra-regular">the charity platte</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is collected by three </span>people <span class="gemarra-regular">and distributed by three </span>people <span class="gemarra-regular">because its collection and its distribution </span>take place on <span class="gemarra-regular">the same </span>day. Food for <span class="gemarra-regular">the charity platter </span>is collected and distributed <span class="gemarra-regular">every day, </span>and therefore a third individual must participate in the collection so that he will be available to take part in the distribution without delay; whereas the money of <span class="gemarra-regular">the charity fund </span>is distributed only once a week, on <span class="gemarra-regular">each Shabbat eve.</span>
There are additional differences between these two types of charity operations: The food from <span class="gemarra-regular">the charity platter </span>is distributed <span class="gemarra-regular">to the poor of the world, </span>meaning, to any poor individual arriving in the city; the money of <span class="gemarra-regular">the charity fund </span>is allocated exclusively <span class="gemarra-regular">to the poor of the city. But it is permitted for the residents of the city to use </span>money that has been collected for <span class="gemarra-regular">the charity fund </span>to purchase food for <span class="gemarra-regular">the charity platter </span>to feed the poor; <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>similarly they may use food that had been collected for <span class="gemarra-regular">the charity platter </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">the charity fund. </span>In general, it is permitted for them <span class="gemarra-regular">to change </span>the purpose toward which charity will be used <span class="gemarra-regular">to whatever they want</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> in accordance with the needs of the community.
Similarly, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is permitted for the residents of the city to set the measure</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> used in that city, <span class="gemarra-regular">the prices </span>set for products sold there, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the wages </span>paid <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>its <span class="gemarra-regular">workers, and to fine </span>people <span class="gemarra-regular">for violating their </span>specifications, in order to enforce observance of these <span class="it-text">halakhot</span>. This marks the end of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, the details of which the Gemara proceeds to analyze.
<span class="gemarra-regular">The Master said </span>in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">One does not appoint an authority over the community </span>composed <span class="gemarra-regular">of fewer than two </span>people. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">From where are these matters </span>derived? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman says </span>that this is derived from a verse referring to those engaged in building the Tabernacle and weaving the priestly vestments, who received the community’s donations. <span class="gemarra-regular">The verse states: “And they shall take the gold, </span>and the sky-blue wool, and the purple wool” (Exodus 28:5). The plural “they” indicates that the collection must be performed by two people.
The Gemara comments: The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> indicates that <span class="gemarra-regular">authority may not be exercised </span>by less than two people, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>even a single individual <span class="gemarra-regular">is truste</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> to be a treasurer. That is, money for the charity fund is collected by two people, not because a single individual is not trusted not to misappropriate the money, but rather because a single individual should not be given authority over the community. <span class="gemarra-regular">This supports </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Ḥanina, as Rabbi Ḥanina says: There was an incident where Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">appointed two brothers to </span>administer <span class="gemarra-regular">the charity fund. </span>Even though the brothers were relatives who are not trusted to testify against each other, Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi was not concerned and he appointed them.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What authority </span>is associated with collecting charity? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">As Rav Naḥman says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba bar Avuh says: Because they can seize collateral for the charity</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span> i.e., they can collect charity by force, <span class="gemarra-regular">and even on Shabbat eve, </span>when people are busy and might claim that they have no time or money. The Gemara objects: <span class="gemarra-regular">Is that so? But isn’t it</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> written: “I will punish all that oppress them” </span>(Jeremiah 30:20), <span class="gemarra-regular">and Rabbi Yitzḥak bar Shmuel bar Marta says in the name of Rav: And </span>punishment will be meted out <span class="gemarra-regular">even to charity collectors? </span>If charity collectors are permitted to force people to contribute charity, why are they counted among Israel’s oppressors?
The Gemara answers: This is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult. This, </span>Rabbi Naḥman’s statement, applies <span class="gemarra-regular">when </span>the contributor is <span class="gemarra-regular">rich, </span>in which case the collectors may seize money from him even by force. <span class="gemarra-regular">That, </span>Rabbi Yitzḥak’s statement, applies <span class="gemarra-regular">when</span> he is <span class="gemarra-regular">not rich, </span>in which case the collectors who take money from him by force are termed oppressors of Israel. <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>right to force contributions from the rich is <span class="gemarra-regular">like </span>what occurred in the incident in which <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava compelled Rav Natan bar Ami and took four hundred dinar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from him for charity.</span>
Having raised the issue of charity collection, the Gemara cites various rabbinic expositions with regard to the matter. The verse states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And they who are wise shall shine like the brightness of the firmament; </span>and they who turn many to righteousness like the stars for ever and ever” (Daniel 12:3). <span class="gemarra-regular">“And they who are wise shall shine like the brightness of the firmament</span><span class="gemarra-regular">”;</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> this is a judge who judges an absolutely true judgment, </span>as his wisdom and understanding lead him to a correct judgment. <span class="gemarra-regular">“And they who turn many to righteousnes</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> like the stars for ever and ever</span><span class="gemarra-regular">”;</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> these are the charity collectors, </span>who facilitate the giving of charity.
<span class="gemarra-regular">It was taught in a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">baraita</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: “And they who are wise shall shine like the brightness of the firmament</span><span class="gemarra-regular">”;</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> this is a judge who judges an absolutely true judgment and </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">charity collectors</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> “And they who turn many to righteousness like the stars for ever and ever</span><span class="gemarra-regular">”;</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> these are schoolteachers. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Like whom? </span>Certainly not every schoolteacher is worthy of such accolades. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav said: For example, Rav Shmuel bar Sheilat</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> As </span>it is told that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav </span>once <span class="gemarra-regular">found Rav Shmuel bar Sheilat standing in a garden. </span>Rav <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Have you abandoned your trust </span>and neglected your students? Rav Shmuel bar Sheilat <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: It has been thirteen years </span>now <span class="gemarra-regular">that I have not seen </span>my garden, <span class="gemarra-regular">and even now my thoughts are on </span>the children.
In light of the praises heaped upon judges, tax collectors, and schoolteachers, the Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And what </span>was said about <span class="gemarra-regular">the Sages? Ravina said </span>that about them it is stated: <span class="gemarra-regular">“But let them that love Him be as the sun when it comes out in its might” </span>(Judges 5:31).
The Gemara resumes its discussion of the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of charity collection: <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Charity collectors may not separate from each other</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> each one collecting in a different place; <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>in a place where the two can see each other, one collector <span class="gemarra-regular">may separate </span>from the other, e.g., <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>one going <span class="gemarra-regular">to the gate </span>of a house <span class="gemarra-regular">and that </span>one going <span class="gemarra-regular">to a store. </span>If a charity collector <span class="gemarra-regular">found coins in the market</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he may not put them into his </span>own <span class="gemarra-regular">pocket, but </span>rather <span class="gemarra-regular">he must put them into the charity purse, and </span>then later <span class="gemarra-regular">when he comes home, he may take them </span>from there. This is necessary so that people should not suspect him of taking charity money for himself. <span class="gemarra-regular">Similarly, </span>if the charity collector <span class="gemarra-regular">was owed one hundred dinars by another, and </span>the latter <span class="gemarra-regular">repaid </span>his debt <span class="gemarra-regular">in the market, </span>the collector <span class="gemarra-regular">may not put </span>the money he received <span class="gemarra-regular">into his </span>own <span class="gemarra-regular">pocket, but </span>rather <span class="gemarra-regular">he must put it into the charity purse, and </span>then later <span class="gemarra-regular">when he comes home, he may take it.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Charity collectors who have no poor people to </span>whom they can <span class="gemarra-regular">distribute </span>the money, <span class="gemarra-regular">may exchange </span><span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">poretin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> the money, i.e., exchange the copper coins, which tend to rust, for silver dinars, <span class="gemarra-regular">with other </span>people, <span class="gemarra-regular">but they should not change it </span>by <span class="gemarra-regular">themselves, </span>i.e., with their own coins, to avoid any suspicion of wrongdoing. Likewise, <span class="gemarra-regular">collectors </span>of food <span class="gemarra-regular">for the charity platter who do not have poor people </span>to whom <span class="gemarra-regular">to distribute </span>the food <span class="gemarra-regular">may sell </span>the food <span class="gemarra-regular">to others, but they should not sell it to themselves, </span>for a similar reason. <span class="gemarra-regular">Coins of charity are not counted two </span>by two, <span class="gemarra-regular">but rather one by one, </span>to avoid errors in tallying.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said: At first, </span>my <span class="gemarra-regular">Master, </span>Rabba, <span class="gemarra-regular">would not sit on the mats in the synagogu</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> because </span>they had been purchased with charity funds. <span class="gemarra-regular">Once he heard that which is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, that it is permitted for the residents of a city <span class="gemarra-regular">to change </span>the purpose toward which charity will be used <span class="gemarra-regular">to whatever they want, he did sit </span>on them. <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said: At first, </span>my <span class="gemarra-regular">Master, </span>Rabba, <span class="gemarra-regular">would make two purses, one for the poor of </span>the rest of <span class="gemarra-regular">the world, and one for the poor of his city. Once he heard what Shmuel said to Rav Taḥalifa bar Avdimi: Make </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">one purse, </span>

Daf 9a

<span class="gemarra-regular">and stipulate about it </span>with the people of your city that the money collected will be given to whomever needs it, <span class="gemarra-regular">he too made </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">one purse and stipulated </span>with the people of his city <span class="gemarra-regular">about it. Rav Ashi said: I do not even need to make a stipulation, as whoever comes </span>to donate to this charity fund <span class="gemarra-regular">comes </span>relying <span class="gemarra-regular">on my discretion and </span>understanding that <span class="gemarra-regular">I will give </span>the funds <span class="gemarra-regular">to whomever I want.</span>
The Gemara relates: There were <span class="gemarra-regular">these two butchers who made an agreemen</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with each other that whichever one of them worked on the day </span>assigned <span class="gemarra-regular">to the other </span>according to their mutually agreed-upon schedule <span class="gemarra-regular">would tear up the hide </span>of the animal that he slaughtered that day. <span class="gemarra-regular">One of them went and worked on the other’s day, and </span>the other butcher <span class="gemarra-regular">tore up the hide </span>of the animal that he slaughtered. <span class="gemarra-regular">They came before Rava </span>for judgment, and <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava obligated him to pay </span>the butcher who slaughtered that animal.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yeimar bar Shelamya raised an objection to Rava: </span>Isn’t it stated among actions that the residents of a city may take: <span class="gemarra-regular">And to fine </span>people <span class="gemarra-regular">for violating their </span>specifications, i.e., those ordinances that the residents passed? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava did not respond to him. Rav Pappa said: He did well that he did not respond to him, </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">this matter </span>applies only <span class="gemarra-regular">where there is no important perso</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> in the city, in which case it is permitted for the residents of the city to draw up ordinances on their own. <span class="gemarra-regular">But where there is an important person</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it is not in </span>the residents’ <span class="gemarra-regular">power to make stipulations, </span>i.e., regulations; rather, they are required to obtain the approval of the city’s leading authority to give force to their regulations.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught: One does not calculate </span>sums <span class="gemarra-regular">with charity collector</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> concerning </span>the money they collected <span class="gemarra-regular">for charity, </span>to verify how much they received and how much they distributed, <span class="gemarra-regular">nor </span>does one calculate sums <span class="gemarra-regular">with the </span>Temple <span class="gemarra-regular">treasurers concerning </span>the property <span class="gemarra-regular">consecrated </span>to the Temple. <span class="gemarra-regular">And even though there is no </span>explicit <span class="gemarra-regular">proof of the matte</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> from the Bible, there is nevertheless <span class="gemarra-regular">an allusion to the matter, as it is stated: “And they did not reckon with the men into whose hand they delivered the money to pay out to the workmen; for they dealt in good faith” </span>(II Kings 12:16).
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar says: Even though a person has a trusted treasurer in his house </span>like the aforementioned Temple treasurers, who were fully trusted, <span class="gemarra-regular">he should </span>nevertheless <span class="gemarra-regular">tie up </span>his money <span class="gemarra-regular">and count </span>it, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is stated: </span>“And the king’s scribe and the High Priest came up, <span class="gemarra-regular">and they tied </span>it in bags <span class="gemarra-regular">and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> counted </span>the money…And they gave the money that was counted into the hands of them that did the work, that had the oversight of the House of the Lord” (II Kings 12:11–12).
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna says: </span>Charity collectors <span class="gemarra-regular">examine </span>the level of poverty of one who asks <span class="gemarra-regular">for food</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> but they do not examine </span>the level of poverty of one who asks <span class="gemarra-regular">for clothing. </span>If a person comes before the charity collectors in tattered clothes, he is given clothing without any questions being asked. <span class="gemarra-regular">If you wish, say </span>that this distinction is derived from <span class="gemarra-regular">a verse; if you wish, say </span>instead that it is derived via <span class="gemarra-regular">logical reasoning.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">If you wish, say </span>that this distinction is derived via <span class="gemarra-regular">logical reasoning: This one </span>who stands before us in rags <span class="gemarra-regular">is exposed to contempt, whereas that one </span>who is hungry <span class="gemarra-regular">is not exposed to contempt. If you wish, say </span>instead that this distinction is derived from <span class="gemarra-regular">a verse, </span>as it is written: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Is it not to share </span><span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">paros</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> your bread with the hungry?” </span>(Isaiah 58:7). The word <span class="it-text">paros</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is written with a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">shin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> alluding to the word <span class="it-text">parosh</span>, meaning <span class="gemarra-regular">examine </span>and investigate, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">then </span>should you <span class="gemarra-regular">give him. And there </span>in the same verse <span class="gemarra-regular">it is written </span>with regard to clothing: <span class="gemarra-regular">“When you see the naked, that you cover him,” </span>indicating that <span class="gemarra-regular">“when you see” </span>him you should <span class="gemarra-regular">immediately </span>cover him.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav Yehuda says </span>just the opposite: Charity collectors <span class="gemarra-regular">examine </span>the level of poverty of one who asks <span class="gemarra-regular">for clothing, but they do not examine </span>the level of poverty of one who asks <span class="gemarra-regular">for food. </span>He too adduces supports for his opinion. <span class="gemarra-regular">If you wish, say </span>that this distinction is derived via <span class="gemarra-regular">logical reasoning; if you wish, say </span>instead that it is derived from <span class="gemarra-regular">a verse.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">If you wish, say </span>that this distinction is derived via <span class="gemarra-regular">logical reasoning: This one </span>who is hungry <span class="gemarra-regular">suffers, whereas that one </span>who is in tattered clothing <span class="gemarra-regular">does not suffer </span>in the same way. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if you wish, say </span>instead that this distinction is derived from <span class="gemarra-regular">a verse. Here, it is written: “Is it not to share </span><span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">paros</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> your bread with the hungry?” </span>meaning, <span class="gemarra-regular">share </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">immediately, just as </span>the word <span class="gemarra-regular">is read. </span>Since the word is read with a <span class="it-text">samekh</span>, Rav Yehuda does not understand it as alluding to examining the recipient. <span class="gemarra-regular">And there, it is written: “When you see the naked, that you cover him,” </span>meaning, <span class="gemarra-regular">when it will be </span>clearly <span class="gemarra-regular">apparent to you, </span>after you have investigated the matter and found that the supplicant is deserving, then you shall cover him. The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">It is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav Yehuda: </span>If a poor person <span class="gemarra-regular">said: Cover me </span>with clothing, the charity collectors <span class="gemarra-regular">examine him; </span>but if he said: <span class="gemarra-regular">Sustain me </span>with food, <span class="gemarra-regular">they do not examine him.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">We learned </span>in a mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">there </span>(<span class="it-text">Pe’a</span> 8:7): <span class="gemarra-regular">One does not give a poor person who is traveling from place to place </span>requesting charity <span class="gemarra-regular">les</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> than a loaf </span>worth <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">pundeyon</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> one forty-eighth of a <span class="it-text">sela</span>, when the standard price of grain is <span class="gemarra-regular">four </span><span class="gemarra-italic">se’a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">sela</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>If the poor person <span class="gemarra-regular">sleeps </span>in that place, <span class="gemarra-regular">one gives him provisions for lodging. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is meant by <span class="gemarra-regular">provisions for lodging?
