Rav Pappa said: A bed and a pillow [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">bei</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">sadya</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> And if he <span class="gemarra-regular">spends Shabbat </span>in that place, <span class="gemarra-regular">one gives him food for three meals. </span>A Sage <span class="gemarra-regular">taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>a poor person <span class="gemarra-regular">was going door to door </span>asking for charity, one is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>required to <span class="gemarra-regular">attend to him </span>and give him money from the charity fund.
It is related that <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain poor person who was going door to door </span>requesting charity <span class="gemarra-regular">came before Rav Pappa, </span>the local charity collector, but Rav Pappa <span class="gemarra-regular">did not attend to him. Rav Sama, son of Rav Yeiva, said to Rav Pappa: If the Master does not attend to him, nobody else will attend to him </span>either; <span class="gemarra-regular">should he </span>be left to <span class="gemarra-regular">die </span>of hunger? Rav Pappa said to him: <span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t it taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>a poor person <span class="gemarra-regular">was going door to door </span>asking for charity, one is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>required to <span class="gemarra-regular">attend to him? </span>Rav Sama <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>That <span class="it-text">baraita</span> means to say that one is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>required to <span class="gemarra-regular">attend to him </span>and give him <span class="gemarra-regular">a large gift</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> since he is already collecting money as he goes door to door, <span class="gemarra-regular">but one does attend to him </span>and give him <span class="gemarra-regular">a small gift.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Asi says: A person should never prevent himself from giving </span>at least <span class="gemarra-regular">one-third of a sheke</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a yea</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> in charity, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is stated: “And we also established mitzvot upon ourselves</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to charge ourselves yearly with the third part of a shekel for the service of the House of our God” </span>(Nehemiah 10:33). <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav Asi says: Charity is equivalent to all the </span>other <span class="gemarra-regular">mitzvot </span>combined, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is stated </span>in that verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“We also established mitzvot upon ourselves.” A mitzva is not written here, but </span>rather <span class="gemarra-regular">mitzvot, </span>in the plural, thereby teaching that this mitzva is equivalent to all the other mitzvot.
The Gemara offers <span class="gemarra-regular">a mnemonic </span>device for the following statements extolling the mitzva of charity: <span class="gemarra-regular">Greater; Temple; Moses. Rabbi Elazar says: One who causes others to perform [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">me’aseh</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] </span>a meritorious act <span class="gemarra-regular">is greate</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> than one who performs </span>that act himself, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is stated: “And the causing [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ma’aseh</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] of righteousnes</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> shall be peace, and the work of righteousness, quietness, and assurance forever” </span>(Isaiah 32:17). If one <span class="gemarra-regular">merits, </span>the following verse is applied to him: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Is it not to share your bread with the hungry?” </span>(Isaiah 58:7), i.e., he will wholeheartedly give charity to the poor. If he <span class="gemarra-regular">does not merit, </span>the latter clause of that verse is applied to him: <span class="gemarra-regular">“You shall bring the poor </span><span class="gemarra-regular">that are cast ou</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to your house,” </span>i.e., he will be compelled by the government to billet soldiers in his house and sustain them against his will.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said to the people of Meḥoza: I beg of you, strive with each other </span>to perform acts of charity and righteousness, <span class="gemarra-regular">so that you will </span>live in <span class="gemarra-regular">peace with the government, </span>since if you do not act charitably toward each other, you will end up paying fines to the government. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Elazar says: When the Temple is standing, a person contributes his sheke</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span> for the Temple service <span class="gemarra-regular">and achieves atonement </span>for his sins. <span class="gemarra-regular">Now that the Temple no longer stands, if </span>people <span class="gemarra-regular">act charitably, </span>it will be <span class="gemarra-regular">well </span>for them; <span class="gemarra-regular">but if not, the nations of the world </span><span class="gemarra-regular">will come and take </span>their money <span class="gemarra-regular">by force. </span>The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">And even so, </span>the money taken from them by force <span class="gemarra-regular">is credited to them as </span>if they had freely given <span class="gemarra-regular">charity</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as it is stated: </span>“And I will make <span class="gemarra-regular">your oppressors charity” </span>(Isaiah 60:17).
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: This </span>following matter <span class="gemarra-regular">was told to me </span>by <span class="gemarra-regular">the infant</span>

Daf 9b

<span class="gemarra-regular">who perverte</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the ways of his mother. </span>He said <span class="gemarra-regular">in the name of Rabbi Elazar: What </span>is the meaning of that <span class="gemarra-regular">which is written: “And He donned charity like a coat of mail” </span>(Isaiah 59:17)? This verse serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to tell you </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">just as </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">this coat of mail, each and every scal</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> of which it is fashioned <span class="gemarra-regular">combines to </span>form <span class="gemarra-regular">one large coat of mail, so too </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">charity</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> each and every </span><span class="gemarra-italic">peruta</span> that one gives <span class="gemarra-regular">combines to </span>form <span class="gemarra-regular">a great sum. Rabbi Ḥanina says: </span>The same idea is derived <span class="gemarra-regular">from here, </span>as it is stated: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And all our charity is as a polluted garment” </span>(Isaiah 64:5). <span class="gemarra-regular">Just as </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">this garment, each and every thread </span>in it <span class="gemarra-regular">combines to </span>form <span class="gemarra-regular">one large garment, so too </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">charity, each and every </span><span class="gemarra-italic">peruta</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> combines to </span>form <span class="gemarra-regular">a great sum.</span>
The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">Why was </span>this Sage <span class="gemarra-regular">called the infant who perverted the ways of his mother? </span>It was because of the following incident: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Aḥadvoi bar Ami asked Rav Sheshet: From where </span>is it derived <span class="gemarra-regular">that a lepe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">renders a person impure </span>through contact <span class="gemarra-regular">during his days of counting</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., during the seven days that the leper must count from the start of his purification process, when he brings his birds, until he completes that process with the bringing of his sacrifices? Rav Sheshet <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Since he renders </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">garments impure, </span>as it states that on the seventh day of his purification he must wash his clothes (see Leviticus 14:9), <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">renders people impure.</span>
Rav Aḥadvoi <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Perhaps connected impurit</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is different, </span>meaning perhaps he renders his garments impure because they are connected to the source of the impurity, but this does not mean that he renders impure a person whom he touches. A proof for this distinction may be brought from the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">one moves an animal carcass</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> an action that renders him impure even if there was no actual contact with the carcass, <span class="gemarra-regular">he renders </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">garments </span>that he is wearing <span class="gemarra-regular">impure but does not render </span>another <span class="gemarra-regular">person impure.</span>
Rav Sheshet <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: But from where </span><span class="gemarra-regular">do we </span>derive that the carcass of <span class="gemarra-regular">a creeping animal renders a person impure</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Is it not because </span>we know <span class="gemarra-regular">that it renders </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">garments impure? </span>Rav Aḥadvoi <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: It is written explicitly </span>with regard to the carcass of <span class="gemarra-regular">a creeping animal: “Or a man who touches any creeping animal, </span>whereby he may be made unclean” (Leviticus 22:5). Rav Sheshet said to him: <span class="gemarra-regular">But from where do we </span>derive that <span class="gemarra-regular">semen renders a person impure</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Is it not because </span>we say that <span class="gemarra-regular">since it renders </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">garments impure </span>(see Leviticus 15:17) <span class="gemarra-regular">it </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">renders a person impure? </span>Rav Aḥadvoi <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: It is also written explicitly </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">semen: “Or a man </span>from whom semen is expelled” (Leviticus 22:4), and the Sages expound the superfluous word “or” as serving <span class="gemarra-regular">to include </span>as impure <span class="gemarra-regular">one who touches </span>semen.
The Gemara relates that with each of his answers Rav Aḥadvoi <span class="gemarra-regular">responded to </span>Rav Sheshet <span class="gemarra-regular">in a mocking tone, </span>intimating that he doubted Rav Sheshet’s grasp of Torah verses. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Sheshet was </span>deeply <span class="gemarra-regular">offended, </span>and as punishment, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Aḥadvoi bar Ami became mute and forgot his learning. </span>Rav Aḥadvoi’s <span class="gemarra-regular">mother came and wept before </span>Rav Sheshet. <span class="gemarra-regular">She cried and cried but he ignored her. </span>As she had once been Rav Sheshet’s nursemaid, <span class="gemarra-regular">she said to him: Look at these breasts of mine from which you suckled. </span>Upon hearing that, Rav Sheshet <span class="gemarra-regular">prayed for mercy for </span>Rav Aḥadvoi, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he was healed. </span>And since it was Rav Aḥadvoi whose behavior led to his mother’s acting in this manner, he was referred to as the infant who perverted his mother’s ways.
The Gemara comments: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">that which we arrived at, </span>i.e., this particular subject, let us clarify the matter: <span class="gemarra-regular">From where do we </span>derive that a leper renders impure a person with whom he comes into contact during his days of counting? <span class="gemarra-regular">As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon bar Yoḥai says: Washing garments is stated with respect to his days of counting, and washing garments is stated with respect to his days of confirmed </span>leprosy, after he has been declared conclusively impure by a priest. <span class="gemarra-regular">Just as there, </span>when he is a confirmed leper <span class="gemarra-regular">he renders a person impure, </span>as is explicitly stated in the Torah, <span class="gemarra-regular">so too here, </span>during his days of counting <span class="gemarra-regular">he renders a person impure.</span>
§ The Gemara resumes its discussion of the virtues of giving charity. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar said: One who performs </span>acts of <span class="gemarra-regular">charity in secret is greater than Moses, our teacher. Whereas with regard to Moses, our teacher, it is written: “For I was afraid of the anger and the wrath” </span>(Deuteronomy 9:19), <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to one who performs </span>acts of <span class="gemarra-regular">charity it is written: “A gift in secret pacifies anger, and a present in the bosom fierce wrath” </span>(Proverbs 21:14). The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">And this </span>statement <span class="gemarra-regular">disagrees with </span>a statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Yitzḥak, as Rabbi Yitzḥak says: </span>A secret gift <span class="gemarra-regular">pacifies anger, </span>but it <span class="gemarra-regular">does not pacify wrath, as it is stated: “And a present in the bosom fierce wrath,” </span>meaning that <span class="gemarra-regular">although a present is in the bosom, </span>i.e., even if one gives charity in secret, nevertheless <span class="gemarra-regular">fierce wrath </span>can still harm him. <span class="gemarra-regular">There are </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">who say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yitzḥak says </span>as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">Any judge who accepts a bribe brings fierce wrath upon the world, as it is stated: “And a present in the bosom </span>fierce wrath.”
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Yitzḥak says: Anyone who gives a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">peruta</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to a poor person receives six blessings, and whoever consoles hi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">m</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with word</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> of comfort and encouragement <span class="gemarra-regular">receives eleven blessings. </span>The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">One who gives a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">peruta</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to a poor person receives six blessings, as it is written: “Is it not to share </span>your bread with the hungry, <span class="gemarra-regular">and that you shall bring the poor that are cast out to your house? When you see the naked, </span>that you cover him” (Isaiah 58:7). And the next verses list six blessings: “Then shall your light break forth like the dawn, and your health shall spring forth speedily, and your righteousness shall go before you, the glory of the Lord shall be your rearguard. Then, shall you call, and the Lord shall answer; you shall cry, and He shall say: Here I am” (Isaiah 58:8–9).
<span class="gemarra-regular">And whoever consoles </span>a poor person <span class="gemarra-regular">with words </span>of comfort and encouragement <span class="gemarra-regular">receives eleven blessings, as it is stated: “And if you draw out your soul to the hungry and satisfy the afflicted soul, then shall your light shine in darkness, and your gloom shall be as the noonday. And the Lord shall guide you continually, and satisfy your thirst in drought… And they that shall be of you shall build the old waste places, you shall raise up the foundations of many generations” </span>(Isaiah 58:10–12).
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Yitzḥak says: What </span>is the meaning of that <span class="gemarra-regular">which is written: “He who pursues charity and mercy finds life, charity, and honor” </span>(Proverbs 21:21)? Is this to say that <span class="gemarra-regular">because one has pursued charity, he </span>himself <span class="gemarra-regular">shall find charity? </span>That is, shall the reward of one who has always given charity be that he will eventually become poor and other people will act charitably toward him? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>the verse serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to tell you </span>that with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">anyone who pursues charity, </span>giving to the poor and leading others to do so, <span class="gemarra-regular">the Holy One, Blessed be He, furnishes him with money with which to perform </span>his acts of <span class="gemarra-regular">charity.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak says: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">The Holy One, Blessed be He, sends him people who are deserving of charity, so that he will reap </span>his just <span class="gemarra-regular">reward for </span>helping <span class="gemarra-regular">them. </span>The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>does this statement serve <span class="gemarra-regular">to exclude? </span>It serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to exclude Rabba’s homiletical interpretation </span>of a different verse, <span class="gemarra-regular">as Rabba taught: What </span>is the meaning of that <span class="gemarra-regular">which is written: “Let them be made to stumble before You; deal thus with them in the time of Your anger” </span>(Jeremiah 18:23)? The prophet <span class="gemarra-regular">Jeremiah said before the Holy One, Blessed be He: Master of the Universe, even when </span>those wicked men who pursued me <span class="gemarra-regular">subdue their inclinations and seek to perform </span>acts of <span class="gemarra-regular">charity before You, cause them to stumble upon </span>dishonest <span class="gemarra-regular">people who are not deserving </span>of charity, <span class="gemarra-regular">so that they will not receive reward </span>for coming to their assistance.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi says: Anyone who is accustomed to performing </span>acts of <span class="gemarra-regular">charity merits </span>blessing; <span class="gemarra-regular">he will have sons who are masters of wisdom, masters of wealth, and masters of </span><span class="gemarra-italic">aggada</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">Masters of wisdom, as it is written: </span>

Daf 10a

“He who pursues charity and mercy, <span class="gemarra-regular">finds life” </span>(Proverbs 21:21), and with regard to wisdom it is written: “He who finds Me, finds life” (Proverbs 8:35). <span class="gemarra-regular">Masters of wealth, as it is written: </span>“He who pursues charity and mercy finds <span class="gemarra-regular">charity,” </span>meaning he will be able to give charity. <span class="gemarra-regular">Masters of </span><span class="gemarra-italic">aggada</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, as it is written: </span>“He who pursues charity and mercy, finds <span class="gemarra-regular">honor.</span><span class="gemarra-regular">”</span> And how do we know that this refers to masters of <span class="it-text">aggada</span>? <span class="gemarra-regular">It is written here “honor,” and it is written there: “The wise shall inherit honor” </span>(Proverbs 3:35).
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">It is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir would say: An opponent may bring an argument against you and say to you: If your God loves the poor, for what </span>reason <span class="gemarra-regular">does He not support them </span>Himself? In such a case, <span class="gemarra-regular">say to him: </span>He commands us to act as His agents in sustaining the poor, <span class="gemarra-regular">so that through them we will be </span>credited with the performance of mitzvot and therefore be <span class="gemarra-regular">saved from the judgment of Gehenna. And this is the question that Turnus Rufu</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the wicked asked Rabbi Akiva</span><span class="gemarra-regular">:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> If your God loves the poor, for what </span>reason <span class="gemarra-regular">does He not support them </span>Himself? Rabbi Akiva <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>He commands us to sustain the poor, <span class="gemarra-regular">so that through them </span>and the charity we give them <span class="gemarra-regular">we will be saved from the judgment of Gehenna.</span>
Turnus Rufus <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Rabbi Akiva: <span class="gemarra-regular">On the contrary, it is this </span>charity <span class="gemarra-regular">which condemns you, </span>the Jewish people, <span class="gemarra-regular">to Gehenna </span>because you give it. <span class="gemarra-regular">I will illustrate </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">to you with a parable. To what is this matter comparable? </span>It is comparable <span class="gemarra-regular">to a king of flesh and blood who was angry with his slave and put him in prison and ordered that he should not be fed or given to drink. And one person went ahead and fed him and gave him to drink. If the king heard about this, would he not be angry with </span>that person? <span class="gemarra-regular">And you, </span>after all, <span class="gemarra-regular">are called slaves, as it is stated: “For the children of Israel are slaves to Me” </span>(Leviticus 25:55). If God decreed that a certain person should be impoverished, one who gives him charity defies the will of God.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Akiva said to </span>Turnus Rufus: <span class="gemarra-regular">I will illustrate </span>the opposite <span class="gemarra-regular">to you with a </span>different <span class="gemarra-regular">parable. To what is this matter comparable? </span>It is comparable <span class="gemarra-regular">to a king of flesh and blood who was angry with his son and put him in prison and ordered that he should not be fed or given to drink. And one person went ahead and fed him and gave him to drink. If the king heard </span>about this once his anger abated, <span class="gemarra-regular">would he not </span>react by <span class="gemarra-regular">sending </span>that person <span class="gemarra-regular">a gift? And we are called sons, as it is written: “You are sons of the Lord your God” </span>(Deuteronomy 14:1).
Turnus Rufus <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: You are called sons and you are called slaves. When you fulfill the will of the Omnipresent, you are called sons; when you do not fulfill the will of the Omnipresent, you are called slaves. And </span>since <span class="gemarra-regular">now you do not fulfill the will of the Omnipresent, </span>the parable that I offered is more apt. Rabbi Akiva <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>The verse <span class="gemarra-regular">states: “Is it not to share your bread with the hungry, and </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">you shall bring the poor that are cast out to your house?” </span>(Isaiah 58:7). <span class="gemarra-regular">When </span>do we <span class="gemarra-regular">bring the poor that are cast out </span>into our <span class="gemarra-regular">houses? Now, </span>when we have to billet the Roman soldiers in our homes; <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>about that very time, the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">states: “Is it not to share your bread with the hungry?”</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda, son of Rabbi Shalom taught: Just as a person’s </span>entire <span class="gemarra-regular">livelihoo</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is allocated to him from Rosh HaShana, </span>when God issues His judgments for the entire year, <span class="gemarra-regular">so too are a person’s </span>monetary <span class="gemarra-regular">losses allocated to him from Rosh HaShana. </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">one merits, </span>the following verse is applied to him: <span class="gemarra-regular">“You shall share your bread with the hungry,” </span>i.e., he will spend the sum allocated to him on gifts of charity; and if <span class="gemarra-regular">he does not merit, </span>the following verse is applied to him: <span class="gemarra-regular">“You shall bring the poor that are cast out to your house, </span>i.e., he will be compelled by the government to billet soldiers in his house and feed them against his will.
It is <span class="gemarra-regular">like this </span>incident <span class="gemarra-regular">involving the nephews of Rabban Yoḥanan ben Zakkai, </span>who once <span class="gemarra-regular">saw in a dream that </span>his nephews <span class="gemarra-regular">were </span>destined <span class="gemarra-regular">to lose seven hundred dinars </span>over the course of the year. <span class="gemarra-regular">He encouraged them </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">took </span>money <span class="gemarra-regular">from them for charity, and they were left with seventeen dinars </span>out of the seven hundred. <span class="gemarra-regular">When Yom Kippur eve arrived, the government sent </span>messengers who came and <span class="gemarra-regular">took </span>the remaining seventeen dinars.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabban Yoḥanan ben Zakkai said to them: Do not fear </span>that they will take even more from you; <span class="gemarra-regular">they took from you </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">seventeen dinars</span> that were still <span class="gemarra-regular">with you. </span>The nephews <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: How did you know? </span>Rabban Yoḥanan ben Zakkai <span class="gemarra-regular">said to them: I saw a dream about you, </span>and he related his dream to them. <span class="gemarra-regular">They said to him: And why did you not tell us </span>about the dream? Rabban Yoḥanan ben Zakkai <span class="gemarra-regular">said to them: I said, </span>It is better <span class="gemarra-regular">that they perform a mitzva for its own sake. </span>Had you known from the start that you were fated to lose that amount of money, the mitzva would not have been performed purely for its own sake.
The Gemara relates: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa was </span>once <span class="gemarra-regular">climbing </span>up <span class="gemarra-regular">a ladder </span>when <span class="gemarra-regular">his foot slipped and he almost fell. He said: Now, is the one who hates us, </span>a euphemism for himself, <span class="gemarra-regular">liable like Shabbat desecrator</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and idol worshippers, </span>who are subject to death by stoning, which is similar to death by falling, the punishment that Rav Pappa narrowly escaped? <span class="gemarra-regular">Ḥiyya bar Rav of Difti said to Rav Pappa: Perhaps a poor person </span>once <span class="gemarra-regular">approached you and you did not sustain him, </span>and therefore you were given a glimpse of the punishment that you actually deserve.
<span class="gemarra-regular">As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehoshua ben Korḥa says: Anyone who turns his eyes away from </span>one seeking <span class="gemarra-regular">charit</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">as if he worships idols. </span>From where is this derived? <span class="gemarra-regular">It is written here: “Beware that there be not a base thought in your heart…</span>and your eye be evil against your poor brother, and you give him nothing” (Deuteronomy 15:9). <span class="gemarra-regular">And it is written there: “Certain base men have gone out…</span>and have drawn away the inhabitants of their city, saying, Let us go and serve other gods” (Deuteronomy 13:14). <span class="gemarra-regular">Just as there, </span>the base men sin with <span class="gemarra-regular">idolatry, so too here, </span>the base thought is treated like <span class="gemarra-regular">idolatry.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">It is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Yosei, said: All </span>acts of <span class="gemarra-regular">charity and kindness that Jews perform in this world </span>make <span class="gemarra-regular">great peace and </span>are <span class="gemarra-regular">great intercessors between the Jewish people and their Father in Heaven, as it is stated: “So said the Lord, enter not into a house of mourning, neither go to lament nor bemoan them, for I have taken away My peac</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from this people, </span>says the Lord, <span class="gemarra-regular">both kindness and mercy” </span>(Jeremiah 16:5). <span class="gemarra-regular">“Kindness</span><span class="gemarra-regular">”;</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> this </span>is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">acts of kindness. “Mercy</span><span class="gemarra-regular">”;</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> this </span>is referring to acts of <span class="gemarra-regular">charity. </span>This indicates that when there is kindness and mercy, God is at peace with His people.
<span class="gemarra-regular">It is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda says: Great is charity in that it advances the redemption</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as it is stated: “So said the Lord, uphold justice and do charity, for My salvation is near to come, and My righteousness to be revealed” </span>(Isaiah 56:1). <span class="gemarra-regular">He would say: Ten strong entities were created in the world, </span>one stronger than the other. <span class="gemarra-regular">A mountain is strong, </span>but <span class="gemarra-regular">iron, </span>which is stronger, <span class="gemarra-regular">cleaves it. Iron is strong, </span>but <span class="gemarra-regular">fire melts it. Fire is strong, </span>but <span class="gemarra-regular">water extinguishes it. Water is strong, </span>but <span class="gemarra-regular">clouds bear it. Clouds are strong, </span>but <span class="gemarra-regular">wind disperses them. Wind is strong, </span>but the human <span class="gemarra-regular">body withstands it. </span>The human <span class="gemarra-regular">body is strong, </span>but <span class="gemarra-regular">fear breaks it. Fear is strong, </span>but <span class="gemarra-regular">wine dispels it. Wine is strong, </span>but <span class="gemarra-regular">sleep drives it off. And death is stronger than them all</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> but charity saves </span>a person <span class="gemarra-regular">from death, as it is written: “And charity delivers from death” </span>(Proverbs 10:2, 11:4).
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Dostai, son of Rabbi Yannai, taught: Come and see that the attribute of the Holy One, Blessed be He, is not like the attribute of flesh and blood. </span>An illustration of <span class="gemarra-regular">the attribute of flesh and blood </span>is that when <span class="gemarra-regular">a person brings a great gift to the king, it is uncertain whether </span>the king <span class="gemarra-regular">will accept it from him or will not accept it from him. And if you say that </span>the king <span class="gemarra-regular">will accept it from him, it is uncertain whether </span>the person who brought the gift <span class="gemarra-regular">will </span>eventually <span class="gemarra-regular">see the face of the king, or will not see the face of the king. But the Holy One, Blessed be He, does not </span>act in <span class="gemarra-regular">this way. </span>Even when <span class="gemarra-regular">a person gives a </span>mere <span class="gemarra-italic">peruta</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to a poor person, he merits to receive the Divine Presence, as it is stated: “As for me, I will behold Your face through charity; I will be satisfied, when I awake, with Your likeness” </span>(Psalms 17:15).
It is related that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar would </span>first <span class="gemarra-regular">give a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">peruta</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">to a poor person and </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">then </span>would he <span class="gemarra-regular">pray</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> He said: As it is written </span>in the same verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“I will behold Your face through charity.” </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is the meaning of that which is written: <span class="gemarra-regular">“I will be satisfied, when I awake, with your likeness”?</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak says: These are Torah scholars, </span>who in pursuit of their studies <span class="gemarra-regular">banish sleep from their eye</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in this world, and the Holy One, Blessed be He, satiates them with the radiance of the Divine Presence in the World-to-Come.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: What </span>is the meaning of that <span class="gemarra-regular">which is written: “He that graciously gives to the poor makes a loan to the Lord, </span>and that which he has given, He will pay him back” (Proverbs 19:17)? How can it be that one is considered to have granted a loan to God? <span class="gemarra-regular">Were it not </span>explicitly <span class="gemarra-regular">written in the verse, it would be impossible to say this, </span>that somebody who is gracious to a poor person is seen as lending to God. It would be impertinent, since <span class="gemarra-regular">“the borrower is servant to the lender” </span>(Proverbs 22:7), <span class="gemarra-regular">as it were.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba says: Rabbi Yoḥanan raises a contradiction </span>between two texts. In one place <span class="gemarra-regular">it is written: “Riches profit not on the day of wrath, but charity delivers from death” </span>(Proverbs 11:4), <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>elsewhere <span class="gemarra-regular">it is written: “Treasures of wickedness profit nothing, but charity delivers from death” </span>(Proverbs 10:2). <span class="gemarra-regular">Why </span>is it necessary to have <span class="gemarra-regular">these two </span>verses about <span class="gemarra-regular">charity, </span>that it delivers from death? Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">One </span>verse serves to teach <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>charity <span class="gemarra-regular">delivers from an unnatural deat</span><span class="gemarra-regular">h</span> in this world, <span class="gemarra-regular">and one </span>verse serves to teach <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>charity <span class="gemarra-regular">delivers from the judgment of Gehenna </span>in the World-to-Come. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">which </span>of the verses <span class="gemarra-regular">is that </span>charity <span class="gemarra-regular">which delivers from the judgment of Gehenna </span>mentioned? It is in <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>verse <span class="gemarra-regular">in which “wrath” is written, as </span>with regard to the day of judgment <span class="gemarra-regular">it is written: “That day is a day of wrath” </span>(Zephaniah 1:15). <span class="gemarra-regular">And which </span>type of charity <span class="gemarra-regular">is that which delivers from an unnatural death? </span>

Daf 10b

It is the type in which <span class="gemarra-regular">one gives </span>the charity <span class="gemarra-regular">without knowin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to whom he gave it, </span>and the other <span class="gemarra-regular">one takes it without knowing from whom he took it. </span>The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">One gives it without knowing to whom he gave it, </span>this serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to exclude </span>the practice <span class="gemarra-regular">of Mar Ukva, </span>who would personally give charity to poor people without their knowing he was the donor. The other one <span class="gemarra-regular">takes it without knowing from whom he took it; </span>this serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to exclude </span>the practice <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Abba, </span>who would render his money ownerless, so that poor people would come and take it without his knowing whom he helped, although they would know from whom the money came. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, how </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">should one act </span>to conceal his own identity and also remain ignorant of the identities of the recipients? The Gemara answers: The best method is <span class="gemarra-regular">to put </span>the money <span class="gemarra-regular">into the charity purse</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
The Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises an objection </span>from what is taught in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">What should a person do to have male offspring</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rabbi Eliezer says: He should distribute his money liberally among the poor. Rabbi Yehoshua says: He should gladden his wife before </span>engaging in the <span class="gemarra-regular">mitzva </span>of conjugal relations. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov says: A person should not donate a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">peruta</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to the charity purse unless </span>a great and trusted individual <span class="gemarra-regular">like Rabbi Ḥananya ben Teradyo</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is appointed </span>as supervisor <span class="gemarra-regular">over it. </span>This seems to indicate that putting money into the charity box is not always preferred. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">When we say </span>that putting money into the charity box is the preferred way to give charity, this is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">when </span>a man <span class="gemarra-regular">like Rabbi Ḥananya ben Teradyon is appointed </span>as supervisor <span class="gemarra-regular">over it.</span>
The Gemara discusses other matters concerning charity. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Abbahu says: Moses said before the Holy One, Blessed be He: Master of the Universe, with what shall the horn of Israel be exalted? </span>God <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: With </span>the passage of <span class="gemarra-regular">“When you raise,” </span>i.e., Israel will be exalted by way of the donations and charity that they will give, as it is stated: “When you raise the heads of the children of Israel…then shall they give” (Exodus 30:12).
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Abbahu says: They asked </span>King <span class="gemarra-regular">Solomon, son of David: How far does the power of charity extend? </span>King Solomon <span class="gemarra-regular">said to them: Go out and see what my father David explained: “He has distributed freely, he has given to the poor, his righteousness endures forever, his horn shall be exalted with honor” </span>(Psalms 112:9). <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Abba said: </span>It is derived <span class="gemarra-regular">from here </span>how far the power of charity extends: <span class="gemarra-regular">“He shall dwell on high, his place of defense shall be the fortress of rocks; his bread shall be given, his water shall be sure” </span>(Isaiah 33:16). <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">“He shall dwell on high, his place of defense shall be the fortress of rocks”? Because “his bread shall be given” </span>to the poor, <span class="gemarra-regular">and “his water shall be sure,” </span>i.e., it shall be given faithfully and he can be trusted in the matter.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Abbahu says: They asked </span>King <span class="gemarra-regular">Solomon: Who is one </span>who is destined <span class="gemarra-regular">for the World-to-Come? </span>King Solomon <span class="gemarra-regular">said to them: All </span>those about whom it is stated: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And before His Elders will be His glory” </span>(Isaiah 24:23), referring to those who are honored in this world due to their wisdom. This is <span class="gemarra-regular">like </span>the incident involving <span class="gemarra-regular">Yosef, son of Rabbi Yehoshua, who became ill </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">fainted. </span>When he returned to good health, <span class="gemarra-regular">his father said to him: What did you see </span>when you were not conscious? Yosef <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: I saw an inverted world. Those above, </span>i.e., those who are considered important in this world, were <span class="gemarra-regular">below, </span>insignificant, while <span class="gemarra-regular">those below</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>i.e., those who are insignificant in this world, were <span class="gemarra-regular">above. </span>Rabbi Yehoshua <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: You have seen a clear world. </span>The world you have seen is the true world, one in which one’s spiritual and moral standing determines his true importance. Rabbi Yehoshua further asked him: <span class="gemarra-regular">And how did you see us, </span>the Torah scholars, there? Yosef <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Just as we are important here, we are important there.</span>
Yosef added: <span class="gemarra-regular">And I heard that they were saying </span>in that world: <span class="gemarra-regular">Happy is the one who arrives with his studies in hand. And I </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">heard that they were saying: Those executed by the government </span>enjoy such exalted status that <span class="gemarra-regular">no one can stand in their section. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Who are these </span>martyrs to whom Yosef was referring? <span class="gemarra-regular">If we say </span>that he was referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Akiva and his colleagues, </span>who were killed by the Romans, this cannot be: Is their elevated status <span class="gemarra-regular">due </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the fact that <span class="gemarra-regular">they were martyred by</span> the Roman <span class="gemarra-regular">government and nothing more? </span>These men were exceptional in their piety and sanctity during their lives as well. Therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">it </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious that even without </span>their martyrdom they would be greater than other people. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>it is referring to those like <span class="gemarra-regular">the martyrs of Lod</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> who died for the sanctification of God’s name but were not Torah scholars.
<span class="gemarra-regular">It is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabban Yoḥanan ben Zakkai said to his students: My sons, what is </span>the meaning of <span class="gemarra-regular">that which the verse states: “Righteousness exalts a nation, but the kindness of the peoples is sin” </span>(Proverbs 14:34)? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Eliezer answered and said: “Righteousness exalts a nation</span><span class="gemarra-regular">”;</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> these are </span>the people of <span class="gemarra-regular">Israel, as it is written: “And who is like your people Israel, one nation on the earth?” </span>(I Chronicles 17:21). <span class="gemarra-regular">“But the kindness of the peoples is sin,” </span>meaning that <span class="gemarra-regular">all the </span>acts of <span class="gemarra-regular">charity and kindness that the nations of the world perform is </span>counted as <span class="gemarra-regular">a sin for them, since they perform them only to elevate themselves </span>in prestige, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is stated: “That they may sacrifice offerings of pleasing aroma to the God of heaven, and pray for the life of the king and of his sons” </span>(Ezra 6:10). Even though they donated offerings, they did so only for their own benefit.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And if one acts this way, is it not full-fledged charity? But isn’t it taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">one who says: </span>I am contributing <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span><span class="gemarra-italic">sela</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to charity so that my sons will live, or </span>if he says: I am performing the mitzva <span class="gemarra-regular">so that I will merit </span>a share in <span class="gemarra-regular">the World-to-Come, this </span>person <span class="gemarra-regular">is a full-fledged righteous person, </span>as far as that mitzva is concerned, even though he has his own welfare in mind? The Gemara answers: This is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult. Here, </span>the statement that he is considered absolutely righteous is <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to a Jew</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span> while <span class="gemarra-regular">there, </span>the statement that such benefaction is not credited as charity is <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to a gentile.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehoshua answered </span>Rabban Yoḥanan ben Zakkai’s challenge to interpret the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">and said: “Righteousness exalts a nation”; these are </span>the people of <span class="gemarra-regular">Israel, as it is written: “And who is like your people Israel, one nation </span>on the earth.” <span class="gemarra-regular">“But the kindness of the peoples is sin” </span>means that <span class="gemarra-regular">all the </span>acts of <span class="gemarra-regular">charity and kindness that the nations of the world perform is </span>counted as <span class="gemarra-regular">a sin for them, since they perform them only to perpetuate their dominion, as it is stated </span>by Daniel to Nebuchadnezzar: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Therefore, O king, let my counsel be acceptable to you, and break off your sins by charity, and your iniquities by showing mercy to the poor; that there may be an extension of your serenity” </span>(Daniel 4:24). Since this is the argument that persuaded Nebuchadnezzar, it would appear that his actual motive was his own benefit.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabban Gamliel answered and said: “Righteousness exalts a nation</span><span class="gemarra-regular">”;</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> these are </span>the people of <span class="gemarra-regular">Israel, as it is written: “And who is like your people Israel, </span>one nation on the earth.” <span class="gemarra-regular">“But the kindness of the peoples is sin” </span>means that <span class="gemarra-regular">all the </span>acts of <span class="gemarra-regular">charity and kindness that the nations of the world perform is </span>counted as <span class="gemarra-regular">a sin for them, since they perform them only in order to act haughtily through them, and whoever acts haughtily falls into Gehenna, as it is stated: “The proud and haughty one, scorner is his name, acts in arrogant wrath” </span>(Proverbs 21:24). <span class="gemarra-regular">And wrath means nothing other than Gehenna, as it is stated: “That day is a day of wrath” </span>(Zephaniah 1:15).
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabban Gamliel said: We still need </span>to hear what <span class="gemarra-regular">the Moda’i </span>has to say, as <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Eliezer HaModa’i says: “Righteousness exalts a nation</span><span class="gemarra-regular">”;</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> these are </span>the people of <span class="gemarra-regular">Israel, as it is written: “And who is like your people Israel, one nation on the earth.” “But the kindness of the peoples is sin” </span>means that <span class="gemarra-regular">all the </span>acts of <span class="gemarra-regular">charity and kindness that the nations of the world perform is </span>counted as <span class="gemarra-regular">a sin for them, since they perform them only to taunt us with them, as it is stated </span>that the Babylonian officer Nebuzaradan said: <span class="gemarra-regular">“The Lord has brought it, and done according as He has said; because you have sinned against the Lord and have not obeyed His voice, therefore this matter is come upon you” </span>(Jeremiah 40:3).
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Neḥunya ben HaKana answered and said: “Righteousness exalts a nation and kindness” </span>is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">Israel; and </span>in addition, <span class="gemarra-regular">“of the peoples is sin.” Rabban Yoḥanan ben Zakkai said to his students: The statement of Rabbi Neḥunya ben HaKana appears </span>to be more precise <span class="gemarra-regular">than </span>both <span class="gemarra-regular">my statement and your statements, because he assigns </span>both <span class="gemarra-regular">righteousness and kindness to Israel, and sin to the peoples </span>of the world. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">By inference, </span>it appears <span class="gemarra-regular">that he, </span>Rabban Yoḥanan ben Zakkai, <span class="gemarra-regular">also offered </span>an interpretation of this verse. <span class="gemarra-regular">What is it? As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabban Yoḥanan ben Zakkai said to them </span>that the verse should be understood as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">Just as a sin-offering atones for Israel, so charity atones for the nations of the world.</span>
It is related that <span class="gemarra-regular">Ifera Hurmiz, the mother of King Shapur, </span>king of Persia, <span class="gemarra-regular">sent four hundred dinars to Rabbi Ami, but he did not accept them</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> She </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">sent them to Rava, and he accepted them for the sake of peace with the kingdom</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rabbi Ami heard </span>what Rava had done <span class="gemarra-regular">and was angry. He said: Does </span>Rava <span class="gemarra-regular">not accept </span>the lesson of the verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“When the boughs are withered, they shall be broken off; the women shall come and set them on fire” </span>(Isaiah 27:11), meaning that when righteousness has ceased from a particular nation, it is time for its citizens to be punished, and therefore we should not help them perform any meritorious deeds, which would delay their punishment? The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>why did <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava </span>accept the money? The Gemara answers: He did so <span class="gemarra-regular">for the sake of peace with the kingdom.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>did <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ami </span>not <span class="gemarra-regular">also </span>see the importance of accepting the money <span class="gemarra-regular">for the sake of peace with the kingdom? </span>The Gemara answers: Rabbi Ami maintains that Rava <span class="gemarra-regular">should have distributed </span>the money <span class="gemarra-regular">to the gentile poor </span>rather than to the Jewish poor, as it is a disgrace to the Jews to require the kindness of the nations of the world in order to support their poor. The Gemara comments: In fact, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava also gave </span>the money <span class="gemarra-regular">to the gentile poor </span>and not to the Jewish poor. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Ami got angry </span>because

Daf 11a

those who reported the story to him <span class="gemarra-regular">did not conclude it before him; </span>consequently, Rav Ami was not informed that Rava had indeed given the money to the gentile poor.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">It is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: The following <span class="gemarra-regular">was said about Binyamin the righteous</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> who was appointed </span>supervisor <span class="gemarra-regular">over the charity fund. Once, a woman came before him during years of drought </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: My master, sustain me. He said to her: </span>I swear <span class="gemarra-regular">by the Temple service that there is nothing </span>left <span class="gemarra-regular">in the charity fund. She said to him: My master, if you do not sustain me, a woman and her seven sons will die. He arose and sustained her with his own </span>funds. <span class="gemarra-regular">After some time, he fell deathly ill. The ministering angels said to the Holy One, Blessed be He: Master of the Universe, You said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">anyone who preserve</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a single life in Israel is </span>regarded <span class="gemarra-regular">as if he has preserved an entire world. Should </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">Binyamin the righteous, who saved a woman and her seven sons, die after these few years, </span>still in his youth? <span class="gemarra-regular">They immediately tore up his sentence. </span>A Sage <span class="gemarra-regular">taught: They added twenty-two years to his life.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught: </span>There was <span class="gemarra-regular">an incident involving King Munbaz</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> who liberally gave away his treasures and the treasures of his ancestors in the years of drought,</span> distributing the money to the poor. <span class="gemarra-regular">His brothers and his father’s household joined together against him </span>to protest against his actions, <span class="gemarra-regular">and they said to him: Your ancestors stored up </span>money in their treasuries <span class="gemarra-regular">and added to </span>the treasures <span class="gemarra-regular">of their ancestors, and you are liberally distributing </span>it all to the poor. King Munbaz <span class="gemarra-regular">said to them: </span>Not so, <span class="gemarra-regular">my ancestors stored up below, whereas I am storing above, as it is stated: “Truth will spring out of the earth and righteousness will look down from heaven” </span>(Psalms 85:12), meaning that the righteous deeds that one has performed are stored up in heaven. <span class="gemarra-regular">My ancestors stored up </span>treasures <span class="gemarra-regular">in a place where the </span>human <span class="gemarra-regular">hand can reach, </span>and so their treasures could have been robbed, <span class="gemarra-regular">whereas I am storing up </span>treasures<span class="gemarra-regular"> in a place where the </span>human <span class="gemarra-regular">hand cannot reach, </span>and so they are secure, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is stated: “Righteousness and justice are the foundation of Your throne” </span>(Psalms 89:15).
<span class="gemarra-regular">My ancestors stored up something that does not generate profit, </span>as money sitting in a treasury does not increase, <span class="gemarra-regular">whereas I am storing up something that generates profit, as it is stated: “Say of the righteous, that it shall be well with them, for they shall eat the fruit of their doings” </span>(Isaiah 3:10). <span class="gemarra-regular">My ancestors stored up treasures of money, whereas I am storing up treasures of souls, as it is stated: “The fruit of the righteous is a tree of life, and he that wins souls is wise” </span>(Proverbs 11:30). <span class="gemarra-regular">My ancestors stored up for others, </span>for their sons and heirs, when they themselves would pass from this world, <span class="gemarra-regular">whereas I am storing up for myself, as it is stated: “And it shall be as righteousness to you” </span>(Deuteronomy 24:13). <span class="gemarra-regular">My ancestors stored up for this world, whereas I am storing up for the World-to-Come, as it is stated: “And your righteousness shall go before you, the glory of the Lord shall be your rearguard” </span>(Isaiah 58:8).
§ The Gemara resumes its analysis of the mishna, which taught that one must reside in a place for twelve months in order to be considered a resident for the purposes of issues such as paying taxes. But if he <span class="gemarra-regular">bought </span>himself <span class="gemarra-regular">a residence in </span>the city, <span class="gemarra-regular">he is </span>immediately considered <span class="gemarra-regular">like </span>one of <span class="gemarra-regular">the people of the city. </span>The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">The mishna is not in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel, as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: If he bought any amount of land in </span>the city, and not necessarily a residence, <span class="gemarra-regular">he is </span>immediately considered <span class="gemarra-regular">like </span>one of <span class="gemarra-regular">the people of the city.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t it taught </span>otherwise in a different <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: If </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">bought land that is suitable for a residence, he is </span>immediately considered <span class="gemarra-regular">like </span>one of <span class="gemarra-regular">the people of the city. </span>This contradicts the first <span class="it-text">baraita</span>. The Gemara answers: This is a dispute between <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna’im</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>they disagree <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel.</span>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> The court <span class="gemarra-regular">does not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">divid</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">a courtyard </span>at the request of one of the joint owners <span class="gemarra-regular">unless there will be </span>in it four by <span class="gemarra-regular">four cubits for this one and </span>four by <span class="gemarra-regular">four cubits for that one, </span>i.e., this minimum area for each of the joint owners. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the court does <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>divide <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span>jointly owned <span class="gemarra-regular">field unless there is </span>space <span class="gemarra-regular">in it </span>to plant <span class="gemarra-regular">nine </span><span class="gemarra-italic">ka</span><span class="gemarra-italic">v</span> of seed <span class="gemarra-regular">for this one and nine </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kav</span> of seed <span class="gemarra-regular">for that one. Rabbi Yehuda says: </span>The court does not divide a field <span class="gemarra-regular">unless there is </span>space <span class="gemarra-regular">in it </span>to plant <span class="gemarra-regular">nine </span><span class="gemarra-regular">half-</span><span class="gemarra-italic">kav</span> of seed <span class="gemarra-regular">for this one and nine </span><span class="gemarra-regular">half-</span><span class="gemarra-italic">kav</span> of seed <span class="gemarra-regular">for that one. And </span>the court does <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>divide a jointly owned <span class="gemarra-regular">garden unless there is </span>space <span class="gemarra-regular">in it </span>to plant <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">half-</span><span class="gemarra-italic">kav</span> of seed <span class="gemarra-regular">for this one and a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">half-</span><span class="gemarra-italic">kav</span> of seed <span class="gemarra-regular">for that one. Rabbi Akiva says </span>that half that amount is sufficient, i.e., the <span class="gemarra-regular">area required for sowing a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">quarter-</span><span class="gemarra-italic">kav</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of seed [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">beit</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">rova</span><span class="gemarra-regular">].</span>
Similarly, the court does <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>divide <span class="gemarra-regular">a hall [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">hateraklin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a drawing room, a dovecote</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a cloak, a bathhouse, an olive press, and an irrigated fiel</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">unless there is enough for this one </span>to use the property in the usual manner <span class="gemarra-regular">and enough for that one </span>to use the property in the usual manner. <span class="gemarra-regular">This is the principle: Anything </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">which </span>when it <span class="gemarra-regular">is divided, </span>each of the parts is large enough to <span class="gemarra-regular">retain the name </span>of the original item, the court <span class="gemarra-regular">divides </span>it. <span class="gemarra-regular">But if </span>the parts will <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>retain the original name, the court <span class="gemarra-regular">does not divide </span>it.
<span class="gemarra-regular">When </span>does this rule apply? It applies <span class="gemarra-regular">when </span>the joint owners <span class="gemarra-regular">do not both wish </span>to divide the item; when only one of the owners wishes to divide the property, he cannot force the other to do so. <span class="gemarra-regular">But when both of them wis</span><span class="gemarra-regular">h</span> to divide the item, <span class="gemarra-regular">they may divide </span>it, <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>if each of the owners will receive <span class="gemarra-regular">less than </span>the amounts specified above. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">sacred writings, </span>i.e., a scroll of any of the twenty-four books of the Bible, that were inherited by two people, <span class="gemarra-regular">they may not divide </span>them, <span class="gemarra-regular">even if both of them wish </span>to do so, because it would be a show of disrespect to cut the scroll in half.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Asi says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: The four cubits </span>of the courtyard <span class="gemarra-regular">which they said </span>each of the joint owners must receive is <span class="gemarra-regular">in addition to </span>the space in front of <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">entrance</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> to each of the houses that is assigned to the owner of the house for loading and unloading. <span class="gemarra-regular">That </span>opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">is also taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: The court <span class="gemarra-regular">does not divide a courtyard unless </span>its area is sufficient so that <span class="gemarra-regular">there will be in it eight cubits for this one and eight cubits for that one. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But didn’t we learn </span>in the mishna that it suffices that there be <span class="gemarra-regular">four cubits for this one and four cubits for that one? Rather, conclude from it </span>that the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> was taught <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Asi. </span>The Gemara affirms: <span class="gemarra-regular">Conclude from it </span>that it is so.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And there are </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">who raise </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> as a contradiction to what is taught in the mishna and use the previously mentioned point to reconcile the two texts. <span class="gemarra-regular">We learned </span>in the mishna: The court <span class="gemarra-regular">does not divide a courtyard </span>at the request of one of the joint owners <span class="gemarra-regular">unless there will be </span>in it four by <span class="gemarra-regular">four cubits for this one and </span>four by <span class="gemarra-regular">four cubits for that one. But isn’t it taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: The court does not divide a courtyard unless there are <span class="gemarra-regular">eight cubits for this one and eight cubits for that one? </span>About this <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Asi said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan said: The four cubits </span>of the courtyard <span class="gemarra-regular">which they said </span>each of the joint owners must receive is <span class="gemarra-regular">in addition to </span>the space in front of <span class="gemarra-regular">the entrances </span>to each of the houses.
Further with regard to the division of a courtyard, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna says: A courtyard is divided according to its entrances</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Each of the owners receives a share of the courtyard in proportion to the number of entrances that his house has opening onto the courtyard. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav Ḥisda says: Four cubits are allotted </span>to each of the owners <span class="gemarra-regular">for each and every entrance</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and the rest </span>of the courtyard <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">divided equally </span>between them.
The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">It is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav Ḥisda: </span>Each of <span class="gemarra-regular">the entrances </span>opening <span class="gemarra-regular">to a courtyard </span>is allotted <span class="gemarra-regular">four cubits. </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">this one has one entrance and that one has two entrances, the one who has one entrance takes four cubits, and the one who has two entrances takes eight cubits, and they divide the rest </span>of the courtyard <span class="gemarra-regular">equally </span>between them. If <span class="gemarra-regular">this one had an entrance eight cubits wide, </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">takes eight cubits adjacent to the entrance and four cubits in the courtyard. </span>The Gemara expresses surprise: <span class="gemarra-regular">What are </span>these <span class="gemarra-regular">four cubits in the courtyard doing here? </span>Doesn’t it all depend on the size of the courtyard? <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said: This </span>is what the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is saying: </span>For the entrance <span class="gemarra-regular">he takes eight cubits along the length of the courtyard and four cubits along the width of the courtyard. </span>In other words, he takes a strip four cubits wide along the entire length of his entrance.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Ameimar says: A pit for </span>holding <span class="gemarra-regular">animal food </span><span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">p</span><span class="gemarra-italic">eira</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">desuflei</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> has four cubits on each and every side </span>so that there will be sufficient space for the animals to stand. The Gemara adds: <span class="gemarra-regular">And we said </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">only when </span>the pit <span class="gemarra-regular">has no special entranc</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> to reach it, but rather it is accessed from all sides. 

Daf 11b

<span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">he designates an entrance </span>leading to this pit and does not approach it from all sides, <span class="gemarra-regular">he has four cubits only in front of his entrance.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna says: A portico [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">akhsadra</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> that opens onto a courtyard <span class="gemarra-regular">does not have </span>the adjoining <span class="gemarra-regular">four cubits. </span>The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>that four cubits were granted for each entrance? The four cubits were granted so that the owner would have room <span class="gemarra-regular">for unloading </span>his animal of <span class="gemarra-regular">its burden. Here he can go inside </span>the portico <span class="gemarra-regular">and unload. Rav Sheshet raises an objection </span>from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Both gates of houses and gates of porticos have </span>the adjoining <span class="gemarra-regular">four cubits </span>for unloading. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">When that </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is taught, it is </span>specifically <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to the portico of a study hall</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> which is closed and is not used for unloading burdens. The Gemara expresses surprise at this answer: It is <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious that </span>this is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> governing <span class="gemarra-regular">the portico of a study hall, </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">it is a proper room. Rather, </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">a Roman portico</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> which is more open than the portico of a study hall, but also not used for unloading.
<span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">A gatehouse</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">a portico, and a balcony </span>with a staircase leading down to the courtyard <span class="gemarra-regular">have </span>the adjoining <span class="gemarra-regular">four cubits </span>for unloading. Even if <span class="gemarra-regular">five houses open onto the balcony, they only have four cubits </span>in front of the entrance to the staircase that leads to the balcony. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan asked Rabbi Yannai: </span>Does <span class="gemarra-regular">a chicken coo</span><span class="gemarra-regular">p</span> that also has a staircase <span class="gemarra-regular">have four cubits or does it not have four cubits? </span>Rabbi Yannai <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: What is the reason </span>that four cubits are granted? It is so that the owner will have room <span class="gemarra-regular">for unloading </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">burden </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">his </span>animal. <span class="gemarra-regular">Here </span>this space is not needed, as the chickens <span class="gemarra-regular">climb u</span><span class="gemarra-regular">p</span> to get into the coop <span class="gemarra-regular">and climb down </span>to get out. No additional place is required for the owner to stand alongside them.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava asked Rav Naḥman: </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">a house </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">half roofe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and half unroofed, does it have </span>the adjoining <span class="gemarra-regular">four cubits or does it not have </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">four cubits? </span>Rav Naḥman <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: It does not have </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">four cubits. </span>The Gemara comments: It is <span class="gemarra-regular">not necessary </span>to state this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> when the house’s <span class="gemarra-regular">roofing is </span>over <span class="gemarra-regular">the inside </span>portion of the house, <span class="gemarra-regular">since </span><span class="gemarra-regular">it is possible </span>for the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">to go inside and unload </span>his animal. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, even </span>when the house’s <span class="gemarra-regular">roofing is </span>over <span class="gemarra-regular">the outside </span>portion of the house, it is not given four cubits, as even in such a case <span class="gemarra-regular">it is possible </span>for the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">to go inside and unload </span>his animal there.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna asked Rabbi Ami: </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">one of the residents of an alleyway </span>onto which several courtyards open <span class="gemarra-regular">wishes to alter his entrance to a different alleyway, </span>i.e., to make an entrance to his courtyard that will open onto a different alleyway, can <span class="gemarra-regular">the residents of the </span>other <span class="gemarra-regular">alleyway prevent hi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">m</span> from opening this entrance, <span class="gemarra-regular">or can they not prevent him </span>from doing so? Rabbi Ami <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: The residents of </span>the other <span class="gemarra-regular">alleyway can prevent him </span>from making the change.
Rav Huna further asked: When a king issues <span class="gemarra-regular">a billeting</span> order to the residents of a courtyard, obligating them to house his soldiers in their homes, is the burden <span class="gemarra-regular">divided according to </span>the number of <span class="gemarra-regular">peopl</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> in each household, <span class="gemarra-regular">or </span>is it <span class="gemarra-regular">divided according to </span>the number of <span class="gemarra-regular">entrances </span>that each house has opening into the courtyard? Rabbi Ami <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: It is divided according to the </span>number of <span class="gemarra-regular">people </span>in each household. The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">That </span>opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">is also taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">The dung in a courtyar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> which the residents wish to use <span class="gemarra-regular">is divided </span>among them <span class="gemarra-regular">according to </span>the number of <span class="gemarra-regular">entrances </span>that open into the courtyard, whereas <span class="gemarra-regular">billeting </span>is divided <span class="gemarra-regular">according to </span>the number of <span class="gemarra-regular">people </span>in each household.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna says: </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">one of the residents of an alleyway wishes to close off </span>an area <span class="gemarra-regular">adjacent to his entrance</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., to build a structure in the alleyway adjacent to the entrance to his courtyard, <span class="gemarra-regular">the residents of the alleyway can prevent him </span>from doing so. This is because <span class="gemarra-regular">it will increase the way for them, </span>since they will have to circumvent the structure when going to and from their homes.
