The Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises an objection </span>from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: If <span class="gemarra-regular">five courtyards open onto an alleyway</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> all </span>the residents of the alleyway may <span class="gemarra-regular">use </span>that part of the alleyway that faces the entrance to <span class="gemarra-regular">the outermost </span>courtyard, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the residents of <span class="gemarra-regular">the outermost </span>courtyard may <span class="gemarra-regular">use </span>only that part of the alleyway adjacent to <span class="gemarra-regular">its own </span>entrance. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>similarly, the residents of <span class="gemarra-regular">the other </span>courtyards may <span class="gemarra-regular">use </span>that part of the alleyway that faces <span class="gemarra-regular">the second </span>courtyard, i.e., the one next to the outermost courtyard, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the residents of <span class="gemarra-regular">the second </span>courtyard may <span class="gemarra-regular">use </span>that part of the alleyway adjacent to <span class="gemarra-regular">its own </span>entrance <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>they may <span class="gemarra-regular">use </span>that part of the alleyway facing <span class="gemarra-regular">the outermost </span>courtyard.
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues: The <span class="gemarra-regular">outcome </span>is that the residents of <span class="gemarra-regular">the innermost </span>courtyard may <span class="gemarra-regular">use </span>that part of the alleyway adjacent to <span class="gemarra-regular">its own </span>entrance, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>they may <span class="gemarra-regular">use </span>that part of the alleyway facing <span class="gemarra-regular">each and every </span>other courtyard as well. According to this analysis, it should be permitted for the owner of the innermost courtyard to close off the area in front of his courtyard, since he is the only one who has permission to use it.
The Gemara answers: It <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>a dispute between <span class="gemarra-italic">tanna’im</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: If <span class="gemarra-regular">one of the residents of an alleyway wishes to alter his entrance to a different alleyway, the residents of the </span>other <span class="gemarra-regular">alleyway can prevent him </span>from doing so. If <span class="gemarra-regular">there had been </span>an entrance there beforehand which is now <span class="gemarra-regular">sealed and he wishes to open it</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the residents of the </span>other <span class="gemarra-regular">alleyway cannot prevent him </span>from doing so; this is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar says: </span>If there are <span class="gemarra-regular">five courtyards which open onto an alleyway, </span>the residents of all the courtyards <span class="gemarra-regular">may all use the alleyway with each other.</span>
The Gemara expresses surprise about this last ruling: <span class="gemarra-regular">Courtyards, who mentioned anything about them? </span>Why are they mentioned, considering that the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is not discussing the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of courtyards? The Gemara answers: The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is incomplete </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and this </span>is what <span class="gemarra-regular">it is teaching</span><span class="gemarra-regular">:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Additionally, </span>if there are <span class="gemarra-regular">five courtyards which open onto an alleyway, </span>the residents of all the courtyards <span class="gemarra-regular">may all use </span>the area facing <span class="gemarra-regular">the outermost </span>courtyard, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the </span>residents of the <span class="gemarra-regular">outermost one </span>may <span class="gemarra-regular">use </span>only the area facing their <span class="gemarra-regular">own </span>entrance; this is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar says: </span>If there are <span class="gemarra-regular">five courtyards which open onto an alleyway, </span>the residents of all the courtyards <span class="gemarra-regular">may all use the alleyway.</span>
The Gemara directs the discussion to the details mentioned in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">The Master said: </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">there had been </span>an entrance there beforehand that is now <span class="gemarra-regular">sealed and he wishes to open it</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the residents of the </span>other <span class="gemarra-regular">alleyway cannot prevent him </span>from doing so. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava says: This was taught only when he did not break its doorposts, </span>i.e., when the doorposts remained intact even after the entrance was sealed. <span class="gemarra-regular">But if he </span>sealed the entrance and <span class="gemarra-regular">broke its doorposts, </span>thereby demonstrating that the entrance had been completely negated, <span class="gemarra-regular">the residents of the </span>other <span class="gemarra-regular">alleyway can prevent him </span>from opening a new entrance. <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said to Rava: </span>A <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is taught which supports you:</span>

Daf 12a

<span class="gemarra-regular">A house </span>that has <span class="gemarra-regular">a sealed </span>entrance still <span class="gemarra-regular">has </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">four cubits </span>adjoining that entrance because the entrance can be reopened. If <span class="gemarra-regular">one broke its doorposts </span>and sealed the entrance, the entrance is completely negated, and <span class="gemarra-regular">it</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> does not have </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">four cubits </span>adjoining it.
There is a similar distinction with regard to the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of ritual impurity. There is a <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that a house in which there is a corpse transmits ritual impurity only through its doorways. The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">A grave whose entrance</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is seale</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> does not render all its surroundings ritually </span><span class="gemarra-regular">impure; </span>the ritual impurity extends only to the area opposite the entrance. But if <span class="gemarra-regular">one broke its doorposts and sealed </span><span class="gemarra-regular">it, </span>it is no longer considered an entrance, and the grave <span class="gemarra-regular">renders all its surroundings ritually impure, </span>because impurity that has no egress bursts from all sides. Similarly, <span class="gemarra-regular">a house </span>in which there is a corpse that has <span class="gemarra-regular">a sealed </span>entrance <span class="gemarra-regular">does not rende</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> all its surroundings ritually impure</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> But if <span class="gemarra-regular">one broke its doorposts, </span>it is no longer considered an entrance, and the corpse <span class="gemarra-regular">renders all of its</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> surroundings ritually impure.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba bar bar Ḥana says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Yoḥanan says: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">alleyways that are open to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> another city</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and through which one would ordinarily travel to reach that other city, if <span class="gemarra-regular">the residents of the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> city </span>in which the alleyways are located <span class="gemarra-regular">wished to block</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> them </span>off, <span class="gemarra-regular">the residents of the city </span>into which the alleyways open <span class="gemarra-regular">can prevent them </span>from doing so, because they have a right to reach their city via those routes. The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">It is not necessary </span>to state <span class="gemarra-regular">that</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> they can prevent </span>them from blocking the alleyways <span class="gemarra-regular">when there</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is no alternative route </span>to reach their town, <span class="gemarra-regular">but they</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> can prevent </span>them from blocking the alleyways <span class="gemarra-regular">even when there</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is an alternative route.</span>
This is <span class="gemarra-regular">due to </span>the reasoning that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda </span>says that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says. As Rav</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> says: </span>One is <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibited from ruining a path that the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> public has establishe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> as a public thoroughfare, i.e., steps may not be taken to prevent people from using it. This is in accordance with the statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Giddel, as Rav Giddel says: </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">the public has chosen</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a route for itself </span>and they walk on it, <span class="gemarra-regular">what</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> they have chosen is chosen, </span>and it cannot be taken away from them.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Anan says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel says: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">alleyways that open onto a public thoroughfare</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> if <span class="gemarra-regular">the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> residents of the alleyways wished to put up doors </span>at the entrance to their alleyways, <span class="gemarra-regular">the people </span>who use <span class="gemarra-regular">the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> public thoroughfare can prevent them </span>from doing so.
Some Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">understood from this </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">this statement </span>applies specifically to the area <span class="gemarra-regular">within four cubits </span>of the public thoroughfare, <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the statement <span class="gemarra-regular">that Rabbi Zeira </span>says that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman says, as Rabbi Zeira says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Naḥman says: The four cubits </span>in an alleyway <span class="gemarra-regular">that are</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> adjacent to the public thoroughfare are considered like the public</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> thoroughfare </span>itself. Consequently, this area has the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of a public thoroughfare. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">is not so. There, </span>the ruling of Rav Naḥman was stated <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to the issue</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of ritual impurity</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> with regard to which only the first four cubits of the alleyway are considered like the public thoroughfare. <span class="gemarra-regular">But here, </span>with regard to doors set up at the entrance to the alleyway, <span class="gemarra-regular">sometimes the public thoroughfare</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> becomes crowded with people and they enter far </span>into the alleyway, even farther than four cubits.
§ The mishna teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the court does <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>divide a jointly owned <span class="gemarra-regular">field unless there is </span>space <span class="gemarra-regular">in it </span>to plant <span class="gemarra-regular">nine </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kav</span> of seed <span class="gemarra-regular">for this one and nine </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kav</span> of seed <span class="gemarra-regular">for that one. </span>Rabbi Yehuda says: The court does not divide a field unless there is space in it to plant nine half-<span class="it-text">kav</span> of seed for this one and nine half-<span class="it-text">kav</span> of seed for that one. The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>they <span class="gemarra-regular">do not disagree </span>with regard to the fundamental <span class="it-text">halakha</span>, as this <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage </span>ruled <span class="gemarra-regular">in</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> accordance with </span>the custom of <span class="gemarra-regular">his locale</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage </span>ruled <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the custom of <span class="gemarra-regular">his locale</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>In Rabbi Yehuda’s locale, even a smaller parcel of land was considered a viable field.
The Gemara asks: The mishna was taught in Eretz Yisrael; <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>practice should be followed <span class="gemarra-regular">in Babylonia</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rav Yosef said: </span>In Babylonia, a parcel of land the size of which is <span class="gemarra-regular">the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> area of a day’s plowin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span> is considered a field; if each of the parties will receive less than that, the field should not be divided.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is meant by a parcel of land the size of which is <span class="gemarra-regular">the area </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of a day’s plowing? If </span>it means <span class="gemarra-regular">a day’</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s </span>plowing in <span class="gemarra-regular">the planting </span>season, i.e., the winter, when it is easy to plow, since the earth has already been turned over at the end of the summer, the field will <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>require <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>full <span class="gemarra-regular">days </span>of plowing in <span class="gemarra-regular">the plowing </span>season, i.e., at the end of the summer, when it is more difficult to plow, since the earth is hard and dry. In that case, he will have to pay his summer plowman two days’ wages for less than two days of work. And <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>it means <span class="gemarra-regular">a day’s </span>plowing in the <span class="gemarra-regular">plowing </span>season, the field will <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>require a full <span class="gemarra-regular">day </span>of plowing in the <span class="gemarra-regular">planting </span>season. In that case, he will have to pay his winter plowman a full day’s wages for less than a full day of work.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">If you wish, say</span> it is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">a day’s </span>plowing in the <span class="gemarra-regular">plowing </span>season, and the field will still require a full day of plowing in the planting season <span class="gemarra-regular">since he plows</span> once before he sows the seeds <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>then he <span class="gemarra-regular">repeat</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> the plowing after the seeds are sown. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if </span><span class="gemarra-regular">you wish, say </span>instead that it is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">day’s </span>plowing in the <span class="gemarra-regular">planting </span>season, and the field will in fact require two full days of plowing in the plowing season if it is <span class="gemarra-regular">rocky ground</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> on which plowing takes longer.
In connection with this discussion, the Gemara clarifies the conditions under which <span class="gemarra-regular">a cistern</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> from which its joint owners draw their water, is divided. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman said: </span>It should be divided only if each party will receive <span class="gemarra-regular">the volume of </span>water needed for <span class="gemarra-regular">a day’s irrigation </span>work. As for <span class="gemarra-regular">an orchard, Shmuel’s father says: </span>It should be divided only if each party will receive <span class="gemarra-regular">an area </span>large enough to plant <span class="gemarra-regular">three </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kav</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>one-third of the measure required for a field.
<span class="gemarra-regular">That </span>opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">is also taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who says to another: I am selling you part </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of a vineyard, </span>without specifying how much of the vineyard, <span class="gemarra-regular">Sumakhos says: He may not </span>give him <span class="gemarra-regular">less than an </span><span class="gemarra-regular">area </span>large enough to plant <span class="gemarra-regular">three </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kav</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. Rabbi Yosei said: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">These are nothing other than words of prophecy, </span>i.e., I do not see the logic behind this statement, and it is as if based on prophecy and a heavenly decree, as the seller did not mention any area, but rather spoke in the most general of terms: Part of a vineyard. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is the measure with regard to this matter <span class="gemarra-regular">in Babylonia? Rava bar Kisna said: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Three rows [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">atzyata</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of twelve vines, which is </span>the area <span class="gemarra-regular">a person can hoe in </span>a single <span class="gemarra-regular">day.</span>
§ In connection with Rabbi Yosei’s statement that Sumakhos’s words are nothing but words of prophecy, the Gemara reports that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Avdimi</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from Haifa says: From the day that the Temple </span><span class="gemarra-regular">was destroyed prophecy was taken from the prophets and given </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to the Sages. </span>The Gemara expresses astonishment: <span class="gemarra-regular">Is that </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a Sage is not </span>fit to be <span class="gemarra-regular">a prophet? </span>Rabbi Avdimi seems to say that these are two distinct categories of people. The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">This is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> what </span>Rabbi Avdimi <span class="gemarra-regular">is saying: Even though </span>prophecy <span class="gemarra-regular">was </span><span class="gemarra-regular">taken from the prophets</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it was not taken from </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the Sages.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Ameimar said: And a Sage is greater than </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a prophet, as it is stated: “And a prophet has</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a heart of wisdom” </span>(Psalms 90:12), i.e., he is wise. When comparisons are drawn, <span class="gemarra-regular">who is compared to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">whom? You must say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the lesser is compared to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the greater. </span>Here too, prophecy is compared to wisdom, thus indicating that wisdom is greater than prophecy.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye </span><span class="gemarra-regular">said: Know </span>that this is so, that the Sages still enjoy the prophetic gift, <span class="gemarra-regular">as a great man makes a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">statement </span>with regard to a point of <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the same statement <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">cited in the name of a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">different great man in accordance with his </span>statement, indicating that the Sages makes their statements by way of prophecy. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava</span> disagreed and <span class="gemarra-regular">said: And what is the difficulty </span>with explaining this? <span class="gemarra-regular">Perhaps they were born under the same constellation, </span>and since they are similar in their traits, they reach the same conclusions. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Rava said: Know </span>that this is so, <span class="gemarra-regular">as a great man makes a statement and </span>the same statement <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">cited</span>

Daf 12b

<span class="gemarra-regular">in the name of </span>the well-known <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Akiv</span><span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> bar Yosef in accordance with his </span>statement. It certainly cannot be maintained that the first Sage is similar in his nature to the illustrious Rabbi Akiva, so he must have arrived at his statement through prophecy. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi said: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">And what is the difficulty </span>with explaining this? <span class="gemarra-regular">Perhaps </span>they were born under <span class="gemarra-regular">the same constellation, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> this issue </span>the first Sage has the same understanding as Rabbi Akiva.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Rav</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Ashi said: Know </span>that this is so, <span class="gemarra-regular">as a great</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> man makes a statement and </span>the same statement <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">cited as a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> transmitted <span class="gemarra-regular">to Moses from Sinai in</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> accordance with his </span>statement. The Sage makes a statement that corresponds to words pronounced in Heaven, which, without prophecy, is beyond human capability. The Gemara states: <span class="gemarra-regular">But perhaps </span>he arrived at this idea by chance, without the assistance of prophecy, <span class="gemarra-regular">like a blind man </span>who makes his way <span class="gemarra-regular">through </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a skylight. </span>A blind man cannot deliberately find a skylight; therefore, his finding it occurs by chance. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">But does </span>the Sage <span class="gemarra-regular">not offer a reason </span>for his statement? The fact that he demonstrates an understanding of the issue indicates that he does not arrive at his idea by chance, but rather by prophecy.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan said: From</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the day that the Temple was destroyed, prophecy was taken</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from the prophets and given to imbeciles and children. </span>The Gemara explains: In <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>way was prophecy given <span class="gemarra-regular">to imbeciles</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? </span>It was <span class="gemarra-regular">like this </span>incident involving <span class="gemarra-regular">Mar bar Rav Ashi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> who was standing in the street [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">beristeka</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Meḥoza </span>when <span class="gemarra-regular">he heard a certain imbecile say: The head</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of the yeshiva who will be appointed in Mata Meḥasya</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> signs </span>his name <span class="gemarra-regular">Tavyumei</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Mar bar Rav Ashi <span class="gemarra-regular">said</span> to himself: <span class="gemarra-regular">Who among the Sages signs </span>his name <span class="gemarra-regular">Tavyumei</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? </span>Nobody but <span class="gemarra-regular">me. Conclude from </span>the statement by the imbecile <span class="gemarra-regular">that my hour has arrived, </span>and I will reap success in this matter. <span class="gemarra-regular">He arose and went </span>to Mata Meḥasya. <span class="gemarra-regular">By the time he arrived, the Sages </span>had already <span class="gemarra-regular">decided to appoint Rav Aḥa of Dift</span><span class="gemarra-regular">i</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as the head</span> of the yeshiva.
<span class="gemarra-regular">As soon as</span> the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">heard that </span>Mar bar Rav Ashi <span class="gemarra-regular">had arrived</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>they determined not to proceed with their appointment without the approval of an important figure such as him. <span class="gemarra-regular">They sent</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a pair of Sages to him to consult with him</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">he detained them. They again sent a pair of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Sages </span>to him, and <span class="gemarra-regular">he detained them </span>as well. This continued <span class="gemarra-regular">until they completed </span>a quorum <span class="gemarra-regular">of ten </span>Sages. <span class="gemarra-regular">Once</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> they reached ten </span>men, Mar bar Rav Ashi <span class="gemarra-regular">opened </span>his lecture, <span class="gemarra-regular">taught, and expounded. </span>He did not speak earlier <span class="gemarra-regular">because one should not open a lecture during </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kalla</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>the gatherings for Torah study during the months of Elul and Adar, when <span class="gemarra-regular">less than ten </span>men are present. He was then appointed as head of the yeshiva.
Understanding that he had been passed over for the position, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Aḥa </span>of Difti <span class="gemarra-regular">read about himself </span>the rabbinic aphorism: <span class="gemarra-regular">Anyone who is treated poorly will not soon </span><span class="gemarra-regular">be treated well; and anyone who is treated well will </span><span class="gemarra-regular">not soon be treated poorly. </span>Rav Aḥa understood that he had lost the chance to be appointed, whereas Mar bar Rav Ashi had the good fortune to be appointed, and would remain in his position.
And in <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>way was prophecy given <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">children? </span>It was <span class="gemarra-regular">like this </span>incident involving the <span class="gemarra-regular">daughter of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rav Ḥisda, </span>who when she was a child <span class="gemarra-regular">was sitting</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> on her father’s lap </span>while he sat and learned. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava and Rami bar Ḥama were sitting before him. </span>Rav Ḥisda jokingly <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>his daughter: <span class="gemarra-regular">Which of them would</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> you want </span>as a husband? <span class="gemarra-regular">She said: </span>I want <span class="gemarra-regular">both</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of them. Rava said: And I </span>will be <span class="gemarra-regular">last. </span>And this is what happened; first she married Rami bar Ḥama, and when he died she married Rava.
Having already cited one statement of Rabbi Avdimi from Haifa, the Gemara cites another statement in his name: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Avdimi from Haifa says: Before a person eats and drinks</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he has two hearts</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> meaning his heart is unsettled because he is distracted by hunger. But <span class="gemarra-regular">after he eats</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and drinks he has only one heart, as it is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> stated: “A hollow [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">nevuv</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] man is two-hearted” </span>(Job 11:12). How is it indicated that “<span class="it-text">nevuv</span>” means hungry? <span class="gemarra-regular">As</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it is written </span>concerning the altar: <span class="gemarra-regular">“</span><span class="gemarra-italic">Nevuv</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">luḥot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">” </span>(Exodus 27:8), <span class="gemarra-regular">which we translate </span>into Aramaic as: <span class="gemarra-regular">Hollow with </span><span class="gemarra-regular">planks, </span>meaning that a hollow person, i.e., one who has not yet eaten, is two-hearted.
The Gemara continues to discuss the meaning of <span class="it-text">nevuv</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, says: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who is accustomed to wine, although his heart, </span>i.e., his mind, <span class="gemarra-regular">is closed like a virgin, wine</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> opens it, as it is stated: “And new wine opens</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">yenovev</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] the virgins” </span>(Zechariah 9:17). The word <span class="it-text">yenovev</span> is used here in the sense of clearing out a space: Even if one’s heart and mind are closed, wine will open them to understanding.
§ The Gemara resumes its discussion of the division of property. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, says: </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious</span> that if a person inherits <span class="gemarra-regular">a portion </span>of his father’s estate because he is the <span class="gemarra-regular">firstborn, and </span>he also inherits <span class="gemarra-regular">a portion </span>of that estate as <span class="gemarra-regular">an ordinary </span>son, like the rest of his brothers, <span class="gemarra-regular">he is given</span> his two portions <span class="gemarra-regular">along one boundary, </span>so that they are adjacent to one another and form a single property. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">yavam</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> a man whose brother died without children, who is obligated by Torah law to marry his deceased brother’s widow or grant her <span class="it-text">ḥalitza</span>? If he marries his brother’s widow, the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> dictates that he receive his brother’s portion of their father’s estate in addition to his own. Does he too receive the two portions along one boundary?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said: This </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>equal to <span class="gemarra-regular">that</span> case. <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>for this? <span class="gemarra-regular">The Merciful </span><span class="gemarra-regular">One calls </span>the <span class="it-text">yavam</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">“firstborn” </span>(see <span class="it-text">Yevamot</span> 24a) and therefore he is treated like a firstborn in all regards. He receives the two portions of his father’s estate as a single parcel of land. But <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: The </span><span class="gemarra-regular">verse states: “And it shall be, the firstborn” </span>(Deuteronomy 25:6). With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">his being, </span>i.e., his inheritance itself, he <span class="gemarra-regular">is like a firstborn; but </span>as for <span class="gemarra-regular">the distribution</span> of the estate, he <span class="gemarra-regular">is not like a firstborn</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and the brothers are not obligated to give him two adjacent portions.
It is reported that <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain person bought land along</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the boundary of his father’s property</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> After some time the father died. <span class="gemarra-regular">When they </span>came to <span class="gemarra-regular">divide </span>the estate, this person <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>his brothers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Give me my</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> portion </span>of the estate <span class="gemarra-regular">along my boundary</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rabba said</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: In </span>a case <span class="gemarra-regular">such as this, </span>the court <span class="gemarra-regular">compels </span>people to refrain from <span class="gemarra-regular">conduct </span>characteristic <span class="gemarra-regular">of Sodom. </span>The court forces a person to waive his legal rights in order to prevent him from acting in a manner characteristic of the wicked city of Sodom. Since it makes no difference to the brothers which portion they receive since the parcels of land must be of equal value, whereas it matters to this brother that the area he receives should be adjacent to the land he already bought, the court forces the others to give this brother his portion along his boundary.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Yosef objects to this, </span>saying this is not a case involving conduct characteristic of Sodom, since the brothers can explain their refusal to grant the request. <span class="gemarra-regular">The brothers </span>can <span class="gemarra-regular">say</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to him: We assess this </span>field that you want for yourself <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>particularly <span class="gemarra-regular">valuable</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> like the property of the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> house of bar Maryon</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> The brothers can claim that the portion he wants is more desirable than the others, and for that reason they do not want to give it to him. The Gemara concludes: <span class="gemarra-regular">And the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef, </span>and the brothers can refuse the request.
If a father leaves his two sons <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>parcels of <span class="gemarra-regular">land next to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> two </span>water <span class="gemarra-regular">channels [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">nigrei</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and one brother requests the field that is next to a field that he already owns, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba says: In </span>a case <span class="gemarra-regular">such as this, </span>the court <span class="gemarra-regular">compels </span>people to refrain from <span class="gemarra-regular">conduct </span>characteristic <span class="gemarra-regular">of Sodom</span> and allows that brother to receive the field adjoining his own. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef objects to this, </span>saying that if the other brother protests and wants that parcel of land, it is not a case involving conduct characteristic of Sodom because he may have a valid reason for objecting: <span class="gemarra-regular">Sometimes this</span> water channel <span class="gemarra-regular">continues running </span>well, <span class="gemarra-regular">while this </span>second one <span class="gemarra-regular">does</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not continue running </span>well; therefore, the second brother wants to receive land that adjoins a water channel on both sides. The Gemara concludes: <span class="gemarra-regular">And the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with</span> the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef.</span>
If a father leaves his two sons <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>parcels of land <span class="gemarra-regular">next to one channe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span> and one of the brothers already owns a field next to one of those parcels of land, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef said:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> In </span>a case <span class="gemarra-regular">such as this, </span>the court <span class="gemarra-regular">compels </span>people to refrain from <span class="gemarra-regular">conduct </span>characteristic <span class="gemarra-regular">of Sodom </span>and allows that brother to receive the field adjoining his own. <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye </span><span class="gemarra-regular">objects to this, </span>saying that this is not a case involving conduct characteristic of Sodom because the other brother <span class="gemarra-regular">can</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> say </span>to him: <span class="gemarra-regular">I want </span>the number of <span class="gemarra-regular">sharecroppers to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> increase. </span>If my field is in the middle and you have fields on either side, you will need more sharecroppers to work them and my field will enjoy greater security. <span class="gemarra-regular">And the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef </span>because <span class="gemarra-regular">the increase </span>of sharecroppers <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>considered as <span class="gemarra-regular">nothing, </span>and this is therefore not a valid reason for objecting. 

Daf 13a

If there is a water <span class="gemarra-regular">channel </span>on <span class="gemarra-regular">one sid</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> of the field <span class="gemarra-regular">and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a river </span>on <span class="gemarra-regular">the other side</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the field <span class="gemarra-regular">is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> divided diagonally [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">bekarna</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">zol</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> between the two brothers, so that they each receive land adjoining both the river and the water channel.
§ The mishna teaches that <span class="gemarra-regular">a hall, </span>a drawing room, and the like should <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>be divided unless the two parties will be able to use their respective portions in the same manner that they had previously used them. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> if <span class="gemarra-regular">there is not enough</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for this one and that one? </span>What is to be done if one of the parties wishes to dissolve the partnership? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda said: There is a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> of: Either <span class="gemarra-regular">you set </span>a price <span class="gemarra-regular">or I will se</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> a price. That is to say, one party can say to the other: Set a price you are willing to pay for my share, and I will sell my share to you or purchase your share from you at that price. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman said: There is no </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> of: Either <span class="gemarra-regular">you</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> set </span>a price <span class="gemarra-regular">or I will set </span>a price; rather, the partnership continues.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said to Rav Naḥman: According to you who say</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">there is no </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> of: Either <span class="gemarra-regular">you set </span>a price <span class="gemarra-regular">or I will set </span>a price, <span class="gemarra-regular">what should they</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> do </span>if there was <span class="gemarra-regular">a firstborn </span>son <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>an <span class="gemarra-regular">ordinary</span> brother <span class="gemarra-regular">whose father left them a slave and a non</span><span class="gemarra-regular">-kosher animal </span>as an inheritance? How are they to be divided? Rav Naḥman <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: I say that they</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> work for this one, </span>the ordinary brother, <span class="gemarra-regular">one day, and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for the other one, </span>the firstborn, <span class="gemarra-regular">two days.</span>
The Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises an objection </span>to Rav Yehuda’s approach from what is taught in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Gittin</span> 41a): <span class="gemarra-regular">One who is half-slav</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> half-freeman, </span>e.g., a slave who had been jointly owned by two people, one of whom emancipated him, <span class="gemarra-regular">serves his master one </span><span class="gemarra-regular">day and himself one day; </span>this is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Hillel. Beit Shammai say: You have remedied </span>the situation of <span class="gemarra-regular">his master, </span>who benefits fully from all his rights to the slave, but <span class="gemarra-regular">you have not remedied his own </span>situation. <span class="gemarra-regular">He cannot marry a maidservant, </span>since half of him is free, and a free Jew may not marry a Canaanite maidservant. <span class="gemarra-regular">He is </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">not able to marry a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">free woman, </span>since half of him is a slave, and a Jewish woman may not marry a Canaanite slave. And if you say <span class="gemarra-regular">he should be idle </span>and not marry, <span class="gemarra-regular">but is it not </span>true that <span class="gemarra-regular">the world was created </span><span class="gemarra-regular">only for procreation, as it is stated: “He did not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">create it to be a waste; He formed it to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">be inhabited” </span>(Isaiah 45:18)?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>the court <span class="gemarra-regular">forces</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> his maste</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to make him a freeman </span>by emancipating the half that he owns, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the court <span class="gemarra-regular">writes a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">bill </span>in which the slave accepts responsibility to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">half </span><span class="gemarra-regular">his value </span>to his master. This was the original version of the mishna. The ultimate version of the mishna records the retraction of Beit Hillel: <span class="gemarra-regular">And Beit Hillel retracted </span>its opinion and <span class="gemarra-regular">ruled in accordance with the statement of Beit </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Shammai. </span>This indicates that it is only in this case, where there is the particular consideration of procreation, that the court compels one of the parties to forfeit his portion and dissolve the partnership. But in other cases there is no <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of: Either you set a price or I will set a price.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">It is different here, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>the slave can say: <span class="gemarra-regular">I will se</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> a price, but he is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>able to say: <span class="gemarra-regular">You set </span>a price. In other words, the slave cannot offer to sell himself, because his Jewish side precludes him from selling himself as a Canaanite slave. Therefore, the court would not be able force the master to sell his share, were it not for the consideration of procreation. By contrast, in a situation where either side can buy or sell, one partner can compel the other to either buy his portion or sell his portion to him.
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a proof from what is taught in a mishna (172a): In a case where there are <span class="gemarra-regular">two brothers, one poo</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and one rich, and their </span><span class="gemarra-regular">father left them a bathhouse or an olive press </span>as an inheritance, if the father had <span class="gemarra-regular">built </span>these facilities <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span><span class="gemarra-regular">profit, </span>i.e., to charge others for using them, <span class="gemarra-regular">the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> profit </span>that accrues after the father’s death is <span class="gemarra-regular">shared</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> equally </span>by the two brothers. If the father had <span class="gemarra-regular">built</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> them for himself </span>and for the members of his household to use, the poor brother, who has little use for these amenities, cannot force the rich brother to convert the facilities to commercial use; rather, <span class="gemarra-regular">the rich </span>brother can <span class="gemarra-regular">say</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to the poor </span>brother: 

Daf 13b

Go <span class="gemarra-regular">take servants </span><span class="gemarra-regular">for yourself</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and they will bathe in the bathhouse.</span> Or he can say: Go <span class="gemarra-regular">take olives for yourself and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> come and transform </span>them into oil <span class="gemarra-regular">in the olive press</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>Evidently, the poor brother cannot say to him: Buy my share. The Gemara rejects this proof: <span class="gemarra-regular">There too </span>the poor brother can say: <span class="gemarra-regular">You set </span>a price and buy my share, as the rich brother has the means to buy his poor brother’s portion; but he is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>able to say: Or else <span class="gemarra-regular">I will set </span>a price and buy your share, as the poor brother does not have the money to buy his brother out.
The Gemara further proposes: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a proof from what is taught in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Anything which, </span>even after it <span class="gemarra-regular">is divided</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> each of the parts <span class="gemarra-regular">retains the name </span>of the original item, <span class="gemarra-regular">may </span><span class="gemarra-regular">be divided. </span>And <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>the parts will <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>retain the original name, the item should not be divided, but rather <span class="gemarra-regular">its monetary </span>value <span class="gemarra-regular">is assessed, </span>because one of the joint owners can say to the other: Either you set a price and buy it from me, or I will set a price and buy it from you. The Gemara explains: Actually, this matter <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>a dispute between <span class="gemarra-italic">tanna’im</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, as</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: If a courtyard or the like was not large enough to warrant division into two, and one of the co-owners said to the other: <span class="gemarra-regular">You take </span>a minimum <span class="gemarra-regular">measure </span>of the courtyard, e.g., four cubits, <span class="gemarra-regular">and I </span>will take <span class="gemarra-regular">less</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the court <span class="gemarra-regular">listens to him. Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: They</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> do not listen to him.</span>
The Gemara clarifies the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">What are the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> circumstances </span>of the case under discussion? <span class="gemarra-regular">If we say it</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is </span>exactly <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is taught, what is Rabban Shimon</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> ben Gamliel’s reasoning? </span>Why does he rule that the court ignores the party who is prepared to settle for less? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, is it not that </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is incomplete</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and this </span>is what it <span class="gemarra-regular">is saying: </span>If one of the co-owners said to the other: <span class="gemarra-regular">You take </span>a minimum <span class="gemarra-regular">measure </span>of the courtyard, <span class="gemarra-regular">and I </span>will take <span class="gemarra-regular">less, </span>all agree that the court <span class="gemarra-regular">listens to him. </span>And the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> adds: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>if one says: Either <span class="gemarra-regular">you set </span>a price and buy it from me, <span class="gemarra-regular">or I will set </span>a price and buy it from you, <span class="gemarra-regular">they also listen to him. And Rabban Shimon ben </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Gamliel comes to say: </span>In the first case the court does listen to him, but <span class="gemarra-regular">they do not listen to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">him </span>when he says: Either you set a price or I will set a price. Accordingly, this issue is the subject of a tannaitic dispute.
The Gemara rejects this interpretation of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> should <span class="gemarra-regular">actually </span>be understood exactly <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span><span class="gemarra-regular">it is taught. And with regard to what you said: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">What is Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel’s reasoning? </span>Why can’t one of the parties say that they should divide the property and he will settle for less? It is <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>the second one <span class="gemarra-regular">can say to him: If </span>you want me to compensate you with <span class="gemarra-regular">money </span>for the difference between my share and your share, <span class="gemarra-regular">I have no money </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to give you. </span>And if you wish to give it to me as <span class="gemarra-regular">a gift, I am not at ease </span>with that, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is written: “But he who hates </span><span class="gemarra-regular">gifts shall live” </span>(Proverbs 15:27). The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> indicates that there is a <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of: Either you set a price or I will set a price, in accordance with the opinion of Rav Yehuda.
As a continuation of this discussion, <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said to Rav Yosef: That</span> statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav Yehuda is </span>actually the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Shmuel</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> his teacher, <span class="gemarra-regular">as we learned </span>in the mishna (11a): <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">sacred writings, </span>i.e., a scroll of any of the twenty-four books of the Bible, that were inherited by two people, <span class="gemarra-regular">they may not</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> divide </span>them, <span class="gemarra-regular">even if both of them wish </span>to do so, because it would be a show of disrespect to cut the scroll in half. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Shmuel said: They taught</span> that sacred writings should not be divided <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>if they are contained <span class="gemarra-regular">in one scroll</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> but </span>when they are contained <span class="gemarra-regular">in two scrolls, they may be divided. And if</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it should enter your mind </span>to say <span class="gemarra-regular">that there is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> no </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of: </span>Either <span class="gemarra-regular">you set </span>a price <span class="gemarra-regular">or I</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> will set </span>a price, <span class="gemarra-regular">why </span>does the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> apply <span class="gemarra-regular">specifically to one scroll? Even </span>if the sacred writings were contained <span class="gemarra-regular">in two scrolls, </span>they should <span class="gemarra-regular">also </span>not divide them, since the respective parts will not be even and one of the recipients will have to compensate the other.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Shalman interpreted </span>the mishna: It is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where they both want </span>to divide the sacred writings; therefore, Shmuel said that they may do so when they are contained in two scrolls. But if just one of them wishes to divide them, there is no proof that he can compel the other one to accept the division.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Ameimar said: The </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is in accordance with the opinion of Rav Yehuda that <span class="gemarra-regular">there is a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of: </span>Either <span class="gemarra-regular">you set </span>a price <span class="gemarra-regular">or I will </span><span class="gemarra-regular">set </span>a price. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi said to Ameimar: What </span>about <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav Naḥman, </span>who disagrees with Rav Yehuda and says that there is no such <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? Ameimar <span class="gemarra-regular">said</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to him: I do not know </span>of it, <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is to say, I do not maintain </span>this opinion. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>in accordance with the opinion of Rav Naḥman? <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>it happened that <span class="gemarra-regular">the father of Ravin bar Ḥinnana and Rav Dimi bar </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Ḥinnana </span>died and <span class="gemarra-regular">left them two maidservants, one </span>of whom <span class="gemarra-regular">knew how to bake and to cook, and the other </span>of whom <span class="gemarra-regular">knew how to spin and to weave. </span>One of the brothers suggested that each of them take one of the maidservants entirely for himself and forfeit his rights to the other maidservant. <span class="gemarra-regular">They came before Rava and he </span><span class="gemarra-regular">said to them: There is no </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of: </span>Either <span class="gemarra-regular">you </span><span class="gemarra-regular">set </span>a price <span class="gemarra-regular">or I will set </span>a price.
The Gemara answers: It is <span class="gemarra-regular">different there, since this </span><span class="gemarra-regular">master wanted both of the</span><span class="gemarra-regular">m</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and the other master wanted</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> both of them. </span>Therefore, <span class="gemarra-regular">when </span>one of the brothers <span class="gemarra-regular">said</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to </span>the other: <span class="gemarra-regular">You take one and I </span>will take the other <span class="gemarra-regular">one</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it is not </span>a case of: Either <span class="gemarra-regular">you set </span>a price <span class="gemarra-regular">or I will set </span>a price. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And can we not say so</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? But </span>there is the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">sacred writings, which both</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of them </span>presumably <span class="gemarra-regular">want, and Shmuel said: They taught </span>that sacred writings should not be divided <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>if they are contained <span class="gemarra-regular">in one scroll; but </span>when they are contained <span class="gemarra-regular">in</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> two scrolls, they may be divided. </span>The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Shalman interpreted </span>the mishna: It is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where they </span>both <span class="gemarra-regular">want </span>to divide the sacred writings, and in such a case they may divide them, provided that they are in two scrolls.
§ The Gemara now begins a general discussion about sacred writings. <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages </span><span class="gemarra-regular">taught: A person may attach the Torah, the Prophets, and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the Writings togethe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as one </span>scroll; this is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Yehuda says: The Torah </span>should be a scroll <span class="gemarra-regular">by itself</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the books of the <span class="gemarra-regular">Prophets</span> a scroll <span class="gemarra-regular">by themselves, and </span>the books of the <span class="gemarra-regular">Writings</span> a scroll <span class="gemarra-regular">by themselves. And the Sages say: Each one</span> of the books of the Prophets and the Writings should be a scroll <span class="gemarra-regular">by itself.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Yehuda said: </span>There was <span class="gemarra-regular">an incident involving Baitos ben Zunin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> who had</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> eight </span>books <span class="gemarra-regular">of the Prophets attached together as one </span>scroll, and he did this <span class="gemarra-regular">with the approval of Rabbi Elazar</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> ben Azarya</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> And others say that each and every</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> one </span>of the books was a scroll <span class="gemarra-regular">by itself, </span>in accordance with the opinion of the Sages. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">said: </span>There was <span class="gemarra-regular">an incident where they brought before us</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the Torah, the Prophets, and the Writings attached together as</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> one </span>scroll <span class="gemarra-regular">and we </span>ruled in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Meir and <span class="gemarra-regular">deemed them fit.</span>
The Gemara states: When different books are included in the same scroll, <span class="gemarra-regular">four </span>empty <span class="gemarra-regular">lines </span>of space should be left <span class="gemarra-regular">between each book of the Torah</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and similarly between one </span>book of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Prophets and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> another. But </span>between each of the books of <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Twelve Prophets </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">three </span>empty <span class="gemarra-regular">lines </span>should be left, because they are considered one book. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the scribe may <span class="gemarra-regular">finish </span>a book <span class="gemarra-regular">at the botto</span><span class="gemarra-regular">m</span> of one column <span class="gemarra-regular">and begin</span> the next book <span class="gemarra-regular">at the top </span>of the next column without leaving any empty space in between.
<span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">One who wishes to attach the Torah, the Prophets, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and the Writings together as one </span>scroll <span class="gemarra-regular">may attach </span>them. <span class="gemarra-regular">He should leave enough </span>empty parchment <span class="gemarra-regular">at the beginning </span>of the scroll <span class="gemarra-regular">for winding around the pole </span>to which the beginning of the scroll is fastened. <span class="gemarra-regular">And at the end</span> of the scroll he should leave enough empty parchment <span class="gemarra-regular">for</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> winding around the </span>entire <span class="gemarra-regular">circumferenc</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> of the rolled-up scroll. <span class="gemarra-regular">And he may finish </span>a book <span class="gemarra-regular">at the bottom </span>of one column <span class="gemarra-regular">and begin </span>the next book <span class="gemarra-regular">at the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">top </span>of the next column without leaving any empty space between them. 

Daf 14a

<span class="gemarra-regular">And if he wishes to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> cu</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> the scroll, <span class="gemarra-regular">he may cut </span>it. The Gemara is surprised at this: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">saying? </span>Why is mention made here of cutting the scroll? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">This is what </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is saying: </span>He arranges the text so that if he finishes a book at the bottom of one column, he begins the next book at the top of the next column without leaving any empty space, <span class="gemarra-regular">so that if he wishes to cut </span>the scroll, <span class="gemarra-regular">he may cut </span>it. If he does not begin the next book at the top of the next column, he will not be able to cut the scroll, because it is not fitting for a scroll to begin with an empty space.
The Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises a contradiction </span>between this <span class="it-text">baraita</span> and another <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">Enough </span>parchment should be left at <span class="gemarra-regular">the beginning of the scroll and at its en</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for winding. </span>The Gemara clarifies: <span class="gemarra-regular">For winding </span>around <span class="gemarra-regular">what? </span><span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>it means <span class="gemarra-regular">for winding around the pole </span>to which the beginning of the scroll is fastened, this is <span class="gemarra-regular">difficult</span> in light of what is taught in the first <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, that at the end of the scroll enough parchment should be left for winding around the entire <span class="gemarra-regular">circumference </span>of the scroll. And <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>it means <span class="gemarra-regular">for winding around </span>the entire <span class="gemarra-regular">circumference, </span>this is <span class="gemarra-regular">difficult </span>in light of what is taught in the first <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that at the beginning of the scroll enough parchment should be left for winding around the <span class="gemarra-regular">pole.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> said: </span>The <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">disjunctively, </span>referring to two separate cases. He issues a general statement requiring that enough parchment be left for winding as needed: At the beginning of the pole, enough to wind around the pole, and at the end of the scroll, enough to wind around the circumference.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi said: When that</span> second <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is taught, </span>indicating that the same measure of parchment is left at both the beginning and the end of the scroll, it was referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to a Torah scroll</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">All </span>other <span class="gemarra-regular">scrolls</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> are wound from the beginning to the en</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> around a single pole, <span class="gemarra-regular">but a Torah scroll is wound </span>from both ends <span class="gemarra-regular">to the middl</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> around two <span class="gemarra-regular">poles, </span>one of which <span class="gemarra-regular">he attaches at this </span>end of the scroll <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the other <span class="gemarra-regular">at the other </span>end. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Eliezer, son </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Tzadok, said: This is how the scribes in </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Jerusalem made their scrolls, </span>i.e., with poles at either end so that it could be rolled to the middle.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught: A</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Torah scroll should not be made </span>in such a manner <span class="gemarra-regular">that its length, </span>i.e., its height, <span class="gemarra-regular">is greater than</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> its circumferenc</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> when it is rolled up; <span class="gemarra-regular">nor </span>should <span class="gemarra-regular">its circumference be greater than its length. They asked Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi: <span class="gemarra-regular">What should the size of a Torah scroll</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> be? </span>Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">said to them: </span>If it was written <span class="gemarra-regular">on a hide that was treated with gallnuts </span><span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">g</span><span class="gemarra-italic">evil </span><span class="gemarra-regular">] </span>it should be <span class="gemarra-regular">six </span>handbreadths long. They asked him further: <span class="gemarra-regular">How much </span>should it be if it was written <span class="gemarra-regular">on </span>ordinary <span class="gemarra-regular">parchment [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">kelaf </span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi said to them: <span class="gemarra-regular">I do not know.</span>
It is related that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna wrote seventy Torah scrolls </span>himself, <span class="gemarra-regular">and it</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> happened for him </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">once </span>that the length and the circumference were equal. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov wrote one</span> Torah scroll <span class="gemarra-regular">on calf hide and it happened </span>to have the same length and circumference. <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages looked at him</span> and his achievement with jealousy, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he died </span>from their envious gaze.
<span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages said to Rav Hamnuna: Rabbi Ami</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> wrote four hundred Torah scrolls. </span>Rav Hamnuna <span class="gemarra-regular">said to them</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: Perhaps he wrote </span>the verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Moses commanded us the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Torah” </span>(Deuteronomy 33:4) four hundred times, rather than four hundred complete Torah scrolls, as it is difficult to say that he could have written so many, even over a lifetime. Similarly, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said to Rabbi Zeira: Rabbi Yannai planted</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> four hundred vineyards</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Rava <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Perhaps </span>he did not plant large vineyards, but only the smallest possible vineyards recognized by <span class="it-text">halakha</span>, which are composed of <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>vines <span class="gemarra-regular">facing </span>another <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>vines, with a fifth <span class="gemarra-regular">one protruding </span>like <span class="gemarra-regular">a tail, </span>extending out beyond the square.
The Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises an objection </span>to what is taught with regard to the length of a Torah scroll from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">the Ark </span>of the Covenant <span class="gemarra-regular">that Moses fashioned</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> its length was two and one-</span><span class="gemarra-regular">half cubits, its width was one and one-half cubits, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and its height was one and one-half cubits </span>(see Exodus 25:10), <span class="gemarra-regular">the cubit </span>used for these measurements <span class="gemarra-regular">being six</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> handbreadths. </span>Therefore, the Ark was fifteen handbreadths long, nine handbreadths wide, and nine handbreadths high.
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">And</span> as for <span class="gemarra-regular">the tablets, their length was six </span>handbreadths, <span class="gemarra-regular">their</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> width was six </span>handbreadths, <span class="gemarra-regular">and their thickness was three </span>handbreadths. The tablets <span class="gemarra-regular">were placed along the length of the Ark</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>one next to the other. If so, <span class="gemarra-regular">how much </span>space did <span class="gemarra-regular">the tablets occupy </span>along the length <span class="gemarra-regular">of the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Ark? Twelve handbreadths, </span>as each tablet was six handbreadths long. <span class="gemarra-regular">Three handbreadths were left there </span>along the length of the Ark, for a total of fifteen handbreadths. <span class="gemarra-regular">Deduct a handbreadth</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from them: One-half </span>a handbreadth <span class="gemarra-regular">for this wall, </span>namely, the thickness of the wooden Ark itself, <span class="gemarra-regular">and one-</span><span class="gemarra-regular">half </span>a handbreadth <span class="gemarra-regular">for the other wall. </span>Accordingly, <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span><span class="gemarra-regular">handbreadths were left there, in which the Torah scroll </span>written by Moses <span class="gemarra-regular">lay.</span>
What biblical source indicates that a Torah scroll was placed there? <span class="gemarra-regular">As it is stated: “There </span><span class="gemarra-regular">was nothing in the Ark except the two tablets of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">stone which Moses put there” </span>(I Kings 8:9). <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>does <span class="gemarra-regular">“there was nothing in the Ark except” </span>mean? This is an example of <span class="gemarra-regular">a restriction following a restriction, </span>as both terms, “nothing” and “except,” indicate that the Ark was empty. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>there is a hermeneutical principle that <span class="gemarra-regular">a restriction </span><span class="gemarra-regular">following a restriction serv</span>es <span class="gemarra-regular">only to amplify </span>and include other matters. In this case, it serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to include a Torah</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> scroll that lies in the Ark.</span>
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues: With this explanation <span class="gemarra-regular">you have accounted for the</span> entire <span class="gemarra-regular">length of the Ark; go </span>now <span class="gemarra-regular">and account for</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the width of the Ark, </span>which was nine handbreadths. <span class="gemarra-regular">How much </span>space did <span class="gemarra-regular">the tablets occupy </span>of the width <span class="gemarra-regular">of the Ark, </span>which was nine handbreadths wide? <span class="gemarra-regular">Six handbreadths; </span>therefore, <span class="gemarra-regular">three handbreadths were left there </span>along the width of the Ark. <span class="gemarra-regular">Deduct a handbreadth from them: One-half </span>a handbreadth <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>the thickness of <span class="gemarra-regular">this wall and one-half</span> a handbreadth <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>the thickness of <span class="gemarra-regular">the other wall. </span>Accordingly, <span class="gemarra-regular">two handbreadths were left there. </span>What was their purpose? These were necessary <span class="gemarra-regular">so that the Torah scroll would be </span><span class="gemarra-regular">able to go in and out without being pressed; </span>this is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of Rabbi Meir.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda </span>disagrees and <span class="gemarra-regular">says: </span>The <span class="gemarra-regular">cubit </span>used for all the measurements of the Ark <span class="gemarra-regular">was five handbreadths</span> long. There-fore, the Ark was twelve and one-half handbreadths long, seven and one-half handbreadths wide, and seven and one-half handbreadths high. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>as for <span class="gemarra-regular">the tablets, their</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> length was six </span>handbreadths, <span class="gemarra-regular">their width was six </span>handbreadths, <span class="gemarra-regular">and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> their thickness was three </span>handbreadths, and <span class="gemarra-regular">they were placed along</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the length of the Ark, </span>one next to the other. If so, <span class="gemarra-regular">how much </span>space did <span class="gemarra-regular">the tablets occupy </span>along the length <span class="gemarra-regular">of the Ark? Twelve handbreadths, </span>so that <span class="gemarra-regular">one-half a handbreadth was left there, </span>which is two fingerbreadths. <span class="gemarra-regular">One fingerbreadth </span>of those two was <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>the thickness of <span class="gemarra-regular">this wall and one fingerbreadth </span>of those two was <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>the thickness of <span class="gemarra-regular">the other wall.</span>
With this explanation, <span class="gemarra-regular">you have accounted </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>entire <span class="gemarra-regular">length of the Ark; go </span>now <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">account for the width of the Ark, </span>which was seven and one-half handbreadths. <span class="gemarra-regular">How much </span>space did <span class="gemarra-regular">the tablets </span><span class="gemarra-regular">occupy in the Ark?
