Six handbreadths, </span>meaning that <span class="gemarra-regular">one and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">one-half handbreadths were left there </span>along the width of the Ark. <span class="gemarra-regular">Deduct one-half a handbreadth, one and one</span><span class="gemarra-regular">-half fingerbreadth</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for </span>the thickness of <span class="gemarra-regular">this wall, and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">one and one-half fingerbreadths for </span>the thickness of <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">other wall. </span>Accordingly, <span class="gemarra-regular">one handbreadth was left there in which </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>silver <span class="gemarra-regular">column</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> were placed </span>on either side of the tablets, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is stated: “King Solomon made himself a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> palanquin of the timbers of Lebanon; he made its columns</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of silver, its back of gold, its seat of purple</span><span class="gemarra-regular">” </span>(Song of Songs 3:9–10). This is understood as an allusion to the Ark of the Covenant.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And the chest in which the Philistines sent the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">gift to the God of Israel was placed alongside </span>the Ark, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is stated: “And put the golden devices </span><span class="gemarra-regular">which you are restoring to Him for a guilt-offering </span><span class="gemarra-regular">in a chest by the side of it, and send </span><span class="gemarra-regular">it away that it may go” </span>(I Samuel 6:8). <span class="gemarra-regular">And</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> upon </span>this chest <span class="gemarra-regular">lay the Torah scroll, as it is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> stated: “Take this Torah scroll and put it at the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> side of the Ark of the Covenant of the Lord</span><span class="gemarra-regular">” </span>(Deuteronomy 31:26). This means that <span class="gemarra-regular">it was placed at </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the side </span>of the Ark, <span class="gemarra-regular">and not inside </span>it.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>accordingly, <span class="gemarra-regular">how do I realize </span>the meaning of that which is stated: <span class="gemarra-regular">“There was nothing in the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Ark except </span>the two tablets of stone which Moses put there,” which, according to the opinion of Rabbi Meir, teaches that something else was in the Ark besides the tablets themselves? It serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to include</span>

Daf 14b

<span class="gemarra-regular">the broken pieces of the</span> first set of <span class="gemarra-regular">tablets, which were placed in the Ark</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>Having cited the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, the Gemara now presents its objection to what was taught earlier with regard to the dimensions of a Torah scroll: <span class="gemarra-regular">And if it should enter </span><span class="gemarra-regular">your mind </span>to say, as Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi held, that <span class="gemarra-regular">the circumference of a Torah scroll is six handbreadths, now </span><span class="gemarra-regular">since any </span>cylindrical object <span class="gemarra-regular">having a circumference of three handbreadths </span><span class="gemarra-regular">has a diameter of one handbreadth</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> a Torah scroll with a circumference of six handbreadths has a diameter of two handbreadths. <span class="gemarra-regular">And since </span>a Torah scroll <span class="gemarra-regular">is wound to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the middle, </span>since it is rolled from both sides, <span class="gemarra-regular">it </span>must take up <span class="gemarra-regular">more than two handbreadths </span>due to <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">space between </span>the sheets of parchment and the double rolling. According to Rabbi Meir, who says that the Torah scroll was placed inside the ark, <span class="gemarra-regular">how did </span>the scroll <span class="gemarra-regular">fit </span><span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the remaining <span class="gemarra-regular">two handbreadths [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">pushkei</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> of space in the Ark?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Aḥa bar Ya’akov said: The scroll of the </span>Temple <span class="gemarra-regular">courtyard, </span>which was kept in the Ark, <span class="gemarra-regular">was wound to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">its beginning, </span>i.e., it had only a single pole, so that its circumference was only two handbreadths. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But still, how does </span>an item <span class="gemarra-regular">that is two </span>handbreadths wide <span class="gemarra-regular">fit into </span>a space that is precisely <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>handbreadths? It would be impossible to fit it in. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Ashi said: A small section </span>of the scroll <span class="gemarra-regular">was wound</span> separately <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">placed on top </span>of the scroll.
Having concluded its current discussion, the Gemara now addresses the details of the aforementioned <span class="it-text">baraita</span> and asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>according to <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda, </span>who says that the Torah scroll rested on the chest that came from the Philistines, <span class="gemarra-regular">where was the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Torah scroll placed before the chest arrived? </span>The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">A shelf protruded from </span>the Ark <span class="gemarra-regular">and the Torah scroll</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> rested on it. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>according to <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Meir, </span>who says that the Torah scroll rested inside the Ark, <span class="gemarra-regular">what does he do with this </span>verse: “Take this Torah scroll and put it <span class="gemarra-regular">at the side of the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Ark” </span>(Deuteronomy 31:26)? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">He requires </span>that verse to teach <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the Torah scroll <span class="gemarra-regular">was placed at </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the side </span>of the tablets, <span class="gemarra-regular">and that it was not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">placed between </span>the two <span class="gemarra-regular">tablets, but </span>it was <span class="gemarra-regular">actually </span>placed <span class="gemarra-regular">inside </span>the Ark <span class="gemarra-regular">at the side </span>of the tablets.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>according to <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">where were the </span>silver <span class="gemarra-regular">columns placed? </span>The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Outside </span>the Ark. The Gemara further asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And from where does</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rabbi Meir </span>derive that <span class="gemarra-regular">the broken pieces of the </span>first set of <span class="gemarra-regular">tablets were placed in the Ark, </span>as the verse from which Rabbi Yehuda learns this: “There was nothing in the Ark except” (I Kings 8:9), is needed by Rabbi Meir to teach that the Torah scroll was placed there? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">He derives </span>this point <span class="gemarra-regular">from what</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rav Huna </span>expounded, <span class="gemarra-regular">as Rav Huna says: What </span>is the meaning of that <span class="gemarra-regular">which is written: </span>“The Ark of God, <span class="gemarra-regular">whereupon is called the Name</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the name of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the Lord of hosts that sits upon the cherubs” </span>(II Samuel 6:2)? The phrase “the name, the name of the Lord” <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches that </span>both <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>second <span class="gemarra-regular">tablets and the broken</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> pieces of the </span>first set of <span class="gemarra-regular">tablets were placed in</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the Ark.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>what does <span class="gemarra-regular">the other </span>Sage, i.e., Rabbi Yehuda, derive from this verse? The Gemara responds: <span class="gemarra-regular">He requires </span>that text <span class="gemarra-regular">for</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">which Rabbi Yoḥanan </span>says, <span class="gemarra-regular">as Rabbi Yoḥanan says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon ben Yoḥai says: </span>This <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches that the </span>ineffable <span class="gemarra-regular">name </span>of God <span class="gemarra-regular">and all of His appellations were placed</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in the Ark.</span>
The Gemara inquires: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>doesn’t <span class="gemarra-regular">the other </span>Sage, Rabbi Meir, <span class="gemarra-regular">also require it</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for that? </span>The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Yes, </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">is indeed so</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. Rather, from where does he </span>derive that <span class="gemarra-regular">the broken pieces</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of the </span>first set of <span class="gemarra-regular">tablets were placed in the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Ark? </span>The Gemara expounds: <span class="gemarra-regular">He derives </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">which</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rav Yosef taught, as Rav Yosef taught </span>a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: The verses state: “At that time the Lord said to me: Hew for yourself two tablets of stone like the first…and I will write on the tablets the words that were on the first tablets, <span class="gemarra-regular">which you broke, and you</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> shall put the</span><span class="gemarra-regular">m</span> in the Ark” (Deuteronomy 10:1–2). <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span><span class="gemarra-regular">teaches that </span>both <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>second set of <span class="gemarra-regular">tablets and the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">broken pieces of the </span>first set of <span class="gemarra-regular">tablets were placed </span><span class="gemarra-regular">in the Ark.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>what does <span class="gemarra-regular">the other </span>one, Rabbi Yehuda, learn from this verse? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">He requires it</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">which Reish Lakish </span>teaches, <span class="gemarra-regular">as Reish Lakish </span><span class="gemarra-regular">says: </span>What is the meaning of that which is stated: “The first tablets, <span class="gemarra-regular">which you broke [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">asher</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">shibbarta</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]”? </span>These words allude to the fact that God approved of Moses’ action, as if <span class="gemarra-regular">the Holy One, Blessed be He, said to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Moses: May your strength be straight </span><span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">yishar</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">koḥakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] because you</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> broke </span>them.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught: The order of the </span>books of the <span class="gemarra-regular">Prophet</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> when they are attached together is as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">Joshua and Judges, Samuel and Kings, Jeremiah and Ezekiel</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">Isaiah and the Twelve </span>Prophets. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Consider: Hosea preceded </span>some of the other prophets whose books are included in the Bible, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is written: “The </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Lord spoke first to Hosea” </span>(Hosea 1:2). At first glance this verse is difficult: <span class="gemarra-regular">But did God speak first with</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Hosea, </span>and not with any other prophet before him? <span class="gemarra-regular">Weren</span><span class="gemarra-regular">’t there many prophets between Moses and Hosea? And Rabbi</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Yoḥanan says: He was the first of four prophets </span><span class="gemarra-regular">who prophesied in that period, and they were: Hosea and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Isaiah, Amos and Micah. </span>Accordingly, Hosea preceded those three prophets; <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the book of <span class="gemarra-regular">Hosea </span>as well <span class="gemarra-regular">should precede </span>the books of those prophets.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Since his prophecy </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is written together with </span>those of <span class="gemarra-regular">Haggai, Zechariah, and Malachi </span>in one book of the Twelve Prophets, <span class="gemarra-regular">and Haggai, Zechariah, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and Malachi were the last of the prophets, he is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">counted with them. </span>The Gemara inquires: <span class="gemarra-regular">But let </span>the book of Hosea <span class="gemarra-regular">be written separately and let it precede </span>the others. The Gemara answers: Were it written separately, <span class="gemarra-regular">since it </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is small it would be lost.</span>
The Gemara further asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Consider: Isaiah preceded Jeremiah and Ezekiel; let </span>the book of <span class="gemarra-regular">Isaiah precede </span>the books of those other prophets. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Since </span>the book of <span class="gemarra-regular">Kings ends with </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the destruction </span>of the Temple, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the book of <span class="gemarra-regular">Jeremiah </span>deals <span class="gemarra-regular">entirely with </span>prophecies of <span class="gemarra-regular">the destruction</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>the book of <span class="gemarra-regular">Ezekiel begins with the destruction </span>of the Temple <span class="gemarra-regular">but ends with consolation </span>and the rebuilding of the Temple, <span class="gemarra-regular">and Isaiah </span>deals <span class="gemarra-regular">entirely with consolation, </span>as most of his prophecies refer to the redemption, <span class="gemarra-regular">we juxtapose destruction to destruction </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and consolation to consolation. </span>This accounts for the order: Jeremiah, Ezekiel, and Isaiah.
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">The order </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of the Writing</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> is: <span class="gemarra-regular">Ruth and the book of Psalms</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, and Job and Proverbs; Ecclesiastes, Song of Songs, and Lamentations</span><span class="gemarra-regular">; Daniel and the Scroll of Esther; </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">Ezra and Chronicles</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And according to the one who says</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">Job </span>lived <span class="gemarra-regular">in the time of Moses, let </span>the book of <span class="gemarra-regular">Job precede </span>the others. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">We</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> do not begin with suffering, </span>i.e., it is inappropriate to start the Writings with a book that deals so extensively with suffering. The Gemara asks: But the book of <span class="gemarra-regular">Ruth, </span>with which the Writings opens, <span class="gemarra-regular">is also </span>about <span class="gemarra-regular">suffering</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>since it describes the tragedies that befell the family of Elimelech. The Gemara answers: This is <span class="gemarra-regular">suffering which has a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> futur</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> of hope and redemption. <span class="gemarra-regular">As Rabbi Yoḥanan says: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Why was she named Ruth, </span>spelled <span class="it-text">reish</span>, <span class="it-text">vav</span>, <span class="it-text">tav</span>? Because there <span class="gemarra-regular">descended from her David who sated, </span>a word with the root <span class="it-text">reish</span>, <span class="it-text">vav</span>, <span class="it-text">heh</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">the Holy One, Blessed </span><span class="gemarra-regular">be He, with songs and praises.</span>
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> now considers the authors of the biblical books: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span><span class="gemarra-regular">who wrote </span>the books of the Bible? <span class="gemarra-regular">Moses wrote his </span><span class="gemarra-regular">own book, </span>i.e., the Torah, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the portion of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Balaa</span><span class="gemarra-regular">m</span> in the Torah, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the book of <span class="gemarra-regular">Job. </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Joshua wrote his own book and eight verses in the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Torah, </span>which describe the death of Moses. <span class="gemarra-regular">Samuel wrote his </span><span class="gemarra-regular">own book, </span>the book of <span class="gemarra-regular">Judges, and </span>the book of <span class="gemarra-regular">Ruth. David wrote the book of Psalms by means of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">ten elder</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> of previous generations, assembling a collection that included compositions of others along with his own. He included psalms authored <span class="gemarra-regular">by Adam the first </span>man, <span class="gemarra-regular">by Melchizedek </span>king of Salem, <span class="gemarra-regular">and by Abraham, and by Moses, and by </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Heman, and by Jeduthun, and by Asaph, </span>

Daf 15a

<span class="gemarra-regular">and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">by the three sons of Korah</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Jeremiah </span><span class="gemarra-regular">wrote his own book, and the book of Kings, and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Lamentations. Hezekiah and his colleague</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> wrote </span>the following, and <span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> mnemonic </span>to remember which books they wrote is <span class="gemarra-italic">yod</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span><span class="gemarra-italic">mem</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span><span class="gemarra-italic">shin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kuf</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: Isaiah [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">Yeshaya</span><span class="gemarra-regular">], Proverbs [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">Mishlei</span><span class="gemarra-regular">], Song of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Songs [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">Shir</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">HaShirim</span><span class="gemarra-regular">], and Ecclesiastes [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">Kohelet</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]. The members of the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Great Assembly wrote </span>the following, and <span class="gemarra-regular">a mnemonic </span>to remember these books is <span class="gemarra-italic">kuf</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span><span class="gemarra-italic">nun</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span><span class="gemarra-italic">dalet</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span><span class="gemarra-italic">gimmel</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: Ezekiel [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">Yeḥezkel </span><span class="gemarra-regular">], and the Twelve Prophets [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">Sheneim</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">Asar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Daniel </span>[<span class="gemarra-italic">Daniel </span>], <span class="gemarra-regular">and the Scroll of Esther [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">Megillat</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">Ester</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]. Ezra wrote </span><span class="gemarra-regular">his own book and the genealogy of </span>the book of <span class="gemarra-regular">Chronicles until his </span>period.
The Gemara comments: This <span class="gemarra-regular">supports Rav, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">as Rav Yehuda says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: Ezra did not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">ascend from Babylonia </span>to Eretz Yisrael <span class="gemarra-regular">until he established his </span><span class="gemarra-regular">own genealogy, and </span>after that he <span class="gemarra-regular">ascended. </span>This genealogy is what is written in the book of Chronicles. <span class="gemarra-regular">And who </span><span class="gemarra-regular">completed </span>the book of Chronicles for the generations following Ezra? <span class="gemarra-regular">Nehemiah, son of Hacaliah.</span>
The Gemara elaborates on the particulars of this <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">The </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Master said </span>above that <span class="gemarra-regular">Joshua wrote his own book and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">eight verses of the Torah</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> The Gemara comments: This <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is taught in accordance with the one who says </span><span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>it was <span class="gemarra-regular">Joshua </span>who <span class="gemarra-regular">wrote the </span>last <span class="gemarra-regular">eight verses </span><span class="gemarra-regular">in the Torah. </span>This point is subject to a tannaitic dispute, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is taught </span>in another <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And Moses</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the servant of the Lord died there” </span>(Deuteronomy 34:5); <span class="gemarra-regular">is it possible that </span>after <span class="gemarra-regular">Moses died, he </span>himself <span class="gemarra-regular">wrote “</span><span class="gemarra-regular">And Moses died there”? Rather, Moses wrote </span>the entire Torah <span class="gemarra-regular">until this point, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">Joshua wrote from this </span>point <span class="gemarra-regular">forward; </span>this is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of Rabbi Yehuda. And some say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Neḥemya </span>stated this opinion.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Shimon said to him: Is it possible </span>that the <span class="gemarra-regular">Torah </span><span class="gemarra-regular">scroll was missing a single letter? But it is written: “</span><span class="gemarra-regular">Take this Torah scroll” </span>(Deuteronomy 31:26), indicating that the Torah was complete as is and that nothing further would be added to it. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, until this point the Holy One</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, Blessed be He, dictated and Moses repeated </span>after Him <span class="gemarra-regular">and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> wrot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> the text. <span class="gemarra-regular">From this </span>point <span class="gemarra-regular">forward, </span>with respect to Moses’ death, <span class="gemarra-regular">the Holy One, Blessed be He, dictated </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and Moses wrote with tears. </span>The fact that the Torah was written by way of dictation can be seen <span class="gemarra-regular">later, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">as it is stated </span>concerning the writing of the Prophets: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And Baruch said to them: He dictated all these words</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to me, and I wrote them with ink in the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> scroll” </span>(Jeremiah 36:18).
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">In accordance with whose </span>opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">is that which Rabbi Yehoshua </span><span class="gemarra-regular">bar Abba says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Giddel says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: </span>When the Torah is read publicly in the synagogue, <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>person <span class="gemarra-regular">read</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the </span>last <span class="gemarra-regular">eight verse</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in the Torah, </span>and that section may not be divided between two readers? <span class="gemarra-regular">Shall we say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">this is </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda and not in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon, </span>as according to Rabbi Shimon these verses are an integral part of the Torah, written by Moses just like the rest? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Even </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">you say </span>that this was said in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon, since they differ </span>from the rest of the Torah in one way, as Moses wrote them with tears, <span class="gemarra-regular">they differ </span>from the rest of the Torah in this way as well, i.e., they may not be divided between two readers.
It is stated in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">Joshua wrote his own book. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span><span class="gemarra-regular">isn’t it written </span>toward the end of the book: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And Joshua, son of Nun, the servant of the Lord</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, died” </span>(Joshua 24:29)? Is it possible that Joshua wrote this? The Gemara answers: Aaron’s son <span class="gemarra-regular">Eleazar completed it. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t it </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">written: “And </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Eleazar, son of Aaron, died” </span>(Joshua 24:33)? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Pinehas completed it.</span>
It is also stated in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">Samuel wrote his own book. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t it written: “And Samuel died” </span>(I Samuel 28:3)? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Gad the seer and Nathan </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the prophet finished it.</span>
It is further stated that <span class="gemarra-regular">David wrote the book of Psalms by means </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of ten elders, </span>whom the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> proceeds to list. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">let it also count Ethan the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Ezrahite </span>among the contributors to the book of Psalms, as it is he who is credited with Psalms, chapter 89. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: Ethan the Ezrahite is </span>the same person as <span class="gemarra-regular">Abraham. </span>Proof for this is the fact that <span class="gemarra-regular">it is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">written here: </span>“A Maskil of <span class="gemarra-regular">Ethan the Ezrahite” </span>(Psalms 89:1), <span class="gemarra-regular">and it is written there: “Who raised up one </span><span class="gemarra-regular">from the east [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">mizraḥ</span><span class="gemarra-regular">], whom righteousness </span>met wherever he set his foot” (Isaiah 41:2). The latter verse is understood as referring to Abraham, who came from the east, and for that reason he is called Ethan the Ezrahite in the former verse.
The Gemara asks: The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">counts Moses </span>among the ten elders whose works are included in the book of Psalms, <span class="gemarra-regular">and it </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">counts Heman. But doesn’t Rav </span><span class="gemarra-regular">say: </span>The <span class="gemarra-regular">Heman </span>mentioned in the Bible (I Kings 5:11) <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>the same person as <span class="gemarra-regular">Moses? </span>This is proven by the fact that <span class="gemarra-regular">it is written here: “Heman” </span>(Psalms 88:1), which is Aramaic for trusted, <span class="gemarra-regular">and it is written </span><span class="gemarra-regular">there </span>about Moses: <span class="gemarra-regular">“For he is the trusted one in</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> all My house” </span>(Numbers 12:7). The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">There </span><span class="gemarra-regular">were two Hemans, </span>one of whom was Moses, and the other a Temple singer from among the descendants of Samuel.
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> further states that <span class="gemarra-regular">Moses wrote </span><span class="gemarra-regular">his own book, </span>i.e., the Torah, <span class="gemarra-regular">the portion of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Balaam, and </span>the book of <span class="gemarra-regular">Job. This supports Rabbi Levi</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> bar Laḥma, as Rabbi Levi bar Laḥma says: Job </span>lived <span class="gemarra-regular">in the time of Moses. It is written here </span>with regard to Job: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Oh, that my words were written </span><span class="gemarra-regular">now [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">eifo</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]” </span>(Job 19:23), <span class="gemarra-regular">and it is written there </span>in Moses’ words to God: <span class="gemarra-regular">“For in what shall it </span><span class="gemarra-regular">be known here [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">eifo</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]” </span>(Exodus 33:16). The unusual use of the word <span class="it-text">eifo</span> in these two places indicates that Job and Moses lived in the same generation.
The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if that is the proof, <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that Job lived <span class="gemarra-regular">in the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> time of Isaac, as it is written </span>in connection with Isaac: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Who then [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">eifo</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] is he that has taken </span><span class="gemarra-regular">venison” </span>(Genesis 27:33). <span class="gemarra-regular">Or say </span>that he lived <span class="gemarra-regular">in the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> time of Jacob, as it is written </span>with respect to Jacob: <span class="gemarra-regular">“If it must be so now [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">eifo</span><span class="gemarra-regular">], do </span><span class="gemarra-regular">this” </span>(Genesis 43:11). <span class="gemarra-regular">Or say </span>that he lived <span class="gemarra-regular">in the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> time of Joseph, as it is written </span>with respect to Joseph: “Tell me, I pray you, <span class="gemarra-regular">where [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">eifo</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] </span><span class="gemarra-regular">are they feeding their flocks?” </span>(Genesis 37:16).
The Gemara answers: It could <span class="gemarra-regular">not enter your mind </span>to say this, <span class="gemarra-regular">as</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it is written </span>in the continuation of the previously mentioned verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Oh, that </span>my words <span class="gemarra-regular">were inscribed [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">veyuḥaku</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] in </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a book” </span>(Job 19:23), <span class="gemarra-regular">and it is Moses who is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> called the inscriber, as it is written </span>with regard to him: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And he provided the first part for himself, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">for there was the inscriber’s [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">meḥokek</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] portion reserved” </span>(Deuteronomy 33:21).
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava says: Job</span> lived <span class="gemarra-regular">at the time of the spies </span>whom Moses sent to scout the land of Canaan. This is proven by the fact that <span class="gemarra-regular">it is written here: “There was a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> man in the land of Utz, whose name was Job</span><span class="gemarra-regular">” </span>(Job 1:1), <span class="gemarra-regular">and it is written there </span>in the account of the spies: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Whether there are trees [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">eitz</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] in</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it” </span>(Numbers 13:20). The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Is it comparable? </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Here </span>the word that is used is <span class="gemarra-italic">Utz</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>whereas <span class="gemarra-regular">there</span> the word is <span class="gemarra-italic">eitz</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">This is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">what Moses said to Israel, </span>i.e., to the spies: <span class="gemarra-regular">Is that man </span>named Job still alive, <span class="gemarra-regular">he whose years </span><span class="gemarra-regular">are as long as </span>the years <span class="gemarra-regular">of a tree and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">who protects his generation like a tree? </span>This is why the allusion to him here is through the word <span class="it-text">eitz</span>, rather than <span class="it-text">Utz</span>.
The Gemara relates that <span class="gemarra-regular">one of the Sages sat before Rabbi Shmuel </span><span class="gemarra-regular">bar Naḥmani and he sat and said: Job never existed </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and was never created; </span>there was never such a person as Job. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>his story <span class="gemarra-regular">was a parable. </span>Rabbi Shmuel bar Naḥmani <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>In rebuttal <span class="gemarra-regular">to you, the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">verse states: “There was a man in the Land of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Utz whose name was Job” </span>(Job 1:1), which indicates that such a man did indeed exist.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But if that is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> so, </span>that the words “there was” prove that Job existed, what shall we say about the parable that Natan the prophet presented to David: “There were two men in one city; the one rich and the other poor. The rich man had very many flocks and herds, <span class="gemarra-regular">but the poor</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> man had nothing except one little lamb, which he had</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> bought and reared” </span>(II Samuel 12:3)? <span class="gemarra-regular">Was there </span>really such a person? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, it was merely a parable; here </span><span class="gemarra-regular">too it is merely a parable. </span>The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span><span class="gemarra-regular">so, </span>that it is a parable, <span class="gemarra-regular">why </span>state <span class="gemarra-regular">his name </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and the name of his city? </span>Rather, Job was clearly a real person.
The Gemara cites another opinion with regard to the time when Job lived. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and Rabbi Elazar both say: Job was among those who </span><span class="gemarra-regular">ascended from the exile </span>to Eretz Yisrael at the start of the Second Temple period, <span class="gemarra-regular">and his house of study </span><span class="gemarra-regular">was in Tiberias. </span>The Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises an objection </span>from what is taught in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">The days of Job’s </span><span class="gemarra-regular">life </span>extended <span class="gemarra-regular">from when Israel entered Egypt until they left, </span>indicating that this is the period during which he lived and not, as suggested, in the early days of the Second Temple. 

Daf 15b

The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Say </span>that the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> means that the duration of Job’s life lasted as long <span class="gemarra-regular">as from when Israel entered Egypt </span><span class="gemarra-regular">until when they left, </span>but not that he lived during that specific time frame.
The Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises an objection </span>from another <span class="it-text">baraita</span> against the notion that Job was a Jew: <span class="gemarra-regular">Seven prophets</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> prophesied to the nations of the world, and they are</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: Balaam and his fathe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> Beor, <span class="gemarra-regular">and Job, Eliphaz the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Temanite, and Bildad the Shuhite, and Zophar the Naamathite, and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Elihu ben Barachel the Buzite, </span>which indicates that Job was not Jewish. <span class="gemarra-regular">He said to him: And according to your </span><span class="gemarra-regular">reasoning </span>that Job could not have been Jewish because he prophesied to the nations of the world, <span class="gemarra-regular">was Elihu ben </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Barachel not a Jew? Is it </span>not <span class="gemarra-regular">written: “Of the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">family of Ram” </span>(Job 32:2), meaning Abraham?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>one must explain that Elihu is included in this list because <span class="gemarra-regular">he prophesied to the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> nations of the world; </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">so too </span>it may be maintained that <span class="gemarra-regular">Job </span>is included in this list, even though he is Jewish, because he <span class="gemarra-regular">prophesied to the nations of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the world. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But did not all </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>other <span class="gemarra-regular">prophets </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">prophesy to the nations of the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">world? </span>Why then are only these seven mentioned? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">There, </span>with regard to the other prophets, <span class="gemarra-regular">their main </span><span class="gemarra-regular">prophecies were </span>directed <span class="gemarra-regular">to Israel, </span>whereas <span class="gemarra-regular">here, </span>with regard to these seven prophets, <span class="gemarra-regular">their main prophecies were </span>directed <span class="gemarra-regular">to the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">nations of the world.</span>
The Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises an objection </span>from what is taught in a different <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">There was a </span>certain <span class="gemarra-regular">pious man among the nations of the world and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">his name was Job, and he came into the world </span><span class="gemarra-regular">only to receive his reward. The Holy One, Blessed be </span><span class="gemarra-regular">He, brought afflictions upon him, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">he began to blaspheme </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and curse. The Holy One, Blessed be He, doubled his </span><span class="gemarra-regular">reward in this world in order to expel him from </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the World-to-Come. </span>This <span class="it-text">baraita</span> states that Job was not a Jew, but rather a gentile.
The Gemara responds: The matter of whether or not Job was Jewish <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>a dispute between <span class="gemarra-italic">tanna’im</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> with regard to the period during which Job lived: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar says: Job </span>lived <span class="gemarra-regular">in the days of the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> judging of the Judges, as it is stated </span>in connection with Job: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Behold, all you yourselves have seen it; </span><span class="gemarra-regular">why then have you become altogether vain?” </span>(Job 27:12). <span class="gemarra-regular">Which</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> generation was completely vain</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> You must say it was</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the generation of the judging of the Judges, </span>when the people judged the Judges, as will be explained shortly.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehoshua ben Korḥa says</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: Job </span>lived <span class="gemarra-regular">in the days of Ahasuerus, as it is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> stated: “And in all the world were no women found</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> so beautiful as the daughters of Job” </span>(Job 42:15). In <span class="gemarra-regular">which generation were beautiful women sought? You must say </span><span class="gemarra-regular">it was the generation of Ahasuerus </span>(Esther, chapter 2). The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>why not <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>it was <span class="gemarra-regular">in the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> days of David, as it is written: “And they sought</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a beautiful maiden” </span>(I Kings 1:3)? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">There, </span>in the time of David, they searched <span class="gemarra-regular">“throughout the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> territory of Israel” </span>(I Kings 1:3), whereas <span class="gemarra-regular">here, </span>in the time of <span class="gemarra-regular">Ahasuerus, </span>they searched <span class="gemarra-regular">throughout the world, </span>as is similarly stated with regard to Job’s daughters.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Natan says: Job </span>lived <span class="gemarra-regular">in the days of the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> kingdom of Sheba, as it is stated: “And Sheba fell</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> upon them, and took them away” </span>(Job 1:15). <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis say: Job </span>lived <span class="gemarra-regular">in the days of </span>the kingdom of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Chaldeans </span>in the time of Nebuchadnezzar, <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span><span class="gemarra-regular">it is stated: “The Chaldeans formed three bands” </span>(Job 1:17). <span class="gemarra-regular">And some say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Job </span>lived <span class="gemarra-regular">in the days of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Jacob and </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">he married Dina, the daughter of Jacob</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>As <span class="gemarra-regular">it is written here: “You speak as one of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the loathsome women speaks” </span>(Job 2:10), <span class="gemarra-regular">and it is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">written there </span>in the account of the incident involving Dina: <span class="gemarra-regular">“He has done a loathsome act in Israel” </span>(Genesis 34:7). This concludes the text of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>. The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">And all </span>these <span class="gemarra-italic">tanna’im</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> hold that Job </span><span class="gemarra-regular">was a Jew except for </span>the opinion introduced with the phrase: <span class="gemarra-regular">And some say, </span>according to which Job lived in the time of Jacob, and he was certainly not one of Jacob’s sons.
And what is the proof that all these <span class="it-text">tanna’im</span> maintain that Job was Jewish? <span class="gemarra-regular">As if it should enter your mind </span>to say that he came <span class="gemarra-regular">from the nations of the world, </span>there is a difficulty: <span class="gemarra-regular">After Moses died, did the Divine Presence rest</span> any longer <span class="gemarra-regular">on the nations of the world? But doesn</span><span class="gemarra-regular">’t the Master say: Moses requested that the Divine Presence</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not rest </span>again <span class="gemarra-regular">on the nations of the world, and</span> his request <span class="gemarra-regular">was granted to him, as it is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">stated: “That we shall be differentiated, I and Your people, </span>from all the people that are upon the face of the earth” (Exodus 33:16), and it is stated there that God acceded to his request.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Yoḥanan says: The generation of Job was awash in licentiousness, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">as it is stated: “Behold, all of you yourselves have </span><span class="gemarra-regular">seen [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ḥazitem</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] it; why then have you become altogether vain?” </span>(Job 27:12), <span class="gemarra-regular">and it is written: “Return, return, O Shulamite</span><span class="gemarra-regular">; return, return, that we may look [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">veneḥeze</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] upon you” </span>(Song of Songs 7:1), which teaches that the phrase “you have seen it” connotes a licentious gaze. The Gemara asks: But <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that the phrase “you yourselves have seen it” signifies <span class="gemarra-regular">prophecy, as it is written: “The vision [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ḥazon</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Isaiah ben Amoz” </span>(Isaiah 1:1). The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, why do I </span>need the words: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Why then have </span><span class="gemarra-regular">you become altogether vain”? </span>Rather, the reference must be to inappropriate licentious gazing.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>further, with regard to Rabbi Elazar’s statement in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that the generation of the judging of the Judges was one of vanity, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: What </span>is the meaning of that <span class="gemarra-regular">which is written: “And it </span><span class="gemarra-regular">happened in the days of the judging of the Judges” </span>(Ruth 1:1)? This indicates <span class="gemarra-regular">a generation that judged its judges</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>If a judge would <span class="gemarra-regular">say to </span>the defendant standing before him: <span class="gemarra-regular">Remove the splinter from between your eyes, </span>meaning rid yourself of some minor infraction, the defendant would <span class="gemarra-regular">say to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> him: Remove the beam from between your eyes, </span>meaning you have committed far more severe sins. If the judge would <span class="gemarra-regular">say to him: “Your silver is become dross” </span>(Isaiah 1:22), meaning your coins are counterfeit, the defendant would <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to him: “Your wine is mixed with water” </span>(Isaiah 1:22), meaning you yourself dilute your wine with water and sell it. Since nobody behaved in proper manner, the judges were unable to judge.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shmuel bar </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Naḥmani says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yonatan says: Anyone who says that </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the queen of Sheba [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">malkat</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">Sheva</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> who came to visit King Solomon (see I Kings, chapter 10) <span class="gemarra-regular">was a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">woman is nothing other than mistaken. What </span>is the meaning of <span class="gemarra-italic">malkat</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Sheba? The kingdom [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">malkhuta</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] of Sheba, </span>as is mentioned in Job: “And Sheba fell on them and took them away” (Job 1:15).
§ Having mentioned the book of Job, the Gemara addresses several matters relating to it. It is stated: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Now there was a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> day when the sons of God came to present themselves</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> before the Lord, and the Satan came also among them</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. And the Lord said to the Satan: From where do</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> you come? And the Satan answered </span>the Lord, and said: From going to and fro in the earth, and from walking through it” (Job 1:6–7). The Satan <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>God: <span class="gemarra-regular">Master of the Universe, I have gone to and fro</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> throughout the entire world and I have not found anyone</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as faithful as Your servant Abraham, to whom You said</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: “Arise, walk through the land in the length of it</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and in the breadth of it; for I will give</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it to you” </span>(Genesis 13:17). <span class="gemarra-regular">And even so, when </span><span class="gemarra-regular">he did not find a place to bury Sarah before </span><span class="gemarra-regular">he purchased </span>a burial site <span class="gemarra-regular">for four hundred silver shekels, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">he did not find fault with Your ways </span>or complain about the fact that you had failed to fulfill Your promise.
<span class="gemarra-regular">“And the Lord</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> said to the Satan: Have you considered My servant Job</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, that there is none like him on earth, </span>a perfect and upright man, one who fears God and turns away from evil?” (Job 1:8). About this <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: That</span> which <span class="gemarra-regular">is stated about Job is greater than that </span>which <span class="gemarra-regular">is stated about Abraham. As with regard to Abraham it</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is written: “For now I know that you fear God</span><span class="gemarra-regular">” </span>(Genesis 22:12), <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to Job it is written: “</span><span class="gemarra-regular">A perfect and an upright man, one who fears God </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and turns away from evil” </span>(Job 1:8).
The Gemara clarifies the meaning of the aforementioned verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is meant by <span class="gemarra-regular">“and turns away from </span><span class="gemarra-regular">evil”? Rabbi Abba bar Shmuel says: Job was forgiving with</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> his money. </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">the way of the world </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">one pays the storekeeper </span>for even <span class="gemarra-regular">half-</span><span class="gemarra-italic">peruta</span> of merchandise purchased from him. But if somebody bought an item of such little value from <span class="gemarra-regular">Job, </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">would forgive him </span>his half-<span class="it-text">peruta</span>.
The Gemara continues to clarify the verses concerning Job. <span class="gemarra-regular">“Then the Satan answered the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Lord, and said: Does Job fear God for naught? Have</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> You not made a hedge about him, and about his</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> house, </span>and about all that he has on every side? You have blessed the work of his hands, and his cattle is increased in the land” (Job 1:9–10). <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is meant by: <span class="gemarra-regular">“You have blessed the work of his </span><span class="gemarra-regular">hands”? Rabbi Shmuel bar Rav Yitzḥak says: Anyone who took</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">peruta</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from Job was blessed. </span>Not only was Job’s own handiwork blessed, but anybody who received anything from him was also blessed.
The Gemara continues with its explication of these verses. <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is meant by: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And his livestock is increased </span><span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">p</span><span class="gemarra-italic">aratz</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] in </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the land” </span>(Job 1:10)? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei bar Ḥanina says: Job</span><span class="gemarra-regular">’s livestock breached </span><span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">p</span><span class="gemarra-italic">aretzu</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] the order of the world. </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">the way of the world </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">wolves kill goats</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>but in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">Job’s livestock, the goats</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> killed the wolves.</span>
The Gemara continues to relate the Satan’s challenge to God: <span class="gemarra-regular">“But now put forth Your hand, and touch all </span><span class="gemarra-regular">that he has, and he will curse You to Your </span><span class="gemarra-regular">face. And the Lord said to the Satan: Behold, all </span><span class="gemarra-regular">that he has is in your power; only upon himself </span><span class="gemarra-regular">do not put forth your hand. </span>And the Satan went out from the presence of the Lord” (Job 1:11–12). The verses relate what then occurred: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Now there was a day</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> when his sons and his daughters were eating and drinking</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> wine in their eldest brother’s house, and there came</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a messenger to Job, and said: The oxen were plowing</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>and the asses were feeding beside them” (Job 1:13–14). The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is meant by: <span class="gemarra-regular">“The oxen were </span><span class="gemarra-regular">plowing and the asses were feeding beside them”? Rabbi Yoḥanan</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> says: This teaches that the Holy One, Blessed be He</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, gave Job a taste</span>

Daf 16a

<span class="gemarra-regular">of the World-to-Come, </span>when plowing and harvesting will take place at the same time. Here too, the oxen plowed and the donkeys grazed on the crops that grew from that effort.
The Gemara continues to interpret verses from the book of Job. <span class="gemarra-regular">“While he was yet speaking, there </span><span class="gemarra-regular">came also another and said: The fire of God </span>has fallen from heaven, and has burned up the sheep, and the servants, and consumed them…<span class="gemarra-regular">W</span><span class="gemarra-regular">hile he was yet speaking, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">there came also another and said: The Chaldeans formed three </span><span class="gemarra-regular">bands, and fell among the camels, and have carried them </span><span class="gemarra-regular">away, </span>and have slain the servants with the edge of the sword…<span class="gemarra-regular">While he was yet speaking, there came also </span><span class="gemarra-regular">another and said: Your sons and your daughters were eating </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and drinking wine in their eldest brother’s house; and, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">behold, there came a great wind from across the wilderness, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and smote the four corners of the house, and it </span><span class="gemarra-regular">fell upon the young men, </span>and they are dead…<span class="gemarra-regular">Then </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Job arose, and rent his coat, and shaved his head, </span>and fell down on the ground and prostrated himself. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span><span class="gemarra-regular">he said: I came naked out of my mother’s </span><span class="gemarra-regular">womb, and naked I shall return there; the Lord gave, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and the Lord has taken away, blessed be the name </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of the Lord. In all this Job sinned not, nor </span><span class="gemarra-regular">did he lay reproach on God” </span>(Job 1:16–22).
<span class="gemarra-regular">“Again there was a day when </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the sons of God came to present themselves </span>before the Lord, and the Satan came also among them to present himself before God. <span class="gemarra-regular">And the Lord said to the Satan: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">From where do you come? And the Satan answered the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Lord, and said: From going to and fro in the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">earth </span>and from walking up and down in it” (Job 2:1–2). The Satan <span class="gemarra-regular">said before </span>God: <span class="gemarra-regular">Master of the Universe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, I have gone to and fro across the entire world</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and have not found anyone as faithful as your servant</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Abraham, to whom you said: “Arise, walk through the land</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in the length of it and in the breadth of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it; for I will give it to you” </span>(Genesis 13:17). <span class="gemarra-regular">And when he wanted to bury Sarah, he could </span><span class="gemarra-regular">not find a place to bury her, and </span>yet <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span><span class="gemarra-regular">did not criticize Your ways, </span>or accuse You of having failed to keep Your promise.
About this it says: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Lord said to the Satan: Have you considered My servant </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Job, that there is none like him on earth, </span>a perfect and an upright man, one that fears God and turns away from evil? <span class="gemarra-regular">And still he holds fast to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">his integrity, although you moved Me against him, to destroy </span><span class="gemarra-regular">him without cause” </span>(Job 2:3).
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: Were it not </span>explicitly <span class="gemarra-regular">written</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in the verse, it would be impossible to say this</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as it would be insulting to God’s honor. The verse states: “You moved Me against him,” <span class="gemarra-regular">like </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a person whom others persuade and </span>allows himself to be <span class="gemarra-regular">persuaded, </span>as if God had not wanted to do anything, but allowed Himself to be persuaded to bring harm to Job.
<span class="gemarra-regular">It was taught in a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">baraita</span> with regard to the methods of the Satan: He <span class="gemarra-regular">descends </span>to this world <span class="gemarra-regular">and misleads </span>a person into sinning. He then <span class="gemarra-regular">ascends </span>to Heaven, levels accusations against that very sinner, <span class="gemarra-regular">and inflames </span>God’s <span class="gemarra-regular">anger </span>against him. He then <span class="gemarra-regular">receives permission </span>to act <span class="gemarra-regular">and takes away the </span>sinner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">soul </span>as punishment.
The Gemara returns to discuss the text of the book of Job: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And the Satan</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> answered the Lord, and said: Skin for skin, for all</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that a man has he will give for his life</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. But put forth Your hand now, and touch his bone</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and his flesh, and he will curse You to Your</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> face. And the Lord said to the Satan: Behold, he</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is in your hand; only spare his life. So the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Satan went forth from the presence of the Lord, and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> smote Job </span>with vile sores from the sole of his foot to his crown” (Job 2:4–7). <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yitzḥak says: Satan</span><span class="gemarra-regular">’s suffering was more difficult than that of Job. </span>This can be explained by means of <span class="gemarra-regular">a parable involving a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> servant whose master said to him: Break the barrel but</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> save its wine. </span>Here too, God told the Satan that he could do whatever he liked short of taking Job’s life, and that limitation caused Satan to suffer.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Reish Lakish says: Satan, the evil inclination, and the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Angel of Death are one, </span>that is, they are three aspects of the same essence. <span class="gemarra-regular">He is the Satan </span>who seduces people and then accuses them, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is written</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: “So the Satan went forth from the presence of the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Lord, </span>and smote Job with vile sores” (Job 2:7). <span class="gemarra-regular">He</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">the evil inclination, </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">it is written there</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: </span>“The impulse of the thoughts of his heart <span class="gemarra-regular">was </span><span class="gemarra-regular">only evil continuously” </span>(Genesis 6:5); <span class="gemarra-regular">and it is written here</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: “Only upon himself do not put forth your hand” </span>(Job 1:12). The verbal analogy between the various uses of the word “only” teaches that the evil inclination is to be identified with the Satan. <span class="gemarra-regular">He is </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">the Angel </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of Death, as it is written: “Only spare his life” </span>(Job 2:6); <span class="gemarra-regular">apparently </span>Job’s life <span class="gemarra-regular">depends upon him, </span>the Satan, and accordingly the Satan must also be the Angel of Death.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Levi says: </span>Both <span class="gemarra-regular">Satan</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>who brought accusations against Job, <span class="gemarra-regular">and Peninnah, </span>who tormented Hannah, mother of Samuel the prophet, acted with <span class="gemarra-regular">intent </span>that was <span class="gemarra-regular">for the sake of Heaven. </span>As for <span class="gemarra-regular">Satan, when </span><span class="gemarra-regular">he saw that the Holy One, Blessed be He, inclined </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>favor <span class="gemarra-regular">Job </span>and praised him, <span class="gemarra-regular">he said: Heaven forbid </span><span class="gemarra-regular">that He should forget the love of Abraham. </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">Peninnah, as it is written: “And her rival wife </span><span class="gemarra-regular">also provoked her sore, to make her fret” </span>(I Samuel 1:6), i.e., Peninnah upset Hannah in order to motivate her to pray. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov taught </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">in Paphunya, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">Satan came and kissed his feet </span>in gratitude for speaking positively about him.
The Gemara considers the character of Job. The verse states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“In all this Job did not sin </span><span class="gemarra-regular">with his lips” </span>(Job 2:10). <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava says: </span>A close reading of the verse indicates that <span class="gemarra-regular">he did not sin with</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> his lips, </span>but <span class="gemarra-regular">he sinned in his heart. What did</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he say </span>that suggests that he had wicked thoughts? <span class="gemarra-regular">“</span><span class="gemarra-regular">The earth is given into the hand of the wicked, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">he covers the faces of its judges; if not he, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">then who is it?” </span>(Job 9:24). <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava says: Job sought</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to turn the bowl upside down, </span>that is to say, he alluded here to a heretical thought, as he said that the earth is given into the hand of the wicked, indicating that he had God in mind. <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to him: Job was referring </span>here <span class="gemarra-regular">only to the Satan</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>he being the wicked one into whose hands the land was given.
The Gemara comments: This is <span class="gemarra-regular">parallel to </span>a dispute between <span class="gemarra-italic">tanna’im</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>as it was taught in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">“The earth is given into the hand of the wicked</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.” Rabbi Eliezer says: Job sought to turn the bowl upside</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> down; Rabbi Yehoshua said to him: Job was referring </span>here <span class="gemarra-regular">only to the Satan.</span>
The Gemara continues to discuss Job’s statements: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Although You know </span><span class="gemarra-regular">that I am not wicked, and there is none that </span><span class="gemarra-regular">can deliver out of Your hand” </span>(Job 10:7). <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava says</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: Job sought to exempt the whole worl</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from judgment, </span>claiming that all of a person’s actions are directed by God, and therefore one cannot be held culpable for his misdeeds. Job <span class="gemarra-regular">said before </span>God: <span class="gemarra-regular">Master of the Universe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, You created the ox with split hooves, </span>making it kosher, and <span class="gemarra-regular">You created the donkey with closed hooves, </span>making it forbidden; <span class="gemarra-regular">You created the Garden of Eden, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">You created</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Gehenna; </span>and similarly, <span class="gemarra-regular">You created righteous people </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">You created</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> wicked people; who can restrain You? </span>Seeing that You created people as either righteous or wicked, You cannot later complain about their actions.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And how did</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Job’s friends answer him? “You do away with</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> fear, and impair devotion before God” </span>(Job 15:4) with such statements. True, <span class="gemarra-regular">the Holy One, Blessed be He, created </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the evil inclination, </span>but <span class="gemarra-regular">He </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">created the Torah </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">an antidote </span>to counter its effects and prevent it from gaining control of a person.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava interpreted </span>a verse <span class="gemarra-regular">homiletically: What </span>is the meaning of that <span class="gemarra-regular">which is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">written, </span>Job saying about himself: <span class="gemarra-regular">“The blessing of him that</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> was lost came upon me, and I caused the widow</span><span class="gemarra-regular">’s heart to sing for joy” </span>(Job 29:13). <span class="gemarra-regular">“The</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> blessing of him that was lost came upon me” teaches</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that </span>Job <span class="gemarra-regular">used to steal a field from orphans</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> cultivate it, <span class="gemarra-regular">improve it, and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">return it to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">them; </span>consequently, they would bless him for the field they had lost. <span class="gemarra-regular">“I caused the widow’s heart to sing</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for joy” </span>teaches that <span class="gemarra-regular">anywhere that there was a widow</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> whom no one would marry, he would go </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">cast</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> his name upon her, </span>i.e., he would start a rumor that she was related to him, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">somebody</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> would </span>come forward and <span class="gemarra-regular">marry her.</span>
Job further said: <span class="gemarra-regular">“O </span><span class="gemarra-regular">that my vexation were thoroughly weighed, and my calamity laid </span><span class="gemarra-regular">in the balances” </span>(Job 6:2). <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: Dust </span>should be put <span class="gemarra-regular">in the mouth of Job, </span>meaning, he should not have spoken in such a manner, as if he were weighing his deeds against those of God; may one act as if he is in <span class="gemarra-regular">a friendship with Heaven? </span>And similarly, Job said: <span class="gemarra-regular">“There is no arbiter between us, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">who may lay his hand upon us both” </span>(Job 9:33). <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: Dust </span>should be put <span class="gemarra-regular">in the mouth of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Job </span>for saying this; <span class="gemarra-regular">is there a servant who rebukes</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> his master? </span>Job also said: <span class="gemarra-regular">“I have made a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">covenant with my eyes; why then should I look upon </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a virgin?” </span>(Job 31:1). <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava says: Dust </span>should be put <span class="gemarra-regular">in the mouth </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">Job </span>for saying this; <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span>did not look <span class="gemarra-regular">at other </span>women, but <span class="gemarra-regular">Abraham did not even</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> look at his own </span>wife, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is written: “Now</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> I know that you are a beautiful woman” </span>(Genesis 12:11). One may learn <span class="gemarra-regular">by inference that initially he did </span><span class="gemarra-regular">not know </span>how beautiful she was because he had not gazed at her.
Job further said: <span class="gemarra-regular">“As the cloud is consumed and vanishes away, so he</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> who goes down to the grave shall come up no</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> more” </span>(Job 7:9). <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava says: From here </span>it may be inferred <span class="gemarra-regular">that Job denied the resurrection of the dead, </span>as he said that one who goes down to the grave will not come up and live again, just as a cloud that dissipates will not return. He also stated: <span class="gemarra-regular">“He crushes me with a tempest, and multiplies my wounds</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> without cause” </span>(Job 9:17). <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba says: Job blasphemed with </span>mention of <span class="gemarra-regular">a tempest and he was answered with </span>mention of <span class="gemarra-regular">a tempest.</span>
Rabba explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">He blasphemed with </span>mention of <span class="gemarra-regular">a tempest [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">bise</span><span class="gemarra-italic">’ara</span><span class="gemarra-regular">], as it is written: “He crushes me with a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> tempest.” </span>Job <span class="gemarra-regular">said before </span>God: <span class="gemarra-regular">Master of the Universe, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">perhaps a tempest passed before You and You confused </span><span class="gemarra-italic">Iyov</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>Job, <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span><span class="gemarra-italic">oyev</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>enemy. <span class="gemarra-regular">He was answered with </span>mention of <span class="gemarra-regular">a tempest, as it is written: “Then the Lord answered </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Job out of the tempest, and said: </span>Who is this that darkens counsel by words without knowledge? <span class="gemarra-regular">Gird up now </span><span class="gemarra-regular">your loins like a man, for I will demand of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">you and let me know your answer” </span>(Job 38:1–3).
What is the meaning of “out of the tempest”? God <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: I have created many hairs [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">nimin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> on a person, and for each hair I created</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> its own follicl</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> through which the hair is sustained, <span class="gemarra-regular">so that two </span>hairs <span class="gemarra-regular">should not draw from one follicle. </span><span class="gemarra-regular">As were two </span>hairs <span class="gemarra-regular">to draw from one follicle, they </span><span class="gemarra-regular">would impair a man’s vision. </span>Now, if <span class="gemarra-regular">I do </span><span class="gemarra-regular">not confuse one follicle with another, would I confuse </span><span class="gemarra-italic">Iyov</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span><span class="gemarra-italic">oyev</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? </span>The Hebrew word for tempest, <span class="it-text">se’ara</span>, is phonetically identical to the Hebrew word for hair.
God further said to Job: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Who has divided a channel [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">te’ala</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] for</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the torrent </span>of rain, or a path for the lightning of thunder”?
