(Job 38:25). <span class="gemarra-regular">I have created many drops </span>of water <span class="gemarra-regular">in the clouds, and for each drop I created</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> its own channel, so that two drops should not emerge</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from the same channel</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> As were two drops to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> emerge from the same channel they would destroy the earth</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and it would not yield produce. </span>Now, if <span class="gemarra-regular">I do</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not confuse one drop with another, would I confuse </span><span class="gemarra-italic">Iyov</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with </span><span class="gemarra-italic">oyev</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? </span>Incidentally, the Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">From where may </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">be inferred that this </span>term <span class="gemarra-italic">te’ala</span> means <span class="gemarra-regular">a channel</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? Rabba bar Sheila said: As it is written </span>with regard to Elijah the prophet: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And he fashioned a channel</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">te’ala</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] </span>about the altar, <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>great as would contain <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span><span class="gemarra-italic">se’a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of seed” </span>(I Kings 18:32).
The second half of the aforementioned verse in Job states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Or a path for the lightning of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">thunder,” </span>which is interpreted as follows: God said: <span class="gemarra-regular">I have </span><span class="gemarra-regular">created many thunderclaps in the clouds, and for each and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">every thunderclap I created its own path, so that two </span><span class="gemarra-regular">thunderclaps should not issue forth from the same path. As </span><span class="gemarra-regular">were two thunderclaps to issue from the same path, they </span><span class="gemarra-regular">would destroy the world. </span>Now, <span class="gemarra-regular">if I do not confuse </span><span class="gemarra-regular">one thunderclap with another, would I confuse </span><span class="gemarra-italic">Iyov</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with </span><span class="gemarra-italic">oyev</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span>
It is further stated there: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Do you</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> know when the wild goats of the rock give birth</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? Can you mark when the hinds do calve?” </span>(Job 39:1). <span class="gemarra-regular">This goat is cruel to her young </span>and shows them no pity; <span class="gemarra-regular">when she squats</span>

Daf 16b

<span class="gemarra-regular">to give birth she </span><span class="gemarra-regular">ascends to the top of a mountain so that </span>the kid <span class="gemarra-regular">should fall down from her and die. And I </span><span class="gemarra-regular">summon her an eagle that receives it with his wings </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and places it before her; and if </span>the eagle <span class="gemarra-regular">reached </span>her <span class="gemarra-regular">one moment early or was one moment late, </span>the kid <span class="gemarra-regular">would immediately die. </span>Now, if <span class="gemarra-regular">I do not confuse </span><span class="gemarra-regular">one moment with another moment, would I confuse </span><span class="gemarra-italic">Iyov</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with </span><span class="gemarra-italic">oyev</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span>
Similarly: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Can you mark when the hinds do</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> calve?” </span>(Job 39:1). <span class="gemarra-regular">The womb of this hind is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">narrow, </span>which makes for a difficult delivery. <span class="gemarra-regular">When she squats </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to give birth, I summon her a snake [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">derakon</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">that bites her at the opening of the womb, which </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">becomes loose, and she gives birth, and if </span>the snake <span class="gemarra-regular">reached </span>her <span class="gemarra-regular">one moment early or was one moment </span><span class="gemarra-regular">late, she would immediately die. </span>Now, if I <span class="gemarra-regular">do not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">confuse one moment with another moment, would I confuse </span><span class="gemarra-italic">Iyov</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span><span class="gemarra-italic">oyev</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span>
The Gemara comments: On the one hand, the text states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Job has spoken without knowledge, and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> his words were without wisdom” </span>(Job 34:35). <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>on the other hand, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is written </span>with regard to Job’s friends: <span class="gemarra-regular">“You have not spoken of Me the thing</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that is right, like my servant Job” </span>(Job 42:8). <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: From here </span>it may be inferred <span class="gemarra-regular">that a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">person is not held responsible </span>for what he says <span class="gemarra-regular">when </span><span class="gemarra-regular">he is in distress. </span>Although Job uttered certain words that were wrong and inappropriate, he was not punished for them because he said them at a time of pain and hardship.
The verse states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Job’s three friends heard of all this evil that</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> was come upon him, they came every one from his</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> own place, Eliphaz the Temanite, and Bildad the Shuhite, and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Zophar the Naamathite; for they had made an appointment together</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to come to mourn with him and to comfort him</span><span class="gemarra-regular">” </span>(Job 2:11). <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>does <span class="gemarra-regular">“they had made an appointment</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> together” </span>mean? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: This </span>phrase <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches that they all entered </span>through <span class="gemarra-regular">one gat</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> at the same time. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>a Sage <span class="gemarra-regular">taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: There were <span class="gemarra-regular">three hundred parasangs between each and every one </span>of them, i.e., each one lived three hundred parasangs away from the other.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">How did they </span>all <span class="gemarra-regular">know </span>at the same time what had happened to Job so that the three of them came together? <span class="gemarra-regular">There are </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">who </span><span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">they </span>each <span class="gemarra-regular">had a crown </span>which displayed certain signs when something happened to one of the others. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span><span class="gemarra-regular">there are </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">who say they </span>each <span class="gemarra-regular">had trees and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">when </span>the trees <span class="gemarra-regular">withered they knew </span>that sorrow had visited one of them. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>closeness between Job and his friends explains the adage <span class="gemarra-regular">that people say: Either </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a friend like the friends of Job or death. </span>If a person lacks close friends, he is better off dead.
The Gemara cites another place where Job is mentioned. <span class="gemarra-regular">“And it came to pass</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, when men began to multiply [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">larov</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] on the face of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the earth, and daughters were born to them” </span>(Genesis 6:1). <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: </span><span class="it-text">Larov</span> means that <span class="gemarra-regular">propagation [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">reviyya</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] came </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to the worl</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> through these daughters. <span class="gemarra-regular">Reish Lakish says: Strife</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">meriva</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] came to the world. </span>Once daughters were born, the men began to fight among themselves over them. <span class="gemarra-regular">Reish </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Lakish said to Rabbi Yoḥanan: According to you who say </span>that due to the daughters <span class="gemarra-regular">propagation came to the world, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">for what </span>reason <span class="gemarra-regular">were </span>the number of <span class="gemarra-regular">Job’s daughters </span><span class="gemarra-regular">not doubled, </span>when at the end of the story God doubled everything that Job had lost (see Job 1:3, 42:12)?
Rabbi Yoḥanan <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, </span>the numbers of Job’s daughters <span class="gemarra-regular">were not doubled </span><span class="gemarra-regular">in name, </span>meaning they did not become twice as many, <span class="gemarra-regular">but they were doubled in beauty, as it is written: “</span><span class="gemarra-regular">He had also seven sons and three daughters. And he </span><span class="gemarra-regular">called the name of the first Jemimah, and the name </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of the second was Keziah, and the name of the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">third one was Keren-happuch” </span>(Job 42:13–14). All three names relate to the daughters’ beauty.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Jemimah [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">Yemima</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]; </span>in her beauty <span class="gemarra-regular">she was similar to the day </span><span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">y</span><span class="gemarra-italic">om</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]. Keziah; her scent</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> wafted like </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">cassia [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ketzia</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> tree. <span class="gemarra-regular">Keren-happuch; in</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the school of Rav Sheila they say: She was similar</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to the horn [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">keren</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] of a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">keresh</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> an animal whose horns are particularly beautiful. <span class="gemarra-regular">They laughed at this in</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the West, </span>Eretz Yisrael, since it is considered <span class="gemarra-regular">a blemish</span> when a person resembles <span class="gemarra-regular">the horn of a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">keresh</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. Rather</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, Rav Ḥisda said: </span>She was <span class="gemarra-regular">like garden saffron [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">kekurkema</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">derishka</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> which is the best <span class="gemarra-regular">of its kind. </span><span class="it-text">Keren</span> refers to a garden, and <span class="it-text">pukh</span> means ornament, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> stated: “Though you enlarge </span>your eyes <span class="gemarra-regular">with paint </span><span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">p</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ukh</span><span class="gemarra-regular">], </span>you beautify yourself in vain” (Jeremiah 4:30).
It is reported that <span class="gemarra-regular">a daughter was born to Rabbi Shimon, son of Rabbi</span> Yehuda HaNasi, and <span class="gemarra-regular">he was upset </span>that he did not have a son. <span class="gemarra-regular">His father said to him: Propagation </span><span class="gemarra-regular">has come to the world </span>through the birth of a daughter. <span class="gemarra-regular">Bar Kappara said to </span>Rabbi Shimon: <span class="gemarra-regular">Your father has</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> consoled you with meaningless consolation, as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">The world cannot endure without males and females</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>as both are needed for the perpetuation of humanity. <span class="gemarra-regular">But</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> fortunate is he whose children are males and woe to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> him whose children are females. </span>Similarly, <span class="gemarra-regular">the world cannot endure</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> without either a spice dealer </span>whose wares are sweet-smelling, <span class="gemarra-regular">or a tanner [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">bursi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> who is engaged in a foul-smelling occupation. <span class="gemarra-regular">Fortunate is he whose occupation is a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> spice seller, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">woe to him whose occupation is a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> tanner.</span>
The Gemara comments that this disagreement is <span class="gemarra-regular">parallel to </span>a dispute between <span class="gemarra-italic">tanna’im</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: </span>The Torah states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Lord blessed Abraham with everything [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">bakkol</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]” </span>(Genesis 24:1), and the Sages disagree about <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span><span class="gemarra-italic">bakkol</span> means. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir says: </span>The blessing is <span class="gemarra-regular">that he did not have a daughter. </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda says: </span>On the contrary, the blessing was <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span><span class="gemarra-regular">he had a daughter. Others say: Abraham had a daughter </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and her name was Bakkol. Rabbi Elazar HaModa’i says:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Abraham our forefather was so knowledgeable in astrology [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">itztagninut</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that all the kings of the East and the West</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> would come early to his door </span>due to his wisdom. This is the blessing of <span class="it-text">bakkol</span>, that he possessed knowledge that everybody needed. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon ben Yoḥai says: A precious</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> stone hung around the neck of Abraham our forefather; any</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> sick person who looked at it would immediately be healed</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. When Abraham our forefather died, the Holy One, Blessed be</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> He, hung </span>this stone <span class="gemarra-regular">from the sphere of the sun</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>which from that point on brought healing to the sick. <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said: This </span>explains the adage <span class="gemarra-regular">that people say: As</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the day progresses, sickness is lifted.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Alternatively, </span>what is the blessing of <span class="it-text">bakkol</span>? <span class="gemarra-regular">That Esau did not rebel in </span>Abraham’s <span class="gemarra-regular">lifetime, </span>that is to say, as long as Abraham lived Esau did not sin. <span class="gemarra-regular">Alternatively, </span>the blessing of <span class="it-text">bakkol</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">that Ishmael repented in </span>Abraham’s <span class="gemarra-regular">lifetime. </span>The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">From where do we </span>derive that <span class="gemarra-regular">Esau did not rebel</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in </span>Abraham’s <span class="gemarra-regular">lifetime? As it is written: </span>“And Jacob was cooking a stew <span class="gemarra-regular">and Esau came in from </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the field and he was faint” </span>(Genesis 25:29), <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">taught: On that day Abraham our forefather passed away</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, and Jacob our forefather prepared a lentil stew to comfort</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Isaac, his father, </span>as it was customary to serve mourners lentil stew.
The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">And what is different about lentils </span>that they in particular are the fare customarily offered to mourners? <span class="gemarra-regular">They </span><span class="gemarra-regular">say in the West, </span>Eretz Yisrael, <span class="gemarra-regular">in the name of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rabba bar Mari: Just as this lentil has no mouth</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>i.e., it does not have a crack like other legumes, <span class="gemarra-regular">so too a mourner has no mouth, </span>that is, his anguish prevents him from speaking. <span class="gemarra-regular">Alternatively, just as this</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> lentil is </span>completely <span class="gemarra-regular">round, so too mourning comes around to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the inhabitants of the world. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is</span> the practical difference <span class="gemarra-regular">between </span>the two explanations? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">There is </span>a practical difference <span class="gemarra-regular">between them </span>with regard to whether it is appropriate <span class="gemarra-regular">to console </span>a mourner <span class="gemarra-regular">with eggs</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> which have no opening but are not completely round.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: That</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> wicked </span>Esau <span class="gemarra-regular">committed five transgressions on that day </span>that Abraham died: <span class="gemarra-regular">He engaged in sexual intercourse with a betrothed maiden</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, he killed a person, he denied the principle </span>of God’s existence, <span class="gemarra-regular">he denied resurrection of the dead, and he</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> despised the birthright.</span>
The Gemara cites proofs to support these charges. <span class="gemarra-regular">He engaged in sexual intercourse with</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a betrothed maiden, </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">it is written here: “And Esau</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> came in from the field”; and it is written there</span> with regard to rape of a betrothed maiden: <span class="gemarra-regular">“For </span><span class="gemarra-regular">he found her in a field” </span>(Deuteronomy 22:27). <span class="gemarra-regular">He killed</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a person, </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">it is written here: </span>“And he was <span class="gemarra-regular">faint”; and it is written there: “Woe is me, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">for my soul faints before the slayers” </span>(Jeremiah 4:31). <span class="gemarra-regular">And</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he denied the principle </span>of God’s existence, as <span class="gemarra-regular">it</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is written here: “What profit is this to me” </span>(Genesis 25:32); <span class="gemarra-regular">and it is written there: “This is my </span><span class="gemarra-regular">God and I will glorify Him” </span>(Exodus 15:2). When he questioned the profit of “this,” he was challenging the assertion that “this is my God.” <span class="gemarra-regular">And he denied resurrection of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the dead, as it is written: “Behold, I am at</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the point of death” </span>(Genesis 25:32), indicating that he did not believe in resurrection after death. <span class="gemarra-regular">And he despised </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the birthright, as it is written: “And Esau despised the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">birthright” </span>(Genesis 25:34).
<span class="gemarra-regular">And from</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> where do we </span>derive <span class="gemarra-regular">that Ishmael repented in </span>Abraham’s <span class="gemarra-regular">lifetime? From </span>the incident involving <span class="gemarra-regular">Ravina and Rav Ḥama bar</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Buzi, </span>who <span class="gemarra-regular">were sitting before Rava, and Rava was dozing</span> while they were talking. <span class="gemarra-regular">Ravina said to Rav Ḥama bar</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Buzi: Is it true that you say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">any death</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with regard to which </span>the word <span class="gemarra-italic">gevia</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>expire, is mentioned <span class="gemarra-regular">is the death of the righteous? </span>Rav Ḥama bar Buzi <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Yes. </span>For example: “And Isaac expired [<span class="it-text">vayyigva</span>], and died” (Genesis 35:29). Ravina objected: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">the generation of the flood </span>it states: “And all flesh expired [<span class="it-text">vayyigva</span>]” (Genesis 7:21), and there they died for their wickedness. Rav Ḥama bar Buzi <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: We </span><span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>this only when both <span class="gemarra-italic">gevia</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span><span class="gemarra-italic">asifa</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>gathering, are used; when these two terms are mentioned together they indicate the death of a righteous person.
Ravina asked: <span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t there Ishmael, about </span><span class="gemarra-regular">whom </span><span class="gemarra-italic">gevia</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span><span class="gemarra-italic">asif</span><span class="gemarra-italic">a</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">are written, </span>as it is stated: “And these are the years of the life of Yishmael…and he expired and died [<span class="it-text">vayyigva</span> <span class="it-text">vayyamot</span>]; and was gathered to his people” (Genesis 25:17)? <span class="gemarra-regular">Meanwhile Rava, </span>who had heard the discussion in his dozed state, fully <span class="gemarra-regular">awoke </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">said to them: Children [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">dardekei</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> this is what Rabbi </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Yoḥanan says: Ishmael repented in the lifetime of his father,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as it is stated: “And Isaac and Ishmael, his sons</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, buried him” </span>(Genesis 25:9). The fact that Ishmael allowed Isaac to precede him demonstrates that he had repented and accepted his authority.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span><span class="gemarra-regular">perhaps </span>the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">listed them in the order of their </span><span class="gemarra-regular">wisdom; </span>that is to say, perhaps in fact Ishmael preceded Isaac but the Torah did not list them in that order. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">But if that is so, </span>consider that the verse states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And Esau and Jacob, his </span><span class="gemarra-regular">sons, buried him” </span>(Genesis 35:29). <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>that the verse there <span class="gemarra-regular">did not list them in the order</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of their wisdom? Rather, since </span>Ishmael <span class="gemarra-regular">allowed </span>Isaac <span class="gemarra-regular">to precede</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> him, </span>it is clear that he <span class="gemarra-regular">made </span>Isaac <span class="gemarra-regular">his leader</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, and since he made him his leader, learn from it</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that he repented in </span>Abraham’s <span class="gemarra-regular">lifetime.</span>
Incidental to the discussion of the verse “And God blessed Abraham with everything” (Genesis 24:1), the Gemara states that <span class="gemarra-regular">the Sages taught</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: </span>There were <span class="gemarra-regular">three </span>people <span class="gemarra-regular">to whom the Holy One, Blessed</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> be He, gave </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">in this world</span>

Daf 17a

<span class="gemarra-regular">a taste of the World-to-Come</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. They are: Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob. Abraham, as it is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> written with regard to him: </span>“And the Lord blessed Abraham <span class="gemarra-regular">with everything” </span>(Genesis 24:1). <span class="gemarra-regular">Isaac, as it is written</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with regard to him: </span>“And I have eaten <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span><span class="gemarra-regular">everything” </span>(Genesis 27:33). <span class="gemarra-regular">Jacob, as it is written with regard</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to him: </span>“Because I have <span class="gemarra-regular">everything” </span>(Genesis 33:11). This teaches that already in their lifetimes they merited everything, i.e., perfection.
There were <span class="gemarra-regular">three </span>people <span class="gemarra-regular">over whom the evil inclination had no sway</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> They are: Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, as it is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> written </span>with regard <span class="gemarra-regular">to them, </span>respectively: <span class="gemarra-regular">“With everything,” “from </span><span class="gemarra-regular">everything,” “everything.” </span>The completeness of their blessings means that they did not have to contend with their evil inclinations. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span><span class="gemarra-regular">some say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">even David </span>was not subject to his evil inclination, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is written: “And my heart has </span><span class="gemarra-regular">died within me” </span>(Psalms 109:22), meaning that the evil inclination in his heart was nullified as if his heart had died. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>how does <span class="gemarra-regular">the other </span>authority, who does not include David in his list, explain this verse? <span class="gemarra-regular">He is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> mentioning his travails. </span>David means to say that his heart died within him owing to all the suffering that he endured, but he says nothing about his evil inclination.
<span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: </span>There were <span class="gemarra-regular">six </span>people <span class="gemarra-regular">over whom the Angel of Death</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> had no sway </span>in their demise, <span class="gemarra-regular">and they are: Abraham</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, Isaac, and Jacob, Moses, Aaron, and Miriam. Abraham, Isaac, and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Jacob, as it is written </span>with regard <span class="gemarra-regular">to them, </span>respectively: <span class="gemarra-regular">“With everything,” “from everything,” “everything”; </span>since they were blessed with everything they were certainly spared the anguish of the Angel of Death. <span class="gemarra-regular">Moses, Aaron, and Miriam, as it is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">written </span>with regard <span class="gemarra-regular">to them </span>that they died <span class="gemarra-regular">“by the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> mouth of the Lord” </span>(Numbers 33:38; Deuteronomy 34:5), which indicates that they died with a kiss, and not at the hand of the Angel of Death.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span><span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to Miriam it is not written: “By the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">mouth of the Lord.” Rabbi Elazar says: Miriam also died </span><span class="gemarra-regular">with a kiss, as this is learned </span>through a verbal analogy between the word <span class="gemarra-regular">“there” </span>mentioned in regard to Miriam: “And Miriam died there” (Numbers 20:1), and the word <span class="gemarra-regular">“</span><span class="gemarra-regular">there” </span>mentioned in regard <span class="gemarra-regular">to Moses: </span>“And Moses died there” (Deuteronomy 34:5). <span class="gemarra-regular">And for what </span>reason <span class="gemarra-regular">is “by the mouth</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of the Lord” not stated with </span>regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">her? It</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is unseemly to mention </span>death by a kiss with regard to a woman.
<span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught: </span>There were <span class="gemarra-regular">seven </span>people <span class="gemarra-regular">over whom the worm and the maggot had no sway</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, and they are: Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, Moses, Aaron </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and Miriam, and Benjamin, son of Jacob. Abraham, Isaac, and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Jacob, as it is written with regard to them, </span>respectively: <span class="gemarra-regular">“With everything,” “from everything,” “everything.” Moses, Aaron, and Miriam, as</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it is written with regard to them: “By the mouth</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of the Lord”; Benjamin, son of Jacob, as it is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> written: “And to Benjamin he said: The beloved of the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Lord, he shall dwell in safety by Him” </span>(Deuteronomy 33:12). Even in death, he rests securely, unbothered by worms. <span class="gemarra-regular">And some say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">even David </span>is included, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is written: “My flesh also dwells secure” </span>(Psalms 16:9). The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>how does <span class="gemarra-regular">the other </span>authority, who does not include David, explain this? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">He </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is asking for mercy, </span>that his flesh should dwell secure and not be subject to worms and maggots, but his request was denied.
<span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: There were <span class="gemarra-regular">four </span>people <span class="gemarra-regular">who died </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">because of the counsel of the </span>primordial <span class="gemarra-regular">snake, </span>in the wake of which all of humanity became mortal, and not on account of any personal sin. <span class="gemarra-regular">And they are: Benjamin, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">son of Jacob; Amram, father of Moses; Yishai, father of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">David; and Chileab, son of David. And all of these </span><span class="gemarra-regular">are known through tradition except for Yishai, father of David, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>whom <span class="gemarra-regular">it is written explicitly: “And Absalom </span><span class="gemarra-regular">placed Amasa over the army instead of Joab, and Amasa </span><span class="gemarra-regular">was the son of a man whose name was Ithra </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the Israelite, who engaged in intercourse with Abigail, daughter of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Nahash, the sister of Zeruiah, mother of Joab” </span>(II Samuel 17:25). <span class="gemarra-regular">But was </span>Abigail <span class="gemarra-regular">the daughter of Nahash? Was she</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not the daughter of Yishai, as it is written: “And</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> their sisters were Zeruiah and Abigail” </span>(I Chronicles 2:16)? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>she was called “daughter of Nahash” to indicate that <span class="gemarra-regular">she was the daughter of one who died </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of the counsel of the snake.</span>

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">A person may not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">di</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">pi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">close to the pit of another, </span>in order to avoid damaging the latter’s pit. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>similarly, one <span class="gemarra-regular">may </span><span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>dig <span class="gemarra-regular">a ditch, nor a cave, </span>i.e., a covered pit, <span class="gemarra-regular">nor a water channel, nor a launderer’s</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">pond</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> which is a pit used for washing clothes, <span class="gemarra-regular">unless he distanced </span>all of these <span class="gemarra-regular">three handbreadths from </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the wall of another and he plasters lime </span>on the place where there is water.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And one must distance the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">solid residue </span>of produce that has been pressed free of its oil, e.g., the refuse of olives from which oil has been squeezed, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>animal <span class="gemarra-regular">manure, and salt, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and lime, and rock</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> three handbreadths from the wall of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> another, </span>as all these items produce heat and can damage the wall. <span class="gemarra-regular">Or, alternatively, he </span>may <span class="gemarra-regular">plaster </span>the wall <span class="gemarra-regular">with</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> lime </span>to prevent damage. <span class="gemarra-regular">One must </span>likewise <span class="gemarra-regular">distance seeds</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., one may not plant seeds, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>one may not operate <span class="gemarra-regular">the plow, and </span>one must eliminate <span class="gemarra-regular">urine, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">three handbreadths from the wall </span>of another.
The mishna continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">And one must distance a mil</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span> from a neighbor’s wall by <span class="gemarra-regular">three </span>handbreadths <span class="gemarra-regular">from the lower stone </span>of the mill, <span class="gemarra-regular">which is four </span>handbreadths <span class="gemarra-regular">from the </span>smaller <span class="gemarra-regular">upper</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> stone </span>of the mill. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>there must be a distance of <span class="gemarra-regular">three </span>handbreadths <span class="gemarra-regular">from the </span>protruding <span class="gemarra-regular">base [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">hakalya</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">an ove</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> until the wall, <span class="gemarra-regular">which is four </span>handbreadths <span class="gemarra-regular">from the </span>narrow <span class="gemarra-regular">upper rim [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">hassafa</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] </span>of the oven. 

Daf 17b

<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The <span class="it-text">tanna</span> of the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">opens by </span>speaking of <span class="gemarra-regular">a pit: </span>A person may not dig a pit close to the pit of another, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>yet <span class="gemarra-regular">he ends with </span>a reference to <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">wall: </span>Unless he distances it from the wall of another. <span class="gemarra-regular">Let </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">teach: Unless he distanced </span>his pit or ditch <span class="gemarra-regular">three handbreadths from the pit of another, </span>just as he begins his statement by referring to a pit. Why does the mishna suddenly mention a wall here?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said, and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">some say it was Rav Yehuda </span>who said: <span class="gemarra-regular">We learned </span>that the mishna means: <span class="gemarra-regular">From the wall of his pit</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> In other words, one should read the mishna as follows: Unless he distanced his pit or ditch three handbreadths from the wall of another’s pit. The neighbor also built his pit close to the border between the two properties, and the mishna is teaching that the one digging a pit must distance it three handbreadths from the wall of the pit of the other.
The Gemara challenges: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>even so, <span class="gemarra-regular">let it teach</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: Unless he distanced </span>his excavations <span class="gemarra-regular">three handbreadths from the pit</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of another, </span>and one would understand that the term pit is referring to the wall of the other’s pit. The Gemara responds: By using the phrase: From the wall of another, <span class="gemarra-regular">this teaches us </span>incidentally <span class="gemarra-regular">that the wall of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a pit </span>must be at least <span class="gemarra-regular">three handbreadths </span>thick, as the wall of the other’s pit occupied the full three handbreadths between the cavity of his pit and the property of his neighbor. The practical <span class="gemarra-regular">difference </span>of this observation is <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to buying and selling, as it </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who </span><span class="gemarra-regular">says to another: I am selling you a pit and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">its walls</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the wall </span>of the pit <span class="gemarra-regular">must be </span>at least <span class="gemarra-regular">three handbreadths </span>thick.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">It was stated: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who comes to </span>dig any of these excavations or <span class="gemarra-regular">place </span>any of the items listed in the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">close</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to the boundar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span> of his field, where his neighbor currently has no pit, <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye says: He may </span>dig or <span class="gemarra-regular">place </span>them <span class="gemarra-regular">close </span>to the boundary; <span class="gemarra-regular">and Rava says: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">He may not </span>dig or <span class="gemarra-regular">place </span>them <span class="gemarra-regular">close </span>to the boundary. The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">All agree that he may not</span> dig or <span class="gemarra-regular">place </span>them <span class="gemarra-regular">close </span>to <span class="gemarra-regular">a field </span>of his neighbor if <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>field <span class="gemarra-regular">is designated for </span>digging <span class="gemarra-regular">pits</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as he will thereby restrict his neighbor from using his field in the manner it is expected to be used. <span class="gemarra-regular">When they disagree </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to a field</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that is not designated for </span>digging <span class="gemarra-regular">pits.</span>
The Gemara elaborates: <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye says</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: He may </span>dig these excavations or <span class="gemarra-regular">place </span>these items <span class="gemarra-regular">close</span> to the boundary, <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>the neighbor’s field <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">not designated for pits, </span>so he is not causing any damage by doing so. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava says: He may not </span>dig these excavations or <span class="gemarra-regular">place </span>these items <span class="gemarra-regular">close </span>to the boundary, <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>the neighbor can <span class="gemarra-regular">say to him: Just as you</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> changed your mind and dug </span>a pit, <span class="gemarra-regular">I too </span>might <span class="gemarra-regular">change my mind and dig </span>a pit, and I will no longer be able to dig near my border if you dig your pit close to the boundary.
<span class="gemarra-regular">There are </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">who say </span>a different version of this discussion: <span class="gemarra-regular">All agree </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">one may </span>dig these excavations or <span class="gemarra-regular">place </span>these items <span class="gemarra-regular">close </span>to the boundary of <span class="gemarra-regular">a field that is not designated for </span>digging <span class="gemarra-regular">pits. When</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> they disagree </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to a field that</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is designated for </span>digging <span class="gemarra-regular">pits. Abaye says: One may </span>dig these excavations or <span class="gemarra-regular">place </span>these items <span class="gemarra-regular">close </span>to the boundary; and this is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">even according to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis, who say </span>in the mishna (25b): <span class="gemarra-regular">One</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> must distance a tree twenty-five cubits from a cistern</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>lest the roots of the tree grow and damage a neighbor’s cistern in his field. The difference is that <span class="gemarra-regular">there it </span>is prohibited, <span class="gemarra-regular">as when he plants </span>the tree <span class="gemarra-regular">there is </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">a cistern. But here, </span>at the time <span class="gemarra-regular">when he digs </span>his cistern, <span class="gemarra-regular">there is </span>as yet <span class="gemarra-regular">no cistern </span>in his neighbor’s field.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rava says: </span>One <span class="gemarra-regular">may not </span>dig these excavations or <span class="gemarra-regular">place </span>these items <span class="gemarra-regular">close </span>to the boundary; and this is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">even according to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei, who </span><span class="gemarra-regular">says </span>in that same mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">This one may dig in </span><span class="gemarra-regular">his </span>field <span class="gemarra-regular">and that one may plant in his </span>field, i.e., one need not distance his tree for fear of damaging his neighbor’s field through expanding roots. The reason that Rava maintains that his ruling is correct even according to the opinion of Rabbi Yosei is that <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span><span class="gemarra-regular">matter </span>applies only <span class="gemarra-regular">there, as when he plants </span>the tree, <span class="gemarra-regular">its roots, which </span>might <span class="gemarra-regular">damage the cistern, are not </span>yet present. Consequently, when he plants he does not cause any damage. <span class="gemarra-regular">But here, </span>the neighbor can <span class="gemarra-regular">say to him: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Each and every strike of yours with the hoe loosens </span><span class="gemarra-regular">my earth, </span>and therefore you are already causing damage as you dig your cistern.
The Gemara suggests a proof: <span class="gemarra-regular">We learned </span>in the mishna that <span class="gemarra-regular">a person may not dig a pit close to the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">pit of another, </span>unless he does so at a distance of three handbreadths from his neighbor’s wall. The Gemara analyzes this statement: Apparently, the <span class="gemarra-regular">reason </span>he may not dig close to the boundary of his neighbor’s field <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">that there is a pit </span>there, from which it may be inferred that if <span class="gemarra-regular">there is no pit he </span>may dig his pit <span class="gemarra-regular">close </span>to his neighbor’s wall. <span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">according to that </span>second <span class="gemarra-regular">version </span>of the dispute, <span class="gemarra-regular">in which </span><span class="gemarra-regular">you said: All agree </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">one may </span>dig these excavations or <span class="gemarra-regular">place </span>these items <span class="gemarra-regular">close </span>to the boundary of <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">field that is not designated for </span>digging <span class="gemarra-regular">pits, </span>one can explain that <span class="gemarra-regular">the mishna </span>is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to a field that </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is not designated for </span>digging <span class="gemarra-regular">pits.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>according <span class="gemarra-regular">to that </span>first <span class="gemarra-regular">version </span>of the dispute, <span class="gemarra-regular">in which you said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">they disagree with regard to a field that is not</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> designated for </span>digging <span class="gemarra-regular">pits, </span>there is a difficulty. <span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">works out well according to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye, </span>who says that one may dig one’s pit near the boundary when the neighbor has no pit. <span class="gemarra-regular">But according </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava, </span>who maintains that it is prohibited to dig a pit near the boundary under any circumstances, the ruling of this mishna is <span class="gemarra-regular">difficult.</span>
The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava </span>could have <span class="gemarra-regular">said to you: Wasn’t it stated with regard to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>mishna that <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye says, and some say it was </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda </span>who says: <span class="gemarra-regular">We learned </span>that the mishna means: <span class="gemarra-regular">From the wall of his pit? </span>This indicates that the neighbor must distance the edge of his pit from the boundary by the thickness of his wall, which is three handbreadths. Therefore, even according to the ruling of the mishna, one may not dig his pit directly adjacent to the boundary.
<span class="gemarra-regular">There are </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">who say </span>this discussion in the form of a challenge to the opinion of Abaye. The mishna teaches that one must distance his pit from that of his neighbor, <span class="gemarra-regular">and it was stated with regard to that </span>ruling that <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye says, and some say it was Rav Yehuda </span>who says: <span class="gemarra-regular">We learned </span>that it means: <span class="gemarra-regular">From the wall of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">his pit. </span>In other words, the edge of the neighbor’s pit must be three handbreadths away from the boundary. <span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, according to that </span>first <span class="gemarra-regular">version </span>of the dispute, <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span><span class="gemarra-regular">which you said: All agree that he may not </span>dig or <span class="gemarra-regular">place </span>them <span class="gemarra-regular">close </span>to <span class="gemarra-regular">a field </span>of his neighbor if <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>field <span class="gemarra-regular">is designated for </span>digging <span class="gemarra-regular">pits, </span>one can explain that <span class="gemarra-regular">the mishna </span>is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to a field that </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is designated for </span>digging <span class="gemarra-regular">pits.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">But according to that </span>second <span class="gemarra-regular">version </span>of the dispute, <span class="gemarra-regular">in which you said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">they disagree with regard</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to a field that is designated for </span>digging <span class="gemarra-regular">pits, </span>there is a difficulty. <span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">works out well according </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava, </span>who says that it is prohibited to dig a pit near the boundary in this case. <span class="gemarra-regular">But according to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye, </span>the ruling of this mishna is <span class="gemarra-regular">difficult, </span>as if the mishna is referring to the wall of the neighbor’s pit, this indicates that the first pit was dug close to the boundary.
The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye </span>could have <span class="gemarra-regular">said to you: The mishna </span>is referring to the specific case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>both neighbors <span class="gemarra-regular">came to</span> dig their <span class="gemarra-regular">pits at the same time. </span>Consequently, they must both distance their pits from one another. If there is no pit as yet next to the boundary, and the neighbor is not digging at that point, one may dig his pit alongside the boundary.
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a proof from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">rock that </span>is so soft that it <span class="gemarra-regular">crumbles in </span>one’s <span class="gemarra-regular">hands</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and no tool is needed, <span class="gemarra-regular">this one</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> may dig his pit from here, and that one may</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> dig his pit from there. This one distances </span>his pit <span class="gemarra-regular">three handbreadths and plasters with lime, and that one distances</span> his pit <span class="gemarra-regular">three handbreadths and plasters with lime. </span>This indicates that the first one who digs a pit must distance his pit even when the second one does not yet have a pit. The Gemara rejects this proof: Rock that <span class="gemarra-regular">crumbles in </span>one’s <span class="gemarra-regular">hands is different</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> In this case, one must maintain a distance from the boundary due to the softness of the ground.
The Gemara is puzzled by this exchange: <span class="gemarra-regular">And</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he who asked it</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> why did he ask it</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? </span>The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is explicitly referring to rock that crumbles in one’s hands, so this is clearly a unique case. The Gemara answers that the Sage who asked the question assumed that the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> includes all types of soil, and he thought that <span class="gemarra-regular">it was necessary for</span> the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> to mention the specific example of rock that <span class="gemarra-regular">crumbles in </span>one’s <span class="gemarra-regular">hands, </span>as it could <span class="gemarra-regular">enter your</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> mind to say that since </span>this substance <span class="gemarra-regular">crumbles in </span>one’s <span class="gemarra-regular">hands he is required </span>to keep his pit at an even <span class="gemarra-regular">greater distance. </span>To counter this, the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> us </span>that a distance of three handbreadths is sufficient.
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a proof from the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">One must distance the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> solid residue </span>of produce that has been pressed free of its oil, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>animal <span class="gemarra-regular">manure, and</span>

Daf 18a

<span class="gemarra-regular">salt, and lime, and rocks</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> three handbreadths from the wall of another, or he </span>can <span class="gemarra-regular">plaster </span>the wall <span class="gemarra-regular">with lime. </span>The Gemara analyzes this statement: The <span class="gemarra-regular">reason </span>for this ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">is that there is a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> wall </span>there belonging to his neighbor, from which it may be inferred that if <span class="gemarra-regular">there is no wall </span>there, <span class="gemarra-regular">one</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> may place </span>these substances <span class="gemarra-regular">close </span>to the boundary of his neighbor’s courtyard. This presents a difficulty for the opinion of Rava according to the first version of the dispute, which states that one may not place these substances close to a boundary even in the case of a field that is not designated for pits.
The Gemara rejects this proof: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>even <span class="gemarra-regular">if there is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> no wall one may also not place </span>these substances <span class="gemarra-regular">close</span> to the boundary. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, what </span><span class="gemarra-regular">does </span>mentioning a wall here <span class="gemarra-regular">teach us? </span>The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">This teaches us that </span>all <span class="gemarra-regular">these </span>substances <span class="gemarra-regular">are damaging to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a wall.</span>
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>another proof from the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">One must distance seeds, and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the plow, and urine three handbreadths from the wall </span>of another. The Gemara analyzes this ruling: The <span class="gemarra-regular">reason </span>for this ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">is that there is a wall, </span>from which it may be inferred that if <span class="gemarra-regular">there is no wall, one </span><span class="gemarra-regular">may place </span>these substances <span class="gemarra-regular">close </span>to the boundary of the field. The Gemara rejects this proof as well: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>even <span class="gemarra-regular">if there is no wall, one may also not place </span>these substances <span class="gemarra-regular">close </span>by the boundary. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> rather, what does </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">teach us? </span>The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">This teaches us that dampness [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">dimtunta</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is damaging to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a wall.</span>
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>another proof from the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>one must distance <span class="gemarra-regular">a mill </span>from a wall by <span class="gemarra-regular">three </span>handbreadths <span class="gemarra-regular">from the lower stone </span>of the mill, <span class="gemarra-regular">which is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> four </span>handbreadths <span class="gemarra-regular">from the upper stone. </span>The Gemara analyzes this statement: The <span class="gemarra-regular">reason </span>for this ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">is that there is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a wall, </span>from which it may be inferred that if <span class="gemarra-regular">there is no wall, one may place </span>a mill <span class="gemarra-regular">close</span> by the boundary. The Gemara rejects this proof: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>even <span class="gemarra-regular">if there is no wall, one may also not place</span> his mill <span class="gemarra-regular">close </span>by the boundary. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But rather, what does </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">teach us? </span>The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">This teaches us that vibrations are damaging to a wall</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come</span> and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>another proof from the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">And the oven</span> must be distanced <span class="gemarra-regular">three </span>handbreadths <span class="gemarra-regular">from the base, which is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> four </span>handbreadths <span class="gemarra-regular">from the upper rim </span>of the oven. The Gemara analyzes this statement: The <span class="gemarra-regular">reason </span>for this ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">is that there is a wall, </span>from which it may be inferred that if <span class="gemarra-regular">there is no wall, one may </span><span class="gemarra-regular">place </span>an oven <span class="gemarra-regular">close </span>by the boundary. The Gemara rejects this proof as well: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>even <span class="gemarra-regular">if there is no </span><span class="gemarra-regular">wall, one may also not place </span>his oven <span class="gemarra-regular">close </span>by the boundary. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, what does </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">teach us? </span>The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">This teaches us that heat </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is damaging to a wall.</span>
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a proof from the mishna (20b): <span class="gemarra-regular">A person may not open a baker</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> or a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> dye shop beneath </span>the wine <span class="gemarra-regular">storeroom of another, nor may</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> one </span>open <span class="gemarra-regular">a cattle barn </span>there. The Gemara analyzes this mishna: The <span class="gemarra-regular">reason </span>for this ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">is that there is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a storeroom </span>already in place, from which it may be inferred that <span class="gemarra-regular">if there is no storeroom one may do</span> so. If this is the case, then with regard to a pit as well, one may dig next to a boundary if there is as yet no pit.
The Gemara answers: The case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a residence is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> different</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as in general one can use his domicile in any manner of his choosing unless he directly causes damage to another or his property. The Gemara adds: The language of the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">is also precise, as </span>an explicit <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is taught with regard to that </span>mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>the construction of <span class="gemarra-regular">the cattle barn preceded the storeroom, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">permitted. </span>Nothing can be inferred from the case of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> with regard to the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of the mishna, which does not concern living quarters.
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a proof from a mishna (26a): <span class="gemarra-regular">A person may not plant a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">tree close to </span>another’s <span class="gemarra-regular">field unless he distances it </span><span class="gemarra-regular">four cubits from </span>his neighbor. <span class="gemarra-regular">And it is taught with </span><span class="gemarra-regular">regard to this </span>mishna: The <span class="gemarra-regular">four cubits of </span>which the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">spoke </span>are <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>enable <span class="gemarra-regular">the work of the vineyard,</span> i.e., a small space next to the trees is necessary to enable animals to plow between them.
The Gemara analyzes this ruling: The <span class="gemarra-regular">reason </span>this distance is required <span class="gemarra-regular">is due to the work of the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> vineyard, </span>from which it may be inferred that if <span class="gemarra-regular">not</span> for the problem <span class="gemarra-regular">due to the work of the vineyard</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>it would be permitted for one to plant his tree <span class="gemarra-regular">close </span>to the boundary, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>apparently, this is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">even though there are roots </span>of the tree <span class="gemarra-regular">that</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> damage </span>his neighbor’s field. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">With what</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> are we dealing here? </span>We are dealing with a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>a hard <span class="gemarra-regular">rock [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">tzunema</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> interrupts </span>between the two fields, preventing the roots from passing through to the other field.
The Gemara continues: The language of the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">is also precise</span> with regard to this point, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it teaches </span>further on: If there <span class="gemarra-regular">was a fence between them, this one </span><span class="gemarra-regular">places, </span>i.e., plants a tree, <span class="gemarra-regular">close </span>to <span class="gemarra-regular">the fence</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from here, and that one places, </span>i.e., plants a tree, <span class="gemarra-regular">close </span>to <span class="gemarra-regular">the fence from here. </span>If the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> were referring to a case where the roots could travel across, how could it be permitted for both neighbors to plant their trees alongside each other? Consequently, it must be referring to a situation where a rock separates between the two fields below, and therefore the neighbors may plant their trees near the fence.
The Gemara responds: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, say the last clause </span>of that mishna: If <span class="gemarra-regular">the roots </span>of the tree <span class="gemarra-regular">extended into </span>the field <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">another, </span>the neighbor <span class="gemarra-regular">may cut them off to a depth </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of three handbreadths, so that they do not impede the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">plow. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But if a rock interrupts </span>between the two fields and forms a barrier, <span class="gemarra-regular">what are </span>these roots <span class="gemarra-regular">doing there, </span>i.e., how did they get there? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>is what the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> of the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">is saying: And if </span>there is <span class="gemarra-regular">no rock, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and the roots </span>of the tree <span class="gemarra-regular">extended into </span>the field <span class="gemarra-regular">of another, </span>the neighbor <span class="gemarra-regular">may cut them off to a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> depth of three handbreadths so that they do not impede</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the plow.</span>
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come</span> and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a proof from a mishna (25b): <span class="gemarra-regular">One must</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> distance a tree twenty-five cubits from a cistern. </span>The Gemara analyzes this <span class="it-text">halakha</span>: The <span class="gemarra-regular">reason </span>for this ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that there is a cistern, </span>from which it may be inferred that <span class="gemarra-regular">if there is no cistern, one may place</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>i.e., plant, his tree <span class="gemarra-regular">close </span>to the neighbor’s field. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>even <span class="gemarra-regular">when there is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> no cistern one may also not place </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">close </span>to the neighbor’s field. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>by mentioning a cistern, the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> of the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us this: That the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">roots </span>of a tree <span class="gemarra-regular">extend and damage the cistern up </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>a distance of <span class="gemarra-regular">twenty-five cubits </span>away.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span><span class="gemarra-regular">so, say the last clause </span>of that mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">And if </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the tree preceded </span>the cistern, <span class="gemarra-regular">one is not </span>required to <span class="gemarra-regular">cut down </span>the tree. <span class="gemarra-regular">But if </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">may not place </span>the tree <span class="gemarra-regular">close </span>to the boundary even if there is no cistern, <span class="gemarra-regular">how can you find </span>a case where the tree preceded the cistern? Why would its owner not be required to cut it down? The Gemara answers: This is <span class="gemarra-regular">as Rav Pappa says </span>with regard to a similar matter, that it is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to a buyer </span>who purchases part of a field. <span class="gemarra-regular">So too </span>here, it is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a buyer. </span>In other words, a field contained a cistern and tree alongside each other, and the owner sold the part of the field containing the cistern.
The Gemara cites yet another source: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come</span> and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a proof from a mishna (25a): <span class="gemarra-regular">One must</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> distance the water in which flax is steeped from vegetables</span> growing in a neighbor’s field, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>one must distance <span class="gemarra-regular">leeks from onion</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> growing in a neighbor’s field, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>one must likewise distance <span class="gemarra-regular">mustard from bees </span>that are in a neighbor’s field. The Gemara analyzes this statement: The <span class="gemarra-regular">reason is that there are vegetables </span>present, from which it may be inferred that <span class="gemarra-regular">if there are no</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> vegetables, one may place </span>the water <span class="gemarra-regular">close </span>to the neighbor’s field. The Gemara rejects this opinion: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>even <span class="gemarra-regular">if there are no vegetables one may also not place </span>the water <span class="gemarra-regular">close </span>to the neighbor’s field. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us that these </span>items mentioned in that mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">are harmful to each other.</span>
The Gemara responds: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, say the last</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> clause </span>of that mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei renders it permitted </span>to plant near the neighbor’s bees <span class="gemarra-regular">in the </span>case of <span class="gemarra-regular">mustard. </span>As explained in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, this is <span class="gemarra-regular">because he</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> can say to </span>the owner of the bees: <span class="gemarra-regular">Just as</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> you say to me: Keep your mustard away from my</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> bees, </span>I can say to you: <span class="gemarra-regular">Keep your bees away</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from my mustard, as they come and eat my mustard</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> plants</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> In other words, you are damaging my property as well. 

Daf 18b

<span class="gemarra-regular">And if </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">may not place </span>an item that might cause damage <span class="gemarra-regular">close </span>to his neighbor’s boundary, <span class="gemarra-regular">how can you find </span>a case where each neighbor is damaging the property of the other? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> says: </span>This is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to a buyer </span>who purchased part of his neighbor’s field, and it contains a substance or items that might cause damage, e.g., the water in which flax is steeped or mustard. In the other section of the field the neighbor retained an item or substance that could be damaged. In this manner, it is possible for the item that causes damage to be found near the boundary of the neighbor without one having violated the ruling of the mishna.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>this is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to a buyer, what is the reason of the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rabbis, </span>who say that the neighbor can demand that the buyer distance that which causes damage? After all, he has not acted improperly. <span class="gemarra-regular">And furthermore, what is the reason of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rabbi Yosei </span>for disagreeing only in the case of the mustard and the bees? <span class="gemarra-regular">Even </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">water in</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> which flax is steeped and vegetables </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">also </span>subject to the same reasoning: Why should he have to distance his water, considering that he did not act improperly?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Ravina sai</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> that the explanation is as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">The Rabbis hold </span>that the responsibility falls <span class="gemarra-regular">on the one </span><span class="gemarra-regular">who causes damage to distance himself. </span>The one who has the potential to cause damage must act to prevent the damage from occurring. This is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> even if his initial placement was done in accordance with <span class="it-text">halakha</span>, as in the case where one bought part of a field.
The Gemara asks: Does this prove <span class="gemarra-regular">by</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> inference </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei, </span>who disagrees with the ruling of the Rabbis, <span class="gemarra-regular">holds that </span>that the responsibility falls <span class="gemarra-regular">on the</span> one whose property <span class="gemarra-regular">was damaged to distance himself; </span>i.e., to avoid being damaged? But <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>the responsibility to distance oneself falls <span class="gemarra-regular">on the </span>one whose property <span class="gemarra-regular">was damaged</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> even </span>in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">water in which flax </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is steeped and vegetables </span>the owner should <span class="gemarra-regular">also </span>not have to distance himself. Why does Rabbi Yosei distinguish between that situation and the case of bees and mustard?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">actually Rabbi Yosei also holds </span>that the responsibility to distance oneself falls <span class="gemarra-regular">on the one who causes damage, </span>even if he did not act improperly. <span class="gemarra-regular">And this </span>is what <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Yosei is saying to the Rabbis: </span>Your explanation <span class="gemarra-regular">works out </span><span class="gemarra-regular">well </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">water in which flax is steeped </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and vegetables, </span>where the one who causes damage must distance himself, as <span class="gemarra-regular">these damage those, but those do not damage </span><span class="gemarra-regular">these, </span>i.e., the water in which flax is steeped damages the vegetables, but the vegetables do not damage the water. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">mustard and bees</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> they both damage one another. </span>In light of this factor, and since the initial planting of the mustard was permitted, the owner of the bees should distance them from the mustard.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>as for <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis, </span>how do they respond to this claim? They maintain that <span class="gemarra-regular">bees do not</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> damage mustard. </span>Their reasoning is that <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>it is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to a seed, </span>the bees will <span class="gemarra-regular">not fin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> If </span>it is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to a leaf, it will grow</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> back, </span>and therefore no damage has been caused.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And does Rabbi Yosei hold </span>that the responsibility falls <span class="gemarra-regular">on the one who causes damage to distance himself</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?
