But didn’t we learn </span>in a mishna (25b) that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei says: Even though the cistern preceded the tree</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>the owner need <span class="gemarra-regular">not cut down </span>the tree, <span class="gemarra-regular">as this</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> one digs a cistern in his </span>property, <span class="gemarra-regular">and that one</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> plants </span>the tree <span class="gemarra-regular">in his </span>property? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, actually Rabbi Yosei</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> holds </span>that the responsibility falls <span class="gemarra-regular">on the </span>one whose property <span class="gemarra-regular">was damaged to distance himself. And </span>Rabbi Yosei <span class="gemarra-regular">spoke to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the Rabbis in accordance with their statement.</span>
The Gemara elaborates: Rabbi Yosei was saying to the Rabbis: <span class="gemarra-regular">In my </span>opinion, the responsibility falls <span class="gemarra-regular">on the </span>one whose property <span class="gemarra-regular">was damaged to distance himself, and </span>therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">water in which flax is steeped </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and vegetables, </span>the owner of the water <span class="gemarra-regular">need not distance </span>himself. <span class="gemarra-regular">But according to your </span>opinion, that the responsibility falls <span class="gemarra-regular">on the one who causes damage </span>to distance himself, this <span class="gemarra-regular">works out well </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">water in which flax </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is steeped and vegetables, as these damage those and those </span><span class="gemarra-regular">do not damage these. But mustard and bees both damage </span><span class="gemarra-regular">one another, </span>and if the mustard owner acted properly, the owner of the bees should be required to move his bees.
The Gemara continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>how do <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis </span>respond to this claim? They hold that <span class="gemarra-regular">bees do not damage mustard: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>this is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to a seed, </span>

§ The mishna teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">Nor </span>may one set up <span class="gemarra-regular">a launderer’s pond </span>near his neighbor’s wall unless he distances it three handbreadths from the wall. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman </span><span class="gemarra-regular">says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba bar Avuh says: They taught this only </span><span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to a soaking pond</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> in which soiled clothes are left to soak for several days. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>in the case <span class="gemarra-regular">of a washing pond [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">hanadyan</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> where clothes are actively cleaned, <span class="gemarra-regular">four cubits </span>are required. <span class="gemarra-regular">That </span>opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">also taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">A launderer’s pond </span>must be kept <span class="gemarra-regular">four cubits </span>from one’s neighbor’s wall. <span class="gemarra-regular">But didn’t we learn </span>in the mishna that one must keep a distance of only <span class="gemarra-regular">three handbreadths? Rather, </span>must one <span class="gemarra-regular">not conclude from </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that the statement of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman </span>is correct?
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span><span class="gemarra-regular">some raise </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">as a contradiction, </span>and present the mishna and <span class="it-text">baraita</span> as apparently conflicting sources. <span class="gemarra-regular">We learned </span>in the mishna that <span class="gemarra-regular">a launderer’s pond </span>must be kept <span class="gemarra-regular">three </span><span class="gemarra-regular">handbreadths </span>from his neighbor’s property. <span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t it</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">four cubits </span>are required? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Naḥman says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba bar Avuh says: </span>This is <span class="gemarra-regular">not</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> difficult. Here, </span>the mishna is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">a soaking pond</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>which requires three handbreadths; <span class="gemarra-regular">there, </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">a washing pond, </span>in which case four cubits are necessary. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥiyya, son of Rav Avya, teaches </span>the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">explicitly</span> as reading: <span class="gemarra-regular">Unless he distanced three handbreadths from the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">rim of the soaking pond and the wall.</span>
§ The mishna teaches that one who digs a pit must distance it three handbreadths from another’s property and <span class="gemarra-regular">plaster </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">with lime. A dilemma was</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> raised before </span>the Sages: What is the precise wording of the mishna? <span class="gemarra-regular">Did we learn: And plasters with lime,</span> meaning that the walls must be plastered with lime in addition to distancing the pit three handbreadths, <span class="gemarra-regular">or perhaps we</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> learned: Or plasters with lime, </span>i.e., one may plaster the walls with lime instead of digging the pit at a distance of three handbreadths.
The Gemara answers: It is <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious that we learned: And plasters with lime</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as, if it enters your mind </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">we learned: Or</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> plasters with lime, </span>which is the same as what is stated in the clause of the mishna discussing olive refuse, <span class="gemarra-regular">if so, let </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">combine them and teach them</span> together. If the same <span class="it-text">halakha</span> applied in all circumstances, all of the mishna’s cases could be taught together.
The Gemara answers: This is not proof, as <span class="gemarra-regular">perhaps</span> these cases are taught separately <span class="gemarra-regular">because this </span>type of <span class="gemarra-regular">damage</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is not similar to that </span>type of <span class="gemarra-regular">damage. The first</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> clause </span>of the mishna addresses the issue of <span class="gemarra-regular">damage </span>due <span class="gemarra-regular">to moisture, </span>whereas <span class="gemarra-regular">the last clause </span>addresses the issue of <span class="gemarra-regular">damage </span>due <span class="gemarra-regular">to heat.</span>
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a proof from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda says: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">rock that </span>is so soft it <span class="gemarra-regular">crumbles in </span>one’s <span class="gemarra-regular">hands, this one digs</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> his pit from here, </span>on his property, <span class="gemarra-regular">and that one</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> digs his pit from there. This one distances </span>his pit <span class="gemarra-regular">three handbreadths and plasters with lime, and that one distances</span> his pit <span class="gemarra-regular">three handbreadths and plasters with lime. </span>The Gemara analyzes this ruling: The specific <span class="gemarra-regular">reason </span>one must also plaster with lime is that he is using rock that <span class="gemarra-regular">crumbles</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in </span>one’s <span class="gemarra-regular">hands, </span>from which it may be inferred that if it is rock that <span class="gemarra-regular">does not crumble in</span> one’s <span class="gemarra-regular">hands, </span>one would <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>be required to plaster with lime as well.
The Gemara answers: One could say that <span class="gemarra-regular">the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> same is true, </span>i.e., <span class="gemarra-regular">that even though </span>he is using rock <span class="gemarra-regular">that does not crumble in </span>one’s <span class="gemarra-regular">hands, </span>he must <span class="gemarra-regular">also plaster with lime. And it was</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> necessary for </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> to mention the case of rock that <span class="gemarra-regular">crumbles in </span>one’s <span class="gemarra-regular">hands, </span>as it might <span class="gemarra-regular">enter</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> your mind to say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">since it crumbles in </span>one’s <span class="gemarra-regular">hands, let us require a greater distance. </span>Therefore, the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>that this is not the case.
§ The mishna teaches that <span class="gemarra-regular">one must distance the solid residue </span>of produce that has been pressed free of its oil, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>animal <span class="gemarra-regular">manure</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, and salt, and lime, and rocks </span>three handbreadths from the wall of another, or plaster its receptacle with lime. The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">We learned </span>in a mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">there </span>(<span class="it-text">Shabbat</span> 47b): <span class="gemarra-regular">With what </span>substances <span class="gemarra-regular">may one insulat</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> a pot of cooked food on Shabbat eve, <span class="gemarra-regular">and with what </span>substances <span class="gemarra-regular">may</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> one not insulate </span>it?
<span class="gemarra-regular">One may insulate </span>the pot <span class="gemarra-regular">neither with the solid residue </span>of produce that has been pressed free of its oil, <span class="gemarra-regular">nor with manure</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, nor with salt, nor with lime, nor with sand, whether</span> those materials are <span class="gemarra-regular">moist </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">whether </span>they are <span class="gemarra-regular">dry. </span>All of these materials spontaneously generate heat when piled up for an extended period of time. Therefore, they add heat to the pot they insulate. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is different</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> here that </span>the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">rocks and it does not teach </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">sand, and what is different there that</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it teaches </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">sand and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it does not teach </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">rocks?</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef says: </span>There is a practical reason for this difference. Rocks are not mentioned there <span class="gemarra-regular">because it is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not customary for people to insulate </span>food <span class="gemarra-regular">with rocks. Abaye</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> said to him: And is it customary for people to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> insulate </span>food <span class="gemarra-regular">with wool fleece and tabs of purple wool</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">One may insulate</span> food <span class="gemarra-regular">with wool fleece; with combed wool clumps, </span>which are unwoven; <span class="gemarra-regular">with tabs of purple wool</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and with </span>swatches of <span class="gemarra-regular">soft material; but </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">may not move the</span><span class="gemarra-regular">m</span> on Shabbat because they are set-aside [<span class="it-text">muktze</span>].
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Abaye said </span>that the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> follows the biblical aphorism in the verse that states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Its neighbor</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> tells about him” </span>(Job 36:33), i.e., one example is mentioned and the same applies to the other case. <span class="gemarra-regular">He taught </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">rocks here </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and the same is true of sand; he taught </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">sand there and the same </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is true of rocks. Rava said to </span>Abaye: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>this is correct, that <span class="gemarra-regular">“its neighbor tells about him,” let</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> him teach </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">all of </span>these examples <span class="gemarra-regular">in</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> one </span>case, <span class="gemarra-regular">and let him teach </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of just <span class="gemarra-regular">one in the other </span>case, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>it can be said that <span class="gemarra-regular">the same is true </span>with regard <span class="gemarra-regular">to the others</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Rava</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> said: There, this is </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">reason that </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">does</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not teach </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">rocks: Because</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> they break, </span>i.e., scratch, <span class="gemarra-regular">the pot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and consequently people do not use them for insulating food at all. <span class="gemarra-regular">Here, this is </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">reason that </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">does </span><span class="gemarra-regular">not teach </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">sand: Because </span><span class="gemarra-regular">it heats hot </span>items <span class="gemarra-regular">and cools cold </span>items, and therefore it does not cause any damage to the wall.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But Rabbi Oshaya taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that one must distance <span class="gemarra-regular">sand </span>from his neighbor’s wall. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">There, </span>it is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to damp </span>sand, which must be kept at a distance due to its moisture. The Gemara challenges: <span class="gemarra-regular">Let the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> our </span>mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">also teach </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in the case of sand <span class="gemarra-regular">and we will interpret it </span>as referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to damp</span> sand. The Gemara answers: This <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">already taught </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a water channel, </span>which is a source of dampness, and therefore there was no need to mention damp sand as well.
The Gemara rejects this answer: That is incorrect, as <span class="gemarra-regular">is that to say </span>that the mishna includes only one example of a source of dampness? <span class="gemarra-regular">Doesn’t </span>the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teach </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a water channel? And </span>yet <span class="gemarra-regular">it </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>the example of <span class="gemarra-regular">a launderer’s pond. </span>This demonstrates that the mishna teaches many cases, despite the similarity between them, and therefore it should have mentioned the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in the case of sand as well.
The Gemara answers: Both of <span class="gemarra-regular">those </span>particular examples <span class="gemarra-regular">are necessary, as, had </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">taught </span>only the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a water channel, </span>one would have claimed that a distance must be kept <span class="gemarra-regular">because it is fixed, </span>i.e., water constantly passes through it. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a launderer’s pond, which is not fixed, </span>as it sometimes holds water and sometimes does not, one might <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that one need <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>distance it from his neighbor’s property. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>conversely, <span class="gemarra-regular">had </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">taught </span>only the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a launderer’s pond, </span>one might have said that this must be distanced <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>its water <span class="gemarra-regular">is fixed</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and standing </span>in one location and therefore leaks out. <span class="gemarra-regular">But</span> with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a water channel, </span>one might say distancing it is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>required. Consequently, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is necessary </span>to state both examples. By contrast, including the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in the case of sand would not add any novel understanding.
§ The mishna teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">One must distance seeds, </span>i.e., one may not plant seeds, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>one may not operate <span class="gemarra-regular">the plow, </span>and one must eliminate urine, three handbreadths from the wall of another. The Gemara asks: Why is it necessary to mention <span class="gemarra-regular">seeds? </span>Let him <span class="gemarra-regular">derive this </span>requirement to distance the seeds <span class="gemarra-regular">due to </span>the requirement to distance <span class="gemarra-regular">a plow, </span>as in any event the ground must be plowed before it can be sown? The Gemara answers: This is referring to planting <span class="gemarra-regular">with a single hand motion, </span>which is performed without plowing.
The Gemara further challenges: The mishna teaches that one must distance <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">plow; but </span>let him <span class="gemarra-regular">derive this </span>requirement to distance a plow <span class="gemarra-regular">due to </span>the requirement to distance the <span class="gemarra-regular">seeds, </span>as plowing is preparation for planting. The Gemara answers: This is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to one who plows </span>to prepare the ground <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span><span class="gemarra-regular">trees. </span>The Gemara challenges: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if so, let him <span class="gemarra-regular">derive this </span>requirement to distance a plow due to the requirement to distance the <span class="gemarra-regular">water. </span>If there are trees, there must be a water channel to irrigate them, and arranging one’s field in such a manner should be prohibited for that reason. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">The </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is referring </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to Eretz Yisrael, </span>concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">which it is written: “And drinks </span><span class="gemarra-regular">water as the rain of heaven comes down” </span>(Deuteronomy 11:11). In Eretz Yisrael, water channels were not needed.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Is this to say that seeds</span>

<span class="gemarra-regular">take root </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to the sides, </span>i.e., the growing roots spread sideways and cause damage to walls? <span class="gemarra-regular">But didn’t we learn </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Kilayim</span> 7:1): With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who </span><span class="gemarra-regular">bend</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> a branch of <span class="gemarra-regular">a grapevin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> into the ground </span>so that it strikes roots and produces a new vine, <span class="gemarra-regular">if it does not have three handbreadths of earth over </span><span class="gemarra-regular">it he may not plant a seed above </span>it, as he would thereby transgress the prohibition of diverse kinds?
<span class="gemarra-regular">And it is taught with regard to </span>this mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">But one may plant on either sid</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> of that bent branch. This indicates that there is no concern that the roots of the seeds will spread out sideways. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Ḥagga says in the name of Rabbi Yosei: </span>The issue here is not that the roots will spread out sideways and reach the wall. Rather, it is prohibited to plant seeds near one’s neighbor’s property <span class="gemarra-regular">because they break</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> up the groun</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and cause loose soil to rise </span><span class="gemarra-regular">up, </span>which damages the foundation of the wall.
§ The mishna teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">And urine </span>must be kept at a distance of <span class="gemarra-regular">three handbreadths from the wall</span> of one’s neighbor. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba bar bar Ḥana says: </span>It <span class="gemarra-regular">is permitted </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">a person to urinate alongside the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">wall of another, as it is written: “And I will </span><span class="gemarra-regular">cut off from Ahab those who urinate against the wall, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and him that is shut up and him that is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">left at large in Israel” </span>(I Kings 21:21). As the verse employs the term “those who urinate against the wall” to mean males, it seems that urinating against a wall was a common practice. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But didn’t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> we learn </span>in the mishna that <span class="gemarra-regular">urine </span>must be kept a distance of <span class="gemarra-regular">three handbreadths from the wall? </span>The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">There, </span>the mishna is referring to urine <span class="gemarra-regular">that is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> poure</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> from a chamber pot, as opposed to urine that is passed from the body.
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">A </span><span class="gemarra-regular">person may not pour wate</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> at the side of the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> wall of another unless he distances </span>the water <span class="gemarra-regular">three handbreadths</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from it. </span>If pouring water is prohibited, then all the more so should urination be prohibited. The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">There too, </span>it is referring to urine <span class="gemarra-regular">that is poured </span>from a chamber pot.
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>another proof from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">A person may not urinat</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> alongside the wall of another unless he distances </span>himself <span class="gemarra-regular">three</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> handbreadths from it. In what </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">is this statement said</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? </span>It is said <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a brick wall</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> But in </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a stone wall, </span>one must distance himself <span class="gemarra-regular">enough so that it does not cause</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> damage. And how far </span>must he distance himself? One <span class="gemarra-regular">handbreadth</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. And </span>if there is <span class="gemarra-regular">hard roc</span><span class="gemarra-regular">k</span> present, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">permitted </span>to urinate there. The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">The refutation of </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba bar bar Ḥana is a conclusive </span><span class="gemarra-regular">refutation</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and his ruling is rejected.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But Rabba bar bar Ḥana stated a verse </span>in support of his opinion; how can the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> rule counter to what is written in a verse? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>is what it <span class="gemarra-regular">is saying there, </span>i.e., this is the meaning of that verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">I will not even leave</span> Ahab <span class="gemarra-regular">something whose manner is to urinate against a wall</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. And what is that? A dog. </span>According to this interpretation, the verse is not referring to people at all.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Tovi bar Kisna say</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel says: A wafer does not reduce </span>the dimensions <span class="gemarra-regular">of a window</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> When a corpse, or a significant part thereof, is in one room, its impurity can spread to a room adjacent to it if there is a window of a certain size between the rooms. Shmuel states that when one puts a wafer in a window, the wafer is not considered an obstruction, so the size of the opening as relevant to this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> remains the same. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Why </span>discuss <span class="gemarra-regular">specifically </span>this case? Why does Shmuel teach this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a wafer? </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Even a thick </span>chunk of bread <span class="gemarra-regular">also </span>does not reduce the dimensions of a window.
The Gemara answers: Shmuel <span class="gemarra-regular">is speaking </span>utilizing the style of: <span class="gemarra-regular">It is not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">necessary, </span>as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">It is not necessary </span>to state this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">thick </span>bread. <span class="gemarra-regular">Since it is fit</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for him </span>to consume, <span class="gemarra-regular">he does not nullify it, </span>i.e., he does not plan to leave it in the window for an extended amount of time. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a wafer, which </span>becomes <span class="gemarra-regular">disgustin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span> when placed in a window, <span class="gemarra-regular">I might say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">he does nullify</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it </span>and it becomes part of the house, thereby reducing the size of the window. To counter this, Shmuel <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> us </span>that even a wafer is not nullified, as it can be used to feed animals, as one is not particular about their food. Therefore, the wafer does not become part of the window in which it is placed.
The Gemara challenges: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>let him <span class="gemarra-regular">derive this </span><span class="it-text">halakha</span> from the fact that a wafer is <span class="gemarra-regular">an item that is susceptible to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> ritual impurity, and any item that is susceptible to impurity</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> does not serve as a barrier against </span>the spread of <span class="gemarra-regular">impurity. </span>The Gemara explains: This is referring to a wafer <span class="gemarra-regular">that was kneaded in fruit juice</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> which is not one of the liquids that renders food susceptible to ritual impurity, and therefore the wafer is not susceptible to ritual impurity. Consequently, one might have thought that it serves as a barrier before ritual impurity and reduces the dimensions of the window.
The Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises an objection </span>to Shmuel’s opinion from a mishna (<span class="it-text">Oholot</span> 6:2): With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a basket </span>that is <span class="gemarra-regular">full</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of straw</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> or </span>an earthenware <span class="gemarra-regular">barrel full of dried</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> figs, which are placed in a window, </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">considers: If</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the straw or dried figs would stand on their own</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> were </span>the basket or barrel <span class="gemarra-regular">removed, </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">they would serve</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as a barrier against </span>the spread of impurity. <span class="gemarra-regular">But if</span> they would <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>stand on their own <span class="gemarra-regular">they would not</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> serve as a barrier. </span>The Gemara explains the objection: <span class="gemarra-regular">But</span> why should the straw or dried figs serve as a barrier? Even <span class="gemarra-regular">straw </span>that can stand on its own <span class="gemarra-regular">is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> fit for </span>feeding to <span class="gemarra-regular">one’s animal </span>and will likely be removed from the opening, which means it should not be considered part of the window.
The Gemara answers: The ruling of the mishna is stated <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to rotted </span>straw, which is unfit for animal consumption. The Gemara asks: But <span class="gemarra-regular">it is fit for </span>use in the making of <span class="gemarra-regular">clay </span>for bricks. The Gemara answers: This is referring to straw <span class="gemarra-regular">that has thorns in i</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> and therefore is not fit for making bricks. The Gemara challenges: Even so, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">fit for kindling </span>a fire. The Gemara answers that this is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">wet </span>straw. The Gemara responds: Nevertheless, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">fit for </span><span class="gemarra-regular">kindling a large </span>fire. If one builds a large fire, wet straw will dry and become ignitable. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">A large fire is not common, </span>and therefore, in all likelihood, the straw will remain in the window.
The Gemara further asks: But <span class="gemarra-regular">dried figs are</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> fit for him </span>to consume, and he will certainly remove them. Consequently, they should not be considered fixed in their place. <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel says: </span>This is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the figs <span class="gemarra-regular">became worm infested [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">beshehitrifu</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> And so </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba bar Avuh teaches: </span>This is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the figs <span class="gemarra-regular">became worm infested.</span>
The Gemara clarifies: <span class="gemarra-regular">What are the </span>exact <span class="gemarra-regular">circumstances of this barrel </span>that held the dried figs? <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>this is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>its <span class="gemarra-regular">opening faced outward, </span>i.e., not toward the source of the ritual impurity, 

Daf 20a

<span class="gemarra-regular">let </span>the barrel <span class="gemarra-regular">itself serve as a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">barrier. </span>It should not be susceptible to impurity in this case, <span class="gemarra-regular">as an earthenware vessel does not contract impurity </span><span class="gemarra-regular">if its exterior </span>is exposed to impurity. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>one must say <span class="gemarra-regular">that its opening faces inward, </span>and it is rendered impure because the impurity enters through its opening. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if </span><span class="gemarra-regular">you wish, say </span>instead that <span class="gemarra-regular">actually its opening faces outward, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and with what are we dealing here? </span>We are dealing <span class="gemarra-regular">with a metal barrel, </span>which does contract impurity through its exterior.
The Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises </span>another <span class="gemarra-regular">objection </span>to the assumption that an item for which there is a use does not reduce the dimensions of a window, even if is not susceptible to impurity, from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> (<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span>, <span class="it-text">Oholot</span> 14:6): With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">gras</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that one</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> plucke</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and placed in a window or that grew </span><span class="gemarra-regular">on its own in windows; and scraps of fabri</span><span class="gemarra-regular">c</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> do not measure three by three </span>fingerbreadths; <span class="gemarra-regular">and a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">limb or flesh danglin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from an animal or a beast</span><span class="gemarra-regular">; and a bird resting in the window</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> gentile sittin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in the window</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>a child <span class="gemarra-regular">born </span>after <span class="gemarra-regular">eight </span>months of pregnancy, who is not expected to survive, <span class="gemarra-regular">that is placed in the window; and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">salt</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and an earthenware vessel</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and a Torah </span><span class="gemarra-regular">scroll</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> all these reduce the dimensions of the window. </span>Consequently, impurity passes through only if there remains an open space of a square handbreadth. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">snow, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">hail</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> frost, ice</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and water, all these do </span><span class="gemarra-regular">not reduce the dimensions of a window.</span>
The Gemara proceeds to challenge Shmuel’s ruling from each of the cases of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>according to Shmuel, who says that an item that has a use is not considered part of the window and does not reduce the dimensions of the space, <span class="gemarra-regular">grass is fit </span>for consumption by <span class="gemarra-regular">one’s animal, </span>so it will not remain in the window. Yet the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> states that grass reduces the dimensions of the window. The Gemara answers: This is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span><span class="gemarra-italic">afrazta</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> which is poisonous grass that is unfit for an animal to consume.
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">Or </span>grass <span class="gemarra-regular">that grew on </span><span class="gemarra-regular">its own </span>also reduces the dimensions of the window. The Gemara asks: But <span class="gemarra-regular">since </span>the grass <span class="gemarra-regular">damages the wall, </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">will remove it. </span>Therefore, it should not serve as a barrier to impurity. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba says: </span>This is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to a wall of a ruin, </span>whose structural integrity is insignificant, and therefore the owner will not trouble himself to remove the grass. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa says: </span>The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> may even be referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to a wall </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">a settled </span>house, and it is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the grass <span class="gemarra-regular">comes</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from three </span>handbreadths <span class="gemarra-regular">beyond </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">window. </span>In other words, the grass does not grow on the window but takes root some distance away, and from there it reaches the window. The homeowner is not particular about this grass and will not uproot it.
The Gemara further asks: Why do <span class="gemarra-regular">scraps of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> fabric </span>reduce the dimensions of the window? After all, <span class="gemarra-regular">they</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> are fit for </span>patching <span class="gemarra-regular">a tea</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in a garment. </span>The Gemara answers: This is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to thick </span>scraps, which are unsuitable for patching. The Gemara challenges: Nevertheless, they are <span class="gemarra-regular">fit for a bloodletter </span>to wipe up the blood at the point of incision. The Gemara answers: It is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to sackcloth, </span>which scratches the skin, and would not be used for that purpose.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>it is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to sackcloth, </span>why does the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> state <span class="gemarra-regular">that it is not three by three </span>fingerbreadths? It <span class="gemarra-regular">should have </span>said that <span class="gemarra-regular">it is not four by four </span>handbreadths. Rough woven material of the kind used for sacks rather than clothes is susceptible to impurity only if its area measures at least four by four handbreadths. The Gemara answers: It is not actual sackcloth; rather, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">like </span><span class="gemarra-regular">sackcloth, </span>i.e., it is stiff, and will therefore not be used by a bloodletter, but is woven like regular clothing.
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">And a limb or </span><span class="gemarra-regular">flesh dangling from an animal or a beast </span>reduces the dimensions of a window. The Gemara asks: According to the opinion of Shmuel, why should this be so? After all, the animal can <span class="gemarra-regular">arise and escape, </span>and therefore it should not be considered as part of the window. The Gemara answers: This is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>an animal that is <span class="gemarra-regular">tied </span>in place.
The Gemara challenges: But the owner of the animal will take it and <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughter it. </span>The Gemara answers: It is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>an animal that is <span class="gemarra-regular">non-kosher </span>and will not be slaughtered. The Gemara challenges: Even so, <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span>will take it and <span class="gemarra-regular">sell it to a gentile. </span>The Gemara responds: It is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to a lean </span>animal, which no one will buy. The Gemara continues: Even if the animal does not move, there is a use for the part that is dangling, <span class="gemarra-regular">since he </span>can <span class="gemarra-regular">cut it off</span> and <span class="gemarra-regular">throw it to the dogs. </span>The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Since</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> there is suffering to an anima</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span> if he cuts it off, <span class="gemarra-regular">he will not do </span>that.
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> further teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">And</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a bird resting in the window </span>reduces its dimensions. The Gemara challenges: But it will <span class="gemarra-regular">fly away, </span>and therefore it should not be considered as part of the window. The Gemara answers: This is referring to a bird <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is tied </span>in place. The Gemara further challenges: But the owner will take it and <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughter it. </span>The Gemara answers: This is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to a non-kosher bird, </span>which he will not slaughter. The Gemara continues: Even if it is non-kosher <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span>will take it and <span class="gemarra-regular">sell it </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to a gentile. </span>The Gemara responds: It is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kelanita</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> a type of bird that is so bony that no one would purchase it to consume it.
The Gemara asks: But even so, <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span>can <span class="gemarra-regular">give it to a child </span>to play with, so why does it reduce the dimensions of the window? The Gemara answers: It is referring to a bird <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span><span class="gemarra-regular">scratches. </span>The Gemara challenges: But <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kelanita</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> does not scratch. </span>The Gemara answers: The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is referring to a type of bird that is <span class="gemarra-regular">like a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kelanita</span> in that it is bony, but is inclined to scratch people.
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> further states: <span class="gemarra-regular">And a gentile sitting in the window </span>reduces its dimensions. The Gemara asks: But the gentile will <span class="gemarra-regular">arise and leave</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>so why does he reduce the dimensions of the window? The Gemara answers: This is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>someone <span class="gemarra-regular">who is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> tied </span>in place. The Gemara continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">Another </span>person <span class="gemarra-regular">will </span><span class="gemarra-regular">come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">release him. </span>The Gemara answers: This is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to a leper, </span>whom people are afraid to touch. The Gemara challenges: <span class="gemarra-regular">Another leper will come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">release him. Rather, </span>this is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to a prisoner of the monarchy. </span>Since he is confined as a punishment, others are afraid to release him.
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>a child <span class="gemarra-regular">born </span>after <span class="gemarra-regular">eight </span>months of pregnancy <span class="gemarra-regular">who is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">placed in the window </span>reduces its dimensions. The Gemara challenges: Perhaps <span class="gemarra-regular">his mother will come and remove him </span>from there. The Gemara answers: This is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to Shabbat, </span>when it is prohibited to move this child, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is taught</span> in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: A child <span class="gemarra-regular">born </span>after <span class="gemarra-regular">eight </span>months <span class="gemarra-regular">is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> like a stone </span>with regard to the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of set-aside [<span class="it-text">muktze</span>], <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">it is prohibited to move him</span><span class="gemarra-regular">; but his mother may bend over </span>the child <span class="gemarra-regular">and nurse</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> him, due to the dange</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> that failure to nurse will cause her to fall ill.
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">Salt </span>reduces the dimensions of a window. The Gemara challenges: <span class="gemarra-regular">It is fit </span>for use and people will remove it from there. The Gemara answers: This is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to bitter </span>salt, which is not used as a seasoning. The Gemara challenges: Nevertheless, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is fit for </span>tanning <span class="gemarra-regular">hides. </span>The Gemara responds: It is referring to salt <span class="gemarra-regular">that has thorns </span>mixed with it, and therefore it will not be used for tanning.
The Gemara challenges: Even so, <span class="gemarra-regular">since </span>this salt <span class="gemarra-regular">is damaging to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the wall, he will remove it </span>from there. The Gemara answers: This is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where it sits </span><span class="gemarra-regular">on a shard </span>of earthenware, and consequently it does not damage the wall. The Gemara states: If it is resting on earthenware, <span class="gemarra-regular">let </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">shard itself serve as a barrier</span> against the spreading of the impurity. Why, then, is the salt mentioned? 

Daf 20b

The Gemara answers: This is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where</span> the shard <span class="gemarra-regular">does not have </span>the sufficient <span class="gemarra-regular">measur</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> for ritual impurity, and is therefore considered insignificant. <span class="gemarra-regular">As we learned </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Shabbat</span> 82a): One who carries a shard of <span class="gemarra-regular">earthenware </span>on Shabbat is liable only if it is <span class="gemarra-regular">equivalent </span>in size to that which is used <span class="gemarra-regular">to place </span><span class="gemarra-regular">between one pillar and another </span>when they are piled on the ground, to strengthen the pillars.
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">An earthenware </span><span class="gemarra-regular">vessel </span>reduces the dimensions of a window. The Gemara challenges: But it is <span class="gemarra-regular">fit for one </span>to use; therefore, it is likely to be removed from the window. The Gemara answers: This is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the earthenware <span class="gemarra-regular">is dirty. </span>The Gemara challenges: Even so, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is fit </span><span class="gemarra-regular">for a bloodletter </span>to collect the blood. It would not matter to him if the earthenware were dirty. The Gemara answers: It is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where it is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">perforated </span>and therefore unfit for that use.
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">A </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Torah scroll </span>reduces the dimensions of a window. The Gemara challenges: But it <span class="gemarra-regular">is fit for reading; </span>therefore, it might be removed. The Gemara answers: This is referring to a Torah scroll <span class="gemarra-regular">that is worn out </span>and unfit for reading. The Gemara challenges: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>one is <span class="gemarra-regular">required </span>to place the Torah scroll in <span class="gemarra-regular">a repository </span>for unusable sacred books; therefore, he will certainly remove it to be stored away. The Gemara answers: This is referring to one who determines that <span class="gemarra-regular">its repository will be there. </span>In other words, it was placed in the window with the intent of storing it there in its worn-out state.
§ With regard to the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> referring to salt, the Gemara cites that which <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: One can construct a barrier </span>to delineate a private domain on Shabbat or to block the spreading of ritual impurity <span class="gemarra-regular">with anythin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> except for salt</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and fat, </span>as salt crumbles and fat melts in the heat. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Shmuel says: Even salt </span>can be used as a barrier. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa said: And they do not disagree</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>ruling of Shmuel is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">Sodomite salt</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>which is like stone and can be used as a barrier, and <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>ruling of Rav is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span><span class="gemarra-italic">isterokanit</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> salt</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> which is taken from the sea and is composed of grains.
The Gemara adds: <span class="gemarra-regular">And</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> now that Rabba said: </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">a person makes two piles</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of salt </span>at the opening to an alleyway <span class="gemarra-regular">and places</span> a cross <span class="gemarra-regular">beam on top of them</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> so <span class="gemarra-regular">that</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the salt supports the </span>cross <span class="gemarra-regular">beam and the </span>cross <span class="gemarra-regular">beam</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> supports the salt </span>by weighing it down and compressing it, he can use this beam to render it permitted to carry in the alleyway on Shabbat, one can say that <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span><span class="gemarra-italic">isterokanit</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> salt </span>can be used as a barrier. <span class="gemarra-regular">And</span> even so, Rav and Shmuel <span class="gemarra-regular">do not disagree: This </span>ruling of Shmuel is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where there is</span> a cross <span class="gemarra-regular">beam </span>to weigh the salt down, and <span class="gemarra-regular">that</span> ruling of Rava is referring to a case where <span class="gemarra-regular">there</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is no </span>cross <span class="gemarra-regular">beam.</span>
§ The mishna teaches that <span class="gemarra-regular">one must distance a mil</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span> from a neighbor’s wall by a distance of <span class="gemarra-regular">three </span>handbreadths <span class="gemarra-regular">from the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> lower stone </span>of the mill, <span class="gemarra-regular">which is four </span>handbreadths <span class="gemarra-regular">from the upper stone </span>of the mill. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>that one must distance a mill from the property of his neighbor? It is <span class="gemarra-regular">due to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the vibrations </span>it causes. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the measure for distancing a mill <span class="gemarra-regular">on a bas</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">three </span>handbreadths <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the lower millstone [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ha’isterobil</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> which is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">four </span>handbreadths <span class="gemarra-regular">from the mouth [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">hakelet</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> where the wheat is fed in? But <span class="gemarra-regular">there, what vibrations are there</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>the reason for the distancing is <span class="gemarra-regular">due to the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">nois</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> generated by the mill.
The mishna teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>there must be a distance of <span class="gemarra-regular">three</span> handbreadths <span class="gemarra-regular">from the </span>protruding <span class="gemarra-regular">base </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">an oven </span>until the wall, <span class="gemarra-regular">which is four </span>handbreadths <span class="gemarra-regular">from the </span>narrow <span class="gemarra-regular">upper rim</span> of the oven. <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said: Learn from </span>the mishna that <span class="gemarra-regular">the base of an oven </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">a handbreadth </span>wider than its rim. The practical <span class="gemarra-regular">difference </span>of this observation is with respect <span class="gemarra-regular">to buying and selling, </span>i.e., a buyer should know that this is the proper ratio for the dimensions of an oven.
mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">A person may not set </span><span class="gemarra-regular">up an </span><span class="gemarra-regular">ove</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">inside a house unless there is a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> space four cubits high above it, </span>i.e., between the top of the oven and the ceiling, to avoid burning the ceiling, which serves as the floor of the residence above. If <span class="gemarra-regular">one was setting up </span>an oven <span class="gemarra-regular">in the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> upper story, there must be a plaster floor beneath it</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>which serves as the ceiling of the lower story, at least <span class="gemarra-regular">three handbreadths </span>thick, so that the ceiling below does not burn. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>in the case <span class="gemarra-regular">of a stove </span>the plaster floor must be at least one <span class="gemarra-regular">handbreadt</span><span class="gemarra-regular">h</span> thick.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span><span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">causes damage </span>in any case, <span class="gemarra-regular">he pays </span>compensation for that <span class="gemarra-regular">which he damaged. Rabbi Shimon says: They said </span><span class="gemarra-regular">all of these measurements </span>to teach <span class="gemarra-regular">only that if he </span><span class="gemarra-regular">causes damage he is exempt from paying, </span>as he took all reasonable precautions.
The mishna continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">A person may not open </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a baker</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> or a dye shop beneath the storeroom of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> another, and </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">may not </span>establish <span class="gemarra-regular">a cattle barn </span>there, as these produce heat, smoke, and odors, which rise and damage the items in the storeroom. The mishna comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">In</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> truth, </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is that in the case <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span>a storeroom of <span class="gemarra-regular">wine </span>the Sages rendered it <span class="gemarra-regular">permitted </span>to set up a bakery and a dye shop beneath, as the heat that rises does not damage the wine. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>they did <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>render it permitted to establish <span class="gemarra-regular">a cattle barn</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>because its odor damages the wine.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t it taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">an oven </span>the plaster floor must be <span class="gemarra-regular">four </span>handbreadths thick, <span class="gemarra-regular">and with regard to a stove </span>it must be <span class="gemarra-regular">three? </span>By contrast, the mishna says that the plaster floor beneath and oven and a stove must be three handbreadths and one handbreadth thick, respectively. <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">When that </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is taught </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>ovens and stoves <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">bakers</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Since they bake all day long, their implements get very hot. The <span class="gemarra-regular">oven </span>discussed <span class="gemarra-regular">in our </span>mishna is similar to <span class="gemarra-regular">a baker’s stove, </span>which is why in both cases a distance of three handbreadths is required.
The mishna teaches that one <span class="gemarra-regular">may not open a bakery </span>or a dye shop beneath the storeroom of another, and he may not establish a cattle barn there. A Sage <span class="gemarra-regular">taught: If the cattle </span><span class="gemarra-regular">barn precede</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the storeroom it is permitted, </span>i.e., the barn owner is not required to move it. With regard to this point, <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye raises a dilemma: </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">he cleaned</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and sprinkle</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> the area, i.e., he prepared it for use <span class="gemarra-regular">as a storeroom </span>but he has not yet filled it, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? Is it considered a storeroom already, and therefore others may no longer put a cattle barn beneath it, or perhaps the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is that as long as it is empty he cannot prevent others from establishing a cattle barn?
Similarly, if he <span class="gemarra-regular">added window</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> for ventilation, which demonstrates his intention to use it as a storeroom, <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? Likewise, if he establishes <span class="gemarra-regular">an enclosed veranda </span><span class="gemarra-regular">beneath the storeroom</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> what </span>is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? If he <span class="gemarra-regular">built an upper roo</span><span class="gemarra-regular">m</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> on top of his house </span>for storage, <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? None of these questions are answered, and the Gemara declares that they <span class="gemarra-regular">shall stand </span>unresolved. The Gemara cites a similar question: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna, son </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav Yehoshua, raises a dilemma: </span>If he placed <span class="gemarra-regular">dates </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and pomegranate</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> there, <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? Is this considered the start of its use as a storeroom or not? No answer was found to this question either, and the Gemara declares: The dilemma <span class="gemarra-regular">shall stand</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">teiku</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] </span>unresolved.
§ The mishna teaches that <span class="gemarra-regular">in truth, it is permitted</span> in the case <span class="gemarra-regular">of wine </span>but not in the case of a cattle barn. The Gemara states that a Sage <span class="gemarra-regular">taught: They permitted </span>it in the case <span class="gemarra-regular">of win</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>the heat and the smoke <span class="gemarra-regular">improve </span>the wine. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>they did <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>permit one to establish <span class="gemarra-regular">a cattle barn, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>a barn <span class="gemarra-regular">creates a bad odor. Rav Yosef said: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>wine <span class="gemarra-regular">of ours </span>spoils quickly, and therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">even the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">smoke of a candle also damages it. Rav Sheshet said: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">And alfalfa [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ve’aspasta</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is considered like a cattle barn </span>in this regard, because it rots over time and creates a foul odor.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If a resident wants to open <span class="gemarra-regular">a store</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">courtyard</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> his neighbor <span class="gemarra-regular">can protest </span>to prevent <span class="gemarra-regular">him </span>from doing so <span class="gemarra-regular">and say to him: I am</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> unable to sleep due to the sound of people </span><span class="gemarra-regular">enterin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span> the store <span class="gemarra-regular">and the sound of people exiting. But </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">may fashion utensils </span>in his house and <span class="gemarra-regular">go out </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and sell </span>them <span class="gemarra-regular">in the market, </span>despite the fact that he is not allowed to set up a store in the courtyard, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the neighbor <span class="gemarra-regular">cannot protest </span>against <span class="gemarra-regular">him </span>doing so <span class="gemarra-regular">and say to him: I am unable to sleep </span><span class="gemarra-regular">due to the sound of the hammer </span>you use to fashion utensils, <span class="gemarra-regular">nor </span>can he say: I cannot sleep <span class="gemarra-regular">due </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to the sound of the mill </span>that you use to grind, <span class="gemarra-regular">nor </span>can he say: I cannot sleep <span class="gemarra-regular">due to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the sound of the children. </span>It is permitted for one to make reasonable use of his own home.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is different</span> in <span class="gemarra-regular">the first clause </span>of the mishna, which states that one can prevent his neighbor from opening a store in the courtyard because the noise keeps him awake, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">what is different </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">the latter clause, </span>which states that one cannot protest when his neighbor performs labor that is noisy? <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said: </span>In <span class="gemarra-regular">the latter clause we arrive at </span>the case of one who operates in <span class="gemarra-regular">another courtyard, </span>i.e., one cannot prevent activity in a separate courtyard that is connected to the alleyway in which he lives. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava </span><span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: If so, let it teach </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a different courtyard it is permitted. </span>Why does the mishna not specify that it is referring to a different courtyard? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Rava said: </span>

Daf 21a

In <span class="gemarra-regular">the latter clause we arrive at </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">schoolchildre</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> who come to learn Torah in his house, <span class="gemarra-regular">and</span> this ruling applies <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the time of <span class="gemarra-regular">the ordinance of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Yehoshua ben Gamla and onward.</span>
What was this ordinance? <span class="gemarra-regular">As</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rav Yehuda says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: Truly, that man is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> remembered for the good, and his name is Yehoshua ben</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Gamla</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> If not for him </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">Torah would have</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> been forgotten from the Jewish people. Initially, whoever had a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> father </span>would have his father <span class="gemarra-regular">teach him Torah, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">whoever</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> did not have a father would not learn Torah </span>at all. The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>verse <span class="gemarra-regular">did they interpret homiletically</span> that allowed them to conduct themselves in this manner? They interpreted the verse that states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And you shall teach </span><span class="gemarra-regular">them [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">otam</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] </span>to your sons” (Deuteronomy 11:19), to mean: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span><span class="gemarra-regular">you yourselves [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">atem</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] shall teach, </span>i.e., you fathers shall teach your sons.
When the Sages saw that not everyone was capable of teaching their children and Torah study was declining, <span class="gemarra-regular">they instituted </span>an ordinance <span class="gemarra-regular">that teachers of children should be established in </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Jerusalem. </span>The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>verse <span class="gemarra-regular">did they interpret homiletically </span>that enabled them to do this? They interpreted the verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“For Torah emerges from Zion” </span>(Isaiah 2:3). <span class="gemarra-regular">But still</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, whoever had a father, </span>his father <span class="gemarra-regular">ascended with him </span>to Jerusalem <span class="gemarra-regular">and had him taught, but whoever did not have</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a father, he did not ascend and learn. </span>Therefore, the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">instituted </span>an ordinance <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>teachers of children <span class="gemarra-regular">should be</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> established </span>in one city <span class="gemarra-regular">in each and every region [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">pelekh</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> And they brought </span>the students <span class="gemarra-regular">in at </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">age</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">sixtee</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> and <span class="gemarra-regular">at </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">age </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">seventeen.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>as the students were old and had not yet had any formal education, a student <span class="gemarra-regular">whose teacher </span><span class="gemarra-regular">grew angry at him </span>would <span class="gemarra-regular">rebel against him and leave. </span>It was impossible to hold the youths there against their will. This state of affairs continued <span class="gemarra-regular">until Yehoshua ben Gamla </span><span class="gemarra-regular">came and instituted </span>an ordinance <span class="gemarra-regular">that teachers of children should </span><span class="gemarra-regular">be establishe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in each and every province and in each</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and every town, and they </span>would <span class="gemarra-regular">bring </span>the children <span class="gemarra-regular">in</span> to learn <span class="gemarra-regular">at </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">age </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">six </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">at </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">age </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">seven</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> With regard to the matter at hand, since this system was established for the masses, the neighbors cannot prevent a scholar from teaching Torah in the courtyard.
Concerning that same issue, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav said to Rav Shmuel bar Sheilat, </span>a teacher of children: <span class="gemarra-regular">Do not accept </span>a student <span class="gemarra-regular">before </span>the age of <span class="gemarra-regular">six, </span>as he is too young, and it is difficult for him to learn in a steady manner. <span class="gemarra-regular">From this</span> point <span class="gemarra-regular">forward, accept him and stuff him </span>with Torah <span class="gemarra-regular">like</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> an ox. And Rav </span>further <span class="gemarra-regular">said to Rav Shmuel bar</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Sheilat: When you strike a chil</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> for educational purposes, <span class="gemarra-regular">hit him only with the strap of a sandal, </span>which is small and does not cause pain. Rav further advised him: <span class="gemarra-regular">He who reads, </span>let him <span class="gemarra-regular">read </span>on his own; <span class="gemarra-regular">whoever does not read, let him be a companion to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">his friends</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> which will encourage him to learn to read.
With regard to a courtyard, the Gemara concluded that it is permitted for one to establish an elementary school to teach Torah and the neighbors cannot protest. The Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises an objection </span>to this ruling from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span><span class="gemarra-regular">member of a courtyard who wishes to become a doctor</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a bloodletter, a weaver </span><span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">vegardi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> or a teacher </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of children, the </span>other <span class="gemarra-regular">members of the courtyard can prevent </span><span class="gemarra-regular">him </span>from doing so. This indicates that neighbors can protest the teaching of children in their shared courtyard. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">With what are we dealing here, </span>i.e., when can they protest his teaching children? We are dealing <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">gentile children</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as there is no mitzva to educate them. In this situation, the neighbors can protest about the noise.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>another <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">two people who are residing in </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">courtyard, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and one of them sought to become a doctor, a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">bloodletter, a weaver, or a teacher of children, the other </span><span class="gemarra-regular">can prevent him </span>from doing so. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Here </span><span class="gemarra-regular">too, </span>we are dealing <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">gentile children.</span>
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>another <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">One who has a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">house in a jointly owned courtyard may not rent i</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to a doctor, nor to a bloodletter, nor to a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> weaver, nor to a Jewish teacher [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">sofer</span><span class="gemarra-regular">], nor to a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> gentile teacher. </span>This indicates that one’s neighbors can prevent him from teaching Jewish children. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">With what</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> are we dealing here? </span>We are dealing <span class="gemarra-regular">with the scribe</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">sofer</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] of the town</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> who does not teach children but writes documents and letters for residents of the town. This type of work is not a mitzva, and since many people seek his services, the residents of the courtyard can prevent him from performing this job near their houses.
