§ With regard to the ordinance of Yehoshua ben Gamla, and concerning teaching children in general, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava says: From </span>the time of <span class="gemarra-regular">the ordinance of Yehoshua ben Gamla, </span>that schoolteachers must be established in each town, <span class="gemarra-regular">and onward, one does not bring</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a chil</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from one town to another. </span>Rather, each child is educated where he resides. <span class="gemarra-regular">But one does bring </span><span class="gemarra-regular">them from one synagogue </span>where they learn <span class="gemarra-regular">to another synagogue. </span><span class="gemarra-regular">And if a river separates </span>the areas <span class="gemarra-regular">one does not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">bring </span>the children across, lest they fall into the river. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if there is a bridge </span>spanning the river <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span><span class="gemarra-regular">may bring </span>them across the river. <span class="gemarra-regular">But if there is </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">a narrow bridge </span><span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">gamla</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> one does not bring </span>them.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rava said: </span>The maximum <span class="gemarra-regular">number </span>of students for one <span class="gemarra-regular">teache</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of children </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">twenty</span><span class="gemarra-regular">-five children. And if there are fifty </span>children in a single place, <span class="gemarra-regular">one establishes two </span>teachers, so that each one teaches twenty-five students. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if there are fort</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span> children, <span class="gemarra-regular">one establishes an assistant, and </span>the teacher <span class="gemarra-regular">receives help </span><span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the residents of <span class="gemarra-regular">the town </span>to pay the salary of the assistant.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rava said: </span>If there is <span class="gemarra-regular">a teacher of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">children who teaches </span>a few subjects, <span class="gemarra-regular">and there is another </span><span class="gemarra-regular">who teaches more </span>subjects <span class="gemarra-regular">than him, one does not remove </span>the first teacher from his position to hire the second, as <span class="gemarra-regular">perhaps </span>the other teacher <span class="gemarra-regular">will come to be negligen</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> due to the lack of competition. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Dimi from Neharde</span><span class="gemarra-regular">’a said: </span>On the contrary, <span class="gemarra-regular">all the more so </span>is it the case that he will <span class="gemarra-regular">teac</span><span class="gemarra-regular">h</span> in <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">better </span>manner if he knows that he is the sole instructor in the place, as <span class="gemarra-regular">jealousy among teachers increases wisdom. </span>The one who was dismissed will try to refine his skills so that he will be rehired, and this will prevent negligence on the part of the other teacher.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rava </span><span class="gemarra-regular">said: </span>If there are <span class="gemarra-regular">two teachers of children, one </span>who <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>a lot of material <span class="gemarra-regular">but is not precise </span>in his statements, <span class="gemarra-regular">and one </span>who <span class="gemarra-regular">is precise but does not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">teach </span>a lot of material, <span class="gemarra-regular">one hires the one who </span><span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>a lot of material <span class="gemarra-regular">but is not precise. </span>Why is this? <span class="gemarra-regular">Errors will be corrected by themselves, </span>and no lasting harm will be caused. By contrast, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Dimi of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Neharde’a said: One hires </span>the instructor <span class="gemarra-regular">who is precis</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and does not teach </span>a lot of material, <span class="gemarra-regular">as once</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> an error is taught, it is taught, </span>and cannot be easily corrected.
The Gemara cites a proof for the opinion of Rav Dimi of Neharde’a: This is <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is written: “For Joab and all Israel remained</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> there six months until he had cut off every male</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in Edom” </span>(I Kings 11:16). <span class="gemarra-regular">When </span>Joab <span class="gemarra-regular">came before </span>King <span class="gemarra-regular">David </span>after this episode, David <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>

Daf 21b

<span class="gemarra-regular">What</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is the reason </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">you did that? </span>Why did you kill only the males? Joab <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: As it</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is written: You shall blot out the males [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">zakhar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Amalek, </span>i.e., the male descendants of Amalek, who descend from Edom. David <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: But we read </span>the verse as stating: <span class="gemarra-regular">“You shall blot out the remembrance</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">zekher</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] of Amalek” </span>(Deuteronomy 25:19). Joab <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: I was taught to read it as </span><span class="gemarra-italic">zakhar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>Joab <span class="gemarra-regular">went and asked his </span>childhood Bible <span class="gemarra-regular">teacher. </span>Joab <span class="gemarra-regular">said to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> him: How did you read </span>this word <span class="gemarra-regular">to us</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> The teacher <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>I read it as <span class="gemarra-italic">zekher</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>The teacher had read it the proper way, but he failed to notice that his student had learned it incorrectly.
Joab <span class="gemarra-regular">took a sword to kill him. </span>The teacher <span class="gemarra-regular">said</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to him: Why </span>do you want to kill me? Joab <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: As it is written: “Cursed is he</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> who does the work of the Lord with a slack</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> hand” </span>(Jeremiah 48:10), and you taught me incorrectly. The teacher <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Leave that man to remain </span><span class="gemarra-regular">as cursed. </span>This is a sufficient punishment; there is no need to kill me. Joab <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: It is </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">written: “And cursed is he who keeps back his </span><span class="gemarra-regular">sword from blood” </span>(Jeremiah 48:10). <span class="gemarra-regular">There are </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">who say</span> that Joab <span class="gemarra-regular">killed him, and there are </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">who say</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">he did not kill him. </span>In any event, this episode demonstrates that an error learned in one’s childhood stays with him his whole life.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rava says: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a teacher of children</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> a professional <span class="gemarra-regular">tree planter</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a butcher</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a bloodletter</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, and a town scribe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> all </span>these <span class="gemarra-regular">are considered forewarned</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>In other words, they need not be exhorted to perform their jobs correctly, as if they err in the performance of their duties they can be dismissed immediately. The <span class="gemarra-regular">principle</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of the matter </span>is: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">any </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">where loss is irreversible, </span>the individual <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">forewarned.</span>
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Huna said: </span>There was <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain resident of an alleyway</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> who set up a mill </span>in the alleyway and earned his living grinding grain for people. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>subsequently <span class="gemarra-regular">another resident</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of the alleyway came and set up </span>a mill <span class="gemarra-regular">next</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to his. The </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is that </span>the first one <span class="gemarra-regular">may</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> prevent him </span>from doing so if he wishes, <span class="gemarra-regular">as he</span> can <span class="gemarra-regular">say to him: You are disrupting my livelihood </span>by taking my customers.
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Let us say </span>that a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">supports his </span>opinion: <span class="gemarra-regular">One must distance fish traps from fish</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., from other fish traps, <span class="gemarra-regular">as far as the fish travels, </span>i.e., the distance from which the fish will travel. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And how much </span>is this distance? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba </span><span class="gemarra-regular">bar Rav Huna says: Up to a parasang [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">parsa</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]. </span>This indicates that one must distance himself from the place where another has established his business. The Gemara responds that this is no proof: Perhaps <span class="gemarra-regular">fish are different, as they look </span><span class="gemarra-regular">around</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> One fish explores the area ahead of the others, indicating to them where to go. Once they encounter the first trap they will not approach the second.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Ravina said to Rava: Shall we say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna spoke in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda? As we learned </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Bava</span> <span class="it-text">Metzia</span> 60a): <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda says: A storekeeper may not hand out </span><span class="gemarra-regular">toasted grain and nut</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to children </span>who patronize his store, <span class="gemarra-regular">due to </span>the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that he </span>thereby <span class="gemarra-regular">accustoms them to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> come to him </span>at the expense of competing storekeepers. <span class="gemarra-regular">And</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the Rabbis permit </span>doing so. This indicates that according to the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda, all forms of competition are prohibited, which would include the scenario concerning the mill.
The Gemara rejects this suggestion: <span class="gemarra-regular">You </span>may <span class="gemarra-regular">even say </span>that Rav Huna holds in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. The Rabbis disagree with Rabbi Yehuda only there, as </span>the storekeeper <span class="gemarra-regular">can say to </span>his competitor: If <span class="gemarra-regular">I distribute walnuts</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, you </span>can <span class="gemarra-regular">distribute almonds [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">shiyuskei</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> But here, </span>with regard to a resident of an alleyway who sets up a mill in that alleyway where another mill already exists, <span class="gemarra-regular">even</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the Rabbis concede that </span>the owner of the first mill can <span class="gemarra-regular">say to him: You are disrupting my livelihood, </span>as beforehand whoever required grinding came to me, and you have provided them with another option.
The Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises an</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> objection </span>from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">A man may establish a shop</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> alongside the shop of another, and a bathhouse alongside the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> bathhouse of another, and </span>the other <span class="gemarra-regular">cannot protest, because </span>the newcomer <span class="gemarra-regular">can say to him: You operate in your </span>space, <span class="gemarra-regular">and I operate in my </span>space.
The Gemara answers: This entire matter <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>a dispute between <span class="gemarra-italic">tanna’im</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">The residents </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of an alleyway can compel one anothe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> to agree <span class="gemarra-regular">not</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to allow among the</span><span class="gemarra-regular">m</span> in that alleyway <span class="gemarra-regular">a tailor, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a tanner, a teacher of children, nor any type of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">craftsman. </span>They can bar outside craftsmen from plying their trade in that alleyway. <span class="gemarra-regular">But one cannot compel his neighbor, </span>i.e., one who already lives in the alleyway, to refrain from practicing a particular occupation there. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel </span><span class="gemarra-regular">says: </span>One can <span class="gemarra-regular">even compel his neighbor </span>not to conduct such work in the alleyway. Rav Huna holds in accordance with the opinion of Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna, son of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rav Yehoshua, says: </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious to me </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> resident of </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">town can prevent a resident of another</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> town </span>from establishing a similar business in the locale of the first individual. <span class="gemarra-regular">But if he pays the ta</span><span class="gemarra-regular">x</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">of that </span>first town, <span class="gemarra-regular">he cannot prevent him </span>from doing business there, as he too is considered a resident of the town. <span class="gemarra-regular">The resident of an alleyway cannot prevent a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> resident of his alleyway </span>from practicing a particular trade there, in accordance with the opinion of the Rabbis in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, and contrary to the opinion of Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel.
With these conclusions in mind, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, raises a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">dilemma: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a resident of </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">alleyway </span>protesting about <span class="gemarra-regular">a resident of another alleywa</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span> conducting business there, <span class="gemarra-regular">what</span> is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? No answer was found, and the Gemara states that the dilemma <span class="gemarra-regular">shall stand </span>unresolved. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef said</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: And Rav Huna, </span>who said that a resident of an alleyway can prevent another from setting up an additional mill, <span class="gemarra-regular">concedes with regard to those who teach childre</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that </span><span class="gemarra-regular">one cannot prevent </span>him from working, <span class="gemarra-regular">as the Master said: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Ezra institute</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> an ordinance <span class="gemarra-regular">for the Jewish people </span>requiring <span class="gemarra-regular">that</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> they establish </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">teacher alongside </span>another <span class="gemarra-regular">teacher, </span>to raise the standard of teaching.
The Gemara challenges: <span class="gemarra-regular">And let us be concerned lest </span>the teachers <span class="gemarra-regular">will </span>thereby <span class="gemarra-regular">come to be negligent. </span>Rav Yosef <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>the Sage who raised this objection: 

Daf 22a

<span class="gemarra-regular">Jealousy among teachers increases wisdom.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman </span><span class="gemarra-regular">bar Yitzḥak said: And Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, </span>who said that townspeople can bar craftsmen who come from other cities, <span class="gemarra-regular">concedes with regard to </span>perfume <span class="gemarra-regular">salesmen who travel</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">town </span>to another <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the townspeople <span class="gemarra-regular">cannot </span><span class="gemarra-regular">prevent </span>them from entering their town. <span class="gemarra-regular">As the Master said: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Ezra instituted </span>an ordinance <span class="gemarra-regular">for the Jewish people that </span>perfume <span class="gemarra-regular">salesmen shall travel from town to town so that cosmetics </span><span class="gemarra-regular">will be available to Jewish women. </span>Since this ordinance was instituted on behalf of Jewish women, the Sages ruled that these peddlers could not be barred from entering a town.
The Gemara continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">And this matter </span>applies only to one who seeks <span class="gemarra-regular">to travel </span>from town to town as a salesman. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if he wants <span class="gemarra-regular">to establish </span>a shop, this ruling was <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>stated, and the townspeople can prevent him from doing so. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if he is a Torah schola</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he may</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> even establish </span>a shop as a perfume salesman. This is <span class="gemarra-regular">like that </span>incident in <span class="gemarra-regular">which Rava permitted Rabbi Yoshiya and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rav Ovadya to establish </span>a shop <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>in accordance <span class="gemarra-regular">with</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. What is the reason </span>for this ruling? The reason is that <span class="gemarra-regular">since they are rabbis, they are </span><span class="gemarra-regular">likely to be distracted from their studies </span>should they be required to travel from place to place.
§ The Gemara relates: There were <span class="gemarra-regular">these basket seller</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> who brought baskets </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to Babylonia. The townspeople came </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">prevented them </span>from selling there. The two parties <span class="gemarra-regular">came before Ravina </span>for a ruling. Ravina <span class="gemarra-regular">said to them: </span>The basket sellers <span class="gemarra-regular">came from outsid</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> the town, <span class="gemarra-regular">and they sell to </span>those from <span class="gemarra-regular">outsid</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> the town, i.e., to guests who are not residents of the town. The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">And this statement </span>applies only <span class="gemarra-regular">on a market day, </span>when people from other towns come to shop, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>they may <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>sell their wares <span class="gemarra-regular">on non-market days. And even with regard to market</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> days, we say </span>so <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>with regard <span class="gemarra-regular">to selling in</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the market, but </span>this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> does <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>apply <span class="gemarra-regular">to circulating</span> around the town.
The Gemara further relates: There were <span class="gemarra-regular">these wool sellers who</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> brought wool to </span>the city of <span class="gemarra-regular">Pum Nahara. The townsfolk</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> came </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">prevented them </span>from selling it. The two parties <span class="gemarra-regular">came before Rav Kahana </span>for a ruling. Rav Kahana <span class="gemarra-regular">said</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to them: The </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is that they may prevent you</span> from selling your wares. The wool sellers <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">him: We have debts </span>to collect in the city, and we must sell our wares in the meantime to sustain ourselves until we are paid. Rav Kahana <span class="gemarra-regular">said to them: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Go </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">sell the amount </span>needed <span class="gemarra-regular">to sustain yourselves until </span><span class="gemarra-regular">you have collected your debts, and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">leave.</span>
§ The Gemara relates: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Dimi of Neharde’a brought </span><span class="gemarra-regular">dried figs on a ship </span>to sell them. <span class="gemarra-regular">The Exilarch </span><span class="gemarra-regular">said to Rava: Go </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">see; if he is a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Torah scholar, reserve the market for him</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., declare that he has the exclusive right to sell dried figs. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said to </span>his student <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Adda bar Abba</span><span class="gemarra-regular">:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Go </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">smell his jar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., determine whether or not Rav Dimi is a Torah scholar.
Rav Adda bar Abba <span class="gemarra-regular">went </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">asked </span>Rav Dimi a question: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">an elephant that swallowe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a wicker baske</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">excreted it </span>intact along <span class="gemarra-regular">with its waste, what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? Is the vessel still susceptible to ritual impurity or is it considered digested and not susceptible to impurity? An answer <span class="gemarra-regular">was not available to </span>Rav Dimi. Rav Dimi <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>Rav Adda bar Abba: <span class="gemarra-regular">Is the Master Rava, </span>i.e., are you Rava, as you have asked me such a difficult question? Rav Adda bar Abba <span class="gemarra-regular">struck him on </span><span class="gemarra-regular">his shoe </span>in a disparaging way and <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">There is a great </span>difference <span class="gemarra-regular">between me and Rava; but </span><span class="gemarra-regular">I am perforce your teacher, and Rava is your teacher’</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s teacher.</span>
Based on this exchange, Rav Adda bar Abba decided that Rav Dimi was not a great Torah scholar, and therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">he did not reserve the market for him, and </span>Rav Dimi <span class="gemarra-regular">lost his dried figs, </span>as they rotted. Rav Dimi <span class="gemarra-regular">came before Rav Yosef </span>to complain, and <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">The Master </span>should <span class="gemarra-regular">see what they did to me. </span>Rav Yosef <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: He Who did not delay </span>retribution for <span class="gemarra-regular">the humiliation of the King of Edom should not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">delay </span>His response to <span class="gemarra-regular">your humiliation, </span>but should punish whoever distressed you, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is written: “So says the Lord: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">For three transgressions of Moab, indeed for four I will </span><span class="gemarra-regular">not reverse for him, because he burned the bones of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the King of Edom into lime” </span>(Amos 2:1).
The Gemara reports that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Adda bar</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Abba died. Rav Yosef said: I punished him</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., I am to blame for his death, <span class="gemarra-regular">as I</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> cursed him. Rav Dimi from Neharde’a said: I punished</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> him, as he caused my loss of dried figs. Abaye</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> said: I punished him, </span>i.e., he was punished on my account because he did not exhibit the proper respect for me. <span class="gemarra-regular">As </span>Rav Adda bar Abba <span class="gemarra-regular">said to the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Sages: Instead of gnawing the bones in the school of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Abaye, you </span>would do <span class="gemarra-regular">better </span>to <span class="gemarra-regular">eat fatty meat in</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the school of Rava, </span>i.e., it is preferable to study with Rava than with Abaye. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rava said: I</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> punished him, as when he would go to the butcher</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to buy a piece of meat, he would say to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the butchers: I will take meat before Rava’s servant</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, as I am greater than he is</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: I</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> punished him, </span>i.e., he was punished because of me, <span class="gemarra-regular">as Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak was the head of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kalla</span> lectures, the gatherings for Torah study during Elul and Adar. Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak would teach the students immediately following the lesson taught by the head of the academy. <span class="gemarra-regular">Every day, before he went in for the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kalla</span> lecture, <span class="gemarra-regular">he reviewed his lecture with Rav Adda bar Abba</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, and then he would enter </span>the study hall <span class="gemarra-regular">for the</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">kalla</span> lecture.
On <span class="gemarra-regular">that day Rav Pappa and Rav Huna, son</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of Rav Yehoshua, seized Rav Adda bar Abba, because they</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> had not been present at the conclusion </span>of Rava’s lecture. <span class="gemarra-regular">They said to him: Tell us how Rava stated</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> these </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakhot</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of animal tithe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Rav Adda bar Abba <span class="gemarra-regular">said to them: Rava said this and Rava said that</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. Meanwhile, it grew late for Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak, and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rav Adda bar Abba </span>had <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>yet <span class="gemarra-regular">arrived.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages said to Rav Naḥman bar</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Yitzḥak: Arise </span>and teach us, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is late for</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> us. Why does the Master sit </span>and wait? Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak <span class="gemarra-regular">said to them: I am sitting and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">waiting for the bier of Rav Adda bar Abba, </span>who has presumably died. <span class="gemarra-regular">Meanwhile, a rumor emerged that Rav Adda </span><span class="gemarra-regular">bar Abba had </span>indeed <span class="gemarra-regular">died. </span>The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">And so </span><span class="gemarra-regular">too, it is reasonable </span>to conclude that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman bar </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Yitzḥak punished him, </span>i.e., he died as a result of Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak’s statement, as the unfortunate event occurred just as he announced that Rav Adda bar Abba’s bier was on its way.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">One whose wall was close to the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">wal</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">of another may not </span>build <span class="gemarra-regular">another wall close </span>to the neighbor’s wall <span class="gemarra-regular">unless he distances it four cubits</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from </span>the wall of the neighbor. And one who desires to build a wall opposite <span class="gemarra-regular">the windows </span>of a neighbor’s house must distance the wall <span class="gemarra-regular">four cubits </span>from the windows, <span class="gemarra-regular">whether </span><span class="gemarra-regular">above</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">below, or opposite.</span>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara comments: Before addressing the construction of the second wall, one could ask: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>with regard to the <span class="gemarra-regular">first </span>man, <span class="gemarra-regular">how did he</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> place </span>his wall <span class="gemarra-regular">close </span>to the neighbor’s wall in the first place? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">this is what</span> the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is saying: </span>

Daf 22b

<span class="gemarra-regular">One who comes to place </span>a wall <span class="gemarra-regular">close </span>to his neighbor’s wall <span class="gemarra-regular">may place </span>that wall <span class="gemarra-regular">close </span>to the neighbor’s wall <span class="gemarra-regular">only if he distances </span>his wall <span class="gemarra-regular">four cubits from the existing wall. </span>Accordingly, the mishna is discussing one constructing a wall close to his neighbor’s wall the first time. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava objects to this </span>explanation: <span class="gemarra-regular">But</span> the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches: One whose wall was near the wall</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of another</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> which indicates that there had already been a wall there.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Rava said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">this</span> is what the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">is teaching: </span>In a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one whose wal</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> was near the wall of anothe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> at a distance of four cubits and </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">fell, he</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> may not place another wall close </span>to his neighbor’s wall <span class="gemarra-regular">unless he distances </span>the wall <span class="gemarra-regular">four cubits from it</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. What is the reason </span>that this distance must be observed? The reason is <span class="gemarra-regular">that walking here benefits there, </span>i.e., the ground is strengthened by people walking on the land in the area between the walls.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: They taught </span>that one must leave a space of four cubits between his wall and that of his neighbor <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>if he builds it alongside <span class="gemarra-regular">the wall</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of </span>his neighbor’s <span class="gemarra-regular">garden</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> where people do not usually walk due to the seeds. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">the wall of a courtyard, </span>where people walk, <span class="gemarra-regular">if he</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> comes to place </span>his wall <span class="gemarra-regular">close </span>by, <span class="gemarra-regular">he may </span><span class="gemarra-regular">place </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">close </span>by. By contrast, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Oshaya says: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">both the wall of a garden and the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> wall of a courtyard, if one comes to place </span>his wall <span class="gemarra-regular">close </span>by, <span class="gemarra-regular">he may not place </span>his wall <span class="gemarra-regular">close </span>by.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei bar Ḥanina said: And </span>the two <span class="it-text">amora’im</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">do not disagree, </span>as they are referring to different cases. <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>statement of Rav is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to an </span><span class="gemarra-regular">old city, </span>whose ground is well trodden and stable, and <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>statement of Rabbi Oshaya is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to a new </span><span class="gemarra-regular">city, </span>where even the wall of a courtyard requires walking on its adjacent ground to strengthen it.
With regard to the claim that the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of the mishna is due to the need for space for people to walk on the ground between the walls, the Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">We learned </span>in the mishna: And one who desires to build a wall opposite <span class="gemarra-regular">the windows </span>of a neighbor’s house must distance the wall <span class="gemarra-regular">four cubits </span>from the windows, <span class="gemarra-regular">whether above</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> below</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> or opposite. And it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to thi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> ruling: Concerning the requirement of a distance <span class="gemarra-regular">above, </span>the wall must be high <span class="gemarra-regular">enough so that</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> one cannot peer </span>into the window <span class="gemarra-regular">and see </span>into the window; concerning the requirement of a distance <span class="gemarra-regular">below, </span>the wall must be low <span class="gemarra-regular">so that he will not </span>be able to <span class="gemarra-regular">stand </span>on top of it <span class="gemarra-regular">and see </span>into the window; <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>concerning the requirement of a distance <span class="gemarra-regular">opposite</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>one must distance the wall from the windows <span class="gemarra-regular">so that</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it will not darken </span>his neighbor’s house by blocking the light that enters the house through the window.
The Gemara analyzes this statement: The <span class="gemarra-regular">reason </span>that distance is required opposite the window is so <span class="gemarra-regular">that he</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> will not darken </span>his neighbor’s house by blocking the light that enters the house through the window, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">not due to </span>the fact that <span class="gemarra-regular">walking </span>will strengthen the ground. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">With what are we dealing</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> here? </span>We are dealing with a wall <span class="gemarra-regular">that is positioned</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to the side</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., perpendicular to the wall with the window in it, and therefore it blocks the light from entering the house through the window but does not prevent walking along the length of the neighbor’s wall.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And how fa</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> must one distance his wall if it is perpendicular to the other wall? <span class="gemarra-regular">Yeiva, the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">father-in-law of Ashyan bar Nidbakh, says in the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">name of Rav: </span>As much <span class="gemarra-regular">as the full width of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the window</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>why is this sufficient? <span class="gemarra-regular">Can’t he </span>still <span class="gemarra-regular">peer int</span><span class="gemarra-regular">o</span> the window if he is that close? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Zevid says: </span>This is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to one who slopes his wall, </span>i.e., he fashions an incline on the upper surface of the wall so that he will not be able to stand on top of it and look through the window.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But didn’t we learn </span>in the mishna that one must keep the wall <span class="gemarra-regular">four cubits </span>away from the window? The Gemara answers: This is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult; here, </span>he builds the wall <span class="gemarra-regular">on one side </span>of the window, whereas <span class="gemarra-regular">there, </span>in the mishna, he builds walls <span class="gemarra-regular">on two side</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> of the window. In the latter case, if he builds the walls any closer he will block the light from entering the house through the window even if they are perpendicular.
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a further difficulty from the mishna below with regard to the claim that the requisite gap between the walls is for the purpose of walking, as the mishna teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>one must distance his <span class="gemarra-regular">wall four cubits from a roof gutter </span><span class="gemarra-regular">so that </span>his neighbor <span class="gemarra-regular">can lean a ladder </span>in the empty space to clean and repair the gutter. The Gemara analyzes this statement: The <span class="gemarra-regular">reason </span>this distance is required is <span class="gemarra-regular">due to </span>the fact that he will be able to lean <span class="gemarra-regular">a ladder, but </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">not due to </span>the fact that <span class="gemarra-regular">walking </span>will strengthen the ground. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">With what are we dealing here? </span>We are dealing <span class="gemarra-regular">with</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a sloping roof gutter, </span>which protrudes beyond the boundary of the wall. <span class="gemarra-regular">As </span>in this case, <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>the reason for distancing the wall <span class="gemarra-regular">is due to walking, one can </span><span class="gemarra-regular">walk back and forth beneath it. </span>Nevertheless, a distance of four cubits from the roof gutter is required so that repairs can be performed.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">One must distance </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">ladder </span><span class="gemarra-regular">fou</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">cubits from </span>a neighbor’s <span class="gemarra-regular">dovecote so that a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">mongoos</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">will not </span>be able to <span class="gemarra-regular">jump </span>from the ladder to the dovecote and devour the birds. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>one must distance his <span class="gemarra-regular">wall four</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> cubits from a roof </span><span class="gemarra-regular">gutter</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">so that </span>the neighbor <span class="gemarra-regular">can lean</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">ladde</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r </span>in the empty space to clean and repair the gutter.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">Let us say that the mishna is not</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei, as, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>it were in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Yosei, doesn’t </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>with regard to planting a tree next to a neighbor’s cistern: <span class="gemarra-regular">This one digs </span><span class="gemarra-regular">within his </span>land, <span class="gemarra-regular">and that one plants within his </span>land, and neither individual need consider what is happening in the property of the other?
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">You </span>may <span class="gemarra-regular">even say </span>that the mishna follows the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei, </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">didn’t Rav Ashi say: When </span><span class="gemarra-regular">we were </span>studying <span class="gemarra-regular">in the study hall of Rav Kahana, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">he would say </span>to us that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei concedes with </span><span class="gemarra-regular">regard to his arrows</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., he concedes that one must distance himself if his actions will cause damage to his neighbor. <span class="gemarra-regular">Here too, sometimes when he places </span>the ladder, the mongoose might be <span class="gemarra-regular">sitting in a hole and </span>will immediately <span class="gemarra-regular">jump </span>up and climb the ladder to the dovecote. The Gemara challenges: <span class="gemarra-regular">But that is indirect </span>damage, as he is not the immediate cause. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Tovi bar Mattana </span><span class="gemarra-regular">said: That is to say </span>that it <span class="gemarra-regular">is prohibited </span>to cause even <span class="gemarra-regular">indirect damage</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
The Gemara relates: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef had </span><span class="gemarra-regular">certain small palm trees [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">talei</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and

Daf 23a

<span class="gemarra-regular">bloodletters </span>would <span class="gemarra-regular">come and sit beneath them </span>and perform their work there, <span class="gemarra-regular">and crows </span>would <span class="gemarra-regular">come, eat the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> blood, and fly up to the palm trees and damage</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the dates. Rav Yosef said to </span>the bloodletters: <span class="gemarra-regular">Remove </span><span class="gemarra-regular">these crowing </span>birds <span class="gemarra-regular">from here, </span>i.e., leave in order to avoid further damage. <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said to him: But it</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is an indirect </span>action, as the bloodletters themselves are not damaging the dates. Rav Yosef <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Tovi bar Mattana said </span>as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">That is to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that it <span class="gemarra-regular">is prohibited </span>to cause even <span class="gemarra-regular">indirect damage.</span>
Abaye said to Rav Yosef: <span class="gemarra-regular">But they have established an acquired </span><span class="gemarra-regular">privilege </span>to use that particular spot for their work. Rav Yosef replied: <span class="gemarra-regular">Doesn’t Rav Naḥman say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba bar </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Avuh says: There is no acquired privilege </span>of use <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>cases of <span class="gemarra-regular">damage</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., an established situation may not be allowed to continue in the event that damage results. Abaye inquired further: <span class="gemarra-regular">But wasn’t it stated with </span><span class="gemarra-regular">regard to that </span>statement of Rav Naḥman that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Mari </span><span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>it is referring specifically <span class="gemarra-regular">to smoke, and Rav Zevid </span><span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>it is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to a bathroom</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> In other words, this principle was stated specifically in the context of damage caused by these substances. Rav Yosef <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">For me, as I am sensitive</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> these are like </span><span class="gemarra-regular">smoke and a bathroom to me, </span>which is why I have the right to demand that the bloodletters leave.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">One must distance a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">dovecot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">fifty cubits from the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">cit</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span> to prevent doves from eating seeds in the town. <span class="gemarra-regular">And a person should not establish</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a dovecote within his own </span>property <span class="gemarra-regular">unless he has fifty</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> cubits in each direction </span>between the dovecote and the edge of his property. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda says </span>that one must have surrounding the dovecote the <span class="gemarra-regular">area required for sowing four </span><span class="gemarra-italic">ko</span><span class="gemarra-italic">r</span> of seed on each side, which generally extends <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span><span class="gemarra-regular">far as a dove flies </span>in a single flight. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span><span class="gemarra-regular">if one bought </span>the dovecote with the land, <span class="gemarra-regular">he has </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the acquired privilege </span>of its use <span class="gemarra-regular">even if </span>it has surrounding it only the <span class="gemarra-regular">area required for sowing a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">quarter-</span><span class="gemarra-italic">kav</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of seed [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">beit</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">rova</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] </span>around it, and he need not remove it from there.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: Must one distance a dovecote only <span class="gemarra-regular">fifty cubits </span>from the city <span class="gemarra-regular">and no more? </span>Is that as far as one can expect a dove to fly? <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">contradiction </span>from a mishna (<span class="it-text">Bava</span> <span class="it-text">Kamma</span> 79b): One <span class="gemarra-regular">may spread </span><span class="gemarra-regular">out traps [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">neshavin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] </span><span class="gemarra-regular">for doves only if </span>this was performed <span class="gemarra-regular">at a distance of </span>at least <span class="gemarra-regular">thirty </span><span class="gemarra-italic">ris</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>or four <span class="it-text">mil</span>, which is eight thousand cubits, <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>any <span class="gemarra-regular">settled </span><span class="gemarra-regular">area</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> to avoid catching birds that belong to another. Apparently, doves fly a distance of thirty <span class="it-text">ris</span>, whereas the mishna here states fifty cubits.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said: </span>Doves do <span class="gemarra-regular">fly great distances, </span>which is why one must avoid catching others’ birds by keeping traps thirty <span class="it-text">ris</span> away from settled areas. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>as they eat along their way, <span class="gemarra-regular">their stomachs are filled </span>after a distance of <span class="gemarra-regular">fifty cubits, </span>at which point they will do no more damage to seeds. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And do they fly</span> only <span class="gemarra-regular">thirty </span><span class="gemarra-italic">ris</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and no more? But isn’t it</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">And in a settled area, </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">may not spread out </span>a trap <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>if the area under his control extends as far as <span class="gemarra-regular">one hundred </span><span class="gemarra-italic">mil</span> in each direction? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef says: </span>That <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to a settled area of vineyards, </span>i.e., a contiguous region of vineyards and gardens. In that case the doves pass from place to place even over a great distance.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: </span>The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">settled area of dovecotes, </span>i.e., where many dovecotes are distributed. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>according to Rava, <span class="gemarra-regular">let </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">derive </span>that one may not establish a new dovecote there <span class="gemarra-regular">due to </span>the other <span class="gemarra-regular">dovecotes themselves, </span>as he will trap doves belonging to others. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">If you</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> wish, say </span>that this is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">his own </span>dovecotes. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if you wish, say </span>it is referring to the dovecotes of <span class="gemarra-regular">a gentile</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> whose property one is not obligated to protect from harm. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if you wish, say</span> it is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to ownerless </span>dovecotes.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda says </span>that one must have surrounding the dovecote the <span class="gemarra-regular">area required for sowing four </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kor</span> of seed on each side, which is as far as a dove flies in a single flight. And if one bought the dovecote with the land, he has the acquired privilege of its use. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa said, and some say </span>it was <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Zevid: That is to say </span>that a court <span class="gemarra-regular">issues a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> claim </span>on behalf <span class="gemarra-regular">of a buyer</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and issues a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> claim </span>on behalf <span class="gemarra-regular">of an heir. </span>This is referring to the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of taking possession. If one has been physically in possession of an item for a period of time, generally three years, this serves as proof that he is in fact the legal owner. This possession must be accompanied by a claim of how one acquired the item; he cannot simply state that no one protested his possessing the item for three years. Rav Pappa is saying that the court will lodge a claim on behalf of a buyer or heir that they acquired the item from someone who was the owner, just as here the court assumes that the previous owner of the dovecote came to an agreement with his neighbors that he may use it.
The Gemara asks: Why is it necessary for Rav Pappa to state this <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? <span class="gemarra-regular">We </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">learn </span>this with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">an </span><span class="gemarra-regular">heir </span>(41a): In the case of land <span class="gemarra-regular">that comes </span><span class="gemarra-regular">as an inheritance, one is not required to make a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">claim </span>as to how the land came into his benefactor’s possession when one’s ownership of the land is challenged. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">It was necessary for him </span>to state this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a buyer. </span>The Gemara asks: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a buyer as well, we learn</span> this in a mishna (60a): If one <span class="gemarra-regular">bought a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">courtyard in which there are projections and balconies [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ugzuztraot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> extending into the public domain, this courtyard <span class="gemarra-regular">retains its presumptive </span><span class="gemarra-regular">status, </span>i.e., the owner has the acquired privilege of their use, and the court does not demand their removal.
The Gemara answers: It was <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>for the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> of the mishna to state this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in both cases, <span class="gemarra-regular">as, if he had</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> taught us this </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">there, </span>in that mishna, one might have said that it applies specifically <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>a protrusion or a balcony that extends into <span class="gemarra-regular">the public </span><span class="gemarra-regular">domain, as </span>one can <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that perhaps <span class="gemarra-regular">it is </span>a case where the seller had <span class="gemarra-regular">drawn back into his own </span>land before adding the projections and balconies, and they in fact do not extend into the public thoroughfare. <span class="gemarra-regular">Alternatively, </span>perhaps <span class="gemarra-regular">the public waived </span>their right <span class="gemarra-regular">to him </span>and allowed him to place them over the common area, as otherwise they would have protested. <span class="gemarra-regular">But here, </span>where he causes damage to private individuals, one might have thought that the buyer does <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>have a privilege of use, and therefore the mishna teaches us otherwise.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if </span><span class="gemarra-regular">he had taught this </span>only in the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">here, </span>one might <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">since </span>the party potentially suffering damage <span class="gemarra-regular">is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> an individual, </span>the owner of the dovecote <span class="gemarra-regular">appeased </span>his neighbor by paying him to permit him to construct it. <span class="gemarra-regular">Alternatively, </span>the neighbor might have <span class="gemarra-regular">waived </span>his right <span class="gemarra-regular">to him. </span><span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>in a case where damage is caused to <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">public, </span>one might argue: <span class="gemarra-regular">Whom did he appease</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">who yielded </span>to him? Consequently, one might <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that the purchaser does <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>retain the privilege of use. Therefore, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>for the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> to state the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in this case as well.
§ The mishna teaches that if one bought the dovecote with the land, <span class="gemarra-regular">he has the acquired privilege </span>of use. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But doesn’t Rav Naḥman say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba bar Avuh</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> says: There is no acquired privilege </span>of use <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>cases of <span class="gemarra-regular">damage? </span>Why should he retain his acquired privilege of use when his doves cause damage? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Mari said: </span>Rav Naḥman’s statement is referring specifically <span class="gemarra-regular">to smoke, </span>which causes serious damage, and that is why it overrides an acquired privilege. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Zevid said: </span>It is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to a bathroom</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>whose odor is particularly strong. 

Daf 23b

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to a dove <span class="gemarra-regular">chick [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">nippul</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that was foun</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> within fifty cubits </span>of a dovecote, <span class="gemarra-regular">it belongs to the owner of the dovecote. </span>If it was found <span class="gemarra-regular">beyond fifty cubits </span>from a dovecote, <span class="gemarra-regular">it </span><span class="gemarra-regular">belongs to its finder. </span>In a case where it <span class="gemarra-regular">was </span><span class="gemarra-regular">found between two dovecotes, </span>if it was <span class="gemarra-regular">close to this </span><span class="gemarra-regular">one, </span>it belongs <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the owner of this dovecote; if it was <span class="gemarra-regular">close to that one, </span>it belongs <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the owner of that dovecote. If it was <span class="gemarra-regular">half and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">half, </span>i.e., equidistant from the two dovecotes, <span class="gemarra-regular">the two </span>owners <span class="gemarra-regular">divide </span>the value of the chick.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ḥanina says: </span>When resolving an uncertainty with regard to the halakhic status of an item, e.g., a found item, if the status of the <span class="gemarra-regular">majority </span>of like items indicates that it has one status <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>the item in question is <span class="gemarra-regular">proximat</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> to a source that indicates otherwise, one <span class="gemarra-regular">follows the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">majority</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">And even though </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">majority </span>applies <span class="gemarra-regular">by </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Torah law and </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">of proximity </span>also applies <span class="gemarra-regular">by </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Torah law, even so the majority is preferable.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Zeira raises an objection </span>from the Torah’s statement with regard to a murder victim where the identity of the murderer is unknown. In a case of this kind, the court measures the distances between the corpse and the nearby towns, in order to determine which town is closest and must consequently perform the rite of the heifer whose neck is broken. The verse states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And it shall be, that</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the city that is nearest to the slain man, </span>the Elders of that city shall take a heifer of the herd…and shall break the heifer’s neck” (Deuteronomy 21:3–4). <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>this town is chosen <span class="gemarra-regular">even though there </span>might <span class="gemarra-regular">be another </span>town <span class="gemarra-regular">that is large</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> in population <span class="gemarra-regular">than </span><span class="gemarra-regular">it. </span>According to Rabbi Ḥanina, in a case of this kind one should follow the majority.
The Gemara answers: This verse is referring to a situation <span class="gemarra-regular">where there is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">no </span>other town that is larger than that one. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>still, if one follows the majority, why should the court follow the closest city? <span class="gemarra-regular">Let us follow</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the majority of the world, </span>as most people are found elsewhere. The Gemara answers: This is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>a case where the city <span class="gemarra-regular">sits </span>in isolation <span class="gemarra-regular">between mountains, </span>and therefore it is unlikely that the murderer arrived from elsewhere.
The Gemara continues to discuss the issue of majority as opposed to proximity. <span class="gemarra-regular">We learned </span>in the mishna: With regard to a dove <span class="gemarra-regular">chick that </span><span class="gemarra-regular">was found within fifty cubits </span>of a dovecote, <span class="gemarra-regular">it belongs </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to the owner of the dovecote. And </span>as the mishna does not make a distinction between different cases, it indicates that this is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">even though there is another</span> dovecote <span class="gemarra-regular">that is larger than </span>the proximate one in terms of number of birds. This shows that closeness, not majority, is the determining factor. The Gemara answers: This is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where there is no </span>other dovecote in the area.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, say the latter</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> clause </span>of the mishna: If it was found <span class="gemarra-regular">beyond fifty</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> cubits </span>from a dovecote, <span class="gemarra-regular">it belongs to its finder. </span><span class="gemarra-regular">And if there is no </span>other dovecote in the area, it <span class="gemarra-regular">certainly fell from that </span>dovecote. How, then, can it be given to the finder? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">With what </span><span class="gemarra-regular">are we dealing here? </span>We are dealing <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>a chick that <span class="gemarra-regular">hop</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> from place to place but does not yet fly. <span class="gemarra-regular">As Rav Ukva bar Ḥama says: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">any </span>creature <span class="gemarra-regular">that hops, </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">does not hop more than</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> fift</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span> cubits. Consequently, any bird found within fifty cubits of a dovecote is assumed to have come from there. If it is farther away than that, it likely came from elsewhere or was dropped by travelers.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Yirmeya raises a dilemma: </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">one leg </span>of the chick was <span class="gemarra-regular">within fifty cubits </span>of the dovecote, <span class="gemarra-regular">and one leg</span> was <span class="gemarra-regular">beyond fifty cubits, what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">And it was for </span>his question about <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>far-fetched scenario <span class="gemarra-regular">that they removed Rabbi Yirmeya from the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">study hall</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as he was apparently wasting the Sages’ time.
The Gemara further suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>the mishna: In a case where it <span class="gemarra-regular">was found between two dovecotes, </span>if it was <span class="gemarra-regular">close to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">this one, </span>it belongs <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the owner of this dovecote; if it was <span class="gemarra-regular">close to that one, </span>it belongs <span class="gemarra-regular">to</span> the owner of that dovecote. The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">And</span> this is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">even though one of them is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> greater </span>in number of birds <span class="gemarra-regular">than the other one. </span>Apparently, one rules based on proximity, not majority. The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">With what are we dealing here? </span>We are dealing with a situation <span class="gemarra-regular">where the two </span>dovecotes <span class="gemarra-regular">are equal </span>in size. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>even so, why should one follow the closer dovecote? <span class="gemarra-regular">Let us follow the majority of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the world, </span>as there are many other dovecotes besides these, and the number of doves they contain is greater. The Gemara responds: <span class="gemarra-regular">With what are we dealing here? </span>

Daf 24a

We are dealing <span class="gemarra-regular">with a path</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that </span>passes between <span class="gemarra-regular">vineyards, </span>and these two dovecotes are situated there. <span class="gemarra-regular">As, if it is so that </span>you claim the chick <span class="gemarra-regular">came from </span>anywhere else in <span class="gemarra-regular">the world, since </span><span class="gemarra-regular">it </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">hops, it could not have come </span>there. The reason is <span class="gemarra-regular">that any </span>bird <span class="gemarra-regular">that hops and turns </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">sees its nest </span>will continue <span class="gemarra-regular">to hop; but if it </span><span class="gemarra-regular">does not </span>see its nest because it has gone too far, <span class="gemarra-regular">it will not hop </span>farther. Consequently, this found chick that hops must have come from one of these two dovecotes.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said: We learn </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Nidda</span> 17b) <span class="gemarra-regular">as well </span>that one follows the majority rather than proximity: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">blood that is found in the corridor</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">baperozdor</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., the cervical canal, and <span class="gemarra-regular">it is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> uncertain </span>whether or not it is menstrual blood, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">ritually impure </span>as menstrual blood, <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>there is <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">it </span>came <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the uterus, which is <span class="gemarra-regular">the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> source </span>of menstrual blood. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>this is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">even</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> though there is an upper chamber</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> which empties into the canal, <span class="gemarra-regular">which is closer.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said to </span>Abaye, in response to this claim: <span class="gemarra-regular">You state </span>a proof from a case where the factors of <span class="gemarra-regular">majority and frequenc</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span> are both present. When there is <span class="gemarra-regular">majority and frequency, there is no one who says</span> that one ignores the majority and follows proximity. Here, not only is the blood from the uterus greater in quantity, it also passes through the canal more frequently, as blood generally does not come from the upper chamber.
Rava cites a proof for his statement. <span class="gemarra-regular">As Rabbi Ḥiyya teaches: Blood that is found in the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> corridor </span>is considered definite menstrual blood, and therefore if she engages in sexual intercourse, both she and her partner would be <span class="gemarra-regular">liable as a result of i</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> to receive <span class="it-text">karet</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">for entering the Temple </span>intentionally when ritually impure or to bring an offering for entering unwittingly. <span class="gemarra-regular">And one burns </span><span class="gemarra-italic">teruma</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> due to it, </span>if the woman touches such produce. Evidently, the status of this blood is not considered uncertain.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rava says: Learn from </span>that which <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ḥiyya </span>said <span class="gemarra-regular">three </span>conclusions: <span class="gemarra-regular">Learn from </span>his statement that when the relevant factors are <span class="gemarra-regular">majority and proximity, follow the majority; and learn from </span>his statement that the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that one follows <span class="gemarra-regular">the majority </span>applies <span class="gemarra-regular">by Torah law</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as <span class="it-text">teruma</span> is burned in this case on account of the blood and she is liable to receive <span class="it-text">karet</span> if she enters the Temple in this state; <span class="gemarra-regular">and learn from </span>his statement that <span class="gemarra-regular">there is </span>a source <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">which Rabbi Zeira </span>said.
This statement of Rabbi Zeira was issued in reference to a case discussed in tractate <span class="it-text">Ketubot</span> (15a). If there are ten stores in a city, nine of which sell kosher meat and one of which sells non-kosher meat, and one found meat outside the stores and he does not know from which store it came, one follows the majority. The Gemara there suggests that perhaps one follows the majority only in a case where the gates of the city are unlocked, when the meat could have come to the city from the majority of kosher meat outside in a circumstance where the majority of the meat sold in the surrounding area was kosher. In this case there are two majorities, the majority of kosher meat stores inside the city, and the majority from outside. The Gemara there explains <span class="gemarra-regular">that Rabbi Zeira says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">even if the city gates are locke</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> one follows the majority, and the meat is kosher, as there is a no need for a double majority.
The Gemara elaborates: The two cases are analogous, <span class="gemarra-regular">as the woman </span>here <span class="gemarra-regular">is considered like the locked</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> gates of the city, </span>i.e., there is only a single majority, <span class="gemarra-regular">and even so we follow the majority.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But Rava is the one who says</span> with regard to the case of the blood that when there is <span class="gemarra-regular">majority and frequency, there is no </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">who</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> says </span>that one ignores the majority and follows the proximity. In other words, Rava rejected this case as proof of the principle that one follows the majority even when it is not frequent. Here, by contrast, Rava claims that one can learn from the ruling of Rabbi Ḥiyya that one follows the majority by Torah law. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> retracted that </span>claim in favor of the opinion that one follows the majority in all cases.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">It was stated: </span>In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a barrel </span>of wine <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>was found <span class="gemarra-regular">floating </span><span class="gemarra-regular">in a river</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and the status of the wine was unknown, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: </span>If it was <span class="gemarra-regular">found opposite a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">town of which the majority </span>of residents <span class="gemarra-regular">are Jews, </span>the wine is <span class="gemarra-regular">permitted, </span>as it can be assumed that the wine belongs to a Jew. If it was <span class="gemarra-regular">found opposite </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a town of which the majority are gentiles, it is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">forbidden, </span>as it presumably belongs to a gentile. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Shmuel </span><span class="gemarra-regular">says: It is forbidden even </span>if it was <span class="gemarra-regular">found opposite </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a town of which the majority are Jews. </span>Why? Regardless of where it was found, one can <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">it </span><span class="gemarra-regular">came from that </span>place called <span class="gemarra-regular">Dekira, </span>where the majority of people are gentiles. In other words, there is a distinct possibility that a floating barrel came from far away.
