The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Shall we say that </span>Rav and Shmuel <span class="gemarra-regular">disagree with </span><span class="gemarra-regular">regard to </span>the statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Ḥanina, </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage, </span>Shmuel, <span class="gemarra-regular">is of </span>the opinion that the ruling is in accordance with the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Ḥanina, </span>and he rules based on the majority, which in this case includes even distant locales, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage, </span>Rav, <span class="gemarra-regular">is of </span>the opinion that the ruling is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>in accordance with the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Ḥanina, </span>which is why he rules based on proximity.
The Gemara rejects this suggestion: <span class="gemarra-regular">No; everyone agrees</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Ḥanina, and here they </span><span class="gemarra-regular">disagree about this: As </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage, </span>Rav, <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span><span class="gemarra-regular">it is so, that </span>the barrel <span class="gemarra-regular">came from that </span>place called <span class="gemarra-regular">Dekira, </span>this cannot be, as <span class="gemarra-regular">the currents and bays </span>of the river, where the river flow is weak, <span class="gemarra-regular">would have sunk it. </span>Therefore, it is logical that the barrel came from a nearby town. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage, </span>Shmuel, <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that perhaps <span class="gemarra-regular">the force of the river caught </span>the barrel <span class="gemarra-regular">and brought it, </span>as it is evident that the flow of a river can bring items from far away.
The Gemara relates that <span class="gemarra-regular">Ravina </span>deemed <span class="gemarra-regular">permitted a certain barrel of wine </span><span class="gemarra-regular">that was found </span>hidden <span class="gemarra-regular">in a vineyard </span>where there were <span class="gemarra-italic">orl</span><span class="gemarra-italic">a</span> grapes, and he was not concerned that the wine might be from the grapes of that vineyard. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Shall we say </span>that this is <span class="gemarra-regular">because he holds</span> in accordance with the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Ḥanina </span>that one follows the majority of vineyards, which are not <span class="it-text">orla</span>, rather than proximity?
The Gemara answers: It <span class="gemarra-regular">is different there, as, if </span>thieves <span class="gemarra-regular">had stolen </span>the barrel <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>that very vineyard <span class="gemarra-regular">they would not have hidden</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it there</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Since the barrel was hidden there, it is reasonable to assume that it was stolen from somewhere else. The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">And this matter, </span>that thieves would not hide a stolen barrel in the same vineyard from which they stole it, <span class="gemarra-regular">applies </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">to wine; but</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> they </span>would <span class="gemarra-regular">hide grapes </span>there, as grapes are not readily identifiable by the owner. Consequently, there is a concern that grapes found hidden there might be from that same vineyard.
The Gemara further relates that <span class="gemarra-regular">there were these jug</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">of win</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that were found between vines [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">bei kofa’ei</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> of a Jew. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava </span>deemed the contents <span class="gemarra-regular">permitted </span>and was unconcerned that they might be wine owned by a gentile. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Shall we say </span>that Rava <span class="gemarra-regular">does not</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> hold in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ḥanina, </span>who says that one follows the majority, in this case gentiles? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">There it is different, as the majority</span>

Daf 24b

<span class="gemarra-regular">of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> those who pour wine </span>from barrels into jugs <span class="gemarra-regular">are Jews</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>and therefore it is reasonable that the wine belongs to a Jew. The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">And this matter </span>applies <span class="gemarra-regular">only</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to large </span>jugs. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if they were <span class="gemarra-regular">small </span>jugs, one can <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">they were dropped by travelers, </span>most of whom are gentiles, and therefore the jugs of wine are forbidden. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if there are large </span>jugs <span class="gemarra-regular">among </span>the found jugs, <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that they all belong to Jews, as travelers do not usually carry large jugs; it can be assumed that the small ones <span class="gemarra-regular">were placed to balance </span>the donkey’s load, and the jugs all fell together.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">One must distance a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">tre</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">twenty-five cubits from</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">city</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>in the cases <span class="gemarra-regular">of a carob</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">tre</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and of a sycamore </span><span class="gemarra-regular">tree</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> which have a great many branches, they must be distanced <span class="gemarra-regular">fifty cubits. </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Abba Shaul says: Every barren </span><span class="gemarra-regular">tre</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> must be distanced <span class="gemarra-regular">fifty</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> cubits. And if the city preceded </span>the tree, as one later planted the tree alongside the city, he <span class="gemarra-regular">cuts down</span> the tree, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the city <span class="gemarra-regular">does not give money </span>to the tree’s owner in compensation. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if the tree</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> preceded </span>the city, which expanded after one planted the tree until it reached the tree, he <span class="gemarra-regular">cuts down </span>the tree <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the city <span class="gemarra-regular">gives money </span>to its owner. If it is <span class="gemarra-regular">uncertain whether this one was first or that one</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> was first, </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">cuts down </span>the tree <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the city <span class="gemarra-regular">does not give money.</span>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>that one must distance a tree from a city? <span class="gemarra-regular">Ulla says: </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">due </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to the beauty of the city, </span>as it is unattractive for a city’s walls to be obscured by tree branches. The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">And let him derive </span>this <span class="it-text">halakh</span><span class="it-text">a</span> from the statement in tractate <span class="it-text">Arakhin</span> (33b) <span class="gemarra-regular">that one</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> may neither convert a field </span>of a city into <span class="gemarra-regular">an</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> open </span><span class="gemarra-regular">are</span><span class="gemarra-regular">a</span> surrounding the city, <span class="gemarra-regular">nor may one </span>convert <span class="gemarra-regular">an open area </span>into <span class="gemarra-regular">a field, </span>as these have fixed places and measurements (see Numbers 35:1–8). If one plants trees in a city’s open area, he thereby turns the open area into a field.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>to supply the reason given by Ulla <span class="gemarra-regular">according to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar, who says: </span>One <span class="gemarra-regular">may convert a field </span>into <span class="gemarra-regular">an open area, and an open area </span>into <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">field. Here, we do not </span>plant trees, <span class="gemarra-regular">due to the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">beauty of the city.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And according </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis as well, who say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">one may not convert a field </span>into <span class="gemarra-regular">an open </span><span class="gemarra-regular">area, nor </span>convert <span class="gemarra-regular">an open area </span>into <span class="gemarra-regular">a field, </span>one can say that <span class="gemarra-regular">this matter </span>applies only to <span class="gemarra-regular">seeds, </span>i.e., one may not plant seeds in a city’s open area and thereby turn it into a field. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">trees, we do </span>plant them in an open area. <span class="gemarra-regular">But here </span>we do <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>plant trees, <span class="gemarra-regular">due </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to the beauty of the city.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And from where do </span><span class="gemarra-regular">you say, </span>i.e., on what basis do you maintain, <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>there is <span class="gemarra-regular">a difference between seeds and trees? As </span><span class="gemarra-regular">it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that discusses the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of Shabbat: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">an enclosure [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">karpef </span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> whose area is <span class="gemarra-regular">greater than two </span><span class="gemarra-italic">beit</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">se’a</span> but <span class="gemarra-regular">that</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> was enclosed </span>from the outset <span class="gemarra-regular">for the purpose of residence</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>it is permitted to carry within it on Shabbat regardless of its size, as it is considered a private domain.
If subsequently <span class="gemarra-regular">the greater part of it was sown </span>with seed crops, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">like a garden, </span>which is not a place of residence, <span class="gemarra-regular">and it is prohibited </span>to carry anything within it on Shabbat. If <span class="gemarra-regular">the greater part of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it was planted </span>with trees, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">like a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> courtyard</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> which is a place of dwelling, <span class="gemarra-regular">and it</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is permitted </span>to carry there on Shabbat. This shows that planting trees in an enclosure does not transform the area into a field, as is the case when seeds are planted.
§ The mishna teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">And if the city preceded </span>the tree he <span class="gemarra-regular">cuts down </span>the tree, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the city <span class="gemarra-regular">does not give money. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is different with regard to a cistern, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> of another mishna (25b) <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>that if one plants a tree next to a neighbor’s existing cistern, the owner of the tree <span class="gemarra-regular">cuts down </span>the tree <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the owner of the cistern <span class="gemarra-regular">gives money; and what </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is different here that </span>the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>that the owner of the tree <span class="gemarra-regular">cuts down </span>the tree <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the city <span class="gemarra-regular">does not give money?</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Kahana </span><span class="gemarra-regular">said, </span>citing a popular aphorism: <span class="gemarra-regular">A pot belonging to partner</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is neither hot nor cold, </span>i.e., no one takes responsibility for an item that belongs to several people, as opposed to a single individual. Here too, there is no specific person who will pay for the tree.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And what is the difficulty </span>to begin with? <span class="gemarra-regular">Perhaps damage </span>caused <span class="gemarra-regular">to public </span>property <span class="gemarra-regular">is different from damage</span> caused to the property <span class="gemarra-regular">of an individual. </span>Consequently, when one’s tree causes damage to the public he is not compensated for having to cut it down, whereas he does receive payment when his tree damages a private cistern.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, if Rav Kahana’s </span>comment <span class="gemarra-regular">was stated </span>in this context, <span class="gemarra-regular">it was stated about the latter clause: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">If the tree preceded </span>the city, he <span class="gemarra-regular">cuts down </span>the tree <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the city <span class="gemarra-regular">gives money </span>to its owner. Concerning this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> one could ask: <span class="gemarra-regular">And let </span>the tree owner <span class="gemarra-regular">say to </span>the city residents: <span class="gemarra-regular">Give me money first and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> then I will cut down </span>the tree. In this context, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Kahana said: A pot belonging to partners is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">neither hot nor cold. </span>If the owner of the tree is entitled to wait until he had first collects money, a good deal of time would pass before the tree would be cut down. Therefore, a community need not collect money and pay immediately, unlike an individual.
§ The mishna teaches that if it is <span class="gemarra-regular">uncertain whether this one was first or that</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> one was first, </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">cuts down </span>the tree <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the city <span class="gemarra-regular">does not give money. </span>The Gemara asks: In <span class="gemarra-regular">what</span> way <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>this case <span class="gemarra-regular">different from </span>that of a tree alongside <span class="gemarra-regular">a cistern, </span>concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">which you said </span>in the mishna (25b) that in a case of uncertainty the owner of the tree need <span class="gemarra-regular">not cut down </span>the tree?
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">There, </span>if it were a case <span class="gemarra-regular">of certaint</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span> the tree would <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>be <span class="gemarra-regular">subject to being cut </span><span class="gemarra-regular">down; </span>therefore, in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">of uncertainty too, we do </span><span class="gemarra-regular">not say to </span>the owner of the tree: <span class="gemarra-regular">Cut </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">down. </span>In that case, if the tree preceded the cistern, the owner of the tree would not be required to cut it down. <span class="gemarra-regular">Here, </span>if it were a case <span class="gemarra-regular">of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> certainty, </span>the tree would be <span class="gemarra-regular">subject to being cut down</span> even if it preceded the city, and the only uncertainty is whether or not the owner of the tree would need to be compensated. Consequently, in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">of uncertainty</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> too, we say to </span>the owner of the tree: <span class="gemarra-regular">Cut </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">down. And if </span>the owner of the tree lodges a claim <span class="gemarra-regular">due </span>to the <span class="gemarra-regular">value </span>of the tree, as he wants compensation for it, <span class="gemarra-regular">we say to him: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Bring proof </span>that your tree came first, <span class="gemarra-regular">and take </span>your money. Since he has no proof, he does not receive any money.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">One must distance a permanent threshing</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">floo</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">fifty cubits from the city, </span>so that the chaff will not harm the city’s residents. Furthermore, <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">person should not establish a permanent threshing floor </span>even <span class="gemarra-regular">on </span><span class="gemarra-regular">his own </span>property <span class="gemarra-regular">unless he has fifty cubits </span>of open space <span class="gemarra-regular">in every direction. And one must distance </span>a threshing floor <span class="gemarra-regular">from the plantings of another and from </span>another’s <span class="gemarra-regular">plowed field </span>far <span class="gemarra-regular">enough that it does not cause damage.</span>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is different </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> first clause </span>of the mishna, which states a fixed measurement for the distance of a threshing floor from a city, <span class="gemarra-regular">and what is different </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">the latter clause, </span>which does not provide a measurement but simply states in general terms: Enough that it does not cause damage? <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said: </span>In <span class="gemarra-regular">the latter clause we arrive at </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> threshing floor that is not permanent. </span>This threshing floor must be far enough from a neighbor that it does not cause damage to his property.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What are the circumstances </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">threshing floor that is not permanent? Rabbi Yosei, son of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ḥanina, says: </span>It refers to <span class="gemarra-regular">any </span>threshing floor <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>one processes such a small quantity of grain that <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span><span class="gemarra-regular">does not winno</span><span class="gemarra-regular">w</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with a winnowing shovel</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> but employs some other method that does not scatter the chaff as far. This is one resolution of the contradiction.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi said </span>that the phrase: Enough that it does not cause damage, is not referring to a distance but provides an explanation. In other words, the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is saying: What is the reason </span>for the ruling of the first clause, as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the reason </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">one must distance a permanent threshing floor</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> fifty cubits from the city? </span>It must be far <span class="gemarra-regular">enough</span> away <span class="gemarra-regular">that it does not cause damage.</span>
The Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises an objection </span>against the opinion of Abaye from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">One must distance a permanent threshing floor fifty cubits</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from the city; and just as one distances </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">fifty</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> cubits from the city, so too does one distance </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">fifty cubits from the gourds, cucumbers, plantings, and plowed field</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of another, enough that it does not cause damage. Granted</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">works out well according to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi, </span>as he claims that in both clauses the same distance is required: One must move a threshing floor fifty cubits from a plowed field and from those plantings. <span class="gemarra-regular">But according to </span>the explanation of <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">difficult.</span> The Gemara comments: Indeed, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">difficult.</span>
The Gemara asks with regard to the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, </span>one must distance his threshing floor <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span><span class="gemarra-regular">his </span>neighbor’s <span class="gemarra-regular">cucumbers and gourds</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as the chaff </span>from the threshing floor <span class="gemarra-regular">goes </span>and penetrates <span class="gemarra-regular">into the heart </span>of the flower <span class="gemarra-regular">and dries it out. But why </span>must one distance the threshing floor <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>another’s <span class="gemarra-regular">plowed field? </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Abba bar Zavda said, and some say </span>it was <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Abba bar Zutra: </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">because</span>

Daf 25a

<span class="gemarra-regular">he turns it </span>into <span class="gemarra-regular">manure, </span>i.e., the chaff acts like manure, and an excessive amount of manure damages the seeds.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">One must distance </span>animal <span class="gemarra-regular">carcasses</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and graves, and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a tannery [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">haburseki</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> a place where hides are processed, <span class="gemarra-regular">fifty cubits from the city. One may establish a tannery</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> only on the east </span><span class="gemarra-regular">sid</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">of the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">city</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> because winds usually blow from the west and the foul smells would therefore be blown away from the residential area. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Akiva says: One may establish </span>a tannery <span class="gemarra-regular">on any </span><span class="gemarra-regular">sid</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> of a city <span class="gemarra-regular">except for the west, </span>as the winds blowing from that direction will bring the odors into the city, <span class="gemarra-regular">and one must distance </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">fifty cubits </span>from the city. <span class="gemarra-regular">One must distance from vegetables water in </span><span class="gemarra-regular">which flax is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">steeped</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> because this water ruins them; <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>likewise one must distance <span class="gemarra-regular">leeks from </span><span class="gemarra-regular">onions</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> mustard from bees. And Rabbi Yosei permits </span>one not to do so in the case <span class="gemarra-regular">of mustard.</span>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">A dilemma was raised before </span>the Sages: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">is Rabbi Akiva speaking? </span>Did he mean that <span class="gemarra-regular">one may establish </span>a tannery <span class="gemarra-regular">on any</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> side </span>of a city, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>one may even <span class="gemarra-regular">place </span>the tannery <span class="gemarra-regular">close </span>to the city, <span class="gemarra-regular">except for the west </span><span class="gemarra-regular">side, </span>where <span class="gemarra-regular">one must establish it at a distance of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">fifty cubits? Or perhaps </span>he meant that <span class="gemarra-regular">one may establish </span>a tannery <span class="gemarra-regular">on any side and distance it fifty cubits, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">except for the west side, </span>where one <span class="gemarra-regular">may not establish </span>a tannery <span class="gemarra-regular">at all.</span>
The Gemara cites a proof: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear, as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Akiva says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">one may establish </span>a tannery <span class="gemarra-regular">on any side </span>of the city <span class="gemarra-regular">and distance it fifty </span><span class="gemarra-regular">cubits, except for the west side, </span>where one <span class="gemarra-regular">may not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">establish </span>a tannery <span class="gemarra-regular">at all, because </span>the western wind is <span class="gemarra-regular">frequent.</span>
§ With regard to the last statement of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said to Rav Naḥman: What</span> does <span class="gemarra-regular">frequent </span>mean in this context? <span class="gemarra-regular">If we say </span>it means <span class="gemarra-regular">frequent among the winds, </span>i.e., this wind blows all the time, that is difficult. <span class="gemarra-regular">But doesn’t Rav</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Ḥanan bar Abba say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: Four winds blow</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> every day </span>from different directions, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the northern wind </span>blows <span class="gemarra-regular">with each of </span>the other three; <span class="gemarra-regular">as, if this</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> were not so, </span>i.e., if it did not blow, <span class="gemarra-regular">the world would not exist for even one hour, </span>as the northern wind is pleasant and tempers the bitter effects of the other winds. <span class="gemarra-regular">And the southern win</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">harsher than all of them, and were it not </span>for the angel named <span class="gemarra-italic">Ben</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">Netz</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> who <span class="gemarra-regular">stops it </span>from blowing even harder, it would <span class="gemarra-regular">destroy the </span>entire <span class="gemarra-regular">world, as</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it is stated: “Does the hawk [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">netz</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] soar by your</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> wisdom, and stretch her wings toward the south?” </span>(Job 39:26). This indicates that the northern wind is the most constant, not the western wind.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, what </span>is the meaning of <span class="gemarra-regular">frequent? </span>It means <span class="gemarra-regular">frequent with the Divine </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Presence, </span>i.e., the Divine Presence is found on the western side, and therefore it is inappropriate to set up a tannery there with its foul odors. <span class="gemarra-regular">As Rabbi Yehoshua</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> ben Levi says: Come and let us be grateful to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> our ancestors who revealed </span>to us <span class="gemarra-regular">the place of prayer</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as it is written: “And the hosts of heaven</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> bow down to You” </span>(Nehemiah 9:6). Since the celestial bodies move from east to west, they bow in that direction, which indicates that the Divine Presence is in the west.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Aḥa bar Ya’akov objects to this: But perhaps </span>the celestial bodies are <span class="gemarra-regular">like a servant who receives a gift</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from his master and walks backward </span>while <span class="gemarra-regular">bowing. </span>If so, the Divine Presence is in the east and the celestial bodies are moving backward. The Gemara comments: Indeed, this is <span class="gemarra-regular">difficult, </span>i.e., the verse does not provide a definitive proof.
The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">And</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rabbi Oshaya holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the Divine Presence </span>is found <span class="gemarra-regular">in</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> every place, as Rabbi Oshaya says: What </span>is the meaning of that <span class="gemarra-regular">which is written: “You are the Lord, even</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> You alone, You have made heaven…</span>You preserve them all alive and the hosts of heaven bow down to You” (Nehemiah 9:6)? This indicates that <span class="gemarra-regular">Your messengers are not like</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the messengers of flesh and blood. The messengers of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">flesh and blood return to the place from where they </span><span class="gemarra-regular">were sent </span>to report on <span class="gemarra-regular">their mission. But Your messengers</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> return </span>and report on <span class="gemarra-regular">their mission from the </span>very same <span class="gemarra-regular">place </span>to <span class="gemarra-regular">which they are sent, as it is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">stated “Can you send forth lightnings, that they may go </span><span class="gemarra-regular">out and say to you: Here we are?” </span>(Job 38:35). The verse <span class="gemarra-regular">does not state: They will come and say</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>i.e., they do not return to their point of departure, <span class="gemarra-regular">but: “They may go out and say,” </span>which <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that the Divine Presence </span>is found <span class="gemarra-regular">in every place.</span>
The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Yishmael</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, too, holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the Divine Presence </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">in every place</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, as </span>one of the Sages of <span class="gemarra-regular">the school of Rabbi</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Yishmael taught: From where </span>is it derived <span class="gemarra-regular">that the Divine</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Presence </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">in every place? As it is stated: “And</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> behold the angel who spoke with me went forth, and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> another angel went out to meet him” </span>(Zechariah 2:7). Although both angels were coming from the Divine Presence, the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">does not state: After him, but: “To meet him,” </span>which <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches that the Divine Presence </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">in every place, </span>and therefore the angels depart for their missions from every place.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Sheshet, too, holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the Divine Presence </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">in every </span><span class="gemarra-regular">place, as Rav Sheshet said to his servant: Set me</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> facing any direction </span>to pray <span class="gemarra-regular">except for the east. </span>Rav Sheshet, who was blind, required the assistance of his aide to prepare for prayer. He explained to his servant: <span class="gemarra-regular">And</span> the reason I do not wish to face east is <span class="gemarra-regular">not because it does not contain the Divine Presence, but</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> because the heretics instruct </span>people to pray <span class="gemarra-regular">in that </span>direction.
<span class="gemarra-regular">But Rabbi Abbahu says: The Divine Presence </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">in</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the west, as Rabbi Abbahu says: What </span>is the meaning of <span class="gemarra-italic">oriyya</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> which is a name for the west? It means <span class="gemarra-regular">the air of God [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">avir</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">Yah</span><span class="gemarra-regular">], </span>i.e., this is the place of the Divine Presence.
The Gemara cites a statement connected to the four winds. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda said</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: What </span>is the meaning of that <span class="gemarra-regular">which is written: “My</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> doctrine shall drop as the rain, </span>my speech shall distill as the dew; as the small rain upon the tender growth, and as the showers upon the herb” (Deuteronomy 32:2)? “My doctrine shall drop [<span class="it-text">ya’aro</span><span class="it-text">f </span>] as the rain”; <span class="gemarra-regular">this is the western wind, which comes from the back</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">me’orpo</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] the world</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as the west is also referred to as the back.
<span class="gemarra-regular">“My speech shall distill [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">tizzal</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] as </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the dew”; this is the northern wind, which </span>brings dry air that reduces the rain and grain and thereby <span class="gemarra-regular">devalues [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">mazzelet</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] gold</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> When grain crops are reduced their price appreciates, and consequently the value of gold decreases. <span class="gemarra-regular">And in </span><span class="gemarra-regular">addition, it says: “You who lavish [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">hazzalim</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] gold out of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the bag” </span>(Isaiah 46:6).
<span class="gemarra-regular">“As the small rain [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">kisirim</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> upon the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">tender growth”; this is the eastern wind that rages through [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">maseret</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] the entire world like a demon [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">sa’ir</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] </span>when it blows strongly. <span class="gemarra-regular">“And as the showers upon the herb</span><span class="gemarra-regular">”; this is the southern wind, which raises showers and causes</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> herbs to grow.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">It is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Eliezer</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> says: </span>The <span class="gemarra-regular">world</span>

Daf 25b

<span class="gemarra-regular">is similar to </span>a partially enclosed <span class="gemarra-regular">veranda [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">le’akhsadra</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> enclosed on three sides, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the northern side </span>of the world <span class="gemarra-regular">is not enclosed </span>with a partition like the other directions. The sun begins its revolution in the east and passes to the south and the west, <span class="gemarra-regular">and once </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the sun reaches the northwestern corner it turns around and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">ascends </span>throughout the night <span class="gemarra-regular">above the sky </span>to the east side and does not pass the north side. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Yehoshua says: The world is similar to a small tent [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">lek</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ubba</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and the north side is enclosed </span>with a partition as well, <span class="gemarra-regular">but once the sun reaches the northwestern </span><span class="gemarra-regular">corner </span>it emerges from this small tent, and <span class="gemarra-regular">circles and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">passes behind the dome, </span>i.e., outside the northern partition, until it reaches the east.
<span class="gemarra-regular">As it is stated: </span>“The sun also rises and the sun goes down, and hastens to its place, where it rises again. <span class="gemarra-regular">It goes toward the south</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and turns</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> about to the north; </span>round and round goes the wind, and on its circuits the wind returns” (Ecclesiastes 1:5–6). The verse is understood as describing the sun’s movements, as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">“It goes toward the south” during the day,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> “and turns about to the north,” </span>on the outside of the firmament, <span class="gemarra-regular">at night. “Round and round goes the wind</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ruaḥ</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] and the wind returns again to its circuits”; </span>as the word <span class="it-text">ruaḥ</span> can also mean direction or side, Rabbi Yehoshua explains that <span class="gemarra-regular">these are the face of the east</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and the face of the west. Sometimes, </span>in the short winter days, the sun <span class="gemarra-regular">turns about them </span>without being seen, <span class="gemarra-regular">and sometimes, </span>in the long summer days, <span class="gemarra-regular">it traverses them</span> visibly.
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues: Rabbi Yehoshua <span class="gemarra-regular">would say: </span>With this <span class="gemarra-regular">we arrive at </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Eliezer </span>that the world is like a partially enclosed veranda. He cites a verse as proof that the north side is open: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Out of the chamber comes </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the storm”; this is the southern sid</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> that forms a room with the other two sides. <span class="gemarra-regular">“And cold out </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of the dispersed parts” </span>(Job 37:9); <span class="gemarra-regular">this is the northern</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> side, </span>which is open, and from which a cold wind comes. <span class="gemarra-regular">“By the breath of God ice is given”; </span><span class="gemarra-regular">this is the western side. “And the breadth of the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">waters is straitened” </span>(Job 37:10); <span class="gemarra-regular">this is the eastern side</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>from which the rains come.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> doesn’t the Master say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the southern wind raises</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> showers and causes herbs to grow? </span>The Gemara answers that this is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult: This </span>is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">rain that</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> falls gently, </span>which waters plants and brings growth; <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">a downpour </span>of rain that causes damage.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥisda said: What </span>is the meaning of that <span class="gemarra-regular">which is written: “Out of the north comes gold” </span>(Job 37:22)? <span class="gemarra-regular">This is the northern wind, which devalues gold </span>by causing a drought that raises the price of grain. <span class="gemarra-regular">And, in addition, it says: “You who lavish gold out </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of the bag” </span>(Isaiah 46:6).
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rafram bar </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Pappa says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥisda says: From the day the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Temple was destroyed the southern wind has not brought rain, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">as it is stated </span>in the description of the destruction of the Temple: <span class="gemarra-regular">“He decrees on the right and there</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is hunger, and consumes on the left and they are</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not satisfied” </span>(Isaiah 9:19). This means that God decreed that the southern wind, which is called right, shall bring famine with it. <span class="gemarra-regular">And it is written: “North and right, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">You have created them” </span>(Psalms 89:13). This proves that the term right means south.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rafram bar Pappa says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥisda says: From</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the day the Temple was destroyed, the rains no </span>longer <span class="gemarra-regular">descend from the good storehouse, as it is stated: “The</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Lord will open to you His good storehouse, </span>the skies, to give the rain of your land in its season” (Deuteronomy 28:12). <span class="gemarra-regular">In a time when the Jewish people perform</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> God’s will, and the Jewish people are settled in</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> their land, rain descends from the good storehouse. In a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> time when the Jewish people are not settled in their</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> land, rain does not descend from the good storehouse.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yitzḥak says: One who wishes to become wise</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> should face south</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>one who wishes <span class="gemarra-regular">to become</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> wealthy should face north. And your mnemonic </span>for this is that in the Temple the <span class="gemarra-regular">Table, </span>which symbolized blessing and abundance, <span class="gemarra-regular">was in the north, and the Candelabrum, </span>which symbolized the light of wisdom, <span class="gemarra-regular">was in the sout</span><span class="gemarra-regular">h</span> of the Sanctuary. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi says: One </span><span class="gemarra-regular">should always face south, as once he becomes wise he </span><span class="gemarra-regular">will </span>subsequently also <span class="gemarra-regular">become wealthy, as it is stated </span>with regard to the Torah: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Length of days is in her</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> right hand; in her left hand are riches and honor</span><span class="gemarra-regular">” </span>(Proverbs 3:16).
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the Divine Presence is in the west. </span>How, then, can one pray facing south? The Gemara explains <span class="gemarra-regular">that one should </span><span class="gemarra-regular">turn aside </span>slightly, so that he faces southwest. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ḥanina </span><span class="gemarra-regular">said to Rav Ashi: </span>An individual <span class="gemarra-regular">such as you, who </span><span class="gemarra-regular">lives to the north of Eretz Yisrael, should face south </span>when you pray. <span class="gemarra-regular">And from where do we </span>derive <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Babylonia is located to the nort</span><span class="gemarra-regular">h</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of Eretz Yisrael? As</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it is written </span>in a prophecy concerning the destruction of Jerusalem by the Babylonians: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Out of the north evil </span><span class="gemarra-regular">shall break forth upon all the inhabitants of the land” </span>(Jeremiah 1:14).
§ The mishna teaches that <span class="gemarra-regular">one must distance from vegetables the water in which </span><span class="gemarra-regular">flax is steeped, </span>and distance mustard from bees. A Sage <span class="gemarra-regular">taught </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei permits </span>one not to do so in the case <span class="gemarra-regular">of mustard because he can say to</span> the beekeeper: <span class="gemarra-regular">Before you tell me: Distance your mustard from</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> my bees, </span>I can tell you: <span class="gemarra-regular">Distance your bees from</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> my mustard, as they come and eat my mustard plants</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>In other words, you are also causing damage to my property. Since they each cause damage to the other, neither can force his neighbor to move.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">One must distance a tree twenty-five </span><span class="gemarra-regular">cubits from a cistern, and </span>in the case <span class="gemarra-regular">of a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">carob and of a sycamore tree, </span>whose roots extend farther, one must distance the tree <span class="gemarra-regular">fifty cubits. </span>This is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">whether </span>the cistern or tree <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>located <span class="gemarra-regular">above or </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to the side </span>of the other. <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>the digging of <span class="gemarra-regular">the cistern preceded </span>the tree, the owner of the tree <span class="gemarra-regular">cuts down </span>the tree <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the owner of the cistern <span class="gemarra-regular">pays </span>him <span class="gemarra-regular">money. And if the tree preceded </span>the cistern the owner of the tree need <span class="gemarra-regular">not cut down </span>the tree. If it is <span class="gemarra-regular">uncertain whether this came first </span><span class="gemarra-regular">or that came first, </span>the owner of the tree need <span class="gemarra-regular">not cut down </span>the tree. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei says: Even if </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the cistern </span><span class="gemarra-regular">precede</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">tree</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the owner of the tree need <span class="gemarra-regular">not cut down </span>the tree. This is due to the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that this one digs in his own</span> property, <span class="gemarra-regular">and that one plants in his own </span>property.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara discusses the mishna’s statement that a tree must be distanced if it is above a cistern. A Sage <span class="gemarra-regular">taught: </span>This is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">whether the cistern is below </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and the tree is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">above</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> or <span class="gemarra-regular">whether the cistern </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is above and the tree is below. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, </span>if the <span class="gemarra-regular">cistern is below and the tree is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">above, </span>it will cause damage, as <span class="gemarra-regular">the roots extend and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> damage the cistern </span>when they breach its walls. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">the cistern is above and the tree is below, why</span> should he have to distance the tree, considering that the roots extend downward? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ḥagga says in the name </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Yosei: </span>He must distance the tree <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>its roots <span class="gemarra-regular">form holes in the ground and ruin the floor </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of the cistern.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei says: Even if the cistern preceded </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the tree, </span>the owner of the tree need <span class="gemarra-regular">not cut </span><span class="gemarra-regular">down </span>the tree. This is due to the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span><span class="gemarra-regular">this one digs in his own </span>property, <span class="gemarra-regular">and that one </span><span class="gemarra-regular">plants in his own </span>property. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel </span><span class="gemarra-regular">says: </span>The <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei. Rav Ashi said: When we were </span>studying <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the study hall of Rav Kahana, we would say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei concedes with regard to one’s arrows, </span>i.e., one must distance his activities from his neighbor if his actions will cause immediate damage to his neighbor, even if he is acting on his own property.
The Gemara relates that a man called <span class="gemarra-regular">Pappei Yona’</span><span class="gemarra-regular">a was poor and became wealthy</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> He <span class="gemarra-regular">built a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">mansion [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">appadna</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> on his land. <span class="gemarra-regular">There were these </span>sesame seed <span class="gemarra-regular">presser</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in his neighborhood who </span>would work, and <span class="gemarra-regular">when</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> they would press the sesame seeds </span>their activity <span class="gemarra-regular">would shake</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> his mansion. He came before Rav Ashi </span>to complain. Rav Ashi <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: When we were </span>studying <span class="gemarra-regular">in the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> study hall of Rav Kahana, we would say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Yosei concedes with regard to one’s arrows. </span>Here too, because the sesame seed pressers cause immediate damage they must distance themselves.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And how much </span>must the mansion shake for the owner to have the right to compel the sesame seed pressers to distance themselves? 

Daf 26a

It must shake enough <span class="gemarra-regular">that the lid [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">nakhtema</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> positioned <span class="gemarra-regular">at the mouth of a jug shake</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> if it is placed on a wall.
The Gemara relates: <span class="gemarra-regular">When the</span> members of the <span class="gemarra-regular">household of bar Maryon, son of Ravin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, would beat </span>their <span class="gemarra-regular">flax, the chaff [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">rakta</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> would fly</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> off and harm people. </span>Those people <span class="gemarra-regular">came before Ravina </span>to complain. Ravina <span class="gemarra-regular">said to them: When we say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei concedes with regard to his arrows, this statement </span>applies only <span class="gemarra-regular">when </span>the damaging item <span class="gemarra-regular">moves by his direct </span><span class="gemarra-regular">force. Here, </span>by contrast, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is the wind that </span><span class="gemarra-regular">carries </span>the chaff.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Mar bar Rav </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Ashi objects to this: </span>In <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>way <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>this case <span class="gemarra-regular">different from </span>one who <span class="gemarra-regular">winnow</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> on Shabbat by throwing the grain into the wind so that the chaff is blown away <span class="gemarra-regular">and the wind assists him</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> That is considered a primary category of labor on Shabbat despite the fact that the act is performed partly with the aid of the wind. The Gemara relates that the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">stated </span>this objection with regard to beating flax <span class="gemarra-regular">before Mareimar. </span>Mareimar <span class="gemarra-regular">said to them: This </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>the same as <span class="gemarra-regular">one</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> who winnows and the wind assists him. </span>Just as this is considered his direct force for the purposes of the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of Shabbat, it is likewise considered his direct force with regard to the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of damages.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And according to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Ravina, </span>who rejects this comparison and claims that flying chaff is not considered one’s arrow, in <span class="gemarra-regular">what</span> way <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>this situation <span class="gemarra-regular">different from </span>that of <span class="gemarra-regular">a spark</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that flies from a hamme</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and causes damage, </span>in which case all agree <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the one wielding the hammer <span class="gemarra-regular">is liable to pay? </span>The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">There, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">preferable for him that </span>the spark <span class="gemarra-regular">go </span>as far as possible, rather than staying nearby. <span class="gemarra-regular">Here </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">not</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> preferable for him, </span>i.e., it is immaterial to him, <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the chaff <span class="gemarra-regular">go </span>some distance.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">A person may not plant </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a tree near the field of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">anothe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">unless he distances</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it four cubits from </span>the field. This is the case <span class="gemarra-regular">whether </span>he is planting <span class="gemarra-regular">grapevines or any </span>kind of <span class="gemarra-regular">tree</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>If there <span class="gemarra-regular">was a fence between </span>them, <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">may place, </span>i.e., plant, his grapevines or trees <span class="gemarra-regular">close </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to the fence from here, and that </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">may place</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>i.e., plant, his produce <span class="gemarra-regular">close to the fence from</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> there.</span>
If the <span class="gemarra-regular">roots were spreadin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> into </span>the field <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">another, </span>the owner of the field <span class="gemarra-regular">may dig to a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> depth </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">three handbreadths </span>even if he severs those roots, <span class="gemarra-regular">so that </span>they do <span class="gemarra-regular">not impede </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">plow. </span>If he <span class="gemarra-regular">was digging a cistern </span>in that spot, or <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">ditch, or a cave, </span>and he came upon the roots of his neighbor’s tree, <span class="gemarra-regular">he may cut downward </span>normally, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the wood </span>from the roots <span class="gemarra-regular">is his.</span>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> A <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">taught: </span>The <span class="gemarra-regular">four cubits that </span>the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">stated </span>one must leave between a vineyard and a neighbor’s field are <span class="gemarra-regular">for the work of the vineyard, </span>so that the owner of the vineyard does not take oxen and a plow into his neighbor’s field while working his vineyard. <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel says: They taught </span>this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span><span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to Eretz Yisrael, but in Babylonia two </span><span class="gemarra-regular">cubit</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> are sufficient, as their plows are shorter. <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> also taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">A person may not plant</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a tree near the field of another unless he distances</span> the tree <span class="gemarra-regular">two cubits from </span>the field. <span class="gemarra-regular">But didn’t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> we learn </span>in the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">Four cubits? Rather, is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it not </span>correct that there is a difference between Eretz Yisrael and Babylonia in this regard, <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>stated <span class="gemarra-regular">by Shmuel</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? </span>The Gemara concludes: Indeed, <span class="gemarra-regular">learn from it </span>that it is so.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And there are </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">who raise </span>this matter in the form <span class="gemarra-regular">of a contradiction.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> We learned </span>in the mishna that <span class="gemarra-regular">a person may not</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> plant a tree near the field of another unless he</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> distances it four cubits from </span>the field. <span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">two cubits </span>are sufficient? <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel said </span>that this is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult: Here </span>it is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to Babylonia, </span>whereas <span class="gemarra-regular">there </span>it is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Eretz Yisrael.</span>
The Gemara relates: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava bar Rav Ḥanan had</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> these palm trees </span>that stood <span class="gemarra-regular">adjacent to the boundary of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rav Yosef’s vineyard. Birds would come and roost </span><span class="gemarra-regular">on the palm trees and </span>would subsequently <span class="gemarra-regular">descend to the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">vineyard and damage it. </span>Rav Yosef <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Rava bar Rav Ḥanan: <span class="gemarra-regular">Go </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">cut dow</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> your palm trees. Rava bar Rav Ḥanan <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: But I distanced </span>them the required amount. Rav Yosef <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: This</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> matter, </span>i.e., this specific distance, applies only <span class="gemarra-regular">to trees</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, but a greater </span>distance <span class="gemarra-regular">is required for vines</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
Rava bar Rav Ḥanan protested: <span class="gemarra-regular">But didn’t we </span><span class="gemarra-regular">learn </span>in the mishna that this is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">whether </span>he is planting <span class="gemarra-regular">grapevines or any </span>kind of <span class="gemarra-regular">tree? </span>Rav Yosef <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: This matter </span>applies only to the distance between one <span class="gemarra-regular">tree and </span>another <span class="gemarra-regular">tree, or </span>the distance between one <span class="gemarra-regular">vine and </span>other <span class="gemarra-regular">vines. But </span>with regard to the space between <span class="gemarra-regular">a tree and vines, one </span><span class="gemarra-regular">requires a greater distance.</span>
Rava bar Rav Ḥanan <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: I </span>myself <span class="gemarra-regular">will</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not cut them down</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as Rav said: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">this palm tree that produces one </span><span class="gemarra-italic">ka</span><span class="gemarra-italic">v</span> of fruit, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibited to cut it down, </span>due to the verse: “You shall not destroy the trees” (Deuteronomy 20:19). <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Ḥanina says: My son Shikhḥat died only</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> because he cut down a fig tree before its time</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>Rava bar Rav Ḥanan continued: <span class="gemarra-regular">If the Master is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">amenable </span>to do so, he <span class="gemarra-regular">may cut </span>them down, but I will not do it.
The Gemara further relates that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Papp</span><span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> had these palm trees </span>that stood <span class="gemarra-regular">adjacent</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to the boundary of </span>the property of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna, son</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of Rav Yehoshua. He went </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">found </span>Rav Huna <span class="gemarra-regular">digging and cutting his roots. </span>Rav Pappa <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">What is this? </span>Rav Huna <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">we</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> learned </span>in the mishna: If the <span class="gemarra-regular">roots were spreading into</span> the field <span class="gemarra-regular">of another, </span>the owner of the field <span class="gemarra-regular">may dig to a depth </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">three handbreadths </span>even if he severs those roots, <span class="gemarra-regular">so that </span>they do <span class="gemarra-regular">not impede </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">plow.</span>
Rav Pappa <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to him: This statement </span>applies only up to <span class="gemarra-regular">three </span>handbreadths, whereas the <span class="gemarra-regular">Master is digging </span>and cutting <span class="gemarra-regular">more </span>than three. Rav Huna <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: I am </span>digging <span class="gemarra-regular">cisterns, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">ditches, and caves, as we learned </span>in the mishna: If he <span class="gemarra-regular">was digging a cistern, a ditch, or a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> cave, he may cut downward </span>normally <span class="gemarra-regular">and the wood </span>from the roots <span class="gemarra-regular">is his. Rav Pappa said: I told</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> him all </span>the proofs I could find, <span class="gemarra-regular">but I was</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> unable to </span>convince <span class="gemarra-regular">him </span>that I was correct,

<span class="gemarra-regular">until I told him that</span> which <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda says: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a strip </span>of land over <span class="gemarra-regular">which the public has an acquired privilege </span>of use, one <span class="gemarra-regular">may not destroy it. </span>Here too, since I have an acquired privilege of use of this land, you are not permitted to destroy that which I possess. <span class="gemarra-regular">After </span>Rav Pappa <span class="gemarra-regular">left, </span>Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, <span class="gemarra-regular">said: Why did I not say to him </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">there</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>an acquired privilege of use is effective when it is <span class="gemarra-regular">within sixteen cubits</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as within that area the roots are considered part of the tree, whereas <span class="gemarra-regular">here </span>I cut the roots of the palm trees <span class="gemarra-regular">beyond sixteen cubits.</span>
§ The mishna teaches that if <span class="gemarra-regular">he was digging </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a cistern, a ditch, or a cave, he may cut</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> downward and the wood is his. </span>The Sage<span class="gemarra-regular"> Ya’akov </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of Hadeyyav raised a dilemma before Rav Ḥisda: To whom </span><span class="gemarra-regular">does the wood belong? </span>The mishna says that the wood is his, without specifying to which of the two individuals this refers, the owner of the tree or the owner of the land.
Rav Ḥisda <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: You learned </span>the answer in a mishna in tractate <span class="it-text">Me’ila</span> (13b). If <span class="gemarra-regular">roots of a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">tree </span>belonging <span class="gemarra-regular">to an ordinary person [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">hedyot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> extend into </span>a field belonging <span class="gemarra-regular">to the Temple </span>treasury, <span class="gemarra-regular">one may not</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> derive benefit </span>from them, but if one derived benefit from them he is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>liable for <span class="gemarra-regular">misuse </span>of consecrated property. That is, even if one does transgress the prohibition and benefit from them, it is not considered misuse and he is not liable to bring an offering.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, if you say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">we </span><span class="gemarra-regular">follow the tree, </span>and the roots are considered part of it, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">due to that </span>reason that <span class="gemarra-regular">one is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>liable for <span class="gemarra-regular">misuse, </span>as the tree is not consecrated. <span class="gemarra-regular">But if you say we follow the land, </span>i.e., the roots belong to the land’s owner, <span class="gemarra-regular">why </span>is he <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>liable for <span class="gemarra-regular">misuse </span>of consecrated property?
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, what </span>will you say, that <span class="gemarra-regular">we follow the tree? </span>If so, <span class="gemarra-regular">say the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">last clause </span>of that mishna: If roots of a tree belonging <span class="gemarra-regular">to the Temple </span>treasury <span class="gemarra-regular">extend into </span>a field <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">an ordinary person</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> one may not derive benefit </span>from them, but if one derived benefit from them he is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>liable for <span class="gemarra-regular">misuse </span>of consecrated property. <span class="gemarra-regular">But if we</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> follow the tree, why </span>is he <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>liable for <span class="gemarra-regular">misuse</span> of consecrated property?
The Gemara responds: <span class="gemarra-regular">Are the cases comparable? </span>In both clauses of the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">we are dealing with growths that came</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> thereafter, </span>i.e., after the tree was consecrated, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> of that mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to growths</span> that grew from a consecrated plant or tree, they are <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>subject to the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">misuse </span>of consecrated property. Only the original plant is. Consequently, there is no connection between that mishna and the question of whether roots are considered part of the tree or part of the land.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Ravina said </span>that it is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult: Here, </span>in the first clause of the mishna in <span class="it-text">Me’ila</span>, it is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">within sixteen cubits </span>of the tree. In this case the roots are considered part of the tree. <span class="gemarra-regular">There, </span>in the second clause, it is referring to roots <span class="gemarra-regular">beyond sixteen cubits, </span>in which case the roots are considered part of the ground where they are found.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Ulla said: </span>An individual who maintains <span class="gemarra-regular">a tree that is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> within sixteen cubits of a boundary is a robber, </span>as it draws nourishment from the neighbor’s land, <span class="gemarra-regular">and one</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> does not bring first fruit</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from it</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> since that would be a mitzva that is fulfilled by means of a transgression.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">From where does Ulla </span>derive <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>measurement? <span class="gemarra-regular">If we </span><span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">which we learned </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Shevi’it</span> 1:6), this is problematic. That mishna teaches: If there were <span class="gemarra-regular">ten sapling</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> scattered in a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">beit</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">se</span><span class="gemarra-italic">’a</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, one may plow the entire </span><span class="gemarra-italic">beit</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">se’a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> their </span>sake <span class="gemarra-regular">until Rosh HaShana </span>of the Sabbatical Year. Although it is prohibited to plow other land in the time leading into the Sabbatical Year, to avoid the appearance of preparing to work the ground in that year, it is permitted to do so for the purpose of sustaining these young trees.
The Gemara calculates: <span class="gemarra-regular">How much is </span>the area of a <span class="it-text">beit</span> <span class="it-text">se’a</span>? It is <span class="gemarra-regular">2,500 </span>square <span class="gemarra-regular">cubits</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> And how much </span>area is allocated <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span><span class="gemarra-regular">each and every one </span>of the ten trees? It is <span class="gemarra-regular">250 </span>square cubits. <span class="gemarra-regular">This is not </span>the distance <span class="gemarra-regular">that Ulla</span> taught. An area of sixteen cubits to each side of the tree is a square of thirty-two by thirty-two cubits, or 1,024 square cubits, which is much larger than 250.
<span class="gemarra-regular">But rather, </span>Ulla derived this measurement <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">which </span><span class="gemarra-regular">we learned </span>in the following mishna (<span class="it-text">Shevi’it</span> 1:5): If there were <span class="gemarra-regular">three </span>large <span class="gemarra-regular">tree</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> belonging <span class="gemarra-regular">to three </span>different <span class="gemarra-regular">people</span> in one <span class="it-text">beit</span> <span class="it-text">se’a</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">these </span>trees <span class="gemarra-regular">combine, and one</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> may plow the entire</span>

Daf 27a

<span class="gemarra-italic">beit</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">se’a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for their </span>sake. <span class="gemarra-regular">How much </span>is that area in cubits? It is <span class="gemarra-regular">2,500 </span>square <span class="gemarra-regular">cubits. And how much </span>area is that <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span><span class="gemarra-regular">each </span>of the trees? It is <span class="gemarra-regular">833⅓. This is still </span><span class="gemarra-regular">more than </span>the amount <span class="gemarra-regular">that Ulla </span>established. The Gemara answers: Ulla <span class="gemarra-regular">was not precise </span>in this matter.
The Gemara asks: One can <span class="gemarra-regular">say that we say </span>that a Sage <span class="gemarra-regular">was not precise </span>in his measurements when his ruling leads <span class="gemarra-regular">to a stringency; </span>but <span class="gemarra-regular">do we say </span>that he <span class="gemarra-regular">was not precise </span>if his measurements lead <span class="gemarra-regular">to a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">leniency? </span>According to the previous explanation, Ulla exempts the owner of a tree from first fruits even in a case where his tree does not in fact draw nourishment from his neighbor’s field.
