The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Do </span><span class="gemarra-regular">you maintain </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">we say </span>the roots extend that far <span class="gemarra-regular">in a square, </span>i.e., one measures sixteen cubits to each side of the tree? Not so; <span class="gemarra-regular">we say </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to a circle, </span>that is, the roots extend in a circle surrounding the tree, as the area of a circle is smaller than that of the square circumscribing it.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Now, </span>by <span class="gemarra-regular">how much is </span>the area of <span class="gemarra-regular">a square greater than the </span>area of a <span class="gemarra-regular">circle </span>with a diameter the length of the side of that square? It is greater by <span class="gemarra-regular">one-quarte</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> of the area of the circle. If so, <span class="gemarra-regular">768 </span>square cubits, three-quarters of 1,024, <span class="gemarra-regular">remain </span>for each tree, but <span class="gemarra-regular">there still remains half a cubi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> more based on the mishna’s calculation. In other words, the measurement would be more accurate if a tree is considered to draw nourishment from a distance of sixteen and a half cubits on each side. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">This is </span>why we said that Ulla <span class="gemarra-regular">was not precise, and </span>he was <span class="gemarra-regular">not precise</span> in a manner that leads <span class="gemarra-regular">to a stringency, </span>as one brings first fruits even from a tree that stands just sixteen cubits from the boundary, rather than 16½.
The Gemara cites a proof against the opinion of Ulla. <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>the following mishna (<span class="it-text">Bikkurim</span> 1:11): <span class="gemarra-regular">One who buys a tree and its lan</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">brings </span>first fruits <span class="gemarra-regular">and recites </span>the requisite Torah verses (Deuteronomy 26:5–11) over them. <span class="gemarra-regular">What, is it not </span>referring to a case where one buys <span class="gemarra-regular">any amount </span>of land with the tree? The Gemara rejects this claim: <span class="gemarra-regular">No; </span>it is referring to a case where one buys <span class="gemarra-regular">sixteen cubits </span>of land around the tree.
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>an additional proof from another mishna (<span class="it-text">Bikkurim</span> 1:6): If one <span class="gemarra-regular">bought two tree</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in </span>the field <span class="gemarra-regular">of another, he </span><span class="gemarra-regular">brings </span>first fruits <span class="gemarra-regular">and does not recite </span>the verses, because the land does not belong to him. It may be inferred from here that if he bought <span class="gemarra-regular">three </span>trees <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span><span class="gemarra-regular">does brin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span> first fruits <span class="gemarra-regular">and recite </span>the verses. <span class="gemarra-regular">What, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is it not </span>referring to a case where one buys <span class="gemarra-regular">any amount </span>of land with the trees? The Gemara rejects this claim as well: <span class="gemarra-regular">No; here too </span>it is referring to a case where he acquires <span class="gemarra-regular">sixteen cubits </span>of land around the trees.
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a proof from a mishna (<span class="it-text">Pe’a</span> 3:6). <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Akiva says: </span>The owner of <span class="gemarra-regular">land of any </span>size <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">obligated in </span><span class="gemarra-italic">pe’a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and in first fruits, and </span>a lender <span class="gemarra-regular">can write a document that prevents the Sabbatical Year</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from abrogating an outstanding debt [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">prosbol</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for </span>this land, so that loans he provided will not be canceled at the close of the Sabbatical Year, 

Daf 27b

<span class="gemarra-regular">and he can acquire property that does </span><span class="gemarra-regular">not serve as a guarantee, </span>i.e., movable property, along <span class="gemarra-regular">with it</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> There are specific modes of acquisition for movable property, but if one is acquiring any amount of land at the same time as the movable property, the mode of acquisition employed to acquire the land suffices for the acquisition of the movable property as well. Apparently, any amount of land is subject to first fruits, whereas according to Ulla a tree acquired with less than sixteen cubits of land surrounding it draws nourishment from the land surrounding it and is exempt from first fruits. The Gemara rejects this: <span class="gemarra-regular">With what are we dealing here? </span>We are dealing <span class="gemarra-regular">with wheat, </span>which is subject to the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of first fruits and requires very little land to nourish it.
The Gemara comments that the language of the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">is also precise, as it teaches: </span>Land <span class="gemarra-regular">of any</span> size, which indicates even a miniscule amount, and all normal trees certainly require more land than that. The Gemara affirms: <span class="gemarra-regular">Learn from it </span>that it is so.
The Gemara further suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a proof from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> (<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span>, <span class="it-text">Ma’asrot</span> 2:22): If there is <span class="gemarra-regular">a tree</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, part of which is in Eretz </span>Yisrael <span class="gemarra-regular">and part </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of which is outside of Eretz </span>Yisrael, it is considered as though <span class="gemarra-regular">untithed produce</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., produce that is subject to the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of <span class="it-text">terumot</span> and tithes, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">non-sacred produce, </span>i.e., produce that is exempt from the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of <span class="it-text">terumot</span> and tithes, <span class="gemarra-regular">are mixed together </span>in each one of this tree’s fruits. This is <span class="gemarra-regular">the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> statement of Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: </span>With regard to the fruits in the part of the tree that is <span class="gemarra-regular">growing in </span>a place where there is <span class="gemarra-regular">an obligation </span>to separate tithes, i.e., in Eretz Yisrael, the owner is <span class="gemarra-regular">obligated </span>to separate tithes. With regard to the fruits that are <span class="gemarra-regular">growing in </span>a place where there is <span class="gemarra-regular">an exemption </span>from separating tithes, i.e., outside of Eretz Yisrael, the owner is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt.</span>
The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">They disagree </span><span class="gemarra-regular">only in that </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage, </span>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel, <span class="gemarra-regular">holds</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">there is </span>retroactive <span class="gemarra-regular">designation, </span>and therefore it is assumed that the nourishment drawn from Eretz Yisrael sustained the fruit that grew on that side of the tree, and the nourishment drawn from outside Eretz Yisrael sustained the fruit that grew there. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage, </span>Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi, <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">there is no </span>retroactive <span class="gemarra-regular">designation, </span>and the fruit is considered mixed.
<span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if the tree <span class="gemarra-regular">grew </span>entirely <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>a place where there is <span class="gemarra-regular">an exemption </span>from separating tithes, i.e., outside Eretz Yisrael, <span class="gemarra-regular">all agree </span>that the owner is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt, </span>even though the tree might have roots within sixteen cubits of Eretz Yisrael and draw nourishment from there. This presents a difficulty for the opinion of Ulla, as he claims that the place from where a tree draws its nourishment is decisive with regard to first fruits.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">With what are we dealing</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> here? </span>We are dealing with a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where a rock</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> divides </span>the roots up to the trunk, and therefore it is possible to distinguish between the parts of the tree that draw nutrients from Eretz Yisrael and the parts that draw nutrients from outside of Eretz Yisrael. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, what is the reasoning of Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi? Why does he view the fruits as being a mixture? The Gemara answers: He holds that although there is a division between the roots, they cannot be distinguished from one another, <span class="gemarra-regular">as they then become mixed </span>in the body of the tree.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And with regard to what</span> principle <span class="gemarra-regular">do they disagree? </span>The Gemara answers: One <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage, </span>Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi, <span class="gemarra-regular">holds: The air </span>above the ground <span class="gemarra-regular">mixes </span>the nutrients, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage, </span>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel, <span class="gemarra-regular">holds: This</span> part of the tree <span class="gemarra-regular">stands alone and this </span>part of the tree <span class="gemarra-regular">stands alone. </span>From the roots up to the branches, it is as if the tree were cut along the line of the border.
The Gemara raises a difficulty against Ulla’s opinion from a different perspective: <span class="gemarra-regular">And</span> do roots extend <span class="gemarra-regular">sixteen cubits and no more? Didn’t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> we learn </span>in a mishna (25b): <span class="gemarra-regular">One must distance a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> tree twenty-five cubits from a cistern? </span>This indicates that tree roots reach more than sixteen cubits. <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said: </span>The roots <span class="gemarra-regular">extend farther, </span>but <span class="gemarra-regular">they weaken the ground only up</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to sixteen cubits; </span>with regard to an area any <span class="gemarra-regular">more</span> distant than that, <span class="gemarra-regular">they do not weaken </span>the ground.
Concerning this matter the Gemara relates that <span class="gemarra-regular">when Rav Dimi came </span>from Eretz Yisrael <span class="gemarra-regular">he said: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Reish Lakish raised a dilemma before Rabbi Yoḥanan: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a tree </span>that is <span class="gemarra-regular">within sixteen cubits of a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">boundary</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? Rabbi Yoḥanan <span class="gemarra-regular">said to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> him: </span>The owner <span class="gemarra-regular">is a robber, and one does not</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> bring first fruits from it.</span>
By contrast, <span class="gemarra-regular">when Ravin came </span>from Eretz Yisrael, he related that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: Both </span>in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a tree that is close to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a boundary and a tree that leans </span>into a neighbor’s yard, <span class="gemarra-regular">one brings </span>first fruits <span class="gemarra-regular">and recites </span>the verses, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it was on this conditio</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that Joshua apportioned Eretz</span> Yisrael <span class="gemarra-regular">to the Jewish people, </span>i.e., that they would not be particular about such matters.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a tree that leans into the field of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">another</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the neighbor <span class="gemarra-regular">may cut </span>the branches <span class="gemarra-regular">to the height</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of an ox </span><span class="gemarra-regular">goa</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> raised <span class="gemarra-regular">over the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">plow</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> in places where the land is to be plowed, so that the branches do not impede the use of the plow. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>in the case <span class="gemarra-regular">of a carob tree and </span>the case <span class="gemarra-regular">of a sycamore </span><span class="gemarra-regular">tree</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> whose abundance of branches cast shade that is harmful to plants, all the branches overhanging one’s property may be removed <span class="gemarra-regular">along the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">plumb </span><span class="gemarra-regular">line</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., along a line perpendicular to the boundary separating the fields. And if the neighbor’s field is <span class="gemarra-regular">an irrigated field, all </span>branches of <span class="gemarra-regular">the tree </span>are removed <span class="gemarra-regular">along the plumb line. Abba Shaul says: All </span><span class="gemarra-regular">barren trees </span>are cut <span class="gemarra-regular">along the plumb line.</span>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">A dilemma </span><span class="gemarra-regular">was raised before them: </span>Is <span class="gemarra-regular">Abba Shaul referring to the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">first clause </span>of the mishna, which states that a tree extending into a neighbor’s field is cut only to the height of an ox goad, and Abba Shaul maintains that barren trees have the same <span class="it-text">halakha</span> as carob and sycamore trees in that they are cut along the plumb line? <span class="gemarra-regular">Or </span>is he <span class="gemarra-regular">referring to the latter clause, </span>which discusses an irrigated field, and he permits cutting only barren trees along the plumb line, but not fruit trees?
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a resolution to this dilemma, <span class="gemarra-regular">as</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">an</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> irrigated field, Abba Shaul says: All </span>types of <span class="gemarra-regular">trees </span>are cut <span class="gemarra-regular">along the plumb line, because the shade is harmful</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to an irrigated field</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> This shows that he does not dispute the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of the latter clause. <span class="gemarra-regular">Learn from</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">he is referring to the first claus</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> of the mishna. The Gemara affirms: <span class="gemarra-regular">Learn from it </span>that it is so.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Ashi said </span>that the wording of <span class="gemarra-regular">the mishna is also </span><span class="gemarra-regular">precise, as it teaches: All barren trees. Granted, if you </span><span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that Abba Shaul <span class="gemarra-regular">is referring to the first clause </span>of the mishna, <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>is the reason <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>Abba Shaul <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches: All </span>barren <span class="gemarra-regular">trees. But if you say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is referring to the latter clause, he should have </span>said simply: <span class="gemarra-regular">Barren trees, </span>as the first <span class="it-text">tanna</span> permits one to cut down any type of tree. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, isn’t it </span>correct to <span class="gemarra-regular">conclude from it </span>that he is <span class="gemarra-regular">referring to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the first clause? </span>The Gemara affirms: <span class="gemarra-regular">Learn from it </span>that it is so.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a tree that extends into the public </span><span class="gemarra-regular">domain</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">one cuts </span>its branches <span class="gemarra-regular">so that a camel can pass</span> beneath the tree <span class="gemarra-regular">with its rider </span>sitting on it. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Yehuda says: </span>One cuts enough branches that <span class="gemarra-regular">a camel loaded</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with flax or bundles of branches </span>can pass beneath it. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon says: </span>One cuts <span class="gemarra-regular">all </span>branches of <span class="gemarra-regular">the tree</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that </span>extend into the public domain <span class="gemarra-regular">along the plumb line</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>so that they do not hang over the public area at all, <span class="gemarra-regular">due to ritual impurity.</span>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Who </span>is the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> who <span class="gemarra-regular">taught </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to damage </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">follows the current assessment, </span>and future damage is not taken into account? The mishna states that the tree’s branches are cut to the height of a camel and its rider or load but no more, despite the fact that they will certainly grow again.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Reish </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Lakish says: </span>This <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is taught as a dispute, and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">it is </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Eliezer. As we learned </span>in a mishna (60a): One <span class="gemarra-regular">may not make </span>an empty <span class="gemarra-regular">space beneath the public domain </span>by digging <span class="gemarra-regular">pits, ditches, or</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> caves. Rabbi Eliezer permits </span>one to dig a pit if it is subsequently covered with material strong <span class="gemarra-regular">enough that a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> wagon loaded with stones can travel on it </span>without it collapsing. If the cover can withstand such weight when the pit is dug, it is permitted, despite the fact that the cover might eventually rot.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan said: You </span>may <span class="gemarra-regular">even say </span>that the mishna here represents the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis, </span>who prohibit one from digging beneath the public domain under any circumstances. The difference is that <span class="gemarra-regular">there, </span>the cover <span class="gemarra-regular">will occasionally deteriorate, and </span>as this matter is <span class="gemarra-regular">not</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> on his mind </span>it will cause damage. <span class="gemarra-regular">But here, </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">each </span>branch grows <span class="gemarra-regular">he cuts it off. </span>Since the potential cause of damage is visible, there is no concern that it might be neglected.
§ The mishna teaches that if the branches of a tree extend into the public domain, one may cut them to allow a camel and its rider to pass underneath; <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda says: </span>One cuts enough branches that <span class="gemarra-regular">a camel loaded with flax or bundles of branches </span>can pass beneath it. <span class="gemarra-regular">A dilemma was raised before </span>the Sages: Is <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda’s measure greater, or </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">perhaps </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis’ measure greater? </span>Which reaches a greater height, a camel and rider or a camel loaded with flax?
The Gemara answers: It is <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious that the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbis’ measure </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">greater, as, if it enters your mind </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda’s measure </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">greater, how would the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbis act in </span>the circumstance of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda’s measure? </span>It is clear that a camel will have to pass beneath the tree with a burden, and it would not be able to do so. The Gemara expresses surprise at this claim: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, what </span>then would you say? That <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbis’ measure </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">greater? </span>If so, <span class="gemarra-regular">how would Rabbi Yehuda </span><span class="gemarra-regular">act in </span>the circumstance of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis’ measure? </span>It is also clear that a camel will have to pass there with its rider. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">It is possible for </span>the rider <span class="gemarra-regular">to bend over and to pass underneath </span>the branches.
§ The mishna teaches that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon says: </span>One cuts <span class="gemarra-regular">all</span> branches of <span class="gemarra-regular">the tree </span>that extend into the public domain <span class="gemarra-regular">along the plumb line, due to ritual impurity. </span>The Gemara explains: A <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that this is <span class="gemarra-regular">due to ritual impurity </span>imparted in <span class="gemarra-regular">a tent. </span>Branches over a corpse might create a tent, thereby transferring impurity to whatever is beneath the branches, rendering impure those passing under the tree in the public domain. The Gemara expresses surprise at this statement: It is <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious </span>that this is the reason. <span class="gemarra-regular">We </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">learned </span>that it is <span class="gemarra-regular">due to ritual</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> impurity. </span>How else could ritual impurity be transferred through branches other than by means of a tent?
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>this is learned <span class="gemarra-regular">from the mishna </span>alone, <span class="gemarra-regular">I would say </span>that the concern is that <span class="gemarra-regular">perhaps a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">crow might bring </span>a source of <span class="gemarra-regular">impurity </span>and perch on the tree’s branches <span class="gemarra-regular">and throw it there. And </span>if that were the only concern, <span class="gemarra-regular">a mere scarecrow [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">bedaḥlulei</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">would be sufficient </span>to frighten the crows away and prevent that type of impurity. Therefore, the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>that the concern is due to impurity imparted in a tent.


Daf 28a

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumptive ownership of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">houses</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">pits; and </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">ditches; and </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">caves, </span>which are used to collect water; <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">dovecotes; and </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">bathhouses; and </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">olive presses; and </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">irrigated fields, </span>which must be watered by people; <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">slaves; and all </span>similar property <span class="gemarra-regular">that constantly, </span>i.e., throughout the year, <span class="gemarra-regular">generates profits, their presumptive ownership </span>is established by working and profiting from them for a duration of <span class="gemarra-regular">three years from day to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">day</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> If the one in possession of the property can prove that he worked and profited from it for the previous three full years, there is a presumption that it belongs to him, and would remain in his possession if another were to claim that the property belonged to him or to his ancestors.
With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a non-irrigated field, </span>i.e., one that is watered by rain, in which produce grows during certain seasons during the year, <span class="gemarra-regular">its presumption </span>of ownership is established in <span class="gemarra-regular">three years, but they are not from day to day</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> since the fields are not worked and harvested continually throughout the three-year period.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yishmael says: Three months </span>of possession <span class="gemarra-regular">in the first </span>year, <span class="gemarra-regular">three </span>months of possession <span class="gemarra-regular">in the last </span>year, <span class="gemarra-regular">and twelve months </span>of possession <span class="gemarra-regular">in the middle, which are eighteen months, </span>suffice to establish the presumption of ownership with regard to a non-irrigated field.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Akiva says: A month </span>of possession <span class="gemarra-regular">in the first </span>year, <span class="gemarra-regular">and a month </span>of possession <span class="gemarra-regular">in the last year, and twelve months </span>of possession <span class="gemarra-regular">in the middle, which are fourteen months, </span>suffice to establish the presumption of ownership with regard to a non-irrigated field.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yishmael said: In what </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">is this statement, </span>that eighteen months are required for a non-irrigated field, <span class="gemarra-regular">said? </span>It is said <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to a white field [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">bisdeh</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">lavan</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., a grain field. <span class="gemarra-regular">But with regard to a field of trees, </span>once <span class="gemarra-regular">he gathered his produce, and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">harvested his olives, </span>and then <span class="gemarra-regular">gathered his figs</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> these </span>three harvests <span class="gemarra-regular">are </span>the equivalent of <span class="gemarra-regular">three years. </span>Since he harvested three types of produce, this is equivalent to having possessed the field for three years.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: I heard from those who travel to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Ush</span><span class="gemarra-regular">a</span> to study with the Sages there <span class="gemarra-regular">that they would say: From where </span>is it derived <span class="gemarra-regular">that presumptive ownership </span>is established in <span class="gemarra-regular">three years? From the forewarned ox: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Just as </span>in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a forewarned ox, once it has </span>intentionally <span class="gemarra-regular">gored three </span><span class="gemarra-regular">gorings</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">it left </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumptive status of an innocuous </span>ox <span class="gemarra-regular">and it is established as </span>having the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumptive status of a forewarned </span>ox, <span class="gemarra-regular">here too, once he has </span>worked and <span class="gemarra-regular">profited </span>from the land for <span class="gemarra-regular">three years, </span>the land <span class="gemarra-regular">left the possession of </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">seller, and it is established </span>as being <span class="gemarra-regular">in the possession of </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">buyer.</span>
The Gemara questions this comparison: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>so, say that <span class="gemarra-regular">just as with a forewarned ox, </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">is not liable </span>to pay full damages <span class="gemarra-regular">until the fourth goring, here too, </span>the land should <span class="gemarra-regular">not be established </span>as being <span class="gemarra-regular">in his possession until the fourth year</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> The Gemara rejects this question: <span class="gemarra-regular">How can </span>these cases <span class="gemarra-regular">be compared? There, once it has gored three </span>times <span class="gemarra-regular">it is forewarned, </span>

Daf 28b

<span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the requirement for there to be <span class="gemarra-regular">another, </span>fourth, incident for the owner to be liable to pay full damages exists because <span class="gemarra-regular">before it gores </span>after having become a forewarned ox, <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>is there for the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">to pay? Here, once he has </span>worked and <span class="gemarra-regular">profited </span>from the land for <span class="gemarra-regular">three years, </span>the land <span class="gemarra-regular">is established </span>as being <span class="gemarra-regular">in his possession.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If that is so, </span>according to the explanation that the forewarned ox is the source for the presumption of ownership with regard to land, even <span class="gemarra-regular">possession that is not accompanied by a claim, </span>i.e., where the possessor has no explanation as to how he acquired it, <span class="gemarra-regular">should be </span>sufficient to establish the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership, just as goring three times automatically establishes its having the status of a forewarned ox. <span class="gemarra-regular">Why did we learn </span>in a mishna (41a): <span class="gemarra-regular">Any possession that is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not accompanied by a claim </span>explaining how the possessor became the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">is not </span>sufficient to establish the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership?
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>that possession that is not accompanied by a claim is not sufficient to establish the presumption of ownership? <span class="gemarra-regular">Because </span>in a standard case where one has presumptive ownership, <span class="gemarra-regular">we sa</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span> that even if the claimant proves that the field was once his, since the other is in possession of the land, <span class="gemarra-regular">perhaps </span>the truth is <span class="gemarra-regular">as he says, </span>that he purchased it from the previous owner. But <span class="gemarra-regular">now </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span>himself <span class="gemarra-regular">does not claim </span>that he purchased it, <span class="gemarra-regular">will we claim </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">for him?</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Avira objects to </span>the explanation that the presumption with regard to land is derived from the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of a forewarned ox: <span class="gemarra-regular">If that is so, a protest that </span>the claimant lodges during the three years <span class="gemarra-regular">not in the presence </span>of the possessor <span class="gemarra-regular">should not be </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">a protest, </span>because it must be <span class="gemarra-regular">similar </span>to the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">of a forewarned ox: Just as we require </span>that the testimony concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">a forewarned ox </span>be <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>its owner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">presence</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> so too here, we </span>should <span class="gemarra-regular">also require </span>that a protest be lodged <span class="gemarra-regular">in the </span>possessor’s <span class="gemarra-regular">presence.</span>
The Gemara answers: This is not difficult. <span class="gemarra-regular">There, </span>with regard to a forewarned ox, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is written: “And warning has been given to its owner” </span>(Exodus 21:29), indicating that the warning must be issued in the presence of the owner. <span class="gemarra-regular">Here, </span>with regard to the protest, <span class="gemarra-regular">your friend has a friend, and the friend of your friend has a friend, </span>so that the protest will become known even if lodged not in the presence of the possessor, as word of it will spread. There is no Torah edict mandating that the protest be lodged in his presence, and it is sufficient that he hears of it, even secondhand.
The Gemara further asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>according <span class="gemarra-regular">to Rabbi Meir, who</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> says: </span>When the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">performs its gorings at intervals </span>its owner is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable, </span>if it <span class="gemarra-regular">performs its gorings successively, </span>is it <span class="gemarra-regular">not all the more so </span>the case that its owner is liable? According to his opinion, the animal must gore only three times to become forewarned, and it is not required that the gorings occur on three separate days; they can all occur on the same day. Similarly, one could say that if <span class="gemarra-regular">he profited </span>from the field by consuming <span class="gemarra-regular">three fruits </span>of, <span class="gemarra-regular">for example, a fig </span>tree, <span class="gemarra-regular">within one day, that should be </span>sufficient to establish the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership.
The Gemara answers: This would not be a valid comparison, as presumptive ownership with regard to land must be <span class="gemarra-regular">similar </span>to the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">of a forewarned ox: Just as </span>with <span class="gemarra-regular">a forewarned ox, at the time when </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">has this goring, it does not have that goring, </span>as each act of goring occurs at a separate time, <span class="gemarra-regular">here too, </span>in order for the consumption of the produce to establish the presumption of ownership, it must be that <span class="gemarra-regular">at the time when this fruit is here, that fruit is not here. </span>When all the produce of the field is extant concurrently, consumption of this produce does not establish the presumption of ownership, even if the produce is consumed at three different times.
The Gemara asks: Based on this, if <span class="gemarra-regular">he profited </span>from the field by consuming <span class="gemarra-regular">three fruits within three </span>consecutive <span class="gemarra-regular">days, for example, </span>the fruits of <span class="gemarra-regular">a caper bush</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> whose fruits ripen day after day, <span class="gemarra-regular">that should be </span>sufficient to establish the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership, as all three fruits were not ripe concurrently. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">There, </span>with regard to the caper bush, <span class="gemarra-regular">at least the fruit is here and it is in the process of finishing </span>its ripening during the three days. This is not similar to the goring ox, where each goring is fully independent of the others.
The Gemara challenges: Based on this, if <span class="gemarra-regular">he profited </span>from the field by consuming <span class="gemarra-regular">three fruits within thirty days, for example, alfalfa [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">aspasta</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> which quickly regrows when cut, and which is repeatedly cut over a short period of time, <span class="gemarra-regular">that should be </span>sufficient to establish the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership. The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">What are the circumstances </span>where it could regrow three times within thirty days? <span class="gemarra-regular">Where it grows a little </span>and he cuts <span class="gemarra-regular">and consumes it</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> where it grows a little </span>more <span class="gemarra-regular">and he consumes it, </span>such that he cuts it three times within thirty days. <span class="gemarra-regular">There, he is seizing and consuming </span>the alfalfa, which is not the normal way of farming it, and consequently he does not establish the presumption of ownership, which is established only through standard use of the land.
The Gemara challenges: Based on this, if <span class="gemarra-regular">he profited </span>from the field by consuming <span class="gemarra-regular">three fruits within three months, for example, alfalfa, </span>where he did employ the standard method of harvesting it, <span class="gemarra-regular">that should be </span>sufficient to establish the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership. The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">Who are </span>they <span class="gemarra-regular">who travel to Usha </span>whose opinion is under discussion? It is <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yishmael. Indeed, </span>according <span class="gemarra-regular">to Rabbi Yishmael, </span>this would establish the presumption of ownership.
This is <span class="gemarra-regular">as we learned </span>in the mishna that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yishmael says: In what </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">is this statement, </span>that eighteen months are required for a non-irrigated field, <span class="gemarra-regular">said? With regard to a white field, </span>i.e., a grain field. <span class="gemarra-regular">But with regard to a field of trees, </span>once <span class="gemarra-regular">he gathered his produce, and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">harvested his olives, and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">gathered his figs, these </span>three harvests <span class="gemarra-regular">are </span>the equivalent of <span class="gemarra-regular">three years. </span>Rabbi Yishmael is of the opinion that three harvests are sufficient.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">According to the Rabbis, </span>who hold that three years, and not three harvests, are required to establish the presumption of ownership, <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>is the source for the concept of this type of presumptive ownership?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">it is written </span>in the <span class="gemarra-regular">verse </span>detailing the purchase of a field from Hanamel by Jeremiah, his cousin, during the time of the siege of Eretz Yisrael: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Men shall buy fields for money, and subscribe the deeds, and seal them” </span>(Jeremiah 32:44). This describes the writing of a bill of sale to serve as proof of ownership of the field, since he was unable to remain living there for three years to establish the presumption of ownership. <span class="gemarra-regular">As the prophet </span>Jeremiah <span class="gemarra-regular">stood in the tenth </span>year of King Zedekiah’s reign <span class="gemarra-regular">and warned </span>people to write bills of sale <span class="gemarra-regular">for the eleventh </span>year, when Eretz Yisrael would be overrun. Consequently, despite the fact that one purchasing a field there would be able to live on the land for two years, this would not be sufficient to establish the presumption of ownership, which is why he said that they should have bills of sale written.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said to him: Perhaps there he </span>merely <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us good advice</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> that it is advisable to have documents to preclude the need to present witnesses that can attest that one had been living on the land. This is not a proof that the presumption of ownership cannot be established in less than three years. 

Daf 29a

<span class="gemarra-regular">Because if you do not say so, </span>then when he states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Build houses, and dwell in them, and plant gardens, and eat the fruit of them” </span>(Jeremiah 29:5), <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>halakhic statement <span class="gemarra-regular">was he saying? Rather, he teaches us good advice, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">here too he teaches us good advice. </span>The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">Know </span>that this was mere advice, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is written: “And put them in an earthen vessel; that they may continue many days” </span>(Jeremiah 32:14). This is obviously good advice to preserve the items properly, and is not a halakhic statement. Therefore, this is not a proof that the presumption of ownership cannot be established in under three years.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Rava said </span>a different reason: <span class="gemarra-regular">A person </span>who sees another profiting from his field might <span class="gemarra-regular">waive </span>his rights during <span class="gemarra-regular">the first year, </span>and he might <span class="gemarra-regular">waive </span>his rights for <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>years, but <span class="gemarra-regular">he will not waive </span>his rights for <span class="gemarra-regular">three </span>years. Therefore, if one does not lodge a protest by the end of the third year, it is tantamount to a concession that the land is not his.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said to him: If that is so, when </span>it becomes clear that <span class="gemarra-regular">the land </span>is in fact owned by another and it <span class="gemarra-regular">is returned </span>to its owner, <span class="gemarra-regular">it should be returned, save for the produce </span>that the possessor consumed during the first two years, as the owner waived his rights to it. <span class="gemarra-regular">Why did Rav Naḥman say: The land is returned and the produce is returned?</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Rava said </span>a different reason: <span class="gemarra-regular">A person is not particula</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the first year </span>to lodge a protest, and he <span class="gemarra-regular">is not particular </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>years, even though he does not waive his rights to the pro-duce. He <span class="gemarra-regular">is particular </span>to lodge a protest when he sees another profiting from his field for <span class="gemarra-regular">three </span>years. Therefore, if one does not lodge a protest by the end of the third year, it is tantamount to a concession that the land is not his.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said to him: If that is so, </span>for people <span class="gemarra-regular">such as those of the bar Elyashiv household</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> who are particular even with regard to one who goes on the boundary of their </span>field, <span class="gemarra-regular">here too, </span>will you say <span class="gemarra-regular">that presumptive ownership is </span>established <span class="gemarra-regular">immediately, </span>as soon as one makes use of their property without their lodging a protest? <span class="gemarra-regular">And if you would say </span>that is <span class="gemarra-regular">indeed </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">if so, you have subjected your statement to the </span>varying <span class="gemarra-regular">circumstances </span>of each case, as there will be a different length of time needed to establish the presumption of ownership depending on who the prior owner is. This is untenable.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Rava said </span>a different reason: <span class="gemarra-regular">A person is carefu</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with his document </span>detailing his purchase of land for <span class="gemarra-regular">the first year </span>after the purchase, and he <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">careful </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">two and three </span>years. For <span class="gemarra-regular">more </span>time than that, <span class="gemarra-regular">he is not carefu</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span> and might discard the document if no one has lodged a protest concerning his possession of the land. Therefore, the Sages ruled that after three years have passed, he can prove his ownership by means of presumptive ownership.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said to him: If that is so, a protest that </span>is lodged <span class="gemarra-regular">not in his presence should not be </span>a valid <span class="gemarra-regular">protest, </span>and if three years pass with no protest in his presence, presumptive ownership should be established even if there was a protest lodged before other people. This is <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>the one possessing the land can <span class="gemarra-regular">say to </span>the claimant: <span class="gemarra-regular">If you had protested in my presence, I would have been careful with my document </span>and would not have discarded it.
The Gemara explains that this claim would not be accepted, <span class="gemarra-regular">be-cause </span>the claimant can <span class="gemarra-regular">say to him: Your friend has a friend</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and your friend’s friend has a friend, </span>and the assumption is that word of the protest reached you.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna says: </span>The <span class="gemarra-regular">three years that </span>the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">sai</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> are required to establish the presumption of ownership <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">when he </span>worked and <span class="gemarra-regular">profited </span>from the field in <span class="gemarra-regular">consecutive </span>years. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is </span>Rav Huna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaching us </span>with this statement? <span class="gemarra-regular">We learned </span>this in the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">Their presumption </span>of ownership is established by use for a duration of <span class="gemarra-regular">three years from day to day. </span>The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Lest you say </span>that the phrase: <span class="gemarra-regular">From day to day, </span>serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to exclude partial </span>years and to teach that each of the three years must be full, <span class="gemarra-regular">and actually even scattered, </span>i.e., non-consecutive, years are sufficient, therefore, Rav Huna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>that the years must be consecutive.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥama says: And Rav Huna concedes with regard to locations where </span>they leave <span class="gemarra-regular">fields [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">bagei</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> to <span class="gemarra-regular">lie fallo</span><span class="gemarra-regular">w</span> by planting in alternate years, that the three years combine despite not being consecutive, as that is the manner in which owners profit from the land.
The Gemara asks: Isn’t it <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious </span>that this is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>to state this with regard to locations <span class="gemarra-regular">where there are </span>some people <span class="gemarra-regular">who leave </span>the fields to <span class="gemarra-regular">lie fallow and there are </span>some people <span class="gemarra-regular">who do not leave </span>the fields to <span class="gemarra-regular">lie fallow, and this man left </span>the field to <span class="gemarra-regular">lie fallow. Lest you say </span>that the claimant can <span class="gemarra-regular">say to him: If it is so that </span>the land <span class="gemarra-regular">is yours, you should have sown it, </span>therefore, Rav Ḥama <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us that </span>the possessor <span class="gemarra-regular">can say to </span>the claimant: <span class="gemarra-regular">I am not able to </span>hire someone to <span class="gemarra-regular">guard one </span>parcel of <span class="gemarra-regular">land within an entire field</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and I acted like those who own other land in this location and let the field lie fallow.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And alternatively, </span>the possessor can say to the claimant: <span class="gemarra-regular">In thi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> manner of farming it is <span class="gemarra-regular">beneficial for me </span>to farm, <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>the land <span class="gemarra-regular">produces more </span>later, and I do not wish to plant year after year and weaken the soil.
The Gemara clarifies Rav Huna’s statement that the presumption of ownership can be established only by consecutive use. <span class="gemarra-regular">We learned </span>in the mishna about the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumptive ownership of houses. But </span>with regard to the use of <span class="gemarra-regular">houses, where </span>the witnesses attesting to its use <span class="gemarra-regular">know </span>who uses the house only <span class="gemarra-regular">in the day, </span>but <span class="gemarra-regular">they do not know </span>who uses the house <span class="gemarra-regular">in the night, </span>how then can one establish the presumption of ownership in the case of a house? The possessor’s use is not consecutive, as it is continually interrupted by the nights.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said: Who testifies about houses? Neighbors, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">neighbors kno</span><span class="gemarra-regular">w</span> who is inside <span class="gemarra-regular">in the day and in the night.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said </span>that there is another scenario in which one can bring witnesses with regard to the use of a house. This is <span class="gemarra-regular">such as when two </span>people <span class="gemarra-regular">come and say</span><span class="gemarra-regular">:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> We rented </span>the house <span class="gemarra-regular">from hi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">m</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and we lived in it for three years, in the day and in the night. </span>This testimony substantiates that the house was used under the authority of the one who is attempting to prove that he has established the presumption of ownership.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yeimar said to Rav Ashi: </span>How can their testimony be relied upon? <span class="gemarra-regular">These </span>witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">are biased in their testimony</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> because if they do not say this </span>testimony, that they rented the house from the possessor for three consecutive years, <span class="gemarra-regular">we say to them: Go </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">give payment for </span>the rental of <span class="gemarra-regular">the house to that </span>one who is claiming ownership, as the one you paid has not established that he is the true owner.
Rav Ashi <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Low</span>-level <span class="gemarra-regular">judges rule this way. </span>In other words, only a court composed of ignorant judges would accept the testimony of the renters of the house in a case where they are biased in their testimony. Nevertheless, Rava’s scenario is still possible, as, <span class="gemarra-regular">are we not dealing with </span>a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where they are holding </span>the money for the <span class="gemarra-regular">payment for </span>the rental of <span class="gemarra-regular">the house</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and they are saying </span>to the court: <span class="gemarra-regular">To whom shall we give it? </span>Therefore, they are not biased in their testimony, because they will pay the same amount, regardless of who the actual owner is.
The Gemara quotes a related statement. <span class="gemarra-regular">Mar Zutra said</span><span class="gemarra-regular">:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> And if </span>the claimant <span class="gemarra-regular">claims and says: Let two witnesses come to testify for </span>the possessor <span class="gemarra-regular">that he lived in </span>the house <span class="gemarra-regular">three years in the day and in the night, his claim is </span>a legitimate <span class="gemarra-regular">claim. </span>

Daf 29b

<span class="gemarra-regular">And Mar Zutra concedes with regard to peddler</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> who travel through cities</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> during which time others might live in their houses, <span class="gemarra-regular">that even though </span>the claimant <span class="gemarra-regular">does not claim </span>that he insists on testimony that there was continuous use, day and night, over three years, <span class="gemarra-regular">we </span>the court <span class="gemarra-regular">claim </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">for him. </span>Since people know they are traveling salesmen, it is more likely that people lived in their houses without permission and without their knowledge.
With regard to the requirement for continuous day and night use to establish the presumption of ownership, the Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav Huna concede</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with regard to a store </span>in the town <span class="gemarra-regular">of Meḥoza</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> which </span>is generally <span class="gemarra-regular">used in the day </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">is not </span>generally <span class="gemarra-regular">used in the night, </span>that one is not required to use it in the night to establish the presumption of ownership.
With regard to the requirement of continuous use to establish the presumption of ownership, the Gemara relates that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rami bar Ḥama and Rav Ukva bar Ḥama purchased a maidservant together. </span>One <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage made use of her </span>during the <span class="gemarra-regular">first, third, and fifth </span>years, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage made use of her </span>during the <span class="gemarra-regular">second, fourth, and sixth </span>years. <span class="gemarra-regular">One </span>individual <span class="gemarra-regular">who contested </span>their ownership <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span>the maidservant <span class="gemarra-regular">emerged </span>and claimed that he was the owner.
<span class="gemarra-regular">They came before Rava </span>for a judgment. <span class="gemarra-regular">He said to them: What is the reason you acted like this, </span>making use of her in alternate years, <span class="gemarra-regular">so that </span>each of <span class="gemarra-regular">you would not establish </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption</span> of ownership<span class="gemarra-regular"> concerning each other </span>by making use of her for three consecutive years? <span class="gemarra-regular">Just as </span>this usage does <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>establish the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership<span class="gemarra-regular"> with regard to you</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> it does <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>establish the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption</span> of ownership<span class="gemarra-regular"> with regard to others, </span>i.e., the claimant in this case, <span class="gemarra-regular">as well.</span>
The Gemara adds: <span class="gemarra-regular">And we said </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">was not written </span>in a <span class="gemarra-regular">document </span>that they are partners and are dividing the use, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>if it <span class="gemarra-regular">was written </span>in a <span class="gemarra-regular">document, </span>the document generates <span class="gemarra-regular">publicit</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span> that they own the maidservant as partners rather than individually, and they can jointly establish the presumption of ownership.
§ The Gemara continues its discussion of the requirement for full use of land to establish the presumption of ownership. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava says: </span>If one worked and <span class="gemarra-regular">profited, </span>for three years, <span class="gemarra-regular">from all of </span>the land <span class="gemarra-regular">except for </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">area required for sowing a quarter-</span><span class="gemarra-italic">kav</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of seed [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">beit</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">rova</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> which he did not use, <span class="gemarra-regular">he acquires all </span>of the field based on presumptive ownership <span class="gemarra-regular">except for </span>that <span class="gemarra-italic">beit</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">rova</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna, son of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehoshua, says: And we said </span>this ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">only where </span>that <span class="it-text">beit</span> <span class="it-text">rova</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is suitable for planting, but </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">it is not suitable for planting, he acquires it by means of </span>the acquisition of the rest of the <span class="gemarra-regular">land</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Beivai bar Abaye objects to this: If that is so, how could one acquire </span>an area that is only <span class="gemarra-regular">roc</span><span class="gemarra-regular">k</span> by establishing the presump-tion of ownership, as one does not plant rocky land? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>the presumption of ownership can be established <span class="gemarra-regular">by standing animals on it or spreading produce on it. Here too, he should be require</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to stand animals on </span>the <span class="it-text">beit</span> <span class="it-text">rova</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">or </span>to <span class="gemarra-regular">spread produce on it. </span>If he did not profit from this small piece of land at all, he has not established the presumption of ownership with regard to it, and acquires only the rest of the field.
§ The Gemara relates that there was <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain </span>person <span class="gemarra-regular">who said to another: What do you want, </span>i.e., what are you doing, <span class="gemarra-regular">with this house </span>of mine? The other <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: I purchased it from you and I </span>worked and <span class="gemarra-regular">profited </span>from <span class="gemarra-regular">it </span>for the <span class="gemarra-regular">years </span>necessary for establishing the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership. The claimant <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: I was among the distant settlements</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and was unaware that you were residing in my house, which is why I did not lodge a protest.
The one residing in the house <span class="gemarra-regular">came before Rav Naḥman </span>for a judgment. Rav Naḥman <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Go clarify your profiting</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., prove that you really resided there for three years, and then the case can be judged. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said to </span>Rav Naḥman: Is <span class="gemarra-regular">this the </span>correct <span class="gemarra-regular">judgment? </span>The <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is that <span class="gemarra-regular">the burden of proof rests upon the claimant. </span>Therefore, the one who is attempting to take the house from the possessor should have to prove that the other did not reside in the house.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises a contradiction </span>between this statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rava and </span>another statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rava, and </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">raises a contradiction </span>between this statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav Naḥman and </span>another statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav Naḥman. As </span>there was <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain </span>person

Daf 30a

<span class="gemarra-regular">who said to another: I </span>am hereby <span class="gemarra-regular">selling to you all </span>of the <span class="gemarra-regular">property </span>that I own <span class="gemarra-regular">of the house of bar Sisin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> There was a certain </span>parcel of <span class="gemarra-regular">land that was called: Of the house of bar Sisin. </span>The seller <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>the buyer: <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>parcel of land that I own is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>actually <span class="gemarra-regular">of the house of bar Sisin, and it is </span>merely <span class="gemarra-regular">called: Of the house of bar Sisin, </span>and it is not included in the sale. <span class="gemarra-regular">They came before Rav Naḥman </span>for judgment, and <span class="gemarra-regular">he established </span>the land <span class="gemarra-regular">in the possession of the buyer. Rava said to </span>Rav Naḥman: Is <span class="gemarra-regular">this the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? </span>Isn’t the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">the burden of proof rests upon the claimant, </span>and the land should remain in the possession of the seller?
The Gemara continues: There is <span class="gemarra-regular">a difficulty </span>from one statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rava to </span>another statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rava, </span>and there is also <span class="gemarra-regular">a difficulty </span>from one statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav Naḥman to </span>another statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav Naḥman, </span>as in the first case, where the claimant states that he had been in a distant location, Rav Naḥman ruled in favor of the claimant, and Rava ruled in favor of the possessor; while in the second case, that of the property of bar Sisin, their opinions were reversed.
The Gemara answers: The contradiction between one statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rava and </span>another statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rava </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult, </span>because <span class="gemarra-regular">there, </span>in the case of the property of bar Sisin, the <span class="gemarra-regular">seller </span>had been <span class="gemarra-regular">established </span>as having the land <span class="gemarra-regular">in his property, </span>which is why Rava rules in his favor. But <span class="gemarra-regular">here, </span>in the case where the claimant states that he had been in a distant location, the <span class="gemarra-regular">buyer </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">established </span>as having the house <span class="gemarra-regular">in his property.</span>
The contradiction between one statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav Naḥman and </span>the other statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav Naḥman </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult as well, </span>because there, <span class="gemarra-regular">since </span>the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>I am hereby selling you all of the property that I own <span class="gemarra-regular">of the house of bar Sisin, and </span>this parcel of land is <span class="gemarra-regular">called: Of the house of bar Sisin, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">incumbent on him to revea</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that </span>the parcel under dispute is <span class="gemarra-regular">not of the house of bar Sisin. But here, </span>in the case where the claimant states that he had been in a distant location, it <span class="gemarra-regular">should not be </span>any <span class="gemarra-regular">different </span>from a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the possessor is <span class="gemarra-regular">holding a document </span>as evidence that he purchased the house. <span class="gemarra-regular">Wouldn’t we </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">say to him: </span>First <span class="gemarra-regular">ratify your document, and </span>only then be <span class="gemarra-regular">established in </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">property? </span>In this case as well, since his presumptive ownership is in place of a document, he needs to clarify the matter by means of witnesses.
There was <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain </span>person <span class="gemarra-regular">who </span><span class="gemarra-regular">said to another: What do you want with this house </span>of mine? The possessor <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: I purchased it from you and I </span>worked and <span class="gemarra-regular">profited from it </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">the years </span>necessary for establishing the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership. The claimant <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>him: <span class="gemarra-regular">I was in </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">outer marketplaces</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and was unaware that you were residing in my house, and therefore did not lodge a protest, so your profiting does not establish the presumption of ownership. The possessor <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: But I have witnesses that every year you would come </span>here for <span class="gemarra-regular">thirty days</span> and had an opportunity to know that I was residing in your house and to lodge a protest. The claimant <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: I was occupied with </span>my business in the <span class="gemarra-regular">marketplace</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> for those <span class="gemarra-regular">thirty days. Rava said: A person is apt </span>to be <span class="gemarra-regular">occupied </span>with business <span class="gemarra-regular">in the marketplace for all </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">thirty days, </span>and accepted his claim.
There was <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain </span>person <span class="gemarra-regular">who said to another: What do you want with this land </span>of mine? The possessor <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: I purchased it from so-and-so, who told me that he purchased it from you. </span>The claimant <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Don’t you concede</span>

Daf 30b

<span class="gemarra-regular">that this land is </span>formerly <span class="gemarra-regular">mine</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">you </span>did <span class="gemarra-regular">not purchase it from me</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">Go </span>away; <span class="gemarra-regular">I am not legally answerable to you. Rava said: </span>The claimant <span class="gemarra-regular">stated the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to </span>the possessor, as this is a legitimate claim, and Rava accepted his claim.
There was <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain </span>person <span class="gemarra-regular">who said to another: What do you want with this land </span>of mine? The possessor <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: I purchased it from so-and-so and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">I </span>worked and <span class="gemarra-regular">profited from it </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">the years </span>necessary for establishing the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership. The claimant <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: So-and-so is a robber </span>who robbed me of the field, and he did not have the authority to sell it to you.
The possessor <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: But I have witnesses that I came </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">consulted with you</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and you said to me: Go purchase </span>the land, indicating that you conceded that he had the authority to sell it. The claimant <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>The reason that I advised you to purchase it was because <span class="gemarra-regular">the second </span>person, i.e., you, the possessor, <span class="gemarra-regular">is amenable to me, </span>while <span class="gemarra-regular">the first, </span>i.e., the purported thief, <span class="gemarra-regular">is more difficult than he, </span>i.e., I prefer to litigate with you rather than with him. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: </span>The claimant <span class="gemarra-regular">stated the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to </span>the possessor, as this is a legitimate claim, and Rava accepted his claim.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">In accordance with whose </span>opinion is Rava’s statement? Is it <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Admon? As we learned </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Ketubot</span> 109a): With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who contests </span>ownership <span class="gemarra-regular">of a field, </span>claiming that a field possessed by someone else actually belongs to him, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the claimant himself <span class="gemarra-regular">is signed as a witness on </span>the bill of sale of the field to that other person, <span class="gemarra-regular">Admon says: </span>His signature does not disprove his claim of ownership of the property, as it is possible that the claimant said to himself: <span class="gemarra-regular">The second </span>person <span class="gemarra-regular">is amenable to me </span>to deal with, as I can reason with him, while <span class="gemarra-regular">the first </span>owner, who sold the field to the current possessor, <span class="gemarra-regular">is more difficult </span>to deal with <span class="gemarra-regular">than he. And the Rabbis say: He lost his righ</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> to contest, as he signed a bill of sale that states that the field belongs to the possessor. Rava’s ruling appears to be in accordance with the individual opinion of Admon, and not with the opinion of the Rabbis.
The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">You </span>may <span class="gemarra-regular">even</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> say </span>that Rava’s ruling is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis. There, </span>in the case of the mishna in tractate <span class="it-text">Ketubot</span>, by signing the bill of sale the claimant <span class="gemarra-regular">performed an action </span>indicating that the field was not his <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>the benefit of the possessor of the field, <span class="gemarra-regular">but here, </span>in Rava’s case, there was no action, only <span class="gemarra-regular">speech, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">a person is apt to casually say </span>statements, and he does not lose his right by virtue of this.
There was <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain </span>person <span class="gemarra-regular">who said to another: What do you want with this land </span>of mine? The possessor <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: I purchased it from so-and-so and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">I </span>worked and <span class="gemarra-regular">profited from it </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">the years </span>necessary for establishing the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership. The claimant <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: So-and-so is a robber </span>who robbed me of the field, and he did not have the authority to sell it to you. The possessor <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: But I have witnesses that you came </span>to me <span class="gemarra-regular">at night and you said to me: Sell it to me,</span> indicating that it is not your land, as if it were yours, you would have demanded that I return it without your paying for it. The claimant <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: I said </span>to myself: Let me <span class="gemarra-regular">purchase </span>the benefit of avoiding <span class="gemarra-regular">my litigation </span>in order to reclaim my land. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: A person is apt </span>to pay money <span class="gemarra-regular">to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> purchase </span>the benefit of avoiding <span class="gemarra-regular">his litigation</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
There was <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain </span>person <span class="gemarra-regular">who</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> said to another: What do you want with this land </span>of mine? The possessor <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: I purchased it from so-and-so and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">I </span>worked and <span class="gemarra-regular">profited from it </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">the years </span>necessary for establishing the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership, indicating that he possessed it for three years, as this is the minimum number of years required for establishing the presumption of ownership. The claimant <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: But I am holding a document </span>stating <span class="gemarra-regular">that I purchased it from </span>that seller <span class="gemarra-regular">four years </span>ago. Therefore, if it was sold to you three years ago, as you claim, he did not have the authority to sell it at that time.
