The possessor <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Do you maintain</span> that when I said: I profited from the land for <span class="gemarra-regular">the years </span>necessary <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>establishing the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership, that <span class="gemarra-regular">I was saying </span>I worked and profited from the land for precisely <span class="gemarra-regular">three years? </span>What <span class="gemarra-regular">I </span>actually <span class="gemarra-regular">was saying </span>was that I worked and profited from the land for <span class="gemarra-regular">many years </span>and thereby established the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership. Since my purchase predated yours, it was effective. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">common </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">people to refer to many years </span>as: <span class="gemarra-regular">Years </span>necessary for establishing the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership, and his claim is accepted.
The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">And this matter </span>applies <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">he</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> profited </span>from the land for <span class="gemarra-regular">seven </span>years, so <span class="gemarra-regular">that presumptive </span>ownership<span class="gemarra-regular"> of this </span>possessor <span class="gemarra-regular">preceded the document</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of that </span>claimant. 

Daf 31a

<span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if he profited from the land for only <span class="gemarra-regular">six </span>years, so that the sale to the claimant took place before the years necessary for establishing the presumption of ownership were completed, <span class="gemarra-regular">you </span>can <span class="gemarra-regular">have no greater protes</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> than this, </span>that the purported seller then sold the land to another. By doing so he indicated that he does not concede that the possessor was the rightful owner, and the possessor should have been careful to hold on to his bill of sale for even longer than three years.
There was an incident where two people disputed the ownership of land. <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">says: </span>The land <span class="gemarra-regular">belonged to my ancestors </span>and I inherited it from them, <span class="gemarra-regular">and that </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">says: </span>The land <span class="gemarra-regular">belonged to my ancestors </span>and I inherited it from them. <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">brings witnesses</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that </span>the land <span class="gemarra-regular">belonged to his ancestors, and that </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">brings witnesses that </span>he currently possesses the land and that he worked and <span class="gemarra-regular">profited </span>from the land for <span class="gemarra-regular">the years </span>necessary for establishing the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption</span> of ownership.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba said: </span>The judgment is in favor of the possessor, due to the legal principle that if the judgment would have been decided in one’s favor had he advanced a certain claim, and he instead advanced a different claim that leads to the same ruling, he has credibility, as <span class="gemarra-regular">why would he lie </span>and state this claim? <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>the possessor <span class="gemarra-regular">wanted </span>to lie, he could have <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>the claimant: <span class="gemarra-regular">I purchased </span>the land <span class="gemarra-regular">from you and I </span>worked and <span class="gemarra-regular">profited from it </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">the years </span>necessary for establishing the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership, in which case he would have been awarded the land. <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said to </span>Rabba: <span class="gemarra-regular">We do not say </span>the principle of: <span class="gemarra-regular">Why</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> would I lie</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in </span>a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>there are <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesse</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> contradicting his current claim, as they testify that the land belonged to the ancestors of the claimant. Therefore, he should not be awarded the land.
The possessor <span class="gemarra-regular">then said to </span>the claimant: <span class="gemarra-regular">Yes, </span>it is true that it had <span class="gemarra-regular">belonged to your ancestors, but I purchased it from you</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>by stating <span class="gemarra-regular">that which I said to you: </span>It <span class="gemarra-regular">belonged to my ancestors, </span>I merely meant <span class="gemarra-regular">that I rely upon </span>my ownership of <span class="gemarra-regular">it </span><span class="gemarra-regular">as if </span>it belonged <span class="gemarra-regular">to my ancestors, </span>as I purchased it and then profited from it for the years necessary for establishing the presumption of ownership.
The Gemara asks: Can he <span class="gemarra-regular">state a claim and return</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and state </span>a modified version of his <span class="gemarra-regular">claim, </span>or can he <span class="gemarra-regular">not state a claim and return and state </span>a modified version of his <span class="gemarra-regular">claim? Ulla said: </span>He can <span class="gemarra-regular">state a claim and return and state </span>a modified version of his <span class="gemarra-regular">claim. </span>The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">of Neharde’a say: </span>He <span class="gemarra-regular">cannot state a claim and return and state </span>a modified version of his <span class="gemarra-regular">claim.</span>
The Gemara clarifies their respective opinions: <span class="gemarra-regular">And Ulla concedes </span>that in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he </span>had initially <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>The land <span class="gemarra-regular">belonged to my ancestors and did not belong to your ancestors</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">cannot state a claim and return and state </span>a modified version of his <span class="gemarra-regular">claim,</span> as Ulla allows the litigant only to reinterpret his initial claim, not to replace it with a contradictory claim. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>Ulla also concedes that in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he was standing in court and did not state </span>a particular <span class="gemarra-regular">claim, and </span>he later <span class="gemarra-regular">came in from outside </span>and back into the court <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">stated </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">claim, </span>that he <span class="gemarra-regular">cannot return and state </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">claim. What is the reason </span>for this? It is because it is apparent that these <span class="gemarra-regular">claims of his </span>were <span class="gemarra-regular">taught to him </span>by someone after he left the court.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">of Neharde’a concede </span>that in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the litigant who changed his claim <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>the other litigant that when he had initially claimed: The land belonged to my ancestors, he had actually meant: It <span class="gemarra-regular">belonged to my ancestors, who purchased it from your ancestors</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> that he can state a claim and <span class="gemarra-regular">return</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and state </span>a modified version of his <span class="gemarra-regular">claim, </span>as this serves only to clarify, and not negate, his initial claim. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the Sages of Neharde’a also concede that in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">discussed </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">matter outside </span>of the court <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>did <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>state a particular <span class="gemarra-regular">claim,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>then he <span class="gemarra-regular">came </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">court and stated </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">claim, that </span>he can <span class="gemarra-regular">return and state </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">claim. What is the reason </span>for this? Because <span class="gemarra-regular">a person is apt not to reveal his claims except to </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">court.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Ameimar said: I am </span>from <span class="gemarra-regular">Neharde’a, but I </span>nevertheless <span class="gemarra-regular">hold that </span>a litigant can <span class="gemarra-regular">state a claim and return and state </span>a modified version of his <span class="gemarra-regular">claim. </span>The Gemara concludes: <span class="gemarra-regular">And the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is that a litigant can <span class="gemarra-regular">state a claim and return and state </span>a modified version of his <span class="gemarra-regular">claim</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
In an incident where two people dispute the ownership of land, <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">says: </span>The land <span class="gemarra-regular">belonged to my ancestors </span>and I inherited it from them, <span class="gemarra-regular">and that </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">says: </span>The land <span class="gemarra-regular">belonged to my ancestors </span>and I inherited it from them. The first one <span class="gemarra-regular">brings witnesses that </span>the land <span class="gemarra-regular">belonged to his ancestors, and </span>that he worked and <span class="gemarra-regular">profited </span>from the land for <span class="gemarra-regular">the years </span>necessary for establishing the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership.<span class="gemarra-regular"> And </span>the second one <span class="gemarra-regular">brings witnesses </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>he worked and <span class="gemarra-regular">profited </span>from the land for <span class="gemarra-regular">the years </span>necessary for establishing the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman said: Establish </span>the testimony with regard to the <span class="gemarra-regular">profiting </span>by the first litigant <span class="gemarra-regular">alongside </span>the testimony with regard to the <span class="gemarra-regular">profitin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span> by the second, and the two testimonies cancel each other out, leaving the testimony with regard to ownership by the ancestors of the first litigant. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>therefore, <span class="gemarra-regular">establish the land </span><span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumptive ownership of </span>the litigant who brought witnesses that it belonged to his <span class="gemarra-regular">ancestors. Rava </span>objected and <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">This testimony </span>cannot be relied on, as it <span class="gemarra-regular">is contradicted </span>by the other testimony. Rav Naḥman responded and <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Although </span>it is so <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the testimony <span class="gemarra-regular">was contradicted with regard to profiting </span>from the land, 

Daf 31b

<span class="gemarra-regular">was </span>the testimony <span class="gemarra-regular">contradicted with regard to </span>ownership of <span class="gemarra-regular">the ancestors?</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Shall we say that Rava and Rav Naḥman disagree in the dispute between Rav Huna and Rav Ḥisda?</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">As </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">was stated </span>concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">two groups of witnesses that contradict each other</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna says: This </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">comes </span>to court <span class="gemarra-regular">on its ow</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and testifies, and that </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">comes </span>to court <span class="gemarra-regular">on its own and testifies. </span>Despite the fact that one group certainly testified falsely, which should serve to disqualify one of the groups, each group is able to testify in another case. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav Ḥisda says: Why do I</span> need <span class="gemarra-regular">these lying witnesses</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> In other words, they are all disqualified to testify in another case until it is clarified which of them had testified falsely. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Shall we say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman </span>is the one <span class="gemarra-regular">who says </span>his ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna, and Rava </span>says his ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥisda?</span>
The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">According to </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav Ḥisda, </span>who holds that the witnesses are disqualified, <span class="gemarra-regular">everyone agrees </span>that the testimony concerning ancestral ownership is not accepted, as the witnesses were contradicted concerning their testimony of usage of the land, and Rav Naḥman’s ruling cannot accord with his opinion. <span class="gemarra-regular">When </span>Rav Naḥman and Rava <span class="gemarra-regular">disagree </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">according to </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav Huna, </span>who does not disqualify the witnesses. The ruling of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna, </span>and he therefore accepts the testimony with regard to ancestral ownership, <span class="gemarra-regular">and Rava </span>would say: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna says </span>that the witnesses are accepted <span class="gemarra-regular">only for another testimony, </span>i.e., in a different case. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>they are <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>accepted <span class="gemarra-regular">for the same testimony, </span>as in this incident, where both testimonies concerned ownership of the same land.
The Gemara relates the continuation of the case above. The one who had brought witnesses only to his having profited from the land <span class="gemarra-regular">then brought witnesse</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that it </span>had belonged <span class="gemarra-regular">to his ancestors, </span>thereby balancing the evidence for the two litigants. Therefore, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman said: We </span>previously <span class="gemarra-regular">brought dow</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> to the land the one who initially had evidence of ancestral ownership to take possession of it, and <span class="gemarra-regular">we </span>now <span class="gemarra-regular">bring him up </span>from it, removing him from the land. And <span class="gemarra-regular">we </span>are <span class="gemarra-regular">not concerned about </span>the possible <span class="gemarra-regular">contempt of court</span> that might result from perceived indecisiveness.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava, and some say </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Zeira, raises an objection </span>from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>. If there was a married man whose fate was unknown, and <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">say: </span>This married man <span class="gemarra-regular">died</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and two </span>witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">say: He did not die; </span>or if <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">say: </span>This woman <span class="gemarra-regular">was divorced, and two </span>witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">say: She was not divorced, this </span>woman <span class="gemarra-regular">may not marry</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as there is not unequivocal testimony that she is no longer married, <span class="gemarra-regular">but if she marries, </span>the marriage is valid and <span class="gemarra-regular">she </span>need <span class="gemarra-regular">not leave </span>her husband. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Menaḥem, son of Rabbi Yosei, says: She </span>must <span class="gemarra-regular">leave </span>her husband.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Menaḥem, son of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rabbi Yosei, said: When do I say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">she </span>must <span class="gemarra-regular">leave </span>her husband? She must leave him <span class="gemarra-regular">in</span> a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where witnesses came </span>to testify that she is still married <span class="gemarra-regular">and she then married </span>despite their testimony. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">she married and the witnesses then came </span>to testify that she is still married, <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>woman is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>required to <span class="gemarra-regular">leave </span>her husband based on the uncertainty created by contradictory witnesses. The fact that she is not required to leave her marriage in light of the new testimony seems to indicate an unwillingness to reverse the court’s ruling that she may marry, contrary to the ruling of Rav Naḥman.
Rav Naḥman <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: I </span>had <span class="gemarra-regular">thought to perform an action </span>and reverse the court’s ruling, but <span class="gemarra-regular">now that you raised an objection against me, and Rav Hamnuna </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">raised a </span>similar <span class="gemarra-regular">objection against me in Syria,</span> I will <span class="gemarra-regular">not perform an action in this </span>matter.
The Gemara relates that Rav Naḥman then <span class="gemarra-regular">went out </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">performed an action, </span>taking away the land from the litigant in whose favor he had previously ruled. <span class="gemarra-regular">One who saw </span>what he did <span class="gemarra-regular">thought </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">he</span> made <span class="gemarra-regular">a mistake, but </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">is not so. Rather, </span>he performed an action despite the objections that had been raised <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>the matter <span class="gemarra-regular">depends on great authorities [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ashlei</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">ravrevei</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Since, as the Gemara will demonstrate, this issue is subject to dispute between great authorities, he relied on those that supported his opinion.
<span class="gemarra-regular">As we learned </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Ketubot</span> 23b): <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda </span><span class="gemarra-regular">says: One is not elevated to the </span>presumptive status of <span class="gemarra-regular">priesthood on the basis </span>of the testimony <span class="gemarra-regular">of one witness. </span>Two witnesses are required for that purpose. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar says: When </span>is that the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? <span class="gemarra-regular">In </span>a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where there are challengers </span>to his claim that he is a priest. <span class="gemarra-regular">But in </span>a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where there are no challengers, one is elevated to the </span>presumptive status of <span class="gemarra-regular">priesthoo</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> on the basis </span>of the testimony <span class="gemarra-regular">of one witness. Rabban Shimon Ben Gamliel says in the name of Rabbi Shimon, son of the deputy </span>High Priest: <span class="gemarra-regular">One is elevated to the </span>presumptive status of <span class="gemarra-regular">priesthood on the basis </span>of the testimony <span class="gemarra-regular">of one witness.</span>
The Gemara asks: The opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabban Shimon Ben Gamliel is </span>identical to the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar, </span>as they agree that one is elevated to the presumptive status of priesthood on the basis of one witness when there are no challengers. What is their dispute? <span class="gemarra-regular">And if you would say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">there is </span>a practical difference <span class="gemarra-regular">between them </span>in a case where there is <span class="gemarra-regular">a challenge </span>posed by <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>person, as <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar holds: A challenge </span>posed by <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>person is sufficient to undermine one’s presumptive status of priesthood, and two witnesses are required to overcome that challenge; 

Daf 32a

<span class="gemarra-regular">and Rabban Shimon Ben Gamliel holds </span>that an effective <span class="gemarra-regular">challenge </span>requires <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>witnesses, one could then ask: <span class="gemarra-regular">But doesn’t Rabbi Yoḥanan say: Everyone agrees </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">there is no </span>effective <span class="gemarra-regular">challenge </span>with <span class="gemarra-regular">fewer than two </span>witnesses?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">challenge </span>was established by <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>witnesses. <span class="gemarra-regular">And with what are we dealing here? </span>We are dealing with a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where we presume with regard to the fathe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of that </span>man <span class="gemarra-regular">that he is a priest, and a rumor emerged about </span>the son <span class="gemarra-regular">that he is the son of </span>a priest and <span class="gemarra-regular">a divorced woman, or the son of </span>a priest and <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">ḥalutza</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, and we downgraded hi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">m</span> from the presumptive status of priesthood based on that rumor, <span class="gemarra-regular">and one witness came and said that </span>the man in question <span class="gemarra-regular">is a priest </span>of unflawed lineage, <span class="gemarra-regular">and we elevated </span>him back to the priesthood, as one witness is sufficient to negate a rumor.
The Gemara continues the case: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">came and said that he is the son of a divorced woman or </span>the son of <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">ḥalutza</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, and we downgraded him </span>from the priesthood based on their testimony. Then <span class="gemarra-regular">one witness came and said that he is a priest </span>of unflawed lineage, resulting in two witnesses testifying that his lineage is unflawed, and two testifying that it is flawed. <span class="gemarra-regular">And everyone </span>agrees that the <span class="gemarra-regular">testimony </span>of the two single witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">combine </span>to produce testimony that he is a priest of unflawed lineage, and his presumptive status of priesthood should be restored.
The Gemara explains the dispute: <span class="gemarra-regular">And here </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to concern about contempt of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> cour</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">they disagree. Rabbi Elazar holds: Once we downgraded him </span>from the presumptive status of priesthood based on the testimony of two witnesses, <span class="gemarra-regular">we do not </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">elevate him, </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">we are concerned about contempt of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> court, </span>as a reversal in the court’s decision creates the impression that the court operates indecisively. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabban Shimon Ben Gamliel holds: We downgraded him </span>from the presumptive status of priesthood <span class="gemarra-regular">and we </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">elevate him</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and we are not concerned about contempt </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of court. </span>The primary concern is that the matter should be determined based on the relevant testimonies.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi objects to </span>the analysis that they disagree with regard to concern about contempt of court: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, why specifically </span>is it necessary to establish the dispute in a case where first <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>witness testified as to his unflawed lineage, and then another testified later? <span class="gemarra-regular">The same</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> would hold true even in </span>a case where two witnesses testified together that he is unfit for the priesthood and the court downgraded him, and <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>witnesses testified together that he is fit for the priesthood and the court elevated him. The <span class="it-text">tanna’im</span> would <span class="gemarra-regular">also </span>disagree, as the same concern applies. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Rav Ashi said: Everyone </span>agrees that <span class="gemarra-regular">we are not concerned about contempt of court. And here, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>whether the court is able <span class="gemarra-regular">to combine </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">testimony</span> of two single witnesses that <span class="gemarra-regular">they disagree, and </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the issue that is the subject of <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>following <span class="gemarra-regular">dispute between these </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna’im</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> (<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span>, <span class="it-text">Sanhedrin</span> 5:5): The <span class="gemarra-regular">testimony </span>of individual witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">never combines unless </span>it is so <span class="gemarra-regular">that the two of them see </span>the incident transpire together <span class="gemarra-regular">as one. Rabbi Yehoshua ben Korḥa says: </span>Their testimony combines <span class="gemarra-regular">even in </span>a case where they witnessed the event <span class="gemarra-regular">one after the other</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> but <span class="gemarra-regular">their testimony is established in court only </span>if it is so <span class="gemarra-regular">that the two of them testify </span>together <span class="gemarra-regular">as one. Rabbi Natan says: </span>They are not required to testify together. Their testimony is combined even if the court <span class="gemarra-regular">hears the statement</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of this </span>witness <span class="gemarra-regular">today and when the other </span>witness <span class="gemarra-regular">arrives tomorrow </span>the court <span class="gemarra-regular">hears his statement. </span>Rabbi Elazar and Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel disagree in the dispute between Rabbi Natan and the Rabbis, whether the separate testimonies can be combined.
§ The Gemara relates an incident where two people disputed the ownership of land. There was <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain </span>person <span class="gemarra-regular">who </span><span class="gemarra-regular">said to another: What do you want with this land </span>of mine? The possessor <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: I purchased it from you, and this </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">the bill </span>of sale. 

Daf 32b

The first <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him </span>in response: <span class="gemarra-regular">It is a forged bill </span>of sale. The possessor <span class="gemarra-regular">leaned </span>over and <span class="gemarra-regular">whispered to Rabba: Yes, it is a forged bill. But I had a proper bill </span>of sale <span class="gemarra-regular">and it was lost, and I said </span>to myself: <span class="gemarra-regular">I will hold this </span>bill of sale <span class="gemarra-regular">in my possession, such as it is.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba said: Why would he li</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> and state this claim? <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">wants </span>to lie, he can <span class="gemarra-regular">say to him </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">it is a proper bill </span>of sale, and he would have been deemed credible and awarded the field. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef said to </span>Rabba: In the final analysis, <span class="gemarra-regular">on what </span>are <span class="gemarra-regular">you relying </span>to award him the land? <span class="gemarra-regular">On this bill </span>of sale? <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>admittedly forged <span class="gemarra-regular">bill is merely </span>a worthless <span class="gemarra-regular">shard</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and cannot be used in court as evidence.
The Gemara relates a similar incident: There was <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain </span>person <span class="gemarra-regular">who said to another:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Give me one hundred dinars that I am </span>attempting to <span class="gemarra-regular">collect from you, and this </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>promissory <span class="gemarra-regular">note </span>that attests to the debt. The latter <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him </span>in response: <span class="gemarra-regular">It is a forged </span>promissory <span class="gemarra-regular">note.</span> The first person <span class="gemarra-regular">leaned </span>over and <span class="gemarra-regular">whispered to Rava: Yes, it is a forged </span>promissory <span class="gemarra-regular">note. But I had a proper </span>promissory <span class="gemarra-regular">note and it was lost, and I said </span>to myself: <span class="gemarra-regular">I will hold this </span>promissory note <span class="gemarra-regular">in my possession, such as it is.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba said: Why would he lie </span>and state this claim? <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">wants </span>to lie, he can <span class="gemarra-regular">say to him </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">it is a proper </span>promissory <span class="gemarra-regular">note, </span>and he will be deemed credible and awarded the money. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef said to </span>Rabba: In the final analysis, <span class="gemarra-regular">on what </span>are <span class="gemarra-regular">you relying </span>to award him the money? <span class="gemarra-regular">On this </span>promissory <span class="gemarra-regular">note? This document is merely a shard, </span>and cannot be used in court as evidence.
The Gemara notes the final ruling in these two cases. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Idi bar Avin said: The </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabb</span><span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with regard to land, </span>and the possessor is awarded the land, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance </span><span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav Yosef with regard to money, </span>and the one demanding payment is not awarded the money. He explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">The </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabba with regard to land, </span>as the court rules <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">land </span>should <span class="gemarra-regular">remain where </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">is, </span>i.e., with the possessor. <span class="gemarra-regular">And the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav Yosef with regard to money, </span>as the court rules <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">money </span>should <span class="gemarra-regular">remain </span><span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">is</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., in the possession of the purported debtor.
The Gemara relates: There was <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain guarantor who said to a debtor: Give me one hundred dinars </span>for the money <span class="gemarra-regular">that I repaid the creditor on your </span>behalf, <span class="gemarra-regular">and this </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">the documen</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> that I received from him when I repaid your debt. The debtor <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>the guarantor: <span class="gemarra-regular">Is it not </span>so that <span class="gemarra-regular">I repaid you? </span>The guarantor <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>to the debtor: Yes, you did, but <span class="gemarra-regular">is it not </span>so that <span class="gemarra-regular">you later took the </span>money <span class="gemarra-regular">from me </span>again?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Idi bar Avin sent </span>the following question <span class="gemarra-regular">before Abaye: What </span>is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in <span class="gemarra-regular">a case like this? Abaye sent him </span>the following response: <span class="gemarra-regular">What does he, </span>i.e., Rav Idi bar Avin, <span class="gemarra-regular">ask? Isn’t he </span>the one <span class="gemarra-regular">who said: The </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabba with regard to land, and the</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav Yosef with regard to money, </span>as the court rules <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">money </span>should <span class="gemarra-regular">remain</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> where </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">is? </span>Based on his own ruling, the money should remain with the debtor.
The Gemara notes: <span class="gemarra-regular">And</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> this matter </span>applies only in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the guarantor <span class="gemarra-regular">says to </span>the debtor: <span class="gemarra-regular">You later borrowed </span>the money <span class="gemarra-regular">from me </span>after you had repaid me. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if the guarantor <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>the debtor: <span class="gemarra-regular">I returned to you </span>the money that you had repaid me <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>of the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the coins <span class="gemarra-regular">were worn out or </span>overly <span class="gemarra-regular">reddish, </span>i.e., discolored, and would not be easily accepted as currency, then <span class="gemarra-regular">the lien of the document is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">still </span>in effect. The debt to the guarantor had not actually been repaid, and the document is still in effect. In that case, the guarantor collects from the debtor.
The Gemara relates: <span class="gemarra-regular">A rumor emerged concerning Rava bar Sharshom that</span> he <span class="gemarra-regular">was profiting </span>from <span class="gemarra-regular">land belonging to orphans. Abaye said to him: Tell me, my friend, </span>concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">the incident itself, how is it </span>that this rumor was generated? Rava bar Sharshom <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: I was holding </span>on to <span class="gemarra-regular">the land as collatera</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from the father of the orphans, and I had</span>

Daf 33a

<span class="gemarra-regular">other money with him</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., he owed me money for a different reason, for which I had no collateral, <span class="gemarra-regular">and I profited from</span> the land <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>the duration of the <span class="gemarra-regular">years of </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">collateral</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">I </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>to myself: <span class="gemarra-regular">If I return the land to the orphans </span>now that the years of collateral have finished, <span class="gemarra-regular">and I say that I have other money with your </span>late <span class="gemarra-regular">father, </span>I will not be able to collect it, as <span class="gemarra-regular">the Sages say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">one who comes to collec</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> a debt <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">property of orphan</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> can collect only by </span>means of <span class="gemarra-regular">an oath, </span>and I do not wish to take an oath. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather </span>than do that, <span class="gemarra-regular">I will suppress </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">document </span>detailing the terms <span class="gemarra-regular">of the collateral</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and profit from </span>the land up to the <span class="gemarra-regular">measure </span>of the <span class="gemarra-regular">money </span>that their father owed me. This is legitimate, <span class="gemarra-regular">since if I </span>so <span class="gemarra-regular">desire I can say: It is purchased, </span>and that is why it is <span class="gemarra-regular">in my possession, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">I </span>would have been <span class="gemarra-regular">deemed credible, </span>as I profited from the land for the years necessary to establish the presumption of ownership, so <span class="gemarra-regular">when I say that I have money with you, I </span>am also <span class="gemarra-regular">deemed credible.</span>
Abaye <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Rava bar Sharshom: Your reasoning is incorrect. You would <span class="gemarra-regular">not have been able to say</span><span class="gemarra-regular">:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> It is purchased, </span>and that is why it is <span class="gemarra-regular">in my possession, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>there <span class="gemarra-regular">is publicity concerning it that </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">is land of orphans. </span>Therefore, you are unable to collect your debt based on the fact that you could have made a more advantageous claim [<span class="it-text">miggo</span>]. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, return </span>the land <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the orphans now, <span class="gemarra-regular">and when the orphans become adults, </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">litigate with them, </span>as you have no other option.
The Gemara relates: <span class="gemarra-regular">A relative of Rav Idi bar Avi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> died and left a date tree </span>as an inheritance. Another relative took possession of the tree, claiming to be a closer relative than Rav Idi bar Avin. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Idi bar Avin said: I am close</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> in relation to the deceased than he, <span class="gemarra-regular">and that man said</span><span class="gemarra-regular">:</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">I am closer </span>in relation to the deceased than Rav Idi bar Avin. <span class="gemarra-regular">Ultimately, </span>the other man <span class="gemarra-regular">admitte</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to </span>Rav Idi bar Avin <span class="gemarra-regular">that, </span>in fact, Rav Idi was <span class="gemarra-regular">closer </span>in relation to the deceased. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥisda established </span>the date tree <span class="gemarra-regular">in the possession of </span>Rav Idi bar Avin.
Rav Idi bar Avin <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Rav Ḥisda: The value of the <span class="gemarra-regular">produce that he consumed </span>unlawfully <span class="gemarra-regular">from that day </span>when he took possession of the tree <span class="gemarra-regular">until now should be returned to me. </span>Rav Ḥisda <span class="gemarra-regular">said: </span>Is <span class="gemarra-regular">this he about</span> whom people <span class="gemarra-regular">say: He is a great man? On whom is the Master basing </span>his claim to receive the value of the produce? <span class="gemarra-regular">On this </span>other relative. <span class="gemarra-regular">But he was saying </span>until this point: <span class="gemarra-regular">I am close</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> in relation to the deceased than he. Therefore, you have ownership of the tree only from the time of his admission, and not from when he took possession of the tree. The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye and Rava do not hold </span>in accordance with <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav Ḥisda, </span>

Daf 33b

as they hold that <span class="gemarra-regular">once </span>it is so <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the other relative <span class="gemarra-regular">admitted </span>that he is not a closer relative, <span class="gemarra-regular">he admitte</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> that he never had any right to the produce of the tree. Therefore, by his own admission, he is liable to reimburse Rav Idi bar Avin.
§ There was an incident where two people dispute the ownership of land. <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">says: </span>The land <span class="gemarra-regular">belonged to my ancestors </span>and I inherited it from them, <span class="gemarra-regular">and that </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">says: </span>The land <span class="gemarra-regular">belonged to my ancestors </span>and I inherited it from them. <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">brings witnesses that </span>the land <span class="gemarra-regular">belonged to his ancestors, and that </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">brings witnesses that </span>he worked and <span class="gemarra-regular">profited </span>from the land for <span class="gemarra-regular">the years </span>necessary <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>establishing the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥisda said: </span>The one who is in possession of the land is deemed credible due to the legal principle that if one would have been deemed credible had he stated one claim but instead stated another claim that accomplishes the same result, he has credibility, because <span class="gemarra-regular">why would he </span><span class="gemarra-regular">li</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> and state this claim? <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">wants </span>to lie, he could have <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: I purchased it from you and I </span>worked and <span class="gemarra-regular">profited from it </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">the years </span>necessary for establishing the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership.<span class="gemarra-regular"> Abaye and Rava do not hold </span>in accordance with <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav Ḥisda, </span>because they hold that <span class="gemarra-regular">we do not say </span>that the principle of: <span class="gemarra-regular">Why would I lie, </span>applies in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>there are <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses </span>contradicting the claim he is stating, and in this case, witnesses testify that it belonged to the ancestors of the other claimant.
There was <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain </span>person <span class="gemarra-regular">who said to another: What do you want with this </span><span class="gemarra-regular">land </span>of mine? The possessor <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him </span>in response: <span class="gemarra-regular">I purchased it from you and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">I </span>worked and <span class="gemarra-regular">profited from it </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">the years </span>necessary for establishing the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership. He then <span class="gemarra-regular">went and brought witnesses that </span>he had <span class="gemarra-regular">profited </span>from the land for <span class="gemarra-regular">two years, </span>but he was unable to bring witnesses to testify about a third year. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman said: The</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> land reverts </span>back to the prior owner, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>payment for <span class="gemarra-regular">the produce </span>consumed during those two years <span class="gemarra-regular">revert</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> to the prior owner. Since the possessor was unable to substantiate his claim to the land, the assumption is that he consumed the produce unlawfully.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Zevid said: If</span> initially, when questioned by the other, the one occupying the land <span class="gemarra-regular">claimed and said: I entered </span>the land <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>consume its <span class="gemarra-regular">produc</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> that I had purchased, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">deemed credible. </span>After all, <span class="gemarra-regular">didn’t Rav Yehuda say: This one who is holding a sickle and rope [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">vetovelaya</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and says: I will </span><span class="gemarra-regular">go cull [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">igderei</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> the dates from <span class="gemarra-regular">the date tree of so-and-so who sold it to me, is deemed credible </span>that he has the right to do so? <span class="gemarra-regular">Apparently, a person is not </span>so <span class="gemarra-regular">braze</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that </span>he would <span class="gemarra-regular">cull </span>the dates of <span class="gemarra-regular">a date tree that is not his. Here too, </span>in the case discussed by Rav Zevid, <span class="gemarra-regular">a person </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>so <span class="gemarra-regular">brazen </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">to consume produce that is not his.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If that is so, </span>that the assumption is that he would not lie, let one be deemed credible with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">the land as well</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> The Gemara answers: In terms of <span class="gemarra-regular">the land, we say to him:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Show your bill </span>of sale if you indeed purchased it. The Gemara challenges: <span class="gemarra-regular">If that is so, </span>then in terms of the <span class="gemarra-regular">produce as well, </span>let him be deemed credible only if he can produce documentation of his claim. The Gemara explains: It is <span class="gemarra-regular">not common </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">people </span>to write <span class="gemarra-regular">documents to </span>establish the right to consume <span class="gemarra-regular">produce</span> alone, and one can therefore claim to have consumed the produce based on an oral agreement.
There was <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain </span>person <span class="gemarra-regular">who said to another: What do you want with this land </span>of mine? The possessor <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him</span> in response: <span class="gemarra-regular">I purchased it from you and I </span>worked and <span class="gemarra-regular">profited from it </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">the years </span>necessary for establishing the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership. He then <span class="gemarra-regular">brought one witness </span>who testified <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">profited </span>from the land for the necessary <span class="gemarra-regular">three years. The Rabbis </span>who were studying <span class="gemarra-regular">before</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Abaye maintained </span>that it made sense <span class="gemarra-regular">to say </span>that the principle in this case <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>the same as that in the case of the <span class="gemarra-regular">piece of cast metal [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">naskha</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> adjudicated <span class="gemarra-regular">by Rabbi Abba</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
The Gemara now presents that case: <span class="gemarra-regular">As </span>there was <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain man</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> who snatched a piece of cast metal from another. </span>The one from whom it was taken <span class="gemarra-regular">came before Rabbi Ami </span>while <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Abba was sitting before him, </span>and he <span class="gemarra-regular">brought one witness </span>who testified <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>it was, in fact, <span class="gemarra-regular">snatched from him. </span>The one who snatched it <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Yes, </span>it is true that <span class="gemarra-regular">I snatched </span>it, <span class="gemarra-regular">but I </span>merely <span class="gemarra-regular">snatched </span>that which was <span class="gemarra-regular">mine. Rabbi Ami said: </span>

Daf 34a

<span class="gemarra-regular">How should judges judg</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for this judgment? </span>There are reasons not to implement all potential rulings. If they were to order the one who snatched the metal <span class="gemarra-regular">to pay </span>for it, that would not be the correct ruling, because <span class="gemarra-regular">there are not two witnesses</span> who saw him snatch it, and the court does not force payment based on the testimony of one witness. If they were <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>accept his claim and <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt him </span>entirely, that would not be the correct ruling, because <span class="gemarra-regular">there is one witness </span>who testified against him. If they were to order him <span class="gemarra-regular">to take an oath, </span>which is the usual response to counter the testimony of one witness, <span class="gemarra-regular">didn’t he sa</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span> that he did in fact <span class="gemarra-regular">snatch it, and since he said that he snatched it </span>and there is no proof that it is his, <span class="gemarra-regular">he is like a robber, </span>and the court does not allow a robber to take an oath.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Abba said to them: He </span>is one who <span class="gemarra-regular">is liable </span>to take <span class="gemarra-regular">an oath who is unable to take an oath</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and anyone who is liable </span>to take <span class="gemarra-regular">an oath who is unable to take an oath </span>is liable to <span class="gemarra-regular">pay. </span>The Rabbis who were studying before Abaye thought that the case of the witness to the years of profiting and Rabbi Abba’s case are similar, in that since the possessor is unable to take an oath to refute the witness, as he concedes that he profited from the land for those years, he should have to pay for his consumption of the produce.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said to </span>these Rabbis: <span class="gemarra-regular">Are </span>these two cases <span class="gemarra-regular">comparable? There, </span>in Rabbi Abba’s case, <span class="gemarra-regular">the witness is coming to undermine </span>the position of the one who snatched the metal. This can be seen from the fact that <span class="gemarra-regular">when </span>it would be the case that <span class="gemarra-regular">another </span>witness <span class="gemarra-regular">comes </span>to court and testifies <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>the first witness, <span class="gemarra-regular">we </span>would <span class="gemarra-regular">take away </span>the piece of metal <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the one who snatched it. By contrast, <span class="gemarra-regular">here, </span>in the case of the individual who brought one witness to attest to his profiting from the land, the witness <span class="gemarra-regular">is coming to suppor</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> the possessor. This can be seen from the fact that <span class="gemarra-regular">when another </span>witness would <span class="gemarra-regular">come </span>to court and testify with the first witness, <span class="gemarra-regular">we </span>would <span class="gemarra-regular">establish </span>the land <span class="gemarra-regular">in his possession. </span>Therefore, the testimony of the one witness does not render the one who profited from the land liable to take an oath.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, if this </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Abba is comparable </span>to a case such as this, it is comparable <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>a case where there is <span class="gemarra-regular">one witness and </span>he testifies <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>someone’s profiting from land for <span class="gemarra-regular">two years</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>the comparison is in terms of payment <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">produce</span> that he consumed. In terms of the consumption of the produce, two witnesses would have rendered the possessor liable to pay, as consumption of the produce for only two years does not establish the presumption of ownership. Therefore, one witness renders him liable to take an oath. Since he himself claimed that he profited from the land as the witness testified, he cannot take an oath to contest the testimony. Therefore, he would have to pay for the produce. 

Daf 34b

§ The Gemara relates: There was <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain boat that two </span>people <span class="gemarra-regular">were quarrelin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span> about with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">its </span>ownership. <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">said: It is mine, and that </span>one also <span class="gemarra-regular">said: It is mine. One of them came to court and said: Seize i</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> until I </span>am able to <span class="gemarra-regular">bring witnesses that it is mine. </span>The Gemara asks: In such a case, do <span class="gemarra-regular">we seize </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">or </span>do <span class="gemarra-regular">we not seize </span>it? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna said: We seize </span>it. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda said: We </span>do <span class="gemarra-regular">not seize </span>it, as there is no cause for the court to intervene.
The court seized the boat. The one who requested of the court to seize it <span class="gemarra-regular">went </span>to seek witnesses, <span class="gemarra-regular">but did</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not find witnesses. </span>He then <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>the court: <span class="gemarra-regular">Release </span>the boat, <span class="gemarra-regular">and whoever is stronger prevails</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as this is the ruling in a case where there is neither evidence nor presumptive ownership for either litigant. The Gemara asks: In such a case, do <span class="gemarra-regular">we release </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">or </span>do <span class="gemarra-regular">we not release </span>it? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda said: We </span>do <span class="gemarra-regular">not release </span>it. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa said: We release </span>it. The Gemara concludes: <span class="gemarra-regular">And the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is that <span class="gemarra-regular">we </span>do <span class="gemarra-regular">not seiz</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> property in a case where ownership is uncertain, <span class="gemarra-regular">and where </span>it was <span class="gemarra-regular">seized, we </span>do <span class="gemarra-regular">not release </span>it.
There was an incident where two people dispute the ownership of property. <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">says: </span>It <span class="gemarra-regular">belonged to my ancestor</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> and I inherited it from them, <span class="gemarra-regular">and that </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">says: </span>It <span class="gemarra-regular">belonged to my ancestors </span>and I inherited it from them. There was neither evidence nor presumptive ownership for either litigant. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman said: Whoever is stronger prevails</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>way <span class="gemarra-regular">is</span> this case <span class="gemarra-regular">different from </span>the case where two people produce <span class="gemarra-regular">two deeds </span>of sale or gift for the same field <span class="gemarra-regular">that are issued on one day, </span>

Daf 35a

<span class="gemarra-regular">as Rav said: </span>In that case, <span class="gemarra-regular">they should divid</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> the property between them, <span class="gemarra-regular">and Shmuel said: </span>It is decided based on the <span class="gemarra-regular">discretion</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">shudda</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of the judges</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Why in the seemingly equivalent case of a dispute where there is no evidence for either litigant did Rav Naḥman rule that whoever is stronger prevails? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">There, </span>in the case of the two deeds, it will <span class="gemarra-regular">not be </span>possible for the court <span class="gemarra-regular">to clarify the matte</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> in the future, and therefore, the court issues a ruling according to the information they currently have. <span class="gemarra-regular">Here, </span>in the case of Rav Naḥman, it may <span class="gemarra-regular">be </span>possible for the court <span class="gemarra-regular">to clarify the matter </span>in the future, if one of the litigants was to bring witnesses supporting his claim.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>way <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>this case <span class="gemarra-regular">different from that which we</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> learned </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Bava</span> <span class="it-text">Metzia</span> 100a): With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who exchanges a cow for a donke</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>the cow <span class="gemarra-regular">calved, and similarly one who sells his </span>Canaanite <span class="gemarra-regular">maidservant and she gave birth, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>one, i.e., the seller, <span class="gemarra-regular">says: She gave</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> birth before I sold </span>either the cow or maidservant, and the offspring belongs to me; <span class="gemarra-regular">and that </span>one, i.e., the buyer, <span class="gemarra-regular">says: She gave birth after I purchased her </span>and the offspring belongs to me, the ruling is that <span class="gemarra-regular">they should</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> divide </span>the value of the newborn. In that case, the court is not able to clarify the matter, so they should rule that whoever is stronger prevails.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">There, </span>in the case of the exchange, <span class="gemarra-regular">for this </span>one, i.e., the buyer, 

Daf 35b

<span class="gemarra-regular">he has financial involvement [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">derara</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and for that </span>one, i.e., the seller, <span class="gemarra-regular">he has financial involvement. </span>Since each of them has a definite claim to owning the offspring, as each of them owned the cow or maidservant at one point, it is reasonable for the court to divide the offspring between the two parties. By contrast, <span class="gemarra-regular">here, </span>in the case of Rav Naḥman, <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>it belongs <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">Master </span>it does <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>belong <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Master, and if </span>it belongs <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Master </span>it does <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>belong <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">Master. </span>Only one of the two litigants has any claim to the property, as it belonged either to the ancestors of this one or of that one. Therefore, a ruling to divide it would not be appropriate.
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Neharde’a say: </span>In a case where two parties disputed the ownership of a certain property and the court ruled that whoever is stronger prevails, <span class="gemarra-regular">if</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> one from the marketplace </span>who had no claim <span class="gemarra-regular">came and took possessio</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of it, </span>the court <span class="gemarra-regular">does not remove it from his possession</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">as Rabbi Ḥiyya teaches </span>(<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span>, <span class="it-text">Bava</span> <span class="it-text">Kamma</span> 10:14): <span class="gemarra-regular">A robber of </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">public, </span>meaning a robber whose victim is unknown, <span class="gemarra-regular">is not called a robber.</span> Since it is unclear whom he robbed, no one is able to demand payment. Here too, since it is unclear whose property it is, neither can demand that it be taken from the robber.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi said </span>in disagreement: <span class="gemarra-regular">Actually, </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">is called a robber, </span>and the property is taken from him, <span class="gemarra-regular">and what </span>is meant by: He <span class="gemarra-regular">is not called a robber? </span>It means <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the stolen item is <span class="gemarra-regular">not subject to being returned</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and consequently he is unable to fully atone, as he does not know whom to repay.
§ The mishna teaches with regard to certain types of property that <span class="gemarra-regular">their presumptive ownership</span> is established by use of a duration of <span class="gemarra-regular">three years from day to day. </span>The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Abba says: </span>Nevertheless, there are cases where presumptive ownership is established immediately. For example, <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>the prior owner <span class="gemarra-regular">himself lifte</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a basket of fruit </span>from that field <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>the possessor, that <span class="gemarra-regular">immediately </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>sufficient to establish the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership, and the prior owner can no longer lodge a protest. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Zevid says: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">But if </span>the prior owner <span class="gemarra-regular">stated a claim and said: I brought him dow</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> into my field solely <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>consume the <span class="gemarra-regular">produce</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> e.g., as a sharecropper, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">deemed </span><span class="gemarra-regular">credible. And that </span><span class="it-text">halakha</span>, that the prior owner is deemed credible were he to state such a claim, <span class="gemarra-regular">applies </span>only if he stated it <span class="gemarra-regular">within three </span>years of when the other took possession, <span class="gemarra-regular">but after three </span>years he is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>deemed credible.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi said to Rav Kahana: If </span>in fact he did <span class="gemarra-regular">bring him down </span>into the field solely <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>consume the <span class="gemarra-regular">produce, what was </span>there <span class="gemarra-regular">for him to do </span>to prevent the possessor from establishing the presumption of ownership? Rav Kahana <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> He should have protested </span>during the first three years and publicized that he had granted the possessor rights to the produce alone.
The assumption that lodging a protest would be effective must be correct, <span class="gemarra-regular">since if you do not say so</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> then in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">this mortgage </span>according to the custom <span class="gemarra-regular">in Sura</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> a city in Babylonia, <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>which is <span class="gemarra-regular">written: At the completion of these years this land will be released </span>to its prior owner <span class="gemarra-regular">without </span>any need for the prior owner to give <span class="gemarra-regular">money, if </span>the creditor were to <span class="gemarra-regular">hide </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">mortgage document in his possession and say: </span>This land <span class="gemarra-regular">is purchased </span>and that is why it is <span class="gemarra-regular">in my possession, here </span>is it <span class="gemarra-regular">also </span>the case <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>he would be <span class="gemarra-regular">deemed credible? </span>That cannot be, as is it reasonable that <span class="gemarra-regular">the Sages would institute a matter, </span>such as this type of arrangement, <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>people <span class="gemarra-regular">can be led by it</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to </span>suffer <span class="gemarra-regular">a loss? Rather, </span>in the case of the mortgage the debtor <span class="gemarra-regular">should have protested, </span>and by not protesting, he causes his own loss. <span class="gemarra-regular">Here, too, </span>in the case of the field, the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">should have </span><span class="gemarra-regular">protested.</span>
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a Jew who comes </span>to claim land <span class="gemarra-regular">due to</span> having received it from <span class="gemarra-regular">a gentile</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he is like a gentile </span>in terms of which legal claims are available to him. Therefore, <span class="gemarra-regular">just as a gentile has </span>the ability to establish the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership<span class="gemarra-regular"> only by </span>means of <span class="gemarra-regular">a document</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> so too, a Jew who comes </span>to claim land <span class="gemarra-regular">due to </span>having received it from <span class="gemarra-regular">a gentile has </span>the ability to establish the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership<span class="gemarra-regular"> only by </span>means of <span class="gemarra-regular">a document. Rava said: And if </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">Jew said </span>to a prior owner, who claims to still own the land: 

Daf 36a

The <span class="gemarra-regular">gentile told me that </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">purchased</span> a field <span class="gemarra-regular">from you, </span>this claim is <span class="gemarra-regular">deemed credible. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Is there any case where if a gentile says </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">he is not deemed credible, but if a Jew said </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">in the gentile’s name he would be deemed credible?</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Rava said: If a Jew said </span>to the prior owner: <span class="gemarra-regular">A gentile purchased </span>a field <span class="gemarra-regular">from you in my presence</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>then he <span class="gemarra-regular">sold it to me, </span>this claim is <span class="gemarra-regular">deemed credible, since if he wanted </span>to, he could have <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>the prior owner of the land: <span class="gemarra-regular">I purchased it from you.</span>
The Gemara records a series of <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> pertaining to presumptive ownership. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav Yehuda says: This one who is holding a sickle and rope and says: I will go cull </span>the dates from <span class="gemarra-regular">the date tree of so-and-so, from whom I purchased it,</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">deemed credible. </span>The reason for this is that <span class="gemarra-regular">a person is not </span>so <span class="gemarra-regular">brazen that </span>he would <span class="gemarra-regular">cull </span>the dates from <span class="gemarra-regular">a date tree that is not his.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav Yehuda says: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">this one, who</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> possesses </span>a field only <span class="gemarra-regular">from the fenc</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> built to prevent the entry <span class="gemarra-regular">of the wild donkey</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and outwar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> toward the public property, this conduct <span class="gemarra-regular">is not </span>sufficient to establish the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership.<span class="gemarra-regular"> What is the reason? </span>The owner <span class="gemarra-regular">says </span>to himself: <span class="gemarra-regular">Everything that </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">sows, </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">wild donkeys </span>will <span class="gemarra-regular">eat as well, </span>and cannot establish the presumption of ownership for him, as he is not profiting from the land as an owner would.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav Yehuda says: </span>With regard to one who <span class="gemarra-regular">profited </span>from the land by consuming <span class="gemarra-regular">produce from the first three years after it was planted [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">orla</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> during which time one is prohibited from deriving benefit from the produce, this conduct <span class="gemarra-regular">is not </span>sufficient to establish the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership.<span class="gemarra-regular"> This is also taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: With regard to one who <span class="gemarra-regular">profited </span>from the land by consuming <span class="gemarra-italic">orla</span> produce, or profited from the land by consuming produce of the <span class="gemarra-regular">Sabbatical </span>Year, <span class="gemarra-regular">or </span>consumed produce that was prohibited as it was of <span class="gemarra-regular">diverse kinds</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> this conduct <span class="gemarra-regular">is not </span>sufficient to establish the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef says: </span>With regard to one who <span class="gemarra-regular">profited </span>from the land by consuming <span class="gemarra-regular">fodder</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., produce that has grown stalks but is not yet ripe, this conduct <span class="gemarra-regular">is not </span>sufficient to establish the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership.<span class="gemarra-regular"> Rava said: But if </span>the land was <span class="gemarra-regular">located in</span> the <span class="gemarra-regular">neck of Meḥoza, </span>a valley where it was common to harvest unripe produce to feed animals, this conduct <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>sufficient to establish the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman says: </span>Consumption of produce of land that is <span class="gemarra-regular">fissure</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is not </span>sufficient to establish the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership. This is due to the fact that produce does not grow well there, and therefore, owners do not bother to protest if a trespasser uses the land. Therefore, their silence should not be understood as an admission that it belongs to the possessor. Similarly, consumption of produce of land where one <span class="gemarra-regular">expends a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">ko</span><span class="gemarra-italic">r</span> of seed to sow <span class="gemarra-regular">and retrieves a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">ko</span><span class="gemarra-italic">r</span> of produce when harvesting it, <span class="gemarra-regular">is not </span>sufficient to establish the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership. Here, too, the owners do not bother to protest, as the land is of inferior quality.
