Rav Naḥman continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">And these </span>members <span class="gemarra-regular">of the household of the Exilarc</span><span class="gemarra-regular">h</span> do <span class="gemarra-regular">not establish </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership<span class="gemarra-regular"> in our </span>land, as people are afraid to lodge a protest against them, <span class="gemarra-regular">and we do not establish</span> the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership<span class="gemarra-regular"> in their </span>land, as, due to their wealth, they might not lodge a protest against one who trespasses on their land.
§ The mishna teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">slaves, </span>presumption of ownership of them is established by using them for a duration of three years from day to day. The Gemara asks: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">slaves, is</span> there <span class="gemarra-regular">presumptive ownership of them? But doesn’t Reish Lakish say: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">livestock [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">hagoderot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> possession of them does not </span>establish the presumption of ownership, since they wander from place to place. Therefore, one cannot claim that his mere possession of livestock demonstrates ownership as one can with regard to other movable items, because it may have wandered into his property on its own. The same <span class="it-text">halakha</span> should apply with regard to a slave. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said:</span> It is true that <span class="gemarra-regular">possession of them does not </span>establish the presumption of ownership <span class="gemarra-regular">immediately</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> but there is presumptive ownership of them after three years.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: If </span>the slave in question <span class="gemarra-regular">was a small </span>child <span class="gemarra-regular">placed in a cradle</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> possession of him does </span>establish the presumption of ownership <span class="gemarra-regular">immediately, </span>as it does with regard to other movable items. The Gemara asks: Isn’t that <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious, </span>since he cannot move on his own? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he has a mother. Lest you say: </span>One <span class="gemarra-regular">should be concerned </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">perhaps his mother brought him up to there, </span>and his being on another’s property does not indicate that the latter is his master. Therefore, Rava <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>that there is no concern about this possibility, since <span class="gemarra-regular">a mother does not forget her son. </span>Therefore, possession of the infant slave does establish the presumption of ownership.
The Gemara relates: There were <span class="gemarra-regular">these </span>certain <span class="gemarra-regular">goats that ate peeled </span>barley [<span class="gemarra-italic">ḥushela</span>] <span class="gemarra-regular">in Neharde’a. The owner of </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">peeled </span>barley <span class="gemarra-regular">came and seized </span>the goats, <span class="gemarra-regular">and was claiming a large </span>sum of money for the barley from the owner of the goats. <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel’s father said: </span>He <span class="gemarra-regular">is able to claim up t</span><span class="gemarra-regular">o</span> the <span class="gemarra-regular">value of </span>the goats, <span class="gemarra-regular">since if </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">wants </span>to, he could <span class="gemarra-regular">say: </span>The goats <span class="gemarra-regular">are purchased </span>and that is why they are <span class="gemarra-regular">in my possession. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But doesn’t Reish Lakish say: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">livestock, </span>possession of them <span class="gemarra-regular">does not </span>establish the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Goats are different</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as </span>they are <span class="gemarra-regular">given to shepherds, </span>and do not wander on their own.
The Gemara challenges: <span class="gemarra-regular">But there is morning and evening </span>to consider, when the goats are unsupervised when traveling between the owner and the shepherd, and during those times this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of livestock should apply with regard to them. The Gemara explains: The case under discussion took place in Neharde’a, and <span class="gemarra-regular">Arabs [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">tayya’ei</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> who steal animals <span class="gemarra-regular">are common in Neharde’a, and </span>goats there are <span class="gemarra-regular">delivered from hand to hand </span>and are never left unsupervised.
§ The mishna teaches that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yishmael says: Three months </span>of possession in the first year, three months of possession in the third year, and twelve months of possession in the middle, which are eighteen months, suffices to establish the presumption of ownership. Rabbi Akiva disagrees, and says that one month in the first and third year, in addition to the full middle year, is sufficient. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Shall we say </span>that the difference <span class="gemarra-regular">between</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> them is </span>whether <span class="gemarra-regular">plowing </span>the land is sufficient to establish the presumption of ownership? <span class="gemarra-regular">As Rabbi Yishmael holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">plowing is not </span>sufficient to establish the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership, and three months are needed for the crop to grow, <span class="gemarra-regular">and Rabbi Akiva holds</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">plowing is </span>sufficient to establish the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership, and therefore one month is sufficient.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>how can <span class="gemarra-regular">you understand </span>their opinions this way? If so, <span class="gemarra-regular">according to Rabbi Akiva, why specifically</span> require a full <span class="gemarra-regular">month? </span>

Daf 36b

<span class="gemarra-regular">Even </span>if he plowed the land for <span class="gemarra-regular">one day </span>in the first and third years respectively, it should be sufficient to establish the presumption of ownership. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, everyone </span>agrees that <span class="gemarra-regular">plowing is not </span>sufficient to establish the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership,<span class="gemarra-regular"> and here </span>the difference <span class="gemarra-regular">between</span> their opinions is whether in order to establish the presumption of ownership one needs to possess the land long enough to grow <span class="gemarra-regular">major produce, </span>which requires three months to grow, <span class="gemarra-regular">or </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">minor produce</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> which requires one month.
<span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Plowing is not </span>sufficient to establish the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership.<span class="gemarra-regular"> And there are </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">who say: This is </span>sufficient to establish the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption</span> of ownership.<span class="gemarra-regular"> Whose </span>opinion is it that the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> refers to as: <span class="gemarra-regular">There are </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">who say? Rav Ḥisda said: </span>It <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Aḥa, as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: If the possessor <span class="gemarra-regular">plowed </span>the field for <span class="gemarra-regular">a yea</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and sowed it </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>years, or if he <span class="gemarra-regular">plowed it </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">tw</span><span class="gemarra-regular">o</span> years <span class="gemarra-regular">and sowed it </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">a year, </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">is not</span> sufficient to establish the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership.<span class="gemarra-regular"> Rabbi Aḥa says: This is </span>sufficient to establish the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership, which indicates that he holds that plowing establishes the presumption of ownership.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi said: I asked all </span>of the <span class="gemarra-regular">great </span>men <span class="gemarra-regular">of the generation </span>about this, <span class="gemarra-regular">and they said to me: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">plowing, this is </span>sufficient to establish the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership.<span class="gemarra-regular"> Rav Beivai said to Rav Naḥman: What is the reason of the one who </span><span class="gemarra-regular">says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">plowing is </span>sufficient to establish the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership? Rav Naḥman answered: <span class="gemarra-regular">A person is not apt to </span>have <span class="gemarra-regular">his land plowed </span>by someone else <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>remain <span class="gemarra-regular">silent. </span>Rav Beivai asked: <span class="gemarra-regular">And what is the reason of the one who says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">plowing is not </span>sufficient to establish the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership? Rav Naḥman answered: The owner <span class="gemarra-regular">says </span>to himself: Let <span class="gemarra-regular">each and every clump [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">shibba</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> of earth <span class="gemarra-regular">enter </span>the plow. That is to say, the owner is amenable to having someone else plow the land for him, and then he will sow and harvest.
The <span class="gemarra-regular">residents of Pum Nahara sent </span>a question <span class="gemarra-regular">to Rav Naḥman bar Rav Ḥisda. Our teacher, instruct us: Is plowing </span>sufficient to establish the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership,<span class="gemarra-regular"> or is </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>sufficient to establish the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership? Rav Naḥman bar Rav Ḥisda <span class="gemarra-regular">said to them: Rabbi Aḥa and all </span>of the <span class="gemarra-regular">great </span>men <span class="gemarra-regular">of the generation say: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">plowing, this is </span>sufficient to establish the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: </span>Is it <span class="gemarra-regular">a novelty to enumerate </span>great <span class="gemarra-regular">men</span> who maintain an opinion without taking into account that of others? <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>what of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav and Shmuel in Babylonia, and Rabbi Yishmael and Rabbi Akiva in Eretz Yisrael, </span>who <span class="gemarra-regular">say: Plowing is not </span>sufficient to establish the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership?
The Gemara presents the sources for ascribing to these Sages the opinion that plowing does not establish the presumption of ownership. The basis for ascribing it to <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yishmael and Rabbi Akiva is the mishna, </span>as the Gemara explained above. <span class="gemarra-regular">What is </span>the basis for ascribing this opinion to <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav? As Rav Yehuda says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: This </span>ruling that either a month or three months is sufficient use for the first and third years is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of Rabbi Yishmael and Rabbi Akiva, but the Rabbis, </span>whose opinion is accepted, <span class="gemarra-regular">say: </span>With regard to a field, <span class="gemarra-regular">its presumption </span>of ownership is established by <span class="gemarra-regular">three years, from day to day</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> The phrase: <span class="gemarra-regular">From day to day, </span>serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to exclude what? </span>Does it <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>serve <span class="gemarra-regular">to exclude plowing</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> which does not </span>establish the presumption of ownership?
<span class="gemarra-regular">What is </span>the basis for ascribing this opinion to <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel? As Rav Yehuda says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel says: This </span>ruling that either a month or three months is sufficient use for the first and third years is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of Rabbi Yishmael and Rabbi Akiva, but the Rabbis, </span>whose opinion is accepted, <span class="gemarra-regular">say: </span>He does not establish the presumption of ownership <span class="gemarra-regular">until </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">harvests three </span>date <span class="gemarra-regular">crops</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> or harvests three </span>grape <span class="gemarra-regular">crops, or harvests three </span>olive <span class="gemarra-regular">crops. </span>This indicates that Shmuel holds that plowing does not establish the presumption of ownership. <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is the difference <span class="gemarra-regular">betwee</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> the opinions of Rav and Shmuel? <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said: </span>The difference <span class="gemarra-regular">between </span>their opinions is whether three harvests of <span class="gemarra-regular">a young [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">na’ara</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] date tree</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> which produces </span>a crop <span class="gemarra-regular">three times in </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">year, </span>establishes the presumption of ownership.
§ The mishna teaches that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yishmael said: In what </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">is this statement, </span>that eighteen months are required to establish the presumption of ownership of a non-irrigated field, <span class="gemarra-regular">said? With regard to a white field, </span>i.e., a grain field. But with regard to an orchard, harvesting three different crops suffices. <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said: From </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Yishmael we infer </span>the proper understanding of a detail of the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis </span>who disagree with him, and hold that three years of harvesting one crop is required to establish the presumption of ownership even with regard to an orchard: If <span class="gemarra-regular">one had </span><span class="gemarra-regular">thirty trees </span>of one type in a field, and they were <span class="gemarra-regular">planted </span>with a density of <span class="gemarra-regular">ten trees per </span>each <span class="gemarra-regular">area required for sowing one </span><span class="gemarra-italic">se’a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of seed [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">beit</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">se’a</span><span class="gemarra-regular">], </span>and one <span class="gemarra-regular">consumed </span>the produce of <span class="gemarra-regular">ten </span>trees <span class="gemarra-regular">in this </span>first <span class="gemarra-regular">year, and </span>of another <span class="gemarra-regular">ten </span>trees <span class="gemarra-regular">in this </span>second <span class="gemarra-regular">year, and </span>of another <span class="gemarra-regular">ten </span>trees <span class="gemarra-regular">in this </span>third <span class="gemarra-regular">year, this is </span>sufficient to establish the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption</span> of ownership.

Daf 37a

The Gemara explains the inference from the statement of Rabbi Yishmael and how it clarifies the opinion of the Rabbis: <span class="gemarra-regular">Didn’t Rabbi Yishmael say </span>that harvesting <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>type of <span class="gemarra-regular">fruit is </span>sufficient to establish the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership<span class="gemarra-regular"> for all </span>of the types of <span class="gemarra-regular">fruit, </span>i.e., for the entire field? <span class="gemarra-regular">Here too, these </span>trees <span class="gemarra-regular">are </span>sufficient to establish the<span class="gemarra-regular"> presumption </span>of ownership<span class="gemarra-regular"> for those </span>trees, <span class="gemarra-regular">and those </span>trees <span class="gemarra-regular">are </span>sufficient to establish the<span class="gemarra-regular"> presumption </span>of ownership<span class="gemarra-regular"> for these </span>trees.
The Gemara notes two restrictions to the aforementioned ruling: <span class="gemarra-regular">And this statement </span>applies specifically <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the other twenty trees <span class="gemarra-regular">did not produc</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> fruit, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>if the other trees <span class="gemarra-regular">produced </span>fruit <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>he did <span class="gemarra-regular">not consume </span>their fruit, then his conduct <span class="gemarra-regular">is not </span>sufficient to establish the<span class="gemarra-regular"> presumption </span>of ownership with regard to the other trees. <span class="gemarra-regular">And this </span>principle, that consuming the produce of some of the trees each year establishes the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption</span> of ownership for the entire field, applies only if it is the case <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the trees <span class="gemarra-regular">are scattered [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">devazei</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">bazuzei</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> throughout the field. Otherwise, he establishes the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption</span> of ownership only over the section where the trees are located.
§ In a case where there was a field with trees in it, and <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>person <span class="gemarra-regular">took possessio</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of the trees and that </span>person <span class="gemarra-regular">took possession of the land, Rav Zevid says: This </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">acquired </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">trees and that </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">acquired </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">land. Rav Pappa objects to this: If </span>this is <span class="gemarra-regular">so, </span>then the <span class="gemarra-regular">owner </span>of the <span class="gemarra-regular">trees has no </span>share <span class="gemarra-regular">in the land at all. Let </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">owner </span>of the <span class="gemarra-regular">land say to </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">owner </span>of the <span class="gemarra-regular">trees: Uproot your trees</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> take</span> them, <span class="gemarra-regular">and go. Rather, Rav Pappa said: This </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">acquired </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">trees and half </span>of the <span class="gemarra-regular">land</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and that </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">acquired half </span>of the <span class="gemarra-regular">land.</span>
The Gemara notes: It is <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious </span>that if one <span class="gemarra-regular">sold </span>a section of <span class="gemarra-regular">land and left </span>the ownership of the <span class="gemarra-regular">trees </span>in that land <span class="gemarra-regular">for himself</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he has </span>ownership of the <span class="gemarra-regular">land </span>surrounding the trees. <span class="gemarra-regular">And</span> this is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">even according to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Akiva, who says: One</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> who sells, sells generously, </span>and he is presumed to have included in the sale even items that were not explicitly specified, because <span class="gemarra-regular">that statement </span>applies only <span class="gemarra-regular">concerning </span>a case such as when one sold land and retained ownership of <span class="gemarra-regular">a pit or a cistern</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> In that case, Rabbi Akiva ruled that he does not retain any land, not even a path to access the pit or cistern, as he sold generously, including all of the land in the sale.
The Gemara explains the difference between the cases: That ruling applies there, <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>the pit or cistern <span class="gemarra-regular">causes no harm to the land</span> surrounding them, and since the seller does not foresee a conflict arising from his pit and cistern being located adjacent to the buyer’s property, he therefore transfers the entire land. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>in the case of his retaining the <span class="gemarra-regular">trees, </span>

Daf 37b

<span class="gemarra-regular">since they are causing </span><span class="gemarra-regular">harm to the land, </span>the seller does <span class="gemarra-regular">leave </span>the land that is surrounding the trees for himself, <span class="gemarra-regular">as if </span>he did <span class="gemarra-regular">not leave </span>it, <span class="gemarra-regular">let </span>the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">say to him: Uproot your trees and go.</span>
The Gemara discusses the reverse case: If one <span class="gemarra-regular">sold </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">trees and left</span> the ownership of the <span class="gemarra-regular">lan</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for himself, </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> depends on <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>outcome of the <span class="gemarra-regular">dispute of Rabbi Akiva and the Rabbis. According to Rabbi Akiva, who says: One who</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> sells, sells generously, </span>the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">has </span>ownership of the land surrounding the trees, as the presumption is that the seller included it in the sale. <span class="gemarra-regular">According to the Rabbis, </span>who say: One who sells, sells sparingly, the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">does not have </span>ownership of the land surrounding the trees, as the presumption is that the seller did not include it in the sale.
The Gemara stated previously that <span class="gemarra-regular">according to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Akiva,</span> the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">has </span>ownership of the land surrounding the trees. The Gemara clarifies this opinion: <span class="gemarra-regular">And even according to Rav Zevid, who said </span>(37a) that in a case where one took possession of the land and another took possession of the trees, the one who took possession of the trees <span class="gemarra-regular">has no </span>share in the land, <span class="gemarra-regular">that matter </span>applies only <span class="gemarra-regular">concerning </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span><span class="gemarra-regular">buyers. As </span>in that case, the one who acquired the land can <span class="gemarra-regular">say to </span>the other: <span class="gemarra-regular">Just as </span>it is so <span class="gemarra-regular">that I have no</span> share <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">trees, you also have no </span>share <span class="gemarra-regular">in the land; but here, </span>where one sold the trees and left the land for himself, <span class="gemarra-regular">one who sells, sells generously. </span>Therefore, it is reasonable to assume that the sale included the land surrounding the trees.
The Gemara stated earlier that <span class="gemarra-regular">according to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis, </span>the buyer does <span class="gemarra-regular">not have </span>ownership of the land surrounding the trees. The Gemara clarifies this opinion: <span class="gemarra-regular">And even according to Rav Pappa, who says </span>above that in a case where one took possession of the land and another took possession of the trees that the one who took possession of the trees <span class="gemarra-regular">has </span>ownership of half of the land as well, <span class="gemarra-regular">that matter </span>applies only <span class="gemarra-regular">concerning </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">two buyers. As </span>in that case, the one who acquired the trees can <span class="gemarra-regular">say to </span>the other: <span class="gemarra-regular">Just as </span>it is so <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">sold to you generously,</span> as you have both the land and the right to consume its produce, he <span class="gemarra-regular">also sold to me generously, </span>including the land surrounding the trees; <span class="gemarra-regular">but here, </span>where one sold the trees and left the land for himself, <span class="gemarra-regular">one</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> who sells, sells sparingly, </span>retaining for himself whatever he did not explicitly include in the sale.
§ The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Neharde’a say: </span>If one <span class="gemarra-regular">consumed </span>the produce of <span class="gemarra-regular">an overcrowded </span>orchard, <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span>does <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>thereby <span class="gemarra-regular">have presumptive ownershi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">p</span> of the orchard. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava objects</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to this: If that is so, how </span>does one ever <span class="gemarra-regular">acquire this alfalf</span><span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> field, </span>which is planted without spacing? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Rava said: </span>If one <span class="gemarra-regular">sold an overcrowded</span> orchard, the buyer does <span class="gemarra-regular">not have </span>ownership of the <span class="gemarra-regular">land</span> surrounding the trees. Generally, if one purchases three or more trees, he acquires the surrounding land, as the trees are considered an orchard. If the trees are overcrowded, they will soon have to be uprooted, and that is why the buyer does not acquire the land surrounding the trees.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Zeira said: </span>This is <span class="gemarra-regular">like </span>a dispute between <span class="gemarra-italic">tanna’im</span> (<span class="it-text">Kilayim</span> 5:2): With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a vineyard that is planted on </span>an area where there is <span class="gemarra-regular">les</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> than four cubits </span>of open space between the vines, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon says: </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>considered to be <span class="gemarra-regular">a vineyar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> with regard to the prohibition of diverse kinds and other <span class="it-text">halakhot</span>, as it is overcrowded. <span class="gemarra-regular">And the Rabbis say: This is </span>considered to be <span class="gemarra-regular">a vineyard, and </span>the reason for this is that <span class="gemarra-regular">the middle </span>vines are <span class="gemarra-regular">viewed as if </span>they <span class="gemarra-regular">are not </span>there, and the outer vines meet the requirements for a vineyard. It follows that according to the opinion of the Rabbis, if one sold an overcrowded orchard, the middle trees would be viewed as if they were not there. Therefore, it would be considered an orchard and the buyer would acquire the land surrounding the trees.
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">of Neharde’a say:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> This one who sells a date tree to another, </span>the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">acquires </span>the land <span class="gemarra-regular">from its botto</span><span class="gemarra-regular">m</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> until the depths</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> 

Daf 38a

<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava objects to this </span>ruling that the buyer of the tree acquires the land beneath it: <span class="gemarra-regular">And let </span>the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">say to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> him: I sold you </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">the saffron crocus</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> a small plant normally uprooted by the buyer and taken with him. Therefore, <span class="gemarra-regular">uproot the saffron crocus and go. Rather, Rava said: </span>This ruling is stated <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>one who <span class="gemarra-regular">comes </span>to court <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>a specific <span class="gemarra-regular">clai</span><span class="gemarra-regular">m</span> that the seller had stipulated that he would acquire the land. Without this specific claim he does not acquire the land beneath the tree.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Mar Kashisha, the son of Rav Ḥisda, said to Rav Ashi:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> And if, </span>in fact, the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">sold him the saffron crocus, what was </span>there <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">to do </span>to prevent the buyer from claiming the land beneath the tree, as the buyer could claim that there had been an explicit stipulation that he receive it? Rav Ashi answered: <span class="gemarra-regular">He should have protested </span>during the first three years and publicized that the land was not included in the sale.
The assumption that lodging a protest would be effective must be correct, <span class="gemarra-regular">since if you do not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">say so</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> then in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">these mortgages </span>according to the custom <span class="gemarra-regular">in Sura, </span>a city in Babylonia, the debtor will not have a way to prevent the creditor from keeping his land. <span class="gemarra-regular">As in </span>mortgages of that type it is <span class="gemarra-regular">written like this: At the completion of these years this land will be released </span>to its prior owner <span class="gemarra-regular">without </span>any need for the prior owner to give <span class="gemarra-regular">money. If </span>the creditor were to <span class="gemarra-regular">hide </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">mortgage document in his possession and say: </span>This land <span class="gemarra-regular">is purchased </span>and that is why it is <span class="gemarra-regular">in my possession, here </span>is it <span class="gemarra-regular">also </span>the case <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>he would be <span class="gemarra-regular">deemed credible? </span>That cannot be, as is it reasonable that <span class="gemarra-regular">the Sages would institute a matter, </span>such as this type of arrangement, <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>people <span class="gemarra-regular">can be led by it to </span>suffer <span class="gemarra-regular">a loss? Rather, </span>in the case of the mortgage the debtor <span class="gemarra-regular">should have protested, </span>and by not protesting, he causes his own loss. <span class="gemarra-regular">Here too, </span>in the case of the tree, the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">should have protested.</span>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> There are <span class="gemarra-regular">three </span>independent <span class="gemarra-regular">land</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> in Eretz Yisrael <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>establishing <span class="gemarra-regular">presumptive ownership: Judea, and Transjordan, and the Galilee. </span>If the prior owner of the field <span class="gemarra-regular">was in Judea and </span>another <span class="gemarra-regular">took possession </span>of his field <span class="gemarra-regular">in the Galilee, </span>or if he was <span class="gemarra-regular">in the Galilee and </span>another <span class="gemarra-regular">took possession </span>of his field <span class="gemarra-regular">in Judea, </span>the possessor does <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>establish <span class="gemarra-regular">presumptive ownership until </span>the one possessing the field <span class="gemarra-regular">will be with </span>the prior owner <span class="gemarra-regular">in one province. Rabbi Yehuda </span><span class="gemarra-regular">says</span><span class="gemarra-regular">:</span> The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>that establishing presumptive ownership requires <span class="gemarra-regular">three years only in order that </span>if the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">will be </span><span class="gemarra-regular">in Spain [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">Aspamya</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>another <span class="gemarra-regular">possesses </span>his field for <span class="gemarra-regular">a year, </span>people <span class="gemarra-regular">will go and inform </span>the owner by the end of the next <span class="gemarra-regular">year, and </span>the owner will <span class="gemarra-regular">come </span>back <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">following year </span>and take the possessor to court.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">What does the first </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> hold </span>in ruling that the prior owner and the field need be in the same province in order for the possessor to establish presumptive ownership? <span class="gemarra-regular">If he holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a protest that is </span>lodged <span class="gemarra-regular">not in the presence of </span>the one possessing the field <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>a valid <span class="gemarra-regular">protest,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> even </span>in the case where one is in <span class="gemarra-regular">Judea and </span>one is in the <span class="gemarra-regular">Galilee, </span>the protest should be valid <span class="gemarra-regular">as well. If he holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a protest </span>lodged <span class="gemarra-regular">not in his presence is not </span>a valid <span class="gemarra-regular">protest, even </span>in the case where one is in <span class="gemarra-regular">Judea and </span>the other one is in <span class="gemarra-regular">Judea, </span>the protest should <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>be valid <span class="gemarra-regular">as well.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Abba bar Memel says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: Actually, </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a protest </span>lodged <span class="gemarra-regular">not in his presence is </span>a valid <span class="gemarra-regular">protest</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">taught our mishna with regard to a period of crisis</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> when travel is perilous and information cannot be transmitted between Judea and the Galilee. Therefore, although no word of a protest was received, the possessor does not establish presumptive ownership of the field. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if it is due only to the exigent circumstances that word of the protest does not reach the one possessing the field, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is different </span>about <span class="gemarra-regular">Judea and </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">Galilee that </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">cited? </span>Ostensibly, even within one of the three lands, if travel and communications are restricted the same <span class="it-text">halakha</span> would apply.
The Gemara answers: The <span class="it-text">tanna</span>, by citing specifically a case where each is located in a different land, <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us this: </span>

Daf 38b

<span class="gemarra-regular">That an ordinary </span>situation with regard to travel between <span class="gemarra-regular">Judea and </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">Galile</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is tantamount to a period of crisis</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: </span>One <span class="gemarra-regular">cannot establish </span>the<span class="gemarra-regular"> presumption </span>of ownership <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to the property of </span>one who is <span class="gemarra-regular">fleeing, </span>as he is unable to lodge a protest. Rav Yehuda reports: <span class="gemarra-regular">When I said this </span>ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">before Shmuel, he </span>disagreed and <span class="gemarra-regular">said to me: But does </span>the owner actually <span class="gemarra-regular">have to protest in </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">presence of</span> the possessor? Since that is not the case, and he can lodge a protest wherever he is, one can establish the presumption of ownership with regard to the property of one who is fleeing.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav, </span>who ruled that one cannot establish the presumption of ownership with regard to the property of one who is fleeing, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">teaching us, </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a protest that </span>is lodged <span class="gemarra-regular">not in</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> his presence is not </span>a valid <span class="gemarra-regular">protest? But doesn’t Rav say: A protest that </span>is lodged <span class="gemarra-regular">not in his presence</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is </span>a valid <span class="gemarra-regular">protest? </span>The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav was explaining </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">reason of the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of our </span>mishna, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">himself does </span><span class="gemarra-regular">not hold accordingly. </span>Rav holds, in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda, that the protest is valid.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span><span class="gemarra-regular">there are </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">who say </span>a different version of the previous discussion: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: </span>One <span class="gemarra-regular">can establish </span>the<span class="gemarra-regular"> presumption </span>of ownership <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to the property of </span>one who is <span class="gemarra-regular">fleeing</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Rav Yehuda reports: <span class="gemarra-regular">When I said this</span> ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">before Shmuel</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he said to me: </span>Isn’t that <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious? But does </span>the owner actually <span class="gemarra-regular">have to protest in </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">presence of</span> the possessor?
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav, </span>who ruled that one can establish the presumption of ownership with regard to the property of one who is fleeing, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">teaching us, </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a protest that </span>is lodged <span class="gemarra-regular">not in</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> his presence is </span>a valid <span class="gemarra-regular">protest? But Rav </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">said this </span><span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">one time, </span>and he would not need to repeat it. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>Rav <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us this: That even if</span> the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">proteste</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in the presence of two </span>witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">who are </span>personally <span class="gemarra-regular">unable to tel</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span> the possessor about the protest, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is </span>nevertheless a valid <span class="gemarra-regular">protest.</span>
The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">As Rav Anan said: </span>This <span class="gemarra-regular">was explained to me personally by Shmuel himself: </span>If the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">protested in the presence of two people who are able to </span>personally <span class="gemarra-regular">tell </span>the possessor, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is </span>a valid <span class="gemarra-regular">protest, </span>but if the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">protested in the presence of two people who are unable to </span>personally <span class="gemarra-regular">tell </span>the possessor, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is not </span>a valid <span class="gemarra-regular">protest. And </span>why does <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav </span>hold that it is a valid protest? Because <span class="gemarra-regular">your friend </span>who heard the protest <span class="gemarra-regular">has a friend </span>to whom he tells about the protest, <span class="gemarra-regular">and your friend’s friend has a friend </span>to whom he tells about the protest, and so forth. Therefore, word of the protest will reach the possessor.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava says: </span>The <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is that one <span class="gemarra-regular">cannot establish </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to the property of </span>one who is <span class="gemarra-regular">fleeing</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and a protest that </span>is lodged <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>a possessor’s <span class="gemarra-regular">presence is </span>a valid <span class="gemarra-regular">protest. </span>The Gemara asks: How can he say these <span class="gemarra-regular">tw</span><span class="gemarra-regular">o</span> statements that contradict each other? The Gemara answers: This is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">difficult. Here, </span>the second statement, is referring to a case where he is <span class="gemarra-regular">fleeing due to monetary </span>difficulties. In such a case, he is able to ensure that the protest reaches the possessor, while <span class="gemarra-regular">there, </span>the first statement, is referring to a case where he is <span class="gemarra-regular">fleeing due to </span>a charge of <span class="gemarra-regular">killing [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">meradin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> In such a case, he is unable to publicize his protest out of fear of revealing his whereabouts.
§ The Gemara presents a series of disputes with regard to what is considered a valid protest. <span class="gemarra-regular">What manner </span>of statement constitutes <span class="gemarra-regular">a protest</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rav Zevid said: </span>If the owner says in general terms: <span class="gemarra-regular">So-and-so is a robber</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it is not </span>a valid <span class="gemarra-regular">protest, </span>but if he says: <span class="gemarra-regular">So-and-so is a robber as </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">is holding my land through robbery, </span>

Daf 39a

<span class="gemarra-regular">and tomorrow, </span>i.e., in the future, <span class="gemarra-regular">I will bring a claim </span>against <span class="gemarra-regular">him </span><span class="gemarra-regular">in court</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it is </span>a valid <span class="gemarra-regular">protest.</span>
If the one lodging a protest also <span class="gemarra-regular">said: Do not tell </span>the possessor of the protest, <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Zevid said:</span> It is not a valid protest, because <span class="gemarra-regular">isn’t he saying: Do not tell </span><span class="gemarra-regular">him? </span>Therefore, word of the protest will not reach the possessor and it is meaningless. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa </span>disagreed and <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>that the owner merely meant: <span class="gemarra-regular">Do not tell him personally, </span>but they, i.e. the witnesses, should <span class="gemarra-regular">tell others.</span> In that case, word of the protest will reach the possessor, since <span class="gemarra-regular">your friend has a friend </span>whom he tells about the protest, <span class="gemarra-regular">and your friend’s friend has a friend </span>whom he tells about the protest; therefore, it is a valid protest.
If the witnesses before whom the owner lodged the protest <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: We </span>are <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>going to <span class="gemarra-regular">tell </span>the possessor about your protest, what is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Zevid said:</span> It is not a valid protest, and he has to lodge a protest before other witnesses, as are <span class="gemarra-regular">they </span>not <span class="gemarra-regular">saying to him: We are not </span>going to <span class="gemarra-regular">tell him </span>about your protest? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa </span>disagreed and <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>that they merely meant: <span class="gemarra-regular">We </span>are <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>going to <span class="gemarra-regular">tell him personally, </span>but <span class="gemarra-regular">we are </span>going to <span class="gemarra-regular">tell others. </span>In that case, word of the protest will reach the possessor, since <span class="gemarra-regular">your friend has a friend </span>whom he tells about the protest, <span class="gemarra-regular">and your friend’s friend has a friend </span>whom he tells about the protest; therefore, it is a valid protest.
If the one lodging the protest also <span class="gemarra-regular">said to them: A word [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">shuta</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> should not emerge from yo</span><span class="gemarra-regular">u</span> about this, what is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Zevid said: </span>It is not a valid protest, as <span class="gemarra-regular">isn’t he saying </span>to them: <span class="gemarra-regular">A word should not emerge </span>from you? Similarly, if the people before whom he protested <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: We will not </span>have <span class="gemarra-regular">a word emerge </span>from us, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa said: </span>It is not a valid protest, as <span class="gemarra-regular">aren’t they saying to him: We will not </span>have <span class="gemarra-regular">a word emerge </span>from us? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna, the son of Rav Yehoshua, </span>disagreed and <span class="gemarra-regular">said: </span>It is a valid protest, because with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">any matter that </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>actually <span class="gemarra-regular">incumben</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> on a person </span>to keep secret, it is likely that he will <span class="gemarra-regular">say it</span> to others <span class="gemarra-regular">unawares, </span>and therefore the presumption is that word will reach the possessor.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman says: A protest that </span>is lodged <span class="gemarra-regular">not in </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">presence</span> of the possessor <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>a valid <span class="gemarra-regular">protest. Rava raised an objection to </span>what <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman </span>said from the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda says: </span>The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>that establishing the presumption of ownership requires <span class="gemarra-regular">three years only in order that </span>if the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">will be</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in Spain and </span>another <span class="gemarra-regular">possesses </span>his field for <span class="gemarra-regular">a year, </span>people <span class="gemarra-regular">will go and inform </span>the owner by the end of the next <span class="gemarra-regular">year, and </span>the owner will <span class="gemarra-regular">come </span>back <span class="gemarra-regular">in</span> the <span class="gemarra-regular">following year </span>and take the possessor to court. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">enters your mind </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a protest that </span>is lodged <span class="gemarra-regular">not in his presence</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is </span>a valid <span class="gemarra-regular">protest, why do I </span>need the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">to come? Let him remain there in his place and protest. </span>The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">There, </span>Rabbi Yehuda wishes to <span class="gemarra-regular">teach us good advice, that he </span>should <span class="gemarra-regular">come and collect</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the land and </span>its <span class="gemarra-regular">produce.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">From the fact </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava raised an objection to Rav Naḥman, it may be inferred </span><span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>he does <span class="gemarra-regular">not hold that a protest that </span>is lodged <span class="gemarra-regular">not in his presence is </span>a valid <span class="gemarra-regular">protest. But doesn’t Rava say: A protest that </span>is lodged <span class="gemarra-regular">not in his presence is </span>a valid <span class="gemarra-regular">protest? </span>The Gemara answers: He <span class="gemarra-regular">held that </span>conclusion only <span class="gemarra-regular">after </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">heard this </span><span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">from Rav Naḥman.</span>
§ The Gemara relates: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, encountered </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">students of Rabbi Yoḥanan </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">said to them: Did Rabbi Yoḥanan</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> say in </span>the presence of <span class="gemarra-regular">how many </span>people <span class="gemarra-regular">a protest </span>must be lodged? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan </span>says: <span class="gemarra-regular">A protest </span>must be lodged <span class="gemarra-regular">in the presence of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> two </span>people. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Abbahu said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan </span>said: <span class="gemarra-regular">A protest </span>must be lodged <span class="gemarra-regular">in the presence of three </span>people.
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Shall we say that they disagree with regard to </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabba bar Rav Huna? As Rabba bar Rav Huna says: Any matter that is said in the presence of three </span>people

Daf 39b

<span class="gemarra-regular">is not subject to </span>the prohibition of <span class="gemarra-regular">malicious speech</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as it is already public knowledge. The Gemara elaborates on the suggestion that the dispute hinges upon this point: <span class="gemarra-regular">The one who says </span>that a protest can be lodged <span class="gemarra-regular">in the presence of two </span>people <span class="gemarra-regular">is not of </span>the opinion that the ruling is in accordance with the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabba bar Rav Huna </span>and holds that even if only two people hear of a matter it will become a matter of public knowledge. Therefore, it is sufficient to protest in the presence of two witnesses. <span class="gemarra-regular">And the one who says </span>that a protest must be lodged <span class="gemarra-regular">in the presence of three </span>people <span class="gemarra-regular">is of </span>the opinion that the ruling is in accordance with the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabba bar Rav Huna.</span>
The Gemara rejects this suggestion: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, everyone is of </span>the opinion that the ruling is in accordance with the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabba bar Rav Huna, and here they disagree with regard to this: The one who says</span> that a protest can be lodged <span class="gemarra-regular">in the presence of two </span>people <span class="gemarra-regular">hold</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">a protest that </span>is lodged <span class="gemarra-regular">not in his</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> presence is not </span>a valid <span class="gemarra-regular">protest. </span>Therefore, two witnesses suffice, as they are needed to attest only to the fact that the owner protested. <span class="gemarra-regular">And the one who says </span>that a protest must be lodged <span class="gemarra-regular">in the presence of three </span>people <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a protest that </span>is lodged <span class="gemarra-regular">not in his presence is </span>a valid <span class="gemarra-regular">protest.</span> Since the protest can be lodged not in the possessor’s presence, three people are needed to ensure that word of the protest will reach him.
<span class="gemarra-regular">If you wish,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> say </span>instead <span class="gemarra-regular">that everyone </span>holds that <span class="gemarra-regular">a protest that </span>is lodged <span class="gemarra-regular">not in his presence is </span>a valid <span class="gemarra-regular">protest, and here they disagree with regard to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">this: The one who says </span>that a protest can be lodged <span class="gemarra-regular">in the presence of </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>people <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">we require testimony</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and two are sufficient for testimony. <span class="gemarra-regular">And the one who says </span>that a protest must be lodged <span class="gemarra-regular">in the presence of three </span>people <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">we require </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the matter </span>of the protest be <span class="gemarra-regular">revealed, </span>and for that purpose three people are needed.
§ The Gemara relates: <span class="gemarra-regular">Giddel bar Minyumi had a protest to lodge </span>with regard to his property. He <span class="gemarra-regular">found Rav Huna and Ḥiyya bar Rav and Rav Ḥilkiya bar Tuvi, who were sitting, and </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">protested before them. After a year, </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">came </span>to them <span class="gemarra-regular">again to protest. They said to him: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">You do not need </span>to do so; <span class="gemarra-regular">this is what Rav says: Once </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">protested </span>in the <span class="gemarra-regular">first year</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he no longer needs to protest. And there </span><span class="gemarra-regular">are </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">who say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Ḥiyya bar Rav said to him, </span>not in the name of Rav: <span class="gemarra-regular">Once </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">protested </span>in the <span class="gemarra-regular">first year, </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">no longer needs to protest.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Reish Lakish says in the name of bar Kappara: And </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">needs to protest at the end of each and every </span>period of <span class="gemarra-regular">thre</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> years, so that the possessor will not hold his property for three consecutive years uncontested. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan expressed surprise at this </span>ruling of Reish Lakish and said: <span class="gemarra-regular">But does a robber have </span>the ability to establish the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership? Once the owner lodged one protest, he demonstrated that the possessor occupied his land unlawfully. Therefore, the possessor should never be able to establish the presumption of ownership. The Gemara clarifies: Does it <span class="gemarra-regular">enter your mind </span>that the possessor is actually <span class="gemarra-regular">a robber? </span>There is no evidence that he robbed, there is only a protest by the prior owner. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>emend his question as follows: Does one who is <span class="gemarra-regular">akin to a robber have </span>the ability to establish the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is: The owner <span class="gemarra-regular">needs to protest at the end of each and every </span>period of <span class="gemarra-regular">three</span> years. <span class="gemarra-regular">Bar Kappara teaches: </span>If the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">protested, returned and protested</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and then <span class="gemarra-regular">returned and protested, if, </span>when he <span class="gemarra-regular">protested</span> the later times, his protest was <span class="gemarra-regular">based on </span>the same claim as the <span class="gemarra-regular">initial claim, </span>the possessor <span class="gemarra-regular">has no presumptive ownership. But if </span>the later protests were <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>based on the same claim as the initial protest, the possessor <span class="gemarra-regular">has presumptive ownership </span>since each time the owner advanced a new claim, he thereby nullified his earlier claims.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman says: A protest </span>can be lodged <span class="gemarra-regular">in the presence of tw</span><span class="gemarra-regular">o</span> witnesses, 

Daf 40a

<span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the prior owner <span class="gemarra-regular">does not need to say </span>to the witnesses: <span class="gemarra-regular">Writ</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> a document detailing the protest; they can write one even absent a directive. Similarly, one who desires to state <span class="gemarra-regular">a declaration</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> preemptively invalidating a bill of sale by notifying the court that it was executed under duress, needs to state the declaration <span class="gemarra-regular">in the presence of two </span>witnesses, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">does not need to say </span>to them: <span class="gemarra-regular">Write </span>a document detailing the declaration; they can write one even absent a directive.
The Gemara continues with the statement of Rava: <span class="gemarra-regular">An admission </span>of a monetary obligation needs to be stated <span class="gemarra-regular">in the presence of tw</span><span class="gemarra-regular">o</span> witnesses, <span class="gemarra-regular">and</span> in this case, the one stating the admission <span class="gemarra-regular">needs to sa</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span> to the witnesses: <span class="gemarra-regular">Writ</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> a document detailing the admission, as this document is to his detriment; they may not write one absent a directive. <span class="gemarra-regular">Acquisition </span>by means of a symbolic act utilizing a cloth needs to be done <span class="gemarra-regular">in the presence of tw</span><span class="gemarra-regular">o</span> witnesses, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the parties do <span class="gemarra-regular">not need to say </span>to the witnesses: <span class="gemarra-regular">Writ</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> a document detailing the acquisition; they can write one even absent a directive. <span class="gemarra-regular">And ratification of </span>legal <span class="gemarra-regular">documents</span> needs to be done <span class="gemarra-regular">by </span>means of <span class="gemarra-regular">thre</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> people.
The Gemara presents <span class="gemarra-regular">a mnemoni</span><span class="gemarra-regular">c</span> for the cases discussed above: <span class="gemarra-italic">Mem</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>protest [<span class="it-text">meḥa’a</span>]; <span class="gemarra-italic">mem</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> declaration [<span class="it-text">moda’a</span>]; <span class="gemarra-italic">heh</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>admission [<span class="it-text">hoda’a</span>]; <span class="gemarra-italic">kuf</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>acquisition [<span class="it-text">kinyan</span>].
Rava now discusses the statement of Rav Naḥman that he quoted. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: If </span>any part of this statement is <span class="gemarra-regular">difficult to me, this </span>is what is <span class="gemarra-regular">difficult to me. This acquisition, what is it like? If </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">like an act of the court</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it should require three </span>witnesses for it to take effect, as a court must consist of at least three men. <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">not like an act of the court, why does he not have to say </span>to the witnesses that they should <span class="gemarra-regular">write </span>the document detailing the acquisition? Isn’t transferring an item to another tantamount to admitting a monetary obligation?
<span class="gemarra-regular">After </span>Rava <span class="gemarra-regular">raised the dilemma, </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">then resolves it. Actually, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">not considered like an act of the court. And here, what is the reason that he does not have to say </span>to the witnesses that they should <span class="gemarra-regular">write? </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">due </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>a record of <span class="gemarra-regular">an unspecified acquisition </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">ready to </span>be <span class="gemarra-regular">written</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> A symbolic act of acquisition indicates one’s intention to do everything possible to finalize the transaction as soon as possible without waiting for the actual transfer of the item. Therefore, it is assumed that the parties would desire that a document be written, and no explicit authorization is necessary.
§ The Gemara discusses the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of a preemptive declaration. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba and Rav Yosef both say: We write </span>a preemptive <span class="gemarra-regular">declaration only concerning one who does not </span>generally <span class="gemarra-regular">listen to </span>and implement <span class="gemarra-regular">the judgment </span>of the court. In such a case, there is no recourse other than to write a preemptive declaration on behalf of the seller nullifying the transaction. If the buyer would be willing to listen to the court, the seller is expected to deal with the matter in court, rather than participating in the sale and writing a preemptive declaration. <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye and Rava both say: </span>A preemptive declaration may be written <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>concerning someone who is law abiding, such as <span class="gemarra-regular">for me and for you</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as not every issue can be settled through the courts. The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Neharde’a say: Any </span>preemptive <span class="gemarra-regular">declaration</span>

Daf 40b

<span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>does <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>have <span class="gemarra-regular">written in it </span>the formulation: <span class="gemarra-regular">We are aware of so-and-so’s duress</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., we are aware of the nature of the coercion that forced him to enter this arrangement against his will, <span class="gemarra-regular">is not </span>a valid preemptive <span class="gemarra-regular">declaration.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">For what </span>type of transaction is the preemptive <span class="gemarra-regular">declaration </span>being stated? <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>one were to say that it is a preemptive declaration <span class="gemarra-regular">for a bill of divorce or for a gift</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the preemptive declaration <span class="gemarra-regular">is merely revealing the matter</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Since these actions can’t take place unless he desires it, it is sufficient that he stated that he does not desire them, and he need not specify a particular reason for nullifying them. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">for a sale, but doesn’t Rava say: We do not write </span>a preemptive <span class="gemarra-regular">declaration for a sale</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span>
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Actually, </span>it is referring to a preemptive declaration <span class="gemarra-regular">for a sale, </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava concedes </span>in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where one was compelled to ac</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> due to a threat of monetary loss, <span class="gemarra-regular">as with the incident of the orchard</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as </span>there was <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain man who mortgaged </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">orchard to another for three years. After he </span>worked and <span class="gemarra-regular">profited </span>from <span class="gemarra-regular">it </span>for the <span class="gemarra-regular">three years </span>necessary <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>establishing the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership, <span class="gemarra-regular">he said:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> If you sell </span>the orchard <span class="gemarra-regular">to me, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">well. And if not, </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">I will hide </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">mortgage document and I will say </span>that this land <span class="gemarra-regular">is purchased </span>and that is why it is <span class="gemarra-regular">in my possession, </span>and you will receive no payment for the orchard. <span class="gemarra-regular">In a case like this, we write </span>a preemptive <span class="gemarra-regular">declaration. </span>The declaration states that he does not actually desire to sell his property but was forced to do so.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda says: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>document detailing <span class="gemarra-regular">a concealed gift</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> we do not collect with it. </span>The Gemara clarifies: <span class="gemarra-regular">What are the circumstances </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">a concealed gift? Rav Yosef said: </span>It is referring to a case in <span class="gemarra-regular">which </span>the giver <span class="gemarra-regular">said to witnesses: Go </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hide and write </span>a document <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>the recipient of this gift. <span class="gemarra-regular">And there are </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">who say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef said: </span>It is referring to a case in <span class="gemarra-regular">which </span>the giver <span class="gemarra-regular">did not say to </span>witnesses: <span class="gemarra-regular">Sit outdoors in the marketplac</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and write </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">for him. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is </span>the difference <span class="gemarra-regular">between </span>the two versions of Rav Yosef’s statement? The Gemara answers: The difference <span class="gemarra-regular">between </span>the two versions is in a case where his instructions were <span class="gemarra-regular">without specification</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., he did not tell them to write the document in private or in public.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: But </span>a concealed gift <span class="gemarra-regular">is</span> effective as a preemptive <span class="gemarra-regular">declaration for anothe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> gift. In other words, if he first gave an item as a concealed gift to one person, and then he gave this item as a gift to someone else, the second gift is null and void. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa said: This </span>ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rava was not stated explicitly; rather, it was stated by inference, </span>and he did not, in fact, hold accordingly.
Rav Pappa explains the inference: <span class="gemarra-regular">As </span>there was <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain man who went to betrot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">h</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a woman. She said to him: If you write </span>a document signing over <span class="gemarra-regular">all of your property to me, </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">I will be your </span>wife, <span class="gemarra-regular">and if not, I will not be </span><span class="gemarra-regular">your </span>wife. <span class="gemarra-regular">He went </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">wrote </span>a document signing over <span class="gemarra-regular">all of his property to her. His eldest son came </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: And that man, </span>i.e., me, <span class="gemarra-regular">what will become of him </span>if you give all of your property to this woman? The father <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>two <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses: Go hide in Avar Yemin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and writ</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> a document <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>the son, giving him the father’s property as a gift. Later, the witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">came before Rava. </span>He <span class="gemarra-regular">said to them: </span>This <span class="gemarra-regular">Master, </span>i.e., the son, <span class="gemarra-regular">did not acquire </span>the property <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Master, </span>i.e., the wife, <span class="gemarra-regular">did not acquire </span>it either. The son did not acquire the property because it was a concealed gift.
The Gemara explains why the wife does not acquire it as well. <span class="gemarra-regular">One who observed </span>this incident <span class="gemarra-regular">assumed </span>that Rava invalidated the wife’s acquisition <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>the concealed gift to his son <span class="gemarra-regular">was </span>a preemptive <span class="gemarra-regular">declaration to the other </span>gift, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">is not so. There, </span>in the case of the woman and the son, <span class="gemarra-regular">the matter </span>is self-<span class="gemarra-regular">eviden</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that he wrote </span>a document signing over his property <span class="gemarra-regular">to her because of duress, </span>as she had told him that she would not marry him otherwise; <span class="gemarra-regular">but here, </span>in a typical case of giving one person a concealed gift and then giving a public gift to another, that is not the case. It is possible that it is simply <span class="gemarra-regular">amenable to him that </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">Master, </span>i.e., the one to whom he gave it publicly, <span class="gemarra-regular">should acquire </span>the gift, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">not amenable to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> him that </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">Master, </span>i.e., the one to whom he gave it privately, <span class="gemarra-regular">should acquire </span>the gift. Consequently, an incorrect inference was drawn concerning Rava’s opinion.
<span class="gemarra-regular">A dilemma was raised before </span>the Sages: 

Daf 41a

<span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is the status of a document detailing a gift that is <span class="gemarra-regular">with-out specificatio</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> as to whether the giver desired that it be publicized? <span class="gemarra-regular">Ravina says: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">We are not concerned </span>that it may be a concealed gift, and <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi says: We are concerned. And </span>the <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is that <span class="gemarra-regular">we are concerned</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
