<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">Any possession</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that is not accompanied by a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">clai</span><span class="gemarra-regular">m</span> explaining how the possessor became the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">is not </span>sufficient to establish the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership.<span class="gemarra-regular"> How so? </span>If the prior owner <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>the possessor: <span class="gemarra-regular">What</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> are you doing in my </span>land? <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the possessor <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him </span>in response: I am in possession of the land <span class="gemarra-regular">because no person ever said anything to me </span>about my being here, i.e., he states no valid claim as to why he would be the owner of the land, his mere use <span class="gemarra-regular">is not </span>sufficient to establish the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership.
But if the possessor claimed: I am in possession of the land <span class="gemarra-regular">because you sold </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">to me, </span>or: <span class="gemarra-regular">Because you gave </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">to me as a gift,</span> or: Because <span class="gemarra-regular">your father sold it to me, </span>or: Because <span class="gemarra-regular">your </span><span class="gemarra-regular">father gave it to me as a gift, </span>these are valid claims to ownership. In these cases, his possession <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>sufficient to establish the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership.<span class="gemarra-regular"> And one who comes </span>to claim the land <span class="gemarra-regular">based on inheritanc</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> does not need a claim </span>explaining why his ancestors had a right to the land.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: Why does the mishna need to say this? Isn’t it <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious </span>that one cannot establish the presumption of ownership absent a claim of ownership?
The Gemara answers: It is necessary for the mishna to state this, <span class="gemarra-regular">lest you say: That man </span>had actually <span class="gemarra-regular">purchased this land </span>that he possessed, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he had a bill </span>of sale, <span class="gemarra-regular">but it was lost. And the reason that he said </span>that he is in possession of the land because no person ever said anything to him, is that he <span class="gemarra-regular">thought: If I say </span>that the prior owner <span class="gemarra-regular">sold me this land, </span>the court will <span class="gemarra-regular">say to me: Show </span>us <span class="gemarra-regular">your bill </span>of sale. <span class="gemarra-regular">Therefore, </span>being that this may be the case, <span class="gemarra-regular">let us say to him: Perhaps you had a bill </span>of sale <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">was</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> lost. </span>In a case <span class="gemarra-regular">such as this, </span>one would think that <span class="gemarra-regular">it is </span>a situation where the court should apply the verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Open your mout</span><span class="gemarra-regular">h</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for the mute” </span>(Proverbs 31:8), meaning the court should advise a litigant of his possible claims, because perhaps he does not state them out of ignorance. Therefore, the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>that the court does not advance this claim on his behalf, and if he does not make the claim of his own violation, he does not establish the presumption of ownership.
§ The Gemara presents <span class="gemarra-regular">a mnemonic </span>for the discussion that follows: <span class="gemarra-italic">Ayin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span><span class="gemarra-italic">nun</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span><span class="gemarra-italic">bet</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
The Gemara tells of a related incident: <span class="gemarra-regular">A torrent [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">bideka</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> of water <span class="gemarra-regular">swept </span>through <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Anan’s land, </span>removing the wall which marked the boundary between his land and that of his neighbor. Rav Anan <span class="gemarra-regular">went back </span>and rebuilt <span class="gemarra-regular">the wall, </span>inadvertently placing it <span class="gemarra-regular">in his neighbor’s land. </span>Rav Anan <span class="gemarra-regular">came before Rav Naḥman </span>to ask him what he should do about it. Rav Naḥman <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Go return </span>the boundary to its prior position.
Rav Anan replied: Why should I return the boundary? <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span><span class="gemarra-regular">didn’t I </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">establish </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership of this land? Rav Naḥman <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: In accordance with whose </span>opinion are you claiming a right to the land? Is it <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Yishmael</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> who say: Any </span>taking of possession that is done <span class="gemarra-regular">in the presence of </span>the prior owner <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>sufficient to establish the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership<span class="gemarra-regular"> immediately? </span>If so, your claim is not accepted since <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is not in accordance with </span><span class="gemarra-regular">their </span>opinion.
Rav Anan <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Rav Naḥman: <span class="gemarra-regular">But didn’t </span>the neighbor <span class="gemarra-regular">waiv</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> his ownership of this land, <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">came and assisted in </span>the building of <span class="gemarra-regular">the wall with me? </span>Rav Naḥman <span class="gemarra-regular">said to</span> Rav Anan: <span class="gemarra-regular">It </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">an erroneous waiving</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> since <span class="gemarra-regular">you yourself would not </span>have placed the wall there <span class="gemarra-regular">if you had known </span>that it was the wrong location for it. <span class="gemarra-regular">Just as you did not know </span>that you were building it in the wrong location, <span class="gemarra-regular">so too, he did not know. </span>Therefore, it is reasonable to assume that he did not knowingly waive his ownership of his property.
The Gemara relates a similar incident: <span class="gemarra-regular">A torrent </span>of water <span class="gemarra-regular">swept </span>through <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Kahana’s field, </span>removing the wall that marked the boundary between his land and that of his neighbor. Rav Kahana <span class="gemarra-regular">went back </span>and rebuilt the <span class="gemarra-regular">wall, </span>inadvertently placing it <span class="gemarra-regular">in land that was not his. </span>

Daf 41b

Rav Kahana <span class="gemarra-regular">came before Rav Yehuda. </span>Rav Kahana’s neighbor <span class="gemarra-regular">went </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">brought two witnesses. One said: </span>Rav Kahana <span class="gemarra-regular">entered two rows </span>into his neighbor’s land, <span class="gemarra-regular">and one said: </span>Rav Kahana <span class="gemarra-regular">entered three rows </span>into his neighbor’s land. Rav Yehuda <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Rav Kahana: <span class="gemarra-regular">Go </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">pay</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> two out of </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">three </span>that your neighbor is claiming by moving the wall two rows into your property.
Rav Kahana <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Rav Yehuda: <span class="gemarra-regular">In accordance with whose</span> opinion are you ruling that the testimony of witnesses who contradict each other is valid? Is it <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar? As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar said: Beit</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Shammai and Beit Hillel did not disagree with regard to two sets of witnesses, where one </span>set <span class="gemarra-regular">says </span>that a litigant owes <span class="gemarra-regular">one hundred dinars and one </span>set <span class="gemarra-regular">says </span>that he owes <span class="gemarra-regular">two hundred</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> In such a case, everyone agrees <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>two hundred <span class="gemarra-regular">includes one hundred</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and he is liable to pay one hundred.
<span class="gemarra-regular">With regard to what did </span>Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel <span class="gemarra-regular">disagree? </span>They disagree <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to one set </span>of witnesses, <span class="gemarra-regular">where one </span>witness <span class="gemarra-regular">says </span>that a litigant owes <span class="gemarra-regular">one hundred dinars and one </span>witness <span class="gemarra-regular">says </span>that he owes <span class="gemarra-regular">two hundred; as</span> in such a case, <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Shammai say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">their testimony is divided, </span>and they do not combine to form a set of witnesses, <span class="gemarra-regular">and Beit Hillel say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">two hundred includes one hundred, </span>and they combine to form a set of witnesses. Rav Kahana assumed that Rav Yehuda based his ruling on Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar’s interpretation of the opinion of Beit Hillel.
Rav Kahana then <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Rav Yehuda: How can you rely on this opinion? <span class="gemarra-regular">But I can bring you a letter from the West</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> Eretz Yisrael, stating <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is not in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar, </span>and that in fact Beit Hillel also disqualify two witnesses in such a case. Rav Yehuda <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Rav Kahana: I will accept that ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">when you will</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> brin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span> such a letter. Until then, I stand by my ruling.
§ The Gemara relates: There was <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain man who resided</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in a loft in Kasht</span><span class="gemarra-regular">a</span> for <span class="gemarra-regular">four years. </span>At the end of that period, the prior <span class="gemarra-regular">owner of the house came </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">found him </span>there. The prior owner <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: What do you </span><span class="gemarra-regular">want with this house </span>of mine? The possessor <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>him: <span class="gemarra-regular">I purchased it from so-and-so, who purchased it from you</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> The possessor <span class="gemarra-regular">came before Rabbi Ḥiyya, </span>who <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: If you have witnesse</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> who will testify <span class="gemarra-regular">that he, from whom you purchased </span>the house, <span class="gemarra-regular">resided in it, even </span>if there is testimony that he resided in it for only <span class="gemarra-regular">one day, I will establish it in your possession, but if </span>there is <span class="gemarra-regular">no</span> testimony to his having resided there then I will <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>establish it in your possession, and it will revert back to its prior owner.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav said: I was sitting before my uncle [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">deḥavivi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> Rabbi Ḥiyya, <span class="gemarra-regular">and I said to him: But isn’t it common </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">a person to purchase </span>a house <span class="gemarra-regular">and sell </span>it immediately <span class="gemarra-regular">during the </span>same <span class="gemarra-regular">night? </span>It is possible that the seller purchased and sold the house without witnesses who saw him residing in it. <span class="gemarra-regular">And I saw that </span>Rabbi Ḥiyya’s <span class="gemarra-regular">opinion </span>was that <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>the possessor <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>the claimant: The one who sold it to me <span class="gemarra-regular">purchased it from you in my presence, </span>this claim is <span class="gemarra-regular">deemed credible, since</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> if </span>the possessor <span class="gemarra-regular">wanted </span>to, he could have <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>the prior owner of the house: <span class="gemarra-regular">I purchased it from you.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: </span>It <span class="gemarra-regular">stands to reason </span>that the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Ḥiyya, as </span>the mishna (41a) <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches: </span>In the case of land <span class="gemarra-regular">that comes as an inheritance, one is not required to make a claim </span>as to how the land came into his benefactor’s possession when one’s ownership of the land is challenged. This indicates that <span class="gemarra-regular">it is a claim that </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">does not need, but </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">does need proo</span><span class="gemarra-regular">f </span> that it had been in the possession of his ancestors.
The Gemara rejects the inference from the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">But perhaps </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">does not need proof and does not need a claim. </span>The only reason that the mishna mentions that he does not need a claim is to clarify that this does not fall into the category of a possession that is not accompanied by a claim. Therefore, one cannot infer from the ruling of that mishna what the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> should be in this case. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if you wish, say </span>instead that although the inference from the mishna is correct, it is not relevant to this case, as the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a buyer is different, since </span>he would <span class="gemarra-regular">not throw money </span>away <span class="gemarra-regular">for nothing. </span>The fact that he purchased the house indicates that he must have ascertained that the seller had a right to it.
<span class="gemarra-regular">A dilemma was raised before </span>the Sages: If the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">was seen in </span>the house, <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? Is this sufficient proof that he had purchased the house? <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said: It is identical </span>to testimony that he had resided there. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: </span>This does not constitute proof, as <span class="gemarra-regular">a person is apt to survey [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">desayyar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> land and</span> ultimately <span class="gemarra-regular">not purchase </span>it.
§ The Gemara issues a ruling concerning the establishment of the presumption of ownership. <span class="gemarra-regular">Three buyers </span><span class="gemarra-regular">combin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> to establish the presumption of ownership. If one purchased a field and sold it to another, who then sold it to a third party, and in total, the three of them worked and profited from the field for three years, the third one has established the presumption of ownership. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: And</span> this is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> only if they <span class="gemarra-regular">all </span>purchased the land <span class="gemarra-regular">with a bil</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span> of sale. As a result of the bill of sale, the prior owner will know that it is not the case that each of them worked and profited from the field for only one year and abandoned it, which would explain why he did not bother to lodge a protest.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Is this </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to say that Rav holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a bill </span>of sale generates <span class="gemarra-regular">publicity</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> but witnesses do not </span>generate <span class="gemarra-regular">publicity? But doesn’t Rav </span><span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who sells a field in </span>the presence of <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses, </span>and that field is later seized by the creditors of the seller, the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">collects from </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">liened propert</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span> that the seller had sold to others, to be reimbursed for his seized field? If not for the fact that the sale in the presence of witnesses generates publicity, those who later purchased land from the seller would not have been aware that the property they are purchasing is liened to the first buyer. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">There, </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">buyers, </span>

Daf 42a

<span class="gemarra-regular">they caused their own los</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> by not investigating whether there was a lien on the property that they intended to buy.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And did Rav, </span>in fact, <span class="gemarra-regular">say this, </span>that one can collect sold property by means of witnesses alone? <span class="gemarra-regular">But didn’t we learn </span>in a mishna (175a): <span class="gemarra-regular">One who lends money to another with </span>a promissory <span class="gemarra-regular">note collects </span>his debt <span class="gemarra-regular">from liened </span><span class="gemarra-regular">property </span>that had been sold after the loan, if the debtor has no other property; but if one lent <span class="gemarra-regular">by means of witnesses </span>without a promissory note, he <span class="gemarra-regular">collects </span>his debt only <span class="gemarra-regular">from unsold property</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if you would say</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav is a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, and </span>as such has the authority to <span class="gemarra-regular">dispute </span>the determination in the mishna, <span class="gemarra-regular">but didn’t Rav </span>himself <span class="gemarra-regular">and Shmuel both say: </span>One who is owed a debt due to <span class="gemarra-regular">a loan by oral </span>contract <span class="gemarra-regular">does not collect </span>liened property, <span class="gemarra-regular">not from the heirs </span>of the debtor <span class="gemarra-regular">nor from the buyers, </span>despite the fact that there are witnesses?
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Are you raising a contradiction</span> from a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a loan to </span>a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a sale? </span>They are not comparable. In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a loan, when </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">borrows </span>money he <span class="gemarra-regular">borrows discreetly, in order that his property not be devalued, </span>as people will pay less for his property if they know that he is pressed for capital. Since a loan is issued discreetly, the presumption is that the buyers were unaware of the loan. Therefore, the creditor does not collect from sold property. By contrast, in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a sale, one who sells land sells</span> it <span class="gemarra-regular">in publi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">c</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in order that publicity be generated with regard to it. </span>Therefore, the cases of loans and sales are not comparable.
The Gemara continues the discussion of the establishment of the presumption of ownership by successive possessors. <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught: </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">the father </span>worked and <span class="gemarra-regular">profited </span>from the land for one <span class="gemarra-regular">yea</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and the son </span>who inherited it from him worked and profited from it for <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>years, or if <span class="gemarra-regular">the father </span>worked and profited from the land for <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>years <span class="gemarra-regular">and the son </span>worked and profited from for one <span class="gemarra-regular">year, </span>or if <span class="gemarra-regular">the father </span>worked and profited from the land for one <span class="gemarra-regular">year and the son </span>worked and profited from it for one <span class="gemarra-regular">year, and the buyer, </span>who purchased it from the son, worked and profited from it for one <span class="gemarra-regular">year</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> this is </span>sufficient to establish the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Is this to say</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a buyer, </span>the transaction generates <span class="gemarra-regular">publicity? And </span>one can <span class="gemarra-regular">raise a contradiction </span>from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> (<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span> 2:8): If one worked and <span class="gemarra-regular">profited </span>from the land <span class="gemarra-regular">in the presence of the father, </span>the prior owner, for one <span class="gemarra-regular">year</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and in the presence of the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> son, </span>who then inherited it from the father, for <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>years; or <span class="gemarra-regular">in the presence of the father </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>years <span class="gemarra-regular">and in the presence</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of the son </span>for one <span class="gemarra-regular">year; </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">in the presence of the father </span>for one <span class="gemarra-regular">year and in the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> presence of the son </span>for one <span class="gemarra-regular">year and in the presence of the buyer, </span>who purchased it from the son, for one <span class="gemarra-regular">year; this is </span>sufficient to establish the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership.<span class="gemarra-regular"> And if it enters your mind </span>that with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a buyer, </span>the transaction generates <span class="gemarra-regular">publicity, there is no greater protest than this. </span>By selling his land to someone else, the son of the prior owner is clearly stating that it does not belong to the possessor.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa said: </span>That is not a contradiction, as <span class="gemarra-regular">when that </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is taught, </span>it is taught <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>one who <span class="gemarra-regular">sells his fields without specification. </span>The son of the prior owner sold his fields without clarifying which fields he was selling. Since he did not specify the field from which the possessor is profiting, the possessor had no reason to assume that this field was being sold and that he needed to hold on to his deed, and he establishes the presumption of ownership despite the sale. In a case where the son of the prior owner stated explicitly that he was selling the field in question, the sale would serve as his protest.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">Craftsme</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> who are in possession of items that they are repairing, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">partners</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">sharecroppers</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and stewards [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">veha’apotropin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">do not have </span>the ability to establish the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership with regard to property in their possession, as their possession is not indicative of ownership. Similarly, <span class="gemarra-regular">a man does not have </span>the ability to establish the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to his wife’s </span><span class="gemarra-regular">property</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and a wife does not have </span>the ability to establish the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to her husband’s property. And a father </span>similarly <span class="gemarra-regular">does </span><span class="gemarra-regular">no</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">have </span>the ability to establish the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership<span class="gemarra-regular"> with regard to a son’s property, and a son does not have </span>the ability to establish the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to a father’s property. </span>A husband and wife, or son and father, use each other’s property freely. Possession is therefore not indicative of ownership.
The mishna continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">In what </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">is this statement, </span>that one establishes the presumption of ownership after profiting from the property for a certain duration, with the exception of the above people, <span class="gemarra-regular">said? </span>It is said <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>a case of one who <span class="gemarra-regular">has </span>mere <span class="gemarra-regular">possessio</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> of the property, which does, in some cases, serve as proof of ownership. <span class="gemarra-regular">But in </span>a case where another person <span class="gemarra-regular">gives </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">a gift</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> or </span>there are <span class="gemarra-regular">brothers who divided </span>their inheritance, <span class="gemarra-regular">or </span>there is one who <span class="gemarra-regular">takes possession of </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">property of a conver</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> who died without heirs and his property is now ownerless, as soon as one <span class="gemarra-regular">locke</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> the door of the property, <span class="gemarra-regular">or fenced </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">or breached </span>its fence even <span class="gemarra-regular">a bit, this is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">taking</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> possession </span>of the property, and it effects acquisition. 

Daf 42b

<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel’s father and Levi taught: A partne</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> does not have </span>the ability to establish the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership of property in his possession, <span class="gemarra-regular">and, all the more so, </span>this inability applies to <span class="gemarra-regular">a craftsma</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> as well. But <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel teaches: A craftsman does not have </span>the ability to establish the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership of property in his possession, <span class="gemarra-regular">but a partner </span>does <span class="gemarra-regular">have </span>the ability to establish the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership. The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">And Shmuel follows his </span>line of <span class="gemarra-regular">reasoning, as Shmuel says: Partners establish </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership with regard to the property of <span class="gemarra-regular">each other</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>they <span class="gemarra-regular">testify for each othe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and become paid bailee</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> of their joint property with regard <span class="gemarra-regular">to each other. </span>In terms of these issues, Shmuel considers partners to be independent parties.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Abba raises a contradiction to Rav Yehuda in the cave of Rav Zakkai’s house: Did Shmuel </span>actually <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a partner has </span>the ability to establish the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership?<span class="gemarra-regular"> But doesn’t Shmuel say: A partner is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>one who <span class="gemarra-regular">enters </span>the field <span class="gemarra-regular">with permission</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> such as a sharecropper? <span class="gemarra-regular">Isn’t that to say that a partner does not have </span>the ability to establish the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership? The Gemara answers: It is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult. This </span>is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">enters all of </span>the field, and <span class="gemarra-regular">that</span> is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">enters half </span>of the field.
The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">Some say it in this manne</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and some say it in that manner</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> On the one hand, it is possible to explain that if he entered half of the field he establishes the presumption of ownership with regard to that half, but if he entered the entire field he is merely acting as a partner. On the other hand, one could explain that entering half of the field does not establish the presumption of ownership at all, while entering the entire field does establish it.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Ravina stated </span>a different resolution to the contradiction: <span class="gemarra-regular">Both this and that </span>are referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">enters the entire </span>field, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult. This </span>is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the field <span class="gemarra-regular">is of </span>sufficient area to be subject to the <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of division. </span>In this case, his being in possession of the other half of the field as well, which belonged to his partner, establishes the presumption of ownership. <span class="gemarra-regular">That </span>is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the field <span class="gemarra-regular">is not of </span>sufficient area to be subject to the <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of division. </span>Since the property will not be divided but will remain co-owned, he is merely possessing it as a partner and does not establish the presumption of ownership.
§ The Gemara addresses <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>matter <span class="gemarra-regular">itself. Shmuel says: A partner is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>one who <span class="gemarra-regular">enters </span>the field <span class="gemarra-regular">with permission. What is </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">teaching us, </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">there is no </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership in the context of <span class="gemarra-regular">partnership? </span>If so, <span class="gemarra-regular">let </span>him <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>explicitly: <span class="gemarra-regular">A partner does not have </span>the ability to establish the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership of property in his possession.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba bar Avuh says: </span>Shmuel’s intent was <span class="gemarra-regular">to state that </span>a partner who proactively works to improve their mutual property <span class="gemarra-regular">collects </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">enhancemen</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that reaches shoulders</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., when the produce that grew due to the efforts of the partner is fully grown and ripened and can be harvested and carried upon one’s shoulders. He is not considered as one who entered another’s field without permission and improved it, who collects only for his expenditures. This is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> if he planted trees <span class="gemarra-regular">in a field that is not commonly used for planting </span>trees, <span class="gemarra-regular">just as </span>it is if he planted <span class="gemarra-regular">in a field that is commonly used for planting </span>trees.
The Gemara continues its discussion of Shmuel’s statement: <span class="gemarra-regular">And testify for each other. </span>A partner may join another witness in testifying with regard to the fact that his partner owns a share of their field in order to counter the claim of a one who claims ownership of the field, and his testimony is not disqualified due to being biased. 

Daf 43a

The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Why </span>is this so? Aren’t partners <span class="gemarra-regular">biased in their testimony</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as they jointly own the property in question?
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">With what are we dealing here? </span>We are dealing with a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where</span> the partner who is testifying <span class="gemarra-regular">wrote to </span>the other partner: <span class="gemarra-regular">I</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> do not have </span>any <span class="gemarra-regular">legal </span>dealings <span class="gemarra-regular">or involvement with regard to this field, thereby </span>relinquishing his ownership of the field. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And if </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">wrote </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">to him, what of it? But isn’t it taught</span> in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">one who says to another: I do not have </span>any <span class="gemarra-regular">legal </span>dealings <span class="gemarra-regular">or involvement concerning this field,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> or: I have no dealings with it, or: My hands are removed from it, has said nothing? </span>That is to say, these statements have no legal standing.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">With what are we dealing here? </span>We are dealing with a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the one testifying <span class="gemarra-regular">performed </span>an act of <span class="gemarra-regular">acquisition with </span>the other partner. Since relinquishing his share in this fashion is effective, his testimony is no longer biased. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And if </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">performed</span> an act of <span class="gemarra-regular">acquisition with </span>the one testifying, <span class="gemarra-regular">what of it?</span> His testimony is still biased, as he is <span class="gemarra-regular">establishing </span>the field <span class="gemarra-regular">before his creditor. </span>Once he transferred his share to his partner, his creditor will now be able to collect from the property that he formerly co-owned, as a creditor can collect from property that a debtor once owned despite the fact that he has relinquished his ownership of it. Since his testimony enables him to repay his debt, it is biased.
<span class="gemarra-regular">As Ravin bar Shmuel says in the name of Shmuel: One who sells a field to another </span>even <span class="gemarra-regular">without a guarante</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> that if the field will be repossessed the seller will compensate the buyer for his loss <span class="gemarra-regular">cannot testify with regard to </span>ownership of that field <span class="gemarra-regular">on behalf of </span>the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">establishing </span>the field <span class="gemarra-regular">before his creditor.</span>
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">With what are we dealing</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> here? </span>We are dealing with a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the one testifying <span class="gemarra-regular">assumes </span>financial <span class="gemarra-regular">responsibility for </span>the field. Therefore, his testimony is not biased. The Gemara clarifies: <span class="gemarra-regular">Responsibility with regard to whom? If we say </span>that he assumes <span class="gemarra-regular">general responsibility, </span>such that if anyone collects the field from his former partner for whatever reason, he is liable to compensate the partner, then <span class="gemarra-regular">all the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> more so </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">preferable for him </span>that the field remain in his former partner’s possession, as if the claimant will be successful in obtaining the field, the witness will have to compensate the partner. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>it is referring to a case where he assumes <span class="gemarra-regular">responsibility </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>a loss <span class="gemarra-regular">that comes to</span> his former partner in the property <span class="gemarra-regular">resulting from </span>the field being seized by one of his creditors to collect payment for <span class="gemarra-regular">his </span>debts. He is, therefore, not an interested party, as in any event he owes the same debt, either to his creditor or to his partner.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And if he removes himself from </span>the property by having the former partner acquire his share in it, <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>it actually effective to <span class="gemarra-regular">remove</span> him, so that there is no longer a concern for biased testimony? <span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t it taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: With regard to a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">residents of a city whose Torah scroll was stolen</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the case is <span class="gemarra-regular">not adjudicated by </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">judges of that city, and proof may not be brought from </span>the testimony of the <span class="gemarra-regular">people of that city, </span>as their testimony is biased? <span class="gemarra-regular">And if</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it is so </span>that relinquishing one’s share renders one as not biased, then <span class="gemarra-regular">let two of them remove themselves from </span>their share in the Torah scroll, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>then the court can <span class="gemarra-regular">judge </span>the case based on their testimony.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">A Torah scroll is different, as it stands for </span>the people <span class="gemarra-regular">to listen </span>to the Torah reading from it. Since they are obligated to listen to the Torah reading, they stand to benefit from this Torah scroll even if they relinquish their ownership share in it, and their testimony is biased.
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a proof from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who says: Give one hundred dinars to the residents of my city, </span>the distribution of the funds is <span class="gemarra-regular">not adjudicated by </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">judges of that city, and proof may not be brought from </span>the testimony of the <span class="gemarra-regular">people of that city, </span>as their testimony is biased. <span class="gemarra-regular">Why </span>not? <span class="gemarra-regular">Let two </span>people <span class="gemarra-regular">remove themselves </span>from their share in the funds <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>then the court can <span class="gemarra-regular">judge </span>the case based on their testimony.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Here</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> too, </span>this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is stated <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>a case where the gift was for the purpose of procuring <span class="gemarra-regular">a Torah scroll, </span>and the same aforementioned reasoning applies.
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a proof from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who says: Give one hundred dinars to the poor </span>people <span class="gemarra-regular">of my city</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the distribution of the funds is <span class="gemarra-regular">not adjudicated by </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">judges of that city, and proof may not be brought from </span>testimony of the <span class="gemarra-regular">people of that city, </span>as their testimony is biased. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>how can <span class="gemarra-regular">you understand</span> the fact that the <span class="gemarra-regular">poor take </span>the money and the <span class="gemarra-regular">judges are </span>thereby <span class="gemarra-regular">disqualified </span>as interested parties? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, say: </span>The distribution of the funds is <span class="gemarra-regular">not adjudicated by </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">poor judges of that city, and proof may not be brought from </span>the testimony of the <span class="gemarra-regular">poor people of that city. And why </span>not? <span class="gemarra-regular">Let two </span>people <span class="gemarra-regular">remove themselves </span>from their share in the funds <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>then the court can <span class="gemarra-regular">judge </span>the case based on their testimony.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Here, too </span>this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is stated <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>a case where the gift was for the purpose of procuring <span class="gemarra-regular">a Torah scroll,</span> and the same aforementioned reasoning applies. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>if it is referring to money for purchasing a Torah scroll rather than money earmarked for charity, <span class="gemarra-regular">why </span>does the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">call </span>the recipients: <span class="gemarra-regular">Poor </span>people? <span class="gemarra-regular">Because everyone is poor with regard to a Torah scroll, </span>as it is very expensive.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if you </span><span class="gemarra-regular">wish, say </span>instead: <span class="gemarra-regular">Actually, </span>it is referring to people who are <span class="gemarra-regular">literally poor, as it teaches. And </span>the ruling of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is stated <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">poor people, whose </span>support is <span class="gemarra-regular">incumbent upon </span>all of the residents. Therefore, a gift to these poor people reduces their obligation, and all of their testimony is biased. The Gemara clarifies: <span class="gemarra-regular">And what</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> are the circumstances </span>in which this <span class="it-text">baraita</span> states its ruling? <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>it is a place <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the sum of charity that each resident is obligated to give is <span class="gemarra-regular">fixed for them, let two of </span>them <span class="gemarra-regular">give what is fixed for them </span>to give to the poor, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>then the court can <span class="gemarra-regular">judge </span>the case based on their testimony.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">With what are we dealing here? </span>We are dealing with a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the sum is <span class="gemarra-regular">not fixed for them. </span>Therefore, this is not an option. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if you wish, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>instead: <span class="gemarra-regular">Actually, </span>it is referring to a place <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the sum is <span class="gemarra-regular">fixed for them. And </span>nevertheless, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">amenable to </span>the residents of the city that the poor receive a gift, <span class="gemarra-regular">because once</span> there is <span class="gemarra-regular">a gai</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> for the poor people from this donation, there is <span class="gemarra-regular">a gain, </span>and it lightens the burden on all of the people of the city.
§ The Gemara returns to discuss Shmuel’s statement concerning partners: <span class="gemarra-regular">And they become paid bailees </span>of their joint property with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">each other. </span>

Daf 43b

The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Why </span>are they liable as paid bailees? Isn’t <span class="gemarra-regular">it </span>a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">safeguarding accompanied by </span>employment of the <span class="gemarra-regular">owner</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> Since both partners are safeguarding each other’s property, they are both employed by each other, and they should therefore be exempt from the obligations of safeguarding. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa said: </span>Shmuel is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he says to </span>his partner: <span class="gemarra-regular">Safeguard for me today, and I will safeguard for you tomorrow</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> In this circumstance, they are each the sole bailee at any given moment, and they do not receive the exemption from bailee payments for being employed by the owner.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught: </span>If one <span class="gemarra-regular">sold a house to </span>another, or if he <span class="gemarra-regular">sold a field to him, </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">cannot testify about it for </span>the buyer against a claimant <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>the financial <span class="gemarra-regular">responsibility </span>to compensate the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">for it </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">upon him,</span> and his testimony is biased. By contrast, if he <span class="gemarra-regular">sold a cow to him, </span>or if he <span class="gemarra-regular">sold a cloak to him, </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">can testify about it for </span>the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>the financial <span class="gemarra-regular">responsibility</span> to compensate the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">for it </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">not upon him. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is different </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">the first clause </span>that he cannot testify <span class="gemarra-regular">and what</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is different </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">the latter clause </span>that he can? Why would one assume that in the first case he does bear responsibility, but not in the second?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Sheshet said: The first clause </span>is stated <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">Reuven, who robbe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Shimon of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a fiel</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and sold it to Levi, and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">Yehuda comes and contests </span>Levi’s ownership, stating that it was actually his. The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> teaches <span class="gemarra-regular">that Shimon cannot go </span>to court <span class="gemarra-regular">to testify for Levi, because</span> it is <span class="gemarra-regular">preferable for </span>Shimon <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the field be <span class="gemarra-regular">returned </span>to Levi, so that he can later collect it from him.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But once </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">testified that </span>the field <span class="gemarra-regular">is Levi’s, how is he able to </span>later <span class="gemarra-regular">remove it from his </span>possession? The Gemara answers: This is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>Shimon <span class="gemarra-regular">says </span>in his testimony: <span class="gemarra-regular">I know that this land is not Yehuda’s, </span>but he did not explicitly testify that it belonged to Levi. He is therefore able to later claim it is his and not Levi’s. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>why should he testify that it does not belong to Yehuda? <span class="gemarra-regular">With </span><span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>same <span class="gemarra-regular">right </span>by which he <span class="gemarra-regular">removes </span>the land <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the possession of <span class="gemarra-regular">Levi, let him remove it from </span>the possession of <span class="gemarra-regular">Yehuda. </span>It is not to his advantage to lie in order to establish it in the possession of Levi, and his testimony should not be considered biased.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Because </span>Shimon <span class="gemarra-regular">says </span>to himself: <span class="gemarra-regular">The second </span>person <span class="gemarra-regular">is amenable to me, </span>while <span class="gemarra-regular">the first </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">more difficult than he </span>is, i.e., I prefer to litigate with Levi rather than with Yehuda.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if </span><span class="gemarra-regular">you wish, say </span>instead: It is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">Master, </span>Shimon, <span class="gemarra-regular">has witnesse</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> attesting to his ownership, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Master, </span>Yehuda, also <span class="gemarra-regular">has witnesses </span>attesting to his ownership, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the Sages said </span>that under such circumstances <span class="gemarra-regular">the land should remain where it is. </span>That is to say, it should remain with the one currently in possession. If Yehuda were to be awarded the land, Shimon would not be able to remove the land from his possession despite having witnesses to support his claim, as Yehuda also has witnesses supporting his claim and would be in possession of the land. As a result of Shimon’s testimony, the land will be awarded to Levi, who has possession as a result of his purchase from Reuven. Then Shimon will be able to remove the land from Levi’s possession by proving that Reuven stole it from him. Therefore, Shimon’s testimony is biased. 

Daf 44a

The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>according to the understanding of Rav Sheshet, that the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is disqualifying one whose field was stolen from testifying on behalf of one who purchased the field from the robber, why is it necessary to discuss a case involving a buyer, when it would be simpler to <span class="gemarra-regular">establish it with regard to </span>testifying for the <span class="gemarra-regular">robbe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> himself?
The Gemara answers: The <span class="it-text">tanna</span> of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> discusses a case involving a buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">wants to teach the latter clause: </span>If he <span class="gemarra-regular">sold </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a cow to him, </span>or if he <span class="gemarra-regular">sold a cloak to him, </span>he can testify about it for the buyer. <span class="gemarra-regular">As </span>in this clause, the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">specifically </span>needs to discuss a case where the robber <span class="gemarra-regular">sold </span>it, <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">it is </span>a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">despair </span>by the owners due to the robbery, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>there is also <span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> change in possessio</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> due to the sale, and the one who was robbed can no longer reclaim the stolen item. He is therefore no longer biased in his testimony and can testify for the one who purchased the item. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>in the latter clause, if the robber did <span class="gemarra-regular">not sell</span> it, in which case the stolen item <span class="gemarra-regular">is returned to </span>the robbery victim, he <span class="gemarra-regular">cannot </span>testify, as he prefers that the item be in the possession of the robber, so that he can recover it from him. Therefore, the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">taught </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">the first clause as well</span> about a case where he <span class="gemarra-regular">sold </span>it.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">the latter clause as well, </span>where there is despair and change in possession, <span class="gemarra-regular">granted that </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">despairs of </span>recovering the item <span class="gemarra-regular">itself, </span>but <span class="gemarra-regular">did </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">despair of </span>being reimbursed for <span class="gemarra-regular">its value</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> While it is true that he lost his ownership of the item, he is still entitled to payment. Therefore, he is still biased in his testimony. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where the robber died</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> in which case the robbery victim cannot collect even the value of the stolen item, and is no longer biased in his testimony. <span class="gemarra-regular">As </span><span class="gemarra-regular">we learned </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Bava</span> <span class="it-text">Kamma</span> 111b): In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who robs </span>another of food <span class="gemarra-regular">and feed</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> it to <span class="gemarra-regular">his </span>own <span class="gemarra-regular">children, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">or </span>who <span class="gemarra-regular">left </span>a stolen item <span class="gemarra-regular">to them </span>as an inheritance, the children <span class="gemarra-regular">are exempt from paying </span>the victim of the robbery after their father’s death. Since he is no longer able to collect the value of the stolen item, he is not biased in his testimony and can testify on behalf of the buyer.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>why not <span class="gemarra-regular">establish </span>the entire <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>testifying for the robber’s <span class="gemarra-regular">heir? </span>This would demonstrate the contrast that the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> wanted to teach. In the case of a stolen field, which always must be returned to its owner, the robbery victim is biased in his testimony because the field can be recovered. Therefore, it is in his interest to establish that it is in the possession of the robber’s heirs. In the case of movable property, which cannot be recovered after the death of the robber, he is not biased in his testimony.
The Gemara notes: <span class="gemarra-regular">This works out well according to the one</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> who says </span>that the transfer of an item to the <span class="gemarra-regular">possession </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">an hei</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">not like </span>the transfer of an item to the <span class="gemarra-regular">possession </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">a buyer, </span>but is viewed as an extension of the possession of the legator. According to this opinion, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">well </span>that the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> did not establish its case with regard to the robber’s heir, as the robbery victim would be able to recover the item, and would be considered biased in his testimony. <span class="gemarra-regular">But according</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to the one who says </span>that the transfer of an item to the <span class="gemarra-regular">possession </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">an heir </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">like </span>the transfer of an item to the <span class="gemarra-regular">possession </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">a buyer, </span>and the item is not recoverable in either case, <span class="gemarra-regular">what</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> can be said </span>to explain why the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> does not state its case with regard to an heir?
<span class="gemarra-regular">And furthermore, </span>this explanation was <span class="gemarra-regular">difficult for Abaye </span>to understand, as according to Rav Sheshet’s explanation, is it accurate to state, as the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> does, that the distinction exists between the cases of land and movable property <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>in the first clause the financial <span class="gemarra-regular">responsibility </span>to compensate the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>the land is <span class="gemarra-regular">upon him, and </span>in the latter clause the financial <span class="gemarra-regular">responsibility </span>to compensate the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>the movable property is <span class="gemarra-regular">not upon him? </span>That is not the crucial distinction. The <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">should have </span>taught instead that the difference is: Here he cannot testify <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>the stolen field <span class="gemarra-regular">returns to him, and </span>here he can testify because the stolen item <span class="gemarra-regular">does not return to him.</span>
The Gemara offers a new explanation of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>explain instead <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Ravin bar Shmuel, as Ravin bar Shmuel says in the name of Shmuel: One who sells a field to another </span>even <span class="gemarra-regular">without a guarantee </span>that if the field will be repossessed the seller will compensate the buyer for his loss <span class="gemarra-regular">cannot testify with regard to </span>ownership of that field <span class="gemarra-regular">on behalf of </span>the buyer, <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">establishing </span>the field <span class="gemarra-regular">before his creditor</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
The Gemara clarifies this by noting: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>this is the case <span class="gemarra-regular">specifically </span>in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a house or a field. But </span>in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a cow or a cloak, </span>he is not biased in his testimony, and can testify on behalf of the buyer. The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">It is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not necessary </span>to say that this is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>

Daf 44b

<span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>a case where he sold a cow or cloak <span class="gemarra-regular">without specification, where it is not liened to </span>the creditor. <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason</span> for this? It is because these items <span class="gemarra-regular">are movable </span><span class="gemarra-regular">property, and movable property is not liened to a creditor</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> And even though </span>it is so <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the debtor <span class="gemarra-regular">wrote to </span>the creditor that he can collect the debt even <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">cloak that is on his shoulders,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that matter </span>applies only <span class="gemarra-regular">when it is as is </span>and in the possession of the debtor, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">it is not as is, </span>since it is in the possession of the buyer, then <span class="gemarra-regular">no, </span>the creditor cannot collect from movable property. Therefore, the debtor can testify on behalf of the buyer.
The Gemara continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">But even </span>in a case where he <span class="gemarra-regular">set </span>the cow or cloak <span class="gemarra-regular">aside </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">designated repayment [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">apoteiki</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the creditor <span class="gemarra-regular">cannot </span>collect from it. <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reasoning? </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rava, as Rava says:</span> If a master <span class="gemarra-regular">set aside his slave </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">designated repaymen</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> of a debt <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">sold him, </span>the master’s <span class="gemarra-regular">creditor collects </span>the debt <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the proceeds from the sale of the slave. But if one set aside <span class="gemarra-regular">his ox or his donkey </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">designated repaymen</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">sold it, </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">creditor does not collect </span>the debt <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the proceeds of the sale of the ox or the donkey.
<span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>for this distinction? <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>setting aside of the slave as designated repayment generates <span class="gemarra-regular">publicity, and that </span>setting aside of the ox or donkey as designated repayment does <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>generate <span class="gemarra-regular">publicity. </span>Therefore, when the slave had been set aside as designated repayment, the buyer would have been aware of this. Since he bought the slave while having this knowledge, the slave can be seized from him by the seller’s creditor. By contrast, the buyer of the cow or cloak would not have been aware that it had been set aside as designated repayment, so the seller’s creditor cannot seize it from him.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But let </span>there be <span class="gemarra-regular">a concern </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">perhaps </span>the debtor <span class="gemarra-regular">transferred </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">movable property</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to </span>the creditor, not for him to own, but for him to have a lien on the movable property, <span class="gemarra-regular">by </span><span class="gemarra-regular">means of, </span>i.e., together with, an acquisition of <span class="gemarra-regular">land</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as Rabba said: If </span>the debtor <span class="gemarra-regular">transferred movable property to </span>the creditor as liened property <span class="gemarra-regular">by means of </span>an acquisition of <span class="gemarra-regular">land</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the creditor <span class="gemarra-regular">acquires the land </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">acquires </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">movable property, </span>i.e., a lien is created with regard to both. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav Ḥisda said: And that is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> only <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the debtor <span class="gemarra-regular">wrote to </span>the creditor: This lien is <span class="gemarra-regular">not like a transaction with inconclusive consent [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ke’asmakhta</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> which does not effect acquisition, <span class="gemarra-regular">and not like the template [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ketofesa</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for documents</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> which are not actually used to collect debts. Rather, it is a legally binding document.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">With </span><span class="gemarra-regular">what are we dealing here? </span>We are dealing with a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the debtor had <span class="gemarra-regular">purchased </span>the movable property <span class="gemarra-regular">and immediately sol</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> it, and there was no opportunity for him to have it become liened to a creditor. Therefore, there is no possibility of his being biased in his testimony due to a desire to repay his debt.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> let </span>there be <span class="gemarra-regular">a concern </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">perhaps it is </span>a case in which the debtor wrote to the creditor: I will repay you even from <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>which <span class="gemarra-regular">I will acquir</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> in the future, which would presumably mean that the creditor can collect from the buyer even though the debtor purchased the item after taking the loan. From the fact that this is not a concern, do <span class="gemarra-regular">you learn from it </span>that even if the debtor wrote: I will repay you even from that which <span class="gemarra-regular">I will acquir</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> in the future, and he then <span class="gemarra-regular">purchased and sold </span>property or <span class="gemarra-regular">purchased and bequeathed </span>it, that which he purchases is <span class="gemarra-regular">not liened </span>to his creditor? This would seem to settle what is otherwise assumed to be an unresolved question.
The Gemara rejects this proof: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>one need not reach that conclusion, as it is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>to teach the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> witnesses say: We know about this </span>one who sold these items <span class="gemarra-regular">that he never had </span>any <span class="gemarra-regular">land</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Therefore, it cannot be that the creditor acquired a lien on the movable property by means of an acquisition of land.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But doesn’t Rav Pappa say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">even though the Sages said: </span>In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who sells a field to another without a guarantee, and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a creditor came and repossessed it, </span>the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">cannot return to </span>the seller, i.e. the debtor, who sold him the field, to claim reimbursement; but if it is <span class="gemarra-regular">found that </span>the field <span class="gemarra-regular">was </span><span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>the seller’s in the first place, the buyer can <span class="gemarra-regular">return to </span>the seller to claim reimbursement. In this case, if the claimant establishes that the cow or cloak is his and was not the seller’s, the buyer will be able to claim reimbursement. The seller is therefore biased in his testimony, and should not be able to testify on behalf of the buyer.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">With what are we dealing here? </span>We are dealing <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>a case where the buyer admits that he <span class="gemarra-regular">recognizes that this</span> is the <span class="gemarra-regular">offspring of </span>the seller’s <span class="gemarra-regular">donkey, </span>and will not claim in court that the seller had no right to sell it.
The Gemara returns to the statement of Rav Pappa and comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>in contrast to the opinion of Rav Pappa, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Zevid says: Even </span>if it is <span class="gemarra-regular">found that </span>the field <span class="gemarra-regular">was not </span>the seller’s, the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">cannot return to </span>the seller to claim reimbursement, <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>the seller can <span class="gemarra-regular">say to </span>the buyer: It is <span class="gemarra-regular">for this </span>reason that <span class="gemarra-regular">I sold it to you without a guarantee, </span>i.e., so that if it is taken from you, I will not bear liability.
§ The Gemara returns to Shmuel’s statement, in order to examine <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>matter <span class="gemarra-regular">itself. Ravin bar Shmuel says in the name of Shmuel: One who sells a fiel</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to another </span>even <span class="gemarra-regular">without a guarantee </span>that if the field will be repossessed the seller will compensate the buyer for his loss <span class="gemarra-regular">cannot testify with regard to </span>ownership of that field <span class="gemarra-regular">on behalf of </span>the buyer, <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">establishing </span>the field <span class="gemarra-regular">before his creditor. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What are the circumstances </span>of this <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? 

Daf 45a

<span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>this is a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">has other land</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> that he did not sell, in addition to the field that he sold with regard to which he currently wishes to testify, his creditor will <span class="gemarra-regular">go after it, </span>and collect from that land. In that case, he is not biased in his testimony concerning the field that he sold. <span class="gemarra-regular">If</span> this is a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">does not have other land, what difference does</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it make to him </span>if the buyer is unable to keep the land? In any event the creditor cannot collect directly from the seller.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Actually, </span>Shmuel is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">does not have other land, </span>and the reason that he is nevertheless biased in his testimony is that he wants his creditors to be able to collect the debt <span class="gemarra-regular">because he says </span>to himself that it is <span class="gemarra-regular">uncomfortable for him to b</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> in the category of: <span class="gemarra-regular">“The wicked borrows, and pays not” </span>(Psalms 37:21).
The Gemara asks: But <span class="gemarra-regular">ultimately, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">he is also </span>in the category of: <span class="gemarra-regular">“The wicked borrows, and pays not” </span>(Psalms 37:21) <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to the other </span>one, to whom he sold the land. He took money from the buyer, who did not receive anything in exchange, as the land was seized from him. The Gemara answers: He is not concerned about his behavior toward the buyer, <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>he can <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>to him: <span class="gemarra-regular">For this </span>very reason <span class="gemarra-regular">I sold it to you without a guarantee, </span>so that if it would be seized from you I would not be liable.
§ The Gemara relates: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava announced, and some say </span>it was <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa </span>who announced: All <span class="gemarra-regular">those who ascend </span>from Babylonia to Eretz Yisrael <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>all <span class="gemarra-regular">those who descend </span>from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia should be aware of the following: In a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">this Jew who sold</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a donkey to another Jew, and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">a gentile came and seized it from him, </span>claiming that it was really his, <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the seller should <span class="gemarra-regular">rescue [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">dimfatzei</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it from </span>the gentile or reimburse the buyer.
The Gemara points out: <span class="gemarra-regular">And we said </span>this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>in a case where the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">does not recognize that this is </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">offspring of </span>the seller’s <span class="gemarra-regular">donkey, </span>and it is possible that the gentile’s claim is true. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">recognizes that this is</span> the <span class="gemarra-regular">offspring of </span>the seller’s <span class="gemarra-regular">donkey, </span>then the seller is <span class="gemarra-regular">not</span> liable to reimburse him.
