It is clear that the gentile’s claim is false, so the seller bears no responsibility for the buyer’s loss. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>furthermore, <span class="gemarra-regular">we said </span>this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>in a case where the gentile did <span class="gemarra-regular">not seize it and the saddl</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> with it. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if he <span class="gemarra-regular">seized it and the saddle </span>with it, it is clear that the gentile is a robber, and it is assumed that there is no validity to his claim with regard to the donkey. Therefore, the seller is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>liable to reimburse him.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Ameimar said: Even if there are not any of thes</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> factors, the seller is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>liable to reimburse him. <span class="gemarra-regular">What</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is the reasoning </span>for this? It is that <span class="gemarra-regular">it is known </span><span class="gemarra-regular">that an ordinary gentile is an extortionist</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> so it is assumed that the donkey did indeed belong to the seller, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is stated: “Whose mouth speaks falsehood, and their right hand is a right hand of lying”</span> (Psalms 144:8).
§ The Gemara returns to discuss the statement of Shmuel (42b): <span class="gemarra-regular">A craftsman does not have </span>the ability to establish the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership of the property in his possession, but a partner has the ability to establish the presumption of ownership. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba says: They taught </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">transferred </span>the item <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the craftsman <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the presence of <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses. But </span>if the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">transferred </span>the item <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the craftsman <span class="gemarra-regular">not in </span>the presence of <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses, </span>then, <span class="gemarra-regular">since </span>the craftsman <span class="gemarra-regular">is able to say to </span>the one who claims to be the owner: <span class="gemarra-regular">These matters never occurred, </span>i.e., you did not give me this item but it was mine to begin with, and he would keep possession of the item with that claim, then <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span><span class="gemarra-regular">when </span>the craftsman <span class="gemarra-regular">says to him: It is purchased </span>by me from you, and that is why it is <span class="gemarra-regular">in my possession, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">deemed credible.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said to </span>Rabba: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>if the owner transferred the item to the craftsman <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the presence of <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses as well, </span>he should be deemed credible. <span class="gemarra-regular">Since </span>the craftsman <span class="gemarra-regular">is able to say to </span>the owner: <span class="gemarra-regular">I returned </span>the item <span class="gemarra-regular">to you, </span>and he would be exempt from payment, <span class="gemarra-regular">when</span> the craftsman <span class="gemarra-regular">says to him: It is purchased </span>by me from you, and that is why it is <span class="gemarra-regular">in my possession, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">deemed credible.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba said to </span>Abaye: <span class="gemarra-regular">Do you maintain </span>that

Daf 45b

in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who deposits </span>an item <span class="gemarra-regular">with another in </span>the presence of <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses </span>the recipient <span class="gemarra-regular">need not return </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">to him in </span>the presence of <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses? </span>If that were to be so, the craftsman could claim that he had returned it to the owner, even though there are no witnesses. That possibility should <span class="gemarra-regular">not enter your mind. Rather, </span>in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who deposits </span>an item <span class="gemarra-regular">with another in </span>the presence of <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses,</span> the recipient <span class="gemarra-regular">must return </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">to him in </span>the presence of <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses. </span>Therefore, the craftsman could not have claimed that he returned it to the owner.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye raises an objection </span>to Rabba’s ruling from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> (<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span> 2:6): There is a case where one <span class="gemarra-regular">sa</span><span class="gemarra-regular">w</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> his slav</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">possession of a craftsman, or his cloak in </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">possession of a launderer, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">says to him: What </span>is the <span class="gemarra-regular">nature of its </span>presence <span class="gemarra-regular">in your </span>possession? If the craftsman or launderer replied: <span class="gemarra-regular">You sold me </span>the slave or cloak, or: <span class="gemarra-regular">You gave </span>the slave or cloak <span class="gemarra-regular">to me as a gift, </span>he has <span class="gemarra-regular">not said anything, </span>and must return it, since a craftsman does not establish the presumption of ownership. But if the craftsman or launderer replied: <span class="gemarra-regular">You said in my presence to </span>someone else <span class="gemarra-regular">to sell </span>the slave or cloak to him <span class="gemarra-regular">or to give </span>the slave or cloak <span class="gemarra-regular">to him, </span>i.e., to sell or give the slave or cloak to the craftsman or launderer himself, <span class="gemarra-regular">as a gift, </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">his statement is valid.</span>
Before Abaya raises his objection, he first clarifies the ruling of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">What is different </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">the first clause </span>that the craftsman is not deemed credible <span class="gemarra-regular">and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> what is different </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">the latter clause </span>that he is?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba said: The latter </span><span class="gemarra-regular">clause </span>is stated <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>a case where the slave or cloak <span class="gemarra-regular">emerges from the possession of another</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and not from the possession of the craftsman, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">other </span>person <span class="gemarra-regular">is saying to </span>the owner: <span class="gemarra-regular">You said in my presence to </span>the craftsman <span class="gemarra-regular">to sell </span>the slave or cloak <span class="gemarra-regular">or to give </span>the slave or cloak to me <span class="gemarra-regular">as gift. </span>This person is deemed credible despite acknowledging that he received it from the craftsman, <span class="gemarra-regular">since if he had wanted </span>to, he could have <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>the owner of the item: <span class="gemarra-regular">I purchased </span>the slave or cloak <span class="gemarra-regular">from you. </span>As this third party is not a craftsman, he is able to establish the presumption of ownership through possession and would be deemed credible. Therefore, <span class="gemarra-regular">when </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">says to him as well: You said to him in my presence to sell </span>the slave or cloak, <span class="gemarra-regular">his statement is valid, and he is </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">deemed credible.</span>
After having clarified the ruling of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, Abaye presents his objection: <span class="gemarra-regular">In any event, the first clause </span>of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>that the case where a craftsman is not deemed credible is where the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">saw </span>the slave or cloak in the possession of the craftsman. <span class="gemarra-regular">What are the circumstances? If </span>it is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">where there are witnesses </span>to the fact that the owner gave the slave or cloak to the craftsman for training or cleaning, respectively, <span class="gemarra-regular">why do I </span>need for the owner to have <span class="gemarra-regular">seen </span>them in the craftsman’s possession? Let the owner simply <span class="gemarra-regular">bring witnesses and take </span>back his slave or cloak. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is it not </span>referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where there are no witnesses, and </span>nevertheless, <span class="gemarra-regular">when </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">saw </span>the slave or cloak in the craftsman’s possession, he <span class="gemarra-regular">may seize </span>the slave or cloak <span class="gemarra-regular">in any case? </span>This contradicts Rabba’s statement that the decisive factor is whether the transfer took place in the presence of witnesses.
Rabba answers this objection: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>that is not the case of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">Actually, </span>it is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where there are witnesses, and </span>nevertheless, <span class="gemarra-regular">that is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>, that he may seize the slave or cloak only <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">sa</span><span class="gemarra-regular">w</span> it currently in the possession of the craftsman. But if there are no witnesses that it is currently in his possession, he would be deemed credible if he were to claim that he purchased the slave or cloak from the owner, as he could have claimed that he returned the slave or cloak.
Abaye asked him: <span class="gemarra-regular">But you are </span>the one <span class="gemarra-regular">who said: </span>In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who deposits </span>an item <span class="gemarra-regular">with another in </span>the presence of <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the recipient <span class="gemarra-regular">must return </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">to him in </span>the presence of <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses.</span> Therefore, if it was given to the craftsman in the presence of witnesses, he would not have the ability to make a more advantageous claim [<span class="it-text">miggo</span>] that he returned it. Rabba <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Abaye: <span class="gemarra-regular">I retracted </span>that opinion and hold that he may return it even when not in the presence of witnesses.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava raises an objection </span>from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">to support </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who gives his cloak to a craftsman, </span>and then the <span class="gemarra-regular">craftsman says: You fixed tw</span><span class="gemarra-regular">o</span> dinars as <span class="gemarra-regular">my </span>payment, <span class="gemarra-regular">and that one, </span>the owner, <span class="gemarra-regular">says: I fixed </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>dinar as <span class="gemarra-regular">your </span>payment, then, <span class="gemarra-regular">so long as </span>it is so <span class="gemarra-regular">that the cloak is in </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">possession of </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">craftsman, </span>it is incumbent <span class="gemarra-regular">upon </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">owner to bring proof </span>that the fee was one dinar. If the craftsman <span class="gemarra-regular">gave </span>the cloak back <span class="gemarra-regular">to him, </span>then there are two scenarios: If the claim is lodged <span class="gemarra-regular">in</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> its </span>proper <span class="gemarra-regular">time</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., on the day of the cloak’s return, then the craftsman <span class="gemarra-regular">takes an oath and receives </span>the two dinars. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">its </span>proper <span class="gemarra-regular">time passed, </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">the burden of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> proof rests upon the claimant, </span>and the craftsman would need to bring proof that the fee was two dinars.
Rava continues with an analysis of this <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">What are the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> circumstances </span>of the case discussed in this <span class="it-text">baraita</span>? <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>it is a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where there are witnesses </span>who saw the transfer of the item, <span class="gemarra-regular">let us see what the witnesses say </span>about the fee, as they presumably heard the details of the arrangement. 

Daf 46a

<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, is it not </span>referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where there are no witnesses </span>to the transfer, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>that the <span class="gemarra-regular">craftsman</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">deemed credible? Since if he had wanted </span>to he could have <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: It is purchased </span>and that is why it is <span class="gemarra-regular">in my possession, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">deemed credible with regard to </span>his claim <span class="gemarra-regular">about his fee as well. </span>This supports the ruling of Rabba that if there are no witnesses, the craftsman is deemed credible if he says that the item belongs to him.
The Gemara rejects this proof: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, actually, </span>perhaps the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where there are no witnesses </span>to the transfer, <span class="gemarra-regular">but</span> it is specifically referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">did not see </span>the cloak in the possession of the craftsman, who could consequently deny ever having received it from the owner. Therefore, it is not a proof in support of the ruling of Rabba that the craftsman would be deemed credible even if there are witnesses that it is currently in his possession.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak raises </span><span class="gemarra-regular">an objection </span>to Rabba’s ruling from Shmuel’s paraphrase of the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">A craftsman does not have </span>the ability to establish the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership of property in his possession. This indicates that <span class="gemarra-regular">it is </span>specifically <span class="gemarra-regular">a craftsman who does not have </span>the ability to establish the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership,<span class="gemarra-regular"> but another </span>person in similar circumstances <span class="gemarra-regular">has </span>the ability to establish the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership.
<span class="gemarra-regular">What are the circumstances </span>in which this would apply? <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>it is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where there are witnesses </span>that the person in question received the item from another, <span class="gemarra-regular">why </span>is it that <span class="gemarra-regular">another </span>person <span class="gemarra-regular">has </span>the ability to establish the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership, when there are witnesses that he received this item as a deposit? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, is it not </span>referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where there are no witnesses, and </span>yet, the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches: A craftsman does not have </span>the ability to establish the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership. This indicates that a craftsman does not establish the presumption of ownership under any circumstances, contrary to the ruling of Rabba. The Gemara concludes: <span class="gemarra-regular">The refutation of </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba </span>is indeed <span class="gemarra-regular">a conclusive refutation</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and his ruling is rejected.
§ The Gemara discusses another <span class="it-text">halakha</span> pertaining to the giving of an item to a craftsman. <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught: </span>If one’s <span class="gemarra-regular">utensils were </span>mistakenly <span class="gemarra-regular">switched with </span>another’s <span class="gemarra-regular">utensils in the house of a craftsman</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> this </span>one who received the wrong utensils <span class="gemarra-regular">may </span><span class="gemarra-regular">use them until </span>the time <span class="gemarra-regular">when that </span>one, whose utensils he received, <span class="gemarra-regular">comes and takes his. </span>But if his utensils and another’s utensils were mistakenly switched <span class="gemarra-regular">in a house of mournin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> or in a house of </span>a wedding <span class="gemarra-regular">feast, this </span>one who took the wrong utensils <span class="gemarra-regular">may not use them </span>in the interim, i.e., <span class="gemarra-regular">until </span>the time <span class="gemarra-regular">when that </span>one, whose utensils he took, <span class="gemarra-regular">comes and takes his. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is different </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">the first clause </span>where he may use the utensils, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">what is different </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">the latter clause </span>where he may not?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav said: I was sitting before my uncle, </span>Rav Ḥiyya, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he said </span>the explanation <span class="gemarra-regular">to me: And is a person not likely to say to the craftsman: Sell my cloak for me </span>after you finish repairing it? It is possible that the craftsman mistakenly sold the utensils of another client instead, and gave to that other client the utensils that should have been sold. Since the owner of these utensils received the money from the sale of the other client’s utensils, the craftsman has a right to give the remaining utensils to the other client in the interim. This reasoning does not apply in the case of the house of mourning or a wedding feast, where one simply took utensils belonging to another.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥiyya, son of Rav Naḥman, said: They taught </span>that it is permitted to use the utensils <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>if the craftsman <span class="gemarra-regular">himself </span>gave them to his customer, as in that case, the above reasoning applies. <span class="gemarra-regular">But if </span>the craftsman’s <span class="gemarra-regular">wife or children </span>gave them to him, the customer may <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>use the utensils, as it is likely that they were given to him in error. <span class="gemarra-regular">And even </span>if the craftsman himself gave the utensils to his customer, <span class="gemarra-regular">we said </span>that it is permitted for him to use them <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the craftsman <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>to him, for example: I am returning <span class="gemarra-regular">a cloak, without specification. But </span>if the craftsman said to him: I am returning <span class="gemarra-regular">your cloak, </span>then he may <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>use it, as <span class="gemarra-regular">this is not his cloak, </span>and clearly it was given to him in error.
§ The Gemara presents another statement with regard to craftsmen. <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said to Rava: Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">I will show you what the swindlers of Pumbedit</span><span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> do. </span>There was a case where the owner of an item <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>a craftsman: <span class="gemarra-regular">Give me </span>back <span class="gemarra-regular">my cloak [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">sarbelai</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> that I gave you to repair, and the craftsman replied: <span class="gemarra-regular">These matters never occurred. </span>The owner responded: <span class="gemarra-regular">But I have witnesses who saw it in your </span>possession. The craftsman <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>the owner: <span class="gemarra-regular">That was a different </span>cloak that they saw. The witnesses are uncertain as to whether it was really his cloak. The owner then said: <span class="gemarra-regular">Bring it out and we will see it, </span>so as to determine whose it is. The craftsman <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>the owner: <span class="gemarra-regular">In truth, I will not bring it out</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as you have no valid claim to the cloak and I am not willing to show you another’s property. This is the trickery to which Abaye referred, as it is not a sincere response, and the craftsman merely wishes to keep the cloak.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said</span> to Abaye: The craftsman <span class="gemarra-regular">is saying well to </span>the owner, and his claim will be accepted, 

Daf 46b

as it <span class="gemarra-regular">is taught </span>in the earlier <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that the owner has a valid claim only when he, and witnesses, <span class="gemarra-regular">saw </span>his cloak in the possession of the launderer and can definitively identify it. He cannot state a claim based on the mere possibility that it is his. This validates the claim of the craftsmen of Pumbedita.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi said: And if </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">is clever, he will render </span>the situation into one of his having <span class="gemarra-regular">seen</span> his cloak, <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>the owner can <span class="gemarra-regular">say to </span>the craftsman: <span class="gemarra-regular">Why </span>are you <span class="gemarra-regular">holding it? Is it not due to </span>the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that there is </span>money of <span class="gemarra-regular">yours with me,</span> and you are using the cloak as a means of collecting the debt that I owe you? <span class="gemarra-regular">Now bring out </span>my cloak before the appraisers <span class="gemarra-regular">and they will appraise its </span>value, and then <span class="gemarra-regular">you take </span>what is rightfully <span class="gemarra-regular">yours, and I will take </span>what is rightfully <span class="gemarra-regular">mine.</span> When the craftsman presents the cloak, the ruling will change, as the owner will have seen the cloak. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Aḥa, son of Rav Avya, said to Rav Ashi: </span>If the craftsman is clever, he <span class="gemarra-regular">can say to </span>the owner: <span class="gemarra-regular">I do not need your appraisal, </span>as the <span class="gemarra-regular">earlier ones who preceded you already appraised it </span>and determined that its value does not exceed that of your debt to me.
§ The Gemara discusses a ruling that it paraphrases from the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">A sharecropper does not have </span>the ability to establish the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership of property in his possession. <span class="gemarra-regular">Why </span>not? Isn’t it so that <span class="gemarra-regular">until that time, </span>while he was definitely working as a sharecropper, he consumed only <span class="gemarra-regular">half </span>of the produce of the land, <span class="gemarra-regular">and now, </span>for the past three years, he consumed <span class="gemarra-regular">all of </span>its produce? He should be able to establish the presumption of ownership by consuming more produce than a sharecropper does. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: </span>The ruling of the mishna is stated <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to family sharecroppers</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> This type of sharecropper, who works for a family for many years, gathers all of the produce into his property, and then returns the landowner’s share. Therefore, his collecting all of the produce into his property does not establish the presumption of ownership.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman says: A sharecropper who installed </span>other <span class="gemarra-regular">sharecropper</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in his place has </span>the ability to establish the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership.<span class="gemarra-regular"> What is the reason? </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">not common </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">a person </span>to see <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>unknown <span class="gemarra-regular">sharecroppers </span>have been <span class="gemarra-regular">installed in his land and </span>remain <span class="gemarra-regular">silent. </span>If the prior owner did not lodge a protest, it indicates that the sharecropper is the owner of the land.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: A sharecropper who divided among </span>different <span class="gemarra-regular">sharecropper</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> does not have </span>the ability to establish the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership by that act. <span class="gemarra-regular">What is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the reason? </span>It is that one can <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that the landowner <span class="gemarra-regular">merely appointed him </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">an administrator [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">harmanya</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and there is no indication that he is acting as an owner.
The Gemara relates: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman bar Rav Ḥisda sent</span> this message <span class="gemarra-regular">to Rav Naḥman bar Yaakov: Our teacher, instruct us. Can a sharecropper testify </span>with regard to the ownership of a field of which he is a sharecropper, <span class="gemarra-regular">or can he not testify, </span>as he is biased in his testimony? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yose</span><span class="gemarra-regular">f </span><span class="gemarra-regular"> was sitting before </span>Rav Naḥman bar Yaakov and <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: This is what Shmuel said: A sharecropper can testify</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Rav Naḥman bar Yaakov said to him: <span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t it taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that a sharecropper <span class="gemarra-regular">cannot testify?</span>
Rav Yosef answered: It is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">difficult. This </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span>, which states that he cannot testify, is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where there is produc</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> on the land. </span>Therefore, he is biased in his testimony, as, if the current owner will lose possession of the land, the sharecropper will lose his right to consume the produce. <span class="gemarra-regular">And that </span>statement of Shmuel that he can testify is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where there is no produc</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> on the land, </span>and he is not biased in his testimony.
§ The Gemara presents the word <span class="it-text">Amalek</span> as <span class="gemarra-regular">a mnemonic </span>for the cases discussed in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>. It stands for: <span class="gemarra-italic">Ayin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>guarantor [<span class="it-text">arev</span>]; <span class="gemarra-italic">mem</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>creditor [<span class="it-text">malve</span>]; <span class="gemarra-italic">lamed</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>buyer [<span class="it-text">loke’aḥ</span>]; <span class="gemarra-italic">kuf</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>unconditional guarantor [<span class="it-text">kablan</span>].
<span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> A guarantor can testify for </span>the benefit of <span class="gemarra-regular">the debto</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> that the latter owns a particular parcel of land, <span class="gemarra-regular">but that is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> only <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>the debtor <span class="gemarra-regular">has other lan</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> from which the creditor can collect the debt. Otherwise, he is biased in his testimony, as the creditor could collect from him if the debtor were to lose ownership of this land. <span class="gemarra-regular">A creditor can testify for </span>the benefit of <span class="gemarra-regular">the debtor </span>that the latter owns a particular parcel of land, <span class="gemarra-regular">but that is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> only <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>the debtor <span class="gemarra-regular">has other land </span>from which the creditor can collect. Otherwise, he is biased in his testimony, as this land is the only land available for collection.
Similarly, if two people purchase land from one seller, the <span class="gemarra-regular">first buye</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> can testif</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for </span>the benefit of the <span class="gemarra-regular">second buyer </span>if someone else were to claim that the land was his, <span class="gemarra-regular">but that is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> only <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>the second buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">has other land </span>that he purchased from the same seller either concurrent with or subsequent to the first buyer’s purchase of the land in question. A creditor of the seller can collect a debt from the land that the seller sold most recently. Therefore, if the second buyer purchased only the land in question from the seller, the first buyer is biased in his testimony, as the second buyer’s ownership of the land prevents the creditor from collecting a debt from the land from the first buyer. 

Daf 47a

With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">an unconditional guarantor [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">kablan</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> from whom the creditor can collect even if the debtor is able to repay the loan, <span class="gemarra-regular">some say </span>that he <span class="gemarra-regular">can testify </span>on behalf of the debtor if the latter owns other land, <span class="gemarra-regular">and some say </span>that he <span class="gemarra-regular">cannot testify </span>even if the debtor owns other land. The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">Some say </span>that he <span class="gemarra-regular">can testify </span>because he is <span class="gemarra-regular">like a guarantor, and some say </span>that he <span class="gemarra-regular">cannot testify, </span>as it is <span class="gemarra-regular">preferable for him that both </span>fields <span class="gemarra-regular">be </span><span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the debtor’s <span class="gemarra-regular">possession, </span>so <span class="gemarra-regular">that when a creditor comes </span>to collect the debt, he will <span class="gemarra-regular">take what he wants, </span>and not collect from the unconditional guarantor.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan said: A craftsman does not have </span>the ability to establish the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership, but the <span class="gemarra-regular">so</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of a craftsman has </span>the ability to establish the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership. <span class="gemarra-regular">A sharecropper does not have </span>the ability to establish the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership, but the <span class="gemarra-regular">son of a sharecropper has </span>the ability to establish the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership. Both <span class="gemarra-regular">a robber and </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">son of a robber do not have </span>the ability to establish the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership, but the <span class="gemarra-regular">son of </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">son of a robber has </span>the ability to establish the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What are the circumstances </span>under which there is a distinction between the sons of the craftsman and the sharecropper and the son of the robber? <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>they <span class="gemarra-regular">come</span> to court <span class="gemarra-regular">with the claim </span>that the item in question <span class="gemarra-regular">belonged to their fathers, </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">even these </span>sons of the craftsman and the sharecropper should <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>be able to establish the presumption of ownership, since their claims are based on ownership by those who cannot establish the presumption of ownership. <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>the case is <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>they <span class="gemarra-regular">do not come </span>to court <span class="gemarra-regular">with the claim </span>that the item in question <span class="gemarra-regular">belonged to their fathers,</span> but that they own the item in their own right, then <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">son of a robber </span>should be able to establish the presumption of ownership.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>to state this distinction in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses say: </span>The prior owner <span class="gemarra-regular">admitted to </span>their father <span class="gemarra-regular">in our presenc</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> that the property was the father’s and not stolen. The Gemara explains: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">these, </span>the sons of the craftsman and sharecropper, it <span class="gemarra-regular">can be said </span>that the sons <span class="gemarra-regular">are saying the truth, </span>as their claim is substantiated by the testimony of the admission. But with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>one, the son of the robber, <span class="gemarra-regular">even though </span>the prior owner <span class="gemarra-regular">admitted </span>this, the son is <span class="gemarra-regular">still not deemed credible, in accordance with </span>the statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav Kahana, as Rav Kahana said: If </span>the prior owner would <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>have <span class="gemarra-regular">admitted </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the robber, the robber <span class="gemarra-regular">would have brought him and his donkey to </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">taskmaster [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">leshaḥvar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> meaning he would have caused him great difficulties. As a robber is assumed to be a ruffian, it is likely that the prior owner admitted this because he was intimidated, and not because the statement was true, so there is no evidence to support the claim of the robber’s son.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava says: </span>There are <span class="gemarra-regular">times when even </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">son of </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">son of </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">robbe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> does not have </span>the ability to establish the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership.<span class="gemarra-regular"> What are the circumstances </span>under which this is so? This is so, for example, <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">comes</span> to court <span class="gemarra-regular">with the claim </span>that the item in question <span class="gemarra-regular">belonged to his father’s father. </span>Since his claim is based on its having belonged to one who did not have the ability to establish the presumption of ownership, he too is unable to establish the presumption of ownership.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What are the circumstances </span>under which one is considered <span class="gemarra-regular">a robber</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> who does not have the ability to establish the presumption of ownership? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: </span>In a case <span class="gemarra-regular">such as where it is established </span>that he is in possession <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">this fiel</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> through robbery. And Rav Ḥisda says: </span>Not only in a case where there is knowledge about this specific field, but even in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">such as </span>one where he is a member <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">household of so-and-so, </span>a certain known criminal family at the time <span class="gemarra-regular">who kill people over monetary matters. </span>Since people would be afraid to lodge a protest against them, members of this family cannot establish the presumption of ownership with regard to any land.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught: A craftsman does not have </span>the ability to establish the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership. If he <span class="gemarra-regular">descended from his </span>position of <span class="gemarra-regular">craftsmanshi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">p</span> and no longer works at that craft, then he <span class="gemarra-regular">has </span>the ability to establish the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership with regard to items related to his former craft. <span class="gemarra-regular">A sharecropper does not have </span>the ability to establish the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership. If he <span class="gemarra-regular">descended from his </span>position as <span class="gemarra-regular">a sharecropper</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> then he <span class="gemarra-regular">has </span>the ability to establish the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership with regard to land that he works and from which he profits for three years. A son does not have the ability to establish the presumption of ownership with regard to his father’s property, nor a wife with regard to her husband’s property. But with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a son who separate</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> himself from his father’s finances, <span class="gemarra-regular">and a woman who became divorced</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> they are like other people </span>with regard to this property, and have the ability to establish the presumption of ownership.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, it was necessary </span>to state that <span class="gemarra-regular">a son </span>who <span class="gemarra-regular">separated</span> himself establishes the presumption of ownership. If the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> had not stated this, it would <span class="gemarra-regular">enter your mind to say </span>that the father <span class="gemarra-regular">forgave </span>the unauthorized use of his land <span class="gemarra-regular">by</span> his son, and did not lodge a protest despite the fact that the land did not belong to the son. Therefore, the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us that </span>this is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>so, and that the son does establish the presumption of ownership. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>in the case of the <span class="gemarra-regular">woman who became divorced, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious </span>that she has no relationship with her ex-husband, so why is it necessary for the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> to teach that she is able to establish the presumption of ownership? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary</span> to teach that she does not establish the presumption of ownership

Daf 47b

<span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>a case where there is uncertainty whether <span class="gemarra-regular">she is divorced or </span>whether <span class="gemarra-regular">she is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not divorced, and </span>this is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Zeira. As Rabbi Zeira says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yirmeya bar Abba says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel says: Wherever the Sages said </span>with regard to a woman that there is uncertainty whether <span class="gemarra-regular">she is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> divorced or </span>whether <span class="gemarra-regular">she is not divorced</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> her husband </span>is still <span class="gemarra-regular">obligated with regard to her sustenance</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> One might have thought that since she still has some right to her husband’s property, insofar as he still has an obligation with regard to her sustenance he would not lodge a protest if she used his land without his authorization. It is therefore necessary to clarify that this is not so, and she has the ability to establish the presumption of ownership in her husband’s property.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman said: </span>Rav <span class="gemarra-regular">Huna said to me </span>that with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">all of </span>the types of people who do not have the ability to establish the presumption of ownership, <span class="gemarra-regular">when they bring proo</span><span class="gemarra-regular">f </span> by means of a document or witnesses that a field belongs to them, <span class="gemarra-regular">their proof is </span>a valid <span class="gemarra-regular">proof and </span>the court <span class="gemarra-regular">places</span> the <span class="gemarra-regular">field in their possession. </span>But if there is <span class="gemarra-regular">a robber who brings proof </span>that a field is his, <span class="gemarra-regular">his proof is not </span>a valid <span class="gemarra-regular">proof, and </span>the court <span class="gemarra-regular">does not place </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">field in his possession. </span>This is due to a concern that the proof was obtained through illegitimate means.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">teaching</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> us? We </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">learned </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Gittin</span> 55b): If one <span class="gemarra-regular">purchased </span>land <span class="gemarra-regular">from a Sicarius [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">Sikarikon</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> a violent gentile who had extorted the field from its owner with threats, <span class="gemarra-regular">and</span> afterward one <span class="gemarra-regular">returned and purchased </span>the same field <span class="gemarra-regular">from the </span>prior <span class="gemarra-regular">owner, his purchase is void, </span>as the owner of the field can say that he did not actually intend to sell him the field. This teaches that a purchase following a robbery is invalid, despite the existence of documents or testimony, rendering the statement of Rav Huna superfluous.
The Gemara answers: Rav Huna’s statement serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to exclude that which Rav </span>says, <span class="gemarra-regular">as Rav says: They taught </span>that the purchase of a field from the prior owner after one purchased it from a Sicarius is void <span class="gemarra-regular">only</span> when the prior owner <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>the buyer at the time of the sale: <span class="gemarra-regular">Go take possession and </span>thereby <span class="gemarra-regular">acquire </span>the field, but did not write a document. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if the transaction was performed along <span class="gemarra-regular">with a document </span>being given, the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">acquired </span>the field.
Therefore, Rav Huna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>that he rules <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Shmuel, as </span>Shmuel <span class="gemarra-regular">says: He does not acquire </span>the field <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>if the transaction was performed along <span class="gemarra-regular">with a document </span>being given, <span class="gemarra-regular">until </span>the owner of the field <span class="gemarra-regular">writes a property guarantee</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., a document that states that if the property is seized by the seller’s creditor, the seller will reimburse the buyer for his loss. Writing such a document indicates that it is a sincere transaction.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav Beiva</span><span class="gemarra-regular">i</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> concludes that </span>discussion of the statement of Rav Huna, that a robber does not retain possession of the field even if he brings proof of the transaction, with a comment <span class="gemarra-regular">in the name of Rav Naḥman: </span>The robber <span class="gemarra-regular">does not have </span>rights to the <span class="gemarra-regular">land</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> but he does</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> have </span>rights to the <span class="gemarra-regular">money </span>that he paid for the land, and the owner has to reimburse him. <span class="gemarra-regular">In </span><span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">is this statement </span>that the robber is reimbursed <span class="gemarra-regular">said? </span>It is specifically <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses said: </span>The robber <span class="gemarra-regular">counted </span>out the money <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>the owner and gave it to <span class="gemarra-regular">him in our presence; but </span>if the <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses said: </span>The owner <span class="gemarra-regular">admitted to </span>the robber <span class="gemarra-regular">in our presence </span>that he received payment, then the robber is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>reimbursed, as the admission may have been made under duress. This is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav Kahana, who says: If </span>the owner would <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>have <span class="gemarra-regular">admitted to </span>the robber that he received payment, the robber <span class="gemarra-regular">would have brought him and his donkey to </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">taskmaster.</span>
§ Apropos transactions performed under duress, the Gemara cites that which <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna says: </span>If one was <span class="gemarra-regular">suspended, </span>e.g., from a tree, and thereby coerced to sell a certain item, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he sol</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> it, <span class="gemarra-regular">his sale is valid. What is the reason? </span>The Gemara suggests that it is because <span class="gemarra-regular">whatever a person sells</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> were it not </span>for the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">compelled </span>by his need for money, he <span class="gemarra-regular">would not sell </span>it, <span class="gemarra-regular">and even so, his sale is valid. </span>This indicates that a transaction performed under duress is valid. The Gemara rejects this: <span class="gemarra-regular">But perhaps duress </span>that results <span class="gemarra-regular">from his own </span>needs, such as his need for money, <span class="gemarra-regular">is different from duress </span>that results <span class="gemarra-regular">from another, </span>as in this case. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>the basis for Rav Huna’s ruling is <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: 

Daf 48a

With regard to one who pledges to bring a burnt-offering, the verse states: “If his offering be a burnt-offering of the herd, <span class="gemarra-regular">he shall offer it </span>a male without blemish; he shall bring it to the door of the Tent of Meeting, according to his will, before the Lord” (Leviticus 1:3). The seemingly superfluous phrase “he shall offer it” <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches that they </span>can <span class="gemarra-regular">coerce him </span>to bring the offering. One <span class="gemarra-regular">might </span>have thought that it can be offered entirely <span class="gemarra-regular">against his will, </span>by taking it from his possession and sacrificing it. Therefore, <span class="gemarra-regular">the verse states: “According to his will” </span>(Leviticus 1:3). <span class="gemarra-regular">How </span>can <span class="gemarra-regular">these </span>texts be reconciled? <span class="gemarra-regular">They coerce him </span>with various punishments <span class="gemarra-regular">until he says: I want </span>to bring the offering. This seems to prove that consent resulting from coercion is considered to be valid consent. Perhaps this principle can apply to acquisition, as a source for Rav Huna’s ruling.
The Gemara rejects this proof: <span class="gemarra-regular">But perhaps there it is different, since he is </span>in fact <span class="gemarra-regular">amenable to </span>achieving <span class="gemarra-regular">atonement, </span>despite his earlier statement to the contrary. <span class="gemarra-regular">But rather, </span>prove Rav Huna’s ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">from the latter clause </span>of a mishna (<span class="it-text">Arakhin</span> 21a): <span class="gemarra-regular">And similarly you find </span>this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">with bills of divorce, </span>that when the court rules that he must divorce his wife, <span class="gemarra-regular">they coerce hi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">m</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> until he says: I want </span>to divorce my wife.
The Gemara rejects this proof as well: <span class="gemarra-regular">But perhaps there it is different, because it is a mitzva to listen to the statement of the Sages. </span>The assumption is that when he is required by the court to divorce his wife, his real desire is to perform the mitzva of listening to the Sages, and therefore he actually wants to divorce her. This does not apply to the case of a transaction performed under duress. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>Rav Huna’s ruling does not have a source in a mishna or <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, but <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>based on <span class="gemarra-regular">logical reasoning: By means of his being coerced, </span>the seller then willingly <span class="gemarra-regular">decides </span>to sell the field <span class="gemarra-regular">and transfers </span>it.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda raises an objection</span> to Rav Huna’s ruling from a mishna (<span class="it-text">Gittin</span> 88b): With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a bill of divorce that </span>the husband <span class="gemarra-regular">was compelle</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> by the court to write and give his wife, if he was compelled <span class="gemarra-regular">by a Jewish </span>court it is <span class="gemarra-regular">valid, but </span>if he was compelled <span class="gemarra-regular">by gentiles </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">not valid. And with regard to gentiles, they may beat him </span>at the request of the Jewish court <span class="gemarra-regular">and say to him: Do what the Jews are telling you, </span>and the divorce would then be valid. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But why </span>is a bill of divorce compelled by a gentile court invalid? <span class="gemarra-regular">There too, let us say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">as a result of his coercion, </span>the husband <span class="gemarra-regular">decides </span>to do what the court says <span class="gemarra-regular">and divorces</span> her.
The Gemara answers: In fact that reasoning is correct, as for this reason <span class="gemarra-regular">wasn’t it stated with regard</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to that </span>mishna that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Mesharshiyya says: By Torah law </span>a bill of divorce that the husband was compelled to give, <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>if he was compelled <span class="gemarra-regular">by gentiles, </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">valid</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> And what is the reason </span>the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>that if it is compelled <span class="gemarra-regular">by gentiles </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">not valid? </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">so that each and every </span>woman <span class="gemarra-regular">will not go and </span>through temptation or bribery <span class="gemarra-regular">depend on a gentile </span>to compel her husband to divorce her, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>thereby <span class="gemarra-regular">release herself from her husband </span>illegitimately.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Hamnuna raises an objection </span>to Rav Huna’s ruling from a mishna (<span class="it-text">Gittin</span> 55b): If one <span class="gemarra-regular">purchased </span>land <span class="gemarra-regular">from a Sicarius and </span>afterward <span class="gemarra-regular">returned and purchased </span>the same field <span class="gemarra-regular">from the </span>prior <span class="gemarra-regular">owner, his purchase is void, </span>as the prior owner of the field can say that he did not actually intend to sell the field to this buyer. <span class="gemarra-regular">But why </span>is the sale invalid? <span class="gemarra-regular">There too, let us say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">by means of his </span><span class="gemarra-regular">being coerced, </span>the seller then willingly <span class="gemarra-regular">decides </span>to sell the field <span class="gemarra-regular">and transfers </span>it.
The Gemara answers: In fact that reasoning is correct, as <span class="gemarra-regular">it was stated with regard </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to that </span>mishna that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: They taught </span>that the purchase from the prior owner after the purchase from a Sicarius is void <span class="gemarra-regular">only</span> when the prior owner <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>the buyer at the time of the sale: <span class="gemarra-regular">Go take possession and </span>thereby <span class="gemarra-regular">acquire </span>the field, but did not write a bill of sale. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if the transaction was performed along <span class="gemarra-regular">with a bill </span>of sale being given, the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">acquires </span>the field.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And according to Shmuel, who says: He does not acquire </span>the field <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>if the transaction was performed along <span class="gemarra-regular">with a bill </span>of sale being given, <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span><span class="gemarra-regular">can be said? </span>The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel concedes </span>that the sale is valid <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">gave money </span>for the field even though the owner sold it under duress, as is the case in the ruling of Rav Huna.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And according to Rav Beivai, who </span><span class="gemarra-regular">concludes that </span>statement of Rav Huna with a comment <span class="gemarra-regular">in the name of Rav Naḥman: </span>The robber <span class="gemarra-regular">does not have </span>rights to the <span class="gemarra-regular">land, </span>but <span class="gemarra-regular">he does have </span>rights to the <span class="gemarra-regular">money </span>that he paid for the land, and the owner has to reimburse him, <span class="gemarra-regular">what can </span><span class="gemarra-regular">be said? </span>Rav Beivai, who is referring to a case where there was a payment, as the robber is being reimbursed, seems to hold that the sale is invalid even where the robber paid for the field. The Gemara answers: The statement of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Beivai is an </span>amoraic <span class="gemarra-regular">statement, </span>not a citation of a tannaitic ruling, <span class="gemarra-regular">and Rav Huna, </span>who is also an <span class="it-text">amora</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">does not hold </span>in accordance with that amoraic <span class="gemarra-regular">statement.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava says: </span>The <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is that if one was <span class="gemarra-regular">suspended </span>and thereby coerced to sell a certain item, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he sol</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> it, <span class="gemarra-regular">his sale is valid. And we said </span>that this is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">only</span>

Daf 48b

<span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>a case where the seller was compelled to sell <span class="gemarra-regular">an unspecified field</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Since he had a choice as to which field to sell, the presumption is that he sold it sincerely. <span class="gemarra-regular">But in </span>a case where the one coercing him specified <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>specific <span class="gemarra-regular">field </span>to be sold, the sale is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>valid, as the seller did not decide freely on any aspect of the sale.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And even in </span>a case where the one coercing him specified <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>specific <span class="gemarra-regular">field </span>to be sold, <span class="gemarra-regular">we said </span>that the sale is invalid <span class="gemarra-regular">only where </span>the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">did not count [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">artzei</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">mone</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span> for the field, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>if the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">did count </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">money, </span>then we do <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>say that the sale is invalid.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And we said </span>that the sale is invalid in the case of a specified field when money was not counted <span class="gemarra-regular">only</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> where </span>the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">had no </span>way <span class="gemarra-regular">to avoid </span>the coercion. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">had </span>a way <span class="gemarra-regular">to avoid </span>the coercion and did not avoid it, then we do <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>say that the sale is invalid.
The Gemara concludes: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in all of </span>these cases is that <span class="gemarra-regular">the sale is valid</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>this is so <span class="gemarra-regular">even in </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a specified field. </span>This can be inferred <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a woman </span>forced to accept betrothal <span class="gemarra-regular">is comparable to </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a specified field, </span>as a specific man is performing the betrothal, <span class="gemarra-regular">and Ameimar says: </span>If a man <span class="gemarra-regular">suspended </span>a woman <span class="gemarra-regular">and betrothe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> her, <span class="gemarra-regular">his betrothal is valid, </span>despite the fact that she was coerced.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Mar bar Rav Ashi said: In </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a woman </span>who was forced to accept betrothal, the <span class="gemarra-regular">betrothal is certainly not </span>valid. <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>man <span class="gemarra-regular">acted improperly; consequently, </span>the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">acted improperly with him, and the Sages expropriated her betrothal from him.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Ravina said to Rav Ashi: </span>This <span class="gemarra-regular">works out well </span>in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he betrothed </span>his wife <span class="gemarra-regular">with money</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as it is possible to say that the Sages expropriated from the possession of its owner the money used for the betrothal, resulting in a retroactive cancellation of the betrothal. But if <span class="gemarra-regular">he betrothed </span>her <span class="gemarra-regular">by means of sexual intercourse, </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">what is there to say? </span>Rav Ashi <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: The Sages deemed his sexual intercourse </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">licentious sexual intercourse</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> which does not create a bond of betrothal.
§ The Gemara relates: Someone named <span class="gemarra-regular">Tavi suspended </span>another person named <span class="gemarra-regular">Pafi on a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kinar</span><span class="gemarra-italic">a</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>compelled him to <span class="gemarra-regular">sell </span>his field. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba bar bar Ḥana signed </span>both <span class="gemarra-regular">on </span>Pafi’s preemptive <span class="gemarra-regular">declaration </span>nullifying the sale (see 40b) <span class="gemarra-regular">and on </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">bill of sale [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ashkalta</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rav Huna said: </span>The <span class="gemarra-regular">one who signed on </span>the preemptive <span class="gemarra-regular">declaratio</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> acted <span class="gemarra-regular">well </span>by <span class="gemarra-regular">signing</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">one who signed on </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">bill of sale </span>acted <span class="gemarra-regular">well </span>by <span class="gemarra-regular">signing.</span>
The Gemara challenges: <span class="gemarra-regular">Whichever way you </span>look at it, Rav Huna’s statement is problematic. <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>the preemptive <span class="gemarra-regular">declaration </span>is valid, then there is <span class="gemarra-regular">no</span> place for <span class="gemarra-regular">a bill of sale. And if </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">bill of sale </span>is valid, then there is <span class="gemarra-regular">no </span>place for a preemptive <span class="gemarra-regular">declaration. </span>How can Rav Huna commend signing on both of these mutually exclusive documents? The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>is what Rav Huna <span class="gemarra-regular">is saying: If </span>it were <span class="gemarra-regular">not for </span>his also having signed the preemptive <span class="gemarra-regular">declaration, </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">one who signed on </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">bill of sale </span>acted <span class="gemarra-regular">well </span>by <span class="gemarra-regular">signing. </span>In this statement, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna </span>conforms <span class="gemarra-regular">to his </span>line of <span class="gemarra-regular">reasoning, as Rav Huna says: </span>If one was <span class="gemarra-regular">suspended </span>and thereby coerced to sell a certain item <span class="gemarra-regular">and he sold </span>it, <span class="gemarra-regular">his sale is valid.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Is that so </span>that Rabba bar bar Ḥana can, by means of the preemptive declaration, invalidate the bill of sale that he himself signed? <span class="gemarra-regular">But doesn’t Rav Naḥman say: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses who said: Our statement </span>that we signed <span class="gemarra-regular">was </span>a document of <span class="gemarra-regular">trust</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., a false promissory note given by one person to another, trusting that he will not make use of it until there is an actual loan,

they <span class="gemarra-regular">are not deemed credible. </span>And similarly, witnesses who said: <span class="gemarra-regular">Our statement </span>that we signed <span class="gemarra-regular">was </span>accompanied by a preemptive <span class="gemarra-regular">declaration, are not deemed credible. </span>They cannot negate the testimony of the document that they themselves signed by claiming that there had been a preemptive declaration. Similarly, how could Rabba bar bar Ḥana’s signing of the preemptive declaration override his signing the bill of sale?
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">That matter </span>of witnesses not being deemed credible to nullify a document applies only when the witnesses attempt to nullify the document by means of <span class="gemarra-regular">an oral </span>declaration, <span class="gemarra-regular">as an oral </span>declaration <span class="gemarra-regular">cannot come and weaken </span>a written <span class="gemarra-regular">document. But </span>if the witnesses attempt to nullify the bill of sale by means of testimony <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>another <span class="gemarra-regular">document, </span>e.g., by signing the preemptive declaration, then this preemptive <span class="gemarra-regular">document </span>can <span class="gemarra-regular">come and weaken </span>a written <span class="gemarra-regular">document, </span>in this case, the bill of sale.
The Gemara returns to discuss <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>matter <span class="gemarra-regular">itself: Rav Naḥman says </span>that witnesses who said: <span class="gemarra-regular">Our statement </span>that we signed <span class="gemarra-regular">was </span>a document of <span class="gemarra-regular">trust</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> are not deemed credible. </span>And similarly, witnesses who said: <span class="gemarra-regular">Our statement </span>that we signed <span class="gemarra-regular">was </span>accompanied by a preemptive <span class="gemarra-regular">declaration, are not deemed credible.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Mar bar Rav Ashi says </span>that witnesses who said: <span class="gemarra-regular">Our statement </span>that we signed <span class="gemarra-regular">was </span>a statement of <span class="gemarra-regular">trust, are not deemed credible; </span>but witnesses who said: <span class="gemarra-regular">Our statement </span>that we signed <span class="gemarra-regular">was </span>accompanied by a preemptive <span class="gemarra-regular">declaration, are deemed credible</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> What is the reason </span>for the difference between the cases? The reason is <span class="gemarra-regular">that this </span>document that was accompanied by a preemptive declaration <span class="gemarra-regular">may be written</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as it is merely written under duress, <span class="gemarra-regular">but that </span>document of trust <span class="gemarra-regular">may not be written, </span>as it is a false document. Testifying that they wrote it is self-incriminating, and the witnesses are not deemed credible to incriminate themselves.
§ The mishna teaches that <span class="gemarra-regular">a man does not have </span>the ability to establish the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership<span class="gemarra-regular"> with regard to his wife’s propert</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span> and a wife does not have the ability to establish the presumption of ownership with regard to her husband’s property. The Gemara asks: Isn’t this <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious? Since he has </span>the right <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>enjoy <span class="gemarra-regular">the profits </span>of her property while they are married, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is</span> known <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>he is only <span class="gemarra-regular">enjoying the profits </span>and that he has no claim to the field itself. On what grounds, then, would he establish the presumption of ownership?
The Gemara responds: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>to teach this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the husband <span class="gemarra-regular">wrote to </span>his wife: <span class="gemarra-regular">I do not have any legal </span>dealings <span class="gemarra-regular">or involvement with your property, </span>i.e., he forfeits his right to enjoy the profits of her property, and therefore if he subsequently did enjoy the profits of her field, one might assume that it is because he acquired the land from her. It was therefore necessary for the mishna to teach that this does not indicate that he owns the land, since it is possible that she does not prevent him from enjoying the profits, due to their relationship.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And if </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">wrote </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">to her, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">what of it? And isn’t it taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">One who says to another: I do not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">have </span>any <span class="gemarra-regular">legal </span>dealings <span class="gemarra-regular">or involvement concerning this field, or: I have no dealings with it, or: My hands are removed from it, has not said anything. </span>That is to say, these statements have no legal standing.
The scholars <span class="gemarra-regular">of the school of Rabbi Yannai said </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">this: The mishna </span>states its ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>one who <span class="gemarra-regular">writes </span>this formulation <span class="gemarra-regular">to her while she is still </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">betrothed, </span>before he had any rights to her property. Therefore, he is able to prevent his rights from taking effect after the marriage. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>this is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav Kahana, as Rav Kahana says: </span>

Daf 49b

With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">an inheritance that comes to a person from another place, </span>i.e., an inheritance one will receive in the future, <span class="gemarra-regular">a person can make a condition about it </span>from the outset <span class="gemarra-regular">that he will not inherit it, </span>since one can waive his future rights to property that is not currently his. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>this ruling is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rava, as </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said </span>that with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">anyone who says: I do not want </span>to avail myself <span class="gemarra-regular">of an ordinance of the Sages such as this </span>one that was instituted for my benefit, one <span class="gemarra-regular">listens to him.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is meant by: <span class="gemarra-regular">Such as this </span>one? The Gemara explains: Rava is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav Huna, </span>who said that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says </span>a certain ruling. <span class="gemarra-regular">As Rav Huna says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: A woman can sa</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to her husband: I will not be sustained </span>by you and, in turn, <span class="gemarra-regular">I will not work, </span>i.e., you will not keep my earnings. The Sages instituted that a husband must provide sustenance for his wife, and in exchange is entitled to her wages. Since this was instituted for the benefit of wives, the wife is able to opt out of this arrangement. Similarly, the husband may waive his rights to the profits from his wife’s land. It is in such a circumstance that the mishna rules that even if he relinquished his rights, he does not establish the presumption of ownership by enjoying the profits.
§ The mishna teaches that a husband does not establish the presumption of ownership of his wife’s field by enjoying its profits. The Gemara suggests: By inference, the husband <span class="gemarra-regular">has </span>the ability to bring <span class="gemarra-regular">proof </span>that he purchased the field from his wife or received it as a gift from her and consequently be regarded as the owner of the field. The Gemara asks: Why is this proof decisive? <span class="gemarra-regular">Let her say: I did </span>it, i.e., I gave or sold the field to my husband, only to <span class="gemarra-regular">please my husband, </span>but I did not mean it.
