The Gemara quotes a source for this claim: <span class="gemarra-regular">Didn’t we learn</span> in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Gittin</span> 55b): If one first <span class="gemarra-regular">purchased </span>land <span class="gemarra-regular">from the husban</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>afterward <span class="gemarra-regular">returned and purchased </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">from the wife, </span>i.e., he purchased her rights to this land for after the death of her husband or in the event of their divorce, as stipulated in her marriage contract, then <span class="gemarra-regular">his transaction is void</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Apparently, she said: I did </span>it, i.e., signed this bill of sale, only to <span class="gemarra-regular">please my husband, </span>but I did not mean it. <span class="gemarra-regular">Here too let her say</span><span class="gemarra-regular">:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> I did </span>it only to <span class="gemarra-regular">please my husband </span>but did not mean to give or sell the field to him.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">But wasn’t it stated with regard to that </span>mishna that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba bar Rav Huna says: </span>The <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that a woman can claim that she acted only in order to please her husband is not stated with regard to all of her property, but <span class="gemarra-regular">is necessary only with regard to those three </span>types of <span class="gemarra-regular">fields </span>that have special status: <span class="gemarra-regular">One </span>field about <span class="gemarra-regular">which he wrote to her in her marriage contract </span>that it would serve as payment of her marriage contract; 

Daf 50a

<span class="gemarra-regular">and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">one that he specified to her </span>as payment <span class="gemarra-regular">for her marriage contract</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> even though it was not stipulated explicitly in the contract; <span class="gemarra-regular">and one </span>in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where she brought into </span>the marriage <span class="gemarra-regular">an appraisal </span>of a field <span class="gemarra-regular">from her own </span>property that she owned prior to the marriage, which took on the status of guaranteed property, meaning that she will receive it if her husband dies or divorces her. If a field of one of these three types is sold with her approval, she can claim that she did not truly consent to this sale, but stated her consent only in order to please her husband.
The Gemara clarifies: <span class="gemarra-regular">To exclude what </span>type of property did Rabba specify these three types of fields? <span class="gemarra-regular">If we say </span>that he intends <span class="gemarra-regular">to exclude </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">rest of </span>the husband’s <span class="gemarra-regular">propert</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span> secured to pay her marriage contract, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">all the more</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> so </span>the case <span class="gemarra-regular">that he will bear </span>her <span class="gemarra-regular">enmity </span>if she does not agree to the sale, <span class="gemarra-regular">as he will say to her: </span>You <span class="gemarra-regular">have placed your eyes on divorce or on </span>my <span class="gemarra-regular">death, </span>i.e., you will not allow me to sell my property because you are expecting and planning for my death or our divorce. Therefore, she should be able to claim that she consented to the sale only in order to please her husband with regard to other property as well.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>these three types of fields were specified in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to exclude usufruct property</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., property that belongs to the wife and remains in her possession while the husband has the right to enjoy the profits, in which case if the wife consents to the sale, it is valid. The Gemara asks: But <span class="gemarra-regular">doesn’t Ameimar say </span>that if there was <span class="gemarra-regular">a man or a woman, </span>i.e., a husband or a wife, <span class="gemarra-regular">who sold </span>the wife’s <span class="gemarra-regular">usufruct property, they did not accomplish anything, </span>as the sale does not take effect?
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">When </span>the statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Ameimar was stated, </span>it was to say that neither the husband nor the wife can sell the property unilaterally. <span class="gemarra-regular">Where he sol</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> the property <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">died, she can come and remove </span>it from the buyer. <span class="gemarra-regular">Alternatively, </span>in a case where <span class="gemarra-regular">she sold </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">died, he can come and remove it, due to a rabbinic ordinance, and in accordance with </span>the statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Yosei bar Ḥanina, as Rabbi Yosei bar Ḥanina says: </span>When the Sanhedrin convened <span class="gemarra-regular">in Usha, they instituted </span>that in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a woman who sold </span>her <span class="gemarra-regular">usufruct propert</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span> in her husband’s lifetime <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">died, the husband repossesses </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">from the buyers.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">But where the two of them sold i</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to someone, or if she sold it to </span>her husband, <span class="gemarra-regular">the sale is valid. </span>The inference that the Gemara drew from the mishna, that if the husband produces evidence that his wife sold usufruct property to him then he is regarded as the owner, is relevant when she sells her usufruct property to him.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if you wish, say </span>instead that <span class="gemarra-regular">Ameimar said </span>his statement <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> who holds that one can sell property only if he possesses the item itself and also has the right to enjoy its profits.
This is <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who sells his </span>Canaanite <span class="gemarra-regular">slave </span>to another, <span class="gemarra-regular">and contracted with him </span>that the sale is <span class="gemarra-regular">on the condition that </span>the slave <span class="gemarra-regular">will serve </span>the seller for <span class="gemarra-regular">thirty days </span>before he is transferred to the buyer, the outcome of this sale is that during those thirty days, the first master enjoys the use of the slave and the buyer is the owner of the slave himself. As detailed in the Torah (Exodus 21:18–21), if one strikes another and the injury leads directly to the victim’s death, the one who struck him is subject to court-imposed capital punishment. But if a master strikes his Canaanite slave, and the slave lingers with his injuries for more than a day or two days and then dies, the master is exempt from court-imposed capital punishment. The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> addresses who is considered the owner of the slave with regard to this <span class="it-text">halakha</span>.
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> states four opinions: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir says </span>that during those thirty days, only <span class="gemarra-regular">the first </span>master <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>included <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">“a day or two days” </span>(Exodus 21:21). Rabbi Meir holds that in this case, the first master is included in this exemption, <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>the slave <span class="gemarra-regular">is under his </span>authority, as he enjoys the use of the slave, <span class="gemarra-regular">but the second </span>master <span class="gemarra-regular">is not </span>included <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">“a day or two days,” because</span> the slave <span class="gemarra-regular">is not under his </span>authority.
Rabbi Meir’s reasoning is that <span class="gemarra-regular">he holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">ownership of </span>the rights to use an item and the <span class="gemarra-regular">profits </span>it engenders is <span class="gemarra-regular">like ownership of the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> item itself. </span>The status of the first master as the owner negates the possibility that the second master would be regarded as the owner with regard to this <span class="it-text">halakha</span>, and he would not be included in the exemption.
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the second </span>master <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>included <span class="gemarra-regular">in</span> the <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">“a day or two days,” because </span>the slave <span class="gemarra-regular">is “his money” </span>(Exodus 21:21), i.e., his property; but <span class="gemarra-regular">the first </span>master is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>included <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">“a day or two days,” because </span>the slave <span class="gemarra-regular">is not “his money.” </span>Rabbi Yehuda’s reasoning is that <span class="gemarra-regular">he holds</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">ownership of </span>the rights to use an item and the <span class="gemarra-regular">profits </span>it engenders is <span class="gemarra-regular">not like ownership of the item</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> itself. </span>Therefore, the first master, who currently enjoys the use of the slave, does not have the status of an owner with regard to this <span class="it-text">halakha</span>.
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei says </span>that

Daf 50b

<span class="gemarra-regular">both of them are </span>included <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">“a day or two days.” This </span>first master is included <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>the slave <span class="gemarra-regular">is under his </span>authority, <span class="gemarra-regular">and that</span> second master is included <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>the slave <span class="gemarra-regular">is “his money.” </span>The Gemara explains Rabbi Yosei’s reasoning: <span class="gemarra-regular">And he is uncertain if ownership of </span>the rights to use an item and the <span class="gemarra-regular">profits </span>it engenders is <span class="gemarra-regular">like ownership of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the item itself, </span>in which case only the first master would be exempt, or <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">not like ownership of the item</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> itself, </span>in which case only the second master would be exempt. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>where there is <span class="gemarra-regular">an uncertainty </span>in a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">capital </span>law, the ruling is <span class="gemarra-regular">to be lenient. </span>Therefore, neither of them would receive court-imposed capital punishment in this case.
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">both of them are no</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> included <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">“a day or two days,” </span>and both would receive court-imposed capital punishment. <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>second master is not included <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>the slave <span class="gemarra-regular">is not under his </span>authority, <span class="gemarra-regular">and that </span>first master is not included <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>the slave <span class="gemarra-regular">is not “his money.” </span>Rabbi Eliezer holds that one must both own the slave himself and enjoy the use of the slave to be included in the exemption.
The Gemara explains how Ameimar’s statement is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Elazar. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rava says: What is the reason </span>for the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Elazar? </span>The <span class="gemarra-regular">verse states:</span> “Notwithstanding if he continue a day or two days, <span class="gemarra-regular">he shall not be punished; for he is his money” </span>(Exodus 21:21), and he understands this to be referring to a slave that is <span class="gemarra-regular">“his money,” </span>a slave <span class="gemarra-regular">that is unique to him, </span>so this exemption does not apply to one who does not have total ownership of the slave. Rabbi Elazar holds that one is considered to own an item only if he owns the item itself and also enjoys the use of it. This is the source of Ameimar’s statement that neither the husband nor the wife can sell usufruct property: The husband cannot sell it because he does not own it, and the wife cannot sell it because only the husband has the right to enjoy the profits.
§ The mishna teaches that <span class="gemarra-regular">a man does not have </span>the ability to establish the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to his wife’s property. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But doesn’t Rav say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a married woman must protest? </span>The Gemara clarifies: <span class="gemarra-regular">With regard to whom </span>must she protest? <span class="gemarra-regular">If we say: With regard to another, </span>i.e., one who is not her husband who has taken possession of her property, that is problematic: <span class="gemarra-regular">But doesn’t Rav say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">one cannot establish </span>the<span class="gemarra-regular"> presumption </span>of ownership <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to the property of a married woman</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as she can claim that she did not lodge a protest because she expected her husband to do so? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>Rav’s intention must be that she must lodge a protest <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to the husband. </span>This indicates that absent her protest, it is possible for a husband to establish the presumption of ownership with regard to her property, in contrast to the ruling of the mishna.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: Actually, </span>Rav is referring to her lodging a protest <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the husband, and </span>is speaking of a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">dug pits</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">ditches, and caves in </span>her property. In other words, he did not simply work and profit from the land, but damaged it in a way that demonstrates that he considered himself the owner. If he does this for three years and she does not lodge a protest, he establishes the presumption of ownership. The mishna, which states that he cannot establish the presumption of ownership, is referring to standard use.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But doesn’t Rav Naḥman say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba bar Avuh said: There is no presumptive ownership with regard to damage</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> This is understood to mean that one cannot establish the presumption of ownership of another’s field by damaging it, as it is not considered to be standard use. Therefore, even after three years have passed the owner can remove one from his field. Since in this case the husband is damaging the field, he should not be able to establish the presumption of ownership.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Say </span>that this means that <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of presumptive ownership does not </span>apply <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to damage, </span>meaning that one who damages another’s property without the owner lodging a protest does not need three years to establish the presumption of ownership, but does so immediately, as an owner who sees another damage his land is expected to protest without delay. Consequently, a husband who digs pits and the like in his wife’s property without her lodging a protest establishes the presumption of ownership immediately.
The Gemara offers an alternative answer. <span class="gemarra-regular">If you wish, say </span>instead: <span class="gemarra-regular">Was it not stated with regard to </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that there is no presumptive ownership with regard to damage that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Mari says: </span>Damage is referring specifically <span class="gemarra-regular">to smoke, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Zevid says </span>that it is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to a bathroom? </span>The statement that there is no presumptive ownership [<span class="it-text">ḥazaka</span>] with regard to damage was not stated concerning establishing the presumption of ownership of property, but concerning acquiring the privilege [<span class="it-text">ḥazaka</span>] to engage in certain activities on one’s own property, and is stating that even if one has engaged in activities that produce smoke or foul odors, the fact that the neighbors did not lodge a protest in the past does not prevent them from doing so in the future.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef said: Actually, </span>Rav is referring to her lodging a protest <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to another, and </span>is speaking of a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the one who has possession of her property worked and <span class="gemarra-regular">profite</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> from the field for <span class="gemarra-regular">part </span>of the time necessary to establish the<span class="gemarra-regular"> presumption </span>of ownership<span class="gemarra-regular"> during the husband’s lifetime, and </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">three </span>additional years <span class="gemarra-regular">after the husband’s death. </span>In this case, if the woman does not lodge a protest, the possessor establishes the presumption of ownership, <span class="gemarra-regular">since if he wanted </span>to, he could <span class="gemarra-regular">say to </span>the woman: <span class="gemarra-regular">I purchased it from you </span>and then possessed the field for three years, and he would be awarded the field. <span class="gemarra-regular">When he said to her as well: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">You sold </span>the field <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>your husband <span class="gemarra-regular">and he sold it to me, he is deemed credible.</span>
The Gemara returns to discuss Rav’s statement: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>matter <span class="gemarra-regular">itself, Rav says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">one cannot establish </span>the<span class="gemarra-regular"> presumption </span>of ownership<span class="gemarra-regular"> with regard to the property of a married woman, </span>

Daf 51a

<span class="gemarra-regular">but the judges of </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">exil</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">one can establish </span>the<span class="gemarra-regular"> presumption </span>of ownership.<span class="gemarra-regular"> Rav says: </span>The <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is in accordance with </span>the opinion of the <span class="gemarra-regular">judges of </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">exile. Rav Kahana and Rav Asi said to Rav: </span>Has the <span class="gemarra-regular">Master retracted his </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> that one cannot establish the presumption of ownership with regard to the property of a married woman? Rav <span class="gemarra-regular">said to them: I said </span>that the opinion of the judges of the exile <span class="gemarra-regular">is reasonable, </span>as the presumption of ownership can be established with regard the property of a married woman under certain circumstances. The Gemara comments: This is <span class="gemarra-regular">like </span>that ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav Yosef </span>with regard to one who possesses the land for three years after the death of the husband.
§ The mishna teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">And a wife does not have </span>the ability to establish the presumption of ownership <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to her husband’s property. </span>The Gemara asks: Isn’t that <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious? Since she has </span>the right to <span class="gemarra-regular">sustenance </span>from her husband’s property, <span class="gemarra-regular">she is enjoying </span>the profits as payment of her <span class="gemarra-regular">sustenance, </span>so her use of the property does not establish the presumption of ownership. The Gemara responds: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>to state this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in the event <span class="gemarra-regular">that he designated another </span>parcel of <span class="gemarra-regular">lan</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for her sustenance. </span>The mishna teaches that even if she enjoys the profits of a second field for three years, she does not establish the presumption of ownership of that field.
The Gemara asks: By inference, the wife <span class="gemarra-regular">has </span>the ability to bring <span class="gemarra-regular">proof </span>of her ownership and take possession of her husband’s field. Why is this proof valid? <span class="gemarra-regular">Let </span>him <span class="gemarra-regular">say that he desires to expose </span>her concealed <span class="gemarra-regular">money. </span>If he offers to sell the field to her and she agrees, it will be discovered that she has money of which he had been unaware. His intention was never to sell the property, but to claim money to which he is entitled.
Can one <span class="gemarra-regular">conclude from this </span>mishna that in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who sells a field to his wife, she has acquired </span>it, <span class="gemarra-regular">and we do not say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">he desires to expose </span>her concealed <span class="gemarra-regular">money? </span>The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>as one may <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that the inference from the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">that</span> if she <span class="gemarra-regular">has proof </span>then she has ownership rights is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> only <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to a deed of gift</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as, if her husband gave her the field as a gift, he cannot claim that he did so in order to expose her concealed money.
The Gemara relates: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman said to Rav Huna: </span>The <span class="gemarra-regular">Master was not with us in the evening </span>in the study hall that is <span class="gemarra-regular">within the boundaries </span>of the town, <span class="gemarra-regular">where we said a superior matter. </span>Rav Huna <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: What superior matter did you say? </span>Rav Naḥman responded: In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who sells a field to his wife, she has acquired </span>it, <span class="gemarra-regular">and we do not say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">he desires to expose </span>her concealed <span class="gemarra-regular">money.</span>
Rav Huna <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>That is <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious; remove </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">money from her</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and she will acquire </span>the property <span class="gemarra-regular">by means of the bill </span>of sale, as, even if she has not yet given him the money, she acquires the land by means of the bill of sale. <span class="gemarra-regular">Didn’t we learn </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Kiddushin</span> 26a): <span class="gemarra-regular">Property that serves as a guarantee</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., land, <span class="gemarra-regular">can be acquired by </span>means of giving <span class="gemarra-regular">money, by </span>means of giving <span class="gemarra-regular">a document, or by </span>means of <span class="gemarra-regular">taking possession </span>of it?
Rav Naḥman <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: But wasn’t it stated with regard to this </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel says: They taught </span>that the document alone suffices <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>if the transaction is <span class="gemarra-regular">with a deed of gift, but </span>if the transaction is <span class="gemarra-regular">with a bill of sale, </span>the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">does not acquire </span>the property <span class="gemarra-regular">until he gives him its money</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> Rav Huna responded: <span class="gemarra-regular">But didn’t Rav Hamnuna raise an objection </span>to this, based on this following <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">How </span>is acquisition <span class="gemarra-regular">by </span>means of giving <span class="gemarra-regular">a document </span>performed? If he <span class="gemarra-regular">wrote </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">for him on paper or </span><span class="gemarra-regular">earthenware, </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">even though </span>the paper or the earthenware <span class="gemarra-regular">is not worth </span>even <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span><span class="gemarra-italic">peruta</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>if he writes: <span class="gemarra-regular">My field is sold to you, </span>or: <span class="gemarra-regular">My field is acquired by you </span>as a gift, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is thereby sold or given. </span>This indicates that a document suffices to complete an acquisition both in the case of a sale and a gift.
Rav Naḥman responded: <span class="gemarra-regular">But is it not </span>so that <span class="gemarra-regular">he, </span>Rav Hamnuna, <span class="gemarra-regular">raises the objection and he </span>himself <span class="gemarra-regular">resolves it? </span>The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> states its ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>one who <span class="gemarra-regular">sells his field due to its poor </span>quality. The seller wants to be rid of his field due to its low value, and would like to transfer ownership of it as quickly as possible. In this case, writing a document suffices to complete the acquisition. By contrast, in standard cases it does not. Since the acquisition of a field requires monetary payment in addition to a bill of sale, Rav Naḥman’s statement, that if one sells a field to his wife the sale is valid and we do not say that he desires to expose her concealed money, is a novelty.
The Gemara notes that in interpreting this <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Beivai </span>would <span class="gemarra-regular">conclude in the name of Rav Naḥman, or, </span>according to another version, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi says: </span>Why does a document suffice for him to acquire the land? It is because it is assumed that <span class="gemarra-regular">he wanted to give it to him as a gift</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> And why did he write </span>the document <span class="gemarra-regular">for him </span>employing the <span class="gemarra-regular">terminology of a sale? </span>It was <span class="gemarra-regular">in order to enhance </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">power </span>of the one acquiring the land, since with regard to a property guarantee, i.e., a document that states that if the property is seized by the seller’s creditor, the seller will reimburse the buyer for his loss, a bill of sale is superior to a deed of gift.
The Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises an objection </span>to the ruling of Rav Naḥman, that we do not say that he desires to expose her concealed money, from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: If one <span class="gemarra-regular">borrowed </span>money <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>his own <span class="gemarra-regular">slave and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">frees him</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> or if one borrowed money <span class="gemarra-regular">from his wife and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">divorces her, they do not have any </span>claim <span class="gemarra-regular">on him, </span>and he need not repay them. <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>for this? Is it <span class="gemarra-regular">not because we say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">he desires to expose </span>their concealed <span class="gemarra-regular">money, </span>and his taking of the loan was a mere artifice to claim money to which he was entitled?
The Gemara answers: It <span class="gemarra-regular">is different there, </span>because there is an additional reason to think it was an artifice, <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">uncomfortable for him to make </span>applicable to <span class="gemarra-regular">himself </span>the verse: “The rich rules over the poor, and <span class="gemarra-regular">the borrower is servant to the lender” </span>(Proverbs 22:7). It is therefore reasonable to posit that his intention was not to borrow money, but to expose the concealed money that was in the possession of his slave or wife. This concern does not apply to one who sells property to his wife, and therefore the sale is valid.
The Gemara relates that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna bar Avin sent </span>a ruling to those in the study hall: In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who sells a field to his wife, she has acquired </span>it, 

Daf 51b

<span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>as long as they remain married, the <span class="gemarra-regular">husband enjoys the profits, </span>as he would with any usufruct property. <span class="gemarra-regular">But Rabbi Abba and Rabbi Abbahu and all of the great </span>Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">of the generation said </span>that the assumption is that the husband <span class="gemarra-regular">wanted to give it to her as a gift. And why did he write </span>the deed <span class="gemarra-regular">for her </span>employing terminology indicating that it is <span class="gemarra-regular">for the sake of a sale? </span>It was <span class="gemarra-regular">in order to enhance </span>her <span class="gemarra-regular">power</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
The Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises an objection </span>from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> to the ruling that the wife acquires the property: If one <span class="gemarra-regular">borrowed from </span>his own <span class="gemarra-regular">slave and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">freed him, </span>or if one borrowed <span class="gemarra-regular">from his wife and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">divorced her, they do not have any </span>claim <span class="gemarra-regular">on him, </span>and he need not repay them. <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>for this? Is it <span class="gemarra-regular">not because </span>we <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">he desired to expose </span>their concealed <span class="gemarra-regular">money, </span>and his taking of the loan was merely an artifice to claim money to which he was entitled? Similarly, the assumption should be that his sale to her was merely an artifice.
The Gemara answers: It <span class="gemarra-regular">is different there, </span>because there is an additional reason to think it was an artifice, <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">uncomfortable for a person to be </span>described by the verse: “The rich rules over the poor, and <span class="gemarra-regular">the borrower is servant to the lender” </span>(Proverbs 22:7). It is therefore reasonable to posit that his intention was not to borrow money, but to expose the concealed money that was in the possession of his slave or wife. This concern does not apply to one who sells property to his wife, and therefore the sale is valid.
The Gemara quotes a related statement. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: </span>In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who sells a field to his wife</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> she has acquired </span>it, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the husband enjoys the profits. </span>In the case of one who gives a married woman the field <span class="gemarra-regular">as a gift, she has acquired i</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and the husband does not enjoy the profits</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> since he gave it to her completely. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Elazar says: </span>In <span class="gemarra-regular">both </span><span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">and that </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">she has acquired </span>it, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the husband does not enjoy the profits.</span>
The Gemara relates: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥisda performed an action </span><span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar, </span>and did not allow a husband to enjoy the profits of a field he sold to his wife. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabban Ukva and Rabban Neḥemya</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the sons of Rav’s daughters, said to Rav Ḥisda: </span>Does the <span class="gemarra-regular">Master abandon a greater </span>Sage, i.e., Rav, the greatest Sage of his generation, <span class="gemarra-regular">and act in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">a lesser </span>Sage, i.e., Rabbi Elazar, who was Rav’s student? Rav Ḥisda <span class="gemarra-regular">said to them: But I too am acting in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">a greater </span>Sage, <span class="gemarra-regular">as when Ravin came </span>from Eretz Yisrael, <span class="gemarra-regular">he said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan </span>said: In <span class="gemarra-regular">both this </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">and that </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">she has acquired </span>it, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the husband does not enjoy the profits. </span>I am consequently not relying exclusively on Rabbi Elazar’s opinion, but also on that of Rabbi Yoḥanan.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is: In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who sells a field to his wife, she has not acquired </span>it, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the husband enjoys the profits. </span>In the case of one who gives a married woman the field <span class="gemarra-regular">as a gift, she has acquired it and the husband does not enjoy the profits. </span>The Gemara asks with regard to the first <span class="it-text">halakha</span>: Can these <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>ostensibly contradictory rulings be given? Rava’s statement that the wife has not acquired the field means that the husband still owns it, while his statement that the husband enjoys the profits, i.e., he merely enjoys the profits but does not own the field, indicates that the field itself is owned by the wife.
The Gemara responds: This is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult, </span>because Rava is referring to two different cases. <span class="gemarra-regular">Here, </span>where he says that she has not acquired the land, he is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>her <span class="gemarra-regular">money </span>was <span class="gemarra-regular">concealed</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and the sale was an artifice to expose it; while <span class="gemarra-regular">there, </span>where he says that she acquires the land, he is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>she had <span class="gemarra-regular">money that is not concealed. As Rav Yehuda says: </span>If she purchased the field with <span class="gemarra-regular">concealed money, she has not acquired </span>it; if she purchased it with <span class="gemarra-regular">money that is not concealed,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> she has acquired </span>it.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">One may not accept deposit</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from women, and not from slaves, and not from children. </span>Since it is likely that they do not own property, they might have taken the item without authorization from their husband, master, or parent, respectively. Consequently, one should not accept the deposit. If, however, one <span class="gemarra-regular">accepted </span>a deposit <span class="gemarra-regular">from a woman, he must return it to the woman, </span>as he cannot be certain that it is not hers. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if </span>the woman <span class="gemarra-regular">died, he must return it to her husband, </span>as he is her heir. If one <span class="gemarra-regular">accepted </span>a deposit <span class="gemarra-regular">from a slave, he must return it to the slave, </span>since it might not belong to the master. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if </span>the slave <span class="gemarra-regular">died, he must return it to his master</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> 

Daf 52a

If one <span class="gemarra-regular">accepted </span>a deposit <span class="gemarra-regular">from a minor, </span>he cannot return it to him, as a minor is unable to properly safeguard the item. Instead, <span class="gemarra-regular">he must make a safe investment [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">segulla</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for him, and if </span>the minor <span class="gemarra-regular">dies, </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">must return </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">to his heirs.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">all these </span>people, <span class="gemarra-regular">who said at the time of their death </span>that the deposited item <span class="gemarra-regular">belongs to so-and-so, </span>the bailee <span class="gemarra-regular">should act as they </span>had <span class="gemarra-regular">explained, and if </span>their explanation was <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>credible, the bailee <span class="gemarra-regular">should </span><span class="gemarra-regular">form an explanatio</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of their explanation, </span>i.e., ignore what they said.
The Gemara relates: <span class="gemarra-regular">When the wife of Rabba bar bar Ḥana was dying she said: These rings </span>that are in my possession <span class="gemarra-regular">belong to Marta and the sons of her daughter. </span>Rabba bar bar Ḥana <span class="gemarra-regular">came before Rav </span>to ask what he should do. Rav <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: If she is credible in your </span>eyes, <span class="gemarra-regular">act as she </span>had <span class="gemarra-regular">explained, and if not, form an explanation of her explanation, </span>i.e., ignore what she said, and as her heir, keep them for yourself.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And there are </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">who say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">this is what </span>Rav <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: If you assess </span>that it is likely that the rings were deposited with her, <span class="gemarra-regular">act as she </span>had <span class="gemarra-regular">explained, and if not, form an explanation of her explanation.</span>
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> stated that if the bailee took a deposit <span class="gemarra-regular">from a minor, he must make a safe investment for him. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is meant by <span class="gemarra-regular">a safe investment? Rav Ḥisda says: </span>The bailee should purchase <span class="gemarra-regular">a Torah scroll </span>for the minor. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba bar Rav Huna says: </span>He should purchase <span class="gemarra-regular">a date palm</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from which </span>the minor <span class="gemarra-regular">will consume dates.</span>
§ The mishna teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">And a father does not have </span>the ability to establish the presumption of ownership <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to a son’s property, and a son does not have </span>the ability to establish the presumption of ownership <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to a father’s property. Rav Yosef says: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Even </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">they separated </span>and the son is no longer dependent on his father, the presumption of ownership still cannot be established by a father or son with regard to the other’s property. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava says: </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">they separated, </span>that is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>, and the presumption of ownership can be established.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yirmeya of Difti said: Rav Pappi performed an action </span>and ruled that if <span class="gemarra-regular">they separated, </span>that is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava. Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥiyya, from </span>the city of <span class="gemarra-regular">Hurmiz Ardeshid</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> told me that Rav Aḥa bar Yaakov told him in the name of Rav Naḥman bar Yaakov: </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">they separated, </span>that is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>. The Gemara notes: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>this is the <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">they separated, </span>that is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>, and the presumption of ownership can be established. <span class="gemarra-regular">This is also taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">A son who separated </span>himself from his father’s finances <span class="gemarra-regular">and a wife who became divorced are like all other people </span>with regard to establishing the presumption of ownership.
§ It <span class="gemarra-regular">was stated: </span>There was a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one of the brothers </span>in a family <span class="gemarra-regular">who was engaging in commerce in the house</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>managing the family finances after the death of their father, <span class="gemarra-regular">and there were bills of sale [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">onot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>other <span class="gemarra-regular">documents circulating with his name </span>appearing as the owner of the property and as a lender, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>that brother <span class="gemarra-regular">said: </span>The money and property <span class="gemarra-regular">are mine, as they fell to me as an inheritance from the house of </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">father of </span>my <span class="gemarra-regular">mother, </span>who is not the mother of the other brothers, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">upon him to bring proof </span>of ownership; otherwise the property is divided equally among the brothers. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Shmuel says: </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">upon the brothers to bring proof </span>that the money or property belonged to their common father and consequently now belongs to all of them. <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel says: Abba, </span>i.e., Rav, <span class="gemarra-regular">concedes to me that if </span>that brother <span class="gemarra-regular">dies, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">upon the brothers to bring proof </span>in order to collect money from the deceased brother’s heirs.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa objects to </span>Shmuel’s addendum: Do <span class="gemarra-regular">we claim on behalf of orphans anything that their father </span>could <span class="gemarra-regular">not claim for them? But didn’t Rava remove a pair </span>of scissors used <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>cutting <span class="gemarra-regular">garment</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and a book of </span><span class="gemarra-italic">aggada</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from orphans without </span>requiring the prior owner who had asked the orphans to return these items to bring <span class="gemarra-regular">proof</span> of ownership, and he would rule the same <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the case of all <span class="gemarra-regular">items </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">which it is common </span>for them <span class="gemarra-regular">to be lent, </span>and the one in possession has no presumption of ownership? 

Daf 52b

<span class="gemarra-regular">As Rav Huna bar Avin sent </span>a ruling: If one other than the one previously established to be the owner is in possession of <span class="gemarra-regular">items that are typically len</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> or rented, and says: They are purchased, </span>and that is why they are <span class="gemarra-regular">in my possession, he is not deemed credible. </span>In this case as well, as the father of the orphans could not be awarded these documents without bringing proof, the same should be true of his orphans. Why, then, would Rav concede to Shmuel? The Gemara concedes: This is <span class="gemarra-regular">difficult.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥisda says: They, </span>i.e., Rav, <span class="gemarra-regular">taught </span>his ruling, that the brother must bring proof that he owns the property listed in the documents that appear under his name, <span class="gemarra-regular">only when they do not divide </span>any of their property, even <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to their dough</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., they share everything, even their food. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">they divide with regard to their dough, say </span>that this brother <span class="gemarra-regular">removed </span>money <span class="gemarra-regular">from his dough, </span>i.e., reduced his expenses for food, thereby amassing his own property.
With regard to the requirement that proof be brought, the Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">With what </span>is one considered to have brought <span class="gemarra-regular">proof</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rabba says: Proof </span>is brought <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>the testimony of <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses</span> that he purchased the property listed in the document or granted the loan with his own money or that he inherited it from his mother’s family. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Sheshet says: Proof </span>is brought <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>the court’s <span class="gemarra-regular">ratification of the documen</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> in which his name appears.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said to Rav Naḥman: This </span>is the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav and this </span>is the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel; this </span>is the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba and this </span>is the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Sheshet. In accordance with whose </span>opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">does </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">Master hold? </span>Rav Naḥman <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: I know a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">baraita</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> which is the source of my opinion, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is taught </span>(<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span> 9:2): In a case where there was <span class="gemarra-regular">one of the brothers who was engaging in commerce in the house, </span>managing the family finances, <span class="gemarra-regular">and there were bills of sale and </span>other <span class="gemarra-regular">documents circulating with </span><span class="gemarra-regular">his name </span>appearing as the owner of the property or as a lender, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>that brother <span class="gemarra-regular">said: </span>The money and property <span class="gemarra-regular">are mine, as they fell to me as an inheritance from the house of </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">father of </span>my <span class="gemarra-regular">mother, </span>who is not the mother of the other brothers, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">upon him to bring proof </span>of ownership.
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">And similarly, </span>in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a woman, </span>i.e., a widow, if her husband’s heirs see <span class="gemarra-regular">that she is engaging in commerc</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in the house </span>with the property that had belonged to her husband, <span class="gemarra-regular">and there were bills of sale and </span>other <span class="gemarra-regular">documents circulating with her name </span>appearing on them as the owner, <span class="gemarra-regular">and she said: </span>The money and property <span class="gemarra-regular">are mine </span>alone, <span class="gemarra-regular">as they fell to me as an inheritance from the house of </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">father of </span>my <span class="gemarra-regular">father or from </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">house of </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">father of </span>my <span class="gemarra-regular">mother, </span>and did not belong to my husband, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">upon her to bring proof. </span>Rav Naḥman consequently holds in accordance with the opinion of Rav.
Having quoted the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, the Gemara seeks to clarify it, and asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is the purpose of the clause of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that begins: <span class="gemarra-regular">And similarly, </span>where the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> appears to be identical to that of the first clause? <span class="gemarra-regular">Lest you say </span>that in the case of the <span class="gemarra-regular">woman, since the matter is laudable for her, </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>people <span class="gemarra-regular">say: She is toiling on behalf of orphans; she </span>would <span class="gemarra-regular">not steal from </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">orphans, </span>and is therefore deemed credible if she says that the property in the documents that bear her name is her own, the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>that this assumption cannot be relied upon, and she must bring proof of ownership.
§ The mishna teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">In what </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">is this statement, </span>that one establishes the presumption of ownership after profiting from the property for a certain duration, <span class="gemarra-regular">said? </span>It is said <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>a case of one who <span class="gemarra-regular">has </span>mere <span class="gemarra-regular">possession </span>of the property, which does in some cases serve as proof of ownership. <span class="gemarra-regular">But in </span>a case of one who <span class="gemarra-regular">gives a gift, or brothers who divided </span>their inheritance, or one who takes possession of the property of a convert who died without heirs and his property is now ownerless, as soon as one locked the door of the property, or fenced it or breached its fence even a bit, this is considered taking possession of the property, and effects acquisition. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Is that to say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">all of these whom we </span>previously <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>possessed the field for three years <span class="gemarra-regular">are not subject to </span>the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">taking possession </span>of property in this manner?
The Gemara responds that the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">is incomplete and this </span>is what <span class="gemarra-regular">it is teaching</span><span class="gemarra-regular">:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> In what </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">is this statement said? </span>It is said <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to possession that is accompanied by a claim, </span>i.e., when the possessor has a claim to counter that of the claimant, <span class="gemarra-regular">such as </span>where the <span class="gemarra-regular">seller, </span>i.e., the claimant, <span class="gemarra-regular">says: I did not sell, and the buyer, </span>i.e., the possessor, <span class="gemarra-regular">says: I purchased. </span>In that case, working and profiting from the land for three years establishes the presumption of ownership.
<span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">possession that </span>does <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>need to be <span class="gemarra-regular">accompanied by a claim, </span>as the prior owner concedes that the one in possession is the owner, <span class="gemarra-regular">such as </span>a case where another person <span class="gemarra-regular">gives </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">a gift, or </span>there are <span class="gemarra-regular">brothers who divided </span>their property, <span class="gemarra-regular">or </span>there is <span class="gemarra-regular">one who takes possession of </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">property of a convert </span>who died without heirs, <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the function of possessing the item is <span class="gemarra-regular">only to acquire </span>it and not to establish the presumption of ownership, if one <span class="gemarra-regular">locke</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> the door of the property, or <span class="gemarra-regular">fenced </span>it or <span class="gemarra-regular">breached </span>its fence even <span class="gemarra-regular">a bit, this is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">taking possession </span>of the property.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Hoshaya teaches in </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> of tractate <span class="gemarra-italic">Kiddushin</span> that was taught in the <span class="gemarra-regular">school of Levi: </span>If one <span class="gemarra-regular">locked </span>the door of the property, or <span class="gemarra-regular">fenced </span>it or <span class="gemarra-regular">breached </span>its fence even <span class="gemarra-regular">a bit, </span>if this was done <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">presence </span>of the seller, <span class="gemarra-regular">this is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">taking possession </span>of the property. The Gemara asks: One could infer that <span class="gemarra-regular">in his presence, yes, </span>he acquires it; but <span class="gemarra-regular">not in his presence, no, </span>he does not acquire it. Why not? In any event he has taken possession. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>is what Rav Hoshaya <span class="gemarra-regular">is saying: </span>If the act was performed <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the seller’s <span class="gemarra-regular">presence, </span>the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">need not say to him: Go, take possession, and </span>thereby <span class="gemarra-regular">acquir</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> the property. Since the buyer is performing the act in the seller’s presence, there is no need for the seller to specify that he consents to the buyer’s acquiring it. 

Daf 53a

But if the act was performed <span class="gemarra-regular">not in </span>the seller’s <span class="gemarra-regular">presence, </span>the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">must say to him: Go, take possession</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>thereby <span class="gemarra-regular">acquire </span>the property for him to acquire it.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav raises a dilemma: How </span>does one acquire <span class="gemarra-regular">a gift, </span>i.e., is it necessary for the giver to say: Go, take possession and thereby acquire? <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel said: What dilemma is raised to Abba, </span>i.e., Rav? <span class="gemarra-regular">Now </span>one could say the following: <span class="gemarra-regular">And what </span>is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a sale</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> where </span>the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">is giving money </span>to the seller? <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">says to </span>the buyer: <span class="gemarra-regular">Go, take possession and </span>thereby <span class="gemarra-regular">acquire </span>the property, the acquisition <span class="gemarra-regular">does </span>take effect, but <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>he did <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>say this, it does <span class="gemarra-regular">not. </span>Therefore, with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a gift, </span>where no money is given to the seller, is it <span class="gemarra-regular">not all the more so </span>reasonable that the acquisition not take effect without a clear directive from the seller? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav holds </span>that it is possible to say that <span class="gemarra-regular">one who gives a gift gives </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">generously, </span>and would allow the acquisition even absent a clear directive.
§ The mishna teaches that taking possession can be performed by building a fence or breaching a fence even a bit. The Gemara clarifies: <span class="gemarra-regular">And how much </span>is the measure of <span class="gemarra-regular">a bit</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> It is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Shmuel, as Shmuel says: </span>If one had previously <span class="gemarra-regular">built a fence, and </span>now <span class="gemarra-regular">completed i</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to </span>a height of <span class="gemarra-regular">ten </span>handbreadths, which is the height of a halakhically significant barrier; <span class="gemarra-regular">or </span>similarly, if one had previously <span class="gemarra-regular">breached a breach</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and now expanded it <span class="gemarra-regular">in order </span>that it be large enough <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>a person can <span class="gemarra-regular">enter and exit through it, this is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">taking possession.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What are the circumstances </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">this fence? If we say that initially </span>one could <span class="gemarra-regular">not climb over it </span>to enter the field, <span class="gemarra-regular">and now too </span>one still could <span class="gemarra-regular">not climb over it, what did he accomplish? </span>Nothing has changed through his completing the height of the fence. <span class="gemarra-regular">And alternatively, </span>if it was such <span class="gemarra-regular">that initially </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">could climb over it </span>to enter the field, <span class="gemarra-regular">and now</span> one could <span class="gemarra-regular">not climb over it, </span>he has <span class="gemarra-regular">accomplished a great deal, </span>and the mishna should not have referred to this addition as: A bit. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary to </span>state this ruling if the height of the fence was such <span class="gemarra-regular">that initially </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">could climb over it with ease, and now </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">could climb over it </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">with effort.</span>
The Gemara similarly asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What are the circumstances </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">this breach? If we say that initially, </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">could enter </span>the field <span class="gemarra-regular">through it, and now too </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">could enter </span>the field <span class="gemarra-regular">through it, what did </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">accomplish? </span>Nothing has changed through his expanding the breach? <span class="gemarra-regular">And alternatively, </span>if it was such <span class="gemarra-regular">that initially </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">could not enter </span>the field <span class="gemarra-regular">through it, and now </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">could enter </span>the field <span class="gemarra-regular">through it, </span>he has <span class="gemarra-regular">accomplished a great deal, </span>and the mishna should not have referred to this as: A bit. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>to state this ruling if the size of the breach was such <span class="gemarra-regular">that initially </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">could enter </span>the field <span class="gemarra-regular">through it with effort, and now </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">could enter </span>the field <span class="gemarra-regular">through it with ease.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Asi says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: </span>If one <span class="gemarra-regular">placed a ston</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">helps </span>to serve some objective, or if one <span class="gemarra-regular">removed a stone and </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">helps </span>to serve some objective, <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>act <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">taking possession. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is the meaning of <span class="gemarra-regular">placed, and what </span>is the meaning of <span class="gemarra-regular">removed?</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">If we say </span>that he <span class="gemarra-regular">placed a stone </span>in the fence <span class="gemarra-regular">and stopped the water from </span>flooding the field, or he <span class="gemarra-regular">removed a stone </span>from the fence <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>thereby fashioned an opening that <span class="gemarra-regular">released water </span>that had been flooding the field, <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>is analogous to one who <span class="gemarra-regular">chases away a lion from another’s property. </span>In other words, these acts prevent damage to the field, which one is obligated to prevent even in the case of the property of another, and accordingly, they do not constitute a demonstration of ownership. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>it means that he <span class="gemarra-regular">placed a stone that connected water to </span>the field and irrigated it, or he <span class="gemarra-regular">removed a stone and enhanced </span>the flow of <span class="gemarra-regular">water to it.</span>
§ The Gemara cites another statement of the same <span class="it-text">amora</span> with regard to taking possession. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav Asi says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: </span>If there were <span class="gemarra-regular">two field</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with one boundar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> between them, </span>and one <span class="gemarra-regular">took possession of one of </span>the fields in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to acquire it, </span>he has <span class="gemarra-regular">acquired it. </span>

Daf 53b

If his intention was <span class="gemarra-regular">to acquire it and </span>also acquire <span class="gemarra-regular">the othe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> field, he has <span class="gemarra-regular">acquired </span>the first field, but has <span class="gemarra-regular">not acquired the other </span>field, since the fields are separated by a boundary. If he took possession of one field in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to acquire </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">the other </span>field, <span class="gemarra-regular">he has not acquired even that </span>field of which he took possession, since his intention when taking possession was to acquire the other field, and one does not acquire an item without the intention to do so.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Zeira raises a dilemma: What is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> if one <span class="gemarra-regular">took possession of one </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of </span>the fields in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to acquire it, and the boundary, and the other </span>field, all together? <span class="gemarra-regular">Do we say</span> that the <span class="gemarra-regular">boundary of the land is one, </span>i.e., these two fields are joined by means of their common boundary, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>therefore he has <span class="gemarra-regular">acquired </span>all of them? <span class="gemarra-regular">Or perhaps this </span>field <span class="gemarra-regular">stands alone and that </span>field <span class="gemarra-regular">stands alone. </span>The Gemara notes that the dilemma <span class="gemarra-regular">shall stand </span>unresolved.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar raises a dilemma: What is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> if one <span class="gemarra-regular">took possession of the boundary </span>between the two fields in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to acquire both of </span>the fields? <span class="gemarra-regular">Do we say </span>that the legal status of <span class="gemarra-regular">this boundary</span> is that of <span class="gemarra-regular">the halter of the land and he acquires</span> the fields, just as one acquires an animal through the acquisition of its halter? <span class="gemarra-regular">Or perhaps </span>this field <span class="gemarra-regular">stands alone and that </span>field <span class="gemarra-regular">stands alone, </span>as the boundary is not connected to the field in the same manner that a halter is connected to an animal. The Gemara notes that the dilemma <span class="gemarra-regular">shall stand </span>unresolved.
Similarly, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba bar Avuh says: </span>If there were <span class="gemarra-regular">two houses </span>in a courtyard, <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>one situated <span class="gemarra-regular">within </span>the courtyard relative <span class="gemarra-regular">to that </span>one, and one <span class="gemarra-regular">took possession of the outer </span>house in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to acquire it, he has acquired it. </span>If his intention was <span class="gemarra-regular">to acquire it and </span>also acquire <span class="gemarra-regular">the inner </span>house, <span class="gemarra-regular">he has acquired the outer </span>house, but has <span class="gemarra-regular">not acquired the inner </span>house. If he took possession of the outer house in order to <span class="gemarra-regular">acquire the inner </span>house alone, he <span class="gemarra-regular">has not acquired even the outer </span>house.
If he <span class="gemarra-regular">took possession of the inner </span>house in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to acquire it, </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">has acquired it. </span>If his intention was <span class="gemarra-regular">to acquire it and </span>also acquire <span class="gemarra-regular">the outer house, </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">has acquired both of them. </span>Since the residents of the inner house possess the right to pass through the outer house in order to enter and exit the courtyard, the outer house is viewed as an extension of the inner house. If he took possession of the inner house in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to acquire </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">the outer </span>house, he has <span class="gemarra-regular">not acquired even the inner </span>house, since he did not take possession of the property that he intended to acquire.
§ The Gemara continues its discussion of taking possession of ownerless property. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba bar Avuh says: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who builds large palaces </span><span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">palterin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> on the property of a convert </span>who died without heirs, <span class="gemarra-regular">and another came and placed doors </span>upon <span class="gemarra-regular">them, </span>the latter <span class="gemarra-regular">has acquired </span>the property. The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>for this? <span class="gemarra-regular">The first, </span>i.e., the one who built the palaces, <span class="gemarra-regular">merely turned over bricks, </span>i.e., building an incomplete house is not sufficient to take possession of the property.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Dimi bar Yosef says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar says: One who finds palace</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> built <span class="gemarra-regular">on the property of a convert </span>who died without heirs <span class="gemarra-regular">and plastered them </span>with <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>application of <span class="gemarra-regular">plaster or </span>tiled them with <span class="gemarra-regular">one tile, has acquired them. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And how much, </span>i.e., what is the minimum area that must be plastered or tiled? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef said: </span>A square <span class="gemarra-regular">cubit. Rav Ḥisda said: And </span>he acquires it in this manner only if it was plastered or tiled <span class="gemarra-regular">opposite the entrance, </span>where it can be easily seen.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Amram said: Rav Sheshet said this statement to us, and he enlightened our eyes from a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">barait</span><span class="gemarra-italic">a</span> that alludes to the same matter. He said: <span class="gemarra-regular">One who spreads </span>out <span class="gemarra-regular">mattresse</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> on the property of a conver</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> who died without heirs <span class="gemarra-regular">has acquired </span>it. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>that which I said, that <span class="gemarra-regular">he enlightened our eyes from a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">baraita</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, what is it? As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> (<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span>, <span class="it-text">Kiddushin</span> 1:5): <span class="gemarra-regular">How </span>does one acquire a Canaanite slave <span class="gemarra-regular">through taking possession</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> If the slave <span class="gemarra-regular">placed </span>one’s <span class="gemarra-regular">shoe for him, or untied </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">shoe for him, or </span>if it occurred <span class="gemarra-regular">that he carried his garments after him to the bathhouse, or undresses him, or bathes him, </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">anoints him, </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">scrubs </span>the oil off <span class="gemarra-regular">him, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">or dresses him, or puts on his shoes, or lifts him, </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">acquires </span>the slave. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon said: </span>The acquisition generated by taking <span class="gemarra-regular">possession should not be </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">greater than </span>the acquisition generated by <span class="gemarra-regular">lifting, as lifting acquires </span>property <span class="gemarra-regular">in any situation.</span>
With regard to this last statement, the Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is </span>Rabbi Shimon <span class="gemarra-regular">saying </span>here, as the first <span class="it-text">tanna</span> also said that a slave can be acquired by lifting? The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>is what he <span class="gemarra-regular">is saying: </span>The first <span class="it-text">tanna</span> holds that if <span class="gemarra-regular">he lifted his master, </span>the master <span class="gemarra-regular">acquires him, </span>as he is performing labor for the master, but if <span class="gemarra-regular">his master lifted him, </span>the master <span class="gemarra-regular">does not acquire him, </span>as the slave has not performed labor on his behalf. With regard to this <span class="it-text">halakha</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon said: </span>Acquisition generated through taking <span class="gemarra-regular">possession should not be greater than </span>acquisition generated through <span class="gemarra-regular">lifting, as lifting acquires </span>property <span class="gemarra-regular">in any situation. </span>Consequently, one can acquire a slave even by lifting him.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yirmeya Bira’a says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda says: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">this one</span>

Daf 54a

<span class="gemarra-regular">who threw turni</span><span class="gemarra-regular">p</span> seeds <span class="gemarra-regular">in the crevices [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">filei</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of the land of a convert </span>who died without heirs, it <span class="gemarra-regular">is not </span>sufficient to <span class="gemarra-regular">take possession. What is the reason </span>for this? <span class="gemarra-regular">As at the time that </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">threw </span>the seeds <span class="gemarra-regular">there was no enhancement </span>to the value of the field. <span class="gemarra-regular">Now that </span>the turnips have grown and the value of the field <span class="gemarra-regular">is enhanced, it is enhanced by itself.</span>
