The Gemara records a series of rulings with regard to taking possession of land. <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel says: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">this one who cuts </span>the branches of <span class="gemarra-regular">a palm tree</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> if he had <span class="gemarra-regular">in mind </span>the acquisition <span class="gemarra-regular">of the palm tree, </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">has acquired </span>it; but if he had <span class="gemarra-regular">in mind </span>the benefit <span class="gemarra-regular">of the animals, </span>to feed his animals the branches, he <span class="gemarra-regular">has not acquired </span>it. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What are the circumstances </span>in which it can be known what he had in mind? The Gemara answers: If he <span class="gemarra-regular">took </span>branches <span class="gemarra-regular">from this side and from that side, </span>he had <span class="gemarra-regular">in mind </span>the acquisition <span class="gemarra-regular">of the palm tree, </span>as this assists the growth of the tree; but if the branches that he took were <span class="gemarra-regular">all from one side, </span>he had <span class="gemarra-regular">in mind </span>the benefit <span class="gemarra-regular">of the animals.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Shmuel says </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">this one who clears [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">dezakkei</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">zikheya</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> a field of trees, if he had <span class="gemarra-regular">in mind </span>the improvement <span class="gemarra-regular">of the field, </span>to prepare it for plowing, <span class="gemarra-regular">he has acquired </span>it; but if he had <span class="gemarra-regular">in mind </span>the collection <span class="gemarra-regular">of the wood, he has not acquired </span>it. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What are the circumstances </span>in which it can be known what he had in mind? The Gemara answers: If he <span class="gemarra-regular">took large and small </span>pieces of wood, he had <span class="gemarra-regular">in mind </span>the improvement <span class="gemarra-regular">of the field; </span>however, if <span class="gemarra-regular">he took </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">large </span>pieces of wood <span class="gemarra-regular">but left </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">small </span>ones, he had <span class="gemarra-regular">in mind </span>the collection <span class="gemarra-regular">of the wood.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Shmuel says </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">this one who removes protuberance</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> and levels the ground, if he had <span class="gemarra-regular">in mind </span>the improvement <span class="gemarra-regular">of the field, </span>to prepare it for plowing, he <span class="gemarra-regular">has acquired </span>it; but if he had <span class="gemarra-regular">in mind </span>the conversion <span class="gemarra-regular">of</span> the field into <span class="gemarra-regular">a threshing floor</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he has not acquired </span>it. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What are the circumstances </span>in which it can be known what he had in mind? The Gemara answers: If he <span class="gemarra-regular">took a mound and threw it in a ditch, </span>thereby leveling both areas, he had <span class="gemarra-regular">in mind </span>the improvement <span class="gemarra-regular">of the field; </span>but if he leveled the ground with <span class="gemarra-regular">a mound in </span>the place of <span class="gemarra-regular">a mound and a ditch in </span>the place of <span class="gemarra-regular">a ditch, </span>expanding each area but leaving the field as a whole uneven, he had <span class="gemarra-regular">in mind </span>the conversion <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span>the field into <span class="gemarra-regular">a threshing floor.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Shmuel says </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">this one who opened </span>a blockage and enabled <span class="gemarra-regular">wate</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> to enter <span class="gemarra-regular">into </span>a section of <span class="gemarra-regular">land, </span>if he had <span class="gemarra-regular">in mind </span>the improvement <span class="gemarra-regular">of the field, </span>to irrigate it, he <span class="gemarra-regular">has acquired </span>it; but if he had <span class="gemarra-regular">in mind </span>the catching <span class="gemarra-regular">of the fish, </span>i.e., to enable the water to flow in so that he could catch the fish therein, he <span class="gemarra-regular">has not acquired </span>it. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What are the circumstances </span>in which it can be known what he had in mind? The Gemara answers: If he <span class="gemarra-regular">opened two gates, one bringing in </span>the water <span class="gemarra-regular">and one taking out </span>the water, this indicates that he had <span class="gemarra-regular">in mind </span>the catching <span class="gemarra-regular">of the fish, </span>as the water will flow out of the field, giving him the means to catch the fish; but if he opened only <span class="gemarra-regular">one gate, </span>this indicates that he had <span class="gemarra-regular">in mind </span>the improvement <span class="gemarra-regular">of the field.</span>
The Gemara relates: There was <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain woman who profited </span>from an ownerless <span class="gemarra-regular">palm tree by cuttin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span> its branches for <span class="gemarra-regular">thirteen years. Another </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">came </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">plowed beneath it a bit. </span>The case <span class="gemarra-regular">came before Levi, and some say </span>that it came <span class="gemarra-regular">before Mar Ukva, </span>who <span class="gemarra-regular">established </span>the property <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">possession </span>of the one who plowed. The woman <span class="gemarra-regular">came </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">shouted before him, </span>protesting the perceived injustice of his ruling. Mar Ukva <span class="gemarra-regular">said to her: What can I do for you, as you did not take possession </span>of the property <span class="gemarra-regular">in the manner that people take possession?</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: One who draws an imag</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e,</span> e.g., he paints an image on the wall, <span class="gemarra-regular">on the property of a convert </span>who died without heirs <span class="gemarra-regular">has acquired </span>it, <span class="gemarra-regular">as Rav </span>himself <span class="gemarra-regular">acquired the garden of the house </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav, </span>which had been ownerless property, <span class="gemarra-regular">only by </span>drawing <span class="gemarra-regular">an image.</span>
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">It was stated: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a field </span>that is <span class="gemarra-regular">defined by its boundaries</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., it has clearly demarcated boundaries on all sides, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: Once he struck </span>the land with a hoe <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>time, he <span class="gemarra-regular">acquired the entire </span>property. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Shmuel says </span>that he <span class="gemarra-regular">has acquired only the place </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">he struc</span><span class="gemarra-regular">k</span> with the hoe. 

Daf 54b

<span class="gemarra-regular">And if it is not define</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> by its boundaries, up to how much </span>of the field is acquired by one strike of the hoe? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa said: </span>He acquires as far <span class="gemarra-regular">as an ox driver goe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and returns, </span>i.e., the size of a standard furrow, beginning where the hoe entered the ground.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel says: </span>With regard to the <span class="gemarra-regular">property of a gentile </span>that was sold to a Jew for money, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is </span>ownerless <span class="gemarra-regular">like a deser</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> until the purchaser performs an act of acquisition; <span class="gemarra-regular">anyone who takes possession of it </span>in the interim has <span class="gemarra-regular">acquired it</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> What is the reason </span>for this? The <span class="gemarra-regular">gentile relinquishes </span>ownership of it <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the moment <span class="gemarra-regular">when </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">money reaches his hand</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> while the <span class="gemarra-regular">Jew </span>who purchased it <span class="gemarra-regular">does not acquir</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> it <span class="gemarra-regular">until the deed reache</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> his hand. Therefore, </span>in the period of time between the giving of the money and the receiving of the deed, the property <span class="gemarra-regular">is like a desert, and anyone who takes possession of it </span>has <span class="gemarra-regular">acquired it.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said to Rav Yosef: Did Shmuel </span>actually <span class="gemarra-regular">say this? But doesn’t Shmuel say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the law of the kingdom is the law</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> obligates Jews to observe the laws of the locale in which they reside, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the king said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">land may not be acquired without a document? </span>Therefore, taking possession should not be effective for acquisition. Rav Yosef <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: I do not know </span>how to reconcile this contradiction, but <span class="gemarra-regular">there was an incident in </span>the village of <span class="gemarra-regular">Dura that </span>was founded by <span class="gemarra-regular">shepherds</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> where </span>there was <span class="gemarra-regular">a Jew who purchased land from a gentile </span>by giving money, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>in the interim <span class="gemarra-regular">another Jew came </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">plowed it a bit. </span>The two Jews <span class="gemarra-regular">came before Rav Yehuda </span>for a ruling, and he <span class="gemarra-regular">established </span>the property <span class="gemarra-regular">in the possession of the second </span>individual. This accords with the ruling of Shmuel that the property is ownerless until a Jew performs an act of acquisition.
Abaye <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Are you saying </span>that the incident occurred in <span class="gemarra-regular">Dura that </span>was founded by <span class="gemarra-regular">shepherds? </span>Proof cannot be brought from that case, as <span class="gemarra-regular">there </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">fields were concealed</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> since </span>the owners of fields <span class="gemarra-regular">would not pay the land tax [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">taska</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to the king, and the king says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">one who pays land tax </span>may <span class="gemarra-regular">profit </span>from <span class="gemarra-regular">the field. </span>Therefore, in that case, the gentile who sold the property did not actually own it, and consequently by the laws of the kingdom could not sell it. The one who took possession of the property acquired it in accordance with the law of the kingdom, as he committed to pay the land tax. Elsewhere, one would not acquire the field until he received a deed of sale from the gentile.
The Gemara relates: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna purchased land from a gentile. Another Jew came and plowed it slightly. </span>Rav Huna and that Jew <span class="gemarra-regular">came before Rav Naḥman, </span>who <span class="gemarra-regular">established </span>the property <span class="gemarra-regular">in the possession </span>of the latter. Rav Huna <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Rav Naḥman: <span class="gemarra-regular">What are you thinking </span>in issuing this ruling? Is it <span class="gemarra-regular">because Shmuel says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the property of a gentile is like a desert, and anyone who takes possession of it </span>has <span class="gemarra-regular">acquired it? </span>

Daf 55a

If so, <span class="gemarra-regular">the Master should do</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for me in accordance with another </span>statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Shmuel, as Shmuel says </span>that one who hoes ownerless property <span class="gemarra-regular">has acquired only the place that he struck </span>with the hoe. Rav Naḥman <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: In this </span>matter <span class="gemarra-regular">I hold in accordance with our </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, as Rav Huna says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: Once he struck </span>the land with a hoe <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>time, he <span class="gemarra-regular">acquired the entire </span>property.
The Gemara relates that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna bar Avin sent </span>a ruling: In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a Jew who purchased a field from a gentile, and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">another Jew came and took possession of it, it is not removed from </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">possession of </span>the second Jew. <span class="gemarra-regular">And so too, Rabbi Avin, and Rabbi Ile’a, and all of our Rabbis agree with regard to </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">matter.</span>
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba said: These three statements were told to me </span>by <span class="gemarra-regular">Ukvan bar Neḥemya the Exilarc</span><span class="gemarra-regular">h</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in the name of Shmuel: The law of the kingdom is the law; and </span>the term of <span class="gemarra-regular">Persian sharecropping [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">arisuta</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> is for <span class="gemarra-regular">up to forty years, </span>since according to Persian laws the presumption of ownership is established after forty years of use; <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">these tax officials [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">zaharurei</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">who sold land </span>in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>pay the <span class="gemarra-regular">land tax, the sale is valid, </span>as the tax officials were justified in seizing it, and one may purchase the land from them.
The Gemara notes: <span class="gemarra-regular">And this statement </span>applies to land seized <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>pay the <span class="gemarra-regular">land tax, but not </span>to land seized <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>pay the <span class="gemarra-regular">head tax. What is the reason </span>for this? The <span class="gemarra-regular">head tax is placed on a man’s head, </span>i.e., the obligation of this tax is on the individual and is unrelated to his property. It is therefore theft for the tax officials to sell land for this purpose. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, said: </span>Everything, <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">barley in the pitcher, is mortgaged for </span>the payment of the <span class="gemarra-regular">head tax.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi said: Huna bar Natan said to me </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Ameimar raised a difficulty with regard to this </span>statement of Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, you have abolished the inheritance of the firstborn so</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> of one who owes taxes to the kingdom. If everything can be seized by the tax collectors to pay the father’s debt, any property that he left behind <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">a potential </span>inheritance, not actually property of the heirs, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is that <span class="gemarra-regular">the firstborn does not take </span>a double share <span class="gemarra-regular">in a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> potential </span>inheritance <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>he does <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>property that the deceased <span class="gemarra-regular">possessed.</span>
The Gemara continues the statement of Huna bar Natan: And <span class="gemarra-regular">I said to </span>Ameimar: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">so </span>that this presents a difficulty, then <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>if the property can be seized as payment for the <span class="gemarra-regular">land tax </span>this difficulty would present itself <span class="gemarra-regular">as well, </span>as the sons would not inherit their father’s estate in the event that it is seized to pay the land tax. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, what have you to say </span>to deflect this question? That the firstborn son’s right is not negated in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where</span> the father <span class="gemarra-regular">gave </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">land tax and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">died, </span>so that he is no longer indebted to the government and the field is completely his. <span class="gemarra-regular">Here too, </span>the firstborn son maintains his rights in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the father <span class="gemarra-regular">gave </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">head tax and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">died.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi said: Huna bar Natan said to me: I asked </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">scribes </span>who wrote documents and recorded halakhic rulings in the court <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rava, and they said to me </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, </span>who states that one’s possessions are all mortgaged for the payment of the head tax. The Gemara notes: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">is not so, </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">there, </span>Huna bar Natan <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>that in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to buttress his </span>previous <span class="gemarra-regular">statement</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav Ashi said: An idler </span><span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">p</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ardakht</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> must <span class="gemarra-regular">assist the tow</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> by paying taxes even though he has no income in that town. <span class="gemarra-regular">And this matter </span>applies in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where the town saved him </span>from his obligation by asking for a reduction on his behalf. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if the <span class="gemarra-regular">tax collectors [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">andisekei</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> do not seek to collect his debt this <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>regarded as <span class="gemarra-regular">heavenly assistance, </span>and he is not obligated to volunteer to pay his share.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Asi says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: The boundary </span>between fields <span class="gemarra-regular">and the sea squil</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span> that was planted to demarcate the border between fields <span class="gemarra-regular">serve as a barrier </span>between fields <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to the property of a convert </span>who died without heirs, so that one who takes possession of the property acquires land only until the boundary or the sea squill, but not other land the convert had possessed beyond that point. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>they do <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>serve as a barrier between fields <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to the matter of produce in the corner of the field, which is given to the poor </span><span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">pe’a</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and ritual impurity</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and even the area beyond it is considered to be part of the same field. <span class="gemarra-regular">When Ravin came </span>to Babylonia from Eretz Yisrael, he <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>in the name of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan: </span>They serve as a barrier between the fields <span class="gemarra-regular">even with regard to </span>the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of <span class="gemarra-italic">pe’a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and ritual impurity.</span>
The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of <span class="gemarra-italic">pe’a</span> that is affected by determining whether it is one or two fields? <span class="gemarra-regular">As we learned </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Pe’a</span> 2:1): <span class="gemarra-regular">And these serve as a barrier for </span>the purpose of <span class="gemarra-italic">pe’a</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., the presence of any of these divides a field so that each section constitutes a distinct field from which <span class="it-text">pe’a</span> must be given independently: <span class="gemarra-regular">A strea</span><span class="gemarra-regular">m</span> that passes through the field; <span class="gemarra-regular">and a canal</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span> 

Daf 55b

<span class="gemarra-regular">and a public roa</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> that is at least sixteen cubits wide; <span class="gemarra-regular">and a private road </span>that is four cubits wide; <span class="gemarra-regular">and a public trail; and a permanent private trai</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span> that is used <span class="gemarra-regular">whether in the summer or in the rainy season, </span>i.e., winter. Rav Asi and Ravin disagree with regard to whether Rabbi Yoḥanan held that a boundary or sea squill also serves to subdivide a field for the purpose of <span class="it-text">pe’a</span>.
The Gemara further clarifies: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">ritual impurit</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span> that is affected by determining whether an area is one or two fields? <span class="gemarra-regular">As we learned </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Teharot</span> 6:5): With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who enters into a valley during the rainy season</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., winter, when people generally do not enter this area, and therefore for the purpose of this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> it is considered a private domain, and there is a principle that in a case of uncertainty concerning whether one contracted ritual impurity in a private domain he is ritually impure; <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>there was <span class="gemarra-regular">ritual impurity in such and such a field, and </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">said: </span>I know <span class="gemarra-regular">I walked to that place, </span>i.e., I walked in the valley, <span class="gemarra-regular">but I do not know whether I entered that place </span>where the ritual impurity was <span class="gemarra-regular">or whether I did not </span>enter, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Eliezer deems him pur</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and the Rabbis deem him impure.</span>
Rabbi Eliezer deems him pure, <span class="gemarra-regular">as Rabbi Eliezer would say: </span>Concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">uncertainty </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">entry, </span>i.e., it is uncertain whether he entered the area where the ritual impurity is located, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">ritually pure. </span>But if he certainly entered the area where the ritual impurity is located and the <span class="gemarra-regular">uncertainty </span>is with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">contact </span>with <span class="gemarra-regular">ritual impurity, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">ritually impure. </span>It is with regard to this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that Ravin said in the name of Rabbi Yoḥanan that a boundary or sea squill defines these fields as distinct areas.
The Gemara infers, though, that even Ravin holds that a boundary or sea squill serves as a barrier only with regard to <span class="it-text">pe’a</span> and ritual impurity, <span class="gemarra-regular">but with regard to </span>the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">Shabbat, </span>they do <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>serve as a barrier between fields.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava says: </span>They serve as a barrier between fields <span class="gemarra-regular">even with regard to the matter of Shabbat</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: With regard to one who <span class="gemarra-regular">carried out half </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">a dried fi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span> from a private domain <span class="gemarra-regular">into the public domain and placed it </span>there, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">returned and carried out another half </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">a dried fig, </span>if it was done <span class="gemarra-regular">within one lapse of awareness, </span>i.e., he did not remember in the interim that this act is prohibited or that it was Shabbat, the two acts are considered as one, and since the two items together equal the size of a dried fig, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to bring a sin-offering. But if it was done <span class="gemarra-regular">within two lapses </span>of awareness, i.e., after he carried out the first half of a dried fig he remembered that this act is prohibited or that it was Shabbat, but subsequently forgot again and carried out the second half of a dried fig, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt.</span>
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei says: </span>If it was done <span class="gemarra-regular">within one lapse of awareness, </span>

Daf 56a

and <span class="gemarra-regular">in one domain</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., he carried half the dried fig into the same public domain each time, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable, </span>but if it was <span class="gemarra-regular">in two domains, </span>i.e., he carried the item into two separate public domains, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabba says </span>in explanation of Rabbi Yosei’s opinion: <span class="gemarra-regular">And this </span>division of the public domain applies only <span class="gemarra-regular">where there is </span>a property where one would incur <span class="gemarra-regular">liability </span>to bring <span class="gemarra-regular">a sin-offering </span>if one unintentionally carried out of it or into it, i.e., a private domain, <span class="gemarra-regular">between </span>the two sections. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if there was only <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">karmelit</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., an area that is not defined as either a private domain or public domain and to and from which the prohibition against carrying is only of rabbinic origin, it does <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>divide the public domain. <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye says: Even a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">karmelit</span> divides the public domain into separate sections, <span class="gemarra-regular">but a beam </span><span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">p</span><span class="gemarra-italic">isela</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> does <span class="gemarra-regular">not. Rava says: Even a beam </span>divides the public domain, since it is no less than a boundary or sea squill, which do serve as a barrier between fields.
The Gemara notes: <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rava follows his </span>own line of <span class="gemarra-regular">reasoning, as Rava says: </span>The definition of <span class="gemarra-regular">a domain </span>for the purpose of <span class="gemarra-regular">Shabbat is like </span>the definition of <span class="gemarra-regular">a domain </span>for the purpose of <span class="gemarra-regular">bills of divorce</span><span class="gemarra-regular">:</span> Just as a beam is defined as a distinct domain for the purpose of bills of divorce, so too it is considered a distinct domain for the purpose of Shabbat.
The Gemara returns to discuss the acquisition of a field that belonged to a convert who died without heirs. The Gemara asks: If <span class="gemarra-regular">there was no boundar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>there was <span class="gemarra-regular">no sea squill, what </span>are the limits to the acquisition? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Marinus explains in the name </span>of Rabbi Yoḥanan: <span class="gemarra-regular">Any </span>area <span class="gemarra-regular">that is called by his name</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What are the circumstances </span>where it is called by his name? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa said: Where it is called: The place </span>that is irrigated by <span class="gemarra-regular">so-and-so’s well</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> The entire area referred to as such would be considered one section with regard to acquisition.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Aḥa bar Avya sat before Rabbi Asi, and he sat and was saying </span>the following <span class="gemarra-regular">in the name of Rabbi Asi bar Ḥanina: </span>A row of <span class="gemarra-regular">sea squill serves as a barrier with regard to the property of a convert </span>who died without heirs, so that each section is considered a distinct field.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">sea squill? Rav Yehuda says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: </span>It is the growth <span class="gemarra-regular">by which Joshua established the boundaries of Eretz </span>Yisrael <span class="gemarra-regular">for the Jews.</span>
The Gemara teaches a related statement. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav Yehuda says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: </span>In his book, <span class="gemarra-regular">Joshua enumerated only the towns that stand upon the borders, </span>but not the towns that were within the portions of each tribe.
On the subject of the boundaries of Eretz Yisrael, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel says: Any </span>area <span class="gemarra-regular">that the Holy One, Blessed be He, showed to Moses </span>before his death, as it is written: “And the Lord showed him all the land, Gilead…as far as Zoar” (Deuteronomy 34:1–3), is within the boundaries of Eretz Yisrael, and therefore produce that grows there is <span class="gemarra-regular">obligated in tithe.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">To exclude what </span>area? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">To exclude </span>the lands of the <span class="gemarra-regular">Kenite, Kenizzite, and Kadmonite, </span>as God had promised to Abraham at the Covenant between the Pieces: “To your offspring have I given this land…to…the Kenite, and the Kenizzite, and the Kadmonite” (Genesis 15:18–19). These areas are not obligated in tithe. What are these three areas? It <span class="gemarra-regular">is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir says: </span>They are <span class="gemarra-regular">Naftuḥa, Arva’a, and Shalma’a</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rabbi Yehuda says: </span>They are <span class="gemarra-regular">Mount Seir, Ammon, and Moab</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rabbi Shimon says: </span>They are <span class="gemarra-regular">Ardisekis, Asya, and Aspamya</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If <span class="gemarra-regular">there were two </span>witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">testifying on his </span><span class="gemarra-regular">behal</span><span class="gemarra-regular">f </span> <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>he, the possessor of the land, worked and <span class="gemarra-regular">profited </span>from a field for <span class="gemarra-regular">three years, </span>and therefore has presumptive ownership, <span class="gemarra-regular">and they were found </span>to be <span class="gemarra-regular">conspiring </span>witnesses, as it was proven that they were not present to witness the matter about which they had testified, they must <span class="gemarra-regular">pay </span>the true owner of the field <span class="gemarra-regular">the full </span>value of the field that they attempted, through their testimony, to remove from his possession, as it is written in the Torah: “Then shall you do to him, as he had planned to do to his brother” (Deuteronomy 19:19). If <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>witnesses testify that he worked and profited from the field <span class="gemarra-regular">during the first </span>year, another <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>testify that he worked and profited from it <span class="gemarra-regular">during the second </span>year, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>another <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>testify that he worked and profited from it <span class="gemarra-regular">during the third, </span>and all were found to be conspiring witnesses, 

Daf 56b

payment of the value of the field to the owner is <span class="gemarra-regular">divided among them.</span>
If the testimony was given by <span class="gemarra-regular">three brothers</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> each of whom testify about one year, <span class="gemarra-regular">and another </span>unrelated individual <span class="gemarra-regular">joined with </span>each of the brothers as the second witness, <span class="gemarra-regular">these are three </span>distinct <span class="gemarra-regular">testimonies </span>and they are accepted by the court. If they were to be considered one testimony, it would not be accepted, as brothers may not testify together. <span class="gemarra-regular">But they are one testimon</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for </span>the purpose of rendering them as <span class="gemarra-regular">conspiring </span>witnesses, and the payment is divided among them.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara notes: <span class="gemarra-regular">The mishna is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Akiva, as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> (<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span>, 2:10) that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei said: When Abba </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Ḥalafta</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> Rabbi Yosei’s father, <span class="gemarra-regular">went to Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri to study Torah, and some say: </span>When <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri </span>went <span class="gemarra-regular">to Abba Ḥalafta to study Torah, he said to him: What is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> if <span class="gemarra-regular">there is </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">who </span>worked and <span class="gemarra-regular">profited </span>from a field <span class="gemarra-regular">in the presence of two </span>witnesses during the <span class="gemarra-regular">first year, </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">in the presence of two </span>other witnesses during the <span class="gemarra-regular">second </span>year, and finally <span class="gemarra-regular">in the presence of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>other witnesses during the <span class="gemarra-regular">third </span>year? He <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: This is </span>sufficient for establishing the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership.
The latter <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: I say this as well, but Rabbi Akiva disagrees with regard to this matter, as Rabbi Akiva would say </span>that since the verse states: “At the mouth of two witnesses, or at the mouth of three witnesses, shall a matter be established” (Deuteronomy 19:15), one can derive that testimony is accepted only with regard to a complete <span class="gemarra-regular">matter, and not </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">half </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">a matter. </span>In this mishna, although presumptive ownership requires testimony that the property had been worked and profited from for three years, testimony is accepted from each pair of witnesses with regard to one year. Consequently, the ruling of the mishna does not accord with the opinion of Rabbi Akiva.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis, </span>who accept the testimony of each of the three pairs of witnesses, <span class="gemarra-regular">what do they do with this </span>derivation of: A complete <span class="gemarra-regular">matter, and not half </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">a matter, </span>i.e., what type of testimony is disqualified based on this derivation? <span class="gemarra-regular">If we say </span>that it serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to exclude</span> a case where two witnesses testify that a young woman has two pubic hairs and has therefore reached maturity, where <span class="gemarra-regular">one says </span>she has <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>hair <span class="gemarra-regular">on her bac</span><span class="gemarra-regular">k</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and one says </span>she has <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>hair <span class="gemarra-regular">on her </span>lower <span class="gemarra-regular">abdomen</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., they are testifying to two different pubic hairs, and in this case the Rabbis say this testimony is not accepted, since they each testify with regard to only half of the matter, that is difficult. But <span class="gemarra-regular">this is </span>both <span class="gemarra-regular">half </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">a matter and half </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">a testimony, </span>as there is only one witness with regard to each pubic hair. This testimony would not be valid even without the derivation.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>in the opinion of the Rabbis the derivation serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to exclude </span>a case where <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>she has <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>hair <span class="gemarra-regular">on her bac</span><span class="gemarra-regular">k</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and two </span>witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>she has <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>hair <span class="gemarra-regular">on her </span>lower <span class="gemarra-regular">abdomen. </span>In this case, each group of witnesses gives full testimony with regard to half of a matter, i.e., one pubic hair, as both hairs must be present concurrently in order for her to assume the status of an adult. By contrast, in the case of the mishna, the years are by definition not concurrent. Therefore, the Rabbis rule that testimony with regard to one year is accepted.
§ In a related matter, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda says: </span>If two witnesses testify that one had worked and profited from a field for three years, where <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>witness <span class="gemarra-regular">says he consumed wheat </span>from the field, <span class="gemarra-regular">and one says he consumed barley </span>from <span class="gemarra-regular">it, this is </span>sufficient for establishing the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership.<span class="gemarra-regular"> Rav Naḥman objects to this </span>ruling: <span class="gemarra-regular">If that is so, </span>then if <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>witness <span class="gemarra-regular">says </span>he worked and <span class="gemarra-regular">profited </span>from the field during the <span class="gemarra-regular">first, third, and fifth </span>years; <span class="gemarra-regular">and one </span>witness <span class="gemarra-regular">says he </span>worked and <span class="gemarra-regular">profited </span>from <span class="gemarra-regular">it </span>during the <span class="gemarra-regular">second, fourth, and sixth </span>years, would you <span class="gemarra-regular">also </span>say <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>sufficient for establishing the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership? What is the difference between testifying about different crops and testifying about different years?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda said to him: How can </span>these cases <span class="gemarra-regular">be compared? There, </span>i.e., in your example, <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the year </span>about which one <span class="gemarra-regular">Master, </span>i.e., witness, <span class="gemarra-regular">is testifying, </span>the other <span class="gemarra-regular">Master is not testifying </span>about it, while <span class="gemarra-regular">here, both are testifying with regard to one year. What is there to say, </span>that there is a contradiction in their testimonies <span class="gemarra-regular">between wheat and barley</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> It does not enter people’s minds </span>to note this distinction. Two witnesses did, however, testify that he worked and profited from the field for three years.
§ The mishna teaches that if the testimony was given by <span class="gemarra-regular">three brothers, </span>each of whom testified about one year, <span class="gemarra-regular">and another, </span>unrelated individual <span class="gemarra-regular">joined with </span>each of the brothers as the second witness, <span class="gemarra-regular">these are three </span>distinct <span class="gemarra-regular">testimonies </span>and they are accepted by the court. <span class="gemarra-regular">But they are one testimony for</span> the purpose of rendering them as <span class="gemarra-regular">conspiring </span>witnesses. 

Daf 57a

The Gemara relates: There was <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain document that had the signature</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of two </span>individuals <span class="gemarra-regular">on it. One of </span>the signatory witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">died, </span>and when the court sought to ratify the document, which requires either that the witnesses personally attest to the validity of their signatures or that two other witnesses attest to the validity of the signatures, <span class="gemarra-regular">the brother of the </span>witness <span class="gemarra-regular">who remained </span>alive <span class="gemarra-regular">and one other </span>individual <span class="gemarra-regular">came to testify with regard to the signature of the other, </span>deceased, witness, while the living witness attested to his own signature.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Ravina thought to say </span>that this case <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>the same as the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in <span class="gemarra-regular">the mishna, </span>which states that if testimony was given by <span class="gemarra-regular">three brothers, </span>each of whom testify about one year, <span class="gemarra-regular">and another, </span>unrelated individual <span class="gemarra-regular">joined with </span>each of the brothers as the second witness, these are considered to be three distinct testimonies. Similarly, in this case, one brother attests to his own signature, while the other brother attests to the signature of the deceased witness.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi said to him: Are </span>these cases <span class="gemarra-regular">comparable? There, the property less one-quarter, </span>i.e., three-quarters of the property in question, <span class="gemarra-regular">is not removed </span>from the possession of the prior owner based <span class="gemarra-regular">upon the mouth, </span>i.e., the testimony, <span class="gemarra-regular">of brothers. </span>Each brother provides only half of the testimony for each year about which he testifies. <span class="gemarra-regular">Here, the property less one-quarter </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is removed </span>from the possession of the debtor detailed in the document based <span class="gemarra-regular">upon the mouth of brothers. </span>One brother attests to his own signature, which constitutes half of the testimony, while the other signature is authenticated by the testimony of the other brother and another individual. It follows that three-quarters of the testimony is given by brothers, and it is therefore invalid.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">These are </span>uses of property <span class="gemarra-regular">that have </span>the means to establish the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership,<span class="gemarra-regular"> and these are </span>uses of property <span class="gemarra-regular">that do not have </span>the means to establish the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership: If one <span class="gemarra-regular">would </span><span class="gemarra-regular">stan</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">an </span><span class="gemarra-regular">anima</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">in a courtyard; </span>or if one would place <span class="gemarra-regular">an </span><span class="gemarra-regular">oven</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">a millstone, or a stove </span>there; <span class="gemarra-regular">or </span>if one <span class="gemarra-regular">raises chickens </span>in a courtyard, <span class="gemarra-regular">or places his fertilizer in a courtyard, </span>these actions <span class="gemarra-regular">are not </span>sufficient to establish the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership.<span class="gemarra-regular"> But </span>if one <span class="gemarra-regular">constructed a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">partitio</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">ten handbreadths high to </span>contain <span class="gemarra-regular">his animal, and similarly </span>if he constructed a partition <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">oven, and similarly </span>if he constructed a partition <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">stove, and similarly </span>if he constructed a partition <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">millstone; </span>or if one <span class="gemarra-regular">brought chickens into the house, or </span>if he <span class="gemarra-regular">fashioned a place </span>in the ground <span class="gemarra-regular">for his fertilizer </span>that is <span class="gemarra-regular">three </span>handbreadths <span class="gemarra-regular">deep or three </span>handbreadths <span class="gemarra-regular">high, </span>these actions <span class="gemarra-regular">are </span>sufficient to establish the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of ownership.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is different </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">the first clause, </span>where having an animal stand in a courtyard is insufficient to establish the presumption of ownership, <span class="gemarra-regular">and what is different </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">the latter clause, </span>where constructing a partition is sufficient to establish the presumption of ownership?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Ulla says: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">any </span>act <span class="gemarra-regular">which, if </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">were </span>to perform it <span class="gemarra-regular">on </span>ownerless property such as the <span class="gemarra-regular">property of a convert </span>who dies without heirs he would <span class="gemarra-regular">acquir</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> that property, that same act is sufficient for him to <span class="gemarra-regular">acquire the property of another </span>if he performed it over the course of three years, provided it is accompanied by the claim that the property had been purchased. Conversely, <span class="gemarra-regular">any </span>act <span class="gemarra-regular">that if </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">were </span>to perform it <span class="gemarra-regular">on </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">property of a convert </span>who died without heirs he would <span class="gemarra-regular">not acquire </span>that property, that same act is sufficient for him to <span class="gemarra-regular">acquire the property of another. </span>Taking possession of ownerless property requires an act to be done with regard to the property itself, such as constructing a partition, but merely having an animal stand there is not sufficient. Therefore, it does not establish the presumption of ownership.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Sheshet objects to this </span>explanation: <span class="gemarra-regular">And is </span>this an established <span class="gemarra-regular">principle? But there is plowing</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> which, </span>if performed <span class="gemarra-regular">on </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">property of a convert </span>who died without heirs one <span class="gemarra-regular">acquires </span>it, but if performed <span class="gemarra-regular">on </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">property of another </span>one does <span class="gemarra-regular">not acquire </span>it. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>additionally, <span class="gemarra-regular">there is consumption of produce </span>for the duration of three years, <span class="gemarra-regular">which, </span>if performed <span class="gemarra-regular">on </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">property of another </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">acquires</span> it by establishing the presumption of ownership, but if performed <span class="gemarra-regular">on </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">property of a convert</span> who died without heirs one does <span class="gemarra-regular">not acquire </span>it. These cases contradict Ulla’s claim that the modes of acquisition are analogous.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Rav Naḥman said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba bar Avuh said: </span>

Daf 57b

<span class="gemarra-regular">Here we are dealing with a courtyard belonging to partners</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> where they are not particular with regard to the mere placing </span>of items in the courtyard, but <span class="gemarra-regular">are particular with regard to </span>the construction of <span class="gemarra-regular">a partition. </span>The presumption of ownership is established only where the lack of a protest indicates that the prior owner concedes that the property is no longer his. The co-owner’s silence in the face of his partner using the courtyard for a temporary purpose does not indicate a concession, but silence in the face of one who constructed a partition is a concession.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And are </span>they <span class="gemarra-regular">not particular with regard to the mere placing </span>of items? <span class="gemarra-regular">But didn’t we learn </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Nedarim</span> 45b): <span class="gemarra-regular">Partners who through vows prohibited </span>themselves <span class="gemarra-regular">from deriving benefi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from one another are forbidden to enter into a courtyard </span>jointly owned by them, since each one has a portion in it, and it would be considered a violation of one’s vow if one were to benefit from any part of the other’s property? This indicates that partners are particular even with regard to passage through the field; all the more so are they particular with regard to placing animals or vessels in the field.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Rav Naḥman said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba bar Avuh said: Here we are dealing with </span>a fenced-in <span class="gemarra-regular">yard </span>located <span class="gemarra-regular">behind </span>a group of <span class="gemarra-regular">house</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> that is used to store items not in regular use, <span class="gemarra-regular">where they are not par-ticular with regard to the mere placing </span>of items <span class="gemarra-regular">but are particular with regard to </span>the construction of <span class="gemarra-regular">a partition.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa said: This and that, </span>i.e., the rulings of the mishna in tractate <span class="it-text">Nedarim</span> as well as the rulings of the mishna here, are stated <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a courtyard belonging to partners, and </span>the reason for the difference in the rulings is that <span class="gemarra-regular">there are those who are particular </span>with regard to the other partner placing items in or passing through the courtyard, <span class="gemarra-regular">and there are those who are not particular. </span>Therefore, in the mishna here, which issues a ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">concerning monetary matters, </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">to</span> be <span class="gemarra-regular">lenient</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and it is assumed that the partner is not particular about placing items in the courtyard, and the presumption of ownership is established. In the mishna in tractate <span class="it-text">Nedarim</span>, which issues a ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">concerning ritual matters, </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>be <span class="gemarra-regular">stringent, </span>to prevent one from violating a vow.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Ravina said: Actually, </span>partners <span class="gemarra-regular">are not particular </span>about placing items in the courtyard, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>in accordance with <span class="gemarra-regular">whose </span>opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">is this </span>mishna in tractate <span class="it-text">Nedarim</span>? <span class="gemarra-regular">It is </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Eliezer, as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Eliezer says: Even </span>negligible benefits ordinarily <span class="gemarra-regular">waived </span>are <span class="gemarra-regular">forbidden in </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one prohibited by a vow from deriving benefit </span>from another. In other words, one prohibited by a vow may not derive any benefit from the other, even a benefit that people commonly are not particular about and allow others to enjoy without first receiving permission. Therefore, although people are ordinarily not particular about others passing through their property, according to the opinion of Rabbi Eliezer, one who is prohibited by a vow from deriving benefit from his partner is prohibited from walking on the property.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says in the name of Rabbi Bena’a</span><span class="gemarra-regular">:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Partners may prevent each other </span>from using their courtyard <span class="gemarra-regular">for any </span>purpose <span class="gemarra-regular">except for </span>washing <span class="gemarra-regular">laundry</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> This is <span class="gemarra-regular">because it is not the way of Jewish women to be degraded over </span>washing <span class="gemarra-regular">laundry </span>by laundering their clothing in a public area. Therefore, they must be allowed to launder in the courtyard.
In connection with the matter of laundry being washed in public, the Gemara quotes the homiletic interpretation of a verse: “He that walks righteously, and speaks uprightly; he that despises the gain of oppressions, that shakes his hands from holding of bribes, that stops his ears from hearing of blood, <span class="gemarra-regular">and shuts his eyes from looking upon evil”</span> (Isaiah 33:15). <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba says: This </span>is referring to one <span class="gemarra-regular">who does not gaze at wome</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">while they are standing over the laundry, </span>as it was common for them to stand in the water and raise the hems of their garments while laundering their clothing.
The Gemara clarifies: <span class="gemarra-regular">What are the circumstances? If </span>it is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where there is another way </span>by which the one walking could reach his destination, then one who walks past the women, consequently placing himself in a situation where he will be tempted to gaze at them, <span class="gemarra-regular">is wicked. </span>Alternatively, <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>it is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where there is no other way </span>by which he can reach his destination, then <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">a victim of circumstance, </span>so why is he required to shut his eyes? The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">Actually, </span>it is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where there is no other way </span>by which he can reach his destination, <span class="gemarra-regular">and even so, he is required to compel himself </span>to avoid gazing at the women.
§ The Gemara quotes additional matters that Rabbi Yoḥanan learned from Rabbi Bena’a. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan asked Rabbi Bena’a: How </span>should <span class="gemarra-regular">the garment of a Torah schola</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> worn under his clothes be fashioned? He replied: He can wear <span class="gemarra-regular">any </span>garment long enough <span class="gemarra-regular">that his flesh is not visible from beneath it</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Rabbi Yoḥanan asked: <span class="gemarra-regular">How </span>should <span class="gemarra-regular">the cloak of a Torah scholar </span>be fashioned? He replied: He can wear <span class="gemarra-regular">any </span>garment long enough <span class="gemarra-regular">that a handbreadth of his garment </span>worn under his clothes <span class="gemarra-regular">is not visible from beneath it. </span>Rabbi Yoḥanan asked: <span class="gemarra-regular">How </span>should <span class="gemarra-regular">the table of a Torah schola</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> appear? He replied: <span class="gemarra-regular">Two-thirds </span>of the table is covered with <span class="gemarra-regular">a cloth</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and one-third </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">uncovered, and upon </span>that third are <span class="gemarra-regular">dishes and vegetables. And its ring</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> used to hang the table, should be positioned <span class="gemarra-regular">on the outside, </span>not on the side that faces the one who is eating.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t it taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">its ring </span>should be positioned <span class="gemarra-regular">on the inside? </span>The Gemara answers: This is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult. This </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span>, which states that its ring should be positioned on the outside, is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where there is a child </span>who may play with the ring and overturn the table, while <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span>, which states that its ring should be positioned on the inside, is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where there is no child </span>present.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if you wish, say </span>instead that both <span class="gemarra-regular">this and that </span>refer to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where there is no child </span>present, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>this is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult: This </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span>, which states that its ring should be positioned on the inside, is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where there is an attendant </span>who may bump into the ring, while <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span>, which states that its ring should be positioned on the outside, is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where there is no attendant.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if you wish, say </span>instead that both <span class="gemarra-regular">this and that </span>refer to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where there is an attendant, and </span>this is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult: This </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span>, which states that its ring should be positioned on the outside, is referring to when the meal is eaten <span class="gemarra-regular">during the day, </span>when the attendant can see the ring and avoid it, while <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span>, which states that its ring should be positioned on the inside, is referring to when the meal is eaten <span class="gemarra-regular">during the night.</span>
The Gemara continues: All of the above is referring to the table of a Torah scholar, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>the table <span class="gemarra-regular">of an ignoramus is similar</span>

<span class="gemarra-regular">to a bonfire, </span>where the fire is in the center <span class="gemarra-regular">and pots surround it. </span>Similarly, the table of an ignoramus is arranged with the food in the center and is surrounded by plates.
Rabbi Yoḥanan asked: <span class="gemarra-regular">How </span>should <span class="gemarra-regular">the bed of Torah scholars </span>be kept? He replied: It is acceptable <span class="gemarra-regular">as long as there </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">nothing except sandal</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> beneath it during the summer, and shoes </span>beneath it <span class="gemarra-regular">during the rainy season, </span>i.e., winter. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the bed <span class="gemarra-regular">of an ignoramus </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">similar to a cluttered [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">balus</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> storehouse</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as he keeps a wide array of items beneath it.
§ Having mentioned Rabbi Bena’a, the Gemara relates an incident in which he was involved. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Bena’a was marking </span>burial <span class="gemarra-regular">caves </span>for the purpose of helping to prevent the contracting of ritual impurity. <span class="gemarra-regular">When he arrived at the cave of Abraham, </span>i.e., the Cave of Machpelah, <span class="gemarra-regular">he encountered Eliezer</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the <span class="gemarra-regular">servant </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">Abraham, who was standing before the entrance. </span>Rabbi Bena’a <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: What is Abraham doing </span>at this moment? Eliezer <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>He is <span class="gemarra-regular">lying in the arms of Sarah, and she is examining his head.</span>
Rabbi Bena’a <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Go tell him </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Bena’a is standing at the entrance, </span>so that he should assume an appropriate position to receive a visitor. Eliezer <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Let </span>him, i.e., Rabbi Bena’a, <span class="gemarra-regular">enter, </span>since <span class="gemarra-regular">it is known that there is no </span>evil <span class="gemarra-regular">inclination in this </span>higher <span class="gemarra-regular">world, </span>so it is not inappropriate for Rabbi Bena’a to see Abraham and Sarah in this position. He <span class="gemarra-regular">entered, examined </span>the cave in order to measure it, <span class="gemarra-regular">and exited.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">When he arrived at the cave of Adam the first </span>man, who is buried in the same area, <span class="gemarra-regular">a Divine Voice emerged and said: You gazed upon the likeness of My image</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., Abraham, who is similar to the image of Adam the first man. <span class="gemarra-regular">Do not gaze upon My image itself, </span>i.e., Adam the first man, about whom the verse states that he was formed in the image of God (see Genesis 1:27). Rabbi Bena’a said: <span class="gemarra-regular">But I need to mark the cave. </span>The voice said to him: <span class="gemarra-regular">As </span>the measurements of the <span class="gemarra-regular">dimensions of the outer </span>cave where Abraham is buried, <span class="gemarra-regular">so </span>are the measurements of the <span class="gemarra-regular">dimensions of the inner </span>cave, where Adam is buried. The Gemara notes: <span class="gemarra-regular">And according to the one who says </span>that the Cave of Machpelah consists of <span class="gemarra-regular">two chambers, this </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">above that </span>one, not two adjacent chambers, the voice said: <span class="gemarra-regular">As </span>the measurements of the <span class="gemarra-regular">dimensions of the upper </span>cave where Abraham is buried, <span class="gemarra-regular">so </span>are the measurements of the <span class="gemarra-regular">dimensions of the lower </span>cave. Therefore, there is no need to measure it.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Bena’a says: I gazed at his, </span>Adam’s, <span class="gemarra-regular">two heels, and </span>they shone so brightly that <span class="gemarra-regular">they are similar to two suns</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Along these lines, the Gemara states that <span class="gemarra-regular">all </span>people <span class="gemarra-regular">compared to Sarah </span>are <span class="gemarra-regular">like a monkey compared to a human, </span>as Sarah was exceedingly beautiful; <span class="gemarra-regular">Sarah compared to Eve </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">like a monkey compared to a human; Eve compared to Adam </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">like a monkey compared to a human; </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">Adam compared to the Divine Presence </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">like a monkey compared to a human.</span>
It was also stated that <span class="gemarra-regular">the beauty of Rav Kahana is a semblance of the beauty of Rav. The beauty of Rav is a semblance of the beauty of Rabbi Abbahu. The beauty of Rabbi Abbahu is a semblance of the beauty of Jacob our forefather. The beauty of Jacob our forefather is a semblance of the beauty of Adam the first </span>man.
On the topic of burial caves, the Gemara relates that there was <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain magus [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">amgusha</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> who was rummaging </span>through the graves of the <span class="gemarra-regular">dead</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> When </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">arrived at the </span>burial <span class="gemarra-regular">cave of Rav Tovi bar Mattana, </span>Rav Tovi <span class="gemarra-regular">grabbed him by his beard </span>and would not release him. <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye came and said to </span>Rav Tovi: <span class="gemarra-regular">I beg of you </span>to <span class="gemarra-regular">release him. </span>The magus <span class="gemarra-regular">came again in another year, </span>and Rav Tovi <span class="gemarra-regular">grabbed him by his beard. Abaye came </span>and requested that he release him, but Rav Tovi <span class="gemarra-regular">did not release him, until </span>Abaye <span class="gemarra-regular">brought a scissors and cut his beard.</span>
§ The Gemara relates additional incidents involving Rabbi Bena’a: There was <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain </span>individual <span class="gemarra-regular">who said to </span>his family before he died: <span class="gemarra-regular">A barrel of earth to one of my sons, a barrel of bones to one of my sons, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">a barrel of wads </span>of wool <span class="gemarra-regular">to one of my sons. They did not know what he was saying to them. They came before Rabbi Bena’a </span>for guidance. Rabbi Bena’a <span class="gemarra-regular">said to them: Do you have land </span>that your father left as an inheritance? <span class="gemarra-regular">They said to him: Yes. </span>He asked: <span class="gemarra-regular">Do you have livestock </span>that your father left as an inheritance? They said: <span class="gemarra-regular">Yes. </span>He asked: <span class="gemarra-regular">Do you have quilts [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">bistarkei</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> that your father left as an inheritance? They said: <span class="gemarra-regular">Yes. </span>He said to them: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, this is what he said to you, </span>i.e., he meant that he is bequeathing land to one son, livestock to the second, and quilts to the third.
There was <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain man who heard his wife saying to her daughter: Why do you not act clandestinely </span>when you engage <span class="gemarra-regular">in forbidden </span>sexual intercourse? <span class="gemarra-regular">That woman has, </span>i.e., I have, <span class="gemarra-regular">ten sons, and I have only one from your father, </span>and no one knows. So too, you must be careful so that no one will discover your illicit behavior. <span class="gemarra-regular">They did not know </span>to <span class="gemarra-regular">which of them </span>he intended to leave his property. <span class="gemarra-regular">They came before Rabbi Bena’a </span>for guidance, and <span class="gemarra-regular">he said to </span>the sons: <span class="gemarra-regular">Go strike your father’s grave, until he rises and reveals to you to which of you he left </span>his property. <span class="gemarra-regular">They all went, </span>but <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">who was his son did not go. </span>Rabbi Bena’a <span class="gemarra-regular">said to them: All of </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">property belongs </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to this </span>son who did not go. The king’s guards <span class="gemarra-regular">brought </span>Rabbi Bena’a <span class="gemarra-regular">and imprisoned him.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">The wife of </span>Rabbi Bena’a <span class="gemarra-regular">went </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>the guards: <span class="gemarra-regular">I had one servant. They cut off his head, and skinned him and ate his flesh, and they fill him with water and </span>give their <span class="gemarra-regular">friends to drink from him, and they have not paid me </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">value nor have they rented him.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">They did not know what she was saying to them. They said: Let us bring the wise </span>man <span class="gemarra-regular">of the Jews, and let him say </span>what she meant. <span class="gemarra-regular">They called Rabbi Bena’a, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">he said to them: She spoke to you of a water skin [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">zarnuka</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> In other words, she was referring to a goat she owned that was slaughtered, its meat eaten, and its skin made into a water skin that could be filled with drinking water. <span class="gemarra-regular">They said: Since </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">so wise, let </span>him <span class="gemarra-regular">sit at the gate </span>where the judges congregate <span class="gemarra-regular">and render judgment.</span>
Rabbi Bena’a <span class="gemarra-regular">saw that it was written upon the gate [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">be’abbula</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Any judge who is summoned to judgment is not considered a judge, </span>as judges must be above reproach. <span class="gemarra-regular">He said to them: If that is so, </span>then if <span class="gemarra-regular">a person comes from elsewhere</span>

<span class="gemarra-regular">and summons </span>a judge <span class="gemarra-regular">to judgment, </span>has he <span class="gemarra-regular">disqualified </span>the judge even if he were later to be exonerated? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>it should say: <span class="gemarra-regular">Any judge who is summoned to judgment and money is lawfully taken from him</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., he was ordered to return someone’s property, <span class="gemarra-regular">is not considered a judge. </span>When they heard this, <span class="gemarra-regular">they wrote this </span>addendum to the original inscription: <span class="gemarra-regular">But the elders of the Jews say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">any judge who is summoned to judgment and money is lawfully taken from him is not considered a judge.</span>
Rabbi Bena’a also <span class="gemarra-regular">saw that it was written </span>there: <span class="gemarra-regular">At the head </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">all death am I, blood, </span>i.e., people die from an excess of blood; <span class="gemarra-regular">at the head </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">all life am I, wine, </span>i.e., wine is what gives life. He said to them: <span class="gemarra-regular">If that is so, </span>in the case of someone <span class="gemarra-regular">who falls from a roof and dies, or</span> someone <span class="gemarra-regular">who falls from a palm tree and dies, </span>was it <span class="gemarra-regular">blood </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">killed him? And furthermore, </span>concerning someone <span class="gemarra-regular">who is on the way to death, can they give him a drink of wine and </span>he will <span class="gemarra-regular">live? Rather, this </span>is what <span class="gemarra-regular">should be written: At the head of all illness am I, blood; at the head of all healing am I, wine. </span>When they heard this, <span class="gemarra-regular">they wrote this </span>addendum to the original inscription: <span class="gemarra-regular">But the elders of the Jews say: At the head of all illness am I, blood; at the head of all healing am I, wine. In a place where there is no wine, herbs are required there </span>as medicines.
