Having related that incident, the Gemara notes that <span class="gemarra-regular">at the entrance of Kapotekiyy</span><span class="gemarra-regular">a</span> it was <span class="gemarra-regular">written: </span><span class="gemarra-italic">Anpak</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span><span class="gemarra-italic">anbag</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">antal</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>which are all names for the same measurement. <span class="gemarra-regular">And what is </span><span class="gemarra-italic">antal</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? It is </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">quarter</span>-<span class="it-text">lo</span><span class="it-text">g</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">Torah.</span>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">spou</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> protruding from one’s roof gutter draining water into another’s property, its owner <span class="gemarra-regular">has no </span>means to establish <span class="gemarra-regular">an acquired privilege for its </span>use, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>he does <span class="gemarra-regular">have </span>the means to establish <span class="gemarra-regular">an acquired </span><span class="gemarra-regular">privileg</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to its place, </span>as the Gemara will explain. With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a gutter </span><span class="gemarra-regular">pip</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> that traverses the length of the roof, one does <span class="gemarra-regular">have </span>the means to establish <span class="gemarra-regular">an acquired privilege for its </span>use.
With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">an Egyptian ladder</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> which is small and portable, one <span class="gemarra-regular">has no </span>means to establish <span class="gemarra-regular">an acquired privilege for its </span>use. <span class="gemarra-regular">But with regard to a Tyrian </span>ladder, which is large and fixed in place, one does <span class="gemarra-regular">have </span>the means to establish <span class="gemarra-regular">an acquired privilege for its </span>use.
With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">an Egyptian window</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> one <span class="gemarra-regular">has no </span>means to establish <span class="gemarra-regular">an acquired privilege for its </span>use; <span class="gemarra-regular">but with regard to a Tyrian </span>window, one does <span class="gemarra-regular">have </span>the means to establish <span class="gemarra-regular">an acquired privilege for its </span>use. <span class="gemarra-regular">What is </span>the defining feature of <span class="gemarra-regular">an Egyptian window? </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">any </span>window that is so small <span class="gemarra-regular">that a person’s head is not able to fit inside it. Rabbi Yehuda says: If </span>a window <span class="gemarra-regular">has a frame, even though a person’s head is not able to fit inside it, </span>one does <span class="gemarra-regular">have </span>the means to establish <span class="gemarra-regular">an acquired privilege for its </span>use.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is the meaning of the mishna’s statement: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a spout, </span>its owner <span class="gemarra-regular">has no </span>means to establish <span class="gemarra-regular">an acquired privilege for its </span>use, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>he does <span class="gemarra-regular">have </span>the means to establish <span class="gemarra-regular">an acquired privilege with regard to its place? Rav Yehuda said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel said: This </span>is what it <span class="gemarra-regular">is saying: </span>Concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">a spout, </span>its owner <span class="gemarra-regular">has no </span>means to establish <span class="gemarra-regular">an acquired privilege for its </span>use <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to one </span><span class="gemarra-regular">side</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., the owner of the field below has the right to move the spout from one place to another on one side of the roof, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>he does <span class="gemarra-regular">have </span>the means to establish <span class="gemarra-regular">an acquired privilege </span><span class="gemarra-regular">concerning its place with regard to two sides, </span>i.e., the owner of the field below does not have the right to move it to another side of the roof.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ḥanina said </span>there is a different explanation: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a spout, </span>its owner <span class="gemarra-regular">has no </span>means to establish <span class="gemarra-regular">an acquired privilege for its </span>size, <span class="gemarra-regular">as if it was long, </span>the owner of the field below may <span class="gemarra-regular">shorten it, but </span>one does <span class="gemarra-regular">have </span>the means to establish <span class="gemarra-regular">an</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> acquired privilege with regard to its place, as if </span>the owner of the field below <span class="gemarra-regular">comes to remove it </span>entirely, <span class="gemarra-regular">he may not remove it.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yirmeya bar Abba said </span>there is a different explanation: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a spout, </span>its owner <span class="gemarra-regular">has no </span>means to establish <span class="gemarra-regular">an acquired privilege for its </span>use, <span class="gemarra-regular">as if </span>the owner of the field below <span class="gemarra-regular">wishes to buil</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> beneath it</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> he may <span class="gemarra-regular">build, </span>and the owner of the spout may not prevent him from doing so; <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>one does <span class="gemarra-regular">have </span>the means to establish <span class="gemarra-regular">an</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> acquired privilege with regard to its place, as if </span>the owner of the field below <span class="gemarra-regular">comes to remove i</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> entirely, <span class="gemarra-regular">he may not remove it. </span>

Daf 59a

<span class="gemarra-regular">We learned </span>in the mishna: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a gutter pipe, </span>one does <span class="gemarra-regular">have </span>the means to establish <span class="gemarra-regular">an acquired privilege for its </span>use. <span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, according to the one who says those </span>first <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>explanations, i.e., Shmuel and Rabbi Ḥanina, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">well. </span>The distinction between the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to a spout and that of a gutter pipe is clear: Since the gutter pipe is fixed in place, there is an acquired privilege, and it may not be moved or shortened.
<span class="gemarra-regular">But according to </span>Rav Yirmeya bar Abba, <span class="gemarra-regular">the one who says </span>that the mishna means: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>the owner of the field <span class="gemarra-regular">wishes to build beneath it </span>he may <span class="gemarra-regular">build, what difference does it make to </span>the owner of the gutter pipe if the owner of the field builds beneath it? Why would he have the right to prevent it?
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Here we are dealing with a gutter pipe </span>that is made of stone and is built into the walls <span class="gemarra-regular">of</span> the <span class="gemarra-regular">building, </span>in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the owner of the gutter pipe <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>the owner of the field: <span class="gemarra-regular">It is not amenable to me </span>that you build beneath my gutter pipe, <span class="gemarra-regular">as my walls will weaken </span>as a result.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel says: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a pipe </span>from <span class="gemarra-regular">which water is drainin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> into another’s courtyard and the owner of the roof comes to seal </span>his drainage pipe, <span class="gemarra-regular">the owner of the courtyard can prevent him </span>from doing so. <span class="gemarra-regular">As </span>the owner of the field can <span class="gemarra-regular">say to him: Just as you have acquired my courtyard for </span>the purpose of <span class="gemarra-regular">throwing your water into it, I have also acquired the water of your roof, </span>and since I wish to use it, you may not seal the pipe.
It <span class="gemarra-regular">was stated </span>that there is a dispute with regard to this issue, as <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Oshaya says: </span>The owner of the courtyard <span class="gemarra-regular">can prevent </span>the owner of the roof from sealing the pipe, while <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ḥama, </span>Rabbi Oshaya’s father, <span class="gemarra-regular">says: He cannot prevent </span>it. Rabbi Oshaya <span class="gemarra-regular">went </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">asked </span>Rabbi Ḥama’s father, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Bisa</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Rabbi Bisa <span class="gemarra-regular">said to them: </span>He <span class="gemarra-regular">can prevent </span>it. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rami bar Ḥama read </span>the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">about </span>him: “And if a man prevail against him that is alone, two shall withstand him; <span class="gemarra-regular">and a threefold cord is not quickly broken” </span>(Ecclesiastes 4:12), saying that <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>applies to <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Oshaya, son of Rabbi Ḥama, son of Rabbi Bisa, </span>three generations of Torah scholars in one family who knew one another and conversed with each other with regard to matters of <span class="it-text">halakha</span>.
§ The mishna teaches that with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">an Egyptian ladder, </span>which is small and portable, one <span class="gemarra-regular">has no </span>means to establish <span class="gemarra-regular">an acquired privilege for its </span>use. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is an Egyptian ladder like? </span>The members <span class="gemarra-regular">of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the school of Rabbi Yannai say: It </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">any </span>ladder that <span class="gemarra-regular">does not have four rungs.</span>
The mishna teaches that with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">an Egyptian</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> window, </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">has no </span>means to establish <span class="gemarra-regular">an acquired privilege for its </span>use. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is different with regard to </span>an Egyptian <span class="gemarra-regular">ladder, that </span>the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">does not explain </span>what it is, <span class="gemarra-regular">and what is different with regard to </span>an Egyptian <span class="gemarra-regular">window, that </span>the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">does explain </span>what it is? The Gemara answers: It was necessary for the mishna to state the definition of an Egyptian window according to the unattributed opinion of the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">wants to </span>cite the <span class="gemarra-regular">dissenting </span>opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda in the latter clause.</span>
With regard to windows, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Zeira says: </span>If one built a large window at a height that is <span class="gemarra-regular">lower than four cubit</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> from the ground, he <span class="gemarra-regular">has </span>the means to establish <span class="gemarra-regular">an acquired privilege for its </span>use, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>therefore, his neighbor <span class="gemarra-regular">can protest </span>the initial construction of the window. If one built a large window at a height that is <span class="gemarra-regular">above four cubits </span>from the ground, he <span class="gemarra-regular">has no </span>means to establish <span class="gemarra-regular">an acquired privilege for its </span>use, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>therefore his neighbor <span class="gemarra-regular">cannot protest </span>its construction. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Ile’a says: Even </span>if it is built at a height that is <span class="gemarra-regular">above four cubit</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> from the ground, he <span class="gemarra-regular">has no </span>means to establish <span class="gemarra-regular">an acquired privilege for its </span>use, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>nevertheless, his neighbor <span class="gemarra-regular">can protest </span>its construction.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Shall we say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">they disagree with regard to </span>whether there is <span class="gemarra-regular">coercion concerning conduct </span>characteristic <span class="gemarra-regular">of Sodom</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> Perhaps their dispute is with regard to a circumstance where one will not suffer any loss while another gains some benefit, and the former desires to prevent the latter from gaining the benefit, if the former is coerced into not being evil without reason and consequently allows the latter to derive the benefit, counter to the behavior of the residents of Sodom. One <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage, </span>Rabbi Zeira, <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that there is <span class="gemarra-regular">coercion, </span>and therefore the neighbor who does not suffer any damage from a high window cannot protest, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage, </span>Rabbi Ile’a, <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that there is <span class="gemarra-regular">no coercion.</span>
The Gemara rejects this: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, everyone </span>agrees that there is <span class="gemarra-regular">coercion </span>concerning conduct characteristic of Sodom, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">is different here, </span>as according to the opinion of Rabbi Ile’a this is not conduct characteristic of Sodom, <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>the neighbor can <span class="gemarra-regular">say to </span>the one who constructed the window: There are <span class="gemarra-regular">times when you place a benc</span><span class="gemarra-regular">h</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> beneath yourself, and </span>you <span class="gemarra-regular">stand and see </span>into my home. Therefore, I can protest. The Gemara relates that there was <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain </span>individual <span class="gemarra-regular">who came before Rabbi Ami </span>and presented this precise scenario. Rabbi Ami <span class="gemarra-regular">sent him before Rabbi Abba bar Memel </span>to ask for a ruling. Rabbi Abba bar Memel <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Act in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ile’a.</span>
Since the mishna cited a dispute with regard to the conditions under which an owner has acquired the privilege to use a window, the Gemara teaches that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel says: And </span>if a window was built <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>the purpose of enabling <span class="gemarra-regular">light </span>to enter a dark room, then the owner of the window <span class="gemarra-regular">has </span>the means to establish <span class="gemarra-regular">an acquired privilege for its </span>use, <span class="gemarra-regular">whatever </span>size <span class="gemarra-regular">it is</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> not only if it is a large window. And if the neighbor did not protest its construction, he cannot subsequently force the owner of the window to seal it.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a projection </span>emerging from the wall of one’s house, overhanging a courtyard, one <span class="gemarra-regular">has </span>the means to establish <span class="gemarra-regular">an acquired privilege for its </span>use if it protrudes at least <span class="gemarra-regular">as far as a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">handbreadth</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> 

Daf 59b

<span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the owner of the courtyard <span class="gemarra-regular">can protest </span>its construction. If it protrudes <span class="gemarra-regular">less than a handbreadth, </span>the owner of the house <span class="gemarra-regular">has no </span>means to establish <span class="gemarra-regular">an acquired privilege for its </span>use, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the owner of the courtyard <span class="gemarra-regular">cannot protest </span>its construction.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Asi says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Mani says, and some say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ya’akov says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Mani says: </span>If one <span class="gemarra-regular">established an acquired privilege with regard to</span> a projection of <span class="gemarra-regular">a handbreadth, </span>he has <span class="gemarra-regular">established an acquired privilege with regard to four </span>handbreadths. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is he saying? Abaye said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>is what he <span class="gemarra-regular">is saying: </span>If one <span class="gemarra-regular">established an acquired privilege </span>with regard to a projection that measures <span class="gemarra-regular">one handbreadth wide by four </span>handbreadths <span class="gemarra-regular">long</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> he has <span class="gemarra-regular">established an acquired privilege with regard to </span>extending the projection to <span class="gemarra-regular">a width </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">four </span>handbreadths.
The mishna teaches that if the projection protrudes <span class="gemarra-regular">less than a handbreadth </span>the owner of the house <span class="gemarra-regular">has no </span>means to establish <span class="gemarra-regular">an acquired privilege for its</span> use, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the owner of the courtyard <span class="gemarra-regular">cannot protest. Rav Huna says: They taught only </span>that the <span class="gemarra-regular">owner of the roof </span>cannot protest the actions <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">owner of the courtyard, </span>i.e., he may not demand that the owner of the courtyard refrain from construction that interferes with the former’s use of the projection. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">owner of the courtyar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> can protest </span>the actions <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">owner of the roof, </span>and demand that the latter not build a projection of any size, even less than a handbreadth. He can also demand that the owner of the roof not use an existing projection, since it leads to damage caused by sight. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav Yehuda says: Even </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">owner of the courtyard cannot protest </span>the actions <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">owner of the roof.</span>
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Shall we say that </span>they <span class="gemarra-regular">disagree with regard to damage </span>caused by <span class="gemarra-regular">sight? As </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage, </span>Rav Huna, <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">it is considered </span>to be <span class="gemarra-regular">damage, </span>and therefore the owner of the courtyard can protest, since the owner of the roof has the means to see into the other’s courtyard when using this projection, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage, </span>Rav Yehuda, <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">it is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not considered </span>to be <span class="gemarra-regular">damage.</span>
The Gemara rejects this: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, everyone </span>agrees that damage caused by sight <span class="gemarra-regular">is considered </span>to be <span class="gemarra-regular">damage. And </span>Rav Yehuda holds it <span class="gemarra-regular">is different here, as </span>the owner of the roof can <span class="gemarra-regular">say to </span>the owner of the courtyard: The projection <span class="gemarra-regular">is not suitable for use, </span>since it is too small for me to stand upon and look into the courtyard. <span class="gemarra-regular">For what </span>purpose <span class="gemarra-regular">is it suitable? To hang items on it, </span>and nothing more. <span class="gemarra-regular">I will turn my face </span>away <span class="gemarra-regular">and hang </span>items <span class="gemarra-regular">on it </span>without looking into your courtyard.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And the other </span><span class="it-text">amora</span>, Rav Huna, holds that the owner of the courtyard can <span class="gemarra-regular">say to </span>the owner of the roof: There may be <span class="gemarra-regular">times when you are </span><span class="gemarra-regular">frightene</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> due to the height of the projection, and you will look into my courtyard while using it.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">A person may not open his windows, </span>i.e., build an opening in a wall to use as a window, <span class="gemarra-regular">into a courtyard belonging to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">partners</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., a courtyard in which he is a partner. If he <span class="gemarra-regular">purchased a house in another, </span>adjacent <span class="gemarra-regular">courtyard</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> he <span class="gemarra-regular">may not open </span>the house <span class="gemarra-regular">into a courtyard belonging to partners. </span>If he <span class="gemarra-regular">built a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">lof</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">on top of his house, he may not open it into a courtyard belonging to partners. Rather, if he desired </span>to build a loft, he may <span class="gemarra-regular">build a room within his house, or </span>he may <span class="gemarra-regular">build a loft on top of his house, and open it into his house, </span>not directly into the courtyard.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> With regard to the mishna’s ruling that one may not open a window into a courtyard that he co-owns, the Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Why </span>did the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">specifically </span>render it prohibited for one to open a window <span class="gemarra-regular">into </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a courtyard belonging to partners? </span>One may <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>open a window <span class="gemarra-regular">into another’s courtyard either, </span>as it will lead to damage caused by sight.
The Gemara replies that the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">is speaking </span>utilizing the style of: <span class="gemarra-regular">It is not necessary, </span>as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">It is not necessary </span>to say <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>permitted for one to open a window <span class="gemarra-regular">into</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> another’s courtyard, </span>where he is certainly not allowed to look; <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>where one wants to open a window <span class="gemarra-regular">into a courtyard belonging to partners, where </span>the owner of the window can <span class="gemarra-regular">say to </span>the other partner: <span class="gemarra-regular">Ultimately, </span>since <span class="gemarra-regular">you need to conceal </span>yourself <span class="gemarra-regular">from me </span>and conduct yourself modestly <span class="gemarra-regular">in the courtyard </span>where I too am a partner and have the right to be present, why does it bother you if I open a window into there? Therefore, the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us that </span>the partner may <span class="gemarra-regular">say to him: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Until now I needed to conceal </span>myself <span class="gemarra-regular">from you </span>only when we were both <span class="gemarra-regular">in the courtyard. Now I will need to conceal </span>myself <span class="gemarra-regular">from you even in the house</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as you can see into my house from your window.
<span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: There was <span class="gemarra-regular">an incident involving a person who opened his window</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> into a courtyard belonging to partners and came before Rabbi Yishmael bar Rabbi Yosei, </span>who <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: You have established an acquired privilege, my son; you have established an acquired privilege, </span>and you may not be prevented from using the windows. <span class="gemarra-regular">And he </span><span class="gemarra-regular">came before Rabbi Ḥiyya, </span>who <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>to him: <span class="gemarra-regular">You toiled and opened </span>the windows; you must <span class="gemarra-regular">toil and seal </span>them, as the partners have the right to prevent you from using these windows.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman said: </span>

Daf 60a

<span class="gemarra-regular">And to seal</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., if one sealed another’s window in his presence, <span class="gemarra-regular">there is an acquired privilege </span>established <span class="gemarra-regular">immediatel</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span> to keep the window sealed, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is not common </span>behavior for <span class="gemarra-regular">a person to have his </span>source of <span class="gemarra-regular">light sealed in his presence and </span>remain <span class="gemarra-regular">silent. </span>The fact that he did not immediately protest indicates that the one who sealed the window had the legal right to do so unilaterally, or that the owner of the window agreed.
§ The mishna teaches that if one <span class="gemarra-regular">purchased a house in another, </span>adjacent <span class="gemarra-regular">courtyard, </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">may not open </span>the house <span class="gemarra-regular">into a courtyard belonging to partners. </span>The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>for this? <span class="gemarra-regular">Because </span>by adding residents to the courtyard <span class="gemarra-regular">it increases their traffic, </span>and the residents of the courtyard do not wish to be disturbed by additional people passing through.
The Gemara questions this. But <span class="gemarra-regular">say the last clause </span>of the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, if he desired </span>to build a loft, he may <span class="gemarra-regular">build a room within his house, or </span>he may <span class="gemarra-regular">build a loft above his house, </span>and have it open into his house, not directly into the courtyard. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if he does so, <span class="gemarra-regular">isn’t </span>there still a concern that <span class="gemarra-regular">it increases the traffic? Rav Huna said </span>as an explanation: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>does the mishna mean when it says that he may build <span class="gemarra-regular">a room</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> It means <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>he may <span class="gemarra-regular">divide </span>an existing room <span class="gemarra-regular">in two. And what is </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">loft </span>to which the mishna is referring? It is <span class="gemarra-regular">an internal story </span>created by dividing an existing space into two stories.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">A person may not open an entrance opposite </span>another <span class="gemarra-regular">entranc</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">or a window opposite </span>another <span class="gemarra-regular">window toward a courtyard belonging to partners, </span>so as to ensure that the residents will enjoy a measure of privacy. If there <span class="gemarra-regular">was a small </span>entrance <span class="gemarra-regular">he may not enlarge it. </span>If there was <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>entrance <span class="gemarra-regular">he may not fashion it </span>into <span class="gemarra-regular">two. But </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">may open an entrance opposite </span>another <span class="gemarra-regular">entrance or a window opposite </span>another <span class="gemarra-regular">window toward the public domain. </span>Similarly, if there <span class="gemarra-regular">was a small </span>entrance <span class="gemarra-regular">he may enlarge it, </span>and if there was <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>entrance <span class="gemarra-regular">he may fashion it </span>into <span class="gemarra-regular">two.</span>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">From where are these matters, </span>i.e., that one may not open an en-trance opposite another entrance, or a window opposite another window, derived? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says that </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">verse states: “And Balaam lifted up his eyes, and he saw Israel dwelling tribe by tribe;</span> and the spirit of God came upon him” (Numbers 24:2). The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>was it that Balaam <span class="gemarra-regular">saw </span>that so inspired him? He <span class="gemarra-regular">saw that the entrances of their tents were not aligned with each other, </span>ensuring that each family enjoyed a measure of privacy. And he <span class="gemarra-regular">said: </span>If this is the case, <span class="gemarra-regular">these </span>people <span class="gemarra-regular">are worthy of having the Divine Presence rest on them.</span>
The mishna teaches that if there <span class="gemarra-regular">was a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">small </span>entrance <span class="gemarra-regular">he may not enlarge it. Rami bar Ḥama thought to say </span>this means that if the entrance was the width <span class="gemarra-regular">of four </span>cubits, one <span class="gemarra-regular">may not fashion it </span>to the width <span class="gemarra-regular">of eight </span>cubits, <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>he would then be allowed to <span class="gemarra-regular">take eight </span>corresponding cubits <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">courtyard. </span>The <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is that one is entitled to utilize the area of the courtyard up to a depth of four cubits along the width of the opening. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if the entrance was the width <span class="gemarra-regular">of two </span>cubits and one wishes <span class="gemarra-regular">to fashion it </span>to the width <span class="gemarra-regular">of four </span>cubits, one may <span class="gemarra-regular">well </span>do so, as in any event he already had the right to use an area of four cubits by four cubits in front of the entrance. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said to him: </span>This is not so, as his neighbor <span class="gemarra-regular">can say to him: I can conceal </span>myself <span class="gemarra-regular">from you with </span>there being <span class="gemarra-regular">a small entrance, </span>but <span class="gemarra-regular">I cannot conceal </span>myself <span class="gemarra-regular">from you with </span>there being <span class="gemarra-regular">a large entrance.</span>
The mishna teaches that if there <span class="gemarra-regular">was one </span>entrance <span class="gemarra-regular">he may not fashion it into two. </span>In this case as well, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rami bar Ḥama</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> thought to say </span>that this means if the entrance was the width <span class="gemarra-regular">of four </span>cubits he <span class="gemarra-regular">may not make it into two </span>openings, <span class="gemarra-regular">each </span>the width <span class="gemarra-regular">of two </span>cubits, <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>he would then be allowed to <span class="gemarra-regular">take eight </span>corresponding cubits <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">courtyard,</span> four for each entrance. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if it was the width <span class="gemarra-regular">of eight </span>cubits and he wishes <span class="gemarra-regular">to make it into </span>two openings, <span class="gemarra-regular">each </span>the width <span class="gemarra-regular">of four </span>cubits, he may <span class="gemarra-regular">well </span>do so, as in any event he already had the right to use an area of eight cubits by four cubits in front of his entrance. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said to him: </span>This is not so, as his neighbor <span class="gemarra-regular">can say to him: I can conceal </span>myself <span class="gemarra-regular">from you with </span>there being <span class="gemarra-regular">one entrance</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> but <span class="gemarra-regular">I cannot conceal </span>myself <span class="gemarra-regular">from you with </span>there being <span class="gemarra-regular">two entrances.</span>
The mishna teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">may open an entrance opposite </span>another <span class="gemarra-regular">entrance </span>or a window opposite another window <span class="gemarra-regular">toward the public domain. </span>Why is this so? <span class="gemarra-regular">Because </span>he can <span class="gemarra-regular">say to </span>the one who wishes to protest: <span class="gemarra-regular">Ultimately, you must conceal yourself from </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">people of the public domain. </span>Since you cannot stop them from passing by and therefore cannot engage in behavior that requires privacy with your entrance open, it is of no consequence to you if I open an entrance as well.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> One <span class="gemarra-regular">may not form an </span>empty <span class="gemarra-regular">spac</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">be-neath the public domain </span>by digging <span class="gemarra-regular">pits, ditches, or caves. Rabbi Eliezer deems </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">permitted </span>for one to do so, provided that he places a covering strong enough that <span class="gemarra-regular">a wagon laden with stones would </span>be able to <span class="gemarra-regular">tread </span>on it without breaking it, therefore ensuring that the empty space will not cause any damage to those in the public domain. One <span class="gemarra-regular">may not extend </span><span class="gemarra-regular">projection</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">or balconies [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ugzuztraot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">into the public domain. Rather, if he desired </span>to build one he may <span class="gemarra-regular">draw back into his </span>property by moving his wall, <span class="gemarra-regular">and extend </span>the projection to the end of his property line. If one <span class="gemarra-regular">purchased a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">courtyar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">in which there are projections and balconies </span>extending into the public domain, this courtyard <span class="gemarra-regular">retains its presumptive </span><span class="gemarra-regular">status</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., the owner has the acquired privilege of their use, and the court does not demand their removal.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: Rabbi Eliezer’s opinion that if the covering of the space is strong enough to support a wagon laden with stones then it is permitted to dig out the empty space, is eminently reasonable; <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>what do <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis </span>hold? The Gemara answers: There are <span class="gemarra-regular">times when </span>the cover <span class="gemarra-regular">erodes </span>over time, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not aware, </span>thereby potentially causing damage to those in the public domain.
The mishna teaches that <span class="gemarra-regular">one may not extend projections or balconies </span>into the public domain. The Gemara relates: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Am</span><span class="gemarra-regular">i</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> had a projection that protruded into an alleyway, and a certain man also had a projection that protruded into the public domain, </span>and the <span class="gemarra-regular">general public was preventing </span>the man from leaving it there, as it interfered with traffic. He <span class="gemarra-regular">came before Rabbi Ami, </span>who <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Go sever </span>your projection.
The man <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: But </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">Master also has </span>a similar projection. Rabbi Ami said to him: It is different, as <span class="gemarra-regular">mine protrudes into an alleyway, </span>where a limited number of people live, and the <span class="gemarra-regular">residents of the alleyway waive </span>their right to protest <span class="gemarra-regular">to me. Yours protrudes into the public domain, </span>which does not belong to any specific individuals. <span class="gemarra-regular">Who </span>can <span class="gemarra-regular">waive </span>their right to protest <span class="gemarra-regular">to you?</span>
The Gemara relates: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular">i</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> had a tree that was leaning into the public domain. </span>There <span class="gemarra-regular">was a certain man who also had a tree that was leaning into the public domain, </span>and the <span class="gemarra-regular">general public was preventing him </span>from leaving it there, insisting he cut it down, as required by the mishna (27b). He <span class="gemarra-regular">came before Rabbi Yannai, </span>who <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>

Daf 60b

<span class="gemarra-regular">Go now, and come tomorrow. At night, </span>Rabbi Yannai <span class="gemarra-regular">sent </span>and had someone <span class="gemarra-regular">cut </span>down <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>tree that belonged <span class="gemarra-regular">to him.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">The next day, </span>that man <span class="gemarra-regular">came before </span>Rabbi Yannai, who <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Go, cut </span>down your tree. The man <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: But </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">Master also has </span>a tree that leans into the public domain. Rabbi Yannai <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Go </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">see: If mine is cut </span>down, then <span class="gemarra-regular">cut yours </span>down. <span class="gemarra-regular">If mine is not cut </span>down, <span class="gemarra-regular">you do not </span>have to <span class="gemarra-regular">cut </span>yours down, either.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">At the outset what did </span>Rabbi Yannai <span class="gemarra-regular">hold, and ultimately, what did he hold? </span>The Gemara replies: <span class="gemarra-regular">At the outset, he held </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the general public is amenable </span>to having the tree there, <span class="gemarra-regular">as they sit in its shade. Once he saw that </span>they were <span class="gemarra-regular">preventing </span>someone else who owned a tree from keeping his, he understood that it was only out of respect that they did not object to his tree being there. He therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">sent </span>someone to <span class="gemarra-regular">cut it </span>down. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But</span> why did he tell the man to return the next day? <span class="gemarra-regular">Let </span>him <span class="gemarra-regular">say to him: Go cut </span>down <span class="gemarra-regular">your </span>tree, <span class="gemarra-regular">and then I will cut mine </span>down. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Because of </span>the statement of <span class="gemarra-regular">Reish Lakish, who said: </span>The verse states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Gather yourselves together and gather [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">hitkosheshu</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">vakoshu</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]” </span>(Zephaniah 2:1), and this can be explained homiletically to mean: <span class="gemarra-regular">Adorn [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">keshot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] yourself and afterward adorn others, </span>i.e., act properly before requiring others to do so.
§ The mishna teaches that one may not extend projections or balconies into the public domain. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, if he desired </span>to build one he may <span class="gemarra-regular">draw back into his </span>property by moving his wall, <span class="gemarra-regular">and extend</span> the projection to the end of his property line. <span class="gemarra-regular">A dilemma was raised before </span>the Sages: If one <span class="gemarra-regular">drew back </span>into his property <span class="gemarra-regular">but did not extend </span>the projection at that time, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">whether </span>he may <span class="gemarra-regular">return and extend </span>it at a later date? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: </span>If one <span class="gemarra-regular">drew back </span>into his property, he <span class="gemarra-regular">may exten</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> it even later, <span class="gemarra-regular">and Reish Lakish says: </span>If one <span class="gemarra-regular">drew back </span>into his property but did not build the projection at that time, he <span class="gemarra-regular">may</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not extend </span>it later.
The Gemara presents an alternative version of the dispute: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ya’akov said to Rabbi Yirmeya bar Taḥlifa: I will explain </span>the matter <span class="gemarra-regular">to you. To </span>later <span class="gemarra-regular">extend </span>a projection, <span class="gemarra-regular">everyone agrees that </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">may extend </span>it, since he is adding within his own property. <span class="gemarra-regular">Where they disagree </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>whether he may <span class="gemarra-regular">return </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">walls to their </span>prior <span class="gemarra-regular">place. And </span>with regard to this disagreement <span class="gemarra-regular">the opposite was stated: Rabbi Yoḥanan says </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">may not return </span>the walls to their prior place, <span class="gemarra-regular">and Reish Lakish says </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">may return </span>them.
Rabbi Ya’akov explains their reasoning: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says </span>that he <span class="gemarra-regular">may not return </span>the walls to their prior place <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>of the statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav Yehuda, as Rav Yehuda says: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a path that </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">public has established </span>as a public thoroughfare, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is prohibited to ruin it, </span>i.e., to prevent people from using it. Once the public has become accustomed to using the place where his wall had stood, he may not repossess that space. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Reish Lakish says </span>that he <span class="gemarra-regular">may return </span>the walls to their prior place, because <span class="gemarra-regular">that</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> matter </span>applies in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where there is no space, </span>i.e., if he were to move back the wall there would be no space for the public to walk, but <span class="gemarra-regular">here there is space, </span>since they can still walk through the public domain.
The mishna teaches that if one <span class="gemarra-regular">purchased a courtyard in which there are projections and balconies </span>extending into the public domain, this courtyard <span class="gemarra-regular">retains its presumptive status, </span>allowing the owner to use the projections. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna says: </span>If the wall of the courtyard <span class="gemarra-regular">fell, he may return and build i</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> as it was, including the projections or balconies.
The Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises an objection </span>based on that which is taught in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> (<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span> 9:17): <span class="gemarra-regular">One may not plaster</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and one may not tile, and one may not paint [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">mefayyeḥin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> images <span class="gemarra-regular">in the present, </span>as a sign of mourning for the destruction of the Temple. But if one <span class="gemarra-regular">purchased a courtyard </span>that was <span class="gemarra-regular">plastered</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> tiled, </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">painted </span>with images, <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>courtyard <span class="gemarra-regular">retains its presumptive status, </span>and it is assumed that it was done in a permitted manner. If <span class="gemarra-regular">it </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">fell, he may not return and build it </span>in its previous form. This indicates that one may not rebuild a building in a manner that is prohibited, even if there was an acquired privilege to maintain it in that manner.
The Gemara answers: A case of <span class="gemarra-regular">forbidden </span>matters <span class="gemarra-regular">is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> different, </span>i.e., in the case of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, he may not rebuild it because it is prohibited for him to do so. In this mishna, the issue is encroachment upon the rights of others, and once he had an acquired privilege to use the projections or balconies, he maintains that right.
§ With regard to the ruling of the above-quoted <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">the Sages taught </span>(<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span>, <span class="it-text">Sota</span> 15:9): <span class="gemarra-regular">A person may not plaster his house with plaster, but if </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">mixed sand or straw into </span>the plaster, which dulls its luster, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">permitted. Rabbi Yehuda says: </span>If he <span class="gemarra-regular">mixed sand into it, it is </span>white <span class="gemarra-regular">cement [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">terakesid</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> which is of a higher quality than standard plaster, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibited, </span>but if he mixed in <span class="gemarra-regular">straw, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">permitted.</span>
§ Having mentioned the prohibition against plastering, which is a sign of mourning over the destruction of the Temple, the Gemara discusses related matters. <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> (<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span>, <span class="it-text">Sota</span> 15:11): <span class="gemarra-regular">When the Temple was destroyed a second </span>time, there was <span class="gemarra-regular">an increase </span>in the number of <span class="gemarra-regular">ascetics among </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">Jews, </span>whose practice was <span class="gemarra-regular">to not eat meat and to not drink wine. Rabbi Yehoshua joined them </span>to discuss their practice. <span class="gemarra-regular">He said to them: My children, for what </span>reason do <span class="gemarra-regular">you not eat meat and </span>do <span class="gemarra-regular">you not drink wine? They said to him: Shall we eat meat, from which </span>offerings <span class="gemarra-regular">are sacrificed upon </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">altar, and now </span>the altar <span class="gemarra-regular">has ceased </span>to exist? <span class="gemarra-regular">Shall we drink wine, which is poured </span>as a libation <span class="gemarra-regular">upon the altar, and now </span>the altar <span class="gemarra-regular">has ceased </span>to exist?
Rabbi Yehoshua <span class="gemarra-regular">said to them: If so, we will not eat bread </span>either, <span class="gemarra-regular">since </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">meal-offerings </span>that were offered upon the altar <span class="gemarra-regular">have ceased. </span>They replied: You are correct. It is <span class="gemarra-regular">possible </span>to subsist <span class="gemarra-regular">with produce. </span>He said to them: <span class="gemarra-regular">We will not eat produce </span>either, <span class="gemarra-regular">since </span>the bringing of <span class="gemarra-regular">the first fruit</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> have ceased. </span>They replied: You are correct. We will no longer eat the produce of the seven species from which the first fruits were brought, as it is <span class="gemarra-regular">possible </span>to subsist <span class="gemarra-regular">with other produce. </span>He said to them: If so, <span class="gemarra-regular">we will not drink water, since the water libatio</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> has ceased. They</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> were silent, </span>as they realized that they could not survive without water.
Rabbi Yehoshua <span class="gemarra-regular">said to them: My children, come, and I will tell you </span>how we should act. <span class="gemarra-regular">To not mourn at all </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">impossible, as </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">decree was already issued </span>and the Temple has been destroyed. <span class="gemarra-regular">But to mourn excessively </span>as you are doing is also <span class="gemarra-regular">impossible, as </span>the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">do not issue a decree upon the public unless a majority of the public is able to abide by it, as it is written: “You are cursed with the curse, yet you rob Me, even this whole nation” </span>(Malachi 3:9), indicating that the prophet rebukes the people for neglecting observances only if they were accepted by the whole nation.
Rabbi Yehoshua continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, this </span>is what <span class="gemarra-regular">the Sages said: A person </span>may <span class="gemarra-regular">plaster his house with plaster, but </span>he must <span class="gemarra-regular">leave </span>over <span class="gemarra-regular">a small amount in it </span>without plaster to remember the destruction of the Temple. The Gemara interjects: <span class="gemarra-regular">And how much </span>is a small amount? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef said: </span>One <span class="gemarra-regular">cubit by </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">cubit. Rav Ḥisda said: </span>This should be <span class="gemarra-regular">opposite the entrance, </span>so that it is visible to all.
Rabbi Yehoshua continues: The Sages said that <span class="gemarra-regular">a person </span>may <span class="gemarra-regular">prepare all </span>that he <span class="gemarra-regular">needs for a meal, but </span>he must <span class="gemarra-regular">leave </span>out <span class="gemarra-regular">a small ite</span><span class="gemarra-regular">m</span> to remember the destruction of the Temple. The Gemara interjects: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>small item? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa said: </span>Something akin to <span class="gemarra-regular">small, fried fish</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
Rabbi Yehoshua continues: The Sages said that <span class="gemarra-regular">a woman </span>may <span class="gemarra-regular">engage </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">all </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">her cosmetic treatments</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> but </span>she must <span class="gemarra-regular">leave </span>out <span class="gemarra-regular">a small matter </span>to remember the destruction of the Temple. The Gemara interjects: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>small matter? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav said: </span>She does not remove hair from the place on the <span class="gemarra-regular">temple </span>from which women would remove hair. The source for these practices is a verse, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is stated: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">“If I forget you, Jerusalem, let my right hand forget its cunning. Let my tongue cleave to the roof of my mouth, </span>if I remember you not; if I set not Jerusalem above my highest joy” (Psalms 137:5–6).
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is the meaning of: <span class="gemarra-regular">Above my highest [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">rosh</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] joy? Rav Yitzḥak says: This </span>is referring to the <span class="gemarra-regular">burnt ashe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> that are customarily placed <span class="gemarra-regular">on the head [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">rosh</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">bridegrooms </span>at the time of their wedding celebrations, to remember the destruction of the Temple. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa said to Abaye: Where are they placed? </span>Abaye replied: <span class="gemarra-regular">On </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">place </span>where <span class="gemarra-regular">phylacteries </span>are placed, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is stated: “To appoint to them that mourn in Zion, to give to them a garland in place of ashes” </span>(Isaiah 61:3). Since phylacteries are referred to as a garland (see Ezekiel 24:17), it may be inferred from this verse that the ashes were placed in the same place as the phylacteries.
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">And anyone who mourn</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for </span>the destruction of <span class="gemarra-regular">Jerusalem </span>will <span class="gemarra-regular">merit and see its joy, as it is stated: “Rejoice with Jerusalem, </span>and be glad with her, all that love her; rejoice for joy with her, all that mourn for her” (Isaiah 66:10).
<span class="gemarra-regular">It is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> (<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span>, <span class="it-text">Sota</span> 15:10) that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yishmael ben Elisha said: From the day that the Temple was destroyed, by right, we should decree upon ourselves not to eat meat and not to drink wine, but </span>the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">do not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">issue a decree upon the public unles</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a majority of the public is able to abide by it.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And from the day that the wicked kingdom, </span>i.e., Rome, <span class="gemarra-regular">spread</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> who decree evil and harsh decrees upon us, and nullify Torah </span>study <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the performance of <span class="gemarra-regular">mitzvot for us, and do not allow us to enter </span>the celebration of the first <span class="gemarra-regular">week of a son</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., circumcision, <span class="gemarra-regular">and some say: To </span>enter the celebration of the <span class="gemarra-regular">salvation of </span>a firstborn <span class="gemarra-regular">son</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> by right we should </span>each <span class="gemarra-regular">decree upon ourselves not to marry a woman and </span>not <span class="gemarra-regular">to produce offspring, and it will turn out </span>that the <span class="gemarra-regular">descendants of Abraham our forefather will ceas</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> to exist <span class="gemarra-regular">on their own, </span>rather than being forced into a situation where there are sons who are not circumcised.
<span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>concerning a situation such as this, the following principle is applied: <span class="gemarra-regular">Leave the Jews alone </span>and do not impose decrees by which they cannot abide. <span class="gemarra-regular">It is better that they be unwitting </span>sinners, who do not know that what they are doing is improper considering the circumstances, <span class="gemarra-regular">and not be intentional </span>wrongdoers, who marry and procreate despite knowing that they should not. 


Daf 61a

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> One <span class="gemarra-regular">who sells a house </span>without specifying what is included in the sale <span class="gemarra-regular">has not sold the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">gallery</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> an extension built above or alongside the main building, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>this is so <span class="gemarra-regular">even if </span>the gallery is attached to the house and <span class="gemarra-regular">opens into it. Nor </span>has he sold <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">roo</span><span class="gemarra-regular">m</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">behind </span>the house, even if it is accessible only from inside the house. He has <span class="gemarra-regular">also not </span>sold <span class="gemarra-regular">the roof</span>  <span class="gemarra-regular">when it has a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">parape</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">ten handbreadths high, </span>as such a roof is considered a separate entity and is therefore not included in the sale of the house. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda says: If </span>the parapet <span class="gemarra-regular">has the form of a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">doorway</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> that is, if it consists of two upright posts with a beam crossing over them, then <span class="gemarra-regular">even if </span>the parapet <span class="gemarra-regular">is not ten handbreadths high, </span>the roof <span class="gemarra-regular">is not sold </span>together with the house, unless it is specifically included in the sale.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">What is a gallery? Here </span>in Babylonia <span class="gemarra-regular">they interpreted </span>this as referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">an attic [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">apta</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef said: </span>It means <span class="gemarra-regular">a windowed structure [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">bidka</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">ḥalila</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> attached to the main building. The Gemara notes that <span class="gemarra-regular">according to the one who says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">an attic is not sold </span>together with a house, <span class="gemarra-regular">all the more so is a windowed structure </span>attached to the house <span class="gemarra-regular">not sold </span>together with a house, as it is certainly considered a separate entity and not part of the main building. But <span class="gemarra-regular">according</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to the one who says </span>that a gallery is <span class="gemarra-regular">a windowed structure </span>attached to the house, it is only such a structure that is not included in the sale of the house, <span class="gemarra-regular">but an attic is sold </span>together with a house.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef taught: </span>A small structure attached to a building <span class="gemarra-regular">has three names </span>in the Bible: <span class="gemarra-regular">Gallery </span><span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">yatzia</span><span class="gemarra-regular">], side chamber [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">tzela</span><span class="gemarra-regular">], </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">cell [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ta</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]. </span>Such a structure is called <span class="gemarra-regular">a gallery, as it is written: “The bottommost gallery [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">hayyatzia</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] was five cubits wide” </span>(I Kings 6:6). It is also called <span class="gemarra-regular">a side chamber, as it is written: “And the side chambers [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">vehatzelaot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] were one over another, thirty-three times” </span>(Ezekiel 41:6). Additionally, it is called <span class="gemarra-regular">a cell, as it is written: “And the cell [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">vehata</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] was one reed long, and one reed wide; and the space between the cells was five cubits” </span>(Ezekiel 40:7). <span class="gemarra-regular">And if you wish, say </span>instead that it can be seen that a small structure attached to a building is called a cell <span class="gemarra-regular">from here, </span>as was taught in the mishna (<span class="it-text">Middot</span> 4:7): <span class="gemarra-regular">The wall of the Sanctuary </span>was <span class="gemarra-regular">six </span>cubits wide, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the cell [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">vehata</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] </span>in back of it was <span class="gemarra-regular">six </span>cubits wide, and <span class="gemarra-regular">the wall of the cell </span>was <span class="gemarra-regular">five </span>cubits wide.
§ Relating to the mishna’s statement that a gallery is not included in the sale of a house, <span class="gemarra-regular">Mar Zutra said: And that </span>is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> only <span class="gemarra-regular">when </span>the gallery <span class="gemarra-regular">has </span>an area of at least <span class="gemarra-regular">four </span>by four <span class="gemarra-regular">cubits</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Ravina said to Mar Zutra: According to your </span>opinion, <span class="gemarra-regular">that you say </span>a gallery is not excluded from the sale of a house <span class="gemarra-regular">unless it is </span>at least <span class="gemarra-regular">four </span>by four <span class="gemarra-regular">cubits </span>in size, there is a difficulty. As <span class="gemarra-regular">if that is so, </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>the exclusion of <span class="gemarra-regular">a pit </span>or a cistern from the sale of a house, <span class="gemarra-regular">about which we learned </span>in a mishna (64a): One who sells a house has sold <span class="gemarra-regular">neither the pit nor the cistern</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> even if he writes for </span>the buyer in the bill of sale that he is selling <span class="gemarra-regular">him the depth and the height </span>of the house; <span class="gemarra-regular">so too, </span>should we say that only <span class="gemarra-regular">if they have </span>an area of at least <span class="gemarra-regular">four </span>by four <span class="gemarra-regular">cubits, yes, </span>they are excluded from the sale of the house, but <span class="gemarra-regular">if not, no, </span>they are not excluded? This is difficult, as a pit is not four cubits wide, and consequently, it would never be excluded.
Mar Zutra responded: <span class="gemarra-regular">How can </span>these cases <span class="gemarra-regular">be compared? There, </span>in that mishna, <span class="gemarra-regular">this, </span>the excavations, have <span class="gemarra-regular">a discrete use, </span>to store water, and they cannot possibly be used as living quarters, <span class="gemarra-regular">and that, </span>the house, has <span class="gemarra-regular">a discrete use, </span>to serve as living quarters, and so they are considered separate entities even if the excavation is not four cubits wide. But <span class="gemarra-regular">here, </span>in the case of a gallery, both <span class="gemarra-regular">this, </span>the gallery, <span class="gemarra-regular">and that, </span>the house, <span class="gemarra-regular">have the same use, </span>and so <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>the gallery <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>at least <span class="gemarra-regular">four </span>by four <span class="gemarra-regular">cubits </span>it is deemed <span class="gemarra-regular">significant </span>and considered a separate entity, <span class="gemarra-regular">but if </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>four by four cubits, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>deemed <span class="gemarra-regular">significant </span>in its own right, but simply another part of the house.
The mishna teaches that one who sells a house without specifying what is included in the sale has not sold the gallery, <span class="gemarra-regular">nor </span>has he sold <span class="gemarra-regular">the room behind </span>the house, even if it is accessible only <span class="gemarra-regular">from it. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Now </span>that the mishna taught that <span class="gemarra-regular">a galler</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is not sold </span>along with the house, <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>to teach that <span class="gemarra-regular">a room </span>behind the house is not included in such a sale? 

Daf 61b

<span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>this ruling is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>to teach that the room behind the house is excluded from the sale of the house <span class="gemarra-regular">even if </span>the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">delineate</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the boundaries </span>of the house <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>the buyer in the bill of sale by listing places <span class="gemarra-regular">outsid</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> the room, e.g., noting the houses that border the property being sold. Even though this might suggest that the room is included in the sale, the mishna teaches that it is not.
This is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav Naḥman, as Rav Naḥman says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba bar Avuh says: </span>With regard to one <span class="gemarra-regular">who sells a residence to another in a large building [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">bira</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> containing several residences, <span class="gemarra-regular">even if he delineates for him the external boundaries </span>of the large building, he did not sell him the entire building, but rather <span class="gemarra-regular">he enlarged </span>upon <span class="gemarra-regular">the boundaries for him</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> That is, the seller did not mean to delineate the precise borders of what he was selling; rather, he delineated the boundaries in a broad manner, giving the general location of the specific residence subject to the transaction.
With regard to Rav Naḥman’s statement, the Gemara inquires: <span class="gemarra-regular">What are the circumstances </span>of the case? <span class="gemarra-regular">If</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> we say </span>that this is referring to a place <span class="gemarra-regular">where they call a residence a residence, and a building a building, </span>and they always differentiate between the two terms, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious </span>that he did not intend to sell him the entire building but merely enlarged upon the boundaries for him, as <span class="gemarra-regular">he sold him a residence </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">did not sell him a large building. Rather, </span>explain that this is referring to a place <span class="gemarra-regular">where they also call a building a residence. </span>But in that case, why not say that the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">sold him the entire </span>building, since he delineated the external boundaries of the large building?
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>Rav Naḥman’s ruling is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>in a place <span class="gemarra-regular">where most </span>of the people <span class="gemarra-regular">call a residence a residence, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">a building </span>they call <span class="gemarra-regular">a building, but there are also </span>some people <span class="gemarra-regular">who call a building a residence. Lest you say </span>that since the seller delineated the building’s external boundaries, this indicates that he meant to <span class="gemarra-regular">sell him the entire </span>building, Rav Naḥman <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>that this is not so. <span class="gemarra-regular">As, </span>if the seller intended to sell him the entire building, <span class="gemarra-regular">he would have written </span>in the bill of sale: <span class="gemarra-regular">And I have not withheld anything </span>for myself <span class="gemarra-regular">in this sale, but </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">he did not write </span>this clause, <span class="gemarra-regular">conclude from it </span>that the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">withheld </span>something for himself and did not mean to sell everything located within the delineated boundaries.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>in a similar fashion, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba bar Avuh says: </span>With regard to one <span class="gemarra-regular">who sells a field to another in a large expanse of fields</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> even if he delineates for him the external boundaries </span>of the large expanse of fields he did not sell him the entire expanse of fields; rather, <span class="gemarra-regular">he enlarged </span>upon <span class="gemarra-regular">the boundaries for him. </span>That is, the seller did not mean to delineate the precise borders of what was being sold; rather, he delineated the boundaries in a broad manner, giving the general location of the particular field he was selling.
The Gemara inquires: <span class="gemarra-regular">What are</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the circumstances </span>of the case? <span class="gemarra-regular">If we say </span>that this is referring to a place <span class="gemarra-regular">where they call a field a field, and an expanse of fields an expanse of fields, </span>and always differentiate between the two terms, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious </span>the he did not intend to sell him the entire expanse of fields, as <span class="gemarra-regular">he sold him a field </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">did not sell him an expanse of fields. Rather, </span>explain that this is referring to a place <span class="gemarra-regular">where they also call an expanse of fields a field. </span>But in that case, why not say that the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">sold him the entire </span>expanse of fields, since he delineated the external boundaries of the expanse of fields?
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>Rav Naḥman’s ruling is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>in a place <span class="gemarra-regular">where there are </span>some people <span class="gemarra-regular">who call a field a field, and an expanse of fields </span>they call <span class="gemarra-regular">an expanse of fields, but there are also </span>some people <span class="gemarra-regular">who call an expanse of fields a field. Lest you say </span>that since the seller delineated the expanse’s external boundaries, this indicates that he meant to <span class="gemarra-regular">sell him the entire </span>expanse, Rav Naḥman <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>that this is not so. <span class="gemarra-regular">As, </span>if the seller intended to sell him the entire expanse, <span class="gemarra-regular">he would have written for him </span>in the bill of sale: And <span class="gemarra-regular">I have not withheld anything for myself in this sale, but </span>since <span class="gemarra-regular">he did not write </span>this clause <span class="gemarra-regular">for him, conclude from it </span>that the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">withheld </span>something for himself and did not mean to sell everything located within the delineated boundaries.
The Gemara notes: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>it was <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>for Rav Naḥman to teach the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in both cases, even though the two rulings appear to be the same. <span class="gemarra-regular">As had he taught us </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> only in the case of the <span class="gemarra-regular">residence, </span>that he did not sell him the entire building even if he delineated the building’s external boundaries, I might have said that this is <span class="gemarra-regular">due to </span>the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that this, </span>the residence, has <span class="gemarra-regular">a discrete use, </span>separate from that of the rest of the building, <span class="gemarra-regular">and that, </span>the building, has <span class="gemarra-regular">a discrete use. But </span>as for <span class="gemarra-regular">an expanse of fields, all of which has a single use, </span>since it can be sown with grain in its entirety, <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">sold him the entire </span>expanse.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And had </span>Rav Naḥman <span class="gemarra-regular">taught us </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> only in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">an expanse of fields, </span>that he did not sell him the entire expanse even if he delineated its external boundaries, I might have said that this is <span class="gemarra-regular">due to </span>the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">had no </span>way <span class="gemarra-regular">to delineate </span>the particular field’s boundaries, since all of the fields are similar, and they all belong to the seller. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>as for <span class="gemarra-regular">a residence, with regard to which </span>the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">had </span>a way <span class="gemarra-regular">to delineate </span>its borders, through the use of descriptive terms that would isolate it from the rest of the building, <span class="gemarra-regular">but he did not delineate </span>them, I might say that <span class="gemarra-regular">he sold him the entire </span>building. Therefore, it was <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>to mention both cases explicitly.
