The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">In accordance with whose </span>opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">is that </span><span class="gemarra-regular">which Rav Mari, son of the daughter of Shmuel</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> said in the name of Abaye: One who sells something to another must write for hi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">m</span> in the bill of sale: <span class="gemarra-regular">I have not withheld anything for myself in this sale. In accordance </span><span class="gemarra-regular">with whose </span>opinion is that? It is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman, </span>who says that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba bar Avuh says </span>that even when the seller delineates the boundaries of what he is selling, he does not necessarily mean to sell everything included within those boundaries. Inserting this clause in the bill of sale removes uncertainties that could lead to conflict.
The Gemara relates: There was <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain </span>man <span class="gemarra-regular">who said to another: I am selling you land of the house of Ḥiyya</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> but <span class="gemarra-regular">there were two </span>plots of <span class="gemarra-regular">land that were called </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">of the house of Ḥiyya, </span>and the Sages deliberated as to whether both were included in this sale or only one. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi said: He said to him </span>that he was selling him <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>plot of land, and <span class="gemarra-regular">he did not say to him </span>that he was selling him <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>plots of land, as he employed a singular term. Therefore, only one is included in the sale.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if he said to him: </span>I am selling you <span class="gemarra-regular">fields, without specifying </span>how many, <span class="gemarra-regular">the minimum </span>number of fields that would justify being called <span class="gemarra-regular">fields </span>in the plural is <span class="gemarra-regular">two, </span>and therefore the seller has to give the buyer only two of his fields, even if he owns many fields. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if he said to him: </span>I am selling you <span class="gemarra-regular">all </span>of my <span class="gemarra-regular">fields, </span>what he means is that he is selling him <span class="gemarra-regular">all the fields that he owns, excluding </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">orchards [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">bustanei</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and vineyards. And if he said to him: </span>I am selling you my <span class="gemarra-regular">landed property</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> what he means is that he is selling him <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">orchards and vineyards, </span>but <span class="gemarra-regular">excluding </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">houses and </span>Canaanite <span class="gemarra-regular">slaves. </span>

Daf 62a

<span class="gemarra-regular">And if he said to him: </span>I am selling you my <span class="gemarra-regular">property, </span>it means that he is selling him <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">houses and </span>his Canaanite <span class="gemarra-regular">slaves.</span>
§ The Gemara continues its examination of the concept of delineating boundaries in a wide manner, and considers the following case: If in the bill of sale the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">delineated one boundary line </span>on one side of the field <span class="gemarra-regular">long, and the other boundary line </span>on the opposite side of the field he delineated <span class="gemarra-regular">short, Rav said: </span>The buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">acquires only </span>a width of land <span class="gemarra-regular">corresponding to the short </span>border, as it is assumed that the short boundary line delineates the actual size of the field that was sold to him, while the long boundary line was merely intended to point to the field under discussion. That is to say, the seller delineated the boundaries in a broad manner, but did not intend to include everything found within those boundaries in the sale.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Kahana and Rav Asi said to Rav: But let him </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">acquire the triangular plot [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">rosh</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">tor</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> bounded by the diagonal line connecting the end of the short border and the end of the long border. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav was silent </span>and did not respond.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav concedes </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">where there is a boundary line </span>defined by the fields <span class="gemarra-regular">of Reuven and Shimon on one side </span>of the field being sold, <span class="gemarra-regular">and a boundary line </span>defined by the fields <span class="gemarra-regular">of Levi and Yehuda on the other side, </span>and in the bill of sale the seller describes the field being sold as bordered by the fields of Reuven and Shimon on one side but mentions only the field of Levi on the other side, <span class="gemarra-regular">since </span>had he intended to sell only half the field <span class="gemarra-regular">he should have written for </span>the buyer in the bill of sale that the field is bordered by the field <span class="gemarra-regular">of Reuven </span>on the one side, which is <span class="gemarra-regular">opposite </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">of Lev</span><span class="gemarra-regular">i</span> on the other, <span class="gemarra-regular">or </span>by the field <span class="gemarra-regular">of Shimon </span>on the one side, which is <span class="gemarra-regular">opposite </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">of Yehuda </span>on the other, <span class="gemarra-regular">but he did not write </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">for him, </span>one can <span class="gemarra-regular">conclude from it that he is telling him </span>that he is selling him not only the area between the fields of Reuven and Levi, but also <span class="gemarra-regular">the triangular plot </span>bounded by the diagonal line connecting the end of Shimon’s field to the end of Levi’s field.
The Gemara continues: If the field being sold is <span class="gemarra-regular">bounded by </span>the fields of <span class="gemarra-regular">Reuven </span>on <span class="gemarra-regular">the east and the west</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">bounded by </span>the fields of <span class="gemarra-regular">Shimon </span>on <span class="gemarra-regular">the north and the south, </span>it is not enough to designate the field for the buyer as the field between the fields of Reuven and Shimon, but <span class="gemarra-regular">it is necessary to write for him </span>in the bill of sale that the field is <span class="gemarra-regular">bounded by </span>the fields of <span class="gemarra-regular">Reuven </span>on <span class="gemarra-regular">two sides, and </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">bounded by </span>the fields of <span class="gemarra-regular">Shimon </span>on <span class="gemarra-regular">two sides. </span>Otherwise, all that the buyer acquires is a triangular plot bounded by one of Reuven’s fields and one of Shimon’s fields, and the boundary is the diagonal line connecting the end of Reuven’s field to the end of Shimon’s field.
<span class="gemarra-regular">A dilemma was raised before </span>the Sages: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">defined for </span>the buyer only <span class="gemarra-regular">the corners </span>of the field being sold, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? Does this mean that he is selling him only the corners of the field or the entire field marked by those corners? A second dilemma was also raised: If he defined the boundaries of the field in a shape <span class="gemarra-regular">resembling </span>the Greek letter <span class="gemarra-regular">gamma </span><span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">gam</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> or the English letter L, noting the boundaries on two adjacent sides that meet at a right angle, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? Does this mean that he is selling him the entire field, or only the triangular plot marked by those boundaries and the diagonal line running from the end of one to the end of the other? 

Daf 62b

A third dilemma was also raised before the Sages: If the seller defined the boundaries of the property he is selling <span class="gemarra-regular">in an alternating </span>fashion, mentioning only some of the fields bordering each side of the field being sold, while omitting others, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? No resolution was found for these questions, and these dilemmas <span class="gemarra-regular">shall stand </span>unresolved.
§ The Gemara raises a similar dilemma. If, in the bill of sale, the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">delineated for </span>the buyer the field’s <span class="gemarra-regular">first boundary, </span>its <span class="gemarra-regular">second boundary, and </span>its <span class="gemarra-regular">third boundary</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> but he did not delineate </span>its <span class="gemarra-regular">fourth boundary </span>at all, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: </span>The buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">acquires the entire </span>field, <span class="gemarra-regular">except for </span>the one furrow along which <span class="gemarra-regular">the fourth boundary </span>runs, which is usually differentiated in some way from the field itself. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Shmuel says: </span>The buyer acquires <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>the furrow along which <span class="gemarra-regular">the fourth boundary </span>runs. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav Asi says: He acquires only </span>the width of <span class="gemarra-regular">one furro</span><span class="gemarra-regular">w</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> along the entire </span>perimeter of the three boundaries specified by the seller.
The Gemara explains Rav Asi’s opinion: He <span class="gemarra-regular">holds in </span><span class="gemarra-regular">accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav, who said </span>that by failing to delineate the fourth boundary, the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">withheld </span>some part of the field, i.e., one furrow, for himself. But Rav Asi takes this further <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>says that <span class="gemarra-regular">since he withheld </span>some part of the field for himself <span class="gemarra-regular">at the </span>fourth <span class="gemarra-regular">boundary, he withheld also </span>some portion <span class="gemarra-regular">of the entire </span>field, and therefore the buyer acquires only that which is adjacent to the specified boundaries.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: The </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is that the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">acquires the entire </span>field <span class="gemarra-regular">except for </span>the one furrow along which <span class="gemarra-regular">the fourth boundary </span>runs, in accordance with the opinion of Rav. <span class="gemarra-regular">And we said </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the fourth boundary <span class="gemarra-regular">is not include</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> within the space between two adjacent boundaries, but rather juts out beyond them. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>when <span class="gemarra-regular">it is included </span>within the space delineated by the other boundaries, the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">acquires </span>it as well.
Rava adds: <span class="gemarra-regular">And even when it is not included </span>in that space, <span class="gemarra-regular">we said </span>that the buyer does not acquire it <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where there is a row of trees on it, or it is </span>an area fit for sowing <span class="gemarra-regular">nine </span><span class="gemarra-italic">ka</span><span class="gemarra-italic">v</span> of seed. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>where <span class="gemarra-regular">there is no row of trees on it, and it is not </span>an area fit for sowing <span class="gemarra-regular">nine </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kav</span> of seed, the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">acquires </span>it along with the rest of the field. <span class="gemarra-regular">By inference </span>one derives from here <span class="gemarra-regular">that when </span>the fourth border <span class="gemarra-regular">is included </span>within the space delineated by the two adjacent boundaries, <span class="gemarra-regular">even if there is a row of trees on it and it is </span>an area fit for sowing <span class="gemarra-regular">nine </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kav</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">acquires </span>it.
<span class="gemarra-regular">There are </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">who say </span>that Rava’s ruling and the conclusion drawn from it are as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: The </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is that the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">acquires the entire </span>field, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>he acquires <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>the furrow along which <span class="gemarra-regular">the fourth boundary </span>runs, in accordance with the opinion of Shmuel. <span class="gemarra-regular">And we said </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the fourth boundary <span class="gemarra-regular">is included </span>within the space delineated by the two adjacent boundaries. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>when <span class="gemarra-regular">it is not included </span>within those boundaries, the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">does not acquire </span>it.
Rava adds: <span class="gemarra-regular">And even when it is included </span>within the adjoining boundaries, <span class="gemarra-regular">we said </span>that the buyer acquires it <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where there is no row of trees on it, and it is not </span>an area fit for sowing <span class="gemarra-regular">nine </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kav</span> of seed. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>where <span class="gemarra-regular">there is a row of trees on it, or it is </span>an area fit for sowing <span class="gemarra-regular">nine </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kav</span> of seed, the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">does not acquire </span>it. <span class="gemarra-regular">By inference </span>one derives from here <span class="gemarra-regular">that when </span>the fourth boundary <span class="gemarra-regular">is not included </span>within the two adjacent boundaries, <span class="gemarra-regular">even if there is no row of trees on it and it is not </span>an area fit for sowing <span class="gemarra-regular">nine </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kav</span> of seed, the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">does not acquire </span>it.
<span class="gemarra-regular">We conclude according to both versions </span>of the statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rava that </span>even if the seller withheld something for himself along the fourth boundary, <span class="gemarra-regular">he did not withhold anything at all in the field </span>itself. <span class="gemarra-regular">And we also conclude </span>according to both versions <span class="gemarra-regular">that where </span>the fourth boundary <span class="gemarra-regular">is included </span>within the space defined by the two adjacent boundaries, <span class="gemarra-regular">and there is no row of trees on it and it is not </span>an area fit for sowing <span class="gemarra-regular">nine </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kav</span> of seed, the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">acquires </span>it. And furthermore, we conclude according to both versions that if the fourth boundary <span class="gemarra-regular">is not included </span>within the two adjacent boundaries, <span class="gemarra-regular">and there is a row of trees on it, or it is </span>an area fit for sowing <span class="gemarra-regular">nine </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kav</span> of seed, the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">does not acquire </span>it.
If the fourth boundary <span class="gemarra-regular">is included </span>within the two adjacent boundaries, <span class="gemarra-regular">and there is </span>a row of trees <span class="gemarra-regular">on it </span>or it is fit for sowing nine <span class="it-text">kav</span> of seed, or if the fourth boundary <span class="gemarra-regular">is not included </span>within the two adjacent boundaries, <span class="gemarra-regular">and there is no </span>row of trees <span class="gemarra-regular">on it </span>nor is it fit for sowing nine <span class="it-text">kav</span>, the ruling in these cases <span class="gemarra-regular">was stated in this direction, </span>that the land adjacent to the fourth boundary is acquired by the buyer, <span class="gemarra-regular">and it was stated in that direction, </span>that this land is not acquired by the buyer, depending upon which version of Rava’s statement is accepted. Since there is no clear ruling in these cases, the decision is left to <span class="gemarra-regular">the discretion of the judges</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> who must rule in accordance with what appears to them to be the intention of the seller.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba said: </span>If one owns a field in partnership with another, and he says to a third person: I am selling you <span class="gemarra-regular">the half that I have in this land</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> he means to sell him <span class="gemarra-regular">half </span>of that field, i.e., his entire share. If he says to the buyer: I am selling you <span class="gemarra-regular">half of the land that I have, </span>he means to sell him <span class="gemarra-regular">one-quarter </span>of that field, i.e., half of his share. <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said to him: What is different </span>about <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>wording <span class="gemarra-regular">and what is different </span>about <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>wording, that you rule differently in the two cases? Rabba <span class="gemarra-regular">was silent, </span>offering no reply.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said: I had assumed that since he was silent, he </span>must have <span class="gemarra-regular">accepted </span>my opinion and retracted his statement; <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">is not so. </span>As on another occasion <span class="gemarra-regular">I saw certain bills </span>of sale <span class="gemarra-regular">that issued from </span>my <span class="gemarra-regular">Master’s house,</span> that is, they were issued under the auspices of my master Rabba, <span class="gemarra-regular">in which it was written: The half that I have in this land, </span>and it was clear from another clause in the bill that <span class="gemarra-regular">half </span>of the field was being sold. And there was another bill of sale in which it was written: <span class="gemarra-regular">Half of the land that I have, </span>and it was clear from another clause in the bill that <span class="gemarra-regular">one-quarter </span>of the field was being sold.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabba </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">said: </span>If one sold land to another and delineated boundaries on three sides of the field, and with regard to the fourth side he wrote in the bill of sale: <span class="gemarra-regular">The boundary </span>of the field is <span class="gemarra-regular">the land through which </span>the field <span class="gemarra-regular">is halved, </span>he has sold him <span class="gemarra-regular">half </span>of the field. If he writes with regard to the fourth boundary: <span class="gemarra-regular">The boundary </span>of the field is <span class="gemarra-regular">the land from which </span>a plot <span class="gemarra-regular">can be set apart, </span>he has sold him only an area fit for sowing <span class="gemarra-regular">nine </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kav</span> of seed, as that is the minimum size of a plot of land defined as a field.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said to him: What is different </span>about <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>wording, <span class="gemarra-regular">and what is different </span>about <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>wording, that you rule differently in the two cases? Rabba <span class="gemarra-regular">was silent, </span>and did not respond. The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">understood from this </span>silence that Abaye understood that Rabba retracted his ruling and conceded that in both <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">and that </span>case, the buyer acquires <span class="gemarra-regular">half </span>of the field. 

Daf 63a

<span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">is not so, as Rav Yeimar bar Shelemya said: </span>The matter <span class="gemarra-regular">was explained to me by Abaye, </span>as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">Whether </span>the seller writes with regard to the fourth boundary: <span class="gemarra-regular">The boundary </span>of the field is <span class="gemarra-regular">the land through which </span>the field <span class="gemarra-regular">is halved</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> or </span>he writes: <span class="gemarra-regular">The boundary </span>of the field is <span class="gemarra-regular">the land through which </span>a plot <span class="gemarra-regular">can be set apart, if he said to </span>the buyer: <span class="gemarra-regular">These are its boundaries</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> he has sold him <span class="gemarra-regular">half </span>of the field. But if <span class="gemarra-regular">he did not say to </span>the buyer: <span class="gemarra-regular">These are its boundaries, </span>he has sold him only an area fit for sowing <span class="gemarra-regular">nine </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kav</span> of seed.
§ The Gemara raises a question about a similar case: <span class="gemarra-regular">It </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious </span>that if one <span class="gemarra-regular">said: So-and-so should share in my property, </span>he means to give him <span class="gemarra-regular">half </span>of the property. If he said: <span class="gemarra-regular">Give so-and-so a portio</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of my property</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> what </span>is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? What portion of the property must he give him?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Ravina bar Kisi said: Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a proof concerning the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in this case, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who says: Give so-and-so a portion of </span>my <span class="gemarra-regular">cister</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> for his water needs, <span class="gemarra-regular">Sumakhos says: </span>He must give him <span class="gemarra-regular">not less than one-quarter </span>of the water in the cistern. If he qualifies his words and says: Give so-and-so a portion of my cistern’s water <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">barrel, </span>he must give him <span class="gemarra-regular">not less than one-eighth </span>of the water. If he says: Give him a portion <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">pot, </span>he must give him <span class="gemarra-regular">not less than one-twelfth </span>of the water. And if he says: Give him <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">cup</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> he must give him <span class="gemarra-regular">not less than one-sixteenth </span>of the water. In any event, this <span class="it-text">baraita</span> indicates that the unqualified phrase: Give so-and-so a portion, should be understood to mean: Give him one-quarter.
The Gemara now considers another case in which the seller withholds something for himself in a sale. <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a Levit</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> who sold a field to an Israelit</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and said to him: </span>I am selling you this field <span class="gemarra-regular">on the condition that the first tith</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> from the produce growing in the field, which must be given to a Levite, is <span class="gemarra-regular">mine, </span>and it will be given to me every year and not to any other Levite, <span class="gemarra-regular">the first tithe is his. And if he said: </span>I am selling you the field on the condition that the tithe will be given <span class="gemarra-regular">to me and to my sons, </span>then if <span class="gemarra-regular">he dies, </span>the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">must give </span>the tithe <span class="gemarra-regular">to his sons.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">But if </span>the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>the buyer: This stipulation will remain in force <span class="gemarra-regular">as long as this field is in your possession, </span>then if the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">sold it and</span> afterward <span class="gemarra-regular">bought it </span>back <span class="gemarra-regular">again, </span>the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">has no </span>claim <span class="gemarra-regular">on him. </span>Since the field left the buyer’s possession in the interim, the seller no longer has a claim to the tithe.
The Gemara challenges the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> taught in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Why </span>should the seller ever have a right to the tithe after he has sold the field? After all, <span class="gemarra-regular">a person cannot transfer ownership </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">an object</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that has not </span>yet <span class="gemarra-regular">come into the world</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> How, then, can the seller acquire a portion of the produce that does not yet exist? The Gemara answers that <span class="gemarra-regular">since </span>the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>the buyer: I am selling you this field <span class="gemarra-regular">on the condition that the first tithe </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">mine, </span>it is as if <span class="gemarra-regular">he withheld the site </span>where the <span class="gemarra-regular">tithe </span>is grown for himself when he sold the field, and that site already exists.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Reish Lakish said: That is to say </span>that with regard to one <span class="gemarra-regular">who sells a house to another and says to him: </span>I am selling you this house <span class="gemarra-regular">on the condition that the upper story [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">deyota</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is mine, the upper story is his. </span>

Daf 63b

<span class="gemarra-regular">With regard to what </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakh</span><span class="gemarra-italic">a</span> did Reish Lakish say this? In any case the upper story is his, as when he sold the house, it was only the lower story that he sold to the buyer. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Zevid says: </span>He said this to teach the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">that if </span>the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">wishes to extend </span>from the upper story <span class="gemarra-regular">projection</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> over the courtyard, which was included in the sale, <span class="gemarra-regular">he may extend </span>them. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa says: </span>He said this to teach the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">that if </span>this upper story collapses and the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">wishes to build an upper story on top of it </span>to replace it, <span class="gemarra-regular">he may build </span>it.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, </span>according <span class="gemarra-regular">to Rav Zevid</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> this </span>explanation is consistent with <span class="gemarra-regular">that which </span>Reish Lakish <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches, </span>which begins with: <span class="gemarra-regular">That is to say. </span>As according to Rav Zevid, Reish Lakish infers from the ruling of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> about tithes that even though the seller of the house did not explicitly withhold anything for himself, the court interprets his use of his superfluous stipulation as an indication that he wished to withhold for himself the space over the courtyard for the projections. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>according <span class="gemarra-regular">to Rav Pappa, what </span>did Reish Lakish mean when he said his statement that begins with the phrase: <span class="gemarra-regular">That is to say? </span>The seller’s right to rebuild the upper story after it collapses is not derived from the superfluous stipulation that he attached to the transaction, and it is not inferred from the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>. The Gemara concludes: Indeed, Rav Pappa’s interpretation is <span class="gemarra-regular">difficult, </span>as it does not account for the wording of Reish Lakish’s statement.
§ The Gemara discusses what is included in the wordings of various contracts. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Dimi from Neharde’a said: </span>Concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">this one who sells a house to another </span>and wants the sale to include the entire property, <span class="gemarra-regular">even if he writes for </span>the buyer in the bill of sale: I am selling you <span class="gemarra-regular">the depth and the heigh</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> of the house, he <span class="gemarra-regular">must </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">write for him</span><span class="gemarra-regular">:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Acquire for yourself </span>the property <span class="gemarra-regular">from the depth of the earth up to the height of the sky. What is the reason </span>for this addition? The reason is <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">does not acquire the depth and the height </span>of the property <span class="gemarra-regular">without </span>explicit <span class="gemarra-regular">specification</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and therefore, unless the matter has been explicitly stipulated, the buyer may not dig under the house or build above it. The words: <span class="gemarra-regular">The depth and the height, effect the acquisition of the depth and the height </span>of the house for the buyer, allowing him to dig below or build above the house. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the additional phrase: <span class="gemarra-regular">From the depth of the earth up to the height of the sky, effect</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the acquisition of the pit and the cistern and the tunnel</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> associated with the house.
The Gemara proposes: <span class="gemarra-regular">Let us say </span>that the mishna (64a) <span class="gemarra-regular">supports </span>Rav Dimi’s opinion: One who sells a house has sold <span class="gemarra-regular">neither the pit nor the cistern, even if he writes for </span>the buyer in the bill of sale that he is selling <span class="gemarra-regular">him the depth and the height </span>of the house. <span class="gemarra-regular">As if it enters your mind </span>to say that the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">acquires the depth and the height </span>of the house even <span class="gemarra-regular">without </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">specification </span>that the depth and the height of the house are included in the sale, <span class="gemarra-regular">let </span>the phrase <span class="gemarra-regular">the depth and the height effect the acquisition of the pit and the cistern and the tunnels, </span>as he attached an additional stipulation to the transaction. The Gemara rejects this opinion: The mishna is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">did not write </span>these words <span class="gemarra-regular">for him.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>this line of reasoning is difficult, as the mishna explicitly <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>that the pit and the cistern are not sold <span class="gemarra-regular">even if </span>the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">writes for </span>the buyer that he is selling <span class="gemarra-regular">him </span>the depth and the height of the house. The Gemara answers that <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>is what the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">is saying: Even though </span>the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">did not write </span>these words <span class="gemarra-regular">for him </span>in the bill of sale, <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>the purpose of <span class="gemarra-regular">acquiring the depth and the height </span>of the house, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is considered as if he wrote </span>them, as it is assumed that they were omitted by accident. By contrast, <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>the purpose of <span class="gemarra-regular">acquiring the pit and the cistern and the tunnels, if </span>the seller explicitly <span class="gemarra-regular">wrote for him </span>the words <span class="gemarra-regular">the depth and the height, </span>the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">acquires </span>them, <span class="gemarra-regular">but if he did not write </span>that phrase in the bill of sale, the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">does not acquire </span>them. No proof can be derived from this mishna.
§ The Gemara now considers a different mishna. <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>what was taught in the mishna (61a): One who sells his house without explicitly stating what is included in the sale has <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>sold <span class="gemarra-regular">the roof </span>along with the house <span class="gemarra-regular">when it has a parapet ten handbreadths high, </span>as such a roof is considered a separate entity and is not included in the sale of the house. 

Daf 64a

<span class="gemarra-regular">And if it enters your mind </span>to say that when a house is sold <span class="gemarra-regular">without specification, </span>the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">acquires the depth and the height </span>of the house, then even <span class="gemarra-regular">when </span>it has a parapet <span class="gemarra-regular">ten handbreadths high, what of it</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> Why shouldn’t the buyer acquire the roof? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Since </span>the parapet <span class="gemarra-regular">is ten handbreadths high</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the roof <span class="gemarra-regular">is significant </span>in its own right, and therefore, unless it is specifically included in the sale, the buyer does not acquire such a roof along with the house.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Ravina said to Rav Ashi: Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>another proof, <span class="gemarra-regular">as Reish Lakish says: That is to say </span>that with regard to one <span class="gemarra-regular">who sells a house to another and says to him: </span>I am selling you this house <span class="gemarra-regular">on the condition that the upper story is mine, the upper story is his. And </span>in the Gemara’s examination of Reish Lakish’s statement, <span class="gemarra-regular">we said: With regard to what </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> did Reish Lakish say this? In any case the upper story is his, as when he sold the house it was only the lower story that he sold to the buyer. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Zevid says: </span>He said this to teach the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">that if </span>the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">wishes to extend from </span>the upper story <span class="gemarra-regular">projections </span>over the courtyard, which was included in the sale, <span class="gemarra-regular">he may extend </span>them. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa says: </span>He said this to teach the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">that if </span>this upper story collapses and the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">wishes to build an upper story on top of it </span>to replace it, <span class="gemarra-regular">he may build </span>it.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if it enters your mind </span>to say that when a house is sold <span class="gemarra-regular">without specification, </span>the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">does not acquire </span>the depth and the height of a house, Rav Pappa’s statement is puzzling. As <span class="gemarra-regular">why do I </span>need the seller to stipulate that he is selling the house <span class="gemarra-regular">on the conditio</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> that the upper story is his when in any event the space above the house remains in the seller’s possession? The Gemara answers: Stipulating that he is selling the house <span class="gemarra-regular">on the condition </span>that the upper story is his <span class="gemarra-regular">benefits him </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">that</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> if </span>the upper story <span class="gemarra-regular">collapses, he </span>may <span class="gemarra-regular">rebuild it. </span>Without this stipulation the seller could not rebuild it, even if the sale did not include the depth and the height of the house.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> One who sells a house without specification has sold <span class="gemarra-regular">neither the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">pi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">nor the cistern [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">dut</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">even if he writes for </span>the buyer in the bill of sale that he is selling <span class="gemarra-regular">him the depth and the height </span>of the house, as anything that is not part of the house, like pits and cisterns, must be explicitly mentioned in the contract or else they remain in the seller’s possession. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>therefore the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">must purchase for himself a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">pat</span><span class="gemarra-regular">h</span> through the buyer’s domain to reach whatever remains his, because he has sold the area of the house along with the house itself, and he no longer has permission to walk there. This is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of Rabbi Akiva. And the Rabbis say: </span>The seller <span class="gemarra-regular">need not purchase for himself a path </span>through the buyer’s domain, as this is certainly included in what he has withheld for himself from the sale.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Akiva concedes that when </span>the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">says to </span>the buyer in the bill of sale: I am selling you this house <span class="gemarra-regular">apart from </span>the pit and the cistern, <span class="gemarra-regular">he need not purchase for himself a path </span>through the buyer’s domain. Since the seller unnecessarily emphasized that the pit and the cistern are not included in the sale, he presumably intended to reserve for himself the right of access to them.
If the seller kept the house, but <span class="gemarra-regular">sold </span>the pit and the cistern <span class="gemarra-regular">to another</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rabbi Akiva says: </span>The buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">need not purchase for himself a path </span>through the seller’s domain to reach what he has bought. <span class="gemarra-regular">But the Rabbis say: He must purchase for himself a path </span>through the seller’s domain.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> It is related that <span class="gemarra-regular">Ravina </span>once <span class="gemarra-regular">sat </span>and examined the matter <span class="gemarra-regular">and posed a difficulty: A pit is </span>the same as <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">cistern</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Why, then, was it necessary to mention both of them? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava Tosfa’a said to Ravina: Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a solution to this question, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Both a pit and a cistern </span>are dug out <span class="gemarra-regular">in the ground; </span>the difference is <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a pit </span>is constructed <span class="gemarra-regular">through digging </span>alone, <span class="gemarra-regular">while a cistern </span>is subsequently finished on the inside <span class="gemarra-regular">by </span><span class="gemarra-regular">buildin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span> masonry walls. It is similarly related that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi </span>once <span class="gemarra-regular">sat and posed a difficulty: A pit is </span>the same as <span class="gemarra-regular">a cistern. Mar Kashisha, son of Rav Ḥisda, said to Rav Ashi: Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a solution to this question, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Both a pit and a cistern </span>are dug <span class="gemarra-regular">in the ground, </span>the difference is <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a pit </span>is constructed <span class="gemarra-regular">through digging </span>alone, <span class="gemarra-regular">while a cistern </span>is subsequently finished on the inside <span class="gemarra-regular">by building </span>masonry walls.
§ The mishna teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">must purchase for himself a path </span>through the buyer’s domain; this is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of Rabbi Akiva. And the Rabbis say: </span>The seller <span class="gemarra-regular">need not </span>purchase such a path. <span class="gemarra-regular">What, is it not about this </span>issue, which will immediately be explained, that Rabbi Akiva and the Rabbis <span class="gemarra-regular">disagree? </span>

Daf 64b

<span class="gemarra-regular">As Rabbi Akiva holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span><span class="gemarra-regular">who sells, sells generously</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> so that whatever is not explicitly excluded from the sale is assumed to be sold, <span class="gemarra-regular">while the Rabbis hold </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">one who sells, sells sparingly,</span> so that whatever is not explicitly included in the sale is assumed to be unsold. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>perhaps <span class="gemarra-regular">that which is also stated generally: Rabbi Akiva </span>conforms <span class="gemarra-regular">to his </span>standard line of <span class="gemarra-regular">reasoning, as he says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">one who sells, sells</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> generously, </span>is derived <span class="gemarra-regular">from here.</span>
The Gemara rejects this opinion and asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">From where </span>do you arrive at such a conclusion? <span class="gemarra-regular">Perhaps </span>Rabbi Akiva and the Rabbis do not disagree whether, in principle, a person who sells, sells generously or sparingly, but rather their disagreement is limited to this specific case. As <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Akiva holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a person does not want to spend his money </span>on the purchase of a house <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>then have <span class="gemarra-regular">others tread upon his </span>property, and therefore he says that the seller must purchase for himself a path through the buyer’s domain to reach his pit. <span class="gemarra-regular">And the Rabbis hold </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a person does not want to receive money </span>for the sale of his house <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>then have to <span class="gemarra-regular">fly through the ai</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> in order to reach his pit, and therefore they say that the seller presumably withheld for himself a path to his pit.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>the proof is <span class="gemarra-regular">from the last clause </span>of the mishna, which states: If the seller kept the house but <span class="gemarra-regular">sold </span>the pit and the cistern <span class="gemarra-regular">to another, Rabbi Akiva says: </span>The buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">need not purchase for himself a path </span>through the seller’s domain. <span class="gemarra-regular">But the Rabbis say: He must purchase for himself a path </span>through the seller’s domain. The <span class="it-text">tanna’im</span> seem to disagree as to whether a person who sells, sells generously or sparingly.
The Gemara rejects this proof as well: <span class="gemarra-regular">Perhaps they disagree about </span>the following: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Akiva holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">we follow the intention of the buyer, </span>as we assume that he would not have bought the pit if he would have to fly through the air to get there. <span class="gemarra-regular">And the Rabbis hold </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">we follow the intention of the seller, </span>as presumably he would not have sold the pit if the buyer had the right to tread upon the seller’s property to reach it.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>the proof that these <span class="it-text">tanna’im</span> disagree whether one who sells, sells generously or sparingly is <span class="gemarra-regular">from this </span>mishna (71a), which teaches: One who sells a field, even if he states that he is selling everything in it to the buyer, has sold <span class="gemarra-regular">neither the cistern, nor the winepress</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> nor the dovecote</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> whether </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">abandoned or utilized, </span>as these items are not part of the field itself. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">must purchase </span>for himself <span class="gemarra-regular">a path </span>through the buyer’s domain to reach whatever remains his. This is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of Rabbi Akiva.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> And the Rabbis say: </span>The seller <span class="gemarra-regular">need not </span>purchase a path through the buyer’s domain.
The Gemara explains the proof: <span class="gemarra-regular">Why do I need this </span>ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">as well, </span>seeing that this case involving the sale of a field appears to be identical to that involving the sale of a house? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, is it not teaching us that Rabbi Akiva holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">one who sells, sells</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> generously, </span>and therefore the seller must purchase for himself a path to his property, <span class="gemarra-regular">while the Rabbis hold </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">one who sells, sells sparingly, </span>and therefore the purchase of such a path is not necessary?
The Gemara rejects this opinion: <span class="gemarra-regular">Perhaps </span>the first mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">taught us </span>this dispute with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a house, and </span>the later mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>this dispute with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a field. And </span>while this may seem redundant, both rulings are <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as had </span>the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">taught us </span>this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> only with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a house, </span>I would have said that the buyer is particular about people passing through his house, <span class="gemarra-regular">because he desires privac</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span> there. And it is for this reason that Rabbi Akiva says that in the absence of an explicit stipulation, the seller must purchase for himself a path to the pit. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a field, </span>which is exposed to all, <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that the buyer is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>concerned about privacy.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And, </span>conversely, <span class="gemarra-regular">had </span>the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">taught us </span>this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> only with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a field, </span>I would have said that the buyer is particular about people passing through his field, <span class="gemarra-regular">because treading </span>upon the field <span class="gemarra-regular">is detrimental to it</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> And it is for this reason that Rabbi Akiva says that the seller must purchase for himself a path to the pit. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a house, </span>which is not adversely affected by treading through it, <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that the buyer is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>opposed to the seller passing through.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>the proof that Rabbi Akiva and the Rabbis disagree whether one who sells, sells generously or sparingly is <span class="gemarra-regular">from the latter clause </span>of that mishna (71a), which teaches: But if the seller kept the field but <span class="gemarra-regular">sold </span>the cistern and winepress <span class="gemarra-regular">to another </span>person, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Akiva says: </span>The buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">need not purchase for himself a path </span>through the seller’s domain to reach what he has bought, since a seller sells generously. <span class="gemarra-regular">But the Rabbis say: He must </span>purchase for himself a path through the seller’s domain.
The Gemara explains the proof: <span class="gemarra-regular">Why do I also </span>need <span class="gemarra-regular">this, </span>seeing as <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>case involving the sale of a pit or a winepress in a field <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>identical to <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>involving the sale of a pit or a cistern in a house? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, is it not teaching u</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that Rabbi Akiva holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">one who sells, sells generously</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> while the Rabbis hold </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">one who</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> sells, sells sparingly? </span>The Gemara affirms: <span class="gemarra-regular">Conclude from </span>the latter clauses of these <span class="it-text">mishnayot</span> that this is so.
<span class="gemarra-regular">It was stated </span>that the <span class="it-text">amora’im</span> disagree about how the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> should be decided with regard to this issue. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna </span>says that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: </span>

Daf 65a

<span class="gemarra-regular">The </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with the statement of the Rabbis, while Rav Yirmeya bar Abb</span><span class="gemarra-regular">a</span> says that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel says: The </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Akiva. Rav Yirmeya bar Abba said to Rav Huna</span><span class="gemarra-regular">:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> But many times I said before Rav </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Akiva, and never did he say anything to me, </span>which indicates that he holds that the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Akiva and not that of the Rabbis. Rav Huna <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: How did you teach </span>the mishna before Rav? Rav Yirmeya bar Abba <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: I taught </span>it with <span class="gemarra-regular">the opposite </span>attributions, that is to say, the opinion that is attributed in the mishna to Rabbi Akiva, I would teach in the name of the Rabbis. Rav Huna said to him: <span class="gemarra-regular">Due to that </span>reason, <span class="gemarra-regular">he never said anything to you, </span>as Rav agreed with the version that you attributed to Rabbi Akiva.
With regard to the opinions of Rav and Shmuel, <span class="gemarra-regular">Ravina said to Rav Ashi: Shall we say </span>that Rav and Shmuel, in their opinions stated with regard to this matter, each <span class="gemarra-regular">follow their </span>general lines of <span class="gemarra-regular">reasoning, </span>as they appear to have disagreed about this same issue in another context as well?
<span class="gemarra-regular">As Rav Naḥman says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel says: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">brothers who divide</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> their father’s estate between them, <span class="gemarra-regular">they do not have </span>a right of <span class="gemarra-regular">way against each other, </span>i.e., to walk through the other’s property to reach his own, even though this is how the place was used in their father’s lifetime; <span class="gemarra-regular">nor </span>do they have the right of <span class="gemarra-regular">ladders against each other, </span>i.e., the right to set up a ladder in the other’s property in order to get to his own; <span class="gemarra-regular">nor </span>do they have the right of <span class="gemarra-regular">windows against each other, </span>i.e., the right to prevent the other from building a wall facing his windows; <span class="gemarra-regular">nor </span>do they have the right of <span class="gemarra-regular">a water channel against each other, </span>i.e., the right to pass a water channel through the other’s property.
Rav Naḥman continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">And be careful with these </span>rulings, <span class="gemarra-regular">since they are established </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakhot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. And Rav says: They do </span>retain all of these privileges. Consequently, Rav and Shmuel appear to be following their general lines of reasoning here, as Shmuel holds that when the brothers, who are like sellers, divide their father’s estate, they transfer property to each other generously without retaining privileges in each other’s property, while Rav holds that they transfer the property sparingly.
The Gemara comments: Nevertheless, it was <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>to teach this disagreement in both cases, as the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in the one case cannot be derived from the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in the other. <span class="gemarra-regular">As had we been taught </span>this dispute only <span class="gemarra-regular">in that </span>case, of the brothers who divided their father’s estate, I would have said that only <span class="gemarra-regular">in that </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">does Rav say </span>that they retain all of the earlier privileges, <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>one brother can <span class="gemarra-regular">say to </span>the other: <span class="gemarra-regular">I wish to live in </span>this house <span class="gemarra-regular">just as my ancestors, </span>who had all of those privileges, <span class="gemarra-regular">lived in it. Know </span>that there is substance to this claim, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is written: “Instead of your fathers shall be your sons” </span>(Psalms 45:17). <span class="gemarra-regular">But in this </span>case of an ordinary house sale, <span class="gemarra-regular">say that he concedes to Shmuel </span>that a seller sells generously.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if </span>the dispute <span class="gemarra-regular">was stated </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">in this </span>case of an ordinary house sale, I would have said that only <span class="gemarra-regular">in this </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">does Shmuel say </span>that a seller sells generously and does not withhold a path for himself, <span class="gemarra-regular">but in that </span>case, of the brothers who divided their father’s estate, <span class="gemarra-regular">say that he concedes to Rav </span>that the desire to live there just as his ancestors did supersedes the seller’s general tendency to sell generously. Therefore, it was <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>to teach this dispute in both cases.
As for the ruling itself, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman, </span>who was a disciple of Shmuel, <span class="gemarra-regular">said to Rav Huna: </span>Is <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in accordance with our opinion, or is the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in accordance with your opinion? </span>Rav Huna <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: The </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with your opinion, as you are near the gate of the Exilarch</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> where the judges are </span>frequently <span class="gemarra-regular">found, </span>and therefore you are more proficient in monetary law.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">It was stated: </span>If there are <span class="gemarra-regular">two residences, one </span>situated <span class="gemarra-regular">behind the other</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and the owner transferred ownership of the <span class="gemarra-regular">two of them, </span>each one to a different person, <span class="gemarra-regular">by means of </span>a <span class="gemarra-regular">sale, </span>or if he transferred ownership of the <span class="gemarra-regular">two of them, </span>each to a different person, <span class="gemarra-regular">as a gift, they do not have </span>a right of <span class="gemarra-regular">way against each other</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>That is, the one who acquired the inner residence may not pass through the outer residence, since each of them received equal privileges from the previous owner. And <span class="gemarra-regular">all the more so </span>is this the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> if <span class="gemarra-regular">the outer </span>residence was transferred <span class="gemarra-regular">by means of a gift, and the inner </span>residence was transferred <span class="gemarra-regular">by means of a sale, </span>as it may be assumed that a gift is made in a more generous manner than is a sale.
As for the case where the <span class="gemarra-regular">outer </span>residence was transferred <span class="gemarra-regular">by means of a sale, and the inner </span>residence was transferred <span class="gemarra-regular">by means of a gift, </span>some Sages at first <span class="gemarra-regular">understood from here </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">they do not have a </span>right of <span class="gemarra-regular">way against each other, </span>that is, that the recipient of the inner residence may not pass through the outer residence.
<span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">is not so, </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">didn’t we learn </span>in a mishna (71a): <span class="gemarra-regular">In what </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">is this statement, </span>that these items are excluded, <span class="gemarra-regular">said? </span>It is said <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to one who sells </span>a field, <span class="gemarra-regular">but with regard to one who gives </span>it away as <span class="gemarra-regular">a gift, </span>it is assumed that <span class="gemarra-regular">he gives all of it, </span>including everything found in the field. <span class="gemarra-regular">Apparently, one who gives </span>property <span class="gemarra-regular">as a gift gives </span>it more <span class="gemarra-regular">generously </span>than does one who sells it, as gifts are generally given to friends to whom one wishes to transfer as many privileges as possible. <span class="gemarra-regular">Here too, </span>then, <span class="gemarra-regular">one who gives </span>property <span class="gemarra-regular">as a gift gives </span>it more <span class="gemarra-regular">generously </span>than does one who sells it, and so the recipient of the inner residence acquires a right of way through the outer apartment.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> One <span class="gemarra-regular">who sells a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">hous</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">has, </span>as part of the sale, <span class="gemarra-regular">sold </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">the door, but not the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">key</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">He has sold the mortar that is fixed </span>in the ground, <span class="gemarra-regular">but not the portable </span>one. <span class="gemarra-regular">He has sold the </span>immovable <span class="gemarra-regular">lower millstone [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ha’itzterobil</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">but not the </span>portable <span class="gemarra-regular">upper stone [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">hakelet</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the funnel into which one pours the grain to be ground. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>he has sold <span class="gemarra-regular">neither the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">ove</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">nor the double stove,</span> as they are deemed movable. <span class="gemarra-regular">When </span>the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">says to </span>the buyer: I am selling you <span class="gemarra-regular">it, and everything that is in it, </span>

<span class="gemarra-regular">all these </span>components <span class="gemarra-regular">are sold </span>as part of the sale of the house.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Let </span><span class="gemarra-regular">us say that the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">mishn</span><span class="gemarra-regular">a</span> that distinguishes between different types of household items <span class="gemarra-regular">is not in accordance </span><span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir. As if </span>it is in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir, doesn’t he say </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> (78b): If <span class="gemarra-regular">one sold a vineyard, he has sold </span>all of <span class="gemarra-regular">the utensils of the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">vineyard</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> including the movable ones? The same should be true for the sale of a house.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">You </span>may <span class="gemarra-regular">even say </span>that the mishna was taught in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir, </span>as a distinction can be made between the two cases. <span class="gemarra-regular">There, </span>in the case of a vineyard, the reference is to utensils that are <span class="gemarra-regular">fixe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> in the vineyard and never removed from it, and therefore they are included in the sale, while <span class="gemarra-regular">here, </span>in the case of a house, the mishna is referring to utensils that are <span class="gemarra-regular">not fixed </span>in the house, and therefore they are not part of the sale. The Gemara objects: <span class="gemarra-regular">But doesn’t </span>the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teach </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> governing <span class="gemarra-regular">a key in similar fashion to </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> governing <span class="gemarra-regular">the door, </span>indicating that <span class="gemarra-regular">just as a door </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">fixed </span>in the house, <span class="gemarra-regular">so too, a key </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">fixe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> in the house? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, it is clear </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the mishna is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> (<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span> 3:1): One <span class="gemarra-regular">who sells a house has sold the door and the door bolt and the lock, but </span>he has <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>sold <span class="gemarra-regular">the key. He has sold the morta</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that was hollowed out </span>of the ground <span class="gemarra-regular">but not </span>the mortar <span class="gemarra-regular">that was fixed </span>to the ground after its construction. <span class="gemarra-regular">He has sold the </span>immovable <span class="gemarra-regular">lower millstone but not the </span>portable <span class="gemarra-regular">upper stone. </span>And he has sold <span class="gemarra-regular">neither the oven, nor the double stove, nor the hand mill. Rabbi Eliezer says: </span>The principle is that <span class="gemarra-regular">any </span>item <span class="gemarra-regular">attached to the ground is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">like the ground </span>and included in the sale.
<span class="gemarra-regular">When </span>the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">says to </span>the buyer: I am selling you <span class="gemarra-regular">it and everything that</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is in it, all these </span>components <span class="gemarra-regular">are sold </span>along with the house. <span class="gemarra-regular">Both </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">he did not sell the pit or the cistern or the gallery, </span>as they are considered separate entities that are not at all part of the house.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">A duc</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that one hollowed ou</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and afterward attached </span>to the ground or to a building <span class="gemarra-regular">invalidates a ritual bat</span><span class="gemarra-regular">h</span> through the water it channels to the bath. The water in a ritual bath must be gathered directly from rain or a stream, not drawn with vessels. If one hollowed out a log and used it to channel water into the bath, this is considered drawn water, as he used a vessel. By contrast, if <span class="gemarra-regular">one attached it </span>first <span class="gemarra-regular">and afterward hollowed it out, it does not invalidate the ritual bath. </span>Before the log was hollowed out, it was already attached to and considered part of the ground, and therefore the act of hollowing it out does not turn it into a vessel. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Whose </span>opinion is this? It appears to be <span class="gemarra-regular">neither </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Eliezer, nor </span>that of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis.</span>
The Gemara clarifies the question: To <span class="gemarra-regular">which </span>opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Eliezer </span>is this referring? <span class="gemarra-regular">If we say </span>it is referring to the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Eliezer </span>in the aforementioned <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>the sale of <span class="gemarra-regular">a house, </span>that any item attached to the ground is considered part of the house and is sold along with it, there is a difficulty. As <span class="gemarra-regular">perhaps this is the reasoning </span>employed in the dispute with regard to the sale of a house, <span class="gemarra-regular">that Rabbi Eliezer holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">one who sells, sells generousl</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span> anything that is attached to the ground, <span class="gemarra-regular">while the Rabbis hold </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">one who sells, sells sparingly, </span>selling only utensils that serve an intrinsic function in the house and nothing else, even if they are attached to the ground. But this teaches us nothing about the opinions of Rabbi Eliezer and the Rabbis with respect to a ritual bath.
<span class="gemarra-regular">But rather, </span>the reference must be to the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Eliezer concerning a beehive. As we learned </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Shevi’it</span> 10:7): With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a beehive </span>attached to the ground by clay, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Eliezer says: It is like land</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">one may write a document that prevents the Sabbatical Year from canceling an outstanding debt </span><span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">prosbol</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] </span>based <span class="gemarra-regular">upon it. </span>Such a document cannot be written unless the borrower owns some land, and a beehive is considered like land for this purpose. 

Daf 66a

<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>such a beehive <span class="gemarra-regular">is not susceptible to ritual impurity </span>as long as it is fixed <span class="gemarra-regular">in its place</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> And one who removes </span>honey <span class="gemarra-regular">from it on Shabba</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to bring <span class="gemarra-regular">a sin-offering, </span>as he is likened to one who harvests produce attached to the ground.
<span class="gemarra-regular">But the Rabbis say: </span>Such a beehive <span class="gemarra-regular">is not like land</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">one may not write a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">prosbol</span> based <span class="gemarra-regular">upon it, and it is susceptible to ritual impurity </span>even when it is fixed <span class="gemarra-regular">in its place, and one who removes </span>honey <span class="gemarra-regular">from it on Shabba</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from bringing a sin-offering. This mishna suggests that Rabbi Eliezer holds that a vessel that was affixed to the ground is considered like land for all purposes. This contradicts the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that states that if one hollowed out a pipe and then affixed it to the ground, it is still considered a vessel, and water flowing through it is considered drawn water that invalidates a ritual bath. This indicates that the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> was not taught in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Eliezer.
The Gemara rejects this opinion, stating that <span class="gemarra-regular">there, </span>in the mishna, Rabbi Eliezer treats the beehive like land for <span class="gemarra-regular">the reason that Rabbi Elazar stated, </span>and not because he holds that all vessels that are affixed to the ground are considered like land. <span class="gemarra-regular">As Rabbi Elazar stated: What is the reasoning for </span>the statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Eliezer </span>with regard to one who removes honey from a beehive? His rationale is <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is written: </span>“And he put forth the end of the rod that was in his hand <span class="gemarra-regular">and dipped it in the honeycomb </span><span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ya’arat</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">hadevash</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]” </span>(I Samuel 14:27).
Rabbi Eliezer understands that since the Hebrew words used here for honeycomb can also mean honey forest, the verse comes to teach that <span class="gemarra-regular">just as </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a forest</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> one who picks </span>anything from a tree <span class="gemarra-regular">on Shabbat </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to bring <span class="gemarra-regular">a sin-offering, so too, </span>with regard to a beehive containing <span class="gemarra-regular">honey, one who removes </span>honey <span class="gemarra-regular">from it on Shabbat </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to bring <span class="gemarra-regular">a sin-offering, </span>as the beehive is treated like land. Consequently, Rabbi Eliezer relies here on a special derivation, which does not necessarily apply to other vessels. Therefore, nothing can be learned from this about Rabbi Eliezer’s opinion with regard to the pipe in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>the reference with regard to the hollowed-out duct must be to the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Eliezer concerning </span>a baker’s <span class="gemarra-regular">board </span>on which he kneads the dough, <span class="gemarra-regular">as we learned </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Kelim</span> 15:2): With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a baker’s board [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">daf</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">shel</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">naḥtomin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that was affixed to the wall</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rabbi Eliezer renders </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">not susceptible to ritual impurity, while the Rabbis render </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">susceptible to ritual impurity. </span>This seems to indicate that, according to Rabbi Eliezer, anything that is affixed to the ground or to something else that is affixed to the ground is treated like land, and therefore it cannot become ritually impure.
Having concluded that this is the dispute between Rabbi Eliezer and the Rabbis that was referred to previously, the Gemara repeats the question raised earlier about the ruling in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> with regard to a duct: <span class="gemarra-regular">Whose </span>opinion is it? It appears to be neither that of Rabbi Eliezer nor that of the Rabbis.
