As <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>it is the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Eliezer, </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">even if one hollowed out </span>a duct <span class="gemarra-regular">and afterward he fixed it </span>to the ground, water flowing through it should not be considered drawn water that invalidates a ritual bath, as according to Rabbi Eliezer, a baker’s board that was first a vessel, but then became fixed in a wall, is treated like land. And <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>it is the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis, </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">even if he </span>first <span class="gemarra-regular">fixed </span>the duct to the ground <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">afterward he hollowed it out, </span>the duct should <span class="gemarra-regular">also </span>be treated like a vessel, and the water flowing through it should be considered drawn water, as the Rabbis do not differentiate with regard to the stage at which the baker’s board was affixed to the wall.
The Gemara responds: <span class="gemarra-regular">Actually, </span>one can explain that the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Eliezer, but </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> governing <span class="gemarra-regular">flat wooden vessel</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> without a receptacle, such as a baker’s board, <span class="gemarra-regular">is different, as </span>they are vessels susceptible to <span class="gemarra-regular">ritual impurity </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">by rabbinic law</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> but by Torah law they are not vessels susceptible to ritual impurity. Therefore, Rabbi Eliezer agrees that when the baker’s board is affixed to the wall, it is no longer subject to the rabbinic decree. A hollowed-out duct, however, is a vessel susceptible to ritual impurity by Torah law, and it remains so even if afterward it was affixed to the ground. Therefore, the water flowing through it invalidates a ritual bath.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">By inference, </span>from the fact that Rabbi Eliezer is more stringent in the case of the duct and distinguishes between a duct that was first hollowed out and only afterward affixed to the ground, and one that was first affixed to the ground and only afterward hollowed out, does it not follow <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> governing <span class="gemarra-regular">drawn </span>water, i.e., that drawn water added to a ritual bath that does not already contain the necessary quantity of water invalidates it, applies <span class="gemarra-regular">by Torah law? </span>

Daf 66b

<span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>this is difficult, as <span class="gemarra-regular">we maintain </span>that the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that drawn water invalidates a ritual bath applies only by <span class="gemarra-regular">rabbinic </span>decree. <span class="gemarra-regular">And furthermore, doesn’t Rabbi Yosei ben Rabbi Ḥanina say </span>that the <span class="gemarra-regular">dispute </span>between Rabbi Eliezer and the Rabbis is <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to a board of metal</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and a metal vessel, even if it is flat and lacks a receptacle, is susceptible to ritual impurity by Torah law? This means that, according to Rabbi Eliezer, even a vessel that is susceptible to ritual impurity by Torah law loses its status as a vessel when it is affixed to the ground. Consequently, the question returns: Whose opinion is cited in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that states that if one first hollowed out a duct and afterward fixed it to the ground, it is still considered a vessel and water flowing through it invalidates a ritual bath, but if he first fixed it to the ground and afterward hollowed it out, the water flowing through it does not invalidate a ritual bath?
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Actually, </span>one can explain that the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> who deem the baker’s metal board susceptible to ritual impurity even when it is fixed to a wall, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> governing <span class="gemarra-regular">drawn </span>water added to a deficient ritual bath <span class="gemarra-regular">is different, </span>because drawn water invalidates a deficient ritual bath only <span class="gemarra-regular">by rabbinic law</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and therefore the Rabbis were lenient.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>if one first <span class="gemarra-regular">hollowed out </span>the duct <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">afterward fixed it </span>to the ground, water flowing through it should not invalidate the ritual bath <span class="gemarra-regular">as well. </span>The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">It is different there, </span>where the duct was hollowed out before being affixed to the ground, <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>the duct <span class="gemarra-regular">had the status of a vesse</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> when </span>it was still <span class="gemarra-regular">detached </span>from the ground, and therefore the Rabbis were not willing to be lenient to such an extent and rule that water flowing through the duct does not invalidate a ritual bath.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef raises a dilemma: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">rainwater </span>that was falling and the owner consciously <span class="gemarra-regular">desired </span>that it should fall <span class="gemarra-regular">so that it would wash </span>his immovable <span class="gemarra-regular">lower millstones</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to the seeds </span>in the millstones? The verse “But if any water be put upon the seed…it shall be unclean to you” (Leviticus 11:38) teaches that seeds and other food become susceptible to ritual purity only after they have been detached from the ground, and water, or another of the seven liquids specified in the mishna (<span class="it-text">Makhshirin</span> 6:4), has been put on them. The food must be exposed to the liquid willfully by the owner; that is, he must desire or at least be pleased that the food should become wet. Rav Yosef asks about a case where the owner wants the rain to fall on the millstones: Does that water make the seeds upon which it falls susceptible to ritual impurity?
The Gemara clarifies Rav Yosef’s question: <span class="gemarra-regular">Do not raise this dilemma according to </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Eliezer, who says: Anything attached to the ground </span>has the same legal status <span class="gemarra-regular">as the ground. </span>Since the lower millstones are attached to the ground, they therefore have the same legal status as the ground, and water that falls on the ground, even if it is pleasing to the owner, does not make food susceptible to ritual impurity. <span class="gemarra-regular">When should you raise this dilemma? </span>Raise it <span class="gemarra-regular">according to </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of the Rabbis, who say: </span>It does <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>have the same legal status <span class="gemarra-regular">as the ground. What </span>is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with respect to imparting susceptibility to ritual impurity? The Gemara concludes: An answer to this question was not found; therefore, the dilemma <span class="gemarra-regular">shall stand </span>unresolved.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Neḥemya, son of Rav Yosef, sent </span>a message <span class="gemarra-regular">to Rabba son of Rav Huna the Short at Neharde’a: When this woman </span>bearing this letter <span class="gemarra-regular">comes before you, </span>

Daf 67a

<span class="gemarra-regular">collect for her one-tenth of </span>her father’s <span class="gemarra-regular">estate</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> in keeping with the rabbinic ordinance that states that if a man dies, his sons are obligated to give his daughter a tenth of his landed properties as a dowry, and collect it <span class="gemarra-regular">even from </span>his immovable <span class="gemarra-regular">lower millstones</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as they too are considered landed property. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi said: When we were </span>students <span class="gemarra-regular">in Rav Kahana’s house we would collect </span>for this purpose <span class="gemarra-regular">even from the rent of houses</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span> since this money is earned from real estate, it too has the status of landed property and is included in the dowry calculations.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> One <span class="gemarra-regular">who sells a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">courtyar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> without specifying what is included in the sale <span class="gemarra-regular">has sold </span>with it <span class="gemarra-regular">the houses, pits, ditches, and caves </span>found in the courtyard, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>he has <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>sold <span class="gemarra-regular">the movable </span><span class="gemarra-regular">property</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">When </span>the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">says to </span>the buyer: I am selling you <span class="gemarra-regular">it and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> everything that is in it, all these </span>components <span class="gemarra-regular">are sold </span>along with the courtyard, even the movable property. <span class="gemarra-regular">Both </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>case, where he executes the sale without specification, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>case, where he adds the phrase that includes the movable property, <span class="gemarra-regular">he has not sold the bathhouse, nor </span>has he sold <span class="gemarra-regular">the olive press that is in </span>the courtyard, as each is an entity with a discrete purpose and not an integral part of the courtyard. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Eliezer says: </span>One <span class="gemarra-regular">who sells a courtyard </span>without specifying what is included in the sale <span class="gemarra-regular">has sold only the airspace, </span>i.e., the open space, <span class="gemarra-regular">of the courtyard, </span>but nothing found in the courtyard, not even the houses.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> (<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span>, 3:1): One <span class="gemarra-regular">who sells a courtyard has sold </span>with it <span class="gemarra-regular">the outer houses </span>that can be accessed directly from the courtyard, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the inner houses </span>that can be entered only via the outer houses, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the area of the sand fields [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">uveit</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">haḥolsaot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> As for the <span class="gemarra-regular">stores, </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">that open into </span>the courtyard <span class="gemarra-regular">are sold </span>along <span class="gemarra-regular">with it; </span>those that <span class="gemarra-regular">do not open into it, </span>but rather open into the public domain, even if they are located in the courtyard, <span class="gemarra-regular">are not sold </span>along <span class="gemarra-regular">with it; </span>and those that <span class="gemarra-regular">open </span>both <span class="gemarra-regular">into this </span>courtyard <span class="gemarra-regular">and into that </span>other public domain are grouped together with those that open into this courtyard alone, and both <span class="gemarra-regular">these and those are sold with it. Rabbi Eliezer says: </span>One <span class="gemarra-regular">who sells a courtyard </span>without specifying what is included in the sale <span class="gemarra-regular">has sold only the open space of the courtyard.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">The Master said </span>in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: Stores that <span class="gemarra-regular">open </span>both <span class="gemarra-regular">into this </span>courtyard <span class="gemarra-regular">and into that </span>public domain <span class="gemarra-regular">are sold </span>along <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>the courtyard. The Gemara raises an objection: <span class="gemarra-regular">But didn’t Rabbi Ḥiyya teach </span>a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that states that such stores <span class="gemarra-regular">are not sold with </span>the courtyard? The Gemara answers that this is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult: This </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span>, that teaches that the stores are sold along with the courtyard, is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where the majority of their use is from within, </span>i.e., the stores are mainly accessed from within the courtyard, while <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span> of Rabbi Ḥiyya, that teaches that the stores are not sold along with the courtyard, is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where the majority of their use is from without, </span>i.e., the stores are accessed mainly from the public domain.
The mishna teaches, and it was similarly taught in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Eliezer says: </span>One <span class="gemarra-regular">who sells a courtyard has sold only the airspace of the courtyard, </span>and he has sold nothing found in the courtyard, not even the houses. To clarify the disagreement between the unattributed opinion in the mishna and Rabbi Eliezer, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba said: If </span>the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>the buyer that he is selling him <span class="gemarra-italic">dirata</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>i.e., the place of residence, <span class="gemarra-regular">everyone agrees that he means </span>to sell <span class="gemarra-regular">the houses </span>and that they are also included in the sale. <span class="gemarra-regular">When they disagree, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">where he said to him </span>that he is selling him <span class="gemarra-italic">darta</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>i.e., the courtyard. One <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage, </span>Rabbi Eliezer, <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">he means </span>to sell only <span class="gemarra-regular">the garden, </span>i.e., the space between the houses, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage, </span>the unattributed first opinion in the mishna, <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">he means </span>to sell also <span class="gemarra-regular">the houses.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Some state </span>a different version of this discussion, according to which <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba says: If </span>the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">says to </span>the buyer that he is selling him <span class="gemarra-italic">darta</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, everyone agrees that he means </span>to sell also <span class="gemarra-regular">the houses </span>and that they are included in the sale. <span class="gemarra-regular">When they disagree, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">where he said to him </span>that he is selling him the <span class="gemarra-italic">ḥatzer</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>the Hebrew term for courtyard. One <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage, </span>Rabbi Eliezer, <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that when he says <span class="gemarra-italic">ḥatzer</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, he means </span>to sell him only <span class="gemarra-regular">the airspace, </span>i.e., the open space of the courtyard itself, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage, </span>the unattributed first opinion in the mishna, <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that houses are also included in the sale, just <span class="gemarra-regular">as the courtyard of the Tabernacle </span>included the Tabernacle itself.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabba says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman says: </span>If one <span class="gemarra-regular">sold </span>another <span class="gemarra-regular">a sand field </span>for glass making, <span class="gemarra-regular">and a pon</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> for fishing or some other purpose, if the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">took possession of the sand fiel</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> in order to finalize the transaction, <span class="gemarra-regular">he has not acquired the pond </span>and must therefore perform a separate act of acquisition for it. Conversely, if <span class="gemarra-regular">he took possession of the pond, he has not acquired the sand field. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Is that so? But doesn’t Shmuel say: </span>If one <span class="gemarra-regular">sold </span>another <span class="gemarra-regular">ten fields in ten </span>different <span class="gemarra-regular">regions, </span>all in a single bill of sale, <span class="gemarra-regular">once he takes possession of one of them, he has acquired them all;</span> and the two cases seem to be analogous.
The Gemara rejects the parallel: <span class="gemarra-regular">There, </span>in the case of the ten fields, <span class="gemarra-regular">the land is </span>all located in <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>geographic <span class="gemarra-regular">block, and it all has one use, </span>i.e., to be farmed. The buyer, therefore, acquires all of the fields when he takes possession of one of them, even if they are not adjacent. <span class="gemarra-regular">But here, </span>in the case of the sand field and the pond, <span class="gemarra-regular">this, </span>the sand field, has <span class="gemarra-regular">a distinct use, </span>i.e., to supply sand for glass making, <span class="gemarra-regular">and that, </span>the pond, has <span class="gemarra-regular">a distinct use, </span>i.e., for fishing. Therefore, taking possession of one of them does not effect a transfer of the other.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And some state </span>a different version of the previous discussion. 

Daf 67b

<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba </span>actually <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman said: </span>If one sold another a sand field and a pond, and the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">took possession of the sand field, he has </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">acquired the pond</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> The Gemara asks: This is <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious, as Shmuel says: </span>If one <span class="gemarra-regular">sold ten fields to </span>another in ten different regions, once he takes possession of one of them, he has acquired them all. The Gemara explains why Rav Naḥman’s statement was nevertheless necessary: It is necessary <span class="gemarra-regular">lest you say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">there, </span>in the case of the ten fields, <span class="gemarra-regular">the land is </span>all located in <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>geographic <span class="gemarra-regular">block </span>with a single use, and therefore all the fields are acquired together. <span class="gemarra-regular">But here, </span>in the case of the sand field and the pond, <span class="gemarra-regular">this, </span>the sand field, has <span class="gemarra-regular">a distinct use, and that, </span>the pond, has a <span class="gemarra-regular">distinct use, </span>and therefore taking possession of one of them should not effect acquisition of the other. Therefore, Rav Naḥman <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>that if the buyer took possession of the sand field, he has acquired the pond as well.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> One <span class="gemarra-regular">who sells an olive </span><span class="gemarra-regular">pres</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> without specifying what is included in the sale <span class="gemarra-regular">has sold </span>with it <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">ya</span><span class="gemarra-italic">m</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">memel</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">betulot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the immovable elements of the olive press. <span class="gemarra-regular">But he has not sold </span>with it <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">avirim</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">galgal</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kora</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>the movable utensils of the olive press. <span class="gemarra-regular">When </span>the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">says to </span>the buyer: I am selling you <span class="gemarra-regular">it and everything that is in it, all these </span>components <span class="gemarra-regular">are sold </span>along with the olive press, even the movable utensils. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Eliezer says: </span>One <span class="gemarra-regular">who sells an olive press has sold the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kora</span> as well, as it is the most fundamental element of the olive press.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara explains the terms used in the mishna. The <span class="gemarra-italic">yam</span> is the <span class="gemarra-regular">lentil</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the round stationary container into which the olives are placed before being crushed. As for the <span class="gemarra-italic">memel</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, Rabbi Abba bar Memel said: </span>This is the <span class="gemarra-regular">crusher</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the utensil used to pound and crush the olives. As for the <span class="gemarra-italic">betulot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, Rabbi Yoḥanan said: </span>These are the <span class="gemarra-regular">cedar </span><span class="gemarra-regular">post</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">klonsot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">that support the beam </span>of the olive press. The <span class="gemarra-italic">avirim</span> are the <span class="gemarra-regular">pressers</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> wooden boards that are placed on top of the crushed olives, and upon which the beam is lowered in order to press the olives. The <span class="gemarra-italic">galgal</span> is the <span class="gemarra-italic">ḥumrata</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> a round stone that is placed on the beam to weigh it down. The <span class="gemarra-italic">kora</span> is the heavy wooden <span class="gemarra-regular">beam </span>used to press down upon the olives and thereby extract the oil.
<span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> (<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span>, 3:2): One <span class="gemarra-regular">who sells an olive press </span>without specifying what is included in the sale <span class="gemarra-regular">has sold </span>with it <span class="gemarra-regular">the boards </span>that are fixed in place to hold the olives; <span class="gemarra-regular">and the vat</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> for collecting the oil, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the crushers</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> used to pound and crush the olives before pressing them, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the lower millstone</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., the stationary millstone base; <span class="gemarra-regular">but not the upper </span>millstone. <span class="gemarra-regular">But when </span>the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">says to </span>the buyer: I am selling you <span class="gemarra-regular">it and everything that is in it, all these </span>components <span class="gemarra-regular">are sold. Both </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>case, where he executes the sale without specification, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>case, where he adds the phrase that he is selling everything that is in the olive press, <span class="gemarra-regular">he has not sold the </span>wooden <span class="gemarra-regular">boards </span>that are placed on top of the crushed olives when they are being pressed, <span class="gemarra-regular">nor </span>has he sold <span class="gemarra-regular">the sacks, nor </span>has he sold <span class="gemarra-regular">the leather bags </span>for carrying the olives, as these are all movable goods that are not specifically part of the olive press.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Eliezer says: </span>One <span class="gemarra-regular">who sells an olive press has sold the </span>heavy wooden <span class="gemarra-regular">beam </span>used to press down upon the olives, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is called an olive press [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">beit</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">habad</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> only due to </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">beam, </span>the most essential part of the press, and this beam is otherwise known as a <span class="it-text">bad</span>.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> One <span class="gemarra-regular">who sells a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">bathhous</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> without specifying what is included in the sale <span class="gemarra-regular">has not sold </span>with it <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">board</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> that are placed on the floor, <span class="gemarra-regular">nor </span>has he sold <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">basin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">or the curtains [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">habilaniyot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">When </span>the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">says to </span>the buyer: I am selling you <span class="gemarra-regular">it and everything that is in it, all these </span>components <span class="gemarra-regular">are sold </span>along with the bathhouse. <span class="gemarra-regular">Both </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>case, where he executes the sale without specification, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>case, where he adds the phrase that he is selling everything that is in the bathhouse, <span class="gemarra-regular">he has not sold the tanks of water, nor </span>has he sold <span class="gemarra-regular">the storerooms for wood, </span>as an explicit sales agreement is required for these matters.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> (<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span>, 3:3): One <span class="gemarra-regular">who sells a bathhouse </span>without specifying what is included in the sale <span class="gemarra-regular">has sold </span>with it <span class="gemarra-regular">the storeroom </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">boards</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and the storeroom </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>implements called <span class="gemarra-italic">yekamin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and the storeroom for the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">basins</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and the storeroom for the curtains [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">vilaot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>he has <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>sold <span class="gemarra-regular">the boards themselves, nor the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">yekami</span><span class="gemarra-italic">n</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">themselves, nor the basins themselves, nor the curtains themselves. When </span>the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">says to </span>the buyer: I am selling you <span class="gemarra-regular">it and everything that is in it, all these </span>components <span class="gemarra-regular">are sold </span>along with the bathhouse. <span class="gemarra-regular">Both </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>case, where he executes the sale without specification, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>case, where he adds the phrase that he is selling everything that is in the bathhouse, <span class="gemarra-regular">he has not sold him the pools that supply him with water, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">whether</span>

Daf 68a

<span class="gemarra-regular">in the summer seaso</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> or in the rainy season, nor </span>has he sold him <span class="gemarra-regular">the storeroom for the wood</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> But if </span>the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">says to </span>the buyer: <span class="gemarra-regular">I am selling you the bathhouse and all of its accompaniments</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> all these </span>components <span class="gemarra-regular">are sold.</span>
The Gemara relates: There was <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain </span>person <span class="gemarra-regular">who said to another: I am selling you </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">olive press and all of its accompaniments. There were certain store</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> outside </span>of the olive press, <span class="gemarra-regular">where, </span>in addition to the ordinary services that these stores provided, <span class="gemarra-regular">sesame seeds would </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">be spread out </span>to dry before they would be pressed for their oil. The seller and the buyer disagreed about whether these stores were included in the sale, and the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">came before Rav Yosef, </span>presenting him with his claim to ownership of the stores.
Rav Yosef <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: We learned </span>in the previously cited <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">says </span>to the buyer: <span class="gemarra-regular">I am selling you the bathhous</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and all of its accompaniments, all these </span>components <span class="gemarra-regular">are sold. </span>Rav Yosef held that in this case too, the disputed stores were sold. <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said to </span>Rav Yosef: <span class="gemarra-regular">But didn’t Rabbi Ḥiyya teach </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">They are not all sold? Rather, </span>the issue should be resolved as <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi said: We consider </span>the seller’s statement, and <span class="gemarra-regular">if he said to </span>the buyer: I am selling you <span class="gemarra-regular">the olive press and all of its accompaniments, and these are its boundaries</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and he included the area of the stores within those boundaries, the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">has acquired </span>those stores, <span class="gemarra-regular">but if </span>the seller does <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>say this, <span class="gemarra-regular">he has not acquired </span>them, as they are not actually part of the olive press.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> One <span class="gemarra-regular">who sells a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">cit</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span> without specifying what is included in the sale <span class="gemarra-regular">has sold </span>with it <span class="gemarra-regular">the houses, the pits, </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">ditches and caves, the bathhouses and the dovecotes, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">the olive presses and </span><span class="gemarra-italic">beit</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">hashelaḥin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>as will be explained in the Gemara, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>he has <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>sold <span class="gemarra-regular">the movable </span><span class="gemarra-regular">propert</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span> in the city. <span class="gemarra-regular">But when </span>the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">says to </span>the buyer: I am selling you <span class="gemarra-regular">it and everything that is in it, even if there were cattle and </span>Canaanite <span class="gemarra-regular">slaves in </span>the city, <span class="gemarra-regular">all these </span>entities <span class="gemarra-regular">are sold. Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: </span>One <span class="gemarra-regular">who sells a city has sold </span>with it <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">santar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the meaning of which will be explained in the Gemara.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Aḥa, son of Rav Avya, said to Rav Ashi: Learn from </span>the mishna that the legal status of a Canaanite <span class="gemarra-regular">slave is like </span>that of <span class="gemarra-regular">movable property, as if </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">like </span>that of <span class="gemarra-regular">land, </span>the slave <span class="gemarra-regular">should be sold along with the city. </span>Rav Ashi responded: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, what </span>do you claim, that the legal status of a Canaanite <span class="gemarra-regular">slave is like </span>that of <span class="gemarra-regular">movable property? </span>If that is the case, <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>is the meaning of the mishna’s statement that <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>if there were cattle and Canaanite slaves in the city, they are all sold? This is obvious, as the slaves should be treated no differently than the rest of the city’s movable property.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, what have you to say? </span>You must explain that there <span class="gemarra-regular">is a difference between movable property that moves about </span>by itself, such as slaves, <span class="gemarra-regular">and movable property that does not move about </span>by itself, i.e., inanimate objects. In exactly the same manner, one can claim that <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">you say </span>that the legal status of a Canaanite <span class="gemarra-regular">slave is like </span>that of <span class="gemarra-regular">land, </span>there <span class="gemarra-regular">is a difference between land that moves about </span>by itself, i.e., slaves, <span class="gemarra-regular">and land that does not move about </span>by itself.
§ The mishna teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: </span>One <span class="gemarra-regular">who sells a city has</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> sold </span>with it <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">santar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is the meaning of the term <span class="gemarra-italic">santar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Here </span>in Babylonia <span class="gemarra-regular">they interpreted </span>it to mean the land <span class="gemarra-regular">registra</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">bar maḥavanita</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> in charge of keeping track of property boundaries. <span class="gemarra-regular">Shimon ben Avtolemos </span>disagrees and <span class="gemarra-regular">says </span>that it is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">the field</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> that surround the city. The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">The one who says </span>that <span class="it-text">santar</span> means the land <span class="gemarra-regular">registrar </span>understands that according to Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel, when one sells a city, <span class="gemarra-regular">all the more so </span>are <span class="gemarra-regular">the fields </span>that surround the city included in the sale. <span class="gemarra-regular">But the one who says </span>that it means <span class="gemarra-regular">the fields </span>that surround the city holds that the land <span class="gemarra-regular">registrar </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">not sold </span>with the city.
The Gemara attempts to adduce proof in support of one of the opinions: <span class="gemarra-regular">We learned </span>in the mishna here that <span class="gemarra-regular">the olive presses and </span><span class="gemarra-italic">beit</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">hashelaḥin</span> are sold along with the city. The Sages initially <span class="gemarra-regular">maintained: What </span>is meant by <span class="gemarra-italic">shelaḥin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? </span>This is referring to irrigated <span class="gemarra-regular">fields, </span>fields that require additional irrigation to supplement the rain that they receive. <span class="gemarra-regular">As it is written: </span>“Who gives rain upon the earth <span class="gemarra-regular">and sends [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">shole’aḥ</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] water upon the fields” </span>(Job 5:10). <span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, according to the one who says </span>that <span class="it-text">santar</span> means the land <span class="gemarra-regular">registrar, the first </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span> of the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the fields </span>that surround the city <span class="gemarra-regular">are sold </span>with the city, but the land <span class="gemarra-regular">registrar is not sold, and Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel comes to say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>the land <span class="gemarra-regular">registrar is sold. But according to the one who says </span>that <span class="it-text">santar</span> means <span class="gemarra-regular">fields, this </span>is what <span class="gemarra-regular">the first </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is saying as well. </span>In what way, then, does Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel disagree with the first <span class="it-text">tanna</span>?
The Gemara rejects this proof: <span class="gemarra-regular">Do you maintain </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>is meant by <span class="gemarra-italic">shelaḥin</span> is irrigated <span class="gemarra-regular">fields? </span>This is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>the case. Rather, <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>is meant by <span class="gemarra-italic">shelaḥin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? </span>This is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">gardens </span>found within the city, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is stated: “Your shoots [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">shelaḥayikh</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] are an orchard of pomegranates” </span>(Song of Songs 4:13). <span class="gemarra-regular">But the field</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> that surround the city <span class="gemarra-regular">are not sold. And Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel comes to say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">fields are sold as well. </span>This is one version of the discussion.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Some say </span>that the discussion took place as follows: The Sages initially <span class="gemarra-regular">assumed </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>is meant by <span class="gemarra-italic">shelaḥin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? </span>This is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">gardens </span>found within the city. <span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, according to the one who said </span>that <span class="it-text">santar</span> means <span class="gemarra-regular">the fields </span>that surround the city, <span class="gemarra-regular">the first </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span> of the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the gardens </span>found within the city <span class="gemarra-regular">are sold </span>along with the city, but <span class="gemarra-regular">the fields </span>that surround the city <span class="gemarra-regular">are not sold, and Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel comes to say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">even the fields </span>that surround the city <span class="gemarra-regular">are sold. </span>

Daf 68b

<span class="gemarra-regular">But according to the one who says </span>that <span class="it-text">santar</span> means the land <span class="gemarra-regular">registrar, </span>is it reasonable that <span class="gemarra-regular">the first </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span> of the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>that the <span class="gemarra-regular">gardens </span>within the city are included in the sale of the city, <span class="gemarra-regular">and Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel responded to him </span>that the land <span class="gemarra-regular">registrar </span>is included? How are the two connected? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Do you maintain </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>is meant by <span class="gemarra-italic">shelaḥin</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">gardens? </span>This is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>the case. Rather, <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>is meant by <span class="gemarra-italic">shelaḥin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? </span>This is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">the fields </span>that surround the city, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is written: </span>“Who gives rain upon the earth <span class="gemarra-regular">and sends [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">sholeaḥ</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] waters upon the fields” </span>(Job 5:10). According to the first <span class="it-text">tanna</span>, it is specifically the fields that are sold with the city, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>the land <span class="gemarra-regular">registrar is not sold. And Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel comes to say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>the land <span class="gemarra-regular">registrar is also sold.</span>
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a proof from the following <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda says</span><span class="gemarra-regular">:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> The </span><span class="gemarra-italic">santar</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is not sold </span>with the city, but <span class="gemarra-regular">the city scribe [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ankolemus</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is sold </span>with it. <span class="gemarra-regular">What, is it not </span>clear <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that the city scribe is a man </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">santar</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is also a man? </span>The Gemara rejects this proof: <span class="gemarra-regular">Are the cases comparable? This </span>case is <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is, and that </span>case is <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is, </span>and <span class="it-text">santar</span> means fields, and not the land registrar.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">How can you say </span>that according to Rabbi Yehuda the fields surrounding the city are not sold along with it? <span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t it taught in the latter clause </span>of this <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>when one sells a city he has <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>sold <span class="gemarra-regular">its remnants</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and not its daughters, </span>i.e., the nearby rural villages, <span class="gemarra-regular">and not the woods that are set aside </span>and designated <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>the city, <span class="gemarra-regular">and not the enclosures [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">beivarin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for animals, for birds, and for fish. And we said </span>in explanation: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is meant by <span class="gemarra-regular">its remnants? </span><span class="gemarra-italic">Bizlei</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is the meaning of <span class="gemarra-italic">bizlei</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? Rabbi Abba said: The strips of the field</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> that are separated from the main fields by a stretch that cannot be cultivated. From here, it may be inferred that <span class="gemarra-regular">it is the strips of the fields that are not sold </span>with the city, <span class="gemarra-regular">but the fields themselves are sold </span>with it.
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Reverse </span>the statement found in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> so that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehud</span><span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">santar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>now understood to mean fields, <span class="gemarra-regular">is sold </span>with the city, but the <span class="gemarra-regular">city scribe is not sold </span>with it.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">How can you say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda holds in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel, </span>to the point that you adduce proof from the words of Rabbi Yehuda with regard to the opinion of Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel? <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>doesn’t <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda hold in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis? As it is taught in the latter clause </span>of that same <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>when one sells a city he does <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>sell <span class="gemarra-regular">its remnants, and </span>he does <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>sell <span class="gemarra-regular">its daughters, </span>i.e., the nearby rural villages. <span class="gemarra-regular">Whereas </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel, doesn’t he say </span>that one <span class="gemarra-regular">who sold a city sold its daughters </span>along with it, i.e., the nearby rural villages, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: One <span class="gemarra-regular">who sells a city has not sold its daughters; Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel </span>disagrees and <span class="gemarra-regular">says: </span>One <span class="gemarra-regular">who sells a city has sold its daughters.</span>
The Gemara answers: This does not prove that Rabbi Yehuda disagrees with Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel, as it may be suggested that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda holds in accordance with </span>the opinion of Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to one </span>issue, that the fields that surround the city are included in the sale, <span class="gemarra-regular">and disagrees with him with regard to </span>another issue, as according to Rabbi Yehuda the nearby villages are not sold along with the city.
§ The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> teaches: When one sells a city he has <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>sold, among other things, <span class="gemarra-regular">the enclosures for animals, for birds, and for fish. And </span>the Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises a contradiction </span>from another <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>the city <span class="gemarra-regular">has daughters, </span>i.e., nearby villages, they <span class="gemarra-regular">are not sold </span>along <span class="gemarra-regular">with it. If it has one part on the se</span><span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and one part on dry land, </span>or if it has <span class="gemarra-regular">enclosures for animals, for birds, or for fish, these are </span>all <span class="gemarra-regular">sold </span>along <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>the city.
The Gemara answers that this is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult, </span>as a distinction can be made between different cases: <span class="gemarra-regular">Here, </span>the one <span class="it-text">baraita</span> addresses animal enclosures <span class="gemarra-regular">whose openings fac</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> inward, </span>i.e., toward the city, and they are therefore considered a part of the city, whereas <span class="gemarra-regular">there, </span>the other <span class="it-text">baraita</span> addresses animal enclosures <span class="gemarra-regular">whose openings face outward, </span>i.e., away from the city, and therefore they are not included in its sale. The Gemara raises a difficulty: <span class="gemarra-regular">But doesn’t </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">teach: And </span>he has <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>sold <span class="gemarra-regular">the woods that are set aside for </span>the city, indicating that they face the city, and nevertheless they are not sold along with the city? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Say </span>that the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> should be emended so that it reads instead: And he has not sold the woods <span class="gemarra-regular">that are set apart </span>from the city, i.e., that are at a distance and do not face the city.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> One <span class="gemarra-regular">who sells a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">fiel</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> without specifying what is included in the sale <span class="gemarra-regular">has sold the stones </span>in the field <span class="gemarra-regular">that are for its </span><span class="gemarra-regular">use</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and the reeds in the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">vineyar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">that are for its use, and the produce that is </span>still <span class="gemarra-regular">attached to the ground, and the cluster of reeds that </span>occupy <span class="gemarra-regular">less than the area required for sowing a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">quarter-kav</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of seed [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">beit</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">rova</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and the watch station that is not plastered with </span><span class="gemarra-regular">clay</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the young <span class="gemarra-regular">carob tree that has not </span>yet <span class="gemarra-regular">been </span><span class="gemarra-regular">grafted</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and the untrimmed </span><span class="gemarra-regular">sycamor</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> that is still young.
<span class="gemarra-regular">But he has not sold </span>along with the field <span class="gemarra-regular">the stones that are not </span>designated <span class="gemarra-regular">for use </span>in the field, <span class="gemarra-regular">and not the reeds in the vineyard that are not </span>designated <span class="gemarra-regular">for its use, and not the produce that is </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">detached from the ground. When </span>the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">says to </span>the buyer: I am selling you <span class="gemarra-regular">it and everything that is in it, all these </span>components <span class="gemarra-regular">are sold </span>along with the field. <span class="gemarra-regular">Both </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>case, where he executes the sale without specification, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>case, where he adds the phrase that he is selling everything that is in the field, <span class="gemarra-regular">he has not sold the cluster of reeds that </span>occupy <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">beit</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">rova</span> or more, as they are considered a separate field, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>he has <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>sold <span class="gemarra-regular">the watch station that is plastered with clay, and not the carob tree that has been grafted, and not the sycamore trunk. </span>All of these entities are significant in their own right and have a status independent from that of the fields, and they are therefore not included in the sale of the field. 

Daf 69a

<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna teaches that one who sells a field has sold the stones in the field that are for its use. The Gemara clarifies: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is meant by <span class="gemarra-regular">stones that are for its use</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Here </span>in Babylonia <span class="gemarra-regular">they interpreted </span>it as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">Stones </span>placed <span class="gemarra-regular">on the sheave</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> in the field to protect them from being scattered by the wind. <span class="gemarra-regular">Ulla says: </span>The mishna is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">stones that are arranged for </span>the future building of <span class="gemarra-regular">a fenc</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> for the field. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But didn’t Rabbi Ḥiyya teach </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that they are <span class="gemarra-regular">stones that are piled up for </span>the future building of <span class="gemarra-regular">a fence, </span>and not necessarily arranged? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Teach </span>that Rabbi Ḥiyya said: They are stones that are <span class="gemarra-regular">arranged </span>for the future building of a fence.
The Gemara elaborates on the two explanations: It was stated that <span class="gemarra-regular">here </span>in Babylonia <span class="gemarra-regular">they interpreted </span>the mishna as referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">stones </span>that are placed <span class="gemarra-regular">on the sheaves. According to Rabbi Meir </span>this should be understood as referring to stones <span class="gemarra-regular">that are read</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span> to be used to protect the sheaves, <span class="gemarra-regular">even though they are not </span>yet <span class="gemarra-regular">placed </span>on them. This is in keeping with Rabbi Meir’s opinion that whenever a place is sold, all the accompaniments that are necessary for its proper utilization are included in the sale (see 78b). <span class="gemarra-regular">According to the Rabbis, </span>the mishna is referring specifically to stones <span class="gemarra-regular">that are </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">place</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> on the sheaves.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And according to Ulla, who says </span>that the mishna is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">stones that are arranged for </span>the future building of <span class="gemarra-regular">a fence </span>for the field, <span class="gemarra-regular">according to Rabbi Meir, </span>stones <span class="gemarra-regular">that are ready </span>to be used for building a fence are also included in the sale, <span class="gemarra-regular">even though they are not </span>yet <span class="gemarra-regular">arranged </span>for that purpose. <span class="gemarra-regular">According to the Rabbis, </span>the mishna is referring specifically to stones <span class="gemarra-regular">that are </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">arranged </span>for building a fence.
The Gemara continues with its clarification of the mishna, which teaches that one who sells a field has <span class="gemarra-regular">also </span>sold <span class="gemarra-regular">the reeds in the vineyar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that are for its use. </span>The Gemara asks: With regard to the <span class="gemarra-regular">reeds, what is their purpose </span>in the vineyard? The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">of the school of Rabbi Yannai said: </span>These are <span class="gemarra-regular">reeds that are spli</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> on top and <span class="gemarra-regular">placed under the vines </span>so that the boughs of the vines can rest on them. <span class="gemarra-regular">According to Rabbi Meir, </span>this is referring to reeds <span class="gemarra-regular">that have been smoothed </span>and made ready for this purpose, <span class="gemarra-regular">even though they are not </span>yet <span class="gemarra-regular">set in their place. According to the Rabbis, </span>the mishna refers specifically to reeds <span class="gemarra-regular">that are </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">set in their place.</span>
The Gemara continues expounding the mishna, which includes among the components that are sold with a field <span class="gemarra-regular">the produc</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that is </span>still <span class="gemarra-regular">attached to the ground. </span>The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">Even though </span>the time <span class="gemarra-regular">has </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">come </span>for the produce <span class="gemarra-regular">to be cut down</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> it is included in the sale since it is still attached to the ground. The mishna also includes among the things that are sold with a field <span class="gemarra-regular">the cluster of reed</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that </span>occupy <span class="gemarra-regular">less than a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">beit</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">rova</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>The Gemara notes: <span class="gemarra-regular">Even though </span>these reeds <span class="gemarra-regular">are thick, </span>they are still classified as part of the field.
The mishna teaches that one who sells a field sells with it <span class="gemarra-regular">the watch statio</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that is not plastered with clay. </span>The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">Even though it is not fixed in the ground </span>and can still be moved, since it is not plastered, it is not significant enough to be considered an independent entity, and it is considered part of the field. The mishna also includes the following among the components that are sold with a field: <span class="gemarra-regular">And the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> carob tree that has not been grafted, and the untrimmed sycamore. </span>The Gemara notes: <span class="gemarra-regular">Even though they are </span>big and <span class="gemarra-regular">thick, </span>since they have not yet reached the stage of grafting, in the case of the carob, or trimming, in the case of the sycamore, they are considered part of the field.
The Gemara proceeds to explain the second half of the mishna, which teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">But he has not sold </span>along with the field <span class="gemarra-regular">the stones that are not </span>designated <span class="gemarra-regular">for use </span>in the field. On the assumption that the mishna speaks of stones that are placed on the sheaves to prevent them from being scattered, <span class="gemarra-regular">according to Rabbi Meir, </span>the mishna is referring to stones <span class="gemarra-regular">that are not ready </span>to be used for this purpose, whereas <span class="gemarra-regular">according to the Rabbis, </span>even if the stones are ready to be used to protect the sheaves, they are not included in the sale if <span class="gemarra-regular">they are not </span>yet <span class="gemarra-regular">placed </span>on them.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And according to Ulla, who says </span>that the mishna is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">stones that are arranged for </span>the future building of <span class="gemarra-regular">a fence </span>for the field, <span class="gemarra-regular">according to Rabbi Meir, </span>this clause addresses a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the stones <span class="gemarra-regular">were not ready </span>to be used for this purpose, whereas <span class="gemarra-regular">according to the Rabbis, </span>it addresses a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the stones <span class="gemarra-regular">were not </span>yet <span class="gemarra-regular">arranged </span>for building a fence, even though they were ready to be used for that purpose.
The mishna teaches that one who sells a field has <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>sold <span class="gemarra-regular">the reeds in the vineyard that are not </span>designated <span class="gemarra-regular">for its use. </span>The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">According to Rabbi Meir, </span>this is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the reeds <span class="gemarra-regular">are not smoothed, </span>whereas <span class="gemarra-regular">according to the Rabbis, </span>the reference is to reeds <span class="gemarra-regular">that are not </span>yet <span class="gemarra-regular">set in their place, </span>even if they are smoothed. The mishna further teaches: One who sells a field has also <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>sold <span class="gemarra-regular">the produce that is detached from the ground. </span>The Gemara comments: The produce is not included in the sale <span class="gemarra-regular">even though it </span>still <span class="gemarra-regular">requires the ground</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> that is, it needs to be left in the field in order to dry out completely.
The mishna teaches that one who sells a field has <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>sold <span class="gemarra-regular">the cluster of reeds that </span>occupy <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">beit</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">rova</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>this is so <span class="gemarra-regular">even though they are thin, </span>as since they occupy the area of a <span class="it-text">beit</span> <span class="it-text">rova</span> they are considered a separate entity and are not part of the field. Concerning this ruling, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">not only a cluster of reeds </span>that is considered a separate entity, and therefore not included in the sale; <span class="gemarra-regular">rather, even a small garden bed of spice</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> that does not occupy the area of a <span class="it-text">beit</span> <span class="it-text">rova</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">but has a distinct name is not sold </span>along <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>the field. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa said: </span>What <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>means is <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>people <span class="gemarra-regular">call it the roses [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">vardda</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of so-and-so, </span>thereby establishing for it a name of its own.
The mishna teaches that the sale does <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>include <span class="gemarra-regular">the watch station that is plastered with clay. </span>The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>this is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">even though it is attached to the ground, </span>as it is still considered a separate entity and not part of the field. The mishna teaches: He has also <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>sold <span class="gemarra-regular">the carob tree that has been grafted, and </span>he has <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>sold <span class="gemarra-regular">the sycamore trunk. </span>The Gemara notes: <span class="gemarra-regular">Even though they are small, </span>they are considered their own entity.
Apropos the discussion of a watch station that is attached to the ground, the Gemara cites a discussion about the sale of a house: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar raised the dilemma: </span>With regard to wooden <span class="gemarra-regular">door frames</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? Are they sold together with the house, or not? The Gemara explains the question: <span class="gemarra-regular">Do not raise the dilemma </span>in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the frames <span class="gemarra-regular">are attached </span>to the house <span class="gemarra-regular">with clay, as they are </span>certainly <span class="gemarra-regular">attached </span>to the house and sold along with it. <span class="gemarra-regular">When you can raise this dilemma is where they are connected </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">with small wooden pegs. What </span>is the ruling in that case? No resolution was found for this question, and so the dilemma <span class="gemarra-regular">shall</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> stand [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">teiku</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> unresolved.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Zeira raises </span>a similar <span class="gemarra-regular">dilemma </span>about what is included in the sale of a house: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">window frames</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? Are they sold together with the house, or not? <span class="gemarra-regular">Do we say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">they serve merely </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">an ornament, </span>and are not included in the sale, and the seller can remove them from the house and keep them for himself? <span class="gemarra-regular">Or perhaps, since they are attached </span>to the window, <span class="gemarra-regular">they are attached. </span>The dilemma <span class="gemarra-regular">shall stand </span>unresolved.
And similarly, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yirmeya raised a dilemma: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">stands for the legs of a be</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> that are placed under the legs to prevent them from being damaged by moisture, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? The Gemara explains the question: <span class="gemarra-regular">Do not raise the dilemma wherever </span>the stands <span class="gemarra-regular">move </span>along <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>the bed, <span class="gemarra-regular">as they move </span>along with it and are therefore not considered part of the house. <span class="gemarra-regular">Where you can raise this dilemma is where they do not move </span>along with the bed. <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is the ruling in that case? No resolution was found for this question either, and therefore the dilemma <span class="gemarra-regular">shall stand </span>unresolved.
The mishna teaches: One who sells a field has <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>sold <span class="gemarra-regular">the carob tree that has been grafted, and </span>he has <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>sold <span class="gemarra-regular">the sycamore trunk. </span>

Daf 69b

The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">From where are these matters, </span>i.e., that a grafted carob and a sycamore trunk are not included in the sale of a field, derived? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav said: As the verse states: “So the field of Ephron, which was in Machpelah,</span> which was before Mamre, the field, and the cave that was within it, and all the trees that were in the field, that were in all the boundaries around, were established for Abraham as a possession” (Genesis 23:17–18). This teaches that <span class="gemarra-regular">anything that requires a boundar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> around </span>it, as it does not have natural demarcations, is included in the sale of a field. This <span class="gemarra-regular">excludes these </span>trees, i.e., the grafted carob and the sycamore trunk, <span class="gemarra-regular">which do not require a boundary around </span>them, as they stand out individually on their own. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Mesharshiyya says: From here </span>there is a source <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the acquisition of the actual <span class="gemarra-regular">boundaries </span>in a sale <span class="gemarra-regular">is from the Torah</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda said: One who sells land to anothe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> must write for him </span>the following in the bill of sale: <span class="gemarra-regular">Acquire for yourself the palm tree</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and the date</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and the branches and the seedlings</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> And even if he did not write this for him </span>the buyer would still <span class="gemarra-regular">acquire </span>all of these entities, as demonstrated by the mishna that it is only a grafted carob and a sycamore trunk that are excluded from the sale of a field. <span class="gemarra-regular">Even so, it is an enhancement of the bill </span>of sale that he write all of the details of the transaction so that there be no possible room for disagreement.
If the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>the buyer: I am selling you <span class="gemarra-regular">the land and palm trees</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> we consider </span>the situation. <span class="gemarra-regular">If he has palm trees, he must give him two palm tree</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> as two is the minimum number of trees that would justify being called: Trees, in the plural. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if he has no </span>palm trees, <span class="gemarra-regular">he must buy two palm trees for him </span>somewhere else. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if </span>he has palm trees, but <span class="gemarra-regular">they are mortgaged </span>to another person, <span class="gemarra-regular">he must redeem</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> two palm trees </span>and give them to the buyer.
If the seller said to the buyer: I am selling you <span class="gemarra-regular">land with palm trees, we consider </span>the situation. <span class="gemarra-regular">If there are palm trees on </span>the land, <span class="gemarra-regular">he must give him </span>the land, <span class="gemarra-regular">and if not, </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">is a mistaken transactio</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> and the sale is void. If the seller said to the buyer: I am selling you <span class="gemarra-regular">land of palm trees</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">has no </span>claim to receive <span class="gemarra-regular">palm trees. </span>Therefore, if the land has no palm trees, this is not a mistaken transaction, as the seller meant to <span class="gemarra-regular">say to him </span>that the land <span class="gemarra-regular">was fit for palm trees, </span>and not that it already contained them. Furthermore, if the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>the buyer that he is selling the land <span class="gemarra-regular">except for such and such a palm tree</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> we consider </span>the situation. <span class="gemarra-regular">If it is a good palm tree</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> we assume that <span class="gemarra-regular">he retained </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">that</span> one for himself and did not include it in the sale, but <span class="gemarra-regular">if it is a bad palm tree, </span>we assume that <span class="gemarra-regular">all the more so </span>did he retain for himself <span class="gemarra-regular">the other </span>ones that are of higher quality.
If the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>the buyer that he is selling him the entire field <span class="gemarra-regular">except for the trees, </span>we consider the situation. <span class="gemarra-regular">If he has </span>different types of <span class="gemarra-regular">trees</span> in the field, for example, olive and fig trees, he has sold the entire field <span class="gemarra-regular">except for the trees. If he has </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">palm trees </span>in the field, we assume that he meant to sell the entire field <span class="gemarra-regular">except for the palm trees, </span>even though one does not ordinarily refer to palm trees by the more general term: Trees. Similarly, <span class="gemarra-regular">if he has </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">grapevines </span>in the field, the buyer acquires everything <span class="gemarra-regular">except for the grapevines.</span>
If the field has both <span class="gemarra-regular">trees and grapevines, </span>he has sold everything <span class="gemarra-regular">except for the trees</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span> therefore, the buyer does not acquire the trees, which the seller excluded from the sale, but he does acquire the grapevines. Similarly, if in the field there are both <span class="gemarra-regular">trees and palm trees, </span>he has sold everything <span class="gemarra-regular">except for the trees</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> If there are no other trees in the field, but only <span class="gemarra-regular">grapevines and palm trees</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> everything, including the palm trees, is sold <span class="gemarra-regular">except for the grapevines, </span>which we assume the seller reserved for himself.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: </span>If the seller specified that he is selling a field but not the trees, <span class="gemarra-regular">any </span>tree that is so tall <span class="gemarra-regular">that one must climb it by rope </span>in order to harvest its fruit <span class="gemarra-regular">is retained </span>and is not included in the sale, and <span class="gemarra-regular">any </span>tree <span class="gemarra-regular">that one need not climb by rope is not retained </span>and is sold along with the field. 

Daf 70a

<span class="gemarra-regular">But the judges of the exile, </span>Shmuel and Karna, <span class="gemarra-regular">say: Any </span>tree <span class="gemarra-regular">that is bent </span>back <span class="gemarra-regular">by the yoke </span>of oxen as the animals plow the ground under the tree, and in this way the tree does not impede the plowing, <span class="gemarra-regular">is not retained </span>by the seller, as it is not a significant tree. <span class="gemarra-regular">Any </span>tree <span class="gemarra-regular">that is not bent </span>back <span class="gemarra-regular">by the yoke </span>of the oxen <span class="gemarra-regular">is retained </span>by the seller and not included in the sale.
