The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>these <span class="it-text">amora’im</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">do not disagree </span>with regard to the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">That </span>which Rav said, that the only trees that the seller retains for himself and excludes from the sale are those that must be climbed by means of a rope, was said <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to palm trees, </span>while <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>which the judges of the exile said, that the only trees that are retained are those that are not bent back by the yoke of the oxen, was said <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>other types of <span class="gemarra-regular">trees.</span>
§ The Gemara cites a discussion related to the mishna’s ruling that a grafted carob tree and a sycamore trunk are not included in the sale of the field: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Aḥa bar Huna raised a dilemma before Rav Sheshet: </span>If one selling a field said to the buyer: I am selling you the entire field <span class="gemarra-regular">except for such and such </span>grafted <span class="gemarra-regular">carob tree</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> or <span class="gemarra-regular">except for such and such </span>sycamore <span class="gemarra-regular">trunk, </span>and there were other grafted carob trees or sycamore trunks in the field, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? The Gemara explains the two sides of the question: Does the seller mean to say that <span class="gemarra-regular">it is this carob tree that </span>the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">does not acquire, but he does acquire the other carob trees, or perhaps </span>he means that <span class="gemarra-regular">he also does not acquire the rest of the carob trees? </span>Rav Sheshet <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him </span>in response: The buyer does <span class="gemarra-regular">not acquire </span>any of them.
Rav Aḥa <span class="gemarra-regular">raised an objection to </span>Rav Sheshet from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that states: If the seller said to the buyer: I am selling you this field <span class="gemarra-regular">except for such and such carob tree</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> or <span class="gemarra-regular">except for such and such </span>sycamore <span class="gemarra-regular">trunk, </span>the buyer does <span class="gemarra-regular">not acquire </span>it. <span class="gemarra-regular">What, is it not </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">it is this carob tree that he does not acquire, but he does acquire the other carob trees?</span>
Rav Sheshet <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: No, </span>what this means is that <span class="gemarra-regular">he does not acquire even the other carob trees. Know </span>that this is correct, <span class="gemarra-regular">as if </span>a person selling a field <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>the buyer: <span class="gemarra-regular">My field is sold to you except for such and such fiel</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> that is adjacent to it, would you say that <span class="gemarra-regular">it is </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>adjacent field <span class="gemarra-regular">that he does not acquire, but he acquires </span>all <span class="gemarra-regular">the other </span>fields owned by the seller? This is clearly not the case, as the seller explicitly stated that he is selling a certain field, not all of his fields. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>everyone would agree that the buyer does <span class="gemarra-regular">not acquire </span>the other fields. Therefore, <span class="gemarra-regular">here too</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the buyer does <span class="gemarra-regular">not acquire </span>the other carob trees.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And there are </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">who say </span>that the discussion took place as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Aḥa bar Huna raised a dilemma before Rav Sheshet: </span>If one selling a field said to the buyer: I am selling you the entire field <span class="gemarra-regular">except for half of such and such carob tree</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> or <span class="gemarra-regular">except for half of such and such </span>sycamore <span class="gemarra-regular">trunk, what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? The Gemara explains the two sides of the question: Do we say that the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">certainly does not acquire the other carob trees, but he does acquire what remains from that carob tree </span>that was mentioned, that is, the half of the carob tree that the seller did not specifically retain for himself? <span class="gemarra-regular">Or perhaps he does not acquire even what remains from that carob tree? </span>Rav Sheshet <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>Even what remains from that carob tree the buyer does <span class="gemarra-regular">not acquire.</span>
Rav Aḥa <span class="gemarra-regular">raised an objection to </span>Rav Sheshet from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that states: If the seller said to the buyer: I am selling you the entire field <span class="gemarra-regular">except for half of such and such carob tree</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> or <span class="gemarra-regular">except for half of such and such </span>sycamore <span class="gemarra-regular">trunk, </span>the buyer does <span class="gemarra-regular">not acquire the other carob trees. What, is it not </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">it is the other carob trees that he does not acquire, but what remains of that carob tree he does acquire?</span>
Rav Sheshet <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: No, </span>what this means is that <span class="gemarra-regular">he does not acquire even what remains of that carob tree. Know </span>that this is correct, <span class="gemarra-regular">as if </span>a person selling a field <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>the buyer: <span class="gemarra-regular">My field is sold to you except for half of such and such field </span>that is adjacent to it, would you say that <span class="gemarra-regular">it is </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>half of the field <span class="gemarra-regular">that he does not acquire, but he acquires the other </span>half of the field? This is clearly not the case, as the seller explicitly stated that he is selling a certain field and nothing else. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>everyone would agree that the buyer does <span class="gemarra-regular">not acquire </span>the other half of the field. Therefore, <span class="gemarra-regular">here too, </span>the buyer does <span class="gemarra-regular">not acquire </span>what remains of the carob tree.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Amram raised a dilemm</span><span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> before Rav Ḥisda: </span>If one <span class="gemarra-regular">deposits </span>certain items <span class="gemarra-regular">with another </span>and receives <span class="gemarra-regular">a documen</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> signed by witnesses testifying that he deposited these items with this individual, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the bailee later <span class="gemarra-regular">says to him: I returned </span>the items <span class="gemarra-regular">to you, </span>but the document is still in the hands of the depositor, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? <span class="gemarra-regular">Do we say that since if </span>the bailee <span class="gemarra-regular">wanted to </span>lie <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span>could have <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>that the items <span class="gemarra-regular">were taken </span>from him <span class="gemarra-regular">under circumstances beyond his control</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and <span class="gemarra-regular">he would have been deemed credible; </span>therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">now too, </span>when he claims that he returned the items, <span class="gemarra-regular">he is deemed credible as well? Or perhaps, </span>the one who deposited the items can <span class="gemarra-regular">say to him: </span>If you returned the items, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is your document doing in my possession</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> Upon return of the deposit, you should have retrieved the document. Rav Ḥisda <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>The bailee <span class="gemarra-regular">is deemed credible.</span>
Rav Amram asked: <span class="gemarra-regular">But let </span>the depositor <span class="gemarra-regular">say to </span>the bailee: If you returned the items, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is your document doing in my possession? </span>Rav Ḥisda <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: And according to your reasoning, if </span>the bailee had <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him </span>that the items <span class="gemarra-regular">were taken </span>from him <span class="gemarra-regular">under circumstances beyond his control, would he be able to say to him: What is your document doing in my possession? </span>Since this claim could not have been stated had the bailee stated the alternative claim, it can also not be stated when the bailee claims that the items were returned. Rav Amram <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>

Daf 70b

<span class="gemarra-regular">Ultimately, </span>even <span class="gemarra-regular">when </span>the bailee <span class="gemarra-regular">says to </span>the depositor that the items were <span class="gemarra-regular">taken </span>from him <span class="gemarra-regular">under circumstances beyond his control, is he not required to take an oath</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> How, then, can you assert that he is deemed credible to claim that he returned the items without taking an oath? Rav Ḥisda said to him: <span class="gemarra-regular">Here too, what </span>did I mean when I said that he is <span class="gemarra-regular">deemed credible? </span>It means that <span class="gemarra-regular">he is deemed credible when </span>he takes <span class="gemarra-regular">an oath.</span>
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Let us say </span>that Rav Amram and Rav Ḥisda disagree <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>the issue that is the subject of <span class="gemarra-regular">the dispute between these </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna’</span><span class="gemarra-italic">im</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, as </span>a <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> purse document</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., a document that records an arrangement whereby one gives another money as an investment in a joint venture on condition that the profits will be divided equally between the two parties. If the person who received the money died, and this document <span class="gemarra-regular">was presented </span>by the lender <span class="gemarra-regular">against the orphans</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the judges of the exile say </span>that the lender <span class="gemarra-regular">takes an oath </span>that the money had never been returned to him, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">collects the entire </span>sum. <span class="gemarra-regular">And the judges of Eretz Yisrae</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> say </span>that he <span class="gemarra-regular">takes an oath and collects </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">hal</span><span class="gemarra-regular">f </span> of the sum.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>it is understood <span class="gemarra-regular">that everyone agrees with </span>the opinion of the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">of Neharde’a, as </span>the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">of Neharde’a say: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">this joint venture</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> whereby one person gives money to another on condition that it will be used for business purposes and that the profits will be divided equally between the two parties, <span class="gemarra-regular">half </span>of the invested money is considered <span class="gemarra-regular">a loan, </span>for which the borrower is exclusively liable, <span class="gemarra-regular">and half </span>is considered <span class="gemarra-regular">a deposit, </span>so that if it is lost under circumstances beyond his control, the borrower is exempt from the liability to return it.
According to this assumption, everyone agrees that the claimant can recover from the orphans by means of an oath the half of the money that is considered a loan, just as he would have been able to demand that money from their father. Concerning the half that is considered a deposit, <span class="gemarra-regular">what, is it not with regard to this </span>point that <span class="gemarra-regular">they disagree, as </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage, </span>the judges of the exile, <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>like Rav Amram <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the depositor <span class="gemarra-regular">can say to </span>the bailee: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is your document doing in my possession? </span>Therefore, neither the father nor his children are deemed credible to claim that they had returned the half that is considered a deposit, and the investor can collect that half as well. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage, </span>the judges of Eretz Yisrael, <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>like Rav Ḥisda, that one <span class="gemarra-regular">cannot assert </span>this claim, and therefore the investor can collect only the half that is considered a loan. But as for the half that is considered a deposit, the father would have been deemed credible in his claim that he had already returned it.
The Gemara rejects this opinion: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, everyone, </span>i.e., both the judges of the exile and the judges of Eretz Yisrael, <span class="gemarra-regular">agrees with </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav Ḥisda, </span>that the father can claim that he returned the money. <span class="gemarra-regular">And here, they disagree about </span>the following issue, <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage, </span>the judges of the exile, <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">if it is so </span>that he had in fact <span class="gemarra-regular">repaid </span>the money, <span class="gemarra-regular">he would have tol</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> his children that he repaid it. Since he did not tell them, it may be assumed that he never repaid the money. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage, </span>the judges of Eretz Yisrael, <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that you can <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">it was the Angel of Deat</span><span class="gemarra-regular">h</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that prevented him </span>from doing so, meaning he died before he had the opportunity to give his children a detailed report concerning his financial affairs.
Apropos this discussion, it is related that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna bar Avin sent </span>the following ruling: If one <span class="gemarra-regular">deposits </span>an item <span class="gemarra-regular">with another </span>and receives <span class="gemarra-regular">a document </span>attesting to the deposit, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the bailee later <span class="gemarra-regular">says to him: I returned </span>the item <span class="gemarra-regular">to you, </span>the bailee is <span class="gemarra-regular">deemed credible </span>even if the document is still in the hands of the depositor. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a purse document </span>attesting to a joint venture <span class="gemarra-regular">that was presented </span>by the lender to support his claim <span class="gemarra-regular">against the </span>borrower’s <span class="gemarra-regular">orphans, </span>the lender <span class="gemarra-regular">takes an oath </span>that the money had never been returned to him <span class="gemarra-regular">and collects the entire </span>sum from the orphans.
The Gemara asks: Don’t these <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span><span class="it-text">halakhot</span> contradict each other? If the father is deemed credible when he claims that he repaid a loan, the court should present this claim on behalf of his orphans. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">It is different there, as if it is so </span>that the father had, in fact, <span class="gemarra-regular">repaid </span>the money, <span class="gemarra-regular">he would have told </span>his children that he repaid it. Since he did not tell them anything about it, it may be assumed that he never repaid the money.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: </span>With regard to the case of a purse document that was presented to support a claim against orphans, <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is that the claimant <span class="gemarra-regular">takes an oath </span>that the money had never been returned to him <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">collects hal</span><span class="gemarra-regular">f </span> of the sum recorded in the document, in accordance with the judges of Eretz Yisrael. The Gemara relates that two generations later, <span class="gemarra-regular">Mar Zutra said: The </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the judges of the exile. Ravina said to Mar Zutra: Didn’t Rava say </span>that the claimant <span class="gemarra-regular">takes an oath and collects half </span>of the sum? Mar Zutra <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>With regard to the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of the judges of the exile, we</span>

Daf 71a

<span class="gemarra-regular">learned the reverse, </span>that is to say, according to our version of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, it is the judges of the exile who maintain that the claimant collects only half the sum, which corresponds to the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> taught by Rava.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In continuation of the previous mishna (68b) discussing one who sells a field, the mishna teaches that even if he says that he is selling it and everything that is in it, has sold <span class="gemarra-regular">neither the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">cistern</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">nor the winepress, nor the dovecote, whether </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">abandoned or utilized, </span>as these items are not part of the field itself. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">must purchase </span>for himself <span class="gemarra-regular">a path </span>through the buyer’s domain to reach whatever remains his. This is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of Rabbi Akiva, </span>who holds that one who sells, sells generously; therefore, whatever is not explicitly excluded from the sale is assumed to be sold, and it is presumed that the seller did not retain for himself the right to the path that he requires to access his property. <span class="gemarra-regular">And the Rabbis say: </span>The seller <span class="gemarra-regular">need not </span>purchase a path through the buyer’s domain, as it is assumed that since the seller withholds these items for himself, he also reserves a path to reach them.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Akiva concedes that when </span>the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">says to </span>the buyer in the bill of sale that he is selling the field <span class="gemarra-regular">apart from these </span>things, i.e., the cistern and the winepress, <span class="gemarra-regular">he need not purchase for himself a path </span>through the buyer’s domain. Since these items would have been excluded from the sale even if he had said nothing, it is assumed that he also meant to reserve for himself the right to access them. But if the seller kept the field but <span class="gemarra-regular">sold </span>the cistern and winepress <span class="gemarra-regular">to another </span>person, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Akiva says: </span>The buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">need not purchase for himself a path </span>through the seller’s domain to reach what he has bought, since a seller sells generously. <span class="gemarra-regular">But the Rabbis say: He must purchase for himself a path </span>through the seller’s domain.
<span class="gemarra-regular">In what </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">is this statement, </span>that these items are excluded, <span class="gemarra-regular">said? </span>It is said <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to one who sells </span>a field, <span class="gemarra-regular">but with regard to one who gives </span>it away as <span class="gemarra-regular">a gift</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> it is assumed that <span class="gemarra-regular">he gives all of it</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> including everything found in the field. Similarly, with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">brothers who divid</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> their father’s estate among themselves, when they each <span class="gemarra-regular">acquire </span>a <span class="gemarra-regular">field </span>as part of their inheritance, <span class="gemarra-regular">they acquire all of it, </span>including the items that would be excluded from a sale. So too, with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who takes possession of the property of a convert</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> when <span class="gemarra-regular">he takes possession of a field, he takes possession of all of it.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">One who consecrates a field has consecrated all of it. Rabbi Shimon says: One who consecrates a field has not consecrated </span>any of the items that are ordinarily excluded from a sale <span class="gemarra-regular">except for the grafted carob tre</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and the sycamore trunk.</span>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: In <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>way <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a sale different from </span>a gift, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>way <span class="gemarra-regular">is a gift different from </span>a sale? Why does the mishna distinguish between the two with regard to what is retained by the prior owner? <span class="gemarra-regular">Yehuda ben Nekosa explained before Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi: The difference between the cases is that <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>one, the seller, <span class="gemarra-regular">specified </span>that certain items were not included in the sale, <span class="gemarra-regular">and that </span>one, the donor, <span class="gemarra-regular">did not specify.</span>
The Gemara asks: How can it be suggested that <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">specified and that </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">did not specify, </span>when in fact <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">did not specify, and that one did not specify, </span>as in neither case did the prior owner specify what items he was reserving for himself? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>the difference is that <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>one, the buyer, <span class="gemarra-regular">should have specifie</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> that those items that are not integral parts of the field are nevertheless included in the sale, and since he neglected to do so, he suffers the loss. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>in the case of a gift, <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>one, the recipient, <span class="gemarra-regular">should not have specified </span>what was included in the gift, as it would have been inappropriate for him to act in this manner.
It is related that there was <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain </span>person <span class="gemarra-regular">who said to </span>others: <span class="gemarra-regular">Give to so-and-so </span>my <span class="gemarra-regular">house containing 100 barrels </span><span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">gulfei</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> as a gift. <span class="gemarra-regular">It was found that there was </span>a house in his possession that <span class="gemarra-regular">contained 120 </span>barrels. <span class="gemarra-regular">Mar Zutra said: </span>The owner <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him </span>that he was giving him a house containing <span class="gemarra-regular">100 </span>barrels, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">did not say to him </span>that he was giving him a house containing <span class="gemarra-regular">120 </span>barrels. Therefore, the recipient receives only the portion of the house that holds 100 barrels, and not the rest of the house.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi said: Didn’t we learn </span>in the mishna here: <span class="gemarra-regular">In </span><span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">is this statement said? </span>It is said <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to one who sells </span>a field, <span class="gemarra-regular">but with regard to one who gives </span>it away as <span class="gemarra-regular">a gift, </span>it is assumed that <span class="gemarra-regular">he gives all of it. Apparently, one who gives a gif</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> gives generously. Here too, </span>then, say that <span class="gemarra-regular">one who gives a gift gives generously, </span>even if he is not always precise in his wording. Therefore, it should be assumed that the donor intended to give the recipient the entire house, which contains more than 100 barrels.
§ The mishna teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">One who consecrates a field, has consecrated </span>all of it. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna said: Even though the Rabbis said</span><span class="gemarra-regular">:</span> If <span class="gemarra-regular">one buys two trees in </span>the field <span class="gemarra-regular">of another</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he does not acquire </span>any of <span class="gemarra-regular">the land </span>but acquires only the trees, and if <span class="gemarra-regular">he sells land </span>to another, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">retains two trees for himself</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">retains the lan</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> around those trees, that does not always apply. Rav Huna elaborates: <span class="gemarra-regular">And even according to Rabbi Akiva, who says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">one who sells, sells generously </span>and does not retain anything for himself, <span class="gemarra-regular">this does not always apply, </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">this statement </span>applies only <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to a pit and a cistern, which do not weaken the land, </span>and therefore the seller feels no need to protect himself from the potential claims of the buyer. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">trees, which do weaken the land, </span>as they draw water and nutrients from the soil, 

Daf 71b

<span class="gemarra-regular">if it is so that </span>the prior owner <span class="gemarra-regular">did not retain </span>some of the land for himself, <span class="gemarra-regular">let </span>the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">say to him: Uproo</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> your trees, take </span>them, <span class="gemarra-regular">and go, </span>as the trees draw water and nutrients from the soil, causing damage to the buyer’s land. Therefore, the seller must have retained for himself the land needed for these trees.
The Gemara raises an objection: <span class="gemarra-regular">We learned </span>in the mishna here that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon says: One who consecrates a field has not consecrated </span>any of the items that are ordinarily excluded from a sale <span class="gemarra-regular">except for the grafted carob tree and the sycamore trunk. And it is taught with regard to </span>this in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon said: What is the reason </span>that it is specifically the carob tree and the sycamore trunk that are consecrated? <span class="gemarra-regular">Since </span>they <span class="gemarra-regular">draw </span>their <span class="gemarra-regular">nutrients from a consecrated field</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the owner must have had in mind to consecrate them as well, as otherwise his trees would be nurtured from consecrated property.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if it enters your mind, </span>as Rav Huna claims, that when the seller retains certain trees for himself, he also <span class="gemarra-regular">retains </span>the land around them so that they will be nurtured from soil that belongs to him, what is the reason for Rabbi Shimon’s ruling? <span class="gemarra-regular">When </span>these trees <span class="gemarra-regular">draw </span>their <span class="gemarra-regular">nutrients, they draw </span>their <span class="gemarra-regular">nutrients from </span>the ground that the consecrator had retained for himself that still <span class="gemarra-regular">belongs to him, </span>not from consecrated property.
The Gemara answers: The assumption that Rav Huna’s statement is true according to everyone must be reconsidered. Rather, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon, who says </span>that one who consecrates his field does not retain for himself the land around the trees, holds <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of his teacher, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Akiva</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> According to Rabbi Akiva, one who sells, sells generously, and there is no presumption that he retained some item or right for himself unless this was stated explicitly. Therefore, Rabbi Shimon rules that one who consecrates his field has also consecrated the carob trees, as otherwise they would draw nutrients from consecrated land. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav Huna, who says </span>that when a seller retains trees for himself he also retains the land around them, holds <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis, </span>who say that one who sells, sells sparingly.
The Gemara asks: If Rav Huna’s statement is only <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis, </span>then isn’t his statement <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> What novel idea is he adding? The Gemara answers: The practical <span class="gemarra-regular">difference </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>while one might have thought that the prior owner retains a right to the land only for the sake of trees that were there, this is not the case. Rather, he retains absolute ownership of the land, and therefore, <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>the trees <span class="gemarra-regular">fall </span>or die <span class="gemarra-regular">he can plant them again</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> 

Daf 72a

The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But can you establish that </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Akiva, </span>that one who sells or consecrates property does so generously? <span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t it taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: If <span class="gemarra-regular">one consecrates three tree</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> in a field <span class="gemarra-regular">where ten </span>trees are <span class="gemarra-regular">planted in an area required for sowing one </span><span class="gemarra-italic">se’a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of seed [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">beit</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">se’a</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he has consecrated </span>not only those trees, but also <span class="gemarra-regular">the land and the </span>young <span class="gemarra-regular">tree</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> between them? Therefore, </span>if this is an ancestral field of his, <span class="gemarra-regular">when he redeems </span>them, <span class="gemarra-regular">he redeems </span>the land and everything contained within it according to the standard rate established by the Torah, whereby <span class="gemarra-regular">an area </span>fit <span class="gemarra-regular">for the sowing of a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">ḥomer</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., a <span class="it-text">kor</span>, of <span class="gemarra-regular">barley see</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> is redeemed <span class="gemarra-regular">for fifty silver shekels.</span>
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues: If the ratio of land to trees was <span class="gemarra-regular">less than this</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and the trees were planted more densely, <span class="gemarra-regular">or </span>if the ratio of land to trees was <span class="gemarra-regular">more than this</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and the trees were planted less densely, <span class="gemarra-regular">or if he consecrated </span>each of the trees separately, <span class="gemarra-regular">one after the other</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> this </span>person <span class="gemarra-regular">has consecrated neither the land nor the </span>young <span class="gemarra-regular">trees between them. Therefore, when he redeems </span>them, <span class="gemarra-regular">he redeems the trees in accordance with their worth. And moreover, even if one consecrates the trees </span>where they are planted more densely, less densely, or one after the other, <span class="gemarra-regular">and then </span>afterward <span class="gemarra-regular">he consecrates the land, </span>so that everything belongs to the Temple treasury, <span class="gemarra-regular">when he redeems </span>them, <span class="gemarra-regular">he redeems the trees </span>separately <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with their worth, and then he redeems </span>the land according to the standard rate, where <span class="gemarra-regular">an area </span>fit <span class="gemarra-regular">for the sowing of a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">ḥomer</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">barley seed </span>is redeemed <span class="gemarra-regular">for fifty silver shekels.</span>
The Gemara clarifies: <span class="gemarra-regular">Whose </span>opinion is expressed in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>? <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>it is the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Akiva, doesn’t he say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">one who sells, sells generously</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and all the more so one who consecrates </span>does so generously? This being the case, even if the trees were consecrated one after the other, some of the land should be consecrated along with them. And <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> reflects the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis, don’t they say </span>in the mishna that <span class="gemarra-regular">it is </span>specifically <span class="gemarra-regular">the seller who sells sparingly, but one who consecrates, consecrates generously</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and therefore the pit and the winepress are consecrated along with the field? Therefore, the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> stated here is not in accordance with their opinion either. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious </span>that the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimo</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> in the mishna here, that even one who consecrates a field does not consecrate the cistern and the winepress along with it.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of whom? If </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Akiva, doesn’t he say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">one who sells, sells generously, and all the more so one who consecrates </span>does so generously? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious </span>that his opinion is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of the Rabbis, </span>who disagree with Rabbi Akiva and say that one who sells, sells sparingly. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Shimon </span>disagrees with the Rabbis insofar as <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span>himself <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">just as one who sells, sells sparingly, one who consecrates also consecrates sparingly and retains the land </span>around the trees for himself. 

Daf 72b

The Gemara concludes stating the difficulty: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>this is <span class="gemarra-regular">difficult, </span>as Rabbi Shimon himself said that the grafted carob tree and the sycamore trunk are consecrated along with the field <span class="gemarra-regular">since they draw </span>their <span class="gemarra-regular">nutrients from a consecrated field, </span>indicating that one who consecrates acts generously and does not retain the land around the trees for himself.
The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>it must be understood that when <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon </span>stated his ruling in the mishna, he was not expressing his own opinion. Rather, <span class="gemarra-regular">he was speaking to the Rabbis in accordance with their statement</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and he meant to say: <span class="gemarra-regular">According to my </span>opinion, <span class="gemarra-regular">just as one who sells, sells sparingly, so too, one who consecrates, consecrates sparingly and retains </span>for himself land to nurture the trees. Therefore, when one consecrates a field, even the sycamore and carob tree are not consecrated along with it. But <span class="gemarra-regular">according to your </span>opinion, that one who consecrates does so generously, <span class="gemarra-regular">agree with m</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> at least that </span>one who consecrates a field <span class="gemarra-regular">has consecrated only the grafted carob and the sycamore trunk, </span>because they draw nutrients from consecrated ground, but he has not consecrated the other items that are not integral parts of the field. <span class="gemarra-regular">And the Rabbis said to him: There is no differenc</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> between the two in this regard. Since one who consecrates an item does so generously, everything found in the field is consecrated.
The Gemara returns to the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that it had concluded was taught according to the opinion of Rabbi Shimon, and asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">In accordance with which opinion did you interpret </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> discussing consecrated property? It was interpreted <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon. </span>But <span class="gemarra-regular">say the last clause: And moreover, even if one consecrates the trees and then </span>afterward <span class="gemarra-regular">he consecrates the land, when he redeems </span>them, <span class="gemarra-regular">he redeems the trees </span>separately <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with their worth, and then he redeems </span>the land according to the standard rate, where <span class="gemarra-regular">an area </span>fit <span class="gemarra-regular">for the sowing of a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">ḥomer</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">barley seed </span>is redeemed <span class="gemarra-regular">for fifty silver shekels.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon, let him follow </span>the character of the field at the time of its <span class="gemarra-regular">redemption, and </span>so the trees should <span class="gemarra-regular">be redeemed along with their land, </span>as at the time of the redemption both the trees and the land are consecrated. <span class="gemarra-regular">As we have </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">heard that Rabbi Shimon follows </span>the time of the redemption, i.e., he determines the price at which a field is redeemed based on the time it is being redeemed.
<span class="gemarra-regular">As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">From where </span>is it derived that <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to one who purchases a field from his father and consecrates it</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and afterward his father dies, </span>so the field would now be considered his as an inheritance, <span class="gemarra-regular">from where </span>is it derived <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>with regard to its redemption <span class="gemarra-regular">it should be </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">before him as an ancestral fiel</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> and not a field that he purchased? <span class="gemarra-regular">The verse states </span>about a field that was purchased: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And if </span>he sanctifies to the Lord <span class="gemarra-regular">a field that he has bought, which is not of his ancestral fields” </span>(Leviticus 27:22). The verse speaks specifically of <span class="gemarra-regular">a field that is not fit </span>at the time of its consecration <span class="gemarra-regular">to be an ancestral field, </span>meaning that he never could have inherited it in the future. This specification <span class="gemarra-regular">excludes this </span>field <span class="gemarra-regular">that was fit to be an ancestral field </span>from this <span class="it-text">halakha</span>, since eventually it would have become his through inheritance, even had he not purchased it. This is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Shimon.</span>
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir </span>learns a different <span class="it-text">halakha</span> from this verse, and he <span class="gemarra-regular">says: From where </span>is it derived <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who purchases a field from his father, and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">his father dies, and afterward he consecrates </span>the field, <span class="gemarra-regular">from where </span>is it derived <span class="gemarra-regular">that it should be </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">before him like an ancestral field? The verse states: “And </span><span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>he sanctifies to the Lord <span class="gemarra-regular">a field that he has bought, which is not of his ancestral fields.” </span>The verse refers specifically to <span class="gemarra-regular">a field that is not </span>now <span class="gemarra-regular">an ancestral field </span>at the time of its consecration. This specification <span class="gemarra-regular">excludes this </span>field, <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>after the death of the father, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is an ancestral field.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>according to <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Shimon, a verse is not required </span>to teach that, in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where his father dies and afterward he consecrates </span>the field, it is considered to be an ancestral field, as this is obvious. <span class="gemarra-regular">A verse is required </span>only to teach the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he consecrates </span>the field after having bought it, <span class="gemarra-regular">and afterward his father dies.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">From where do </span>Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Shimon arrive at this conclusion? <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>they derive it only <span class="gemarra-regular">from this verse, </span>you can <span class="gemarra-regular">say that </span>the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">came </span>to be interpreted <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as opposed to the opinions of Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Shimon, as there is no clear proof from the verse to support either opinion. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, is it not due to </span>the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that they follow </span>the time of the <span class="gemarra-regular">redemption, </span>and at the time of the redemption the father is dead, and the field is the son’s ancestral field that is currently in the possession of the Temple treasury?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak says: Actually, </span>I can say to you that <span class="gemarra-regular">generally </span>speaking, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Shimon do not follow </span>the time of the <span class="gemarra-regular">redemption, </span>and therefore their ruling here is not based on this premise. <span class="gemarra-regular">But here they found a verse and interpreted it, </span>as, if the verse is to be understood as it was explained by Rabbi Meir, then <span class="gemarra-regular">let the verse write: And if </span>he sanctifies to the Lord <span class="gemarra-regular">a field that he has bought, which is not his ancestral estate, or </span>let it write: Which is not <span class="gemarra-regular">his ancestral field. What </span>is meant by the expression: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Which is not of his ancestral fields” </span>(Leviticus 27:22)? It means that <span class="gemarra-regular">a field that is not fit to </span>ever <span class="gemarra-regular">be an ancestral field </span>is considered a purchased field. That <span class="gemarra-regular">excludes this </span>field, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is fit to be an ancestral field. </span>Based on this explanation, the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that addresses one who consecrates trees can, in fact, be understood to be in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Shimon.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna says: A grafted carob and a sycamore trunk have </span>both <span class="gemarra-regular">the status of a tree and the status of land. </span>Each of these <span class="gemarra-regular">has the status of a tree</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> so if one consecrates or buys two trees and this </span>carob or sycamore, <span class="gemarra-regular">he has </span>also consecrated or bought <span class="gemarra-regular">the land </span>between them, as the sycamore or carob joins with the other two trees to form a unit of three trees that take their land with them. And each <span class="gemarra-regular">has the status of land, as it is not sold along with land, </span>as explained in the mishna, that one who sells a field has not sold a grafted carob or a sycamore trunk that is in the field.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav Huna says </span>in a similar fashion: A large <span class="gemarra-regular">sheaf </span>of grain <span class="gemarra-regular">that contains two </span><span class="gemarra-italic">se’a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> has </span>both <span class="gemarra-regular">the status of a sheaf and the status of a heap </span>with regard to the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of forgotten sheaves that must be left for the poor. <span class="gemarra-regular">It has the status of a sheaf, as </span>the principle is that <span class="gemarra-regular">two sheaves </span>that were inadvertently <span class="gemarra-regular">left in the field are </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">forgotten </span>sheaves that must be left for the poor, whereas three sheaves need not be left for the poor, but rather the owner of the field may go back and take them for himself. In this regard a two-se’a sheaf is considered one sheaf, so if one forgot <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>sheaves <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>sheave that contains two <span class="it-text">se’a</span>, the three together are three sheaves and <span class="gemarra-regular">are not </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">forgotten </span>sheaves that must be left for the poor.
And <span class="gemarra-regular">it has the status of a heap, as we learned </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Pe’a</span> 6:6): In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a sheaf that contains two </span><span class="gemarra-italic">se’a</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> if <span class="gemarra-regular">one forgets it </span>in a field, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">a forgotten </span>sheaf that must be left for the poor, as its size and importance grant it the status of a heap, rather than a sheaf.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba bar bar Ḥana says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Reish Lakish says: </span>With regard to whether <span class="gemarra-regular">a grafted carob and a sycamore trunk </span>are consecrated along with a field that one has consecrated, <span class="gemarra-regular">we have arrived at the dispute between </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Menaḥem bar Yosei and the Rabbis, </span>as Rabbi Menaḥem bar Yosei rules that they are not consecrated, whereas the Rabbis rule that they are. 

Daf 73a

The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But let us say </span>that this is <span class="gemarra-regular">the disput</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> between Rabbi Shimon and the Rabbis, </span>as it was concluded previously that according to Rabbi Shimon himself, even the carob and sycamore trees are not consecrated. The Gemara answers: Reish Lakish <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us this</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that Rabbi Menaḥem, son of Rabbi Yosei, holds in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon, </span>and therefore Rabbi Shimon is not the only Sage who holds this opinion.

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">One who sells a shi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">p</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> has sold </span>along with it <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">toren</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, and the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">nes</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, and the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">ogin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, and all </span>of the equipment that is used for <span class="gemarra-regular">directing it. But he has not sold the slaves </span>who serve as oarsmen, <span class="gemarra-regular">nor the packing bags </span>that are used for transporting goods, <span class="gemarra-regular">nor the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">antikei</span> on the ship. <span class="gemarra-regular">And when one said to </span>the buyer: You are purchasing <span class="gemarra-regular">it, </span>the ship, <span class="gemarra-regular">and all that it contains, all of these </span>latter elements <span class="gemarra-regular">are </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">sold.</span>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The <span class="gemarra-italic">toren</span> is the <span class="gemarra-regular">mast [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">iskarya</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>in this regard <span class="gemarra-regular">it states: “They have taken </span><span class="gemarra-regular">cedar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">from Lebanon to make masts [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">toren</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] for you”</span> (Ezekiel 27:5). The <span class="gemarra-italic">nes</span> is the <span class="gemarra-regular">sail, and </span>in this regard <span class="gemarra-regular">it states: “Of fine </span><span class="gemarra-regular">line</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">with richly woven work from Egypt was your sail, that it might be to you for an ensign [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">nes</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]” </span>(Ezekiel 27:7). With regard to the meaning of <span class="gemarra-italic">ogin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, Rabbi Ḥiyya teaches: These are </span>the ship’s <span class="gemarra-regular">anchors, and </span>so <span class="gemarra-regular">it states: “Would you tarry for them until they were grown? Would you shut yourselves off for them [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">te’agena</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] and have no husbands?” </span>(Ruth 1:13). This demonstrates that the root <span class="it-text">ayin</span>, <span class="it-text">gimmel</span>, <span class="it-text">nun</span>, means being shut up and held firmly in one place.
The mishna teaches that the buyer acquires all the equipment used for <span class="gemarra-regular">directing </span>the ship. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Abba says: These are the </span>ship’s <span class="gemarra-regular">oars</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> And </span>this is as <span class="gemarra-regular">it states: “Of the oaks of Bashan they have made your oars” </span>(Ezekiel 27:6). Since a verse discussing ships focuses on its oars, evidently the oars are an integral part of the ship. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if you wish, say </span>instead that it is demonstrated <span class="gemarra-regular">from here: “And all that handle the oar, </span>the mariners, and all the pilots of the sea, <span class="gemarra-regular">shall come down from their ships” </span>(Ezekiel 27:29).
<span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught: One who sells a ship has </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">sold the gangway [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">iskala</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> used for boarding the ship, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the water tank it contains</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Natan says: One who sells a ship has sold the </span>ship’s <span class="gemarra-regular">boat [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">bitzit</span><span class="gemarra-regular">], </span>which is used as a lifeboat or for fishing in shallow waters. <span class="gemarra-regular">Sumakhos says: One who sells a ship has sold the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">dugit</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>as explained below.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: </span>The <span class="gemarra-italic">bitzit</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is </span>the same as the <span class="gemarra-italic">dugit</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. Rabbi Natan was a Babylonian, </span>and therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">he called </span>small boats <span class="gemarra-italic">butzit</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, as people say: The </span><span class="gemarra-italic">botziata</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>small boats, <span class="gemarra-regular">of Miashan</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Sumakhos, who was from Eretz Yisrael, called </span>these boats <span class="gemarra-italic">dugit</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, as it is written: </span>“You shall be taken away with hooks, <span class="gemarra-regular">and your residue in fishing boats [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">duga</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]” </span>(Amos 4:2).
§ The Gemara cites several incidents that involve ships and the conversation of seafarers. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabb</span><span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> said: Seafarers related to m</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> that when <span class="gemarra-regular">this wave that sinks a shi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">p</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> appears with a ray of white fire at its head, we strike it with clubs that are inscribed </span>with the names of God: <span class="gemarra-regular">I am that I am, </span><span class="gemarra-italic">Yah</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, the Lord of Hosts, amen amen, Selah. And </span>the wave then <span class="gemarra-regular">abates.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba said: Seafarers related to me </span>that in a certain place <span class="gemarra-regular">between </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">wave and </span>the next <span class="gemarra-regular">wav</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> there are <span class="gemarra-regular">three hundred parasangs</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and the height of a wave is three hundred parasangs. Once, </span>seafarers recounted, <span class="gemarra-regular">we were traveling along the route and a wave lifted us up until we saw the resting place of a small star, and it </span>appeared <span class="gemarra-regular">to me </span>the size of the area needed for <span class="gemarra-regular">scattering forty </span><span class="gemarra-italic">se’a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of mustard seeds. And if it had lifted us higher, we would have been scorched by the heat </span>of the star.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And the wave raised its voice </span>and shouted <span class="gemarra-regular">to another </span>wave: <span class="gemarra-regular">My friend, did you leave anything in the world that you did not wash away, that I may come and destroy it? </span>The second wave <span class="gemarra-regular">said to it: Go out </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">see the greatness of your Master, </span>God, as even when there is <span class="gemarra-regular">as much as a string of sand </span>on the land <span class="gemarra-regular">I cannot pass, as it is stated: “Will you not fear Me, said the Lord; will you not tremble at My presence? Who has placed the sand for the bound of the sea, an everlasting ordinance, which it cannot pass?” </span>(Jeremiah 5:22).
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba said: I have seen </span>the one called <span class="gemarra-regular">Hurmin, son of Lilith</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> when he was running on the pinnacles of the wall of </span>the city of <span class="gemarra-regular">Meḥoza, and a horseman was riding an animal below him but was unable </span>to catch up to <span class="gemarra-regular">him. Once, they saddled for him two mules and they stood</span>

Daf 73b

<span class="gemarra-regular">on the two bridges of </span>the river <span class="gemarra-regular">Rognag, and he jumped from this one to that one, and from that one to this one. And he was holding two cups of wine in his hands and was pouring from this one to that one, and from that one to this one, and not </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">drop fell to the ground. And that day was</span> stormy, similar to the description in a verse dealing with seafarers: <span class="gemarra-regular">“They mounted up to the heavens, they went down to the deeps; </span>their soul melted away because of trouble” (Psalms 107:26). He continued in this manner <span class="gemarra-regular">until </span>word of his behavior <span class="gemarra-regular">was heard in the house of the king</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and they killed him.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba said: I have seen a day-old antelope [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">urzila</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that was </span>as large <span class="gemarra-regular">as Mount Tabor. And how </span>large <span class="gemarra-regular">is Mount Tabor? </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">four parasangs. And the length of its neck </span>was <span class="gemarra-regular">three parasangs, and the place where his head rests </span>was <span class="gemarra-regular">a parasang and a half. It cast feces [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">kufta</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] and </span>thereby <span class="gemarra-regular">dammed up the Jordan.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabba bar bar Ḥan</span><span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> said: I have seen a certain frog [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">akrokta</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that was </span>as large <span class="gemarra-regular">as the fort [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">akra</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of Hagronya. And how </span>large <span class="gemarra-regular">is the fort of Hagronya? </span>It is as large as <span class="gemarra-regular">sixty houses. A snake came and swallowed </span>the frog. <span class="gemarra-regular">A raven came and swallowed the snake, and </span>flew <span class="gemarra-regular">up and sat in a tree. Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">see how great is the strength of the tree, </span>which could bear the weight of that raven. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa bar Shmuel said: If I had not been there </span>and seen this, <span class="gemarra-regular">I would not believe </span>it.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabba bar bar Ḥana said: Once we were traveling in a ship and we saw a certain fish in</span> whose <span class="gemarra-regular">nostril [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">b</span><span class="gemarra-italic">e</span><span class="gemarra-italic CharOverride-1">’</span><span class="gemarra-italic">u</span><span class="gemarra-italic">syeih</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a mud eater [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">akhla</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">tina</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., a type of insect, <span class="gemarra-regular">had sa</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> and killed him. <span class="gemarra-regular">And the waters thrust </span>the fish <span class="gemarra-regular">and threw it upon the shore. And sixty districts were destroyed by </span>the fish, <span class="gemarra-regular">and sixty districts ate from it, and </span>another <span class="gemarra-regular">sixty districts salted its </span>meat to preserve it. <span class="gemarra-regular">And they filled from one of its eyeballs three hundred flasks of oil. And when we returned </span>there <span class="gemarra-regular">after </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">twelve months </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">the year </span>had passed, <span class="gemarra-regular">we saw that they were cutting beams from its bones, and they had set out to build those districts </span>that had been destroyed.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabba bar bar Ḥana said: Once we were traveling on a ship and we saw a certain fish upon which sand had settled</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and grass grew on it. We assumed </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">it was dry land and went up and baked and cooked on the back </span>of the fish, <span class="gemarra-regular">but when its back </span>grew <span class="gemarra-regular">hot it turned over. And were it not for </span>the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">ship was close </span>by, <span class="gemarra-regular">we would have drowned.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabba bar bar Ḥana said: Once we were traveling in a ship and the ship traveled between </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">fin [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">shitza</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>the other <span class="gemarra-regular">fi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of a fish </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">three days and three nights. </span>The fish was swimming in the opposite direction of the ship, so that <span class="gemarra-regular">it </span>was swimming <span class="gemarra-regular">upward </span>against the wind and the waves, <span class="gemarra-regular">and we were </span>sailing <span class="gemarra-regular">downward. And if you would say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the ship did not travel very fast, when Rav Dimi came </span>from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia <span class="gemarra-regular">he said: </span>In the short amount of time required to <span class="gemarra-regular">heat a kettle of water, </span>that ship can <span class="gemarra-regular">travel sixty parasangs. And </span>another demonstration of its speed is that <span class="gemarra-regular">a horseman shot an arrow, and </span>yet the ship was traveling so swiftly that it <span class="gemarra-regular">outraced it. And Rav Ashi said: That </span>fish <span class="gemarra-regular">was a sea </span><span class="gemarra-italic">gildana</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> which has two </span>sets of <span class="gemarra-regular">fins.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabba bar bar Ḥana said: Once we were traveling in a ship and we saw a certain bir</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that was standing with water up to its ankles [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">kartzuleih</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and its head </span>was <span class="gemarra-regular">in the sky. And we said </span>to ourselves that <span class="gemarra-regular">there is no </span>deep <span class="gemarra-regular">water </span>here, <span class="gemarra-regular">and we wanted to go down to cool ourselves off. And a Divine Voic</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> emerged and said to us: Do not go down here, as the ax of a carpenter fell </span>into it <span class="gemarra-regular">seven years </span>ago <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>it has still <span class="gemarra-regular">not reached the bottom. And </span>this is <span class="gemarra-regular">not because the water is so large </span>and deep. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">because the water is turbulent. Rav Ashi said: And that </span>bird <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>called <span class="gemarra-italic">ziz</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">sadai</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>wild beast, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is written: </span>“I know all the fowls of the mountains; <span class="gemarra-regular">and the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">ziz</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">sadai</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is Mine” </span>(Psalms 50:11).
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabba bar bar Ḥana said: Once we were traveling in the desert and we saw these geese whose wings were sloping because they were so fat, and streams of oil flowed beneath them. I said to them: Shall we have a portion of you in the World-to-Come? One raised a wing, and one raised a leg, </span>signaling an affirmative response. <span class="gemarra-regular">When I came before Rabbi Elazar, he said to me: The Jewish people will </span>eventually <span class="gemarra-regular">be held accountable for </span>the suffering <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span>the geese. § The Gemara provides <span class="gemarra-regular">a mnemoni</span><span class="gemarra-regular">c</span> for the items shown by an Arab man to Rabba bar bar Ḥana in the following stories: <span class="gemarra-regular">Like the dust of the sky-blue; the scorpion stung the basket.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabba bar bar Ḥana said: Once we were traveling in the desert and we were accompanied by a certain Arab who would take dust and smell it and say: This is the road to such and such a place, and that is the road to such and such a place. We brought </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">to him, and he said: Eight parasangs. </span>Later, we said this <span class="gemarra-regular">a second time, and gave him </span>dust, and <span class="gemarra-regular">he said to us that we are at a distance of three parasangs.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> I switched </span>the type of dust to test him, <span class="gemarra-regular">but I could not </span>confuse <span class="gemarra-regular">him, </span>as he was an expert in this matter.

<span class="gemarra-regular">When I came before the Sages, they said to me </span>in rebuke: <span class="gemarra-regular">Every Abba </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">a donkey, and every bar bar Ḥana </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">an idiot. Rabba bar bar Ḥana continues his account. This Arab also <span class="gemarra-regular">said to me: Come, I will show you </span>the place <span class="gemarra-regular">where the earth and the heavens touch each other. I said to him: Are there thieves here? He said to me: This is the heavenly sphere that is turning around; wait here until tomorrow and you will find it.</span>

§ Apropos the stories of large sea creatures, the Gemara discusses the large sea creatures mentioned in the Bible. <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught: </span>There was <span class="gemarra-regular">an incident involving Rabbi Eliezer and Rabbi Yehoshua, who were traveling on a ship, and Rabbi Eliezer was sleeping and Rabbi Yehoshua was awake. Rabbi Yehoshua trembled, and Rabbi Eliezer awoke.</span> Rabbi Eliezer <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: What is this, Yehoshua; for what </span>reason <span class="gemarra-regular">did you tremble? </span>Rabbi Yehoshua <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: I saw a great light in the sea. </span>Rabbi Eliezer <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Perhaps you saw the eyes of the leviathan, as it is written: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">“And his eyes are like the eyelids of the morning” </span>(Job 41:10).
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi said: Huna bar Natan said to me: Once we were traveling in the desert, and we had a thigh of meat with us. We cut open </span>the thigh <span class="gemarra-regular">and tore </span>off the sciatic nerve and the forbidden fat <span class="gemarra-regular">and put it on the grass. When I came before Ameimar, he said to me: That grass was a drug of life [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">samterei</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> while <span class="gemarra-regular">those coals were of broom</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
The verse states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And God created the great sea monsters” </span>(Genesis 1:21). <span class="gemarra-regular">Here, </span>in Babylonia, <span class="gemarra-regular">they interpreted </span>this as a reference to the <span class="gemarra-regular">sea oryx.
