§ The Gemara provides <span class="gemarra-regular">a mnemonic </span>for the following statements of Rav Yehuda citing Rav: <span class="gemarra-regular">Everything; time; Jordan. Rav Yehuda says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: Everything that the Holy One, Blessed be He, created in His world, He created male and female. Even leviathan the slant serpent and leviathan the tortuous serpent </span><span class="gemarra-regular">He created male and female. And if they would have coupled </span>and produced offspring, they would have <span class="gemarra-regular">destroyed the entire world. What did the Holy One, Blessed be He, do? He castrated the male and killed the female, and salted </span>the female to preserve it for the banquet <span class="gemarra-regular">for the righteous in the future. As it is stated: “And He will slay the serpent that is in the sea” </span>(Isaiah 27:1).
<span class="gemarra-regular">And He created even the beast</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> on the thousand hills </span>(see Psalms 50:10) <span class="gemarra-regular">male and female. And </span>they were so enormous that <span class="gemarra-regular">if they would have coupled </span>and produced offspring, <span class="gemarra-regular">they would have destroyed the entire world</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> What did the Holy One, Blessed be He, do? He castrated the male and cooled </span>the sexual desire of <span class="gemarra-regular">the female and preserved it for the righteous in the future. As it is stated </span>about the beasts: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Lo now, his strength is in his loins” </span>(Job 40:16); <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>is referring to the <span class="gemarra-regular">male. </span>The continuation of the verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And his force is in the stays of his body”; this </span>is the <span class="gemarra-regular">female, </span>alluding to the idea that they did not use their genitals for the purpose of procreation.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">There too, </span>with regard to the leviathan, <span class="gemarra-regular">let Him castrate the male and cool the female; </span>why was it necessary to kill the female? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Fish are unrestrained</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and therefore even if the female was cooled, the female would still procreate. The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">And let Him do the opposite, </span>and kill and preserve the male leviathan. The Gemara responds: <span class="gemarra-regular">If you wish, say </span>that the <span class="gemarra-regular">salted female is better; if you wish, say </span>instead <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>since <span class="gemarra-regular">it is written: “There is leviathan, whom You have formed to sport with” </span>(Psalms 104:26), the male must be left alive for sport, because it is <span class="gemarra-regular">not proper conduct </span>to sport <span class="gemarra-regular">with a female</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Here too, </span>with regard to the beasts, <span class="gemarra-regular">let Him </span>preserve the <span class="gemarra-regular">female in salt, </span>instead of cooling it. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Salted fish is good, </span>but <span class="gemarra-regular">salted meat is not good.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav Yehuda says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: At the time when the Holy One, Blessed be He, sought to create the world, He said to the minister of the sea</span><span class="gemarra-regular">:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Open your mouth and swallow all the waters of the world, </span>so that there will be room for land. The minister of the sea <span class="gemarra-regular">said before Him: Master of the Universe, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">enough that I will stay within my own </span>waters. God <span class="gemarra-regular">immediately struck him and killed him; as it is stated: “He stirs up the sea with His power, and by His understanding He smites through Rahab” </span>(Job 26:12).
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yitzḥak said: Conclude from here </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the name of the minister of the sea is Rahab, and were it not for waters </span>of the sea that <span class="gemarra-regular">cover him, no creature could withstand his smell, </span>as his corpse emits a terrible stench. <span class="gemarra-regular">As it is stated: “They shall not hurt nor destroy in all My holy mountain; </span>for the earth shall be full of the knowledge of the Lord, <span class="gemarra-regular">as the waters cover the sea” </span>(Isaiah 11:9). <span class="gemarra-regular">Do not read </span>this phrase as <span class="gemarra-regular">“cover the sea”; rather </span>read it as: <span class="gemarra-regular">Cover the minister of the sea, </span>i.e., the term sea is referring to the minister of the sea, not to the sea itself.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav Yehuda says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: The Jordan issues fort</span><span class="gemarra-regular">h</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from the cave of Pamyas</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> That is also taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">The Jordan issues forth from the cave of Pamyas, and travels in the Sea of Sivkhi, </span>i.e., the Hula Lake, <span class="gemarra-regular">and in the Sea of Tiberias, </span>the Sea of Galilee, <span class="gemarra-regular">and rolls dow</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to the Great Sea, and rolls down until it reaches the mouth of the leviathan. As it is stated: “He is confident, though the Jordan rush forth to his mouth” </span>(Job 40:23). <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava bar Ulla strongly objects to this </span>explanation of the verse, stating: But <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>verse <span class="gemarra-regular">is written about the beasts on the thousand hills. Rather, Rava bar Ulla said </span>that this is the meaning of the verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">When are the beasts on the thousand hills confident? When the Jordan rushes forth into the mouth of the leviathan.</span>

<span class="gemarra-regular">When Rav Dimi came </span>from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia, he said that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan said: When </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">leviathan is hungry</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he produces breath from his mouth and </span>thereby <span class="gemarra-regular">boils all of the waters in the depths </span>of the sea. <span class="gemarra-regular">As it is stated: “He makes the deep boil like a pot” </span>(Job 41:23). <span class="gemarra-regular">And if </span>the leviathan <span class="gemarra-regular">did not place its head in the Garden of Eden, no creature could withstand his </span>foul <span class="gemarra-regular">smell, as it is stated: “He makes the sea like a seething mixture [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">merkaḥa</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]” </span>(Job 41:23), and the term <span class="it-text">merkaḥa</span> is also used to describe something with a smell (see Exodus 30:25).
<span class="gemarra-regular">And when he is thirsty, he makes many furrows in the sea, as it is stated: “He makes a path to shine after him” </span>(Job 41:24). <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Aḥa bar Yaakov says: </span>After the leviathan drinks from the sea, <span class="gemarra-regular">the depth </span>of the sea does <span class="gemarra-regular">not return to its normal condition until seventy years </span>have passed, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is stated: “One would think the deep to be hoary” </span>(Job 41:24), <span class="gemarra-regular">and hoary </span>indicates a person who is <span class="gemarra-regular">no less than seventy </span>years old.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: </span>In the <span class="gemarra-regular">future, the Holy One, Blessed be He, will make a feast for the righteou</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from the flesh of the leviathan, as it is stated: “The </span><span class="gemarra-italic">ḥabbarim</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> will make a feast </span><span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">yikhru</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] of him” </span>(Job 40:30). <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kera</span> means <span class="gemarra-regular">nothing other than a feast, as it is stated: “And he prepared [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">va’yikhreh</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] for them a great feast [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">kera</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]; and they ate and drank” </span>(II Kings 6:23). <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span><span class="gemarra-italic">ḥabbarim</span> means <span class="gemarra-regular">nothing other than Torah scholars</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as it is stated: “You that dwell in the gardens, the companions [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ḥaverim</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] hearken for your voice: Cause me to hear it” </span>(Song of Songs 8:13). This verse is interpreted as referring to Torah scholars, who listen to God’s voice.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">the remainder </span>of the leviathan, they will <span class="gemarra-regular">divide it and use it for commerce in the markets of Jerusalem, as it is stated:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> “They will part him among the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kena’anim</span><span class="gemarra-regular">” </span>(Job 40:30). <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kena’anim</span> means <span class="gemarra-regular">nothing other than merchants, as it is stated: “As for the merchant [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">kena’an</span><span class="gemarra-regular">], the balances of deceit are in his hand. He loves to oppress” </span>(Hosea 12:8). <span class="gemarra-regular">And if you wish, say </span>that the proof is <span class="gemarra-regular">from here: “Whose merchants are princes, whose traffickers [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">kinaneha</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> are the honorable of the earth” </span>(Isaiah 23:8).
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabba says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: </span>In the <span class="gemarra-regular">future, the Holy One, Blessed be He, will prepare a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">sukka</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">for the righteous from the skin of </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">leviathan, as it is stated: “Can you fill his skin with barbed irons [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">besukkot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]” </span>(Job 40:31). If one <span class="gemarra-regular">is deserving </span>of being called righteous, an entire <span class="gemarra-italic">sukka</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is prepared for him </span>from the skin of the leviathan; if one is <span class="gemarra-regular">not deserving </span>of this honor, <span class="gemarra-regular">a coverin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is prepared for his </span>head, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is stated: “Or his head with fish-spears” </span>(Job 40:31).
If one is <span class="gemarra-regular">deservin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span> at least of this reward, <span class="gemarra-regular">a covering is prepared for him, </span>and if one is <span class="gemarra-regular">not deserving, a necklace is prepared for him, as it is stated: “And necklaces about your neck” </span>(Proverbs 1:9). If one is somewhat <span class="gemarra-regular">deserving, a necklace is prepared for him, </span>and if one is <span class="gemarra-regular">not deserving </span>even of this, only <span class="gemarra-regular">an amu-let is prepared for him </span>from the skin of the leviathan, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is stated: “Or will you bind him for your maidens” </span>(Job 40:29), i.e., a small amulet is prepared for him, like the amulets tied on children’s necks.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">the remaining </span>part of the skin of the leviathan, <span class="gemarra-regular">the Holy One, Blessed be He, spreads it on the walls of Jerusalem, and its glory radiates from </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">end of the world until the </span>other <span class="gemarra-regular">end. As it is stated: “And nations shall walk in your light, and kings at the brightness of your rising” </span>(Isaiah 60:3).
§ With regard to the future glory of Jerusalem, the Gemara interprets the verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And I will make your pinnacles of </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kadkhod</span><span class="gemarra-regular">” </span>(Isaiah 54:12). <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shmuel bar Naḥmani said: Two angels in heaven, Gabriel and Michael</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> disagre</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> with regard to the material that will be used to form the walls of Jerusalem. <span class="gemarra-regular">And some say </span>that this dispute is between <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span><span class="gemarra-italic">amora’im</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in the West, </span>i.e., Eretz Yisrael. <span class="gemarra-regular">And who are they? </span>They are <span class="gemarra-regular">Yehuda and Ḥizkiyya, the sons of Rabbi Ḥiyya. One said </span>they will be made of <span class="gemarra-regular">onyx</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and one said </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">jasper</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> The Holy One, Blessed be He, said to them: Let it be like this [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">kedein</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] and like that [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ukhedein</span><span class="gemarra-regular">], </span>i.e., let them be formed from both together. This compromise is indicated by the word <span class="it-text">kadkhod</span>, a combination of this [<span class="it-text">kedein</span>] and that [<span class="it-text">ukhedein</span>].
The Gemara analyzes the rest of that verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And your gates of precious stones” </span>(Isaiah 54:12). This should be understood <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>light of <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>incident <span class="gemarra-regular">where Rabbi Yoḥanan sat and taught: </span>In the <span class="gemarra-regular">future, the Holy One, Blessed be He, will bring precious stones and pearls that are thirty by thirty </span>cubits, <span class="gemarra-regular">and He will hollow out in them </span>a hole of <span class="gemarra-regular">ten by twenty </span>cubits <span class="gemarra-regular">and set them in the gates of Jerusalem. A certain </span>unnamed <span class="gemarra-regular">student sneered at him, </span>saying: <span class="gemarra-regular">Now we do not find </span>precious stones even <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span>the size of <span class="gemarra-regular">an egg of a dove, </span>and yet <span class="gemarra-regular">all of this we will find?</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">After </span>a period of <span class="gemarra-regular">time </span>that student’s <span class="gemarra-regular">ship went to sea</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> where <span class="gemarra-regular">he saw ministering angels sitting and sawing precious stones and pearls that were thirty by thirty </span>cubits, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">hollowed out in them </span>were holes of <span class="gemarra-regular">ten by twenty </span>cubits. <span class="gemarra-regular">He said to </span>the angels: <span class="gemarra-regular">For whom are these? They said to him that </span>in the <span class="gemarra-regular">future, the Holy One, Blessed be He, will place them in the gates of Jerusalem. </span>Later, the student <span class="gemarra-regular">came before Rabbi Yoḥanan </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>Continue to <span class="gemarra-regular">interpret, my teacher, it is fitting for you to interpret, </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">I saw </span>just <span class="gemarra-regular">as you said. </span>Rabbi Yoḥanan <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Worthless </span>man, <span class="gemarra-regular">if you had not seen, you would not have believed; </span>clearly, <span class="gemarra-regular">you are mocking the statement of the Sages. </span>Rabbi Yoḥanan <span class="gemarra-regular">set his eyes upon him, and </span>the student was instantly killed <span class="gemarra-regular">and turned into a pile of bones.</span>
The Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises an objection </span>against Rabbi Yoḥanan’s statement, based on a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>. The verse states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And I will make you go upright [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">komemiyyut</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]” </span>(Leviticus 26:13). <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir says: </span>In the future, the Jewish people will have the stature of <span class="gemarra-regular">two hundred cubits, equivalent to two </span>times the <span class="gemarra-regular">height [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">komot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] of Adam the first </span>man, whose height was one hundred cubits. Rabbi Meir interprets the word <span class="it-text">komemiyyut</span> as two <span class="it-text">komot</span>.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda says: </span>They will have the stature of <span class="gemarra-regular">one hundred cubits, corresponding to the Sanctuary and its walls, as it is stated: “We whose sons are as plants grown up in their youth; whose daughters are as corner-pillars carved after the fashion of the Sanctuary” </span>(Psalms 144:12). But if they are each one hundred cubits tall, how could the Jews enter the gates of Jerusalem, whose entrance gate will be ten by twenty cubits, as claimed by Rabbi Yoḥanan? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">When Rabbi Yoḥanan stated </span>that idea, he was not referring to the gates themselves but <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">windows that </span>allow <span class="gemarra-regular">wind </span>to enter.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabba says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: </span>In the <span class="gemarra-regular">future, the Holy One, Blessed be He, will fashion seven canopie</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for each and every righteous </span>individual, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is stated: “And the Lord will create over the whole habitation of Mount Zion, and over those who are invited to it, a cloud and smoke by day, and the shining of a flaming fire by night; for over all the glory shall be a canopy”</span> (Isaiah 4:5). This <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches that </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">each and every </span>righteous individual, <span class="gemarra-regular">the Holy One, Blessed be He, fashions for him a canopy </span>seven times over, <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with his honor, </span>i.e., greater individuals receive grander and larger canopies.
The Gemara asks a question with regard to the above verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">Why </span>should there be <span class="gemarra-regular">smoke in a canopy? Rabbi Ḥanina said: </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">because anyone whose eyes are narrow, </span>i.e., is stingy, <span class="gemarra-regular">toward Torah scholars in this world, his eyes fill with smoke in the World-to-Come. And why</span> should there be <span class="gemarra-regular">fire in a canopy? Rabbi Ḥanina said: </span>This <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches that each and every one is burned from </span>embarrassment at the size of <span class="gemarra-regular">the canopy of the other</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and says: <span class="gemarra-regular">Woe for this embarrassment, woe for this disgrace, </span>that I did not merit a canopy as large as his.
<span class="gemarra-regular">In a similar manner, you </span>can <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that God said to Moses about Joshua: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And you shall put of your honor upon him” </span>(Numbers 27:20), which indicates that you should put some of your honor, <span class="gemarra-regular">but not all of your honor. The elders of that generation said: The face of Mose</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> was as bright <span class="gemarra-regular">as the face of the sun; the face of Joshua </span>was <span class="gemarra-regular">like the face of the moon. Woe for this embarrassment, woe for this disgrace, </span>that we did not merit another leader of the stature of Moses.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ḥama bar Ḥanina says: The Holy One, Blessed be He, fashioned ten canopies for Adam the first </span>man, <span class="gemarra-regular">in the Garden of Eden; as it is stated </span>to Hiram, king of Tyre: <span class="gemarra-regular">“You were in Eden the garden of God; every precious stone </span>was your covering, the carnelian, the topaz, and the emerald, the beryl, the onyx, and the jasper, the sapphire, the carbuncle, and the smaragd, and gold; the workmanship of your drums and of your holes was in you; they were prepared on the day that you were created” (Ezekiel 28:13). This verse mentions ten items, from carnelian to gold. <span class="gemarra-regular">Mar Zutra said: </span>There were <span class="gemarra-regular">eleven</span> canopies, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it states: “Every precious stone,” </span>which is also part of the tally. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan said: And the worst of all of them </span>was <span class="gemarra-regular">gold, as it is counted last, </span>which indicates that the other items are more valuable.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is the meaning of the phrase: <span class="gemarra-regular">“The workmanship of your drums and of your holes [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">nekavekha</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]” </span>(Ezekiel 28:13)? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: The Holy One, Blessed be He, said to Hiram, king of Tyre: </span>Were you in the Garden of Eden when I created all of this for you? <span class="gemarra-regular">I looked at you,</span> saw that you would one day claim divinity for yourself, <span class="gemarra-regular">and created many orifices [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">nekavim</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] in man</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>i.e., the excretory system, so that you would know that you are human and not a god. <span class="gemarra-regular">And there are </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">who say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>is what God <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>to Hiram: <span class="gemarra-regular">I looked at you</span>

Daf 75b

<span class="gemarra-regular">and I decreed deat</span><span class="gemarra-regular">h</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> on Adam the first </span>man, to demonstrate that he was human and not a god.
§ The Gemara returns to the aforementioned verse: “And the Lord will create over the whole habitation of Mount Zion, and over those who are invited to it, a cloud and smoke by day” (Isaiah 4:5). <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is the meaning of the phrase: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And over those who are invited to it”? Rabba says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: Jerusalem of the World-to-Come is not like Jerusalem of this world. </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">Jerusalem of this world, anyone who wants to ascend </span>there can <span class="gemarra-regular">ascend. </span>With regard to Jerusalem <span class="gemarra-regular">of the World-to-Come, only those who are invited to i</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> can <span class="gemarra-regular">ascend.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabba says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: </span>In the <span class="gemarra-regular">future, the righteous will be called by the name of the Holy One, Blessed be He</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as it is stated: “Every one that is called by My name, and whom I have created for My glory, I have formed him, yea, I have made him” </span>(Isaiah 43:7). This indicates that one who was created by God and causes Him glory is called by His name. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Shmuel bar Naḥmani says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: Three were called by the name of the Holy One, Blessed be He</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and they are: The righteous, and the Messiah, and Jerusalem.</span>
With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">the righteous, this </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">as we </span>have just <span class="gemarra-regular">said. </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">the Messiah, </span>this is <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is written: “And this is his name whereby he shall be called, the Lord is our righteousness” </span>(Jeremiah 23:6). With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">Jerusalem, </span>this is <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is writ-ten: “It shall be eighteen thousand reeds round about. And the name of the city from that day shall be, the Lord is there [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">shamma</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]” </span>(Ezekiel 48:35). <span class="gemarra-regular">Do not read </span>the word as <span class="gemarra-regular">“there” [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">shamma</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]; rather, </span>read it as: The Lord is <span class="gemarra-regular">its name [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">shemah</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]. Rabbi Elazar says: </span>In the <span class="gemarra-regular">future, the righteous will </span>have the name: <span class="gemarra-regular">Holy, recited before them</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as one recites before the Holy One, Blessed be He; as it is stated: “And it shall come to pass, that he who is left in Zion, and he who remains in Jerusalem, shall be called holy” </span>(Isaiah 4:3).
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabba says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: </span>In the <span class="gemarra-regular">future, the Holy One, Blessed be He, will raise Jerusale</span><span class="gemarra-regular">m</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> three parasangs upward; as it is stated: “And it shall be lifted up and inhabited in its place” </span>(Zechariah 14:10). <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is the meaning of the phrase <span class="gemarra-regular">“in its place”? </span>It means <span class="gemarra-regular">equivalent to its place, </span>i.e., Jerusalem will be raised to a height whose measure in parasangs corresponds to the measure of its area in square parasangs. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And from where </span>is it derived <span class="gemarra-regular">that the place </span>of Jerusalem <span class="gemarra-regular">was </span>an area of <span class="gemarra-regular">three </span>square <span class="gemarra-regular">parasangs? Rabba said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain elder said to me: I saw the initial Jerusalem, </span>when it was still extant, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>its area <span class="gemarra-regular">was three </span>square <span class="gemarra-regular">parasangs.</span>
The Gemara continues to discuss the statement of Rabbi Yoḥanan: <span class="gemarra-regular">And lest you say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">there is discomfort in ascending </span>to a place so high, <span class="gemarra-regular">the verse states </span>in a prophecy depicting the return of the Jewish people to Jerusalem: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Who are these that fly as a cloud, and as the doves to their cotes” </span>(Isaiah 60:8). This indicates that they can easily ascend to Jerusalem, as though they were clouds or doves. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa said: </span>Incidentally, one can <span class="gemarra-regular">learn from </span>that statement that <span class="gemarra-regular">this cloud </span>mentioned in the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">is three parasangs high, </span>as it reaches Jerusalem, which will be raised three parasangs.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ḥanina bar Pappa says: The Holy One, Blessed be He, wished to give </span>a set <span class="gemarra-regular">measure for Jerusalem, as it is stated </span>in a prophecy of Zechariah: “And I lifted up my eyes and saw, and behold a man with a measuring line in his hand. <span class="gemarra-regular">Then I said: Where are you going? And he said to me: To measure Jerusalem, to see what is its breadth, and what is its length” </span>(Zechariah 2:5–6).
<span class="gemarra-regular">The ministering angels said before the Holy One, Blessed be He: Master of the Universe, You have created many cities in Your world for the nations of the world, and You did not give the measure of their length or the measure of their width, </span>i.e., they are not limited by any set measure, but expand as they develop. With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">Jerusalem, which has Your name in it, and Your Temple in it, and righteous people in it, </span>will <span class="gemarra-regular">You give it a measure? Immediately: </span>“And, behold, the angel that spoke with me went forth, and another angel went out to meet him, <span class="gemarra-regular">and said to him: Run, speak to this young man, saying: Jerusalem shall be inhabited without walls for the multitude of men and cattle within it” </span>(Zechariah 2:7–8).
<span class="gemarra-regular">Reish Lakish says: </span>In the <span class="gemarra-regular">future, the Holy One, Blessed be He, will add to Jerusalem one thousand </span>times the numerical value of <span class="gemarra-italic">tefa</span><span class="gemarra-italic">f </span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">gardens; one thousand </span>times the numerical value of <span class="gemarra-italic">kefel</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">towers; one thousand </span>times the value of <span class="gemarra-italic">litzoy</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">fortifications; </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">one thousand and two </span>times the value of <span class="gemarra-italic">shilo</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">small houses [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">totpera’ot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> And each and every one </span>of these additions <span class="gemarra-regular">will be like </span>the great city of <span class="gemarra-regular">Tzippori in its prosperity.</span>
The Gemara clarifies the size of the city of Tzippori. <span class="gemarra-regular">It is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei said: I saw Tzippori in its prosperity, and there were one hundred and eighty thousand markets of sellers of </span>meat <span class="gemarra-regular">sauces in it</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>On this basis, one can estimate the future size of Jerusalem.
In a similar manner, the Gemara interprets the verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And the side-chambers were one over another, three and thirty times” </span>(Ezekiel 41:6). <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is the meaning of: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Three and thirty times”</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rabbi Levi says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappi says in the name of Rabbi Yehoshua of Sikhnei: If </span>in the future <span class="gemarra-regular">Jerusalem </span>will triple in size, so that it occupies <span class="gemarra-regular">three </span>times its former area, then <span class="gemarra-regular">each and every </span>dwelling will <span class="gemarra-regular">contain thirty stories upward. If </span>the area of <span class="gemarra-regular">Jerusalem </span>will be multiplied by <span class="gemarra-regular">thirty, each and every </span>dwelling will <span class="gemarra-regular">contain three stories above </span>every house.
§ The Gemara returns to discuss the mishna, which discusses the acquisition of a ship. <span class="gemarra-regular">It was stated </span>that there was a dispute among <span class="it-text">amora’im</span> with regard to the manner in which <span class="gemarra-regular">a shi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">p</span> is acquired. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: Once </span>the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">has pulled </span>the ship and moved it by <span class="gemarra-regular">any amount</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> he has <span class="gemarra-regular">acquired </span>it. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Shmuel says: </span>He does <span class="gemarra-regular">not acquire </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">until he pulls the entire </span>ship to the extent that the end of the ship has at least reached the place previously occupied by its front.
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Let us say </span>that this dispute <span class="gemarra-regular">is parallel to </span>a dispute between <span class="gemarra-italic">tanna’im</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>as it is taught in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">How </span>is an animal acquired <span class="gemarra-regular">through passing</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> If the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">grasped it by its hoof, </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">by its hair, </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">by the saddle that is on it, </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">by the load that is on it, </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">by the bit </span><span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">perumbiyya</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in its mouth, </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">by the bell on its neck, </span>he has <span class="gemarra-regular">acquired it. How </span>is an animal acquired <span class="gemarra-regular">through pulling</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> If <span class="gemarra-regular">he calls it and it comes, or </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">he hits it with a stick and it runs before him, once it lifts a foreleg and a hind leg </span>from where it was standing, he has <span class="gemarra-regular">acquired it. Rabbi Aḥai, and some say Rabbi Aḥa, says: </span>It is not enough if the animal lifts its hooves. Rather, one does not acquire it <span class="gemarra-regular">until it walks its full length.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Shall we say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav, who </span>holds that a buyer can acquire the ship even by moving it only a minimal distance, <span class="gemarra-regular">states </span>his ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the first </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span> that it is enough for the animal to lift two legs; <span class="gemarra-regular">and Shmuel, who </span>holds that the entire ship must be moved, <span class="gemarra-regular">states </span>his ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance </span>with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Aḥa </span>that the animal must move its full length? The Gemara rejects this suggestion: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav </span>could have <span class="gemarra-regular">said to you: I state </span>my ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Aḥa, </span>since <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Aḥa states </span>his opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">only with regard to animals, as although it lifted a foreleg and a hind leg, it stands in its place. But </span>in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a ship, once a bit of it moves, all of it moves, </span>and therefore the buyer acquires it.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Shmuel </span>could <span class="gemarra-regular">say: I stated </span>my ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">even in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the first </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. The first </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> states </span>his opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">only with regard to animals, as once </span>an animal has <span class="gemarra-regular">lifted a foreleg and a hind </span><span class="gemarra-regular">leg, the other </span>legs <span class="gemarra-regular">stand </span>ready <span class="gemarra-regular">to be lifted. But </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a ship, if he pulls the entire </span>ship, <span class="gemarra-regular">yes, </span>he acquires it, but <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>he does <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>pull the whole ship, he does <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>acquire it.
The Gemara offers another suggestion: <span class="gemarra-regular">Let us say </span>that the dispute of Rav and Shmuel is <span class="gemarra-regular">parallel to </span>the dispute between <span class="gemarra-regular">these </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna’im</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">A ship is acquired by pulling. Rabbi Natan says: A ship and letters</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., the content of a promissory note, <span class="gemarra-regular">are acquired by pulling </span>the document

Daf 76a

<span class="gemarra-regular">and by </span>means of <span class="gemarra-regular">a bill </span>of sale.
The Gemara clarifies the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Letters </span>in promissory notes, <span class="gemarra-regular">who mentioned </span>anything about <span class="gemarra-regular">them</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> Why would Rabbi Natan speak about promissory notes, which are not discussed by the first <span class="it-text">tanna</span>? The Gemara answers: The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is incomplete, and this </span>is what <span class="gemarra-regular">it is teaching</span><span class="gemarra-regular">:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> A ship is acquired by pulling, and letters, </span>i.e., the content of a promissory note, <span class="gemarra-regular">are acquired by </span>merely <span class="gemarra-regular">transferring </span>the document, not through pulling. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Natan says: A ship and letters are acquired by pulling and </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">by </span>means of <span class="gemarra-regular">a bill </span>of sale.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Why do I </span>need <span class="gemarra-regular">a bill </span>of sale <span class="gemarra-regular">for a ship? </span>A ship <span class="gemarra-regular">is movable property, </span>which is acquired not by means of giving a bill of sale, but through other acts of acquisition. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, is it not </span>correct to say that <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>is what the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is teaching: A ship is acquired by pulling, and letters </span>of credit <span class="gemarra-regular">by passing. Rabbi Natan says: A ship </span>is acquired <span class="gemarra-regular">by pulling, and letters, </span>i.e. the contents of a promissory note, are acquired either through pulling or <span class="gemarra-regular">by </span>means of <span class="gemarra-regular">a bill </span>of sale.
The Gemara asks: If Rabbi Natan holds that <span class="gemarra-regular">a ship </span>is acquired <span class="gemarra-regular">by pulling, </span>his opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>apparently identical to the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the first </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. Rather, </span>the practical difference <span class="gemarra-regular">between </span>the two opinions is the dispute <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav and Shmuel</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> According to the opinion of one <span class="it-text">tanna</span> the buyer must move the entire ship out of its current location, while the other <span class="it-text">tanna</span> maintains that one must move the ship only a minimal amount. The Gemara rejects this suggestion: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, everyone, </span>Rabbi Natan and the first <span class="it-text">tanna</span>, holds <span class="gemarra-regular">either in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> or in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel. And with regard to a ship, everyone agrees </span>that it is acquired through pulling.
<span class="gemarra-regular">When they disagree, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>acquiring <span class="gemarra-regular">letters, </span>i.e. the contents of a promissory note. <span class="gemarra-regular">And this </span>is what <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Natan is saying to the first </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: With regard to a ship, I certainly concede to you </span>that it is acquired by pulling. But <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to letters, </span>whereas you maintain that passing suffices to acquire them, I hold that <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>in addition <span class="gemarra-regular">there is a bill </span>of sale, <span class="gemarra-regular">yes, </span>the acquisition is valid, but <span class="gemarra-regular">if not, </span>the act of passing is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>effective.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>according to this interpretation, the first <span class="it-text">tanna</span> and Rabbi Natan disagree <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to the dispute </span>between <span class="gemarra-regular">these </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna’im</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Letters, </span>i.e., the contents of a promissory note, <span class="gemarra-regular">are acquired by </span>merely <span class="gemarra-regular">transferring </span>the document; this is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi. <span class="gemarra-regular">And the Rabbis say: Whether one wrote </span>a bill of sale <span class="gemarra-regular">but did not transfer </span>the promissory note to the buyer, or <span class="gemarra-regular">whether he transferred </span>the promissory note <span class="gemarra-regular">but did not write </span>a bill of sale, the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">does not acquire </span>the documents <span class="gemarra-regular">until </span>the seller both <span class="gemarra-regular">writes </span>a bill of sale <span class="gemarra-regular">and transfers </span>the promissory note.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">In accordance with which </span>opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">did you interpret </span>the opinion of the first <span class="it-text">tanna</span> of the aforementioned <span class="it-text">baraita</span>? If it is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi, then <span class="gemarra-regular">let a ship be acquired also by passing, </span>not only through pulling, as stated in the following <span class="it-text">baraita</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">A shi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">p</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is acquired by passing; </span>this is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi. <span class="gemarra-regular">And the Rabbis say: </span>The buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">does not acquire </span>it

Daf 76b

<span class="gemarra-regular">until he pulls it, or until he rents its place</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> How, then, can the opinion of the first <span class="it-text">tanna</span> of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> be ascribed to Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi?
The Gemara answers: This is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult; here, </span>where Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi states that a ship is acquired through passing, he is referring to a ship situated <span class="gemarra-regular">in the public domain. </span>Since a ship in the public domain cannot be acquired through pulling, which must be performed in a domain that is in one’s possession, it is acquired through passing. By contrast, <span class="gemarra-regular">there, </span>in the first <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, the ship is situated <span class="gemarra-regular">in an alleyway [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">simta</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> which is not the public domain, as both parties have the right to keep their possessions there. A ship in this location must be acquired through pulling.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">To what </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">did you interpret that last </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span> to be referring? It was interpreted as referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to the public domain. </span>If so, <span class="gemarra-regular">say the latter clause </span>of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">And the Rabbis say </span>that the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">does not acquire </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">until he pulls it </span>or until he rents its place. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But if </span>the ship is situated <span class="gemarra-regular">in the public domain</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from whom can he rent </span>the place? <span class="gemarra-regular">And furthermore, does pulling in the public domain effect acquisition? But don’t Abaye and Rava both say </span>with regard to the different methods of acquisition: <span class="gemarra-regular">Passin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> effects acquisition in the public domai</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> or in a courtyard that does not belong to either of </span>the parties; <span class="gemarra-regular">pullin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> effects acquisition in an alleyway or in a courtyard that belongs to both of </span>the parties; <span class="gemarra-regular">and liftin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> effects acquisition in every place, </span>even in the seller’s domain.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>does the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> mean <span class="gemarra-regular">when it says: Until he pulls it, and what </span>does it mean <span class="gemarra-regular">when it says: Until he rents its place? This </span>is what it <span class="gemarra-regular">is saying: </span>The buyer does not acquire the ship <span class="gemarra-regular">until he pulls it from the public domain into an alleyway</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> And if </span>the ship <span class="gemarra-regular">is</span> located in <span class="gemarra-regular">the domain </span>of some other <span class="gemarra-regular">owner</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">does not acquire </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">until he rents its place </span>from the owner.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Shall we say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye and Rava state </span>their opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi, not that of the Rabbis? The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> indicates that only Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi maintains that one can acquire ownership by means of passing in the public domain.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi said: </span>The Rabbis agree that it is possible to effect acquisition in the public domain through the act of passing. Therefore, <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>it is a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">says to him: Go take possession and </span>thereby <span class="gemarra-regular">effect acquisition</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> so too </span>he can effect acquisition through the act of passing, and does not need to pull it. <span class="gemarra-regular">Here </span>the Rabbis disagree with Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi, as <span class="gemarra-regular">we are dealing with </span>a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">says to him: Go pull and </span>thereby <span class="gemarra-regular">effect acquisitio</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> of it.
Rav Ashi elaborates: One <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage, </span>the Rabbis, <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that the seller is <span class="gemarra-regular">particula</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> about the method by which the item is acquired, and therefore it can be acquired only through pulling. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage, </span>Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi, <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that the seller is merely <span class="gemarra-regular">indicating the manne</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to him, </span>i.e., he advises him to use this act of acquisition but he does not mind if the buyer prefers to perform a different act of acquisition.
§ The Gemara returns to the issues of acquiring promissory notes. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa says: One who sells </span>a promissory <span class="gemarra-regular">note to another must write to him: Acquire it and all liens on property that are </span>contained <span class="gemarra-regular">within it</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rav Ashi said: I stated </span>this <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> before Rav Kahana, and I said to him </span>the following analysis: <span class="gemarra-regular">The reason </span>the buyer acquires it is <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">wrote this for him. </span>This indicates that if <span class="gemarra-regular">he did not write this for him, </span>the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">does not acquire </span>the monetary rights recorded in the promissory note.
Rav Ashi asks: Why, then, did he purchase the promissory note? <span class="gemarra-regular">But does he require</span> it <span class="gemarra-regular">to tie around the mouth of his flas</span><span class="gemarra-regular">k</span> as a stopper? Clearly, he purchased the document for the purpose of collecting the debt recorded in it. Rav Pappa <span class="gemarra-regular">said to me: Yes, </span>it is possible that he purchased the promissory note in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to tie </span>it around his flask. Since the owner did not transfer ownership of the obligation recorded in the promissory note, the buyer acquires only the paper itself. 

Daf 77a

<span class="gemarra-regular">Ameimar says: The </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is that <span class="gemarra-regular">letters are acquired by </span>merely <span class="gemarra-regular">transferrin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span> the document to the buyer, <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi said to Ameimar: </span>Is your ruling based on <span class="gemarra-regular">a tradition or </span>on your own <span class="gemarra-regular">logical reasoning</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> Ameimar <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>It is based on <span class="gemarra-regular">a tradition. Rav Ashi said: It also </span>stands to <span class="gemarra-regular">reason </span>that the contents of a promissory note are acquired through transferring, <span class="gemarra-regular">as letters, </span>i.e., the contents of a promissory note, <span class="gemarra-regular">are words</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., the buyer is acquiring the right to a monetary obligation, not a physical item, <span class="gemarra-regular">and words cannot be acquired through </span>other <span class="gemarra-regular">words</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>is it true that documents <span class="gemarra-regular">cannot </span>be acquired through words? <span class="gemarra-regular">But doesn’t Rabba Bar Yitzḥak say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: There are two </span>types of <span class="gemarra-regular">documents. </span>The first type is where one says to others: <span class="gemarra-regular">Take possession of this fiel</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for so-and-s</span><span class="gemarra-regular">o</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and write the document for him </span>as proof of the sale of the field. In this case, <span class="gemarra-regular">he may renege with regard to the document</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., he may change his mind and tell them not to write it. <span class="gemarra-regular">But he may not renege with regard to the field, </span>as the buyer has already acquired it.
The second type of document is where he said: Take possession of this field for so-and-so <span class="gemarra-regular">on the condition that you writ</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> him a document. </span>If the document has not yet been delivered <span class="gemarra-regular">he can retract </span>his instruction <span class="gemarra-regular">both with regard to the document and with regard to the field, </span>as the transfer of the field is dependent on the writing of the document.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav Ḥiyya bar Avin </span>says that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna says: There are </span>actually <span class="gemarra-regular">three </span>types of <span class="gemarra-regular">documents. Two </span>are <span class="gemarra-regular">those that we stated </span>above, and <span class="gemarra-regular">the other </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">seller wrote the document in advance</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> 

Daf 77b

This is <span class="gemarra-regular">like that which we learned </span>in a mishna (167b): A scribe <span class="gemarra-regular">may write a bill </span>of sale <span class="gemarra-regular">for the selle</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> even if the buyer is not with hi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">m</span> when the seller presents his request. In a case of this kind, <span class="gemarra-regular">once this </span>buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">takes possession of the lan</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the deed is acquired wherever it is. And this is that which we learned </span>in another mishna (<span class="it-text">Kiddushin</span> 26a): <span class="gemarra-regular">Property that does not serve as a guarantee</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., movable property, can be <span class="gemarra-regular">acquired </span>together <span class="gemarra-regular">with property that serves as a guarantee, </span>i.e., land, when the land is acquired <span class="gemarra-regular">by </span>means of giving <span class="gemarra-regular">money, or </span>by means of giving <span class="gemarra-regular">a document, or </span>by means of taking <span class="gemarra-regular">possession. </span>This shows that a bill of sale can be transferred without any act of acquisition performed for the document, and certainly through words, which presents a difficulty to Rav Ashi’s opinion.
The Gemara answers: Acquiring a bill of sale <span class="gemarra-regular">by means of </span>acquisition of land <span class="gemarra-regular">is different</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as it is similar to acquisition through an item, not by means of words. The reason is <span class="gemarra-regular">that money</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> which cannot be acquired through </span>symbolic <span class="gemarra-regular">exchange</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> a pro forma act of acquisition effecting the transfer of ownership of an item, nevertheless <span class="gemarra-regular">can be acquired by means of land.</span>
This is <span class="gemarra-regular">like that </span>incident <span class="gemarra-regular">where Rav Pappa had </span>deposited <span class="gemarra-regular">twelve thousand dinars </span>with bailees <span class="gemarra-regular">in Bei Ḥozai. He transferred </span>ownership of the money in Bei Ḥozai <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>his agent <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Shmuel bar Aḥa by means of the threshol</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of his house. </span>The Gemara adds: <span class="gemarra-regular">When </span>Rav Shmuel bar Aḥa <span class="gemarra-regular">came </span>from Bei Ḥozai with the money, Rav Pappa was so happy that he was bringing him his money that he <span class="gemarra-regular">went out </span>all the way <span class="gemarra-regular">until Tavak</span><span class="gemarra-regular">h</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to </span>greet <span class="gemarra-regular">him.</span>
§ The mishna teaches that when one sells a ship he has sold various other items; <span class="gemarra-regular">but he has not sold the slaves, nor the packing bags, nor the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">antikei</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>But when one said to the buyer: You are purchasing the ship and all that it contains, all of these are sold as well. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is the meaning of <span class="gemarra-italic">antikei</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rav Pappa said: </span>It means <span class="gemarra-regular">the merchandise that is on </span>the ship. This merchandise is not sold together with the ship.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> One who <span class="gemarra-regular">sold a wagon [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">hakkaron</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">has not sold the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">mule</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> that pull the wagon. Similarly, if one <span class="gemarra-regular">sold the mules, he has not sold the wagon. </span>One who <span class="gemarra-regular">sold a yoke [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">hatzemed</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">has not sold the oxen, </span>and one who <span class="gemarra-regular">sold the oxen has not sold the yoke. Rabbi Yehuda says: The </span>sum of <span class="gemarra-regular">money indicates </span>what one has sold. <span class="gemarra-regular">How so? </span>If the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>the seller: <span class="gemarra-regular">Sell me your yoke for two hundred dinars, </span>since <span class="gemarra-regular">it is a known matter that a yoke is not </span>sold <span class="gemarra-regular">for two hundred dinars </span>he clearly intended to purchase the oxen as well. <span class="gemarra-regular">And the Rabbis say: The </span>sum of <span class="gemarra-regular">money is not proof.</span>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Taḥlifa, from the West, </span>i.e., Eretz Yisrael, <span class="gemarra-regular">taught </span>a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">before Rabbi Abbahu. </span>If one <span class="gemarra-regular">sold a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">wagon</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">he has sold the mules </span>together with it. Rabbi Abbahu asked: <span class="gemarra-regular">But didn’t we learn </span>in the mishna that <span class="gemarra-regular">he has not sold </span>the mules? Rav Taḥlifa <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>Should <span class="gemarra-regular">I erase </span>this <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, as it is incorrect? Rabbi Abbahu <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: No, </span>do not erase it; you should <span class="gemarra-regular">explain </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">your </span><span class="gemarra-italic">baraita</span> is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the mules <span class="gemarra-regular">are fastened to </span>the wagon. In that situation, one who purchases the wagon receives the mules as well.
The mishna teaches: One who <span class="gemarra-regular">sold a yoke has not sold the oxen; </span>and the Rabbis and Rabbi Yehuda disagree over whether the sum of money proves exactly what was sold. The Gemara analyzes their disagreement: <span class="gemarra-regular">What are the circumstances? If we say </span>that the mishna is referring to a place <span class="gemarra-regular">where they call a yoke: </span><span class="gemarra-italic">Tzimda</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, and </span>they call <span class="gemarra-regular">oxen: </span><span class="gemarra-italic">Bakar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">he sold him a yoke </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">did not sell him </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">oxen. But </span>if the mishna is referring to a place <span class="gemarra-regular">where they also call oxen: </span><span class="gemarra-italic">Tzimda</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> then the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">sold him everything.</span>
The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>their dispute is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary in a plac</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> where they call a yoke: </span><span class="gemarra-italic">Tzimda</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, and </span>call <span class="gemarra-regular">oxen: </span><span class="gemarra-italic">Bakar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, but there are also </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">who cal</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> oxen: </span><span class="gemarra-italic">Tzimda</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>Since it is unclear what is meant by the term: <span class="it-text">Tzimda</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>sum of <span class="gemarra-regular">money indicates </span>whether he purchased a yoke or oxen, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the Rabbis hold </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>amount of <span class="gemarra-regular">money does not </span>serve as <span class="gemarra-regular">proof</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But if the </span>amount of <span class="gemarra-regular">money does not </span>serve as <span class="gemarra-regular">proof, </span>then in a case where the buyer paid two hundred dinars and received only a yoke, <span class="gemarra-regular">let </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">transaction be nullified</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> 

Daf 78a

<span class="gemarra-regular">And if you would say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis do not </span>hold that in a case of exploitation of less than one-sixth one must return the money and that if it was more than one-sixth there is <span class="gemarra-regular">nullification of </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">transaction</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> can it be maintained that they do <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>accept these <span class="it-text">halakhot</span>? <span class="gemarra-regular">But didn’t we learn </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Bava</span> <span class="it-text">Metzia</span> 56b) that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda says: Even </span>in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who sells a Torah scroll, an animal, or a pearl</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> these items <span class="gemarra-regular">are not </span>subject to the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">exploitation, </span>as they have no fixed price. The Rabbis <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>The early Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">stated </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">only these </span>items listed earlier in the mishna, i.e., land, slaves, and documents, are not subject to the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of exploitation. Therefore, the Rabbis should agree that the sale of the yoke is nullified.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is the meaning of the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">that teaches </span>that according to the opinion of the Rabbis <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>sum of <span class="gemarra-regular">money is not proof?</span> This means <span class="gemarra-regular">that the transaction is nullified</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> And if you wish, say </span>instead that the sale of the yoke is not nullified, because <span class="gemarra-regular">when the Sages spoke </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">exploitation and the nullification of a transaction</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> they meant that these <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> apply only in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where</span> the difference in price is an amount about <span class="gemarra-regular">which one could be</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> mistaken </span>and believe that this is the correct price. <span class="gemarra-regular">But when </span>the difference in price is so great a sum <span class="gemarra-regular">that one could not be mistaken</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> this sale is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>subject to the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of exploitation. In that case, one must <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">gave </span>the extra money <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the seller as <span class="gemarra-regular">a gift; </span>he could not have thought that this was the actual price of the object.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">One who sells a donkey has not sold its vessels, </span>i.e., its equipment, with it. <span class="gemarra-regular">Naḥum the Mede says: </span>He has <span class="gemarra-regular">sold </span><span class="gemarra-regular">its vessels. Rabbi Yehuda says: </span>There are <span class="gemarra-regular">times </span>when the vessels <span class="gemarra-regular">are sold, </span>and there are <span class="gemarra-regular">times </span>when <span class="gemarra-regular">they are not sold. How so? If the donkey was before him and its vessels </span>were <span class="gemarra-regular">on it, and </span>the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Sell me this donkey of yours, its vessels are sold. </span>If the buyer said to him: <span class="gemarra-regular">Is the donkey </span><span class="gemarra-regular">yours</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span> I wish to purchase it, <span class="gemarra-regular">its vessels are not sold.</span>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">Ulla says: </span>The <span class="gemarra-regular">dispute </span>in the mishna is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the donkey’s <span class="gemarra-regular">sack and </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">saddlebag [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">disakkaya</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the <span class="gemarra-italic">kumni</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>a term explained later in the Gemara. <span class="gemarra-regular">As the first </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> holds: An ordinary donkey is </span>used primarily <span class="gemarra-regular">for riding, </span>and therefore these articles, which are not used for riding but for carrying burdens, are not included in the sale. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Naḥum the Mede holds: An ordinary donkey is </span>used <span class="gemarra-regular">for carrying </span><span class="gemarra-regular">burdens</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and therefore the items that serve this purpose are sold along with the donkey. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">the saddle and the saddlecloth, the harness and the saddle band, everyone agrees </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">they are sold, </span>as they are used both for riding and for carrying burdens.
The Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises an objection </span>from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>. If a seller says: <span class="gemarra-regular">I am selling you a donkey and its vessels, this </span>one has <span class="gemarra-regular">sold the saddle, and the saddlecloth, and the harness, and the saddle band</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> But he has not sold the sack, and the saddlebag, and the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kumni</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. And when </span>the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>the buyer: I am selling <span class="gemarra-regular">it and everything that is on it, </span>to you; the donkey and <span class="gemarra-regular">all of these </span>items <span class="gemarra-regular">are sold. </span>It can be inferred from here that the <span class="gemarra-regular">reason that </span>the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">acquires the saddle and the saddlecloth </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>I am selling you <span class="gemarra-regular">a donkey and its vessels. </span>By inference, if the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">did not say this, </span>the buyer does <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>acquire them.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">The same is true even if </span>the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">did not say to him: </span>I am selling you <span class="gemarra-regular">a donkey and its vessels. </span>In that case <span class="gemarra-regular">as well, the saddle and the saddlecloth are sold. And this </span>is what the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us: That even though </span>the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>I am selling you <span class="gemarra-regular">a donkey and its vessels, </span>the buyer still <span class="gemarra-regular">does not acquire </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">sack and </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">saddlebag and </span>the <span class="gemarra-italic">kumni</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
The Gemara inquires: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is the meaning of: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the <span class="gemarra-italic">kumni</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? Rav Pappa bar Shmuel said: </span>This is the <span class="gemarra-regular">saddle </span>used <span class="gemarra-regular">by women</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">A dilemma was raised before </span>the Sages: Does this <span class="gemarra-regular">dispute </span>apply only to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where</span> the vessels <span class="gemarra-regular">are on </span>the donkey, <span class="gemarra-regular">but when </span>the vessels <span class="gemarra-regular">are not on </span>the donkey, <span class="gemarra-regular">Naḥum the Mede concedes to </span>the Rabbis that they are not sold? <span class="gemarra-regular">Or perhaps </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">dispute </span>applies <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where</span> the vessels <span class="gemarra-regular">are not on </span>the donkey, <span class="gemarra-regular">but when </span>the vessels <span class="gemarra-regular">are on </span>the donkey <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis concede to Naḥum </span>that the vessels are sold. The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a proof from the aforementioned <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">And when </span>the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>the buyer: I am selling <span class="gemarra-regular">it and everything that is on it, </span>the donkey and <span class="gemarra-regular">all of these </span>items <span class="gemarra-regular">are sold. </span>In this case, the vessels are on the donkey, and everything is sold.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, if you say </span>that the <span class="gemarra-regular">dispute </span>applies <span class="gemarra-regular">when </span>the vessels <span class="gemarra-regular">are on </span>the donkey, in accordance with <span class="gemarra-regular">whose </span>opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">is this </span>ruling? <span class="gemarra-regular">It is </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis </span>that although in general one does not acquire the vessels, if the seller explicitly says that he is selling the donkey and everything on it, the buyer acquires it all. <span class="gemarra-regular">But if you say that </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">dispute </span>applies <span class="gemarra-regular">when </span>the vessels <span class="gemarra-regular">are not on </span>the donkey, <span class="gemarra-regular">but when </span>the vessels <span class="gemarra-regular">are on </span>the donkey <span class="gemarra-regular">everyone agrees </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">they are sold, </span>in accordance with <span class="gemarra-regular">whose </span>opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">is this </span>ruling? Even according to the opinion of the Rabbis there is no need to say explicitly that he is selling everything.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Actually, </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">dispute </span>applies <span class="gemarra-regular">when </span>the vessels <span class="gemarra-regular">are not on </span>the donkey, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis, and </span>the language of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> should be emended to <span class="gemarra-regular">say: And when he said to him: </span>I am selling <span class="gemarra-regular">it and everything that is fit to be on it, </span>i.e., those items usually found on a donkey, everything is sold.
The Gemara suggests another proof: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a solution from the mishna. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda says: </span>There are <span class="gemarra-regular">times </span>when the vessels <span class="gemarra-regular">are sold, </span>and there are <span class="gemarra-regular">times when they are not sold. What, is it not </span>the case <span class="gemarra-regular">that Rabbi Yehuda is referring to that which the first </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> said</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> If so, the dispute between the Rabbis and Naḥum the Mede must be referring to a case where the vessels are on the donkey, as Rabbi Yehuda addresses the same set of circumstances. The Gemara rejects this proof: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, Rabbi Yehuda</span>

Daf 78b

<span class="gemarra-regular">was speaking of a different matte</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> and was not necessarily addressing the same case discussed in the beginning of the mishna.
