<span class="gemarra-regular">Ravina said to Rav Ashi: Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a resolution of the dilemma, as it was taught in the previous mishna: If one <span class="gemarra-regular">sold a wagon he has not sold the mules </span>that pull the wagon. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav Taḥlifa, from the West, </span>i.e., Eretz Yisrael, <span class="gemarra-regular">taught </span>a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">before Rabbi Abbahu: </span>If one <span class="gemarra-regular">sold a wagon, he has sold the mules </span>along with it. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>Rabbi Abbahu <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: But didn’t we learn </span>in the mishna that <span class="gemarra-regular">he has not sold </span>the mules? <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>Rav Taḥlifa <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Should I erase </span>this <span class="it-text">baraita</span>? <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>Rabbi Abbahu <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: No, </span>you should <span class="gemarra-regular">explain </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">your </span><span class="gemarra-italic">baraita</span> is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the mules <span class="gemarra-regular">are fastened to </span>the wagon.
One can learn <span class="gemarra-regular">by inference </span>from Rabbi Abbahu’s statement <span class="gemarra-regular">that the mishna </span>is referring to a situation <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the mules <span class="gemarra-regular">are not fastened to</span> the wagon. <span class="gemarra-regular">And since the first clause, </span>i.e., the previous mishna, is referring to a case corresponding to <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the vessels <span class="gemarra-regular">are not on </span>the donkey, i.e., the mules are not fastened to the wagon, <span class="gemarra-regular">the latter clause, </span>the mishna here, must <span class="gemarra-regular">also</span> be referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>a situation <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the vessels <span class="gemarra-regular">are not on </span>the donkey.
The Gemara rejects this proof: <span class="gemarra-regular">On the contrary, say the first clause, </span>i.e., the preceding mishna: One who sells a ship sells the mast along with it, <span class="gemarra-regular">but he has not sold either the slaves or the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">antikei</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. And we said: What </span>is the meaning of <span class="gemarra-italic">antikei</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? Rav Pappa said: </span>It means <span class="gemarra-regular">the merchandise that is in </span>the ship. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>according to your logic, <span class="gemarra-regular">since the first clause, </span>i.e., the mishna concerning the ship, is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the merchandise <span class="gemarra-regular">is on </span>the ship, <span class="gemarra-regular">the latter clause, </span>the mishna here, must <span class="gemarra-regular">also </span>be referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the vessels <span class="gemarra-regular">are on </span>the donkey. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> teaches each statement </span>individually, and the circumstances of one ruling do not prove that another ruling is referring to a parallel case.
The Gemara provides <span class="gemarra-regular">a mnemonic </span>based on the letters of the names of the <span class="it-text">tanna’im</span> who appear here: <span class="gemarra-italic">Zayin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span><span class="gemarra-italic">gimmel</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span><span class="gemarra-italic">mem</span><span class="gemarra-regular">; </span><span class="gemarra-italic">nun</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span><span class="gemarra-italic">samekh</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span><span class="gemarra-italic">nun</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. Abaye said: Rabbi Eliezer, and Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel, and Rabbi Meir, and Rabbi Natan, and Sumakhos, and Naḥum the Mede all hold </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">when a person sells an item, he sells it and all of its accoutrements.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Eliezer </span>holds this, <span class="gemarra-regular">as we learned </span>in a mishna (67b) that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Eliezer says: One who sells an olive press has sold the beam </span>used for pressing the olives, despite the fact that the beam can be removed from the press. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel </span>holds this, <span class="gemarra-regular">as we learned </span>in a mishna (68b) that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: One who sells a city has sold the </span>city’s <span class="gemarra-regular">guardsman. Rabbi Meir </span>holds this, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir says: </span>If one <span class="gemarra-regular">sold a vineyard, he has sold the accoutrements of the vineyard. Rabbi Natan and Sumakhos </span>hold this, as they state with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">bitzit</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">dugit</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>i.e., the light-going boats of the ship, which they claim are sold when the ship is sold (73a). <span class="gemarra-regular">Naḥum the Mede </span>holds this, as is evident from <span class="gemarra-regular">that which we said </span>in the mishna here.
§ The mishna teaches that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda says: </span>There are <span class="gemarra-regular">times </span>when the vessels <span class="gemarra-regular">are sold, </span>and there are times when they are not sold. How so? If the donkey was before him and its vessels were on it, and the buyer said to him: Sell me this donkey of yours, its vessels are sold. If the buyer said: Is the donkey yours? I wish to purchase it, its vessels are not sold. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is different </span>in a case where the buyer said: Sell me <span class="gemarra-regular">this donkey of yours, and what is different </span>in a case where he said: <span class="gemarra-regular">Is the donkey yours?</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said </span>that when the buyer says: Sell me <span class="gemarra-regular">this donkey of yours</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he knows that the donkey belongs to </span>the seller, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>as for <span class="gemarra-regular">that which he said to him: This, he said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">to him </span><span class="gemarra-regular">due to its vessels. </span>By contrast, when the buyer says: <span class="gemarra-regular">Is the donkey yours, </span>this indicates <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">does not know that the donkey belongs to </span>the seller, <span class="gemarra-regular">and this </span>is what <span class="gemarra-regular">he is saying to him: Is the donkey yours that you can sell it to me? </span>In this case, he is interested only in the donkey and not its vessels.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">One who sells </span>a female <span class="gemarra-regular">donkey has sold </span>its <span class="gemarra-regular">foal </span>along with it. But one who <span class="gemarra-regular">sold a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">co</span><span class="gemarra-regular">w</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">has not sold its young. </span>One who <span class="gemarra-regular">sold a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">dunghil</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">has sold its manure. </span>One who <span class="gemarra-regular">sold a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">cister</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">has sold its water. </span>One who <span class="gemarra-regular">sold a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">beehiv</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">has sold the bees </span>in it, and likewise one who <span class="gemarra-regular">sold a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">dovecot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">has sold </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">doves.</span>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna teaches that if one sells a donkey he has sold its foal, but if one sells a cow he has not sold its calf. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What are the circumstances? If </span>this is a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">says to the </span>buyer that he is selling <span class="gemarra-regular">it and its young, even the cow and its young </span>should be sold <span class="gemarra-regular">as well. If </span>this is a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he does not say to him </span>that he is selling <span class="gemarra-regular">it and its young, even the donkey </span>should <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>be sold with its foal.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa said: </span>This is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">said to the </span>buyer: <span class="gemarra-regular">I am selling you a nursing donkey, or: </span>I am selling you <span class="gemarra-regular">a nursing cow. Granted, </span>with regard to the <span class="gemarra-regular">cow, one could say that he needs it for its milk,</span> and the suckling calf would not necessarily be included in the sale. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>with regard to the <span class="gemarra-regular">donkey, </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>reason <span class="gemarra-regular">is he saying to him </span>that the donkey is nursing? Since he does not need the milk of a donkey, <span class="gemarra-regular">learn from here </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">he is saying to him </span>that he is selling <span class="gemarra-regular">it and its young. </span>The Gemara adds tangentially: <span class="gemarra-regular">And why </span>does the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">call </span>a donkey foal <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">seyaḥ</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> It is <span class="gemarra-regular">because it follows after </span>and obeys <span class="gemarra-regular">pleasant talk [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">siḥa</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> whereas an old donkey must be led forcibly.
The Gemara cites a related discussion. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shmuel bar Naḥman says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: What </span>is the meaning of that <span class="gemarra-regular">which is written: “Therefore they that speak in parables [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">hamoshlim</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] say:</span> Come to Heshbon! Let the city [<span class="it-text">ir</span>] of Sihon be built and established! For a fire is gone out of Heshbon, a flame from the city of Sihon; it has devoured Ar of Moab, the lords of the high places of Arnon” (Numbers 21:27–28)?
The Gemara interprets these verses homiletically. <span class="gemarra-regular">“</span><span class="gemarra-italic">Hamoshlim</span><span class="gemarra-regular">”; these are </span>the people <span class="gemarra-regular">who rule over [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">hamoshlim</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] their </span>evil <span class="gemarra-regular">inclination. </span>They will say: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Come to Heshbon,” </span>meaning: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come and let us calculate the account of [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ḥeshbono</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] the world, </span>i.e., the financial <span class="gemarra-regular">loss </span>incurred by the fulfillment of <span class="gemarra-regular">a mitzv</span><span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in contrast to its reward, and the reward </span>for committing <span class="gemarra-regular">a transgression, </span>i.e., the pleasure and gain received, <span class="gemarra-regular">in contrast to the loss it </span>entails.
<span class="gemarra-regular">“Let it be built and established” </span>means that <span class="gemarra-regular">if you </span>make this calculation, <span class="gemarra-regular">you will be built in this world and you will be established in the World-to-Come. </span>The phrase <span class="gemarra-regular">“city [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ir</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] of Sihon” </span>means that <span class="gemarra-regular">if a person fashions himself like this young donkey [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ayir</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] that follows after pleasant talk [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">siḥa</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., if one is easily tempted to listen to his inclination, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is written after it? “For a fire is gone out of Heshbon…</span>it has devoured,” i.e., <span class="gemarra-regular">a fire will go out from </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">who calculate </span>the effect of their deeds in the world, <span class="gemarra-regular">and will consum</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> those who do not calculate </span>and examine their ways but instead do as they please.
A similar interpretation applies to the continuation of the verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“A flame from the city of Sihon”; </span>this means that a flame will come <span class="gemarra-regular">from the city of righteous people, who are called trees [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">siḥin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> “It has devoured Ar of Moab”</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> this </span>is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who follows after his inclination like this young donkey [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ayir</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] that follows after pleasant talk. “The lords of the high places of Arnon”; this </span>is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">the arrogant. As the Master says: Every person who has arrogance in him will fall into Gehenna.</span>
The Gemara interprets a subsequent verse: “We have shot at them [<span class="it-text">vanniram</span>], Heshbon is perished, even until Dibon, and we have laid waste even until Nophah, which reaches until Medeba” (Numbers 21:30). <span class="gemarra-regular">“</span><span class="gemarra-italic">Vanniram</span><span class="gemarra-regular">”; </span>this indicates that the <span class="gemarra-regular">wicked </span>person <span class="gemarra-regular">says: There is no higher [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ein</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">ram</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] </span>power governing the world. <span class="gemarra-regular">“Heshbon is perished” </span>means: <span class="gemarra-regular">The account [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ḥeshbon</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] of the world has perished, </span>i.e., they claim there is no accountability for one’s actions. <span class="gemarra-regular">“Even until Dibon [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">divon</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]”; the Holy One, Blessed be He, says: Wait until judgment comes </span><span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">yavo</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">din</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]. </span><span class="gemarra-regular">“And we have laid waste</span>

Daf 79a

<span class="gemarra-regular">even until Nophah,” </span>meaning <span class="gemarra-regular">until the fire comes that does not require fanning [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">nippuaḥ</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., the fire of Gehenna, which will consume them. <span class="gemarra-regular">“Until Medeba [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">Medeva</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]”; </span>this means <span class="gemarra-regular">until their souls are pained [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">tadiv</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]. And some say </span>an alternative explanation: It means <span class="gemarra-regular">until </span>God <span class="gemarra-regular">doe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> what He wishes [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">mai</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">deva’ei</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] </span>with them and punishes them as they deserve.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">anyone who separates </span>himself <span class="gemarra-regular">from matters of Torah, a fire consumes him, as it is stated: “And I will set My face against them; out of the fire they come forth, and the fire shall devour them” </span>(Ezekiel 15:7). The Torah is likened to fire in the verse: “Is not My word like fire?” (Jeremiah 23:29). The verse in Ezekiel teaches: “Out of the fire they come forth,” referring to those who separate themselves from the fire of Torah; “and the fire shall devour them,” i.e., they are consumed by the fire of Gehenna.
<span class="gemarra-regular">When Rav Dimi came </span>from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia, he said that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yonatan says: Anyone who separates himself from the matters of Torah falls into Gehenna. As it is stated: “The man who strays out of the way of understanding shall rest in the congregation of the spirits” </span>(Proverbs 21:16). “The way of understanding” is the way of the Torah. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>one who departs from the Torah arrives in the place of the <span class="gemarra-regular">spirits, </span>which <span class="gemarra-regular">is nothing other than Gehenna, as it is stated: “But he does not know that the spirits are there; that those whom she has called are in the depths of the netherworld” </span>(Proverbs 9:18).
§ The mishna teaches: One who <span class="gemarra-regular">sold a dunghill has sold its manure, </span>and one who sold a cistern has sold its water. <span class="gemarra-regular">We learned </span>in a mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">elsewhere </span>(<span class="it-text">Me’ila</span> 12b): With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">any </span>item that is <span class="gemarra-regular">fit to</span> be sacrificed on <span class="gemarra-regular">the alta</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> but </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>fit <span class="gemarra-regular">for Temple maintenance, </span>or is fit <span class="gemarra-regular">for Temple maintenance but not for the altar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> or items that are fit <span class="gemarra-regular">neither for the altar nor for Temple maintenanc</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> in their current state and are slated to be sold with the profit used for the Temple, in all these cases if one consecrates these items and then derives benefit <span class="gemarra-regular">from them or their contents</span> for a non-sacred purpose, he thereby is liable for <span class="gemarra-regular">misuse </span>of consecrated property and is obligated to bring an offering as atonement.
<span class="gemarra-regular">How so? </span>One who <span class="gemarra-regular">consecrated a cistern filled with water, dunghills filled with manure, a dovecote filled with doves, a field filled with plants, </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">a tree bearing fruit, </span>and subsequently derived benefit <span class="gemarra-regular">from them or their contents </span>is liable for <span class="gemarra-regular">misuse </span>of consecrated property.
<span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>with regard to one who <span class="gemarra-regular">consecrated a cistern and it was later filled with water</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a dunghill and it was later filled with manure, a dovecote and it later was filled with doves, a tree and it later bore fruit, </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">a field and it was later filled with plants, </span>if he derives benefit <span class="gemarra-regular">from them </span>he is liable for <span class="gemarra-regular">misuse </span>of consecrated property but he is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>liable for <span class="gemarra-regular">misuse </span>of consecrated property by deriving benefit from <span class="gemarra-regular">its contents</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> This is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of Rabbi Yehuda. Rabbi Yosei says: </span>With regard to one who <span class="gemarra-regular">consecrated a field or a tree, </span>he is liable for <span class="gemarra-regular">misuse </span>of consecrated property if he derives benefit from <span class="gemarra-regular">them or that which grows from them, because they are growths of consecrated </span>property.
<span class="gemarra-regular">It is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">said: The statement of Rabbi Yehuda appears </span>to be correct <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the cases of <span class="gemarra-regular">a cistern and a dovecote, </span>i.e., if one consecrated an empty cistern or dovecote, the water or doves that later fill it do not become consecrated. <span class="gemarra-regular">And the statement of Rabbi Yosei </span>appears to be correct <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the cases of <span class="gemarra-regular">a field and a tree. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is </span>the meaning of <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>statement of Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi? <span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, </span>when he says that <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of Rabbi Yehuda appears </span>to be correct <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the cases of <span class="gemarra-regular">a cistern and a dovecote, by inference </span>this means <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>Rabbi Yehuda <span class="gemarra-regular">disagrees </span>with Rabbi Yosei <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the cases of <span class="gemarra-regular">a field and a tree, </span>and Rabbi Yehuda does explicitly disagree in those cases.
<span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>when Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi says that <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of Rabbi Yosei appears </span>to be correct <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the cases of <span class="gemarra-regular">a field and a tree, </span>this indicates <span class="gemarra-regular">by inference that </span>Rabbi Yosei <span class="gemarra-regular">disagrees </span>with Rabbi Yehuda <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the cases of <span class="gemarra-regular">a cistern and a dovecote. But Rabbi Yosei stated </span>his opinion solely <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the cases of <span class="gemarra-regular">a field and a tree, </span>as only plants and fruit grow directly from consecrated property, and this reasoning is not relevant in the case of a cistern or dovecote.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if you would say </span>that Rabbi Yosei <span class="gemarra-regular">stated </span>his opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with the statement of Rabbi Yehuda</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> whereas he himself holds that even the items found in a dovecote or a cistern are consecrated, this is difficult: <span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t it taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei said: I do not see the statement of Rabbi Yehuda </span>as correct <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the cases of <span class="gemarra-regular">a field and a tree, because </span>the plants and the fruit <span class="gemarra-regular">are the growths of consecrated </span>property? Infer from here that it is <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the cases of <span class="gemarra-regular">a field and a tree that </span>Rabbi Yosei <span class="gemarra-regular">does not see </span>and accept the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda. <span class="gemarra-regular">But in </span>the cases of <span class="gemarra-regular">a cistern and a dovecote, he </span>does <span class="gemarra-regular">see </span>and accept his opinion.
The Gemara answers that <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>is what Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">is saying: The statement of Rabbi Yehuda appears to Rabbi Yosei </span>to be correct <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the cases of <span class="gemarra-regular">a cistern and a dovecote. </span>In other words, Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi is saying <span class="gemarra-regular">that even Rabbi Yosei disagrees with </span>Rabbi Yehuda <span class="gemarra-regular">only in </span>the cases of <span class="gemarra-regular">a field and a tree. But in </span>the cases of <span class="gemarra-regular">a cistern and a dovecote, he concedes to him </span>that the prohibition against misuse of consecrated property does not apply to items that were added afterward and were not present at the time of the consecration.
<span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught: </span>In the case of cisterns, with regard to one who <span class="gemarra-regular">consecrated them </span>when they were <span class="gemarra-regular">empty and they were later filled, </span>if one derives benefit <span class="gemarra-regular">from them </span>he is liable for <span class="gemarra-regular">misuse </span>of consecrated property, <span class="gemarra-regular">but</span> he is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>liable for <span class="gemarra-regular">misuse </span>of consecrated property if he derives benefit <span class="gemarra-regular">from their contents. </span>This ruling will be clarified below. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, says: </span>One is liable for <span class="gemarra-regular">misuse </span>of consecrated property <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>by deriving benefit <span class="gemarra-regular">from their contents.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba says: </span>This <span class="gemarra-regular">dispute </span>in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> applies only <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the cases of <span class="gemarra-regular">a field and a tree, as the first </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> holds in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda, and Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, holds in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei. But in </span>the cases of <span class="gemarra-regular">a cistern and a dovecote, everyone agrees </span>that if one derives benefit <span class="gemarra-regular">from them</span> he is liable for <span class="gemarra-regular">misuse </span>of consecrated property <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>liable for <span class="gemarra-regular">misuse </span>of consecrated property if he derives benefit <span class="gemarra-regular">from their contents.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said to him: But </span>consider <span class="gemarra-regular">that which is taught </span>in the continuation of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: If one <span class="gemarra-regular">consecrated them </span>when they were <span class="gemarra-regular">full </span>and then derives benefit <span class="gemarra-regular">from them </span><span class="gemarra-regular">or from their contents, </span>he is liable for <span class="gemarra-regular">misuse </span>of consecrated property. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, reverse</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> his previous ruling in this case and holds that if the items were consecrated when full their contents are not subject to the prohibition against misuse of consecrated property. 

Daf 79b

<span class="gemarra-regular">And if </span>their dispute is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to a field and a tree, why does </span>Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, <span class="gemarra-regular">reverse </span>his opinion? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>Rabba’s statement must be adjusted, and this is what <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba said: </span>This <span class="gemarra-regular">dispute </span>between the first <span class="it-text">tanna</span> and Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, applies only <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the cases of <span class="gemarra-regular">a cistern and a dovecote. But in </span>the cases of <span class="gemarra-regular">a field and a tree, everyone agrees </span>that one is liable for <span class="gemarra-regular">misuse </span>of consecrated property if one derives benefit <span class="gemarra-regular">from them or their contents.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And in </span>the cases of <span class="gemarra-regular">a cistern and a dovecote, where </span>the cistern and the dovecote <span class="gemarra-regular">are empty, with regard to what </span>matter <span class="gemarra-regular">do they disagree? And </span>similarly, <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the cistern and the dovecote <span class="gemarra-regular">are full, with regard to what do they disagree? </span>The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">In </span>the cases of a cistern and a dovecote that <span class="gemarra-regular">are empty, they disagree with regard to </span>the matter that is the subject of <span class="gemarra-regular">the dispute between Rabbi Meir and the Rabbis.</span>
The first <span class="it-text">tanna</span> and Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, disagree <span class="gemarra-regular">because the first </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> holds in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis, who say: A person cannot transfer </span>ownership of <span class="gemarra-regular">an object that has not </span>yet <span class="gemarra-regular">come into the world</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., that one does not currently own. Therefore, one cannot consecrate water or doves that will enter the cistern or dovecote only in the future. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, holds in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir, who says: A person can transfer </span>ownership of <span class="gemarra-regular">an object that has not </span>yet <span class="gemarra-regular">come into the world</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
The Gemara raises a difficulty with regard to this answer: You can <span class="gemarra-regular">say that you heard Rabbi Meir </span>express this opinion in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">such as </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">fruit of palm trees, which are likely to come </span>into existence, as the trees naturally produce fruit. But with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">these </span>doves and water, <span class="gemarra-regular">who can say that they will come? Rava said: You </span>can <span class="gemarra-regular">find </span>cases where one consecrates water or doves that are likely to arrive, e.g., <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">water that comes by way of his courtyard into the cister</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> when it rains, so that he does not need to fill the cistern. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>similarly with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">doves that come by way of his </span>other, full <span class="gemarra-regular">dovecot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> into </span>this empty <span class="gemarra-regular">dovecote.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>in cases <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the cistern and the dovecote <span class="gemarra-regular">are </span><span class="gemarra-regular">full, with regard to what </span>matter <span class="gemarra-regular">do they disagree? Rava said: </span>This dispute concerns a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he consecrated a cistern without specification. And Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, holds in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">his father, who says: One infers the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> of consecration to the <span class="gemarra-regular">Most High from the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> of transactions between one <span class="gemarra-regular">ordinary </span>person <span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">hedyot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> and another.
The Gemara elaborates: <span class="gemarra-regular">Just as the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> with regard to transactions between one <span class="gemarra-regular">ordinary </span>person and another is that <span class="gemarra-regular">one can say: I sold you the cistern </span>but <span class="gemarra-regular">I did not sell you the water </span>it contains, <span class="gemarra-regular">so too, the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> in the case of consecration to the <span class="gemarra-regular">Most High </span>is that one can say: <span class="gemarra-regular">I consecrated the cistern </span>but <span class="gemarra-regular">I did not consecrate the water </span>within it. <span class="gemarra-regular">And the first </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">one does not infer the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> of consecration to the <span class="gemarra-regular">Most High from the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> of transactions between one ordinary person and another. Rather, one who consecrates property does so generously, i.e., the most expansive meaning is assumed for his vow of consecration, and therefore even if he did not say so explicitly, he consecrated the water together with the cistern.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>does <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> concerning a transaction with <span class="gemarra-regular">an ordinary </span>person say that one does <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>sell the water along with the cistern? <span class="gemarra-regular">But didn’t we learn </span>in the mishna (78b) that one who <span class="gemarra-regular">sold a cistern has sold its water? Rava said: </span>The ruling in <span class="gemarra-regular">the mishna is an individual </span>opinion, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: One who <span class="gemarra-regular">sold a cister</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> has not sold its water. Rabbi Natan says: </span>One who <span class="gemarra-regular">sold a cistern has sold its water. </span>

Daf 80a

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">One who buys the produce of a dovecot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from another</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., the doves that will hatch over the course of the year in a dovecote, <span class="gemarra-regular">must leave [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">mafriaḥ</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> the <span class="gemarra-regular">first </span>pair of doves from the <span class="gemarra-regular">broo</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> for the seller. If one buys <span class="gemarra-regular">the produce of a beehive</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., all the bees produced from a beehive over the course of the year, the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">takes three swarm</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>then the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">renders </span>the bees <span class="gemarra-regular">impotent, </span>so that they will stop producing offspring and instead produce only honey. One who buys <span class="gemarra-regular">honeycomb</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> must leave two combs</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> If one buys <span class="gemarra-regular">olive </span>trees <span class="gemarra-regular">for felling, he must leave </span><span class="gemarra-regular">two shoot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> for the seller.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna teaches that one who buys the brood of a dovecote must leave the first pair of the brood for the seller. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t it taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that one must leave the <span class="gemarra-regular">first and </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">second </span>pairs of <span class="gemarra-regular">a brood </span>for the seller? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Kahana said: </span>This is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult. This </span>statement in the mishna is referring to the pair left <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>the first pair of the brood <span class="gemarra-regular">itself, </span>i.e., an extra pair of doves must be left behind to ensure that the first brood will not fly away. <span class="gemarra-regular">That </span>statement of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is referring to a pair left <span class="gemarra-regular">for the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">mothe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> of the pair discussed in the mishna. In other words, the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is saying that one must leave a pair of doves for the mother, and later a second pair from the brood of her children, which is the pair mentioned by the mishna.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is different </span>about <span class="gemarra-regular">the mother </span>that there is no concern that she will escape from the dovecote? If the reason is <span class="gemarra-regular">that she is attached to her daughter and the mat</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> which one leaves for her, </span>this should also be true with regard to the daughter, i.e., <span class="gemarra-regular">she too will become attached to her mother and the mate which one leaves for her. </span>Why, then, is it necessary to leave behind a pair of the daughter’s own brood to ensure that the daughter will not leave? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">A mother is attached to her daughter, </span>whereas <span class="gemarra-regular">a daughter is not attached to her mother. </span>Therefore, in order for the daughter to remain in the dovecote it is necessary to leave the daughter’s brood with her.
§ The mishna teaches that one who buys the <span class="gemarra-regular">produce of a beehive takes three swarms and </span>then the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">renders </span>the bees <span class="gemarra-regular">impotent [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">mesares</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">By what </span>means <span class="gemarra-regular">does he render them impotent? Rav Yehuda said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel said: </span>He renders them impotent <span class="gemarra-regular">by </span>feeding them <span class="gemarra-regular">mustard. They say in the West, </span>Eretz Yisrael, <span class="gemarra-regular">in the name of Rabbi Yosei bar Ḥanina: </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">mustard </span>itself that <span class="gemarra-regular">renders them impotent</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rather, since their mouths sting </span>from the bitterness of the mustard, <span class="gemarra-regular">they return and eat their own honey. </span>Due to their excessive eating of honey, they cease to form new swarms and instead produce honey for the seller.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: </span>This is not the meaning of <span class="it-text">mesares</span>. Rather, the mishna should be understood as follows: One <span class="gemarra-regular">takes three swarms by skipping [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">beseirus</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> every other swarm, so that the buyer receives the first, third, and fifth swarms, while the others remain with the seller. <span class="gemarra-regular">It is taught in a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">baraita</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: </span>The buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">takes </span>the first <span class="gemarra-regular">three swarms one after the other, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">from this </span>point <span class="gemarra-regular">forward he takes one and leaves one.</span>
§ The mishna teaches that one who buys <span class="gemarra-regular">honeycombs must leave two combs </span>and one who buys olive trees for felling must leave two shoots. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Kahana says: </span>As long as <span class="gemarra-regular">honey </span>remains <span class="gemarra-regular">in the beehive it never leaves </span>its status as <span class="gemarra-regular">food, </span>i.e., it is always considered fit for human consumption. The Gemara notes: <span class="gemarra-regular">Apparently, </span>Rav Kahana <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that honey <span class="gemarra-regular">does not require </span>that one have <span class="gemarra-regular">intentio</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> to eat it for it to be susceptible to ritual impurity.
The Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises an objection </span>from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Honey in a beehive is not </span>considered to have the status of <span class="gemarra-regular">either food or liqui</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> with regard to ritual impurity. <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said: </span>This <span class="it-text">halakha</span>, that honey is considered neither food nor liquid, <span class="gemarra-regular">is necessary only with </span>regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">those two combs </span>mentioned in the mishna, which are designated for the sustenance of the bees and are not for human consumption. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: </span>The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>in accordance with the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Eliezer. </span>

Daf 80b

<span class="gemarra-regular">As we learned </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Shevi’it</span> 10:7): Concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">a beehive, Rabbi Eliezer says: It is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">like lan</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> with regard to the manner in which one purchases it and with regard to other matters, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">one writes a document that prevents the Sabbatical Yea</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from canceling an outstanding debt [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">prosbol</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> based <span class="gemarra-regular">on it, </span>as a <span class="it-text">prosbol</span> can be written only if the debtor possesses land of some sort.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>a beehive <span class="gemarra-regular">is not susceptible to ritual impurity, </span>provided that it is <span class="gemarra-regular">in its place </span>and attached to the ground, as it is considered equivalent to the ground itself, which is not susceptible to impurity. <span class="gemarra-regular">And one who takes </span>honey <span class="gemarra-regular">out of it on Shabbat </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to bring <span class="gemarra-regular">a sin-offering, </span>like one who uproots something from the ground. According to this opinion, honey in a beehive is not considered to have the status of either food or liquid with regard to ritual impurity, as it is attached to the ground.
The mishna continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">And the Rabbis say: </span>A beehive has the status of movable property; <span class="gemarra-regular">one may not write a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">prosbol</span> based <span class="gemarra-regular">on it, and it is not </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">like land </span>with regard to its sale but is instead sold in the manner of movable property. <span class="gemarra-regular">And it is susceptible to ritual impurity </span>even when it is <span class="gemarra-regular">in its place, and one who takes </span>honey <span class="gemarra-regular">out of it on Shabbat is exemp</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> from bringing a sin-offering. According to this opinion, the honey contained within the beehive is considered detached from the ground and is therefore susceptible to ritual impurity, as stated by Rav Kahana.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar said: What is the reasoning of Rabbi Eliezer? As it is written </span>with regard to Jonathan: “He put forth the end of the rod that was in his hand, <span class="gemarra-regular">and dipped it in the honeycomb </span><span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ya’arat</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">hadevash</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]” </span>(I Samuel 14:27). <span class="gemarra-regular">Now, what does a forest </span><span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ya’ar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> have to do with honey [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">devash</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]? </span>Why is the honeycomb called a forest of honey [<span class="it-text">ya’arat</span> <span class="it-text">hadevash</span>]? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>this serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to tell you: Just as </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a forest, one who picks </span>fruit <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>a tree <span class="gemarra-regular">on Shabbat is liable </span>to bring <span class="gemarra-regular">a sin-offering, so too, </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">honey, one who removes </span>honey <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>a beehive <span class="gemarra-regular">on Shabbat is liable </span>to bring <span class="gemarra-regular">a sin-offering.</span>
The Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises an objection </span>from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Honey that flows from one’s beehive is not </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">either food or liquid. Granted, according to </span>the reasoning of <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">works out well, </span>since he would explain here, as in the previous case, that this is referring to the two combs in the beehive designated for the sustenance of the bees, and is not intended for human consumption.
<span class="gemarra-regular">But according to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava, </span>who says that the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is in accordance with the ruling of Rabbi Eliezer, this presents <span class="gemarra-regular">a difficulty, </span>as even according to Rabbi Eliezer the honey is not considered attached to the ground once it leaves the beehive. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Zevid said: </span>The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the honey <span class="gemarra-regular">flowed onto a repulsive vesse</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span> and therefore is unfit for human consumption. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Aḥa bar Yaakov said: </span>It is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where it flowed onto straw [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">kashkashin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> and weeds, which renders it inedible.
The Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises </span>another <span class="gemarra-regular">objection </span>from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Honey in one’s beehive is not </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">either food or liquid. </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">one intended to </span>use <span class="gemarra-regular">it </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">food, it </span>is susceptible to <span class="gemarra-regular">ritual impurity </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">food, </span>and if one intended <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>use it as <span class="gemarra-regular">liquid, it is susceptible to ritual impurity as liquid. Granted, according to </span>the reasoning of <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye, </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">works out well, </span>as he can explain that this too is referring to the two combs of honey left for the bees, and that if one reconsidered and decided to eat the honey, it is once again considered fit for human consumption.
<span class="gemarra-regular">But according to Rava, </span>who said that the ruling of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that honey in a beehive does not have the status of food or liquid is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Eliezer, this poses <span class="gemarra-regular">a difficulty. </span>This <span class="it-text">baraita</span> does not accord with the reasoning of Rabbi Eliezer, as he maintains that one’s intention is not enough for honey attached to the ground to be considered as though it were detached. Therefore, the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> must be in accordance with the opinion of the Rabbis, and yet it contradicts Rav Kahana’s statement that intention is not required for honey to be susceptible to ritual impurity.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava </span>could have <span class="gemarra-regular">said to you </span>that the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is in fact in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Eliezer, and you should resolve the difficulty <span class="gemarra-regular">and answer like this</span><span class="gemarra-regular">:</span> If <span class="gemarra-regular">one intended to </span>use the honey as <span class="gemarra-regular">food, it </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>susceptible to <span class="gemarra-regular">ritual impurity </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">food, </span>and if one intended <span class="gemarra-regular">to</span> use it as <span class="gemarra-regular">liquid, it is not susceptible to ritual impurity </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">liquid. </span>The Gemara notes: It <span class="gemarra-regular">is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav Kahana: Honey in one’s beehive is susceptible to ritual impurity </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">food </span>even if there was <span class="gemarra-regular">no intention </span>to use it as food, as it has an innate status of food.
§ The mishna teaches: If one buys <span class="gemarra-regular">olive </span>trees <span class="gemarra-regular">for felling</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">he must leave two shoot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> from the tree. <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught: One who buys a tree from another for felling must cut </span>the tree <span class="gemarra-regular">one handbreadth above the ground, </span>to allow the tree to grow again. In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">an untrimmed sycamore, </span>he must cut the tree a minimum of <span class="gemarra-regular">three handbreadths </span>above the ground, and with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a large sycamore, </span>which has strong roots because the sycamore has been cut down once already, he must cut the tree a minimum of <span class="gemarra-regular">two handbreadths </span>above the ground. <span class="gemarra-regular">In </span>the case <span class="gemarra-regular">of reeds or of vines, </span>he may cut only <span class="gemarra-regular">from the knot and above, </span>so that they will grow back. <span class="gemarra-regular">In </span>the cases <span class="gemarra-regular">of palm and of cedar </span>trees, <span class="gemarra-regular">he may dig down and uproot </span>them, <span class="gemarra-regular">because their trunks do not replenish </span>themselves after they are cut down, and therefore there is no reason to leave anything behind.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And do we </span><span class="gemarra-regular">require an untrimmed sycamore </span>to be cut a minimum of <span class="gemarra-regular">three handbreadths </span>above the ground for it to grow back? <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises a contradiction </span>from a mishna (<span class="it-text">Shevi’it</span> 4:5): <span class="gemarra-regular">One may not fell an untrimmed sycamore during the Sabbatical </span>Year <span class="gemarra-regular">because it is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">work</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as it promotes the growth of the tree.
The mishna continues. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda says: </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibited </span>for one to fell the tree during the Sabbatical Year <span class="gemarra-regular">in its </span>usual <span class="gemarra-regular">manner; rather, he must cut </span>the tree <span class="gemarra-regular">ten handbreadths </span>above the ground, <span class="gemarra-regular">or raze </span>the tree until it is <span class="gemarra-regular">even with the ground</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>Neither of these methods promote the growth of the tree; in fact, they damage it. It can be inferred from here that it is only cutting the sycamore until it is <span class="gemarra-regular">even with the ground that is harmful </span>for it, and it does not grow again. Cutting in <span class="gemarra-regular">another </span>manner <span class="gemarra-regular">is beneficial for it, </span>even if it is cut less than three handbreadths from the ground.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said </span>that the mishna should be understood as follows: Cutting down a sycamore from a height of <span class="gemarra-regular">three handbreadths is beneficial for it, </span>whereas cutting it so that it is <span class="gemarra-regular">even with the ground is certainly harmful for it </span>and is permitted during the Sabbatical Year. Cutting it down <span class="gemarra-regular">from this </span>point <span class="gemarra-regular">onward, </span>i.e., between the ground and three handbreadths, is <span class="gemarra-regular">neither </span>very <span class="gemarra-regular">harmful for it nor </span>particularly <span class="gemarra-regular">beneficial for it. With regard to the Sabbatical </span>Year, <span class="gemarra-regular">we perform </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">a matter that is certainly harmful to it, </span>so as to avoid enhancing it. <span class="gemarra-regular">With regard to buying and selling</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> we perform </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">a matter that is certainly beneficial for it, </span>as the seller intended to sell the sycamore in such a manner that the tree would grow again.
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> teaches: In the case <span class="gemarra-regular">of palm and cedar trees, </span>a buyer may <span class="gemarra-regular">dig down and uproot </span>them, <span class="gemarra-regular">because their trunks do not replenish </span>themselves after being cut down. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>is it correct with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a cedar </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">its trunk does not replenish </span>itself? <span class="gemarra-regular">But didn’t Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Lulyani teach: What </span>is the meaning of that <span class="gemarra-regular">which is written: “The righteous shall flourish like the palm tree; he shall grow like a cedar in Lebanon” </span>(Psalms 92:13)? <span class="gemarra-regular">If “palm tree” is stated, why is “cedar” stated? And if “cedar” is stated, why is “palm tree” stated? </span>What is added by this double comparison?
Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Lulyani explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">Had </span>the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">stated </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">“cedar” and had not stated “palm tree,” I would have said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">just as a cedar does not produce fruit, so too, a righteous person does not produce fruit</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., he will have no reward in the World-to-Come. <span class="gemarra-regular">Therefore, it is stated: “Palm tree,” </span>which is a fruit-bearing tree.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And had </span>the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">stated </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">“palm tree” and had not stated “cedar,” I would have said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">just as </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a palm tree its trunk does not replenish </span>itself after being cut down, <span class="gemarra-regular">so too, </span>in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a righteous person, his trunk does not replenish </span>itself, i.e., he will be unable to recover from misfortune. <span class="gemarra-regular">There-fore, it is stated: “Cedar,” </span>to indicate that just as the trunk of the cedar replenishes itself, so too, the righteous will thrive again. This demonstrates that the trunk of a cedar does grow again.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, with what are we are dealing here? </span>We are dealing <span class="gemarra-regular">with other types of cedars, </span>as the trunks of certain species do not grow back after the tree is felled. This is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabba bar Rav Huna. As Rabba bar Rav Huna says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">they say </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">the school of Rav: There are ten types of cedars; as it is stated: “I will place in the wilderness the cedar [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">erez</span><span class="gemarra-regular">], the acacia tree [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">shitta</span><span class="gemarra-regular">], and the myrtle [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">hadas</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] and the pine tree [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">etz</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">shemen</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]; I will set </span>in the desert the juniper [<span class="it-text">berosh</span>], the teak [<span class="it-text">tidhar</span>], and the cypress [<span class="it-text">te’ashur</span>] all together” (Isaiah 41:19). The Gemara elaborates: <span class="gemarra-italic">Erez</span> means <span class="gemarra-regular">cedar; </span><span class="gemarra-italic">shitta</span> means <span class="gemarra-regular">acacia tree [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">tornita</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">hadas</span> is the <span class="gemarra-regular">myrtle; </span><span class="gemarra-italic">etz</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">shemen</span> is the <span class="gemarra-regular">balsam tree; </span><span class="gemarra-italic">berosh</span> means <span class="gemarra-regular">juniper [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">berati</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">tidhar</span> is the <span class="gemarra-regular">teak [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">shaga</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span><span class="gemarra-italic">te’ashur</span> is the <span class="gemarra-regular">cypress [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">shurbina</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
The Gemara asks: But <span class="gemarra-regular">these are seven </span>species of cedar, not ten. <span class="gemarra-regular">When Rav Dimi came </span>from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia <span class="gemarra-regular">he said: They added to </span>the list of cedars <span class="gemarra-italic">allonim</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span><span class="gemarra-italic">almonim</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>and <span class="gemarra-italic">almugim</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span><span class="gemarra-italic">Allonim</span> refers to <span class="gemarra-regular">pistachio trees [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">butnei</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">almonim</span> are <span class="gemarra-regular">oaks [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">balutei</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and <span class="gemarra-italic">almugim</span>

Daf 81a

refers to <span class="gemarra-regular">coral trees [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">kasita</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]. There are </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">who say </span>that the other three are as follows: <span class="gemarra-italic">Aronim</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span><span class="gemarra-italic">armonim</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, and </span><span class="gemarra-italic">almugim</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span><span class="gemarra-italic">Aronim</span> refers to <span class="gemarra-regular">laurel trees [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">arei</span><span class="gemarra-regular">], </span><span class="gemarra-italic">armonim</span> to <span class="gemarra-regular">plane trees [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">dulevei</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and <span class="gemarra-italic">almugim</span> to <span class="gemarra-regular">coral trees [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">kasita</span><span class="gemarra-regular">].</span>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who buys two </span><span class="gemarra-regular">tree</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">in the field of another, this </span>one has <span class="gemarra-regular">not acquired </span>any <span class="gemarra-regular">ground, </span>but only the trees. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir says: </span>He has <span class="gemarra-regular">acquired </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">ground </span>under them. The mishna states a <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in accordance with the opinion of the first <span class="it-text">tanna</span>: If the trees <span class="gemarra-regular">grew, </span>the owner of the field <span class="gemarra-regular">may not cut down </span>their branches, despite the fact that their shade damages his field. <span class="gemarra-regular">And that which grows out of the trunk </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">his, </span>i.e., it belongs to the owner of the tree, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>that which grows <span class="gemarra-regular">out of the roots </span>belongs <span class="gemarra-regular">to the owner of the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">ground</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">And if </span>the trees <span class="gemarra-regular">died, </span>their owner <span class="gemarra-regular">has no </span>rights to the <span class="gemarra-regular">ground </span>where the trees had stood.
If one <span class="gemarra-regular">bought three </span>trees, he has <span class="gemarra-regular">acquired </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">ground </span>along with them. If <span class="gemarra-regular">they grew, </span>the owner of the field <span class="gemarra-regular">may cut down </span>their branches, as he sold a specific piece of land along with the trees, not his entire field. <span class="gemarra-regular">And that which grows out of the trunk and out of the roots </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">his, </span>i.e., it belongs to the owner of the trees. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if </span>the trees <span class="gemarra-regular">died, </span>the owner of the trees still <span class="gemarra-regular">has </span>possession of the <span class="gemarra-regular">ground</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as it was sold along with the trees.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">We learned </span>in a mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">elsewhere </span>(<span class="it-text">Bikkurim</span> 1:6): With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who buys two trees in </span>the field <span class="gemarra-regular">of another, he brings </span>the first fruits <span class="gemarra-regular">but does not recite </span>the passages of thanks to God that appear in the Torah (Deuteronomy 26:1–11), as the land does not belong to him and therefore he cannot state: “I have brought the first of the fruit of the land, which You, Lord, have given me” (Deuteronomy 26:10). <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir says: He brings </span>the first fruits <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">recites </span>the passage.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel says: Rabbi Meir would obligate even one who buys fruit from the marketplace </span>to bring first fruits, not only one who grew the fruits on his own tree. <span class="gemarra-regular">From where </span>did he derive this <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? <span class="gemarra-regular">From </span>the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>an apparently <span class="gemarra-regular">superfluous mishna</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Since </span>Rabbi Meir already <span class="gemarra-regular">taught </span>in the mishna here <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the owner of two trees <span class="gemarra-regular">has </span>possession of the <span class="gemarra-regular">ground, </span>isn’t it <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious that he brings </span>first fruits <span class="gemarra-regular">and recites </span>the passage? What is added by his statement in the mishna in <span class="it-text">Bikkurim</span>?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, learn from </span>the mishna in <span class="it-text">Bikkurim</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir would obligate even one who buys fruit from the marketplac</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> to bring first fruits to the Temple. Rabbi Meir is saying that even if the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is in accordance with the opinion of the Rabbis that one who buys two trees does not own the ground between them, he still must bring the first fruits and recite the passage of thanks.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t it written: “Which you shall bring in from your land” </span>(Deuteronomy 26:2)? This verse indicates that the fruit must be the produce of your land, not land that belongs to another. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">That </span>verse serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to exclude </span>land that is <span class="gemarra-regular">outside of Eretz </span>Yisrael, which is not the land of the Jewish people. It does not exclude land that does not belong to that specific individual.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t it written: </span>“The choicest first fruits of <span class="gemarra-regular">your lan</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> you shall bring” (Exodus 23:19)? The Gemara answers: This serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to exclude </span>fruit bought by a Jew that was grown on the <span class="gemarra-regular">land of a gentil</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> in Eretz Yisrael. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t it written: </span>“I have brought the first of the fruit of the land, <span class="gemarra-regular">which You, </span>Lord, <span class="gemarra-regular">have given me” </span>(Deuteronomy 26:10)? If he purchased the fruit, then the land on which it grew was not given to him by God. The Gemara answers that the phrase “which You have given me” can mean <span class="gemarra-regular">that You have given me money, and with that </span>money <span class="gemarra-regular">I bought </span>this fruit.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba raises an objection </span>to the opinion of Shmuel from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">One who buys one tre</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in </span>the field <span class="gemarra-regular">of another brings </span>first fruits <span class="gemarra-regular">but does not recite </span>the passage, <span class="gemarra-regular">as he did not acquire </span>any <span class="gemarra-regular">land; </span>this is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of Rabbi Meir. </span>This is <span class="gemarra-regular">a conclusive refutatio</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> of Shmuel’s opinion, as he said that according to Rabbi Meir even one who simply purchases fruit is obligated to bring first fruits to the Temple.
Apropos the discussion of the obligation to bring first fruits of one who buys a tree in the field of another, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon ben Elyakim said to Rabbi Elazar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">:</span> 

Daf 81b

<span class="gemarra-regular">What is the rationale of Rabbi Meir </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one tree, </span>an individual is obligated to bring first fruits but does not recite the passage, <span class="gemarra-regular">and what is the rationale of the Rabbis </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">two trees, </span>an individual is obligated to bring the first fruits but does not recite the passage? If one owns the ground and is obligated to bring the first fruits to the Temple, he should also recite the passage of thanks. If he does not own the ground and therefore is not obligated to recite the passage, why does he bring the first fruits to the Temple? Rabbi Elazar <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Rabbi Shimon ben Elyakim: <span class="gemarra-regular">Do you ask me </span>publicly, <span class="gemarra-regular">in the study hall, </span>about <span class="gemarra-regular">a matter for which the early </span>Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">did not give a reason, in order to embarrass me? </span>In other words, I do not know the reason, as not even the early Sages explained this matter.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba said: What is the difficulty? Perhaps Rabbi Meir is uncertain, in </span>the case of an individual who purchases <span class="gemarra-regular">one tree, </span>whether or not the buyer owns the ground, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the Rabbis are uncertain</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in </span>the case of an individual who purchases <span class="gemarra-regular">two trees</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> whether or not the buyer owns the ground. Due to this uncertainty, the owner of the tree must bring the first fruits to the Temple, as he might be obligated in this mitzva. He does not recite the passage of thanks because it is not definitely established that he is obligated to bring the fruits.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And is </span>Rabbi Meir really <span class="gemarra-regular">uncertain </span>whether the buyer owns the ground? <span class="gemarra-regular">But it teaches: Since he did not acquire </span>any <span class="gemarra-regular">land; </span>this is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of Rabbi Meir. </span>Rabbi Meir states definitively that the owner of the tree does not own the ground. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Say </span>that the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> should be emended as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">Perhaps he did not acquire </span>any <span class="gemarra-regular">land.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But let us be concerned that perhaps </span>these fruits <span class="gemarra-regular">are not first fruits, and he is bringing non-sacred </span>fruit <span class="gemarra-regular">to the </span>Temple <span class="gemarra-regular">courtyard, </span>which is prohibited. The Gemara answers: The case is <span class="gemarra-regular">where he consecrates them</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>the priest <span class="gemarra-regular">is required to eat </span>first fruits, and he cannot do so if they are consecrated. The Gemara answers: The case is <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the priest <span class="gemarra-regular">redeems them</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But perhaps they are not first fruits, and </span>thereby <span class="gemarra-regular">he removes them from </span>the obligation of <span class="gemarra-italic">terum</span><span class="gemarra-italic">a</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and tithes, </span>as one does not separate <span class="it-text">teruma</span> and tithes from first fruits. The Gemara answers: The case is <span class="gemarra-regular">where he separates </span><span class="it-text">teruma</span> and tithes from the fruits, due to the uncertainty over their status.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, </span>the <span class="gemarra-italic">teruma</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">gedola</span> that he separates from these fruits <span class="gemarra-regular">he gives to a priest</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and the priest may partake of it, as it has the halakhic status of either first fruits or <span class="it-text">teruma</span> <span class="it-text">gedola</span>, both of which are eaten by a priest. It is understood with regard to the <span class="gemarra-regular">second tith</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as well; he gives it to a priest, </span>who eats it in Jerusalem, either as first fruits or as second tithe. If it is the third or the sixth year of the Sabbatical cycle, when instead of second tithe one is obligated to give the <span class="gemarra-regular">poor man’s tithe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> here <span class="gemarra-regular">too, he gives it to a poor priest, </span>who eats it as either first fruits or poor man’s tithe. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">first tithe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> which is </span>given to <span class="gemarra-regular">a Levite, to whom can he give it? </span>A Levite may not eat first fruits.
The Gemara answers: The case is <span class="gemarra-regular">where he gives it to a priest, in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya. As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-italic">Teruma</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">gedola</span> is given only <span class="gemarra-regular">to a priest, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">first tithe </span>is given only <span class="gemarra-regular">to a Levite; </span>this is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of Rabbi Akiva. Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya says: First tithe </span>may <span class="gemarra-regular">also </span>be given <span class="gemarra-regular">to a priest</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But perhaps they are </span>in fact <span class="gemarra-regular">first fruits and require recitatio</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> of the passage of thanks, and yet the owner does not recite it due to the uncertainty. The Gemara answers: The <span class="gemarra-regular">recitation </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">not indispensable, </span>i.e., one can perform the mitzva of bringing first fruits without the recitation.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>is the recitation <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>indispensable? <span class="gemarra-regular">But doesn’t Rabbi Zeira say </span>in the context of offerings: For <span class="gemarra-regular">any </span>measure of flour <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">suitable for mixin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span> with oil in a meal-offering, the lack of <span class="gemarra-regular">mixing does not invalidate</span> the meal-offering.
