Even though there is a mitzva to mix the oil and the flour <span class="it-text">ab</span> <span class="it-text">initio</span>, the meal-offering is fit for sacrifice even if the oil and the flour are not mixed. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">any </span>measure of flour <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">not suitable for mixing </span>with oil in a meal-offering, the lack of <span class="gemarra-regular">mixing</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> invalidates </span>the meal-offering. The principle is: <span class="it-text">Ab</span> <span class="it-text">initio</span> requirements prevent the fulfillment of a mitzva in situations where they are not merely absent but impossible. Accordingly, first fruits that are unfit for recitation should not be brought to the Temple.
The Gemara answers: The case is <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span><span class="gemarra-regular">he renders them </span>exempt from the obligation of recitation, <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei bar Ḥanina, who says: </span>If one <span class="gemarra-regular">harvested </span>the fruits <span class="gemarra-regular">and sent the</span><span class="gemarra-regular">m</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in the possession of an agent, and </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">agent died on the way</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the owner or any other person <span class="gemarra-regular">brings </span>the first fruits <span class="gemarra-regular">but does not recite </span>the passage of thanks. <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason? As it is written: And you shall take, and you shall bring. </span>The Gemara is citing from the following verse with a slight variation: “And you shall take of the first of all the fruit of the ground, which you shall bring in from your land that the Lord your God gives you” (Deuteronomy 26:2). 

Daf 82a

The passage is not recited <span class="gemarra-regular">until the taking and the bringing </span>of the first fruits are performed <span class="gemarra-regular">by one </span>person, <span class="gemarra-regular">and that is not</span> the case here. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Aḥa, son of Rav Avya, said to Rav Ashi: Since </span>the passage <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>composed of <span class="gemarra-regular">verses</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> let him read them. </span>What is objectionable about reciting verses from the Torah?
Rav Ashi <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>The problem is <span class="gemarra-regular">due to </span>the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>this practice <span class="gemarra-regular">has the appearance of falsehood</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> because he issues a declaration before God that is possibly untrue, as he might not own the ground. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Mesharshiyya, son of Rav Ḥiyya, said: </span>The declaration is not recited <span class="gemarra-regular">lest he come to remove </span>the fruits <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>their obligation of <span class="gemarra-italic">teruma</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and tithes, </span>if they are treated entirely as first fruits. For this reason one does not recite the passage, to ensure that their unique status is maintained.
§ The mishna teaches: With regard to one who buys two trees in the field of another, if the trees <span class="gemarra-regular">grew, </span>the owner of the field <span class="gemarra-regular">may not cut down </span>their branches. The mishna further teaches: That which grows out of the trunk belongs to the owner of the tree, but that which grows out of the roots belongs to the owner of the ground. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What are the circumstances </span>in which something is considered to be growing <span class="gemarra-regular">out of the trunk, and what are the circumstances </span>in which it is considered to be growing <span class="gemarra-regular">out of the roots?</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan said: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">anything that sees the face of the sun</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., which is visible and aboveground, <span class="gemarra-regular">this is </span>considered to be growing <span class="gemarra-regular">out of the trunk. And </span>with regard to that <span class="gemarra-regular">which does not see the face of the sun </span>but is concealed in the earth, <span class="gemarra-regular">this is</span> considered to be growing <span class="gemarra-regular">out of the roots.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if everything that is visible belongs to the owner of the tree, no matter how close it is to the ground, <span class="gemarra-regular">let us be concerned </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">perhaps the land is covered with sediment </span>from flowing water, and some of the tree’s trunk will be covered, in which case the branches that grow from the trunk will appear as though they are separate trees; <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the owner of the trees will <span class="gemarra-regular">say to </span>the owner of the field: <span class="gemarra-regular">You </span>actually <span class="gemarra-regular">sold me three </span>trees <span class="gemarra-regular">and I </span>therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">have </span>ownership over the <span class="gemarra-regular">ground. Rather, Rav Naḥman said: </span>That which grows from the trunk belongs to the owner of the tree, but <span class="gemarra-regular">he must cut </span>it down. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Yoḥanan </span>himself <span class="gemarra-regular">likewise said: </span>The owner of the tree <span class="gemarra-regular">must cut </span>it down.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman said: We hold </span>by tradition that <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">palm tre</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> bought from another <span class="gemarra-regular">has no trunk. Rav Zevid thought to say </span>this means that <span class="gemarra-regular">the owner of the palm tree has no </span>right to that which grows from the <span class="gemarra-regular">trunk</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> The reason is <span class="gemarra-regular">that since it stands </span>ready <span class="gemarra-regular">to be dug up and uprooted, </span>as when the tree dies its owner is not entitled to plant another in its place, <span class="gemarra-regular">he diverts his mind </span>from that which grows from the trunk.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa objects to this: But </span>this is comparable to one who <span class="gemarra-regular">buys two tree</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> in a field belonging to another, <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>the trees <span class="gemarra-regular">stand </span>ready <span class="gemarra-regular">to be dug up and uprooted </span>because their owner has no right to plant new trees in their place when they die; <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>yet it <span class="gemarra-regular">is taught </span>in the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">that he has </span>the right to that which grows from the <span class="gemarra-regular">trunk. Rather, Rav Pappa said: </span>The statement of Rav Naḥman means that <span class="gemarra-regular">the owner of a palm tree, </span>in contrast to owners of other types of trees, <span class="gemarra-regular">has no </span>right to that which grows from the <span class="gemarra-regular">trunk, since </span>a palm tree <span class="gemarra-regular">does not produce </span>branches from its <span class="gemarra-regular">trunk</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But according to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Zevid, </span>who maintains that Rav Naḥman is referring to all types of trees, <span class="gemarra-regular">the mishna </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">difficult. </span>The Gemara answers: Rav Zevid interprets the mishna as referring to a situation <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the owner of the trees <span class="gemarra-regular">bought </span>the trees <span class="gemarra-regular">for five year</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> and stipulated that he may plant new trees in place of the original trees in the event the original ones are cut down.
§ The mishna teaches: If <span class="gemarra-regular">one bought three </span>trees <span class="gemarra-regular">he has acquired </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">ground </span>along with them. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And how much </span>of the field does he acquire? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: This </span>buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">has acquire</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> the ground that is located <span class="gemarra-regular">underneath </span>the trees, <span class="gemarra-regular">and</span> the area <span class="gemarra-regular">between them, and </span>with regard to the space <span class="gemarra-regular">outside of </span>the trees and their branches,

Daf 82b

he has acquired an area <span class="gemarra-regular">sufficient for a gatherer of figs and his basket </span>in hand to stand close to the tree. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar objects to this: Now </span>that the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is that the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">has no pat</span><span class="gemarra-regular">h</span> and must purchase a path through the field to access his trees; if so, does <span class="gemarra-regular">he have </span>possession of an area for <span class="gemarra-regular">the gatherer and his basket? </span>The Gemara elaborates: <span class="gemarra-regular">He has no </span><span class="gemarra-regular">path, </span>even though he has no other means of gaining access to the trees, <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>the ground he acquired along with the trees <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">another land </span>and is not part of the rest of the field. Why, then, would <span class="gemarra-regular">he have </span>possession of an area for <span class="gemarra-regular">a gatherer and his basket?</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Zeira says: From the statement, </span>i.e., the objection, <span class="gemarra-regular">of our teacher</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> we learn </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">it is </span>in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">three </span>trees <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the owner of the trees <span class="gemarra-regular">has no path, </span>as the buyer acquired a separate piece of land along with the trees. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>trees the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">has </span>a path, <span class="gemarra-regular">as he says to </span>the owner of the field: My trees <span class="gemarra-regular">are standing on your land, </span>and as I am allowed to use your field to tend to my trees I have the right to walk through your land to reach them.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said to Rava: Shall we say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar does not </span>accept the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Shmuel, </span>who was <span class="gemarra-regular">his teacher? As Shmuel says: </span>The <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Akiva, who says: One who sells, sells generously. </span>According to Rabbi Akiva, one sells in a manner that is advantageous for the buyer, and is presumed to have included in the sale even items that were not explicitly specified. In this case, as he has sold a tree that remains on his property, the seller grants the buyer the right to access his tree.
Rava <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>Even if Rabbi Elazar himself agrees with Rabbi Akiva, <span class="gemarra-regular">the mishna cannot be explained in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Akiva. </span>Rather, the mishna must be in accordance with the opinion of the Rabbis, who hold that one who sells does so sparingly, and the difficulty that Rabbi Elazar raised against Rabbi Yoḥanan is predicated on the fact that the mishna is in accordance with the opinion of the Rabbis.
<span class="gemarra-regular">From where </span>does Rava derive that the mishna is not in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Akiva? <span class="gemarra-regular">From </span>the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches: </span>If the three trees <span class="gemarra-regular">grew, </span>the owner of the land <span class="gemarra-regular">may cut down </span>the branches that extend into his field. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if it enters your mind </span>that the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Akiva, why may he cut </span>them <span class="gemarra-regular">down? Doesn’t </span>Rabbi Akiva <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">one who sells, sells generously?</span>
Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>This does not prove that the mishna is not in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Akiva. You can <span class="gemarra-regular">say that Rabbi Akiva stated </span>his ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">in the case</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of a pit and a cistern </span>that are situated in a field belonging to another, which one sells in a generous manner, <span class="gemarra-regular">as they do not weaken the land. </span>But <span class="gemarra-regular">did you hear him </span>say that the seller is generous toward the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to a tree</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> which can weaken the land?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Doesn’t Rabbi Akiva concede in </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a tree that leans out into the field of another, </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">which </span>the owner of the other field <span class="gemarra-regular">cuts down </span>the branches until the <span class="gemarra-regular">full </span>height of <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox-goad, </span>the handle that protrudes <span class="gemarra-regular">over a plow? </span>Since the extending branches impede his efforts to plow his field, it is permitted for him to cut them down. This indicates that even according to Rabbi Akiva one does not grant privileges that are detrimental to his own interests. If so, the mishna can be explained even in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Akiva, which indicates that Rabbi Elazar does not accept his ruling.
The Gemara points out: <span class="gemarra-regular">It is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba: </span>If one buys three trees in a field belonging to another, <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">has acquired </span>the ground that is found <span class="gemarra-regular">underneath </span>the trees, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the area <span class="gemarra-regular">between them, and outside of </span>the trees and their branches <span class="gemarra-regular">an area </span>sufficient for <span class="gemarra-regular">a gatherer of figs and his basket.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said to Rav Yosef: Those </span>areas around the trees that are designated for <span class="gemarra-regular">a gatherer of figs</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and his basket </span>are used for this purpose only at specific times. <span class="gemarra-regular">Who sows </span>that land during the rest of the year, the owner of the trees or the owner of the field? Rav Yosef <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: You learned </span>the answer in a mishna (99b): If one owns a garden that is surrounded by the garden of another, the owner of the inner garden has a right to a path through the outer garden. Even so, the owner of <span class="gemarra-regular">the outer </span>garden <span class="gemarra-regular">may sow the path.</span>
Abaye <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Are </span>the cases <span class="gemarra-regular">comparable? There, </span>in the case of the outer and inner gardens, <span class="gemarra-regular">there is no loss </span>suffered <span class="gemarra-regular">by the buyer </span>when the owner of the outer garden sows the path, as he can still pass through it. <span class="gemarra-regular">But here, there is a loss for the buyer, as </span>the one who bought the trees <span class="gemarra-regular">says to </span>the owner of the field: The <span class="gemarra-regular">fruits </span>that fall from the trees will become <span class="gemarra-regular">soile</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> by the plants.
<span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>case is <span class="gemarra-regular">similar only to the last clause </span>of that mishna, which states: If the owner of the inner garden is given a side path, so that he suffers a loss of some kind because he cannot take the shortest path to reach his garden, both <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>owner of the inner garden <span class="gemarra-regular">and that </span>owner of the outer garden <span class="gemarra-regular">are not permitte</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to sow </span>the path. Similarly, here too, neither the owner of the trees nor the owner of the field are permitted to sow the place designated for the gatherer of figs and his basket.
The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">It is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Abaye: This </span>buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">has acquired </span>the ground that is found <span class="gemarra-regular">underneath </span>the trees, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the area <span class="gemarra-regular">between them, and outside of </span>the trees and their branches <span class="gemarra-regular">an area </span>sufficient for <span class="gemarra-regular">a gatherer of figs and his basket. </span><span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>both <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>owner of the field <span class="gemarra-regular">and that </span>owner of the trees <span class="gemarra-regular">are not permitted to sow it.</span>
The Gemara inquires: <span class="gemarra-regular">And how much </span>space <span class="gemarra-regular">must there be betwee</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> the three trees for them to be considered one unit, which means that the land is acquired by the owner of the trees? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef </span>says that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel says: </span>The distance between the trees must be <span class="gemarra-regular">from four cubits to eight </span>cubits. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava </span>says that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel says: </span>It must be <span class="gemarra-regular">from eight </span>cubits <span class="gemarra-regular">to sixteen </span>cubits. <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said to Rav Yosef: Do not disagree with Rav Naḥman, as we learned </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">a mishna in accordance with his </span>opinion.
<span class="gemarra-regular">As we learned </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Kilayim</span> 4:9): <span class="gemarra-regular">One who plants his vineyard sixteen cubit</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> by sixteen cubits, </span>i.e., he leaves sixteen cubits between each row of vines, is <span class="gemarra-regular">permitted to bring </span>other species of <span class="gemarra-regular">seeds </span>to the empty spaces between the rows and sow them <span class="gemarra-regular">there. </span>This is not considered a violation of the biblical prohibition with regard to sowing diverse crops in a vineyard, which is one of the prohibitions of diverse kinds.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda said: There was an incident in </span>the city of <span class="gemarra-regular">Tzalmon, where one </span>individual <span class="gemarra-regular">planted his vineyard sixteen by sixteen cubits. And he would tur</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the branche</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">two rows </span>that were facing each other <span class="gemarra-regular">to one side, </span>so that there was a space of sixteen cubits between the two rows, <span class="gemarra-regular">and sow the clearing. The following year he would turn the branches to the place </span>that was <span class="gemarra-regular">sown </span>the year before, <span class="gemarra-regular">and would sow </span>the land that had been left <span class="gemarra-regular">uncultivated </span>the previous year, as it had been filled with the branches from the vines. <span class="gemarra-regular">And the incident came before the Sages and they permitted it. </span>This demonstrates that sixteen cubits between plants is required for them to be considered separate units.
Rav Yosef <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: I do not know </span>about this, <span class="gemarra-regular">but there was </span>a similar <span class="gemarra-regular">incident</span>

Daf 83a

involving the sale of trees <span class="gemarra-regular">in a village of shepherds</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and they came before Rav Yehuda, and he said to </span>the seller: <span class="gemarra-regular">Go </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">give to </span>the one who bought the trees <span class="gemarra-regular">sufficient </span>land <span class="gemarra-regular">for an ox and its vessels. But I did not know how much </span>was <span class="gemarra-regular">sufficient </span>land <span class="gemarra-regular">for an ox and its vessels. When I heard that which we learned </span>in a mishna (26a), I came to a conclusion with regard to this case. The mishna teaches as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">A person may not plan</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a tree close by the field of another, unless he places it at a distance </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">four cubits from </span>the other field.
Rav Yosef continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">And it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>this mishna: The <span class="gemarra-regular">four cubits that </span>the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">stated </span>are <span class="gemarra-regular">for the work of the vineyard, </span>so that he does not take oxen and a plow into his neighbor’s field while tending to his vineyard. <span class="gemarra-regular">I </span>studied this mishna and <span class="it-text">baraita</span> and <span class="gemarra-regular">said: Learn from it </span>that the phrase: <span class="gemarra-regular">Sufficient for the ox and its vessels, </span>means <span class="gemarra-regular">four cubits. </span>At this stage, the Gemara has demonstrated that Rav Naḥman’s opinion is supported by a mishna, whereas Rav Yosef’s ruling is supported by the incident involving Rav Yehuda.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But didn’t we </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">learn </span>a ruling in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Kilayim</span> 4:9) <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef? </span>That mishna teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir and Rabbi Shimon say: </span>In a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who plants his vineyard eight cubits by eight </span>cubits, i.e., he leaves eight cubits between each row of vines, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">permitted </span>for him <span class="gemarra-regular">to bring seeds to </span>the empty spaces between the rows. This ruling can be cited in support of the opinion of Rav Yosef that if there is a space of eight cubits between trees or vines they are not considered one unit. Why, then, is this mishna not brought as proof?
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Even so, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">preferable </span>to cite the <span class="gemarra-regular">incident </span>in Tzalmon as proof. Whenever possible, it is preferable to provide support for an opinion by means of a practical ruling, as it demonstrates that the Sages took action in accordance with that opinion and did not merely teach it as <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in theory.
The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, according to </span>the analysis of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef </span>stated <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon, we hear </span>about the maximum distance that the trees can be <span class="gemarra-regular">scattered, and we hear </span>about the minimum distance that they can be planted <span class="gemarra-regular">close together. </span>The distance that the trees can be <span class="gemarra-regular">scattered </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">that which we said, </span>i.e., eight cubits. The minimum distance that they can be planted <span class="gemarra-regular">close together </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">as we learned </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Kilayim</span> 5:2): <span class="gemarra-regular">A vineyard that is planted </span>in consecutive rows <span class="gemarra-regular">with less than four cubits </span>between the rows <span class="gemarra-regular">is not </span>classified as <span class="gemarra-regular">a vineyard, </span>because the rows are planted too close together. This is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of Rabbi Shimon. And the Rabbis say: </span>It is considered <span class="gemarra-regular">a vineyard, and one views the middle </span>vines <span class="gemarra-regular">as if they are not </span>there, as they are slated to be uprooted.
<span class="gemarra-regular">But according to </span>the analysis of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman </span>stated <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of the Rabbis, we hear </span>the maximum distance that the trees can be <span class="gemarra-regular">scattered,</span> i.e., sixteen cubits, as in the incident in Tzalmon. Concerning the minimum distance that they can be planted <span class="gemarra-regular">close together, did we hear </span>this distance? The Gemara answers: This <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>based on <span class="gemarra-regular">logical reasoning; from </span>the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that according to Rabbi Shimon </span>the minimum distance is <span class="gemarra-regular">half </span>of the maximum distance, according <span class="gemarra-regular">to the Rabbis as well, </span>the minimum distance is <span class="gemarra-regular">half </span>of the maximum, i.e., eight cubits.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava says: The </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is that one who buys three trees acquires the land if the distance between the trees is anywhere <span class="gemarra-regular">from four cubits to sixtee</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> cubits. This ruling is a combination of the two opinions, which is favorable to the buyer. <span class="gemarra-regular">It is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rava: How close </span>may <span class="gemarra-regular">they be? Four cubits. And how far apart </span>may <span class="gemarra-regular">they be? Sixteen </span>cubits.
If one bought three trees planted in this manner, <span class="gemarra-regular">this one has acquired </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">land and the </span>small <span class="gemarra-regular">tree</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that </span>are <span class="gemarra-regular">between them. Therefore, </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">the tree dried up or was cut down he has </span>ownership of the <span class="gemarra-regular">land. </span>If the distance between the trees was <span class="gemarra-regular">les</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> than this or more than this, or if he bought </span>the trees <span class="gemarra-regular">one after the other, this </span>buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">has not acquired either the land or the trees that </span>are <span class="gemarra-regular">between them. Therefore, </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">the tree dried up or was cut down he has no </span>ownership over the <span class="gemarra-regular">land.</span>
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yirmeya raises a dilemma: When one measures </span>the distance between the trees, <span class="gemarra-regular">does he measure from the narrow plac</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> on the trunk of the tree <span class="gemarra-regular">or does he measure from the wide place</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rav Geviha of Bei Khatil said to Rav Ashi: Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a proof, <span class="gemarra-regular">as we learned </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Kilayim</span> 7:1): When one comes to measure from <span class="gemarra-regular">the layered branc</span><span class="gemarra-regular">h</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of the vin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he measures only from the second root, </span>as this is the average, not the widest part of the vine.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yirmeya raises a dilemma: </span>If the owner of the field <span class="gemarra-regular">sold to </span>someone <span class="gemarra-regular">three branches </span>that grew from one <span class="gemarra-regular">tree</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and its trunk was covered with earth so that the branches appeared to be three separate trees, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? Are they considered three trees, which would mean that their owner acquires the ground between them?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Geviha of Bei Khatil said to Rav Ashi: Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a proof, <span class="gemarra-regular">as we learned </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Kilayim</span> 7:2): With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who layers </span>the branches of <span class="gemarra-regular">three vine</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> into the ground so that they take root while still attached to the base of the vine, <span class="gemarra-regular">and their roots </span>that rise above the ground <span class="gemarra-regular">are visible</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Tzadok, says: If there is </span>a distance <span class="gemarra-regular">between them of four cubits to eight </span>cubits, <span class="gemarra-regular">they combine </span>to form one vineyard composed of six grapevines. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if not, they do not combine. </span>It can be inferred from this mishna that the different branches of a tree are considered separate entities when the trunk is covered by earth, provided the required distance between them is maintained.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa raises a dilemma: </span>If the owner of a field <span class="gemarra-regular">sold to </span>someone <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>trees <span class="gemarra-regular">in his fiel</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and one </span>situated <span class="gemarra-regular">on </span>its <span class="gemarra-regular">border</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? Similarly, if one bought <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>trees <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the field <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span>one person <span class="gemarra-regular">and one in </span>the field <span class="gemarra-regular">of another, what </span>is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? Do the trees combine to form one unit of three trees, or not? The Gemara states that this dilemma <span class="gemarra-regular">shall stand </span>unresolved. 

Daf 83b

<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi raises a dilemma: </span>In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a pi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> situated between the trees, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to the possibility <span class="gemarra-regular">that it divides </span>between the trees, and therefore the owner of the trees does not acquire the ground? Similarly, in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a stream of water, what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to the possibility <span class="gemarra-regular">that it divides </span>between the trees? With regard to the <span class="gemarra-regular">public thoroughfar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> that divides between trees, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? Finally, in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a line of palm trees</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? No answer is found for these problems, and the Gemara states that the dilemmas <span class="gemarra-regular">shall stand </span>unresolved.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Hille</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> raises a dilemma before Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi: If <span class="gemarra-regular">a cedar grew between </span>the three trees that one bought, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? The Gemara asks: If it <span class="gemarra-regular">grew, </span>then it <span class="gemarra-regular">emerged in his domain, </span>as he already owns the ground, and therefore it is obvious that the cedar belongs to him. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>the dilemma is as follows: If, when one bought three trees, <span class="gemarra-regular">there </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">was a cedar between them</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? Is it considered a division between the three trees? Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>Since he bought the trees, <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span>has thereby <span class="gemarra-regular">acquired </span>the cedar <span class="gemarra-regular">and acquired </span>the land between them.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">In what manner </span>must the three trees be <span class="gemarra-regular">positioned </span>for the buyer to acquire the ground between them? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: </span>They may be planted <span class="gemarra-regular">in a straight line, and Shmuel says: </span>They must be planted <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the form of <span class="gemarra-regular">a tripod</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> The Gemara notes: According to <span class="gemarra-regular">the one who says </span>that the trees may be positioned <span class="gemarra-regular">in a straight line, all the more so </span>one acquires the ground when the trees are planted <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the form <span class="gemarra-regular">a tripod. But </span>according to <span class="gemarra-regular">the one who says </span>they must be positioned <span class="gemarra-regular">in a tripod, </span>the buyer acquires the ground only in this case; <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>if the trees were planted <span class="gemarra-regular">in a straight line, </span>he does <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>acquire the ground. <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason? </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>when the trees are planted in the form of a straight line <span class="gemarra-regular">one can sow between them, </span>and therefore the seller would not relinquish his right to the ground between the trees.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Hamnuna objects to this: And according to the one who says </span>that the trees must be planted <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the form of <span class="gemarra-regular">a tripod, what is the reason </span>that one who buys the trees acquires the ground? Is it <span class="gemarra-regular">that one cannot sow between </span>the trees? <span class="gemarra-regular">But if that is so, </span>in a case where <span class="gemarra-regular">he sold him three Roman thorny shrubs</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> where one cannot sow between them, so too </span>would he say <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the purchaser <span class="gemarra-regular">has </span>ownership of the <span class="gemarra-regular">ground? </span>The other Sage <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Rav Hamnuna: <span class="gemarra-regular">Those </span>Roman shrubs <span class="gemarra-regular">are not significant, </span>as they are merely shrubs and not trees, and therefore the ground is not acquired when one purchases them. By contrast, <span class="gemarra-regular">these </span>trees <span class="gemarra-regular">are important.</span>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">One who sells the head </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">a large domesticated </span><span class="gemarra-regular">anima</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">has not sold </span>along with it <span class="gemarra-regular">the forelegs, </span>as each part is considered important in its own right. All the more so, if one <span class="gemarra-regular">sold the forelegs he has not sold the head. </span>Similarly, if one <span class="gemarra-regular">sold the windpipe </span>and the lungs <span class="gemarra-regular">he has not sold the liver, </span>despite the fact that they are sometimes attached, and if he <span class="gemarra-regular">sold the liver he has not sold the windpipe </span>and lungs. <span class="gemarra-regular">But in </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">small </span>domesticated animals, if one <span class="gemarra-regular">sold the head he has sold the forelegs, </span>although if one <span class="gemarra-regular">sold the legs he has not sold the head. </span>Likewise, if one <span class="gemarra-regular">sold the windpipe </span>and lungs <span class="gemarra-regular">he has sold the liver, </span>but if he <span class="gemarra-regular">sold the liver he has not sold the windpipe </span>and lungs.
There are <span class="gemarra-regular">four </span>basic <span class="gemarra-regular">cases with regard to seller</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> and buyers. If the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">sold him wheat </span>and said that the wheat was <span class="gemarra-regular">good, and it is found </span>to be <span class="gemarra-regular">bad</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the buyer, </span>but not the seller, <span class="gemarra-regular">can renege on </span>the sale. If the seller sold him what he thought was <span class="gemarra-regular">bad </span>wheat <span class="gemarra-regular">and it is found </span>to be <span class="gemarra-regular">good</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the seller can renege on </span>the sale but the buyer cannot. If he sold <span class="gemarra-regular">bad </span>wheat <span class="gemarra-regular">and it is found </span>to be <span class="gemarra-regular">bad, </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">good </span>wheat <span class="gemarra-regular">and it is found </span>to be <span class="gemarra-regular">good, neither one of them can renege on </span>the sale, as the condition of the sale was met.
If the seller sold <span class="gemarra-regular">reddish-brow</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> wheat <span class="gemarra-regular">and it is found </span>to be <span class="gemarra-regular">white, </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">white </span>wheat <span class="gemarra-regular">and it is found </span>to be <span class="gemarra-regular">reddish-brown, </span>and similarly, if he sold <span class="gemarra-regular">olive wood and it is found </span>to be wood <span class="gemarra-regular">of a sycamore, </span>or he sold wood <span class="gemarra-regular">of a sycamore and it is found </span>to be wood <span class="gemarra-regular">of an olive </span>tree, or if the seller sold him <span class="gemarra-regular">wine and it is found </span>to be <span class="gemarra-regular">vinegar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> or <span class="gemarra-regular">vinegar and it is found </span>to be <span class="gemarra-regular">wine, </span>in all of these cases <span class="gemarra-regular">both </span>the seller and the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">can renege on </span>the sale. Since the sale was for a different item than that which was delivered, the transaction can be nullified even if there was no mistake with regard to the price.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥisda says: </span>If the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">sold him </span>an item that was <span class="gemarra-regular">worth five </span>dinars <span class="gemarra-regular">for six </span>dinars, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the item <span class="gemarra-regular">became more expensive and </span>its value <span class="gemarra-regular">stood at eight</span> dinars, and the seller wished to return the money and cancel the sale because the item’s value had increased, <span class="gemarra-regular">who was exploited </span>here? <span class="gemarra-regular">The buyer; </span>therefore, <span class="gemarra-regular">the buyer, but not the seller, can renege on </span>the sale, despite the fact that in such a situation the seller loses out. This is <span class="gemarra-regular">because</span>

Daf 84a

the buyer can <span class="gemarra-regular">say to </span>the seller: <span class="gemarra-regular">If you had not exploited me</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> you would not be able to renege on </span>the sale, and I would receive the profit. <span class="gemarra-regular">Now that you have exploited me, can you renege on </span>the sale and benefit? <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>similarly, <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span> of the mishna also <span class="gemarra-regular">taught</span><span class="gemarra-regular">:</span> If the seller sold him wheat while claiming that the wheat was <span class="gemarra-regular">good, and it is found </span>to be <span class="gemarra-regular">bad, the buyer can renege on </span>the sale. This implies that the buyer can renege <span class="gemarra-regular">but not the seller, </span>even in a situation where the seller would want to renege on the sale, e.g., if the item became more expensive.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>similarly, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥisda says: </span>If he <span class="gemarra-regular">sold him </span>an item that was <span class="gemarra-regular">worth six </span>dinars <span class="gemarra-regular">for five </span>dinars, <span class="gemarra-regular">and its price was reduced and </span>its value now <span class="gemarra-regular">stood at three </span>dinars, <span class="gemarra-regular">who was exploited </span>in this case? <span class="gemarra-regular">The seller; </span>therefore, <span class="gemarra-regular">the seller, but not the buyer, can renege on </span>the sale. The reason is <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">can say to him: If you had not exploited me, you would not be able to renege on </span>the sale. <span class="gemarra-regular">Now </span>that you have exploited me, <span class="gemarra-regular">can you renege on </span>the sale? <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>similarly, <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span> of the mishna also <span class="gemarra-regular">taught: </span>If the seller sold him <span class="gemarra-regular">bad </span>wheat <span class="gemarra-regular">and it is found </span>to be <span class="gemarra-regular">good, the seller can renege on </span>the sale, <span class="gemarra-regular">but not the buyer.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is </span>Rav Ḥisda <span class="gemarra-regular">teaching us</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> It is </span>all already taught in <span class="gemarra-regular">the mishna. </span>The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> were derived <span class="gemarra-regular">from the mishna </span>alone, <span class="gemarra-regular">I would say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">perhaps </span>in the cases brought <span class="gemarra-regular">by Rav Ḥisda</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> both </span>the buyer and the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">are able to renege on </span>the sale. The reason is that this is a case of exploitation, as the item was sold for more than its value, and therefore as long the buyer can renege on the sale, the sale is not complete. Consequently, as the seller lost out as well, he can also renege on the sale. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>as for <span class="gemarra-regular">the mishna, </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">comes to teach us that </span>if the seller said that he is selling good wheat and it is found to be bad, <span class="gemarra-regular">the buyer can renege on </span>the sale, as this is considered a case of exploitation.
It is necessary to teach this, <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>it might <span class="gemarra-regular">enter your mind to say </span>that this is not a case of exploitation <span class="gemarra-regular">because it is written: “It is bad, it is bad, says the buyer;</span> but when he is gone his way, then he boasts” (Proverbs 20:14). In other words, it is the usual manner of sellers to praise their merchandise, while buyers disparage it. Therefore, the mishna teaches that the buyer can renege on the sale if the item was found to be bad, and the seller can change his mind if it was found to be good.
§ The mishna teaches that if the seller said that he was selling <span class="gemarra-regular">reddish-brown [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">sheḥamtit</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] </span>wheat <span class="gemarra-regular">and it is found </span>to be <span class="gemarra-regular">white, </span>both the seller and the buyer can renege on the sale. The Gemara assumes that <span class="it-text">sheḥamtit</span> means the color of the sun [<span class="it-text">ḥama</span>]. Therefore, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa said: From </span>the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches: White</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> in contrast to <span class="it-text">sheḥamtit</span>, and there are two types of wheat, one white and the other red, <span class="gemarra-regular">conclude from </span>the mishna that <span class="gemarra-regular">this sun is red</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> not white. <span class="gemarra-regular">Know </span>that this is the case, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it reddens in </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">morning and evening. And </span>the reason <span class="gemarra-regular">that we do not see </span>the red color <span class="gemarra-regular">all day </span>is because <span class="gemarra-regular">our eyesight is not strong </span>and we cannot discern the redness of the sun.
The Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises an objection </span>to this claim: With regard to a verse that speaks of leprosy: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And, behold, if its appearance is deeper than the skin” </span>(Leviticus 13:30), the Sages explain: This means that it is <span class="gemarra-regular">like the appearance of the sun, </span>which is <span class="gemarra-regular">deeper than the shadow</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> But there, </span>leprosy <span class="gemarra-regular">is white </span>and yet it is likened to the sun. The Gemara answers: There, it means that it <span class="gemarra-regular">has an appearance like the sun </span>in certain respects, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">not like the appearance of the sun </span>in all respects. It is <span class="gemarra-regular">like the appearance of the sun </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">deeper than the shadow, and </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>entirely <span class="gemarra-regular">like the appearance of the sun, as there </span>the leprous spot is <span class="gemarra-regular">white, and here </span>the sun is <span class="gemarra-regular">red.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And according to that which entered our mind initially, </span>that the sun is white, doesn’t <span class="gemarra-regular">it redden in </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">morning and evening? </span>The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">In the morning </span>it becomes red <span class="gemarra-regular">as it passes over the site of </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">roses of the Garden of Eden, </span>whose reflections give the light a red hue. <span class="gemarra-regular">In the evening </span>the sun turns red <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">passes over the entrance of Gehenna, </span>whose fires redden the light. <span class="gemarra-regular">And there are </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">who say the opposite </span>in explaining why the sun is red in the morning and the evening, i.e., in the morning it passes over the entrance of Gehenna, while in the evening it passes over the site of the roses of the Garden of Eden.
§ The mishna teaches: If the seller sold <span class="gemarra-regular">wine and it is found </span>to be <span class="gemarra-regular">vinegar, both </span>the seller and the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">can renege on </span>the sale. The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Shall we say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the mishna is </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">and not </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis? As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: 

Daf 84b

<span class="gemarra-regular">Wine and vinega</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> are one type </span>of food, which means that if, for example, one separated <span class="it-text">teruma</span> from one of these with the intention that it should exempt the other, his action is effective. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">says: </span>They are <span class="gemarra-regular">two types </span>of food. Apparently, the mishna is not in accordance with the opinion of the Rabbis in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>. The Gem ara rejects this claim: <span class="gemarra-regular">You </span>may <span class="gemarra-regular">even say </span>that the mishn a is in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis, </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis disagree with Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">only with regard to </span>the issue of whether one can separate <span class="gemarra-regular">tithe and </span><span class="gemarra-italic">teruma</span> from wine to redeem vinegar and vice versa. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the Rabbis hold <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Ela</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">As Rabbi Ela says: From where </span>is it derived <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>one who <span class="gemarra-regular">separates </span><span class="gemarra-italic">teruma</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from poor</span>-<span class="gemarra-regular">quality </span>produce <span class="gemarra-regular">for superior</span>-<span class="gemarra-regular">quality </span>produce, i.e., in order to fulfill the obligation of separating <span class="it-text">teruma</span> from the high-quality produce, <span class="gemarra-regular">that his </span><span class="gemarra-italic">teruma</span> is valid <span class="gemarra-italic">teruma</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? As it is stated: “And you shall bear no sin by reason of it, seeing as you have set apart from it its best” </span>(Numbers 18:32).
The verse is understood as indicating that one who sets aside inferior produce has sinned. It also demonstrates that if one did, in fact, set aside <span class="it-text">teruma</span> from poor-quality produce in order to render permitted superior-quality produce, his action is effective and the inferior produce is sanctified as <span class="it-text">teruma</span>. The reason is that <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>the inferior produce <span class="gemarra-regular">is not consecrated, why </span>would one <span class="gemarra-regular">bear a sin? </span>It should be considered as though he did nothing. <span class="gemarra-regular">From here </span>it is derived <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>one who <span class="gemarra-regular">separates </span><span class="gemarra-italic">teruma</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from poor</span>-<span class="gemarra-regular">quality</span> produce <span class="gemarra-regular">for superior</span>-<span class="gemarra-regular">quality </span>produce <span class="gemarra-regular">that his </span><span class="gemarra-italic">teruma</span> is valid <span class="gemarra-italic">teruma</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>The Rabbis agree and hold that in the case of one who separates vinegar in order to redeem wine, his <span class="it-text">teruma</span> is valid despite the difference in quality, as wine and vinegar are considered a single type of food.
<span class="gemarra-regular">But with regard to buying and selling, everyone, </span>including the Rabbis, agrees that wine and vinegar are two types of food, as they have different uses. <span class="gemarra-regular">There are </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">for whom wine is preferable and vinegar is not preferable, and there are </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">for whom vinegar is preferabl</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and wine is not preferable.</span>
mishna This mishna discusses several methods of acquiring movable property. With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who sells produce to another, </span>if the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">pulled </span>the produce <span class="gemarra-regular">but did not measure </span>it, <span class="gemarra-regular">he has acquired </span>the produce through the act of acquisition of pulling. If <span class="gemarra-regular">he measured </span>the produce <span class="gemarra-regular">but did not pull </span>it, <span class="gemarra-regular">he has not acquired </span>it, and either the seller or the buyer can decide to rescind the sale. <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">is perspicacious </span>and wants to acquire the produce without having to pull it, and he wishes to do so before the seller could change his mind and decide not to sell, <span class="gemarra-regular">he rents its </span><span class="gemarra-regular">place</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> where the produce is located, and his property immediately effects acquisition of the produce on his behalf.
With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who buys flax from another, </span>because flax is usually carried around <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>purchaser <span class="gemarra-regular">has not acquired </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">until he carries i</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from place to place </span>and acquires it by means of the act of acquisition of lifting. Pulling the flax is ineffective. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if it was attached to the ground, and he detached any amount, </span>he has <span class="gemarra-regular">acquired </span>it, as the Gemara will explain.
gemara The mishna mentions several modes of acquisition without elaboration. It does not explain in which domain the act takes place, whether on the property of the seller or in the public domain. Likewise, it does not specify who performs these actions. The Gemara clarifies these details. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Asi says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: </span>If the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">measured </span>the produce <span class="gemarra-regular">and placed </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">in an </span><span class="gemarra-regular">alleyway</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> which is not the public domain but a location where people can keep their belongings, then even if the buyer did not pull the produce, he <span class="gemarra-regular">acquires </span>it.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Zeira said to Rabbi Asi: Perhaps my teacher heard </span>this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> from Rabbi Yoḥanan <span class="gemarra-regular">only with regard to one who measures into his basket</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., that of the buyer, in which case his possessions effect acquisition of the produce for him. But if the produce is placed on the floor of the alleyway, the buyer does not acquire the produce. Rabbi Asi <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: This one of the Sages, </span>i.e., Rabbi Zeira, <span class="gemarra-regular">seems like one who has not studied </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>If he <span class="gemarra-regular">measured </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">into the basket </span>of the buyer, is it <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary to sa</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span> that he acquires it? If an item is placed in the buyer’s basket it is clearly acquired by him, regardless of the location of the basket. Rather, Rabbi Yoḥanan’s statement with regard to an alleyway must be referring to items placed on the floor of the alleyway.
The Gemara asks: Did Rabbi Zeira <span class="gemarra-regular">accept </span>this claim <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>Rabbi Asi, <span class="gemarra-regular">or </span>did <span class="gemarra-regular">he not accept </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">from him? </span>The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a proof, <span class="gemarra-regular">as Rabbi Yannai say</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">says: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a courtyard belonging to partners, </span>which is similar in status to an alleyway, the partners <span class="gemarra-regular">acquir</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from one another. What, is it not </span>correct to say that there is no difference between placing items on the ground and in their basket, as a partner acquires an item even when it is placed <span class="gemarra-regular">upon the ground, </span>in accordance with the statement of Rabbi Asi? The Gemara rejects this suggestion: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>this is referring to a case where the item is measured <span class="gemarra-regular">into the basket </span>of the buyer.
The Gemara points out: <span class="gemarra-regular">So, too, </span>Rabbi Zeira’s statement <span class="gemarra-regular">is reasonable, as Rabbi Ya’akov says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: </span>If one <span class="gemarra-regular">measured and placed </span>an item <span class="gemarra-regular">in an alleyway, </span>the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">has not acquired </span>it. Apparently, these two <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> cited in the name of Rabbi Yoḥanan <span class="gemarra-regular">are difficult, </span>as they contradict <span class="gemarra-regular">each other, </span>since earlier it was stated that according to Rabbi Yoḥanan the buyer can acquire an item in this manner. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, isn’t it </span>correct to <span class="gemarra-regular">conclude from </span>this apparent contradiction that <span class="gemarra-regular">here, </span>i.e., in the statement cited by Rabbi Asi, he is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to one who measures into the baske</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> of the buyer, which effects acquisition; and <span class="gemarra-regular">there, </span>i.e., in the statement of Rabbi Yaakov, he is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> one who measures onto the ground, </span>which does not effect acquisition. The Gemara affirms: <span class="gemarra-regular">Learn from it </span>that this is the case.
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a proof from the mishna: If <span class="gemarra-regular">he measured </span>the produce <span class="gemarra-regular">but did not pull </span>it, <span class="gemarra-regular">he does not acquire </span>it. <span class="gemarra-regular">What, is it not </span>referring to one who did so <span class="gemarra-regular">in an alleyway, </span>which indicates that placing produce on the ground of an alleyway does not effect acquisition, in accordance with the statement of Rabbi Zeira? The Gemara rejects this proof: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>the mishna is referring to one who did so <span class="gemarra-regular">in the public domain</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If that is so, say the first clause: </span>If the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">pulled </span>the produce <span class="gemarra-regular">but did not measure </span>it, <span class="gemarra-regular">he has acquired </span>the produce. But <span class="gemarra-regular">does pulling in the public domain effect acquisition?</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">But don’t Abaye and Rava both say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">passing effects acquisition in the public domain and in a courtyard that </span>does <span class="gemarra-regular">not belong to either of them; pulling effects acquisition </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">in an alleyway or in a courtyard that belongs to both of them, </span>but not in the public domain; <span class="gemarra-regular">and lifting effects acquisition in every place, </span>even in the seller’s domain? This demonstrates that pulling in the public domain does not effect acquisition.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">What</span> is the meaning of the phrase: If <span class="gemarra-regular">he pulled </span>it, <span class="gemarra-regular">that is taught </span>in the mishna? It means that he pulled it <span class="gemarra-regular">from the public domain into an alleyway. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If that is so, say the latter clause: If </span>the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">is perspicacious he rents its place, </span>i.e., where the produce is located. The Gemara explains the difficulty: <span class="gemarra-regular">But if </span>the mishna is referring to a spot <span class="gemarra-regular">in the public domain, from whom can he rent </span>the place where the produce is located? The Gemara answers: The latter clause is referring to a separate <span class="it-text">halakha</span>, and <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>is what the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">is saying: And if </span>the produce is <span class="gemarra-regular">in a domain </span>that has <span class="gemarra-regular">an owner</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> if he </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is perspicacious he rents the place </span>where the produce is located from the owner.
§ The Gemara continues to discuss the manner in which an acquisition takes place. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav and Shmuel both say: </span>

Daf 85a

<span class="gemarra-regular">A person’s vessel</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> effect acquisition </span>of any item placed inside them <span class="gemarra-regular">for him, in any plac</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> in which they are situated, <span class="gemarra-regular">except for the public domain</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> And Rabbi Yoḥanan and Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish both say: Even in the public domain, </span>one’s vessels effect acquisition of items placed in them.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa said: </span>These <span class="it-text">amora’im</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">do not disagree: Here, </span>when Rav and Shmuel state that one’s vessel does not effect acquisition for him, they are speaking of a vessel placed <span class="gemarra-regular">in the public domain; there, </span>when Rabbi Yoḥanan and Reish Lakish state that his vessel effects acquisition on his behalf, they are referring to a vessel located <span class="gemarra-regular">in an alleyway</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> And why do they call </span>an alleyway <span class="gemarra-regular">the public domain? </span>The reason is <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>an alleyway is <span class="gemarra-regular">not a private domain.</span>
The Gemara points out: <span class="gemarra-regular">So, too, it is reasonable </span>to interpret Rabbi Yoḥanan’s statement in this manner, <span class="gemarra-regular">as Rabbi Abbahu says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: A person’s vessels effect acquisition for hi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">m</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in any place where he has permissio</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to keep them. </span>It can be inferred from here: In a location where <span class="gemarra-regular">he has permission </span>to keep them, <span class="gemarra-regular">yes, </span>his vessels effect acquisition for him. But in a place where <span class="gemarra-regular">he does not have permission </span>to keep his vessels, they do <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>effect acquisition for him, and one has permission to keep his vessels in an alleyway but not in the public domain. The Gemara affirms: <span class="gemarra-regular">Conclude from </span>this statement that when Rabbi Yoḥanan referred to the public domain he meant an alleyway.
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come</span> and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a difficulty from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: There are <span class="gemarra-regular">four case</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with regard to sellers, </span>i.e., four methods through which merchandise is acquired. When the seller measures merchandise for the buyer, <span class="gemarra-regular">before the measuring </span>vessel <span class="gemarra-regular">has been filled </span>the merchandise in the vessel still belongs <span class="gemarra-regular">to the selle</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> and he can change his mind and cancel the sale. <span class="gemarra-regular">Once the measuring </span>vessel <span class="gemarra-regular">has been fille</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> the merchandise belongs <span class="gemarra-regular">to the buyer. In what </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">is this statement said? </span>It is said when the seller measures <span class="gemarra-regular">with a measuring </span>vessel <span class="gemarra-regular">that does not belong to either of them</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> But if the measuring </span>vessel <span class="gemarra-regular">belonged to one of them</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">acquires </span>the items of sale <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>by <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>as they are placed in the measuring vessel.
<span class="gemarra-regular">In what </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">is this statement said? </span>It is said when the seller measures the items <span class="gemarra-regular">in the public domain or in a courtyard that does not belong to either of them. But </span>if it happens <span class="gemarra-regular">in the domain of </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">seller</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">does not acquir</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> the merchandise <span class="gemarra-regular">until he lifts </span>the measuring vessel <span class="gemarra-regular">or until he moves it out of the domain </span>of the seller. If it is <span class="gemarra-regular">in the domain of </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">buyer</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> once </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">seller accepts upon himself </span>to sell, the <span class="gemarra-regular">buyer acquires </span>it. If the merchandise is located <span class="gemarra-regular">in the domain of this </span>individual <span class="gemarra-regular">with whom it had been deposited</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">does not acquire </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">until </span>the bailee <span class="gemarra-regular">accepts upon himsel</span><span class="gemarra-regular">f </span> to designate a place where the merchandise is to be stored for the buyer, <span class="gemarra-regular">or until </span>the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">rents </span>from the bailee <span class="gemarra-regular">the place </span>where the merchandise is situated.
<span class="gemarra-regular">In any event, </span>this <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches with regard to </span>a transaction in <span class="gemarra-regular">the public domain or in a courtyard that does not belong to either of them </span>that if the measuring vessel belonged to one of them, the buyer acquires the items of sale one by one as they are placed in the vessel. 

Daf 85b

<span class="gemarra-regular">What, </span>is it <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>stating that a buyer’s vessels effect acquisition of items on his behalf even <span class="gemarra-regular">in the actual public domain</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> which contradicts Rav Pappa’s explanation? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">an alleyway, </span>not the actual public domain. The Gemara asks: How can this be what the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> means? <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>that it is <span class="gemarra-regular">similar to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a courtyard that does not belong to either of them, </span>i.e., a location to which neither of them have any rights, whereas they both have some rights in an alleyway. Consequently, this must be referring to the actual public domain, not an alleyway.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is the meaning of the phrase: <span class="gemarra-regular">A courtyard that does not belong to either of them? </span>It <span class="gemarra-regular">also </span>refers to shared property, specifically a courtyard shared by partners, <span class="gemarra-regular">which does not </span>belong to <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">entirely and does not </span>belong to <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">entirely, but rather </span>it is the property <span class="gemarra-regular">of both of them. </span>Consequently, this courtyard is comparable to an alleyway.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Sheshet raises a dilemma before Rav Huna: </span>If the <span class="gemarra-regular">vessels of the buyer </span>are <span class="gemarra-regular">in the domain of the seller, </span>does the <span class="gemarra-regular">buyer acquire </span>the merchandise once it is placed in his vessels <span class="gemarra-regular">or not? </span>Rav Huna <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: You learned </span>the answer already in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Gittin</span> 77a): A wife is divorced when her husband hands her a bill of divorce or places it in a manner that is considered equivalent to handing it to her, e.g., placing in her courtyard. Accordingly, if the husband <span class="gemarra-regular">threw </span>the bill of divorce <span class="gemarra-regular">to her</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> into her lap or into her basket [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">kaltah</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> this </span>woman <span class="gemarra-regular">is divorce</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> even if she was in her husband’s domain at that time. By the same token, even if the buyer’s vessels are in the domain of the seller, they effect acquisition of the sold items on his behalf.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman said to </span>Rav Huna: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">you resolved </span>Rav Sheshet’s dilemma <span class="gemarra-regular">from that </span>mishna, <span class="gemarra-regular">which </span>has already been <span class="gemarra-regular">struck </span>with <span class="gemarra-regular">one hundred strikes of a hammer [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">uklei</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">be’ukela</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> In their analysis of this mishna, the Sages have already inserted so many qualifications that it cannot be understood in a straightforward manner.
<span class="gemarra-regular">As Rav Yehuda says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel says: This </span><span class="it-text">halakha</span> of the mishna in <span class="it-text">Gittin</span> applies only if <span class="gemarra-regular">her basket</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> was hangin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from her </span>body, so that it is considered on her or in her hand. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Reish Lakish says: </span>It is sufficient if <span class="gemarra-regular">it</span> was <span class="gemarra-regular">tied </span>to her, <span class="gemarra-regular">even though it is not hanging from her, </span>but resting on the ground. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Adda bar Ahava says: </span>The mishna is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where her basket was placed between her thighs. </span>Although it is not hanging from her, since it is placed on her body it serves to acquire the bill of divorce on her behalf. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Mesharshiyya, son of Rabbi Ami, says: </span>This is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where her husband </span>was <span class="gemarra-regular">a basket seller</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Since he is not particular about the place where the basket into which he placed the bill of divorce is located, as his entire courtyard is full of baskets, it is considered as though he expressly granted her the right to make use of its location.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: The place of her lap, </span>i.e., the place within her husband’s property where she stands or sits, <span class="gemarra-regular">belongs to her, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">the place of her basket is acquired to her. Rava said: What is the reason </span>behind the statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Yoḥanan? </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">because a person, </span>including a husband, <span class="gemarra-regular">is not particular neither about the place of her lap nor about the place of her basket, </span>as she requires these areas and they do not take up much space. It is evident from all of these qualifications that one cannot infer a halakhic principle from here with regard to a buyer’s vessels in a seller’s domain.
