<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, resolve </span>the dilemma <span class="gemarra-regular">from that </span>which was taught in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: If the merchandise was <span class="gemarra-regular">in the domain of a seller, </span>the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">does not acquire </span>the merchandise <span class="gemarra-regular">until he lifts </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">or until he removes it from the domain </span>of the seller. <span class="gemarra-regular">What, </span>is it <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>referring to merchandise placed <span class="gemarra-regular">in the vessels of the buyer, </span>which proves that the buyer’s vessels do not effect acquisition of the merchandise on his behalf when they are in the seller’s domain? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>this does not serve as proof, as it is referring to merchandise placed <span class="gemarra-regular">in the vessels of the seller</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> That is why the buyer must lift or pull the merchandise to acquire it.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But from </span>the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that the first clause </span>is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to the vessels of the seller, </span>as currently understood, <span class="gemarra-regular">the latter clause </span>must <span class="gemarra-regular">also </span>be referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to the vessels of the seller. Say the latter clause: </span>If the merchandise was <span class="gemarra-regular">in the domain of the buyer, once the seller accepts upon himself </span>to sell an item, <span class="gemarra-regular">the buyer acquires </span>it. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if </span>this is referring to merchandise <span class="gemarra-regular">in the vessels of the seller, </span>as in the earlier clause, <span class="gemarra-regular">why does the buyer acquire </span>it? The Gemara answers: In <span class="gemarra-regular">the latter clause, we come to </span>a different scenario, which involves <span class="gemarra-regular">the vessels of the buyer.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if the clauses of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> are addressing different cases, <span class="gemarra-regular">why </span>was it stated <span class="gemarra-regular">without qualification</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">The normal </span>way <span class="gemarra-regular">of things </span>is that <span class="gemarra-regular">in the house of the seller the vessels of the seller are </span>commonly <span class="gemarra-regular">found, and in the house of the buyer the vessels of the buyer are </span>commonly <span class="gemarra-regular">found. </span>In sum, the dilemma cannot be resolved from the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a resolution from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: If <span class="gemarra-regular">one pulled his donkey drivers, </span>thereby dragging along with them the donkeys laden with goods, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>likewise, if he pulled <span class="gemarra-regular">his laborers</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> who were carrying merchandise he wished to purchase, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he brought them into his house, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">whether he fixed </span>a price <span class="gemarra-regular">before he measure</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> the merchandise <span class="gemarra-regular">or whether he measured before fixing </span>a price, <span class="gemarra-regular">both </span>parties <span class="gemarra-regular">can renege on </span>the sale, provided that the merchandise has not been unloaded from the laborers or the donkeys. 

Daf 86a

But in a case where <span class="gemarra-regular">he unloade</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> the merchandise from them <span class="gemarra-regular">and brought it into his house, </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">he fixed </span>a price <span class="gemarra-regular">before he measured </span>the merchandise, <span class="gemarra-regular">both </span>parties <span class="gemarra-regular">are no </span>longer <span class="gemarra-regular">able to renege on </span>the sale. If <span class="gemarra-regular">he measured </span>the merchandise <span class="gemarra-regular">before fixing </span>a price, <span class="gemarra-regular">both of them are able to renege on </span>the sale. The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">And from </span>the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that the vessels of the seller </span>when <span class="gemarra-regular">in the domain of </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">buyer do not effect acquisition </span>of the merchandise for the seller, i.e., they do not prevent the buyer from acquiring the merchandise, one can derive that <span class="gemarra-regular">the vessels of the buyer in the domain of </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">seller do not effect acquisition </span>of the merchandise on his behalf <span class="gemarra-regular">as well.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: </span>The merchandise was not placed in the domain of the buyer in vessels belonging to the seller. Rather, the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he emptied </span>the vessels onto the ground. Conversely, if the merchandise remains in the seller’s vessels, the buyer does not acquire it. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava became angr</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span> with Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak at his rejection of Rava’s proof, and retorted: <span class="gemarra-regular">Does </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">teach: He emptied them? </span>No; <span class="gemarra-regular">it teaches: He unloaded them</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., he kept the goods in vessels belonging to the seller. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Mar bar Rav Ashi says: </span>This proof can be rejected by means of a different interpretation, as the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> does not refer to vessels full of goods but is stated <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to bundles of garli</span><span class="gemarra-regular">c</span> that were tied together. Therefore, they are unloaded straight onto the floor in the buyer’s domain.
With regard to the matter itself, <span class="gemarra-regular">Huna, son of Mar Zutra, said to Ravina: Since </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches: He unloaded them, </span>which indicates that unloading the merchandise constitutes the act of acquisition, <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>difference is there <span class="gemarra-regular">to me </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">he fixed </span>a price, <span class="gemarra-regular">and what </span>difference is there <span class="gemarra-regular">to me </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">he did not fix </span>a price? Ravina <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">he fixed </span>a price <span class="gemarra-regular">he has made up his min</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> to sell, and therefore the transaction can take place. If <span class="gemarra-regular">he did not fix </span>a price, <span class="gemarra-regular">he has not made up his mind</span> to sell and the transaction does not occur. In any event, no convincing proof has been found with regard to the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in a case where the vessels of the buyer are in the domain of the seller.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Ravina said to Rav Ashi: Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a resolution, <span class="gemarra-regular">as Rav and Shmuel both say: A person’s vessel effects acquisition for him </span>of any item placed inside it, <span class="gemarra-regular">in any place </span>that it is situated. <span class="gemarra-regular">What is added </span>by the phrase: In any place? Does it <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>serve <span class="gemarra-regular">to add </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">domain of the seller? </span>Rav Ashi answered: <span class="gemarra-regular">There, </span>it is referring to a specific case, <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Go </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">acquire </span>it. In that situation, the buyer does acquire the merchandise. This does not refer to a standard case where the buyer’s vessels are located in the domain of the seller.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">We learned </span>in a mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">elsewhere </span>(<span class="it-text">Kiddushin</span> 26a): <span class="gemarra-regular">Property that is guaranteed</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., land, <span class="gemarra-regular">is acquired by </span>means of <span class="gemarra-regular">money, or by </span>means of <span class="gemarra-regular">a bill, or by taking possession </span>of it. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>property <span class="gemarra-regular">that does not</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> have a guarantee, </span>i.e., movable property, <span class="gemarra-regular">can be acquired only by </span>means of <span class="gemarra-regular">pulling. In Sura they taught this </span>following <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in the name of Rav Ḥisda, </span>while <span class="gemarra-regular">in Pumbedita they taught it in the name of Rav Kahana, and some say in the name of Rava: They taught </span>that movable property is acquired by means of pulling <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">items that are not typically lifte</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> due to their weight or for some other reason. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">items that are typically lifted, </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">yes, </span>they are acquired <span class="gemarra-regular">by </span>means of <span class="gemarra-regular">lifting, </span>but they are <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>acquired <span class="gemarra-regular">by </span>means of <span class="gemarra-regular">pulling.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye sat and related this </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. Rav Adda bar Mattana raised an objection to Abaye </span>from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">One who steals a purse on Shabba</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">liabl</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> for theft. Based on the principle that one who is liable to receive two punishments receives only the greater of the two, in this case one might think that he should be exempt from paying for the theft, as the performance of a prohibited labor on Shabbat is punishable by death. The reason he is liable in this case, in apparent contradiction to that principle, is <span class="gemarra-regular">that he already became liable for </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">theft </span>as soon as he lifted the purse. This occurred <span class="gemarra-regular">before he came to </span>violate <span class="gemarra-regular">the prohibition </span>of performing prohibited labor on <span class="gemarra-regular">Shabbat </span>by carrying the purse into the public domain.
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues: If he did not lift the purse but <span class="gemarra-regular">was dragging </span>it on the ground <span class="gemarra-regular">and exiting </span>the private domain, continuously <span class="gemarra-regular">dragging and exiting, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt, as the prohibition </span>of performing labor on <span class="gemarra-regular">Shabba</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>the prohibition of <span class="gemarra-regular">theft </span>are violated <span class="gemarra-regular">simultaneously </span>the moment he drags the purse out of the owner’s property into the public domain. Therefore, he receives only the greater punishment, death, for carrying on Shabbat.
Rav Adda bar Mattana explains his objection: <span class="gemarra-regular">But a purse is an item that can be lifted, and even so </span>it is apparent from the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that one <span class="gemarra-regular">acquires </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">by </span>means of <span class="gemarra-regular">pulling. </span>How then can it be stated that items that are typically lifted are not acquired by pulling? Abaye <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is referring to a case where the thief pulled the purse <span class="gemarra-regular">with a rope. </span>Rav Adda bar Mattana thought that Abaye meant that the thief happened to drag it with a rope, and he responded: <span class="gemarra-regular">I also state </span>my question even in a case where he pulled the purse <span class="gemarra-regular">with a rope, </span>as it is still evident that one can acquire the purse by means of pulling instead of lifting. Abaye <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>I meant that the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">an item that requires a rope</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> It is a purse that is so large that it cannot be lifted and must be pulled, therefore it is acquired by means of pulling.
The Gemara raises another objection. <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear: </span>If the merchandise is <span class="gemarra-regular">in the domain of </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">seller, </span>the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">does not acquire </span>the merchandise <span class="gemarra-regular">until he lifts it or until he removes it from the domain </span>of the seller. <span class="gemarra-regular">Apparently, </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">an item that can be lifted, if he </span>so <span class="gemarra-regular">desires he acquires it by lifting, and if he </span>so <span class="gemarra-regular">desires he acquires it by pulling. Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: </span>This is not a proof, as it can be explained that the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches it disjunctively, </span>i.e., the two options are referring to two different cases: In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">an item that can be lifted, </span>he acquires it <span class="gemarra-regular">by lifting, </span>whereas with regard to regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">an item that can be pulled, </span>he acquires it <span class="gemarra-regular">by pulling. </span>

Daf 86b

The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a proof from the mishna (84b) that even items that are usually lifted can be acquired by means of pulling: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who sells produce to another, </span>if the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">pulled </span>the produce <span class="gemarra-regular">but did not measure </span>it, <span class="gemarra-regular">he has acquired </span>it. The Gemara explains the proof: <span class="gemarra-regular">But produce can be lifted, and </span>yet the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches that it is acquired by </span>means of <span class="gemarra-regular">pulling.</span>
The Gemara rejects this proof: <span class="gemarra-regular">With what are we dealing here? </span>We are dealing <span class="gemarra-regular">with large bundle</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> that are pulled from place to place and are not carried, due to their size. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If that is so, say the latter clause </span>of the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">One who buys fla</span><span class="gemarra-regular">x</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from another has not acquired </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">until he carries it from this place to another place</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., it is acquired only though lifting and not through pulling. <span class="gemarra-regular">Is that to say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">flax is not prepared in large bundles</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> The Gemara answers: Yes, <span class="gemarra-regular">flax is different. </span>Unlike other produce, flax is not packed in large bundles, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it </span>would <span class="gemarra-regular">sli</span><span class="gemarra-regular">p</span> from its place. Rather, it is packed in small bundles, and therefore flax is acquired specifically through lifting.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Ravina said to Rav Ashi: Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a proof from a mishna (<span class="it-text">Kiddushin</span> 25b): <span class="gemarra-regular">Large domesticated animals are acquire</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> through passing </span>the animal’s leash to the buyer, <span class="gemarra-regular">and small </span>domesticated animals are acquired <span class="gemarra-regular">through lifting; </span>this is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of Rabbi Meir and Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar. And the Rabbis say: Small domesticated animals </span>are acquired <span class="gemarra-regular">through pulling. </span>Ravina explains the proof: <span class="gemarra-regular">But small domesticated animals are </span>creatures <span class="gemarra-regular">that can be lifted, and </span>yet the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches that </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">acquires </span>them <span class="gemarra-regular">through pulling. </span>Rav Ashi rejected this proof: <span class="gemarra-regular">Domesticated animals are different, as they clin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span> to the ground and it is difficult to lift them. Therefore, the usual manner of moving animals is to pull them.
§ The Gemara cites another case with regard to sales. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav and Shmuel both say: </span>If a seller said to a buyer: <span class="gemarra-regular">I am selling you one </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kor</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> a measure equivalent to thirty <span class="it-text">se’a</span>, of grain <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>the price of <span class="gemarra-regular">thirty </span><span class="it-text">sela</span>, the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">can renege on </span>the sale as long as the measuring vessel is not filled, <span class="gemarra-regular">even when </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">the last </span><span class="gemarra-italic">se’</span><span class="gemarra-italic">a</span> has yet to be measured, because he had agreed to sell only a complete <span class="it-text">kor</span>. By contrast, if the seller said: <span class="gemarra-regular">I am selling you one </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kor</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for thirty </span><span class="it-text">sel</span><span class="it-text">a</span> and each <span class="gemarra-italic">se’a</span> is sold <span class="gemarra-regular">for one </span><span class="gemarra-italic">sela</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> he cannot completely renege on the sale in the middle of the transaction. This is because the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">acquires </span>each <span class="it-text">se’a</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>by <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>as it is measured, since the seller sold each <span class="it-text">se’a</span> individually.
The Gemara raises a difficulty from the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> cited on 85a. <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear: If the measuring </span>vessel <span class="gemarra-regular">belonged to one of them</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">acquires </span>the items of sale <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>by <span class="gemarra-regular">one. And </span>since this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is stated in general terms, it indicates that the buyer acquires each item as it is placed in the measuring vessel, <span class="gemarra-regular">even though the measuring </span>vessel <span class="gemarra-regular">was not filled</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
The Gemara answers: The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: I am selling you one </span><span class="gemarra-italic">hin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>a liquid measure equivalent to twelve <span class="it-text">log</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">for twelve </span><span class="gemarra-italic">sela</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>each <span class="gemarra-italic">lo</span><span class="gemarra-italic">g</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">for one </span><span class="gemarra-italic">sela</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. And </span>this is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>an observation <span class="gemarra-regular">that Rav Kahana says: </span>In the Temple <span class="gemarra-regular">there were markings on the </span>vessel that measured <span class="gemarra-italic">hin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>with which one could measure the different libations. <span class="gemarra-regular">Here too, there were marking</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> on the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">measuring </span>vessels, and since the measuring vessel indicates at which point each <span class="it-text">log</span> had been filled, the buyer acquires it. This is comparable to the case of one who sells each <span class="it-text">se’a</span> individually.
The Gemara raises another difficulty. <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear: One who hires a labore</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> in the winter or the spring <span class="gemarra-regular">to work for him in the harvest, for </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">dinar a day</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> 

Daf 87a

<span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>a day of a laborer’s work during the <span class="gemarra-regular">harvest is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> worth a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">sela</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the equivalent of four silver dinars, for each day, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibited to </span>derive <span class="gemarra-regular">benefit from him</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., one may not employ the laborer under these conditions. The reason is that this is akin to taking interest, as the laborer works and receives less than he is entitled to in exchange for early payment. <span class="gemarra-regular">But if one hires him </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">from now </span>to work <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">dina</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a day </span>for an extended period of time, including the harvest season, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the work of a laborer during the <span class="gemarra-regular">harvest is worth a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">sela</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>this is <span class="gemarra-regular">permitted.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if it enters your mind, </span>as Rav and Shmuel claim, that if a seller said: <span class="gemarra-regular">I am selling you one </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kor</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for thirty </span><span class="it-text">sela</span>, each <span class="gemarra-italic">se’a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for one </span><span class="gemarra-italic">sela</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>he cannot fully renege on the sale in the middle of the transaction, as the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">acquires </span>each <span class="it-text">se’a</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>by <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>as it is measured, then the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in this case should be different. <span class="gemarra-regular">Here too, </span>as he does not agree to one large sum but <span class="gemarra-regular">fixes </span>a price for each day, <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>by <span class="gemarra-regular">one, </span>it is akin to taking interest, as the laborer works and receives less than he is entitled to in exchange for early payment. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>therefore, it should be <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibited to </span>derive <span class="gemarra-regular">benefit from him. </span>Whereas the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> states: If one hires him from now to work <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">dinar a da</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span> over an extended period of time, including the harvest, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>one day of a laborer’s work during the <span class="gemarra-regular">harvest </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">worth one </span><span class="gemarra-italic">sela</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>this is <span class="gemarra-regular">permitted. Why </span>is it permitted? <span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t it payment for waiting, </span>i.e., for advancing the money to the laborer?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: And </span>how can <span class="gemarra-regular">you understand </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> in that manner? <span class="gemarra-regular">Is it prohibited </span>for one <span class="gemarra-regular">to lower </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">hiring </span>price and receive lower wages in order to ensure that he is employed? This arrangement is not a form of interest and violates no prohibition. The Gemara asks: If this is not considered taking interest, then <span class="gemarra-regular">what is different </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">the first clause, </span>where the laborer is not employed immediately and this arrangement is prohibited, <span class="gemarra-regular">and what is different </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">the latter clause, </span>where it is permitted?
The Gemara explains: In <span class="gemarra-regular">the first clause, as </span>the laborer <span class="gemarra-regular">does not work with him from now, it has the appearance of payment for waiting</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., advancing the money to the laborer. In <span class="gemarra-regular">the latter clause, as </span>the laborer <span class="gemarra-regular">works with him from now, it does not have the appearance of payment for waiting.</span>
§ The mishna teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">And if </span>the flax <span class="gemarra-regular">was attached to the ground and he detached any amount, </span>he has <span class="gemarra-regular">acquired </span>it. The Gemara asks: Is it correct to say that <span class="gemarra-regular">due to </span>the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he detache</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> any amount, </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">acquired </span>it? If he does not perform an act of acquisition with all of the flax, how can he acquire all of it? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Sheshet said: Here we are dealing with </span>a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">sai</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to him: Go </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">clear for yourself any amount of land, and </span>thereby <span class="gemarra-regular">acquire everything that is on it. </span>When the buyer clears the land by detaching the flax from the ground, he is considered to be renting the land and thereby acquires all the flax that grows on it.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who sells </span>food or drink that has an established price, such as <span class="gemarra-regular">wine and oil, to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">another</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the price <span class="gemarra-regular">rises or falls </span>and the buyer or the seller wishes to renege on the sale, <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>the price changed <span class="gemarra-regular">before the measuring </span>vessel <span class="gemarra-regular">is filled, </span>the merchandise still belongs <span class="gemarra-regular">to the seller </span>and he can cancel the sale. <span class="gemarra-regular">Once the measuring </span>vessel <span class="gemarra-regular">is filled </span>the merchandise belongs <span class="gemarra-regular">to the buyer, </span>and the seller can no longer cancel the sale. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if there was a middleman [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">sarsur</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">between </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the</span><span class="gemarra-regular">m</span> and <span class="gemarra-regular">the barrel </span>belonging to the middleman, being used to measure the merchandise, <span class="gemarra-regular">broke </span>during the transaction and the merchandise is ruined, <span class="gemarra-regular">it broke for the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">middleman</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., he is responsible for the ruined merchandise.
The mishna teaches an additional <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to sales: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>anyone who sells wine, oil, or similar liquids is <span class="gemarra-regular">obligated, </span>after he transfers the liquid into the buyer’s vessel, <span class="gemarra-regular">to drip for him three </span>extra <span class="gemarra-regular">drop</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> from the measure. After he drips those three drops, if <span class="gemarra-regular">he turned </span>the barrel on its side <span class="gemarra-regular">and drained </span>out the last bits of liquid that it contained, this <span class="gemarra-regular">belongs to the seller </span>and he is not required to give these last drops to the buyer. <span class="gemarra-regular">And a storekeeper is not obligate</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to drip three drops, </span>because he is too busy to do this constantly. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda says: </span>If the sale occurs on <span class="gemarra-regular">Shabbat eve as nightfall </span>arrives, one is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from dripping these three drops, as there is a need to complete the transaction before Shabbat begins.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara clarifies the mishna’s statement that the sale occurs once the measuring vessel is filled. <span class="gemarra-regular">This measuring </span>vessel, <span class="gemarra-regular">to whom </span>does it belong? <span class="gemarra-regular">If we say </span>that the <span class="gemarra-regular">measuring </span>vessel belongs <span class="gemarra-regular">to the buyer, </span>why does the mishna teach that <span class="gemarra-regular">before the measuring </span>vessel <span class="gemarra-regular">is filled </span>the merchandise still belongs <span class="gemarra-regular">to the seller? </span>Since <span class="gemarra-regular">it is the measuring </span>vessel <span class="gemarra-regular">of the buyer, </span>he should acquire everything that is placed in his vessel, whether or not it is filled. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if we say that the <span class="gemarra-regular">measuring </span>vessel belongs <span class="gemarra-regular">to the seller, </span>why does the mishna teach that <span class="gemarra-regular">once the measuring </span>vessel <span class="gemarra-regular">is filled </span>the merchandise belongs <span class="gemarra-regular">to the buyer? </span>Since <span class="gemarra-regular">it is the measuring </span>vessel <span class="gemarra-regular">of the seller, </span>the merchandise has yet to enter the possession of the buyer.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ela says: </span>The mishna is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> measuring </span>vessel belongs to the <span class="gemarra-regular">middleman. </span>The middleman lends it to the seller, and once it is filled it is loaned to the buyer so that he can transfer its contents into his vessels. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But from </span>the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that the latter clause teaches: And if there was a middleman between them </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">the barrel broke, it broke for the middleman, it may be inferred that </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">the first clause we are not dealing with a middleman. </span>The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">The first clause </span>addresses <span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> measuring </span>vessel belonging to a middleman <span class="gemarra-regular">without </span>the presence of the <span class="gemarra-regular">middleman </span>at the transaction, whereas <span class="gemarra-regular">the latter clause </span>is concerned <span class="gemarra-regular">with a middleman himself, </span>who is present at the sale and therefore accepts responsibility for the barrel and its contents.
§ The mishna teaches that if <span class="gemarra-regular">he turned </span>the barrel on its side <span class="gemarra-regular">and drained </span>out the last bits of liquid within it, this liquid <span class="gemarra-regular">belongs to the seller. </span>The Gemara relates: <span class="gemarra-regular">When Rabbi Elazar ascended </span>from Babylonia to Eretz Yisrael, <span class="gemarra-regular">he found Ze’eiri</span> and <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Who here </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to whom Rav taught </span>this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">measures? </span>Ze’eiri <span class="gemarra-regular">showed him Rav Yitzḥak bar Avdimi. </span>Rav Yitzḥak bar Avdimi <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Rabbi Elazar: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is it about this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>poses <span class="gemarra-regular">a difficulty for you? </span>Rabbi Elazar said to him that the problem is <span class="gemarra-regular">that we learned </span>in the mishna: If <span class="gemarra-regular">he turned </span>the barrel on its side <span class="gemarra-regular">and drained </span>out the last bits of liquid within it, that liquid <span class="gemarra-regular">belongs to the seller. </span>

Daf 87b

<span class="gemarra-regular">But didn’t we learn </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Terumot</span> 11:8): If one poured oil or wine of <span class="it-text">teruma</span> from one vessel to another and <span class="gemarra-regular">turned </span>the vessel on its side <span class="gemarra-regular">and drained </span>out the last bits of liquid inside, <span class="gemarra-regular">this is </span><span class="gemarra-italic">terum</span><span class="gemarra-italic">a</span> and must be given to the priest? This indicates that the last remnants of the liquid in the vessel belong to the one who receives the oil or wine, not the owner, i.e., the seller. Why, then, does the mishna here teach that the last remnants belong to the seller?
Rav Yitzḥak bar Avdimi <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Rabbi Elazar: <span class="gemarra-regular">But wasn’t it stated with regard to that </span>mishna that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Abbahu says: Due to </span>of the <span class="gemarra-regular">despair </span>of the <span class="gemarra-regular">owner</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> who relinquishes his right to such a small amount of wine or oil, the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">touched upon it </span>and ruled that any remnants extracted from the vessel belong to the seller? By contrast, with regard to <span class="it-text">teruma</span>, which is forbidden to non-priests, the despair of the buyer is irrelevant, and therefore anything that remains in the vessels is <span class="it-text">teruma</span>.
§ The mishna teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">And a storekeeper is not obligated to drip </span>three drops. Rabbi Yehuda says: If the sale occurs on Shabbat eve as nightfall arrives, one is exempt from dripping these three drops. <span class="gemarra-regular">A dilemma was raised before </span>the Sages: Is <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda referring to the first claus</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> of the mishna, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>if so his ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">is lenient, </span>as the mishna states that one must drip three drops and he states that on Shabbat eve one is exempt from doing so? <span class="gemarra-regular">Or perhaps he is referring to the latter clause and is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> stringent, </span>as the mishna teaches that a storekeeper is always exempt, whereas Rabbi Yehuda rules that this is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> only on Shabbat eve?
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a resolution of this dilemma, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda says: On Shabbat eve at nightfall a storekeeper is exempt because </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">storekeeper is busy. </span>This proves that Rabbi Yehuda was referring to the latter clause of the mishna, i.e., he exempts the storekeeper from dripping the drops only on Shabbat eve.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who sends his </span><span class="gemarra-regular">so</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">to a storekeeper with a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">pundeyon</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> a coin worth two <span class="it-text">issar</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">in his </span><span class="gemarra-regular">hand</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the storekeeper <span class="gemarra-regular">measured oil for him for </span>one <span class="gemarra-italic">issa</span><span class="gemarra-italic">r</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and gave him the </span>second <span class="gemarra-italic">issar</span> as change, and the son <span class="gemarra-regular">broke the jug and lost the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">issar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, the storekeeper </span>must compensate the father, as he gave the jug and coin to one who is not halakhically competent. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda exempts </span>him from liability, <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>he holds that the father <span class="gemarra-regular">sent </span>his son <span class="gemarra-regular">in order to </span>do <span class="gemarra-regular">this, </span>i.e., to bring back the jug and coin. <span class="gemarra-regular">And the Rabbis </span><span class="gemarra-regular">conced</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">to Rabbi Yehuda </span>with regard to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">when the jug is in the hand of the child and </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">storekeeper measured </span>the oil <span class="gemarra-regular">into it that </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">storekeeper </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>if the child breaks the jug.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, with regard to </span>the <span class="gemarra-italic">issar</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">oil, </span>one can explain that <span class="gemarra-regular">they disagree over this </span>matter: <span class="gemarra-regular">As the Rabbis hold </span>that the father <span class="gemarra-regular">sent </span>his son <span class="gemarra-regular">to inform </span>the storekeeper that he needed oil but did not intend for the storekeeper to send the oil with the boy. For this reason, if the storekeeper gave the child the oil he is liable for its loss. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Yehuda holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">he sent </span>his son so that the storekeeper would <span class="gemarra-regular">send him </span>back with the oil, and therefore the storekeeper is exempt from liability. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if the child <span class="gemarra-regular">broke the jug, </span>why do the Rabbis hold that the storekeeper is responsible for it? <span class="gemarra-regular">It is a deliberate loss </span>on the part of the father, as he entrusted the jug to his young son, who is not responsible enough to care for it.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Hoshaya said: Here we are dealing with a proprietor who sells jugs, </span>and the father sent his son with a jug in case the store owner might want to buy it. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>this is a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where the storekeeper took </span>the jug <span class="gemarra-regular">in order to examine it</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>the ruling is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>a statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Shmuel. As Shmuel says: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who takes a vessel from a craftsman</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in order to examine it </span>and buy it if he chooses, <span class="gemarra-regular">and an accident occurred </span>while it was <span class="gemarra-regular">in his possession </span>and it broke, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to pay restitution for the vessel. He has the halakhic status of a borrower, and therefore he bears financial responsibility for the loss.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Shall we say </span>that the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Shmuel is </span>subject to a dispute between <span class="gemarra-italic">tanna’</span><span class="gemarra-italic">im</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? </span>Since Rabbi Yehuda disagrees with the Rabbis, his opinion evidently differs from that of Shmuel. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Rabba and Rav Yosef both say </span>that the disagreement in the mishna should be explained as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">Here, we are dealing with a storekeeper who sells jugs, </span>and the father sent his son to buy from him a jug filled with oil. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Yehuda follows his </span>line of <span class="gemarra-regular">reasoning, </span>as explained above, that the father sent his son to bring back the merchandise, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the Rabbis </span>follow <span class="gemarra-regular">their</span> line of <span class="gemarra-regular">reasoning, </span>that the father sent the son to inform the storekeeper what he needed, but not to carry it back.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If that is so, say the last clause: The Rabbis conced</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to Rabbi Yehuda </span>in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">when the jug was in the hand of the child, and the storekeeper measured </span>the oil <span class="gemarra-regular">into it, that the storekeeper </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt. </span>Why would the Rabbis rule that the storekeeper is exempt? <span class="gemarra-regular">But you said </span>that the father <span class="gemarra-regular">sent </span>his son only <span class="gemarra-regular">to inform </span>the storekeeper of his order, but he did not intend for the storekeeper to give anything to his son. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Abaye bar Avin and Rabbi Ḥanina bar Avin both say </span>that the disagreement in the mishna should be explained as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">With what are we dealing here? </span>

Daf 88a

The mishna is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the storekeeper <span class="gemarra-regular">took </span>the jug from the child in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to measure with i</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> for him, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>because he took it in his hands, he is liable in the event of an accident, <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba. As Rabba says: </span>With regard to the obligation to return lost animals, even in a case where the finder is exempt from caring for the animal and returning it to its owner, e.g., if he is an elderly person and it is beneath his dignity, if <span class="gemarra-regular">he struck </span>the animal in order to lead it, then <span class="gemarra-regular">he becomes obligated </span>to return <span class="gemarra-regular">it. </span>Likewise, the Rabbis here maintain that the storekeeper’s action renders him liable for the jug.
The Gemara asks: You can <span class="gemarra-regular">say that Rabba says </span>his statement <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to animals,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as </span>the finder <span class="gemarra-regular">taught them </span>to <span class="gemarra-regular">take steps away</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., he worsened the situation, as he causes them to stray even further from their owner. Nevertheless, in <span class="gemarra-regular">a case like this, </span>where the storekeeper took the jug from the child, <span class="gemarra-regular">did </span>Rabba <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that the storekeeper is liable? The storekeeper’s action does not make it any more likely that the jug will break.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Rava said: I and the lion of the group explained it. And who is </span>this great Sage, referred to as a lion? It is <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Zeira</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and the explanation is as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">Here we are dealing with </span>a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the storekeeper <span class="gemarra-regular">took </span>the jug from the child in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to measure with it for others, </span>without the knowledge of the father.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the Rabbis and Rabbi Yehuda <span class="gemarra-regular">disagree with regard to a borrower </span>who takes an item <span class="gemarra-regular">without </span>the owner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">knowledge</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> One <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage, </span>Rabbi Yehuda, <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that the storekeeper <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>considered like any other <span class="gemarra-regular">borrower </span>and once he returns the jug to the child, he is no longer responsible for it. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage, </span>i.e., the Rabbis, <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that someone who borrows without the owner’s knowledge <span class="gemarra-regular">is a robbe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> and is obligated to return the item to its owner. Therefore, the storekeeper must pay for the jug that the child broke before it reached the father.
The Gemara returns to <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>matter <span class="gemarra-regular">itself. Shmuel says: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who takes a vessel from a craftsman </span>in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> examine it</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and an accident occurred </span>while it was <span class="gemarra-regular">in his possession </span>and it broke, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to pay restitution for the vessel. The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">And this statement</span> applies only in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where the monetary </span>value of the vessel <span class="gemarra-regular">is fixed</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> because he examines the vessel merely to ensure there is nothing wrong with it, and it is assumed that if he finds no defect he will buy it.
The Gemara relates: There was <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain man who entered a butcher shop and lifted a thigh of meat </span>to examine it. <span class="gemarra-regular">While he was lifting it, a horseman came </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">seized </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">from him. </span>The buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">came before Rav Yeimar, </span>who <span class="gemarra-regular">deemed him liable to pay its monetary </span>value to the seller, because it was seized from him after he had lifted it. The Gemara again notes: <span class="gemarra-regular">And this matter, </span>i.e., <span class="it-text">halakha</span>, applies only in a place <span class="gemarra-regular">where the monetary </span>value of the item is <span class="gemarra-regular">fixed, </span>and therefore lifting it is equivalent to finalizing the sale.
The Gemara relates a similar incident: There was <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain man who brought pumpkins to </span>the city of <span class="gemarra-regular">Pum Nahara. Everyone came </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">took a pumpkin </span>with the intention of buying it, but had yet to pay for it. The seller was angry, and since he did not know from whom to demand payment, <span class="gemarra-regular">he said to them: </span>The pumpkins <span class="gemarra-regular">are hereby consecrate</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to Heaven.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">They came before Rav Kahana </span>to inquire about the halakhic status of the pumpkins. Rav Kahana <span class="gemarra-regular">said to them: </span>This statement has no effect, as <span class="gemarra-regular">a person cannot consecrate an item that is not his, </span>and since the buyers had lifted the pumpkins, they no longer belonged to the seller. Once again the Gemara points out: <span class="gemarra-regular">And this matter, </span>i.e., <span class="it-text">halakha</span>, applies only in a place <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the item’s <span class="gemarra-regular">monetary </span>value is <span class="gemarra-regular">fixed</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and therefore lifting it is akin to finalizing the sale. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if the item’s <span class="gemarra-regular">monetary </span>value is <span class="gemarra-regular">not fixed, it remains in the jurisdiction of its owner, and </span>the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">did well, </span>i.e., was successful, in <span class="gemarra-regular">that he consecrated </span>it.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught: </span>In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who </span>wishes to <span class="gemarra-regular">buy vegetable</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from the market </span>and the seller is an <span class="it-text">am</span> <span class="it-text">ha’aretz</span>, i.e., one who is unreliable with regard to tithes, in which case the buyer is required to separate tithes after his purchase, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he selected </span>superior-quality vegetables from inferior-quality vegetables <span class="gemarra-regular">and place</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> them to the side, as he was considering purchasing them, <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>if he did this <span class="gemarra-regular">all day, </span>if he does not decide to buy the vegetables <span class="gemarra-regular">he does not acquire </span>them <span class="gemarra-regular">and does not become obligated in </span>separating <span class="gemarra-regular">tithes.</span>
If <span class="gemarra-regular">he had determined to buy </span>the vegetables he selected, <span class="gemarra-regular">he acquires </span>them <span class="gemarra-regular">and becomes obligated in </span>separating <span class="gemarra-regular">tithes. </span>In such a case, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is not possible </span>for him to decide to not buy the vegetables and <span class="gemarra-regular">to return </span>them to the seller in their present state, <span class="gemarra-regular">as they have already became obligated in tithes, and, </span>likewise, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is not possible to tithe them </span>and return them to the seller, <span class="gemarra-regular">as he would then lower their monetary </span>value. <span class="gemarra-regular">How </span>should he proceed? <span class="gemarra-regular">He </span>should <span class="gemarra-regular">tithe </span>the produce, give the tithes to an appropriate recipient, <span class="gemarra-regular">and give </span>the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">money </span>in exchange for the <span class="gemarra-regular">tithes </span>that he separated from it.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Is that to say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">because one determined to buy </span>the produce, even though he says nothing and performs no act of acquisition, <span class="gemarra-regular">he acquires </span>the produce <span class="gemarra-regular">and becomes obligated in tithes</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rav Hoshaya said: Here, we are dealing with </span>a buyer who is <span class="gemarra-regular">God-fearing, such as Rav Safra</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> who <span class="gemarra-regular">himself fulfilled </span>the verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And speaks truth in his heart” </span>(Psalms 15:2). With regard to business matters Rav Safra considered himself bound by his thoughts at the time of negotiations, even if he did not express them verbally or perform any action (see <span class="it-text">Makkot</span> 24a). A person on the ethical level of Rav Safra acquires the produce and becomes obligated to separate tithes from the moment that he decides to buy it.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">A wholesaler [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">hassiton</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">must clean his measuring </span>vessels, which are used for measuring liquids such as oil and wine, <span class="gemarra-regular">once every thirty days, </span>because the residue of the liquids sticks to the measure and reduces its capacity. <span class="gemarra-regular">And a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">homeowne</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> who sells his goods must clean his measuring vessels only <span class="gemarra-regular">once every twelve months. Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: The matters are </span><span class="gemarra-regular">reversed</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> In the case of one who is constantly using his vessels for selling merchandise the residue does not adhere to the measuring vessel, and therefore a wholesaler must clean his measures only once a year. But in the case of a homeowner, who does not sell as often, the residue adheres to the measuring vessel; therefore, he must clean them every thirty days.
<span class="gemarra-regular">A storekeeper</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> who constantly sells merchandise in small quantities, <span class="gemarra-regular">cleans his measuring </span>vessels <span class="gemarra-regular">twice a week and cleans his weights once a week; and he cleans </span>the pans of <span class="gemarra-regular">his scale</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> after each and every weighing</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>to ensure that no merchandise has adhered to the pans, thereby increasing their weight. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel said: In what </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">is this statement, </span>that it is necessary to clean a measuring vessel, <span class="gemarra-regular">said? With regard to moist </span>items, which are likely to adhere to the measuring vessels. <span class="gemarra-regular">But with regard to dry </span>goods, which do not adhere to the measuring vessels, one <span class="gemarra-regular">does not nee</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> to clean his measuring vessels.

<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>before adding the weights and merchandise the seller is <span class="gemarra-regular">obligated to let </span>the pans of the scale that will hold the merchandise <span class="gemarra-regular">tilt </span>an extra <span class="gemarra-regular">handbreadt</span><span class="gemarra-regular">h</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for </span>the buyer by adding a weight to that side. If the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">weighed for him exactly, </span>i.e., with the scales equally balanced initially, instead of allowing the scales to tilt an extra handbreadth, <span class="gemarra-regular">he must give </span>the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">additional amounts [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">geirumin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> an additional <span class="gemarra-regular">one-tenth in </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">liquids </span>sold by weight, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>an additional <span class="gemarra-regular">one-twentieth in </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">dry </span>goods.
The mishna continues to discuss the correct method of weighing: In <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">place where they were accustome</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to measure </span>merchandise in several stages <span class="gemarra-regular">with a small </span>measuring vessel, <span class="gemarra-regular">one may not measure </span>all the items at once <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>a single <span class="gemarra-regular">large </span>measuring vessel. In a place where they measure <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">large </span>measuring vessel, <span class="gemarra-regular">one may not measure with </span>several <span class="gemarra-regular">small </span>measuring vessels. In a place where the custom is <span class="gemarra-regular">to leve</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span> the top of the measuring vessel to remove substances heaped above its edges, <span class="gemarra-regular">one may not heap </span>it, and where the custom is <span class="gemarra-regular">to heap </span>it, <span class="gemarra-regular">one may not level </span>it.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">From where are these matters, </span>that the seller must initially let the scales tilt an extra handbreadth, <span class="gemarra-regular">derived? Reish Lakish said: </span>The source is <span class="gemarra-regular">that the verse states </span>that one should have: <span class="gemarra-regular">“A perfect and just [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">tzedek</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] weight” </span>(Deuteronomy 25:15), which is interpreted as an instruction to the seller: <span class="gemarra-regular">Be righteous [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">tzaddek</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] with that which is yours and give it to </span>the buyer. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If that is so, say the latter clause: </span>If the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">weighed for him exactly, he gives </span>the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">additional amounts. But if letting </span>the scales <span class="gemarra-regular">tilt </span>is obligatory <span class="gemarra-regular">by Torah law, how can he </span>originally <span class="gemarra-regular">give him </span>by weighing <span class="gemarra-regular">exactly?</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>it is not obligatory to let the scales tilt, and <span class="gemarra-regular">the first clause </span>is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to a place where they are accustomed </span>to let the scales tilt an extra handbreadth. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if </span>the statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Reish Lakish was stated, </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">was stated with regard to the latter clause: </span>If the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">weighed for him exactly, he gives </span>the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">additional amounts. From where is this matter </span>derived? <span class="gemarra-regular">Reish Lakish said </span>that this is <span class="gemarra-regular">as the verse states: “And just [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">tzedek</span><span class="gemarra-regular">],” </span>which indicates: <span class="gemarra-regular">Be righteous [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">tzaddek</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with that which is yours and give it to </span>the buyer. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And how much </span>are the <span class="gemarra-regular">additional amounts </span>that are given? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Abba bar Memel says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: In </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">liquids, one-tenth of a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">litr</span><span class="gemarra-italic">a</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>every <span class="gemarra-regular">ten </span><span class="gemarra-italic">litra</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>i.e., one-hundredth.
The mishna teaches that the seller adds <span class="gemarra-regular">one-tenth in </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">liquids, and one-twentieth for dry </span>goods. <span class="gemarra-regular">A dilemma was raised before </span>the Sages: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> of the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">speaking? </span>Does he mean <span class="gemarra-regular">one-tenth in </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">liquids for </span>every <span class="gemarra-regular">ten </span>units <span class="gemarra-regular">of liquid, and </span>similarly <span class="gemarra-regular">one-twentieth in </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">dry </span>goods <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>every <span class="gemarra-regular">twenty </span>units <span class="gemarra-regular">of dry </span>goods, i.e., one four-hundredth? <span class="gemarra-regular">Or perhaps, </span>he means <span class="gemarra-regular">one-tenth for </span>every <span class="gemarra-regular">ten </span>units <span class="gemarra-regular">of liquid, and </span>similarly one-tenth <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>every <span class="gemarra-regular">twenty </span>units <span class="gemarra-regular">of dry </span>goods, i.e., one two- hundredth? The Gemara states that the dilemma <span class="gemarra-regular">shall stand </span>unresolved.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Levi says: The punishment for </span>using false <span class="gemarra-regular">measures is more severe than the punishment for </span>transgressing the prohibition of <span class="gemarra-regular">forbidden sexual relations. As </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>case, forbidden relations, it <span class="gemarra-regular">is stated with regard to them </span>a shortened term for the word “these”: <span class="gemarra-regular">“</span><span class="gemarra-italic">El</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,”</span> in the verse: “For all these [<span class="it-text">el </span>] abominations” (Leviticus 18:27). <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>case, false measures, it <span class="gemarra-regular">is stated </span>an expanded term for the word “these”: <span class="gemarra-regular">“</span><span class="gemarra-italic">Elleh</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,” </span>in the verse: “For all that do these [<span class="it-text">elleh</span>] things, even all that do unrighteously, are an abomination unto the Lord your God” (Deuteronomy 25:16). <span class="gemarra-regular">And from where may it be inferred that this </span>expression <span class="gemarra-regular">“</span><span class="gemarra-italic">el</span><span class="gemarra-regular">”</span> indicates that the prohibition <span class="gemarra-regular">is severe, </span>based on which it is understood that the form this word takes indicates a level of severity? <span class="gemarra-regular">As it is written: “And the mighty [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">eilei</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] of the land he took away” </span>(Ezekiel 17:13).
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But with regard to forbidden relations isn’t it also written: </span>“For whosoever shall do any of <span class="gemarra-regular">these [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">elleh</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] </span>abominations” (Leviticus 18:29)? If so, why is the punishment for using false measures considered harsher? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">That </span>expression of “<span class="it-text">elleh</span>” (Leviticus 18:29) in the context of forbidden relations does not serve to emphasize its severity. Rather, it serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to exclude </span>one who uses deception in <span class="gemarra-regular">measures from </span>the penalty of <span class="gemarra-regular">excision from the World-to-Come [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">karet</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if the punishment is in fact less severe, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is the advantage, </span>i.e., the greater severity, in the case of false measures? The Gemara answers <span class="gemarra-regular">that there,</span> in the case of one who engages in forbidden relations, <span class="gemarra-regular">he has the possibility of repentance</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> But here, </span>in the case of one who uses false measures, <span class="gemarra-regular">there is no possibility of repentanc</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> because he has no way of knowing whom he cheated, and is therefore unable to return the stolen money.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Levi says: Robbing an ordinary </span>person <span class="gemarra-regular">is more severe than robbing the Most High, </span>i.e., taking consecrated property. <span class="gemarra-regular">As </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>regular robber, the verse states <span class="gemarra-regular">“sin” before “</span><span class="gemarra-italic">me</span><span class="gemarra-italic">’ila</span><span class="gemarra-regular">”</span><span class="gemarra-regular">:</span> “If any one sin, and commit a trespass [<span class="it-text">me’ila</span>] against the Lord, and deal falsely with his neighbor in a matter of deposit, or of pledge, or of robbery, or have oppressed his neighbor” (Leviticus 5:21). <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>one who misuses consecrated items, the verse states <span class="gemarra-italic">me’ila</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> before sin: </span>“If any one engages in misuse [<span class="it-text">timol</span> <span class="it-text">ma’al</span>] and sins unwittingly” (Leviticus 5:15).
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Levi says: Come and see that the attribute of flesh and blood is unlike the attribute of the Holy One, Blessed be He. The Holy One, Blessed be He, blessed the Jewish people with twenty-two, and cursed them with </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">eight. </span>Rabbi Levi explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">He blessed them with </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">twenty-two </span>letters of the Hebrew alphabet, <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the first letter, <span class="it-text">alef</span>, that begins the verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“If [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">im</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] you </span>walk <span class="gemarra-regular">in My statutes” </span>(Leviticus 26:3), <span class="gemarra-regular">until “upright [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">komemiyyut</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]” </span>(Leviticus 26:13), which ends with the letter <span class="it-text">tav</span>, the last letter of the Hebrew alphabet.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And He cursed them with eight </span>letters, <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the letter <span class="it-text">vav</span> that begins the verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And if [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ve’im</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] you shall reject My statutes” </span>(Leviticus 26:15), <span class="gemarra-regular">until: “And My statutes were abhorred by their soul [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">nafsham</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]” </span>(Leviticus 26:43), which ends with the letter <span class="it-text">mem</span>. There are eight letters in the Hebrew alphabet from the letter <span class="it-text">vav</span> to the letter <span class="it-text">mem</span>, inclusive.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And yet Moses, our teacher, </span>who is flesh and blood, <span class="gemarra-regular">blessed them with eight </span>letters, <span class="gemarra-regular">and cursed them with twenty-two. He blessed them with eight </span>letters,

<span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the letter <span class="it-text">vav</span> that begins the verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And it shall come to pass [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">vehaya</span><span class="gemarra-regular">], if you shall hearken diligently” </span>(Deuteronomy 28:1), <span class="gemarra-regular">until: “To serve them [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">le’ovdam</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]” </span>(Deuteronomy 28:14), which ends with the letter <span class="it-text">mem</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">And he cursed them with twenty-two </span>letters, <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the letter <span class="it-text">vav</span> that begins the verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“But it shall come to pass [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">vehaya</span><span class="gemarra-regular">], if you will not hearken </span>to the voice of the Lord” (Deuteronomy 28:15), <span class="gemarra-regular">until: “And no man shall buy [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">koneh</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]” </span>(Deuteronomy 28:68). This verse ends with a letter <span class="it-text">heh</span>, which comes just before <span class="it-text">vav</span> in the alphabet. Starting with a <span class="it-text">vav</span> and ending with a <span class="it-text">heh</span> encompasses the twenty-two letters of the alphabet.
§ The mishna teaches that <span class="gemarra-regular">in a place where they were accustomed to measure with </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">large </span>measuring vessel, one may not measure with several small measuring vessels. In a place where the custom is to level the top of the measuring vessel to remove substances heaped above its edges, one may not heap it; and where they are accustomed to heap it, one may not level it. The Gemara provides <span class="gemarra-regular">a mnemonic </span>for the ensuing <span class="it-text">halakhot</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">One may not balance with precision; and one may not heap </span>it; <span class="gemarra-regular">with market inspectors [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ba’agardamin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and with a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">litra</span><span class="gemarra-regular">; three; and ten; fulcrum; weights; a thick leveler; you may not do; one may not do.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught: From where </span>is it derived <span class="gemarra-regular">that one may not leve</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span> a measuring vessel <span class="gemarra-regular">in a place where they </span>are accustomed to <span class="gemarra-regular">heap </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">one may not heap </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">in a place where they </span>are accustomed to <span class="gemarra-regular">level </span>it? <span class="gemarra-regular">The verse states: “A perfect weight” </span>(Deuteronomy 25:15), which indicates that one must use whatever is considered a perfect measuring vessel in that locale, as this ensures that there is no deception or trickery.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And from where </span>is it derived <span class="gemarra-regular">that if </span>the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">said in a place where they heap</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">I am hereby levelin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>am willing in exchange <span class="gemarra-regular">to reduce the price for </span>you, or said, <span class="gemarra-regular">in a place where they level: I am hereby heaping and </span>am willing <span class="gemarra-regular">to increase the price for </span>you, <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the court <span class="gemarra-regular">does not listen to him? The verse states: “A perfect and just weigh</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> you shall have” </span>(Deuteronomy 25:15). The addition of the term “just,” beyond the requirement that the weight be “perfect,” teaches that one must keep his weights in a just manner, i.e., that employed by the people of that locale.
<span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught: From where </span>is it derived <span class="gemarra-regular">that one may not </span>balance a scale so that it will <span class="gemarra-regular">balance with precision [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">me’ayyenin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in a place where they </span>are accustomed to <span class="gemarra-regular">let </span>the scales <span class="gemarra-regular">tilt </span>a handbreadth for the benefit of the buyer, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">one may not let </span>the scales <span class="gemarra-regular">tilt </span>a handbreadth <span class="gemarra-regular">in a place where they </span>are accustomed to <span class="gemarra-regular">balance with precision? The verse states: “A perfect weight” </span>(Deuteronomy 25:15), which teaches that the weight must be considered perfect in that locale.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And from where </span>is it derived <span class="gemarra-regular">that if </span>a seller <span class="gemarra-regular">said, in a place where </span>it is the custom to <span class="gemarra-regular">let </span>the scales <span class="gemarra-regular">tilt </span>a handbreadth: <span class="gemarra-regular">I am hereby balancing with precision</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>am willing <span class="gemarra-regular">to reduce the price for </span>the buyer; <span class="gemarra-regular">or, in a place where </span>it is the custom to <span class="gemarra-regular">balance with precision: I am hereby letting </span>the scales <span class="gemarra-regular">tilt </span>a handbreadth <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>am willing <span class="gemarra-regular">to increase the price for </span>the buyer, <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the court <span class="gemarra-regular">does not listen to him? The verse states: “A perfect and just weight”</span> (Deuteronomy 25:15), which teaches that the just way of acting is to weigh in accordance with the practice in that locale.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda of Sura says </span>a homiletic interpretation of the phrase: “You shall not have in your house diverse measures” (Deuteronomy 25:14): <span class="gemarra-regular">“You shall not have in your house” </span>means that you will become a pauper, who has nothing in his house. <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>for this? It is <span class="gemarra-regular">due to </span>the fact that you used <span class="gemarra-regular">diverse measures, </span>buying with a large vessel and selling with a small one.
The phrase: “You shall not have in your purse diverse weights” (Deuteronomy 25:13), is interpreted in a similar fashion: <span class="gemarra-regular">“You shall not have in your purse,” </span>i.e., you will become a pauper, who has nothing in his purse. <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>for this? It is <span class="gemarra-regular">due to </span>the fact that you used <span class="gemarra-regular">diverse weights. But </span>if you possess only <span class="gemarra-regular">“a perfect and just weight,” </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">“you shall have” </span>wealth. Likewise, if you possess only <span class="gemarra-regular">“a perfect and just measure,” </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">“you shall have” </span>wealth.
