§ <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>that the phrase: <span class="gemarra-regular">“You shall not have,” teaches that </span>the court <span class="gemarra-regular">appoints market inspectors to </span>supervise the accuracy of <span class="gemarra-regular">measures</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> The Gemara infers: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>the court <span class="gemarra-regular">does not appoint market inspectors for </span>supervising market <span class="gemarra-regular">prices</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> The Gemara relates: <span class="gemarra-regular">The house of the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">Nasi</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> appointed market inspectors for </span>supervising <span class="gemarra-regular">both measures and prices. Shmuel said to </span>his student, the Sage <span class="gemarra-regular">Karna</span><span class="gemarra-regular">:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Go out </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">teach them </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">one appoints market inspectors for </span>supervising <span class="gemarra-regular">measures but one does not appoint market inspectors for prices.</span>
Karna <span class="gemarra-regular">went out </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">taught them </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">one appoints market inspectors for </span>supervising <span class="gemarra-regular">both measures and prices. </span>Shmuel, hearing what he had done, <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: What is your name? </span>He replied: <span class="gemarra-regular">Karna. </span>Shmuel said: <span class="gemarra-regular">Let a horn [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">karna</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] emerge in his eye. A horn, </span>i.e., a growth of flesh, <span class="gemarra-regular">emerged in his eye. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>Karna, <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with whose </span>opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">did he hold, </span>which led him to disregard his teacher’s statement? He held <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with that which Rami bar Ḥama says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yitzḥak says: One appoints market inspectors for </span>supervising <span class="gemarra-regular">both measures and prices</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> due to swindlers</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> to prevent people from using smaller measures or from selling at a steep price while falsely claiming that they are selling superior-quality merchandise.
The Gemara discusses several <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> related to the cases of the mishna. <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught: </span>If the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">requested from </span>the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">litra</span> of a specific item, <span class="gemarra-regular">he weighs for him </span>using <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">litra</span> weight. If he asks for <span class="gemarra-regular">half a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">litra</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, he weighs for him using a half-</span><span class="gemarra-italic">litra</span> weight. If he wants <span class="gemarra-regular">one-quarter </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">litra</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, he weighs for him </span>using <span class="gemarra-regular">a quarter</span>-<span class="gemarra-italic">litra</span> weight. The Gemara asks: Isn’t this obvious? <span class="gemarra-regular">What is </span>this <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">teaching us? </span>The Gemara explains: It teaches <span class="gemarra-regular">that one sets weight</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> until this </span>amount, one-quarter of a <span class="it-text">litra</span>, but not less. If a buyer asks the seller to weigh a smaller amount for him, his request is not granted.
Furthermore, <span class="gemarra-regular">the Sages taught: </span>If the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">requested from him three-quarters </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">litra</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>and there is no weight equal to this amount, the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">may not say to him: Weigh for me three </span>units using <span class="gemarra-regular">a quarter-</span><span class="gemarra-italic">litr</span><span class="gemarra-italic">a</span> weight, <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>by <span class="gemarra-regular">one, </span>so that the seller lets the scales tilt by a handbreadth as he measures each quarter-<span class="it-text">litra</span> weight. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, he weighs </span>the merchandise all at once, as he places <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">litra</span> weight on one pan of the scale, and <span class="gemarra-regular">places </span>on the other pan of the scale <span class="gemarra-regular">a quarter-</span><span class="gemarra-italic">litra</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> weight </span>together <span class="gemarra-regular">with the meat </span>that is being sold.
<span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages </span>likewise <span class="gemarra-regular">taught: </span>In a case where the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">requested from </span>the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">ten </span><span class="gemarra-italic">litra</span> of merchandise, the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">may not say to him: Weigh for me </span>each <span class="it-text">litra</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>by <span class="gemarra-regular">one, and let </span>the scales <span class="gemarra-regular">tilt </span>each time, as on every occasion that the seller does this the buyer receives more than that for which he paid. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, he weighs all </span>the merchandise <span class="gemarra-regular">at the same tim</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and lets </span>the scales <span class="gemarra-regular">tilt once for all </span>the merchandise.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught: The fulcrum of a scal</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> must be <span class="gemarra-regular">suspen-ded in the ai</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> so that the point the lever goes through it is at a distance of <span class="gemarra-regular">three handbreadths </span>from the ceiling, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the pans of the scale must be <span class="gemarra-regular">three handbreadths above the ground. And </span>the scale’s <span class="gemarra-regular">lever and cord</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> from which each pan is suspended, must be <span class="gemarra-regular">twelve handbreadths </span>long. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the fulcrum of a scale <span class="gemarra-regular">of wool-weavers and glassmaker</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> must be <span class="gemarra-regular">suspended in the air </span>at a distance of <span class="gemarra-regular">two handbreadths </span>from the ceiling, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the pans of the scale must be <span class="gemarra-regular">two handbreadths above the ground. And its lever and cord </span>must be <span class="gemarra-regular">nine handbreadths </span>long.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the fulcrum of a scale <span class="gemarra-regular">of a storekeeper and of a homeowne</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> must be <span class="gemarra-regular">suspended in the air </span>at a distance of <span class="gemarra-regular">one handbreadth </span>from the ceiling, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the pans of the scale must be <span class="gemarra-regular">one handbreadth above the ground. And its lever and cord </span>must be <span class="gemarra-regular">six handbreadths long. And </span>the fulcrums of small <span class="gemarra-regular">scales [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">turtanei</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> used for weighing gold and silver must be <span class="gemarra-regular">suspended in the air </span>at a distance of <span class="gemarra-regular">three fingerbreadths </span>from the ceiling, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the pans of the scales must be <span class="gemarra-regular">three fingerbreadths above the ground. </span>The <span class="it-text">tanna</span> continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">its lever and cord, I do not know </span>their required length.
Since the function of each type of balance scale is mentioned with the exception of the first type, the Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And that </span>large balance scale, which is mentioned <span class="gemarra-regular">first, for what </span>is it used? 

Daf 89b

<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa says: </span>It is a balance scale <span class="gemarra-regular">for blacksmiths</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> who weigh heavy pieces of metal.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Mani Bar Pattish says: Just as </span>the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">said with regard to the prohibition of </span>the scales that one may not use a scale that does not meet the criteria listed in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">so </span>too <span class="gemarra-regular">they said </span>that this applies <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to their ritual impurity</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> In other words, if the cords and pole are not attached in the proper manner, they are not susceptible to ritual impurity as part of the scale.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is </span>this statement <span class="gemarra-regular">teaching us? We learned </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Kelim</span> 29:5): With regard to the <span class="gemarra-regular">rope </span>from which the <span class="gemarra-regular">scales </span>are suspended, if the balance scale belongs <span class="gemarra-regular">to a storekeeper or to homeowners </span>it must be <span class="gemarra-regular">one handbreadth </span>in length for it to be susceptible to ritual impurity. Why, then, is the statement of Rabbi Mani Bar Pattish necessary? The Gemara answers: Although the mishna in tractate <span class="it-text">Kelim</span> discusses the rope from which the scales are suspended, <span class="gemarra-regular">it was </span>still <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary for </span>Rabbi Mani Bar Pattish to mention the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to the scale’s <span class="gemarra-regular">lever and cord, which we did not learn about </span>in that mishna.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught: One may not prepare weights of tin [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ba’atz</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> nor of lead, nor of a metal alloy </span><span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">gisteron</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> nor of any other types of metal</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> because all of these deteriorate over time and the buyer will ultimately pay for more merchandise than he receives. <span class="gemarra-regular">But one </span>may <span class="gemarra-regular">prepare </span>weights <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span>hard <span class="gemarra-regular">rock and of glass.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages </span>further <span class="gemarra-regular">taught: One may not prepare the leveler, </span>used to remove the excess from the mouth of a vessel, <span class="gemarra-regular">from a gourd, because it is a light </span>material and does not level effectively, thereby causing a loss for the seller. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>it may <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>be made <span class="gemarra-regular">of metal</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> because it weighs dow</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> and removes too much of the merchandise, leading to a loss for the buyer. <span class="gemarra-regular">But one </span>may <span class="gemarra-regular">prepare it from </span>the wood <span class="gemarra-regular">of an olive</span> tree, <span class="gemarra-regular">or of a nut </span>tree, or <span class="gemarra-regular">of a sycamore </span>tree, <span class="gemarra-regular">or </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of a boxwood </span>tree,which are of medium weight.
<span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught: One may not prepare the leveler </span>in such a manner that <span class="gemarra-regular">one of its sides is thick and one </span>other <span class="gemarra-regular">side is thin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> because in such a case the two sides will not level equally. Furthermore, <span class="gemarra-regular">one may not level all at once</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> by a single quick movement, <span class="gemarra-regular">as one who levels all at once </span>acts in a manner that is <span class="gemarra-regular">bad for the seller and good for the buyer, </span>because he removes less of the excess than one who levels in the regular fashion. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>conversely <span class="gemarra-regular">one may not level little by little, </span>i.e., with several slow movements, <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>this is <span class="gemarra-regular">bad for the buyer and good for the seller.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabban Yoḥanan ben Zakkai said with regard to all </span>these <span class="it-text">halakhot</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Woe to me if I say </span>them, and <span class="gemarra-regular">woe unto me if I do not say </span>them. <span class="gemarra-regular">If I say </span>them, <span class="gemarra-regular">perhaps swindlers will learn </span>new methods of cheating of which they were previously unaware. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if I do not say </span>them, <span class="gemarra-regular">perhaps swindlers will say</span><span class="gemarra-regular">:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Torah scholars are not well versed in our handiwork. A dilemma was raised before </span>the Sages: <span class="gemarra-regular">Did </span>Rabban Yoḥanan ben Zakkai decide to <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>these <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> in public <span class="gemarra-regular">or did he not say </span>them? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Shmuel bar Rav Yitzḥak says: He said them, and he said them on </span>the basis of <span class="gemarra-regular">this verse: “For the ways of the Lord are right, and the just walk in them; but transgressors stumble over them” </span>(Hosea 14:10).
§ The Gemara further discusses weights and measures. <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught: “You shall do no unrighteousness in judgment, in measure [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">bammidda</span><span class="gemarra-regular">], in weight, or in measure [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">uvamesura</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]” </span>(Leviticus 19:35). The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> defines these terms: <span class="gemarra-regular">“In measure [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">bammidda</span><span class="gemarra-regular">],” this </span>is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">measuring land</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> teaching <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>in order to measure land in a just manner <span class="gemarra-regular">one may not measure for one </span>person <span class="gemarra-regular">in the summe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> when the measuring rope has become dry and short, <span class="gemarra-regular">and for one </span>other individual <span class="gemarra-regular">in the rainy season, </span>when the measuring rope is wet and limp, and therefore stretches more. <span class="gemarra-regular">“In weight” </span>means <span class="gemarra-regular">that one may not cover his weight</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in salt</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as salt erodes the weights, causing a loss for the buyer. <span class="gemarra-regular">“Or in measure [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">bamesura</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]” </span>means <span class="gemarra-regular">that one may not cause </span>liquid he is measuring <span class="gemarra-regular">to foa</span><span class="gemarra-regular">m</span> by pouring it speedily, as this results in a loss for the buyer, who receives less of the liquid than the amount for which he paid.
The Gemara notes: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>it can be inferred by means of an <span class="gemarra-italic">a</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">fortiori</span> inference <span class="gemarra-regular">that if</span> in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">mesura</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, which is </span>a measure equivalent to merely <span class="gemarra-regular">one thirty-sixth of a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">log</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, the Torah was particular that </span>one must measure honestly, so too, <span class="gemarra-italic">a</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">fortiori</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>one must be careful in the case <span class="gemarra-regular">of one </span><span class="gemarra-italic">hin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and a half-</span><span class="gemarra-italic">hin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, and a third-</span><span class="gemarra-italic">hin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, and a quarter-</span><span class="gemarra-italic">hin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> which is twelve <span class="it-text">log</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">and one </span><span class="gemarra-italic">log</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, and a half-</span><span class="gemarra-italic">log</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, and a quarter-</span><span class="gemarra-italic">log</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">and a half-</span><span class="gemarra-italic">tomen</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., one-sixteenth of a <span class="it-text">kav</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>even <span class="gemarra-regular">an </span><span class="gemarra-italic">ukla</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>a smaller unit, as defined below.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: It is prohibited for a person to keep in his house a measure </span>that is <span class="gemarra-regular">too small or too larg</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> than its supposed volume or weight, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>this is the case <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>if he does not measure with it but simply uses <span class="gemarra-regular">it </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">a chamber pot for urine. Rav Pappa said: We said </span>this prohibition <span class="gemarra-regular">only with regard to a place where </span>measures <span class="gemarra-regular">are not stamped </span>with the government’s seal, which confirms that the measure is accurate. <span class="gemarra-regular">But in a place where </span>the measures <span class="gemarra-regular">are stamped, if </span>the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">does not see the seal he would not take </span>the merchandise. Since they could not be used dishonestly, one is permitted to utilize these measures for other purposes. <span class="gemarra-regular">And in a place where </span>measures <span class="gemarra-regular">are not stamped as well</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> we said </span>that it is prohibited to keep these measures in one’s house <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>in a place <span class="gemarra-regular">where they do not inspec</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> measures to see if they are fit for use. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">they do inspect </span>measures, <span class="gemarra-regular">we have no </span>problem <span class="gemarra-regular">with it.</span>
The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">is not so; </span>one is never permitted to keep incorrect measures in his house, as <span class="gemarra-regular">sometimes it happens </span>that one measures <span class="gemarra-regular">at twilight, </span>when people are hurried, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>consequently <span class="gemarra-regular">it happens </span>that the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">takes </span>the merchandise despite the fact that it was measured with an incorrect measure. <span class="gemarra-regular">This is also taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">A person may not keep in his house a measure </span>that is <span class="gemarra-regular">too small or too large, even </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">it </span>is used as <span class="gemarra-regular">a chamber pot for urine. But he </span>may <span class="gemarra-regular">prepare </span>measures in accordance with the established format: Measurements of <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">se’a</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tarkav</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> which is three <span class="it-text">kav</span> or one-half of a <span class="it-text">se’a</span>; <span class="gemarra-regular">and a half-</span><span class="gemarra-italic">tarkav</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>which is one and one-half <span class="it-text">kav</span>; <span class="gemarra-regular">and a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kav</span><span class="gemarra-regular">; and a half-</span><span class="gemarra-italic">kav</span><span class="gemarra-regular">; and a quarter-</span><span class="gemarra-italic">kav</span>; <span class="gemarra-regular">and a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tomen</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>which is one-eighth of a <span class="it-text">kav</span>; <span class="gemarra-regular">and a half-</span><span class="gemarra-italic">tomen</span><span class="gemarra-regular">; </span>

Daf 90a

<span class="gemarra-regular">and an </span><span class="gemarra-italic">ukla</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. And how much is an </span><span class="gemarra-italic">ukla</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">one-fifth of a quarter </span>of a <span class="it-text">kav</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>in the case <span class="gemarra-regular">of liquid measures</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> one </span>may <span class="gemarra-regular">prepare a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">hin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>which is twelve <span class="it-text">log</span>; <span class="gemarra-regular">and a half-</span><span class="gemarra-italic">hin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>or six <span class="it-text">log</span>; <span class="gemarra-regular">and a third</span>-<span class="gemarra-italic">hin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>or four <span class="it-text">log</span>; <span class="gemarra-regular">and a quarter-</span><span class="gemarra-italic">hin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>three <span class="it-text">log</span>; <span class="gemarra-regular">and a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">log</span><span class="gemarra-regular">; and a half</span>-<span class="gemarra-italic">log</span><span class="gemarra-regular">; and a quarter</span>-<span class="it-text">log</span>; <span class="gemarra-regular">and an eighth-</span><span class="it-text">log</span>; <span class="gemarra-regular">and an eighth of an eighth-</span><span class="it-text">log</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">and this, </span>the last mentioned, <span class="gemarra-regular">is a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kortov</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And let one also prepare </span>a measure equal to <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kav</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>The Gemara answers that this measure is not used, lest people <span class="gemarra-regular">come to mistake it for a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tarkav</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>which is three <span class="it-text">kav</span>. The Gemara observes: <span class="gemarra-regular">Apparently, people er</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> by <span class="gemarra-regular">one-third </span>of a measure. <span class="gemarra-regular">If that is so, one should also not prepare </span>a measure equal to <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kav</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as </span>people may <span class="gemarra-regular">come to mistake it for a half-</span><span class="gemarra-italic">tarkav</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>which is equal to one and one-half <span class="it-text">kav</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, this is the reason that one may not prepare a two-</span><span class="gemarra-italic">kav</span> measure: <span class="gemarra-regular">That </span>people might <span class="gemarra-regular">come to mistake it for a half-</span><span class="gemarra-italic">tarkav</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>which is equal to one and one-half <span class="it-text">kav</span>.
The Gemara again suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Apparently, people err </span>by <span class="gemarra-regular">one-quarter </span>of a measure. <span class="gemarra-regular">If that is so, one should also not prepare </span>measures of <span class="gemarra-regular">a half-</span><span class="gemarra-italic">tomen</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>which is one-sixteenth of a <span class="it-text">kav</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">and an </span><span class="gemarra-italic">ukla</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>which is one-twentieth of a <span class="it-text">kav</span>. Since they differ by only one-fifth, there is a concern that people might mistake one measure for the other. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa said: People are well-versed in small measure</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> and can distinguish between them.
The Gemara continues: If people err by one-quarter of a measure, then since one may prepare a measure equal to four <span class="it-text">log</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">one-third of a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">hin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> let one not prepare </span>a measure equal to three <span class="it-text">log</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">one-quarter </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">hin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Since </span>these measures <span class="gemarra-regular">were </span>used <span class="gemarra-regular">in the Temple</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the Sages did not decree </span>that they not be used. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">In the Temple as well, let </span>the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">decre</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> that they should not be used, in case the two measures are mistaken for each other. The Gemara answers: The <span class="gemarra-regular">priests </span>who serve in the Temple <span class="gemarra-regular">are vigilan</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> and would not commit this error.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel says: </span>If the residents of a certain place want to change the standard of their measures and augment them by a certain fraction, <span class="gemarra-regular">they may not increase the measure</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> by <span class="gemarra-regular">more than one-sixth, and </span>they may <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>increase the value of <span class="gemarra-regular">a coin </span>by <span class="gemarra-regular">more than one-sixth </span>of its previous value. <span class="gemarra-regular">And one who profit</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> from his sales <span class="gemarra-regular">may not profit </span>by <span class="gemarra-regular">more than one-sixth. </span>The Gemara analyzes these statements. When Shmuel said: <span class="gemarra-regular">They may not increase the measures </span>by <span class="gemarra-regular">more than one-sixth, what is the reaso</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> for this? <span class="gemarra-regular">If we say </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>doing so causes market <span class="gemarra-regular">prices to rise</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the same concern should apply to raising the prices by <span class="gemarra-regular">one-sixth, </span>and therefore this should <span class="gemarra-regular">also not </span>be allowed.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>you will say that the prohibition is <span class="gemarra-regular">due to </span>concern for <span class="gemarra-regular">exploitation; </span>and they may increase the measures only by up to one-sixth, so <span class="gemarra-regular">that there will not be nullification of the transaction</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as the transaction is nullified only when the disparity is more than one-sixth of the value of the item. The Gemara raises an objection: <span class="gemarra-regular">But doesn’t Rava say: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">any item that </span>is otherwise subject to the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of exploitation, and it is sold <span class="gemarra-regular">by measure, or by weight, or by number</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> even </span>if the disparity was <span class="gemarra-regular">less than the measure of exploitation </span>in the transaction, the transaction is <span class="gemarra-regular">reversed</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> A disparity of one-sixth between the value of an item and its price constitutes exploitation only in cases where there is room for error in assessing the value of an item. In a case where the details of the item are easily quantifiable, any deviation from the designated quantity results in a nullification of the transaction.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>the prohibition is <span class="gemarra-regular">so that there will not be a loss </span>suffered <span class="gemarra-regular">by the merchant, </span>who might not realize that a new standard was issued, and sell in accordance with the old standard. Since a merchant usually enjoys a profit of one-sixth of the value of an item, if the standard is not increased by more than this amount he will not suffer a loss, as at worst he will forfeit his profit margin.
This Gemara notes: This explanation is also difficult, since even if the aim is to ensure <span class="gemarra-regular">that there will not be a loss </span>for the merchant, <span class="gemarra-regular">does he not need </span>to earn <span class="gemarra-regular">a profit? </span>There is a well-known adage in this regard: If you <span class="gemarra-regular">buy and sell </span>without making any profit, <span class="gemarra-regular">will </span>you <span class="gemarra-regular">be called a merchant? </span>A merchant must profit from his sales; therefore, if this decree was instituted for the protection of merchants, the Sages should have ensured that they earn a profit.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Rav Ḥisda said: </span>The prohibition is not based on logical reasoning. Instead, <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel found a vers</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and interpreted it homiletically: “And the shekel shall be twenty </span><span class="gemarra-italic">gera</span><span class="gemarra-regular">; twenty shekels, five and twenty shekels, ten, and five shekels, shall be your </span><span class="gemarra-italic">maneh</span><span class="gemarra-regular">” </span>(Ezekiel 45:12). According to this verse, the combination of all of these numbers, sixty shekels, is equivalent to a <span class="it-text">maneh</span>. 

Daf 90b

This is problematic: How can <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">maneh</span> consist of sixty shekels? Since each biblical shekel is equivalent to four dinars, if a <span class="it-text">maneh</span> is equal to sixty shekels, a <span class="it-text">maneh</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is two hundred and forty</span> dinars. But a <span class="it-text">maneh</span> is actually equal to twenty-five shekels, which is one hundred dinars. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>one can <span class="gemarra-regular">learn from </span>the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">three </span>matters: <span class="gemarra-regular">Learn from it </span>that the <span class="gemarra-regular">sacred </span><span class="gemarra-italic">maneh</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> was doubled</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> so that it equaled fifty dinars, not twenty-five. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>furthermore, as Ezekiel stated that the <span class="it-text">maneh</span> will be sixty dinars, not fifty, <span class="gemarra-regular">learn from it </span>that a community may <span class="gemarra-regular">increase measures, but they may not increase </span>them by <span class="gemarra-regular">more than one-sixth</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> And learn from it </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the one-sixth </span>is calculated <span class="gemarra-regular">from the outside, </span>i.e., it is one-sixth of the final sum, which is one-fifth of the previous sum.
The Gemara relates: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa bar Shmuel instituted </span>a new <span class="gemarra-regular">measure of three </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kefiza</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> which is equal to three <span class="it-text">log</span>. The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: But doesn’t Shmuel say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">one may not increase the measures </span>by <span class="gemarra-regular">more than one-sixth? </span>You have added one-third, as there already exists a measure of a half-kav, which is the equivalent of two <span class="it-text">log</span>. Rav Pappa bar Shmuel <span class="gemarra-regular">said to them: I instituted a new measure</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> He <span class="gemarra-regular">sent </span>the measure <span class="gemarra-regular">to Pumbedita, and they did not accept it; he sent it to </span>the city of <span class="gemarra-regular">Paphunya, and they accepted it and called it the measur</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">Pappa.</span>
§ The Gemara provides <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">mnemonic </span>for the ensuing discussions: <span class="gemarra-regular">Hoarders of produce; one may not hoard; and one may not export; and one may not earn </span>a profit; <span class="gemarra-regular">twice </span>from the sale <span class="gemarra-regular">of eggs; </span>they <span class="gemarra-regular">sound the alarm; and one may not leave.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught: Hoarders of produce, </span>who drive up prices by causing a shortage of available goods, <span class="gemarra-regular">and usurers, and those </span>sellers <span class="gemarra-regular">who </span>falsely <span class="gemarra-regular">reduce </span>their <span class="gemarra-regular">measures, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and those who raise </span>market <span class="gemarra-regular">price</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> by selling for more than the accepted price, <span class="gemarra-regular">about them the verse states: </span>“You that would swallow the needy and destroy the poor of the land, <span class="gemarra-regular">saying: When will the new moon be gone, that we may sell produce? And the Shabbat, that we may set forth grain? Making the measure small, and the shekel great, and falsifying the balances of deceit” </span>(Amos 8:4–5). <span class="gemarra-regular">And it is written:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> “The Lord has sworn by the pride of Jacob: Surely I will never forget any of their works” </span>(Amos 8:7).
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Hoarders of produce, such as whom? Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Such as Shabbtai, the hoarder of produce, </span>who would buy and hoard large amounts of produce and later sell it at a high price.
The Gemara relates: <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel’s father would sell produce during </span>the period of the <span class="gemarra-regular">early </span>market <span class="gemarra-regular">price</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> when produce is cheap, <span class="gemarra-regular">for the early </span>market <span class="gemarra-regular">price. His son Shmuel </span>acted differently, and <span class="gemarra-regular">would keep the produc</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and sell it during </span>the period of the <span class="gemarra-regular">late </span>market <span class="gemarra-regular">price, </span>when produce is expensive, <span class="gemarra-regular">for the early </span>market <span class="gemarra-regular">price. They sent </span>a message <span class="gemarra-regular">from there, </span>Eretz Yisrael: The practice <span class="gemarra-regular">of the father is better than </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">of the son. What is the reason </span>for this? A market <span class="gemarra-regular">price that </span>has been <span class="gemarra-regular">ease</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> and starts out low will remain <span class="gemarra-regular">eased, </span>with little increase over the course of the year. Therefore, one who makes produce available at the beginning of the season, like Shmuel’s father, aids people during the entire year. By contrast, a market price that starts out high, because people are not making their produce available at the market, is not easily lowered.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: A person may turn his </span>own <span class="gemarra-italic">kav</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> into a storeroom</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., he may hoard the produce of his own field and sell it only at a later stage, without violating the prohibition of hoarding produce. <span class="gemarra-regular">This is also taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">One may not hoar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> produce </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">items that contain </span>an element of basic <span class="gemarra-regular">sustenance, such as wines, oils, and flours, but </span>in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">spices, </span>such as <span class="gemarra-regular">cumin and pepper, it is permitted. In what </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">is this statement said? </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to one who buys </span>that produce <span class="gemarra-regular">from the market </span>to resell later; <span class="gemarra-regular">but with regard to one who brings in </span>produce <span class="gemarra-regular">from his </span>own field, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is permitted </span>for any type of produce.
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">And it is permitted for a person to hoard produce in Eretz Yisrael </span>for these <span class="gemarra-regular">three years: The year preceding the Sabbatical </span>Year, <span class="gemarra-regular">the Sabbatical </span>Year, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the year that follows the Sabbatical </span>Year, because the land lies fallow during the seventh year, the Sabbatical Year, and the produce of the sixth year must last through these three years, until near the end of the eighth year.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And in years of drough</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> one may not hoard even a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kav</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of carobs, because </span>he thereby <span class="gemarra-regular">brings a curse on </span>market <span class="gemarra-regular">prices, </span>as everyone is fearful of selling and even a small fluctuation in supply can cause a significant rise in prices. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, </span>who was living in Eretz Yisrael, <span class="gemarra-regular">said to his servant Fuga: Go </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hoard produce for me </span>for the coming <span class="gemarra-regular">three years</span><span class="gemarra-regular">:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> The year preceding the Sabbatical </span>Year, <span class="gemarra-regular">the Sabbatical </span>Year, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the year that follows the Sabbatical </span>Year.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught: One may not export produce from Eretz Yisrae</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span> if it consists of <span class="gemarra-regular">items that contain </span>an element of basic <span class="gemarra-regular">sustenance, such as wines, oils, and flours, </span>because this causes them to become more expensive in Eretz Yisrael. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda ben Beteira permits </span>export <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">wine, because </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">lessens licentiousness </span>in Eretz Yisrael. <span class="gemarra-regular">And just as one may not export </span>these types of produce <span class="gemarra-regular">from Eretz </span>Yisrael <span class="gemarra-regular">to outside </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">Eretz </span>Yisrael, <span class="gemarra-regular">so </span>too <span class="gemarra-regular">one may not export </span>them <span class="gemarra-regular">from Eretz Yisrael to Syria</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as Syria is not considered part of Eretz Yisrael in this context. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">permits </span>the export of produce

Daf 91a

<span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the northernmost <span class="gemarra-regular">province [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">mehiparkheya</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> of Eretz Yisrael <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the southernmost <span class="gemarra-regular">provinc</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> of Syria.
<span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught: One may not earn </span>a profit <span class="gemarra-regular">in Eretz Yisrae</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> by </span>buying and reselling <span class="gemarra-regular">items that contain </span>an element of basic <span class="gemarra-regular">sustenance, such as wines, oils, and flours, </span>because this causes their price to rise. Rather, those who grow the produce should sell them in the markets, without recourse to a middleman.
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">said of Rabbi Elazar ben Azary</span><span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that he would earn </span>a profit <span class="gemarra-regular">through </span>the sale of <span class="gemarra-regular">wine and oil. With regard to wine, he holds in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda </span>ben Beteira, who says that it is permitted to export wine from Eretz Yisrael despite the fact that this causes it to become more expensive, as drinking wine leads to licentiousness. <span class="gemarra-regular">With regard to oil, in Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya’s locale oil was common; </span>consequently, there was no concern that its price would rise if it were not sold directly to the consumer.
<span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught: One may not earn </span>a profit <span class="gemarra-regular">twice </span>from the sale <span class="gemarra-regular">of eggs</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Mari bar Mari said: Rav and Shmuel disagree </span>about the meaning of <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>statement. <span class="gemarra-regular">One said </span>it means that the seller may not charge <span class="gemarra-regular">doubl</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> the price he paid for the eggs. <span class="gemarra-regular">And one said </span>that one <span class="gemarra-regular">merchant</span> may not sell <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>another <span class="gemarra-regular">merchant</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span> rather, the merchant who buys from the owner of the eggs must sell directly to the consumer.
§ Apropos price fluctuations, the Gemara cites a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught: </span>A community <span class="gemarra-regular">sounds the alarm </span>and gathers in public prayer <span class="gemarra-regular">for merchandise </span><span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">perakmatya</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> whose price has dropped. <span class="gemarra-regular">And even on Shabbat </span>it is permitted to cry and plead, even though one may not pray for his personal needs on Shabbat, as this hardship affects the entire public.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan said: </span>The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is referring specifically to merchandise that serves as the basis of the local economy, <span class="gemarra-regular">such as linen garments in Babylonia, and wine and oil in Eretz Yisrael. Rav Yosef said: And that </span><span class="it-text">halakha</span>, that public prayer is recited even on Shabbat, applies only <span class="gemarra-regular">when </span>the merchandise <span class="gemarra-regular">was reduced in price and stood </span>at such prices that goods that had been worth <span class="gemarra-regular">ten </span>are currently selling <span class="gemarra-regular">for six</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught: One may not leave Eretz </span>Yisrael <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>live <span class="gemarra-regular">outside of Eretz </span>Yisrael <span class="gemarra-regular">unless </span>the price of <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span><span class="gemarra-italic">se’a</span> of grain <span class="gemarra-regular">stood at a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">sela</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>which is double its usual price. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon said: When </span>does this exception, permitting one to leave Eretz Yisrael under certain circumstances, apply? It applies <span class="gemarra-regular">when one is unable to find </span>produce <span class="gemarra-regular">to buy, </span>as he has no money. <span class="gemarra-regular">But when one </span>has money and <span class="gemarra-regular">is able to find </span>produce <span class="gemarra-regular">to buy, even </span>if the price of <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">se’a</span> of grain <span class="gemarra-regular">stood at a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">sela</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, he may not leave.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Shimon ben Yoḥai would likewise say: Elimelech </span>and his sons <span class="gemarra-regular">Mahlon and Chilion were prominent </span>members <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span>their <span class="gemarra-regular">generation and were leaders of </span>their <span class="gemarra-regular">generation. And for what </span>reason <span class="gemarra-regular">were they punished? </span>They were punished <span class="gemarra-regular">because they left Eretz </span>Yisrael <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>go <span class="gemarra-regular">outside of Eretz </span>Yisrael, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is stated </span>concerning Naomi and Ruth: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And all the city was astir concerning them, and the women said: Is this Naomi?” </span>(Ruth 1:19). The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is the meaning of the phrase: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Is this Naomi”? </span>How does this indicate that her husband and sons were punished for leaving Eretz Yisrael? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yitzḥak says </span>that the women <span class="gemarra-regular">said: Have you seen what befell Naomi, who left Eretz </span>Yisrael <span class="gemarra-regular">for outside of Eretz </span>Yisrael? Not only did she not escape tribulations there, but she lost her status entirely.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Yitzḥak </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">says </span>with regard to this passage: <span class="gemarra-regular">That </span>very <span class="gemarra-regular">day when Ruth the Moabite came to Eretz Yisrael, the wife of Boaz died, </span>i.e., from the moment of their arrival the possibility was created for Ruth’s eventual marriage to Boaz. <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>explains the adage <span class="gemarra-regular">that people say: Before the deceased dies, the person </span>who will next be <span class="gemarra-regular">in charge of his house arises</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as in this case Boaz’s new wife, Ruth, arrived as his previous wife died.
Apropos the story of Ruth the Gemara adds: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba bar Rav Huna says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: </span>The judge <span class="gemarra-regular">Ibzan </span>of Bethlehem (see Judges 12:8–10) <span class="gemarra-regular">is Boaz. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is he teaching us? </span>The Gemara explains that this comment is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with the other </span>statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabba bar Rav Huna, as Rabba bar Rav Huna says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: Boaz prepared one hundred and twenty feast</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for his children </span>at their weddings. <span class="gemarra-regular">As it is stated, </span>concerning Ibzan: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And he had thirty sons, and thirty daughters he sent abroad, and thirty daughters he brought in from abroad for his sons. And he judged Israel seven years” </span>(Judges 12:9). The verse indicates that he had sixty children.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And at each and every </span>wedding he prepared for his children, <span class="gemarra-regular">he made two feasts, one in the house of the father </span>of the groom <span class="gemarra-regular">and one in the house of the father-in-law </span>of the groom. <span class="gemarra-regular">And he did not invite Manoah, </span>the future father of Samson, whose wife was barren (see Judges 13:2) <span class="gemarra-regular">to any of them, </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">he said: </span>It is not worth inviting him; he is <span class="gemarra-regular">a sterile mule, how will he pay me back? </span>Manoah will never invite me in return, as he has no children.
A Sage <span class="gemarra-regular">taught: And all </span>of the children of Ibzan <span class="gemarra-regular">died during his lifetime. And this </span>explains the adage <span class="gemarra-regular">that people say: Why do you </span>need the <span class="gemarra-regular">sixty, </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">sixty </span>children <span class="gemarra-regular">that you beget during your lifetime? Go to the trouble and beget one who will be more diligent than sixty</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> This adage refers to Boaz, who had sixty children who died, and yet his last child, born from Ruth, is his glory, as King David was born from this line.
The Gemara provides <span class="gemarra-regular">a mnemonic </span>for the ensuing statements that Rav Ḥanan bar Rava said that Rav said: <span class="gemarra-regular">Melech; Abraham; ten years; when he died; and He alone was exalted. Rav Ḥanan bar Rava says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">Elimelech, and </span>Boaz’s father, <span class="gemarra-regular">Salmon, and So-and-so, </span>the unnamed relative who was a closer relative to Elimelech than Boaz (Ruth 4:1), <span class="gemarra-regular">and Naomi’s father, all of these are descendants of Nahshon, son of Amminadab, </span>the head of the tribe of Judah (see Ruth 4:20–21 and Numbers 2:3). The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is he teaching us </span>by this statement? He is teaching <span class="gemarra-regular">that even </span>in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who has the merit of his ancestor</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> to protect him, this merit <span class="gemarra-regular">does not stand for him when he leaves Eretz </span>Yisrael <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>go <span class="gemarra-regular">outside of Eretz </span>Yisrael, as Elimelech died on account of this sin.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav Ḥanan bar Rava says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: The mother of Abraham </span>was called <span class="gemarra-regular">Amatlai bat Karnevo. The mother of Haman </span>was called <span class="gemarra-regular">Amatlai bat Orevati. And your mnemonic,</span> to ensure that the two are not confused for one another, is that a raven [<span class="it-text">orev</span>] is <span class="gemarra-regular">impure, </span>and in this manner one remembers that Orevati is the grandmother of the <span class="gemarra-regular">impure </span>Haman, while a sheep [<span class="it-text">kar</span>] is <span class="gemarra-regular">pure</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> which indicates that Karnevo is the grandmother of the <span class="gemarra-regular">pure </span>Abraham.
Rav Ḥanan bar Rava continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">The mother of David was named Natzvat bat Ada’el. The mother of Samson </span>was named <span class="gemarra-regular">Tzelelponit, and his sister </span>was called <span class="gemarra-regular">Nashyan. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the </span>practical <span class="gemarra-regular">difference </span>as to what their names were? The Gemara answers: It is important with regard <span class="gemarra-regular">to an answer for heretics </span>who inquire into the names of these women, which are not stated in the Bible. One can reply that there is a tradition handed down concerning their names.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav Ḥanan bar Rava says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: Our forefather Abraham was imprisoned </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">ten years, </span>because he rejected the idol worship that was accepted in his land. He was imprisoned for <span class="gemarra-regular">three </span>years <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the city of <span class="gemarra-regular">Khuta, and seven </span>years <span class="gemarra-regular">in Karddu. And Rav Dimi of Neharde’a teaches the opposite, </span>that he was imprisoned seven years in Khuta and three in Karddu. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥisda said: The small passag</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of Khuta, this is Ur of the Chaldeans </span>(see Genesis 11:31).
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav Ḥanan bar Rava says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: </span>On <span class="gemarra-regular">that day when our forefather Abraham left the world, the leaders of the nations of the world stood in a line, </span>in the manner of mourners, <span class="gemarra-regular">and said: Woe to the world that has lost</span>

Daf 91b

<span class="gemarra-regular">its leader, and woe to the ship that has lost its captain</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
With regard to leaders, the Gemara adds that it is stated in praise of God: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And You are exalted as head above all” </span>(I Chronicles 29:11). <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥanan bar Rava says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: Even </span>one with the most insignificant position of authority, e.g., <span class="gemarra-regular">an appointee over irrigation</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is appointed by Heaven.</span>
The Gemara returns to its discussion of the punishment of Elimelech and his sons, which Rabbi Shimon ben Yoḥai says they received because they left Eretz Yisrael. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥiyya bar Avin says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehoshua ben Korḥa says: Heaven forfend </span>that they sinned in this manner, <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>if Elimelech and his sons <span class="gemarra-regular">had found even bran they would not have left </span>Eretz Yisrael. <span class="gemarra-regular">But rather, for what </span>reason were <span class="gemarra-regular">they punished? </span>They were punished <span class="gemarra-regular">because they should have requested mercy </span>of God <span class="gemarra-regular">for their generation, and they did not request </span>this, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is stated: “When you cry, let those you have </span><span class="gemarra-regular">gathered</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> deliver you” </span>(Isaiah 57:13).
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba bar bar Ḥana says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: They taught </span>that it is prohibited to leave Eretz Yisrael <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">money is cheap, </span>i.e., not excessively difficult to obtain, <span class="gemarra-regular">and produce is expensive, </span>similar to the case in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> where two <span class="it-text">se’a</span> of wheat are sold for a <span class="it-text">sela</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>when <span class="gemarra-regular">money is expensive, </span>i.e., it is difficult to earn money for sustenance, <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>if the price of <span class="gemarra-regular">four </span><span class="gemarra-italic">se</span><span class="gemarra-italic">’a</span> of grain <span class="gemarra-regular">stood at a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">sela</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, one </span>may <span class="gemarra-regular">leave </span>Eretz Yisrael in order to survive.
The Gemara provides <span class="gemarra-regular">a mnemonic </span>for the following list of Rabbi Yoḥanan’s recollections: <span class="gemarra-italic">Sela</span><span class="gemarra-regular">; laborer; carob; boy; they would say. </span>The first statement is <span class="gemarra-regular">that Rabbi Yoḥanan said: I remember when four </span><span class="gemarra-italic">se’a</span> of produce <span class="gemarra-regular">were </span>sold <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>one <span class="gemarra-italic">sela</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, and </span>yet <span class="gemarra-regular">there were many swollen from hunger in Tiberias, as they did not have </span>even one <span class="gemarra-italic">issar</span> coin with which to purchase food. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Yoḥanan </span>further <span class="gemarra-regular">said: I remember when laborers would not </span>agree to <span class="gemarra-regular">work on the east </span>side of the <span class="gemarra-regular">city, </span>because <span class="gemarra-regular">they would die from the smell of the brea</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> that would waft over them from the city’s west side.
The Gemara continues to relate other, more salutary, memories: <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Yoḥanan said: I remember when a child would break a carob, and a line of honey would extend over his two arms. And Rabbi Elazar said: I remember when a raven would take </span>a piece of <span class="gemarra-regular">meat, and a line of fat would extend from the top of the wall </span>upon which it was standing <span class="gemarra-regular">to the ground. And Rabbi Yoḥanan said: I remember when a boy and girl, of sixteen and seventeen years of age, would walk </span>together <span class="gemarra-regular">in the market, and they would not sin. And Rabbi Yoḥanan said: I remember when they would say in the study hall that one who agrees with </span>the gentiles <span class="gemarra-regular">falls into their hands, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">that one who relies on the</span><span class="gemarra-regular">m</span> sees that which is <span class="gemarra-regular">his </span>become <span class="gemarra-regular">theirs.</span>
The Gemara returns to its discussion of the story of Ruth. <span class="gemarra-regular">It is written: “Mahlon and Chilion” </span>(Ruth 1:2), <span class="gemarra-regular">and it is written </span>elsewhere: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Joash and Saraph, </span>who had dominion in Moab” (I Chronicles 4:22). Apparently, both names refer to the same individuals who married Moabite wives. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav and Shmuel </span>disagreed with regard to their true names. <span class="gemarra-regular">One says: Their </span>given <span class="gemarra-regular">names were Mahlon and Chilion, and why were they called </span>by the <span class="gemarra-regular">names Saraph and Joash? </span>One was called <span class="gemarra-regular">Joash </span><span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">yoash</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] because they despaired [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">nitya’ashu</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] of the redemption </span>of Eretz Yisrael, as they established themselves in Moab and lived there for many years. The other was called <span class="gemarra-regular">Saraph, because they were liable </span>to receive the punishment of <span class="gemarra-regular">burning [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">sereifa</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] for </span>their sins against <span class="gemarra-regular">God, </span>because they left their community.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And one </span>of them <span class="gemarra-regular">says: Their </span>given <span class="gemarra-regular">names were Joash and Saraph, and why were they called </span>by the <span class="gemarra-regular">names Mahlon and Chilion? </span>One was called <span class="gemarra-regular">Mahlon [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">maḥlon</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] because they made their bodies profane [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ḥullin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>the other was called <span class="gemarra-regular">Chilion [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">khilyon</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] because they were liable to </span>receive the punishment of <span class="gemarra-regular">destruction [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">kelaya</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] for </span>their sins against <span class="gemarra-regular">God.</span>
The Gemara notes: It <span class="gemarra-regular">is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with the one who says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">their </span>given <span class="gemarra-regular">names were Mahlon and Chilion. As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is the meaning of that <span class="gemarra-regular">which is written: “And Jokim, and the men of Cozeba</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and Joash, and Saraph, who had dominion in Moab, and Jashubi Lehem. And the matters are ancient” </span>(I Chronicles 4:22)? <span class="gemarra-regular">“And Jokim,” this </span>refers to <span class="gemarra-regular">Joshua, who established [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">sheh</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ekim</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] </span>and kept the <span class="gemarra-regular">oath with people of Gibeon </span>(see Joshua, chapter 9). <span class="gemarra-regular">“And the men of Cozeba,” these are the men of Gibeon, who lied [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">shekizevu</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] to Joshua </span>by saying that they came from a distant land. <span class="gemarra-regular">“And Joash, and Saraph,” these are Mahlon and Chilion. And why were they called </span>by the <span class="gemarra-regular">names Joash and Saraph? </span>One was called <span class="gemarra-regular">Joash because they despaired [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">shenitya’ashu</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] of the redemption; </span>the other was called <span class="gemarra-regular">Saraph because they were liable </span>to receive the punishment of <span class="gemarra-regular">burning [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">sereifa</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] for </span>their sins against <span class="gemarra-regular">God.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">“Who had dominion in Moab,” </span>this means <span class="gemarra-regular">that they married Moabite women. “And Jashubi Lehem,” this </span>is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">Ruth the Moabite, who returned [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">sheshava</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] and attached </span>herself <span class="gemarra-regular">to Bethlehem </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">Judea. “And the matters are ancient,” </span>this means that <span class="gemarra-regular">these matters were said by the Ancient of Days</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., they occurred through God’s will, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is written: “I have found David My servant”</span> (Psalms 89:21); <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the same term “found” also appears with regard to the daughters of Lot, as <span class="gemarra-regular">it is written: “Your two daughters that are found </span>here” (Genesis 19:15). This teaches that David’s ancestry can be traced this far back, as he was destined to be born from Moab, who was the son of Lot’s daughter and Lot himself.
The Gemara cites a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that analyzes the next verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“These were the potters, and those who dwelt among plantations and hedges; there they dwelt occupied in the king’s work” </span>(I Chronicles 4:23). <span class="gemarra-regular">“These were the potters </span><span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">y</span><span class="gemarra-italic">otzerim</span><span class="gemarra-regular">],” these are the sons of Jonadab, son of Rechab, who kept [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">natzeru</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] their father’s oath</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">“Those who dwelt among plantations,” this </span>is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">Solomon, who in his kingship </span>was <span class="gemarra-regular">similar to a plant</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> “And hedges [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ugdera</span><span class="gemarra-regular">],” this </span>is the <span class="gemarra-regular">Sanhedrin, which fenced </span><span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">g</span><span class="gemarra-italic">aderu</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] in the breaches of the Jewish people </span>by means of ordinances. <span class="gemarra-regular">“There they dwelt occupied in the king’s work,” this </span>is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">Ruth the Moabite, who saw the kingship of Solomon, </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">grandson of her grandson. As it is stated </span>about Solomon: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And he caused a throne to be set for the king’s mother” </span>(I Kings 2:19), <span class="gemarra-regular">and Rabbi Elazar says: </span>This means <span class="gemarra-regular">for the mother of the </span>dynasty of <span class="gemarra-regular">kingship</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., Ruth.
§ Since the Gemara has discussed times of famine in Eretz Yisrael, it concludes the chapter with a blessing of times of prosperity: <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught: </span>When the verse states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And you shall eat of the produce of the old store” </span>(Leviticus 25:22), referring to the produce grown in the sixth year of the Sabbatical cycle, this means <span class="gemarra-regular">without </span><span class="gemarra-italic">salmanton</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is the meaning of: <span class="gemarra-regular">Without </span><span class="gemarra-italic">salmanton</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? Rav Naḥman said: Without worms [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">retzinta</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> that consume the produce, <span class="gemarra-regular">and Rav Sheshet said: Without blight</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> which destroys the taste of the produce.
The Gemara notes: It <span class="gemarra-regular">is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav Sheshet, </span>and it <span class="gemarra-regular">is taught </span>in another <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav Naḥman. </span>It <span class="gemarra-regular">is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav Naḥman: </span>From the verse: “And you shall sow the eighth year, <span class="gemarra-regular">and you shall eat </span>of the produce of <span class="gemarra-regular">the old store, </span>until the ninth year” (Leviticus 25:22), one <span class="gemarra-regular">might </span>have thought that <span class="gemarra-regular">the Jewish people will wait for the new </span>produce <span class="gemarra-regular">because the old store has </span>been <span class="gemarra-regular">destroyed. </span>Therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>same <span class="gemarra-regular">verse states: “Until its produce comes in,” </span>to indicate that they will not stop eating the old produce <span class="gemarra-regular">until the </span>new <span class="gemarra-regular">produce comes of itself</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., until it is fully ripe and they do not need the old produce. The old produce will last until then and will not become worm infested, as stated by Rav Naḥman.
It <span class="gemarra-regular">is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav Sheshet: </span>From the verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And you shall eat of the produce of the old store,” </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">might </span>have thought that <span class="gemarra-regular">the Jewish people will wait for the new </span>produce <span class="gemarra-regular">due to the old store because </span>the old store will have gone <span class="gemarra-regular">bad, </span>since blight will ruin the taste of the produce. Therefore, <span class="gemarra-regular">the verse states: “Until its produce comes in,” </span>which indicates that they will not stop eating the old produce <span class="gemarra-regular">until the </span>new <span class="gemarra-regular">produce comes of itself, </span>as the stored produce will not suffer from blight.
<span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>with regard to a verse in the chapter of the blessings stated to the Jewish people: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And you shall eat old store long kept” </span>(Leviticus 26:10). This <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches that any </span>produce <span class="gemarra-regular">that is older than other </span>produce of that same type will be <span class="gemarra-regular">better than </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">other </span>produce. <span class="gemarra-regular">And I have </span>derived that this is the case <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">items </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">which </span>it is the normal <span class="gemarra-regular">manner to age them. From where </span>do I derive in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">items </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">which </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>the normal <span class="gemarra-regular">manner to age them, </span>e.g., fruit, that they too will improve with age? <span class="gemarra-regular">The verse states: “Old store long kept,” </span>a general expression that indicates that <span class="gemarra-regular">in any case </span>the land will keep its produce from spoiling, as all types of produce will improve with age.
The continuation of the verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“You shall bring forth the old from before the new,” teaches that there will be storehouses full of old </span>produce <span class="gemarra-regular">and threshing floors full of new </span>produce, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the Jewish people will say: How will we </span>manage to <span class="gemarra-regular">take out this </span>produce from the storehouse <span class="gemarra-regular">before that </span>produce is brought in? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa said: Everything </span>that is <span class="gemarra-regular">old is superior </span>in quality to the new, <span class="gemarra-regular">except for dates, liquor, and small fish, </span>which are better when they are fresh.


Daf 92a

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who sells produce to anothe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> that is sometimes purchased for consumption and sometimes for planting, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">planted it and it did not sprout</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and even </span>if he had sold <span class="gemarra-regular">flaxseeds</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> which are only occasionally eaten, the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">does not bear </span>financial <span class="gemarra-regular">responsibility for them, </span>i.e., he is not required to compensate the buyer. Since the buyer did not specify that he purchased the produce in order to plant it, the seller can claim that he assumed the buyer intended to eat it. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: </span>If he had sold <span class="gemarra-regular">seeds </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">garden </span>plants, <span class="gemarra-regular">which are not eate</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> at all, then the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">bears </span>financial <span class="gemarra-regular">responsibility for</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> them</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as they were certainly purchased for planting.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> An amoraic dispute <span class="gemarra-regular">was stated </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who sells an ox to another and </span>the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">is found </span>to be <span class="gemarra-regular">one that habitually </span><span class="gemarra-regular">gores</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: This is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a mistaken transaction, </span>since the buyer can claim that he bought the ox specifically for labor, and an ox that gores is not suitable for this function. Therefore, the seller must take back the ox and reimburse the buyer. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Shmuel says: </span>The sale is not voided, as the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">can say to him: I sold it to you for </span><span class="gemarra-regular">slaughter</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and the fact that it gores is immaterial.
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">But let us see if </span>the buyer is <span class="gemarra-regular">a ma</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> who </span>generally <span class="gemarra-regular">purchases </span>oxen <span class="gemarra-regular">for slaughter, </span>in which case it can be presumed that he also purchased this ox <span class="gemarra-regular">for slaughter, or if </span>he is a man who generally purchases oxen <span class="gemarra-regular">for plowing</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> in which case it can be presumed that he also purchased this ox <span class="gemarra-regular">for plowing. </span>The Gemara answers: The dispute <span class="gemarra-regular">concerns a man who </span>sometimes <span class="gemarra-regular">purchases </span>oxen <span class="gemarra-regular">for this </span>purpose <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>sometimes <span class="gemarra-regular">for that </span>purpose, and so it is uncertain for which purpose he purchased this ox.
