The Gemara persists: <span class="gemarra-regular">But let us see the paymen</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> he made; <span class="gemarra-regular">how much was it? </span>Since an ox fit for plowing costs more than one fit only for slaughter, the purpose for which the ox was purchased will be apparent from the price paid.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary</span> to discuss the case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the price of an ox to be slaughtered for its <span class="gemarra-regular">meat appreciated and reached </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">value of </span>an ox for <span class="gemarra-regular">plowing.</span> But if the price disparity is significant, there is no dispute. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, for </span>the sake of <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>practical <span class="gemarra-regular">difference </span>did they discuss the case? Even if the ox was not suitable for the buyer’s purposes, he could sell it for the same price of the ox he needs. The Gemara answers: The practical <span class="gemarra-regular">difference </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to the effor</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> of selling the ox in order to recover its value; who must go to the effort of doing so?
The Gemara clarifies: <span class="gemarra-regular">What are the circumstances </span>of the case under discussion? 

Daf 92b

<span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>this is a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">does not </span>have sufficient funds for the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">to be reimburse</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> by him, </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">let </span>the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">retain the ox </span>itself <span class="gemarra-regular">in lieu of his money, as people say: </span>If you wish to ensure that you will get paid, <span class="gemarra-regular">collect </span>even <span class="gemarra-regular">bran, </span>an inferior commodity, <span class="gemarra-regular">from one who is in your debt. </span>Consequently, even according to the opinion of Rav, the buyer will be likely to retain the ox. What, then, is the practical difference between the opinions of Rav and Shmuel?
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>to discuss the case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">does have </span>sufficient funds for the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">to be reimbursed by him.</span>
The Gemara explains the logic of each opinion: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: This is a mistaken transaction, </span>as in cases of uncertainty <span class="gemarra-regular">we follow the majority, and </span>since <span class="gemarra-regular">the majority </span>of people <span class="gemarra-regular">purchase</span> oxen <span class="gemarra-regular">for plowing, </span>it is presumed that this buyer also purchased the ox for plowing. Accordingly, since the ox he received was not suitable for plowing, the sale is void. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Shmuel </span>could have <span class="gemarra-regular">said to you: When we follow the majority, </span>that is only <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to ritual matters</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> but <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to monetary matters</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> such as this, we do <span class="gemarra-regular">no</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> follow the majority. Accordingly, there is no basis for voiding the sale.
The Gemara cites <span class="gemarra-regular">a mnemonic </span>that indicates the topics of the cases it will reference to challenge either Rav’s or Shmuel’s opinion: <span class="gemarra-regular">Woman, and slave, ox, oxen, and produce.</span>
The Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises an objection </span>to Rav’s opinion from a mishna (<span class="it-text">Ketubot</span> 15b): With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a woman who was widowe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> or divorced</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and is in dispute with her husband or his heirs over the value of the payment she should receive for her marriage contract, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">she says: </span>When <span class="gemarra-regular">you married me </span>I was <span class="gemarra-regular">a virgin, </span>and so I am entitled to two hundred dinars, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he says: That is not </span>the case; <span class="gemarra-regular">rather, </span>when <span class="gemarra-regular">I married you, </span>you were <span class="gemarra-regular">a widow, </span>and so you are entitled to only one hundred dinars, then <span class="gemarra-regular">if there are witnesses that she went out </span>of her father’s house to her wedding <span class="gemarra-regular">with a veil [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">hinnuma</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> or </span>with the hair of <span class="gemarra-regular">her head loose, </span>in the typical manner of virgin brides, that is considered sufficient evidence in support of her claim, and so the payment of <span class="gemarra-regular">her marriage contract is two hundred </span>dinars.
The Gemara infers: <span class="gemarra-regular">The reason </span>that she receives two hundred dinars is <span class="gemarra-regular">that there are witnesses </span>to her claim. Therefore, if <span class="gemarra-regular">there were no witnesses, </span>her claim would <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>be successful. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But why? Let us say </span>that since there is an uncertainty, one should <span class="gemarra-regular">follow </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">majority of women, and </span>since the <span class="gemarra-regular">majority of women marry as virgins, </span>it should be presumed that this woman also married as a virgin. Accordingly she should be entitled to two hundred dinars. Since this is not the case, it is apparent that the majority is not followed in monetary matters.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Ravina said: </span>In this case, one cannot decide the case based on the majority of women <span class="gemarra-regular">because there is </span>room <span class="gemarra-regular">to say </span>that it is so that the <span class="gemarra-regular">majority of women marry as virgins and </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">a minority </span>marry <span class="gemarra-regular">as widows </span>or non-virgins. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>it is also so that there is an additional presumption: The marriage of <span class="gemarra-regular">anyone who marries </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">a virgin generates publicit</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span> of that fact. <span class="gemarra-regular">And</span> with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>woman, who is in a dispute over the value of her marriage contract, <span class="gemarra-regular">because her </span>marriage <span class="gemarra-regular">did not generate publicity</span> of her marrying as a virgin, the ability to apply what is true of <span class="gemarra-regular">the majority </span>of women to her case <span class="gemarra-regular">is undermined. </span>Accordingly, there is no proof that the majority is not followed in monetary matters.
The Gemara questions this: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>it is really true that the marriage of <span class="gemarra-regular">anyone who marries </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">a virgin generates publicity </span>of that fact, then even <span class="gemarra-regular">when there are witnesses </span>that she was a virgin bride, <span class="gemarra-regular">what of it? From </span>the fact that <span class="gemarra-regular">her </span>marriage <span class="gemarra-regular">did not generate publicity </span>of her marrying as a virgin, perforce <span class="gemarra-regular">they are false witnesses.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>one must modify the above argument to say that <span class="gemarra-regular">the majority </span>of marriages <span class="gemarra-regular">of women who marry </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">virgins generate publicity</span> of that fact, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>woman, <span class="gemarra-regular">since her </span>marriage <span class="gemarra-regular">did not generate publicity </span>of her having been married as a virgin, the ability to apply what is true of <span class="gemarra-regular">the majority </span>of women to her case <span class="gemarra-regular">is undermined</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>another challenge to Rav’s opinion from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who sells a slave to another, and </span>the slave <span class="gemarra-regular">is found to be a thie</span><span class="gemarra-regular">f </span><span class="gemarra-regular"> or a gambler [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">kuvyustus</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and the buyer does not wish to have such a slave, nevertheless <span class="gemarra-regular">it has come to him, </span>i.e., the slave is acquired by the one who purchased him and the transaction is nonrefundable. By contrast, if the slave is found to be <span class="gemarra-regular">an armed bandit [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">listim</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> or </span>has been judged and <span class="gemarra-regular">written </span>to be executed <span class="gemarra-regular">by the govenment</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> then the buyer can return the slave to the seller and <span class="gemarra-regular">say to him: That which is yours is before you; </span>return the money I paid for him, as the sale is void.
The Gemara explains the proof from the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: In <span class="gemarra-regular">the first clause </span>of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, 

Daf 93a

<span class="gemarra-regular">what is the reaso</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> that the sale is not considered to be a mistaken transaction? Is it <span class="gemarra-regular">not because a majority </span>of slaves <span class="gemarra-regular">are like this, </span>i.e., either thieves or gamblers? Apparently, the majority is followed in monetary matters.
The Gemara rejects the proof: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>it is because <span class="gemarra-regular">all </span>slaves <span class="gemarra-regular">are like this</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Accordingly, no proof can be drawn as to whether we follow the majority in monetary matters.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>another challenge to Rav’s opinion from a mishna (<span class="it-text">Bava</span> <span class="it-text">Kamma</span> 46a): In the case of an innocuous <span class="gemarra-regular">ox that gored </span>and killed <span class="gemarra-regular">a cow</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>the cow’s <span class="gemarra-regular">fetus</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> was found </span>dead <span class="gemarra-regular">at its side, and it is not known whether </span>the cow <span class="gemarra-regular">calved before </span>the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">gored it </span>and the fetus’ death was unrelated to the goring, <span class="gemarra-regular">or whether it calved after </span>the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">gored it </span>and the fetus died on account of the goring, the ox’s owner <span class="gemarra-regular">pays half </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the damage</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for the cow, </span>as is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> for an innocuous ox (see Exodus 21:35), <span class="gemarra-regular">and one-quarter </span>of the cost of the damage <span class="gemarra-regular">for the offspring. </span>Since it is uncertain whether the ox caused the death of the fetus, its owner pays for half of the standard liability of half the cost of the damage.
The Gemara explains the proof from the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">But why, </span>according to Rav, should he only pay for one-quarter of the damage to the fetus? Since there is an uncertainty, <span class="gemarra-regular">let us say:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Follow </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">majority of cows, and </span>since the <span class="gemarra-regular">majority of cows become pregnant and calve </span>live offspring, one should conclude that <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>cow, which did not, <span class="gemarra-regular">certainly miscarried due to </span>the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">goring </span>it, and the ox’s owner should be liable for half the cost of the fetus. Since that line of reasoning is not applied here, it is apparent that the majority is not followed in monetary matters.
The Gemara rejects the proof: <span class="gemarra-regular">There, </span>the reason that the ox’s owner pays for only one-quarter of the damage for the fetus is <span class="gemarra-regular">due </span>to the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that we are uncertain </span>about how it died, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is </span>possible <span class="gemarra-regular">to say </span>that the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">approached </span>the cow <span class="gemarra-regular">from its front and </span>it was <span class="gemarra-regular">due to </span>the cow’s <span class="gemarra-regular">fright, </span>not due to the goring, that <span class="gemarra-regular">it miscarried</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> meaning that the ox’s owner would not be liable; <span class="gemarra-regular">and it is </span>also possible <span class="gemarra-regular">to say that </span>the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">approached </span>the cow <span class="gemarra-regular">from behind it and gored it, and </span>that is why the cow <span class="gemarra-regular">miscarried. </span>Accordingly, the payment for such damage constitutes <span class="gemarra-regular">property of uncertain ownership, and </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is that <span class="gemarra-regular">all property of uncertain ownership is divided </span>equally between the two parties.
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Let us say </span>that this dispute between Rav and Shmuel <span class="gemarra-regular">is parallel to </span>a dispute between <span class="gemarra-italic">tanna’im</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>as it is taught in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox that was grazing and </span>another <span class="gemarra-regular">ox </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">was found killed at its side, even though this </span>dead ox <span class="gemarra-regular">has been gored and that </span>grazing ox <span class="gemarra-regular">is forewarne</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with regard to goring, </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>dead ox <span class="gemarra-regular">has been bitten and that </span>grazing ox <span class="gemarra-regular">is forewarned with regard to biting, </span>nevertheless <span class="gemarra-regular">one does not say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">it is evident that this </span>grazing ox <span class="gemarra-regular">gored </span>the dead ox <span class="gemarra-regular">or that </span>grazing ox <span class="gemarra-regular">bit it, </span>despite the fact such behavior is typical for the ox; rather, one cannot draw any definite conclusions. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Aḥa says </span>that in the case of a rutting male <span class="gemarra-regular">camel that is rampagin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> among </span>other <span class="gemarra-regular">camel</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>another <span class="gemarra-regular">camel </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">was found killed at its side, it is evident that this </span>rampaging camel <span class="gemarra-regular">killed it</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as such behavior is typical for a rutting camel. Therefore, the owner of that camel is liable.
Those who suggested the parallel between the tannaitic dispute and the dispute between Rav and Shmuel <span class="gemarra-regular">assumed that a majority and </span>a logical <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>about whether an event will happen <span class="gemarra-regular">are equivalen</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> in their capacity to determine the facts of a case. Consequently, <span class="gemarra-regular">let us say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav, who says </span>that one follows the majority in monetary matters, holds <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Aḥa, </span>who follows a presumption to determine the facts of a case, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel, who says </span>that one does not follow the majority in monetary matters, holds <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the first </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>who does not follow a presumption.
The Gemara rejects this: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav </span>could have <span class="gemarra-regular">said to you: I am stating </span>my ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">even in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the first </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">the first </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">says </span>that one cannot draw a definite conclusion <span class="gemarra-regular">only there, </span>in the case of the grazing ox, <span class="gemarra-regular">as we do not follow a presumption </span>in monetary matters, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>he concedes that <span class="gemarra-regular">we follow the majorit</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span> in monetary matters.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Shmuel </span>could have <span class="gemarra-regular">said to you: I am stating </span>my ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">even in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Aḥa, </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Aḥa says </span>that one can draw a definite conclusion <span class="gemarra-regular">only there, </span>in the case of the camels, <span class="gemarra-regular">since we follow a presumption </span>in monetary matters, <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>this camel <span class="gemarra-regular">itself is presumed</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> based on its behavior, to be the killer. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>he concedes that <span class="gemarra-regular">we do not follow the majority </span>in deciding monetary matters.
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>another challenge to Rav’s opinion from the mishna: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who sells produce to another </span>that is sometimes purchased for consumption and sometimes for planting, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">planted it and it did not sprout, and even </span>if he had sold <span class="gemarra-regular">flaxseeds, </span>which are rarely sold as food, the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">does not bear </span>financial <span class="gemarra-regular">responsibility for them.</span>
The Gemara explains the proof: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>novelty is indicated by saying: <span class="gemarra-regular">Even </span>if he had sold flaxseeds? Is it <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>where he sold <span class="gemarra-regular">flaxseeds, of which the majority is purchased for planting, and </span>they were not suitable for that purpose, <span class="gemarra-regular">nevertheless </span>the sale stands because <span class="gemarra-regular">we do not follow the majority </span>in monetary matters?
The Gemara concedes that the mishna cannot be reconciled with Rav’s opinion, but suggests that there are other <span class="it-text">tanna’im</span> who hold in accordance with his opinion. It <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>a dispute between <span class="gemarra-italic">tanna’im</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who sells produce to another,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">planted it and it did not sprout, </span>if the produce was <span class="gemarra-regular">seeds </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">garden </span>plants, <span class="gemarra-regular">which are not eaten </span>at all, then the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">bears </span>financial <span class="gemarra-regular">responsibility for them. </span>If the produce was <span class="gemarra-regular">flaxseeds, </span>which are only occasionally eaten, then the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">does not bear </span>financial <span class="gemarra-regular">responsibility for them. Rabbi Yosei says: </span>

Daf 93b

The seller <span class="gemarra-regular">gives</span> back <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">the value of the seeds. </span>Since the majority of flaxseeds are sold are for planting, it is a mistaken transaction. <span class="gemarra-regular">They said to him, </span>i.e., to Rabbi Yosei: <span class="gemarra-regular">Many, </span>i.e., a majority of people, <span class="gemarra-regular">purchase </span>flaxseeds <span class="gemarra-regular">for purposes other </span>than planting. Consequently, the sale stands.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Who </span>are the <span class="gemarra-italic">tanna’im</span> in this <span class="it-text">baraita</span> who have a dispute that parallels the dispute between Rav and Shmuel? <span class="gemarra-regular">If we say </span>that they are <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei and </span>the opinion cited as: <span class="gemarra-regular">They said to him, </span>that is incorrect, as <span class="gemarra-regular">both of them </span>hold that one <span class="gemarra-regular">follows the majority </span>in monetary matters. Their dispute concerns only which majority to follow: One <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage, </span>i.e., the opinion cited as: They said to him, <span class="gemarra-regular">follows the majority of people </span>making purchases, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage, </span>i.e., Rabbi Yosei, <span class="gemarra-regular">follows the majority </span>of the volume <span class="gemarra-regular">of seeds </span>that are sold overall. The disparity arises because the majority of sales are each made with a relatively small quantity of seeds that are purchased for purposes other than planting. The minority of sales involve large quantities of seeds that are purchased for planting. This means that the majority of the seeds sold overall are purchased for planting, but the majority of people purchasing seeds do so for purposes other than planting.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>the dispute that parallels the dispute between Rav and Shmuel is <span class="gemarra-regular">either </span>the dispute between <span class="gemarra-regular">the first </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and Rabbi Yosei, or the </span>dispute between <span class="gemarra-regular">the first </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>the opinion cited as: <span class="gemarra-regular">They said to him.</span>
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: When the seller bears financial responsibility for selling seeds that did not sprout, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is </span>he liable to <span class="gemarra-regular">give to </span>the buyer? He is liable to give him only the <span class="gemarra-regular">value of the seeds </span>themselves, <span class="gemarra-regular">but not the expenses </span>that the buyer incurred in planting them, e.g., the hire of laborers. <span class="gemarra-regular">And some say: </span>He is liable to give him <span class="gemarra-regular">even the expense</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> that the buyer incurred.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Who is </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> whose opinion is cited as: <span class="gemarra-regular">Some say</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rav Ḥisda said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">it is Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel.</span>
The Gemara clarifies: From <span class="gemarra-regular">which </span>statement of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel </span>is it apparent that he holds the seller is liable for the buyer’s expenses? One possibility is <span class="gemarra-regular">if we say</span> that the statement in question is that of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel in the mishna, as we learned </span>in the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">One who sells</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to another produce </span>that is sometimes purchased for consumption and sometimes for planting, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">planted it and it did not sprout, and even </span>if he had sold <span class="gemarra-regular">flaxseeds, </span>which are only occasionally eaten, the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">does not bear </span>financial <span class="gemarra-regular">responsibility for them. </span>The Gemara extrapolates: By inference, if this <span class="it-text">tanna</span> holds that he had sold <span class="gemarra-regular">seeds </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">garden </span>plants, <span class="gemarra-regular">which are not eaten </span>at all, then the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">bears </span>financial <span class="gemarra-regular">responsibility </span>to compensate the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">for them.</span>
The Gemara continues: But accordingly, <span class="gemarra-regular">say the latter clause: Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: </span>If he had sold <span class="gemarra-regular">seeds </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">garden </span>plants, <span class="gemarra-regular">which are not eaten </span>at all, then the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">bears </span>financial <span class="gemarra-regular">responsibility for them. </span>The Gemara asks: But according to the inference made from the first clause, <span class="gemarra-regular">the first </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is also saying this, </span>as he holds that it is only for the sale of <span class="gemarra-regular">flaxseeds that </span>the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">does not bear </span>financial <span class="gemarra-regular">responsibility </span>to compensate the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">for them, </span>but with regard to the sale of <span class="gemarra-regular">seeds </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">garden </span>plants, <span class="gemarra-regular">which are not eaten </span>at all, the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">bears </span>financial <span class="gemarra-regular">responsibility for them. </span>What, then, is the dispute between the first <span class="it-text">tanna</span> and Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel?
The Gemara therefore suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is it not </span>that the differ-ence <span class="gemarra-regular">between them </span>is whether the seller is liable for the buyer’s <span class="gemarra-regular">expenses? </span>One <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage, </span>i.e., the first <span class="it-text">tanna</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that the seller is liable only for the <span class="gemarra-regular">value of </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">seeds, and </span>the other <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage, </span>i.e., Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel, <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that the seller is liable <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>for the buyer’s <span class="gemarra-regular">expenses.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">From where </span>is it apparent that it is Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel who holds that the seller is liable for the expenses? <span class="gemarra-regular">Perhaps </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">the opposite, </span>i.e., it is the first <span class="it-text">tanna</span> who holds that the seller is liable for the expenses, and Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel holds that he is liable only for the value of the seeds. The Gemara rejects this suggestion: <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult, </span>because <span class="gemarra-regular">the last </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span> cited <span class="gemarra-regular">always comes to add somethin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span> to the ruling of the first <span class="it-text">tanna</span>, not to detract from it.
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">But perhaps all of </span>the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>stating the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel, and</span> the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">is incomplete, and this </span>is what <span class="gemarra-regular">it is teaching: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who sells</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> produce to another </span>that is sometimes purchased for eating and sometimes for planting, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">planted it and it did not sprout, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>if he had sold <span class="gemarra-regular">flaxseeds, </span>which are only occasionally eaten, the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">does not bear </span>financial <span class="gemarra-regular">responsibility for them. </span>But if he sold <span class="gemarra-regular">seeds </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">garden </span>plants, <span class="gemarra-regular">which are not eaten </span>at all, the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">bears </span>financial <span class="gemarra-regular">responsibility for them. </span>This is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel, as Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">it is </span>only for the sale of <span class="gemarra-regular">flaxseeds that </span>the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">does not bear </span>financial <span class="gemarra-regular">responsibility </span>to compensate the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">for them, </span>but by inference, for the sale of <span class="gemarra-regular">seeds </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">garden </span>plants, <span class="gemarra-regular">which are not eaten </span>at all, the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">bears </span>financial <span class="gemarra-regular">responsibility for</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> them. </span>Interpreted in this way, there is no evidence from the mishna that Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel holds that the seller is liable for the expenses.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>the statement in question is <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>statement of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel, as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> (<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span>, <span class="it-text">Bava</span> <span class="it-text">Kamma</span> 10:9) In a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who brought whea</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> to a miller <span class="gemarra-regular">to grind, and </span>the miller <span class="gemarra-regular">did not wet </span>the grains sufficiently for the grinding to be performed effectively, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>as a result <span class="gemarra-regular">he converted </span>the grain <span class="gemarra-regular">into bran or coarse bran [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">mursan</span><span class="gemarra-regular">], </span>or in a case of one who gave <span class="gemarra-regular">flour to the baker and </span>the baker <span class="gemarra-regular">made it </span>into <span class="gemarra-regular">bread </span>that is <span class="gemarra-regular">underbaked </span>and tends to crumble, or if one gave <span class="gemarra-regular">an animal to a butcher and </span>the butcher killed it in a way that <span class="gemarra-regular">rendered it </span>an unslaughtered <span class="gemarra-regular">animal carcass, </span>in all these cases the worker is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable, because he is like a paid bailee.</span>
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: </span>If the owner had invited guests to eat the food and due to the worker’s actions he was unable to serve them, then the worker must <span class="gemarra-regular">give him compensation for his humiliation and compensation for the humiliation of his guests.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> And similarly, Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel would say: There was a great custom in Jerusalem </span>that if <span class="gemarra-regular">one gives </span>raw materials for <span class="gemarra-regular">a meal to another </span>to prepare the meal for him, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>that person <span class="gemarra-regular">spoils it, </span>that person <span class="gemarra-regular">gives </span>the former <span class="gemarra-regular">compensation for</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> his humiliation and compensation for the humiliation of his guests.</span>
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">Another great custom </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">was </span>followed <span class="gemarra-regular">in Jerusalem </span>was that when one made a feast, there would be <span class="gemarra-regular">a cloth [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">mappa</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> sprea</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> over the entrance </span>to the hall. <span class="gemarra-regular">As long as the cloth was spread, </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">guests would enter, </span>as the presence of the cloth indicated that there was food for more guests. When <span class="gemarra-regular">the cloth was removed, the guests would not enter </span>any more.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> When selling a significant quantity of produce or a number of items, there is a possibility that there will be a certain proportion of impurities in it or that some of the product will be of substandard quality. The mishna delineates what proportion is considered acceptable, for which a buyer may not demand compensation. With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who sells </span><span class="gemarra-regular">produce</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., grain, <span class="gemarra-regular">to another, this </span>buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">accepts upon himself </span>that up to <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">quarter-</span><span class="it-text">ka</span><span class="it-text">v</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">impuritie</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> may be present <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>each <span class="gemarra-italic">se’a</span> of produce purchased. When purchasing <span class="gemarra-regular">figs</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">he accepts upon himself </span>that up to <span class="gemarra-regular">ten infested </span>figs may be present <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>each <span class="gemarra-regular">hundred </span>figs purchased. When purchasing <span class="gemarra-regular">a cellar </span>containing barrels <span class="gemarra-regular">of wine, he accepts upon himself </span>that up to <span class="gemarra-regular">ten </span>barrels of <span class="gemarra-regular">souring </span>wine may be present <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>each <span class="gemarra-regular">hundred </span>barrels purchased. When purchasing <span class="gemarra-regular">jugs </span>of wine <span class="gemarra-regular">in the Sharon </span>region, <span class="gemarra-regular">he accepts upon himself </span>that up to <span class="gemarra-regular">ten inferior-quality jugs [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">pitasot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> of wine may be present <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>each <span class="gemarra-regular">hundred </span>jugs purchased.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ketina taught: </span>When the mishna states that a buyer accepts upon himself that a quarter-<span class="it-text">kav</span> of impurities per <span class="it-text">se’a</span> may be present, that means only that he accepts upon himself the presence of <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">quarter-</span><span class="it-text">kav</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> legumes, </span>but he does not accept upon himself the presence of a quarter-<span class="it-text">kav</span> of dirt. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>is it so that the buyer does <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>also accept upon himself that some quantity of <span class="gemarra-regular">dirt </span>might be present in the produce? <span class="gemarra-regular">But doesn’t Rabba bar Ḥiyya Ketosfa’a say in the name of Rabba: </span>One who <span class="gemarra-regular">picks out a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">pebbl</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the wheat on <span class="gemarra-regular">another’s threshing </span><span class="gemarra-regular">floo</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> 

Daf 94a

must <span class="gemarra-regular">give him the value of whea</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> of equal volume to the pebble that he removed. Had he not removed the pebble, the owner would have sold his wheat together with the pebble, all for the price of wheat. Accordingly, the removal of the pebble effectively caused the owner a small loss. It is apparent from this ruling that when selling produce, a buyer accepts upon himself that a quantity of dirt may be mixed in.
The Gemara answers: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">legumes</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> one accepts <span class="gemarra-regular">a quarter-</span><span class="it-text">kav</span> per <span class="it-text">se’a</span>, but with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">dirt, </span>he accepts <span class="gemarra-regular">less than a quarter-</span><span class="it-text">kav</span>.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>is so that he does <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>accept <span class="gemarra-regular">a quarter</span>-<span class="it-text">kav</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">dirt? But isn’t it taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who sells produce to another, </span>if he sells him <span class="gemarra-regular">wheat, </span>the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">accepts upon himself </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a quarter-</span><span class="it-text">kav</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">of legumes </span>may be present <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>each <span class="gemarra-italic">se’a</span> of wheat purchased. When purchasing <span class="gemarra-regular">barley, he accepts upon himself </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a quarter-</span><span class="it-text">kav</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">chaf</span><span class="gemarra-regular">f </span> may be present <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>each <span class="gemarra-italic">se’a</span> purchased. When purchasing <span class="gemarra-regular">lentils</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he accepts upon himself </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a quarter-</span><span class="it-text">kav</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">of dirt </span>may be present <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>each <span class="gemarra-italic">se’a</span> purchased.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What, is it not </span>that just as the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> rules with regard to lentils, <span class="gemarra-regular">the same is true for wheat and for barley</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> The Gemara answers: No, <span class="gemarra-regular">lentils are different, because they are dug up </span>from the ground and dirt can easily get mixed in. Lentils often contain a higher percentage of dirt than do wheat and barley, which are harvested rather than dug up.
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>according to this, <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">reason </span>that a buyer accepts that dirt may be present in lentils but not in wheat and barley is <span class="gemarra-regular">that lentils are dug up </span>from the ground, <span class="gemarra-regular">whereas wheat and barley </span>are <span class="gemarra-regular">not. </span>If so, <span class="gemarra-regular">resolve </span>the dilemma <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>this <span class="it-text">baraita</span> and conclude that when purchasing <span class="gemarra-regular">wheat and barley, </span>a buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">does not accept </span>that a quarter-<span class="it-text">kav</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">dirt </span>may be present in each <span class="it-text">se’a</span>.
The Gemara rejects this: <span class="gemarra-regular">Actually, </span>perhaps when purchasing <span class="gemarra-regular">wheat and barley </span>as well, a buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">accepts </span>that a quarter-<span class="it-text">kav</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">dirt </span>may be present in each <span class="it-text">se’a</span>, but <span class="gemarra-regular">it was necessary for </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> to state the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> specifically with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">lentils. </span>This is <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>it might <span class="gemarra-regular">enter your mind to say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">since </span>lentils <span class="gemarra-regular">are dug up </span>from the ground, the buyer would <span class="gemarra-regular">also accept </span>even <span class="gemarra-regular">more than a quarter-</span><span class="it-text">kav</span> of dirt. Therefore, the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>that this is not the case.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna says: If </span>the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">comes to sif</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> the produce to check if there is more than the acceptable proportion of impurities and he finds that there is too much, <span class="gemarra-regular">he sifts all of it </span>and returns all the impurities to the seller, not just the amount in excess of a quarter-<span class="it-text">kav</span> per <span class="it-text">se’a</span>. The seller must instead provide produce that is free of any impurities. <span class="gemarra-regular">Some say </span>that this is the strict <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, and some say </span>that it is <span class="gemarra-regular">a penalty</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
The Gemara elaborates: <span class="gemarra-regular">Some say </span>that this is the strict <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">one who gives money </span>for produce <span class="gemarra-regular">gives </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">for good-quality produce </span>containing no impurities at all. Even so, where there is just <span class="gemarra-regular">a quarter</span>-<span class="it-text">kav</span> of impurities per <span class="it-text">se’a</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">a person will not take the troubl</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> to sift the grain to remove the impurities; instead, he accepts the small quantity of impurities that are present. By contrast, where there is <span class="gemarra-regular">more than a quarter-</span><span class="it-text">kav</span> of impurities per <span class="it-text">se’a</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">a person will take the trouble </span>to sift the grain to remove the impurities, <span class="gemarra-regular">and once he takes the trouble </span>to sift the grain, he does not stop once he reduces the proportion of impurities to a quarter-<span class="it-text">kav</span> per <span class="it-text">se’a</span>; rather, <span class="gemarra-regular">he takes the trouble </span>to sift <span class="gemarra-regular">all of it. </span>Accordingly, once he has sifted out the impurities, he never agrees to accept any quantity of impurities, and so the seller must take back all the impurities.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And some say </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">a penalty. </span>They understand that it is <span class="gemarra-regular">usual </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">a quarter-</span><span class="it-text">kav</span> of impurities to be present in each <span class="it-text">se</span><span class="it-text">’a</span> of produce, and so it is presumed that a buyer accepts that quantity. <span class="gemarra-regular">More </span>than a quarter-<span class="it-text">kav</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is unusual, and </span>consequently the seller is suspected of having deceitfully <span class="gemarra-regular">mixed </span>additional impurities into the produce that he sold. <span class="gemarra-regular">And since </span>the seller deceitfully <span class="gemarra-regular">mixed </span>in impurities, <span class="gemarra-regular">the Sages penalized him </span>by requiring him to pay for <span class="gemarra-regular">all of </span>the impurities present, even those which he did not add.
The Gemara presents <span class="gemarra-regular">a mnemonic </span>for the cases it will cite: <span class="gemarra-regular">All two documents of Ravin bar Rav Naḥman </span>are <span class="gemarra-regular">exploitation and a contract.</span>
The Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises an objection </span>to Rav Huna’s ruling from a mishna (<span class="it-text">Kilayim</span> 2:1): With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">any </span><span class="gemarra-italic">se’a</span> of seeds <span class="gemarra-regular">that contains a quarter</span>-<span class="it-text">kav</span> or more of seeds <span class="gemarra-regular">of a different kind</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> before sowing such seeds <span class="gemarra-regular">one must reduc</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> the quantity of the other kind of seeds in the mixture so as not to violate the prohibition against growing a mixture of diverse kinds (see Leviticus 19:19). The Gemara explains: It can be <span class="gemarra-regular">assumed that </span>the presence of <span class="gemarra-regular">a quarter-</span><span class="it-text">kav</span> of seeds of a different kind per <span class="it-text">se’a</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>the prohibition of <span class="gemarra-regular">diverse kind</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is as </span>problematic as <span class="gemarra-regular">more than a quarter-</span><span class="it-text">kav</span> of impurities per <span class="it-text">se’a</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>a sale, as discussed <span class="gemarra-regular">here, and </span>therefore, since the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>with regard to diverse kinds only that <span class="gemarra-regular">one must reduce </span>the additional amount, but not that one is required to remove all the seeds of a different kind, it follows that the same is true in the case of a sale, and the seller should not have to take back all of the impurities. This contradicts Rav Huna’s ruling.
The Gemara deflects the challenge: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>this assumption is not necessarily correct; perhaps the presence of <span class="gemarra-regular">a quarter-</span><span class="it-text">kav</span> of seeds of a different kind per <span class="it-text">se’a</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to diverse kinds is comparable to a quarter-</span><span class="it-text">kav</span> of impurities per <span class="it-text">se’a</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>a sale, as discussed <span class="gemarra-regular">here</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and both are considered acceptable levels of admixture.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">so </span>that a quarter-<span class="it-text">kav</span> of seeds of a different kind per <span class="it-text">se’a</span> is acceptable, <span class="gemarra-regular">why </span>does the mishna teach that <span class="gemarra-regular">one must reduce </span>the quantity of seeds of a different kind? The Gemara answers: The requirement is a rabbinic decree <span class="gemarra-regular">due to the severity of </span>the prohibition of <span class="gemarra-regular">diverse kinds.</span>
The Gemara challenges this answer: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, </span>

Daf 94b

<span class="gemarra-regular">say the latter clause </span>of the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei says: </span>It is insufficient to merely reduce the quantity of seeds of a different kind; rather, <span class="gemarra-regular">one must pick out </span>all the seeds of a different kind.
The Gemara explains the difficulty: <span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, if you say </span>that a quarter-<span class="it-text">kav</span> of seeds of a different kind per <span class="it-text">se’a</span> with regard to diverse kinds <span class="gemarra-regular">is comparable to more than a quarter-</span><span class="it-text">kav</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">of impuritie</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> per <span class="it-text">se’a</span> with regard to a sale, then it is <span class="gemarra-regular">about this that they disagree: The first </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> holds that we do not penalize </span>one by requiring him to remove <span class="gemarra-regular">that which is permitted due to that which is prohibited, </span>and consequently it is sufficient to merely reduce the quantity of seeds of a different kind to an acceptable level, <span class="gemarra-regular">whereas Rabbi Yosei holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">we </span>do <span class="gemarra-regular">penalize </span>one by requiring him to remove that which is permitted due to that which is prohibited. <span class="gemarra-regular">But if you say </span>that a quarter-<span class="it-text">kav</span> of seeds of a different kind per <span class="it-text">se</span><span class="it-text">’a</span> with regard to diverse kinds <span class="gemarra-regular">is comparable to a quarter-</span><span class="it-text">ka</span><span class="it-text">v</span> of impurities per <span class="it-text">se’a</span> with regard to a sale, then <span class="gemarra-regular">why </span>does Rabbi Yosei rule that <span class="gemarra-regular">one must pick out </span>all the seeds of a different kind?
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">There, </span>with regard to diverse kinds, <span class="gemarra-regular">this is the reasoning of Rabbi Yosei: </span>One must pick out all the seeds, <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>once he is purifying the admixture of seeds, if he deliberately leaves a quantity of seeds of a different kind mixed in, <span class="gemarra-regular">it appears as though he is </span>intentionally planting and <span class="gemarra-regular">maintaining diverse kinds </span>in his field.
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>another challenge to Rav Huna’s ruling from a mishna (<span class="it-text">Bava</span> <span class="it-text">Metzia</span> 37a): In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>people <span class="gemarra-regular">who deposite</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> money <span class="gemarra-regular">with one </span>person, and <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>one deposited <span class="gemarra-regular">one hundred dinars and that </span>one deposited <span class="gemarra-regular">two hundred </span>dinars, and when they return to collect their deposits, <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">says: My </span>deposit was <span class="gemarra-regular">two hundred </span>dinars, <span class="gemarra-regular">and that </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">says: My </span>deposit was <span class="gemarra-regular">two hundred </span>dinars, the bailee <span class="gemarra-regular">gives one hundred dinars to this </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">and one hundred dinars to that </span>one, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the rest </span>of the money, i.e., the contested one hundred dinars, <span class="gemarra-regular">will be placed </span>in a safe place <span class="gemarra-regular">until Elijah comes </span>and prophetically determines the truth. In this case, one of the parties is certainly lying, but nevertheless, the Sages did not penalize the parties by placing all of the money in a safe place. Similarly, in the case of a sale, where a seller deceitfully mixed additional impurities into the produce he sold, he should not be penalized and required to take back all of the impurities.
The Gemara rejects this challenge: <span class="gemarra-regular">How can </span>these cases <span class="gemarra-regular">be compared? There, </span>in the case of the deposits, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is certain </span>that at least <span class="gemarra-regular">one hundred dinars </span>belongs <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">Master and one hundred dinars </span>belongs <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Master. Here, </span>in the case of a sale where there is an unacceptable proportion of impurities mixed in, <span class="gemarra-regular">who can say that </span>the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">did not mix in the entire </span>amount intentionally? Accordingly, no proof can be drawn from the mishna.
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a support for Rav Huna’s ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">from the latter clause </span>of that mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei says: If so, what did the swindler lose? </span>He lost nothing by claiming the one hundred dinars that belongs to another, and he has no incentive to admit the truth. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, the entire </span>deposit <span class="gemarra-regular">will be placed </span>in a safe place <span class="gemarra-regular">until Elijah comes. </span>Since through his lie the swindler risks losing even the one hundred dinars that he deposited, perhaps that will induce him to admit his deceit. According to Rabbi Yosei, the Sages did penalize one who acts deceitfully, which accords with Rav Huna’s ruling.
The Gemara rejects the proof: <span class="gemarra-regular">How can </span>these cases <span class="gemarra-regular">be compared? There, </span>in the case of the deposits, <span class="gemarra-regular">there is certainly a swindler, </span>and it is reasonable to penalize both parties in order to induce the swindler to admit his deceit. <span class="gemarra-regular">Here, </span>in the case of a sale where there is an unacceptable level of impurities mixed in with the produce, <span class="gemarra-regular">who can say that </span>the seller intentionally <span class="gemarra-regular">mixed in </span>anything? Perhaps the impurities were inadvertently mixed in during the processing. Accordingly, no proof can be drawn from the mishna.
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>another support for Rav Huna’s ruling from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: In the case of a promissory <span class="gemarra-regular">note in which </span>the details of a loan with <span class="gemarra-regular">interest </span>were written, the court <span class="gemarra-regular">penalizes </span>the creditor, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he may collect neither the principal nor the interest</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span> this is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of Rabbi Meir. </span>According to Rabbi Meir, the Sages did penalize one who acts improperly, which accords with Rav Huna’s ruling.
The Gemara rejects the proof: <span class="gemarra-regular">How can </span>these cases <span class="gemarra-regular">be compared? There, </span>in the case of a loan with interest, it is already <span class="gemarra-regular">at the time of the writing </span>of the bill that the lender <span class="gemarra-regular">performed the </span>transgression of <span class="gemarra-regular">placin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span> interest upon the borrower. Since he certainly committed a transgression, it is reasonable that the Sages penalized him. But <span class="gemarra-regular">here, </span>in the case of a sale where there is an unacceptable proportion of impurities mixed in with the produce, <span class="gemarra-regular">who can say that </span>the seller intentionally <span class="gemarra-regular">mixed in </span>anything? Perhaps the impurities were inadvertently mixed in during the processing. Accordingly, no proof can be drawn from the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>.
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a challenge to Rav Huna’s ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">from the latter clause </span>of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">But the Rabbis say: He may collect the principal but may not collect the interest. </span>According to Rabbi Meir, the Sages did not penalize one who acts improperly, contrary to Rav Huna’s ruling.
The Gemara rejects this challenge: <span class="gemarra-regular">How can </span>these cases <span class="gemarra-regular">be compared? There, </span>in the case of a loan with interest, according to strict <span class="it-text">halakha</span> it <span class="gemarra-regular">is certainly permitted </span>to collect <span class="gemarra-regular">the principal, </span>so the Sages did not penalize him with regard to it. But <span class="gemarra-regular">here, </span>in the case of a sale where there is an unacceptable proportion of impurities mixed in, <span class="gemarra-regular">who can say that </span>the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">did not mix in the entire </span>amount intentionally? Accordingly, no proof can be drawn from the mishna.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>further support for Rav Huna’s ruling from <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>which <span class="gemarra-regular">Ravin bar Rav Naḥman teaches </span>(104b). Ravin bar Rav Naḥman’s statement is with regard to a situation when land that was sold is later found to be larger than stated at the time of the sale. If the deviation is not more than an area required to sow a quarter-<span class="it-text">kav</span> of seed per <span class="it-text">beit</span> <span class="it-text">se’a</span> of land, then the buyer need not return any land to the seller. If the proportion of extra land is larger than this, <span class="gemarra-regular">not only must </span>the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">return the extra </span>land that is beyond the limit of a quarter-<span class="it-text">kav</span> area per <span class="it-text">beit</span> <span class="it-text">se’a</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">but he must </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">return to him every one of the </span>extra <span class="gemarra-regular">quarter-</span><span class="it-text">kav</span> areas of land that he received beyond the stated area of a <span class="it-text">beit</span> <span class="it-text">kor</span>. The Gemara infers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Apparently, when one is required to return </span>part of a sale because of a discrepancy that is beyond the acceptable limit of deviation, then <span class="gemarra-regular">one is required to return </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">entire </span>discrepancy and not just the amount that is beyond the acceptable limit. This supports Rav Huna’s ruling.
The Gemara rejects this: <span class="gemarra-regular">How can </span>these cases <span class="gemarra-regular">be compared? </span>

Daf 95a

<span class="gemarra-regular">There, </span>in the case of the sale of land, the reason the buyer may keep the extra land when it is less than the acceptable limit is that the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>I am selling you this piece of land <span class="gemarra-regular">whether it is </span>slightly <span class="gemarra-regular">less or </span>slightly <span class="gemarra-regular">mor</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> than a <span class="it-text">beit</span> <span class="it-text">kor</span>, i.e., he agrees to accept a small deviation from the stated area. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>while an extra <span class="gemarra-regular">quarter</span>-<span class="it-text">kav</span> area per <span class="it-text">beit</span> <span class="it-text">se’a</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">not significant, </span>and therefore the seller is willing to forgo it, <span class="gemarra-regular">more than a quarter</span>-<span class="it-text">kav</span> area per <span class="it-text">beit</span> <span class="it-text">se’a</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is significant, </span>and the seller is not willing to forgo any of it. Consequently, all of the extra land must be returned. By contrast, in the case of Rav Huna’s ruling, the buyer is aware that it is normal to have a certain proportion of impurities mixed in and accepts this possibility from the outset. Accordingly, even if the proportion of impurities is greater than the acceptable limit, it might be sufficient if the seller takes back only the quantity of impurities above the acceptable limit.
The Gemara explains why more than an area required to sow a quarter-<span class="it-text">kav</span> of seed per <span class="it-text">beit</span> <span class="it-text">se’a</span> of land is significant: The reason is <span class="gemarra-regular">that since </span>all those extra areas of land <span class="gemarra-regular">are fit to combine together to </span>form an area in which one could sow <span class="gemarra-regular">nine </span><span class="gemarra-italic">ka</span><span class="gemarra-italic">v</span> of seed, the extra land <span class="gemarra-regular">is a significant plot of land in its own right, and </span>therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">it must </span>all <span class="gemarra-regular">be returned. </span>The land that was sold was stated to be a <span class="it-text">beit</span> <span class="it-text">kor</span>, which is thirty <span class="it-text">beit</span> <span class="it-text">se’a</span>. If the area of the extra land was of a proportion somewhat more than an area required to sow a quarter-<span class="it-text">kav</span> of seed per <span class="it-text">beit</span> <span class="it-text">se’a</span> of land, then thirty such areas would collectively be about equal to an area required to sow nine <span class="it-text">kav</span>.
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a support for Rav Huna’s ruling from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">The </span><span class="it-text">halakha</span> of price <span class="gemarra-regular">exploitatio</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> is that if the disparity is <span class="gemarra-regular">less than one-sixth </span>of the value of the merchandise, the <span class="gemarra-regular">merchandise is acquired </span>immediately and the sum of the exploitation need not be returned. If the disparity is <span class="gemarra-regular">greater than one-sixth, </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">the transaction is nullified. </span>If the disparity is precisely <span class="gemarra-regular">one-sixth, </span>the buyer has <span class="gemarra-regular">acquired </span>the merchandise, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the one who benefited from the exploitation <span class="gemarra-regular">returns </span>the entire sum of the <span class="gemarra-regular">exploitation.</span>
The Gemara explains the proof: <span class="gemarra-regular">Why, </span>in the case where the disparity is precisely one-sixth, is the entire sum of the exploitation returned? Instead, <span class="gemarra-regular">let him return </span>only a small amount of the exploitation <span class="gemarra-regular">until </span>the difference is <span class="gemarra-regular">less than one-sixth. </span>The Gemara concludes: <span class="gemarra-regular">Learn from </span>the fact that he must return the entire sum that <span class="gemarra-regular">when one is required to return </span>part of a sale because of a discrepancy that is beyond the acceptable limit of deviation, <span class="gemarra-regular">one is required to return </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">entire </span>discrepancy and not just the amount that is beyond the acceptable limit. This supports Rav Huna’s ruling.
The Gemara rejects this: <span class="gemarra-regular">How can </span>these cases <span class="gemarra-regular">be compared? There, </span>in the case of exploitation, the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">initially said to </span>the buyer that he would sell the merchandise for a sum <span class="gemarra-regular">equal to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">its value</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Any price difference should be unacceptable. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>a disparity of <span class="gemarra-regular">less than one-sixth is not recognizable in </span>a sale worth <span class="gemarra-regular">one hundred dinars</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and a person </span>will <span class="gemarra-regular">forgo </span>it. By contrast, a disparity of <span class="gemarra-regular">one-sixth</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is considered </span>significant, <span class="gemarra-regular">and a person will not forgo </span>it. Consequently, the entire sum of the exploitation must be returned. If the disparity is <span class="gemarra-regular">greater than one-sixth, it is a mistaken transaction and the transaction is nullified. </span>By contrast, in the case of Rav Huna’s ruling, the buyer is aware that it is normal to have a certain proportion of impurities mixed in and accepted that possibility from the outset. Accordingly, even if the proportion of impurities was greater than the acceptable limit, it might be sufficient if the seller takes back only the quantity of impurities above the acceptable limit.
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a support for Rav Huna’s ruling from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: When <span class="gemarra-regular">one receives a field from another </span>under a contract <span class="gemarra-regular">to plan</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> trees in it, then <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>field owner <span class="gemarra-regular">accepts upon himself </span>that there may be <span class="gemarra-regular">ten deficient trees per </span>every <span class="gemarra-regular">hundre</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> trees planted, as he is aware that not every tree planted will necessarily flourish. If the number of deficient trees is <span class="gemarra-regular">more than this, </span>the court <span class="gemarra-regular">imposes upon him </span>the responsibility to replace <span class="gemarra-regular">all </span>of those trees, and not only the number of trees above the acceptable limit. This supports Rav Huna’s ruling.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, said: </span>There is no proof from this case, because <span class="gemarra-regular">any </span>time there are <span class="gemarra-regular">more than this </span>number of deficient trees, the overall area that contains the deficient trees is of a size equivalent to a whole field. Therefore, the contractor is <span class="gemarra-regular">comparable to one who comes to plant </span>a whole field <span class="gemarra-regular">from the outset</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> who has not fulfilled his remit if he plants only a few trees; rather, he must plant the entire area. But in the case of Rav Huna’s ruling, the impurities never constitute an independent unit; consequently, it might be sufficient if the seller takes back only the quantity of impurities that is above the acceptable limit.
§ The mishna teaches: When purchasing <span class="gemarra-regular">a cellar </span>containing barrels <span class="gemarra-regular">of wine, </span>one accepts upon himself that up to ten barrels of souring wine may be present in each hundred barrels purchased. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What are the circumstances </span>of the sale? <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>the buyer: I am selling to you <span class="gemarra-regular">a wine cellar, with-out specification </span>of which cellar he meant, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">difficult, </span>as the Gemara will soon explain. And <span class="gemarra-regular">if he said to him: </span>I am selling to you <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>particular <span class="gemarra-regular">wine cellar, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">difficult.</span>
The Gemara elaborates: <span class="gemarra-regular">If he said to him: </span>I am selling to you <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>particular wine <span class="gemarra-regular">cellar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> it is <span class="gemarra-regular">difficult, as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: If one said to a buyer: <span class="gemarra-regular">I am selling to you a wine cellar, </span>then he is required to <span class="gemarra-regular">give him wine that is all </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">good </span>quality, i.e., the buyer does not have to accept any quantity of souring wine. If he said: <span class="gemarra-regular">I am selling to you this </span>particular <span class="gemarra-regular">wine cellar, </span>then he may <span class="gemarra-regular">give him </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">wine </span>that is in his possession, even if it is of the quality <span class="gemarra-regular">that is sold in the shops</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., it is beginning to sour. If he said: <span class="gemarra-regular">I am selling to you this</span> particular <span class="gemarra-regular">cellar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> without mentioning the word: Wine, then <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">everything </span>he gives him is wine that had turned into <span class="gemarra-regular">vinegar, it has come to </span>the buyer and the sale is valid. The mishna’s ruling that the buyer must accept that up to ten percent of the wine might be souring does not accord with any of the rulings of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Actually, </span>the mishna concerns a case <span class="gemarra-regular">when he said to </span>the buyer: I am selling to you <span class="gemarra-regular">a wine cellar, without specification</span> of which cellar he was selling. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>emend the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> and <span class="gemarra-regular">teach </span>the following qualification <span class="gemarra-regular">in the first clause of the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">baraita</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: And </span>the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">accepts upon himsel</span><span class="gemarra-regular">f </span> that up to <span class="gemarra-regular">ten </span>barrels of <span class="gemarra-regular">souring </span>wine may be present <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>each <span class="gemarra-regular">hundred </span>barrels purchased.
The Gemara challenges this addition: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if he sold the buyer a wine cellar <span class="gemarra-regular">without specification </span>of which one he was selling, <span class="gemarra-regular">does </span>the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">accept </span>upon himself any souring wine at all? <span class="gemarra-regular">Didn’t Rabbi Ḥiyya teach: One who sells a barrel of win</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to another </span>must <span class="gemarra-regular">give him wine that is all </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">good </span>quality? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">A barrel is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> different, because </span>the wine inside <span class="gemarra-regular">is all one </span>body of <span class="gemarra-regular">win</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> of the same quality.
The Gemara once again challenges the addition: <span class="gemarra-regular">But didn’t Rav Zevid teach </span>a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> of the <span class="gemarra-regular">school of Rabbi Oshaya: </span>If one says to a buyer: <span class="gemarra-regular">I am selling to you a wine cellar, </span>then he is required to <span class="gemarra-regular">give him wine that is all </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">good </span>quality? Similarly, if he said: <span class="gemarra-regular">I am selling to you this </span>particular <span class="gemarra-regular">wine cellar, </span>then he is required to <span class="gemarra-regular">give him wine that is all </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">good </span>quality, but the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">accepts upon himself ten souring </span>barrels <span class="gemarra-regular">per hundred </span>barrels. 

Daf 95b

Rav Zevid concludes: <span class="gemarra-regular">And this is </span>the case of the <span class="gemarra-regular">storeroom</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., the cellar, <span class="gemarra-regular">that the Sages taught in the mishna. </span>It is clear from this <span class="it-text">baraita</span> both that it contradicts the suggested addition to the previous <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, and that the mishna concerns a case where one specified which wine cellar he was selling.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>as indicated by the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">the mishna also </span>concerns a case where one <span class="gemarra-regular">says to </span>the buyer: I am selling you <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>particular cellar, and because he specified a particular cellar the buyer accepts upon himself the possibility that up to ten barrels per hundred might be sour.
Having retracted the addition to the first <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, the Gemara asks: If so, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">difficult </span>to reconcile the first <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, which rules that if the seller specified that he was selling <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>cellar, he must provide wine that is all of good quality, with the second <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, that of Rav Zevid, which rules with regard to the same case, in which the seller specified he was selling <span class="gemarra-regular">this</span> cellar, that the buyer accepts that up to ten barrels per hundred may contain souring wine.
The Gemara answers: This is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult.
