This </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span> is referring to a case where the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him </span>that he needs the wine <span class="gemarra-regular">for cooking</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and therefore he requires good-quality wine, whereas <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span> is referring to a case where the buyer did <span class="gemarra-regular">not say to him </span>that he needs the wine <span class="gemarra-regular">for cooking. </span>The Gemara elaborates: The second <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, taught by <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Zevid, </span>is referring to a case where the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>that he needs the wine <span class="gemarra-regular">for cooking, </span>whereas the first <span class="gemarra-italic">baraita</span> is referring to a case where the buyer did <span class="gemarra-regular">not say to him </span>that he requires it <span class="gemarra-regular">for cooking.</span>
The Gemara concludes: <span class="gemarra-regular">Therefore, </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is that if one said that he is selling: <span class="gemarra-regular">A wine cellar, and </span>the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>I need the wine <span class="gemarra-regular">for cooking</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> then the seller is obligated to <span class="gemarra-regular">give him wine that is all </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">good </span>quality. If one said that he is selling: <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>particular <span class="gemarra-regular">wine cellar, and </span>the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>I need the wine <span class="gemarra-regular">for cooking, </span>then the seller is obligated to <span class="gemarra-regular">give him wine that is all </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">good </span>quality, but the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">accepts upon himself ten </span>barrels of <span class="gemarra-regular">souring </span>wine <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>each <span class="gemarra-regular">hundred </span>barrels purchased. If one said that he is selling: <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>particular <span class="gemarra-regular">wine cellar, </span>and the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">did not say to him: </span>I need the wine <span class="gemarra-regular">for cooking</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> then the seller may <span class="gemarra-regular">give to him </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">wine </span>that is in his possession, even if it is of a quality <span class="gemarra-regular">that is sold in the shops, </span>i.e., it is beginning to sour.
<span class="gemarra-regular">A dilemma was raised before </span>the Sages: If one said that he is selling: <span class="gemarra-regular">A</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> wine cellar, and </span>the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">did not say to him: </span>I need the wine <span class="gemarra-regular">for cooking, what </span>is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Aḥa and Ravina disagree about this. One says: </span>The buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">must accept </span>ten barrels of souring wine per hundred, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the other <span class="gemarra-regular">one says: </span>The buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">need</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not accept </span>any barrels of souring wine.
The Gemara explains their reasoning. <span class="gemarra-regular">The one who says </span>that the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">must accept </span>ten barrels of souring wine per hundred <span class="gemarra-regular">infers </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">though </span>a precise reading of the <span class="it-text">barait</span><span class="it-text">a</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav Zevid, as it teaches: </span>If one says: <span class="gemarra-regular">I am selling to you a wine cellar, </span>then he is required to <span class="gemarra-regular">give him wine that is all </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">good </span>quality. <span class="gemarra-regular">And we interpreted </span>this <span class="it-text">baraita</span> as referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>I need the wine <span class="gemarra-regular">for cooking. </span>The Gemara explains the inference: <span class="gemarra-regular">The </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">reason </span>that he must provide him with wine that is all of good quality is <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him </span>that he needed it <span class="gemarra-regular">for cooking. </span>By inference, where the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">does not say to him: </span>I need it <span class="gemarra-regular">for cooking, </span>the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">must accept </span>ten barrels of souring wine per hundred.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And the one who says </span>that the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">need not accept </span>any barrels of souring wine <span class="gemarra-regular">infers </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">through </span>a precise reading <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span>the first <span class="gemarra-italic">baraita</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, as it teaches: </span>If one says: <span class="gemarra-regular">I am selling to you a wine cellar, </span>then he is required to <span class="gemarra-regular">give him wine that is all </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">good </span>quality. <span class="gemarra-regular">And we interpreted </span>this <span class="it-text">baraita</span> as referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he did not say to him: </span>I need the wine <span class="gemarra-regular">for cooking, </span>and even so, the buyer need not accept any barrels of souring wine.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>then, <span class="gemarra-regular">according to the one who infers </span>his opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">through </span>a precise reading of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav Zevid, the </span>first <span class="gemarra-italic">baraita</span> poses <span class="gemarra-regular">a difficulty. </span>The Gemara answers that according to his opinion, the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is incomplete and this </span>is what <span class="gemarra-regular">it is teaching: </span>If one says: I am selling to you a cellar of wine, then he is required to give him wine that is all of good quality. <span class="gemarra-regular">In what </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">is this statement said?</span> It is said in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>I need the wine <span class="gemarra-regular">for cooking. </span>By inference, where the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">did not say to him: </span>I need the wine <span class="gemarra-regular">for cooking, </span>the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">must accept </span>ten barrels of souring wine per hundred. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>if one said that he is selling: <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>particular <span class="gemarra-regular">wine cellar, and </span>the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">did not say to him:</span> I need the wine <span class="gemarra-regular">for cooking, </span>then one may <span class="gemarra-regular">give to him </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">wine</span> that is in his possession, even if it is of a quality <span class="gemarra-regular">that is sold in the shops, </span>i.e., it is beginning to sour.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And according to the one who infers </span>his opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">through </span>a precise reading of the first <span class="gemarra-italic">baraita</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav Zevid </span>poses <span class="gemarra-regular">a difficulty, as we interpreted it </span>as referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>I need the wine <span class="gemarra-regular">for cooking. </span>And this opinion inferred that if the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">did not say to him:</span> I need it <span class="gemarra-regular">for cooking, </span>then the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">must accept </span>ten barrels of souring wine per hundred.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">The same is true </span>according to both <span class="it-text">baraitot</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">that even where </span>the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">did not say to him: </span>I need the wine <span class="gemarra-regular">for cooking, </span>the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">need not accept </span>ten barrels of souring wine. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>there is no proof from the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that we interpreted </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> as referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he said to him: </span>I need it <span class="gemarra-regular">for cooking, </span>since we did so only <span class="gemarra-regular">due to the difficulty </span>of the contradiction between the ruling of the first <span class="it-text">baraita</span> in the case where the seller specified that he was selling <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>cellar and the ruling of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> of Rav Zevid in the same case where the seller specified he was selling <span class="gemarra-regular">this</span> cellar. Due to that difficulty, the entire <span class="it-text">baraita</span> was interpreted as referring to a case where the buyer said: I need the wine for cooking, despite the fact that in the case where he did not mention a specific cellar it makes no difference whether or not he said so.
§ Apropos wine that is sold in the shops, the Gemara considers additional <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> pertaining to such wine: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda says: Over wine </span>of the same quality as that <span class="gemarra-regular">which is sold in the shops</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> one recites the </span>standard <span class="gemarra-regular">blessing </span>for wine: <span class="gemarra-regular">Who creates fruit of the vine. </span>Despite the fact that such wine is not of the highest quality, it is still regarded as wine. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav Ḥisda said: Over wine that has formed a film </span>as it begins to sour, <span class="gemarra-regular">why do I </span>need to recite the blessing for wine? Since it has begun to sour, it is no longer regarded as wine. Instead, one should recite the generic blessing recited over foods of lower importance: By Whose word all things came to be.
The Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises an objection </span>to Rav Yehuda’s opinion. It is taught in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Over bread that has become moldy</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and over wine that has formed a film, and over a cooked dish that has spoiled, one recites </span>the blessing: <span class="gemarra-regular">By Whose word all things came to be. </span>Since these foods have partially spoiled, it is inappropriate to recite the specific blessings designated for such foods in their fresh state.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Zevid said: Rav Yehuda concedes </span>that one does not recite the blessing of: Who creates fruit of the vine, <span class="gemarra-regular">on wine made from grape seeds that is sold on the </span>street <span class="gemarra-regular">corners</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> It is to such significantly inferior wine that the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> refers. Wine sold in the shops still has the taste and appearance of wine, so one should recite the standard blessing for wine.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said to Rav Yosef: This </span>is the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>is the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥisda. In accordance with whose </span>opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">does the Master hold? </span>Rav Yosef <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: I know a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">barait</span><span class="gemarra-italic">a</span> from which it is possible to derive the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>. 

Daf 96a

<span class="gemarra-regular">As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> (<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span>, <span class="it-text">Terumot</span> 2:8): With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who inspects a barre</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span> to see if it still contains enough wine <span class="gemarra-regular">to continually </span>mentally <span class="gemarra-regular">separate </span><span class="gemarra-italic">teruma</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from it </span>to exempt other untithed wine he has, until all the wine in that barrel would be <span class="it-text">teruma</span> and would be given to a priest, <span class="gemarra-regular">and afterward </span>the contents of the barrel <span class="gemarra-regular">were found </span>to have turned to <span class="gemarra-regular">vinegar, </span>which cannot be set aside as <span class="it-text">teruma</span> for untithed wine, then <span class="gemarra-regular">all three days </span>after he had last inspected it, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">definitely </span>viewed as having been wine, and any wine for which <span class="it-text">teruma</span> was separated during those days is tithed. <span class="gemarra-regular">From that </span>point <span class="gemarra-regular">onward, </span>more than three days after the previous inspection, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">uncertai</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> as to whether it had already turned to vinegar, and any wine for which <span class="it-text">teruma</span> was separated during those days is not tithed.
The Gemara clarifies: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">saying</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rabbi Yoḥanan says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>is what it <span class="gemarra-regular">is saying: </span>For <span class="gemarra-regular">all </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">the first three days </span>following the inspection, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">definitely </span>viewed as having been <span class="gemarra-regular">wine </span>that had not yet turned to vinegar. <span class="gemarra-regular">From that </span>point <span class="gemarra-regular">onward, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">uncertain </span>as to whether it had already turned to vinegar. Accordingly, any wine for which <span class="it-text">teruma</span> was separated after those three days by means of designating the contents of that barrel as <span class="it-text">teruma</span> has an uncertain status.
<span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason? </span>The process in which <span class="gemarra-regular">wine turns sour </span>and becomes vinegar starts <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>the wine at the <span class="gemarra-regular">top </span>of the barrel; <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>wine which <span class="gemarra-regular">he tasted </span>when he inspected it, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>at that time <span class="gemarra-regular">it had not </span>yet <span class="gemarra-regular">soured. </span>And even <span class="gemarra-regular">if you say </span>that immediately <span class="gemarra-regular">after he tasted it </span>the wine began to <span class="gemarra-regular">sour, </span>during the following three days <span class="gemarra-regular">it </span>would <span class="gemarra-regular">have the odor of vinegar and its taste </span>would be <span class="gemarra-regular">of wine, and anything </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">has an odor of vinegar but its taste is of win</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> is regarded as <span class="gemarra-regular">wine.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi says </span>that there is a different interpretation of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: For <span class="gemarra-regular">all </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">the last three days </span>preceding the discovery that the wine had turned into vinegar, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">definitely </span>viewed as having been <span class="gemarra-regular">vinegar. From that </span>point and <span class="gemarra-regular">earlier, </span>until the time it had been inspected, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">uncertain </span>whether or not it was wine or vinegar.
<span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason? </span>The process in which <span class="gemarra-regular">wine turns sour </span>and becomes vinegar starts <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>the wine at the <span class="gemarra-regular">bottom </span>of the barrel, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>therefore, since the inspection was limited to the wine at the top of the barrel, it is possible to <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that wine at the bottom <span class="gemarra-regular">had</span> already started to <span class="gemarra-regular">sour and one was unaware of it. </span>Consequently, it is possible that on the day he tasted it the wine turned entirely into vinegar. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>even <span class="gemarra-regular">if you say </span>that the process in which <span class="gemarra-regular">wine turns sour </span>and becomes vinegar starts <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>the wine at the <span class="gemarra-regular">top </span>of the barrel, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>wine that <span class="gemarra-regular">he tasted </span>when he inspected it <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>at that time <span class="gemarra-regular">it had not </span>yet <span class="gemarra-regular">soured, perhaps </span>immediately <span class="gemarra-regular">after he tasted it </span>the wine began to <span class="gemarra-regular">sour, </span>in which case <span class="gemarra-regular">its odor </span>would be <span class="gemarra-regular">of vinegar and its taste of wine, and </span>anything that <span class="gemarra-regular">has an odor of vinegar but its taste is of wine </span>is regarded as <span class="gemarra-regular">vinegar.</span>
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">of the South taught </span>another interpretation of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">in the name of Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi: </span>For the <span class="gemarra-regular">first </span>three days it is <span class="gemarra-regular">definitely </span>viewed as having been <span class="gemarra-regular">wine. </span>For the <span class="gemarra-regular">last </span>three days it is <span class="gemarra-regular">definitely </span>viewed as having been <span class="gemarra-regular">vinegar. </span>The status of the wine during the <span class="gemarra-regular">intervening </span>period is <span class="gemarra-regular">uncertain.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">This matter itself </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">difficult, </span>as, since <span class="gemarra-regular">you said </span>that for the <span class="gemarra-regular">first </span>three days it is <span class="gemarra-regular">definitely </span>viewed as having been <span class="gemarra-regular">wine; apparently, </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">it has the odor of vinegar but its taste is of wine </span>it is regarded as <span class="gemarra-regular">wine. But then you said </span>that for the <span class="gemarra-regular">last </span>three days it is <span class="gemarra-regular">definitely </span>viewed as having been <span class="gemarra-regular">vinegar; apparently, </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">it has the odor of vinegar but its taste is of wine </span>it is regarded as <span class="gemarra-regular">vinegar, </span>as it can be established only that the odor had changed three days ago.
The Gemara resolves the difficulty: The Sages of the South hold that as long as the wine still tastes like wine, it is regarded as wine. When they said that when a barrel is found to contain vinegar it is certain that the wine had already turned into vinegar three days previously, they were referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the barrel <span class="gemarra-regular">was found </span>to contain <span class="gemarra-regular">strong vinegar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as, had it not </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">soured three days </span>previously, the barrel <span class="gemarra-regular">would not have been found </span>to contain <span class="gemarra-regular">strong vinegar; </span>rather, it would contain only mild vinegar.
Rav Yosef claimed that this <span class="it-text">baraita</span> can serve as proof with regard to which blessing is recited over wine that has the odor of vinegar but tastes like wine. Having cited three different interpretations of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, the Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">In accordance with </span>whose interpretation did Rav Yosef <span class="gemarra-regular">resolve </span>the question of which blessing to recite? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Mari and Rav Zevid disagree about it. One said </span>that Rav Yosef resolved it <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the interpretation of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan, </span>that this liquid is regarded as wine and the blessing for wine should be recited over it. <span class="gemarra-regular">And one said </span>that Rav Yosef resolved it <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the interpretation of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi, </span>that the liquid is regarded as vinegar and the generic blessing: By Whose word all things came to be, should be recited over it. There is no definitive resolution of the dispute.
§ An amoraic dispute <span class="gemarra-regular">was stated </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who sells a barrel of wine to another, and </span>following the sale <span class="gemarra-regular">it turned to vinegar. Rav said: </span>If it soured during <span class="gemarra-regular">any of the first three days </span>following the sale, it is presumed that it had already began to sour <span class="gemarra-regular">in the domain of </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">seller</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and he bears financial responsibility for it; <span class="gemarra-regular">from that </span>point <span class="gemarra-regular">onward, </span>it is presumed that the wine soured <span class="gemarra-regular">in the domain of </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">buyer, </span>and it is his loss. 

Daf 96b

<span class="gemarra-regular">And Shmuel said: </span>Even if the wine sours shortly after the purchase, the seller does not bear responsibility, as <span class="gemarra-regular">the win</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is agitated </span>as it is carried <span class="gemarra-regular">upon the shoulders of its </span>new <span class="gemarra-regular">owner, </span>causing it to sour quickly.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef ruled </span>in an actual <span class="gemarra-regular">case in accordance with </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav, in </span>which <span class="gemarra-regular">bee</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> spoiled shortly after it was sold, <span class="gemarra-regular">and in accordance with </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Shmuel in </span>a similar case involving <span class="gemarra-regular">wine. And the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Shmuel.</span>
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Whether </span>one drinks <span class="gemarra-regular">date beer, or barley beer</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> or </span>a beverage made from soaking <span class="gemarra-regular">pomace </span>from the production of <span class="gemarra-regular">win</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> in water, known as <span class="it-text">tamad</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">one recites over them the blessing: By Whose word all things came to be. </span><span class="gemarra-italic">Aḥerim</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> say: Over </span>wine made from <span class="gemarra-regular">pomace that has the taste of wine </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">recites the blessing: Who creates fruit of the vine. Rabba and Rav Yosef both say: The </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">not in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-italic">Aḥerim</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: </span>According to the opinions <span class="gemarra-regular">of everyone </span>mentioned in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, if <span class="gemarra-regular">one poured three </span>jugs of water over grape pomace <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>then, after removing the pomace, the volume of the resulting beverage <span class="gemarra-regular">came to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">four </span>jugs, then that beverage <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>regarded as <span class="gemarra-regular">wine. </span>Evidently, a quarter of the resulting beverage is from juice that was contained in the pomace, which is pure wine, and that is a sufficient ratio for the beverage as a whole to be regarded as wine. The Gemara interjects Rava’s comments: With this statement, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava </span>conforms <span class="gemarra-regular">to his </span>standard line of <span class="gemarra-regular">reasoning, as Rava said: Any wine that does not contain three </span>parts <span class="gemarra-regular">water to one </span>part pure wine <span class="gemarra-regular">is not </span>regarded as <span class="gemarra-regular">wine, </span>as it is excessively strong.
Rava continues: If <span class="gemarra-regular">one poured thre</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> jugs of water over pomace, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the volume of the resulting beverage still <span class="gemarra-regular">came to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">three </span>jugs, then <span class="gemarra-regular">it is nothing, </span>i.e., it is not regarded as wine. <span class="gemarra-regular">When </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna’im</span> in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">disagree </span>is in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where one poured three </span>jugs of water over pomace <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the volume of the resulting beverage <span class="gemarra-regular">came to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">three and a half </span>jugs, <span class="gemarra-regular">as the Rabbis, </span>i.e., the first <span class="it-text">tanna</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">hold </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">three </span>jugs of water <span class="gemarra-regular">were absorbed into </span>the pomace and then the same <span class="gemarra-regular">three </span>jugs of water <span class="gemarra-regular">seeped out </span>of the pomace; therefore, there <span class="gemarra-regular">remains </span><span class="gemarra-regular">half </span>a jug of the resulting beverage that was originally pure wine contained in the pomace. <span class="gemarra-regular">But half </span>a jug of pure wine mixed <span class="gemarra-regular">into six half-</span>jugs of <span class="gemarra-regular">water is nothing, </span>i.e., the mixture is too weak to be regarded as wine.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span><span class="gemarra-italic">Aḥerim</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> hold </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">three </span>jugs of water <span class="gemarra-regular">were absorbed</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> into </span>the pomace but only <span class="gemarra-regular">two and a half </span>jugs of water <span class="gemarra-regular">seeped out </span>of the pomace, as one jug of water replaced the one jug of pure wine contained in the pomace. Therefore, there <span class="gemarra-regular">remains </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">jug </span>of the resulting beverage that is pure wine that was previously contained in the pomace. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">jug </span>of pure wine mixed <span class="gemarra-regular">into two and a half </span>jugs of water <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>regarded as <span class="gemarra-regular">full-fledged wine.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And where </span>the volume of the resulting beverage <span class="gemarra-regular">is greater than the amount </span>of water that was poured over the pomace, <span class="gemarra-regular">do </span>the Sages ever <span class="gemarra-regular">disagree? But didn’t we learn </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Ma’asrot</span> 5:6): 

Daf 97a

In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who produces </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tamad</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> a beverage made by steeping grape pomace in water, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he placed a measured </span>amount of <span class="gemarra-regular">water </span>into a container together with the pomace, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>after removing the pomace <span class="gemarra-regular">he found </span>that the volume of the <span class="it-text">tamad</span> produced was <span class="gemarra-regular">equivalent to the amount </span>of water used, one is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from the requirement to tithe the <span class="it-text">tamad</span>, even though the pomace came from grapes that had not been tithed. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Yehuda deems </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to tithe the <span class="it-text">tamad</span>. The Gemara explains the difficulty posed by this mishna: It would appear that <span class="gemarra-regular">they disagree only with regard to </span>a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the volume of the <span class="it-text">tamad</span> produced was <span class="gemarra-regular">equivalent to the amount </span>of water used, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>in a case where the volume of the <span class="it-text">tamad</span> produced was <span class="gemarra-regular">greater than the amount </span>of water used, <span class="gemarra-regular">they do not disagree; </span>rather, they all agree that it must be tithed because it is regarded as wine. This would appear to contradict Rava’s explanation.
The Gemara resolves the difficulty: Actually, <span class="gemarra-regular">the same is true </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">that they would disagree even where </span>the volume of the <span class="it-text">tamad</span> produced was <span class="gemarra-regular">greater than the amount </span>of water used. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the reason <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the mishna records only that <span class="gemarra-regular">they disagree </span>about a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the volume of the <span class="it-text">tamad</span> produced was <span class="gemarra-regular">equivalent to the amount </span>of water used is in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to convey to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> you the far-reaching nature of </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Yehuda, </span>who holds that one is liable to tithe the <span class="it-text">tamad</span> even in this case.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak asked Rav Ḥiyya bar Avin: </span>If one steeps <span class="gemarra-regular">pomace </span>and produces <span class="it-text">tamad</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">that has the taste of wine</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> what is </span>the blessing that one should recite before drinking it? Rav Ḥiyya bar Avin <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Do you hold </span>that such a beverage <span class="gemarra-regular">is wine? It is merely a sharp-flavored </span>beverage, not wine.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> concerning the production of successive batches of <span class="it-text">tamad</span> of decreasing strengths by reusing the pomace after each time a <span class="it-text">tamad</span> is produced: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">pomace of </span><span class="gemarra-italic">teruma</span> wine, the <span class="gemarra-regular">first and second </span>products are considered to be <span class="it-text">teruma</span>, and it is <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibite</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> for a non-priest to drink it. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">the third </span>product, a non-priest <span class="gemarra-regular">is permitted </span>to drink it. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir says: Even </span>with regard to the <span class="gemarra-regular">third </span>product, if the wine that seeps out of the pomace <span class="gemarra-regular">imparts </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">flavo</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> of wine to the water, it is forbidden to a non-priest.
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>with regard to water added to pomace <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span>second<span class="gemarra-regular">-tithe </span>wine, the <span class="gemarra-regular">first </span>product is also considered to be second tithe, and it is <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibited </span>to drink it outside Jerusalem. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">the second </span>product, it <span class="gemarra-regular">is permitted </span>to drink it anywhere. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir says: Even </span>with regard to the <span class="gemarra-regular">second </span>product, if the wine that seeps out of the pomace <span class="gemarra-regular">imparts </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">flavor </span>of wine to the water, it may be consumed only in Jerusalem. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>with regard to water added to pomace <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span>wine that was <span class="gemarra-regular">consecrate</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> to the Temple, up to the <span class="gemarra-regular">third </span>product it is <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibited </span>to derive any benefit from it, as it is considered to be consecrated, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>from <span class="gemarra-regular">the fourth </span>product, it <span class="gemarra-regular">is permitted. Rabbi Meir says: Even </span>with regard to the <span class="gemarra-regular">fourth </span>product, if the wine that seeps out of the pomace <span class="gemarra-regular">imparts </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">flavor </span>of wine to the water, it is prohibited.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises a contradiction </span>from a different <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="it-text">Tamad</span> produced from the pomace <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span>wine that was <span class="gemarra-regular">consecrated </span>to the Temple is <span class="gemarra-regular">always forbidden, </span>even after having steeped them many times, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the beverage produced from pomace <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span>second <span class="gemarra-regular">tithe is always permitted, </span>even from the first such product. The Gemara explains: The ruling concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">consecrated </span>pomace is <span class="gemarra-regular">difficult, </span>as it is contradicted by the ruling of the first <span class="it-text">baraita</span> concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">consecrated </span>pomace. And the ruling concerning second-<span class="gemarra-regular">tithe </span>pomace is <span class="gemarra-regular">difficult, </span>as it is contradicted by the ruling of the first <span class="it-text">baraita</span> concerning second-<span class="gemarra-regular">tithe </span>pomace.
The Gemara answers: The contradiction between the ruling of one <span class="it-text">baraita</span> concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">consecrated </span>pomace and the ruling of the other <span class="it-text">baraita</span> concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">consecrated </span>pomace is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult, </span>as one can explain that <span class="gemarra-regular">here, </span>the second <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is referring to pomace <span class="gemarra-regular">with inherent sanctity</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and <span class="gemarra-regular">there, </span>the first <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is referring to pomace <span class="gemarra-regular">with sanctity </span>that inheres in its <span class="gemarra-regular">value. </span>Also, the contradiction between the ruling of one <span class="it-text">baraita</span> concerning pomace of second <span class="gemarra-regular">tithe </span>and the ruling of the other <span class="it-text">baraita</span> concerning pomace of second <span class="gemarra-regular">tithe </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult, </span>as one can explain that <span class="gemarra-regular">here, </span>the first <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is referring to pomace whose status as second <span class="gemarra-regular">tithe </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">certain </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">there, </span>the second <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is referring to pomace <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span>second <span class="gemarra-regular">tithe </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">doubtfully tithed produce [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">demai</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says in the name of Rabbi Shimon ben Yehotzadak: </span>In the <span class="gemarra-regular">same way in which </span>the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>concerning differing strengths of <span class="it-text">tamad</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to their prohibition, </span>after a certain number of times the <span class="it-text">tamad</span> produced is not considered to be wine, <span class="gemarra-regular">so </span>too <span class="gemarra-regular">they said </span>the same rulings <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to their capacity to render </span>foods <span class="gemarra-regular">susceptible </span>to ritual impurity.
The Gemara asks: When the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">their capacity to render</span> other foods <span class="gemarra-regular">susceptible </span>to ritual impurity, why does it matter <span class="gemarra-regular">which </span>kind of beverage the <span class="it-text">tamad</span> is considered to be? <span class="gemarra-regular">Whether </span>the <span class="it-text">tamad</span> is regarded <span class="gemarra-regular">as wate</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> it can <span class="gemarra-regular">render </span>food <span class="gemarra-regular">susceptible </span>to impurity, or <span class="gemarra-regular">whether </span>it is regarded as <span class="gemarra-regular">wine it </span>can <span class="gemarra-regular">render </span>food <span class="gemarra-regular">susceptible </span>to impurity. The Gemara clarifies: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>in a case in <span class="gemarra-regular">which one produced </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tamad</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> rainwate</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> that he had not previously intended to use. Rainwater does not render food susceptible to ritual impurity, so the <span class="it-text">tamad</span> will do so only if it is regarded as wine.
The Gemara challenges this: <span class="gemarra-regular">But since he took </span>the rainwater <span class="gemarra-regular">and poured it into a container</span> holding the grape pomace, <span class="gemarra-regular">he has </span>thereby <span class="gemarra-regular">intended it </span>for a use. Even if the resulting <span class="it-text">tamad</span> is regarded as water, such rainwater renders food susceptible to ritual impurity. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the pomace <span class="gemarra-regular">produced </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tamad</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> by itself</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> having been steeped in water that happened to fall upon it.
The Gemara persists: The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> above states that from the third product, the <span class="it-text">tamad</span> is regarded as water, which the Gemara has explained is referring to rainwater that one did not intend to use and that consequently cannot render food susceptible to impurity. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But since he draws off </span>each subsequent lot of <span class="it-text">tamad</span> that is produced, <span class="gemarra-regular">one by one, </span>in order to allow more rainwater to fall onto the pomace and produce more <span class="it-text">tamad</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span>thereby demonstrates his <span class="gemarra-regular">intent to </span>use the rainwater. Therefore, even if the <span class="it-text">tamad</span> is regarded as water, it should render food susceptible to impurity. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa says </span>that this is a case <span class="gemarra-regular">of a cow that dran</span><span class="gemarra-regular">k</span> the lots of <span class="it-text">tamad</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">one by one, </span>and some inadvertently dripped from the cow’s mouth onto food. Since no person intended to use the <span class="it-text">tamad</span>, if it is regarded as water it will not render food susceptible to impurity.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Zutra bar Toviyya says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: One may recite the sanctification of the </span>Shabbat <span class="gemarra-regular">day only over wine </span>of a quality that is <span class="gemarra-regular">fit to be poured </span>as a libation <span class="gemarra-regular">upon the altar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
The Gemara asks: This statement is said <span class="gemarra-regular">to exclude what? If we say </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">to exclude </span>the use of <span class="gemarra-regular">wine </span>fresh <span class="gemarra-regular">from one’s press</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., grape juice, which has not yet fermented, that is difficult. <span class="gemarra-regular">But didn’t Rabbi Ḥiyya teach: One may not bring wine </span>fresh <span class="gemarra-regular">from his pres</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> as a libation <span class="it-text">ab</span> <span class="it-text">initio</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">but if one brought </span>it as a libation, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is valid </span>after the fact. <span class="gemarra-regular">And since if one brought </span>it as a libation <span class="gemarra-regular">it is valid </span>after the fact, <span class="gemarra-regular">we </span>should <span class="gemarra-regular">also </span>be able to use it for the sanctification of the Shabbat day, <span class="gemarra-regular">even</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">ab</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">initio</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>

Daf 97b

<span class="gemarra-regular">As Rava says: A person may squeeze </span>the juice from <span class="gemarra-regular">a cluster of grapes and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">recite the sanctification of the </span>Shabbat <span class="gemarra-regular">day over it.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>Rav’s statement is <span class="gemarra-regular">to exclude </span>wine that is taken <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">mouth of </span>the barrel, which has scum floating in it, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>wine taken <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">bottom of </span>the barrel, which contains the pomace. The Gemara challenges this: <span class="gemarra-regular">But didn’t Rabbi Ḥiyya teach: One may not bring </span>wine that is taken <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">mouth of </span>the barrel <span class="gemarra-regular">or from </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">bottom of </span>the barrel as a libation <span class="it-text">ab</span> <span class="it-text">initio</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">but if one brought</span> it as a libation <span class="gemarra-regular">it is valid </span>after the fact? Accordingly, it should be fit for use for the sanctification of the Shabbat day.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>Rav’s statement is <span class="gemarra-regular">to exclude black wine</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">borek</span> wine, <span class="gemarra-regular">sweet wine [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">heiliston</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> wine <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">cellar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and wine made <span class="gemarra-regular">from raisins</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> The Gemara challenges: <span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t it taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">With regard to all of </span>these types of wine, <span class="gemarra-regular">one may not bring </span>them as a libation <span class="it-text">ab</span> <span class="it-text">initio</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">but if one brought </span>one of them as a libation <span class="gemarra-regular">it is valid </span>after the fact. Accordingly, it should be fit for use for the sanctification of the Shabbat day.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>Rav’s statement serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to exclude souring wine</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> diluted </span>wine, wine that has been left <span class="gemarra-regular">uncovered</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as there is a concern that a snake may have injected its venom into it, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>wine made <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>grape <span class="gemarra-regular">pomace, and </span>wine that has a <span class="gemarra-regular">foul odor. As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">With regard to all of </span>these types of wine, <span class="gemarra-regular">one may not bring </span>them as a libation, <span class="gemarra-regular">and if one brought </span>one of them as a libation, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is disqualified.</span>
The Gemara asks again: Rav’s statement serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to exclude which </span>of these types of wine? <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>one suggests Rav intended <span class="gemarra-regular">to exclude souring </span>wine, that cannot be, as the status of wine that tastes like wine but has the odor of vinegar <span class="gemarra-regular">is the</span> subject of a <span class="gemarra-regular">dispute between Rabbi Yoḥanan and Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi </span>(96a).
<span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>one suggests that Rav’s statement serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to exclude diluted </span>wine, why would such wine be disqualified for the sanctification of the Shabbat day? Diluting wine <span class="gemarra-regular">is an improvement </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of it, as Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, says: </span>Even though the Rabbis disagree with Rabbi Eliezer and hold that over undiluted wine one recites the blessing: Who created the fruit of the vine, nevertheless the <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbis concede to Rabbi Eliezer with regard to a cup </span>used <span class="gemarra-regular">for a blessing, </span>such as the cup of wine over which Grace after Meals is recited, <span class="gemarra-regular">that one does not recite </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">blessing over it until he adds water to it </span>to make it palatable.
<span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>one suggests that Rav’s statement serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to exclude </span>wine that has been left <span class="gemarra-regular">uncovered, </span>it would be unnecessary for Rav to teach this, because such wine, which <span class="gemarra-regular">is dangerous </span>to drink, as a snake may have injected its venom into it, is already forbidden.
<span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>one suggests that Rav’s statement serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to exclude </span>wine made <span class="gemarra-regular">from pomace, what are the circumstances? If </span>it is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where one poured three </span>jugs of water over the pomace <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the volume of the resulting beverage <span class="gemarra-regular">came to fou</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> jugs, that <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">full-fledged wine, </span>which may certainly be used for the sanctification of the Shabbat day. <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>it is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">where one poured three </span>jugs of water over the pomace, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the resulting beverage <span class="gemarra-regular">came to three and a half </span>jugs, this <span class="gemarra-regular">is the </span>subject of a <span class="gemarra-regular">dispute </span>between <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis and </span><span class="gemarra-italic">Aḥerim</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>and the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is in accordance with the opinion of the Rabbis, who rule that it is not regarded as wine.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>Rav’s statement serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to exclude </span>wine <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>has <span class="gemarra-regular">a foul odor</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> And if you wish, say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">actually </span>his statement serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to exclude </span>wine that has been left <span class="gemarra-regular">uncovered, and </span>it teaches the novelty that <span class="gemarra-regular">even though one passes it through a sieve, in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Neḥemya </span>(see <span class="it-text">Terumot</span> 8:7), <span class="gemarra-regular">nevertheless, </span>it still may not be used for the sanctification of the Shabbat day. This is because it is disrespectful to use inferior wine for a mitzva, as derived from the verse in which God rebukes the Jewish people for offering lame animals as offerings: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Present it now unto your governor; will he be pleased with you or will he accept your person? </span>says the Lord of hosts” (Malachi 1:8).
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Kahana, father-in-law of Rav Mesharshiyya, asked Rava: </span>With regard to using <span class="gemarra-regular">white win</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> for libations and for the sanctification of the Shabbat day, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? <span class="gemarra-regular">He said to him </span>in response that the verse states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Do not look upon the wine when it is red,</span> when it gives its color in the cup, when it glides down smoothly” (Proverbs 23:31), which indicates that red wine is considered to be of a superior quality.
§ The mishna teaches: When purchasing <span class="gemarra-regular">jugs </span>of wine <span class="gemarra-regular">in the Sharon </span>region, he accepts upon himself that up to ten inferior-quality jugs may be present in each hundred jugs purchased. <span class="gemarra-regular">It was taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: The buyer must accept ten inferior-quality jugs in one hundred only when even those ten <span class="gemarra-regular">inferior-quality jugs </span>are <span class="gemarra-regular">beautifu</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and sealed with pitch </span>to strengthen them.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If one <span class="gemarra-regular">sells wine to another and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">it </span><span class="gemarra-regular">sours</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">does not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">bear </span>financial <span class="gemarra-regular">responsibility for its </span>loss. <span class="gemarra-regular">But if it is known </span>of this seller <span class="gemarra-regular">that his</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> wine </span>always <span class="gemarra-regular">sours, then this </span>sale <span class="gemarra-regular">is a mistaken transaction, </span>i.e., one based upon false assumptions, as the buyer intended to purchase wine that would maintain its quality; therefore, the seller must reimburse the buyer. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if </span>the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>the buyer: It is <span class="gemarra-regular">wine</span>

Daf 98a

that is <span class="gemarra-regular">spiced</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> which is preserved and of lasting quality, that <span class="gemarra-regular">I am selling to you, </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span><span class="gemarra-regular">bears </span>financial <span class="gemarra-regular">responsibility to provide him </span>with wine that will keep <span class="gemarra-regular">until </span>the festival of <span class="gemarra-italic">Shavuot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> And </span>if the seller said: I am selling you <span class="gemarra-regular">old </span>wine, he is responsible to provide wine <span class="gemarra-regular">from the previous year. And </span>if he said: I am selling you <span class="gemarra-regular">aged </span>wine, he is responsible to provide wine that is <span class="gemarra-regular">from three year</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> earlier.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, says: </span>When <span class="gemarra-regular">they taught </span>that the seller does not bear responsibility if the wine sours, that was <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>if it soured while <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">jugs of the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">buyer</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>if it soured <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">jugs of the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">seller</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> then the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">could say to him: This is your wine and this is your jug; </span>take it and reimburse me. Since it soured while still in the original jugs, it was clearly flawed from the outset.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>even <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>the wine soured while in the <span class="gemarra-regular">jugs of the seller, what of it? Let </span>the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>to the buyer: <span class="gemarra-regular">You should not have left i</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> for so long after purchasing it; I should not be responsible just because you chose to do so. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>this ruling is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>in a case where the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">had said to him </span>that he was purchasing the wine <span class="gemarra-regular">for cooking, </span>in which case it is understood that he needs it to maintain its quality over a longer period of time, as only a small amount is used each time.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And what impelled Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, to interpret the mishna as referring to </span>a case where the wine soured while in the <span class="gemarra-regular">jugs of the buyer, and where he had said to him </span>that he wanted the wine <span class="gemarra-regular">for cooking? </span>Instead, <span class="gemarra-regular">let him interpret it as referring to </span>a case where the wine soured while in the <span class="gemarra-regular">jugs of the seller, and </span>to <span class="gemarra-regular">where he had not said to him </span>that he wanted the wine <span class="gemarra-regular">for cooking.</span>
In explanation, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: The mishna was difficult for him, as it teaches </span>in the following clause: <span class="gemarra-regular">But if it is known </span>of this seller <span class="gemarra-regular">that his wine </span>always <span class="gemarra-regular">sours, then this </span>sale <span class="gemarra-regular">is a mistaken transaction. </span>With regard to this clause one could ask: <span class="gemarra-regular">Why </span>is that so? <span class="gemarra-regular">Let </span>the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">say to him: You should not have left it </span>for so long after purchasing it. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, isn’t it </span>correct to <span class="gemarra-regular">conclude from </span>that clause <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the mishna is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">had said to him </span>that he wants the wine <span class="gemarra-regular">for cooking? </span>The Gemara concludes: Yes, one can <span class="gemarra-regular">conclude from it </span>that this is so.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, <span class="gemarra-regular">disagrees </span>with the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav Ḥiyya bar Yosef, as Rav Ḥiyya bar Yosef says: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">wine, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">the owner’s </span>poor <span class="gemarra-regular">fortune </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">causes </span>the wine to go sour, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is stated: “And moreover, wine is a treacherous dealer; </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">haughty man </span>abides not” (Habakkuk 2:5), which is interpreted to mean that the wine of a haughty man will betray him, as it will sour as a punishment for his arrogance. Accordingly, since the wine soured after the buyer purchased it, he cannot place the blame upon the seller.
The Gemara offers additional homiletic interpretations of the verse just cited. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Mari said: One who is haughty is not accepted even by the members of his household</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as it is stated: “The haughty man abides not” </span>(Habakkuk 2:5). <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>does the phrase <span class="gemarra-regular">“abides </span><span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">y</span><span class="gemarra-italic">inveh</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] not” </span>mean? It means that <span class="gemarra-regular">even in his abode [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">naveh</span><span class="gemarra-regular">], </span>he is not accepted.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">anyone who glorifies himself </span>by wearing <span class="gemarra-regular">a garment of </span>the style worn by <span class="gemarra-regular">a Torah scholar, but </span>in reality <span class="gemarra-regular">he is not a Torah scholar, he will not be brought within the boundar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of the Holy One, Blessed be He, </span>in the World-to-Come. This is alluded to by the fact that it is <span class="gemarra-regular">written </span>in the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">here: “Abides </span><span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">y</span><span class="gemarra-italic">inveh</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] not,” and </span>the meaning of the word <span class="it-text">yinveh</span> may be derived from that which <span class="gemarra-regular">is written </span>in a verse <span class="gemarra-regular">there: “To Your holy habitation [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">neveh</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]” </span>(Exodus 15:13).
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava says: </span>In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who sells a barrel of wine to a shopkeepe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with the understanding </span>that the wine will be <span class="gemarra-regular">for servin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span> to the shopkeeper’s customers and that he will be liable to pay the seller only once the barrel is finished, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the wine <span class="gemarra-regular">spoiled </span>when <span class="gemarra-regular">one-half or one-third </span>of the wine still remained, <span class="gemarra-regular">the</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is that </span>the seller must <span class="gemarra-regular">accept </span>back the remaining wine <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the shopkeeper, as the shopkeeper is liable to pay only for the wine that he sells. <span class="gemarra-regular">And we stated this </span><span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the shopkeeper <span class="gemarra-regular">had not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">switched the ta</span><span class="gemarra-regular">p</span> of the barrel; <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">he had switched the tap, </span>the seller does <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>have to take the wine back and the shopkeeper must pay for it all. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>furthermore, <span class="gemarra-regular">we stated this </span><span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">only where </span>the wine soured <span class="gemarra-regular">before the market da</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> arrived </span>and the shopkeeper did not have the opportunity to sell the entire barrel; <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>if the wine was still of good quality when <span class="gemarra-regular">the market day arrived, </span>then the seller does <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>have to take the wine back.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rava says: </span>In the case of a vintner who enters a business venture with another person who will sell the wine for him and afterward they will split the profits, then if <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>middleman <span class="gemarra-regular">who receives the wine </span>to sell does so <span class="gemarra-regular">with the understanding that he will bring i</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to the por</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span>the city of <span class="gemarra-regular">Vol Shefa</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> and sell it only there, <span class="gemarra-regular">and before he arrives there </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">price </span>of the wine <span class="gemarra-regular">drops, the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">that</span> the vintner must <span class="gemarra-regular">accept </span>the loss.
With regard to the previous case, <span class="gemarra-regular">a dilemma was raised before </span>the Sages: If the wine <span class="gemarra-regular">becomes vinegar </span>before he reaches Vol Shefat, <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Hillel said to Rav Ashi: When we were in the study hall of Rav Kahana, he said to us: </span>If the wine becomes <span class="gemarra-regular">vinegar, </span>the vintner does <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>have to accept the loss; <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>this is <span class="gemarra-regular">not in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, </span>who holds that as long as the wine is in the jug of the seller he is able to return it to the seller. The reason for this is that it is possible that the poor fortune of the middleman caused it to sour.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And there are </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">who say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>if the wine turns into <span class="gemarra-regular">vinegar, </span>the vintner must <span class="gemarra-regular">also accept </span>the loss. <span class="gemarra-regular">In accordance with whose </span>opinion is this? It is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina.</span>
The mishna teaches: If the seller said: I am selling you <span class="gemarra-regular">old </span>wine, he is responsible to provide wine <span class="gemarra-regular">from the previous year. </span>And if he said: I am selling you aged wine, he is responsible to provide wine that is from three years earlier. 

Daf 98b

<span class="gemarra-regular">It is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>where he sold him aged wine, he is responsible to provide wine that will <span class="gemarra-regular">continue to age, </span>i.e., maintain its quality, <span class="gemarra-regular">until the festival </span>of <span class="it-text">Sukkot</span>.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who sells a plot </span>of land <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">another</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> with the buyer intending to build a bridal house for his son or a widowhood home for his daughter on that plot, <span class="gemarra-regular">and similarly, </span>with regard to a contractor <span class="gemarra-regular">who receives a plot </span>of land <span class="gemarra-regular">from another </span>under a commission <span class="gemarra-regular">to build for </span>the owner on that land <span class="gemarra-regular">a bridal house for his </span><span class="gemarra-regular">son</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">or a widowhood </span><span class="gemarra-regular">hom</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">for his daughter, </span>the terms of the transaction are a matter of dispute. The mishna presents the dispute: In the latter case, the contractor must <span class="gemarra-regular">build </span>a building that is at least <span class="gemarra-regular">four cubits by six </span>cubits in size, and similarly, in the case of the sale, the seller must provide a plot of land that can accommodate a building of that size; this is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of Rabbi Akiva. Rabbi Yishmael says: </span>A structure of <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>size <span class="gemarra-regular">is a cowshed, </span>and a bridal house or a widowhood home is larger than that.
<span class="gemarra-regular">One who wants to construct a cowshe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> builds </span>a structure at least <span class="gemarra-regular">four cubits by six </span>cubits in size.
The mishna delineates the standard dimensions for various other structures. <span class="gemarra-regular">A small house</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">six by eight </span>cubits. <span class="gemarra-regular">A large </span>house is <span class="gemarra-regular">eight by ten </span>cubits. <span class="gemarra-regular">A banquet hall [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">teraklin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">ten by ten </span>cubits. The standard <span class="gemarra-regular">height </span>for each of these structures is <span class="gemarra-regular">equal to</span> the sum of <span class="gemarra-regular">half its length and half its width. </span>There is <span class="gemarra-regular">a proof of the matter; Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: </span>The proportions are <span class="gemarra-regular">like the building of the Sanctuary; </span>it was forty cubits wide and twenty cubits long and its height was thirty cubits, which is the sum of half the width and half the length.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">Why do I </span>need the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">to teach </span>specifically: <span class="gemarra-regular">A bridal house for his son, and: A widowhood home for his daughter? </span>Instead, <span class="gemarra-regular">let it teach: A bridal house for his son or his daughter, and a widowhood home for his son or his daughter. </span>The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">It teaches us a matter in passing, that it is not the </span>proper <span class="gemarra-regular">manner </span>of conduct <span class="gemarra-regular">for a son-in-law to live in his father-in-law’s home. </span>Therefore, it is the father of the groom who generally provides a bridal home for the couple and the bride will return to live near her parents’ house only if she is widowed or divorced.
Support for this is <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is written in the book of ben Sira</span><span class="gemarra-regular">:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> I have weighed everything in the pan of a balance scale and I have not found anything inferior to bran</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> but inferior to bran is a son-in-law who lives in his father-in-law’s house</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and inferior to a son-in-law is a guest who brings in a guest;</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and inferior to a guest is one who answers a matter before he listens. As it is stated: “He that gives an answe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> before he listens</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it is folly for him and a disgrace” </span>(Proverbs 18:13).
§ The mishna teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yishmael says: </span>A structure of <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>size <span class="gemarra-regular">is a cowshed. </span>And then the mishna continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">One who wants to construct </span>a cowshed builds a structure at least four cubits by six cubits in size. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Who teaches </span>this subsequent clause about <span class="gemarra-regular">a cowshed? There is </span>a Sage <span class="gemarra-regular">who says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yishmael teaches it </span>and it is an elaboration of his statement. <span class="gemarra-regular">And there is </span>a Sage <span class="gemarra-regular">who says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Akiva teaches it </span>in response to Rabbi Yishmael’s statement.
The Gemara elaborates: <span class="gemarra-regular">There is </span>a Sage <span class="gemarra-regular">who says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Akiva teaches it, and this </span>is what Rabbi Akiva <span class="gemarra-regular">is saying: Even though </span>this structure <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>of the same dimensions as <span class="gemarra-regular">a cowshed, </span>nevertheless, since there are <span class="gemarra-regular">times when a person constructs his home </span>as small <span class="gemarra-regular">as a cowshed, </span>a contractor has fulfilled his commission if he builds a house to such dimensions. <span class="gemarra-regular">And there is </span>a Sage <span class="gemarra-regular">who says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yishmael teaches it</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and this </span>is what Rabbi Yishmael <span class="gemarra-regular">is saying </span>to Rabbi Akiva: The dimensions that you stated are clearly not the correct dimensions for a bridal house or widowhood home, <span class="gemarra-regular">as one who wants to construct a cowshed constructs</span> a structure of <span class="gemarra-regular">four cubits by six </span>cubits. A house for human dwelling is certainly larger than that.
§ The mishna teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">A banquet hall </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">ten by ten </span>cubits. The Gemara clarifies: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is a banquet hall? A pavilion of roses</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">It is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: The standard size of <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kanteir</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">twelve by twelve </span>cubits. The Gemara clarifies: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kanteir</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? </span>It is a decorative <span class="gemarra-regular">courtyard of a mansion</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
The mishna teaches: The standard <span class="gemarra-regular">height </span>for each of these structures is <span class="gemarra-regular">equal to </span>the sum of <span class="gemarra-regular">half its length and half its width. </span>There is <span class="gemarra-regular">a proof of the matter; Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: </span>The proportions are <span class="gemarra-regular">like the building of the Sanctuary. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Who teaches </span>the phrase: <span class="gemarra-regular">Proof of the matter? There is </span>a Sage <span class="gemarra-regular">who says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel teaches it, and this </span>is what he <span class="gemarra-regular">is saying: From where </span>can <span class="gemarra-regular">a proof of the matter </span>be derived? The mishna then cites that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">everything is like the building of the Sanctuary.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And there is </span>a Sage <span class="gemarra-regular">who says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the first </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> teaches it, and, </span>understanding that the proof the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> wished to cite was from the example of the Sanctuary, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel </span>interjected and <span class="gemarra-regular">expressed astonishmen</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> at the idea. <span class="gemarra-regular">And this is what </span>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel <span class="gemarra-regular">is saying to the first </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: From where </span>do you derive <span class="gemarra-regular">a proof? </span>Do you derive it <span class="gemarra-regular">from the building of the Sanctuary? Is that to say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">everyone constructs </span>their buildings <span class="gemarra-regular">like the building of the Sanctuary? </span>Why should they do so?
