<span class="gemarra-regular">It is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-italic">Aḥerim</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> say: </span>The standard <span class="gemarra-regular">height of </span>each of these structures is <span class="gemarra-regular">equal to </span>the length of <span class="gemarra-regular">its crossbeams. </span>The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">And let </span>us <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>more simply that <span class="gemarra-regular">its height </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">equal to its width. </span>The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">If you wish, say </span>that formulating the ruling in this way is necessary, because the space inside <span class="gemarra-regular">a house widens at the top, </span>as the walls get thinner toward the top and the crossbeams are actually longer than the width of the floor of the building. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if you wish, say </span>instead that formulating it in this way is necessary <span class="gemarra-regular">because there are indentations </span>in the wall into which the crossbeams are inserted. The crossbeams are consequently longer than the space inside the house.
§ Apropos the building of the Sanctuary, the Gemara relates the following incident: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ḥanina </span>once <span class="gemarra-regular">went out to the villages </span>to teach Torah there, and <span class="gemarra-regular">he raised a contradiction between </span>two <span class="gemarra-regular">verses </span>that detail the dimensions of the Sanctuary: <span class="gemarra-regular">It is written: “And the house that King Solomon built for the Lord, was sixty cubits in length, and twenty cubits in width, and its height was thirty cubits” </span>(I Kings 6:2). <span class="gemarra-regular">But it is </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">written: “And before the partition was twenty cubits in length, and twenty cubits in width, and its height was twenty cubits” </span>(I Kings 6:20). The first verse states that its height was thirty cubits, whereas the second verse states that its height was only twenty cubits. <span class="gemarra-regular">He said to </span>the villagers that the reason for the difference is that <span class="gemarra-regular">when </span>the latter verse <span class="gemarra-regular">calculated </span>the height, it did so <span class="gemarra-regular">from the </span>upper <span class="gemarra-regular">edge of the cherubs and upward, </span>as the cherubs themselves stood ten cubits high.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is </span>the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">teaching us </span>by considering only the area above the cherubs? 

Daf 99a

The verse <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us this: </span>The area <span class="gemarra-regular">below </span>the cherubs <span class="gemarra-regular">is like </span>the area <span class="gemarra-regular">above </span>them; <span class="gemarra-regular">just as </span>the area <span class="gemarra-regular">above </span>the cherubs’ wings, which were spread out in the air, <span class="gemarra-regular">was not used for anything, </span>i.e., it was empty space, <span class="gemarra-regular">so too </span>the area <span class="gemarra-regular">below </span>them <span class="gemarra-regular">was not used for anything </span>and was empty.
This <span class="gemarra-regular">supports </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Levi, as Rabbi Levi said, and some say </span>it was <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan </span>who said: <span class="gemarra-regular">This matter is a tradition handed </span>down <span class="gemarra-regular">to us by </span><span class="gemarra-regular">our ancestors: The space </span>occupied by the <span class="gemarra-regular">Ark </span>of the Covenant <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">cherubs is not </span>included <span class="gemarra-regular">in the measurement </span>of the Holy of Holies in which it rested, as miraculously it did not occupy any space at all. The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">This is also taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: When they brought <span class="gemarra-regular">the Ark that Moses crafted </span>into the Holy of Holies in the Temple of King Solomon, even though the total width of the Holy of Holies was only twenty cubits, nevertheless the Ark <span class="gemarra-regular">had ten cubits </span>of empty <span class="gemarra-regular">space </span>between it and the wall <span class="gemarra-regular">in each and every direction.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbenai says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel says: </span>The <span class="gemarra-regular">cherubs stood miraculousl</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span> and did not occupy any physical space, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is stated: “And five cubits was one wing of the cherub, and five cubits was the second wing of the cherub; ten cubits from the tip of its wings until the tip of its wings” </span>(I Kings 6:24). Accordingly, the wings of two cherubs, standing side by side, would occupy the entire twenty cubits width of the Sanctuary. But if so, <span class="gemarra-regular">where, </span>in what space, <span class="gemarra-regular">were their bodies standing? </span>Since their wings alone, which protruded from the sides of cherubs’ bodies, occupied twenty cubits, there was no room left in which their bodies could stand. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>one must <span class="gemarra-regular">conclude from </span>the verse that the cherubs <span class="gemarra-regular">stood miraculously </span>and did not occupy any physical space.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye objects to this </span>proof: <span class="gemarra-regular">But perhaps they stood </span>with their bodies <span class="gemarra-regular">emerging </span>beneath their wings, <span class="gemarra-regular">like chickens, </span>with their wings protruding above them from the same point in the center of their backs. If so, their bodies would stand beneath their wings and would not occupy any additional space. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">objects to this </span>proof: <span class="gemarra-regular">But perhaps they stood </span>so that <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">was not next to that </span>one and the wings of the two cherubs overlapped, thereby allowing for the additional space occupied by their bodies. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Aḥa bar Yaakov </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">objects to this </span>proof: <span class="gemarra-regular">But perhaps they were standing in a diagonal [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ba’alakhsona</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> alignment from one corner of the Holy of Holies to the diagonally opposite corner. In this way there would be enough space for their bodies and their wings.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna son of Rav Yehoshua </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">objects to this </span>proof: <span class="gemarra-regular">But perhaps </span>the width of twenty cubits stated in the verse refers only to the width at ground level, whereas <span class="gemarra-regular">the room widened at the top </span>and was therefore able to accommodate both their wings and the width of the bodies. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">objects to this </span>proof: <span class="gemarra-regular">But perhaps they were folding their wings </span>somewhat; since their wings were not fully extended they did not actually fill the full twenty cubits of the Sanctuary. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">objects to this</span> proof: <span class="gemarra-regular">But perhaps </span>their wings <span class="gemarra-regular">crossed ove</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> one another, so that they did not occupy so much space.
§ Continuing its focus on the cherubs, the Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">How were </span>the cherubs <span class="gemarra-regular">standing? Rabbi Yoḥanan and Rabbi Elazar </span>disagree about this. <span class="gemarra-regular">One says: Their faces </span>were turned <span class="gemarra-regular">one toward the other. And one says: Their faces </span>were turned <span class="gemarra-regular">toward the House</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., the Sanctuary. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But according to the one who says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">their faces </span>were turned <span class="gemarra-regular">one toward the other, isn’t it written: “And their faces were toward the House” </span>(II Chronicles 3:13)? How does he explain the meaning of this verse? The Gemara answers: This is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult, </span>as their faces miraculously changed directions in reflection of the Jewish people’s relationship to God. <span class="gemarra-regular">Here, </span>when it states that the cherubs faced each other, it was <span class="gemarra-regular">when the Jewish people do the will of God. There, </span>the verse that describes that the cherubs faced the Sanctuary and not toward each other, was <span class="gemarra-regular">when the Jewish people do not do the will of God.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And according to the one who says </span>they stood as described in the verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And their faces were toward the House,” isn’t it written: “With</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> their faces one toward the other” </span>(Exodus 25:20). How does he explain the meaning of this verse? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">They were angled sideways </span>so that they turned both to each other and toward the Sanctuary, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Onkelos the Convert said </span>that the <span class="gemarra-regular">cherubs were </span>of the <span class="gemarra-regular">form of children</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as the verse states: “And in the Holy of Holies he made two cherubim of the form of children; and they overlaid them with gold” (II Chronicles 3:10), <span class="gemarra-regular">and their faces were angled sideways </span>toward the Ark of the Covenant, <span class="gemarra-regular">like a student taking leave of his teacher.</span>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">One who has </span>ownership of <span class="gemarra-regular">a cistern </span>located <span class="gemarra-regular">beyond the house of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">another</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., the cistern can be accessed only by entering the property of the other, and also has access rights to that cistern, <span class="gemarra-regular">may enter </span>the house to access his cistern only <span class="gemarra-regular">at a time when it is usual for people to enter, and may leave </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">at a time when it is usual for people to leave. And </span>in addition, <span class="gemarra-regular">he may not bring his animal </span>into the house <span class="gemarra-regular">and water </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">from his cistern; rather, he </span>must <span class="gemarra-regular">fill </span>a pail with water from the cistern <span class="gemarra-regular">and water </span>his animal <span class="gemarra-regular">outside. And this </span>one, the owner of the cistern, <span class="gemarra-regular">constructs for himself a lock </span>on the entrance to the cistern to prevent the homeowner from drawing water from it, <span class="gemarra-regular">and that </span>one, the homeowner, <span class="gemarra-regular">constructs for himself a lock.</span>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna states that the owner of the cistern and the homeowner each construct a lock. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">A lock to where? Rabbi Yoḥanan says: Both of them </span>construct a lock on the opening <span class="gemarra-regular">to the cistern </span>to prevent the other from accessing it unilaterally. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, the owner of the cistern </span>constructs a lock, as <span class="gemarra-regular">he wants to protect the water of his well. But why </span>does <span class="gemarra-regular">the homeowner </span>construct a lock? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar said: </span>

Daf 99b

He does so <span class="gemarra-regular">due to a suspicion </span>that the owner of the cistern might enter the house at a time when the owner of the house is not present, and thereby be secluded together in the house with the homeowner’s <span class="gemarra-regular">wife</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">One who has </span>ownership of <span class="gemarra-regular">a garden </span>located <span class="gemarra-regular">beyond the garden of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">another</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and also has access rights to it, <span class="gemarra-regular">may enter </span>his garden only <span class="gemarra-regular">at a time when it is usual for people to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">enter</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and may leave </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">at a time when it is usual for people to leave. </span>Furthermore, he <span class="gemarra-regular">may not bring merchants into </span>his garden, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he may not </span>enter the garden solely in order to use it as a passageway, to <span class="gemarra-regular">enter from it into another field. And the </span>owner of the <span class="gemarra-regular">outer </span>garden <span class="gemarra-regular">may sow the path </span>leading to the inner garden.
If the court <span class="gemarra-regular">gave him </span>an access <span class="gemarra-regular">path from the side </span>of the outer garden, <span class="gemarra-regular">with the agreement of both of them</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> he <span class="gemarra-regular">may enter at </span>any <span class="gemarra-regular">time he wants, and leave at </span>any <span class="gemarra-regular">time he wants, and may bring merchants into </span>the inner garden. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">may </span>still <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>enter the garden solely in order to <span class="gemarra-regular">enter from it into another field. </span>In such a case, <span class="gemarra-regular">neither this </span>one, the owner of the inner garden, <span class="gemarra-regular">nor that </span>one, the owner of the outer garden, <span class="gemarra-regular">is permitted to plant </span>that side path.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel says: </span>If a field owner says to another: <span class="gemarra-regular">I am selling you </span>from my land a water <span class="gemarra-regular">channel </span>fit <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>bringing water to <span class="gemarra-regular">an irrigated </span><span class="gemarra-regular">field</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> he is required to <span class="gemarra-regular">give him </span>land <span class="gemarra-regular">two cubits </span>wide <span class="gemarra-regular">for the inside </span>of the channel, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">cubi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">on this </span>side <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">cubit on that </span>side <span class="gemarra-regular">for its </span><span class="gemarra-regular">banks</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> If he said to him: <span class="gemarra-regular">I am selling you a shadoof [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">kilon</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] </span><span class="gemarra-regular">channel</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> he is required to <span class="gemarra-regular">give him </span>land <span class="gemarra-regular">one cubit </span>wide <span class="gemarra-regular">for the inside </span>of the channel <span class="gemarra-regular">and half a cubit on this </span>side <span class="gemarra-regular">and half a cubit on that </span>side <span class="gemarra-regular">for its banks.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">those banks, who </span>has permission to <span class="gemarra-regular">sow them</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rav Yehuda </span>says that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel says: The field owner may sow them </span>with vegetables or crops. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman</span> says that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel says: The field owner may plant them </span>with trees. The Gemara elaborates: <span class="gemarra-regular">The one who says </span>that the field owner <span class="gemarra-regular">may </span><span class="gemarra-regular">sow them </span>holds that <span class="gemarra-regular">all the more so he may plant them </span>with trees. <span class="gemarra-regular">And the one who says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">he may plant them </span>with trees holds that he may only plant trees, <span class="gemarra-regular">but sowing them </span>with other plants is <span class="gemarra-regular">no</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> permitted. This is because the roots <span class="gemarra-regular">perforate </span>the ground, which weakens it and can cause damage to the water channel.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav Yehuda says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel says: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a water channel whose banks collapsed</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the owner of the channel may <span class="gemarra-regular">repair it </span>with earth <span class="gemarra-regular">from that field </span>through which the channel runs, even though the field does not belong to him. It is permitted because <span class="gemarra-regular">it is known that </span>when <span class="gemarra-regular">its banks collapsed </span>the earth that the banks were made from spread <span class="gemarra-regular">only into that </span>surrounding <span class="gemarra-regular">field</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa objects to this: But let </span>the field owner <span class="gemarra-regular">say to </span>the owner of the channel: <span class="gemarra-regular">Your water </span>in your channel <span class="gemarra-regular">carried awa</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> your earth </span>from your banks, so you have no right to take earth from my field. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Rav Pappa said </span>he may repair the banks with earth from the field <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>when <span class="gemarra-regular">the field owner </span>sold the rights to the channel <span class="gemarra-regular">he accepted that condition upon himself</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who had a public thoroughfare passing through his </span><span class="gemarra-regular">field</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and he <span class="gemarra-regular">appropriated it and </span>instead <span class="gemarra-regular">gave </span>the public an alternative thoroughfare <span class="gemarra-regular">on the side </span>of his property, the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is that the thoroughfare <span class="gemarra-regular">that he gave </span>them, <span class="gemarra-regular">he gave </span>them, and they may use it. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>the original thoroughfare that he took <span class="gemarra-regular">for himself has not reached him, </span>i.e., he cannot appropriate it for his personal use.
The standard width of <span class="gemarra-regular">a private path </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">four cubits. </span>If a field owner sells the right to pass through his field to an individual, without specifying the width of the path, he must provide him with a path four cubits wide. The standard width of <span class="gemarra-regular">a public thoroughfar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">sixteen cubits. </span>The width of <span class="gemarra-regular">a king’s thoroughfare has no </span>maximum <span class="gemarra-regular">measure</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as the king may appropriate whatever width thoroughfare he wishes. The width of the <span class="gemarra-regular">path for </span>the burial procession to <span class="gemarra-regular">a grav</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> has no </span>maximum <span class="gemarra-regular">measure</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>practice of <span class="gemarra-regular">standin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span> and comforting the mourners following a funeral, <span class="gemarra-regular">the judges of Tzippori said </span>that the standard requisite size is the <span class="gemarra-regular">area required for sowing four </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kav</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of seed.</span>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Why </span>does the mishna rule that the public thoroughfare that the landowner took <span class="gemarra-regular">for himself has not reached </span><span class="gemarra-regular">him</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> If by making the exchange the original thoroughfare now belongs to him, <span class="gemarra-regular">let him take a stick [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">pazra</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and sit </span>on the thoroughfare and physically prevent anyone from passing through. Apparently, the Sages did not permit him to do so. The Gemara suggests: Does it follow that one can <span class="gemarra-regular">conclude from </span>the mishna’s ruling that <span class="gemarra-regular">a person may not execute judgment for himself even in circumstances </span>where refraining from acting will cause him <span class="gemarra-regular">a loss? </span>This would contradict the accepted <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that one may do so.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Zevid said in the name of Rava: </span>Although generally one may do so, in this case the Sages issued <span class="gemarra-regular">a decree </span>prohibiting it, <span class="gemarra-regular">lest he give them a circuitous route </span>that will lengthen the distance the public will have to travel. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Mesharshiyya said in the name of Rava </span>that the ruling of the mishna applies only <span class="gemarra-regular">where he </span>actually <span class="gemarra-regular">gives them a circuitous route </span>instead of the original straight thoroughfare. But one may exchange a public thoroughfare for an equally straight thoroughfare, appropriating the original for his personal use. 

Daf 100a

<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi said: Any </span>alternative path <span class="gemarra-regular">on the sid</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> of the original path <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">a circuitous route, </span>as it is <span class="gemarra-regular">close for this </span>person <span class="gemarra-regular">and it is far for that </span>person. While some will benefit from the change, it will be detrimental to others. Therefore, one may never exchange a public path for an alternative path.
§ The mishna teaches that if a field owner provides an alternative thoroughfare through his field for the public to use, the public may use both thoroughfares. The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">But let him say to them</span><span class="gemarra-regular">:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Take your </span>original thoroughfare back <span class="gemarra-regular">and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> give me my </span>thoroughfare that I provided you. The Gemara answers: In accordance with <span class="gemarra-regular">whose </span>opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">is this</span> mishna? It <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Eliezer, as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda says in the name of Rabbi Eliezer: </span>If the <span class="gemarra-regular">public selected a thoroughfare </span>through a privately owned field <span class="gemarra-regular">for themselves </span>even without gaining the permission of the field owner, <span class="gemarra-regular">that which they selected, they selected, </span>and they have the right to use it.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">According to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Eliezer, are </span>the members of the <span class="gemarra-regular">public </span>entitled to be <span class="gemarra-regular">robbers</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> Why should they be permitted to appropriate land from a private owner? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Giddel said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav said: </span>Rabbi Eliezer refers only to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the public <span class="gemarra-regular">lost a thoroughfare in that field, </span>e.g., the field was plowed over and the original course of the thoroughfare is not known. In such a case, the public has the right to determine the course anew.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, why does Rabba bar Rav Huna say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says </span>that the <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">not in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Eliezer? </span>His reasoning seems valid. The Gemara answers: The <span class="gemarra-regular">one who teaches this, </span>i.e., that Rabbi Eliezer is referring to a case where a thoroughfare was lost, <span class="gemarra-regular">does not teach that, </span>i.e., that Rav rules against Rabbi Eliezer. There is a dispute as to what Rav said.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>according to Rabba bar Rav Huna, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is the reason </span>the field owner cannot reclaim the alternative thoroughfare that he gave to the public? The Gemara answers: It is <span class="gemarra-regular">due to </span>the statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav Yehuda, as Rav Yehuda says: </span>With regard to a strip of land that serves as <span class="gemarra-regular">a border </span>between two strips of land <span class="gemarra-regular">that the public took possession o</span><span class="gemarra-regular">f </span> as a public thoroughfare, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is prohibited to destroy it </span>for them, i.e., prevent people from using it. Accordingly, in the case of the mishna, where the field owner actually provided the public with a thoroughfare, he may certainly not take it back.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>according to <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Eliezer, through what </span>means <span class="gemarra-regular">does the public acquir</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> the thoroughfare they choose? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">By </span>means of <span class="gemarra-regular">walking </span>on the thoroughfare, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: If <span class="gemarra-regular">one walked along </span>a field’s <span class="gemarra-regular">length and its breadth, he has acquired the area </span>inside <span class="gemarra-regular">where he walked, </span>as walking is an effective act of acquisition; this is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of Rabbi Eliezer. And the Rabbis say </span>that by itself, <span class="gemarra-regular">walkin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is not </span>effective <span class="gemarra-regular">at all </span>to acquire a field, and it is not acquired <span class="gemarra-regular">until he takes possession </span>of it using a legal act of acquisition.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar said: What is the reasoning of Rabbi Eliezer? As it is written </span>that after God promised Abraham Eretz Yisrael, He instructed him: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Arise, walk through the land, its length and its breadth; for I will give it to you” </span>(Genesis 13:17), in order that Abraham should thereby acquire the land. <span class="gemarra-regular">And the Rabbis, </span>how do they interpret this verse? They hold that <span class="gemarra-regular">there, </span>in Genesis, it was <span class="gemarra-regular">due to </span>God’s <span class="gemarra-regular">love of Abraham that he said to him </span>to do <span class="gemarra-regular">this, in order that it would be easy for his descendants to conquer </span>the land. His walking was to demonstrate the divine promise and thereby emphasize his descendants’ claim to the land, but it did not effect acquisition of it.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, says: The Rabbis concede to Rabbi Eliezer with regard to a path </span>that passes <span class="gemarra-regular">through vineyard</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">since </span>the path <span class="gemarra-regular">is made </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">for walking </span>on it, <span class="gemarra-regular">it can be acquired by</span> means of <span class="gemarra-regular">walkin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span> on it.
The Gemara relates an incident involving the allocation of a path through a vineyard: <span class="gemarra-regular">When </span>people <span class="gemarra-regular">came before Rav Yitzḥak bar Ami </span>for judgment with regard to the width of a path through a vineyard that someone had purchased, <span class="gemarra-regular">he said to them: Give him </span>a path wide enough <span class="gemarra-regular">so that one can carry a load [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">tuna</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of vine branches [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">dishvishta</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> along it <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>is able to <span class="gemarra-regular">turn around </span>while holding them. The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">And we said </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the sides of the path <span class="gemarra-regular">are bounded by a fence</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> which would physically prevent a person from carrying a load of vine branches that are wider than the path, and therefore, if necessary, the path must be widened by breaking down the fence. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>where the sides <span class="gemarra-regular">are not bound by a fence, </span>a person carrying a load of vine branches will not be prevented from passing along it. Consequently, he needs only to be given a path wide enough <span class="gemarra-regular">so that he can lift up </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">foot and place </span>it in front of the other <span class="gemarra-regular">foot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
§ The mishna teaches: The standard width of <span class="gemarra-regular">a private pat</span><span class="gemarra-regular">h</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">four cubits. The standard width of <span class="gemarra-regular">a public thoroughfare </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">sixteen cubits. A road </span>leading to one of the <span class="gemarra-regular">cities of refug</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> must be at least <span class="gemarra-regular">thirty-two cubits </span>wide. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna said: What is the verse </span>from which this is derived? <span class="gemarra-regular">As it is written </span>with regard to the cities of refuge: <span class="gemarra-regular">“You shall prepare for yourself the way, </span>and divide the borders of your land that the Lord, your God, caused you to inherit, into three parts, so that every manslayer may flee there” (Deuteronomy 19:3). The mishna teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">A king’s thoroughfare has no </span>maximum <span class="gemarra-regular">measure. </span>The Gemara explains: This is <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">that a king may breach </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">fence </span>of an individual <span class="gemarra-regular">in order to create a thoroughfare for himself, and none </span>may <span class="gemarra-regular">protest his </span>actions.

§ The mishna teaches: With regard to the practice of <span class="gemarra-regular">standing </span>and comforting the mourners following a funeral, <span class="gemarra-regular">the judges of Tzippori said </span>that the standard requisite size is the <span class="gemarra-regular">area required for sowing four </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kav</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">of seed. The Sages taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: With regard to a family burial plot, even if <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>of the family <span class="gemarra-regular">sells </span>the land designated for <span class="gemarra-regular">his </span>own <span class="gemarra-regular">grav</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> to another, or sells <span class="gemarra-regular">the path </span>that will be used by the burial procession <span class="gemarra-regular">to his grave, </span>or sells <span class="gemarra-regular">the place </span>that will be used <span class="gemarra-regular">for standing </span>and comforting <span class="gemarra-regular">his </span>mourners, <span class="gemarra-regular">or </span>sells the <span class="gemarra-regular">site </span>that will be used <span class="gemarra-regular">for his eulogy, </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">family members may </span><span class="gemarra-regular">come and bury him </span>in his grave <span class="gemarra-regular">even against the will of </span>the buyer, <span class="gemarra-regular">due to </span>the need to avoid <span class="gemarra-regular">a family flaw</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., harm to the family name that would arise if one of the family members was not buried with the rest of his family.
<span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: On their return from the burial, the mourners would stop after traveling a short distance and would sit to bewail the loss of the deceased. They would then stand and continue journeying for a short while and then repeat the procedure. The mourners perform <span class="gemarra-regular">no fewer than seven standings and sitting</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> in honor <span class="gemarra-regular">of the deceased. </span>These seven <span class="gemarra-regular">correspond </span>to the seven references to “vanity” in the verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Vanity of vanities, says Kohelet; vanity of vanities, all is vanity” </span>(Ecclesiastes 1:2), counting the plural term “vanities” as two references.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Aḥa, son of Rava, said to Rav Ashi: How do they perform </span>this ceremony? Rav Ashi <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him </span>that it is done <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">in Judea, initially they would </span>perform <span class="gemarra-regular">no fewer than seven standings and sitting</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> in honor <span class="gemarra-regular">of the deceased. </span>One of the procession would make a statement <span class="gemarra-regular">such as: Stand, dear </span>friends, <span class="gemarra-regular">stand, </span>after which the mourners would continue on their journey to their home, and then he would say: <span class="gemarra-regular">Sit down, dear </span>friends, <span class="gemarra-regular">sit down, </span>at which point they would sit. The Rabbis <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: If so, </span>that this is all that the practice entails, then it should be <span class="gemarra-regular">permitted to do so even on Shabbat, </span>since there is no explicit eulogy or mourning, whereas the custom is not to do so.
The Gemara relates: <span class="gemarra-regular">The sister of Rami bar Pappa was married to Rav Avya</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> When <span class="gemarra-regular">she died </span>Rav Avya <span class="gemarra-regular">performed </span>the practice of <span class="gemarra-regular">standing and sitting for her</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rav Yosef said: He erred in two </span>matters. <span class="gemarra-regular">He erred, </span>as the ceremony is to be <span class="gemarra-regular">performed </span><span class="gemarra-regular">only with </span>the participation of <span class="gemarra-regular">close </span>family members, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he performed </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">even with a distant </span>relative. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">erred</span> again, <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>mourners should <span class="gemarra-regular">perform this </span>ceremony <span class="gemarra-regular">only on the first day </span>of mourning, the day of the burial, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he performed it on the second day.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said: He also erred in this, as </span>mourners should <span class="gemarra-regular">perform </span>the ceremony <span class="gemarra-regular">only in </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">cemetery, but he performed it in the city.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rava said: He also erred in this, as </span>mourners should <span class="gemarra-regular">perform it only in a locale where </span>people <span class="gemarra-regular">are accustomed do so, but there, </span>where he performed it, <span class="gemarra-regular">it was not the custom </span>to do so.
The Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises an objection </span>to the claims of Rav Yosef and Abaye from the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> cited above: The Rabbis <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: If so, </span>that this is all that the practice entails, then it should be <span class="gemarra-regular">permitted to do so even on Shabbat. </span>The Gemara explains the objection: <span class="gemarra-regular">And if you say, </span>as Abaye did, that the ceremony should be performed only <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">cemetery, or, </span>as Rav Yosef did, <span class="gemarra-regular">on the first day, </span>then how could it occur that the ceremony would be performed on Shabbat; <span class="gemarra-regular">what would </span>anyone <span class="gemarra-regular">want </span>to be doing <span class="gemarra-regular">in a cemetery on Shabbat, </span>when it is prohibited to perform a burial? The Gemara explains: It could happen <span class="gemarra-regular">in a city that is close to the cemetery, </span>and this is a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where they brought </span>the deceased <span class="gemarra-regular">for burial at twiligh</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> just before Shabbat began, so that the return journey took place on Shabbat itself.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> There is the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who sells a plot </span>of land <span class="gemarra-regular">to another </span>in order for him <span The mishna describes the general structure of the catacomb: <span class="gemarra-regular">And he </span>must <span class="gemarra-regular">fashion a courtyar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> at the entrance of the </span>burial <span class="gemarra-regular">chamber </span>that should be <span class="gemarra-regular">six </span>cubits <span class="gemarra-regular">by six </span>cubits, which is <span class="gemarra-regular">equal to the </span>combined <span class="gemarra-regular">length </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">the bier </span>of the deceased <span class="gemarra-regular">and those who bury him, </span>to ensure adequate room for the burial to take place.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And he </span>should <span class="gemarra-regular">open up two </span>burial <span class="gemarra-regular">chambers into </span>the courtyard, <span class="gemarra-regular">one from here and one from there, </span>i.e., on opposite sides of the courtyard. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon says: </span>He should open up <span class="gemarra-regular">four </span>burial chambers, one <span class="gemarra-regular">on </span>each of the courtyard’s <span class="gemarra-regular">four sides.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: Everything </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">dependent on </span>the nature of <span class="gemarra-regular">the bedrock</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> If the bedrock is hard and strong it will be able to accommodate more niches, which will be more closely packed together, with less bedrock between them. If the bedrock is softer, fewer and more sparsely spaced niches should be formed.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> In Rabbi Shimon’s depiction of a burial chamber, he states that two niches should be opened up, one from the right of the entrance and one from the left. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">These two </span>niches, <span class="gemarra-regular">in which </span>direction <span class="gemarra-regular">does he set them? If </span>they are directed <span class="gemarra-regular">toward the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">outsid</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> of the chamber, i.e., under the floor of the courtyard, <span class="gemarra-regular">won’t </span>people <span class="gemarra-regular">trample </span>over <span class="gemarra-regular">them </span>when they enter the courtyard, which is improper? <span class="gemarra-regular">And furthermore, didn’t we </span><span class="gemarra-regular">lear</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> in the mishna (<span class="it-text">Oholot</span> 15:8): With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">the courtyard of a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">catacomb</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">one who stands inside it </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">ritually pure </span>because it can be presumed that he did not stand over a dead body? Clearly, these niches are not to be dug underneath the courtyard.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, said: He makes </span>these two niches at the side of the entrance, vertically, <span class="gemarra-regular">like a door bolt.</span>
The Gemara challenges this explanation: <span class="gemarra-regular">But doesn’t Rabbi Yoḥanan say </span>with regard to the burial of people in a vertical position: 

Daf 101b

<span class="gemarra-regular">This is </span>like <span class="gemarra-regular">a burial of donkeys </span>and is disrespectful.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">According to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan, </span>each of these two niches is <span class="gemarra-regular">formed in </span>a different <span class="gemarra-regular">corne</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> of the chamber, aligned diagonally away from the chamber’s cavity.
The Gemara challenges: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if so, <span class="gemarra-regular">won’t </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">niches </span>located around the corners <span class="gemarra-regular">touc</span><span class="gemarra-regular">h</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">one another? </span>According to Rabbi Yoḥanan’s suggestion, there are, in fact, three niches located at each of the two back corners. One is recessed into the wall of the length of the chamber, at right angles to it, another is recessed into the back wall of the chamber, also at right angles to it, and a third that extends diagonally away from the chamber. The ends of these three niches will overlap, causing there to be too little space in them to fulfill the minimum required measurement.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi said: </span>It is possible to do this <span class="gemarra-regular">where, </span>when constructing the niches that extend diagonally away from the chamber, <span class="gemarra-regular">one deepens </span>them, i.e., forms them lower down in the wall than the other niches adjacent to them. <span class="gemarra-regular">As, if you do not say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>is a solution, then <span class="gemarra-regular">how could </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">four chambers </span>depicted <span class="gemarra-regular">by Rabbi Shimon be constructed? Won’t the niches touch one another? </span>The niches of one chamber will overlap those of the chamber adjacent to it. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>it is possible arrange the niches only <span class="gemarra-regular">where, </span>when constructing the niches of two chambers at opposite ends of the courtyard, <span class="gemarra-regular">one deepens </span>them, i.e., forms them lower down in the wall than the niches of the other two chambers that are adjacent to them. <span class="gemarra-regular">Here too, </span>it is a case in which <span class="gemarra-regular">one deepens them.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, said </span>that there is an alternative explanation: It is possible to fashion the <span class="gemarra-regular">four chambers </span>depicted <span class="gemarra-regular">by Rabbi Shimon where one constructs them </span>so that all the niches extend diagonally away from the cavity of the chamber <span class="gemarra-regular">like </span>the leaves of <span class="gemarra-regular">a palm branch</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> which have spread out from its spine. If formed in this way, the niches of adjacent chambers will not overlap, even if they are at the same depth in the ground.
The Gemara notes: <span class="gemarra-regular">And this </span>statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, is an error, </span>because it is not possible to form all the niches in this way, <span class="gemarra-regular">since </span>the length of <span class="gemarra-regular">the diagonal of every square </span>whose side is <span class="gemarra-regular">one cubit is one and two-fifths cubits. </span>Each chamber is eight cubits long, which means that between two adjacent chambers, placed at right angles to each other, there is a square area of eight cubits by eight cubits into which the niches of those two chambers must be formed. <span class="gemarra-regular">How much is </span>the diagonal of that area? <span class="gemarra-regular">Eleven and one-fifth cubits. How many niches </span>have to fit in that space? <span class="gemarra-regular">Eight. How can you find </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">eight </span>niches can possibly fit <span class="gemarra-regular">into eleven and one-fifth cubits? </span>Each of the niches is a cubit wide, and there must be a cubit wall of bedrock between each niche. To accommodate this once would need an area of at least fifteen cubits. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, this </span>statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, is in error.</span>
The Gemara provides an alternative solution to the problem of the niches at the corners overlapping. <span class="gemarra-regular">Or if you wish, say as Rav Sheisha, son of Rav Idi, said </span>in answer to a similar question: It is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">non-viable newborns, </span>which require only very small burial niches. Similarly, <span class="gemarra-regular">here also, </span>the niches at the corners of the chambers were used <span class="gemarra-regular">for non-viable newborns</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
§ The Gemara considers another mishna that relates to the structure of a catacomb: <span class="gemarra-regular">We learned </span>in a mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">there </span>(<span class="it-text">Nazir</span> 64b): With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who finds a corps</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> while inspecting a place that was not previously established as a cemetery, to ensure that it is free of ritual impurity, and the corpse is <span class="gemarra-regular">lying in </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">usual manner </span>of Jewish burial, <span class="gemarra-regular">he removes it </span>from there <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>also removes <span class="gemarra-regular">its surrounding </span>earth. And similarly, if he finds <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>corpses buried in the usual manner, <span class="gemarra-regular">he removes them and their surrounding </span>earth. Since only one or two corpses were found, it may be assumed that the area is not a cemetery; therefore, the corpses may be removed. 

Daf 102a

If <span class="gemarra-regular">he found thre</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> corpses lying parallel to each other, then <span class="gemarra-regular">if there is between them, </span>i.e., the outer two corpses, a distance <span class="gemarra-regular">of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> four to eigh</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> cubits, then <span class="gemarra-regular">this is </span>presumed to be <span class="gemarra-regular">a graveyard </span>and the corpses may not be removed, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he </span>must <span class="gemarra-regular">examin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from that </span>spot <span class="gemarra-regular">outward twenty cubit</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> to discover whether there are other corpses buried there. If he <span class="gemarra-regular">finds </span>even <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>corpse <span class="gemarra-regular">up to </span>the distance of <span class="gemarra-regular">twenty cubits, he </span>must continue to <span class="gemarra-regular">examine from </span>the place he finds that corpse <span class="gemarra-regular">outward </span>another <span class="gemarra-regular">twenty cubits. </span>He continues to search for additional corpses, even if only one corpse was found within the twenty cubits, <span class="gemarra-regular">as there is a basis for </span>anticipating <span class="gemarra-regular">the matter; </span>it is probable that he has stumbled upon an ancient cemetery. He is not permitted to relocate the corpses, despite that fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that if he had found </span>the single corpse by itself <span class="gemarra-regular">at first, </span>without being aware of the gravesite, he would have been permitted to <span class="gemarra-regular">remove it and its surrounding </span>earth.
The Gemara analyzes that mishna. <span class="gemarra-regular">The Master said: </span>If there is between them a distance <span class="gemarra-regular">of four to eight </span>cubits, then it is presumed to be a graveyard. The reason is that corpses buried in this manner are indicative of the standard layout of a burial chamber. The fact that this is said only when the distance between the corpses is between four and eight cubits assumes that the size of a burial chamber is four cubits by eight cubits. Based on this, the Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Whose </span>opinion is this? <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>it is the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis </span>in the mishna above (100b), <span class="gemarra-regular">didn’t they say </span>that the size of a burial chamber is <span class="gemarra-regular">four </span>cubits <span class="gemarra-regular">by six </span>cubits? <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>it is the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon, didn’t he say </span>that a burial cave is <span class="gemarra-regular">six </span>cubits <span class="gemarra-regular">by eight </span>cubits?
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Actually </span>this mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon, and it is </span>in accordance with another version of Rabbi Shimon’s opinion, which is cited by <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: If <span class="gemarra-regular">one found </span>three corpses lying <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>close <span class="gemarra-regular">succession</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and there is not</span> a distance <span class="gemarra-regular">of four cubits to eight </span>cubits <span class="gemarra-regular">between them, </span>i.e., they are lying closer together, <span class="gemarra-regular">they have </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of the requirement to move their <span class="gemarra-regular">surrounding </span>earth in which they are buried. <span class="gemarra-regular">But they are not </span>considered to be part of <span class="gemarra-regular">a graveyard, </span>since permanent graves are not placed so closely together. Perforce, their corpses were originally buried there on a temporary basis, but then they were never reinterred. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon ben Yehuda says in the name of Rabbi Shimon: The </span>corpses in <span class="gemarra-regular">the middle are viewed as if they are not </span>there, i.e., as if they were buried there incidentally, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the other </span>corpses thereby <span class="gemarra-regular">combine </span>to form a graveyard in which corpses are found with a distance <span class="gemarra-regular">of four cubits to eight </span>cubits between them.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">In accordance with which opinion did</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> you interpret </span>the mishna? If it is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon, </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">say the latter clause </span>of that mishna: If he finds an area of graves, <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span>must <span class="gemarra-regular">examine from there outward twenty cubits </span>to discover whether there are other corpses buried there. Since the burial formation is indicative of burial within a burial chamber of a catacomb, he should continue to investigate the whole area that would be occupied by a catacomb. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Whose </span>opinion is this? <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>it is the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon, </span>the distance one should be required to examine <span class="gemarra-regular">would be twenty-two </span>cubits, which is the total length of a catacomb, i.e., two chambers of eight cubits with a courtyard of six cubits between them. <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>it is the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis, </span>the distance one should be required to examine <span class="gemarra-regular">would be eighteen </span>cubits, as each catacomb consists of two chambers of six cubits long with a chamber of six cubits between them.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Actually, </span>the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis, and </span>it is necessary to examine twenty cubits in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he examined along the diagona</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span> of the catacomb, which is longer than its length.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But since </span>he examined <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>chamber along <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">diagonal, this </span>second chamber on the other side of the courtyard should <span class="gemarra-regular">also </span>be examined along <span class="gemarra-regular">the diagonal. </span>If so, that <span class="gemarra-regular">would be twenty-two </span>cubits. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">We say </span>he should examine <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>chamber along <span class="gemarra-regular">the diagonal, </span>but <span class="gemarra-regular">we do not say </span>he should examine <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>chambers along <span class="gemarra-regular">the diagonal</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> 

Daf 102b

<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Sheisha, son of Rav Idi, said: Actually, </span>the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon, and here we are dealing with </span>a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the corpses found were of <span class="gemarra-regular">non-viable newborn</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> buried in a smaller chamber only six cubits long. Adding a courtyard of six cubits and another regular-sized chamber of eight cubits yields a total length of the catacomb of twenty cubits.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But since this </span>is dealing <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>a chamber that was created for burying <span class="gemarra-regular">non-viable newborns,</span> there too, with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>chamber, on the other side of the courtyard, we are dealing <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>a chamber created for <span class="gemarra-regular">non-viable newborns as well. </span>Therefore, the total length of the catacomb <span class="gemarra-regular">would be eighteen </span>cubits. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">We say </span>that perhaps <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>of the chambers is <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span><span class="gemarra-regular">non-viable newborns, </span>but <span class="gemarra-regular">we do not say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>chambers might have been constructed <span class="gemarra-regular">for non-viable newborns.</span>
§ Above, the Gemara cited a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that relates a dispute between Rabbi Shimon and the Rabbis with regard to three corpses buried close together. The Rabbis hold that this is not considered a graveyard, whereas Rabbi Shimon maintains that it can be. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises a contradiction </span>from another ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">of the Rabbis against </span>this ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">of the Rabbis, and it </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">raises a contradiction </span>from another ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Shimon against </span>this ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Shimon.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">As it is taught </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Kilayim</span> 5:2): With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a vineyard that is planted on</span> an area where there is <span class="gemarra-regular">less than four cubits </span>of open space between the vines, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon says: It is not </span>considered to be <span class="gemarra-regular">a vineyard</span> with regard to the prohibition of diverse kinds and other <span class="it-text">halakhot</span>, as it is overcrowded. <span class="gemarra-regular">And the Rabbis say:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> This is </span>considered to be <span class="gemarra-regular">a vineyard, and </span>the reason for this is that <span class="gemarra-regular">the middle </span>vines are <span class="gemarra-regular">viewed as if </span>they <span class="gemarra-regular">are not </span>there, and the outer vines meet the requirements for a vineyard. Therefore, it is prohibited to plant other crops anywhere in that area.
The ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">of the Rabbis </span>in this mishna is <span class="gemarra-regular">difficult, </span>as it is contradicted <span class="gemarra-regular">by</span> the ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">of the Rabbis </span>in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, as there the Rabbis did not say: The middle ones are viewed as if they are not there. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Shimon </span>in this mishna is <span class="gemarra-regular">difficult, </span>as it is contradicted <span class="gemarra-regular">by </span>the ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Shimon </span>in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, as there he did say: The corpses in the middle are viewed as if they are not there.
The Gemara answers: The fact that one ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Shimon </span>is contradicted <span class="gemarra-regular">by </span>the other ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Shimon </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult. There, </span>with regard to vineyards, Rabbi Shimon holds that middle vines cannot be disregarded, as <span class="gemarra-regular">people do not plant </span>vines <span class="gemarra-regular">with the intention of uprooting </span>them. But <span class="gemarra-regular">here, </span>with regard to burial, <span class="gemarra-regular">sometimes it happen</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> that one has to bury a corpse <span class="gemarra-regular">at twilight </span>just before the onset of Shabbat, <span class="gemarra-regular">and indiscriminately inters </span>the body between other corpses with the intention of reburying it at a later date.
Similarly, the fact that one ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">of the Rabbis </span>is contradicted <span class="gemarra-regular">by </span>the other ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">of the Rabbis </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult. Here, </span>with regard to burial, <span class="gemarra-regular">since it is a disgrac</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> to bury bodies so close together, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is not called </span>an area of <span class="gemarra-regular">graves. </span>But <span class="gemarra-regular">there, </span>with regard to vineyards, the owner of the vineyard <span class="gemarra-regular">says </span>to himself: <span class="gemarra-regular">Whichever of </span>the vines <span class="gemarra-regular">will flourish, will flourish </span>and I will leave them, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>whichever ones <span class="gemarra-regular">do not flourish, </span>I will uproot them and <span class="gemarra-regular">they will be for firewood.</span>

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">If one says to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">another</span><span class="gemarra-regular">:</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">I am selling you </span>a plot of <span class="gemarra-regular">eart</span><span class="gemarra-regular">h</span> of the size <span class="gemarra-regular">required for sowing one </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kor</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of seed [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">beit</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">kor</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and <span class="gemarra-regular">there </span>on that plot <span class="gemarra-regular">there were crevices </span>[<span class="gemarra-italic">neka’im</span>] <span class="gemarra-regular">ten handbreadths deep or rocks ten handbreadths high, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">they are not measured </span>together <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>the rest of the field. Rather, the buyer must be provided with land measuring a <span class="it-text">beit</span> <span class="it-text">kor</span> exclusive of those crevices or rocks. If the crevices or rocks measured <span class="gemarra-regular">less than </span>ten handbreadths, <span class="gemarra-regular">they are measured </span>together <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>the rest of the field. <span class="gemarra-regular">But if </span>the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>the buyer: I am selling you a plot of <span class="gemarra-regular">earth </span>that is <span class="gemarra-regular">about </span>the size of <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">beit</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">kor</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> then <span class="gemarra-regular">even if there </span>on that plot <span class="gemarra-regular">there were crevices deeper than ten handbreadths or rocks higher than ten handbreadths, they are measured </span>together <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>the rest of the field.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">We learned </span>in a mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">elsewhere </span>(<span class="it-text">Arakhin</span> 25a): With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who consecrates his </span>ancestral <span class="gemarra-regular">fiel</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">during the time </span>that the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">of the Jubilee </span>Year are practiced, if he wishes to redeem the field <span class="gemarra-regular">he must give </span>the Temple treasurer <span class="gemarra-regular">fifty silver shekels for </span>every <span class="gemarra-regular">place </span><span class="gemarra-regular">that is fit for sowing a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">ḥomer</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of barley </span><span class="gemarra-regular">seed</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> which is the biblical equivalent of a <span class="it-text">kor</span>, for all the years of the Jubilee cycle, as this is the sum fixed by the Torah for this purpose (see Leviticus 27:16). But if <span class="gemarra-regular">there were </span><span class="gemarra-regular">crevice</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">ten handbreadths deep there, </span>in the field, <span class="gemarra-regular">or rocks ten handbreadths high, </span>

Daf 103a

<span class="gemarra-regular">they are not measured </span>together <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>the rest of the field. If the crevices or rocks were <span class="gemarra-regular">less than </span>ten handbreadths, <span class="gemarra-regular">they are measured </span>together <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>the rest of the field.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But why </span>are the crevices that are deeper and the rocks that are higher than ten handbreadths not measured with the rest of the field? <span class="gemarra-regular">Let them </span>at least <span class="gemarra-regular">be consecrated separatel</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span> and require their own redemption. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if you would say that since they are not </span>the size of <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">beit</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">kor</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, they cannot be consecrated, </span>there is a difficulty.
<span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t it taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> concerning the verse: “And if he that sanctified the field will redeem it” (Leviticus 27:19): <span class="gemarra-regular">Why </span>must <span class="gemarra-regular">the verse state </span>the word <span class="gemarra-regular">“field”? </span>Since the previous verses are all discussing a field, it would have sufficed for this verse to refer to the field with the pronoun: It. Rather, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is stated </span>in an earlier verse: “Then your valuation shall be according to the seed required for it; <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">ḥomer</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of barley seed shall be valued at fifty shekels of silver” </span>(Leviticus 27:16), <span class="gemarra-regular">I have </span>derived <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in the case of one who <span class="gemarra-regular">consecrated in this manner,</span> i.e., an area fit to sow a <span class="it-text">ḥomer</span> of barley seed.
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">From where </span>do I learn that this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is also meant <span class="gemarra-regular">to include </span>the case of one who consecrated a smaller area, e.g., an area fit to sow <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">letekh</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>i.e., a half-<span class="it-text">kor</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">a half-</span><span class="gemarra-italic">letekh</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">se’a</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tarkav</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, and a half-</span><span class="gemarra-italic">tarkav</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? </span>From where is it derived that these smaller plots of land can also be consecrated and redeemed in accordance with the fixed values stated in the Torah? <span class="gemarra-regular">The verse states: “A field,” </span>teaching that this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> applies <span class="gemarra-regular">in any case </span>of a field, even to smaller plots.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ukva bar Ḥama said: Here, </span>in the mishna in <span class="it-text">Arakhin</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">we are dealing with crevices filled with water. </span>Being <span class="gemarra-regular">that they are not fit for sowing, </span>they cannot be consecrated, as the verse states: “Then your valuation shall be according to the seed required for it” (Leviticus 27:16). The Gemara comments: The language of the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">is also precise </span>according to this interpretation, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it teaches </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> about crevices that are <span class="gemarra-regular">similar to rocks, </span>which are certainly not fit for sowing. The Gemara affirms: <span class="gemarra-regular">Learn from this </span>that this explanation is correct.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>this is <span class="gemarra-regular">so, </span>that the crevices and rocks of the mishna are excluded from being consecrated because they are unfit for sowing, then <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>if they <span class="gemarra-regular">are less than </span>ten handbreadths in depth or height, they <span class="gemarra-regular">also </span>should not be consecrated. The Gemara answers: If the crevices or rocks are less than ten handbreadths deep or high, <span class="gemarra-regular">these </span>crevices <span class="gemarra-regular">are called the cracks of the earth, </span>and these rocks <span class="gemarra-regular">are called the spines [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">shidrei</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] of the earth. </span>In other words, since they are considered standard features of the field and do not constitute separate areas, they are consecrated together with the rest of the field.
The Gemara asks: The <span class="it-text">halakha</span> stated above was taught with regard to consecrated property. <span class="gemarra-regular">Here, </span>in the case of a sale of land, with regard to which the mishna teaches that crevices ten handbreadths deep are not measured along with the land, <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? Does that <span class="it-text">halakha</span> apply only when the crevices are filled with water? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa said: Even if they are not filled with water </span>they are not considered part of the field. <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>that in the case of a sale crevices are not considered part of the field even if they are not filled with water? Because <span class="gemarra-regular">a person </span>buying a field <span class="gemarra-regular">does not wan</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to give his money for </span>the purchase of <span class="gemarra-regular">one plot when it appears to him like two or three </span>different <span class="gemarra-regular">plots </span>due to differences in the height of the terrain. Therefore, those crevices that are ten handbreadths deep are not measured along with the rest of the field, regardless of whether or not they are filled with water.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Ravina objects to this: But </span>the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> about crevices in a manner indicating that they are <span class="gemarra-regular">similar to </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">rocks </span>discussed in the mishna. <span class="gemarra-regular">Just as rocks are not fit for sowing, so too, these </span>crevices are such <span class="gemarra-regular">that they are not fit for sowing. </span>But if they are not filled with water, and are therefore fit for sowing, then even if they are lower than the rest of the field, they should be included in the sale. The Gemara replies: <span class="gemarra-regular">When </span>the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> about crevices in a manner indicating that they are <span class="gemarra-regular">similar to </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">rock</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> discussed in the mishna, it teaches about crevices that <span class="gemarra-regular">are less than that, </span>i.e., less than ten handbreadths deep. In such a case, even if they are not fit for sowing, they are measured along with the rest of the field.
§ The mishna teaches that if the crevices or rocks in the field measured <span class="gemarra-regular">less than </span>ten handbreadths, <span class="gemarra-regular">they are measured </span>together <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>the rest of the field. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yitzḥak says: The rocks </span>or crevices that measure less than ten handbreadths <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>are measured together with the rest of the field must not measure more than <span class="gemarra-regular">an area required for sowing four </span><span class="gemarra-italic">ka</span><span class="gemarra-italic">v</span> of seed within an area required for sowing a <span class="it-text">kor</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ukva bar Ḥama says: This applies </span>specifically <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the rocks <span class="gemarra-regular">are scattered throughout an area required for sowing five </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kav</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rav Ḥiyya bar Abba </span>says that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: This applies </span>specifically <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the rocks <span class="gemarra-regular">are scattered throughout the greater part of the field</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba raises a dilemma </span>with regard to the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> taught in the name of Rabbi Yoḥanan: If <span class="gemarra-regular">the majority of </span>the rocks are scattered <span class="gemarra-regular">throughout the smaller par</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> of the field, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the minority</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of </span>the rocks are scattered <span class="gemarra-regular">throughout the greater part </span>of the field, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? The Gemara answers: The dilemma <span class="gemarra-regular">shall stand </span>unresolved, as no answer was found.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yirmeya raises </span>another <span class="gemarra-regular">dilemma: </span>

Daf 103b

If the rocks are scattered throughout the greater part of the field but are arranged <span class="gemarra-regular">like a ring</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> what is</span> the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? If the rocks stand <span class="gemarra-regular">in a row, what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? If the rocks form <span class="gemarra-regular">an angle</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? If they are arranged in the shape of <span class="gemarra-regular">a crooked path</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? The Gemara states: All these dilemmas <span class="gemarra-regular">shall stan</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> unresolved.
