A Sage <span class="gemarra-regular">taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">If there is a solitary rock </span>on the outskirts of the field, <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>if it is of <span class="gemarra-regular">a minimal </span>size, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is not measured </span>together <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>the rest of the field. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>further, <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>that rock <span class="gemarra-regular">is adjacent to the </span>field’s <span class="gemarra-regular">border</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> even </span>if it is of <span class="gemarra-regular">a minimal </span>size, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is not measured </span>together <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>the rest of the field. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa raises a dilemma: </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">earth intervene</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> between </span>the rock and the border of the field, so that the rock does not actually touch the border, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? The Gemara states: This dilemma as well <span class="gemarra-regular">shall stand </span>unresolved. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi raises </span>another <span class="gemarra-regular">dilemma: </span>If there was a layer of <span class="gemarra-regular">earth below and rock above</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> or earth above and rock below, what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? The Gemara states: This dilemma as well <span class="gemarra-regular">shall stand </span>unresolved.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If one says to another: <span class="gemarra-regular">I am selling you </span>a plot of <span class="gemarra-regular">earth </span>the size of <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">beit</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">kor</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, measured </span>precisely <span class="gemarra-regular">with a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">rope</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and <span class="gemarra-regular">he gave </span>him even <span class="gemarra-regular">the slightest amount less </span>than what was stipulated, the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">must deduct </span>the difference from the purchase price of the field and return money to the buyer. If <span class="gemarra-regular">he gave </span>him even <span class="gemarra-regular">the slightest amount more </span>than what was stipulated, the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">must return </span>the difference to the seller. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if </span>the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>to the buyer that he is selling him a <span class="it-text">beit</span> <span class="it-text">kor</span> of land <span class="gemarra-regular">more or </span><span class="gemarra-regular">less</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> then <span class="gemarra-regular">even if he gave </span>him <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">quarter</span><span class="it-text">-kav</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> per </span><span class="gemarra-italic">se’a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> less </span>than what was stipulated, <span class="gemarra-regular">or he gave him a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">quarter</span><span class="it-text">-</span><span class="it-text">kav</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> per </span><span class="gemarra-italic">se’a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> more </span>that what was stipulated, i.e., he gave him one twenty-fourth more or less than what was required, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is his. </span>The sale is valid, since the seller told the buyer in advance that he was not committing himself to precise measurements. If the difference is <span class="gemarra-regular">greater than that </span>amount, <span class="gemarra-regular">he must make a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">calculation</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and the party that suffered a loss must be compensated.
If the buyer received too much land, so that he must now compensate the seller, <span class="gemarra-regular">what does he return to him</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> He returns <span class="gemarra-regular">money, </span>i.e., he pays the seller for the surplus land. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if </span>the seller so <span class="gemarra-regular">wishes, </span>the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">returns </span>the surplus <span class="gemarra-regular">land to him. Why </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">did </span>the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">he returns money to him? </span>They said this <span class="gemarra-regular">in order to enhance the power of the seller, </span>and enable him to demand payment for the surplus land, rather than accept its return. <span class="gemarra-regular">As, if the surplus </span><span class="gemarra-regular">in the field was an area required for sowing nine </span><span class="gemarra-italic">ka</span><span class="gemarra-italic">v</span> of seed, <span class="gemarra-regular">and in a garde</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> an area required for sowing a half-</span><span class="gemarra-italic">kav</span> of seed, <span class="gemarra-regular">or, according to the statement of Rabbi Akiva, an area required for sowing a quarter</span>-<span class="it-text">kav</span> of seed (see 11a), the buyer must <span class="gemarra-regular">return the land </span>itself <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the seller, and the seller cannot demand payment in money. <span class="gemarra-regular">And</span> if the surplus is greater than a quarter-<span class="it-text">kav</span> per <span class="it-text">se’a</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is not only the quarter</span>-<span class="it-text">kav</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">that he returns</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> rather, </span>he returns <span class="gemarra-regular">all of the surplus. </span>Since he is already required to make a refund, the refund must be made in the precise amount.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna considers two cases of selling a <span class="it-text">beit</span> <span class="it-text">kor</span> of land: First, where the seller said that he is selling a <span class="it-text">beit</span> <span class="it-text">kor</span> measured precisely with a rope, in which case a refund must be made no matter how small the deviation; and second, where the seller said that he selling a <span class="it-text">beit</span> <span class="it-text">kor</span> more or less, in which case the sale is valid as long as the deviation is no more than a quarter-<span class="it-text">kav</span> per <span class="it-text">se’a</span>. In connection with these cases, <span class="gemarra-regular">a dilemma was raised before </span>the Sages: If one says he is selling <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">beit</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">kor</span> of land, and he said this <span class="gemarra-regular">without </span>any further <span class="gemarra-regular">specification, what </span>is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a solution from what was taught in the mishna: If one says to another: <span class="gemarra-regular">I am selling you </span>a plot of <span class="gemarra-regular">earth </span>the size of <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">beit</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">kor</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, measured </span>precisely <span class="gemarra-regular">with a rope, </span>

Daf 104a

and he gave him even <span class="gemarra-regular">the slightest amount less </span>that what was stipulated, the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">must deduct </span>the difference from the purchase price of the field and return money to the buyer. If he gave him even <span class="gemarra-regular">the slightest amount more </span>than what was stipulated, the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">must return </span>the difference to the seller. The reason that even the slightest difference in value must be returned is that the seller specified that he was selling land measured precisely with a rope. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>had he sold the land <span class="gemarra-regular">without </span>further <span class="gemarra-regular">specification, </span>it would be <span class="gemarra-regular">like </span>he sold it saying that it is a <span class="it-text">beit</span> <span class="it-text">kor</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">more or less.</span>
The Gemara rejects this argument by proposing another, completely opposite proof: <span class="gemarra-regular">Say the latter clause </span>of the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">And if </span>the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>the buyer that he is selling him a <span class="it-text">beit</span> <span class="it-text">kor</span> of land <span class="gemarra-regular">more or less, </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">even if he gave </span>him <span class="gemarra-regular">one-quarter of a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kav</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> per </span><span class="gemarra-italic">se’a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> less </span>than what was stipulated, <span class="gemarra-regular">or he gave him one-quarter of a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kav</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> per </span><span class="gemarra-italic">se’a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> more </span>than what was stipulated, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is his </span>and the sale is valid. One can infer: The reason that the sale is valid is that he specified that he was selling a <span class="it-text">beit</span> <span class="it-text">kor</span> of land more or less. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>had he sold the land <span class="gemarra-regular">without </span>further <span class="gemarra-regular">specification, </span>it would be <span class="gemarra-regular">like </span>he sold it saying that he was selling the land <span class="gemarra-regular">measured </span>precisely <span class="gemarra-regular">with a rope. Rather, </span>since the mishna can be interpreted in two opposite ways, <span class="gemarra-regular">no </span>inference is <span class="gemarra-regular">to be learned from </span>the mishna.
The Gemara tries to present another proof: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a proof from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: If the seller said to the buyer: <span class="gemarra-regular">I am selling you </span>a plot of <span class="gemarra-regular">earth </span>the size of <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">beit</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">kor</span><span class="gemarra-regular">; </span>or he said to him: <span class="gemarra-regular">I am selling you </span>a plot of <span class="gemarra-regular">earth about </span>the size of <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">beit</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">kor</span><span class="gemarra-regular">; </span>or he said to him: <span class="gemarra-regular">I am selling you </span>a <span class="it-text">beit</span> <span class="it-text">kor</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">more or less; </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">even if he gave </span>him <span class="gemarra-regular">one-quarter of a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kav</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> per </span><span class="gemarra-italic">se’a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> less </span>than what was stipulated, <span class="gemarra-regular">or he gave him one-quarter of a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kav</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> per </span><span class="gemarra-italic">se’a</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">more </span>than what was stipulated, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is his </span>and the sale is valid. One can infer: <span class="gemarra-regular">Apparently, </span>selling a <span class="it-text">beit</span> <span class="it-text">kor</span> of land <span class="gemarra-regular">without </span>further <span class="gemarra-regular">specification </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">also like </span>selling it <span class="gemarra-regular">more or less. </span>The Gemara rejects this proof: <span class="gemarra-regular">There, </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is explaining </span>his statement, which should be understood as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">When is </span>the phrase <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">beit</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">kor</span> treated like the phrase <span class="gemarra-regular">about </span>the size of <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">beit</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">kor</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? </span>In a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">says to </span>the buyer: I am selling you a <span class="it-text">beit</span> <span class="it-text">kor</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">more or less.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi objects to this: If that is so, </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">why do I </span>need to repeat the words: <span class="gemarra-regular">I am selling you, </span>three times? The fact that the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> repeats these words in each clause indicates that it is discussing three separate sale transactions, and not that the three clauses are all referring to one case. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, isn’t it </span>correct to <span class="gemarra-regular">conclude from </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that selling a <span class="it-text">beit</span> <span class="it-text">kor</span> of land <span class="gemarra-regular">without </span>further <span class="gemarra-regular">specificatio</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">like </span>selling it <span class="gemarra-regular">more or less? </span>The Gemara affirms: <span class="gemarra-regular">Conclude from </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that this is so.
§ With regard to a buyer who received too much land and now must compensate the seller, the mishna teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">What does he return to him? </span>He pays him <span class="gemarra-regular">money, </span>and if the seller so wishes, the buyer returns the surplus land to him, because the Sages said that the buyer pays money in order to enhance the power of the seller. In other words, the Sages allowed the seller to choose whether to take back the surplus land or to demand payment for it from the buyer, even though this effectively forces the buyer to purchase the surplus land from him. The Gemara asks: Is it correct that <span class="gemarra-regular">we say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the seller’s power should be enhanced, and </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">we do not say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the buyer’s power should be enhanced?</span>
But <span class="gemarra-regular">isn’t it taught </span>otherwise in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">gave </span>the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">seven and a half </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kav</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> per </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kor</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> less </span>than what was stipulated, which is the equivalent of a quarter<span class="it-text">-kav</span> per <span class="it-text">se’a</span>, as a <span class="it-text">kor</span> is equal to thirty <span class="it-text">se’a</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">or he gave him seven and a half </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kav</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> per </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kor</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> more </span>than what was stipulated, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is his </span>and the sale is valid. If the difference is <span class="gemarra-regular">greater than</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that </span>amount, the court <span class="gemarra-regular">compels the seller to sel</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and the buyer to buy </span>the difference. This indicates that we also say that the buyer’s power should be enhanced, since if the buyer so wishes, the seller is compelled to sell him land and accept payment for it.
The Gemara replies: <span class="gemarra-regular">There, </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is not discussing a case where the buyer wishes to acquire the surplus land, but rather with a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the land <span class="gemarra-regular">was initially, </span>at the time of the sale, <span class="gemarra-regular">expensive</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">but now it is cheap, </span>and the seller wants the buyer to pay him for the surplus land according to the initial higher rate. In this case, <span class="gemarra-regular">we say to </span>the seller, in the name of the buyer: <span class="gemarra-regular">If you </span>wish to <span class="gemarra-regular">give me lan</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> and receive money, <span class="gemarra-regular">give me </span>the land <span class="gemarra-regular">according to the current, cheaper rate. </span>This is what the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is referring to when it states that the seller is compelled to sell.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t it taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">When he gives him </span>money in payment for the surplus land, <span class="gemarra-regular">he gives </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">to him according to the rate at which he had bought </span>the rest of the land <span class="gemarra-regular">from him</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> The Gemara replies: <span class="gemarra-regular">There </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the land <span class="gemarra-regular">was initially chea</span><span class="gemarra-regular">p</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> but now it is expensive. </span>If, in such a case, the seller wants the buyer to pay him for the surplus land, he is compelled to sell it to him according to the cheap rate from the time of the original sale.
§ The mishna teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">As, if the surplus in the field was an area required for the sowing of nine </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kav</span> of seed, and in a garden an area required for the sowing of a half-<span class="it-text">kav</span> of seed, or, according to the Rabbi Akiva, an area required for the sowing of a quarter-<span class="it-text">kav</span> of seed, the buyer can return the surplus land to the seller, and the seller cannot demand payment in money. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna says: </span>The <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">that was stated </span>in the mishna, that a surplus in the size of an area required for the sowing of <span class="gemarra-regular">nine </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kav</span> of seed can be returned to the seller, applies <span class="gemarra-regular">even in a large valley</span> which measures several <span class="it-text">kor</span>. If the surplus is a significant plot of land equal in size to an area required for the sowing of nine <span class="it-text">kav</span> of seed, the buyer can return it to the seller, even if it is less than one-quarter of a <span class="it-text">kav</span> per <span class="it-text">se’</span><span class="it-text">a</span>, i.e., less than one twenty-fourth the size of the field that was sold.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav Naḥman says: He calculates seven and a half </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kav</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for each and every </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kor</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> which is equivalent to one-quarter of a <span class="it-text">kav</span> per <span class="it-text">se’a</span>. As long as the surplus does not exceed that ratio, he is not required to return it, even if the surplus is greater than the area required for the sowing of nine <span class="it-text">kav</span>. 

Daf 104b

<span class="gemarra-regular">And if </span>after this calculation <span class="gemarra-regular">there is </span>still <span class="gemarra-regular">a surplu</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> in excess of a quarter-<span class="it-text">kav</span> per <span class="it-text">se’a</span>, equal in size to an area required <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>the sowing of <span class="gemarra-regular">nine </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kav</span> of seed, the entire surplus must be <span class="gemarra-regular">returned.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava raised an objection to Rav Naḥman: </span>The mishna teaches <span class="gemarra-regular">that if the surplus in the fiel</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> was an area required for the sowing of nine </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kav</span> of seed, the buyer returns the land to the seller. <span class="gemarra-regular">Isn’t this </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> even in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he sold him </span>a field measuring <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kor</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? </span>This would seem to indicate that even if the surplus does not exceed a quarter-<span class="it-text">kav</span> per <span class="it-text">se’a</span>, as a quarter-<span class="it-text">kav</span> per <span class="it-text">se’a</span> in a field of two <span class="it-text">kor</span> is fifteen <span class="it-text">kav</span>, the sole determining factor is whether or not the surplus is equal in size to an area required for the sowing of nine <span class="it-text">kav</span>. Rav Naḥman rejects this argument: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>the case in the mishna is specifically <span class="gemarra-regular">where he sold him a </span>field measuring one <span class="gemarra-italic">kor</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
Rava raised a further objection to Rav Naḥman: We learned in the continuation of the mishna that if the surplus <span class="gemarra-regular">in a garden </span>was <span class="gemarra-regular">an area required for the sowing of a half-</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ka</span><span class="gemarra-italic">v</span> of seed, the buyer returns the land to the seller. <span class="gemarra-regular">Isn’t this </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> even in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he sold him </span>a garden measuring <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span><span class="gemarra-italic">se’a</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? </span>Once again, this would seem to indicate that the surplus is returned to the seller, provided that it is equal in size to the minimum measure of a garden, even if the surplus does not exceed one-half of a <span class="it-text">kav</span> per two <span class="it-text">se’</span><span class="it-text">a</span>, which is equivalent to one-quarter of a <span class="it-text">kav</span> per <span class="it-text">se’a</span>. Rav Naḥman rejects this argument as well: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>the case in the mishna is <span class="gemarra-regular">where he sold him a </span>garden measuring a <span class="gemarra-italic">se’</span><span class="gemarra-italic">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>so that the surplus is proportionately twice as large.
Rava raised yet another objection to Rav Naḥman from the next clause in the mishna, which states: <span class="gemarra-regular">Or, according to the statement of Rabbi Akiva, </span>if the surplus in the garden was <span class="gemarra-regular">an area required for sowing a quarter-</span><span class="gemarra-italic">kav</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of seed, </span>the buyer returns the land to the seller. <span class="gemarra-regular">What, isn’t this </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> even in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he sold him a </span>garden measuring <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">se’a</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? </span>In that case, the surplus does not exceed one-quarter of a <span class="it-text">kav</span> per <span class="it-text">se’</span><span class="it-text">a</span>, and nevertheless the surplus is returned to the seller, provided that it is equal in size to the minimum measure of a garden. Rav Naḥman also rejects this argument: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>the case in the mishna is <span class="gemarra-regular">where he sold him </span>a garden measuring <span class="gemarra-regular">a half-</span><span class="gemarra-italic">se’a</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> so that the surplus is proportionately twice as large.
The mishna teaches that in the case of a field, the buyer can return the land itself if the surplus was an area required for the sowing of nine <span class="it-text">kav</span> of seed, and in the case of a garden, if the surplus was an area required for the sowing of a half-<span class="it-text">kav</span> of seed. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi raises a dilemma: </span>If one sold <span class="gemarra-regular">a field and it </span>turned out that the plot was larger than had been stipulated, but before the buyer returned the surplus, the plot <span class="gemarra-regular">was turned into a garden</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> or </span>if it was initially <span class="gemarra-regular">a garden and it was turned into a fiel</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> (see 11a), <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? Is the surplus governed by the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> applying to a field or by those applying to a garden? The Gemara answers: The dilemma <span class="gemarra-regular">shall stand </span>unresolved, as no answer has been found.
A Sage <span class="gemarra-regular">taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>the field being sold <span class="gemarra-regular">was adjacent to </span>another <span class="gemarra-regular">field </span>belonging to the seller, <span class="gemarra-regular">then even </span>if the surplus was of <span class="gemarra-regular">a minimal </span>amount, the buyer can <span class="gemarra-regular">return the land </span>itself <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the seller, and the seller cannot demand payment in money. This is because the seller loses nothing when he receives a small tract of land, as he can cultivate it along with his adjoining field.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi raises </span>a set of <span class="gemarra-regular">dilemmas: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a pit</span> between the surplus in the sold field and the adjoining field belonging to the seller, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Should </span>the pit <span class="gemarra-regular">be </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">an interposition </span>between the two fields? With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a water channel </span>between the two fields, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Should </span>the water channel <span class="gemarra-regular">be </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">an interposition? </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">the public thoroughfare, what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Should </span>the public thoroughfare <span class="gemarra-regular">be </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">an interposition? </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a row of palm trees, what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Should </span>a row of palm trees <span class="gemarra-regular">be </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">an interposition? </span>The Gemara states: All these dilemmas <span class="gemarra-regular">shall stand </span>unresolved.
§ The mishna teaches that if the surplus is greater than a quarter-<span class="it-text">kav</span> per <span class="it-text">se’a</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is not only the quarter-</span><span class="it-text">kav</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that </span>the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">returns; rather, </span>he returns <span class="gemarra-regular">all of the surplus. </span>Since he is already required to make a refund, the refund must be made in the precise amount. The Gemara raises a question: <span class="gemarra-regular">Isn’t it the opposite </span>[<span class="gemarra-italic">kelappei layya</span>]? The buyer is required to return the surplus even when the quarters of a <span class="it-text">kav</span> remain in his possession. <span class="gemarra-regular">Ravin bar Rav Naḥman taught </span>the mishna as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">Not only must </span>the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">return the extra </span>land that is beyond the limit of a quarter<span class="it-text">-</span><span class="it-text">kav</span> area per <span class="it-text">beit</span> <span class="it-text">se’a</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">but he must </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">return to him every one of the </span>extra <span class="gemarra-regular">quarter-</span><span class="it-text">kav</span> areas of land that he received beyond the stated area of a <span class="it-text">beit</span> <span class="it-text">kor</span>. When he is required to return the surplus, he returns not only the surplus, but also all the quarter-<span class="it-text">kav</span> areas over and above what had originally been stipulated to be included in the sale.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If the seller says to the buyer: <span class="gemarra-regular">I am selling you </span>a plot of land of a certain size <span class="gemarra-regular">measured </span>precisely <span class="gemarra-regular">with a rope more or less, </span>thereby attaching to the sale two contradictory stipulations; in this case, the words: <span class="gemarra-regular">More or less, nullify </span>the words: <span class="gemarra-regular">Measured </span>precisely <span class="gemarra-regular">with a rope. </span>Accordingly, if the surplus did not exceed a quarter-<span class="it-text">kav</span> per <span class="it-text">se’a</span>, the sale is valid as is. Similarly, if the seller says to the buyer: I am selling you a plot of land of a certain size <span class="gemarra-regular">more or less measured </span>precisely <span class="gemarra-regular">with a rope, </span>

Daf 105a

the words: <span class="gemarra-regular">Measured </span>precisely <span class="gemarra-regular">with a rope, nullify </span>the words: <span class="gemarra-regular">More or less, </span>since the principle is that in all cases, one should attend to the final expression; this is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of ben Nanas.</span>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Abba bar Memel says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: Ben Nanas’s colleagues disagree with him </span>with regard to his ruling that one should attend to the final expression. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>new <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>Rav <span class="gemarra-regular">teaching us? </span>Don’t <span class="gemarra-regular">we </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">learn </span>that they disagree from a mishna (<span class="it-text">Bava</span> <span class="it-text">Metzia</span> 102a): There was once <span class="gemarra-regular">an incident in </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Tzippori</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> involving one who rented a bathhouse from another, </span>and it was stated that the rental fee would be <span class="gemarra-regular">twelve gold dinars </span>[<span class="gemarra-italic">zehuvim</span>] <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">year</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">one gold </span>dinar <span class="gemarra-regular">per month, </span>and the year was later intercalated, an extra month being added.
<span class="gemarra-regular">The incident came before Rabban Shimon ben Gamlie</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and before Rabbi Yose</span><span class="gemarra-regular">i</span> for a decision as to whether the intercalated month is included in the words: Twelve gold dinars a year, or whether an additional payment must be made for that month, as the agreement stipulated: One gold dinar per month. <span class="gemarra-regular">And they said: </span>The landlord and the tenant <span class="gemarra-regular">should divide the intercalated month </span>between them, and so the tenant should pay only half a gold dinar for it. This indicates that these Sages ruled that the meaning of an agreement containing two contradictory expressions is in doubt, and therefore the parties divide the disputed amount between them. From here it follows that they disagree with the opinion of ben Nanas, who says that in such a case one should attend to the final expression.
The Gemara replies: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>the Sages’ opinion was derived only <span class="gemarra-regular">from there, </span>I would not know that they disagree with the opinion of ben Nanas in all cases, as <span class="gemarra-regular">I would sa</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">it is </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">there </span>that the Sages say that the parties divide the disputed sum between them. <span class="gemarra-regular">As it is possible to say that </span>the landlord <span class="gemarra-regular">retracted </span>his first statement and set the rental fee at one gold dinar per month, <span class="gemarra-regular">but it is </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">possible to say that he is explaining </span>his earlier statement. That is to say, he did not mean to relate to the intercalated month; rather, he was clarifying that payment was to be made not with a lump sum at the end of the year, but in monthly installments. Since there is uncertainty with regard to his intention, the parties divide the contested sum between them. <span class="gemarra-regular">But here </span>in the mishna, where the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">certainly retracted </span>his first statement, one might <span class="gemarra-regular">say</span> that the Sages do <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>disagree with ben Nanas. Therefore, the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches u</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> that in all cases the Sages disagree with ben Nanas.
Similar to what was cited above in the name of Rav, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel says: This is the statement of ben Nanas, </span>who says with regard to a case of contradictory expressions that one should attend to the final expression; <span class="gemarra-regular">but the Sages say: Follow the least inclusive expression</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the one that is the least advantageous to the buyer, in keeping with the principle that in a case of uncertainty, the burden of proof rests upon the claimant.
The Gemara asks: Did Shmuel mean to say that <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>is the statement of ben Nanas, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>he, Shmuel, <span class="gemarra-regular">does not agree with him</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> But don’t Rav and Shmuel both say:</span> If the seller said to the buyer: <span class="gemarra-regular">I am selling you a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kor</span> of grain, an amount equivalent to thirty <span class="it-text">se’a</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>the sum of <span class="gemarra-regular">thirty </span><span class="it-text">sela</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">he can renege </span>on the entire sale <span class="gemarra-regular">even while </span>measuring out <span class="gemarra-regular">the last </span><span class="gemarra-italic">se’a</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>Since the seller stipulated that he was selling a full <span class="it-text">kor</span> of grain, as long as he has not yet measured out the full amount, he may still renege, as the sale is not yet complete.
But if the seller said to the buyer: <span class="gemarra-regular">I am selling you a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kor</span> of grain <span class="gemarra-regular">for thirty </span><span class="it-text">sela</span>, each <span class="gemarra-italic">se’a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">sela</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">acquires </span>each <span class="it-text">se’a</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">one by on</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> as it is being measured out to him. Since the seller specified the price per <span class="it-text">sela</span>, he has indicated that he is ready to sell each <span class="it-text">sela</span> on its own. This seems to indicate that Shmuel maintains that in a case of contradictory expressions, one should attend to the final expression. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>Shmuel’s formulation: This is the statement of ben Nanas, must be explained as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>is the statement of ben Nanas, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he, </span>Shmuel, <span class="gemarra-regular">agrees with him </span>that one should attend to the final expression.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And does </span>Shmuel actually <span class="gemarra-regular">agree with him? But doesn’t Shmuel say: </span>Concerning the ruling of the Sages that the landlord and the tenant should divide the intercalated month between them, <span class="gemarra-regular">we are dealing with </span>a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the landlord <span class="gemarra-regular">came </span>to collect the rent <span class="gemarra-regular">in the middle of the month. </span>Only in that case is the disputed rent divided between them. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>in a case where <span class="gemarra-regular">he came </span>to collect the rent <span class="gemarra-regular">at the beginning of the month, the entire </span>sum goes <span class="gemarra-regular">to the landlord </span>who is demanding payment, since he is in possession of the property. And if he came <span class="gemarra-regular">at the end of the month, the entire</span> sum goes <span class="gemarra-regular">to the tenant </span>who is refusing payment, since he is in possession of the money. This indicates that Shmuel maintains that in a case of contradictory expressions, one should not attend to the latter expression. Rather, the case is viewed as one of uncertainty, and the burden of proof rests upon the claimant. 

Daf 105b

<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>it must be that Shmuel <span class="gemarra-regular">actually </span>meant to say that <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>is the statement of ben Nanas, <span class="gemarra-regular">but he, </span>Shmuel, <span class="gemarra-regular">does not agree with him </span>that one should attend to the latter expression. In fact, he is in agreement with the Sages who maintain that two contradictory expressions create a case of uncertainty. <span class="gemarra-regular">And there, </span>in the case of the rent for the intercalated month, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is the reason</span> for his ruling that if the landlord came to collect the rent at the beginning of the month, the entire sum goes to the landlord, whereas if he came at the end of the month, the money goes to the tenant? <span class="gemarra-regular">Because </span>the party who is awarded the money <span class="gemarra-regular">was </span>seen as already being <span class="gemarra-regular">in possession </span>of it, and in a case of uncertainty, money is left in the hands of the party enjoying possession.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Here too, </span>in the case where the seller says that he is selling a <span class="it-text">kor</span> of grain for thirty <span class="it-text">sela</span>, each <span class="it-text">se’a</span> for a <span class="it-text">sela</span>, the buyer was seen as already being <span class="gemarra-regular">in possessio</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> of each <span class="it-text">se’a</span> that was measured out to him, and therefore the seller cannot renege on the sale. It is for this reason that the buyer acquires the grain, and not because of the principle that in a case of contradictory expressions, one should attend to the latter expression.
On a similar topic, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">they say </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">the school of Rav: </span>If the seller said to the buyer: I am selling you this item for <span class="gemarra-regular">an </span><span class="gemarra-italic">istera</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> one hundred </span><span class="gemarra-italic">ma’a</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> an <span class="it-text">istera</span> being a silver coin equal to ninety-six copper <span class="it-text">ma’a</span>, it is assumed he meant <span class="gemarra-regular">one hundred </span><span class="gemarra-italic">ma’a</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>And if the seller reversed the order and said that he was selling the item for <span class="gemarra-regular">one hundred </span><span class="gemarra-italic">ma’a</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, an </span><span class="gemarra-italic">istera</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>it is assumed he meant <span class="gemarra-regular">an </span><span class="gemarra-italic">istera</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>new <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>Rav <span class="gemarra-regular">teaching us? </span>Is it that with regard to a statement comprised of contradictory expressions <span class="gemarra-regular">one should attend </span>only to <span class="gemarra-regular">the last statement? Didn’t Rav </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">say this </span>on <span class="gemarra-regular">another occasion? As Rav says: Had I been there </span>as a judge when the ruling was issued with regard to the rental fee for the intercalated month, <span class="gemarra-regular">I would have given the entire </span>month’s rent <span class="gemarra-regular">to the landlord</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> based on the final expression in the rental agreement: One gold dinar per month.
The Gemara answers: Nevertheless, it was necessary to state both rulings, as the one cannot necessarily be inferred from the other. <span class="gemarra-regular">If this </span><span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to the <span class="it-text">istera</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">was stated and that </span><span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to the intercalated month <span class="gemarra-regular">was not stated, I would say </span>that when the seller uttered the second expression: One hundred <span class="it-text">ma’a</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">he retracted hi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> first expression: An <span class="it-text">istera</span>, as the two expressions contradict one another, and for that reason Rav said that one should attend to the final expression. <span class="gemarra-regular">But here,</span> in the case of the intercalated month, <span class="gemarra-regular">perhaps you </span>would <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that when the landlord utters the second expression: One gold dinar per month, <span class="gemarra-regular">he is explaining </span>the original intent of his first expression: Twelve gold dinars a year, and one should view it as a clarification. Therefore Rav comes and <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>that in all cases one should attend to the final expression. 

Daf 106a

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If one sells a field to another, telling him that he is selling him a field measuring a <span class="it-text">beit</span> <span class="it-text">kor</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">with its </span>particular <span class="gemarra-regular">demarcations and border</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> that the seller specifies for the buyer, the field’s measurement is not treated in as exacting a manner as in a standard sale. Therefore, if it later turns out that the field was not precisely a <span class="it-text">beit</span> <span class="it-text">kor</span>, but the difference is still <span class="gemarra-regular">less than one-sixth</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the field <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>the buyer’s, and the sale is valid as is. But if the difference is greater, e.g., one-quarter or one-fifth, then, <span class="gemarra-regular">until </span>it is calculated at <span class="gemarra-regular">one-sixth</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">must deduc</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> the difference from the purchase price and return money to the buyer.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">It was stated </span>that the <span class="it-text">amora’im</span> disagreed about the following issue: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna says:</span> A difference that is precisely <span class="gemarra-regular">one-sixth is like </span>one that is <span class="gemarra-regular">less than one-sixth, </span>and the sale is valid. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda says: </span>A difference that is precisely <span class="gemarra-regular">one-sixth is like </span>one that is <span class="gemarra-regular">more than one-sixth, </span>and the difference must be deducted from the purchase price.
The Gemara explains the respective reasons of the two <span class="it-text">amora’im</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna says </span>that a difference of <span class="gemarra-regular">one-sixth is like </span>a difference of <span class="gemarra-regular">less than one-sixth, </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>is what the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">is saying: </span>If the difference is <span class="gemarra-regular">less than one-sixth, and including </span>a difference that is precisely <span class="gemarra-regular">one-sixth, it is </span>the buyer’s, as the sale is valid, and if it is <span class="gemarra-regular">more than one-sixth, </span>the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">must deduct </span>the difference from the purchase price. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda says </span>that a difference of <span class="gemarra-regular">one-sixth is like </span>a difference of <span class="gemarra-regular">more than one-sixth, </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>is what the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">is saying:</span> If the difference is <span class="gemarra-regular">less than one-sixth, it is </span>the buyer’s, as the sale is valid, and if the difference is greater, <span class="gemarra-regular">until </span>it is calculated at <span class="gemarra-regular">one-sixth, and including </span>a difference that is precisely <span class="gemarra-regular">one-sixth, </span>the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">must deduct </span>the difference from the purchase price.
The Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises an objection </span>to Rav Huna’s statement from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: If one sells a field to another, telling him that he is selling him a field measuring a <span class="it-text">beit</span> <span class="it-text">kor</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">within its </span>particular <span class="gemarra-regular">demarcations and borders, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">he gave </span>him a field that is <span class="gemarra-regular">one-sixth less </span>than the measure stipulated, <span class="gemarra-regular">or, </span>alternatively, <span class="gemarra-regular">he gave </span>him a field that is <span class="gemarra-regular">one-sixth more </span>than the measure stipulated, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is like </span>a sale of orphans’ property that is executed in accordance with <span class="gemarra-regular">the judges’ assessmen</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> of the value of that property, and therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">it is </span>the buyer’s, as the sale is valid. The Gemara states the objection: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>in the case of a sale executed in accordance with <span class="gemarra-regular">the judges’ assessment, </span>an error of precisely <span class="gemarra-regular">one-sixth is like </span>an error of <span class="gemarra-regular">more than one-sixth, </span>and the sale is void. This contradicts Rav Huna’s opinion that an error of one-sixth is like an error of less than one-sixth.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna </span>could have <span class="gemarra-regular">said to you </span>in reply: Even <span class="gemarra-regular">according to your reasoning, </span>there is still a difficulty, since the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">it is </span>the buyer’s, i.e., the sale is final. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>the comparison drawn between this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> and the judges’ assessment is not a general comparison. It is <span class="gemarra-regular">like the judges’ assessment, but </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>entirely <span class="gemarra-regular">like the judges’ assessment. </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">like the judges’ assessment </span>in that the limit is <span class="gemarra-regular">one-sixth</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> but it is not like the judges’ assessment, as there, </span>in the case of the judges’ assessment, <span class="gemarra-regular">the sale is voided, while here, </span>in the mishna, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is </span>the buyer’s, and the sale is final.
It is related that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa bought land from a certain man, </span>

Daf 106b

who, after specifying its demarcations and boundaries, <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: It is </span>an area of <span class="gemarra-regular">twenty </span><span class="gemarra-italic">griv</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>meaning that it is fit for planting twenty <span class="it-text">se’a</span> of grain. Rav Pappa later <span class="gemarra-regular">measured </span>the field <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>found that <span class="gemarra-regular">it was </span>fit for planting <span class="gemarra-regular">only fiftee</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> <span class="it-text">se’a</span>. Rav Pappa <span class="gemarra-regular">came before Abaye </span>to sue the seller. Abaye <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: You knew </span>what you were buying <span class="gemarra-regular">and accepted </span>the field as is.
Rav Pappa raised an objection to Abaye’s ruling from the mishna. <span class="gemarra-regular">But didn’t we learn </span>in the mishna that when the seller specifies the field’s demarcations and borders, if the difference between the stated size of the field and its actual size is <span class="gemarra-regular">less than one-sixth, </span>the field <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>the buyer’s, and the sale is valid as is, but if the difference is greater, <span class="gemarra-regular">until </span>it is calculated at <span class="gemarra-regular">one-sixth, </span>the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">must deduct </span>the difference from the purchase price? And here, in this case, the difference between what the seller promised and the actual size of the field is greater than one-sixth. Abaye replied: <span class="gemarra-regular">That statement</span> applies in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">is unfamiliar with </span>the plot being sold to him, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he is familiar with it, he knew </span>what he was buying <span class="gemarra-regular">and accepted </span>it as is.
Rav Pappa raised another objection to Abaye’s ruling: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>to <span class="gemarra-regular">me</span> that the field is fit for planting <span class="gemarra-regular">twent</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span> <span class="it-text">se’</span><span class="it-text">a</span>, and it is not. Abaye <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>What he meant was <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the field <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">good </span>and as fruitful <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>one that is fit for planting <span class="gemarra-regular">twent</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span> <span class="it-text">se’a</span>.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">It is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei says: </span>When <span class="gemarra-regular">brothers divide </span>their father’s estate between them by lottery, i.e., after dividing the property into equal shares they draw lots to determine which brother is to receive which portion, <span class="gemarra-regular">once the lot for one of them is drawn</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> they all acquire </span>the remainder of the property, and they can no longer retract their decision to divide the estate in this manner. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reaso</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> for this? Drawing lots is not one of the recognized modes of acquisition. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar said: </span>The <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that applies here is <span class="gemarra-regular">similar to the initial </span>division of <span class="gemarra-regular">Eretz Yisrael </span>among the tribes. <span class="gemarra-regular">Just as the initial </span>division of Eretz Yisrael was carried out <span class="gemarra-regular">by </span>drawing <span class="gemarra-regular">lots, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">so too here, </span>the brothers can divide their father’s estate <span class="gemarra-regular">by </span>drawing <span class="gemarra-regular">lots.</span>
The Gemara challenges: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>the brothers’ division of their father’s estate is comparable to the initial division of Eretz Yisrael, an additional comparison should apply: <span class="gemarra-regular">Just as there, </span>the initial division of Eretz Israel was carried out <span class="gemarra-regular">through a receptacle [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">bekalpi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> in which lots were placed <span class="gemarra-regular">and the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">Urim</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">VeTummim</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> so too here, </span>the division of the father’s estate should be executed only <span class="gemarra-regular">through a receptacle and the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">Urim</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">VeTummim</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rav Ashi said: With the satisfaction </span>that each of the brothers receives from the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that they listen to each othe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> and agree to accept the results of the lottery, <span class="gemarra-regular">they fully transfer </span>ownership <span class="gemarra-regular">to each other</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Therefore, the division becomes final as soon as the first lot is drawn.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">It was stated </span>that the <span class="it-text">amora’im</span> disagreed about a related issue: If <span class="gemarra-regular">two brothers divided </span>their father’s estate between them, <span class="gemarra-regular">and</span> then later a third <span class="gemarra-regular">brother, </span>of whose existence they had previously been unaware, <span class="gemarra-regular">arrived from a country overseas</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rav says: The </span>original <span class="gemarra-regular">division </span>of the property <span class="gemarra-regular">is void</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and the brothers must now redivide the property among the three of them. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Shmuel says: </span>The original division is still valid, but the two brothers must each <span class="gemarra-regular">take off a shar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> from their portion and give it to the third brother.
The Gemara clarifies the opinions of Rav and Shmuel: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said to Rav Naḥman: According to Rav, who says that the division is void, apparently </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is that if a division of property was found to have been performed in error, <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>original <span class="gemarra-regular">verdict is reconsidered </span>and the entire division is void. Accordingly, in the case of the brother who arrived from overseas, the original division of the father’s estate is void. <span class="gemarra-regular">But if that is so, </span>then in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">these thre</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> people <span class="gemarra-regular">who stand </span>as partners, <span class="gemarra-regular">and two of them go and divide </span>the property into three parts without consulting with the third partner, <span class="gemarra-regular">so too, the division should be void, </span>and it should be necessary to divide the property a second time between the three partners. But elsewhere (<span class="it-text">Bava</span> <span class="it-text">Metzia</span> 31b), the Gemara indicates that in such a case, if the division of property took place in the presence of a court, it is valid.
Rav Naḥman rejects this comparison: <span class="gemarra-regular">How can </span>these cases <span class="gemarra-regular">be compared? </span>There is a clear difference between them: <span class="gemarra-regular">There, </span>in the case of the three partners, <span class="gemarra-regular">they entered </span>the process of dividing the property <span class="gemarra-regular">from the outset with the knowledge that they were three</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and it was necessary only to clarify the portion to be received by each partner. <span class="gemarra-regular">Here, </span>in the case of the brother who arrived from overseas, <span class="gemarra-regular">they did not enter </span>the process of dividing the property <span class="gemarra-regular">from the outset with the knowledge that they were three, </span>as at the time of the original division, they thought that there were only two brothers.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa said to Abaye:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> According to Shmuel, who says </span>that the two brothers must each <span class="gemarra-regular">take off a share </span>from their portion and give it to the third brother, <span class="gemarra-regular">is this to say that </span>he is of the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>even if a division of property was found to have been made in error, <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>original <span class="gemarra-regular">verdict stand</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> and the division is valid? <span class="gemarra-regular">But don’t Rav and Shmuel both say </span>that if the seller said to the buyer: <span class="gemarra-regular">I am selling you one </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kor</span> of grain, an amount equivalent to thirty <span class="it-text">se</span><span class="it-text">’a</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>the sum of <span class="gemarra-regular">thirty </span><span class="it-text">sela</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">he can renege </span>on the entire sale <span class="gemarra-regular">even while </span>measuring out <span class="gemarra-regular">the last </span><span class="gemarra-italic">se’a</span><span class="gemarra-regular">; </span>but if he said: <span class="gemarra-regular">I am selling you one </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kor</span> of grain <span class="gemarra-regular">for thirty </span><span class="it-text">sela</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">each </span><span class="gemarra-italic">se’a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">sela</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">acquires </span>each <span class="it-text">se’a</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">one by one </span>as it is being measured out to him? If the original verdict stands, why in the first case may the seller renege even on that portion of the sale that already reached the buyer? 

Daf 107a

The Gemara answers: The cases cannot be compared because <span class="gemarra-regular">there, </span>in the case of the sale of grain, <span class="gemarra-regular">the Sages instituted a matter that is suitable for the seller and</span> also <span class="gemarra-regular">suitable for the buyer</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Since the price of grain fluctuates, neither party wants the sale to be considered complete until the last <span class="it-text">se’a</span> is measured out, so that they each are able to renege on the sale should the price rise or fall. This reasoning does not apply in cases of division of property.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">It was stated </span>that the <span class="it-text">amora</span><span class="it-text">’im</span> disagreed about another related matter: If <span class="gemarra-regular">two brothers divided </span>their father’s estate between them, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>then their father’s <span class="gemarra-regular">creditor came and took the portion of one of the</span><span class="gemarra-regular">m</span> as repayment for the father’s debt, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: The </span>original <span class="gemarra-regular">division </span>of the property <span class="gemarra-regular">is void</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and the brothers must now redivide the remaining assets. <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel says: </span>Each brother, upon receiving his portion, <span class="gemarra-regular">has foregone </span>his right to be reimbursed if his portion is lost. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Asi says: </span>The brother whose portion was seized is entitled to half the remaining inheritance: <span class="gemarra-regular">He</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> takes one-quarter in land and one-quarter in money</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
The Gemara explains the rationale for each opinion: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>original <span class="gemarra-regular">division </span>of the property <span class="gemarra-regular">is void. </span>This is because <span class="gemarra-regular">he holds that brothers who divided </span>property received as an inheritance <span class="gemarra-regular">are </span>still considered to be <span class="gemarra-regular">heirs</span> with regard to the inheritance as if they never divided the property, so that they continue to share joint responsibility for their father’s debts. Therefore, if a creditor seizes the portion received by one of them, it is as if he repaid the debt on behalf of all the heirs. Accordingly, they must once again divide the remaining property between them.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Shmuel says </span>that each brother, upon receiving his portion, <span class="gemarra-regular">has foregone </span>his right to be reimbursed if his portion is lost, <span class="gemarra-regular">as he holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">brothers who divided </span>property received as an inheritance <span class="gemarra-regular">are </span>considered as <span class="gemarra-regular">purchaser</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> from each other. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>each one is considered <span class="gemarra-regular">like a purchaser </span>who bought his portion <span class="gemarra-regular">without a guarantee </span>that if the field is seized in payment of a debt, the seller will compensate the buyer for his loss. Accordingly, the brother whose portion of the estate was seized by the creditor has no claim against the brother whose portion remained untouched.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Asi is uncertain whether </span>brothers who divided property received as an inheritance <span class="gemarra-regular">are </span>still considered to be <span class="gemarra-regular">heirs or are </span>considered to be like <span class="gemarra-regular">purchasers </span>who bought their property with a guarantee of compensation should the property be repossessed. <span class="gemarra-regular">Therefore, </span>the brother whose portion was seized by the creditor is entitled to half the remaining inheritance, and <span class="gemarra-regular">he takes one-quarter in land </span>like an heir <span class="gemarra-regular">and one-quarter </span>he receives <span class="gemarra-regular">in money, </span>like a purchaser with a guarantee, who is compensated with money for his loss.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa says: The </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in all </span>the cases dealt with in <span class="gemarra-regular">these statements </span>recording disagreements between Rav and Shmuel is that the brothers must each <span class="gemarra-regular">take off a shar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> from their portion in accordance with the opinion of Shmuel. Rather, any brother currently in possession of his portion must give part of it to his brother who lacks a portion, so that in the end they have equal shares. <span class="gemarra-regular">Ameimar says: </span>The <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in all of these cases is that <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>original <span class="gemarra-regular">division </span>of the property <span class="gemarra-regular">is void, </span>in accordance with the opinion of Rav. The Gemara concludes: <span class="gemarra-regular">The </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is </span>in fact that <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>original <span class="gemarra-regular">division </span>of the property <span class="gemarra-regular">is void</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> in accordance with the opinion of Rav.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> (<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span>, <span class="it-text">Ketubot</span> 11:2): In a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">three </span>experts <span class="gemarra-regular">who went down to assess </span>a certain property in order to determine the amount to be collected from it for repayment of a debt, and <span class="gemarra-regular">one says </span>it is worth <span class="gemarra-regular">one hundred dinars, and </span>the other <span class="gemarra-regular">two say </span>it is worth <span class="gemarra-regular">two hundred, </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">one says </span>it is worth <span class="gemarra-regular">two hundred </span>dinars <span class="gemarra-regular">and</span> the other <span class="gemarra-regular">two say </span>it is worth <span class="gemarra-regular">one hundred, </span>the assessment of <span class="gemarra-regular">the single </span>expert <span class="gemarra-regular">is nullified, since </span>his is <span class="gemarra-regular">the minority </span>opinion, and the assessment of the two others is accepted.
If <span class="gemarra-regular">one says</span> the property is worth <span class="gemarra-regular">one hundred dinars, and another says </span>it is worth <span class="gemarra-regular">twenty </span><span class="it-text">sela</span>, which is equivalent to eighty dinars, since four dinars equal a <span class="it-text">sela</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>yet <span class="gemarra-regular">another says </span>it is worth <span class="gemarra-regular">thirty</span> <span class="it-text">sela</span>, which is equivalent to one hundred and twenty dinars, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is assessed at one hundred dinars, </span>which is the average of the assessments, as it is equivalent to twenty-five <span class="it-text">sela</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Eliezer, son of Rabbi Tzadok, says: It is assessed at ninety </span>dinars, as will be explained below. <span class="gemarra-italic">Aḥerim</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> say: An appraisal </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">performed </span>of the sum <span class="gemarra-regular">between </span>the two most extreme assessments <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">divided by three. </span>This sum is then added to the lowest assessment.
The Gemara clarifies the various opinions: <span class="gemarra-regular">The one who says </span>that the property <span class="gemarra-regular">is assessed at one hundred dinars </span>holds that <span class="gemarra-regular">the middl</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> of the two extreme assessments is followed. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Eliezer, son of Rabbi Tzadok, says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">it is assessed at ninety </span>dinars because <span class="gemarra-regular">he holds that this land</span>

Daf 107b

<span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>in fact <span class="gemarra-regular">worth ninet</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span> dinars, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the one who says </span>it is worth <span class="gemarra-regular">twenty </span><span class="it-text">sela</span>, which is equivalent to eighty dinars <span class="gemarra-regular">errs </span>with an assessment that is <span class="gemarra-regular">ten </span>dinars <span class="gemarra-regular">behind, </span>i.e., too low, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the one who says </span>it is worth <span class="gemarra-regular">one hundred dinars errs </span>with an assessment that is <span class="gemarra-regular">ten </span>dinars <span class="gemarra-regular">ahead, </span>i.e., too high. Therefore, the average of these two assessments is followed.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <span class="gemarra-regular">On the contrary,</span> say that <span class="gemarra-regular">this land is </span>in fact <span class="gemarra-regular">worth one hundred and ten </span>dinars, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the one who says </span>it is worth <span class="gemarra-regular">one hundred dinars errs </span>with an assessment that is <span class="gemarra-regular">ten </span>dinars <span class="gemarra-regular">behind, and the one who says </span>it is worth <span class="gemarra-regular">thirty </span><span class="it-text">sela</span>, which is equivalent to one hundred and twenty dinars, <span class="gemarra-regular">errs </span>with an assessment that is <span class="gemarra-regular">ten </span>dinars <span class="gemarra-regular">ahead. </span>If so, the average of these two assessments, one hundred and ten dinars, should be followed. The Gemara replies: <span class="gemarra-regular">In any event, grasp the first two </span>assessments <span class="gemarra-regular">in your hand, as neither </span>of them <span class="gemarra-regular">takes </span>the assessment <span class="gemarra-regular">beyond the sum of one hundred dinars</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> teaches that <span class="gemarra-italic">Aḥerim</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">an appraisal </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">performed </span>of the sum <span class="gemarra-regular">between</span> the two most extreme assessments <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">divided by three. </span>This sum is then added to the lowest assessment. The Gemara explains this opinion: <span class="it-text">Aḥerim</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">hold </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">this land is </span>in fact <span class="gemarra-regular">worth ninety-three and one-third </span>dinars. <span class="gemarra-regular">The one who says </span>it is worth <span class="gemarra-regular">twenty </span><span class="it-text">sela</span>, the equivalent of eighty dinars, <span class="gemarra-regular">errs </span>with an assessment that is <span class="gemarra-regular">thirteen </span>dinars <span class="gemarra-regular">and one-third behind, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">the one who says it is </span>worth <span class="gemarra-regular">one hundred dinars errs </span>with an assessment that is <span class="gemarra-regular">thirteen </span>dinars <span class="gemarra-regular">and one-third ahead. By right, </span>that assessor <span class="gemarra-regular">should have said more, </span>i.e., quoted a higher sum, since according to this calculation, he should have said it is worth one hundred and six and two-thirds dinars. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the reason <span class="gemarra-regular">that he did not </span>do so is that he <span class="gemarra-regular">thinks </span>as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">It is enough that I add this muc</span><span class="gemarra-regular">h</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> above </span>and beyond the assessment of <span class="gemarra-regular">my colleague </span>who says it is worth eighty dinars. Therefore, he lowers the sum of his assessment to one hundred dinars.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <span class="gemarra-regular">On the contrary, </span>say that <span class="gemarra-regular">this land is </span>in fact <span class="gemarra-regular">worth one hundred and thirteen </span>dinars <span class="gemarra-regular">and one-third, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">the one who says </span>it is worth <span class="gemarra-regular">one hundred dinars errs </span>with an assessment that is <span class="gemarra-regular">thirteen </span>dinars <span class="gemarra-regular">and one-third behind, and the one who says </span>it is worth <span class="gemarra-regular">thirty </span><span class="it-text">sela</span>, which is equal to one hundred and twenty dinars, <span class="gemarra-regular">errs </span>with an assessment that is <span class="gemarra-regular">thirteen </span>dinars <span class="gemarra-regular">and one-third ahead. By right, he should have said more,</span> i.e., quoted a higher sum, since according to this calculation, he should have said it is worth one hundred and twenty-six dinars and two-thirds. And the reason he did not do so is that he <span class="gemarra-regular">thinks </span>as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">It is enough that I add this much above</span> and beyond the assessment of <span class="gemarra-regular">my colleague </span>who says it is worth one hundred dinars. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">In any event, grasp the first two </span>assessments <span class="gemarra-regular">in your hand,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as neither </span>of them <span class="gemarra-regular">take </span>the assessment <span class="gemarra-regular">beyond the sum of one hundred dinars.</span>
