<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna said: The </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is in accordance with </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span><span class="gemarra-italic">Aḥerim</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> who say that the sum of the difference between the two most extreme assessments is calculated and then divided by three, and this sum is then added to the lowest assessment. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi said: We do not </span>even <span class="gemarra-regular">understand the reason of </span><span class="gemarra-italic">Aḥerim</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> shall we </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">establish the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in accordance with their </span>opinion? <span class="gemarra-regular">The judges of the Diaspora taught </span>a <span class="it-text">barait</span><span class="it-text">a</span> that accords with the opinion of <span class="it-text">Aḥerim</span> in the previously cited <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">An appraisal </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">performed </span>to determine the sum of the difference <span class="gemarra-regular">between </span>the two most extreme assessments <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>then that sum is <span class="gemarra-regular">divided by three </span>and added to the lowest assessment. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna said: The </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with the judges of the Diaspora. Rav Ashi said: We do not </span>even <span class="gemarra-regular">understand the reasoning of the judges of the Diaspora; shall we </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">establish the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in accordance with their </span>opinion?
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">If one says to another: I am selling you half a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">field</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> without specifying which half he is selling, <span class="gemarra-regular">an assessment is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">mad</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> of the field, which is then divided <span class="gemarra-regular">between them, and </span>the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">takes half of </span>the seller’s <span class="gemarra-regular">field. </span>If the seller says: <span class="gemarra-regular">I am selling you the half that is on the southern side </span>of the field, <span class="gemarra-regular">an assessment is made </span>of the northern and the southern sides of the field, which is then divided <span class="gemarra-regular">between them, and he takes the half on the southern side. And he accepts upon </span><span class="gemarra-regular">himsel</span><span class="gemarra-regular">f </span> to provide <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">spac</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">for the fence </span>between the two halves of the field out of his own property. He also accepts to provide out of his own property the space for the larger <span class="gemarra-regular">ditch and the smaller </span><span class="gemarra-regular">ditch</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> which are meant to keep animals out of the field. <span class="gemarra-regular">And how </span>wide <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>the larger <span class="gemarra-regular">ditch? Six handbreadths. And </span>how wide is <span class="gemarra-regular">the smaller ditch? Three </span>handbreadths.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: </span>When one sells half of his field to another person, <span class="gemarra-regular">the buyer takes the leaner </span><span class="gemarra-regular">par</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span>the field, the part that is of lower quality. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba said to Rabbi Yoḥanan: But didn’t we learn </span>in the mishna that in such a case <span class="gemarra-regular">an assessment is made </span>of the field, which is then divided <span class="gemarra-regular">between them, </span>which indicates that the buyer and the seller are given similar parcels of land? How then can you say that the buyer takes the leaner part? Rabbi Yoḥanan <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him </span>in a sarcastic manner: <span class="gemarra-regular">While you were eating </span><span class="gemarra-regular">date</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">in Babylonia </span>and neglecting your studies, <span class="gemarra-regular">we explained </span>the matter <span class="gemarra-regular">based on the latter clause </span>of the mishna, which proves that my understanding is correct.
<span class="gemarra-regular">As the latter clause teaches: </span>If the seller says: <span class="gemarra-regular">I am selling you the half that is on the southern side </span>of the field, <span class="gemarra-regular">an assessment is made </span>of the northern and the southern sides of the field, which is then divided <span class="gemarra-regular">between them, and he takes the half on the southern side. </span>If taken literally, this passage gives rise to a difficulty: <span class="gemarra-regular">Why is an assessment made </span>of the northern and the southern sides of the field, which is then divided <span class="gemarra-regular">between them? </span>In any case, <span class="gemarra-regular">didn’t he say to him </span>that he is selling him <span class="gemarra-regular">the southern half? </span>Let the seller give the buyer the southern half of the field. Why is an assessment necessary? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>it must be that the matter is more complicated than it seems, and the mishna is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to money</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> That is to say, the buyer takes the southern half, but the seller must reimburse him with money for the difference in value between the two halves of the field. <span class="gemarra-regular">Here too, </span>in the first case, the mishna is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to money:</span> The buyer takes the leaner half, but the seller must reimburse him with money for the difference in value between the two halves of the field.
§ The mishna teaches that the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">accepts upon himself </span>to provide out of his own property <span class="gemarra-regular">the space for the fence </span>between the two halves of the field and for the larger and smaller ditches. A Sage <span class="gemarra-regular">taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: The larger <span class="gemarra-regular">ditch </span>is dug <span class="gemarra-regular">on the outside, while the smaller ditch </span>is dug <span class="gemarra-regular">on the inside,</span> closer to the field. Both <span class="gemarra-regular">this and that </span>are dug <span class="gemarra-regular">behind the fence, </span>

<span class="gemarra-regular">so that an animal will not jum</span><span class="gemarra-regular">p</span> over the fence, enter the field, and cause damage. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Let him make </span>only a larger <span class="gemarra-regular">ditch and not make a smaller ditch. </span>The Gemara replies: <span class="gemarra-regular">Since </span>the ditch <span class="gemarra-regular">is wide, </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">can stand inside it and jump </span>from there over the fence. The Gemara asks: If so, <span class="gemarra-regular">then let him make </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">a smaller ditc</span><span class="gemarra-regular">h</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and not make </span>a larger <span class="gemarra-regular">ditch? Since the ditch is small, </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">stands on its edge and jumps </span>over the fence. The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> explains the matter further: <span class="gemarra-regular">And how much </span>space is there <span class="gemarra-regular">between </span>the larger <span class="gemarra-regular">ditch and the smaller ditch</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> One handbreadth.</span>

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">There are </span>family members who both <span class="gemarra-regular">inherit </span>from <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">bequeath </span>to each other upon their respective deaths; <span class="gemarra-regular">and there </span><span class="gemarra-regular">are </span>those who <span class="gemarra-regular">inherit </span>from certain relatives <span class="gemarra-regular">but do not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">bequeath </span>to them; and there are those who <span class="gemarra-regular">bequeath </span>to certain relatives <span class="gemarra-regular">but do not inherit </span>from them; and there are those who, despite being relatives, <span class="gemarra-regular">do not inherit </span>from <span class="gemarra-regular">nor bequeath </span>to one another.
The mishna lists those referred to above. <span class="gemarra-regular">And these </span>both <span class="gemarra-regular">inherit </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and bequeath: A father </span>with regard to his <span class="gemarra-regular">sons</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and sons </span>with regard to their <span class="gemarra-regular">father, and paternal brothers</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span> all <span class="gemarra-regular">inherit </span>from one another <span class="gemarra-regular">and bequeath </span>to each other. <span class="gemarra-regular">A man </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">his mother</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a man </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">his wife, and sons of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> sisters</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., nephews born to the sisters of the deceased, all <span class="gemarra-regular">inherit </span>from their respective relatives <span class="gemarra-regular">but do</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not bequeath </span>to them. <span class="gemarra-regular">A woman </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">her</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> sons, and a woman </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">her husband, and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> maternal uncles, </span>all <span class="gemarra-regular">bequeath </span>to their respective relatives <span class="gemarra-regular">but do</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not inherit </span>from them. <span class="gemarra-regular">And maternal brothers, </span>despite being blood relatives, <span class="gemarra-regular">do not inherit </span>from each other <span class="gemarra-regular">nor </span>do they <span class="gemarra-regular">bequeath </span>to one another, as they are not considered relatives for the purpose of inheritance.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara begins by clarifying the order of the list in the mishna. <span class="gemarra-regular">What is different, </span>i.e., what is the reason, <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches: A </span><span class="gemarra-regular">father </span>with regard to his <span class="gemarra-regular">sons, </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">the first </span>example? <span class="gemarra-regular">Let </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">teach: Sons </span>with regard to their <span class="gemarra-regular">father, </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">the first </span>example. The Gemara explains why this would be preferable: <span class="gemarra-regular">One </span>reason is <span class="gemarra-regular">that we do not </span>want to <span class="gemarra-regular">begin with a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">calamity</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as the death of a son during his father’s lifetime is a calamity; therefore, it would have been appropriate to begin with the example of sons inheriting from their father. 

Daf 108b

<span class="gemarra-regular">And furthermore, </span>the verse first states that a son inherits from his father, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is written </span>in the portion concerning inheritance: <span class="gemarra-regular">“If</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a man dies</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and has no son, </span>then you shall pass his inheritance to his daughter” (Numbers 27:8).
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>as for the <span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span> of the mishna who listed the father inheriting first, <span class="gemarra-regular">since </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that a father inherits from his son <span class="gemarra-regular">is learned through a derivatio</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> and is not explicitly mentioned in the verse, this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">dear </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to him; </span>therefore, he listed it first.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And what </span>is the <span class="gemarra-regular">derivation</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> concerning the verse: “And if his father has no brothers, then you shall give his inheritance to his kinsman who is next to him of his family, and he shall inherit it” (Numbers 27:11): <span class="gemarra-regular">“His kinsman”; this </span>is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">the father</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and the Torah <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches that the father precedes the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> brother</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> of the deceased in inheriting from him. One <span class="gemarra-regular">might </span>have thought that the father of the deceased <span class="gemarra-regular">should </span><span class="gemarra-regular">precede the son </span>of the deceased in inheriting from him; <span class="gemarra-regular">the verse </span>therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">states: “Next [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">hakkarov</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] </span>to him,” teaching that the <span class="gemarra-regular">closer [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">karov</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] </span>one is to the deceased, the <span class="gemarra-regular">earlie</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> one is in the order of inheritance, and a son of the deceased is considered to be a closer relative to the deceased than the father of the deceased.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And what did you see </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to include the son </span>as the closer relative than the father <span class="gemarra-regular">and to exclude the brother? </span>The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">I</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> include the son, as he stands in place of his</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> father to designat</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> a Hebrew maidservant as a wife for himself, which a brother cannot do. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>similarly, he stands in place of his father <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to an</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> ancestral field</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> If a son redeems a field consecrated by his father, it is considered as though the father himself redeemed it and the field returns to the family in the Jubilee Year. By contrast, if the brother of the one who consecrated it redeems the field, it does not return to the family (see Leviticus 27:16–21).
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">On the contrary, I </span>should <span class="gemarra-regular">include the brother</span> as the closer relative, <span class="gemarra-regular">as he stands in his </span><span class="gemarra-regular">brother’s place with regard to levirate marriage</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and a son does not. The Gemara answers: This is not a valid claim, as <span class="gemarra-regular">is there levirate marriage except in</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a case where there is no son? In a case</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> where there is a son, there is no levirate marriage</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>This indicates that a son stands in place of the deceased before a brother even with regard to levirate marriage.
The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">The reason </span>that a son is considered to be a closer relative than a brother <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>specifically <span class="gemarra-regular">due</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to this refutation, </span>that where there is a son there is no levirate marriage. This indicates that <span class="gemarra-regular">without this </span>refutation <span class="gemarra-regular">I would say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a brother is superior </span>to a son in terms of how close a relative he is. The Gemara therefore asks: Why not <span class="gemarra-regular">derive </span>that a son is closer to the deceased than a brother

Daf 109a

from the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that here, </span>there are <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>examples of the superiority of a son, designation and an ancestral field, <span class="gemarra-regular">and here, </span>there is only <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>demonstration of the superiority of a brother, levirate marriage?
The Gemara answers: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">an ancestral field itself, the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> establishes his </span>ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span><span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>same <span class="gemarra-regular">reason: Is there levirate marriage except in a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">case where there is no son? In a case where </span><span class="gemarra-regular">there is a son, there is no levirate marriage. </span>The determination that the redemption of the ancestral field by a son is in place of the redemption of the field by the father, whereas the redemption of the field by a brother is not, is based on the reasoning that the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of levirate marriage is not an indication that a brother is a closer relative than a son. Therefore, the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of an ancestral field cannot be regarded as a second example of the son’s superiority, as it stems from the first example, that of levirate marriage.
The Gemara suggests an alternative derivation: Why should the father of the deceased inherit before only the brothers? <span class="gemarra-regular">Say </span>that he should inherit before the daughter of the deceased as well by interpreting the verse as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">“His kinsman” </span>(Numbers 27:11), <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">the father, </span>and the Torah <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches that the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">father precedes the daughter </span>of the deceased in inheriting from him. One <span class="gemarra-regular">might </span>have thought that the father of the deceased <span class="gemarra-regular">should precede the son </span>of the deceased in inheriting from him. <span class="gemarra-regular">The verse </span>therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">states: “Next [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">hakkarov</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] </span>to him,” teaching that the <span class="gemarra-regular">closer [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">karov</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] </span>one is to the deceased, the <span class="gemarra-regular">earlier </span>one is in the order of inheritance.
This suggestion is rejected: <span class="gemarra-regular">Since with regard to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the matter of levirate marriage a son and a daughter</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> are equivalent</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as levirate marriage is not performed if the deceased had either a son or a daughter, it stands to reason that <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to the matter of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> inheritance as well, a son and a daughter are equivalen</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> in that the father does not precede the daughter.
The Gemara suggests an alternative derivation: Why should the father of the deceased inherit before the brothers of the deceased? <span class="gemarra-regular">Say </span>that he should inherit only before his own brothers by interpreting the verse as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">“His kinsman</span><span class="gemarra-regular">” </span>( Numbers 27:11), <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">the father, </span>and the Torah <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches that the father precedes the father’s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> brothers </span>in inheriting from the deceased. One <span class="gemarra-regular">might </span>have thought that the father of the deceased <span class="gemarra-regular">should precede the brothers</span> of the deceased in inheriting from him. <span class="gemarra-regular">The verse </span><span class="gemarra-regular">states: “Next [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">hakkarov</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] </span>to him,” teaching that the <span class="gemarra-regular">closer [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">karov</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] </span>one is to the deceased, the <span class="gemarra-regular">earlier </span>one is in the order of inheritance.
The Gemara responds: <span class="gemarra-regular">A </span><span class="gemarra-regular">verse is not necessary </span>to teach that the father of the deceased inherits before <span class="gemarra-regular">the father’s brothers, </span>for the following reason: <span class="gemarra-regular">By whose virtue do the father’s brothers</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> come </span>to inherit from the deceased? <span class="gemarra-regular">By virtue </span>of the <span class="gemarra-regular">father, </span>as their right to inherit is a result of their being brothers of the father of the deceased. Could it be that while the <span class="gemarra-regular">father is still alive, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">his brothers should inherit? </span>The Gemara therefore concludes that the father precedes the brothers of the deceased.
The Gemara challenges: <span class="gemarra-regular">But</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the verses are not written that way, as it is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> written: </span>“And if he has no brothers, then you shall give his inheritance to his father’s brothers” (Numbers 27:10), and only later is it written: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And if his</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> father has no brothers, </span>then you shall give his inheritance to his kinsman who is next to him” (Numbers 27:11), indicating that the father, whose right to inherit is derived from the term “kinsman,” inherits only after the brothers of the deceased and his own brothers. The Gemara explains: The <span class="gemarra-regular">verses are not written in order, </span>since as explained earlier, it is not reasonable that the father’s brothers inherit before the father. Therefore, it must be that the inheritance of the father is not written in its proper place, and he may inherit even before the brothers of the deceased.
§ The Gemara records an additional derivation for the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that the father precedes the brothers of the deceased. <span class="gemarra-regular">And this </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> cites it </span><span class="gemarra-regular">from here, as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Yishmael, son of Rabbi Yosei, taught this </span><span class="it-text">halakha</span>: It is written: <span class="gemarra-regular">“If a man dies, and has no son,</span> then you shall pass his inheritance to his daughter” (Numbers 27:8). In the rest of the passage the verse employs the phrase “and you shall give.” It is only in this verse that it employs the phrase “and you shall pass.” Based on this, Rabbi Yishmael teaches that <span class="gemarra-regular">in a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> case </span>where there is <span class="gemarra-regular">a daughter, you pass an inheritance</span> to her <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>one who appears to have precedence, namely, <span class="gemarra-regular">the father, and </span>by inference, <span class="gemarra-regular">you do not pass </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">inheritance from the father in a case </span>where there are <span class="gemarra-regular">brothers </span>of the deceased.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>why not <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">in a case </span>where there is <span class="gemarra-regular">a daughter, you pass </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">inheritance </span>to her <span class="gemarra-regular">from the brothers, </span>

Daf 109b

<span class="gemarra-regular">but you do not pas</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> an inheritance from the father even in a case </span>where there is <span class="gemarra-regular">a daughter, </span>so that the father precedes the daughter in the order of inheritance? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, the Merciful One would not write: “Then you </span><span class="gemarra-regular">shall pass </span>the inheritance to his daughter” (Numbers 27:8). This indicates that the logical order of inheritance is being overridden, as the fact that the daughter precedes the brothers of the deceased is due to her being a closer relative of his. It is obvious that the Torah intends that she precede even the father.
Having quoted two derivations for the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that the father precedes the brothers, the Gemara proceeds to discuss them and asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And according </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to the one who derives it from </span>the term: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> you shall pass,” what does he do with this </span>term: <span class="gemarra-regular">“His kinsman,” </span>which was said to refer to the father? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">He requires it for that which</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">“His kinsman.” This </span>is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">his wife, </span>and the Torah <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches that a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> husband inherits </span>from <span class="gemarra-regular">his wife.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And according to the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> one who derives it from </span>the term: <span class="gemarra-regular">“His kinsman,” </span><span class="gemarra-regular">what does he do with this </span>term: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And you shall</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> pass”? He requires it for that which is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">says: In </span>the context of <span class="gemarra-regular">all of </span>the relatives listed in the passage detailing the laws of inheritance, it <span class="gemarra-regular">is stated concerning them </span>with the terminology of <span class="gemarra-regular">giving, and </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">here, </span>in the context of daughters, it <span class="gemarra-regular">is stated concerning them </span>with the terminology of <span class="gemarra-regular">passing. </span>This teaches us <span class="gemarra-regular">that you have</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> no one who passes an inheritance </span>of land in Eretz Yisrael <span class="gemarra-regular">from one tribe to another except for a daughter</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, since her son and husband inherit </span>from <span class="gemarra-regular">her.</span>
§ The Gemara returns to discuss the interpretation of the term: “His kinsman” (Numbers 27:11). <span class="gemarra-regular">And from where </span>does one know to derive <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>with regard to the term: <span class="gemarra-regular">“His kinsman [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">she’</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ero</span><span class="gemarra-regular">],” this </span>is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">the father, as it </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is written </span>in the context of forbidden sexual relations: <span class="gemarra-regular">“She</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is your father’s kinswoman [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">she’er</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]” </span>(Leviticus 18:12)? Perhaps one should <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>instead: <span class="gemarra-regular">“His kinswoman,” this </span>is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">the mother, as it is </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">written:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> “For she is your mother’s kinswoman [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">she’er</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]”</span> (Leviticus 18:13).
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said </span>in response that <span class="gemarra-regular">the verse states</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: </span>“Then you shall give his inheritance to his kinsman who is next to him <span class="gemarra-regular">of his family, and he </span><span class="gemarra-regular">shall inherit it” </span>(Numbers 27:11), emphasizing that “kinsman” is referring specifically to someone who is of his family, and it is <span class="gemarra-regular">the father’s family </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">is called </span>one’s <span class="gemarra-regular">family, </span>while one’s <span class="gemarra-regular">mother’s famil</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">called </span>one’s <span class="gemarra-regular">family. </span>Proof for this is found in another verse, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is written: “By their families, by </span><span class="gemarra-regular">their fathers’ houses” </span>(Numbers 1:2).
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>is one’s <span class="gemarra-regular">mother’s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> family </span>indeed <span class="gemarra-regular">not called </span>one’s <span class="gemarra-regular">family? But it is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> written </span>in the episode of Micah forming an idol to be worshipped: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And there was a young man of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Bethlehem in Judah of the family of Judah who was </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a Levite, and he sojourned there” </span>(Judges 17:7). The Gemara explains the difficulty: <span class="gemarra-regular">This matter itself </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">difficult. You said</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: “Who was a Levite,” </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">apparently he came from </span>the tribe of <span class="gemarra-regular">Levi, </span>but the verse says: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the family of Judah,” </span>so <span class="gemarra-regular">apparently he came from </span>the tribe of <span class="gemarra-regular">Judah. Rather, is it not that his </span><span class="gemarra-regular">father </span>was <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the tribe of <span class="gemarra-regular">Levi and his mother </span>was <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the tribe of <span class="gemarra-regular">Judah, and </span>yet the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">says </span>that he was: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Of the family of Judah”? </span>This appears to prove that one’s mother’s family is also called his family.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava </span><span class="gemarra-regular">bar Rav Ḥanan said </span>in response: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>the verse speaks of <span class="gemarra-regular">a man whose name </span>was <span class="gemarra-regular">Levi, </span>but his father was of the tribe of Judah. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If that is so, </span>how <span class="gemarra-regular">is that which Micah said</span> when that man agreed to serve as his priest: <span class="gemarra-regular">“</span><span class="gemarra-regular">Now I know that the Lord will do me good, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">seeing that I have a Levite as my priest” </span>(Judges 17:13), understood? It is understood only if he was an actual Levite, not if he was from the tribe of Judah and named Levi. Rava bar Rav Ḥanan responded: <span class="gemarra-regular">Yes</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>it is understood. Micah understood the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">man whose name </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">Levi happened upon hi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">m</span> as an auspicious sign.
The Gemara asks further: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>is it <span class="gemarra-regular">so </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">his name </span>was indeed <span class="gemarra-regular">Levi; but wasn’t Jonathan his name, as it </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is stated: “And Jonathan, the son of Gershom, the son </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of Manasseh, he and his sons were priests to the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">tribe of the Danites” </span>(Judges 18:30)? Rava bar Rav Ḥanan <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: And according to your reasoning, </span>that his name was not Levi but he was from the tribe of Levi, there is also a difficulty from that same verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>is it <span class="gemarra-regular">so </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span>was <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">son of Manasseh</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> but wasn’t he the son </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of Moses, as it is written: “The sons of Moses: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Gershom and Eliezer” </span>(I Chronicles 23:15)?
Rava bar Rav Ḥanan explains the verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>although he was the son of Moses, <span class="gemarra-regular">because he acted </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">Manasseh </span>the king of Judah, who was notorious for idol worship, <span class="gemarra-regular">acted, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the verse linked him to Manasse</span><span class="gemarra-regular">h</span> by calling him “the son of Manasseh.” <span class="gemarra-regular">Here too, </span>in the verse from which you seek to prove that one’s mother’s family is called one’s family, <span class="gemarra-regular">since he acted </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">Manasseh, who came from </span>the tribe of <span class="gemarra-regular">Judah, acted, the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">verse linked him to Judah </span>by stating that he was “of the family of Judah,” but he was, in fact, a Levite.
In connection with this, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says in the name </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Shimon ben Yoḥai: From here </span>it is learned <span class="gemarra-regular">that corruption is linked to one who is corrupt</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as this man was linked to Manasseh and Judah despite having no familial connection to them. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei bar Ḥanina </span><span class="gemarra-regular">says: </span>That concept can be seen <span class="gemarra-regular">from here, </span>in the matter of Adonijah, the son of David: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And he</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> was also a very handsome man; and she gave birth</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to him after Absalom,” </span>(I Kings 1:6) <span class="gemarra-regular">but Adonijah </span><span class="gemarra-regular">wasn’t the son of Haggith and Absalom was the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">son of Maachah, </span>so why does the verse state: “And she gave birth to him after Absalom,” as if they were sons of the same mother? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, since Adonijah acted </span>in a manner fit for <span class="gemarra-regular">Absalom, who </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">rebelled against</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the monarchy, the verse linked him to Absalom, </span>referring to him as his full brother. <span class="gemarra-regular">Here too, </span>with regard to Jonathan, <span class="gemarra-regular">since he acted </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">Manasseh acted, the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> verse linked him to Manasseh.</span>
§ In connection with the story of Jonathan, son of Manasseh, the Gemara cites a related statement. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar says: A person should always </span><span class="gemarra-regular">cleave to goo</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> people, meaning one should marry a woman from a good family, as this is beneficial for the offspring of that marriage. <span class="gemarra-regular">As </span>in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">Moses</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, who married a daughter of Yitro, </span>who was a priest of idolatry, <span class="gemarra-regular">Jonathan, </span>who was also a priest of idolatry, <span class="gemarra-regular">descended from him, </span>while in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">Aaron</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, who married the daughter of Amminadab, </span>who was of distinguished lineage in the tribe of Judah, <span class="gemarra-regular">Pinehas descended from </span><span class="gemarra-regular">him.</span>

<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>this is how the matter should be resolved: <span class="gemarra-regular">If his mother’s fathe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> came <span class="gemarra-regular">from</span> the family of <span class="gemarra-regular">Joseph, his mother’s mother </span>came <span class="gemarra-regular">from</span> the family of <span class="gemarra-regular">Yitro, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">if his mother’s father</span> came <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the family of <span class="gemarra-regular">Yitro, his mother’s mother</span> came <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the family of <span class="gemarra-regular">Joseph, </span>so while his mother was descended from Joseph on one side and from Yitro on the other, Pinehas was a more distant relative to Yitro than Jonathan was. Based on this conclusion, the language of the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">is also precise, as it is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> written: </span>“And Elazar, Aaron’s son, took <span class="gemarra-regular">one of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the daughters of Putiel” </span>(Exodus 6:25). <span class="gemarra-regular">Conclude from </span>the wording of the verse that Pinehas was descended from <span class="gemarra-regular">two</span> men who were referred to as Puti: Yitro and Joseph.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava says: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">One who marries a woman needs to </span>first <span class="gemarra-regular">examine her </span><span class="gemarra-regular">brothers </span>so that he will know in advance what character his children will have, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is stated: “And Aaron</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> took Elisheva, the daughter of Amminadav, the sister of Nahshon</span><span class="gemarra-regular">” </span>(Exodus 6:23). <span class="gemarra-regular">By inference from that which is stated</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: “The daughter of Amminadav,” do I not know that</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> she is the sister of Nahshon, </span>as Nahshon was the son of Amminadav? <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is the meaning when <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">verse states: “The sister of Nahshon”?
