In connection with the Gemara’s mention of Jonathan, who served as a priest for Micah, the Gemara quotes additional statements of the Sages concerning that episode. Describing when the men from the tribe of Dan passed through Micah’s house, the verse states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And they turned aside there and said to him: Who</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> brought you here [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">halom</span><span class="gemarra-regular">], and what [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ma</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] are you doing</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in this place, and what do you have here </span><span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">p</span><span class="gemarra-italic">o</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]?” </span>(Judges 18:3). The Sages interpret their multiple questions. <span class="gemarra-regular">They </span><span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Do you not come from Moses, about</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> whom it is written: “Do not draw close to here</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">halom</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]” </span>(Exodus 3:5)? <span class="gemarra-regular">Do you not come from Moses, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">about whom it is written: “What [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ma</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] is that in </span><span class="gemarra-regular">your hand” </span>(Exodus 4:2)? <span class="gemarra-regular">Do you not come from Moses</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, about whom it is written: “But as for you, stand</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> here </span><span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">p</span><span class="gemarra-italic">o</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] with me” </span>(Deuteronomy 5:27)? <span class="gemarra-regular">Shall you, </span>a descendant of our teacher Moses, <span class="gemarra-regular">become a priest for idol</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> worship?</span>
Jonathan <span class="gemarra-regular">said to them: This </span>is the tradition that <span class="gemarra-regular">I</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> received from the house of my father’s father: A</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> person should always hire himsel</span><span class="gemarra-regular">f </span> out <span class="gemarra-regular">to idol worship </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and not require </span>the help <span class="gemarra-regular">of people </span>by receiving charity, and I took this position in order to avoid having to take charity.
The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">And he, </span>Jonathan, <span class="gemarra-regular">thought </span>that this referred <span class="gemarra-regular">to actual </span><span class="gemarra-regular">idol worship</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> but </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">is not so, </span>that was not the intent of the tradition. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>here the term <span class="gemarra-regular">idol worship, </span>literally: Strange service, is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">service</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>i.e., labor, <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">strange, </span>i.e., unsuitable, <span class="gemarra-regular">for him. </span>In other words, one should be willing to perform labor that is difficult and humiliating in his eyes rather than become a recipient of charity. <span class="gemarra-regular">As Rav </span><span class="gemarra-regular">said to Rav Kahana, </span>his student: <span class="gemarra-regular">Skin a carcass in</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the market and take payment, but do not say: I</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> am a great ma</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and this matter is beneath </span><span class="gemarra-regular">me.</span>
The Gemara continues its discussion of that episode. Later, <span class="gemarra-regular">when </span>King <span class="gemarra-regular">David saw that money was excessively precious to </span>Jonathan, <span class="gemarra-regular">he</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> appointed him </span>as director <span class="gemarra-regular">of the treasuries </span>of the Temple, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is stated: “And Shebuel, the son of Gershom</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, the son of Moses, was ruler over the treasuries” </span>(I Chronicles 26:24). The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And was his name </span>really <span class="gemarra-regular">Shebuel; but wasn’t his name Jonathan</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rabbi </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Yoḥanan says: </span>He is called Shebuel in order to allude to the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>he repented and <span class="gemarra-regular">returned to God</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">shav</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">la’el </span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with all his heart.</span>
§ The mishna teaches in the list of those who inherit from and bequeath to each other: <span class="gemarra-regular">Sons </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">their father. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">From where do we </span>derive this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that sons inherit the entire estate and daughters do not receive a share along with them? <span class="gemarra-regular">As it</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is written: “If a man dies, </span>and has no son, then you shall pass his inheritance to his daughter” (Numbers 27:8). <span class="gemarra-regular">The reason </span>the inheritance would be passed to a daughter is <span class="gemarra-regular">that he has no son, but </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">he has a son, </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">son takes precedence. Rav Pappa</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> said to Abaye: </span>Why not <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>the following: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span><span class="gemarra-regular">there is </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">a son, let </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">son inherit </span>the father’s estate; if <span class="gemarra-regular">there is </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">a daughter, let </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">daughter inherit </span>the father’s estate; and if <span class="gemarra-regular">there</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is </span>both <span class="gemarra-regular">a son and a daughter, neither this one</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> should inherit nor that one should inherit.</span>
Abaye asked Rav Pappa: <span class="gemarra-regular">And rather, </span>

Daf 110b

<span class="gemarra-regular">who </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">should inherit? Is that </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to say that the rule</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of the city should inherit</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? </span>Rav Pappa said to him: <span class="gemarra-regular">This is what I </span>meant to <span class="gemarra-regular">say: </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">there is a son and a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">daughter, this </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">should not inherit all of </span>the estate, <span class="gemarra-regular">and that </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">should not inherit all of </span>the estate, <span class="gemarra-regular">but they should inherit it </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">equal </span>portions <span class="gemarra-regular">to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> one another</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> him: But is the verse necessary </span>in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">teach us that when he has only one child, </span>that child <span class="gemarra-regular">should inherit all of his property? </span>If you say that the right of the son and daughter to the inheritance is equal, then the verse: “If a man dies, and has no son” (Numbers 27:8), which teaches that when there is no son his daughter inherits, is superfluous. Rav Pappa responded: <span class="gemarra-regular">And perhaps this </span>verse <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us this: That</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a daughter is also subject to </span>receiving <span class="gemarra-regular">inheritance. </span>The Gemara replies: No, the verse does not need to teach us this, since <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span><span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is derived from </span>the verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And every daughter who possesses an inheritance” </span>(Numbers 36:8), which clearly states that a daughter is subject to receiving inheritance.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov said: </span>The <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that a son inherits his father’s estate and precedes a daughter is derived <span class="gemarra-regular">from here, </span>in the passage in the Torah where the daughters of Zelophehad request their father’s inheritance in Eretz Yisrael. They said to Moses: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Why should</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the name of our father be done away from among</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> his family, because he has no son?” </span>(Numbers 27:4). Rabbi Aḥa ben Ya’akov infers: <span class="gemarra-regular">The reason </span>they requested the inheritance is <span class="gemarra-regular">that, </span>as they said: He <span class="gemarra-regular">has no</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> son. </span>One can infer: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">he has a son</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">son takes precedence </span>and the daughters would not have requested an inheritance.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <span class="gemarra-regular">But perhaps </span>it was <span class="gemarra-regular">the daughters of Zelophehad who said</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> this, </span>i.e., that they were entitled to an inheritance only because their father had no son. They thought that this was the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> based on the custom at that time, but after God spoke to Moses, the <span class="gemarra-regular">Torah was</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> given and a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> was initiated </span>that a daughter’s right to inherit is equal to that of the son. The Gemara accepts this difficulty and states: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, it is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> clear </span>that the source for this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">as we</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> answered initially, </span>i.e., as Abaya derived from the verse of: “If a man dies, and has no son, then you shall pass his inheritance to his daughter” (Numbers 27:8).
<span class="gemarra-regular">Ravina </span><span class="gemarra-regular">said: </span>The source for the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that a son precedes a daughter is <span class="gemarra-regular">from here: “Who is next to him</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">hakkarov</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">elav</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]” </span>(Numbers 27:11), teaching that the <span class="gemarra-regular">closer [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">karov</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] </span>one is to the deceased, the <span class="gemarra-regular">earlier </span>one is in the order of inheritance, and a son of the deceased is considered to be a closer relative to the deceased than the daughter.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And what </span>demonstrates the <span class="gemarra-regular">closeness</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of a son more than </span>that of <span class="gemarra-regular">a daughter? That</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a son stands in place of his father to designate</span> a Hebrew maidservant as a wife for himself <span class="gemarra-regular">and with</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> regard to an ancestral field. </span>The Gemara rejects this: This is not a valid proof, as <span class="gemarra-regular">designation </span>cannot demonstrate that a son is a closer relative; <span class="gemarra-regular">a daughter is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">not subject to designation, </span>because she obviously cannot marry the Hebrew maidservant. With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">an ancestral field as well</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> establishes his </span>ruling that a son is a closer relative than others <span class="gemarra-regular">from this </span>same <span class="gemarra-regular">refutation: Is there</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> levirate marriage except in a case where there is no</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> son? </span>And this applies also where there is no daughter. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, it is clear </span>that the source for this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">as we answered initially.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if you wish, say</span> instead that the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that a son precedes a daughter is derived <span class="gemarra-regular">from here, </span>in the passage in the Torah addressing the inheritance of slaves, which states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And you</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> may make them an inheritance for your sons [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">livneikhem</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] after</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> you” </span>(Leviticus 25:46). One can infer: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Your sons,” but</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not your daughters. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If that is so</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>then when the verse states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“That your days may</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> be multiplied, and the days of your sons [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">beneikhem</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]” </span>(Deuteronomy 11:21), should one infer that <span class="gemarra-regular">this too </span>means: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Your</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> sons,” but not your daughters? </span>Is it not obvious that daughters are also worthy of receiving the blessing of longevity?
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">A blessing is different</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> In a verse that speaks of blessings, the term <span class="it-text">beneikhem</span> should be understood in its broader sense, as “your children.” In a verse that speaks of a <span class="it-text">halakha</span>, it is to be understood in the narrower sense of “your sons.”
§ The mishna teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">And paternal brother</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">inherit </span>from one another <span class="gemarra-regular">and bequeath </span>to each other. <span class="gemarra-regular">From</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> where do we </span>derive this <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba said: </span>It <span class="gemarra-regular">is derived from </span>a verbal analogy between the word: <span class="gemarra-regular">Brothers,</span> stated with regard to inheritance, and the word: <span class="gemarra-regular">Brothers, </span>found in the verses concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">Jacob’s sons. </span>When Jacob’s sons speak to Joseph, they state: “We, your servants, are twelve brothers, the sons of one man in the land of Canaan” (Genesis 42:13), and in the passage discussing inheritance the verse states: “And if he has no brothers, then you shall give his inheritance to his father’s brothers” (Numbers 27:10). <span class="gemarra-regular">Just as there, </span>in the verse concerning Jacob’s sons, the word brothers is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">paternal</span> brothers <span class="gemarra-regular">and not maternal </span>brothers, as the twelve of them shared only the same father, <span class="gemarra-regular">so too here, </span>where this term is used with regard to inheritance, the verse is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">paternal </span>brothers <span class="gemarra-regular">and not maternal </span>brothers.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But why do I </span>need this proof from the verse concerning Jacob’s sons? <span class="gemarra-regular">It is written </span>in the passage concerning inheritance: “Then you shall give his inheritance to his kinsman who is next to him <span class="gemarra-regular">of his </span><span class="gemarra-regular">family, and he shall inherit it” </span>(Numbers 27:11). When the term “family” is used in the Bible, one’s <span class="gemarra-regular">father</span><span class="gemarra-regular">’s family is called </span>one’s <span class="gemarra-regular">family, </span>while one’s <span class="gemarra-regular">mother’s family is not called </span>one’s <span class="gemarra-regular">family, </span>so that in all matters of inheritance, it is the patrilineal relatives who are taken into account.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Yes, it is indeed so </span>that the verbal analogy is not needed to teach the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of inheritance, <span class="gemarra-regular">and when Rabba’s </span>explanation <span class="gemarra-regular">was stated, </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">was stated</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with regard to the matter of levirate marriage, </span>teaching that levirate marriage is performed only by a paternal brother but not by a maternal brother.
§ The mishna teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">And a man </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">his mother </span>inherits from her relatives but does not bequeath to her. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">From </span><span class="gemarra-regular">where are these matters </span>derived? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">As the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Sages taught: </span>

Daf 111a

The verse states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And every</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> daughter who possesses an inheritance from the tribes of the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> children of Israel” </span>(Numbers 36:8). Noting the plural in the phrase “from the tribes of the children of Israel,” the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">How </span>can <span class="gemarra-regular">a daughter inherit </span>land from <span class="gemarra-regular">two tribes? Rather, this </span>is referring to a daughter <span class="gemarra-regular">whose </span><span class="gemarra-regular">father </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">from one tribe but her mother </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span><span class="gemarra-regular">another tribe, and they </span>both <span class="gemarra-regular">died, and she inherited </span>from both of <span class="gemarra-regular">them. </span>Therefore, it can be seen in this verse that a daughter inherits from her mother.
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">I</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> have </span>derived <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a daughter </span>inherits from her mother; <span class="gemarra-regular">from where </span>do I derive that <span class="gemarra-regular">a son </span>inherits from his mother as well? <span class="gemarra-regular">You </span>can <span class="gemarra-regular">say an </span><span class="gemarra-italic">a</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">fortiori</span> inference: <span class="gemarra-regular">And just as a daughter, whose power is diminished</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with regard to </span>her <span class="gemarra-regular">father’s property </span>in that she does not inherit it when there is a son, yet her power <span class="gemarra-regular">is enhanced with regard to </span>her <span class="gemarra-regular">mother’s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> property </span>in that she inherits it; with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> son, whose power is enhanced with regard to </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">father</span><span class="gemarra-regular">’s property </span>in that he is first in the order of inheritance, <span class="gemarra-regular">is it not logical that his power </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is enhanced with regard to </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">mother’s property? </span>The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">And from the place that you came, </span>i.e., from the inference that was just stated, one can say the following: <span class="gemarra-regular">Just as there, </span>with regard to a father’s property, <span class="gemarra-regular">a son precedes a daughter, so too</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> here, </span>with regard to a mother’s property, <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">son precedes a daughter. </span>This is the opinion of the first <span class="it-text">tanna</span>.
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei, son of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rabbi Yehuda, and Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Yosei, said</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in the name of Rabbi Zekharya ben Hakatzav</span><span class="gemarra-regular">:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Both</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the son and the daughter are equal with regard to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the mother’s property. What is the reason </span>for his ruling? <span class="gemarra-regular">It is sufficient for the </span>conclusion that <span class="gemarra-regular">emerges </span><span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>an <span class="it-text">a</span> <span class="it-text">fortiori</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">inference to be like </span>its <span class="gemarra-regular">source. </span>According to this principle, a <span class="it-text">halakha</span> derived by means of an <span class="it-text">a</span> <span class="it-text">fortiori</span> inference cannot go beyond the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of the source from which it is derived. Since the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that a son inherits from his mother was derived via an <span class="it-text">a</span> <span class="it-text">fortiori</span> inference from the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that a daughter inherits from her mother, it cannot be that this inference should lead to the conclusion that a son precedes a daughter in inheriting from their mother.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And doesn’t the first </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span> also <span class="gemarra-regular">interpret </span>verses employing the principle of: <span class="gemarra-regular">It is sufficient </span>for the conclusion that emerges from an <span class="it-text">a</span> <span class="it-text">fortiori</span> inference to be like its source? <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>the principle of: <span class="gemarra-regular">It is sufficient, </span>which limits the extent of <span class="it-text">a</span> <span class="it-text">fortiori</span> inference, <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>found <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the Torah, </span>so how could he disagree with it?
<span class="gemarra-regular">As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that explains the hermeneutical principles: <span class="gemarra-regular">How </span>does <span class="gemarra-regular">an </span><span class="gemarra-italic">a</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">fortiori</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">inference </span>work? The verse states with regard to Miriam, after she spoke ill of her brother Moses: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Lord said to Moses: If her father had but spit </span><span class="gemarra-regular">in her face, should she not hide in shame seven </span><span class="gemarra-regular">days?” </span>(Numbers 12:14). The verse is saying that if a father spits in the face of his daughter and reprimands her, she would feel shame for seven days. By <span class="gemarra-regular">an</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">a</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">fortiori</span> inference it is derived that Miriam, who suffered the more severe reprimand <span class="gemarra-regular">of the Divine Presence</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> should be ostracized for <span class="gemarra-regular">fourteen </span>days. Why then, was Miriam ostracized for only seven days?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, it is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> sufficient for the </span>conclusion that <span class="gemarra-regular">emerges from </span>an <span class="it-text">a</span> <span class="it-text">fortiori</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">inference to be like </span>its <span class="gemarra-regular">source, </span>so her punishment cannot be for longer than the punishment of one who is reprimanded by a father. In any event, the principle the begins with: It is sufficient, can be seen in this verse, so how does the first <span class="it-text">tanna</span> rule that a son precedes a daughter with regard to a mother’s property?
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Generally, </span>the first <span class="it-text">tanna</span> also <span class="gemarra-regular">interprets</span> verses employing the principle that begins with: <span class="gemarra-regular">It is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">sufficient, but it is different here </span>with regard to inheritance, <span class="gemarra-regular">as the verse states: </span>“And every daughter who possesses an inheritance <span class="gemarra-regular">from the tribes </span>of the children of Israel” (Numbers 36:8). The verse <span class="gemarra-regular">juxtaposes </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">tribe of the mother </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">tribe of the father. </span>Therefore, the first <span class="it-text">tanna</span> holds that <span class="gemarra-regular">just as </span>with regard to the <span class="gemarra-regular">tribe of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the father, </span>i.e., inheriting from one’s father, <span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> son precedes a daughter, so too, </span>with regard to the <span class="gemarra-regular">tribe of the mother, </span>i.e., inheriting from one’s mother, <span class="gemarra-regular">a son precedes a daughter.</span>
The Gemara relates: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Nittai thought to perform an action, </span>i.e., issue a ruling, <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Zekharya ben HaKatzav, </span>who taught that a son and daughter are equal with regard to inheriting from their mother. <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel said to him: In accordance with whose </span>opinion do you wish to issue this ruling, <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with</span> the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Zekharya? Zekharya is nil [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">afes</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., his statement was not accepted as <span class="it-text">halakha</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Tavla</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> performed an action, </span>i.e., issued a ruling, <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span><span class="gemarra-regular">accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Zekharya ben HaKatzav. Rav </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Naḥman said to him: What is this? </span>Rabbi Tavla <span class="gemarra-regular">said</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to him: As Rav Ḥinnana bar Shelamya says in the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> name of Rav: </span>The <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Zekharya ben HaKatzav. </span>Rav Naḥman <span class="gemarra-regular">said to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> him: Go retract your </span>ruling, <span class="gemarra-regular">and if </span>you do <span class="gemarra-regular">not</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, I will take Rav Ḥinnana bar Shelamya out of your</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> ear</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., I will punish you severely for ruling against the accepted <span class="it-text">halakha</span>.
The Gemara relates further: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna bar</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Ḥiyya thought to perform an action, </span>i.e., issue a ruling, <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Zekharya</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> ben HaKatzav. Rav Naḥman said to him: What is this</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? </span>Rav Huna bar Ḥiyya <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: As Rav </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Huna says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: </span>The <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance </span><span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Zekharya ben HaKatzav. </span>Rav Naḥman <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Shall I send </span>a messenger <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>Rav Huna to ask him if that is indeed what he said? Rav Huna bar Ḥiyya <span class="gemarra-regular">was embarrassed</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as he was not certain that Rav Huna actually said this ruling. Rav Naḥman <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Now, if Rav Huna </span><span class="gemarra-regular">were </span>to have <span class="gemarra-regular">died, you would have been brazen </span>enough to say <span class="gemarra-regular">before me </span>that this is what he said, but since he is still alive, you cannot be so brazen.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And he, </span>Rav Naḥman, <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with whose </span>opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">does he hold? </span>As there were various sages who ruled in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Zekharya ben HaKatzav, why did Rav Naḥman not agree? The Gemara answers: He holds <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance </span><span class="gemarra-regular">with this </span>statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav and Shmuel, who both say: </span>The <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">not in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Zekharya ben HaKatzav.</span>
The Gemara relates: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Yannai, </span>who had already grown old and whose eyes were dim, <span class="gemarra-regular">would walk leaning on the shoulder of Rabbi Simlai</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, his attendant, and Rabbi Yehuda Nesi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> came toward them. </span>Rabbi Simlai <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Rabbi Yannai: The <span class="gemarra-regular">person who is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">coming toward us is handsome and his cloak </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">handsome</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> When </span>Rabbi Yehuda Nesia <span class="gemarra-regular">reached him, </span>Rabbi Yannai <span class="gemarra-regular">felt</span> his cloak and <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Rabbi Simlai: Concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>cloak, <span class="gemarra-regular">its measurement </span>with regard to the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of ritual impurity <span class="gemarra-regular">is like the </span>measurement of <span class="gemarra-regular">sackcloth</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> meaning it was a cloak of inferior quality, as it was thick and rough.
When Rabbi Yehuda Nesia met Rabbi Yannai he <span class="gemarra-regular">asked him: From where</span> is it derived <span class="gemarra-regular">that a son precedes a daughter with</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> regard to the mother’s property</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> Rabbi Yannai <span class="gemarra-regular">said</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to him: As it is written: </span>“And every daughter who possesses an inheritance from <span class="gemarra-regular">the tribes </span>of the children of Israel” (Numbers 36:8). The verse <span class="gemarra-regular">juxtaposes </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">tribe of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the mother to </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">tribe of the father. </span>This teaches that <span class="gemarra-regular">just as </span>with regard to the <span class="gemarra-regular">tribe of the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> father a son precedes a daughter, so too, </span>with regard to the <span class="gemarra-regular">tribe of the mother, a son precedes </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a daughter. </span>Rabbi Yehuda Nesia <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: If </span>so, if these two <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> are in fact juxtaposed, the following should also be derived: <span class="gemarra-regular">Just as </span>with regard to the inheritance of <span class="gemarra-regular">the father’s tribe a firstborn takes </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a double </span>portion, <span class="gemarra-regular">so too, </span>with regard to inheritance from <span class="gemarra-regular">the mother’s tribe, </span>when he inherits from his mother <span class="gemarra-regular">a firstborn takes a double </span>portion. 

Daf 111b

<span class="gemarra-regular">He said to his attendant: Take </span>me away from here, as <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>man, Rabbi Yehuda Nesia, <span class="gemarra-regular">does not desire to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> lear</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> but is instead raising difficulties that are easily resolved. <span class="gemarra-regular">And what is the reason </span>he does not receive a double portion? <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said: The verse </span>concerning the double portion received by a firstborn son <span class="gemarra-regular">states: </span>“By giving him a double portion <span class="gemarra-regular">of all that he has” </span>(Deuteronomy 21:17), indicating that he receives a double portion in all that <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span>has, <span class="gemarra-regular">but not </span>in all that <span class="gemarra-regular">she </span>has.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And</span> why not <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">this statement </span>applies in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a bachelor who married a widow, </span>i.e., a man who marries a woman who already has children from another man, so that the firstborn son is his firstborn but not hers, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a bachelor</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> who married a virgin, so too </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> will be <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>their firstborn son <span class="gemarra-regular">will take </span>a double portion of his mother’s inheritance?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: </span>There is a different derivation teaching that <span class="it-text">halakha</span>, as the same <span class="gemarra-regular">verse states: </span>“For he is <span class="gemarra-regular">the first fruits of his strength [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ono</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]” </span>(Deuteronomy 21:17), indicating that the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of the double portion is stated with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">his strength, but not her strength,</span> thereby excluding a son who is the firstborn of his mother alone.
The Gemara challenges: But <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>verse <span class="gemarra-regular">is required to </span>derive the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of a child who <span class="gemarra-regular">came </span>into the world <span class="gemarra-regular">after </span>his mother gave birth to <span class="gemarra-regular">non-viable newborn</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> who did not reach the full term of nine months. This verse teaches <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>such a firstborn son <span class="gemarra-regular">should be a firstborn with regard to inheritance, </span>even though he is not a firstborn with regard to the mitzva to redeem one’s firstborn son. How is this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> derived from the verse? The term “his strength [<span class="it-text">ono</span>]” is understood as referring to acute mourning [<span class="it-text">aninut</span>], in the following manner: A firstborn son for the purpose of inheritance of land is only <span class="gemarra-regular">one whose </span>father’s <span class="gemarra-regular">heart is pained</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> about him </span>when he dies, i.e., a son who lives beyond birth, <span class="gemarra-regular">excluding this </span>non-viable newborn <span class="gemarra-regular">whose </span>father’s <span class="gemarra-regular">heart</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is not pained about him </span>when he dies. Therefore, the next viable son to be born after a non-viable newborn is considered the firstborn.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, </span>that the sole purpose of the term: “His strength” is to teach that <span class="it-text">halakha</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">let the verse </span><span class="gemarra-regular">say: For he is the first fruit of strength [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">on</span><span class="gemarra-regular">],</span> omitting the possessive “his,” represented by the letter <span class="it-text">vav</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">What</span> is derived from the more expanded term: <span class="gemarra-regular">“His strength [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ono</span><span class="gemarra-regular">],” </span>which indicates specifically the father’s strength? <span class="gemarra-regular">Conclude two</span> conclusions <span class="gemarra-regular">from it, </span>both with regard to mourning and with regard to the status of the firstborn as the father’s heir specifically.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>one can <span class="gemarra-regular">still say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">this statement </span>applies in a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a widower who married a virgin, </span>so that he already has a firstborn from his previous marriage who is the first fruit of his strength. And the son born to him and his second wife is not the first fruit of his strength, and it is this type of firstborn who does not inherit a double portion of his mother’s estate. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>in a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">bachelor who married a virgin, so too </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> will be <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>their shared firstborn son <span class="gemarra-regular">will take </span>a double portion of his mother’s inheritance.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, Rava said: </span>There is a different derivation teaching that <span class="it-text">halakha</span>, as the same <span class="gemarra-regular">verse states: “The right of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the firstborn is his” </span>(Deuteronomy 21:17). The emphasis on “his” indicates that <span class="gemarra-regular">the primogeniture </span>applies specifically <span class="gemarra-regular">to a man</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and the primogeniture does not </span>apply <span class="gemarra-regular">to a woman, </span>whether the woman is the one inheriting or is the legator.
§ The mishna teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">And a man </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">his wif</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> inherits but does not bequeath. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">From where are these matters </span>derived? The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">As</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the Sages taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: The verse concerning inheritance states: “And if his father has no brothers, then you shall give his inheritance to <span class="gemarra-regular">his kinsman [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">she’ero</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> who is next to him of his family, and he shall inherit it” (Numbers 27:11). <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>kinsman is <span class="gemarra-regular">one’s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> wife, </span>and the Torah <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches that a husband inherits </span>from <span class="gemarra-regular">his wife</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as the Gemara will explain later. One <span class="gemarra-regular">might </span>have thought that <span class="gemarra-regular">she would also inherit </span>from <span class="gemarra-regular">him; </span>therefore, <span class="gemarra-regular">the verse states: “And he shall inherit it,”</span> with the word “it” written in the feminine “<span class="it-text">otah</span>,” which can also be translated as: Her. This teaches that it is <span class="gemarra-regular">he who inherits </span>from <span class="gemarra-regular">her, but she does not</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> inherit </span>from <span class="gemarra-regular">him</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
The Gemara questions this explanation: <span class="gemarra-regular">But the verses</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> are not written like this. </span>The verse states that “his kinsman” inherits from the deceased, so that if that term is referring to one’s wife, a wife should inherit from her husband. <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said: Answer like this, </span>i.e., as if the verse were split into two parts. The first part is: <span class="gemarra-regular">Then you shall give his inheritance</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to he who is next to him, </span>which is a general statement with regard to the inheritance of relatives. The second is: <span class="gemarra-regular">His kinsman, and he shall inherit </span><span class="gemarra-regular">it, </span>meaning that a husband inherits from his kinsman, referring to his wife.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: </span>Does <span class="gemarra-regular">a sharp knife cut verses? </span>How can you split the verse, rearrange it and omit letters from its words? Abaye’s derivation rearranges the words and omits the letter <span class="it-text">lamed</span> from the term “to his kinsman [<span class="it-text">leshe’ero</span>].” <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, Rava said: This </span>is what the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">is saying: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">And you shall give the inheritance of his kinsman [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">she’</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ero</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] to him. </span>The letters should be arranged differently, removing the letter <span class="it-text">lamed</span> from the word <span class="it-text">leshe’ero</span> and the letter <span class="it-text">vav</span> from the word <span class="it-text">naḥalato</span> and combining them to form the word <span class="it-text">lo</span>, meaning: To him. Accordingly, the verse teaches that a husband inherits from his wife. The Gemara explains that Rava <span class="gemarra-regular">holds that </span>the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">subtract and add</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and interpret homiletically</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> meaning that letters can be removed from words and appended to each other, and a <span class="it-text">halakha</span> can be derived from the new word formed by the combination of letters.
The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">And this </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> cites </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that a husband inherits from his wife <span class="gemarra-regular">from here, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And he shall</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> inherit it,” </span>with the word “it” written in the feminine “<span class="it-text">otah</span>,” which can also be translated as: Her. This <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that a husband inherits </span>from <span class="gemarra-regular">his wife; </span>this is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of Rabbi Akiva, </span>similar to the derivation cited in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> above.
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> quotes another <span class="it-text">tanna</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yishmael says</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: </span>This derivation <span class="gemarra-regular">is not necessary</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as </span>the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">states</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: “And every daughter who possesses an inheritance from the tribes</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of the children of Israel </span>shall be wife <span class="gemarra-regular">to one</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of the family </span>of the tribe of her father” (Numbers 36:8). The purpose of this mitzva was so that the land she inherited from her father’s tribe will not be transferred to another tribe upon her death. <span class="gemarra-regular">The verse</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> speaks of a transfer </span>of inheritance from one tribe to another <span class="gemarra-regular">by means of the husband, </span>i.e., she must not marry a man from another tribe so that the land will not be transferred to that tribe when her husband inherits from her upon her death. This indicates that a husband inherits from his wife.
Rabbi Yishmael continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>another verse <span class="gemarra-regular">states</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: “So shall no inheritance of the children of Israel transfer</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from tribe to tribe” </span>(Numbers 36:7), <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>another verse <span class="gemarra-regular">states: “So shall no inheritance transfer from one tribe to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">another tribe” </span>(Numbers 36:9), also indicating that a husband inherits from his wife.
Rabbi Yishmael continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the verse in the Prophets <span class="gemarra-regular">states: “And Elazar, the son of Aaron, died; and they</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> buried him in the Hill of Pinehas his son, </span>which was given him in Mount Ephraim” (Joshua 24:33). <span class="gemarra-regular">And from</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> where </span>did <span class="gemarra-regular">Pinehas hav</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> land <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>his father, <span class="gemarra-regular">Elazar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, did not have? Rather, </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches that Pinehas married a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> woman </span>who inherited her father’s land, <span class="gemarra-regular">and she </span><span class="gemarra-regular">died and he inherited </span>from <span class="gemarra-regular">her </span>so that he had his own land. This also indicates that a husband inherits from his wife.
Rabbi Yishmael continues. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the verse in the Writings <span class="gemarra-regular">states: “And Seguv begot Yair, who had </span><span class="gemarra-regular">twenty-three cities in the land of Gilead” </span>(I Chronicles 2:22). 

Daf 112a

<span class="gemarra-regular">And</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from where </span>did <span class="gemarra-regular">Yair hav</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> land <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>his father, <span class="gemarra-regular">Seguv, did not have? </span>Rather, this <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches that Yair </span><span class="gemarra-regular">married a woman </span>who inherited her father’s land, <span class="gemarra-regular">and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> she died and he inherited </span>from <span class="gemarra-regular">her </span>so that he had his own land. This also indicates that a husband inherits from his wife.
The Gemara proceeds to explain this <span class="it-text">baraita</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is the meaning of: <span class="gemarra-regular">And it states? </span>Why is it necessary to provide additional proofs beyond the first verse? The Gemara explains: The first verse seems to prove the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that a husband inherits from his wife. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if you would say </span>that the <span class="gemarra-regular">verse </span>that rules that a woman who inherited land from her father cannot marry a man from another tribe is not concerned that he will inherit from her, but rather the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">concerned about a transfer </span>of inheritance from one tribe to another by means of <span class="gemarra-regular">the son </span>who will inherit from his mother, as he belongs to his father’s tribe, <span class="gemarra-regular">but a husband does not inherit </span>from his wife; therefore, <span class="gemarra-regular">come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>another verse that is seemingly superfluous: <span class="gemarra-regular">“So</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> shall no inheritance of the children of Israel transfer from</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> tribe to tribe” </span>(Numbers 36:7). This teaches that a transfer of land could occur by means of the husband inheriting from her.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if </span><span class="gemarra-regular">you would say </span>that this verse is also concerned with the transfer of the inheritance by means of the son, and that the seemingly superfluous verse is stated for another purpose, i.e., in order to establish that a woman who inherited land from her father and marries a man from another tribe <span class="gemarra-regular">will violate for that </span>act <span class="gemarra-regular">a prohibition,</span> namely: “So shall no inheritance of the children of Israel transfer,” <span class="gemarra-regular">and a positive mitzva, </span>namely: “Shall be wife to one of the family of the tribe of her father”; therefore, <span class="gemarra-regular">come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>another verse that is seemingly superfluous: <span class="gemarra-regular">“So shall no inheritance transfer from one tribe to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">another tribe” </span>(Numbers 36:9), which teaches that a transfer can occur by means of the husband inheriting from his wife.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if you would say </span>that this verse is also concerned with the transfer of the inheritance by means of the son, and that the seemingly superfluous verse is stated for another purpose, i.e., in order to establish that a woman who inherited land from her father and marries a man from another tribe <span class="gemarra-regular">violates</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for that </span>act <span class="gemarra-regular">two prohibitions and a positive mitzva; </span>therefore, <span class="gemarra-regular">come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>another proof that a husband inherits from his wife, from the verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And Elazar, the son</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of Aaron, died” </span>(Joshua 24:33).
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if </span><span class="gemarra-regular">you would say </span>that Pinehas did not inherit this land from his wife, but from his mother, as <span class="gemarra-regular">it was </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Elazar, </span>his father, <span class="gemarra-regular">who married a woman </span>who inherited land, <span class="gemarra-regular">and she </span>subsequently <span class="gemarra-regular">died, and </span>her son <span class="gemarra-regular">Pinehas inherited </span>from <span class="gemarra-regular">her </span>so that this verse proves the inheritance of a son and not that of a husband; therefore, <span class="gemarra-regular">come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a proof from the verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And Seguv begot </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Yair” </span>(I Chronicles 2:22).
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if you</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> would say: That is </span>the case <span class="gemarra-regular">there as well,</span> that it was Yair who inherited it from his deceased mother, <span class="gemarra-regular">if so, why do I </span>need <span class="gemarra-regular">two verses </span>to teach the same <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? This concludes the Gemara’s explanation of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> said to Abaye: From where </span>do you know that this is how the verse should be understood? <span class="gemarra-regular">Perhaps I </span>could <span class="gemarra-regular">actually say to you: A husband does not inherit </span>from his wife, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the verses are </span>concerned <span class="gemarra-regular">about a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">transfer </span>of inheritance from one tribe to another by means of <span class="gemarra-regular">the son, as we explained, </span>teaching that one who does so violates two prohibitions and a positive mitzva. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">Yair, </span>one could say <span class="gemarra-regular">that he purchased </span>it from a third party and did not inherit it. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">Pinehas as well, </span>one could say <span class="gemarra-regular">that he purchased </span>it from a third party.
Abaye <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> You cannot say that Pinehas purchased </span>the land where he buried his father, <span class="gemarra-regular">as if so, </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">field would return</span> to its original owner <span class="gemarra-regular">in the Jubilee </span>Year (see Leviticus, chapter 25), <span class="gemarra-regular">and it would be found </span>that this <span class="gemarra-regular">righteous man, </span>i.e., Elazar, <span class="gemarra-regular">is burie</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in a grave</span> in land <span class="gemarra-regular">that is not his.</span>
Rav Pappa asked further: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, say that </span>in his capacity as a priest <span class="gemarra-regular">he came into </span>possession of this land <span class="gemarra-regular">as a dedicated</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> field</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Pinehas, as a priest, may have owned the land by that means. Therefore, one can still say that a husband does not inherit from his wife, and the verses are concerned about a transfer of inheritance from one tribe to another by means of the son.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said: </span>Even if you say that her son and not her husband inherits from her, <span class="gemarra-regular">ultimately </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">inheritance</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is uproote</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from the tribe of the mother and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is moved to the tribe of the father, </span>and the prohibition against her marrying a man from another tribe is not effective in achieving its goal. The verse speaks of a woman who inherited the land from her mother who is of a different tribe from her father (see 111a). Even if she marries a man from her own tribe, the inheritance will be transferred from her mother’s tribe to that of her, the woman’s, husband, as even if the woman’s son inherits, he is of his father’s tribe.
Rav Pappa rejects this: <span class="gemarra-regular">And from where </span>do you raise your challenge? <span class="gemarra-regular">But perhaps</span> it <span class="gemarra-regular">is different there, as </span>the inheritance <span class="gemarra-regular">had already been</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> transferred </span>by the mother of the woman when she married the father, so that the Torah is no longer concerned with the continued transfer. When the parents of this now-deceased woman married, the land that her mother would eventually inherit was already thought of as being transferred away from the ownership of her mother’s tribe. Therefore, the fact that even if this woman’s son inherits from her, the fact that the land will permanently belong to a member of her husband’s tribe is of no concern. Abaye <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: We do not say, </span>i.e., employ, the logic of: <span class="gemarra-regular">As it had already been</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> transferred, </span>since as long as this woman owned it, it still belonged to a person of the first tribe.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yeimar said </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to Rav Ashi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">:</span> Even according to Abaye, who holds the verses teach that the husband inherits, there is still a difficulty. <span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, if you say </span>the logic of: <span class="gemarra-regular">As</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it has already been transferred, this is </span>how it can be understood <span class="gemarra-regular">that the verse is established </span>as referring to both scenarios: The verse can be understood <span class="gemarra-regular">either with </span><span class="gemarra-regular">regard to a transfer </span>by means of <span class="gemarra-regular">the son </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to a transfer </span>by means of <span class="gemarra-regular">the husband. </span>In both of these scenarios, the daughter’s marriage to a man from her father’s tribe is effective in ensuring that land she will inherit will not leave the tribe, because if she inherited it from her father it remains within the same tribe, and if she inherited it from her mother it had already been transferred when her mother married her father.
<span class="gemarra-regular">But if you say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">we do not say </span>the logic of: <span class="gemarra-regular">As it</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> has already been transferred, </span>then even <span class="gemarra-regular">when she gets married</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to one of the family of the tribe of her</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> father, what of it? But an inheritance is uprooted</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from the tribe of </span>her <span class="gemarra-regular">mother, </span>who had inherited land from her, the mother’s, father, <span class="gemarra-regular">to the tribe of</span> her <span class="gemarra-regular">father, </span>as her husband is from her father’s tribe.
Rav Ashi said to him: There is a way that the transfer to another tribe can be avoided: <span class="gemarra-regular">Where we marry her to a ma</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> whose father </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">from her father’s tribe and his mother is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">from her mother’s tribe, </span>the transfer is avoided as the land retains the exact status as it had when it was in the woman’s possession. 

Daf 112b

The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, </span>if a daughter who inherits land from both of her parents must marry a man whose father is from her father’s tribe and whose mother is from her mother’s tribe, <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>verse: “Shall be a wife to one of the family of the tribe of her father” (Numbers 36:8), <span class="gemarra-regular">should have </span>said: Shall be a wife <span class="gemarra-regular">to one of the family of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the tribe of her father and her mother. </span>The Gemara replies: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">were written like this, I would </span><span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">even the opposite </span>is permitted, that she may marry a man whose mother is from her father’s tribe and whose father is from her mother’s tribe. As long as she marries someone who is connected to both tribes, it is permitted. The verse therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>that the opposite is not permitted.
The Gemara comments: Concerning the marriage of a woman who inherited land, it <span class="gemarra-regular">is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">transfer </span>of the inheritance <span class="gemarra-regular">by means of the son, and </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">transfer </span>of the inheritance <span class="gemarra-regular">by means of the husband. </span>The Gemara presents the <span class="it-text">baraitot</span>: A <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is taught with regard to </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">transfer </span>of the inheritance <span class="gemarra-regular">by means of the son, </span>as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">“So shall no inheritance of the children of Israel </span><span class="gemarra-regular">transfer from tribe to tribe” </span>(Numbers 36:7); that <span class="gemarra-regular">verse speaks</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">transfer </span>of the inheritance <span class="gemarra-regular">by means of the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> son. </span>The Torah prohibits the woman from marrying a man from a different tribe since her son will inherit from her and thereby the inheritance will transfer away from its original tribe.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Do you say </span>that this is <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">transfer </span>of the inheritance <span class="gemarra-regular">by means of the son, or is it only with</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> regard to </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">transfer </span>of the inheritance <span class="gemarra-regular">by means of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the husband? When it says: “So shall no </span><span class="gemarra-regular">inheritance transfer from one tribe to another tribe” </span>(Numbers 36:9), the verse is <span class="gemarra-regular">speaking with regard to </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">transfer </span>of the inheritance <span class="gemarra-regular">by means of the husband. How do </span><span class="gemarra-regular">I realize </span>the meaning of the verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“So shall no</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> inheritance of the children of Israel transfer from tribe to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> tribe” </span>(Numbers 36:7)? That <span class="gemarra-regular">verse speaks of </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">transfer </span>of the inheritance <span class="gemarra-regular">by means of the son.</span>

Daf 113a

It <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">taught </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">another </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">“So shall no inheritance transfer</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from one tribe to another tribe” </span>(Numbers 36:9); <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">verse speaks of </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">transfer </span>of the inheritance <span class="gemarra-regular">by means </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of the husband. </span>The Torah prohibits the woman from marrying a man from a different tribe since her husband will inherit from her, thereby transferring her inheritance away from its original tribe.

The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">In any event, </span>according to <span class="gemarra-regular">everyone</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., according to both <span class="it-text">baraitot</span>, the phrase in <span class="gemarra-regular">the verse</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> “from one tribe to another tribe” speaks of </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">transfer </span>of the inheritance <span class="gemarra-regular">by means of the husband. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">From where </span>is this <span class="gemarra-regular">inferred? </span>The Gemara supplies <span class="gemarra-regular">a mnemonic</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rabba bar Rav Sheila said </span>that the latter part of <span class="gemarra-regular">the verse states: </span>“So shall no inheritance transfer from one tribe to another tribe; for the tribes of the children of Israel shall cleave <span class="gemarra-regular">each one [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ish</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> to its own inheritance,” alluding to the transfer by means of the husband, as the word “<span class="it-text">ish</span>” means husband, in the context of: “Elimelech the husband [<span class="it-text">ish</span>] of Naomi” (Ruth 1:3). The Gemara asks: But the word <span class="gemarra-regular">“</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ish</span><span class="gemarra-regular">” </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is written in bot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">h</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of </span>the verses. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said </span>a different explanation. The <span class="gemarra-regular">verse states: “Shall cleave,” </span>and this term alludes to marriage, as in the context of: “And he shall cleave to his wife” (Genesis 2:24). The Gemara raises a difficulty: But the term <span class="gemarra-regular">“shall cleave” is written in both </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of </span>the verses. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Rava said </span>a different explanation: The <span class="gemarra-regular">verse states: “</span><span class="gemarra-regular">The tribes </span>of the children of Israel <span class="gemarra-regular">shall cleave,” </span>and tribes cleave to one another through marriage. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi said</span> another explanation: The <span class="gemarra-regular">verse states: “From one tribe to another</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> tribe,” and a son is not </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">“another,” </span>as he is an extension of his mother.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Abbahu says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yannai says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">says, and </span>some <span class="gemarra-regular">determined it </span>was <span class="gemarra-regular">in the name of Rabbi Yehoshua ben</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Korḥa: From where </span>is it derived <span class="gemarra-regular">that a husband </span>who inherits from his wife does not <span class="gemarra-regular">take in </span>inheritance the property <span class="gemarra-regular">du</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> to the deceased <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>he does the property she <span class="gemarra-regular">possessed</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> Instead of the husband inheriting the property that was due to her, that property is inherited by her other relatives, such as her son, or other relatives of her father. <span class="gemarra-regular">As it is stated: “And </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Seguv begot Yair, who had twenty three cities in the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">land of Gilead” </span>(I Chronicles 2:22). The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">From</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> where </span>did <span class="gemarra-regular">Yair have </span>land <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>his father, <span class="gemarra-regular">Seguv, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">did not have? <span class="gemarra-regular">And</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it is stated: “And Elazar, the son of Aaron</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, died; and they buried </span>him in the Hill of Pinehas his son” (Joshua 24:33). <span class="gemarra-regular">From where </span>did <span class="gemarra-regular">Pinehas have </span>land <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>his father, <span class="gemarra-regular">Elazar, did not have? </span>Rather, this <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches that Elazar married a woman and she died in</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the lifetime of her </span>potential <span class="gemarra-regular">legators, and her legators </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">died, and Pinehas </span>her son, not Elazar her husband, <span class="gemarra-regular">inherited </span>the property from <span class="gemarra-regular">her.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And what </span>is the meaning of: <span class="gemarra-regular">And it is stated? </span>Why is it necessary to provide an additional proof beyond the first verse? The Gemara explains. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if you would say:</span> In the verse concerning Seguv and Yair, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">Yair</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>not Seguv, <span class="gemarra-regular">who married a woman and she died and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he inherited </span>from <span class="gemarra-regular">her, </span>and he did not inherit from his mother, <span class="gemarra-regular">the verse states: “And Elazar, the son </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of Aaron, died; </span>and they buried him in the Hill of Pinehas his son” (Joshua 24:33), teaching that Pinehas inherited the land of those from whom his mother inherited, and Elazar did not. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if you would say that </span>this land <span class="gemarra-regular">came into </span>the possession of Pinehas <span class="gemarra-regular">as a dedicated</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> field, </span>as he was a priest, and he did not inherit it from his mother, <span class="gemarra-regular">the verse states: “His </span><span class="gemarra-regular">son,</span><span class="gemarra-regular">”</span> indicating that it was <span class="gemarra-regular">an inheritance that was </span><span class="gemarra-regular">fitting for him, </span>i.e., Elazar, had his wife not predeceased her legators, <span class="gemarra-regular">and his son inherited it.</span>
§ The mishna teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">And sons of sisters</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., nephews born to the sisters of the deceased, inherit from their maternal uncles but do not bequeath to them. <span class="gemarra-regular">It is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: This <span class="it-text">halakha</span> applies to <span class="gemarra-regular">sons of sisters but not </span>to <span class="gemarra-regular">daughters </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of sisters. </span>

<span class="gemarra-regular">With regard to what </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> was this said? It is obvious that in principle daughters have the right to inherit from their maternal uncle, as the mother inherits from him. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Sheshet said: </span>It is said <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>teach that where there are sons as well, they <span class="gemarra-regular">preced</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> the daughters in inheriting from their maternal uncle.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Shmuel </span><span class="gemarra-regular">bar Rav Yitzḥak taught </span>a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">before Rav Huna: </span>At the end of the passage discussing inheritance of land, the verse states: “Then you shall give his inheritance to his kinsman who is next to him of his family, <span class="gemarra-regular">and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he shall inheri</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> it” (Numbers 27:11). The verse <span class="gemarra-regular">juxtaposes a secondary inheritance</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> that of one inheriting from other relatives, <span class="gemarra-regular">to a primary inheritance, </span>that of a child inheriting from a parent. This teaches that <span class="gemarra-regular">just as </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a primary inheritance a son precedes a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">daughter, so too, </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a secondary inheritance a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> son precedes a daughter.</span>
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba bar Ḥanina taught </span>a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">before </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman: </span>A verse in the passage concerning the double portion inherited by a firstborn states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Then it shall </span><span class="gemarra-regular">be on the day that he causes his sons to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">inherit </span>that which he has” (Deuteronomy 21:16). The addition of the phrase “on the day” teaches that <span class="gemarra-regular">it is </span>specifically <span class="gemarra-regular">during the day </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">you may distribute inheritances, but you </span><span class="gemarra-regular">may not distribute inheritances at night. Abaye suggests a different interpretation of Rabba bar Ḥanina’s statement: <span class="gemarra-regular">Perhaps you said</span> a distinction between day and night with regard to the <span class="gemarra-regular">adjudication of inheritances, </span>as judges are permitted to sit only during the day. A proof for this distinction is <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: A verse in the passage concerning inheritance states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And it shall be for</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the children of Israel a statute of judgment” </span>(Numbers 27:11), teaching that <span class="gemarra-regular">the entire portion was placed [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ure’a</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> together <span class="gemarra-regular">to be </span>considered a matter of <span class="gemarra-regular">judgment</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> subject to the procedural rules of a court matter.
Abaye continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>this is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda, as Rav Yehuda says: </span>In a case where there were <span class="gemarra-regular">three </span>men <span class="gemarra-regular">who entere</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> a room <span class="gemarra-regular">to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> visit a sick person </span>and the sick person desired to write a will in order to distribute his property following his death, if the visitors <span class="gemarra-regular">wish </span>to do so <span class="gemarra-regular">they</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> may write </span>his will and sign it as witnesses. And if <span class="gemarra-regular">they wish, they may act </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">judgment, </span>i.e., they may act as a court in the matter, since there are three of them. Therefore, they can determine that the will has the validity of an act of court and transfer the property to the heirs in their capacity as a court. But if only <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>came to visit the sick person, <span class="gemarra-regular">they may write </span>the will and sign it as witnesses, <span class="gemarra-regular">but they may not act </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">judgment, </span>since three are required to form a court. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav Ḥisda says: </span>This <span class="it-text">halakha</span> was <span class="gemarra-regular">taught only </span>in a case where the three came to visit him <span class="gemarra-regular">during</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the day, </span>
