<span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>if they came <span class="gemarra-regular">at night</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> even </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">three </span>men came to visit the sick person, <span class="gemarra-regular">they may write </span>the will and sign it as witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">but they may not act </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">judgment</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> What</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is the reason </span>that they may not act in judgment the next day? § After mentioning Rav Yehuda’s ruling the Gemara cites a related dispute. It <span class="gemarra-regular">was stated: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a transaction, until</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> when </span>may one of the parties <span class="gemarra-regular">reneg</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> on the transaction? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba says: As long as they are seated </span>in the same location they may renege on the transaction. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Yosef says: As long as they are dealing with that </span><span class="gemarra-regular">matter, </span>i.e., they are still discussing that transaction, they may renege on it.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef said: It stands to reason in </span><span class="gemarra-regular">accordance with my opinion, as Rav Yehuda says: </span>In a case where there were <span class="gemarra-regular">three </span>men <span class="gemarra-regular">who entered </span>a room <span class="gemarra-regular">to visit a sick person </span>and the sick person desires to write a will in order to distribute his property following his death, if the visitors <span class="gemarra-regular">wish </span>to do so <span class="gemarra-regular">they may write </span>his will and sign it as witnesses. And if <span class="gemarra-regular">they wish, they may act </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">judgment. And</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> if it enters your mind </span>that one may renege on a deal <span class="gemarra-regular">as long as they are seated </span>in the same location, then <span class="gemarra-regular">let us be concerned </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">perhaps he</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> will renege on </span>his decision. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi said: I stated this </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">before Rav Kahana </span>and I asked him: <span class="gemarra-regular">And according to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef, does it work out well? </span><span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>even according to his opinion there <span class="gemarra-regular">should be a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">concern </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">perhaps he will renege on </span>his decision, as Rav Yosef holds that one may renege on a transaction as long as the two parties are still dealing with that matter. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, what have you to say? </span>That according to Rav Yosef, Rav Yehuda’s ruling applies <span class="gemarra-regular">where they </span><span class="gemarra-regular">withdrew</span>

Daf 114b

<span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>discussing that <span class="gemarra-regular">matter to </span>discuss a different <span class="gemarra-regular">matter, </span>so he can no longer renege on his decision. <span class="gemarra-regular">So too, </span>according to Rabba, one can explain that Rav Yehuda was referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where they </span><span class="gemarra-regular">arose and then sat </span>down again. Although no support for Rav Yosef’s opinion was adduced from Rav Yehuda’s ruling, the Gemara nevertheless states: <span class="gemarra-regular">And the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span><span class="gemarra-regular">accordance with </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav Yosef</span> <span class="gemarra-regular"> in </span>the disputes concerning the division of <span class="gemarra-regular">a field, </span>discussed above (12b), reneging while they are discussing the same <span class="gemarra-regular">matter, </span>discussed here, <span class="gemarra-regular">and a hal</span><span class="gemarra-regular">f</span> of one’s property, discussed below (143a).
§ The mishna teaches that <span class="gemarra-regular">a woman </span>bequeaths to <span class="gemarra-regular">her son, </span>her husband, and her maternal uncles, but she does not inherit from them. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Why do I </span>need <span class="gemarra-regular">this</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as well? But it is </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">taught </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">the former</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> clause: A man </span>inherits from <span class="gemarra-regular">his mother and a man</span> inherits from <span class="gemarra-regular">his wife. </span>The <span class="it-text">halakha</span> stated in this clause seems to be the same as that of the other clause.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">This</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> teaches u</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">a woman </span>who bequeaths to <span class="gemarra-regular">her son </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">similar to that </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">woman </span>who bequeaths to <span class="gemarra-regular">her husband: Just as </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a woman </span>who bequeaths to <span class="gemarra-regular">her husband, the husband </span><span class="gemarra-regular">does not inherit </span>property through <span class="gemarra-regular">his wife </span>while he is <span class="gemarra-regular">in the grave</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., if a husband predeceases his wife, then his relatives, such as children from another marriage, do not inherit the wife’s property through him but rather the wife’s own relatives inherit her property, <span class="gemarra-regular">so too, </span>the same <span class="it-text">halakha</span> applies with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">woman </span>who bequeaths to <span class="gemarra-regular">her son, </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the son does </span><span class="gemarra-regular">not inherit </span>property through <span class="gemarra-regular">his mother </span>while he is <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the grav</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to bequeath to his paternal brothers</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>In both cases, the woman’s own relatives inherit her property.
§ With regard to the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that a mother inherits from her son, the Gemara notes that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says in the name of Rabbi Yehuda ben </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon: By Torah law a father inherits </span>from <span class="gemarra-regular">his </span><span class="gemarra-regular">son</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and a woman inherits </span>from <span class="gemarra-regular">her so</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> if the father is no longer alive, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is stated</span> with regard to a woman receiving inheritance: “And every daughter who possesses an inheritance from the <span class="gemarra-regular">tribes </span>of the children of Israel” (Numbers 36:8). Since the plural term “tribes” includes both her father’s tribe and her mother’s tribe, the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">juxtaposes </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">tribe of the mother to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the tribe of the father, </span>in that <span class="gemarra-regular">just as </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">the father’s tribe a father inherits </span>from <span class="gemarra-regular">his son, so too, </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">the mother’s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> tribe, a woman inherits </span>from <span class="gemarra-regular">her son </span>if the father is deceased. 

Daf 115a

<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan raised an objection </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda ben Shimon </span>from the mishna, which teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">A woman </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">her son, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a woman </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">her husband, and maternal uncles </span>all <span class="gemarra-regular">bequeath </span>to their respective relatives <span class="gemarra-regular">but do not inherit </span>from them. The mishna states explicitly that a mother does not inherit her son’s property. Rabbi Yehuda ben Shimon <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">our mishna, I do</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not know who taught it</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., I am not aware of any <span class="it-text">tanna</span> who concurs with its ruling and it is not the accepted <span class="it-text">halakha</span>.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But let </span>Rabbi Yoḥanan <span class="gemarra-regular">say to </span>Rabbi Yehuda ben Shimon that the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>written in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Zekharya ben HaKatzav, who, </span>as noted on page 111a, <span class="gemarra-regular">does not derive </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that sons precede daughters with regard to the inheritance of their mother from the word <span class="gemarra-regular">“tribes.” </span>Since Rabbi Yehuda ben Shimon’s ruling is based on a derivation from the word “tribes,” it stands to reason that Rabbi Zekharya disagrees with Rabbi Yehuda ben Shimon, and the ruling of the mishna is in accordance with Rabbi Zekharya’s opinion.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">The mishna cannot</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> be interpreted in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Zekharya</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> ben HaKatzav, as it teaches: And the sons of a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> sister </span>inherit but do not bequeath, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>a Sage <span class="gemarra-regular">taught</span> that the mishna is referring only to <span class="gemarra-regular">sons of a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> siste</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and not </span>to <span class="gemarra-regular">daughters of a sister, and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">we say: With regard to what </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is there a distinction between the sons and daughters of a sister? <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Sheshet said: </span>The distinction is meant <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>teach that where there are sons as well, they <span class="gemarra-regular">precede </span>the daughters in inheriting from their maternal uncle.
The Gemara continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">And if it enters your mind </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the mishna </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>written in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Zekharya </span><span class="gemarra-regular">ben HaKatzav, doesn’t he say: Both the son and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the daughter are equal with regard to the mother’s </span><span class="gemarra-regular">property, </span>as they inherit equally? The mishna stands in contraposition to Rabbi Zekharya’s ruling, and therefore it cannot be written in accordance with his opinion.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of our </span>mishna, <span class="gemarra-regular">whichever </span>way <span class="gemarra-regular">you </span>look at it, is inconsistent: <span class="gemarra-regular">If he interprets </span>the word <span class="gemarra-regular">“tribes,” </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">a woman also should inherit </span>from <span class="gemarra-regular">her son</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as noted above (114b). And <span class="gemarra-regular">if he does not interpret </span>the word <span class="gemarra-regular">“tribes,” </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">from where is it </span>clear <span class="gemarra-regular">to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> him </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a son precedes a daughter with regard to</span> the <span class="gemarra-regular">property of the mother? </span>Both <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> are derived from the same source, so how can the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> accept one and reject the other?
The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">Actually, </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> of the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">inter-prets </span>the word <span class="gemarra-regular">“tribes,” but it </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is different here, </span>with regard to a woman inheriting from her son, <span class="gemarra-regular">as the verse states: “And every daughter </span>who <span class="gemarra-regular">possesses </span><span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">y</span><span class="gemarra-italic">oreshet</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] an inheritanc</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> from the tribes” (Numbers 36:8), which teaches that a daughter <span class="gemarra-regular">inherits </span><span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">y</span><span class="gemarra-italic">oreshet</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] </span>from two tribes, <span class="gemarra-regular">but</span> she <span class="gemarra-regular">does not bequeath </span>to two tribes. She bequeaths only to her father’s tribe.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> The <span class="gemarra-regular">order </span>of precedence with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">inheritances is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">this</span><span class="gemarra-regular">:</span> The verse states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“If a man dies, and has no son, then you</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> shall pass his inheritance to his daughter” </span>(Numbers 27:8). This teaches that <span class="gemarra-regular">a son precedes a daughter. </span>Additionally, <span class="gemarra-regular">all</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> descendants of a son precede a daughter. A daughter precedes</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the brothers </span>of the deceased. Additionally, the <span class="gemarra-regular">descendants of a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> daughter precede the brothers </span>of the deceased. <span class="gemarra-regular">Brothers </span>of the deceased <span class="gemarra-regular">precede the uncles </span>of the deceased. Additionally, the <span class="gemarra-regular">descendants of the brothers precede the uncles.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">This is the principle: </span>Concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">anyone who </span><span class="gemarra-regular">precedes </span>another <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to inheritance, his descendants precede </span>the other as well, <span class="gemarra-regular">and a father </span>who inherits <span class="gemarra-regular">precedes all </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of his descendants</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught: </span>The verse states: “If a man dies, and has no <span class="gemarra-regular">son, </span>then you shall pass his inheritance to his daughter” (Numbers 27:8). <span class="gemarra-regular">I </span><span class="gemarra-regular">have </span>derived <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a son </span>precedes others with regard to the inheritance of the deceased; <span class="gemarra-regular">from where </span>do I derive that <span class="gemarra-regular">a son of a son, or a daughter </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of a son, or a son of a daughter of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a son </span>also precedes the deceased’s other relatives? <span class="gemarra-regular">The </span><span class="gemarra-regular">verse states: </span>“If a man dies, and <span class="gemarra-regular">he has no</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ein</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">lo</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> son.” The word <span class="it-text">ein</span> is written <span class="it-text">aleph</span>, <span class="it-text">yod</span>, <span class="it-text">nun</span>. Therefore, the Sages read it as if it states: <span class="gemarra-regular">Investigate with regard to him [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ayyein</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">alav</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> to search for descendants of his son, and give the inheritance to them if they are found.
The next verse states: “And if he has no <span class="gemarra-regular">daughter, </span>then you shall give his inheritance to his brothers” (Numbers 27:9). <span class="gemarra-regular">I have </span>derived <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a daughter </span>precedes others, except a son and his descendants, with regard to the inheritance of the deceased, <span class="gemarra-regular">from where </span>then do I derive that <span class="gemarra-regular">a daughter’s daughter, or a son of a daughter</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, or a daughter of a son of a daughter </span>also precede the deceased’s other relatives? <span class="gemarra-regular">The verse states: </span>“And if he <span class="gemarra-regular">has no [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ein</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">lo</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] </span>daughter.” The word <span class="it-text">ein</span> is written <span class="it-text">aleph</span>, <span class="it-text">yod</span>, <span class="it-text">nun</span>. Therefore, the Sages read it as if it states: <span class="gemarra-regular">Investigate with regard to him</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ayyein</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">alav</span><span class="gemarra-regular">], </span>to search for descendants of his daughter, and give the inheritance to them if they are found.

The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">How so</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., how is the investigation performed when he has no offspring at all? The Gemara answers: The family lineage that determines the <span class="gemarra-regular">inheritance is successively</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> examine</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> up to Reuben, </span>son of Jacob, i.e., the heirs are determined by investigating the family genealogy, and that investigation can extend all the way to Reuben, son of our forefather Jacob. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And let </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">say: Until Jacob </span>himself, rather than until Reuben, since if none of Reuven’s descendants survive, one would have to examine Jacob’s descendants. <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said </span>in reply: It <span class="gemarra-regular">is learned </span>as a tradition <span class="gemarra-regular">that a tribe will not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">be eliminate</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> entirely, and some descendants will always remain.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">anyone who says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a daughter </span>of the deceased <span class="gemarra-regular">should </span><span class="gemarra-regular">inherit </span>the estate of her father along <span class="gemarra-regular">with the daughter </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of the so</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> of the deceased, <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>if he is <span class="gemarra-regular">a prince of the Jewish people</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> one <span class="gemarra-regular">should not</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> listen to him, as this is nothing other than an</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> act of the Sadducees</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and runs counter to the ruling of the mishna that the descendants of a son inherit before a daughter. <span class="gemarra-regular">As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> in <span class="it-text">Megillat</span> <span class="it-text">Ta’anit</span>, which describes various minor holidays on which it is forbidden to fast or eulogize: <span class="gemarra-regular">On</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the twenty-fourth of Tevet, we returned to our law</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>i.e., the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> was reestablished in accordance with the opinion of the Sages after having been dictated by the Sadducees. <span class="gemarra-regular">As the Sadducees would say: A daughter should inherit</span> the estate of her father along <span class="gemarra-regular">with the daughter of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the son </span>of the deceased.
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabban </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Yoḥanan ben Zakka</span><span class="gemarra-regular">i</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> joined them </span>to discuss their ruling, and <span class="gemarra-regular">said to them: Imbeciles, from where </span>do <span class="gemarra-regular">you </span>derive <span class="gemarra-regular">this</span> ruling? <span class="gemarra-regular">And there was no person that answered him </span><span class="gemarra-regular">anything, except for one old </span>man <span class="gemarra-regular">who was chattering at </span><span class="gemarra-regular">him and saying </span>that it is an <span class="it-text">a</span> <span class="it-text">fortiori</span> inference: <span class="gemarra-regular">And just as a daughter of </span>the deceased’s <span class="gemarra-regular">son, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">who comes </span>to claim her inheritance from her grandfather <span class="gemarra-regular">by </span><span class="gemarra-regular">virtue of his son, inherits </span>her grandfather’s property, so too, with regard to the deceased’s own <span class="gemarra-regular">daughter, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">who comes </span>to inherit <span class="gemarra-regular">by virtue of </span>the deceased, <span class="gemarra-regular">all</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the more so </span>is it <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>clear that she should inherit his property?
Rabban Yoḥanan ben Zakkai <span class="gemarra-regular">recited</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> this verse about him: “These are the sons of Seir</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the Horite, the inhabitants of the land: Lotan and Shobal</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and Zibeon and Anah” </span>(Genesis 36:20), <span class="gemarra-regular">and it is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">written: “And these are the children of Zibeon: Aiah and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Anah” </span>(Genesis 36:24). The first verse portrays Zibeon and Anah as brothers, while the second states that they are father and son. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches that Zibeon engaged in sexual</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> intercours</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with his mother and begot Anah, </span>so that he was both Anah’s father and his brother. From the fact that the first verse equates Zibeon and Anah by referring to both of them as Seir’s sons despite Anah being a grandson of Seir, it is clear that grandchildren are equal to children, contrary to the Sadducees’ assertion.
The Gemara interrupts the recounting of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> and questions Rabban Yoḥanan ben Zakkai’s inference: <span class="gemarra-regular">But perhaps there were two </span>people named <span class="gemarra-regular">Anah, </span>so that one Anah was Zibeon’s son, and the other his brother? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba said: I will state a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> matter </span>that even <span class="gemarra-regular">King Shapu</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> did not state. And </span><span class="gemarra-regular">who is </span>this King Shapur? This cannot be a reference to Shapur, king of Persia; rather, it must be a moniker for someone else. He is <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel, </span>whose legal rulings were accepted by the public like the edicts of a king by his subjects. <span class="gemarra-regular">Some state </span>a different version, that it was <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa </span>who <span class="gemarra-regular">said: I will state a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">matter </span>that even <span class="gemarra-regular">King Shapur did not state. And who </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>this King Shapur? He is <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba. The verse </span>goes on to <span class="gemarra-regular">state: “This is Anah” </span>(Genesis 36:24), indicating that <span class="gemarra-regular">he is </span>the same <span class="gemarra-regular">Anah </span>mentioned <span class="gemarra-regular">initially, </span>earlier in the verse. Accordingly, there was only one Anah, who was both Zibeon’s brother and Zibeon’s son.
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues: The Sadducee <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Rabban Yoḥanan ben Zakkai: <span class="gemarra-regular">My teacher, you </span><span class="gemarra-regular">dismiss me with thi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> retort? I agree that the son of a son precedes a daughter, as the verse you quoted suggests; I am asserting that a daughter inherits together with the daughter of a son, and the verse you quoted has no bearing on that claim. Rabban Yoḥanan ben Zakkai <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Imbecile, </span>

Daf 116a

<span class="gemarra-regular">but will our perfect Torah not be </span>as worthy <span class="gemarra-regular">as your frivolous speech, </span>as your inference is fallacious: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is notable <span class="gemarra-regular">about </span>the inheritance of <span class="gemarra-regular">a daughter of </span>the deceased’s <span class="gemarra-regular">son? </span>It is notable <span class="gemarra-regular">in that her right </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is enhanced </span>in that she inherits from her paternal grandfather together <span class="gemarra-regular">with the brother</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> of her father. Would you <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that the same applies <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>the deceased’s <span class="gemarra-regular">daughter, whose right </span>to inherit <span class="gemarra-regular">is diminished </span>in that she does not inherit from her father together <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>her <span class="gemarra-regular">brothers? </span>The Sadducee’s <span class="it-text">a</span> <span class="it-text">fortiori</span> inference is thereby disproved. The Gemara concludes: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>since the Sadducees had no counterargument, the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">were victorious over them, and they established that</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> day, </span>the twenty-fourth of Tevet, as a minor <span class="gemarra-regular">festival </span>to celebrate the establishment of the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in accordance with the opinion of the Sages.
Having discussed the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of a son’s daughter’s right to inheritance, the Gemara cites a verse that relates to the matter. After the incident known as: The concubine in Gibeah, the men of the tribe of Benjamin numbered only six hundred, and each of these men had inherited large plots of land from their deceased relatives. The verse states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And they said: They that are escaped must be</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as an inheritance for Benjamin, that a tribe be not</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> blotted out from Israel” </span>(Judges 21:17).
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yitzḥak of the house of Rabbi Ami says: </span>This <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches that </span>the elders of that generation <span class="gemarra-regular">stipulated with </span><span class="gemarra-regular">regard to the tribe of Benjamin that a daughter of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a son shall not inherit with the brothers </span>of her father. Since the daughter of a son who inherits her grandfather’s property may later bequeath it to her husband, who may be from another tribe, the elders instituted this temporary ordinance in order to ensure that other tribes would not inherit large quantities of land belonging to the tribe of Benjamin, lest the tribe of Benjamin be left with little land of its own.
§ The Gemara presents a related statement. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says in the name of Rabbi Shimon</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> ben Yoḥai: </span>Concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">anyone who does not leave </span>behind <span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> son to inherit </span>from <span class="gemarra-regular">him, the Holy One, Blessed be</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> He, is filled with wrath [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">evra</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] toward him, </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">it</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is written here: </span>“If a man die, and he has no son, <span class="gemarra-regular">then you shall pass his inheritance [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">veha’</span><span class="gemarra-italic">avartem</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] </span>to his daughter” (Numbers 27:8), <span class="gemarra-regular">and it is written</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> there: “That day is a day of wrath [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">evra</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]” </span>(Zephaniah 1:15). The words “<span class="it-text">veha’avartem</span>” and “<span class="it-text">evra</span>” share common root letters, whereby Rabbi Shimon ben Yoḥai interprets that God’s wrath may be the result of the inheritance passing to a daughter rather than a son.
The Gemara presents a related statement. Concerning the verse: “God shall hear, and humble them, even He that is enthroned of old, Selah; <span class="gemarra-regular">those that have no exchange, and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">fear not God” </span>(Psalms 55:20), <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan and Rabbi Yehoshua</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> ben Levi </span>each interpret the verse in a different manner. <span class="gemarra-regular">One says </span>that this is a reference to <span class="gemarra-regular">anyone who</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> does not leave </span>behind <span class="gemarra-regular">a so</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> to inherit from him, as he does not leave anyone to serve in exchange, i.e., as a replacement, for him; <span class="gemarra-regular">and one </span><span class="gemarra-regular">says </span>that this is a reference to <span class="gemarra-regular">anyone who does </span><span class="gemarra-regular">not leave </span>behind <span class="gemarra-regular">a studen</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> to serve in exchange for him.
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">It may be concluded </span>that it was <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan who</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> says </span>that the verse is referring to one who does not leave behind <span class="gemarra-regular">a student, for Rabbi Yoḥanan, </span>whose ten sons died in his lifetime, <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>to those he would console: <span class="gemarra-regular">This is the bone of my tenth son,</span> to encourage them not to succumb to their sorrow. Since Rabbi Yoḥanan knew that he would not leave any sons to inherit his property, it is reasonable to assume that he interpreted the verse as meaning that God is full of wrath toward one who does not leave behind a student. The Gemara comments that <span class="gemarra-regular">it may be concluded that</span> it was <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan who says </span>that the verse is referring to one who does not leave behind <span class="gemarra-regular">a student</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
The Gemara notes: <span class="gemarra-regular">And from </span>this, <span class="gemarra-regular">that Rabbi Yoḥanan </span>is the one who <span class="gemarra-regular">says </span>that the verse is referring to one who does not leave behind <span class="gemarra-regular">a student, </span>it follows that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi says</span> the verse is referring to one who does not leave behind <span class="gemarra-regular">a son.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>this cannot be, as <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi would not go </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to a house of mourning [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">bei</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">tamya</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> to console the bereaved so as not to interrupt his studies, <span class="gemarra-regular">except </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to the house of one who died without any sons, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">as it is written: </span>“Weep not for the dead, neither bemoan him; but <span class="gemarra-regular">weep sore for him that goes away</span><span class="gemarra-regular">” </span>(Jeremiah 22:10), <span class="gemarra-regular">and Rabbi Yehuda says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says </span>that the verse is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>one who <span class="gemarra-regular">departs </span>from this world <span class="gemarra-regular">without </span>leaving behind <span class="gemarra-regular">a male child. </span>From the fact that Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi would console specifically one who died without leaving a son, it is apparent that he does not hold that God is full of wrath toward such an individual. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>it must be that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Yehoshua ben Levi is </span>the Sage <span class="gemarra-regular">who says </span>that the verse is referring to one who does not leave behind <span class="gemarra-regular">a student.</span>
The Gemara notes: <span class="gemarra-regular">And from </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">that Rabbi Yehoshua ben </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Levi is </span>the one <span class="gemarra-regular">who says </span>that the verse is referring to one who does not leave behind <span class="gemarra-regular">a student, </span>it follows that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says </span>it is referring to one who does not leave behind <span class="gemarra-regular">a son.</span>
The Gemara asks: This poses <span class="gemarra-regular">a difficulty </span>from one statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Yoḥanan, </span>that the verse is referring to one who does not leave behind a son, <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>another statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Yoḥanan, </span>as he would say: This is the bone of my tenth son. The Gemara answers: It is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult: This </span>statement, with regard to the bone of his son, <span class="gemarra-regular">is his</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>while <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>statement, with regard to the verse, <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">his teacher’s.</span>
§ The Gemara continues with three homiletic interpretations by Rabbi Pineḥas ben Ḥama, and provides <span class="gemarra-regular">a mnemoni</span><span class="gemarra-regular">c</span> to facilitate the memorization of these expositions: <span class="gemarra-regular">Hadad, poverty, and sage.</span>
The Gemara presents the first homiletic interpretation: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Pineḥas ben Ḥama interpreted </span>a verse <span class="gemarra-regular">homiletically: What </span>is the meaning of that <span class="gemarra-regular">which is written: “And when </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Hadad heard in Egypt that David slept with his fathers, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and that Joab the captain of the host was dead” </span>(I Kings 11:21)? <span class="gemarra-regular">For what </span>reason is it that <span class="gemarra-regular">in</span> the case of King <span class="gemarra-regular">David, sleeping was stated with regard</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to his </span>demise, <span class="gemarra-regular">and in </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">Joab, death</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> was stated with regard to his </span>demise? He answers: Concerning King <span class="gemarra-regular">David, who left a son </span>behind, <span class="gemarra-regular">sleeping was</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> stated with regard to his </span>demise, as it was not a complete death, while concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">Joab, who did not leave</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a son </span>behind, <span class="gemarra-regular">death was stated with regard to his</span> demise, as he left no son to succeed him.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>is it so that <span class="gemarra-regular">Joab did not leave a son </span>behind; <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span><span class="gemarra-regular">isn’t it written: “Of the sons of Joab: Obadiah, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">son of Jehiel” </span>(Ezra 8:9)? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>concerning King <span class="gemarra-regular">David, who</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> left a son as </span>great as <span class="gemarra-regular">himself, sleeping was stated</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with regard to his </span>demise, but concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">Joab, who </span><span class="gemarra-regular">did not leave a son as </span>great as <span class="gemarra-regular">himself, death </span><span class="gemarra-regular">was stated with regard to his </span>demise.
The Gemara presents the second homiletic interpretation: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Pineḥas ben Ḥama interpreted </span>a verse <span class="gemarra-regular">homiletically</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>and derived that <span class="gemarra-regular">poverty in a person’s household is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> more difficul</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> than fifty plagues</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as it is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">stated: “Have pity upon me, have pity upon me, O </span><span class="gemarra-regular">you my friends; for the hand of God has touched </span><span class="gemarra-regular">me” </span>(Job 19:21), <span class="gemarra-regular">and his friends were saying to him</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: “Take heed, regard not iniquity; for this have you chosen</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> rather than poverty” </span>(Job 36:21). Job, who suffered many plagues, was told by his friends that his suffering was preferable to poverty.
The Gemara presents the third homiletic interpretation: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Pineḥas bar Ḥama interpreted </span>a verse <span class="gemarra-regular">homiletically: Anyone who </span><span class="gemarra-regular">has a sick person in his home should go to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a sage, and </span>the sage will <span class="gemarra-regular">ask </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">mercy on </span>the sick person’s behalf, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is stated: “The </span><span class="gemarra-regular">wrath of a king is as messengers of death; but </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a wise man will pacify it” </span>(Proverbs 16:14).
§ The mishna teaches that <span class="gemarra-regular">this is the principle: </span>Concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">anyone who precedes </span>another <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to inheritance, his descendants precede </span>the other as well, <span class="gemarra-regular">and a father precedes all of his descendants</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">Rami bar Ḥam</span><span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> raises a dilemma: </span>With regard to the claim of <span class="gemarra-regular">a father of the </span>deceased’s <span class="gemarra-regular">father and</span> the claim of <span class="gemarra-regular">the brother of the </span>deceased’s <span class="gemarra-regular">father</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, such as </span>the claims of <span class="gemarra-regular">Abraham and Ishmael to the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> property of Esau</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> who was Abraham’s grandson and Ishmael’s nephew, <span class="gemarra-regular">which of them precedes </span>the other and inherits the property? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a proof from the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">A father precedes all of his descendants</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>therefore, Abraham would inherit, as Ishmael was his descendant. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>why did <span class="gemarra-regular">Rami bar Ḥama </span>have a dilemma; was he not aware of the statement of the mishna? 

Daf 116b

The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Due to his keen </span>mind, <span class="gemarra-regular">he did not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">analyze </span>the mishna carefully.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rami bar Ḥama raised a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">dilemma: </span>With regard to the claim of <span class="gemarra-regular">a father of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>deceased’s <span class="gemarra-regular">father and </span>the claim of the deceased’s <span class="gemarra-regular">brother, such as </span>the claims of <span class="gemarra-regular">Abraham and Jacob </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to the property of Esau, </span>who was Abraham’s grandson and Jacob’s brother, <span class="gemarra-regular">which of them precedes </span>the other and inherits the property? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a proof from the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">A father precede</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> all of his</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> descendants, </span>therefore, Abraham would inherit, as Jacob was his descendant. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>why did <span class="gemarra-regular">Rami bar Ḥama </span>have a dilemma; presumably, he was aware of the statement of the mishna? The Gemara answers: Rami bar Ḥama understood that the mishna teaches that a father <span class="gemarra-regular">precedes </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">his </span><span class="gemarra-regular">own </span>immediate <span class="gemarra-regular">descendants, but not the descendants of his son.</span>
The Gemara notes that <span class="gemarra-regular">so too, it </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is reasonable </span>to understand the mishna in that manner, <span class="gemarra-regular">as</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it teaches: This is the principle: Anyone who precedes </span>another <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to inheritance, his descendants precede </span>the other as well. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if Isaac were </span>alive, <span class="gemarra-regular">Isaac </span>would <span class="gemarra-regular">precede </span>Abraham and inherit Esau’s property. <span class="gemarra-regular">Now, also, when Isaac is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not </span>alive, <span class="gemarra-regular">Jacob </span>should <span class="gemarra-regular">precede </span>Abraham, because of the principle that the descendants of one who precedes another with regard to inheritance also precede the other. The Gemara affirms: <span class="gemarra-regular">Conclude</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from </span>this clause of the mishna that the brother of the deceased precedes the grandfather.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">Zelophehad’</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s </span><span class="gemarra-regular">daughter</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">took three portions </span>of land <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">inheritance</span> of Eretz Yisrael: <span class="gemarra-regular">Their father’s portion </span>that he received <span class="gemarra-regular">because he was among those who left Egypt; and his</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> portion </span>that he received <span class="gemarra-regular">with his brothers in </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">property</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of Hepher, </span>their father; <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>an additional portion that he received from Hepher <span class="gemarra-regular">because he was a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">firstborn</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and a firstborn <span class="gemarra-regular">takes two portions </span>of inheritance from his father. 

Daf 117a

<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara comments: In the mishna that teaches that Zelophehad and Hepher were entitled to portions in Eretz Yisrael, <span class="gemarra-regular">we learned in accordance with </span>the opinion of the <span class="gemarra-regular">one who says: Eretz </span>Yisrael <span class="gemarra-regular">was divided among those</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> who left Egypt</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
The Gemara cites a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that presents three opinions as to how Eretz Yisrael was divided. <span class="gemarra-regular">As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoshiya says: Eretz </span>Yisrael <span class="gemarra-regular">was divided</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> among those who left Egypt, as it is stated: “According</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to the names of the tribes of their fathers they</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> shall inherit” </span>(Numbers 26:55), which teaches that the Jewish people would inherit Eretz Yisrael according to the names of their fathers, i.e., those who left Egypt. Rabbi Yoshiya continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">But how do I realize </span>the meaning of the verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Unto these the land shall be divided for an</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> inheritance” </span>(Numbers 26:53), which indicates that the land was to be divided among those recently counted in the wilderness, i.e., those who would enter Eretz Yisrael? He answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Unto these” </span>teaches that the land will be divided among those who are <span class="gemarra-regular">like these </span>people who were counted, in that they were adults above the age of twenty, <span class="gemarra-regular">to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> exclude the children</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> who were not entitled to a portion in Eretz Yisrael, as they were not of age at the time of the Exodus.
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> presents a second opinion. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yonatan</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> says: Eretz </span>Yisrael <span class="gemarra-regular">was divided among those who entered Eretz</span> Yisrael, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is stated: “Unto these the land shall</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> be divided for an inheritance” </span>(Numbers 26:53). <span class="gemarra-regular">But how </span><span class="gemarra-regular">do I realize </span>the meaning of the verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“According to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the names of the tribes of their fathers they shall</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> inherit” </span>(Numbers 26:55)? This teaches that <span class="gemarra-regular">this inheritance is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">different from all </span>other <span class="gemarra-regular">inheritances in the world, for </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">all </span>other <span class="gemarra-regular">inheritances in the world, </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">living inherit </span>from the <span class="gemarra-regular">dead, but here, the dead inherit </span>from the <span class="gemarra-regular">living</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> In other words, the portions of land received by those who entered Eretz Yisrael were transferred to their fathers who left Egypt, and then inherited by the current generation, as the Gemara will now explain.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">said: I will tell you a parable. To what is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> this matter comparable? To two brothers </span>who were <span class="gemarra-regular">priest</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> and <span class="gemarra-regular">who were in one town. One </span>brother <span class="gemarra-regular">has one </span><span class="gemarra-regular">son, and one </span>brother <span class="gemarra-regular">has two sons, and </span>the sons all <span class="gemarra-regular">went to the threshing floor </span>to collect <span class="it-text">teruma</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>brother, <span class="gemarra-regular">who has one son, takes one portion </span>of the <span class="it-text">teruma</span> from his child, <span class="gemarra-regular">and that </span>brother, <span class="gemarra-regular">who has two </span><span class="gemarra-regular">sons, takes two portions </span>from his sons. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the brothers then <span class="gemarra-regular">return </span>with the three portions <span class="gemarra-regular">to their father, and</span> then <span class="gemarra-regular">redivide </span>the portions among themselves <span class="gemarra-regular">equally, </span>so that each brother receives one and one-half portions. When the brothers give their shares to their children, the son of the first brother will receive all that his father had received, while the sons of the other brother will divide what their father had received.
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> presents a third opinion. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon ben</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Elazar says: </span>

Daf 117b

<span class="gemarra-regular">Eretz </span>Yisrael <span class="gemarra-regular">was divided to these</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and to those</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> so as to uphold these two</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> verses. How so? </span>If one <span class="gemarra-regular">was from </span>among <span class="gemarra-regular">those who</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> left Egypt</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he takes his portion </span>along <span class="gemarra-regular">with those</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> who left Egypt. </span>If one <span class="gemarra-regular">was from </span>among <span class="gemarra-regular">those who</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> entered Eretz </span>Yisrael, <span class="gemarra-regular">he takes his portion </span>along <span class="gemarra-regular">with those</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> who entered Eretz </span>Yisrael. If one was <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>both <span class="gemarra-regular">here</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and there</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., he was among those who left Egypt and also entered Eretz Yisrael himself, <span class="gemarra-regular">he takes</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> his portion from here and there, </span>as he is entitled to two portions.
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues: With regard to the twelve <span class="gemarra-regular">spies </span>sent to survey Eretz Yisrael prior to the Jewish people’s entry into the land, <span class="gemarra-regular">Joshua and Caleb</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> took </span>all of the spies’ <span class="gemarra-regular">portions </span>of the land. Additionally, the <span class="gemarra-regular">protesters and the assembly of Korah did not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">have a portion of Eretz </span>Yisrael. Nevertheless, their <span class="gemarra-regular">sons took </span>portions of the land <span class="gemarra-regular">in the merit of their paternal </span><span class="gemarra-regular">grandfathers and in the merit of their maternal grandfathers </span>if they were among those who left Egypt. This concludes the Gemara’s citation of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">From where may </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">be inferred that </span><span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>verse, which states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“According to the names of the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> tribes of their fathers </span>they shall inherit” (Numbers 26:55), <span class="gemarra-regular">is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> written with regard to those who left Egypt; perhaps </span>the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">was stated </span>in reference <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the progenitors of the <span class="gemarra-regular">tribes, </span>and teaches that the land should be divided among the twelve tribes? The Gemara answers: The inference is from a verse, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is written: </span>“And I will bring you in to the land, concerning which I lifted up My hand to give it to Abraham, to Isaac, and to Jacob; <span class="gemarra-regular">and I will give it to you </span><span class="gemarra-regular">for a heritage: I am the Lord” </span>(Exodus 6:8). This verse states that Eretz Yisrael <span class="gemarra-regular">is an inheritance for you</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from your forefathers, and </span>this verse <span class="gemarra-regular">was told to those</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> who left Egypt, </span>indicating that those who left Egypt inherit the land.
The Gemara presents <span class="gemarra-regular">a mnemonic </span>device for the following series of questions posed by Rav Pappa to Abaye relating to the division of Eretz Yisrael: <span class="gemarra-regular">To the more; Zelophehad; and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Joseph; contested; Manasseh; will count.</span>
The Gemara presents the first question. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa said to Abaye: Granted, according to the one</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> who says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Eretz </span>Yisrael <span class="gemarra-regular">was divided among those who</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> left Egypt, this is </span>the meaning of that <span class="gemarra-regular">which is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> written: “To the more you shall give the more inheritance</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, and to the fewer you shall give the less inheritance</span><span class="gemarra-regular">” </span>(Numbers 26:54). The verse may be understood as teaching the novelty that even though the number of Jewish people entering Eretz Yisrael differed from the number who left Egypt, the land is nevertheless divided according to the numbers at the time of the Exodus, not according to the count at the time they received the land. 

Daf 118a

<span class="gemarra-regular">But according to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the one who says </span>that Eretz Yisrael was divided <span class="gemarra-regular">among</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> those who entered Eretz </span>Yisrael, <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>does the verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“</span><span class="gemarra-regular">To the more you shall give the more inheritance” </span>teach? It is obvious that larger families will receive more land due to their greater numbers. The Gemara concludes: This poses <span class="gemarra-regular">a difficult</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span> to one who holds that opinion.
The Gemara presents the second question. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav Pappa said </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to Abaye: Granted, according to the one who says </span>that Eretz Yisrael was divided <span class="gemarra-regular">among those who left Egypt, this </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>why <span class="gemarra-regular">the daughters of Zelophehad cried out </span>in protest of the fact that they would be denied their father’s portion, to which he was entitled as one who left Egypt. <span class="gemarra-regular">But according to the one who says </span>that Eretz Yisrael was divided <span class="gemarra-regular">among those who entered Eretz </span>Yisrael, <span class="gemarra-regular">why did they cry out </span>in protest; after all, Zelophehad <span class="gemarra-regular">was not </span>there <span class="gemarra-regular">to take </span>his portion, so his daughters should have no claim to the land?
Abaye answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>according to this opinion, the protest of Zelophehad’s daughters was in reference <span class="gemarra-regular">to the returning </span>of the portions from the generation that entered Eretz Yisrael to the generation that left Egypt, as described in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> above. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>accordingly, Zelophehad’s daughters demanded <span class="gemarra-regular">to take </span>their portion <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">property of </span>their grandfather <span class="gemarra-regular">Hepher, </span>who received land posthumously through his children, their uncles.
The Gemara presents Rav Pappa’s third question: <span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">according to the one who says </span>that Eretz Yisrael was divided <span class="gemarra-regular">among those who left Egypt, this is </span>why <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">descendants of Joseph cried out </span>in protest of the fact that they would receive an inadequate portion of land due to the fact that they had proliferated greatly in the wilderness. <span class="gemarra-regular">As it is written: “And the children of Joseph </span><span class="gemarra-regular">spoke </span>to Joshua, saying: Why have you given me but one lot and one part for an inheritance, seeing I am a great people, because the Lord has blessed me thus” (Joshua 17:14). <span class="gemarra-regular">But according to the one who says</span> that Eretz Yisrael was divided <span class="gemarra-regular">among those who entered Eretz</span> Yisrael, <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>is the reason <span class="gemarra-regular">they were crying out? They</span> were <span class="gemarra-regular">all </span>entitled to <span class="gemarra-regular">take </span>their own portion of land and should have had no cause for complaint.
The Gemara answers: They protested <span class="gemarra-regular">due to the children</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as they had many </span>children who were not entitled to a portion of the land.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said: Learn from </span>the fact that the Bible records the complaints of only the daughters of Zelophehad and the descendants of Joseph that <span class="gemarra-regular">there was not one </span>other individual <span class="gemarra-regular">who did not tak</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> a portion of land; <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span><span class="gemarra-regular">if it enters your mind </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">there was </span>even <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>other <span class="gemarra-regular">who did not take </span>a portion of land, <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span><span class="gemarra-regular">should have cried out </span>in protest. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if you would </span><span class="gemarra-regular">say: The verse wrote </span>about one <span class="gemarra-regular">who cried out and </span>his protest <span class="gemarra-regular">was effective, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">the verse did not write </span>about one <span class="gemarra-regular">who cried out and </span>his protest <span class="gemarra-regular">was not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">effective, </span>that is difficult. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>there is the counterexample of <span class="gemarra-regular">the descendants of Joseph, who cried out and </span>their protest <span class="gemarra-regular">was not effective</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and the verse wrote </span>about <span class="gemarra-regular">them</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
The Gemara rejects Abaye’s inference: Generally, the verse would not record an instance where one cried out if his protest was not effective, and <span class="gemarra-regular">there, </span>the verse includes the protest of Joseph’s descendants in order to <span class="gemarra-regular">teach us </span>a measure of <span class="gemarra-regular">good advice: That a person should be wary</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of the evil eye</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> And this is what Joshua</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> said to them, as it is written: “And Joshua said</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> unto them: If you be a great people, go up</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to the forest, </span>and cut down for yourself there in the land of the Perizzites and of the Rephaim” (Joshua 17:15). Joshua <span class="gemarra-regular">said to them: Go and conceal yourselves </span><span class="gemarra-regular">in the forests so that the evil eye will not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">have dominion over you. </span>

Daf 118b

Joseph’s descendants <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: We are of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the descendants of Joseph, </span>upon <span class="gemarra-regular">whom the evil eye had </span><span class="gemarra-regular">no dominion, as it is written: “Joseph is a fruitful </span><span class="gemarra-regular">vine, a fruitful vine by a fountain [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">alei</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">ayin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]” </span>(Genesis 49:22), <span class="gemarra-regular">and Rabbi Abbahu states </span>a homiletic interpretation: <span class="gemarra-regular">Do not</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> read </span>it as <span class="gemarra-regular">“</span><span class="gemarra-italic">alei</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">ayin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular">”</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> rather </span>read it as <span class="gemarra-italic">olei</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">ayin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>above the eye, i.e., he transcended the influence of the evil eye. Joseph’s descendants were saying that they also do not need to be wary.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei, son of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rabbi Ḥanina, said </span>that a proof for the notion that the evil eye holds no sway over Joseph and his descendants, is <span class="gemarra-regular">from here, </span>Jacob’s blessing of Joseph’s sons, Ephraim and Manasseh: “The angel who has redeemed me from all evil, bless the lads; and let my name be named in them, and the name of my fathers, Abraham and Isaac; <span class="gemarra-regular">and let them grow into a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">multitude [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">veyidgu</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] in the midst of the earth” </span>(Genesis 48:16). <span class="it-text">Veyidgu</span> is related etymologically to the word for fish [<span class="it-text">dag</span>]. <span class="gemarra-regular">Just as </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">the fish in the sea</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, water covers them and the </span>evil <span class="gemarra-regular">eye has no dominion</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> over them, so too, the seed of Joseph, the </span>evil <span class="gemarra-regular">eye has no dominion over them.</span>
§ The Gemara analyzes the next section of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, which states: With regard to the twelve <span class="gemarra-regular">spie</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> sent to survey Eretz Yisrael prior to the Jewish people’s entry into the land, <span class="gemarra-regular">Joshua and Caleb took</span> all of the spies’ <span class="gemarra-regular">portions </span>of the land. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">From where is this matter </span>derived? <span class="gemarra-regular">Ulla said: </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">as the verse states: “But Joshua, son of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Nun, and Caleb, son of Jephunneh, lived of those men </span>that went to spy out the land” (Numbers 14:38). <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>does the term <span class="gemarra-regular">“lived” </span>mean? <span class="gemarra-regular">If we say </span>that it means <span class="gemarra-regular">literally </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">they lived, but </span>there is <span class="gemarra-regular">another verse</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">states: “And there was not left a man of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> them, save Caleb, son of Jephunneh, and Joshua, son of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Nun” </span>(Numbers 26:65), so why would the Torah state it twice? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, what </span>does the term <span class="gemarra-regular">“lived” </span>mean? <span class="gemarra-regular">That</span> Joshua and Caleb <span class="gemarra-regular">lived in </span>the other spies’ <span class="gemarra-regular">portio</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> of the land.
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> teaches that the <span class="gemarra-regular">protesters and the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> assembly of Korah did not possess a portion of Eretz</span> Yisrael. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t it taught </span>otherwise in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: With regard to the <span class="gemarra-regular">spies, </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">protesters</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, and the assembly of Korah, Joshua and Caleb took their</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> portions </span>of the land? Apparently, the protesters and the assembly of Korah were assigned portions in Eretz Yisrael, which were then given to Joshua and Caleb. The Gemara answers: It is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult: </span>One <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage, </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> quoted earlier, <span class="gemarra-regular">juxtaposes </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">protesters to the spies, </span>teaching that just as the spies were assigned a portion of Eretz Yisrael, so were the protesters. And one <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage, </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> quoted here, <span class="gemarra-regular">does not juxtapose </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">protesters</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to the spies. </span>Although the spies were assigned a portion, the protesters were not.
The Gemara quotes a related <span class="it-text">baraita</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">As it </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that the verse quotes the daughters of Zelophehad: “Our father died in the wilderness, and he was not among the assembly of them that gathered themselves together against the Lord in the assembly of Korah, but he died in his own sin; and he had no sons” (Numbers 27:3), and the daughters of Zelophehad therefore claim they are entitled to his portion. <span class="gemarra-regular">“Our father died</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in the wilderness,” this </span>is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">Zelophehad. “And he</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> was not among the assembly,” this </span>is referring to the <span class="gemarra-regular">assembly of spies. “That gathered themselves together against the Lord</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,” these </span>are the <span class="gemarra-regular">protesters. “In the assembly of Korah,” </span>this is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with its </span>straightforward <span class="gemarra-regular">meaning. </span>It is clear from this verse that those in these categories were not entitled to a portion in Eretz Yisrael.
The Gemara concludes: One <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage juxtaposes</span> the <span class="gemarra-regular">protesters to the spies, </span>so that Joshua and Caleb inherited the portions of both; <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage does</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not juxtapose </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">protesters to the spies.</span>
The Gemara presents Rav Pappa’s fourth question. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav Pappa said </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to Abaye: And according to the one who juxtaposes </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">protesters to the spies, </span>is it reasonable that <span class="gemarra-regular">Joshua and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Caleb contested </span>the spies <span class="gemarra-regular">and inherited all of Eretz Yisrael</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> Many of the Jewish people protested in the wilderness at one point or another, and it cannot be that Joshua and Caleb received all of their portions by virtue of not participating in the sin of the spies. Abaye <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: We are referring to </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">protesters who </span><span class="gemarra-regular">were among the assembly of Korah</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> This term is not referring to all those who protested, but rather to the 250 individuals who protested along with Korah, and it is their portions of land that Joshua and Caleb received.
The Gemara returns to the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> and presents the fifth question. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav Pappa said to Abaye: Granted, according to the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">one who says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Eretz </span>Yisrael <span class="gemarra-regular">was divided among those </span><span class="gemarra-regular">who left Egypt, this is as it is written </span>with regard to the inheritance of the tribe of Manasseh: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> ten parts fell to Manasseh, </span>beside the land of Gilead and Bashan, which is beyond the Jordan; because the daughters of Manasseh had an inheritance among his sons” (Joshua 17:5–6). <span class="gemarra-regular">Six </span>were the portions <span class="gemarra-regular">of the six fathers’ house</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> of Manasseh listed in a previous verse (Joshua 17:2), <span class="gemarra-regular">and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> four </span>parts <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span>the daughters of Zelophehad; <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">ten </span>parts.
<span class="gemarra-regular">But according to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the one who says </span>that Eretz Yisrael was divided <span class="gemarra-regular">among</span> those <span class="gemarra-regular">who entered Eretz </span>Yisrael, <span class="gemarra-regular">there were eight </span>parts, as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">Six </span>were the portions <span class="gemarra-regular">of the six fathers’ </span><span class="gemarra-regular">houses, and two of theirs, </span>which they received from the estate of their grandfather Hepher, of whom Zelophehad was the firstborn; <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">eight. </span>Zelophehad himself, by contrast, was not entitled to a portion, as he did not enter Eretz Yisrael.
The Gemara objects: <span class="gemarra-regular">And according to your reasoning, but </span>even <span class="gemarra-regular">according</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to the one who says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Eretz </span>Yisrael <span class="gemarra-regular">was divided</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> among those who left Egypt, there are </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">nine </span>parts, as the mishna (116b) states that Zelophehad’s daughters took three parts. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, what have you to say? </span>How can the mishna be reconciled with the verse? One must say that according to the opinion that Eretz Yisrael was divided among those who left Egypt, <span class="gemarra-regular">they had one </span>unmentioned <span class="gemarra-regular">paternal</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> uncle </span>who died without children, and Zelophehad’s estate received a share of his portion. <span class="gemarra-regular">So too, </span>according to the opinion that Eretz Yisrael was divided among those who entered Eretz Yisrael, it could be said that <span class="gemarra-regular">they had two</span> unmentioned <span class="gemarra-regular">paternal uncles, </span>so that they received two additional portions of land.
The fact that they received a portion from an uncle may be derived from a verse. <span class="gemarra-regular">As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that the verse states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“You shall give [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">naton</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">titten</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] the</span><span class="gemarra-regular">m</span> a possession of an inheritance” (Numbers 27:7). <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>is referring to the <span class="gemarra-regular">inheritance of their father. </span>The verse continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Among their</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> father’s brothers”; this </span>is referring to the <span class="gemarra-regular">inheritance of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> their father’s father. </span>The verse continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And you </span><span class="gemarra-regular">shall pass the inheritance of their father to them”; this </span>is referring to the <span class="gemarra-regular">portion of the firstborn </span>to which Zelophehad was entitled.
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Eliezer </span><span class="gemarra-regular">ben Ya’akov says: They also took a portion </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">their father’s brother, as it is stated: “You shall </span><span class="gemarra-regular">give [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">naton</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">titten</span><span class="gemarra-regular">].</span><span class="gemarra-regular">”</span> The double expression indicates that they received an additional portion. The Gemara notes: <span class="gemarra-regular">And according to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the one who says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">they had two paternal uncles</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that </span>additional portion <span class="gemarra-regular">is derived from </span>the phrase: “You shall give them <span class="gemarra-regular">a possession of an inheritance,” </span>which would be superfluous were it not to indicate an additional portion.
The Gemara presents the sixth question. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav Pappa said to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye: </span>In <span class="gemarra-regular">the verse </span>quoted above, <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>portions <span class="gemarra-regular">is it</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> counting? If </span>the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">is counting children, </span>i.e., the portions of those who inherited from their antecedents, as with the daughters of Zelophehad, <span class="gemarra-regular">there were many </span>such portions, and the verse did not enumerate all portions inherited by all members of the tribe. And <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">is counting</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> fathers’ houses, there are </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">six, </span>as Hepher is included among the six enumerated in Joshua 17:2. Why, then, does the verse count the portions of the daughters of Zelophehad separately? 

Daf 119a

The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Actually, </span>the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">is counting fathers’ houses.
