And </span>by also counting the inheritance of Zelophehad’s daughters, the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> us this: That </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">daughters of Zelophehad took </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">portion</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of the firstborn </span>due their father. <span class="gemarra-regular">Evidently, Eretz Yisrael is</span> considered already <span class="gemarra-regular">in possession </span>of one who was entitled to his portion of the land, even before the land was assigned. Although a firstborn son does not take a double portion of the property due to his deceased father as he does the property his father possessed, it is considered that Hepher possessed the portion that would eventually be assigned to him, and that Zelophehad was entitled to a double portion.
§ The Gemara continues its discussion of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">The </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Master</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> says: And the sons </span>of the spies and of the protesters <span class="gemarra-regular">took </span>portions of the land <span class="gemarra-regular">in the merit of their paternal grandfathers and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">in the merit of their maternal grandfathers </span>if those grandfathers were among those who left Egypt. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span><span class="gemarra-regular">isn’t it taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> (<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span> 7:10): The sons of the spies and of the protesters took portions <span class="gemarra-regular">in their own merit? </span>The Gemara answers: This is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">difficult: This </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span>, which states they took portions in the merit of their grandfathers, is written <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of the <span class="gemarra-regular">one who says </span>that Eretz Yisrael was divided <span class="gemarra-regular">among those who left Egypt; </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span>, which states that they took portions in their own merit, is written <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of the <span class="gemarra-regular">one who </span><span class="gemarra-regular">says </span>that Eretz Yisrael was divided <span class="gemarra-regular">among those who entered </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Eretz </span>Yisrael.
The Gemara suggests another answer. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if you wish, say </span>instead: <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and that </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span> are written in accordance with the opinion that asserts that Eretz Yisrael was divided <span class="gemarra-regular">among those who</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> entered Eretz </span>Yisrael, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult: This </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span> is discussing one <span class="gemarra-regular">who was twenty </span>years <span class="gemarra-regular">old </span>when the Jewish people entered Eretz Yisrael, and therefore he took a portion in his own merit, and <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span> is discussing one <span class="gemarra-regular">who was not twenty </span>years <span class="gemarra-regular">old</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
§ The mishna teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>Zelophehad took an additional portion that he received from Hepher, <span class="gemarra-regular">because he was a firstborn, </span>and a firstborn <span class="gemarra-regular">takes two portions </span>of inheritance from his father. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But why </span>was he entitled to the double portion of the firstborn? His portion of land <span class="gemarra-regular">is</span> property merely <span class="gemarra-regular">due </span>to Hepher, as Hepher never actually possessed the land, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is that <span class="gemarra-regular">a firstborn does</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not take </span>a double portion <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span>property <span class="gemarra-regular">due </span>to the deceased <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>he does <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span>property the deceased <span class="gemarra-regular">possessed</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rav Yehuda says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel says: </span>This clause of the mishna is stated <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to tent pegs </span>and other assorted movable property that Hepher possessed.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba raises an</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> objection </span>from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda says: </span>The <span class="gemarra-regular">daughters </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of Zelophehad took four parts, as it is stated: “And </span><span class="gemarra-regular">ten parts fell to Manasseh” </span>(Joshua 17:5). Clearly, this is referring to portions of land, and not simply movable property. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Rabba says: Eretz Yisrael is </span>considered already <span class="gemarra-regular">in possessio</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> of one who was entitled to his portion of inheritance land, even before the land was assigned.
The Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises an objection </span>from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Ḥideka said: Shimon HaShikmon</span><span class="gemarra-regular">i</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> was my colleague among the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">students of Rabbi Akiva, and so would Rabbi Shimon HaShikmoni </span><span class="gemarra-regular">say: </span>Even before turning to God for guidance, <span class="gemarra-regular">Moses our</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> teacher knew that the daughters of Zelophehad were inheritors </span>and that they were entitled to their father’s portion, as well as his share in Hepher’s portion. <span class="gemarra-regular">But he</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> did not know if they </span>were entitled to <span class="gemarra-regular">take a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> portion of the firstborn </span>of Hepher’s portion <span class="gemarra-regular">or not</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
Rabbi Ḥideka continues citing Rabbi Shimon HaShikmoni: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the Torah <span class="gemarra-regular">portion </span>concerning the laws <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">inheritances was fi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to have been written through </span>God initiating a commandment to <span class="gemarra-regular">Moses, </span>without mentioning Zelophehad’s daughters. <span class="gemarra-regular">But</span> by demonstrating their desire for land in Eretz Yisrael the <span class="gemarra-regular">daughters of Zelophehad merited </span>that the portion was <span class="gemarra-regular">written through</span> a response to <span class="gemarra-regular">them.</span>
Rabbi Ḥideka continues citing Rabbi Shimon HaShikmoni: <span class="gemarra-regular">And Moses our teacher </span>similarly <span class="gemarra-regular">knew that the </span>wood <span class="gemarra-regular">gatherer, </span>who gathered wood on Shabbat (see Numbers 15:32–36), was to be punished <span class="gemarra-regular">by death, as it is stated: “Every</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> one that profanes it shall be put to death” </span>(Exodus 31:14), <span class="gemarra-regular">but he did not know by which death </span>penalty the wood gatherer <span class="gemarra-regular">must die. And the </span>Torah <span class="gemarra-regular">portion </span>concerning the punishment <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span>the wood <span class="gemarra-regular">gatherer was fi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> have been written through </span>God initiating a commandment to <span class="gemarra-regular">Moses</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>to teach which form of court-imposed capital punishment is administered to one who violates Shabbat. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>the wood <span class="gemarra-regular">gatherer</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> was </span>found <span class="gemarra-regular">guilty, and </span>the portion was <span class="gemarra-regular">written through </span>the incident involving <span class="gemarra-regular">him. </span>This is <span class="gemarra-regular">to teach you</span>

Daf 119b

<span class="gemarra-regular">that merit is brought about by means of </span>one who <span class="gemarra-regular">is meritorious and liability by means of </span>one who <span class="gemarra-regular">is liable. </span>Accordingly, the daughters of Zelophehad merited that the Torah portion concerning a positive matter be written through them, and the wood gatherer deserved that a portion concerning a negative matter be written through him. This concludes Rabbi Ḥideka’s citation of Rabbi Shimon HaShikmoni.
The Gemara states its objection: <span class="gemarra-regular">And if it </span><span class="gemarra-regular">enters your mind </span>to say that <span class="gemarra-regular">Eretz Yisrael </span>was already <span class="gemarra-regular">in possession </span>of the Jewish people even before the land was assigned, <span class="gemarra-regular">what was </span>Moses <span class="gemarra-regular">uncertain </span>about with regard to the right of Zelophehad’s daughters to collect a double portion; after all, Hepher’s portion in the land was in his possession, and Zelophehad was the firstborn?
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>matter <span class="gemarra-regular">itself </span>is what Moses <span class="gemarra-regular">was uncertain </span>about, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is written: “And I will</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> give it to you for a heritage [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">morasha</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]: I am</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the Lord” </span>(Exodus 6:8). Moses was unsure if the verse should be understood: <span class="gemarra-regular">It </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">an inheritance </span><span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">y</span><span class="gemarra-italic">erusha</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] for </span><span class="gemarra-regular">you from your fathers, </span>such that it is considered in the possession of those who left Egypt; <span class="gemarra-regular">or perhaps </span>the verse indicates another matter, <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the generation of those who left Egypt <span class="gemarra-regular">bequeath [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">morishin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] </span>the portions to others <span class="gemarra-regular">but they </span><span class="gemarra-regular">do not inherit </span><span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">y</span><span class="gemarra-italic">oreshin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] </span>the portions themselves, because they are destined to die in the wilderness.
The Gemara continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>God <span class="gemarra-regular">resolved</span> the question <span class="gemarra-regular">for him: </span>The verse teaches <span class="gemarra-regular">both of them</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. It </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">an inheritance for you from your fathers </span>and is considered in your possession; <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>also the generation that left Egypt <span class="gemarra-regular">bequeath but they do not inherit. And </span><span class="gemarra-regular">this is </span>the meaning of that <span class="gemarra-regular">which is written </span>in the song that the Jewish people sang after the splitting of the Red Sea: <span class="gemarra-regular">“You will bring them in, and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> plant them in the mountain of Your inheritance” </span>(Exodus 15:17). It <span class="gemarra-regular">is not stated: You will bring us in, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">rather: “You will bring them in,” </span>which <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches that </span>in their song, the Jewish people <span class="gemarra-regular">were prophesying </span>that their generation would never enter Eretz Yisrael, <span class="gemarra-regular">but they did not know </span><span class="gemarra-regular">what they were prophesying.</span>
§ The Gemara continues its discussion of the incident involving Zelophehad’s daughters. The verse states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And they stood before Moses, and before Eleazar </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the priest, and before the princes and all the congregation” </span>(Numbers 27:2). The Gemara asks: Is it <span class="gemarra-regular">possible </span>that Zelophehad’s daughters <span class="gemarra-regular">stood before Moses </span>and then Eleazar to ask their question, <span class="gemarra-regular">and they said nothing to them; and </span>then the daughters <span class="gemarra-regular">stood before the princes and all the congregation</span> to ask them? How would the princes or the congregation know an answer if Moses and Eleazar did not?
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, transpose the verse and interpret it</span><span class="gemarra-regular">:</span> First, the daughters went to the congregation and ultimately came to Moses, this is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of Rabbi Yoshiya</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. Abba Ḥanan says in the name of Rabbi Eliezer: </span>Those enumerated in the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">were </span>all <span class="gemarra-regular">sitting in the house</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of study, and </span>Zelophehad’s daughters <span class="gemarra-regular">went and stood before</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> all of them </span>at once. They were not asked separately; rather, the order of the verse reflects their stature.
The Gemara clarifies: <span class="gemarra-regular">With regard </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to what do they disagree? </span>One <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage, </span>Abba Ḥanan, <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that one may <span class="gemarra-regular">show honor to a student in the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">presence of the teacher</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> such that the verse would mention all the others even though they were in the presence of Moses; <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage, </span>Rabbi Yoshiya, <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>one may <span class="gemarra-regular">not show </span>honor to a student in the presence of the teacher, such that only Moses would have been mentioned if they were all in the same place.
The Gemara concludes: <span class="gemarra-regular">And the</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is that one may <span class="gemarra-regular">show </span>honor to a student, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is that one may <span class="gemarra-regular">not show </span>honor. The Gemara asks: This is <span class="gemarra-regular">difficult, </span>as there is a contradiction between <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>one <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and the </span>other <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>The Gemara answers: The contradiction between <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>one <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>other <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult, </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>ruling, that one may show honor, was stated <span class="gemarra-regular">where his teacher </span>himself <span class="gemarra-regular">accords </span>the student <span class="gemarra-regular">honor</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>In such a case, others also may show the student honor. And <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>ruling, that one may not show honor, was stated <span class="gemarra-regular">where his teacher</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> does not accord him honor.</span>
§ The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">taught: The daughters of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Zelophehad are wise</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> they are interpreters </span>of verses, and <span class="gemarra-regular">they are righteous.</span>
The Gemara proves these assertions. That <span class="gemarra-regular">they are </span><span class="gemarra-regular">wise </span>can be seen from the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that they spoke </span><span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with the moment, </span>i.e., they presented their case at an auspicious time. <span class="gemarra-regular">As Rabbi Shmuel bar Rav </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Yitzḥak says: </span>Tradition <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches that Moses our teacher was sitting </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and interpreting in </span>the Torah <span class="gemarra-regular">portion about men whose married </span><span class="gemarra-regular">brothers had died childless, as it is stated: “If brothers</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> dwell together, </span>and one of them dies, and has no child, the wife of the dead shall not be married abroad to one not of his kin; her husband’s brother shall come to her, and take her for him as a wife” (Deuteronomy 25:5). The daughters of Zelophehad <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Moses: <span class="gemarra-regular">If we are </span>each <span class="gemarra-regular">considered like a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">son, give us </span>each <span class="gemarra-regular">an inheritance like a son; </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">if not, our mother should enter into levirate marriage. Immediately </span>upon hearing their claim, the verse records: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And Moses brought</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> their cause before the Lord” </span>(Numbers 27:5).
That <span class="gemarra-regular">they are interpreters </span>of verses can be seen from the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that they were saying: If </span>our father <span class="gemarra-regular">had had a son, we would not have spoken; </span>but because he had no son, we are filling the role of the heir. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t it </span><span class="gemarra-regular">taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: They would say, if he had had <span class="gemarra-regular">a daughter, </span>we would not have spoken? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yirmeya </span><span class="gemarra-regular">said: Delete from </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">here </span>the word: <span class="gemarra-regular">Daughter. </span>As they were themselves daughters, this cannot have been their claim. <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said </span>that the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> need not be emended, and should be understood as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">Even if </span>there <span class="gemarra-regular">was a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> daughter of a son </span>of Zelophehad, <span class="gemarra-regular">we would not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">have spoken</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> for she would have been the heir.
That <span class="gemarra-regular">they are righteous </span>can be seen from the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that they </span>did <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>rush to <span class="gemarra-regular">marry, </span>but <span class="gemarra-regular">rather </span>waited <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>marry those <span class="gemarra-regular">fit for them. Rabbi Eliezer</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> ben Ya’akov teaches: Even the youngest </span>to be married <span class="gemarra-regular">among them was not married </span>at <span class="gemarra-regular">less than forty years</span> of age.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Is that so? But</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> doesn’t Rav Ḥisda say: </span>If a woman <span class="gemarra-regular">marries </span>when she is <span class="gemarra-regular">less than twenty </span>years <span class="gemarra-regular">old, </span>she is able to <span class="gemarra-regular">give birth until </span>she reaches the age of <span class="gemarra-regular">sixty</span><span class="gemarra-regular">; </span>if she marries when she is <span class="gemarra-regular">twenty </span>years <span class="gemarra-regular">old </span>or older, she is able to <span class="gemarra-regular">give birth until </span>she reaches the age of <span class="gemarra-regular">forty; </span>if she marries when she is <span class="gemarra-regular">forty </span>years <span class="gemarra-regular">old </span>or older, she is <span class="gemarra-regular">no longer</span> able to <span class="gemarra-regular">give birth </span>at all. If so, how could Zelophehad’s daughters have waited until the age of forty to marry? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, since they are righteous women, a miracle</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> was performed for them, like </span>the one done for <span class="gemarra-regular">Jochebed</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. As it is written: “And a man of the house</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of Levi went, and took as a wife a daughter</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of Levi” </span>(Exodus 2:1). 

Daf 120a

The Gemara asks: Is it <span class="gemarra-regular">possible </span>that this is Jochebed? Jochebed was then <span class="gemarra-regular">130 years old and </span>the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">called</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> her a daughter, </span>indicating one who is very young. Jochebed’s age is established based on a tradition concerning the number of Jacob’s descendants who came to Egypt, as follows: While the verse states that Leah had thirty-three descendants (Genesis 46:15), only thirty-two were enumerated. This was explained <span class="gemarra-regular">as Rabbi Ḥama bar Ḥanina says: This </span>“daughter of Levi” is <span class="gemarra-regular">Jochebed, whose conception </span>occurred <span class="gemarra-regular">on the journey</span> as the family of Jacob descended to Egypt, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">she was born within the walls, </span>i.e., having entered Egypt, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is written: </span>“And the name of Amram’s wife was Jochebed, the daughter of Levi, <span class="gemarra-regular">who</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> was born to Levi in Egypt” </span>(Numbers 26:59).
One can infer from the verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">Her birth </span>was <span class="gemarra-regular">in Egypt, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">but her conception was not in Egypt. </span>Since the Jewish people were in Egypt for 210 years and Moses was eighty years old at the time of the Exodus, Jochebed must have been 130 years old when Moses was born. The Gemara therefore asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And why </span>does the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">call</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> her “a daughter”? Rav Yehuda bar Zevida says: </span>This <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that </span>her <span class="gemarra-regular">signs of youth </span>miraculously <span class="gemarra-regular">came into being </span>again. <span class="gemarra-regular">The flesh became smooth, the wrinkles were straightened out, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and the </span>youthful <span class="gemarra-regular">beauty returned to its place.</span>
The verse concerning Amram’s marriage to Jochebed states: “And a man of the house of Levi went, <span class="gemarra-regular">and took </span>as a wife a daughter of Levi” (Exodus 2:1). The Gemara asks: Since Jochebed had already been married to Amram for some years, as Miriam and Aaron were already born, the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">should have </span>stated: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">took bac</span><span class="gemarra-regular">k</span> as a wife. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda bar Zevida says: </span>The wording of the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches that </span>Amram <span class="gemarra-regular">performed for her </span>a formal <span class="gemarra-regular">act of marriag</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> as though he were marrying her for the first time. He <span class="gemarra-regular">seated her in </span>a bridal <span class="gemarra-regular">palanquin [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">be’appiryon</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and Aaron and Miriam </span>were <span class="gemarra-regular">singing before</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> her, and </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">ministering angels </span>were <span class="gemarra-regular">saying: “A joyful mother</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of children” </span>(Psalms 113:9).
§ The Gemara returns to discuss Zelophehad’s daughters: <span class="gemarra-regular">Later on, the verse lists the</span><span class="gemarra-regular">m</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> according to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">their age, </span>stating: “For Mahlah, Tirzah, and Hoglah, and Milcah, and Noah, the daughters of Zelophehad, were married” (Numbers 36:11), <span class="gemarra-regular">and here </span>the verse lists them in a different order, <span class="gemarra-regular">according to their wisdom: </span>“And these are the names of his daughters: Mahlah, Noah, and Hoglah, and Milcah, and Tirzah” (Numbers 27:1). This <span class="gemarra-regular">supports </span>the ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rabbi Ami, as Rabbi Ami says: In </span>the context of <span class="gemarra-regular">sitting </span>in judgment or learning Torah, <span class="gemarra-regular">follow </span>the participants’ <span class="gemarra-regular">wisdom </span>in determining the seating, so that the wisest is granted the highest honor, and <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the context of <span class="gemarra-regular">reclining</span> for a meal, <span class="gemarra-regular">follow </span>the participants’ <span class="gemarra-regular">age. Rav Ashi </span><span class="gemarra-regular">says: And this </span>is so only <span class="gemarra-regular">when </span>one is <span class="gemarra-regular">outstandin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in wisdom, </span>then wisdom trumps age; <span class="gemarra-regular">and this </span>is so only <span class="gemarra-regular">when </span>one of the participants is <span class="gemarra-regular">outstanding in </span><span class="gemarra-regular">age, </span>i.e., particularly old, then age trumps wisdom.
The Gemara cites an alternative opinion: <span class="gemarra-regular">The school of Rabbi </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Yishmael taught: The daughters of Zelophehad were equal </span>in stature, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is stated: </span>“For Mahlah, Tirzah, and Hoglah, and Milcah, and Noah, the daughters of Zelophehad, <span class="gemarra-regular">were [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">vatihyena</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> married.” The word “<span class="it-text">vatihyena</span>” demonstrates: <span class="gemarra-regular">There was one </span>uniform <span class="gemarra-regular">existence [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">havaya</span><span class="gemarra-regular">], </span>i.e., spiritual level, <span class="gemarra-regular">for all of them</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel says: The daughters of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Zelophehad were permitte</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to marry </span>members <span class="gemarra-regular">of any of the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> tribes, as it is stated: “Let them be married to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> whom they think best” </span>(Numbers 36:6). <span class="gemarra-regular">But how do </span><span class="gemarra-regular">I realize </span>the meaning of the continuation of the same verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Only into the family of the tribe of their</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> father shall they be married” </span>(Numbers 36:6), according to which they were permitted to marry only members of their own tribe? <span class="gemarra-regular">The verse offered them good advice, that they </span><span class="gemarra-regular">should be married only </span>to those <span class="gemarra-regular">fit for them, </span>who were often men from within the family.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba raised </span><span class="gemarra-regular">an objection </span>from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> taught concerning the prohibition against eating consecrated foods while in a state of ritual impurity. Moses was commanded: “Say to them: Whoever will be of all your descendants throughout your generations, who approaches to the holy things, which the children of Israel consecrate to the Lord, having his uncleanness upon him, that soul shall be cut off from before Me” (Leviticus 22:3). Which people are referred to in the phrase <span class="gemarra-regular">“say to them”? </span>It is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to those standing at Mount Sinai. </span>Which people are referred to in the phrase <span class="gemarra-regular">“throughout your generations”? </span><span class="gemarra-regular">These are the coming generations. If </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is stated </span>to <span class="gemarra-regular">the fathers, why is </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">stated </span>to <span class="gemarra-regular">the sons; </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and if </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is stated </span>to <span class="gemarra-regular">the sons, why </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">stated </span>to <span class="gemarra-regular">the fathers? </span>This is <span class="gemarra-regular">because there </span><span class="gemarra-regular">are </span>mitzvot <span class="gemarra-regular">for the fathers that are not for the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">sons, and there are </span>mitzvot <span class="gemarra-regular">for the sons that are </span><span class="gemarra-regular">not for the fathers.</span>
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">For the fathers, </span>the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">states: “</span><span class="gemarra-regular">And every daughter who possesses an inheritance </span>from the tribes of the children of Israel, shall be wife to one of the family of the tribe of her father” (Numbers 36:8). This mitzva, that the woman should marry a member of her own tribe, applied only to the first generation that received tribal portions of Eretz Yisrael. <span class="gemarra-regular">And, </span>by contrast, there were <span class="gemarra-regular">many mitzvot, </span>e.g., all the mitzvot that applied only from the time that Eretz Yisrael was settled, which <span class="gemarra-regular">the sons were commanded </span>to fulfill but <span class="gemarra-regular">which</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the fathers were not commanded </span>to fulfill. <span class="gemarra-regular">Because there </span><span class="gemarra-regular">are </span>mitzvot <span class="gemarra-regular">for the fathers that are not for the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">sons, and there are </span>mitzvot <span class="gemarra-regular">for the sons that are </span><span class="gemarra-regular">not for the fathers, </span>the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">needed to state, </span>i.e., to address, the <span class="gemarra-regular">fathers, </span>and it <span class="gemarra-regular">needed to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">state, </span>i.e., to address, the <span class="gemarra-regular">sons.</span>
Rabba states his objection: <span class="gemarra-regular">In any</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> event, </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches: For the fathers, </span>the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">states: “And every daughter who possesses an inheritance </span>from the tribes of the children of Israel, shall be wife to one of the family of the tribe of her father.” This indicates that this was a mitzva for that entire generation, including Zelophehad’s daughters, in contrast to the statement of Shmuel. The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">He, </span>Rabba, <span class="gemarra-regular">raised the objection</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, and he resolved it: </span>This mitzva applied to everyone <span class="gemarra-regular">except</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for the daughters of Zelophehad, </span>who were explicitly permitted to marry members of any tribe.
<span class="gemarra-regular">The</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Master says </span>in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> cited above: <span class="gemarra-regular">For the fathers</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">states: “And every daughter who possesses an </span><span class="gemarra-regular">inheritance </span>from the tribes of the children of Israel, shall be wife to one of the family of the tribe of her father.” <span class="gemarra-regular">For the fathers, yes, </span>this is the mitzva, but <span class="gemarra-regular">for the sons, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>so. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">From where may </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">be inferred? Rava said</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">the verse states </span>there: <span class="gemarra-regular">“This is the matter </span>that the Lord has commanded” (Numbers 36:6), meaning: <span class="gemarra-regular">This matter </span><span class="gemarra-regular">will not be practiced except in this generation.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba Zuti said to Rav Ashi: If </span><span class="gemarra-regular">that is so, </span>then concerning the phrase <span class="gemarra-regular">“this is the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> matter” </span>written <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>an offering <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughtered outside </span>the Tabernacle (see Leviticus 17:2–3), <span class="gemarra-regular">so too, </span>is it the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">that it will not be practiced except in this generation</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? </span>Certainly that is not so, as that prohibition applies in all generations. What is the difference between the two passages? Rav Ashi answered: It <span class="gemarra-regular">is different there, </span>with regard to offerings slaughtered outside the Tabernacle or Temple, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> written: “Throughout their generations” </span>(Leviticus 17:7), indicating that the prohibition is in effect in all generations. 

Daf 120b

Rabba Zuti asked Rav Ashi about another instance of the same phrase. In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">“this is the matter” </span>written <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">heads of the tribes, </span>in the introductory verse to the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of vows: “And Moses spoke to the heads of the tribes of the children of Israel, saying: This is the matter that the Lord has commanded” (Numbers 30:2), is it <span class="gemarra-regular">also </span>the case <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of vows <span class="gemarra-regular">will not be practiced except in this </span><span class="gemarra-regular">generation? </span>Rav Ashi <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>The <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>case, that of vows, <span class="gemarra-regular">is derived through </span>a verbal analogy between the word <span class="gemarra-regular">“this” </span>stated here, in the verse discussing vows, and the word <span class="gemarra-regular">“this” </span>stated <span class="gemarra-regular">there, </span>in the verse discussing offerings slaughtered outside the Tabernacle or Temple, which is applicable in all generations.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span><span class="it-text">halakha</span>, concerning the daughter inheriting her father’s portion, <span class="gemarra-regular">let it be </span><span class="gemarra-regular">derived through </span>a verbal analogy between the word <span class="gemarra-regular">“this” </span>stated here, with regard to inheritance, and the word <span class="gemarra-regular">“this” </span>stated <span class="gemarra-regular">there, </span>in the verse discussing offerings, <span class="gemarra-regular">as well. </span>The Gemara rejects that comparison: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is this </span>suggestion? <span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, there</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>i.e., with regard to offerings slaughtered outside the Tabernacle or Temple and with regard to vows, the phrase “this is the matter” <span class="gemarra-regular">was necessary </span>for deriving other <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> through <span class="gemarra-regular">a verbal analogy</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as will be explained later. Therefore, the term may also be employed to teach that the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> applies in all generations. But <span class="gemarra-regular">here, </span>with regard to a daughter’s inheritance, <span class="gemarra-regular">for what </span>other <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">was </span>this phrase <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary? </span>If the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> truly applies for posterity, <span class="gemarra-regular">let</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the verse be silent </span>and refrain <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>addressing when this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> applies by not stating “this is the matter,” <span class="gemarra-regular">and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> I </span>would <span class="gemarra-regular">know that it is for all generations, </span>as is the case with all other mitzvot.
The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is the <span class="gemarra-regular">verbal analogy </span>for which the phrase was necessary? <span class="gemarra-regular">As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">It </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is stated here, </span>with regard to vows: <span class="gemarra-regular">“This is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the matter,” and it is stated there, </span>with regard to offerings slaughtered outside the Tabernacle or Temple: <span class="gemarra-regular">“This is the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> matter.” Just as there </span>the mitzva applies to <span class="gemarra-regular">Aaron and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> his sons and all Israel, so too here, </span>with regard to vows, the mitzva applies to <span class="gemarra-regular">Aaron and his sons</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and all Israel. And just as here </span>the mitzva applies to <span class="gemarra-regular">the heads of the tribes, </span>as explicitly stated in the verse cited above, <span class="gemarra-regular">so too there, </span>with regard to offerings slaughtered outside the Tabernacle or Temple, there is particular relevance to <span class="gemarra-regular">the heads of the tribes.</span>
The Gemara analyzes the cited <span class="it-text">baraita</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">The Master says: Just as</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> there, </span>with regard to offerings, the mitzva applies to <span class="gemarra-regular">Aaron and his sons and all Israel, so too here, </span>with regard to vows, the mitzva applies to <span class="gemarra-regular">Aaron and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">his sons and all Israel. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">With regard </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to what </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is this verbal analogy stated? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Aḥa </span><span class="gemarra-regular">bar Ya’akov says: </span>This is written <span class="gemarra-regular">to say that </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">dissolution of vow</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> can be performed <span class="gemarra-regular">by thre</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">layme</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> with no particular expertise in the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of vows, just as the prohibition of offerings slaughtered outside the Tabernacle or Temple applies to all of the Jewish people, including laymen.
The Gemara objects: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>the phrase <span class="gemarra-regular">“the heads of the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> tribes” is written </span>explicitly <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the portion of the vows, indicating that the matter is not entrusted to laymen. The Gemara answers: It is <span class="gemarra-regular">as Rav Ḥisda says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says </span>in a different context: The mention of the heads of tribes teaches that vows may be dissolved <span class="gemarra-regular">by a single exper</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> halakhic authority; <span class="gemarra-regular">so too </span>here, this phrase teaches that vows can be nullified <span class="gemarra-regular">by a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> single expert </span>halakhic authority.
The Gemara analyzes the next clause of the cited <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">And just as here </span>the mitzva applies to <span class="gemarra-regular">the heads of the tribes, so too there, </span>with regard to offerings slaughtered outside the Tabernacle or Temple, there is particular relevance to <span class="gemarra-regular">the heads of the tribes. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">With regard to what </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> are the heads of the tribes linked to the prohibition of slaughtering offerings outside the Tabernacle or Temple? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Sheshet says: </span>This is written <span class="gemarra-regular">to say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">there is </span>a concept of <span class="gemarra-regular">requesting</span> dissolution of consecration <span class="gemarra-regular">of consecrated </span>property, just as one can request dissolution of a vow.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And according to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Beit Shammai, who say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">there is no </span>possibility of <span class="gemarra-regular">requesting </span>that a halakhic authority dissolve a vow <span class="gemarra-regular">of consecrated</span> property, this cannot explain the connection of the heads of the tribes to offerings slaughtered outside the Tabernacle or Temple. <span class="gemarra-regular">As we learned </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Nazir</span> 30b): <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Shammai</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> say: Consecration </span>that one performed <span class="gemarra-regular">in erro</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is </span>nevertheless effective as <span class="gemarra-regular">consecration</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> because one’s mindset does not supersede his verbal declaration; <span class="gemarra-regular">and Beit Hillel say: </span>This is <span class="gemarra-regular">not consecration. </span>Accordingly, in the opinion of Beit Shammai, <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span><span class="gemarra-regular">do they do with this </span>seemingly analogous usage of <span class="gemarra-regular">“this</span><span class="gemarra-regular">” and “this,” </span>in the portions of offerings slaughtered outside the Tabernacle or Temple and vows, respectively?
The Gemara answers: Beit Shammai <span class="gemarra-regular">require “this is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the matter” </span>written <span class="gemarra-regular">of offerings slaughtered outside </span>the Tabernacle or Temple to teach that <span class="gemarra-regular">for the </span>act of <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughtering, he</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is liabl</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> to receive excision from the World-to-Come [<span class="it-text">karet</span>]; <span class="gemarra-regular">but he is not liable </span>to receive <span class="it-text">karet</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">for the </span>act of <span class="gemarra-regular">pinching </span>the neck of a consecrated bird outside the Tabernacle or Temple, which is excluded from the category of slaughtering in this mitzva. And Beit Shammai <span class="gemarra-regular">require “this is the matter” </span>written of <span class="gemarra-regular">the heads of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the tribes </span>in the portion about vows <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>teach that only <span class="gemarra-regular">a halakhic authority can dissolve </span>vows, <span class="gemarra-regular">but a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">husband cannot dissolve </span>them. The halakhic authority can dissolve the vow for a petitioner, but a woman’s husband or father cannot dissolve her vow. And, conversely, <span class="gemarra-regular">a husband can</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> nullif</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span> his wife’s or his daughter’s vows on the day that he hears the vow, regardless of her mindset, <span class="gemarra-regular">but a halakhic authority cannot nullify </span>vows in this manner.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But according</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to Beit Shammai, who do not have </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">verbal analogy</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>meaning that they do not recognize as authoritative the verbal analogy that links vows to offerings slaughtered outside the Tabernacle or Temple, <span class="gemarra-regular">from where do they </span>derive that <span class="gemarra-regular">dissolution of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> vows </span>can be performed <span class="gemarra-regular">by three laymen? </span>The Gemara answers: Beit Shammai <span class="gemarra-regular">derive it from that which is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: The verse states at the end of a passage relating to the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of the Festivals: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Moses declared to the children of Israel the appointed seasons</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of the Lord” </span>(Leviticus 23:44). In explaining the verse, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei HaGelili says: </span>

Daf 121a

<span class="gemarra-regular">The Festivals</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of the Lord were stated, </span>but <span class="gemarra-regular">Shabbat, </span>which commemorates <span class="gemarra-regular">Creation</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, was not stated. Ben Azzai says: The Festivals of the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Lord were stated, </span>but <span class="gemarra-regular">the dissolution of vows was not</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> stated. </span>This concludes the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>.
The Gemara recounts: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei bar Natan learned this </span><span class="gemarra-italic">baraita</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and did not</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> know how to explain it. </span>He <span class="gemarra-regular">followed Rav Sheshet to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Neharde’a </span>in order to ask him about it, <span class="gemarra-regular">but</span> he <span class="gemarra-regular">did not find him </span>there. He <span class="gemarra-regular">followed him to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Meḥoza </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">found him, </span>and he <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: What</span> is meant by Rabbi Yosei HaGelili’s statement: <span class="gemarra-regular">The Festivals</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of the Lord were stated, </span>but <span class="gemarra-regular">Shabbat, </span>which commemorates <span class="gemarra-regular">Creation</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, was not stated? </span>What does he mean, as Shabbat of Creation is explicitly mentioned in that section of the Torah (Leviticus 23:3)?
Rav Sheshet <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: The Festivals of the Lord require sanctification</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> by the court</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> This means that the start of the month, which is dependent upon the appearance of the New Moon, which determines the Festivals, can be established only by a court composed of experts. <span class="gemarra-regular">Shabbat, </span>which commemorates <span class="gemarra-regular">Creation</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, does not require sanctification by the court</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Shabbat is sanctified every week independent of any court action. It may <span class="gemarra-regular">enter your mind to say: Since </span>Shabbat <span class="gemarra-regular">is written adjacent</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to the Festivals, it should require sanctification by the court</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as </span>do the <span class="gemarra-regular">Festivals. </span>Rabbi Yosei HaGelili <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>that Shabbat does not require this.
Rabbi Yosei bar Natan asked: <span class="gemarra-regular">What</span> is meant by ben Azzai’s statement: <span class="gemarra-regular">The Festivals of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the Lord were stated, </span>but <span class="gemarra-regular">the dissolution of vows was</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not stated? </span>After all, the Torah writes explicitly about the dissolution of vows. Rav Sheshet answered him: <span class="gemarra-regular">The Festivals of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the Lord require expert</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> to determine when the months begin and when the Festivals will be observed, but <span class="gemarra-regular">the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> dissolution of vows does not require experts.</span>
The Gemara questions this explanation. <span class="gemarra-regular">But it is written: “The heads of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the tribes” </span>(Numbers 30:2), in the portion discussing the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of vows. How, then, can it be said that vows can be dissolved by laymen? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥisda says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: </span>The phrase teaches that vows can be dissolved <span class="gemarra-regular">by a single expert </span>authority. In any event, the Gemara has established that Beit Shammai can derive that dissolution of vows can be performed by laymen in the manner stated by ben Azzai, as explained by Rav Sheshet.
§ The Gemara discusses a mishna that addresses the issue of inter-tribal marriages. <span class="gemarra-regular">We learned </span>in a mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">there </span>(<span class="it-text">Ta’anit</span> 26b): <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel said: There were no</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> days as joyous for the Jewish people as the fifteenth</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of Av and as Yom Kippur, as on these </span>days <span class="gemarra-regular">the daughters of Jerusalem would emerge in white garments</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> which each woman <span class="gemarra-regular">borrowed </span>from another. Why did they borrow garments? They did this <span class="gemarra-regular">so as not to embarrass one</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> who did not have </span>her own white garments. The Gemara analyzes the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">Granted </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Yom Kippur </span>is a day of joy, because it is <span class="gemarra-regular">a day of pardon and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> forgiveness</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and moreover, it is the <span class="gemarra-regular">day on which</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the last Tablets </span>of the Covenant <span class="gemarra-regular">were given. But what</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is </span>the special joy of the <span class="gemarra-regular">fifteenth of Av?</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> says: </span>This was the <span class="gemarra-regular">day when </span>the members of different <span class="gemarra-regular">tribes were permitte</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to marry </span>into <span class="gemarra-regular">one another’s</span> tribe. Such marriages were restricted for the first generation to enter Eretz Yisrael, as discussed above (120a). <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>verse <span class="gemarra-regular">did</span> the sages of that time <span class="gemarra-regular">interpre</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> in support of their conclusion that this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> was no longer in effect? The verse states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“This is the matter” </span>(Numbers 36:6), meaning, <span class="gemarra-regular">this matter shall be practiced only in this generation,</span> in which Eretz Yisrael is being divided among the tribes.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba bar bar Ḥana</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan </span>offered another explanation: The fifteenth of Av was the <span class="gemarra-regular">day when </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">tribe of Benjamin was</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> permitted to enter into the congregation </span>of the other tribes of Israel through marriage, after the other tribes found a way to dissolve the vow that had prohibited them from marrying a member of the tribe of Benjamin in the aftermath of the episode of the concubine in Gibeah (Judges, chapters 19–20). <span class="gemarra-regular">As it is written: “And the men of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Israel had taken an oath in Mizpah, saying: None of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> us shall give his daughter to Benjamin as a wife</span><span class="gemarra-regular">” </span>(Judges 21:1). The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>verse <span class="gemarra-regular">did </span>the sages of that time <span class="gemarra-regular">interpret </span>that enabled them to dissolve this vow? The verse states: “None <span class="gemarra-regular">of us,” and not</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: </span>None <span class="gemarra-regular">of our children; </span>therefore, the oath applied only to the generation that had taken the oath.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Dimi bar Yosef says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman </span>says: The fifteenth of Av was the <span class="gemarra-regular">day on which those </span><span class="gemarra-regular">designated to perish in the wilderness stopped </span>dying, as the entire generation that had left Egypt had died due to the sin of the spies (Numbers 14:29–30). <span class="gemarra-regular">As the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Master says: As long as those designated to perish </span>in the <span class="gemarra-regular">wilderness had not stopped </span>dying, 

Daf 121b

God <span class="gemarra-regular">did not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">speak with Moses</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as it is stated: “So it </span><span class="gemarra-regular">came to pass, when all the men of war were </span><span class="gemarra-regular">consumed and dead from among the people” </span>(Deuteronomy 2:16), <span class="gemarra-regular">and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> juxtaposed to </span>that verse it is written: <span class="gemarra-regular">“That the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Lord spoke to me, saying” </span>(Deuteronomy 2:17). Moses indicates: Only after the last of that generation had died, <span class="gemarra-regular">was the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> speech </span>of God directed <span class="gemarra-regular">to me. </span>When the Jewish people realized that the decree had been lifted, the day was established as a permanent day of rejoicing.
The Gemara continues to cite explanations for the significance of the fifteenth of Av. <span class="gemarra-regular">Ulla says: </span>The fifteenth of Av was the <span class="gemarra-regular">day </span><span class="gemarra-regular">when </span>King <span class="gemarra-regular">Hoshea, son of Ela, removed </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">guards [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">pardesaot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that Jeroboam, </span>son of Nevat, <span class="gemarra-regular">place</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> on the roads</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> so that Israel </span>would <span class="gemarra-regular">not ascend </span>to Jerusalem <span class="gemarra-regular">for the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> pilgrimage Festival. </span>By doing so, King Hoshea renewed the access to Jerusalem for pilgrims.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Mattana says: </span>The fifteenth of Av was the <span class="gemarra-regular">day when the slain </span>victims <span class="gemarra-regular">of Beitar were afforded burial, </span>several years after they were killed and the Roman emperor Hadrian decreed that they were not to be buried (see <span class="it-text">Gittin</span> 57a). <span class="gemarra-regular">As Rav </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Mattana says: </span>On <span class="gemarra-regular">the day that the slain of Beita</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> were afforded burial, </span>the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">in Yavne instituted </span>the blessing: Blessed is He <span class="gemarra-regular">Who is good and Who does </span><span class="gemarra-regular">good</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> The term: <span class="gemarra-regular">Who is good, </span>is to give thanks <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the corpses <span class="gemarra-regular">did not decompose </span>despite the long delay; and the term: <span class="gemarra-regular">And Who does good, </span>is to give thanks <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the slain ones <span class="gemarra-regular">were </span>ultimately <span class="gemarra-regular">afforded burial</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba and Rav Yosef both say: </span>The fifteenth of Av is the <span class="gemarra-regular">day when they stop cutting woo</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for the arrangement </span>of wood on the altar. It <span class="gemarra-regular">is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Eliezer the Great says</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: Once the fifteenth of Av came, the force of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the sun would weaken</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>from this date <span class="gemarra-regular">they </span><span class="gemarra-regular">would not cut </span>additional <span class="gemarra-regular">wood for the arrangement, </span>because wood cut from then on would not dry properly and would be unfit for use in the Temple. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Menashe said</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: And </span>the people <span class="gemarra-regular">called </span>the fifteenth of Av: The <span class="gemarra-regular">day</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of the breaking of the sickle [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">maggal </span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as they did not need the lumbering tools until the following year.
The Gemara adds: <span class="gemarra-regular">From this </span>point <span class="gemarra-regular">forward, </span>when the nights lengthen, <span class="gemarra-regular">one who adds [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">demosif </span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> to his nightly Torah study <span class="gemarra-regular">will add </span><span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">y</span><span class="gemarra-italic">osif </span><span class="gemarra-regular">] </span>to his life, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he who does not add, </span>that person is <span class="gemarra-italic">yesif</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is the meaning of the term <span class="gemarra-italic">yesi</span><span class="gemarra-italic">f </span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rav Yosef teaches: </span>It means that <span class="gemarra-regular">his mother will bury him, </span>as he will die during his mother’s lifetime.
§ After discussing the generation of those who died in the wilderness, the Gemara mentions a tradition that relates to that generation. <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught: Seven </span>people <span class="gemarra-regular">spanne</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> in their lifetimes <span class="gemarra-regular">the whole world in its entirety, </span>i.e., their lives have spanned all of human history. <span class="gemarra-regular">Methuselah saw Adam </span>in his lifetime; <span class="gemarra-regular">Shem saw Methuselah; Jacob saw Shem; Amram saw</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Jacob; Ahijah the Shilonite saw Amram; Elija</span><span class="gemarra-regular">h</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> saw Ahijah </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the Shilonite; and </span>Elijah <span class="gemarra-regular">is still alive.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>is it true that <span class="gemarra-regular">Ahijah the Shilonite saw Amram? But it is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">written: “And no man among them remained, save Caleb, son </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of Jephunneh, and Joshua, son of Nun” </span>(Numbers 26:65). Since Amram died well before the Jewish people left Egypt, in order to have lived at the time of Amram, Ahijah would have had to be an adult at the time of the Exodus. How, then, could he have lived through the generation of those who died in the wilderness?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Hamnuna says: </span>The <span class="gemarra-regular">decree </span>of death pronounced for the generation of the spies <span class="gemarra-regular">was not decreed upon the tribe of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Levi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as it is written: “Your carcasses shall fall</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in this wilderness, and all those who were counted among</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> you, according to your whole number, from twenty years old</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and upward” </span>(Numbers 14:29). The verse is interpreted: The decree applies to <span class="gemarra-regular">one whose count </span>in the census <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">from the age of twenty </span>and up, <span class="gemarra-regular">excluding the tribe </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of Levi, whose count is from the age of thirty </span>and up. Ahijah was a Levite, and he was not subject to the decree.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>is it true that <span class="gemarra-regular">no </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">from the other tribes entered </span>Eretz Yisrael? <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span><span class="gemarra-regular">isn’t it taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Yair, son of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Manasseh, and Machir, son of Manasseh, were born in the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">days of Jacob, and they did not die until the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Jewish people entered Eretz Yisrael, as it is stated: “And </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the men of Ai killed of them about thirty-six </span><span class="gemarra-regular">men” </span>(Joshua 7:5). <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>concerning this verse, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is taught</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: Literally thirty-six </span>people were killed, this is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of Rabbi Yehuda.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Neḥemya said to him: But is it</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> stated </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">thirty-six </span>were killed? <span class="gemarra-regular">Isn’t it stated</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> nothing other than: “About thirty-six</span><span class="gemarra-regular">”</span> were killed? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, this </span>unusual term is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">Yair, son of Manasseh</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, who </span>was <span class="gemarra-regular">equivalent to the majority of the Sanhedrin, </span>whose maximum number of judges is seventy-one, of which thirty-six is a slight majority. Evidently, then, Yair, son of Manasseh also survived the time in the wilderness.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov said: </span>The <span class="gemarra-regular">decree </span>of death <span class="gemarra-regular">was not decreed either upon </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">less than twenty </span>years <span class="gemarra-regular">old or upon </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">more than sixty </span>years <span class="gemarra-regular">old </span>at the time of the sin of the spies. The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">Not upon </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">less than twenty </span>years <span class="gemarra-regular">old, as</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it is written: “From twenty years old and upward” </span>(Numbers 14:29). <span class="gemarra-regular">And not upon </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">more than sixty </span>years <span class="gemarra-regular">old, </span>because he <span class="gemarra-regular">learns </span>that there is a verbal analogy between <span class="gemarra-regular">“and upward” </span>in the verse cited, and <span class="gemarra-regular">“and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">upward” from </span>the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">valuations, </span>in the phrase: “From sixty years old and upward” (Leviticus 27:7). <span class="gemarra-regular">Just as there</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>concerning valuations, <span class="gemarra-regular">more than sixty </span>years <span class="gemarra-regular">old is comparable to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> less than twenty </span>years <span class="gemarra-regular">old, </span>as there is a distinct category of those between the ages of twenty and sixty, <span class="gemarra-regular">so too here, more than sixty </span>years <span class="gemarra-regular">old is comparable</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to less than twenty </span>years <span class="gemarra-regular">old </span>insofar as those older were not subject to the sentence. Yair, son of Manasseh, who was already older, did not die in the wilderness.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">A dilemma was raised before </span>the Sages: Was <span class="gemarra-regular">Eretz Yisrael divided according to </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">tribes</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> meaning that each of the twelve tribes received an equal portion, and the members of each tribe divided these tribal portions according to their numbers; <span class="gemarra-regular">or perhaps </span>Eretz Yisrael was <span class="gemarra-regular">divided </span><span class="gemarra-regular">according to men’s skulls, </span>meaning that a certain area of land was given to each individual, and the size of the tribal allotments was a function of the tribe’s population? 

Daf 122a

The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a proof. The verse states: “According to the lot shall their inheritance be divided <span class="gemarra-regular">between the more and the fewer” </span>(Numbers 26:56). Evidently, whether the tribe had many or few people, the tribe as a whole received a portion equal to that of every other tribe, and each individual within the tribe received a different amount of land than those in other tribes.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>another proof can be seen from that which <span class="gemarra-regular">is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Eretz Yisrael is destined to be divided among thirteen tribes</span> during the messianic era, unlike the division in the time of Joshua. <span class="gemarra-regular">As, initially </span>the land was <span class="gemarra-regular">divided only </span><span class="gemarra-regular">among twelve tribes, </span>as the Torah does not allot a portion to the tribe of Levi. The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the land was <span class="gemarra-regular">divided only with money, </span>such that each tribe that received a portion more valuable than average compensated another tribe that had received a portion less valuable than average, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is stated: “Between the more and the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">fewer.</span><span class="gemarra-regular">”</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rabbi Yehuda said: </span>The area of land whose yield is <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">se’a</span> of grain <span class="gemarra-regular">in Judea </span>is so valuable that it is <span class="gemarra-regular">equal </span>in value to the area necessary to produce <span class="gemarra-regular">five </span><span class="gemarra-italic">se’a</span> of grain <span class="gemarra-regular">in</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the Galilee.</span>
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the land was <span class="gemarra-regular">divided only by a lottery, as it is stated: “</span><span class="gemarra-regular">Only by lot </span>shall the land be divided” (Numbers 26:55). <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the land was <span class="gemarra-regular">divided only with </span>the <span class="gemarra-italic">Urim</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">VeTummim</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as it is stated: “By the pronouncement of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the lot” </span>(Numbers 26:56).
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">How </span>can <span class="gemarra-regular">these </span>texts be reconciled? One indicates that the land was divided by lottery and the other indicates that the land was divided with the <span class="it-text">Urim</span> <span class="it-text">VeTummim</span>. The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">Elazar</span> the High Priest was <span class="gemarra-regular">dressed </span>with the <span class="gemarra-italic">Urim</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">VeTummim</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Joshua and all the Jewish people </span>were <span class="gemarra-regular">standing before him</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, and </span>a lottery <span class="gemarra-regular">receptacle </span>containing the names <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">tribes</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>another lottery <span class="gemarra-regular">receptacle </span>containing the names <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">boundaries</span> of the twelve different regions of Eretz Yisrael were <span class="gemarra-regular">placed</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> before him.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>Elazar <span class="gemarra-regular">would ascertain </span>the assignments of land <span class="gemarra-regular">with the Divine Spirit and say, </span>in accordance with the notification of the <span class="it-text">Urim</span> <span class="it-text">VeTummim</span>: The name of the tribe <span class="gemarra-regular">Zebulun </span>now <span class="gemarra-regular">emerges </span>from the receptacle in the lottery, and the region whose <span class="gemarra-regular">boundary </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">Akko emerges with it</span> from the other receptacle. After stating this, he would <span class="gemarra-regular">mix</span> the lots <span class="gemarra-regular">in the receptacle of the tribes and </span>the lot of <span class="gemarra-regular">Zebulun </span>would <span class="gemarra-regular">emerge in his hand. </span>He would then <span class="gemarra-regular">mix </span>the lots <span class="gemarra-regular">in the receptacle of the boundaries</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, and </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">boundary </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">Akko </span>would <span class="gemarra-regular">emerge in his hand</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>Elazar <span class="gemarra-regular">would repeat </span>the process <span class="gemarra-regular">and ascertain </span>the assignments <span class="gemarra-regular">with the Divine Spirit and say: </span>The name of the tribe <span class="gemarra-regular">Naftali </span>now <span class="gemarra-regular">emerges, and </span>the region whose <span class="gemarra-regular">boundary </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">Ginnosar emerges with it </span>from the other receptacle. After stating this, he would <span class="gemarra-regular">mix </span>the lots <span class="gemarra-regular">in the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> receptacle of the tribes and </span>the lot of <span class="gemarra-regular">Naftali </span>would <span class="gemarra-regular">emerge in his hand. </span>He would then <span class="gemarra-regular">mix </span>the lots <span class="gemarra-regular">in the receptacle of the boundaries, and </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">boundary </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">Ginnosar </span>would <span class="gemarra-regular">emerge in his hand. And so </span>he would proceed for <span class="gemarra-regular">each and every tribe.</span>
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">And unlike the division in this </span><span class="gemarra-regular">world, </span>i.e., in the time of Joshua, will be the <span class="gemarra-regular">division </span>of portions <span class="gemarra-regular">in the World-to-Come, </span>i.e., in the messianic era. In <span class="gemarra-regular">this world, </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">a person has a field of grain, he does not</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> have a field </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">an orchard; </span>if he has <span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> field </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">an orchard, he does not have a field</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of grain. </span>This is so because each climate and variety of soil is suitable for a different type of produce. But <span class="gemarra-regular">in the World-to-Come, you do not have</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> any person who does not have </span>a portion in Eretz Yisrael <span class="gemarra-regular">in the mountain, and in the lowland, and in</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the valley, as it is stated: “The gate of Reuben</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, one</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the gate of Judah, one; the gate of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Levi, one” </span>(Ezekiel 48:31), which is to say that everyone’s portion will be the same. And <span class="gemarra-regular">the Holy </span><span class="gemarra-regular">One, Blessed be He, will distribute it to them personally, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">as it is stated: “And these are their portions, says </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the Lord” </span>(Ezekiel 48:29). This is the conclusion of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>.
