The Gemara states its proof: <span class="gemarra-regular">In any event, </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches: As initially</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>the land was <span class="gemarra-regular">divided only among </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">twelve tribes. Conclude</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that the land <span class="gemarra-regular">was divided according to</span> the <span class="gemarra-regular">tribes</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and not apportioned directly to each person. The Gemara affirms: <span class="gemarra-regular">Conclude from </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that this is the case.
§ The Gemara returns to analyze the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> just cited. <span class="gemarra-regular">The Master says </span>above: <span class="gemarra-regular">Eretz Yisrael is destined to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">be divided among thirteen tribes. </span>The Gemara asks: As to <span class="gemarra-regular">the other, </span>thirteenth portion, <span class="gemarra-regular">for whom </span>is it? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥisda </span><span class="gemarra-regular">said: For the king</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as it is written: “And </span><span class="gemarra-regular">they that serve the city, out of all the tribes </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of Israel, shall till it” </span>(Ezekiel 48:19). The verse is understood as meaning that the nation will collectively allot a portion to the king, who serves the needs of the nation. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa said to Abaye: </span>Why is the verse interpreted in this way? <span class="gemarra-regular">Say </span>that the verse speaks of <span class="gemarra-regular">mere wages [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">rongar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> so that the king has rights to collect taxes, but not an actual portion of land. The Gemara answers: That possibility should <span class="gemarra-regular">not enter your </span><span class="gemarra-regular">mind, as it is written: “And the residue shall be </span><span class="gemarra-regular">for the prince, on the one side and on the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">other of the sacred offering and of the possession of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the city” </span>(Ezekiel 48:21). Based on this latter verse, the former verse speaks of a specific tract of land.
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> also states: <span class="gemarra-regular">And</span> the land was <span class="gemarra-regular">divided only with money, as it is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> stated: “Between the more and the fewer.” With regard to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> what </span>is this said? <span class="gemarra-regular">If we say </span>it is with regard <span class="gemarra-regular">to beauty and ugliness, </span>i.e., that those who receive inferior-quality land received monetary compensation from the others, <span class="gemarra-regular">is that to say we are dealing with fools [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">beshufetanei</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> who would agree to take inferior-quality land in exchange for more money? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>it is said <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to </span>the difference between land that is <span class="gemarra-regular">close </span>to Jerusalem <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>land that is <span class="gemarra-regular">far </span>from Jerusalem. Those whose property was close to Jerusalem compensated those whose property was farther away.
The Gemara notes: There <span class="gemarra-regular">is</span> a dispute between <span class="gemarra-italic">tanna’im</span> with regard to the manner by which this compensation was given: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Eliezer says: </span>The tribes <span class="gemarra-regular">compensated </span>each other <span class="gemarra-regular">with money. Rabbi Yehoshua says: </span>The tribes <span class="gemarra-regular">compensated </span>each other <span class="gemarra-regular">with land </span>by giving extra land to those whose portions were in less advantageous locations.
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> also states: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the land was <span class="gemarra-regular">divided only by</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a lottery, as it is stated: “Only by lot </span>shall the land be divided” (Numbers 26:55). The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">taught: </span>In the phrase <span class="gemarra-regular">“only by lot,” </span>the term “only” indicates that <span class="gemarra-regular">Joshua and Caleb </span>are <span class="gemarra-regular">excluded </span>from this proviso. The Gemara asks: With regard <span class="gemarra-regular">to what </span>were they excluded? <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span><span class="gemarra-regular">we say that </span>they did <span class="gemarra-regular">not take </span>portions <span class="gemarra-regular">at all, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">now </span>that it has already been taught that they <span class="gemarra-regular">took </span>the portions of the spies (118b) <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>were <span class="gemarra-regular">not their</span> own, <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>to teach that they took <span class="gemarra-regular">their own </span>portions? It goes without saying that they did collect their portions. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>the exclusion teaches <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>they <span class="gemarra-regular">did</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not take </span>portions <span class="gemarra-regular">by a lottery but according to </span>explicit designation by <span class="gemarra-regular">the Lord. </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">Joshua, </span>this is <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is written: “According to the commandment of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the Lord they gave him the city that he asked</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, even Timnath Serah in the hill-country of Ephraim” </span>(Joshua 19:50). 

Daf 122b

The Gemara interjects: <span class="gemarra-regular">It is written </span>concerning Joshua’s burial: “And they buried him in the border of his inheritance in Timnath <span class="gemarra-regular">Serah” </span>(Joshua 24:30), <span class="gemarra-regular">and it is written: </span>“And they buried him in the border of his inheritance in Timnath <span class="gemarra-regular">Heres” </span>(Judges 2:9). Why is the name changed? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Elazar says: Initially, its fruits </span>were as dry <span class="gemarra-regular">as clay</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">keḥeres</span><span class="gemarra-regular">], and ultimately</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> its fruits </span>were so plump that they were <span class="gemarra-regular">spoiling [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">masriḥin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]. And there are </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">who say</span> the opposite: <span class="gemarra-regular">Initially, </span>the fruits were <span class="gemarra-regular">spoiling </span>prematurely, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">ultimately, </span>they lasted as long <span class="gemarra-regular">as clay </span>without spoiling.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Caleb </span>also received his portion directly from God and not through the lottery, <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span><span class="gemarra-regular">it is written: “And they gave Hebron to Caleb, as </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Moses had spoken; and he drove out from there the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">three sons of the giant” </span>(Judges 1:20). The Gemara asks about this verse: But <span class="gemarra-regular">Hebron was a city of refug</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> that belonged to the priests, as described in the book of Joshua (21:13); how could it have been given to Caleb? <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said: Its outskirts [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">parvaraha</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., only the fields and vineyards lying beyond the city limits, were given to Caleb. <span class="gemarra-regular">As it is written: “But </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the fields of the city, and the villages thereof, they </span><span class="gemarra-regular">gave to Caleb the son of Jephunneh for his possession” </span>(Joshua 21:12).
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">Both the son and the daughter </span>of the deceased are included <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">inheritance. But </span>the difference is <span class="gemarra-regular">that the </span>firstborn <span class="gemarra-regular">son takes a double </span>portion <span class="gemarra-regular">of the property of the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">father</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and he does </span><span class="gemarra-regular">not take a double </span>portion <span class="gemarra-regular">of the property of the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">mother. And </span>another difference is that <span class="gemarra-regular">the daughters are </span><span class="gemarra-regular">sustaine</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">from the property of the father </span>after he dies, as it is a mandatory condition of their mother’s marriage contract that they are to be sustained even before the estate is disbursed to the children, <span class="gemarra-regular">but the </span>daughters <span class="gemarra-regular">are not sustained from the property of the mother, </span>which is all inherited by the sons.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara analyzes the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is meant by the first clause of the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">Both the son and the daughter </span>of the deceased are included <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">inheritance? If we </span><span class="gemarra-regular">say that </span>they <span class="gemarra-regular">inherit together, didn’t we learn </span>in a mishna (115a): <span class="gemarra-regular">A son precedes a daughter? </span>Additionally, <span class="gemarra-regular">all descendants of a son precede a daughter. </span>It is clear that a daughter does not inherit together with a son.
<span class="gemarra-italic">Nafsham</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> mnemonic </span>for the names of the Sages cited in the following discussion: Naḥman; Pappa; Ashi; Mar. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> says: This </span>is what the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">is saying: Both the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> son and the daughter take in </span>inheritance the property <span class="gemarra-regular">due</span> to their father <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>they would take <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>inheritance the property that he had <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">possession.</span>
The Gemara questions this explanation: <span class="gemarra-regular">We </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">learn </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">as wel</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span> in a mishna (116b): <span class="gemarra-regular">Zelophehad’s daughters took three </span><span class="gemarra-regular">portions </span>of land <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">inheritance </span>of Eretz Yisrael: <span class="gemarra-regular">Their </span><span class="gemarra-regular">father’s portion </span>that he received <span class="gemarra-regular">because he was among </span><span class="gemarra-regular">those who left Egypt; and his portion </span>that he received <span class="gemarra-regular">with his brothers in </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">property of Hepher, </span>their father, although Zelophehad predeceased his father and never was in possession of the inheritance from Hepher; and an additional portion that he received from Hepher because he was a firstborn. It is already taught in that mishna that property due to the deceased is inherited in the same manner as property possessed by the deceased.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And furthermore, </span>if the explanation of the mishna is as stated by Rav Naḥman, <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>is meant by the phrase: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>the difference is that the firstborn son takes a double portion of the property of the father, and he does not take a double portion of the property of the mother? According to Rav Naḥman’s explanation, what is the contrast between the two clauses in the mishna?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Rav Pappa said: This </span>is what the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">is saying: Both the son and the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">daughter </span>of the deceased <span class="gemarra-regular">take a portion of the firstborn</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
The Gemara questions this explanation: <span class="gemarra-regular">We </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">learn </span>this in a mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">as well </span>(116b), which explains the third portion taken by the daughters of Zelophehad: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>they took an additional portion that he received from Hepher, <span class="gemarra-regular">as he was a firstborn, </span>and a firstborn <span class="gemarra-regular">takes two portions </span>of inheritance from his father. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span><span class="gemarra-regular">furthermore, </span>if the explanation of the mishna is as stated by Rav Pappa, <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>is meant by the phrase: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>the difference is that the firstborn son takes a double portion of the property of the father, and he does not take a double portion of the property of the mother? According to this explanation as well, the first clause of the mishna has nothing to do with inheriting from the mother.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Rav Ashi said: This </span>is what the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">is saying: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">both </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a son among the sons, and a daughter among the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">daughters, if </span>the father <span class="gemarra-regular">says: </span>This particular child <span class="gemarra-regular">shall inherit</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> all my property, his statement stands. </span>A father can do so for any one son, or, when there are no sons, for any one daughter.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">In accordance with whose </span>opinion does Rav Ashi say this? Is it <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka? </span>The Gemara challenges: <span class="gemarra-regular">But</span> the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches this later </span>(130a), as <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan </span><span class="gemarra-regular">ben Beroka says: If </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">said about </span>another <span class="gemarra-regular">who is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">fit to inherit </span>from <span class="gemarra-regular">him </span>that the named individual should inherit all his property, <span class="gemarra-regular">his statement stands, </span>but if one said it <span class="gemarra-regular">about </span>another <span class="gemarra-regular">who is unfit to inherit </span>from <span class="gemarra-regular">him, his statement does not stand. </span>It is not reasonable to say that this mishna is stating the same <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that is recorded in the later mishna in the name of Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if you would say that the</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> here taught us an unattributed </span>mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with</span> the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka, </span>in order to demonstrate that his opinion is accepted as <span class="it-text">halakha</span>, this would not establish the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in accordance with his opinion. The reason is that this would be an instance of <span class="gemarra-regular">an</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> unattributed </span>mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">and thereafter </span>a mishnaic <span class="gemarra-regular">dispute </span>concerning the same matter, as in the later mishna there is a <span class="it-text">tanna</span> who disagrees with the ruling of Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka; <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>in an instance of <span class="gemarra-regular">an unattributed </span>mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">thereafter </span>a mishnaic <span class="gemarra-regular">dispute, the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">not in accordance </span><span class="gemarra-regular">with the unattributed </span>mishna.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And furthermore, </span>if the explanation of the mishna is as stated by Rav Ashi, <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>is meant by the clause: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>the difference is that the firstborn son takes a double portion of the property of the father, and he does not take a double portion of the property of the mother? According to this explanation as well, the first clause of the mishna has nothing to do with inheriting from the mother.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Mar bar Rav Ashi </span><span class="gemarra-regular">said: This </span>is what the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">is saying: Both the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">son and the daughter are equal </span>in their rights both <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">property of the mother and with </span><span class="gemarra-regular">regard to </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">property of the father. </span>Sons and daughters can inherit from either fathers or mothers. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>the differences are that <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>firstborn <span class="gemarra-regular">son takes a double </span>portion <span class="gemarra-regular">of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the property of the father, and he does not take</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a double </span>portion <span class="gemarra-regular">of the property of the mother, </span>and that the daughters are sustained from their father’s estate before it is disbursed to the children, but they are not sustained from the property of their mother.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: When the verse states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“But he shall </span><span class="gemarra-regular">acknowledge the firstborn, the son of the hated, by giving </span><span class="gemarra-regular">him a double portion of all that he has” </span>(Deuteronomy 21:17), this means the firstborn receives <span class="gemarra-regular">double </span>the property received <span class="gemarra-regular">by </span>any other <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>inheritor. The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> analyzes this statement: <span class="gemarra-regular">Do you say </span>the firstborn receives <span class="gemarra-regular">double </span>the property received <span class="gemarra-regular">by </span>any <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>inheritor, <span class="gemarra-regular">or rather, is it a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> double </span>portion <span class="gemarra-regular">of all the property, </span>such that the firstborn receives two-thirds of the entire estate, which is twice the portion left for the other inheritors to divide between themselves? The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">And this </span>question can be resolved through <span class="gemarra-regular">logical inference: </span>

Daf 123a

There may be times when a firstborn takes <span class="gemarra-regular">his portion </span>of the inheritance, dividing the estate <span class="gemarra-regular">with one </span>other brother, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>there may be times when a firstborn takes <span class="gemarra-regular">his portion </span>of the inheritance, dividing the estate <span class="gemarra-regular">with five </span>brothers, and there is no indication that the Torah differentiates between the manner in which the respective firstborns collect in each scenario. Therefore, <span class="gemarra-regular">just as </span>when a firstborn takes <span class="gemarra-regular">his portion, </span>dividing the estate <span class="gemarra-regular">with one</span> other brother, he receives <span class="gemarra-regular">double </span>the property received <span class="gemarra-regular">by </span><span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>inheritor, <span class="gemarra-regular">so too, </span>when a firstborn takes <span class="gemarra-regular">his portion </span>of the inheritance, dividing the estate <span class="gemarra-regular">with five </span>brothers, he receives <span class="gemarra-regular">double </span>the property received <span class="gemarra-regular">by one </span>inheritor.
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> suggests the opposite logical derivation: <span class="gemarra-regular">Or </span>perhaps <span class="gemarra-regular">go this way: </span>There may be times when a firstborn takes <span class="gemarra-regular">his portion </span>of the inheritance, dividing the estate <span class="gemarra-regular">with one </span>other brother, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>there may be times when a firstborn takes <span class="gemarra-regular">his portion </span>of the inheritance, dividing the estate <span class="gemarra-regular">with five </span>brothers. Therefore, <span class="gemarra-regular">just as </span>when a firstborn takes <span class="gemarra-regular">his portion, </span>dividing the estate <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span><span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>other brother, he receives <span class="gemarra-regular">a double </span>portion <span class="gemarra-regular">of all</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the property, so too </span>when a firstborn takes <span class="gemarra-regular">his </span><span class="gemarra-regular">portion </span>of the inheritance, dividing the estate <span class="gemarra-regular">with five </span>brothers, he receives <span class="gemarra-regular">a double </span>portion <span class="gemarra-regular">of all the property.</span>
As the logical inference can lead to either conclusion, the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is determined by a derivation from a verse. <span class="gemarra-regular">The verse states: “Then it shall be</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, in the day that he causes his sons to inherit</span><span class="gemarra-regular">” </span>(Deuteronomy 21:16). As the next verse spells out: “But he shall acknowledge the firstborn, the son of the hated, by giving him a double portion of all that he has” (Deuteronomy 21:17), the former verse is ostensibly redundant. The additional verse is therefore understood as an inclusion: <span class="gemarra-regular">The Torah </span><span class="gemarra-regular">increased inheritance with regard to </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">brothers, </span>indicating that the more brothers there are, the greater the portion they collect from the entire estate. <span class="gemarra-regular">Therefore, you should not reason in</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> accordance with the final formulation, </span>in which the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> suggests that the firstborn inherits twice as much as all the other brothers combined, <span class="gemarra-regular">but in accordance with the first formulation</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>according to which the firstborn inherits twice as much as each other brother.
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> reinforces this statement by citing additional verses: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">states: “And the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> sons of Reuben the firstborn of Israel, for he was</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the firstborn; but, inasmuch as he defiled his father’s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> couch, his birthright [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">bekhorato</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] was given to the sons of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Joseph the son of Israel, yet not so that he</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> was to be reckoned in the genealogy as firstborn” </span>(I Chronicles 5:1). <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the following verse <span class="gemarra-regular">states: “For </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Judah prevailed above his brothers, and the prince came of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">him; but the birthright [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">vehabekhora</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] was Joseph’s” </span>(I Chronicles 5:2).
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> derives: <span class="gemarra-regular">Birthright, </span>i.e., firstborn status, <span class="gemarra-regular">is stated </span>here <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to Joseph, and birthright is stated </span>in another verse concerning the double portion <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>the later <span class="gemarra-regular">generations: </span>“By giving him a double portion of all that he has, for he is the first-fruits of his strength, the birthright [<span class="it-text">habekhora</span>] is his” (Deuteronomy 21:17). <span class="gemarra-regular">Just as</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the birthright stated with regard to Joseph </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">double </span>the property received <span class="gemarra-regular">by one </span>inheritor, as the Gemara will explain, <span class="gemarra-regular">so too the birthright stated with regard to </span>the later <span class="gemarra-regular">generations </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">double </span>the property received <span class="gemarra-regular">by one </span>inheritor.
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> cites additional related verses: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>with regard to Jacob’s bequest to Joseph, the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">states: “Moreover I have given to you</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> one portion above your brothers, which I took out of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the hand of the Amorite with my sword and with</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> my bow” </span>(Genesis 48:22). The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> explains the verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>is it <span class="gemarra-regular">so that </span>Jacob <span class="gemarra-regular">took </span>the portion <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span><span class="gemarra-regular">his sword and with his bow? But isn’t it</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> already stated: </span>“Through You do we push down our adversaries; through Your name do we trample those that rise against us. <span class="gemarra-regular">For I trust not in my bow, neither</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> can my sword save me” </span>(Psalms 44:6–7)? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>what is the meaning of “with <span class="gemarra-regular">my sword”? This </span>is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">prayer</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> What is the meaning of “with <span class="gemarra-regular">my bow”? This </span>is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">petition. </span>This concludes the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>.
The Gemara analyzes the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is the reason the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> cites additional proofs, introducing them with the term: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">states? </span>The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">And if you would say </span>that the proof from the verse: “Then it shall be, in the day that he causes his sons to inherit” is not valid, as perhaps <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>verse <span class="gemarra-regular">comes to </span>teach the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka </span>that a father may designate property for whichever child he desires, then <span class="gemarra-regular">come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a separate proof: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And the sons of Reuben</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the firstborn of Israel…</span>his birthright was given to the sons of Joseph the son of Israel.” As Joseph’s birthright was that his sons received two portions, evidently the birthright of the firstborn is that he receives double the amount received by one inheritor.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if you would say </span>that this is not a proof either, as <span class="gemarra-regular">we do not</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> derive </span>the meaning of the term: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Birthright [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">bekhora</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]” </span>(see Deuteronomy 21:17) <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the similar but not identical term of: <span class="gemarra-regular">“His birthright [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">bekhorato</span><span class="gemarra-regular">],” come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a proof from the term employed in the following phrase from the verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“But the birthright [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">vehabekhora</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] was Joseph’s.”</span>
The Gemara continues to explicate the biblical citations in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">And if you would say </span>that this is not a proof either, as concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">Joseph himself, from where </span>may it be learned <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>his birthright <span class="gemarra-regular">was double </span>the property received <span class="gemarra-regular">by one </span>inheritor? <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a proof: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Moreover I have given to you one portion above </span><span class="gemarra-regular">your brothers,” </span>indicating that Joseph received one more portion than each of the other sons of Jacob.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa said to Abaye: </span>Why not <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that the term “one portion” is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">mere palm tree </span>or some other relatively small extra gift, instead of a full, equal share? Abaye <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">For you, </span>i.e., to answer your question, the <span class="gemarra-regular">verse</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> states: “Ephraim and Manasseh, even as Reuben and Simeon, shall</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> be mine” </span>(Genesis 48:5). Evidently, Joseph’s children together received portions equal to that of Reuben and Simeon together, i.e., two full portions.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ḥelbo asked Rabbi Shmuel bar Naḥmani: What did</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Jacob see that he took </span>the status as <span class="gemarra-regular">firstborn from</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Reuben and gave it to Joseph? </span>The Gemara wonders: What does he mean, <span class="gemarra-regular">what did </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">see? </span>The matter is <span class="gemarra-regular">written </span>explicitly: <span class="gemarra-regular">“But, inasmuch as he defiled his father’</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s couch, </span>his birthright was given to the sons of Joseph” (I Chronicles 5:1). <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>Rabbi Ḥelbo’s question was: <span class="gemarra-regular">What did he see that he gave it </span>specifically <span class="gemarra-regular">to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Joseph?</span>
Rabbi Shmuel bar Naḥmani answered Rabbi Ḥelbo: <span class="gemarra-regular">I will tell you a parable. To what is this</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> matter comparable? To a homeowner who raised an orphan in</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> his home. Eventually, that orphan became wealthy and said: I</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> will provide benefit to the homeowner from my property. </span>Similarly, since Joseph sustained Jacob in Egypt for a number of years, Jacob saw fit to repay the kindness. Rabbi Ḥelbo <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: And if Reuben did not sin, </span>would Jacob <span class="gemarra-regular">not have provided any benefit to Joseph? </span>It cannot be that Jacob repaid Joseph only as a result of Reuben’ sin.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, doesn’t your teacher Rabbi Yonatan say</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> like this: It was appropriate for </span>the child receiving the status of <span class="gemarra-regular">firstborn to emerge from Rachel, as it is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> written: “These are the generations of Jacob, Joseph” </span>(Genesis 37:2), indicating that Joseph was Jacob’s primary progeny. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Leah advanced </span>ahead of Rachel <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>appeals for <span class="gemarra-regular">mercy, </span>i.e., with prayer, and thereby earned the status as firstborn for her firstborn. <span class="gemarra-regular">But because of </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">modesty that Rachel </span><span class="gemarra-regular">possessed, the Holy One, Blessed be He, returned </span>the status as firstborn <span class="gemarra-regular">to her. </span>This is why Jacob gave the status as firstborn to Joseph.
The Gemara explains this answer: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>does it mean that <span class="gemarra-regular">Leah advanced </span>ahead of Rachel <span class="gemarra-regular">with mercy? As </span><span class="gemarra-regular">it is written: “And Leah’s eyes were weak [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">rakkot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]” </span>(Genesis 29:17). <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is the meaning of <span class="gemarra-regular">“</span><span class="gemarra-italic">rakkot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">”? If </span><span class="gemarra-regular">we say </span>that her eyes were <span class="gemarra-regular">literally weak, </span>is it <span class="gemarra-regular">possible </span>that the verse would say that? <span class="gemarra-regular">The verse </span>there <span class="gemarra-regular">did not speak to the disparagement of </span>even <span class="gemarra-regular">a non-</span><span class="gemarra-regular">kosher animal, as it is written: “From the pure animals </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and from the animals that are lacking purity” </span>(Genesis 7:8). The verse states: “That are lacking purity” rather than stating explicitly and disparagingly: That are impure. If that is so with regard to animals, <span class="gemarra-regular">did the verse speak </span>here <span class="gemarra-regular">to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the disparagement of the righteous? Rather, Rabbi Elazar says:</span> The term alludes to the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that her gifts, </span>i.e., the gifts given to her descendants, e.g., the priesthood and the monarchy, <span class="gemarra-regular">were long-lasting [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">arukkot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as they were passed down from generation to generation.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says </span>that there is a different explanation of the verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">Actually, </span>the verse means that her eyes <span class="gemarra-regular">were literally weak, and </span>this is <span class="gemarra-regular">not a denigration</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of her but a praise of her. As she would</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> hear people at the crossroads, </span>coming from the land of Canaan, <span class="gemarra-regular">who would say: Rebecca has two sons, </span>and her brother <span class="gemarra-regular">Laban has two daughters; </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">older </span>daughter will be married <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">older </span>son, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">younger </span>daughter will be married <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">younger </span>son.
Rav continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">And she would sit at the crossroads and ask: What</span> are <span class="gemarra-regular">the deeds of </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">older </span>son? The passersby would answer: <span class="gemarra-regular">He is an evil man, </span>and he <span class="gemarra-regular">robs </span><span class="gemarra-regular">people. </span>She would ask: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>are <span class="gemarra-regular">the deeds of </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">younger </span>son? They would answer: He is <span class="gemarra-regular">“a quiet </span><span class="gemarra-regular">man, dwelling in tents” </span>(Genesis 25:27). <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>because she was so distraught at the prospect of marrying the evil brother, <span class="gemarra-regular">she would cry </span>and pray for mercy <span class="gemarra-regular">until her </span><span class="gemarra-regular">eyelashes fell out. </span>Since the weakness of her eyes was due to this cause, characterizing her eyes as weak constitutes praise. This is Leah’s prayer for mercy to which Rabbi Yonatan referred.
The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>her desire not to marry Esau is the basis of that <span class="gemarra-regular">which is written: “And the Lord saw that Leah was</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> hated, </span>and He opened her womb” (Genesis 29:31). <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is the meaning of <span class="gemarra-regular">“hated”? If we say </span>that she was <span class="gemarra-regular">literally hated</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> is it <span class="gemarra-regular">possible? The</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> verse </span>there <span class="gemarra-regular">did not speak to the disparagement of </span>even <span class="gemarra-regular">a non-kosher animal, </span>so <span class="gemarra-regular">did the verse </span>here <span class="gemarra-regular">speak</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to the disparagement of the righteous? Rather, the Holy </span><span class="gemarra-regular">One, Blessed be He, saw that the behavior of Esau </span><span class="gemarra-regular">was hated by her, </span>and therefore: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And He opened her</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> womb.”</span>
The Gemara now explains the second part of Rabbi Yonatan’s explanation: <span class="gemarra-regular">And what </span>was a demonstration of the <span class="gemarra-regular">modesty that Rachel possessed? As it is written: “And</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Jacob told Rachel that he was her father’s brother</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, and that he was Rebecca’s son” </span>(Genesis 29:12). The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t he the son of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">her father’s sister? </span>Why did he say that he was her father’s brother? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>Jacob and Rachel had the following exchange: Jacob <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Rachel: <span class="gemarra-regular">Will you marry </span><span class="gemarra-regular">me? </span>Rachel <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Yes, but </span>my <span class="gemarra-regular">father is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a deceitful person, and you cannot defeat him.</span>
Jacob <span class="gemarra-regular">said to her: What is his </span>method of <span class="gemarra-regular">deceit </span>of which I need be aware? Rachel <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: I have a sister who is older </span><span class="gemarra-regular">than me, and he will not marry me </span>off <span class="gemarra-regular">before</span> he marries <span class="gemarra-regular">her </span>off, even if he promises that he will do so. Jacob <span class="gemarra-regular">said to her: I am </span><span class="gemarra-regular">his brother, </span>i.e., equal, <span class="gemarra-regular">in deceit</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and he will not be able to deceive me. That is why Jacob said that he was “her father’s brother.” Rachel <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: But is it permitted for the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">righteous to act deceitfully? </span>Jacob answered her: <span class="gemarra-regular">Yes, </span>in certain circumstances. As the verse states concerning God: <span class="gemarra-regular">“With the pure</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> You show Yourself pure; and with the crooked You show</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Yourself subtle” </span>(II Samuel 22:27). Therefore, to counter Laban’s deceit, Jacob <span class="gemarra-regular">gave </span>Rachel secret <span class="gemarra-regular">signs </span>to prove to him that she was the one marrying him.
Laban did in fact attempt to have Jacob marry Leah instead of marrying Rachel. <span class="gemarra-regular">When </span>Laban’s associates <span class="gemarra-regular">were bringing Leah up </span>to the wedding canopy to marry Jacob, Rachel <span class="gemarra-regular">thought: Now my</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> sister will be humiliated </span>when Jacob discovers that she is the one marrying him. Therefore, Rachel <span class="gemarra-regular">gave </span>the signs <span class="gemarra-regular">to</span> Leah. <span class="gemarra-regular">And this is as it is written: “And it</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> came to pass in the morning that, behold, it was</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Leah” </span>(Genesis 29:25). This verse is difficult, as <span class="gemarra-regular">by </span><span class="gemarra-regular">inference, </span>should one derive <span class="gemarra-regular">that until now she was not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Leah? Rather, through the signs that Jacob gave to Rachel </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and that she gave to Leah, he did not know </span>it was <span class="gemarra-regular">she until that moment. </span>This is the modesty of Rachel to which Rabbi Yonatan was referring.
§ The Gemara continues its discussion of Jacob’s family. <span class="gemarra-regular">Abba Ḥalifa Karoya asked Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba: In the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> total </span>tally of Jacob’s family members who descended to Egypt, <span class="gemarra-regular">you find seventy, </span>as stated in the verse: “All the souls of the house of Jacob, that came into Egypt, were seventy” (Genesis 46:27). By contrast, <span class="gemarra-regular">in their</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> individual </span>listing, when the family members of each of his sons are listed by name, <span class="gemarra-regular">you find seventy-less-one</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>How can this be resolved? Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba <span class="gemarra-regular">said</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to him: A twin </span>sister <span class="gemarra-regular">was </span>born <span class="gemarra-regular">with Dinah, as</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it is written: “And [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ve’et</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] his daughter Dinah” </span>(Genesis 46:15). The term <span class="it-text">et</span> implies an unspecified additional person. Abba Ḥalifa Karoya replied: <span class="gemarra-regular">If that is so, </span>one would have to say that <span class="gemarra-regular">a twin </span>sister <span class="gemarra-regular">was </span>born <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Benjamin, as it is written: </span>

Daf 123b

“And he lifted up his eyes, and saw <span class="gemarra-italic">et</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Benjamin his brother, his mother’s </span><span class="gemarra-regular">son” </span>(Genesis 43:29), which would render the count of seventy in-correct. Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba <span class="gemarra-regular">said: </span>There <span class="gemarra-regular">was a goodly</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> pearl [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">margalit</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in my hand, and you are trying</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to have me lose it. </span>He continued: <span class="gemarra-regular">So said </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ḥama bar Ḥanina: This </span>missing seventieth person is <span class="gemarra-regular">Jochebed, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">whose conception was on the journey, </span>as the family of Jacob descended to Egypt, <span class="gemarra-regular">and she was born within the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> walls, </span>i.e., in Egypt, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is stated: </span>“And the name of Amram’s wife was Jochebed, the daughter of Levi, <span class="gemarra-regular">who was born to Levi in Egypt</span><span class="gemarra-regular">” </span>(Numbers 26:59). <span class="gemarra-regular">Her birth </span>was <span class="gemarra-regular">in Egypt, but her</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> conception </span>was <span class="gemarra-regular">not in Egypt. </span>Accordingly, the family had seventy persons upon arrival, but she could not have been listed as descending to Egypt.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ḥelbo asked Rabbi Shmuel bar </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Naḥmani: It is written: “And it came to pass, when </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rachel gave birth to Joseph, </span>that Jacob said to Laban: Send me away, that I may go to my own place, and to my country” (Genesis 30:25). <span class="gemarra-regular">What was different</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> when Joseph was born, </span>that Jacob decided only then to return home? Rabbi Shmuel bar Naḥmani <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Jacob</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> our patriarch saw </span>prophetically <span class="gemarra-regular">that the descendants of Esau </span>will be <span class="gemarra-regular">delivered only to the hand of the descendants of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Joseph, as it is stated: “And the house of Jacob</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> shall be a fire, and the house of Joseph a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> flame, and the house of Esau for straw, </span>and they shall kindle in them, and devour them” (Obadiah 1:18). Jacob had left Eretz Yisrael to escape Esau, but he now felt confident that he could return without endangering his family.
Rabbi Ḥelbo <span class="gemarra-regular">raised an objection to </span>Rabbi Shmuel bar Naḥmani: Concering a battle between the Jewish people and the nation of Amalek, who descend from Esau, the verse states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And David smote them from the twilight even to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the evening of the next day” </span>(I Samuel 30:17). David was from the tribe of Judah, yet he was able to defeat the descendants of Esau. Rabbi Shmuel bar Naḥmani <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Whoever read </span>and taught <span class="gemarra-regular">Prophets to you</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> did not read </span>and teach <span class="gemarra-regular">Writings to you, as it</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is written: “As he went to Ziklag, there fell to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> him of Manasseh, Adnah, and Jozabad, and Jediael, and Michael</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, and Jozabad, and Elihu, and Zillethai, captains of thousands that</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> were of Manasseh, </span>and they helped David against the troop” (I Chronicles 12:21–2). The verse in Writings teaches that David’s campaign against Esau was led by Joseph’s descendants, from the family of Manasseh.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef raises an objection: </span>Another verse indicates that the descendants of Simeon also have the ability to defeat the descendants of Esau: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And some of them, even of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the sons of Simeon, five hundred men, went to Mount </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Seir, having for their captains Pelatiah, and Ne’ariah, and Rephaiah, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and Uzziel, the sons of Ishi. And they struck the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">remnant of the Amalekites that escaped, and dwelled there until </span><span class="gemarra-regular">this day” </span>(I Chronicles 4:42–43). <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba bar Sheila said </span>in response: <span class="gemarra-regular">Ishi came from </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">children of Manasseh, as </span><span class="gemarra-regular">it is written: And the sons of Manasseh: Hepher and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Ishi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> taught </span>(<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span> 7:4–5): <span class="gemarra-regular">The firstborn </span>priest <span class="gemarra-regular">takes a double</span> portion <span class="gemarra-regular">of the foreleg, and of the jaw, and of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the maw</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> which are given to a priest from all slaughtered non-sacred cattle, sheep, and goats (see Deuteronomy 18:3). <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>a firstborn, whether he is a priest or non-priest, takes a double portion <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span>his father’s <span class="gemarra-regular">sacrificial </span>animals <span class="gemarra-regular">and of the enhancement of the property </span>that occurred <span class="gemarra-regular">after the death of their father.</span>
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">How so? </span>To what type of enhancement is this referring? If <span class="gemarra-regular">their father left them</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a cow </span>that was <span class="gemarra-regular">leased or rented in the possession</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of others, or if it was grazing in the meadow</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and it gave birth</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> then the <span class="gemarra-regular">firstborn takes</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a double </span>portion of the rental income or of the calf. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if the inheritors <span class="gemarra-regular">built homes or planted vineyards</span> after their father’s death, thereby enhancing the property, the <span class="gemarra-regular">firstborn does not take a double </span>portion. This is not considered enhancement of the father’s property, but profit due to their actions.
The Gemara analyzes the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: Concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>right to collect a double portion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the foreleg, and the jaw, and the maw, what are </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the circumstances? If </span>they <span class="gemarra-regular">came into the possession of their </span><span class="gemarra-regular">father, </span>then it is <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious </span>that the firstborn collects a double portion. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if </span>they <span class="gemarra-regular">did not come into the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">possession of their father, </span>then these items <span class="gemarra-regular">are </span>merely property <span class="gemarra-regular">due </span>to their father, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the firstborn does not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">take </span>a double portion <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span>property <span class="gemarra-regular">due </span>to the deceased <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>he does the property his father <span class="gemarra-regular">possessed.</span>
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Here, we </span><span class="gemarra-regular">are dealing with associates of the priesthood</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., people who have an arrangement with a specific priest to give him their priestly gifts. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>it was a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">was slaughtered while the father was alive, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> of this <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">holds: </span>Priestly <span class="gemarra-regular">gifts that </span><span class="gemarra-regular">were not </span>yet <span class="gemarra-regular">separate</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> are considered as though they </span>have already been <span class="gemarra-regular">separated. </span>Therefore, even though the gifts were not yet given, they were considered in the possession of the priest before his death.
The Gemara continues to analyze the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: Why does the firstborn take a double portion of the father’s <span class="gemarra-regular">sacrificial </span>animals? Isn’t it so that once the father consecrates them, <span class="gemarra-regular">they </span>belong to Heaven and <span class="gemarra-regular">are not his?</span>
The Gemara answers: This is stated <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">offerings of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> lesser sanctity, </span>such as peace offerings, <span class="gemarra-regular">and in accordance with</span> the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Yosei HaGelili, who says: </span>These sacrificial animals <span class="gemarra-regular">are </span>considered the <span class="gemarra-regular">property of </span>their <span class="gemarra-regular">owners, </span>as opposed to property of Heaven. <span class="gemarra-regular">As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that concerning one who steals another’s property and takes a false oath denying he has done so, incurring the obligation to bring a guilt-offering, the verse states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And commits a trespass against the Lord, </span>and deals falsely with his neighbor” (Leviticus 5:21). The verse serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">include offerings of lesser sanctity</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> which are </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">property </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of </span>their <span class="gemarra-regular">owners; </span>this is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of Rabbi Yosei </span><span class="gemarra-regular">HaGelili. </span>Consequently, the firstborn collects a double portion of these as well.
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> states: If <span class="gemarra-regular">their father left them a cow </span>that was <span class="gemarra-regular">leased or rented in the possession of others, or</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> if it was grazing in the meadow, and it gave</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> birth, </span>then the <span class="gemarra-regular">firstborn takes a double </span>portion of the rental income or calf. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Now </span>that in a case where the cow was <span class="gemarra-regular">leased or rented </span>to others, <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the animals <span class="gemarra-regular">are not in their owner’s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> possession, you say </span>that the firstborn <span class="gemarra-regular">takes </span>a double portion, in a case where it was <span class="gemarra-regular">grazing in the meadow</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, is </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>for the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> to state that he receives a double portion?
The Gemara answers that <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>is what the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us: </span>It teaches <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>a case where the animal was <span class="gemarra-regular">leased or rented</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is similar to </span>a case where it was <span class="gemarra-regular">grazing in</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the meadow, </span>in that <span class="gemarra-regular">just as </span>in a case where it was <span class="gemarra-regular">grazing in the meadow, the enhancement came by</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> itself and </span>the brothers <span class="gemarra-regular">did not lose </span>money for <span class="gemarra-regular">its</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> sustenance, </span>

Daf 124a

<span class="gemarra-regular">so too </span>in the case of a cow that was <span class="gemarra-regular">leased or rented, </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is referring only to a case where <span class="gemarra-regular">the enhancement came by itself, as</span> the brothers <span class="gemarra-regular">did not lose </span>money for <span class="gemarra-regular">its sustenance, </span>since it was stipulated that the one who rented or leased it would provide its feed.
§ The Gemara continues its discussion of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>. In accordance with <span class="gemarra-regular">whose </span>opinion is the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>? <span class="gemarra-regular">It is </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi, <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span><span class="gemarra-regular">it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> (<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span> 7:4): <span class="gemarra-regular">A firstborn</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> does not take a double </span>portion <span class="gemarra-regular">of the enhancement of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the property </span>that occurred <span class="gemarra-regular">after the death of </span>the sons’ <span class="gemarra-regular">father</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">says: I say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a firstborn does take a double </span>portion <span class="gemarra-regular">of the enhancement </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of the property </span>that occurred by itself <span class="gemarra-regular">after their father’</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s death, </span>e.g., the birth of a calf, <span class="gemarra-regular">but not of the enhancement that the orphans caused after </span><span class="gemarra-regular">their father’s death.</span>
Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi continues: Therefore, if they <span class="gemarra-regular">inherited a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">promissory note </span>indicating a debt owed to their father, the <span class="gemarra-regular">firstborn takes a double </span>portion of the money when it is collected, as this is an enhancement to the estate that came by itself. The Gemara adds: In a case where <span class="gemarra-regular">a promissory note emerged against the</span><span class="gemarra-regular">m</span> for their father’s debt, the <span class="gemarra-regular">firstborn gives, </span>i.e., repays, <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">double </span>portion of the debt. <span class="gemarra-regular">But if he says: I </span><span class="gemarra-regular">am not giving </span>a double portion of the debt <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">I am not taking </span>a double portion of the estate, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">permitted </span>to do so, and he is exempt from paying a double portion.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>for the ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">of the Rabbis </span>that the firstborn does not receive a double portion of any enhancements that occur after the death of the father? <span class="gemarra-regular">The verse states: “Giving him a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> double portion” </span>(Deuteronomy 21:17); by employing the term “giving” <span class="gemarra-regular">the Merciful One calls </span>the double portion <span class="gemarra-regular">a gift. Just </span><span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>a recipient of a gift does not acquire <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">gift unless it </span>first <span class="gemarra-regular">reaches the possession of </span>the one giving the gift, <span class="gemarra-regular">so too </span>the firstborn does not acquire <span class="gemarra-regular">the portion of the firstborn unless it has reached the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">possession of </span>the father before he died.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">says </span>that the reason for his ruling that a firstborn receives a double portion of the enhancement is that <span class="gemarra-regular">the verse states: “A double </span><span class="gemarra-regular">portion” </span>(Deuteronomy 21:17). It <span class="gemarra-regular">juxtaposes the portion of the firstborn</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to the portion of an ordinary </span>son, in that <span class="gemarra-regular">just</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as the portion of an ordinary </span>son is inherited <span class="gemarra-regular">even</span> from property <span class="gemarra-regular">that did not reach </span>the father’s <span class="gemarra-regular">possession</span> before he died, <span class="gemarra-regular">so too, the portion of the firstborn</span> is inherited <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>from property <span class="gemarra-regular">that did not reach </span>the father’s <span class="gemarra-regular">possession </span>before he died.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>according to <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis as</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> well, isn’t </span>the phrase <span class="gemarra-regular">“a double portion” written? </span>The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">That </span>phrase can be said to teach a different <span class="it-text">halakha</span>, requiring the brothers <span class="gemarra-regular">to give </span>the firstborn both of his portions <span class="gemarra-regular">on one border</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., adjoining, and not in separate locations.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>according to <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">as well, isn’t </span>the phrase <span class="gemarra-regular">“giving him” written? </span>The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">That</span> phrase can be said to teach a different <span class="it-text">halakha</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">that</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> if </span>the firstborn <span class="gemarra-regular">says: I am not taking </span>a double portion of the estate <span class="gemarra-regular">and I am not giving </span>a double portion of the debt, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">permitted </span>to do so. Since the inheritance is referred to as a gift, he has the right to refuse it.
The Gemara discusses several types of enhancement. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> says</span><span class="gemarra-regular">:</span> With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a palm tree that </span>became enhanced by <span class="gemarra-regular">growing broader </span>after the father’s death, or <span class="gemarra-regular">land that yielded sil</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> and thereby became enhanced, <span class="gemarra-regular">everyone</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> agrees that </span>the firstborn <span class="gemarra-regular">takes </span>a double portion of the enhancement. <span class="gemarra-regular">When they disagree </span>is in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">when fodder</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">baḥafura</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., grain that has grown stalks but is not yet ripe, <span class="gemarra-regular">becomes full ears, </span>of grain, and when <span class="gemarra-regular">date flowers [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">shelofafei</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> become </span>fully developed <span class="gemarra-regular">dates</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> As one <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage, </span>Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi, <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that since this <span class="gemarra-regular">enhancement </span>develops <span class="gemarra-regular">by itself, </span>the firstborn is entitled to a double portion of it, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage, </span>the Rabbis, <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that since the item <span class="gemarra-regular">transformed</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> it is not considered the same item that was in the father’s possession, and the firstborn is not entitled to a double portion of it.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba bar Ḥana says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ḥiyya says: </span>A judge who <span class="gemarra-regular">acted, </span>i.e., ruled, <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> statement of Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">has acted </span>legally, and one who acted <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with the statement of the Rabbis</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> has </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">acted </span>legally. Either way, the decision stands. 

Daf 124b

The Gemara explains: Rabbi Ḥiyya <span class="gemarra-regular">is uncertai</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> as to <span class="gemarra-regular">whether </span>the principle that the <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi in his disputes <span class="gemarra-regular">with his colleague </span>applies specifically to a dispute with one other <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">but not </span>to a dispute <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>several of <span class="gemarra-regular">his colleagues, or </span>whether the principle that the <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi in his disputes <span class="gemarra-regular">with his colleague </span>applies <span class="gemarra-regular">even to </span>a dispute with several of <span class="gemarra-regular">his colleagues, </span>as in this case, where the Rabbis disagree with Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi. Since he was uncertain, he left the decision to each individual judge.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Naḥman says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibited to act </span><span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with the statement of Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi. The Gemara explains: Rav <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that the <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance </span><span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi in his disputes <span class="gemarra-regular">with his </span>single <span class="gemarra-regular">colleague, but not </span>in his disputes <span class="gemarra-regular">with</span> several of <span class="gemarra-regular">his colleagues.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav Naḥman says his own </span>statement: It is <span class="gemarra-regular">permitted</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to act in accordance with the statement of Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi. The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">He holds </span>that the <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi not only in his disputes <span class="gemarra-regular">with his </span>single <span class="gemarra-regular">colleague,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> but even </span>in his disputes <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>several of <span class="gemarra-regular">his colleagues</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava says: </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibited to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> act in accordance with the statement of Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi, <span class="gemarra-regular">but if </span>a judge <span class="gemarra-regular">acted </span>in accordance with the statement of Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi, what is done <span class="gemarra-regular">is done </span>and the decision stands. The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">He holds </span>that it <span class="gemarra-regular">was stated </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">one is incline</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> to follow the opinion of the Rabbis <span class="it-text">ab</span> <span class="it-text">initio</span>, but if a judge rules in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi, his decision stands.
The Gemara comments that there are conflicting opinions in halakhic midrash as to whether the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi or in accordance with the opinion of the Rabbis, as each opinion is supported by a different version of the midrash. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman </span><span class="gemarra-regular">taught </span>a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">from the other books of the school </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">debei</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">Rav</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., a volume of halakhic midrash other than <span class="it-text">Torat</span> <span class="it-text">Kohanim</span>, which is a halakhic midrash on the book of Leviticus. The phrase from the verse: “By giving him a double portion <span class="gemarra-regular">of all that </span><span class="gemarra-regular">he has” </span>(Deuteronomy 21:17), <span class="gemarra-regular">excludes the enhancement that the heirs</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> brought about after their father’s death, </span>of which the firstborn is not entitled to a double portion. The Gemara infers: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">the enhancement of the property </span>that occurred by itself <span class="gemarra-regular">after their father’s death, he does take</span> a double portion. The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">And whose </span>opinion is this? <span class="gemarra-regular">It is </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rami bar Ḥama taught</span> a different version of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">from the other books</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of the school of Rav: “Of all that he</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> has” excludes </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">enhancement of the property </span>that occurred by itself <span class="gemarra-regular">after their father’s death</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> of which the firstborn is not entitled to a double portion. The Gemara infers: <span class="gemarra-regular">And all the more so, he does not take</span> a double portion of the <span class="gemarra-regular">enhancement that the heirs brought</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> about after their father’s death. </span>The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">And</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> whose </span>opinion is this? <span class="gemarra-regular">It is </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rabbis. </span>Accordingly, there is a discrepancy between the <span class="it-text">baraitot</span> as to whether the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is in accordance with the opinion of the Rabbis or Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel </span><span class="gemarra-regular">says: A firstborn does not take a double </span>portion <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a loan, </span>i.e., of a debt that is owed to the father. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">According to whom </span>is this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> stated? <span class="gemarra-regular">If we say </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span><span class="gemarra-regular">accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis, now </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbis say </span>that a firstborn <span class="gemarra-regular">does not take </span>a double portion even with regard to the <span class="gemarra-regular">enhancement </span>of property <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is in the possession of </span>the father, is it <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary</span> to state that he is not entitled to a double portion of <span class="gemarra-regular">a loan? </span>The debt is not in the father’s possession at the time of his death; it is merely due to him.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>it must be <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi. Although he holds that a firstborn is entitled to a double portion of the enhancement of the property itself, he concedes that he is not entitled to a double portion of the payment of a debt, as it was not in the possession of his father at the time of his death.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if so, in accordance with <span class="gemarra-regular">whose </span>opinion is <span class="gemarra-regular">that which is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: If the sons <span class="gemarra-regular">inherited a promissory note, </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">firstborn takes a double </span>portion <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span>the payment of <span class="gemarra-regular">both </span>the value of <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">loan </span>itself <span class="gemarra-regular">and the interest? </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">neither </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi, <span class="gemarra-regular">nor </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis.</span>
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Actually, </span>Shmuel’s statement that the firstborn is not entitled to a double portion of the payment of a debt is <span class="gemarra-regular">in</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis, and it was</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> necessary </span>to state it. It might <span class="gemarra-regular">enter your mind to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> say </span>that with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a loan, since </span>the creditor <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>a promissory <span class="gemarra-regular">note, it is considered as though it</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> has </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">been collected </span>and is in the creditor’s possession, so too, the firstborn should be entitled to a double portion even according to the opinion of the Rabbis. Therefore, Shmuel <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>that the loan is not considered to be in the creditor’s possession, and the firstborn is not entitled to a double portion.
The Gemara relates: <span class="gemarra-regular">They sent </span>the following ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">from there, </span>Eretz Yisrael: If the father lent money to a gentile, the <span class="gemarra-regular">firstborn takes a double </span>portion of the value <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">loan </span>itself, <span class="gemarra-regular">but not of </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">interest, </span>as the interest is considered property due to the father.
