The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">According to whom </span>is this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> stated? <span class="gemarra-regular">If we say </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis, now </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis say </span>that a firstborn <span class="gemarra-regular">does not take </span>a double portion even with regard to the <span class="gemarra-regular">enhancement </span>of property, <span class="gemarra-regular">which is in the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> possession of </span>the father, is it <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>to state that they would hold that he is not entitled to a double portion of <span class="gemarra-regular">a loan? </span>Since the debt is not in the father’s possession at the time of his death, as it is merely due to him, the rabbis would certainly not hold that the firstborn takes a double portion of it.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>it must be <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi</span> Yehuda HaNasi. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And according to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi, is it so that the firstborn is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>entitled to a double portion <span class="gemarra-regular">of the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> interest? But isn’t it taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">says: A firstborn takes a double </span>portion <span class="gemarra-regular">of both </span>the value of <span class="gemarra-regular">the loan </span>itself <span class="gemarra-regular">and the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> interest?</span>
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Actually, </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> sent from the Sages of Eretz Yisrael <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> And </span>the Sages of Eretz Yisrael hold that the Rabbis concede that the firstborn receives a double portion of the value of the loan itself, because <span class="gemarra-regular">a loan is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> considered as though it has </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">been collected </span>and is in the creditor’s possession. By contrast, the interest on the loan is not considered as though it is already in the creditor’s possession, and therefore the firstborn does not receive a double portion of its payment.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Aḥa bar</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rav said to Ravina: Ameima</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> arrived at our locale </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and taught </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a firstborn takes a double </span>portion <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span>the value of <span class="gemarra-regular">a loan </span>itself, <span class="gemarra-regular">but not of </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">interest. </span>Ravina <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">of Neharde’a</span> conform <span class="gemarra-regular">to their </span>standard line of <span class="gemarra-regular">reasoning</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Ameimar followed the opinion of Rav Naḥman, who was one of the Sages of Naharde’a, as was Ameimar.
The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">As Rabba says: </span>If the sons <span class="gemarra-regular">collected land </span>as payment of a debt owed to their father, the firstborn <span class="gemarra-regular">has </span>a double portion of it, but if <span class="gemarra-regular">they</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> collected money, he does not have </span>a double portion. <span class="gemarra-regular">And</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rav Naḥman says </span>that if <span class="gemarra-regular">they collected money, he has</span> a double portion, but if <span class="gemarra-regular">they collected land, he</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> does not have </span>a double portion.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said to Rabba</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: According to your </span>opinion it <span class="gemarra-regular">is difficult, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">according </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">difficult. </span><span class="gemarra-regular">According to your </span>opinion it <span class="gemarra-regular">is difficult</span>

Daf 125a

because <span class="gemarra-regular">what is different </span>about <span class="gemarra-regular">money, </span>resulting in the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the firstborn is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>entitled to a double portion of it, is <span class="gemarra-regular">that their father did not leave </span>them <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>specific <span class="gemarra-regular">money </span>that was collected. With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">land as well, their father did not leave </span>them <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>specific parcel of <span class="gemarra-regular">land </span>when he died, as the debtor could have repaid them with a different parcel of land, or with money.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And furthermore, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">aren’t you </span>the one <span class="gemarra-regular">who said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the explanation </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of the people of the West, </span>Eretz Yisrael, <span class="gemarra-regular">is reasonable? </span>In a case where a married woman had been fit to inherit from her great-grandmother but then predeceased her great-grandmother, who then died, and her widower claims the inheritance in his late wife’s stead, the Sages of Eretz Yisrael ruled that he is not entitled to the inheritance, as it is merely property due to his wife, and a husband does not inherit property due to be inherited by his late wife. Rabba agreed that the inheritance is considered property due to the wife, and not property possessed by her, <span class="gemarra-regular">as if the </span>great-<span class="gemarra-regular">grandmother would have </span><span class="gemarra-regular">sold it before </span>she died, <span class="gemarra-regular">her sale would have </span><span class="gemarra-regular">been </span>a valid <span class="gemarra-regular">sale. </span>Here, too, the land should be considered property due to the father, of which a firstborn is not entitled to a double portion, since the debtor could have sold it. Therefore, Rabba’s opinion is difficult.
Abaya continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">According to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">difficult; what is different </span>about <span class="gemarra-regular">land, </span>resulting in the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the firstborn is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>entitled to a double portion of it, is <span class="gemarra-regular">that their father did not leave</span> them <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>specific parcel of <span class="gemarra-regular">land. </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">money as well, their father did not leave </span>them <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>specific <span class="gemarra-regular">money </span>when he died.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And furthermore, doesn’t Rav Naḥman </span><span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba bar Avuh says: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">orphans </span><span class="gemarra-regular">who collected lan</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for a debt owed to their father</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>their father’s <span class="gemarra-regular">creditor </span>can <span class="gemarra-regular">come and seize this </span>land <span class="gemarra-regular">from them, </span>as any land owned by the father is liened against his debts. Evidently, Rav Naḥman holds that land liened against a debt has the legal status of land that is in the possession of the creditor. If so, why does Rav Naḥman hold that a firstborn is not entitled to a double portion of land that is collected as payment of a debt?
Rabba <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Abaye: <span class="gemarra-regular">According </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to my </span>opinion it <span class="gemarra-regular">is not difficult, and according to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">is not difficult. We </span><span class="gemarra-regular">were </span>merely <span class="gemarra-regular">saying, </span>i.e., explaining, <span class="gemarra-regular">the reason </span>for the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of the people of the West, </span>Eretz Yisrael, introduced with the phrase: They sent the following ruling from there, that a firstborn is entitled to a double portion of the payment of a debt. <span class="gemarra-regular">But we ourselves do </span><span class="gemarra-regular">not hold </span>in accordance with that opinion. Therefore, one cannot raise a contradiction from our opinions stated elsewhere to what we said in explanation of the Sages of Eretz Yisrael.
Having mentioned in passing the case of the great-grandmother, the Gemara discusses that case in depth. <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is the case of the great-<span class="gemarra-regular">grandmother </span>that was mentioned by Abaye? The Gemara explains: There was <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain </span>moribund person <span class="gemarra-regular">who said to </span>those present: 

Daf 125b

All <span class="gemarra-regular">my property </span>is given <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>my <span class="gemarra-regular">grandmother</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and after she </span>dies, it is given <span class="gemarra-regular">to my </span><span class="gemarra-regular">heirs, </span>not inherited by her heirs. He then died. <span class="gemarra-regular">He</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> had a married daughter, </span>who <span class="gemarra-regular">died during the lifetime of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> her husband and during the lifetime of </span>her father’s <span class="gemarra-regular">grandmother. After </span>her father’s <span class="gemarra-regular">grandmother died, </span>her <span class="gemarra-regular">husband came</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and claimed </span>the inheritance, as his wife was the heir of her father, and he is his wife’s heir.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna said: </span>When her father said that his property is given: <span class="gemarra-regular">To my heirs, </span>he meant: <span class="gemarra-regular">And even to the heirs of my heirs. </span>Therefore, since his daughter’s husband is the heir of his heir, he is entitled to the inheritance. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav Anan said</span> that he meant: <span class="gemarra-regular">To my heirs, but not to the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> heirs of my heirs. </span>Therefore, the husband is not entitled to the property.
The Gemara relates: <span class="gemarra-regular">They sent </span>a ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">from there, </span>Eretz Yisrael: <span class="gemarra-regular">The </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Anan, but not due to his reasoning. </span>The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">The </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Anan that the husband does not inherit </span>the property. <span class="gemarra-regular">But not due to his reasoning, as Rav Anan holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">even if his daughter had a son </span>to inherit from her, <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span>would <span class="gemarra-regular">not inherit </span>the property, as her father bequeathed it only to his heirs, not to the heirs of his heirs. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">is not so, as </span><span class="gemarra-regular">if his daughter had a son, he </span>would <span class="gemarra-regular">certainly inherit; </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and this is the reason the husband does not inherit: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Because </span>the inheritance <span class="gemarra-regular">is considered </span>property <span class="gemarra-regular">due </span>to the daughter, as she did not own it during her lifetime, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a husband does not take </span>in inheritance property <span class="gemarra-regular">due </span>to his wife <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>he does the property she <span class="gemarra-regular">possessed.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">By inference, does Rav Huna, </span>who ruled that the husband is entitled to the inheritance, <span class="gemarra-regular">hold </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a husband</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> takes </span>in inheritance property <span class="gemarra-regular">due </span>to his wife <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>he does the property she <span class="gemarra-regular">possessed?</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar says: This matter was</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> introduced by great </span>Sages, namely Rav Huna, <span class="gemarra-regular">and concluded by</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> lesser </span>Sages, i.e., by me. Rabbi Elazar, humbly referring to himself as a lesser Sage, will now explain Rav Huna’s statement. <span class="gemarra-regular">Anyone who says </span>to another upon granting him an inheritance or a gift: <span class="gemarra-regular">After you </span>die it is given to so-and-so, <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">like </span><span class="gemarra-regular">one who says: </span>It is given to so-and-so <span class="gemarra-regular">from now. </span>The first recipient merely has the right to use the property during his lifetime but did not actually become the owner. Accordingly, the inheritance was owned by the daughter in her lifetime, and the great-grandmother merely had usage rights. Therefore, it is inherited by the husband.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba said: The</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> explanation of the people of the West, </span>that the inheritance is considered property due to the daughter and not property possessed by her, <span class="gemarra-regular">is reasonable, as if the grandmother </span><span class="gemarra-regular">would have sold it before </span>she died, <span class="gemarra-regular">her sale would </span><span class="gemarra-regular">have been </span>a valid <span class="gemarra-regular">sale</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and the daughter would not have received it at all.
In conclusion, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Papp</span><span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is that <span class="gemarra-regular">the husband does not</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> take </span>in inheritance property <span class="gemarra-regular">due </span>to his wife <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>he does the property she <span class="gemarra-regular">possessed; and a firstborn does </span><span class="gemarra-regular">not take </span>a double portion of property <span class="gemarra-regular">due </span>to his father <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>he does the property his father <span class="gemarra-regular">possessed; and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a firstborn does not take a double </span>portion <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span>payment for <span class="gemarra-regular">a loan</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> whether </span>the brothers <span class="gemarra-regular">collected land </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">whether they collected money. </span>

Daf 126a

<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>as for <span class="gemarra-regular">a loan that </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is with </span>the firstborn, i.e., he had borrowed money from his father then his father died, it is uncertain whether the payment should be considered property due to the father or property possessed by him. Therefore, the firstborn and his brothers <span class="gemarra-regular">divid</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> the additional portion.
§ With regard to the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that the firstborn is not entitled to a double portion of the enhancement of the property resulting from the actions of the heirs, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Asi says: A </span><span class="gemarra-regular">firstborn who proteste</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> the efforts of enhancing the property before it is divided has <span class="gemarra-regular">protested, </span>and if the brothers use resources from the estate to enhance it against his will, he is entitled to a double portion of the enhanced value.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba said: Rav Asi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">’s opinion is reasonable in </span>a case where they inherited <span class="gemarra-regular">grapes </span>on a grapevine <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the brothers <span class="gemarra-regular">harvested the</span><span class="gemarra-regular">m</span> against the will of the firstborn, or if they inherited <span class="gemarra-regular">olives </span>on olive trees <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the brothers <span class="gemarra-regular">harvested them, </span>as in these cases, the produce itself did not change. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">they treaded </span>on <span class="gemarra-regular">them, </span>converting them into wine or oil, even if the firstborn protested their doing so, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>entitled to a double portion. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav Yosef</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> said: Even </span>if they <span class="gemarra-regular">treaded </span>on <span class="gemarra-regular">them, </span>the firstborn is entitled to a double portion.
The Gemara asks: Why is he entitled to a double portion, according to Rav Yosef, even if <span class="gemarra-regular">they treaded </span>on <span class="gemarra-regular">them? </span>Since the brothers transformed the produce, as <span class="gemarra-regular">initially </span>it was in the form of <span class="gemarra-regular">grapes </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">now </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">wine, </span>they have acquired it in the same manner that a thief acquires an item he stole. Therefore, the firstborn should have no share of the enhancement.
The Gemara answers: Rav Yosef did not mean that the firstborn is entitled to a double portion of the enhanced value of the wine. Rather, his intention was the same <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">which Rav Ukva bar </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Ḥama says </span>in a differnet context, that the ruling is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>a case where the wine spoiled, its value decreasing to below the initial value of the grapes, in which case the brothers must <span class="gemarra-regular">give </span>the firstborn <span class="gemarra-regular">payment for </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage </span>to <span class="gemarra-regular">his </span>additional portion of the <span class="gemarra-regular">grapes. Here, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">too, </span>Rav Yosef meant that the brothers <span class="gemarra-regular">must give </span>the firstborn <span class="gemarra-regular">payment for </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage to his grapes</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">Where, </span>i.e., in what context, <span class="gemarra-regular">was </span>the statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav Ukva bar Ḥama</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> stated? </span>It was <span class="gemarra-regular">in reference to that which Rav Yehuda</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel says: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a firstborn and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> an ordinary </span>son <span class="gemarra-regular">whose father left them grapes and they</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> harvested them, </span>or if he left them <span class="gemarra-regular">olives and they</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> harvested them, </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">firstborn takes a double </span>portion. This is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">they treaded </span>on <span class="gemarra-regular">them. </span>The Gemara asks: Why is he entitled to a double portion if <span class="gemarra-regular">they treaded </span>on <span class="gemarra-regular">them; initially </span>they were <span class="gemarra-regular">grapes, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">now </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">wine? Mar Ukva bar Ḥama says: </span>Shmuel did not mean that he is entitled to a double portion of the wine; rather, the reference is <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>a case where the wine spoiled, its value decreasing to below the initial value of the grapes, in which case the ordinary brother must <span class="gemarra-regular">give </span>the firstborn <span class="gemarra-regular">payment for </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">damage </span>to <span class="gemarra-regular">his grapes.</span>
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Asi says: A firstborn who took a portion</span> of the property <span class="gemarra-regular">like </span>that of <span class="gemarra-regular">an ordinary </span>heir has <span class="gemarra-regular">relinquished </span>his right to an additional portion. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>does it mean that he has <span class="gemarra-regular">relinquished </span>his additional portion? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa says in the name of Rava </span>that he has <span class="gemarra-regular">relinquished </span>his additional portion only <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to that field </span>that was divided, since he did not exercise his right to an additional portion, but he has not relinquished his right to receive an additional portion of the rest of the estate. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Papp</span><span class="gemarra-regular">i</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> says in the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> name of Rava </span>that he has <span class="gemarra-regular">relinquished </span>his additional portion <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to all </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">the property.</span>
The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa says in</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the name of Rava </span>that he has <span class="gemarra-regular">relinquished </span>his additional portion only <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to that field </span>that was divided, because he <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a firstborn does not have </span>a right to his additional portion <span class="gemarra-regular">before </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">divisio</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> of the property. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>therefore, he <span class="gemarra-regular">has waived </span>his additional portion of <span class="gemarra-regular">what has </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">reached his possession, </span>namely, the field that was divided, but he <span class="gemarra-regular">has not waived </span>his portion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the other </span>fields of the estate.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav Pappi says in the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> name of Rava </span>that he has <span class="gemarra-regular">relinquished </span>his additional portion <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to all </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">the property, </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">he holds</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">a firstborn has </span>a right to his additional portion <span class="gemarra-regular">before </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">division </span>of the property. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>therefore, <span class="gemarra-regular">since </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">waived </span>his additional portion <span class="gemarra-regular">in this </span>field, he <span class="gemarra-regular">has waived</span> his portion <span class="gemarra-regular">of all </span>of the property.
The Gemara notes: <span class="gemarra-regular">And this </span>dispute <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav Pappi and Rav Pappa was </span><span class="gemarra-regular">not stated explicitly; rather, it was stated by inference. As</span> there was <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain firstborn who went </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">sold his</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> property and </span>the property <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span>his deceased <span class="gemarra-regular">ordinary </span>brother, i.e., their respective portions of their father’s property, before the property was divided. The <span class="gemarra-regular">orphan sons of </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">ordinary</span> brother <span class="gemarra-regular">went to eat dates from </span>the field that was now in the possession of <span class="gemarra-regular">those purchasers, </span>due to their father’s share in the field. The purchasers <span class="gemarra-regular">hit them</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>as though they were thieves. The <span class="gemarra-regular">relatives </span>of the orphans <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>the purchasers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Not only did you purchase their</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> property </span>illegally, <span class="gemarra-regular">but you now hit them as well? They</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> came before Rava, </span>who <span class="gemarra-regular">said to them: </span>The firstborn <span class="gemarra-regular">has</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> done nothing. </span>His sale was not valid. 

Daf 126b

Rav Pappi and Rav Pappa disagree with regard to Rava’s intention. One <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage, </span>Rav Pappi, <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">he has</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> done nothing with regard to </span>his brother’s <span class="gemarra-regular">portion</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as he had no right to sell it; with regard to his own additional portion, the sale was valid, as it was in his possession even before the division of the property. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage, </span>Rav Pappa, <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that he has done nothing <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to all </span>of the property, as he does not possess the additional portion before the property is divided between the brothers.
The Gemara notes that <span class="gemarra-regular">they sent </span>a ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">from there, </span>Eretz Yisrael: <span class="gemarra-regular">A firstborn who sold </span>his additional portion <span class="gemarra-regular">before </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">divisio</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> of the property <span class="gemarra-regular">has done </span><span class="gemarra-regular">nothing. Apparently, </span>the Sages of Eretz Yisrael hold that <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">firstborn does not have </span>a right to his additional portion <span class="gemarra-regular">before </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">division. But the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is that <span class="gemarra-regular">a firstborn </span><span class="gemarra-regular">has </span>a right to his additional portion <span class="gemarra-regular">before </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">division.</span>
The Gemara relates: <span class="gemarra-regular">Mar Zutra of</span> the house <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rishba, </span>who was a firstborn, <span class="gemarra-regular">divided </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a basket of pepper</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> from the estate of his father <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">brothers equally. </span>He <span class="gemarra-regular">came before Rav Ashi </span>to claim a double portion of the rest of the estate. Rav Ashi <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Since you relinquished </span>your additional portion <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to some </span>of the estate, <span class="gemarra-regular">you have</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> relinquished </span>your additional portion <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to all of the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> property, </span>as a firstborn has a right to his additional portion before the division.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who says: So-and-so, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">my firstborn </span><span class="gemarra-regular">son</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">will not take a double </span>portion of my estate; or one who says: <span class="gemarra-regular">So-and-so, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">my son, will not inherit </span>my estate <span class="gemarra-regular">among his brothers, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">he has said </span><span class="gemarra-regular">nothing</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">as he has stipulated counter </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to that which is written in the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Torah</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>on his deathbed <span class="gemarra-regular">who apportions his </span><span class="gemarra-regular">propert</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> orally, </span>granting it to his sons as a gift, and he <span class="gemarra-regular">increased </span>the portion given <span class="gemarra-regular">to one </span>of his sons <span class="gemarra-regular">and reduced </span>the portion given <span class="gemarra-regular">to one </span>son, <span class="gemarra-regular">or</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> equated </span>the portion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the firstborn to </span>the portions of the other sons, <span class="gemarra-regular">his statement stands. But if he said</span> that they will receive the property not as a gift but <span class="gemarra-regular">as inheritance, he has said nothing. </span>If he <span class="gemarra-regular">wrote </span>in his will, <span class="gemarra-regular">whether at the beginning, or in</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the middle, or at the end, </span>that he is granting them the property <span class="gemarra-regular">as a gift, his statement stands.</span>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Let us say that the mishna is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda, as</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> if </span>it is in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Yehuda, doesn’t he say </span>elsewhere that if one stipulates counter to that which is written in the Torah <span class="gemarra-regular">with</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> regard to monetary matters, his stipulation stands?</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">As it is taught</span> in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> (<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span>, <span class="it-text">Kiddushin</span> 3:7): If one <span class="gemarra-regular">says </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to a woman: You are hereby betrothed to me on </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the condition that you have no </span>ability to claim <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span><span class="gemarra-regular">me food, clothing, and conjugal rights</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> she is betrothed </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and his stipulation is void</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span> this is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Yehuda says: With regard to monetary </span><span class="gemarra-regular">matters</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> such as food and clothing, <span class="gemarra-regular">his stipulation stands, </span>despite being counter to that which is written in the Torah. According to the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda, one should be able to stipulate that his firstborn son not receive a double portion, or that one of his sons not inherit from him at all, as inheritance is a monetary matter.
The Gemara rejects this suggestion: <span class="gemarra-regular">Even </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">you say </span>that the mishna is in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> there, </span>the woman <span class="gemarra-regular">knew </span>of his stipulation <span class="gemarra-regular">and waived </span>her rights. Therefore, the stipulation stands. <span class="gemarra-regular">Here, </span>the son whose portion was reduced <span class="gemarra-regular">did not waiv</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> his portion. Therefore the stipulation is not valid.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> says </span>that if a man <span class="gemarra-regular">says: So-and-so is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> my firstborn son</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the son <span class="gemarra-regular">takes a double </span>portion of his inheritance based on this testimony. If he says: <span class="gemarra-regular">So-and-so is a firstborn, </span>the son <span class="gemarra-regular">does not</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> take a double </span>portion, as <span class="gemarra-regular">perhaps </span>the man <span class="gemarra-regular">was </span><span class="gemarra-regular">saying </span>that the son is his <span class="gemarra-regular">mother’s firstborn </span>but not his own firstborn.
The Gemara relates: There was <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain </span>man <span class="gemarra-regular">who cam</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> before Rabba bar bar Ḥana </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">said to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> him: I know that this </span>man <span class="gemarra-regular">is a firstborn. </span>Rabba bar bar Ḥana <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: From where do you</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> know? </span>He answered: <span class="gemarra-regular">Because his father would call him a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> foolish firstborn. </span>Rabba bar bar Ḥana replied: <span class="gemarra-regular">Perhaps he is</span> his <span class="gemarra-regular">mother’s firstborn, as any firstborn of a mother</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is also called a foolish firstborn</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
The Gemara relates: There was <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain </span>man <span class="gemarra-regular">who came before</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rabbi Ḥanina </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: I know that this</span> man <span class="gemarra-regular">is a firstborn. </span>Rabbi Ḥanina <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: From</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> where do you know? He said to </span>Rabbi Ḥanina: <span class="gemarra-regular">Because when </span>people <span class="gemarra-regular">would come before his father </span>to obtain a cure for their ailing eyes, <span class="gemarra-regular">he would say to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> them: Go to my son Shikhḥat</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as he is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a firstborn and his saliva heals </span>this ailment.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But perhaps he is </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">mother’s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> firstborn? </span>The Gemara answers: It <span class="gemarra-regular">is learned </span>as a tradition that <span class="gemarra-regular">the saliva of a father’s firstborn heals </span>this ailment but <span class="gemarra-regular">the saliva of a mother’s firstborn does</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not heal </span>this ailment.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ami says: </span>In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one whose </span><span class="gemarra-regular">sexual organs are indeterminate [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">tumtum</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">whose </span>skin <span class="gemarra-regular">became </span><span class="gemarra-regular">perforate</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> so that his genitals were exposed <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">was</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> found </span>to be <span class="gemarra-regular">a male, </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">does not take a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> double </span>portion of his father’s estate. <span class="gemarra-regular">As the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">verse states: “And if the firstborn son was [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">vehaya</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] hers </span><span class="gemarra-regular">that was hated” </span>(Deuteronomy 21:15), which is interpreted to mean that he is not considered a firstborn <span class="gemarra-regular">unless he is</span> recognized as <span class="gemarra-regular">a son, </span>i.e., male, <span class="gemarra-regular">from the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">moment of </span>his coming into <span class="gemarra-regular">being [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">havaya</span><span class="gemarra-regular">], </span>i.e., his birth.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak says: </span>A <span class="it-text">tumtum</span> who was found to be male <span class="gemarra-regular">is also </span><span class="gemarra-regular">not judged as a stubborn and rebellious son, as the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">verse states: “If there will be </span><span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">y</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ihyeh</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] to a man </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a stubborn and rebellious son” </span>(Deuteronomy 21:18), which is interpreted to mean that one is not judged in this manner <span class="gemarra-regular">unless he is </span>recognized as <span class="gemarra-regular">a son from the moment</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of </span>his coming into <span class="gemarra-regular">being. </span>

Daf 127a

<span class="gemarra-regular">Ameimar says: </span>A <span class="it-text">tumtum</span> who was found to be male <span class="gemarra-regular">also does not reduce the </span>additional <span class="gemarra-regular">portion of the firstborn</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> His portion is not taken into account in the calculation of the firstborn’s additional portion. For example, if there are three brothers: A firstborn, an ordinary brother, and a <span class="it-text">tumtum</span>, the firstborn receives one-third of the property as his additional portion, as he would if he and the ordinary brother were the only heirs, and the remaining two-thirds are divided among all three brothers. This is <span class="gemarra-regular">because it is stated </span>with regard to the portion of the firstborn: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And they have borne</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> him sons” </span>(Deuteronomy 21:15), which is interpreted to mean that the brother of a firstborn does not affect his additional portion <span class="gemarra-regular">unless he is </span>recognized as <span class="gemarra-regular">a son at </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the moment of </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">birth.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Sheizevi says: </span>A <span class="it-text">tumtum</span> who was found to be male <span class="gemarra-regular">is also not circumcised on </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">eighth </span>day, if his eighth day occurs on Shabbat, although the mitzva of circumcision on the eighth day generally overrides Shabbat prohibtions. <span class="gemarra-regular">As the verse states: “If a woman bears seed </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and gives birth to a male </span>then she shall be unclean seven days; as in the days of the impurity of her sickness shall she be unclean. <span class="gemarra-regular">And on the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> eighth day </span>the flesh of his foreskin <span class="gemarra-regular">shall be circumcised</span><span class="gemarra-regular">” </span>(Leviticus 12:2–3), which is interpreted to mean that he is not circumcised on the eighth day, in the event that it occurs on Shabbat, <span class="gemarra-regular">unless he is </span>recognized as <span class="gemarra-regular">a male from the moment of </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">birth.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Sherevya says: His mother is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">also not </span>rendered <span class="gemarra-regular">ritually impure </span>due to his <span class="gemarra-regular">birth, as </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the verse states: “If a woman bears seed and gives </span><span class="gemarra-regular">birth to a male, then she shall be unclean seven </span><span class="gemarra-regular">days,” </span>which is interpreted to mean that she is not rendered impure <span class="gemarra-regular">unless he is </span>recognized as <span class="gemarra-regular">a male from </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the moment of </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">birth</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
The Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises an objection </span>from a mishna (<span class="it-text">Nidda</span> 28a): A woman <span class="gemarra-regular">who miscarries a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tumtum</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> or a hermaphrodite [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ve’androginos</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">observes </span>the strictures of a woman who gave birth <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a male and to a female</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Since it is uncertain whether the fetus is male or female, the woman must observe the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of ritual impurity according to both possibilities. This appears to be <span class="gemarra-regular">a conclusive refutation </span>of the statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav Sherevya </span>that a woman who gives birth to a <span class="it-text">tumtum</span> is not rendered impure at all. The Gemara affirms: This is <span class="gemarra-regular">a conclusive refutation.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Shall </span><span class="gemarra-regular">we say it is </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">a conclusive refutation </span>of the statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav Sheizevi </span>with regard to circumcision, as the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of circumsicion is stated together with the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of ritual impurity?
The Gemara answers: The <span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span> of the mishna in tractate <span class="it-text">Nidda</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is uncertain </span>whether the birth discussed in the verse includes that of a <span class="it-text">tumtum</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>therefore he rules <span class="gemarra-regular">stringently, </span>that she should observe the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of ritual impurity for both possibilities. Rav Sheizevi’s ruling can follow the same logic: The infant should not be circumcised on Shabbat, as it is uncertain whether the mitzva of his circumcision overrides the prohibitions of Shabbat.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, </span>that the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> of the mishna in tractate <span class="it-text">Nidda</span> is uncertain whether the birth discussed in the verse includes that of a <span class="it-text">tumtum</span>, the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">should have </span>stated that the woman <span class="gemarra-regular">observes </span>the strictures of a woman who gave birth <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>both <span class="gemarra-regular">a male and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to a female, and </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">as a menstruating woman</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> If it is uncertain whether the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of ritual purity after birth pertain to a woman who gives birth to a <span class="it-text">tumtum</span> at all, she should observe the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of ritual impurity for any blood that emerges in the time period following the birth, as it should have the status of the blood of a menstruating woman. The Gemara concludes: This poses <span class="gemarra-regular">a difficulty</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Ami </span>that a <span class="it-text">tumtum</span> firstborn does not receive a double portion of the inheritance. The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> states: From the phrase “the firstborn son” (Deuteronomy 21:15) it is derived that only <span class="gemarra-regular">a son </span>receives a double portion, <span class="gemarra-regular">but not a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tumtum</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>and only a definite <span class="gemarra-regular">firstborn </span>receives a double portion, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span><span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>one about whom it is <span class="gemarra-regular">uncertain </span>if he is a firstborn.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">a son </span>receives a double portion <span class="gemarra-regular">but a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tumtum</span> does <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>is understandable, as it <span class="gemarra-regular">is in accordance with </span>the statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Ami, but what </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">does </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that only a definite <span class="gemarra-regular">firstborn </span>receives a double portion <span class="gemarra-regular">but not </span>one about whom it is <span class="gemarra-regular">uncertain </span>if he is a firstborn serve <span class="gemarra-regular">to exclude? </span>Why would one about whom it is uncertain if he is a firstborn receive a double portion?
The Gemara answers: It serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to exclude that which </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rava taught, as Rava taught </span>that if <span class="gemarra-regular">two wives </span>of the same husband <span class="gemarra-regular">gave birth to two males in hiding, </span>so that it is unknown which son was born first, and the husband subsequently had other sons, <span class="gemarra-regular">each </span>of the two possible firstborns <span class="gemarra-regular">writes an authorizatio</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to the other. </span>Since their brothers can claim against each of them individually that he is not the firstborn and does not deserve a double portion, each writes the other an authorization to collect his portion, so that they can jointly claim the additional portion in any event.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa </span>subsequently <span class="gemarra-regular">said to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rava: But didn’t Ravin send </span>a letter from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia, stating: <span class="gemarra-regular">I asked all my teachers </span>about <span class="gemarra-regular">this matter and they did not tell me anything; but</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> this </span>is what <span class="gemarra-regular">they said in the name of Rabbi</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Yannai: </span>If the two sons <span class="gemarra-regular">were </span>initially <span class="gemarra-regular">recognized, </span>i.e., it was known which one of them was the firstborn, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>they <span class="gemarra-regular">were ultimately mixed</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and now the firstborn cannot be identified, <span class="gemarra-regular">each writes an authorization to the other</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> If <span class="gemarra-regular">they were not </span>initially <span class="gemarra-regular">recognized, each does not</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> write an authorization to the other</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava then</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> established an </span><span class="gemarra-italic">amora</span> to repeat his lesson to the masses aloud <span class="gemarra-regular">and taught: The statements that I said to you</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> are a mistake on my </span>part. <span class="gemarra-regular">But this </span>is what <span class="gemarra-regular">they said in the name of Rabbi Yannai: </span>If the two sons <span class="gemarra-regular">were </span>initially <span class="gemarra-regular">recognized and were ultimately mixed, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">each writes an authorization to the other. </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">they were </span><span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>initially <span class="gemarra-regular">recognized, each does not write an authorization to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the other.</span>
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">The residents of Akra De’Agma sent </span>the following inquiry <span class="gemarra-regular">to Shmuel: Teach us, our master: </span>If the court <span class="gemarra-regular">had a presumption concerning this </span>son, <span class="gemarra-regular">that he is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a firstborn</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and his father says concerning another </span>son of his: <span class="gemarra-regular">He is </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">firstborn, what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? Shmuel <span class="gemarra-regular">sent to them </span>in response: Both of these sons <span class="gemarra-regular">write an authorization, </span>

Daf 127b

<span class="gemarra-regular">each to the other.</span>
The Gemara questions this ruling: <span class="gemarra-regular">Whichever way you </span>look at it, Shmuel’s opinion is difficult. <span class="gemarra-regular">If he holds in accordance with</span> the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis </span>with regard to this issue, <span class="gemarra-regular">he should have sent them </span>a response <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with</span> the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">if he holds in</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda, he should </span><span class="gemarra-regular">have sent them </span>a response <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda. </span>Shmuel’s response is not in accordance with either tannaitic opinion.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">He is uncertain whether </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance </span><span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda or in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis. </span>Therefore he sent them a response that incorporates both opinions.
The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is </span>the dispute between Rabbi Yehuda and the Rabbis? <span class="gemarra-regular">As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: Expounding the verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“He shall acknowledge </span>the firstborn” (Deuteronomy 21:17), the Sages said: <span class="gemarra-regular">He shall acknowledge him to others. </span>In other words, a father is deemed credible to tell others that this is his firstborn.
<span class="gemarra-regular">From here, Rabbi Yehuda says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a man is deemed</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> credible to say: This </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">my firstborn son</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> even if he has sons presumed to be older. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span><span class="gemarra-regular">just as a man is deemed credible to say: This </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">my firstborn son, so too, a man </span>who is a priest <span class="gemarra-regular">is deemed credible to say </span>about his son: <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">a son of a divorced woman</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> or: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">a son of a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">yevama</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> who has performed </span><span class="gemarra-italic">ḥalitza</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ḥalutza</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> in which cases he is disqualified from the priesthood due to his flawed lineage [<span class="it-text">ḥalal</span>]. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis say: He is not deemed credible.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman </span><span class="gemarra-regular">bar Yitzḥak said to Rava: Granted, </span>according <span class="gemarra-regular">to Rabbi Yehuda, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">this is </span>the reason <span class="gemarra-regular">that it is written: “He shall </span><span class="gemarra-regular">acknowledge;” </span>he derives from these words that a father is deemed credible to attest to the identity of his sons. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>according <span class="gemarra-regular">to the Rabbis, why do I </span>need the term <span class="gemarra-regular">“he shall acknowledge”?</span>
The Gemara answers: It is necessary for a case <span class="gemarra-regular">when he requires identification, </span>i.e., when there is no presumption as to the identity of the firstborn. In such a situation the verse teaches that the father is deemed credible. The Rabbis disagree with Rabbi Yehuda’s opinion only in a case where another son is presumed to be the firstborn.
The Gemara asks: According to the Rabbis, <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span><span class="gemarra-regular">regard to what </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is it necessary for the verse to teach that a father’s identification of his firstborn is deemed credible? If it is <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to giving </span><span class="gemarra-regular">him a double </span>portion, it is superfluous. <span class="gemarra-regular">Let </span>the son <span class="gemarra-regular">be only </span>like <span class="gemarra-regular">another </span>person, i.e., one who is not an heir; <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>the father <span class="gemarra-regular">wants to give him</span> a double portion of his estate <span class="gemarra-regular">as a gift, can</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he not give </span>it to <span class="gemarra-regular">him? </span>Since the father can give a double portion to the firstborn without having to testify that he is his firstborn, it cannot be that the verse is teaching us that he is deemed credible with regard to the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that a firstborn receives a double portion.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary with regard to property that came into </span>the father’s possession <span class="gemarra-regular">afterward, </span>after he testified that his son is his firstborn. He could not have given him this property as a gift, as at the time of his testimony, the property did not yet belong to him, and one cannot transfer ownership of an item that one does not own. Therefore, it is necessary for the verse to teach that the father’s testimony is deemed credible so that the son can receive a double portion of the father’s future property as well.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span><span class="gemarra-regular">according to Rabbi Meir</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> who says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a person </span><span class="gemarra-regular">can transfer an entity that has not </span>yet <span class="gemarra-regular">come into </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the world, </span>which would mean that one can give away his property even before it enters his possession, <span class="gemarra-regular">why do </span><span class="gemarra-regular">I </span>need the term <span class="gemarra-regular">“he shall acknowledge”?</span>
The Gemara answers: The term is necessary for a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where property came into </span>the father’s possession <span class="gemarra-regular">when he was moribund</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> at which point he cannot transfer ownership of any of his property to others. It is with regard to such property that the verse states: “He shall acknowledge,” to teach that the son who the father states is the firstborn will receive a double portion even of that property.
<span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> (<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span> 7:3): If the court <span class="gemarra-regular">had a presumption concerning </span>a son <span class="gemarra-regular">that he is a firstborn, and his father said </span><span class="gemarra-regular">concerning another </span>son of his <span class="gemarra-regular">that he is </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">firstborn, </span>the father’s statement is <span class="gemarra-regular">deemed credible. </span>If the court <span class="gemarra-regular">had a presumption concerning </span>a son <span class="gemarra-regular">that he is not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a firstborn, and his father said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">he is </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">firstborn, </span>the father’s statement is <span class="gemarra-regular">not deemed credible.</span>
The Gemara asserts that as the two <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> seem to contradict each other, it must be that <span class="gemarra-regular">the first clause </span>represents the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda, and the latter clause </span>represents the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis.</span>
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says </span>that if one <span class="gemarra-regular">says</span> about another: <span class="gemarra-regular">He is my son, and then says: He</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is my slave</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> his latter statement is <span class="gemarra-regular">not deemed</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> credible. </span>It cannot disqualify him from marrying a Jewish woman or exclude him from his inheritance. Conversely, if he first says: <span class="gemarra-regular">He is my slave, and then says: He </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is my son</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> his latter statement is <span class="gemarra-regular">deemed credible, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>in his first statement he presumably <span class="gemarra-regular">was saying: He </span><span class="gemarra-regular">serves me as a slave </span>does.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">opposite </span><span class="it-text">halakha</span> applies <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">at the tax house: </span>If one <span class="gemarra-regular">is passing the customs house and says </span>about a certain person: <span class="gemarra-regular">He is my son</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and then </span>later <span class="gemarra-regular">says: He is my slave, </span>his latter statement is <span class="gemarra-regular">deemed credible, </span>as he presumably says that the other is his son only to evade paying a tax for possessing a slave. Conversely, if <span class="gemarra-regular">he says </span>at the customs house: <span class="gemarra-regular">He is my slave, and then </span>later <span class="gemarra-regular">says: He is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">my son, </span>his latter statement is <span class="gemarra-regular">not deemed credible, </span>as one would not unnecessarily render himself liable to pay a tax.
The Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises an objection </span>from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: If one <span class="gemarra-regular">was serving </span>another person <span class="gemarra-regular">like a son </span>serves his father, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the person being served <span class="gemarra-regular">came and said: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">He is my son, and then said: He is my</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> slave, </span>his latter statement is <span class="gemarra-regular">not deemed credible. </span>Additionally, if one <span class="gemarra-regular">was serving </span>another person <span class="gemarra-regular">like a slave </span>serves his master, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the one being served <span class="gemarra-regular">came and said: He</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is my slave, and then said: He is my son</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>his latter statement is <span class="gemarra-regular">not deemed credible. </span>This contradicts Rabbi Yoḥanan’s statement that if he first says that he is his slave and then says that he is his son, his latter statement is deemed credible.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: There, </span>in Rabbi Yoḥanan’s statement, it is a case where he is presumed to be a slave <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>everyone <span class="gemarra-regular">calls him</span><span class="gemarra-regular">:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> A slave </span>on whose <span class="gemarra-regular">border [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">metzar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] </span>are <span class="gemarra-regular">one hundred</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Since everyone is referring to him in this manner, the person he served cannot call into question his status as a slave by saying that he is his son. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>does it mean that on his <span class="gemarra-regular">border</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">metzar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] </span>are <span class="gemarra-regular">one hundred? </span>The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">One hundred dinars</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> are adjacent to [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">metzar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">slave. </span>In other words, he is worth one hundred dinars.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Abba sent </span>several rulings from Eretz Yisrael <span class="gemarra-regular">t</span><span class="gemarra-regular">o</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rav Yosef bar Ḥama</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> including the following: In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span><span class="gemarra-regular">who says to another: You stole my slave, and he </span><span class="gemarra-regular">says </span>in response: <span class="gemarra-regular">I did not steal </span>him, and when the first inquires: If so, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is the nature of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">his </span>presence <span class="gemarra-regular">in your </span>possession, the latter responds: <span class="gemarra-regular">You sold </span><span class="gemarra-regular">him to me, </span>

Daf 128a

or: <span class="gemarra-regular">You gave him to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">me as a gift, </span>if he then adds: Although I owe you nothing, as the slave is mine, if it is <span class="gemarra-regular">your desire, take an oath </span>that he is yours <span class="gemarra-regular">and take </span>him; <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the claimant <span class="gemarra-regular">takes an oat</span><span class="gemarra-regular">h</span> that the slave is his, the one in possession of the slave <span class="gemarra-regular">cannot retract </span>his offer, although he was not obligated to make the offer.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is </span>Rabbi Abba <span class="gemarra-regular">teaching us? We</span> already <span class="gemarra-regular">learned </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Sanhedrin</span> 24a) that if one of the litigants <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>the other: My <span class="gemarra-regular">father is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> trusted </span>to adjudicate <span class="gemarra-regular">for me, </span>or: <span class="gemarra-regular">Your father is trusted</span> to adjudicate <span class="gemarra-regular">for me, </span>or: These <span class="gemarra-regular">three cattle herder</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> who are not experts in <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">are trusted </span>to adjudicate <span class="gemarra-regular">for me, </span>and all of the individuals this litigant mentioned are legally disqualified from serving as judges, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir says </span>that the one who stated this <span class="gemarra-regular">can retract </span>his statement, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the Rabbis say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">he cannot retract </span>it, and he is obligated to have them serve as judges if the other litigant so desires. Since this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is already stated in the mishna, what novel <span class="it-text">halakha</span> did Rabbi Abba teach?
The Gemara in tractate <span class="it-text">Sanhedrin</span> records a dispute between <span class="it-text">amora’im</span> as to the circumstances of the case of that mishna, with one <span class="it-text">amora</span> holding that the dispute pertains only to a case where the one accepting the disqualified judge will need to forgive a debt if the judge rules in accordance with his opponent, while another <span class="it-text">amora</span> holds that the dispute pertains even to a case where he will need to pay the other litigant if the judge rules in accordance with his opponent. By stating his ruling in a case where the litigant will have to give the slave to the other, Rabbi Abba <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us this, that the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">dispute </span>between Rabbi Meir and the Rabbis is even <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>a case where the litigant said: <span class="gemarra-regular">I will give yo</span><span class="gemarra-regular">u</span> what you claim if that is the ruling of these judges, and the Rabbis hold that if he subsequently wishes to retract his suggestion, he cannot do so. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>Rabbi Abba also teaches that the <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the statement of the Rabbis.</span>
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Abba </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">sent </span>a ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">to Rav Yosef bar Ḥama </span>that the <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is that the creditors of one who died <span class="gemarra-regular">collect </span>the debts <span class="gemarra-regular">from the </span>Canaanite <span class="gemarra-regular">slaves </span>the deceased left his heirs, i.e., they take the slaves, as slaves have the same status as land in this regard. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav Naḥman says </span>that they <span class="gemarra-regular">do not collec</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> the debt by taking the slaves.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Abba </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">sent </span>a ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">to Rav Yosef bar Ḥama </span>that with regard to people with a common ancestor, the <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is that the testimony of members of the <span class="gemarra-regular">third </span>generation <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>members of the <span class="gemarra-regular">secon</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> generation whose closest familial connection is through that ancestor is <span class="gemarra-regular">valid. </span>For example, one can testify about his first cousin once removed, and is not disqualified as a relative. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava says: Even </span>the testimony of members of the third generation <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>members of the <span class="gemarra-regular">first </span>generation is valid; e.g., one can testify about his great-uncle.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Mar bar Rav Ashi deemed </span>one’s testimony <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">father’s father valid, </span>as he considered it a case of testimony of a member of the third generation with regard to a member of the first generation, which Rava deemed valid. <span class="gemarra-regular">But the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">not in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Mar bar</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rav Ashi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Abba </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">sent </span>a ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">to Rav Yosef bar </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Ḥama </span>concerning testimony: If one <span class="gemarra-regular">knew </span>information that could serve as <span class="gemarra-regular">testimony about </span>the boundary of another’s <span class="gemarra-regular">land before </span><span class="gemarra-regular">he became blind, and </span>then he <span class="gemarra-regular">became blind, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">disqualified </span>from bearing witness in a dispute as to the boundaries of that person’s properties.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Shmuel said: He </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is fit </span>to bear witness, as it is <span class="gemarra-regular">possible </span>for him <span class="gemarra-regular">to determine the boundaries </span>of the fields despite his blindness. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>fit to identify a movable item, e.g., <span class="gemarra-regular">a cloak, </span>as he cannot see it. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav Sheshet said: </span>He can identify <span class="gemarra-regular">even a cloak, </span>as it is <span class="gemarra-regular">possible </span>for him <span class="gemarra-regular">to determine its length </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and its width. But </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>fit to identify <span class="gemarra-regular">a piece of silver. And Rav Pappa said: </span>He can identify <span class="gemarra-regular">even a piece of silver, </span>as it is <span class="gemarra-regular">possible </span>for him <span class="gemarra-regular">to determine its weight.</span>
The Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises an objection </span>from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> (<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span>, <span class="it-text">Sanhedrin</span> 3:5): If one <span class="gemarra-regular">knew </span>information that could serve as <span class="gemarra-regular">testimony about </span>another <span class="gemarra-regular">before he became his son-in</span><span class="gemarra-regular">-law, and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">he became his son-in-law, </span>thereby becoming a relative who is disqualified from bearing witness concerning him; or if he was <span class="gemarra-regular">able to hear </span>at the time he witnessed an incident <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">he became </span><span class="gemarra-regular">deaf; </span>or if he was <span class="gemarra-regular">able to see </span>at the time he witnessed an incident <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">became blind; </span>or if he was halakhically <span class="gemarra-regular">competent and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">became insane, </span>in all these cases, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">disqualified </span>from bearing witness.
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">he knew </span>information <span class="gemarra-regular">about him</span> that could serve as <span class="gemarra-regular">testimony before he became his son</span><span class="gemarra-regular">-in-law, and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">he became his son-in-law</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">his daughter died, </span>so that they are no longer related; or if he was <span class="gemarra-regular">able to hear, and</span> then <span class="gemarra-regular">became deaf, and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">again became able to hear</span><span class="gemarra-regular">; </span>or if he was <span class="gemarra-regular">able to see, and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">became</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> blind, and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">again became able to see; </span>or if he was halakhically <span class="gemarra-regular">competent, and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">became insane, and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">again became </span>halakhically <span class="gemarra-regular">competent, </span>in all these cases, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">fit </span>to bear witness.
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> concludes: <span class="gemarra-regular">This is the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">principle: Anyone whose initial </span>state <span class="gemarra-regular">or his ultimate </span>state, i.e., his state at the time of the incident or at the time of his testimony in court, <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>one of <span class="gemarra-regular">disqualificatio</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> for bearing witness is <span class="gemarra-regular">disqualified </span>from bearing witness. But any-one <span class="gemarra-regular">whose initial </span>state <span class="gemarra-regular">and his ultimate </span>state <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>one of <span class="gemarra-regular">fitness </span>to bear witness is <span class="gemarra-regular">fit </span>to bear witness, even if he was disqualified in the interim. This <span class="it-text">baraita</span> clearly states that one who is blind is disqualified from bearing witness. 

Daf 128b

The Gemara concludes: <span class="gemarra-regular">The</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> refutation </span>of the opinions <span class="gemarra-regular">of all </span>the <span class="it-text">amora’im</span> who held that a person who became blind after witnessing a matter can, in certain cases, testify about it, is indeed <span class="gemarra-regular">a conclusive refutation</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Abba sent </span>another ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">to Rav Yosef bar </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Ḥama: One who says </span>something <span class="gemarra-regular">concerning </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">child among </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">sons </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">deemed credible, and Rabbi Yoḥanan says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is not deemed credible.</span>
