The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is </span>Rabbi Abba <span class="gemarra-regular">saying? Abaye said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>is what Rabbi Abba <span class="gemarra-regular">is saying: One who says concerning </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">child among </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">sons: He shall inherit all my </span><span class="gemarra-regular">property, </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">deemed credible, in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka, </span>who holds that one can bequeath all his property to one of his heirs (130a). <span class="gemarra-regular">And</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rabbi Yoḥanan says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">he is not deemed credible, in</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis, </span>who disagree with Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava objects to this </span>explanation: According to Abaye’s explanation, <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>wording: Is <span class="gemarra-regular">deemed credible, and: He is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not deemed credible, </span>is not precise; <span class="gemarra-regular">he should have </span>employed the terms: <span class="gemarra-regular">Shall inherit, and: Shall not inherit, </span>as the issue is the ability of the father to specify who will inherit from him, not his credibility.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Rava said</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>is what Rabbi Abba <span class="gemarra-regular">is saying: One who</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> says about </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">child among </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">sons </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">he is</span> his <span class="gemarra-regular">firstborn </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">deemed credible, in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda </span>(127b); <span class="gemarra-regular">and Rabbi Yoḥanan says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">he is not deemed credible, in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis, </span>who disagree with Rabbi Yehuda.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Abba sent </span>another ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">to Rav Yosef bar </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Ḥama: </span>In a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who says: My wife </span><span class="gemarra-regular">will take </span>a portion of my estate <span class="gemarra-regular">like one of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the sons</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> she takes </span>a portion <span class="gemarra-regular">like one of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the sons, </span>as it is considered a gift. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava says: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>this ruling is only <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>the husband’s <span class="gemarra-regular">current property</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> which he can give her as a gift. The husband cannot give her a portion of his future property. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>furthermore, the calculation of her portion must take into account not only the number of sons the husband has at the time of his statement, but also <span class="gemarra-regular">the sons who come, </span>i.e., who will be born, <span class="gemarra-regular">afterward.</span>
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Abba sent </span>another ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">to Rav Yosef bar Ḥama: </span>In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who produces a promissory note against</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> another, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">the creditor says: I was not repaid anything</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, and the debtor says: I repaid hal</span><span class="gemarra-regular">f </span> the debt, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the witnesses testify that </span>the debtor <span class="gemarra-regular">repaid the entire </span>debt, then <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>debtor <span class="gemarra-regular">takes an oath </span>that he repaid half, as is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to one who admits to a part of a claim, and he is exempt from paying that half. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the creditor <span class="gemarra-regular">collects </span>the second <span class="gemarra-regular">hal</span><span class="gemarra-regular">f </span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from unsold property</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> but not from </span><span class="gemarra-regular">liened </span>property that was sold after the loan, <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>the buyers can <span class="gemarra-regular">say: We rely on the witnesses </span>that the debt was repaid in its entirety.
The Gemara compares this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> to the case of a promissory note that states that the debtor owes the creditor: <span class="it-text">Sela</span> coins, without stating how many. The creditor claims that he lent the debtor five <span class="it-text">sela</span> and the debtor claims that he borrowed only three. Rabbi Akiva holds that since the wording of the promissory note indicates a minimum debt of two <span class="it-text">sela</span>, and the creditor could not have collected the third <span class="it-text">sela</span> without the debtor’s admission, the latter’s admission to a part of the claim cannot render him liable to take an oath. The Gemara states: <span class="gemarra-regular">And even according to Rabbi Akiva, who says </span><span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the debtor is not liable to take an oath, as with regard to the third <span class="it-text">sela</span> his legal status <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>similar to that of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who returns a lost </span><span class="gemarra-regular">item, this statement </span>applies only in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where there </span><span class="gemarra-regular">are no witnesses </span>to the loan. <span class="gemarra-regular">But where there are </span><span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as is the case in Rabbi Abba’s ruling, the debtor <span class="gemarra-regular">fear</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> denying the entire debt. Therefore he is liable to take an oath that he repaid half, as one who admits to a part of the claim.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Mar bar Rav Ashi objects to this: On the contrary</span><span class="gemarra-regular">; even according to Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar, </span>who disagrees with Rabbi Akiva and <span class="gemarra-regular">says </span>that the debtor <span class="gemarra-regular">is considered </span>one who <span class="gemarra-regular">admits to a part of the claim, this statement</span> applies only in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where there are no witnesses</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> who support him. But </span>here in the case of Rabbi Abba, <span class="gemarra-regular">where there are witnesses who support him, </span>testifying that he repaid the entire debt, his legal status <span class="gemarra-regular">is certainly</span> that of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who returns a lost item, </span>and he does not need to take an oath that he repaid half.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Mar Zutra taught in the name of Rav Shimi </span><span class="gemarra-regular">bar Ashi: The </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in all these </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakhot</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Abba sent to Rav Yosef bar Ḥama. Ravina said </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to Rav Ashi: What </span>about the statement with <span class="gemarra-regular">which Rav </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Naḥman </span>disagreed, i.e., that a debt can be collected by taking the slaves the debtor left his heirs? Is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in accordance with this ruling of Rabbi Abba as well, despite the principle that in monetary matters the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is in accordance with Rav Naḥman’s opinion? Rav Ashi <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: We teach </span>a different tradition, that Rabbi Abba’s statement rules that a creditor <span class="gemarra-regular">does not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">collect </span>the debt from the slaves the debtor left his heirs, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman said the same.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>possibility <span class="gemarra-regular">does </span>Mar Zutra <span class="gemarra-regular">exclude </span>in ruling that <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is in accordance with Rabbi Abba’s statement? 

Daf 129a

<span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>his statement is said <span class="gemarra-regular">to exclude </span>the statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rava </span>that the testimony of members of the third generation concerning members of the first generation is valid, this is difficult, as Rava’s statement is not in conflict with Rabbi Abba’s statement that the testimony of members of the third generation with regard to members of the second generation is valid; <span class="gemarra-regular">it </span>merely <span class="gemarra-regular">adds </span>to it. <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>it is said to exclude the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Mar</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> bar Rav Ashi </span>that a grandfather can testify concerning his grandchild, this is also difficult, as it has already been established that <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">not in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Mar bar Rav Ashi. If </span>it is said <span class="gemarra-regular">to exclude </span>the rulings <span class="gemarra-regular">of Shmuel and Rav Sheshet and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rav Pappa, </span>that a person who became blind can testify about what he saw beforehand, this too is difficult, as their rulings <span class="gemarra-regular">were refuted </span>based on a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>.
The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>Mar Zutra’s statement is said <span class="gemarra-regular">to exclude </span>the statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan </span>that one cannot testify that a specific one of his sons is his firstborn, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>to exclude <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">strong objection of Mar bar Rav Ashi </span>to the statement of Rabbi Abba with regard to a case where a debtor admitted to part of a claim and witnesses testified that he repaid the entire debt. Despite Mar bar Rav Ashi’s objection, the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is that the debtor is not liable to take an oath.
§ The mishna teaches: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>on his deathbed <span class="gemarra-regular">who apportions his property orally, </span>granting it to his sons as a gift, and he <span class="gemarra-regular">increased </span>the portion given <span class="gemarra-regular">to one </span>of his sons <span class="gemarra-regular">and reduced </span>the portion given <span class="gemarra-regular">to one </span>other son, or equated the portion of the firstborn to the portions of the other sons, his statement stands. But if he said that they will receive the property not as a gift but as an inheritance, he has said nothing. If he wrote in his will, whether at the beginning, or in the middle, or at the end, that he is granting them the property as a gift, his statement stands. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What are </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the circumstances </span>where it is phrased as <span class="gemarra-regular">a gift at </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the beginning? What are the circumstances </span>where it is phrased as a gift <span class="gemarra-regular">in the middle? What are the circumstances </span>where it is phrased as a gift <span class="gemarra-regular">at the end?</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">When Rav Dimi came </span>from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia, he said that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says </span>that where one on his deathbed instructed: <span class="gemarra-regular">Such and such </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a field will be given to so-and-so and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">he will inherit it, this is </span>a case where it is phrased as <span class="gemarra-regular">a gift at the beginning. </span>Where he instructed: <span class="gemarra-regular">And he will inherit it and it will be </span><span class="gemarra-regular">given to him, this is </span>a case where it is phrased as <span class="gemarra-regular">a gift at the end</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Where he instructed: <span class="gemarra-regular">He will inherit it and it will be given </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to him and he will inherit it, this is </span>a case where it is phrased as <span class="gemarra-regular">a gift in the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">middle.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that his statement is valid pertains <span class="gemarra-regular">specifically </span>to a case where the two terms, giving and inheritance, are employed <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">one person and one field. But </span>if they are employed <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to one person and two fields, </span>e.g., if he says: Reuven will inherit this field and will be given that field, or <span class="gemarra-regular">one field and two people, </span>e.g., Reuven will inherit half of this field and Shimon will be given the other half, the part that was phrased as inheritance does <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>take effect. Only the part that is phrased as a gift takes effect.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar says: Even </span>in a case where the two terms are employed with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one person and two fields, </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">one field </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and two people, </span>his instruction takes effect, as both terms were employed with regard to the same person or the same field. <span class="gemarra-regular">But with regard to two fields and two </span><span class="gemarra-regular">people, </span>it does <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>take effect, as the two instructions are not connected to one another.
<span class="gemarra-regular">When Ravin came </span>from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia, <span class="gemarra-regular">he said </span>that if one on his deathbed said: <span class="gemarra-regular">Such and such a field will </span><span class="gemarra-regular">be given to so-and-so, and so-and-so, </span>i.e., another person, <span class="gemarra-regular">will inherit such and such a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> field, </span>i.e., another field, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says </span>that even the latter person, who was designated to inherit his field, has <span class="gemarra-regular">acquired </span>it. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar says: </span>He has <span class="gemarra-regular">not acquired</span> it.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said to Ravin: You have lightened our </span>burden with <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>statement that you cited, <span class="gemarra-regular">but you have made it</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> difficult for us </span>with the other <span class="gemarra-regular">one. Granted, </span>the contradiction <span class="gemarra-regular">between </span>this statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Elazar </span>that you cited and the previously cited statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Elazar </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. There, </span>in the previously cited statement, Rabbi Elazar said that the directive takes effect <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one person and two fields, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">here </span>he said that the directive does not take effect <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">two people and two fields.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>the apparent contradiction <span class="gemarra-regular">between </span>one statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Yoḥanan </span>and the other statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Yoḥanan </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">difficult</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>as Rav Dimi cited in Rabbi Yoḥanan’s name that his directive takes effect only in a case of one person and one field, and according to your citation in the name of Rabbi Yoḥanan it takes effect even in a case of two people and two fields.
Ravin answered him: Rav Dimi and I <span class="gemarra-regular">are </span><span class="gemarra-italic">amora’im</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>we each have a different tradition <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Yoḥanan.</span>
Ravin continued: <span class="gemarra-regular">And Reish Lakish says </span>that one has <span class="gemarra-regular">not acquired </span>the field in the case of two people and two fields <span class="gemarra-regular">unless </span>the giver <span class="gemarra-regular">says: So-and-so and so-</span><span class="gemarra-regular">and-so will inherit such and such a field and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">such and such </span>a field <span class="gemarra-regular">that I have given them </span><span class="gemarra-regular">as a gift</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and they will inherit it.</span>
This dispute between the <span class="it-text">amora’im</span> of Eretz Yisrael is also the subject <span class="gemarra-regular">of a disput</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> between the <span class="it-text">amora’im</span> of Babylonia. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Hamnuna says: </span>The mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">taught</span> that when both giving and inheritance are mentioned one can increase the portion of one of his sons <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>with regard to a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one person and one field</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, but </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one person and two fields, </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">one field and two people, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>effective. <span class="gemarra-regular">And</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rav Naḥman says: Even </span>in a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one person</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and two fields, </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">one field and two people, </span>it is effective, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>in a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">two fields and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> two people, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">not. And Rav Sheshet says: Even</span> in a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">two fields and two people, </span>it is effective.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Sheshet said: From</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> where do I say this? As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> (<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span>, <span class="it-text">Ketubot</span> 6:10): If a person on his deathbed, or <span class="gemarra-regular">one who </span>is going overseas, <span class="gemarra-regular">says </span>to his children’s steward: <span class="gemarra-regular">Give a shekel to my children </span>every <span class="gemarra-regular">wee</span><span class="gemarra-regular">k</span> for their needs, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>this is a situation where, based on their needs, <span class="gemarra-regular">they are fit </span>for the steward <span class="gemarra-regular">to give them a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">sela</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>i.e., double the amount, <span class="gemarra-regular">he gives them a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">sela</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>When the father mentioned a shekel, he presumably meant that the children should be given a sum in accordance with their actual requirements, not that specific amount. <span class="gemarra-regular">But if he said: Give</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> them only a shekel, </span>the steward <span class="gemarra-regular">gives them only </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a shekel, </span>and no more. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if he said: If</span> my children <span class="gemarra-regular">die, </span>

Daf 129b

<span class="gemarra-regular">others will inherit </span>their portion <span class="gemarra-regular">in their stead</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> then regardless of <span class="gemarra-regular">whether he said: Give them </span>a shekel, or <span class="gemarra-regular">whether he said: Do not give </span>them more than a shekel, the court <span class="gemarra-regular">gives </span>his children <span class="gemarra-regular">only a shekel </span>per week, so as not to reduce the share of the others, as their father clearly stated that he wishes to give his children only a specific stipend, and that he intends to leave the bulk of his property to others.
Rav Sheshet concludes: <span class="gemarra-regular">And isn’t </span>the case <span class="gemarra-regular">here like </span>a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">two fields and two people, </span>as the father gave part of his property to his sons as a gift, and the rest to others as an inheritance? <span class="gemarra-regular">But it</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is taught that </span>the others <span class="gemarra-regular">acquire </span>the property, although he employed only the terminology of inheritance concerning them.
Rav Sheshet <span class="gemarra-regular">raised the objection and he resolved it: </span>The term others is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>those who are <span class="gemarra-regular">fit to inherit</span> from <span class="gemarra-regular">him; and </span>the ruling of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka, </span>who holds that one can bequeath his property to anyone who is fit to inherit from him. Therefore it is unnecessary for the bequest to be phrased as a gift.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi said: Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a proof for the opinion of Rav Sheshet from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> (<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span> 8:4): If one states: <span class="gemarra-regular">My property </span>will go <span class="gemarra-regular">to you </span>after my death for your use during your lifetime, <span class="gemarra-regular">and after you </span>die, <span class="gemarra-regular">so-and-so will </span><span class="gemarra-regular">inheri</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> the property, <span class="gemarra-regular">and after </span>the one who inherits <span class="gemarra-regular">after</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> you </span>dies, <span class="gemarra-regular">so-and-so will inherit </span>the property, then in this case, when <span class="gemarra-regular">the first </span>recipient <span class="gemarra-regular">dies, the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">second acquires </span>it, and when <span class="gemarra-regular">the second dies, the third </span><span class="gemarra-regular">acquires </span>it. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if the second dies during the lifetime </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of the first, the property returns </span>after his death <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the heirs of the first, </span>and does not go to the third designated recipient, as his right was to inherit it from the second one, who never received it.
Rav Ashi states his proof: <span class="gemarra-regular">And here it is </span>a case <span class="gemarra-regular">like </span>that of <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span><span class="gemarra-regular">field</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and two people, </span>as the bequest to the first recipient was phrased as a gift, and to the second one it was phrased as inheritance; <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>yet the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches that </span>the second recipient <span class="gemarra-regular">acquires </span>the property after the death of the first.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> you would say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">here, too, </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>a case where the recipient is <span class="gemarra-regular">fit to inherit</span> from <span class="gemarra-regular">him, and </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka, if so, </span>why does it state that when <span class="gemarra-regular">the second dies, the third acquires </span>it?
Rav Ashi explains his previous comment: <span class="gemarra-regular">Didn’t Rav </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Aḥa, son of Rav Avya, send </span>the following ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span><span class="gemarra-regular">accordance with the statement of Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka? </span>If a person on his deathbed said: <span class="gemarra-regular">My property </span>is given <span class="gemarra-regular">to you, and after you to so-and-so, and </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">first </span>recipient <span class="gemarra-regular">was fit to inherit </span>from <span class="gemarra-regular">him</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">the second gets nothing in place of the first, </span>i.e., he does not receive the property after the first one dies, <span class="gemarra-regular">as this formulation </span>employed by the owner was <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">of a gift</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> rather, </span>it was <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">formulation of inheritance, and inheritance has no end</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., it cannot be stopped. Therefore, since the first recipient acquired it as inheritance, his heirs inherit it from him, and it cannot be taken by the second one. Therefore, the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is irreconcilable with the opinion of Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka.
The Gemara affirms: <span class="gemarra-regular">The</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> refutation of </span>the opinions <span class="gemarra-regular">of all </span>the Sages who disagree with the opinion of Rav Sheshet that even if one uses the two terms with regard to two fields and two people his gift to both people is effective, is <span class="gemarra-regular">a conclusive refutation.</span>
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Let us say that it is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> also a conclusive refutation </span>of the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Reish Lakish</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>who maintains that giving must be mentioned with regard to both recipients and both fields. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>how can <span class="gemarra-regular">you understand </span>this? <span class="gemarra-regular">But didn’t Rava say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Reish</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Lakis</span><span class="gemarra-regular">h</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with regard to these three </span>issues: Acquisition of land for the rights to its produce, <span class="it-text">ḥalitza</span> of a pregnant woman, and the matter of bequeathal phrased both as a gift and as inheritance?
The Gemara answers: This is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult. Here, </span>in the case where giving can be mentioned concerning one of the recipients and inheritance with regard to the other, it is a case where the two bequests were stated <span class="gemarra-regular">within </span>the time <span class="gemarra-regular">required for speakin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span> a short phrase, i.e., the time it takes to greet one’s teacher. According to the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>, within this time a speaker can retract his statement. Therefore both bequests are considered to be part of one statement. <span class="gemarra-regular">There, </span>in the case where Reish Lakish maintains that giving must be mentioned with regard to both people for it to take effect, it is a case where the final part of the statement, where he said: And they will inherit it, was <span class="gemarra-regular">after </span>the time required <span class="gemarra-regular">for speaking </span>a short phrase.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is that the legal status of <span class="gemarra-regular">any </span>statement interrupted or retracted <span class="gemarra-regular">within </span>the time <span class="gemarra-regular">required for speakin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span> a short phrase <span class="gemarra-regular">is like </span>that of continuous <span class="gemarra-regular">speech</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> This is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in all cases, <span class="gemarra-regular">apart from idol worship</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as one who accepts an idol as his god is liable to receive court-imposed capital punishment even if he retracts his statement within the time required for speaking a short phrase, 

Daf 130a

<span class="gemarra-regular">and betrothal, </span>as if a man betroths a woman and retracts the betrothal within the time required for speaking, his retraction is not effective.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who says: So-and-so will</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> inherit </span>from <span class="gemarra-regular">me</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">in a case where there is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a daughter, </span>or: <span class="gemarra-regular">My daughter will inherit </span>from <span class="gemarra-regular">me, in</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a case where there is a son, he has said</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> nothing, as he has stipulated counter to that which is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> written in the Torah </span>concerning the order of inheritance. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Yoḥanan ben Beroka says: If he said </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">about one</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> fit to inherit </span>from <span class="gemarra-regular">him</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">his statement stands, but</span> if it was <span class="gemarra-regular">about one for whom </span>it was <span class="gemarra-regular">not</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> fit to inherit </span>from <span class="gemarra-regular">him, his statement does not stand</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara infers from the mishna that <span class="gemarra-regular">the reason </span>the first <span class="it-text">tanna</span> rules that his bequeathal is invalid is <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>he bequeathed his estate to <span class="gemarra-regular">another </span>in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>he had <span class="gemarra-regular">a daughter, or </span>to his <span class="gemarra-regular">daughter where </span>he had <span class="gemarra-regular">a son, but </span>if he bequeathed his entire estate to one <span class="gemarra-regular">son among </span>his other <span class="gemarra-regular">sons, or </span>to one <span class="gemarra-regular">daughter among </span>his other <span class="gemarra-regular">daughters, his statement stands. </span>The Gemara questions this inference: <span class="gemarra-regular">Say the latter clause </span>of the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">if he said </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">about one fit to inherit </span>from <span class="gemarra-regular">him, his statement stands.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> This is </span>identical to the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the first </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>What information does this statement of Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka add? With regard to what case do they disagree?
The Gemara continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">And if you would say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka is saying </span>that one’s statement stands <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>in a case where he bequeathed his estate to <span class="gemarra-regular">another where </span>he had <span class="gemarra-regular">a daughter or </span>to <span class="gemarra-regular">a daughter where </span>he had <span class="gemarra-regular">a son, </span>as although he bequeathed it to one who is not currently his heir, the beneficiary would be fit to inherit from him if the current heirs die, and this would be contrary to the opinion of the first <span class="it-text">tanna</span>, this is difficult. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span><span class="gemarra-regular">isn’t it taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> (<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span> 7:18) that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yishmael, son of Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka, says: My </span><span class="gemarra-regular">father and the Rabbis did not disagree about </span>a case where one bequeathed his estate to <span class="gemarra-regular">another where </span>he had <span class="gemarra-regular">a daughter or </span>to <span class="gemarra-regular">a daughter where </span>he had <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">son; </span>in a case such as this, my father concedes <span class="gemarra-regular">that he has said nothing.</span>
Rabbi Yishmael continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">With </span><span class="gemarra-regular">regard to what </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">do they disagree? </span>They disagree <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span><span class="gemarra-regular">regard to </span>a case where he bequeathed his entire estate to one <span class="gemarra-regular">son among </span>his other <span class="gemarra-regular">sons, or </span>to one <span class="gemarra-regular">daughter among </span>his other <span class="gemarra-regular">daughters, as my father says </span>that the son or daughter <span class="gemarra-regular">inherits </span>the entire estate, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbis say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">he does not inherit </span>it.
The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span><span class="gemarra-regular">you wish, say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>Rabbi Yishmael <span class="gemarra-regular">is saying </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">they did not disagree </span>about a case where one bequeathed his estate to another where he had a daughter or to a daughter where he had a son, <span class="gemarra-regular">by inference, the first </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span> of that <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, to whom he was responding, <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">they </span>did <span class="gemarra-regular">disagree </span>in this case.
And <span class="gemarra-regular">if you wish, say </span>instead that the <span class="gemarra-regular">entire </span>mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>stating the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">is incomplete,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and this </span>is what <span class="gemarra-regular">it is teaching</span><span class="gemarra-regular">:</span> With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who says: So-and-so will inherit </span>from <span class="gemarra-regular">me, </span>in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where there is a daughter, </span>or: <span class="gemarra-regular">My daughter will inherit </span>from <span class="gemarra-regular">me, </span>in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> there is a son, he has said nothing, but </span>if he bequeathed his property to one <span class="gemarra-regular">son among </span>his other <span class="gemarra-regular">sons, or </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">daughter among </span>his other <span class="gemarra-regular">daughters, </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">if</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he said </span>that the son or daughter <span class="gemarra-regular">will inherit all</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> his property, his statement stands, as Rabbi Yoḥanan </span>ben Beroka <span class="gemarra-regular">says: If he said </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">about one fit to inherit</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> him, </span>that he should inherit all of his property, <span class="gemarra-regular">his statement stands.</span>
§ As for the halakhic ruling, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Yehuda says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel says: </span>The <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka. And </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rava says as well </span>that the <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance </span><span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: What </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is the reason </span>for the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Yoḥanan ben </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Beroka? The verse states: “Then it shall be, in the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">day that he causes his sons to inherit” </span>(Deuteronomy 21:16), which is interpreted to mean that <span class="gemarra-regular">the Torah gave the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> father permission to bequeath </span>his estate <span class="gemarra-regular">to whomever he wishes</span> among his sons.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to him: </span>Isn’t <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span><span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">derived from </span>the continuation of the verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“He may not make </span>the son of the beloved <span class="gemarra-regular">the firstborn</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> before the son of the hated, who is the firstborn”? From the prohibition against depriving the firstborn of his double portion it can be inferred that one can change the apportionment of the inheritance of his other sons.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">That </span>clause in the verse is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary for that which is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Abba</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Ḥanan says in the name of Rabbi Eliezer: </span>

Daf 130b

<span class="gemarra-regular">Why </span>must <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">verse state: “He may not make </span>the son of the beloved <span class="gemarra-regular">the firstborn” </span>(Deuteronomy 21:16)?
Abba Ḥanan explains: It is necessary <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">is stated </span>previously in the verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Then it shall be, in the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">day that he causes his sons to inherit,” as </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">might </span>have thought: <span class="gemarra-regular">Could this not </span>be derived through an <span class="it-text">a</span> <span class="it-text">fortiori</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">inference, </span>as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">And if </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">an ordinary </span>son, one who is not a firstborn, <span class="gemarra-regular">whose</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> power is enhanced </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">that he takes </span>in inheritance the property <span class="gemarra-regular">due </span>the deceased <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>he does the property the deceased <span class="gemarra-regular">possessed </span>at the time he died, nevertheless, <span class="gemarra-regular">the Torah</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> gave the father permission to bequeath </span>his estate <span class="gemarra-regular">to whichever</span> of his sons <span class="gemarra-regular">he wishes, </span>depriving his other sons of their portions, then with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a firstborn, whose power</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is diminished </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">that he does not take </span>a double portion of the property <span class="gemarra-regular">due </span>his father <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>he takes of the property the deceased <span class="gemarra-regular">possessed </span>at the time of his death, is it <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>clear <span class="gemarra-regular">all the more so</span> that his father can deprive him of the double portion he receives as a firstborn? Therefore, <span class="gemarra-regular">the verse states: “He</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> may not make </span>the son of the beloved <span class="gemarra-regular">the firstborn</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.”</span>
Abba Ḥanan continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">And let </span>the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">state </span>only the prohibition of: <span class="gemarra-regular">“He may not make </span>the son of the beloved <span class="gemarra-regular">the firstborn.” Why </span>must <span class="gemarra-regular">the verse state: “Then it shall</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> be, in the day that he causes his sons to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> inherit”?</span>
It is necessary <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">might </span>have thought: <span class="gemarra-regular">Could this</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not </span>be derived through an <span class="it-text">a</span> <span class="it-text">fortiori</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">inference, </span>as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">And if </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a firstborn, whose power </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is diminished </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">that he does not take </span>a double portion of the property <span class="gemarra-regular">due </span>his father <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>he takes of the property the deceased <span class="gemarra-regular">possessed, </span>nevertheless <span class="gemarra-regular">the Torah states</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: “He may not make </span>the son of the beloved <span class="gemarra-regular">the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> firstborn,” </span>i.e., the firstborn may not be deprived of his double portion, then with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">an ordinary </span>son, <span class="gemarra-regular">whose power is enhanced </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">that he takes </span>in inheritance the property <span class="gemarra-regular">due </span>the deceased <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>he does the property the deceased <span class="gemarra-regular">possessed, </span>is it <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>clear <span class="gemarra-regular">all the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> more so </span>that his father cannot deprive him of his portion of the inheritance?
Therefore, <span class="gemarra-regular">the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> verse states: “Then it shall be, in the day that</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he causes his sons to inherit,” </span>indicating that <span class="gemarra-regular">the Torah</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> gave the father permission to bequeath </span>his estate <span class="gemarra-regular">to whichever</span> of his sons <span class="gemarra-regular">he wishes. </span>Consequently, the prohibition “he may not make the son of the beloved the firstborn” is not available to prove that one may bequeath his estate to whichever of his sons he wishes.
§ The Gemara resumes discussion of the halakhic ruling: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Zerika says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ami says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ḥanina says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">says: </span>The <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka. Rabbi Abba said to </span>Rabbi Zerika: <span class="gemarra-regular">It was stated </span>that Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">ruled </span>in an actual case in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">With regard to what </span>principle <span class="gemarra-regular">do they disagree? </span>Since both Rabbi Zerika and Rabbi Abba agree that the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka, why did Rabbi Abba state that Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi ruled as much in an actual case? The Gemara answers: One <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage, </span>Rabbi Zerika, <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that a ruling in principle is <span class="gemarra-regular">a preferable </span>source for <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>rather than a ruling from an incident; <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage, </span>Rabbi Abba, <span class="gemarra-regular">holds</span> that a specific <span class="gemarra-regular">incident </span>ruled upon by <span class="gemarra-regular">a Sage </span>is a preferable source.
The Gemara examines which source is preferable. <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">One </span><span class="gemarra-regular">may derive </span>the <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> neither from a statemen</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> nor from</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> an inciden</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> where one saw a ruling issued in a certain manner, <span class="gemarra-regular">unless </span>the Sages explicitly <span class="gemarra-regular">tell him </span>that it is the <span class="gemarra-regular">practical </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> If he <span class="gemarra-regular">asked </span>the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">and they told him </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">practical </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, he may </span><span class="gemarra-regular">go and act </span>upon the ruling in those circumstances, <span class="gemarra-regular">provided </span><span class="gemarra-regular">that he does not compare </span>between cases and apply the ruling to other circumstances.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is the meaning of the statement: <span class="gemarra-regular">Provided that he does not compare? </span><span class="gemarra-regular">But don’t we compare </span>cases throughout <span class="gemarra-regular">the entire Torah? </span>The main method of halakhic derivation is through comparing cases where the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> was already established to cases where the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is unclear.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>is what the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is saying: Provided that he does </span><span class="gemarra-regular">not compare between </span>various cases of <span class="gemarra-regular">animals with wounds that </span><span class="gemarra-regular">will cause them to die within twelve months [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">tereifot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">], </span>which are forbidden for consumption. In general, one may compare cases, but with regard to the definition of a <span class="it-text">tereifa</span>, one may not compare.
This is <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">With regard to </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tereifot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, one does not say: This </span>wound <span class="gemarra-regular">is similar to that </span>wound. Every type of wound has its own <span class="it-text">halakhot</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">And do not wonder </span>about this principle, <span class="gemarra-regular">as there are </span>organs with regard to which one <span class="gemarra-regular">cuts </span><span class="gemarra-regular">it from here, </span>i.e., one side, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">dies </span>within twelve months, but one <span class="gemarra-regular">cuts it from there</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>i.e., another side, <span class="gemarra-regular">and it lives.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Asi said to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan: When the Master, </span>i.e., Rabbi Yoḥanan, <span class="gemarra-regular">says</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to us: This is </span>the <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, should we act </span>upon the ruling? Rabbi Yoḥanan <span class="gemarra-regular">said: Do not act </span>upon the ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">unless I say </span>that it is <span class="gemarra-regular">a practical </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said to Rav Pappa and to Rav Huna, son</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of Rav Yehoshua: When a legal ruling of mine comes</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> before you and you perceive a refutation of it, do</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not tear it up until you come before me </span>to discuss it. <span class="gemarra-regular">If I have </span>a valid <span class="gemarra-regular">explanation, I </span><span class="gemarra-regular">will tell you, and if not, I will retract </span>my ruling. If a ruling of mine comes before you <span class="gemarra-regular">after </span>my <span class="gemarra-regular">death, </span>when you can no longer discuss it with me, <span class="gemarra-regular">do not tear it up, but do not learn </span><span class="gemarra-regular">from it either, </span>i.e., do not rule in accordance with it. <span class="gemarra-regular">Do not tear it up, as had I </span><span class="gemarra-regular">been there, perhaps I would have told you </span>a valid <span class="gemarra-regular">explanation </span>that you would have accepted; 

Daf 131a

but <span class="gemarra-regular">do</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not learn from it either, as a judge has only</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> what his eyes se</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> as the basis for his ruling. One must rule according to his own understanding.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava raises a dilemma: In </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a healthy perso</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> who bequeaths his estate to one of his sons, <span class="gemarra-regular">how </span>should the court rule? Should it be reasoned that <span class="gemarra-regular">when Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka says </span>that the bequeathal is valid, he said so specifically <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a person on his deathbed, since</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he is capable of bequeathal, </span>as the verse: “In the day that he causes his sons to inherit” (Deuteronomy 21:16), from which the validity of this bequeathal is derived, is referring specifically to the time of one’s death; <span class="gemarra-regular">but</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a healthy person, </span>he did <span class="gemarra-regular">not</span> say his ruling? <span class="gemarra-regular">Or perhaps </span>he stated his ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">even in </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a healthy person</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Mesharshiyya said to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rava: Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a resolution of your dilemma from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">as Rabbi Natan said to Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi: <span class="gemarra-regular">You taught </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">your Mishna in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka, as we learned </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Ketubot</span> 52b): If the husband <span class="gemarra-regular">did not write for </span><span class="gemarra-regular">her </span>in her marriage contract: Any <span class="gemarra-regular">male childre</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> you will</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> have from me will inherit the money of your marriage</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> contract in addition to their portion </span>of the inheritance <span class="gemarra-regular">that</span> they receive together <span class="gemarra-regular">with their brothers, </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>nevertheless <span class="gemarra-regular">obligated</span> as though he had written it, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> stipulation of the cour</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> and consequently takes effect even if it is not explicitly stated. This mishna is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka that one may add to the share of some of his sons at the expense of the others.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>We did not learn that the male children she has from him will inherit the money of the marriage contract; that version is not accurate. Rather, <span class="gemarra-regular">we learned </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">they </span><span class="gemarra-regular">will take </span>the money of the marriage contract, as a gift. When a bequeathal is worded in this manner, it is valid in any event, as stated in the previous mishna (126b).
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi later retracted his response, and <span class="gemarra-regular">said: </span>My response was because of <span class="gemarra-regular">immaturity </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">I had </span><span class="gemarra-regular">in me, and I was insolent in the presence of </span>Rabbi <span class="gemarra-regular">Natan the Babylonian </span>by responding in a manner that is incorrect. It is incorrect for the following reason: <span class="gemarra-regular">But</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> since we maintain </span>that concerning an obligation detailed in a marriage document ensuring inheritance rights of a woman’s <span class="gemarra-regular">male</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> children, </span>the beneficiaries <span class="gemarra-regular">do not repossess liened </span>property that has been sold, one can infer that they do not receive the money as a gift. As, <span class="gemarra-regular">if it enters</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> your mind </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">we learned </span>in the mishna that <span class="gemarra-regular">they</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> will take </span>the money as a gift, <span class="gemarra-regular">why don’t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> they repossess liened </span>property? The gift was given to them before the property was sold to others. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, conclude from</span> this claim that <span class="gemarra-regular">we learned </span>in the mishna that <span class="gemarra-regular">they</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> will inherit </span>the money.
Rav Mesharshiyya concludes: <span class="gemarra-regular">Of whom have you heard that</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he holds this opinion </span>that one can add to the inheritance of some of his sons at the expense of the others? It is the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan ben</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Beroka, and conclude from </span>the mishna in <span class="it-text">Ketubot</span> that his ruling applies <span class="gemarra-regular">even with regard to a healthy person, </span>as one does not write a marriage contract on his deathbed. This resolves Rava’s dilemma.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa said to Abaye</span><span class="gemarra-regular">:</span> How can one prove that the mishna in tractate <span class="it-text">Ketubot</span> is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka? <span class="gemarra-regular">Whether</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> according to the one who says </span>that the correct version of the mishna is: <span class="gemarra-regular">They will take, and whether according</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to the one who says </span>the correct version of the mishna is: <span class="gemarra-regular">They will inherit, </span>the mishna is difficult, for the following reason: <span class="gemarra-regular">A person cannot transfer ownership </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">an</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> entity that has not </span>yet <span class="gemarra-regular">come into the world</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> How can the husband confer rights to his property to children that have yet to be born?
Rav Pappa explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">And even according to Rabbi Meir, who says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">person can transfer ownership </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">an entity that has not </span>yet <span class="gemarra-regular">come into the world, this statement </span>applies specifically in a case where he transfers the item <span class="gemarra-regular">to an entity</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>i.e., a person, <span class="gemarra-regular">that is in the world; </span><span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>with regard to transferring ownership of an item <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">an entity that is not </span>yet <span class="gemarra-regular">in the world, </span>e.g., to his children that have yet to be born, this statement does <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>apply. Therefore, the ruling of the mishna is difficult according to all opinions.
Rav Pappa explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>evidently <span class="gemarra-regular">a stipulation of the court is different. </span>Since this clause of the marriage contract was instituted by rabbinic ordinance, it is not subject to the standard <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of transferring property, and one can transfer ownership of an item to an entity that is not yet in the world. Accordingly, <span class="gemarra-regular">here too, </span>with regard to the dispute between Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka and the Rabbis, <span class="gemarra-regular">a stipulation of the court</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is different, </span>and even according to the Rabbis, who disagree with the opinion of Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka, one can bequeath the money of his wife’s marriage contract to the male children she will have from him in any manner he chooses. Consequently, there is no proof that the mishna is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka.
Abaye <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>The assertion that the mishna is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka is <span class="gemarra-regular">due to </span>the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that it expresses </span>this bequeathal <span class="gemarra-regular">with</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the wording: They will inherit</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as opposed to: They will take. This indicates that a person can normally apportion his inheritance to his sons in any manner he wishes, in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye then said: That which I </span><span class="gemarra-regular">said is not correct. </span>The expression: They will inherit, is appropriate even according to the Rabbis, who disagree with Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka, <span class="gemarra-regular">as we learned </span>in the continuation of that mishna that even if the husband <span class="gemarra-regular">did not write </span><span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>his wife: Any <span class="gemarra-regular">female childre</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> you will have from</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> me will sit in my house and be sustained from</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> my property until they are taken by men, </span>i.e., until they are married, he <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>nevertheless <span class="gemarra-regular">obligated </span>as though he had written it, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it </span>too <span class="gemarra-regular">is a stipulation</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of the court.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>since these two clauses are written adjacent to each other in the marriage contract, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is </span>effectively a case where one bequeaths his estate to two people: <span class="gemarra-regular">To this </span>one, the daughters, <span class="gemarra-regular">as a gift, and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to that </span>one, the sons, <span class="gemarra-regular">as an inheritance. And </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">any </span>case where one bequeaths his estate <span class="gemarra-regular">to this </span>person <span class="gemarra-regular">as an inheritance and to that </span>person <span class="gemarra-regular">as a gift, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">even the Rabbis concede </span>that the bequest is valid even if it is to people who are not his heirs, as it is considered a gift with regard to both recipients.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥumi, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and some say </span>it was <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥananya bar Minyumi, said </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to Abaye: </span>

Daf 131b

<span class="gemarra-regular">From where </span>do you conclude <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>both clauses, the one for the benefit of the sons and the one for the benefit of the daughters, <span class="gemarra-regular">were instituted by one court </span>and are therefore each read in light of the other? <span class="gemarra-regular">Perhaps they were</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> instituted by two </span>different <span class="gemarra-regular">courts </span>and are unrelated to each other. Accordingly, the wording of the gift and the wording of the inheritance are not part of the same statement.
The Gemara answers: This possibility should <span class="gemarra-regular">not enter your mind, as </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">former clause </span>of that mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>(<span class="it-text">Ketubot</span> 49a): A father is not obligated to provide his daughter’s sustenance. <span class="gemarra-regular">This interpretation was interpreted </span>by <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya before </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the Sages of the vineyard in Yavne</span><span class="gemarra-regular">:</span> Since the Sages instituted that after the father’s death, <span class="gemarra-regular">the sons </span><span class="gemarra-regular">inherit </span>the sum of money specified in their mother’s marriage contract, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the daughters are sustained </span>from their father’s estate, these two <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> are equated: <span class="gemarra-regular">Just as the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">sons inherit only after their father’s death, </span>not during his lifetime, <span class="gemarra-regular">so too, the daughters are sustained </span>from their father’s property <span class="gemarra-regular">only after their father’s death</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, if you say </span>that the two clauses <span class="gemarra-regular">were instituted by one court, this is</span> the reason <span class="gemarra-regular">that we derive </span>the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of one <span class="gemarra-regular">ordinance</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from </span>the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of the other <span class="gemarra-regular">ordinance, </span>under the assumption that a court institutes ordinances in a consistent manner. <span class="gemarra-regular">But</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> if you say </span>that they <span class="gemarra-regular">were instituted by two </span>distinct <span class="gemarra-regular">courts </span>operating in different periods, <span class="gemarra-regular">how can we derive </span>the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of one <span class="gemarra-regular">ordinance from </span>the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of the other <span class="gemarra-regular">ordinance?</span>
The Gemara rejects this explanation: <span class="gemarra-regular">From where </span>is it assumed that they were instituted by one court? <span class="gemarra-regular">Actually, I will say to you </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">perhaps </span>the two clauses <span class="gemarra-regular">were instituted by two </span>separate <span class="gemarra-regular">courts</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, and </span>nevertheless Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya derived the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of one ordinance from the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of the other ordinance, because <span class="gemarra-regular">the latter court </span>presumably <span class="gemarra-regular">instituted </span>its ordinance <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with</span> the format of <span class="gemarra-regular">the former court, so that </span>one should <span class="gemarra-regular">not ask </span>about contradictions between one <span class="gemarra-regular">ordinance and </span>the other <span class="gemarra-regular">ordinance. </span>With regard to the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of inheritance, there is no reason to read the two clauses in light of the other.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel says: </span>A person on his deathbed <span class="gemarra-regular">who writes </span>a document granting <span class="gemarra-regular">all his property </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to his wif</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> has merely rendered her a steward. </span>The assumption is that he did not intend to deprive his heirs of their entire inheritance. Rather, he intended to appoint her as a steward in charge of the property, so that the heirs will honor her.
The Gemara discusses similar cases: It is <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious </span>that if one writes a document granting all his property to <span class="gemarra-regular">his</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> adult son</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> he does not intend to give him the entire inheritance, but to have him distribute it among his brothers. Rather, <span class="gemarra-regular">he has merely rendered him a steward</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">apotropos</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> If he writes it to <span class="gemarra-regular">his minor son</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> what </span>is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? Is it still assumed that his intention is to appoint him as a steward, or is that implausible since a minor boy is not yet capable of assuming this position and therefore the father apparently intended to bequeath to him the entire inheritance?
It <span class="gemarra-regular">was stated </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥanilai bar Idi </span>says that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>if one wrote a document granting all his property to <span class="gemarra-regular">his minor son who is lying in</span> his <span class="gemarra-regular">crib, </span>he does not receive the entire inheritance. Rather, the father presumably intended to appoint him as a steward when he reached adulthood, so that the other heirs would honor him.
The Gemara states: It is <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious </span>that if one wrote a document granting all his property to <span class="gemarra-regular">his son</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and anothe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> person, he intended to give <span class="gemarra-regular">the other </span>person half the property <span class="gemarra-regular">as a gift, and </span>to appoint <span class="gemarra-regular">his son a steward </span>to oversee the property of his brothers, with whom he shares the other half. Similarly, if he wrote a document granting all his property to <span class="gemarra-regular">his </span><span class="gemarra-regular">wife and anothe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> person, he intended to give <span class="gemarra-regular">the other</span> person half the property <span class="gemarra-regular">as a gift, and </span>to appoint <span class="gemarra-regular">his wife a steward </span>to oversee the other half of the property for his sons.
Furthermore, it is obvious that if one wrote a document granting all his property to <span class="gemarra-regular">his betrothe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> wife, </span>whom he did not yet wed, <span class="gemarra-regular">or </span>to <span class="gemarra-regular">his </span>former <span class="gemarra-regular">wife, </span>whom he had <span class="gemarra-regular">divorced</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> he intended to give it to them <span class="gemarra-regular">as</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a gift, </span>as he had no reason to have his heirs honor them.
<span class="gemarra-regular">A dilemma was raised</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> before </span>the Sages: If one wrote a document granting all his property to his <span class="gemarra-regular">daughter before </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">sons</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> in a case where he has sons who would inherit from him, <span class="gemarra-regular">or </span>to his <span class="gemarra-regular">wife before </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">brothers</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> or</span> to his <span class="gemarra-regular">wife before the husband’s sons </span>who are not her sons, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? Is it assumed that his intention was to appoint her as a steward or to give her the property as a gift?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Ravina said in</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the name of Rava </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">in all of </span>these cases the recipient <span class="gemarra-regular">did not acquire </span>the property. Rather, he or she was merely appointed a steward, <span class="gemarra-regular">except for </span>the cases of <span class="gemarra-regular">his betrothed wife and his </span>former <span class="gemarra-regular">wife </span>whom he <span class="gemarra-regular">divorced. </span>By contrast, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Avira said in the name of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rava </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">in all of </span>these cases the recipient <span class="gemarra-regular">acquired</span> the property, <span class="gemarra-regular">except for </span>the cases of his <span class="gemarra-regular">wife before</span> his <span class="gemarra-regular">brothers and </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">wife before the husband’s sons</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>where he clearly intended only to appoint her as a steward. 

Daf 132a

With regard to the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that a person on his deathbed who wrote a document granting all his property to his wife has appointed her as a steward, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava raises a dilemma: In </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a healthy person, what </span>is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? Should it be reasoned that specifically <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a person </span><span class="gemarra-regular">on his deathbed it </span>is assumed that he intended to appoint his wife as a steward, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is preferable </span><span class="gemarra-regular">for him that her word be heard </span>and she is honored after his death, <span class="gemarra-regular">but in </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">healthy person, he is </span>still <span class="gemarra-regular">standing </span>and can ensure that his wife is honored, so he apparently intended to actually give her all of his property? <span class="gemarra-regular">Or perhaps </span>should it be reasoned that <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a healthy person</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as well, it is preferable that </span>his wife’s <span class="gemarra-regular">word be heard </span>and she be given honor <span class="gemarra-regular">from now?</span>
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a resolution of the dilemma from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: If <span class="gemarra-regular">one writes </span>a document that <span class="gemarra-regular">the profits of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> his property </span>should go <span class="gemarra-regular">to his wife </span>in the event that he dies or divorces her, <span class="gemarra-regular">she collects </span>payment of <span class="gemarra-regular">her marriage contract, </span>which he wrote her at the time of their marriage, <span class="gemarra-regular">from the land </span>itself. The profits are hers as a result of his gift. Similarly, if he wrote a document granting her <span class="gemarra-regular">one-half, one-third, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">or one-quarter </span>of his property, <span class="gemarra-regular">she collects </span>payment of <span class="gemarra-regular">her marriage contract from the rest </span>of his property, which he did not give her as a separate gift.
