The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues: If one <span class="gemarra-regular">wrote </span>a document granting <span class="gemarra-regular">all his property to his wife, and </span>subsequently <span class="gemarra-regular">a promissory note emerged against him </span>for a loan he took while they were married but before he gave her this gift, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Eliezer says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">she </span>should <span class="gemarra-regular">tear up</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> her </span>deed of <span class="gemarra-regular">gif</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and remain with her marriage </span><span class="gemarra-regular">contract, </span>so that the creditor will not be able to collect the property she received, as her marriage contract preceded the promissory note. <span class="gemarra-regular">And the Rabbis say: She </span>must <span class="gemarra-regular">tear </span><span class="gemarra-regular">up her marriage contrac</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and remain with her </span>deed of <span class="gemarra-regular">gift, </span>as by accepting the gift of all her husband’s property she waived her right to receive payment of her marriage contract. Since the promissory note preceded the deed of gift, the creditor receives the property, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the wife <span class="gemarra-regular">is found </span>to be <span class="gemarra-regular">bald from here and from there</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>i.e., she receives neither her gift nor her marriage contract.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Yehuda the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> bake</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> said: </span>There was <span class="gemarra-regular">an incident where </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">matter </span><span class="gemarra-regular">occurred to my sister’s daughter </span>who is my <span class="gemarra-regular">daughter-</span><span class="gemarra-regular">in-law [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">kalla</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> that my son wrote such a document to her, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the incident came before the Sages. </span><span class="gemarra-regular">And they said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">she </span>must <span class="gemarra-regular">tear up her marriage </span><span class="gemarra-regular">contract and remain with her </span>deed of <span class="gemarra-regular">gift, and she </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is found </span>to be <span class="gemarra-regular">bald from here and from there.</span>
The Gemara infers: <span class="gemarra-regular">The reason </span>she loses her gift <span class="gemarra-regular">is that a promissory note emerged against him, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">but if a promissory note did not emerge against him, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">she acquires </span>the gift of his property. <span class="gemarra-regular">And with regard </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to what </span>case is this stated? <span class="gemarra-regular">If we say </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to a person on his deathbed, but </span><span class="gemarra-regular">didn’t you say </span>previously that in such a case <span class="gemarra-regular">he merely rendered her a steward? Rather, is it not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to a healthy person? </span>Accordingly, Rava’s dilemma is resolved: If a healthy person writes a document granting all his property to his wife, it is hers.
The Gemara rejects this proof: <span class="gemarra-regular">Actually, </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is stated <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> person on his deathbed; and Rav Avira would interpret </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> as referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to all of </span>the cases mentioned above in which, in his opinion, the wife acquires the property and is not appointed as a steward. And <span class="gemarra-regular">Ravina would</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> interpret </span>it specifically <span class="gemarra-regular">in reference to </span>a case where one wrote a document granting all his property to <span class="gemarra-regular">his betrothed</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> wife or his </span>former <span class="gemarra-regular">wife, whom he divorced</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> where he concedes that she acquires the property.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef bar Minyumi says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> says: </span>The <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is in accordance with the opinion of the Rabbis. <span class="gemarra-regular">She </span>must <span class="gemarra-regular">tear up her marriage contrac</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and remain with her </span>deed of <span class="gemarra-regular">gift, and she is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">found </span>to be <span class="gemarra-regular">bald from here and from there.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Is this to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">say that Rav Naḥman does not follow </span>the principle of <span class="gemarra-regular">assessing </span>intention, meaning that even if one did not state something explicitly, the court assesses what his intention was and decides the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> based on that assessment? Clearly, upon accepting the gift the wife did not intend to waive payment of her marriage contract and thereby be left with nothing in the event that her husband’s creditor produces a promissory note that predates her gift.
<span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t it taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> (<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span>, <span class="it-text">Ketubot</span> 5:9): In a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where one’s </span><span class="gemarra-regular">son went overseas and he heard that his son died, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>then he <span class="gemarra-regular">arose and wrote </span>a document granting <span class="gemarra-regular">all </span><span class="gemarra-regular">his property to others</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and then his son came </span>back, <span class="gemarra-regular">his gift </span>to the other people <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>a valid <span class="gemarra-regular">gift. Rabbi Shimon ben Menasya says: His gift is not</span> a valid <span class="gemarra-regular">gift, as had he known that his son</span> was <span class="gemarra-regular">alive he would not have written </span>a document granting <span class="gemarra-regular">them </span>his property. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav Naḥman says </span>that the <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon ben</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Menasya. </span>Apparently, Rav Naḥman follows the principle of assessing intention.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">There, </span>in the case of one who writes a document granting all his property to his wife, it <span class="gemarra-regular">is different, as </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">beneficial to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">her that it be publicized that he wrote </span>a document granting <span class="gemarra-regular">her </span>all of <span class="gemarra-regular">that property, </span>and she was willing to risk not receiving payment of her marriage contract to gain this benefit.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">We learned </span>in a mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">there </span>(<span class="it-text">Pe’a</span> 3:7): If a man <span class="gemarra-regular">writes </span>a document granting <span class="gemarra-regular">his property to his sons, and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he wrote </span>a document granting <span class="gemarra-regular">any amount of land to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> his wife, she has lost </span>her right to receive payment of <span class="gemarra-regular">her marriage contract</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> The Gemara questions this: <span class="gemarra-regular">Because</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he wrote </span>a document granting <span class="gemarra-regular">her any amount of land</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, she has lost </span>her right to receive payment of <span class="gemarra-regular">her</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> marriage contract? </span>Why should this be?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: </span>This mishna is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>a case where the husband <span class="gemarra-regular">transfers</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> ownership </span>of his property <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>his sons <span class="gemarra-regular">through </span>his wife’s participation in a formal act of acquisition. Not only did she not protest the transfer of property to the sons, but she facilitated the transaction. Clearly, she agreed to waive payment of her marriage contract. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Shmuel says: </span>It is referring not only to a case where she actually participates in the act of acquisition, but also <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>a case where he <span class="gemarra-regular">distributes </span>the property to his sons <span class="gemarra-regular">in</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> her presence, and she is silen</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> and does not ask about her marriage contract. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Ḥanina, says: </span>It is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>a case where <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span><span class="gemarra-regular">says to her: Take </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>parcel of <span class="gemarra-regular">land for </span><span class="gemarra-regular">your marriage contract</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> 

Daf 132b

<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">taught here </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the leniencies </span>that apply to <span class="gemarra-regular">a marriage contract</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> This manner in which the wife loses her right to receive payment of her marriage contract is a leniency for the husband, as an ordinary creditor does not lose money he is owed in this fashion.
The Gemara questions this statement: <span class="gemarra-regular">We learned </span>in the same mishna that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">if she accepted </span>the distribution <span class="gemarra-regular">upon herself, even if</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he did not write </span>a document granting <span class="gemarra-regular">her </span>any amount of land, <span class="gemarra-regular">she has lost </span>her right to receive payment of <span class="gemarra-regular">her marriage contract. By inference, </span>it can be stated <span class="gemarra-regular">that the first </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> holds </span>that both his <span class="gemarra-regular">writing </span>a document granting her a piece of land <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>her <span class="gemarra-regular">acceptance</span> of the distribution <span class="gemarra-regular">are necessary </span>for her to lose her right, contrary to the interpretation of all three <span class="it-text">amora’im</span>, i.e., Rav, Shmuel, and Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, all of whom assumed that she need not affirmatively accept the distribution and that her silence is sufficient.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if you would say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> entire </span>mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei, </span>who holds that either the husband’s writing a deed of gift or the wife’s acceptance of the distribution is sufficient, <span class="gemarra-regular">but isn’t it taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Yehuda said: </span>According to the first <span class="it-text">tanna</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">whe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> does she lose her right to receive payment of her marriage contract? In a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where she was there </span>at the time of the distribution <span class="gemarra-regular">and accepted </span>it; <span class="gemarra-regular">but if </span><span class="gemarra-regular">she was there but did not accept </span>it, or <span class="gemarra-regular">accepted</span> it <span class="gemarra-regular">but was not there, she has not lost </span>her right to receive payment of <span class="gemarra-regular">her marriage contract, </span>as she can claim that her acquiescence was only to please her husband and was not sincere. The Gemara concludes: The <span class="gemarra-regular">refutation </span>of the opinions <span class="gemarra-regular">of all </span>the interpretations of the <span class="it-text">amora’im</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>indeed <span class="gemarra-regular">a conclusive refutation.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman: This </span>is the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav; this </span>is the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel; </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>is the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina. What does the Master </span><span class="gemarra-regular">hold </span>in this matter? Rav Naḥman <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: As </span><span class="gemarra-regular">I say, that once he rendered her a partne</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> in the property <span class="gemarra-regular">among the sons</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> she lost </span>her right to receive payment of <span class="gemarra-regular">her marriage contract.</span>
Rav Naḥman’s opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">was</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> also stated </span>as a halakhic ruling: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef bar Minyumi</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">once he rendered her</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a partner </span>in the property <span class="gemarra-regular">among the sons, she lost</span> her right to receive payment of <span class="gemarra-regular">her marriage contract.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> raises a dilemma: In </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a healthy person</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, what </span>is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? <span class="gemarra-regular">Do we say </span>that the wife loses her right to receive payment of her marriage contract only <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a person on </span><span class="gemarra-regular">his deathbed, as she knew that he had no </span>other property <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>nevertheless <span class="gemarra-regular">waived </span>payment of the marriage contract, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span><span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a healthy person, she </span>might have <span class="gemarra-regular">reasoned </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">he will then acquire </span>other property from which she will be able to collect payment of her marriage contract, and that is why she accepted the distribution of the property? If so, she did not waive her right to receive payment of her marriage contract. <span class="gemarra-regular">Or perhaps, </span>should it be reasoned that since <span class="gemarra-regular">in any event, now he</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> has no </span>other property, her acceptance should be interpreted as waiving her right? The Gemara concludes: The dilemma <span class="gemarra-regular">shall stand</span> unresolved.
§ There was <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain </span>man on his deathbed <span class="gemarra-regular">who said to </span>the people surrounding him: Give <span class="gemarra-regular">one-half </span>of my estate <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>my <span class="gemarra-regular">daughter, and one-half to </span>my other <span class="gemarra-regular">daughter, and one-third of the produce to </span>my <span class="gemarra-regular">wife. Rav Naḥma</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> happened </span>to come <span class="gemarra-regular">to Sura. He</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> entered </span>the study hall <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>see <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥisda</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> who <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>In <span class="gemarra-regular">a case like this, what </span>is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? Rav Naḥman <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>is what <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel says: Even </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">he transferred to her </span>ownership <span class="gemarra-regular">only one palm tree for its produce</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> she has</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> lost </span>her right to receive payment of <span class="gemarra-regular">her marriage contract</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
Rav Ḥisda <span class="gemarra-regular">said</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to him: Say that Shmuel said </span>his statement that she loses her right <span class="gemarra-regular">there, </span>in a case where he gave her a palm tree for its produce, <span class="gemarra-regular">because he transferred</span> rights <span class="gemarra-regular">in the land itself to her ownership, </span>as the palm tree is connected to the ground. But <span class="gemarra-regular">here, </span>in this case, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">produce </span>that he gave her, without any share in the land itself. Perhaps she does not lose payment of her marriage contract. Rav Naḥman <span class="gemarra-regular">said</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to him: You say </span>that he gave her only <span class="gemarra-regular">movable</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> property? I certainly did not </span>mean to <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that she loses her right even if he gave her only <span class="gemarra-regular">movable</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> propert</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span> such as produce. Rather, she receives payment of her marriage contract.
There was <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain </span>man on his deathbed <span class="gemarra-regular">who said to </span>the people surrounding him: Give <span class="gemarra-regular">one-third </span>of my property <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>my <span class="gemarra-regular">daughter, and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">one-third to </span>my other <span class="gemarra-regular">daughter, and one-third to </span>my <span class="gemarra-regular">wife. One of his daughters died </span>before he did, and her portion consequently returned to his possession. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappi </span><span class="gemarra-regular">thought to say </span>that the wife <span class="gemarra-regular">takes only one-third. </span>She cannot receive payment of her marriage contract from the two-thirds bequeathed to the daughters, as by entering a partnership with the daughters in ownership of the property, she waived payment of her marriage contract. 

Daf 133a

<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Kahana said to him: If </span>the husband had <span class="gemarra-regular">then acquired </span>other property, <span class="gemarra-regular">would she not have </span><span class="gemarra-regular">taken </span>it as payment of her marriage contract? <span class="gemarra-regular">And since </span><span class="gemarra-regular">if he </span>would have <span class="gemarra-regular">then acquire</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> other property <span class="gemarra-regular">she would</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> have taken </span>it as payment of her marriage contract, <span class="gemarra-regular">now</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> she also takes </span>the deceased daughter’s share as payment of her marriage contract.
There was <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain</span> person <span class="gemarra-regular">who divided his property between his wife and his</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> son, leaving </span>out a <span class="gemarra-regular">single palm tree. Ravina thought to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> say </span>that the wife <span class="gemarra-regular">has only </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">single palm tree</span> as future payment of her marriage contract, which was presumably left out of the distribution for this reason. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yeimar</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> said to Ravina: If she does not have </span>the right to collect payment of her marriage contract from all of his property, as she presumably waived that right when he gave her the gift of some of his property, <span class="gemarra-regular">she</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> does not have </span>the right to collect it from the <span class="gemarra-regular">single palm tree either </span>and it belongs to the heirs. Rav Yeimar presents a different ruling: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, since </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is that <span class="gemarra-regular">she </span>does <span class="gemarra-regular">descend to </span>collect the <span class="gemarra-regular">palm tree</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> she </span>therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">descends to </span>collect <span class="gemarra-regular">all of the property</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as well, </span>i.e., she receives payment of her marriage contract from all the property.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna says: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a person on his deathbed who wrote </span>a document granting <span class="gemarra-regular">all his property to another, </span>the court <span class="gemarra-regular">investigates </span>the legal status of the recipient: <span class="gemarra-regular">If he is fit </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to inherit </span>from <span class="gemarra-regular">him</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> e.g., if he is one of his sons, <span class="gemarra-regular">he takes </span>the property <span class="gemarra-regular">as an </span><span class="gemarra-regular">inheritance, and if not, he takes it as a gift.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman </span><span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Why should you steal </span>this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> and not attribute it to its source? <span class="gemarra-regular">If you hold in </span><span class="gemarra-regular">accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka, say </span>explicitly that the <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka, as your halakhic statement follows </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka </span>that a person can bequeath his property to any of his heirs.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Perhaps this is what you </span>meant to <span class="gemarra-regular">say</span><span class="gemarra-regular">:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> There was a certain </span>childless person <span class="gemarra-regular">who </span><span class="gemarra-regular">was dying, and </span>those around him <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: To </span><span class="gemarra-regular">whom should his, </span>i.e., your, <span class="gemarra-regular">property </span>be given? <span class="gemarra-regular">Perhaps</span> it should be given <span class="gemarra-regular">to so-and-so? And he</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> said to them: Rather, to whom </span>if not him? <span class="gemarra-regular">And you, </span>Rav Huna, meant to <span class="gemarra-regular">say to us: If</span> that person <span class="gemarra-regular">is fit to inherit </span>from <span class="gemarra-regular">him</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> takes it as an inheritance, and if not, he takes</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it as a gift. </span>Rav Huna <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Yes</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, that is what I was saying</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">With regard to what </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is there a difference whether he receives it as an inheritance or as a gift? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Adda bar Ahava, </span>who was <span class="gemarra-regular">in the presence of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rava, thought </span>that it would be correct <span class="gemarra-regular">to say: If</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he is fit to inherit </span>from <span class="gemarra-regular">him, </span>the giver’s <span class="gemarra-regular">widow is sustained from his property</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as she has the right to be sustained from the inheritance; <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">if not, </span>and the property was given as a gift, <span class="gemarra-regular">his widow is not sustained from his property.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said to him: </span>Can the widow’s right be <span class="gemarra-regular">diminished </span>by the gift? <span class="gemarra-regular">Now </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">you say with regard to inheritance, </span>which is granted <span class="gemarra-regular">by </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Torah law, </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">his widow is sustained from his property, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">gift </span>of a person on his deathbed, which is effective without any formal act of acquisition <span class="gemarra-regular">by rabbinic law</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> all the more so </span>is it <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>clear that the widow has sustenance rights?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Rava said </span>that the difference whether it is inheritance or a gift is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the ruling that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Aḥa bar </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Avya sent: According to the statement of Rabbi Yoḥanan </span><span class="gemarra-regular">ben Beroka, </span>in the case of one who said: <span class="gemarra-regular">My </span><span class="gemarra-regular">property </span>is given <span class="gemarra-regular">to you, and after you to so-</span><span class="gemarra-regular">and-so, and the first </span>recipient <span class="gemarra-regular">was fit to inherit </span>from <span class="gemarra-regular">him, the second gets nothing in place of the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">first, </span>i.e., he does not receive the property after the first one dies, <span class="gemarra-regular">as this formulation </span>employed by the owner was <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">of a gift. Rather, </span>it was <span class="gemarra-regular">a formulation of inheritance, and inheritance has no end, </span>i.e., it cannot be stopped. Therefore, since the first recipient acquired it as an inheritance, his heirs inherit it from him, and it cannot be taken by the second.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said to Rav Naḥman: But he ended</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it. </span>The one who bequeathed it to him ended his inheritance in advance by stating that after the first dies, the property will be given to the second. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">He thought </span>that inheritance <span class="gemarra-regular">has an end; but the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Merciful One states </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">it has no end. </span>

There was <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain </span>person <span class="gemarra-regular">who said to another: My </span><span class="gemarra-regular">property </span>is given <span class="gemarra-regular">to you, and after you, to so</span><span class="gemarra-regular">-and-so, and the first one was fit to inherit</span> from <span class="gemarra-regular">him. </span>After <span class="gemarra-regular">the first died, the second came and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> claimed </span>the property.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ilish, </span>who was <span class="gemarra-regular">in</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the presence of Rava, thought to say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the second</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> also take</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> a share of the property; he divides it with the heirs of the first. Rava <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">him: Judges of compromise</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> who as a matter of course divide disputed property between the parties, <span class="gemarra-regular">rule in this </span><span class="gemarra-regular">manner. </span>But <span class="gemarra-regular">isn’t this </span>identical to the case concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">which Rav Aḥa bar Rav Avya sent </span>a ruling that the second receives nothing?
Rav Ilish <span class="gemarra-regular">was </span><span class="gemarra-regular">embarrassed </span>by his mistake. To comfort him, Rav <span class="gemarra-regular">read </span>the following verse <span class="gemarra-regular">about him: “I, the Lord, will hasten it </span><span class="gemarra-regular">in its time” </span>(Isaiah 60:22), as if to say: It was due to Divine Providence that I was here to correct you before your mistaken ruling was implemented.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who wrote </span>a document granting <span class="gemarra-regular">his property to others </span>as a gift <span class="gemarra-regular">and left his sons </span>with nothing, <span class="gemarra-regular">what he did is done, </span>i.e., it takes effect; <span class="gemarra-regular">but the Sages are displeased with him. Rabban Shimon ben </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Gamliel says: If </span>he did so because <span class="gemarra-regular">his sons were </span><span class="gemarra-regular">not acting properly, he is remembered </span><span class="gemarra-regular">positively</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">A dilemma</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> was raised before </span>the Sages: <span class="gemarra-regular">Do the Rabbis disagree </span><span class="gemarra-regular">with Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel, </span>maintaining that depriving one’s children of their inheritance is inappropriate in any event, <span class="gemarra-regular">or </span><span class="gemarra-regular">not?</span>
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, as Yosef ben Yo’ezer had a son who </span><span class="gemarra-regular">was not acting properly. </span>Yosef ben Yo’ezer <span class="gemarra-regular">had a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">vessel [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">illiyyata</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> full <span class="gemarra-regular">of dinars, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">he arose and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">consecrated it </span>to the Temple treasury, depriving his son of his inheritance. His son <span class="gemarra-regular">went and married the daughter of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">King Yannai’s crown weaver. </span>After the son’s <span class="gemarra-regular">wife</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> gave birth, he bought her a fish [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">binita</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> He</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> tore its </span>stomach open and <span class="gemarra-regular">found a pearl in it</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>He decided to sell it.
His wife <span class="gemarra-regular">said</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to him: Do not bring it to </span>the treasury of <span class="gemarra-regular">the king </span>to sell it, <span class="gemarra-regular">as they will take </span><span class="gemarra-regular">it from you for an insignificant </span>sum of <span class="gemarra-regular">money. </span>Rather, <span class="gemarra-regular">go bring it to the </span>Temple <span class="gemarra-regular">treasurers</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> And do </span><span class="gemarra-regular">not appraise it yourself</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as declaration to the Most </span><span class="gemarra-regular">High is equivalent to transfer to an ordinary </span>person, and if you offer to sell it for an amount less than its worth, you will not be able to change your mind. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, let them appraise it.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">He brought</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it </span>to the Temple treasury, and <span class="gemarra-regular">they appraised it as</span> having the value of <span class="gemarra-regular">thirteen vessels [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">illiyyata</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] </span>full <span class="gemarra-regular">of dinars</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>The treasurers <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: There are seven </span><span class="it-text">illiyyata</span> of dinars at our disposal to pay you for the pearl, but <span class="gemarra-regular">there are not </span>an additional <span class="gemarra-regular">six. He said to</span> the treasurers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Give me </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">seven </span>in exchange for the pearl, and as for the additional <span class="gemarra-regular">six </span>that you owe me, <span class="gemarra-regular">they are hereby consecrated to Heaven.</span>
The treasurers <span class="gemarra-regular">arose and wrote</span><span class="gemarra-regular">:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Yosef ben Yo’ezer bestowed one </span><span class="it-text">illiyyata</span> to the Temple treasury, <span class="gemarra-regular">and his son bestowed six. And there are </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">who say </span>that they wrote: <span class="gemarra-regular">Yosef ben Yo’ezer </span><span class="gemarra-regular">bestowed one </span><span class="it-text">illiyyata</span> to the Temple treasury, <span class="gemarra-regular">and his son </span><span class="gemarra-regular">removed seven, </span>which he received for the pearl.
The Gemara infers: <span class="gemarra-regular">From </span>the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that they said </span>approvingly that Yosef ben Yo’ezer’s son <span class="gemarra-regular">bestowed </span>seven, <span class="gemarra-regular">by inference, he acted </span><span class="gemarra-regular">well </span>when he left him out of his inheritance. The Gemara responds: <span class="gemarra-regular">On the contrary; from </span>the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>according to the second account, <span class="gemarra-regular">they said </span>disparagingly that he <span class="gemarra-regular">removed </span>seven, <span class="gemarra-regular">by inference, </span>Yosef ben Yo’ezer <span class="gemarra-regular">did not act</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> well </span>when he left him out of his inheritance, as he caused money to be removed from the Temple treasury. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, no </span>inference is <span class="gemarra-regular">to be learned from this </span>story with regard to the dilemma as to whether the Rabbis agree with the opinion of Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel, as the two accounts contradict each other on this matter.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>halakhic conclusion <span class="gemarra-regular">was </span>reached <span class="gemarra-regular">about </span>this matter? <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear, as</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Shmuel said to Rav Yehuda: </span><span class="gemarra-italic">Shinnana</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> do not be</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in a house where inheritance is transferre</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> away from its rightful heir, <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>if it is transferred <span class="gemarra-regular">from a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">wicked son to a good son</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and all the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">more so </span>if it is transferred <span class="gemarra-regular">from a son to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a daughter. </span>Evidently, the Rabbis hold that inheritance should not be transferred in any case.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught: </span>There was <span class="gemarra-regular">an incident involving</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> one man whose children did not act properly. He arose</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and wrote </span>a document transferring all <span class="gemarra-regular">his propert</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Yonatan ben Uzziel</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> one of the Sages, as a gift. <span class="gemarra-regular">What did Yonatan ben Uzziel do? <span class="gemarra-regular">Shamma</span><span class="gemarra-regular">i</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> came to </span>Yonatan ben Uzziel <span class="gemarra-regular">with his staff and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">traveling ba</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span> to protest his giving part of the property to the man’s children against the deceased’s wishes. Daf 134a

but <span class="gemarra-regular">if not, </span>as the property is mine and I have the right to do with it whatever I want, <span class="gemarra-regular">you cannot repossess what I </span><span class="gemarra-regular">returned </span>to the man’s children either. Shammai then <span class="gemarra-regular">said: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Ben Uzziel reprimanded me; ben Uzziel reprimanded me, </span>and I have no response.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What did </span>Shammai <span class="gemarra-regular">hold initially, </span>causing him to protest Yonatan ben Uzziel’s behavior? The Gemara answers: He protested <span class="gemarra-regular">due </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to the incident </span>that happened <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the city of <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Ḥoron.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">As </span><span class="gemarra-regular">we learned </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Nedarim</span> 48a): <span class="gemarra-regular">An incident </span>occurred <span class="gemarra-regular">involving someone in </span>the city of <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Ḥoron whose father </span><span class="gemarra-regular">had vowed not to derive benefit from him, and </span>the son <span class="gemarra-regular">was marrying off his </span>own <span class="gemarra-regular">son </span>and wanted his father to be able to participate in the wedding meal. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>he therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">said to another: </span>The <span class="gemarra-regular">courtyard </span>where the wedding will take place <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the wedding <span class="gemarra-regular">meal are hereby </span><span class="gemarra-regular">given to you as a gift, but they are </span>given <span class="gemarra-regular">to you only so that my father will come and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> eat with us at the meal. </span>The son wanted to circumvent the prohibition imposed by the vow and enable his father to participate in the meal, so he transferred ownership to someone else for that purpose.
The recipient <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: If they are</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> mine, they are </span>all <span class="gemarra-regular">hereby consecrated to Heaven, </span>i.e., the Temple, and are forbidden to everyone. The son <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him </span>in anger: <span class="gemarra-regular">I did not give you </span><span class="gemarra-regular">my </span>property <span class="gemarra-regular">so that you should consecrate them to Heaven. </span>The recipient <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: You gave me your </span>property <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>so <span class="gemarra-regular">that you and your father would eat and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">drink and </span>thereby <span class="gemarra-regular">appease each other, and the sin </span>of transgressing the vow would <span class="gemarra-regular">be hung on his, </span>i.e., my, <span class="gemarra-regular">head, </span>as I enabled the transgression.
The mishna continues: In reference to this incident, <span class="gemarra-regular">the Sages said: Any gift that is not</span> so absolute <span class="gemarra-regular">that if </span>the recipient <span class="gemarra-regular">were to consecrate it</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the gift <span class="gemarra-regular">would be consecrated, is not a gift</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>In other words, in order for it to be a gift the recipient must have the ability to consecrate it. Similarly, Shammai had initially reasoned that the gift to Yonatan ben Uzziel was not a valid gift, as its sole purpose was so that the property should not fall into the possession of the man’s children. Once he discovered that Yonatan ben Uzziel consecrated part of the gift, he realized that it was, in fact, a valid gift, with which the recipient could do whatever he pleased.
§ Apropos Yonatan ben Uzziel, the Gemara cites that <span class="gemarra-regular">the Sages taught: Hillel the Elde</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> had eighty </span><span class="gemarra-regular">students. Thirty of them </span>were sufficiently <span class="gemarra-regular">worthy that the Divine </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Presence should rest upon the</span><span class="gemarra-regular">m</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as </span>it did upon <span class="gemarra-regular">Moses</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> our teacher, thirty of them </span>were sufficiently <span class="gemarra-regular">worthy that the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> sun should stand still for them as </span>it did for <span class="gemarra-regular">Joshua bin Nun, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">twenty </span>were on <span class="gemarra-regular">an intermediate </span>level between the other two. <span class="gemarra-regular">The greatest of all </span>the students was <span class="gemarra-regular">Yonatan ben Uzziel, and the least of them </span>was <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabban Yoḥanan ben Zakkai.</span>
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">said about Rabban Yoḥanan ben </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Zakkai </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">he did not neglect Bible and Mishna; Talmud</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">halakhot</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span><span class="gemarra-italic">aggadot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">; minutiae of the Tora</span><span class="gemarra-regular">h</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and minutiae</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of the scribes</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>the hermeneutical principles of the Torah with regard to <span class="gemarra-italic">a</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">fortiori</span> inferences; <span class="gemarra-regular">and verbal </span><span class="gemarra-regular">analogies; and </span>the calculation of the calendric <span class="gemarra-regular">seasons</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">numerical values </span>of Hebrew letters <span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">gimatriyot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and parables of launderers, </span>which are folktales that can be used to explain the Torah, <span class="gemarra-regular">and parables </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of foxes</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> In addition, he did not neglect esoteric matters, including <span class="gemarra-regular">the conversation of demons, and the conversation of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">palm trees</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and the conversation of ministering angels, and </span>more generally, <span class="gemarra-regular">a great matter and a small matter.</span>
The Gemara elaborates: <span class="gemarra-regular">A great matter is </span>referring to the secrets of <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Design of the </span>Divine <span class="gemarra-regular">Chariot </span>(see Ezekiel, chapter 1), the conduct of the transcendent universe, <span class="gemarra-regular">and a small matter </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is, </span>for example, <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> that were ultimately formulated in the framework of <span class="gemarra-regular">the discussions of Abaye and Rava</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> He did not neglect any of these disciplines, so as <span class="gemarra-regular">to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> fulfill that </span>which <span class="gemarra-regular">is stated: “That I may cause those</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that love me to inherit substance and that I may</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> fill their treasuries” </span>(Proverbs 8:21), as Rabban Yoḥanan was filled with the disciplines of Torah and wisdom.
The Gemara adds: <span class="gemarra-regular">And if the least of them </span>was <span class="gemarra-regular">so </span>prolific, <span class="gemarra-regular">the greatest of them </span>was <span class="gemarra-regular">all the more so </span>prolific. The Gemara relates that the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">said o</span><span class="gemarra-regular">f  Y</span><span class="gemarra-regular">onatan </span><span class="gemarra-regular">ben Uzziel, </span>the greatest of Hillel’s students, that <span class="gemarra-regular">when </span><span class="gemarra-regular">he would sit and engage in Torah </span>study, the sanctity that he generated was so intense that <span class="gemarra-regular">any bird that </span><span class="gemarra-regular">would fl</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> over him would be incinerated.</span>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">One who says: This </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is my son, </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">deemed credible. </span>One who says: <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is my </span><span class="gemarra-regular">brother</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">not deemed credible </span>with regard to his other brothers’ obligation to share the inheritance with the subject of his statement. When one claims that this man is his brother, this claim is accepted with regard to the speaker’s own portion, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the man in question <span class="gemarra-regular">takes </span>a share of their father’s inheritance <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span><span class="gemarra-regular">him, </span>i.e., <span class="gemarra-regular">from his </span><span class="gemarra-regular">portion</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
If the man in question <span class="gemarra-regular">dies, </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">property</span> he received from the father’s inheritance <span class="gemarra-regular">shall return to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> its place</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., to the possession of the brother who testified on his behalf, from whose portion he received a share.
If <span class="gemarra-regular">property</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> came into </span>the man in question’s possession <span class="gemarra-regular">from somewhere</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> else, </span>other than from the father, and the man in question died, all of <span class="gemarra-regular">the brothers of </span>the one who testified <span class="gemarra-regular">shall inherit with </span>the one who testified, as according to his claim they too are the heirs of the deceased.
gemara The mishna teaches that one who says: <span class="gemarra-regular">This is my</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> son, </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">deemed credible. With regard to what </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is this stated? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel says: </span>It is stated <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to inheriting </span>from <span class="gemarra-regular">him, </span>i.e., the son inherits from the speaker, <span class="gemarra-regular">and with regard to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">rendering his wife exempt from levirate </span><span class="gemarra-regular">marriage</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Because he claims that the person in question is his son, his wife is not required to enter into levirate marriage after his death, as he has a child. 

Daf 134b

The Gemara asks: Isn’t it <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious </span>that his claim is deemed credible <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>someone <span class="gemarra-regular">inheriting </span>from <span class="gemarra-regular">him</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> Since he could have given this person his property as a gift, it need not be stated that his claim is accepted with regard to his inheritance. The Gemara responds: <span class="gemarra-regular">It </span><span class="gemarra-regular">was necessary for </span>the mishna to state that his claim is deemed credible <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to rendering his wife exempt </span><span class="gemarra-regular">from levirate marriag</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> despite the fact that it is not in his power to render her exempt, but the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of inheritance is not a novelty.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">We </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">learned this </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Kiddushin</span> 64a) <span class="gemarra-regular">as well: One who said</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> at the time of his death: I have children, </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">deemed credible, </span>and his wife is thereby exempt from levirate marriage. If he said: <span class="gemarra-regular">I have brothers</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and his wife therefore must enter levirate marriage, <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">deemed credible.</span>
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">There, </span>in that mishna, it is a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">not presumed by us to </span>have <span class="gemarra-regular">a brother</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Therefore, his wife is already presumed to be exempt from levirate marriage, and his claim that he has a son merely substantiates this presumption. <span class="gemarra-regular">Here, </span>the mishna adds a novelty that <span class="gemarra-regular">even if he is presumed to </span>have <span class="gemarra-regular">a brother, </span>his claim that he has a son is accepted, and his wife is thereby exempted from levirate marriage.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Yehuda says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel says: For what </span>reason <span class="gemarra-regular">did </span>the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that one who says: <span class="gemarra-regular">This is my </span><span class="gemarra-regular">son, </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">deemed credible? Sinc</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a husband who says: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">I divorced my wife, </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">deemed credible, </span>and his wife is thereby exempt from levirate marriage, he is deemed credible with regard to this claim as well.
As Rav Yosef forgot some of his Torah knowledge due to an illness, he questioned the accuracy of his citation of Rav Yehuda. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef said: Master of Abraham! </span>This reasoning <span class="gemarra-regular">makes </span>that which <span class="gemarra-regular">is taught </span>in the Mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">dependent upon </span><span class="gemarra-regular">that which is not taught, </span>as the credibility of one who claims: This is my son, is stated in the mishna, while the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that a husband’s claim that he divorced his wife is accepted is the statement of an <span class="it-text">amora</span>.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, if </span>this explanation <span class="gemarra-regular">was stated, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">it was stated like this: Rav Yehuda says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel </span><span class="gemarra-regular">says: For what </span>reason <span class="gemarra-regular">did </span>the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that one who says: <span class="gemarra-regular">This is my son, </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">deemed credible </span>with regard to rendering his wife exempt from levirate marriage? <span class="gemarra-regular">Since</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it is in his power to divorce her </span>and thereby render her exempt from levirate marriage, he is deemed credible with regard to this claim as well.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef said </span>in addition: <span class="gemarra-regular">Now that you said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">we say </span>that the husband is deemed credible <span class="gemarra-regular">since </span>he has the power to divorce her, <span class="gemarra-regular">a husband who says: I divorced my wife</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>is also <span class="gemarra-regular">deemed credible, since it is in his power</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to divorce her </span>at any time.
<span class="gemarra-regular">When Rav Yitzḥak bar Yosef came </span>from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia, he said that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">A husband who says: I have divorced my wife, </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">not deemed credible</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rav Sheshet waved his hand </span>disparagingly, as if to say that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef’s </span>statement that he is deemed credible <span class="gemarra-regular">since </span>it is in his power to divorce her <span class="gemarra-regular">is gone </span>due to Rabbi Yoḥanan’s statement.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Is that so? </span>Did Rabbi Yoḥanan actually say that? <span class="gemarra-regular">But doesn’t Rabbi Ḥiyya </span><span class="gemarra-regular">bar Avin say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: A husband who </span><span class="gemarra-regular">says: I have divorced my wife, </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">deemed credible?</span>
The Gemara answers: That is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult. Here, </span>in the statement that the husband is not deemed credible, Rabbi Yoḥanan was referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">a retroactive </span>testimony. For example, in a case where he testified that he divorced her on a certain date, and it is discovered that she engaged in sexual intercourse with another man after that date, his testimony is not accepted concerning whether the woman is liable to receive punishment; she is not considered to have been divorced at the time. This is because it is not in the husband’s power to divorce her retroactively.
By contrast, the statement <span class="gemarra-regular">there, </span>where Rabbi Yoḥanan said that the husband’s testimony is deemed credible, refers to testimony <span class="gemarra-regular">for the future, </span>e.g., where he says that he divorced her on that same day, or without specifying a date, in which case his statement is relevant only for the future. Since it was in his power to divorce her at that time, his testimony is deemed credible; if he dies, she is exempt from levirate marriage, and if she engages in sexual intercourse with another man, she is not considered to have committed adultery.
<span class="gemarra-regular">A dilemma </span><span class="gemarra-regular">was raised before </span>the Sages: If the husband <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>that he divorced his wife on a certain date, as <span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> retroactive </span>testimony, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">concerning </span>his testimony being <span class="gemarra-regular">deemed credible </span>and accepted <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to the future, </span>rendering her divorced from that time onward, despite the fact that his claim is not accepted with regard to the past?
The dilemma is based on the following fundamental question: <span class="gemarra-regular">Do we</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> divide the </span>husband’s <span class="gemarra-regular">statement, </span>accepting that he divorced his wife inasmuch as she is considered divorced from that time onward, since it is in his power to divorce her now, even though his claim that he divorced her in the past is not accepted? <span class="gemarra-regular">Or do we not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">divide the statement, </span>and say instead that his claim is rejected altogether, since his claim concerning the past cannot be accepted? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Mari and Rav Zevid </span>engaged in a dispute with regard to this issue. <span class="gemarra-regular">One says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">we divide</span> the husband’s statement, <span class="gemarra-regular">and one says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">we do</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not divide </span>it.
The Gemara asks: In <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>way <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>this case <span class="gemarra-regular">different from Rava’s </span>statement? <span class="gemarra-regular">As Rava says </span>that if a man says: <span class="gemarra-regular">So-and-so engaged in sexual</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> intercourse with my wife</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the husband <span class="gemarra-regular">and another </span>witness <span class="gemarra-regular">combine to kill him, </span>i.e., to have him sentenced to death for adultery. The Gemara infers: He combines with another witness <span class="gemarra-regular">to kill him, but not to kill </span><span class="gemarra-regular">her. </span>The wife is not sentenced to death based on this testimony, even if they testified that she engaged in sexual intercourse willingly, as a husband is disqualified from bearing witness concerning his wife. Evidently, the husband’s testimony is divided; his testimony concerning the man is accepted even though the testimony concerning his wife’s part in the same action is rejected.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">With regard to two </span>separate <span class="gemarra-regular">bodie</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> we divide</span> the statement. Therefore the husband’s testimony is accepted with regard to the man but rejected with regard to his wife. <span class="gemarra-regular">With regard to one body we do not divide</span> it. That is why one Sage holds that a husband’s claim that he divorced his wife in the past cannot be divided, so that his claim that he divorced her would be accepted while his claim as to when he divorced her would be rejected. 

Daf 135a

The Gemara relates: There was <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain </span>man, who was presumed to have brothers but no children, <span class="gemarra-regular">who was dying. </span>His wife was therefore presumed to be obligated in levirate marriage. Those with him <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: To whom </span>may <span class="gemarra-regular">his</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> wife, </span>i.e., your wife, be married? Is she required to enter into levirate marriage, or is she permitted to marry whomever she wishes? <span class="gemarra-regular">He said to them: She</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is fit to </span>marry even <span class="gemarra-regular">a High Priest</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> She is not required to enter into levirate marriage.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: </span>With <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>possibility need <span class="gemarra-regular">we be concerned</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with regard to her? Doesn’t Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: A husband who says: I</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> have divorced my wife, </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">deemed credible</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and she is exempt from levirate marriage? Therefore, this woman will be exempt as well. <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said to him: But when </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yitzḥak bar Yosef came </span>from Eretz Yisrael, he said that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: A husband who says: I have</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> divorced my wife, </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">not deemed credible</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Rava <span class="gemarra-regular">said</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to him: But didn’t we resolve </span>the contradiction, concluding that <span class="gemarra-regular">here </span>Rabbi Yoḥanan was referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">a retroactive </span>testimony <span class="gemarra-regular">and there </span>he was referring to testimony <span class="gemarra-regular">for the future</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? </span>Therefore, according to both versions of Rabbi Yoḥanan’s statement, the husband should be deemed credible in this case.
Abaye responded: <span class="gemarra-regular">But</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> shall we arise and rely on answers </span>in a halakhic ruling? Although the contradiction can be resolved in this manner, there is no guarantee that this resolution is correct. Therefore Rav Yitzḥak bar Yosef’s statement should still be taken into consideration. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava </span>subsequently <span class="gemarra-regular">said to Rav Natan bar Ami</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: Be concerned about it</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> There may be a dispute with regard to this issue, as the resolution cannot be relied upon.
The Gemara relates: There was <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain </span>man <span class="gemarra-regular">who was presumed by</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> us, </span>i.e., the court, <span class="gemarra-regular">to have no brothers</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and he said at the time of his death </span><span class="gemarra-regular">that he has no brothers. Rav Yosef said: </span>With <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>possibility need <span class="gemarra-regular">we be concerned with regard to </span>his wife, in terms of her requiring levirate marriage? For <span class="gemarra-regular">one, he</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is presumed by us to have no brothers, and furthermore</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, he said at the time of </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">death that he</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> has none. Abaye said to him: </span>But <span class="gemarra-regular">don’t </span>people <span class="gemarra-regular">sa</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that there are witnesses overseas who know that </span><span class="gemarra-regular">he has brothers? </span>Therefore, we should be concerned that this report is accurate.
Rav Yosef responded: <span class="gemarra-regular">In any event, now </span>the witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">are not </span>present <span class="gemarra-regular">before us, </span>so this possibility does not need to be taken into account. <span class="gemarra-regular">Isn’t this </span>the same as <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Ḥanina’s </span>ruling in a case where women who were captured and subsequently liberated claimed that they were not raped in captivity (<span class="it-text">Ketubot</span> 23a)? <span class="gemarra-regular">As </span>although people said there were witnesses elsewhere who could testify that they were raped, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Ḥanina says </span>that they were permitted to marry a priest, reasoning: Just because there may be <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses in the north [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">istan</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., in a distant place, <span class="gemarra-regular">will </span>the woman <span class="gemarra-regular">be forbidden?</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said to him</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: If we were lenient with regard to a captive woman</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, due to, </span>among other reasons, the fact that <span class="gemarra-regular">she </span><span class="gemarra-regular">makes herself repulsiv</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> before the captor </span>so that he will not want to rape her, and we assume that she was not raped, <span class="gemarra-regular">should we be lenient with regard to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a married woman? Rava said to Rav Natan bar </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Ami: Be concerned about it</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Do not permit this woman to remarry until the matter is clarified.
§ The mishna teaches that one who says: <span class="gemarra-regular">This is my brother, </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">not deemed credible </span>with regard to his other brothers’ share of their father’s inheritance. Rather, the man in question receives a portion only from the portion of the one who testified concerning him. The Gemara clarifies: <span class="gemarra-regular">And what </span><span class="gemarra-regular">do the other </span>brothers <span class="gemarra-regular">say? If they say: He is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">our brother, why </span>does the man in question <span class="gemarra-regular">take </span>a portion of the inheritance only <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>the one who testified, <span class="gemarra-regular">from his portion, and nothing more? </span>If the other brothers admit that he is their brother, they should give him a share of their portions as well. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, they </span><span class="gemarra-regular">are saying: He is not our brother.</span>
The Gemara questions this: <span class="gemarra-regular">Say the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> last clause </span>of the mishna: If <span class="gemarra-regular">property came into </span>the possession of the man in question <span class="gemarra-regular">from somewhere else, </span>and he died, <span class="gemarra-regular">the brothers of </span>the one who testified <span class="gemarra-regular">shall inherit </span>the man in question’s property <span class="gemarra-regular">with him.</span> Why should they inherit with him? <span class="gemarra-regular">Didn’t they say</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to him: He is not our brother?</span>
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>to state this ruling only in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where they say: We do not know</span> if he is our brother. Therefore, they are not obligated to give him a portion of their inheritance, as he cannot prove to them that he is their brother. Nevertheless, they can claim a portion of his inheritance after his death, on the basis of their brother’s testimony.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava </span><span class="gemarra-regular">says: That is to say </span>that if one says to another: <span class="gemarra-regular">I </span>have <span class="gemarra-regular">one hundred dinars in your possession</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and the other </span>person <span class="gemarra-regular">says: I do not know, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt, </span>similar to this case, where the brothers who claim that they do not know if this person is their brother are not obligated to share their inheritance with him.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said: </span>

Daf 135b

<span class="gemarra-regular">Actually, I will say to you </span>that one who responds to a claim that he does not know if he owes the one hundred dinars is <span class="gemarra-regular">obligated </span>to pay; <span class="gemarra-regular">but here, </span>in the case of the brothers, it <span class="gemarra-regular">is different. </span>The brothers are not obligated to share their portion with the man in question <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>the brother who testified <span class="gemarra-regular">is like </span>one who claims: <span class="gemarra-regular">Another </span>person <span class="gemarra-regular">has</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> one hundred dinars in your possession. </span>Since the claimant is not the one who is owed the money, the other party can reject his claim by merely answering that he does not know whether he owes him.
§ The mishna teaches: If the man in question <span class="gemarra-regular">dies, </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">property </span>he received from the father’s inheritance <span class="gemarra-regular">shall return to its place, </span>i.e., to the possession of the brother who testified on his behalf, and if the man in question received property from elsewhere, it is inherited by all the brothers equally. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava raises a dilemma: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">the enhancement </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of the property </span>received by the man in question from the portion of the brother who testified, <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>its <span class="gemarra-regular">enhanced </span>value was the result of an enhancement that <span class="gemarra-regular">happened naturally, </span>as opposed to one that resulted from exertion, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? Who inherits it?
The Gemara elaborates: <span class="gemarra-regular">With regard to enhancement that reaches shoulders</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., ripe produce that needs only to be harvested from the field, <span class="gemarra-regular">do not raise the dilemma, as </span><span class="gemarra-regular">it is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">like property that came into his possession </span><span class="gemarra-regular">from elsewhere. </span>It is not considered part of the land that was given to him by the brother who testified, and it is therefore divided among all the brothers. Rather, <span class="gemarra-regular">let the dilemma be raised with regard to enhancement that</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> does not reach shoulders, </span>and is not considered separate from the ground, <span class="gemarra-regular">such as a palm tree that thickened, </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">land that yielded silt. What </span>is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in this case? Is the enhancement included in the property itself, or is it considered separate property? The Gemara comments: The dilemma <span class="gemarra-regular">shall stand </span>unresolved.
mishna With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who died, and a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">will written by a person on his deathbed [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">dayetikei</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is found bound to his </span><span class="gemarra-regular">thigh</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> which clearly indicates that it was written by him and was not forged, <span class="gemarra-regular">this is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">nothing</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> The will is not valid, as he did not give it to anyone, and he may have reconsidered. If <span class="gemarra-regular">he transferred ownership of </span>the will to the designated recipient <span class="gemarra-regular">through another </span>person, <span class="gemarra-regular">whether one of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">heir</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> or <span class="gemarra-regular">whether not one of the heirs, his</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> statement stands.</span>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>(<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span> 8:10): <span class="gemarra-regular">Which </span>deed <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">dayetikei</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>and is collected by the designated recipient after the death of the giver? <span class="gemarra-regular">Any </span>deed <span class="gemarra-regular">in which it is written: This will be to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">stand and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">exis</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> after my death. <span class="gemarra-regular">And which </span>type <span class="gemarra-regular">is</span> considered a deed of <span class="gemarra-regular">gift? Any </span>deed <span class="gemarra-regular">in which </span><span class="gemarra-regular">it is written: From today and after </span>my <span class="gemarra-regular">death</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Is it </span>considered a deed of <span class="gemarra-regular">gift only </span>if the expression: <span class="gemarra-regular">From today and after </span>my <span class="gemarra-regular">death, </span>is written, whereas if it is written only: <span class="gemarra-regular">From now, it is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not </span>considered a deed of <span class="gemarra-regular">gift? Abaye said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">this</span> is what the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is saying: Which </span>deed of <span class="gemarra-regular">gift</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of a healthy person is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">like </span>the deed of <span class="gemarra-regular">gift of a person on his deathbed</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> in <span class="gemarra-regular">that</span> the recipient <span class="gemarra-regular">acquires </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">only after </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">death </span>of the giver? <span class="gemarra-regular">Any </span>deed <span class="gemarra-regular">in which it is written: From today</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and after </span>my <span class="gemarra-regular">death.</span>
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba bar Rav Huna was sitting in </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the balcony of Rav’s study hall, and sat and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">said in the name of Rabbi Yoḥanan: </span>If there is <span class="gemarra-regular">a person on his deathbed who says: Write </span>a deed of transfer, granting property of mine to another, <span class="gemarra-regular">and give</span> with it <span class="gemarra-regular">one hundred dinars to so-and-so, and</span> he then <span class="gemarra-regular">died</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> one does not write and give</span> it.
