This is because <span class="gemarra-regular">perhaps he resolved to transfer it</span> to him <span class="gemarra-regular">only with a deed </span>of transfer, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>since the deed was not written in his lifetime it cannot be written after his death, as <span class="gemarra-regular">a deed </span>of transfer is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>effective <span class="gemarra-regular">after the death </span>of the owner.
Rabba bar Rav Huna continued that when Rabbi Yoḥanan stated this <span class="it-text">halakha</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar said to </span>the other Sages: <span class="gemarra-regular">Heed this </span><span class="it-text">halakha</span>; it is correct. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Sheizevi said: </span>That is not what happened; <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar </span>is the one who <span class="gemarra-regular">said this </span><span class="it-text">halakha</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>it was <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan </span>who <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to them: Heed this </span><span class="it-text">halakha</span>.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: </span>It <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">reasonable </span>to say that the incident was <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the version presented <span class="gemarra-regular">by Rav Sheizevi. Granted, if you say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar said </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan needed to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">affirm </span>the ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Elazar. But if you say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan </span>was the one who <span class="gemarra-regular">said it, did </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar need to affirm </span>the ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Yoḥanan, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">his teacher?</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And furthermore, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>proof <span class="gemarra-regular">that Rabbi Elazar </span>was the one who <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>this <span class="it-text">halakha</span>, from another statement of his, <span class="gemarra-regular">as Ravin sent </span>a message <span class="gemarra-regular">in the name of Rabbi </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Abbahu: Know that Rabbi Elazar sent </span>a ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">to the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">exile in the name of our teacher, </span>stating that if there is <span class="gemarra-regular">a person on his deathbed who says: Write </span>a deed of transfer <span class="gemarra-regular">and give </span>with it <span class="gemarra-regular">one hundred </span><span class="gemarra-regular">dinars to so-and-so, and </span>he then <span class="gemarra-regular">died, one </span><span class="gemarra-regular">does not write and give </span>it. This is because <span class="gemarra-regular">perhaps </span><span class="gemarra-regular">he resolved to transfer it only with a deed </span>of transfer, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>since the deed was not written in his lifetime it cannot be written after his death, as <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">deed </span>of transfer is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>effective <span class="gemarra-regular">after the death </span>of the owner. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Yoḥanan says: </span>This ruling is correct; however, the wording of the deed <span class="gemarra-regular">should be examined.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>did Rabbi Yoḥanan mean by saying that the wording <span class="gemarra-regular">should be examined? </span>The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">When Rav Dimi came </span>from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia, he <span class="gemarra-regular">stated </span>two <span class="it-text">halakhot</span>. The first was that <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">dayetikei</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> cancels </span>a previous <span class="gemarra-italic">dayetikei</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> The second explains the examination to which Rabbi Yoḥanan was referring: If there is <span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> person on his deathbed who said</span><span class="gemarra-regular">:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Write </span>a deed of transfer <span class="gemarra-regular">and give </span>with it <span class="gemarra-regular">one hundred dinars to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> so-and-so, and </span>he then <span class="gemarra-regular">died, </span>the court must <span class="gemarra-regular">see </span>what his intention was in instructing the other person to write a deed of transfer; <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>it was <span class="gemarra-regular">to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> enhance </span>the recipient’s <span class="gemarra-regular">power </span>by writing a document proving that he was given the gift, <span class="gemarra-regular">one writes </span>the document even after his death, as he intended to give the money anyway. <span class="gemarra-regular">But if not, </span>rather it was the giver’s intention to transfer the gift specifically through a deed of transfer, <span class="gemarra-regular">one does not write </span>it and give the money, as a deed of transfer is not effective after the death of the owner.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Abba</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> bar Memel raises an objection </span>from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: If there is <span class="gemarra-regular">a healthy person who said</span><span class="gemarra-regular">:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Write </span>a deed of transfer <span class="gemarra-regular">and give </span>with it <span class="gemarra-regular">one hundred dinars to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> so-and-so, and </span>he then <span class="gemarra-regular">died, one does not</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> write and give </span>it. Rabbi Abba bar Memel inferred: <span class="gemarra-regular">But</span> if <span class="gemarra-regular">a person on his deathbed </span>states this request, <span class="gemarra-regular">one</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> writes and gives </span>it. <span class="gemarra-regular">He raises the objection and he</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> resolves it: </span>The ruling of that <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>a case where <span class="gemarra-regular">he was enhancing </span>the recipient’s legal <span class="gemarra-regular">power</span> by writing him a document of proof.
The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">What are the circumstances </span>under which it is apparent that <span class="gemarra-regular">he was enhancing his </span>legal <span class="gemarra-regular">power</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? </span>

Daf 136a

It is <span class="gemarra-regular">as Rav Ḥisda says </span>that if it is written in the will: <span class="gemarra-regular">And we acquired it from </span><span class="gemarra-regular">him </span>through an act of acquisition <span class="gemarra-regular">in addition to this </span><span class="gemarra-regular">gift, </span>this formulation does not cancel the will’s power to take effect after the person’s death, as the intention of referring to it as a gift is merely to enhance the legal power of the recipient by confirming the transfer through an act of acquisition. <span class="gemarra-regular">Here too, </span>in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">says: Write and sign </span>a document <span class="gemarra-regular">as well, and give </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">to him, </span>it is apparent that his request is to enhance the legal power of the recipient by writing a document in addition to transferring the gift itself.
<span class="gemarra-regular">It was stated </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda </span>says that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel says </span>that the <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is that <span class="gemarra-regular">one writes </span>a document <span class="gemarra-regular">and gives </span>the money in this case. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rava says similarly </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman </span><span class="gemarra-regular">says </span>that the <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is that <span class="gemarra-regular">one writes </span>a document <span class="gemarra-regular">and gives </span>the money in this case.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> A healthy person <span class="gemarra-regular">who writes </span>a document granting <span class="gemarra-regular">his property to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> his </span><span class="gemarra-regular">son</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> in his lifetime, but wishes to continue to derive benefit from it until his death, <span class="gemarra-regular">must write: </span>I give the property <span class="gemarra-regular">from today and after </span>my <span class="gemarra-regular">death</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> This is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of Rabbi Yehuda. Rabbi Yosei </span><span class="gemarra-regular">says: He need not </span>write: From today and after my death; it is sufficient for him to write that the transfer will take effect after he dies.
If <span class="gemarra-regular">one writes </span>a document granting <span class="gemarra-regular">his property to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">his son </span>from today and <span class="gemarra-regular">after his death</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">father cannot sell </span>the property <span class="gemarra-regular">because it is written </span>as granted <span class="gemarra-regular">to the son, and the son cannot sell </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">because it is </span>still <span class="gemarra-regular">in the possession of the father </span>with regard to using the property and consuming its produce.
If <span class="gemarra-regular">the father sold </span>the property, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is sold </span>to the purchaser inasmuch as he may use it and consume its produce <span class="gemarra-regular">until </span>the father <span class="gemarra-regular">dies, </span>at which point it belongs to the son. If <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">son sold </span>it during his father’s lifetime, <span class="gemarra-regular">the purchaser </span><span class="gemarra-regular">has no </span>right to use it <span class="gemarra-regular">until the father dies.</span>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">And</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> if he wrote: </span>I give the property <span class="gemarra-regular">from today and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> after </span>my <span class="gemarra-regular">death, what of it? Didn’t we learn</span> in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Gittin</span> 72a): If a husband said to his wife: This is your bill of divorce from <span class="gemarra-regular">today</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and after </span>my <span class="gemarra-regular">death, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">a bill of divorce</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> but not </span>a complete <span class="gemarra-regular">bill of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">divorce</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">if he dies </span>without children his wife <span class="gemarra-regular">performs the ritual</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> through which a woman is freed of her levirate bonds</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ḥalitza</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as perhaps the bill of divorce is invalid and she is bound by the levirate bond and may not remarry without first performing <span class="it-text">ḥalitza</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">But she does </span><span class="gemarra-regular">not enter into levirate marriage, </span>as perhaps the bill of divorce is valid, and it is forbidden for a divorcée to marry her former husband’s brother.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">There, we are uncertai</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> if</span> the expression: And after my death, <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>meant as <span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> condition, </span>i.e., if I die you will be divorced retroactively from today, <span class="gemarra-regular">or if it is a retraction </span>of the statement: From today, meaning that the divorce would take effect only after his death, which would render it invalid. <span class="gemarra-regular">But here, </span>in the case of a deed of gift, there is no contradiction in the statement, as <span class="gemarra-regular">this is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> what </span>the father <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>presumably <span class="gemarra-regular">saying to him: Acquire </span>the property <span class="gemarra-regular">itself today, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">the produce after </span>my <span class="gemarra-regular">death.</span>
§ The mishna teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">he need not </span>write: From today and after my death. The Gemara relates: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba bar Avuh was sick, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Huna and Rav Naḥman entered to </span>visit <span class="gemarra-regular">him. Rav Huna </span><span class="gemarra-regular">said to Rav Naḥman: Ask hi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">m</span> whether the <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei or </span>the <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">not in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Yosei. </span>Rav Naḥman <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Rav Huna: <span class="gemarra-regular">I do </span><span class="gemarra-regular">not know Rabbi Yosei’s reasoning; </span>can <span class="gemarra-regular">I ask him </span>about the <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? </span>Rav Huna <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Rav Naḥman: <span class="gemarra-regular">You </span><span class="gemarra-regular">ask him if </span>the <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is in accordance with his opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">or not, and I will tell you his reasoning</span> afterward.
Rav Naḥman <span class="gemarra-regular">asked </span>Rabba bar Avuh. Rabba bar Avuh <span class="gemarra-regular">said</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to him </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>is what <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: </span>The <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei. After</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> they left, </span>Rav Huna <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Rav Naḥman that <span class="gemarra-regular">this</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is Rabbi Yosei’s reasoning: He says </span>that writing: From today and after my death, is unnecessary because <span class="gemarra-regular">the date</span> written <span class="gemarra-regular">in a document proves </span>when <span class="gemarra-regular">it </span>takes effect. The Gemara adds: <span class="gemarra-regular">That is also taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> (<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span>, <span class="it-text">Ketubot</span> 8:4): <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">he need not </span>write: From today and after my death, <span class="gemarra-regular">because the date </span>written <span class="gemarra-regular">in a document proves </span>when <span class="gemarra-regular">it </span>takes effect.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> asked Rav Naḥman: In </span>a case where the father performed an act of <span class="gemarra-regular">transfer, </span>transferring his property to his son after his death, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? Is it still necessary to write: From today and after my death? Rav Naḥman <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: In </span>a case where he performed an act of <span class="gemarra-regular">transfer, he need not </span>write: From today and after my death.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappi</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> said: There is </span>a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">transfer where </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">needs</span> to write: From today and after my death, <span class="gemarra-regular">and there</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is </span>a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">transfer where </span>he does <span class="gemarra-regular">not need</span> to do so. If it is written in the deed that <span class="gemarra-regular">he transferred </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">to him and we, </span>the witnesses, <span class="gemarra-regular">acquired </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">from him</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> he does <span class="gemarra-regular">not need </span>to write: From today and after my death. But if the statement is written in the opposite order: <span class="gemarra-regular">We acquired </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">from him and he transferred </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">to him, </span>he still <span class="gemarra-regular">need</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> to write: From today and after my death.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥanina of Sura objects to this </span>distinction: <span class="gemarra-regular">Is there</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> anything that we, </span>the Sages, <span class="gemarra-regular">do not know, and the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> scribes know? </span>The distinction between the two opposite orderings of the above statement was unknown to the Sages. The Gemara relates that the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">asked Abaye’s scribes and they</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> knew </span>the distinction, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>they asked <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava’s scribes and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> they </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">knew </span>the distinction.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna, son of Rav</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Yehoshua, said: Whether </span>the wording is <span class="gemarra-regular">he transferred </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> him and we acquired </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">from him, </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">whether </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">we acquired </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">from him and he transferred </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">to him, </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">need not </span>write: From today and after my death, as the act of transfer is mentioned in any event. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Yosei in the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">disagree </span>whether the phrase: From today and after my death, is necessary only <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>a case where the deed merely states: This is <span class="gemarra-regular">a record of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the proceedings that took place in our presence, </span>without any mention of an act of transfer.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Kahana said: I stated </span>this <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in the presence </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav Zevid of Neharde’a, and he said to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">me: You teach it like this, </span>i.e., as a question and answer followed by a dispute; <span class="gemarra-regular">we teach it </span><span class="gemarra-regular">like this, </span>i.e., as a single, unbroken statement: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>a case where <span class="gemarra-regular">transfer </span>is mentioned in the deed, the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">need not</span> write: From today and after my death. This is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">whether </span>the wording is <span class="gemarra-regular">he transferred </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">to him</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and we acquired </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">from him, </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">whether </span>the wording is <span class="gemarra-regular">we acquired </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">from him and he transferred </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">to him; </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">need not </span>write: From today and after my death. They <span class="gemarra-regular">disagree </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>a case where the wording is: This is <span class="gemarra-regular">a record of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the proceedings that took place in our presence.</span>
§ The mishna teaches that if <span class="gemarra-regular">one writes </span>a document granting <span class="gemarra-regular">his property to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> his son </span>from today and <span class="gemarra-regular">after his death, </span>neither he nor the son can sell the property. It <span class="gemarra-regular">was stated</span> that in a case where <span class="gemarra-regular">the son sold </span>the property <span class="gemarra-regular">during the father’s lifetime, and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">the son died</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> during the father’s lifetime, </span>after which the father died as well, 

Daf 136b

<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Yoḥanan says: The purchaser did not acquir</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> the property, <span class="gemarra-regular">and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Reish Lakish says: The purchaser acquire</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> the property.
The Gemara explains their reasoning: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the purchaser did not acquire </span>the property because he holds that <span class="gemarra-regular">ownership of </span>the rights to use an item and the <span class="gemarra-regular">profits </span>it engenders <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">considered </span>to be <span class="gemarra-regular">like ownership of the item itself. </span>Even though the property itself did not belong to the father, it is as though the father owned the property, because all of the produce belonged to him in practice. Therefore, the son’s sale can take effect only after the father’s death. If the son dies first, since he never attained ownership, his sale can never come to fruition.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Reish Lakish says: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">The purchaser acquired </span>the property, because he holds that <span class="gemarra-regular">ownership </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of </span>the rights to use an item and the <span class="gemarra-regular">profits </span>it engenders <span class="gemarra-regular">is not considered </span>to be <span class="gemarra-regular">like ownership of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the item itself. </span>Therefore, the father’s rights do not prevent the son, who owns the property itself, from selling it, and eventually the purchaser receives full rights to it.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But didn’t they </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">engage in a dispute </span>concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>issue <span class="gemarra-regular">one time? As it was stated: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who sells his field for </span>just its <span class="gemarra-regular">produce, </span>meaning that he retains ownership over the field itself and he sells the rights to all of its produce to someone else, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: </span>The purchaser <span class="gemarra-regular">brings </span>first fruits from this field to the Temple <span class="gemarra-regular">and recites </span>the verses in the Torah associated with the bringing of the first fruits, in which he thanks God for: “The land that You, Lord, have given me” (Deuteronomy 26:10). <span class="gemarra-regular">And</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Reish Lakish says: </span>The purchaser <span class="gemarra-regular">brings </span>the first fruits, <span class="gemarra-regular">but he does not recit</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> the verses, since it is not his field.
The Gemara explains the reason behind the dispute: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says he brings </span>the first fruits <span class="gemarra-regular">and recites</span> the verses because <span class="gemarra-regular">he maintains </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">ownership of </span>the rights to use an item and the <span class="gemarra-regular">profits </span>it engenders <span class="gemarra-regular">is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> considered </span>to be <span class="gemarra-regular">like </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">ownership of the item itself</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>Even though the field itself does not belong to him, it is as if he acquired the field because all of the produce belongs to him in practice. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Reish</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Lakish says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">he brings </span>the first fruits <span class="gemarra-regular">and does</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not recite </span>the verses <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>he holds that <span class="gemarra-regular">ownership of</span> the rights to use an item and the <span class="gemarra-regular">profits </span>it engenders <span class="gemarra-regular">is not considered </span>to be <span class="gemarra-regular">like </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">ownership of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the item itself. </span>Why was it necessary for them to engage in a dispute concerning this issue twice?
The Gemara answers: It was necessary for the dispute to be stated also in the context of one who sells his father’s property and then dies. This is because <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan </span>could have <span class="gemarra-regular">said to you </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">although in general ownership of </span>the rights to use an item and the <span class="gemarra-regular">profits </span>it engenders <span class="gemarra-regular">is considered </span>to be <span class="gemarra-regular">like </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">ownership of the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">item itself, here it was necessary </span>to emphasize this principle, because it might <span class="gemarra-regular">enter your mind to say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span><span class="gemarra-regular">regard to a father and son, </span>the father presumably <span class="gemarra-regular">waived </span>his rights in the property itself. Rabbi Yoḥanan <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us</span> that even in this case, the father’s ownership of the rights to use an item and the profits it engenders is considered to be like the ownership of the item itself.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish </span>could have <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">although</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in general ownership of </span>the rights to use an item and the <span class="gemarra-regular">profits </span>it engenders <span class="gemarra-regular">is not considered </span>to be <span class="gemarra-regular">like </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">ownership of the item itself, </span>as one who sells the produce of his field retains full ownership of the land itself, <span class="gemarra-regular">here it was necessary </span>to emphasize this principle, as it might <span class="gemarra-regular">enter your mind to say </span>that in <span class="gemarra-regular">any </span>sale <span class="gemarra-regular">concerning oneself, even vis-à-vis his</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> son, one grants preference to himself. </span>Accordingly, if one grants the property itself to his son, reserving the rights to the produce for himself, he retains the rights to the property itself as well. Reish Lakish <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>that he does not retain the rights to the property.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Yoḥanan raised an objection to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Reish Lakish</span> from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> (<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span> 8:4): If one states: <span class="gemarra-regular">My</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> property </span>will go <span class="gemarra-regular">to you </span>after my death for your use during your lifetime, <span class="gemarra-regular">and after you </span>die, <span class="gemarra-regular">so</span><span class="gemarra-regular">-and-so will inherit </span>the property, <span class="gemarra-regular">and after </span>the one who inherits after you dies, <span class="gemarra-regular">so-and-so will </span><span class="gemarra-regular">inherit </span>the property, in this case, when <span class="gemarra-regular">the first </span>recipient <span class="gemarra-regular">dies, the second acquires </span>it, and when <span class="gemarra-regular">the second dies, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the third acquires </span>it.
If <span class="gemarra-regular">the second dies during the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">lifetime of the first, the property returns </span>after his death <span class="gemarra-regular">to the heirs of the first, </span>and does not go to the third designated recipient, as his right was to inherit it from the second, who never received it.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span><span class="gemarra-regular">if it is so </span>that ownership of the rights to use an item and the profits is not considered to be like ownership of the item itself, the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">should </span><span class="gemarra-regular">have </span>stated that the property returns <span class="gemarra-regular">to the heirs of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the giver, </span>as the first and second recipients received only the right to use the property and enjoy its profits during their lifetimes, after which it was designated to be transferred to others. Therefore, in a case where the transfer does not apply, the property should return to the possession of the one who owns the property itself, namely the giver and his heirs.
Reish Lakish <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Rav Hoshaya already interpreted in </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Babylonia </span>that a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">after you, </span>i.e., where the owner said to the recipient: After you die so-and-so will inherit the property, <span class="gemarra-regular">is different</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as the giver intended to grant full ownership of the property to the first recipient as well, including both the rights to the produce and the property itself. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabba bar</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rav Huna also raised </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">contradiction before Rav, and </span>Rav <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>in response: <span class="gemarra-regular">After you, is different.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But isn</span><span class="gemarra-regular">’t it taught </span>in another <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that if the second designated recipient dies before the first, after the death of the first the property <span class="gemarra-regular">returns to the heirs of the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> giver</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> 

Daf 137a

The Gemara answers: The <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in this case <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>a dispute between <span class="gemarra-italic">tanna’im</span><span class="gemarra-regular">; as it is taught</span> in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: With regard to one who said: <span class="gemarra-regular">My property </span>is given <span class="gemarra-regular">to you, and after you, to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> so-and-so</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">first </span>recipient <span class="gemarra-regular">entered </span>the property <span class="gemarra-regular">and sold </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">and consume</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> the profits, <span class="gemarra-regular">the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> second </span>recipient <span class="gemarra-regular">repossesses </span>the property <span class="gemarra-regular">from the purchasers, </span>as the property belongs to him after the death of the first recipient; <span class="gemarra-regular">this is the statement of Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: The second </span>recipient receives <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span><span class="gemarra-regular">that which the first </span>beneficiary <span class="gemarra-regular">left, </span>since his sale is valid.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises a contradiction </span>from another <span class="it-text">baraita</span> (<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span> 8:4): If one says: <span class="gemarra-regular">My property</span> is given <span class="gemarra-regular">to you, and after you, to so-</span><span class="gemarra-regular">and-so, the first one may enter </span>the property <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">sell </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">and consume </span>the profits; this is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: The</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> first one has only </span>the right of <span class="gemarra-regular">consumption of the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> produce.</span>
This statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi</span> Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">is difficult </span>as it is contradicted by the other statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>this statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel is difficult </span>as it is contradicted by the other statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel. </span>Their opinions in the latter <span class="it-text">baraita</span> seem to be the opposite of those in the former <span class="it-text">baraita</span>.
The Gemara answers: The apparent contradiction between one statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi and the other statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult; this </span>ruling that the first one cannot sell it is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to</span> the property <span class="gemarra-regular">itself, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>ruling that he can sell it is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to the produce. </span>The apparent contradiction between one statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel </span>and the other statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult </span>either; <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>statement, that the first has only the right to consume the produce, is referring to his rights <span class="gemarra-italic">ab</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">initio</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>whereas <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>statement, that if he sold the property the second one gets nothing, is referring to the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">after</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the fact.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye says: Who is a cunning wicked person</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? This </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">one who provides advic</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to sell property </span><span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the ruling of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel. </span>Although Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel holds that the sale is valid, he does not permit one to do so <span class="it-text">ab</span> <span class="it-text">initio</span>, as that would deprive the second designated recipient of the property. Therefore, one who advises the first recipient to do so is considered a cunning wicked person.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: </span>The <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabban </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Shimon ben Gamliel; but </span>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel <span class="gemarra-regular">concedes that </span><span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>the first recipient <span class="gemarra-regular">gave </span>the property to another <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the gift of a person on his deathbed</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> in which case no formal act of acquisition is required, <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span><span class="gemarra-regular">has done nothing; </span>the second recipient can repossess the property from the one to whom it was given.
<span class="gemarra-regular">What is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the reason? Abaye says: </span>The recipient of <span class="gemarra-regular">the gift of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a person on his deathbed acquires </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">only after </span>the person’s <span class="gemarra-regular">death, and </span>in this case, the acquisition of the recipient resulting from the statement of: <span class="gemarra-regular">After you, </span>i.e., the second designated recipient, <span class="gemarra-regular">has already preceded </span>the acquisition of the first one.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But did Abaye</span> actually <span class="gemarra-regular">say this, </span>that the gift of a person on his deathbed takes effect only after his death? <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span><span class="gemarra-regular">wasn’t it stated </span>in an amoraic dispute concerning the matter: <span class="gemarra-regular">From when does </span>the recipient of <span class="gemarra-regular">the gift of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a person on his deathbed acquire </span>it? <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye says: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">With the completion of death, </span>i.e., at the moment he dies; <span class="gemarra-regular">and Rava says: After the completion of death.</span>
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye retracted that </span>latter statement. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">From </span><span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>is it known <span class="gemarra-regular">that he retracted that </span>statement? <span class="gemarra-regular">Perhaps </span><span class="gemarra-regular">he retracted this, </span>i.e., the statement that the recipient acquires it only after the person’s death, and his conclusion is that he acquires it at the moment of his death.
The Gemara answers: That possibility <span class="gemarra-regular">should not enter your mind, as we learned </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Gittin</span> 72b): If a man on his deathbed says to his wife: <span class="gemarra-regular">This is your bill of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">divorce if I die</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> or: <span class="gemarra-regular">This is your bill </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of divorce </span>if I die <span class="gemarra-regular">from this illness, </span>or: <span class="gemarra-regular">This</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is your bill of divorce after I die, he has</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> said nothing</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> The divorce does not take effect after his death. Evidently, when one gives instructions on his deathbed, his intention is for them to be effective after he dies.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Zeira says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: </span>The <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabban Shimon</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> ben Gamliel </span>that if the first recipient sells the property, the sale is valid, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>this is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">even</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> if there were </span>Canaanite <span class="gemarra-regular">slaves </span>included <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the property <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the first recipient <span class="gemarra-regular">emancipated them.</span>
The Gemara asks: Isn’t that <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious? </span>The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Lest you </span><span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that the giver <span class="gemarra-regular">would have said to him: I </span><span class="gemarra-regular">did not give you </span>my Canaanite slaves <span class="gemarra-regular">to transgress a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">prohibition</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as it is prohibited to emancipate Canaanite slaves, Rabbi Yoḥanan <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>that he has the legal right to do so.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: </span>The <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel even if he </span><span class="gemarra-regular">made </span>the gift into <span class="gemarra-regular">shrouds for a corpse. </span>The Gemara asks: Isn’t that <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious? </span>The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Lest you </span><span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that the giver would have said to him: <span class="gemarra-regular">I </span><span class="gemarra-regular">did not give you </span>my possessions <span class="gemarra-regular">to render them into </span><span class="gemarra-regular">items from which </span>deriving <span class="gemarra-regular">benefit is prohibited, </span>but rather so that you may use and enjoy them, and Rabbi Yoḥanan <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>that he may do so.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Naḥman bar Rav Ḥisda taught: </span>If one said to another: <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span><span class="gemarra-italic">etrog</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is given to you as a gift, and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> after you </span>die, <span class="gemarra-regular">to so-and-so, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">the first</span> recipient then <span class="gemarra-regular">took it and fulfilled </span>his obligation of taking the four species on the first day of <span class="it-text">Sukkot</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">with</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> when one is obligated to take species that belong to him, in this case, <span class="gemarra-regular">we have arrived at</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the dispute between Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">and Rabban Shimon ben</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Gamliel </span>as to the nature of the ownership of the first recipient. According to Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi’s opinion that he cannot sell the <span class="it-text">etrog</span>, it is not considered entirely his, and he does not fulfill his obligation by taking it. According to the opinion of Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel, who holds that he can sell it, he fulfills his obligation.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak objects to this </span>statement, reasoning that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">and Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel </span><span class="gemarra-regular">disagree only there, </span>in the case of: After you, with regard to the nature of the recipient’s ownership; <span class="gemarra-regular">as</span> one <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage, </span>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel, <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">ownership of</span> the rights to use an item and the <span class="gemarra-regular">profits </span>it engenders <span class="gemarra-regular">is considered like ownership of the item itself, and</span> the other <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage, </span>Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi, <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">ownership of</span> the rights to use an item and the <span class="gemarra-regular">profits </span>it engenders <span class="gemarra-regular">is not considered like ownership of the item itself</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. But here, </span>with regard to the <span class="it-text">etrog</span>, 

Daf 137b

<span class="gemarra-regular">if he does not</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> fulfil</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span> his obligation <span class="gemarra-regular">with it, for what </span>purpose <span class="gemarra-regular">did </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">give it to him?</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">fulfilling </span>his obligation, <span class="gemarra-regular">everyone agrees that he fulfills </span>his obligation <span class="gemarra-regular">with it. </span>It is only in a case where the first recipient <span class="gemarra-regular">sold it or consumed it, </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">we </span><span class="gemarra-regular">have arrived at the dispute between Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel. </span>According to Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi, if he sold it, the second recipient can repossess the <span class="it-text">etrog</span> from the purchaser, and if he consumed it he must pay the second recipient its value, whereas according to Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel, he owes nothing to the second recipient, as the <span class="it-text">etrog</span> belongs to him.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba bar Rav Huna </span><span class="gemarra-regular">says: </span>In a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">brothers who acquired an </span><span class="gemarra-italic">etrog</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>money from the jointly <span class="gemarra-regular">held </span>property <span class="gemarra-regular">of the estate</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and <span class="gemarra-regular">one of them took it </span>on <span class="it-text">Sukkot</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>attempted to <span class="gemarra-regular">fulfill </span>his obligation <span class="gemarra-regular">with it, </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> depends on the limits of his ownership of the <span class="it-text">etrog</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span><span class="gemarra-regular">he may eat it, </span>i.e., his brothers allow him to do so, <span class="gemarra-regular">he has fulfilled </span>his obligation to perform the mitzva, <span class="gemarra-regular">and if not, he has not fulfille</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> his obligation.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>this is <span class="gemarra-regular">specifically </span>in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where there is an </span><span class="gemarra-italic">etrog</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for each and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> every on</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> of the brothers; <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>if the other brothers get merely <span class="gemarra-regular">a quince or a pomegranate</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> he has <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>fulfilled his obligation even if he has the right to eat it.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava says: </span>If one person said to another: <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span><span class="gemarra-italic">etrog</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is given to you </span><span class="gemarra-regular">as a gift on the condition that you return it </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to me</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and the recipient <span class="gemarra-regular">took it </span>on <span class="it-text">Sukkot</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>attempted to <span class="gemarra-regular">fulfill </span>his obligation <span class="gemarra-regular">with it, </span>if he ultimately <span class="gemarra-regular">returned it, he has fulfilled </span>his obligation; if he <span class="gemarra-regular">did not return it, he has not fulfilled </span>his obligation, as he did not fulfill the condition, thereby retroactively invalidating the gift. The Gemara explains that Rava <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us that </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a gift </span>given <span class="gemarra-regular">on the condition that it be returne</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is considered </span>a valid <span class="gemarra-regular">gift.</span>
§ The Gemara relates: There was <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain woman who had a palm tree on </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the land of Rav Beivai bar Abaye. Whenever she would </span><span class="gemarra-regular">go to harvest </span>the produce from <span class="gemarra-regular">it, he would get </span><span class="gemarra-regular">angry at her </span>for trampling on his crops. Since she did not wish to anger him, <span class="gemarra-regular">she </span>decided to temporarily waive her right to the tree’s produce, and <span class="gemarra-regular">transferred </span>ownership of <span class="gemarra-regular">it to him </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">all the years of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">his life, </span>so that after his death she would once again be able to harvest the produce. <span class="gemarra-regular">He </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">went </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and transferred it to his minor son</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> so that it would remain in his family even following his death.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, said </span>to Rav Beivai bar Abaye: Is it <span class="gemarra-regular">because you descend </span><span class="gemarra-regular">from truncated [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">mula’ei</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] </span>people, as Rav Beivai’s family traced their lineage to Eli, all of whose descendants were condemned to premature death (see I Samuel 2:31), that <span class="gemarra-regular">you speak truncated [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">mulyata</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] </span>and unsound <span class="gemarra-regular">matters? Even Rabban Shimon </span><span class="gemarra-regular">ben Gamliel, </span>who holds that in a case where one says: My property is given to you, and after you, to so-and-so, if the first recipient sells the property the sale is valid, <span class="gemarra-regular">says </span>so <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>in a case where it was to be given <span class="gemarra-regular">to another </span>person; <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>if the giver said that it will return <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">himself, </span>he did <span class="gemarra-regular">no</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> say that the first recipient can sell it, as the giver clearly intended to maintain his ownership of the property. Accordingly, Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, held that Rav Beivai’s sale did not take effect.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava </span><span class="gemarra-regular">says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman says: </span>If one said to another: <span class="gemarra-regular">This ox is given to you as a gift on </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the condition that you return it to me, </span>and the recipient <span class="gemarra-regular">consecrated it and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">returned i</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> to him, <span class="gemarra-regular">it</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is consecrated and returned. </span>The consecration takes effect, and although the owner may not use it, nevertheless it is considered returned and the condition is fulfilled.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said to Rav</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Naḥman: What did he return to him? </span>The ox was not returned to the possession of the giver, as it is consecrated. Rav Naḥman <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: And what </span><span class="gemarra-regular">did he cause him to lose</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> He returned the ox. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Rav Ashi said: </span>We must rule in this case based on what <span class="gemarra-regular">we see. If </span>the giver <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the recipient: <span class="gemarra-regular">On the condition that you return it, </span>it is considered returned, as <span class="gemarra-regular">he returned it. </span>But <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span><span class="gemarra-regular">he said to him: On the condition that you return </span><span class="gemarra-regular">it to me, he was </span>effectively <span class="gemarra-regular">saying to him </span>that he must return <span class="gemarra-regular">something fit for him </span>to use. Consequently, the consecration prevents the condition from being fulfilled, and both the gift and the consecration are retroactively nullified.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel says</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">one writes </span>a document granting <span class="gemarra-regular">his property to another</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, and the other </span>person <span class="gemarra-regular">says: I do not want it</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">acquires </span>it, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>this is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>if he is <span class="gemarra-regular">standing and shouting </span>in protest that he does not want it. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Yoḥanan says </span>that he <span class="gemarra-regular">does</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not acquire </span>it.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Abba bar Memel said: And</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> they do not disagree </span>with each other: 

Daf 138a

<span class="gemarra-regular">Here, </span>in Rabbi Yoḥanan’s statement, it is a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he is shouting</span> in protest <span class="gemarra-regular">at the outset</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> As soon as he is given the deed of gift he states that he does not want it. In this case, he does not receive the property. <span class="gemarra-regular">There, </span>in Shmuel’s statement, it is a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he is initially silent </span>when he receives the deed of gift, <span class="gemarra-regular">and is ultimately shoutin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span> in protest that he does not want it. In this case he acquires the gift before he protests, so it is his.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman </span><span class="gemarra-regular">bar Yitzḥak says </span>that if the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">transfers ownership </span>of the property <span class="gemarra-regular">to him through anothe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> person, who performs an act of acquisition for this other party in his presence, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he was initially silent, </span>i.e., when the act of acquisition is performed, <span class="gemarra-regular">but ultimately shouted </span>in protest when the property is actually given to him, <span class="gemarra-regular">we have </span><span class="gemarra-regular">arrived at the dispute between Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis.</span>
This is <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> (<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span> 8:1): If <span class="gemarra-regular">one wrote </span>a document granting <span class="gemarra-regular">his property to another, and there were slave</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> among his property, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the other </span>person <span class="gemarra-regular">said: I do not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">want them, if their second master, </span>i.e., the recipient, <span class="gemarra-regular">was a priest, they partake of </span><span class="gemarra-italic">teruma</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the portion of the produce designated for the priest, as his protest is ignored. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: Once the other</span> person <span class="gemarra-regular">said: I do not want them, the </span>giver or his <span class="gemarra-regular">heirs have already acquired them, </span>and they are the slaves’ owners.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And we discussed</span> the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>does <span class="gemarra-regular">the first </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span> hold that he acquires them <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">he is standing and shouting </span>in protest that he does not want them? That is not reasonable.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava says, and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> some say </span>it was <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan </span>who says: <span class="gemarra-regular">In </span>a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he is shouting </span>in protest <span class="gemarra-regular">at the outset</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>when he is given the gift, <span class="gemarra-regular">everyone agrees that he</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> did not acquire </span>them. In a case where <span class="gemarra-regular">he was</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> silent </span>at the time <span class="gemarra-regular">and ultimately shouted </span>in protest, <span class="gemarra-regular">everyone</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> agrees that he acquired </span>them.
<span class="gemarra-regular">When</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> they disagree </span>it is in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">when he transfers</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> ownership to him through another </span>person, and the recipient was there <span class="gemarra-regular">and was silent, and ultimately, </span>when he actually receives the slaves, he <span class="gemarra-regular">shouted </span>in protest. <span class="gemarra-regular">As the first </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">once he was </span>initially <span class="gemarra-regular">silent, he acquired </span><span class="gemarra-regular">them, and </span>the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that he is shouting </span>indicates that <span class="gemarra-regular">he is retracting </span>his initial acceptance of the gift. His acquisition cannot be canceled in this manner. If he does not want to own the slaves, he can sell them, give them away, or emancipate them.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">his ultimate </span>actions <span class="gemarra-regular">prove </span>the nature of <span class="gemarra-regular">his initial </span>intent; he never intended to acquire the slaves. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the reason <span class="gemarra-regular">that he did </span><span class="gemarra-regular">not shout </span>in protest <span class="gemarra-regular">until now </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">that he reasoned: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">As long as they did not enter my possession, </span>to <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>end <span class="gemarra-regular">will I shout?</span>
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>(<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span> 9:6): If <span class="gemarra-regular">a person on his deathbed said: Give two hundred dinar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to so-and-so, and three hundred to so-</span><span class="gemarra-regular">and-so, and four hundred to so-and-so, </span>in this case one <span class="gemarra-regular">does not say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">whoever appears first </span><span class="gemarra-regular">in the deed acquires </span>his money first. <span class="gemarra-regular">Therefore, </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> promissory note emerged against </span>the one who gave the gifts, and it becomes clear that the money given was pledged to a creditor, then the creditor <span class="gemarra-regular">collects from all of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> them.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if a person on his deathbed <span class="gemarra-regular">said: Give two hundred dinars to so-and-so, and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> after him, to so-and-so, and after him, to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> so-and-so, </span>then one <span class="gemarra-regular">says: Anyone who appears first</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in the deed gains. Therefore, </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">a promissory note emerged</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> against </span>the giver, the creditor first <span class="gemarra-regular">collects from the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">last </span>one of the recipients. If <span class="gemarra-regular">he does not have </span>enough to repay the debt, <span class="gemarra-regular">he collects from the previous </span>recipient. If <span class="gemarra-regular">he does not have </span>enough to repay the debt, <span class="gemarra-regular">he collects from </span>the recipient listed <span class="gemarra-regular">before the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">previous </span>recipient.
<span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: If there was <span class="gemarra-regular">a person on his deathbed who </span><span class="gemarra-regular">said: Give two hundred dinars to so-and-so, my </span><span class="gemarra-regular">firstborn son</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as is appropriate for him</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the firstborn <span class="gemarra-regular">takes </span>the two hundred dinars <span class="gemarra-regular">and takes his portion </span><span class="gemarra-regular">as a firstborn </span>as well. <span class="gemarra-regular">If he said: </span>Give my firstborn son two hundred dinars <span class="gemarra-regular">for his portion as a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">firstborn, </span>he does not receive both, but <span class="gemarra-regular">he has the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">advantage; </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">he wants, he takes </span>the two hundred dinars, and if <span class="gemarra-regular">he wants, he takes his portion as a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">firstborn.</span>
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>similarly, if there was <span class="gemarra-regular">a person on his deathbed who said</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: Give two hundred dinars to so-and-so, my wife</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, as is appropriate for her, she takes </span>the two hundred dinars <span class="gemarra-regular">and takes </span>payment of <span class="gemarra-regular">her marriage contract </span>as well. <span class="gemarra-regular">If he said: </span>Give her two hundred dinars as payment <span class="gemarra-regular">for her marriage contract, </span>

Daf 138b

<span class="gemarra-regular">she has the advantage</span><span class="gemarra-regular">; </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">she wants, she takes </span>the two hundred dinars, and if <span class="gemarra-regular">she wants, she takes </span>payment of <span class="gemarra-regular">her marriage contract</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>if there was <span class="gemarra-regular">a person on his deathbed who said: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Give two hundre</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> dinars to so-and-so, my creditor</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, as is appropriate for him, </span>the creditor <span class="gemarra-regular">takes </span>the two hundred dinars <span class="gemarra-regular">and takes </span>payment of the<span class="gemarra-regular"> debt </span>as well. <span class="gemarra-regular">But if he said: </span>Give him two hundred dinars as payment <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>the<span class="gemarra-regular"> debt, he takes </span>the two hundred dinars as payment <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>the<span class="gemarra-regular"> debt</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Because he says: As is appropriate for </span><span class="gemarra-regular">him, he takes </span>the two hundred dinars <span class="gemarra-regular">and takes </span>payment of the<span class="gemarra-regular"> debt </span>as well? <span class="gemarra-regular">But perhaps he was saying: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">As is appropriate for him </span>as payment <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>the<span class="gemarra-regular"> debt, </span>and meant only to specify the amount of the debt.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman said: </span>Rav <span class="gemarra-regular">Huna said to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">me: </span>In accordance with <span class="gemarra-regular">whose </span>opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">is this? It is </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Akiva</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> who </span><span class="gemarra-regular">expounds superfluous language. </span>Rabbi Akiva holds that if one uses unnecessary words, he apparently intended to add a matter.
<span class="gemarra-regular">As we learned </span>in a mishna (64a): One who sells a house without specification has sold <span class="gemarra-regular">neither the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> pit nor the cistern [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">dut</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> with it, <span class="gemarra-regular">even if</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he writes for </span>the buyer in the bill of sale: With <span class="gemarra-regular">its depth and its height. </span>This is because anything that is not part of the house, like pits and cisterns, must be explicitly mentioned in the contract or else they remain in the seller’s possession. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>therefore the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">must purchase for himself a path </span>through the buyer’s domain to reach whatever remains his, because he has sold the area of the house along with the house itself, and he no longer has permission to walk there. This is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of Rabbi Akiva.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rabbis say: </span>The seller <span class="gemarra-regular">need not purchase for himself a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> path </span>through the buyer’s domain, as this is certainly included in what he has withheld for himself from the sale. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Akiva concedes that when </span>the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">says</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to </span>the buyer in the bill of sale: I am selling you this house <span class="gemarra-regular">apart from </span>the pit and the cistern, <span class="gemarra-regular">he need not purchase for himself a path </span>through the buyer’s domain. Since the seller unnecessarily emphasized that the pit and the cistern are not included in the sale, he presumably intended to reserve for himself the right of access to them.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Apparently</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>according to Rabbi Akiva, <span class="gemarra-regular">since he did not need </span>to state: Apart from the pit and the cistern, <span class="gemarra-regular">and stated</span> it anyway, the seemingly superfluous statement <span class="gemarra-regular">was coming to add</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a matter. </span>Since the seller unnecessarily stressed that the pit and cistern are not included in the sale, he must have intended to thereby reserve for himself the right of access. <span class="gemarra-regular">Here too, </span>with regard to the gift given by a person on his deathbed to his creditor, <span class="gemarra-regular">since he</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> did not need </span>to say: As is appropriate for him, <span class="gemarra-regular">and said </span>it anyway, this phrase <span class="gemarra-regular">was coming to add</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a matter, </span>i.e., that the two hundred dinars are in addition to the debt.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>(<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span> 8:18): If there was <span class="gemarra-regular">a person on his deathbed who said: I </span><span class="gemarra-regular">have one hundred dinars </span>owed to me <span class="gemarra-regular">by so-and-</span><span class="gemarra-regular">so</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the witnesses </span>that hear this <span class="gemarra-regular">may write </span>his statement in a document <span class="gemarra-regular">even if they do not know </span>whether the statement is true. <span class="gemarra-regular">Therefore, when </span>the person’s heir <span class="gemarra-regular">collects </span>the debt, <span class="gemarra-regular">he must bring proof </span>of the debt, as the document written by these witnesses is not regarded as proof. This is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of Rabbi Meir. </span><span class="gemarra-regular">And the Rabbis say: </span>The witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">may not write </span>the document <span class="gemarra-regular">unless they know </span>for a fact that the statement is true. <span class="gemarra-regular">Therefore, when </span>the heir <span class="gemarra-regular">collects </span>the debt, <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span><span class="gemarra-regular">need not bring proof </span>other than the document written by the witnesses, as it has the status of a promissory note.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman says: </span>Rav <span class="gemarra-regular">Huna told me </span>that the opposite is <span class="gemarra-regular">taught </span>in another <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir </span><span class="gemarra-regular">says </span>that the witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">may not write </span>his statement in a document they know for a fact that the statement is true, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the Rabbis say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">they may write </span>it even if they do not know whether the statement is true; <span class="gemarra-regular">and even Rabbi Meir said </span>that they may not write it <span class="gemarra-regular">only due to </span>the concern that it might be presented before <span class="gemarra-regular">a court that errs </span>and allows the heirs to collect without furnishing additional proof. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Dimi</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of Neharde’a says: The </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is that <span class="gemarra-regular">there is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> no concern about </span>the possibility of <span class="gemarra-regular">a court that errs</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>way <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>this case <span class="gemarra-regular">different from Rava’s </span>statement? <span class="gemarra-regular">As Rava says: </span>A court <span class="gemarra-regular">may not </span>supervise <span class="gemarra-italic">ḥalitza</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> unless </span>the judges <span class="gemarra-regular">recogniz</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> the <span class="it-text">yavam</span> and <span class="it-text">yevama</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>a court <span class="gemarra-regular">may not </span>supervise a declaration of the <span class="gemarra-regular">refusa</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span> of a girl upon her reaching majority to remain married to the man to whom her mother or brothers married her as a minor after the death of her father, <span class="gemarra-regular">unless they recogniz</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> the girl. <span class="gemarra-regular">Therefore, </span>another court <span class="gemarra-regular">may write a document </span>attesting to the performance <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span><span class="gemarra-italic">ḥalitz</span><span class="gemarra-italic">a</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">or a document </span>stating that a declaration <span class="gemarra-regular">of refusal </span>was made in a court elsewhere based on the testimony of witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">even if </span>the judges <span class="gemarra-regular">do</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not recognize </span>these people, relying on the presumption the first court would not have allowed the act to be performed had they not been sure of the identities of the parties.
<span class="gemarra-regular">What is the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">reason </span>Rava said that the court must recognize the participants in these actions? Is it <span class="gemarra-regular">not due to the concern </span><span class="gemarra-regular">that a court that errs </span>might write such a document based on the testimony of witnesses without verifying that the participating parties were recognized by the court where the <span class="it-text">ḥalitza</span> or refusal took place?
The Gemara answers: The two issues are <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>the same. <span class="gemarra-regular">A court does not </span>normally <span class="gemarra-regular">examin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> the act of <span class="gemarra-regular">another</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> court, </span>so there is concern that the court where the document is written might assume that the court where the act took place recognized the participating parties. But <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">court does </span>normally <span class="gemarra-regular">examine </span>the statement of <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses. </span>Therefore, there is no concern that it will rely on a statement written by witnesses without their knowledge of its accuracy.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In continuation of the case discussed in the previous mishna of a father who wrote a document granting his property to his son but reserved the rights to the produce during his lifetime, the mishna states that <span class="gemarra-regular">the father may detach </span>produce from the land <span class="gemarra-regular">and</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">fee</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> the produce <span class="gemarra-regular">to whomever he wishes, and what </span><span class="gemarra-regular">he left detached </span>at the time of his death <span class="gemarra-regular">belongs </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>all the father’s <span class="gemarra-regular">heirs, </span>not only to this son.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna indicates that what the father left <span class="gemarra-regular">detached, yes, </span>it is inherited by all the heirs; but the produce that is <span class="gemarra-regular">connected </span>to the ground at the time of his death, <span class="gemarra-regular">no, </span>it is not inherited by them. Rather, it belongs to the son who received the property. 

Daf 139a
