<span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t it taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> (<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span>, <span class="it-text">Ketubot</span> 8:5) that in a similar case, the court <span class="gemarra-regular">appraises the </span>produce still <span class="gemarra-regular">connected </span>to the ground <span class="gemarra-regular">for the purchase</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> of the land, who must pay the seller’s heirs for it? Accordingly, the connected produce also belongs to the heirs.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Ulla said </span>that this is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult; here, </span>in the mishna, the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is stated <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to his son</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>who receives the connected produce after the father’s death. <span class="gemarra-regular">There, </span>in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is stated <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to another </span>person who purchased the land from the son. <span class="gemarra-regular">Since a person’s disposition is favorable toward his son</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>the father certainly intended to bequeath the connected produce to his son together with the property itself. When the son sold it to another person, there was no such intention.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If a person died and <span class="gemarra-regular">left adult </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and minor sons, the adults are not provided for by </span>using funds of <span class="gemarra-regular">the minors, and the minors are not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">sustained</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., they do not receive food, <span class="gemarra-regular">by</span> using funds <span class="gemarra-regular">of the adults. Rather, they receive a share</span> of the inheritance <span class="gemarra-regular">equally, </span>and each son sees to his needs from his own share.
If <span class="gemarra-regular">the adults married</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the minors marry, </span>as the Gemara will explain. <span class="gemarra-regular">But if the minors say: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">We are marrying in the same manner that you </span>adults <span class="gemarra-regular">married </span>during our father’s lifetime, the court <span class="gemarra-regular">does not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">listen to them. Rather, whatever their father gave </span>the adults in his lifetime <span class="gemarra-regular">he gave </span>them, and the minors do not have the right to receive more than their share of the inheritance.
Similarly, if the father <span class="gemarra-regular">left adult and minor daughter</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> but no sons, in which case his daughters inherit the estate, <span class="gemarra-regular">the adults are </span><span class="gemarra-regular">not provided for by </span>using funds <span class="gemarra-regular">of the minors, and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the minors are not sustained by </span>using funds <span class="gemarra-regular">of the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">adults. Rather, they receive a share </span>of the inheritance <span class="gemarra-regular">equally, </span>and each daughter sees to her needs from her share.
If <span class="gemarra-regular">the adult </span>daughters <span class="gemarra-regular">married</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the minor </span>daughters <span class="gemarra-regular">marry, </span>as the Gemara will explain. <span class="gemarra-regular">But if the minors say: We are marrying </span><span class="gemarra-regular">in the same manner that you </span>adults <span class="gemarra-regular">married </span>during our father’s lifetime, the court <span class="gemarra-regular">does not listen to them.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>following <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is a stringency </span><span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to daughters’ </span>inheritance <span class="gemarra-regular">vis-à-vis sons’ </span>inheritance: The <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">that the daughters are sustained by </span>using funds <span class="gemarra-regular">of the sons</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as stipulated in their mother’s marriage contract, <span class="gemarra-regular">but they are not sustained by </span>using funds <span class="gemarra-regular">of the </span>other <span class="gemarra-regular">daughters.</span>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava says: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span><span class="gemarra-regular">eldest of the brothers who </span><span class="gemarra-regular">wear</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> garments <span class="gemarra-regular">and covers himself</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from </span>the common property of <span class="gemarra-regular">the house, what he did</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">done</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and the other brothers cannot subtract from his share of the inheritance as a result.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But didn’t we learn </span>in the mishna that <span class="gemarra-regular">the adults are not provided for by </span>using funds <span class="gemarra-regular">of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the minors? </span>The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">The mishna </span>is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> an unemployed person [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">bisherakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> whereas Rava was referring to the brother who handles the finances of the entire family. Therefore it is in the interest of all the brothers for him to wear appropriate attire.
The Gemara asks: If the mishna is referring to an <span class="gemarra-regular">unemployed person, </span>isn’t it <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious </span>that he may not take from the common inheritance of all the brothers? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Lest you say </span>that it is <span class="gemarra-regular">preferable </span><span class="gemarra-regular">for them </span>that he dress appropriately so <span class="gemarra-regular">that he will </span><span class="gemarra-regular">not be repulsive, </span>thereby dishonoring the family name, the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>that he does not have the right to take money for clothing from the common inheritance, and if he does so, the brothers can subtract from his share of the inheritance as a result.
§ The mishna teaches that if <span class="gemarra-regular">the adults married, the minors marry. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is it saying? </span>What does this mean?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda says</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>is what <span class="gemarra-regular">it is saying: </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">the adults</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> married after their father’s death </span>and used the common inheritance to pay for their weddings, <span class="gemarra-regular">the minors </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">marry</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> after their father’s death </span>may also pay for their weddings from the common inheritance. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">the adults married</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> during their father’s lifetime, and the minors said after</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> their father’s death: We will marry in the same</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> manner that you married, </span>the court <span class="gemarra-regular">does not listen </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to them. Rather, whatever </span>sum <span class="gemarra-regular">their father gave </span>the adults to pay for their weddings in his lifetime <span class="gemarra-regular">he gave </span>them, and the minors do not have the right to demand that same sum from the inheritance.
§ The mishna teaches that if the father <span class="gemarra-regular">left adult and minor daughters, </span>and the adults married, the minors marry. <span class="gemarra-regular">Avuh bar Geneiva sent </span>a question <span class="gemarra-regular">to Rava</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: Our teacher, instruct us: </span>If a woman <span class="gemarra-regular">borrowed </span>money <span class="gemarra-regular">and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> consumed </span>it, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>before repaying the debt <span class="gemarra-regular">she arose and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> married</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> bringing her property into the marriage, what is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? <span class="gemarra-regular">Is the husband </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">a purchaser </span>of her property <span class="gemarra-regular">or is </span>he considered <span class="gemarra-regular">an hei</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> to her property?
The halakhic ramification of this dilemma is as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">Is he </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">a purchaser, and </span>the creditor therefore cannot collect his wife’s premarital debt from him, as <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span><span class="gemarra-regular">does not collect from the purchasers a loan by oral </span>agreement? <span class="gemarra-regular">Or perhaps he is </span>considered her <span class="gemarra-regular">heir, and one </span><span class="gemarra-regular">collects from the heirs a loan by oral </span>agreement.
Rava <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: We learned </span>the answer to this question in the mishna: If <span class="gemarra-regular">the adult </span>daughters <span class="gemarra-regular">married, the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">minor </span>daughters <span class="gemarra-regular">marry. What, is it not </span>teaching that if <span class="gemarra-regular">the adult </span>daughters <span class="gemarra-regular">married, </span>each one of them transferring money from the common inheritance <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>her <span class="gemarra-regular">husband </span>to cover the wedding expenses, <span class="gemarra-regular">the minor </span>daughters also <span class="gemarra-regular">marry, </span>paying for the wedding <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the money that each elder sister transferred to her <span class="gemarra-regular">husband? </span>Clearly, although the money the elder daughters took from the inheritance for their weddings has the status of a loan by oral agreement, their husbands are liable to return it. This proves that the husbands are considered heirs.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>the mishna is teaching that if <span class="gemarra-regular">the adults married </span>and each one transferred money <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>her <span class="gemarra-regular">husband, the minors </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">marry, </span>and each one may transfer money from the common inheritance <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>her <span class="gemarra-regular">husband </span>for the wedding expenses. They cannot collect money from what was already transferred by their sisters to their husbands.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Is that so? But didn’t </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ḥiyya teach </span>that if <span class="gemarra-regular">the adults married </span>and transferred money <span class="gemarra-regular">to the husband, the minors marry </span>and collect money <span class="gemarra-regular">from the husband </span>of each elder sister?
The Gemara answers: Even according to this interpretation, there is no proof from the mishna with regard to the case of a loan by oral agreement. <span class="gemarra-regular">Perhaps </span>the provision of wedding <span class="gemarra-regular">expenses </span>for the daughters <span class="gemarra-regular">is different, as it generates publicity. </span>Since it is well known that a specific portion of a person’s estate is liened to the future wedding expenses of his single daughters, it has the status of a loan with a promissory note. Therefore, the younger daughters can collect from the husbands of the elder daughters even if the status of the husbands is that of purchasers.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> said to Rava: Is this not </span>identical to the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">that Ravin sent in his letter </span>from Eretz Yisrael? That <span class="it-text">halakha</span> states that with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who died and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> left a widow and a daughter, his widow is sustained</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from his property. </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">the daughter </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">married, the widow</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is </span>still <span class="gemarra-regular">sustained from his property, </span>although it is now in the possession of the daughter’s husband, as she had inherited the property from her father. With regard to a case where <span class="gemarra-regular">the daughter </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">died </span>and her husband inherited from her, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda, son of the sister of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rabbi Yosei ben Ḥanina, says: </span>This <span class="gemarra-regular">incident occurred with me</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>that the late man’s <span class="gemarra-regular">widow is </span>still <span class="gemarra-regular">sustained from his property </span>although it is fully owned by his daughter’s husband.
Rav Pappa explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, if </span><span class="gemarra-regular">you say </span>the husband <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">an heir, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">due to that </span>reason that <span class="gemarra-regular">his </span>father-in-law’s <span class="gemarra-regular">widow is sustained from his property; </span>it is still liened to her sustenance. <span class="gemarra-regular">But if you say </span>that a husband <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">a purchaser </span>of his wife’s property, <span class="gemarra-regular">why </span>is his father-in-law’s widow <span class="gemarra-regular">sustained from his </span><span class="gemarra-regular">property? </span>The purchasers of inherited property are not obligated to sustain the widow.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye </span><span class="gemarra-regular">said: If Ravin had not sent </span>this letter, <span class="gemarra-regular">would we </span><span class="gemarra-regular">not have known </span>that the husband has the status of a purchaser? <span class="gemarra-regular">But didn’t we learn </span>in the mishna (<span class="it-text">Bekhorot</span> 52b): <span class="gemarra-regular">These </span>properties <span class="gemarra-regular">do not return </span>to their original owners <span class="gemarra-regular">in the Jubilee </span>Year (see Leviticus 25:13–24): The portion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the firstborn</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., it does not return to the common ownership of the brothers to be shared equally like the rest of the inheritance, but rather remains in the possession of the firstborn; 

Daf 139b

<span class="gemarra-regular">and one who inherits </span>the property of <span class="gemarra-regular">his wif</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> after her death, i.e., the property is not returned to her family. Evidently, the husband does not have the status of a purchaser, as a purchaser must return the property to its original owner in the Jubilee Year.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said to him: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">And now that </span>Ravin <span class="gemarra-regular">sent </span>the letter, <span class="gemarra-regular">do we </span>in fact <span class="gemarra-regular">know </span>that the husband has the status of an heir? <span class="gemarra-regular">Doesn’t Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, say: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">In Usha they instituted </span>an ordinance that in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a woman who sold her usufruct property</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., property that she alone owns and her husband benefits only from the profits, <span class="gemarra-regular">in her husband’s lifetime and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">died, the husband repossesses </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">from the purchasers? </span>Apparently the husband’s status is that of a purchaser, as a purchaser can appropriate his purchase from a later purchaser, whereas an heir does not inherit property that the person sold before he died.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Rav Ashi says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the Sages equated the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">husband with an heir, and the Sages equated him with </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a purchaser. And they deemed him </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">whichever is better </span><span class="gemarra-regular">for him, </span>based on the circumstances of the case. <span class="gemarra-regular">With </span><span class="gemarra-regular">regard to </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">Jubilee </span>Year, <span class="gemarra-regular">the Sages equated him with</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> an heir</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> due to his </span>potential <span class="gemarra-regular">loss </span>were he to be equated with a purchaser, as he would be obligated to return the property to his wife’s heirs. <span class="gemarra-regular">With regard to </span>the case <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Yosei, son of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rabbi Ḥanina, </span>where the wife sold the property, <span class="gemarra-regular">the Sages</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> equated him with a purchaser, due to his </span>potential <span class="gemarra-regular">loss</span> were he to be equated with an heir. <span class="gemarra-regular">With regard</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to Ravin’s </span><span class="it-text">halakha</span>, concerning the sustenance of the husband’s father-in-law’s widow, <span class="gemarra-regular">due to the </span>potential <span class="gemarra-regular">loss of the widow, the Sages equated him with an</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> heir</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But with regard to </span>the case <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, there is a loss to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the purchasers, </span>from whom the husband appropriates the property, <span class="gemarra-regular">and</span> nevertheless, <span class="gemarra-regular">the Sages equated him with a purchaser.</span>
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">There, </span>the purchasers <span class="gemarra-regular">caused their own loss</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Since </span>they knew <span class="gemarra-regular">that</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> there is a husband, they should not have purchased </span>property <span class="gemarra-regular">from a wife living under </span>the authority of <span class="gemarra-regular">her husband</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>removing it from the husband and his heirs.

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who died and left </span>behind both <span class="gemarra-regular">sons and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">daughters</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">when the estate is large the sons </span><span class="gemarra-regular">inheri</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> the estate <span class="gemarra-regular">and the daughters are provided with sustenance </span>from it according to the stipulations of the deceased’s marriage contract with their mother. With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a small estate, </span>which is insufficient to provide for both the sons and the daughters, <span class="gemarra-regular">the daughters are provided with sustenance. And </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">the sons, </span>who receive in this case neither inheritance nor sustenance, have no other means with which to support themselves, <span class="gemarra-regular">they </span>go and <span class="gemarra-regular">request </span>charity <span class="gemarra-regular">at the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">doors</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Admo</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">says, </span>rhetorically: <span class="gemarra-regular">I lost out </span>just <span class="gemarra-regular">because I am male? </span>Rather, he holds that the sons also receive sustenance. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabban Gamliel said: I see </span>as correct <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of Admon.</span>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And how large </span>must the estate be in order for the sons to inherit it? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: </span>Large <span class="gemarra-regular">enough to provide sustenance from it for </span>both <span class="gemarra-regular">these, </span>the sons, <span class="gemarra-regular">and those, </span>the daughters, for <span class="gemarra-regular">twelve </span><span class="gemarra-regular">months</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Rav Yehuda continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">When I said this </span>ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">before Shmuel, he said: That is the statement of Rabban Gamliel bar Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi. <span class="gemarra-regular">But the Rabbis say: </span>The estate must be large <span class="gemarra-regular">enough to provide sustenance from it for </span>both <span class="gemarra-regular">these and those until </span>the time <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the daughters <span class="gemarra-regular">reach their majority, </span>at age twelve and six months, as indicated in the marriage contract.
This <span class="gemarra-regular">was also stated </span>by other <span class="it-text">amora’im</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">When Ravin came </span>from Eretz Yisrael, he said that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says, and some say </span>it was <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba bar bar Ḥana </span>who <span class="gemarra-regular">says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: Any </span>estate <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>is large enough <span class="gemarra-regular">to provide sustenance from it for </span>both <span class="gemarra-regular">these and those until </span>the time <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the daughters <span class="gemarra-regular">reach their majority is a large </span>estate; <span class="gemarra-regular">less than that, this is a small </span>estate.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And if there is not </span>enough to provide <span class="gemarra-regular">for these and those until </span>the daughters <span class="gemarra-regular">reach their majority, </span>

Daf 140a

shall the <span class="gemarra-regular">daughters </span><span class="gemarra-regular">take all </span>of the estate, even if it is more than is required for their sustenance? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Rava said: </span>The court <span class="gemarra-regular">appropriates sustenance for the daughters until they reach their majority, and the remainder </span>is given <span class="gemarra-regular">to the sons.</span>
§ The Gemara comments: It is <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious </span>that if the estate was <span class="gemarra-regular">large and became small</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the <span class="gemarra-regular">heirs, </span>i.e., the sons, <span class="gemarra-regular">already acquired i</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> when it was large. It remains in their possession, and they must provide for the daughters from it. The Gemara asks: If the estate was <span class="gemarra-regular">small, </span>and was therefore not inherited by the sons, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>then it <span class="gemarra-regular">became large</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> what </span>is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? Does even a small estate <span class="gemarra-regular">remain in the possession of the heirs, </span>while the court reserves it for the daughters’ sustenance, and <span class="gemarra-regular">therefore it appreciated in the possession of </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">heirs </span>and they receive the appreciation in the estate’s value? <span class="gemarra-regular">Or perhaps </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">heirs are </span>totally <span class="gemarra-regular">removed from </span>possession of a small estate, and the appreciation in value is to the benefit of the daughters receiving sustenance.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a proof, <span class="gemarra-regular">as Rabbi Asi says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: </span>In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">orphans who preemptively sol</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> land <span class="gemarra-regular">from a small estate </span>left to them by their father, before the court appropriated it for the daughters’ sustenance, concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">that which they sold, </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">sale </span>is valid, even though they acted improperly. One can infer from this that a small estate remains in the possession of the heirs even when they are not authorized to derive benefit from it, and therefore the appreciation in its value belongs to them.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yirmeya was sitting before Rabbi Abbahu and raised </span>the following <span class="gemarra-regular">dilemma before him: What is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to the sustenance to which the deceased’s <span class="gemarra-regular">wido</span><span class="gemarra-regular">w</span> is entitled? Does it <span class="gemarra-regular">reduce </span>the value of <span class="gemarra-regular">the estate</span> when evaluating whether the estate is categorized as a large estate or a small estate? <span class="gemarra-regular">Do we say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">since she has </span>a right to receive <span class="gemarra-regular">sustenance, </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">reduces </span>the value of the estate? <span class="gemarra-regular">Or perhaps </span>we say that <span class="gemarra-regular">since if she remarries she does not have </span>a right to sustenance, <span class="gemarra-regular">now as well, </span>for the purposes of determining the value of the estate, she is considered as if <span class="gemarra-regular">she does not have </span>a right to sustenance, and therefore it does not reduce the value of the estate.
Furthermore, <span class="gemarra-regular">if you say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">since, if she remarries she does not have </span>a right to sustenance, <span class="gemarra-regular">now as well </span>she is considered as if <span class="gemarra-regular">she does not have </span>a right to sustenance, and it is not taken into account when evaluating the estate, then another dilemma can be raised: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to the sustenance one pledged to give, for a certain number of years, to the <span class="gemarra-regular">daughter of his wife </span>from a previous marriage, i.e., his step-daughter, which is an obligation not affected by his death or by her marriage? Does it <span class="gemarra-regular">reduce </span>the value of <span class="gemarra-regular">the estate? Do we say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">since, when she marries she also has </span>a right to sustenance, it <span class="gemarra-regular">reduces </span>the value of the estate? <span class="gemarra-regular">Or perhaps </span>we say that <span class="gemarra-regular">since, if she dies she does not have </span>a right to sustenance, it <span class="gemarra-regular">does not reduce </span>the value of the estate.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if you say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">since, if she dies she does not have </span>a right to sustenance, therefore it <span class="gemarra-regular">does not reduce</span> the value of the estate, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to a debt owed to the deceased’s <span class="gemarra-regular">creditor? </span>Does it <span class="gemarra-regular">reduce </span>the value of <span class="gemarra-regular">the estate? Do we say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">since, when </span>the creditor <span class="gemarra-regular">dies he also has </span>a right to the money owed him, and it is collected by his heirs, therefore it <span class="gemarra-regular">reduces </span>the value of the estate? <span class="gemarra-regular">Or perhaps </span>we say that <span class="gemarra-regular">since it has not yet been collected, </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">does not reduce </span>the value of the estate.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And there are </span>those who say <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>Rabbi Yirmeya <span class="gemarra-regular">raised the dilemmas in the opposite direction</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., in the reverse order: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to a debt owed to <span class="gemarra-regular">a creditor? </span>Does it <span class="gemarra-regular">reduce </span>the value of <span class="gemarra-regular">the estate? </span>

<span class="gemarra-regular">What is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to sustenance the deceased pledged to give <span class="gemarra-regular">the daughter of his wife </span>from a previous marriage? Does it <span class="gemarra-regular">reduce </span>the value of <span class="gemarra-regular">the estate? What is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to the sustenance to which <span class="gemarra-regular">his widow </span>is entitled? Does it <span class="gemarra-regular">reduce </span>the value of <span class="gemarra-regular">the estate? </span>Furthermore, with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">his widow and daughter</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> which of them takes precedence </span>if the estate is insufficient to provide sustenance for both?
Rabbi Abbahu <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Rabbi Yirmeya: <span class="gemarra-regular">Go now and come </span>back <span class="gemarra-regular">tomorrow. When he came </span>back, Rabbi Abbahu <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>him: <span class="gemarra-regular">Resolve at least one </span>of your questions, <span class="gemarra-regular">as Rabbi Abba says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Asi says: </span>The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">established </span>the status of the <span class="gemarra-regular">widow in relation to the daughte</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as </span>equivalent to the status of the <span class="gemarra-regular">daughter in relation to the brothers in </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a small estate. Just as </span>in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a daughter in relation to </span>her <span class="gemarra-regular">brothers, the daughter is sustained and the brothers </span>go and <span class="gemarra-regular">request </span>charity <span class="gemarra-regular">at the doors, so too </span>in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a widow in relation to the daughter, the widow is sustaine</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and the daughter </span>goes and <span class="gemarra-regular">requests </span>charity <span class="gemarra-regular">at the doors.</span>
§ The mishna teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">Admon says, </span>rhetorically: <span class="gemarra-regular">I lost out </span>just <span class="gemarra-regular">because I am male? </span>Rather, he holds that the sons also receive sustenance. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is he saying? Abaye said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>is what <span class="gemarra-regular">he is saying: Because I am male, and I am fit to engage in </span>the study of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Torah, I lost out </span>and must go begging instead of studying the Torah? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said to him: If that is so, </span>should one conclude that <span class="gemarra-regular">it is </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">one who engages in </span>the study of <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Tora</span><span class="gemarra-regular">h</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> who inherits, </span>whereas one <span class="gemarra-regular">who does not engage in </span>the study of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Torah does not inherit? Rather, Rava said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>is what Admon <span class="gemarra-regular">is saying: Because I am male, and I am fit to inherit in </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a large estate, </span>should <span class="gemarra-regular">I lose </span>my inheritance entirely <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a small estate?</span>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to one who <span class="gemarra-regular">left </span>behind <span class="gemarra-regular">sons and daughters and a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tumtum</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> whose halakhic status as male or female is indeterminate, the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">When the estate is large the males direct </span>the <span class="it-text">tumtum</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">to the females </span>and exclude him from the inheritance, claiming that perhaps the <span class="it-text">tumtum</span> is female. When the <span class="gemarra-regular">estate is small, the females direct </span>the <span class="it-text">tumtum</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">to the males </span>and exclude him from receiving sustenance, claiming that perhaps the <span class="it-text">tumtum</span> is male.
With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who says: If my wife gives birt</span><span class="gemarra-regular">h</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to a mal</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> the offspring <span class="gemarra-regular">shall receive </span>a gift of <span class="gemarra-regular">one hundred dinars, </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">she </span>in fact <span class="gemarra-regular">gave birth to a male, </span>the offspring <span class="gemarra-regular">receives one hundred dinars. </span>If he says: If my wife gives birth to <span class="gemarra-regular">a female </span>the offspring shall receive a gift of <span class="gemarra-regular">two hundred </span>dinars, if <span class="gemarra-regular">she </span>in fact <span class="gemarra-regular">gave birth to a female, </span>the offspring <span class="gemarra-regular">receives two hundred </span>dinars.
If he says: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>my wife gives birth to <span class="gemarra-regular">a male </span>the offspring shall receive a gift of <span class="gemarra-regular">one hundred dinars </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>she gives birth to <span class="gemarra-regular">a female </span>the offspring shall receive a gift of <span class="gemarra-regular">two hundred </span>dinars, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>in fact <span class="gemarra-regular">she gave birth to </span>both <span class="gemarra-regular">a male and a female</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the <span class="gemarra-regular">male </span>offspring <span class="gemarra-regular">receives one hundred dinars </span>and the <span class="gemarra-regular">female </span>offspring <span class="gemarra-regular">receives two hundred </span>dinars. If <span class="gemarra-regular">she gave birth to a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tumtum</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>the <span class="it-text">tumtum</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">does not receive </span>anything. <span class="gemarra-regular">If he said: Whatever </span>offspring <span class="gemarra-regular">my wife gives birth to shall receive </span>a gift of a certain sum, and she gave birth to a <span class="it-text">tumtum</span>, the <span class="it-text">tumtum</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">receives </span>it. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if there is no heir other than </span>the <span class="it-text">tumtum</span>, the <span class="it-text">tumtum</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">inherits all </span>of the estate.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna states that the males direct the <span class="it-text">tumtum</span> to the females. The Gemara asks: Does this mean that <span class="gemarra-regular">they direct him, and he takes </span>sustenance <span class="gemarra-regular">like a daughter? Isn’t it taught </span>in the <span class="gemarra-regular">latter clause </span>of the mishna that if one said that either his male or female child will receive a certain sum once his wife gives birth, and <span class="gemarra-regular">she gave birth to a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tumtum</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>the <span class="it-text">tumtum</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">does not receive </span>anything? This indicates that the <span class="it-text">tumtum</span> does not have the rights of a female. <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye says: </span>The mishna means that <span class="gemarra-regular">they direct him </span>to the females, <span class="gemarra-regular">but he has no </span>rights to sustenance.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rava says: They direct him </span>to the females <span class="gemarra-regular">and he has </span>a right to sustenance. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">the latter clause </span>of the mishna, which grants the <span class="it-text">tumtum</span> nothing at all, there <span class="gemarra-regular">we arrive at </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as it is taught </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Temura</span> 24b): If one consecrates a firstborn animal while it is still a fetus, stating that if it is male it shall be a burnt-offering and if it is female it shall be a peace-offering, and the mother <span class="gemarra-regular">gave birth to a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tumtum</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> or a hermaphrodite [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">androginos</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: It is not imbued with sanctity</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as it is neither male nor female. So too, in the case discussed in the mishna here, Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel maintains that the <span class="it-text">tumtum</span> receives nothing, as he is considered to be a distinct entity of indeterminate sex, neither male nor female.
The Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises an objection </span>from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">A </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tumtum</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> inherits as a son and is sustained as a daughter. Granted, according to Rava, </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> can be explained to mean that the clause: <span class="gemarra-regular">Inherits as a son, </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a small estate, </span>as the daughters direct the <span class="it-text">tumtum</span> to the sons, and just as there is no inheritance for the sons, there is none for the <span class="it-text">tumtum</span> either. And the clause: <span class="gemarra-regular">And is sustained as a daughter, </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a large estate, </span>as the sons direct the <span class="it-text">tumtum</span> to the daughters, and the <span class="it-text">tumtum</span> receives sustenance along with them.

<span class="gemarra-regular">But according to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye, what </span>does it mean that the <span class="it-text">tumtum</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is sustained as a daughter, </span>since Abaye maintains that the <span class="it-text">tumtum</span> does not have the rights of a daughter? The Gemara responds: <span class="gemarra-regular">And according to your reasoning, </span>even <span class="gemarra-regular">according to Rava, what </span>does it mean that a <span class="it-text">tumtum</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">inherits as a son, </span>since Rava concedes that the <span class="it-text">tumtum</span> and sons do not actually inherit anything? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> means that it is <span class="gemarra-regular">fitting </span>for the <span class="it-text">tumtum</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">to inherit but</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he does not </span>actually inherit. <span class="gemarra-regular">Here too, </span>with regard to sustenance, according to Abaye, the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> means that it is <span class="gemarra-regular">fitting </span>for the <span class="it-text">tumtum</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> be sustained, but he is not </span>actually sustained.
§ The mishna teaches: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who says: If my wife gives birth to a male </span>the offspring shall receive one hundred dinars, if she in fact gave birth to a male, the offspring receives one hundred dinars. If he says: If my wife gives birth to a female the offspring shall receive two hundred dinars, if she in fact gave birth to a female, the offspring receives two hundred dinars. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Is this to say that for him a daughter is preferable to a son? But </span>this seems to contradict what <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says in the name of Rabbi Shimon ben Yoḥai: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">anyone who does not leave </span>behind <span class="gemarra-regular">a son to inherit </span>from <span class="gemarra-regular">him, the Holy One, Blessed be He, is filled with wrath upon him, as it is stated: </span>“If a man dies, and has no son, <span class="gemarra-regular">then you shall cause his inheritance to pass [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">veha</span><span class="gemarra-italic">’avartem</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] to his daughter” </span>(Numbers 27:8). The term <span class="gemarra-italic">ha’avara</span> means <span class="gemarra-regular">nothing other </span>than <span class="gemarra-regular">wrath, as it is stated: “That day is a day of wrath [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">evra</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]” </span>(Zephaniah 1:15).
The Gemara resolves the contradiction: <span class="gemarra-regular">With regard to the matter of inheritance, for him a son is preferable </span>to a daughter, as a son bears his name and retains his ancestral heritage within his father’s tribe, but <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to the matter of </span>providing for his offspring’s <span class="gemarra-regular">comfort</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for him his daughter is preferable </span>to his son, as a son is more capable of coping for himself and the daughter needs more support.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Shmuel said: Here we are dealing with </span>a mother who is <span class="gemarra-regular">giving birth for the first time, and </span>this is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav Ḥisda, as Rav Ḥisda says: </span>If one gives birth to <span class="gemarra-regular">a daughter first, </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">is a good sign for sons. There are </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">who say </span>that this is <span class="gemarra-regular">because she raises her brothers, </span>i.e., helps in their upbringing, <span class="gemarra-regular">and there are </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">who say </span>that this is <span class="gemarra-regular">because the evil ey</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> does not have dominion over </span>the father. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥisda said: And </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">for myself, I prefer daughters to sons</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
The Gemara adds: <span class="gemarra-regular">And if you wish, say: </span>In accordance with <span class="gemarra-regular">whose </span>statement is <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>mishna in which preference is given to the daughter? <span class="gemarra-regular">It is </span>in accordance with the statement of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Which </span>statement of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda </span>is this referring to? <span class="gemarra-regular">If we say </span>it is referring to the statement of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda with regard to </span>the term <span class="gemarra-regular">“with everything [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">bakkol</span><span class="gemarra-regular">],” </span>that is difficult. The Gemara cites Rabbi Yehuda’s statement. <span class="gemarra-regular">As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: “And Abraham was old, well stricken in age; <span class="gemarra-regular">and the Lord had blessed Abraham with everything [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">bakkol</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]” </span>(Genesis 24:1). <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir says: </span>The blessing was <span class="gemarra-regular">that he did not have a daughter</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rabbi Yehuda says: </span>The blessing was <span class="gemarra-regular">that he had a daughter, and her name </span>was <span class="gemarra-regular">Bakkol. </span>Evidently, Rabbi Yehuda understands the birth of a daughter to be a blessing. The Gemara explains the difficulty: <span class="gemarra-regular">Say that you heard Rabbi Yehuda </span>explain that the blessing was that <span class="gemarra-regular">the Merciful One did not even deprive Abraham </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">a daughter, </span>in addition to his sons. <span class="gemarra-regular">Did you hear him </span>say <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>a daughter is <span class="gemarra-regular">preferable to a son?</span>
The Gemara proposes another of Rabbi Yehuda’s statements: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>it is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>other statement of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda, as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: One is not halakhically obligated to provide sustenance for his children beyond the age of six. Nevertheless, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">a mitzva to provide sustenance for the daughters</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> And </span>one can infer <span class="gemarra-italic">a</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">fortiori</span> that it is certainly a mitzva to provide <span class="gemarra-regular">for sons, who are engaged in </span>the study of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Torah; </span>this is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Yehuda says: </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">a mitzva to provide sustenance for the sons. And </span>one can infer <span class="gemarra-italic">a</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">fortiori</span> that it is certainly a mitzva to provide <span class="gemarra-regular">for daughters, </span>so <span class="gemarra-regular">that they not be disgraced </span>by having to beg for their livelihood. This indicates that with regard to providing sustenance for one’s children, Rabbi Yehuda gives preference to the daughters.
§ The mishna discusses a case where one stipulated that if his wife gives birth to a male the offspring shall receive one hundred dinars, and if she gives birth to a female the offspring shall receive two hundred dinars. The mishna states that if she gave birth to both a male and a female, the male receives one hundred dinars and the female receives two hundred. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">that which is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> (<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span> 9:4): If she <span class="gemarra-regular">gave birth to a male and a female, the male receives six dinars </span>of gold, which are equivalent to one hundred fifty dinars of silver, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the female receives two dinars </span>of gold, equivalent to fifty dinars of silver, <span class="gemarra-regular">with what </span>situation is this <span class="it-text">baraita</span> dealing?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi said: I said this </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> before Rav Kahana, </span>and he explained it as teaching <span class="gemarra-regular">about one who inverted </span>the stipulations of his gift. The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is referring to one <span class="gemarra-regular">who said: </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">a male </span>is born <span class="gemarra-regular">first </span>he will receive <span class="gemarra-regular">two hundred </span>dinars, and if <span class="gemarra-regular">a female </span>is born <span class="gemarra-regular">after him </span>she will receive <span class="gemarra-regular">nothing. </span>And if <span class="gemarra-regular">a female </span>is born <span class="gemarra-regular">first </span>she will receive <span class="gemarra-regular">one hundred dinars, </span>and if <span class="gemarra-regular">a male </span>is born <span class="gemarra-regular">after her </span>he will receive <span class="gemarra-regular">one hundred dinars. And </span>the mother <span class="gemarra-regular">gave birth to a male and a female, but we do not know which of them emerged </span>from the womb <span class="gemarra-regular">first. </span>In this case, the <span class="gemarra-regular">male takes one hundred dinars, </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">whichever way you </span>look at it, this sum is due to him. <span class="gemarra-regular">The other one hundred dinars are property of uncertain ownershi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">p</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and are divided</span> equally between the male and female.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">that which is taught </span>in another <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: If <span class="gemarra-regular">she gave birth to a male and a female, he </span>receives <span class="gemarra-regular">only one hundred dinars, how can you find these </span>circumstances? <span class="gemarra-regular">Ravina said: </span>This is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>one who said: I shall give a certain sum to whoever <span class="gemarra-regular">informs me. </span>

Daf 141b

This is <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> (<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span> 9:5): In a case where one said: <span class="gemarra-regular">Whoever informs me </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">to what opened my wife’s womb, </span>i.e., what the sex of her child is, <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">a male, </span>the one who informs me <span class="gemarra-regular">shall receive one hundred dinars. </span>Therefore, if the wife <span class="gemarra-regular">gave birth to a male, </span>the one who informed him <span class="gemarra-regular">receives one hundred dinars. </span>If he also said: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">a female </span>he shall receive <span class="gemarra-regular">one hundred dinars, </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">she gave birth to a female, </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">receives one hundred dinars. </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">she gave birth to a male and a female, he </span>receives <span class="gemarra-regular">only one hundred dinars.</span>
The Gemara challenges: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>since <span class="gemarra-regular">he did not say </span>anything about <span class="gemarra-regular">a male and a female, </span>if she gave birth to a male and a female, he should not receive anything. Why does the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> state that he receives one hundred dinars? The Gemara answers: This is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">where he also said: If </span>she gives birth to <span class="gemarra-regular">a male and a female </span>he shall <span class="gemarra-regular">also receive one hundred dinars. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if he stated all of the possibilities, <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>did his stipulations serve <span class="gemarra-regular">to exclude? </span>The Gemara answers: They serve <span class="gemarra-regular">to exclude </span>a case where she gives birth to <span class="gemarra-regular">a non-viable newborn, </span>in which case he receives nothing.
§ The Gemara relates: There was <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain </span>man <span class="gemarra-regular">who said to his wife: My property </span>is given <span class="gemarra-regular">to the one with whom you are pregnant. Rav Huna said: This is </span>a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who transfers ownership </span>of an item <span class="gemarra-regular">to a fetus, and </span>in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who transfers ownership </span>of an item <span class="gemarra-regular">to a fetus</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the fetus <span class="gemarra-regular">does not acquire </span>the item.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman raised an objection to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna </span>opinion from the mishna, which states: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who says: If my wife gives birth to a male </span>the offspring <span class="gemarra-regular">shall receive one hundred dinars, </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">she </span>in fact <span class="gemarra-regular">gave birth to a male, </span>the offspring <span class="gemarra-regular">receives one hundred dinars. </span>This indicates that the fetus did acquire the money. Rav Huna <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: I do not know who taught our mishna. </span>It is not identifiable with a known opinion, and presumably the text has been corrupted.
The Gemara asks why Rav Huna replied in this manner: <span class="gemarra-regular">But let him say to </span>Rav Naḥman: <span class="gemarra-regular">It is </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> who says: A person can transfer ownership </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">an entity that has not </span>yet <span class="gemarra-regular">come into the world, </span>e.g., produce that has not yet grown. Just as he maintains that one can transfer ownership of an entity that has not yet come into the world, so too, he maintains that one can transfer ownership of an item to a fetus, who has not yet been born.
The Gemara rejects this explanation: <span class="gemarra-regular">Say that you heard Rabbi Meir </span>express this opinion with regard to transferring ownership of an entity that has not yet come into the world <span class="gemarra-regular">to an entity that is in the world. Did you hear him </span>speak of transferring ownership <span class="gemarra-regular">to an entity that has not </span>yet <span class="gemarra-regular">come into the world, </span>e.g., a fetus?
The Gemara proposes another resolution to Rav Naḥman’s objection: <span class="gemarra-regular">But let </span>Rav Huna <span class="gemarra-regular">say to </span>Rav Naḥman: <span class="gemarra-regular">It is </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei, who says: A fetus acquires </span>ownership, <span class="gemarra-regular">as we learned </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Yevamot</span> 67a): With regard to an Israelite woman who married a priest and he died and left her pregnant, the <span class="gemarra-regular">fetus disqualifies</span> its father’s Canaanite slaves from partaking of <span class="it-text">teruma</span>, because until it is born the fetus is not considered a priest, and the slaves, who are part of its inheritance, are not the slaves of a priest. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the fetus <span class="gemarra-regular">does not enable </span>its mother <span class="gemarra-regular">to partake </span>of <span class="it-text">teruma</span>, even though it is the child of a priest. This is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of Rabbi Yosei. </span>It is evident from this mishna that Rabbi Yosei holds that a fetus inherits its father’s property.
The Gemara rejects this explanation: <span class="gemarra-regular">Inheritance is different, </span>since, unlike a gift, <span class="gemarra-regular">it comes </span>into the possession of the heir <span class="gemarra-regular">by itself, </span>without a formal act of acquisition. Therefore, a fetus can acquire an inheritance, but not a gift.
The Gemara proposes another resolution to Rav Naḥman’s objection: <span class="gemarra-regular">But let </span>Rav Huna <span class="gemarra-regular">say to </span>Rav Naḥman: <span class="gemarra-regular">It is </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka, who says: </span>The case of <span class="gemarra-regular">an inheritance is not different, and </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a gift</span> one gives to his heir <span class="gemarra-regular">is not different, </span>i.e., the same <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> apply to both. <span class="gemarra-regular">As we learned </span>in a mishna (130a): <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka says: If one said about </span>a person <span class="gemarra-regular">who is fit to inherit </span>from <span class="gemarra-regular">him</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> e.g., one of his sons: This person will inherit all of my property, <span class="gemarra-regular">his statement stands.</span>
The Gemara rejects this explanation: <span class="gemarra-regular">Say that you heard Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka</span> express this opinion with regard to a gift given <span class="gemarra-regular">to an entity that </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">exists in the world, </span>but <span class="gemarra-regular">does he say </span>anything with regard to a gift given <span class="gemarra-regular">to an entity that has not </span>yet <span class="gemarra-regular">come into the world?</span>
The Gemara proposes another resolution to Rav Naḥman’s objection: <span class="gemarra-regular">But let </span>Rav Huna <span class="gemarra-regular">say to </span>Rav Naḥman: <span class="gemarra-regular">It is </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka, </span>who compares a gift to an inheritance, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he holds in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei, </span>that a fetus is fit to inherit. The Gemara rejects this explanation: <span class="gemarra-regular">Who says that </span>Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>in accordance <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>the opinion of Rabbi Yosei?
The Gemara proposes another resolution to Rav Naḥman’s objection: <span class="gemarra-regular">But let </span>Rav Huna <span class="gemarra-regular">say to </span>Rav Naḥman that the mishna is referring not to one who gave a gift to the fetus, but <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>one who said: I shall give a certain sum to whoever <span class="gemarra-regular">informs me.</span> This person is in the world. The Gemara rejects this explanation as well: <span class="gemarra-regular">If that is so, </span>then concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>which <span class="gemarra-regular">the last clause </span>of the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches: And if there is no heir other than </span>the <span class="it-text">tumtum</span>, the <span class="it-text">tumtum</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">inherits all </span>of the estate, <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>the mishna is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>one who said: I shall give a certain sum to whoever <span class="gemarra-regular">informs me, what is the purpose of </span>mentioning <span class="gemarra-regular">an heir, </span>since the mishna is not discussing a gift to the heir at all?
The Gemara proposes another resolution to Rav Naḥman’s objection: <span class="gemarra-regular">But let </span>Rav Huna <span class="gemarra-regular">say to </span>Rav Naḥman: The mishna is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where</span> the gift was made after his wife had already <span class="gemarra-regular">given birth</span> but he did not yet know the sex of the baby. The Gemara rejects this explanation as well: <span class="gemarra-regular">If that is so, </span>then concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>which <span class="gemarra-regular">the latter clause </span>of the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches: Whatever </span>offspring <span class="gemarra-regular">my wife gives birth to shall receive </span>a certain sum, and she gave birth to a <span class="it-text">tumtum</span>, the <span class="it-text">tumtum</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">receives </span>it, there is a difficulty. According to this explanation, the phrase: <span class="gemarra-regular">Whatever </span>offspring my wife <span class="gemarra-regular">gives birth to, </span>is incorrect. The mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">should have said: Whatever </span>offspring my wife <span class="gemarra-regular">gave birth to. </span>

Daf 142a

The Gemara proposes another resolution to Rav Naḥman’s objection: <span class="gemarra-regular">But let </span>Rav Huna <span class="gemarra-regular">say to </span>Rav Naḥman that the mishna is referring to one <span class="gemarra-regular">who says </span>that the transfer of ownership should take effect <span class="gemarra-regular">when she gives birth, </span>at which point the child already exists. The Gemara rejects this resolution: Rav Huna does not interpret the mishna in this way, because <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna </span>conforms <span class="gemarra-regular">to his </span>line of <span class="gemarra-regular">reasoning, as Rav Huna says: Even </span>if one says that the transfer of ownership should take effect <span class="gemarra-regular">when she gives birth, </span>the fetus <span class="gemarra-regular">does not acquire </span>it.
The Gemara clarifies: <span class="gemarra-regular">As Rav Naḥman says: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who transfers ownership </span>of an item <span class="gemarra-regular">to a fetus, </span>the fetus <span class="gemarra-regular">does not acquire </span>it. But if he says that the transfer of ownership of the item should take effect <span class="gemarra-regular">when she gives birth, </span>the fetus <span class="gemarra-regular">acquires </span>it. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav Huna says</span><span class="gemarra-regular">:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Even </span>if he says that the transfer of ownership of the item should take effect <span class="gemarra-regular">when she gives birth, </span>the fetus <span class="gemarra-regular">does not acquire </span>it, because the fetus did not exist in the world when he transferred ownership. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav Sheshet says: </span>In <span class="gemarra-regular">both this </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">and that </span>case, the fetus <span class="gemarra-regular">acquires </span>the item.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Sheshet said: From where</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> do I say </span>that the fetus acquires the item? <span class="gemarra-regular">As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a convert who died, </span>apparently without offspring, <span class="gemarra-regular">and Jews plundered [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">uvizbezu</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> his property</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> assuming that he had no heirs and his property was therefore ownerless, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>subsequently <span class="gemarra-regular">they heard that he had a son or that his wife was pregnant, they are obligated to return </span>the property. If <span class="gemarra-regular">they returned it all, and then they heard that his son died or that his wife miscarried, </span>if one <span class="gemarra-regular">took possession at the second </span>time, after hearing about the death or the miscarriage, he <span class="gemarra-regular">acquired </span>the property, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>if one took possession only <span class="gemarra-regular">at the first </span>time, before it was known there was an heir at all, he <span class="gemarra-regular">did not acquire </span>the property.
Rav Sheshet explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">And if it enters your mind </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a fetus does not acquire </span>property, <span class="gemarra-regular">why do they </span>need to <span class="gemarra-regular">take possession </span>again <span class="gemarra-regular">the second </span>time? <span class="gemarra-regular">Didn’t they </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">take possession one time? </span>Evidently, the miscarried fetus had acquired ownership in the meantime.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said </span>in reply to Rav Sheshet: <span class="gemarra-regular">Inheritance, which comes </span>into the possession of the heir <span class="gemarra-regular">by itself </span>without a formal act of acquisition, <span class="gemarra-regular">is different. </span>Even if a fetus inherits property, it may not be able to acquire property in any other manner, e.g., receiving a gift. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: </span>It <span class="gemarra-regular">is different there, </span>in the case where they plundered the property of the convert, <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>the property <span class="gemarra-regular">was initially </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">loosely held in their hands, </span>as they did not clearly know whether or not the deceased convert had heirs. Therefore, the first time they took possession was not sufficient, and they needed to take possession again in order to acquire the property.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>the difference <span class="gemarra-regular">between </span>Abaye’s refutation and Rava’s refutation? The practical difference <span class="gemarra-regular">between them </span>is in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span><span class="gemarra-regular">they </span>initially <span class="gemarra-regular">heard </span>with regard <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the fetus <span class="gemarra-regular">that he </span>had <span class="gemarra-regular">died, </span>and they then took possession of the property. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>in reality, he had <span class="gemarra-regular">not died, and then </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">died. </span>According to Abaye, a fetus inherits property. Therefore, the property was not ownerless, and the plunderers did not acquire it. According to Rava, since the plunderers heard that the fetus had died, they took a firm hold upon the property, and they acquired it the first time.
The Gemara offers another refutation of the opinion of Rav Sheshet: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a proof from a mishna (<span class="it-text">Nidda</span> 43b–44a): <span class="gemarra-regular">A one-day-old child inherits </span>property <span class="gemarra-regular">and bequeaths </span>property. One can infer that if the child is <span class="gemarra-regular">one day old, yes, </span>he inherits property; but <span class="gemarra-regular">a fetus </span>does <span class="gemarra-regular">not. </span>The Gemara replies: <span class="gemarra-regular">Doesn’t Rav Sheshet say </span>that the mishna teaches a different <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? The mishna teaches that a one-day-old child <span class="gemarra-regular">inherits his mother’s propert</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span> the moment he is born, so that he is able <span class="gemarra-regular">to bequeath </span>it, if he then dies, <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>his heirs who are not the mother’s heirs, e.g., his <span class="gemarra-regular">paternal brothers. </span>This <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">specifically </span>applies from when he is <span class="gemarra-regular">one day old, but a fetus </span>whose mother died <span class="gemarra-regular">does not </span>inherit from her. <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>for this? 

Daf 142b

The reason is <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>we presume that the fetus <span class="gemarra-regular">died first, </span>before its mother died, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the son does</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not inherit from his mother </span>while <span class="gemarra-regular">in the grave, </span>in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to bequeath </span>the inheritance <span class="gemarra-regular">to his paternal</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> brothers. </span>The <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is that if a son dies, and afterward his mother dies, the deceased son does not inherit from his mother and subsequently bequeath the inheritance to his paternal brothers, who are not related to the mother. But in other cases, where it is not his mother’s estate, a fetus inherits property.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Is this to say that </span>it is certain that the fetus <span class="gemarra-regular">died first? But there was an incident </span>where the mother died <span class="gemarra-regular">and</span> the fetus <span class="gemarra-regular">made three spasmodic motions </span>afterward. Apparently, a fetus can die after the mother. <span class="gemarra-regular">Mar bar Rav Ashi said: </span>That incident was <span class="gemarra-regular">just as it</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is with the tail of the lizard</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> which jerks </span>after being severed from the lizard, but it is just a spasmodic motion which does not indicate that it is still alive.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Mar, son of Rav Yosef, says in the name of Rava: </span>The mishna comes <span class="gemarra-regular">to say that </span>a one-day-old child <span class="gemarra-regular">reduces the portion of the firstborn</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> The firstborn is entitled to a double portion of the inheritance, and this is calculated taking into account the portion due to his dead brother. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>it is in this context that <span class="gemarra-regular">specifically </span>the portion of <span class="gemarra-regular">a one-day-old </span>child is taken into account, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>the portion of <span class="gemarra-regular">a fetus is not </span>taken into account, even though a fetus also inherits property. <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is the reason </span>for this? <span class="gemarra-regular">The Merciful One states </span>concerning the portion of the firstborn: “If a man has two wives, the one beloved, and the other hated, <span class="gemarra-regular">and they bore him children, </span>both the beloved and the hated; and if the firstborn son be hers that was hated” (Deuteronomy 21:15). The term “children” excludes a fetus.
This is similar to another <span class="it-text">halakha</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">as Mar, son of Rav Yosef, says in the name of Rava: A son who was born after his father’s deat</span><span class="gemarra-regular">h</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> does not reduce the firstborn’s portion. What is the reason </span>for this? <span class="gemarra-regular">The Merciful One states </span>in the Torah: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And they bore him children,” and this </span>term “children” <span class="gemarra-regular">does not </span>apply to a fetus.
The Gemara notes: <span class="gemarra-regular">In Sura they taught </span>Mar’s statement <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>way, but <span class="gemarra-regular">in Pumbedita they taught </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>way: <span class="gemarra-regular">Mar, son of Rav Yosef, says in the name of Rava: A firstborn who was born after his father’s deat</span><span class="gemarra-regular">h</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> does not receive a double </span>portion. <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>for this? <span class="gemarra-regular">The Merciful One states </span>in the Torah: “But <span class="gemarra-regular">he shall acknowledge</span> the firstborn, the son of the hated, by giving him a double portion” (Deuteronomy 21:17), <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>in this case the father <span class="gemarra-regular">is not </span>there <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>he can <span class="gemarra-regular">acknowledge </span>him. The Gemara concludes: <span class="gemarra-regular">And the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with all these versions </span>of that <span class="gemarra-regular">which Mar, son of Rav Yosef, says in the name of Rava. </span>Accordingly, a one-day-old child reduces the portion of the firstborn, a son born after his father’s death does not reduce the firstborn’s portion, and a firstborn born after his father’s death does not receive a double portion.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yitzḥak says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who transfers ownership </span>of an item <span class="gemarra-regular">to a fetus, </span>the fetus <span class="gemarra-regular">does not acquire </span>the item. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if you say </span>that the statement of <span class="gemarra-regular">our mishna </span>(140b), with regard to one who gives a gift to his unborn child, indicates that an item can be transferred to a fetus, the circumstances there are unique. <span class="gemarra-regular">Since the disposition of a person </span>is to be <span class="gemarra-regular">inclined toward his son</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the Sages validated such a transfer, but one cannot transfer an item to the unborn child of another.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel said to Rav Ḥana of Baghdad: Go out </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">bring me an assembly of ten </span>men, <span class="gemarra-regular">and I will say </span>a <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">to you in their presence, </span>so that it will be well publicized. The <span class="it-text">halakha</span> was: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who transfers ownership </span>of an item <span class="gemarra-regular">to a fetus, </span>the fetus <span class="gemarra-regular">acquires </span>the item. The Gemara concludes: <span class="gemarra-regular">And the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is that with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who transfers ownership </span>of an item <span class="gemarra-regular">to a fetus, </span>the fetus <span class="gemarra-regular">does not acquire </span>the item.
