§ The Gemara relates: There was <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain </span>man <span class="gemarra-regular">who said to his wife, </span>before she conceived: <span class="gemarra-regular">My property </span>is given <span class="gemarra-regular">to the sons that I will have from you</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> His older son </span>from a previous marriage <span class="gemarra-regular">came </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: That man, </span>i.e., me, <span class="gemarra-regular">what will become of him, </span>i.e., will I receive nothing? <span class="gemarra-regular">He said to </span>his son: <span class="gemarra-regular">Go </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">acquire </span>a portion <span class="gemarra-regular">like one of the sons </span>who will be born, i.e., you will receive a share as well. The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">Those </span>sons who were not yet born <span class="gemarra-regular">certainly did not acquire </span>the property, and do not receive more than their share as heirs, <span class="gemarra-regular">as</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> they are not yet </span>in existence.
The Gemara asks: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">this</span> son, <span class="gemarra-regular">does the young man [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">letalya</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> receive an additional <span class="gemarra-regular">shar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> of the inheritance in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>there are other <span class="gemarra-regular">sons </span>from the second wife, since his father gave him an additional share, <span class="gemarra-regular">or does the young man not </span>receive an additional <span class="gemarra-regular">share </span>of the inheritance <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>there are other <span class="gemarra-regular">sons? </span>There are <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Avin, and Rabbi Meyasha, and Rabbi Yirmeya, who </span>all <span class="gemarra-regular">say: The young man does </span>receive an additional <span class="gemarra-regular">share </span>of the inheritance <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>there are other <span class="gemarra-regular">sons. </span>And there are <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Abbahu, and Rabbi Ḥanina bar Pappi, and Rabbi Yitzḥak Nappaḥa, who </span>all <span class="gemarra-regular">say: The young man does not </span>receive an additional <span class="gemarra-regular">shar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> of the inheritance <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>there are other <span class="gemarra-regular">sons.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Abbahu said to Rabbi Yirmeya: </span>Is <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in accordance with our </span>opinion, <span class="gemarra-regular">or </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in accordance with your </span>opinion? Rabbi Yirmeya <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Rabbi Abbahu: It is <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious that the</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with our </span>opinion, <span class="gemarra-regular">as we are older than you</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">not in accordance with your </span>opinion, <span class="gemarra-regular">as you are youngsters [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">dardekei</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Rabbi Abbahu <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Rabbi Yirmeya in reply: <span class="gemarra-regular">Does the matter depend upon age? The matter depends upon the reaso</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> behind the ruling. Rabbi Yirmeya asked him: <span class="gemarra-regular">And what is </span>your <span class="gemarra-regular">reason? </span>Rabbi Abbahu replied: <span class="gemarra-regular">Go to Rabbi Avin, as I explained </span>this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">to him, </span>

Daf 143a

<span class="gemarra-regular">and he nodded [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">vekharkeish</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> his head </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">the study hall </span>in approval <span class="gemarra-regular">of this </span>explanation. Rabbi Yirmeya <span class="gemarra-regular">went to </span>Rabbi Avin, who <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>Rabbi Abbahu’s reasoning is that <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>a father <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>his son: <span class="gemarra-regular">Acquire </span>an item <span class="gemarra-regular">as a donkey </span>does, <span class="gemarra-regular">does he acquire </span>it? In the same manner that the son would not acquire anything if his acquisition were likened to that of a donkey, which possesses no ability to acquire an item, so too, since the father compared the son’s acquisition to the acquisition effected by his unborn children, who possess no ability to acquire property, the son did not acquire any property.
This is <span class="gemarra-regular">as it was stated: </span>With regard to one who says to another: <span class="gemarra-regular">Acquire </span>an item <span class="gemarra-regular">as a donkey </span>does, he <span class="gemarra-regular">does not acquire </span>any property, as a donkey cannot acquire property. But with regard to one who says: <span class="gemarra-regular">You and a donke</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span> shall both acquire my property, there is a disagreement. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman says: </span>The person <span class="gemarra-regular">acquires </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">half </span>of the property, <span class="gemarra-regular">and Rav Hamnuna says: </span>It is as though the giver <span class="gemarra-regular">does not say anything. </span>Since the beneficiary was included with the donkey in the same acquisition, he does not acquire any property, just as the donkey does not acquire any property. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Sheshet says: </span>The person <span class="gemarra-regular">acquires all </span>the property. As the giver knew that a donkey cannot acquire property, he intended for the person, who was capable of acquiring property, to acquire all the property.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Sheshet said: From where do I say this? As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei says: There is nothing bitte</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in the cucumbe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> other than its inner </span>part, which is sometimes bitter and inedible and unfit to be separated as <span class="it-text">teruma</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">Therefore, </span>since one does not know if the cucumber he separates as <span class="it-text">teruma</span> is bitter inside, <span class="gemarra-regular">when he separates </span><span class="gemarra-italic">teruma</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">adds </span>part of another cucumber as <span class="it-text">teruma</span>, in addition <span class="gemarra-regular">to the outer </span>part <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span>the cucumber, which is edible. <span class="gemarra-regular">And he separates </span>both <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span><span class="gemarra-italic">teruma</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>thereby ensuring that the <span class="it-text">teruma</span> consists of sufficient edible cucumber.
Rav Sheshet asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Why </span>does the separation of <span class="it-text">teruma</span> take effect? <span class="gemarra-regular">Is it </span>not analogous to one who states: <span class="gemarra-regular">You and a donkey </span>shall acquire an item, since he designated as <span class="it-text">teruma</span> both the outer part of the cucumber, which is fit to become <span class="it-text">teruma</span>, and the inedible inner part, which is not fit to become <span class="it-text">teruma</span>? Since this does not invalidate the separation of <span class="it-text">teruma</span> with regard to the edible outer part, one can infer that although the donkey cannot acquire property, this does not prevent the person from acquiring the property.
The Gemara replies: <span class="gemarra-regular">It is different there, as by Torah law </span>the bitter inner part <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">properly </span>considered <span class="gemarra-italic">teruma</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>even though by rabbinic law if one separated inferior produce as <span class="it-text">teruma</span> he must again separate produce of superior quality as <span class="it-text">teruma</span>. Therefore, when one designates the entire cucumber as <span class="it-text">teruma</span>, he is not designating both fit and unfit produce.
This is <span class="gemarra-regular">as Rabbi Ile’a says: From where </span>is it derived <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to one who separates </span><span class="gemarra-italic">teruma</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from poor-</span>quality produce <span class="gemarra-regular">for superior-</span>quality produce is <span class="gemarra-regular">that his </span><span class="gemarra-italic">teruma</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is </span>valid <span class="gemarra-italic">teruma</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is stated </span>with regard to <span class="it-text">teruma</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And you shall bear no sin by reason of it, seeing that you have set apart from it the best thereof”</span> (Numbers 18:32). By inference, this indicates that it is a transgression to separate the inferior part of the produce as <span class="it-text">teruma</span>. Rabbi Ile’a explains the proof: <span class="gemarra-regular">And if </span>the inferior produce <span class="gemarra-regular">is not sanctified </span>as <span class="it-text">teruma</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">why </span>does it involve the <span class="gemarra-regular">bearing of sin, </span>as it is a meaningless act? <span class="gemarra-regular">From here </span>one can derive that <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who separates </span><span class="gemarra-italic">teruma</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from poor</span>-quality produce <span class="gemarra-regular">for superior-</span>quality produce is <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>although he acted improperly, <span class="gemarra-regular">his </span><span class="gemarra-italic">teruma</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is </span>valid <span class="gemarra-italic">teruma</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
§ The Gemara cited Rav Hamnuna’s opinion that if one says: You and a donkey shall acquire my property, he did not say anything. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Mordekhai said to Rav Ashi: Rav Avya raises an objection </span>to Rav Hamnuna’s opinion from a mishna (<span class="it-text">Kiddushin</span> 50b): <span class="gemarra-regular">An incident </span>occurred <span class="gemarra-regular">involving five women</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and among them </span>were <span class="gemarra-regular">two sisters, and one person gathered a baske</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of figs that belonged to them, and </span>the fruit <span class="gemarra-regular">was of </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">Sabbatical </span>Year, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he said: You are hereby all betrothed to me with this basket, and one of them accepted </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">on behalf of all of them. The Sages said: The sisters are not betrothed</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as it is prohibited to marry the sister of one’s wife during her lifetime.
One can infer from the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">It is </span>only the <span class="gemarra-regular">sisters who are not betrothed, but </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">unrelated women </span>are <span class="gemarra-regular">betrothed. But why </span>is that so? <span class="gemarra-regular">It is </span>analogous to one who states: <span class="gemarra-regular">You and a donkey </span>shall acquire an item. Since he tried to betroth two women ineligible for betrothal together with the eligible women, the betrothal should not take effect even with regard to the eligible women.
Rav Ashi <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Rav Mordekhai: <span class="gemarra-regular">This is why I saw Rav Huna bar Avya in a dream, because </span>you were going to tell me that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Avya raised an objection </span>to Rav Hamnuna’s opinion. But as for this objection, <span class="gemarra-regular">didn’t we interpret </span>the mishna in <span class="it-text">Kiddushin</span> as referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">where he says: Those of you who are eligible for </span>engaging in <span class="gemarra-regular">sexual intercourse </span>with me <span class="gemarra-regular">shall be betrothed to me? </span>Since the sisters were forbidden to him, they were not included in the betrothal in the first place, and there was no impediment to the betrothal of the eligible women taking effect. The case is therefore not comparable to the case discussed by Rav Hamnuna.
§ The Gemara relates: There was <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain </span>man <span class="gemarra-regular">who said to his wife: My property is given to you and to your sons. Rav Yosef says: </span>In such a case, the wife <span class="gemarra-regular">acquires half </span>of the property, even though the man did not specify how much of his property he was giving her. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav Yosef said: From where do I say this? As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">says: </span>The verse states with regard to the shewbread: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And it shall be for Aaron and his sons” </span>(Leviticus 24:9). This means <span class="gemarra-regular">half for Aaron </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">half for his sons</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> One can infer from the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that when it is specified that a gift is to be divided between an individual and a group, the intention is that the individual receives half.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said to </span>Rav Yosef: <span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, there, </span>in the case of the shewbread, <span class="gemarra-regular">Aaron is eligible to receive a share </span>of the shewbread as a priest; it is <span class="gemarra-regular">for this </span>reason that <span class="gemarra-regular">the Merciful One specified him </span>separately, so <span class="gemarra-regular">that he should take </span>more than other priests, i.e., <span class="gemarra-regular">half. </span>But with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a woman, who is not eligible to inherit </span>her husband’s property, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is sufficient for her to receive </span>a portion of the inheritance <span class="gemarra-regular">as one of the sons, </span>not half of all the property.
The Gemara raises an objection: <span class="gemarra-regular">Is that so? But there was an incident in Neharde’a </span>where a man gave a gift to an individual and to a group of people, <span class="gemarra-regular">and Shmuel collected half </span>the sum for the individual. There was a similar case <span class="gemarra-regular">in Tiberias, and Rabbi Yoḥanan collected half </span>the sum for the individual. <span class="gemarra-regular">And furthermore, when Rav Yitzḥak bar Yosef came </span>from Eretz Yisrael <span class="gemarra-regular">he said: </span>There was <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain coronation tax that was placed by the royal house on the city councilmen [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">a’abulei</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and on the prominent citizens [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ve’a’isterugei</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">said: Let the city councilmen give half and the prominent citizens half. </span>This indicates that when two groups are mentioned together, the intent is that each one represents half.
The Gemara rejects this argument: <span class="gemarra-regular">How can </span>the case concerning the tax <span class="gemarra-regular">be compared </span>to the other cases? <span class="gemarra-regular">There, initially, when they would write </span>the writ of assessment, <span class="gemarra-regular">they would write </span>that it was placed <span class="gemarra-regular">on the city councilme</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> alone. <span class="gemarra-regular">And the prominent citizens would assist them </span>in raising the sum, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the king knew that they were assisting </span>them. Therefore, <span class="gemarra-regular">now, </span>the meaning of <span class="gemarra-regular">what they wrote: </span>It is placed <span class="gemarra-regular">on the city councilmen and on the prominent citizens, is to say that these </span>should give <span class="gemarra-regular">half </span>of the tax, <span class="gemarra-regular">and those </span>should give <span class="gemarra-regular">half.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Zeira raises an objection </span>to Rav Yosef’s ruling from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> (<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span>, <span class="it-text">Menaḥot</span> 12:7): With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who says: It is </span>incumbent <span class="gemarra-regular">upon me </span>to bring <span class="gemarra-regular">a meal-offering </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">one hundred tenths </span>of an ephah <span class="gemarra-regular">in two vessels</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he brings sixty-</span>tenths <span class="gemarra-regular">in one vessel, and </span>the remaining <span class="gemarra-regular">forty-</span>tenths <span class="gemarra-regular">in one vessel, </span>as no more than sixty-tenths may be brought in a single vessel. 

Daf 143b

<span class="gemarra-regular">And if he brought fifty-</span>tenths <span class="gemarra-regular">in one vessel and fifty in one vessel, he fulfilled </span>his obligation. One can infer from the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that after the fact, <span class="gemarra-regular">if he </span>had <span class="gemarra-regular">brought </span>fifty-tenths in each vessel, <span class="gemarra-regular">yes, </span>he fulfilled his obligation, but he may <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>do so <span class="gemarra-italic">ab</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">initio</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. And if it should enter your mind </span>to say that <span class="gemarra-regular">every case like this is </span>divided <span class="gemarra-regular">half and half, </span>it should be permitted to divide the meal-offering into equal halves <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span><span class="gemarra-italic">ab</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">initio</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
The Gemara dismisses Rabbi Zeira’s objection: <span class="gemarra-regular">How can </span>these cases <span class="gemarra-regular">be compared? There, </span>in the case of the meal-offering, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is clear to us that this person initially intended to </span>bring <span class="gemarra-regular">a large offering, and </span>the reason <span class="gemarra-regular">that he said </span>he will bring the offering <span class="gemarra-regular">in two vessels </span>was <span class="gemarra-regular">that he knew that it is not possible to bring </span>the entire offering <span class="gemarra-regular">in a single vessel. </span>Therefore, <span class="gemarra-regular">we bring, </span>in a single vessel, <span class="gemarra-regular">as much as </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">is possible to bring, </span>which is sixty-tenths. In any other case it is possible that the division should be into two equal portions.
The Gemara concludes: <span class="gemarra-regular">And the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav Yose</span><span class="gemarra-regular">f </span> in three matters where he disagreed with Rabba: <span class="gemarra-regular">In </span>the matter of dividing <span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> field </span>between brothers (see 12b); in the matter of whether certain actions are limited by the court session or by the <span class="gemarra-regular">topic </span>of discussion in the court (see 114a); <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>in the matter of <span class="gemarra-regular">half, </span>i.e., this matter, whether an unspecified division into two parts is divided into two equal halves.
§ The Gemara cites additional incidents concerning a gift whose method of division was not specified: There was <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain </span>man <span class="gemarra-regular">who sent swaths of sil</span><span class="gemarra-regular">k</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to his home </span>as a gift. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ami says </span>that in such a case, <span class="gemarra-regular">those </span>swaths that are <span class="gemarra-regular">suitabl</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">sons’ </span>garments are given <span class="gemarra-regular">to the sons, </span>and those that are <span class="gemarra-regular">suitable for </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">daughters’ </span>garments are given <span class="gemarra-regular">to the daughters. </span>The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">We said this only when he does not have daughters-in-law, but if he has daughters-in-law, </span>it is presumed that <span class="gemarra-regular">he sent </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">for his daughters-in-law. And if his daughters are not married, </span>it is presumed that <span class="gemarra-regular">he does not forsake his daughters and send to his daughters-in-law, </span>so the silk is given to his daughters.
There was <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain </span>man <span class="gemarra-regular">who said to </span>those surrounding him: I leave <span class="gemarra-regular">my property to my sons [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">levanai</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and <span class="gemarra-regular">he had </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">a son and a daughter. </span>The question was raised: <span class="gemarra-regular">Do people call </span>a single <span class="gemarra-regular">son </span>in the plural: <span class="gemarra-regular">My sons, and </span>in his will <span class="gemarra-regular">he came to remove his daughter </span>even <span class="gemarra-regular">from</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the tenth </span>of his property that would rightfully be her dowry? <span class="gemarra-regular">Or perhaps people do not call </span>a single <span class="gemarra-regular">son: My sons, and he came to include </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">daughter in the gift?</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said: Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a proof that one does refer to a single son using the plural term sons, as it is written: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And the sons of Dan: Hushim” </span>(Genesis 46:23). <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said to </span>Abaye: <span class="gemarra-regular">Perhaps </span>this verse should be understood <span class="gemarra-regular">as the school of Ḥizkiyya taught, </span>that Hushim is not the name of Dan’s son but <span class="gemarra-regular">that they, </span>Dan’s sons, <span class="gemarra-regular">were as numerous as </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">groups [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ḥushim</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] of reeds. Rather, Rava said: </span>One can prove this usage of the term sons in the verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And the sons of Pallu: Eliab” </span>(Numbers 26:8). <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef said: </span>This can be proven from another verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And the sons of Ethan: Azariah” </span>(I Chronicles 2:8).
There was <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain </span>man <span class="gemarra-regular">who said to </span>those surrounding him: I leave <span class="gemarra-regular">my property to my sons, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">he had a son and a grandson</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., his son’s son. The question was raised: Do <span class="gemarra-regular">people call a grandson a son</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> or </span>do they <span class="gemarra-regular">not? Rav Ḥaviva said: People call a grandson a son. Mar bar Rav Ashi said: People do not call a grandson a son. </span>The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">It is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with</span> the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Mar bar Rav Ashi: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one prohibited by a vow from deriving benefit from </span>a certain person’s <span class="gemarra-regular">sons</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> it is <span class="gemarra-regular">permitted </span>for him to derive benefit <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">sons of </span>that person’s <span class="gemarra-regular">sons, </span>as they are not included in the term sons.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who </span>died and <span class="gemarra-regular">left </span>behind <span class="gemarra-regular">adult and minor </span><span class="gemarra-regular">sons</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> if <span class="gemarra-regular">the adult </span>sons <span class="gemarra-regular">enhanced the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">property</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">they enhanced </span>it so that the profit goes <span class="gemarra-regular">to the middle, </span>i.e., it is distributed among all the heirs. <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>the adult sons <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>from the outset: <span class="gemarra-regular">See that which </span>our <span class="gemarra-regular">father left </span>behind; <span class="gemarra-regular">we are </span>going to <span class="gemarra-regular">engage </span>in business with our share of the property <span class="gemarra-regular">and profit </span>from it, then <span class="gemarra-regular">they enhanced </span>the property <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span><span class="gemarra-regular">themselves</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">And similarly, </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a wife who enhanced the property </span>of her deceased husband, <span class="gemarra-regular">she enhanced </span>it so that the profit goes <span class="gemarra-regular">to the middle, </span>i.e., it is divided between her and the heirs. <span class="gemarra-regular">If she said: See that which my husband left me; I am </span>going to <span class="gemarra-regular">engage </span>in business with my share <span class="gemarra-regular">and profit </span>from it, then <span class="gemarra-regular">she enhanced </span>the property <span class="gemarra-regular">for herself.</span>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥaviva, son of Rav Yosef, son of Rava, says in the name of Rava: They taught </span>this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">where the property was enhanced on account of the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">property</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., the heirs invested money from the common inheritance in order to enhance the property, and their input was only in the management of its investment. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if the <span class="gemarra-regular">property was enhanced on their account, </span>i.e., on account of the efforts or expenditure of the adult sons, the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is that <span class="gemarra-regular">they enhanced </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">for themselves.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Is that so? But doesn’t Rabbi Ḥanina say: Even </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">their father left them nothing but</span>

Daf 144a

<span class="gemarra-regular">a mortar [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">udaini</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> which people pay to use, <span class="gemarra-regular">the rent </span>goes <span class="gemarra-regular">to the middle? But isn’t </span>the profit accruing from <span class="gemarra-regular">a mortar </span>considered profit accruing <span class="gemarra-regular">on his, </span>i.e., the adult son’s, <span class="gemarra-regular">own account, </span>as the adult son must supervise its operation, and there is no outlay from the property? The Gemara dismisses this objection: <span class="gemarra-regular">A mortar is different, as for </span>its <span class="gemarra-regular">typical use </span>it can suffice <span class="gemarra-regular">with supervision</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and even minors are able to supervise its </span>use. Since the adults do not contribute anything more than the minors, they cannot demand a greater share of the profits.
§ The mishna teaches: If the adult sons <span class="gemarra-regular">said</span> from the outset: <span class="gemarra-regular">See that which </span>our <span class="gemarra-regular">father left </span>behind; <span class="gemarra-regular">we are </span>going to <span class="gemarra-regular">engage </span>in business with our share of the property <span class="gemarra-regular">and profit </span>from it, then <span class="gemarra-regular">they enhanced </span>the property <span class="gemarra-regular">for themselves. </span>The Gemara relates: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Safra’s father left </span>him <span class="gemarra-regular">dinars. </span>Rav Safra <span class="gemarra-regular">took them </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">entered </span>into <span class="gemarra-regular">a business venture with them</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> His brothers came </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">charged him in </span>a court of <span class="gemarra-regular">law before Rava, </span>claiming their share of the profits. Rava <span class="gemarra-regular">said to them: Rav Safra is a great man</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he does not abandon his studies and toil for others. </span>It is therefore clear that if he invested the money, it was for his own profit, even if he did not explicitly declare so at the outset.
§ The mishna teaches: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a wife who enhanced the property </span>of her deceased husband, <span class="gemarra-regular">she enhanced </span>it so that the profit goes <span class="gemarra-regular">to the middle. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is </span>the deceased’s <span class="gemarra-regular">wife doing with </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">orphans’ property? </span>What rights does she have to the property? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yirmeya said: </span>The mishna is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to a wife </span>who is <span class="gemarra-regular">an heiress, </span>e.g., if she were the daughter of her husband’s brother, and both brothers died without leaving sons, in which case she inherits in her father’s stead.
The Gemara asks: Isn’t it <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious </span>that the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in this case is the same as with regard to any other heir? The Gemara replies: It is necessary to state this, <span class="gemarra-regular">lest you say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">since it is not </span>a woman’s <span class="gemarra-regular">way to toil </span>to enhance property, then <span class="gemarra-regular">even though she did not expressly state </span>that she is toiling for herself, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is considered as though </span>she <span class="gemarra-regular">had expressly stated </span>this. The mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>that only if she expressly stated this do the profits accrue to her.
The mishna teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">And if she said: See that which my husband left me</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> I am </span>going to <span class="gemarra-regular">engage </span>in business with my share <span class="gemarra-regular">and profit </span>from it, then <span class="gemarra-regular">she enhanced </span>the property <span class="gemarra-regular">for herself. </span>The Gemara asks: Isn’t this <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious? </span>The Gemara explains: It is necessary to state this, <span class="gemarra-regular">lest you say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">since </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">is praiseworthy for her </span>to enhance the property on behalf of the orphans, <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>people will <span class="gemarra-regular">say: </span>See how <span class="gemarra-regular">she toils for the orphans, she relinquishes </span>her right to the profits and they should divide them equally. The mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>that this is not the case.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ḥanina says: </span>In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who marries a woman to his eldest so</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> and arranges the wedding feast <span class="gemarra-regular">in a house </span>that he designated for the purpose of the wedding canopy and the wedding feast, the son <span class="gemarra-regular">acquires </span>the house as a gift. The Gemara notes: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>this is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">specifically </span>in the case of the <span class="gemarra-regular">eldest</span> son, <span class="gemarra-regular">and specifically </span>if he is marrying <span class="gemarra-regular">a virgin, and specifically </span>when this woman is <span class="gemarra-regular">his first wife, and specifically when </span>the father <span class="gemarra-regular">married him off first </span>among his sons. When all these conditions exist, it is presumed that the father has a particular fondness toward the son, due to which he gave him the house.
The Gemara clarifies the details of this <span class="it-text">halakha</span>: It is <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious </span>that if <span class="gemarra-regular">his father designated a house for</span> the son’s nuptials <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>there is <span class="gemarra-regular">an upper story </span>above the house, the son <span class="gemarra-regular">acquired the house, </span>but <span class="gemarra-regular">he did not acquire the upper story. </span>If he designated <span class="gemarra-regular">a house </span>for the son, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>there is <span class="gemarra-regular">a portico [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ve’akhsadra</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> in front of the house, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? If there were <span class="gemarra-regular">two houses, one within the other</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and the inner one was designated for the son’s nuptials, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? The Gemara concludes: These questions <span class="gemarra-regular">shall stand </span>unresolved.
The Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises an objection </span>from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: If <span class="gemarra-regular">his father designated a house and furnitur</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for his </span>son’s nuptials, the son <span class="gemarra-regular">acquired the furniture, </span>but <span class="gemarra-regular">he did not acquire the house. Rabbi Yirmeya says: </span>This is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where his father’s storeroom was placed there. </span>It is clear that just as his father did not intend to give him the storeroom, neither did he intend to give him the house. The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">of Neharde’a say: Even </span>if there is only <span class="gemarra-regular">a dovecot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> in the house that belongs to the father, the son does not acquire the house. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda and Rav Pappi say: Even </span>if there is only <span class="gemarra-regular">a pot [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">atzitza</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of </span>small <span class="gemarra-regular">fried fish</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the son does not acquire the house. <span class="gemarra-regular">Mar Zutra married off his son, and hung a sandal </span>in the house, to indicate that he did not intend to give the house as a gift. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi married off his son, and hung a jug [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ashisha</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of oil </span>in the house.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Mar Zutra says: These three matters were instituted by the Sages as a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> without any explanation </span>of their process, i.e., they instituted these enactments despite the fact that the mechanism by which they function is unclear: <span class="gemarra-regular">One </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span><span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to the son acquiring the house designated for his nuptials. <span class="gemarra-regular">Another </span>is that <span class="gemarra-regular">which Rav Yehuda says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel says: One who writes </span>a deed granting <span class="gemarra-regular">all </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">his property to his wif</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> renders her only a steward </span>of his property, i.e., he intends only to put her in charge of the property and she does not acquire it. <span class="gemarra-regular">Another </span>is that <span class="gemarra-regular">which Rav says: </span>With regard to one who says to another: <span class="gemarra-regular">I </span>have <span class="gemarra-regular">one hundred dinars in your possession; give it to so-and-so, </span>if this occurred <span class="gemarra-regular">in the presence of </span>all <span class="gemarra-regular">three </span>parties, that third person <span class="gemarra-regular">acquires </span>it, without need of witnesses or a formal act of acquisition. 

Daf 144b

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">brothers who were </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">partners, </span>and it occurred <span class="gemarra-regular">that one of them was summoned to </span>public <span class="gemarra-regular">service</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> which is assessed per family, <span class="gemarra-regular">he was summoned from the middle, </span>i.e., the profits or expenses of his service are divided among them. If one of the brothers <span class="gemarra-regular">became sick and sought treatment, the </span>cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">treatment is </span>paid <span class="gemarra-regular">from his own </span>resources.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">taught: This service </span>mentioned in the mishna is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>forced <span class="gemarra-regular">imperial service, </span>but if one of the brothers engaged in a trade of his own volition, the profits are his alone. <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> (<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span> 10:5): In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one of the brothers who was appointed </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">a tax </span><span class="gemarra-regular">collecto</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">or a military commander [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">polmustos</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> a position with the potential for profit, <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>he was appointed <span class="gemarra-regular">on account of </span>all <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">brothers</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as the procedure was to impress a representative from each family for this purpose, any profit accrues <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>all <span class="gemarra-regular">t</span><span class="gemarra-regular">he brothers. If </span>he was appointed <span class="gemarra-regular">on account of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">himself</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the profit accrues <span class="gemarra-regular">to himself.</span>
The Gemara asks: Isn’t it <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>he was appointed <span class="gemarra-regular">on account of </span>all <span class="gemarra-regular">the brothers, </span>then the profit accrues <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>all <span class="gemarra-regular">the brothers? </span>The Gemara responds: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>to state this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the brother appointed was <span class="gemarra-regular">sharper, </span>i.e., more capable, than the other brothers. <span class="gemarra-regular">Lest you say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">his sharpness caused him </span>to be selected for the position, and he should receive all the profits, the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>that his talent notwithstanding, since he was selected as a representative of the family, the profit accrues to all the brothers.
<span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one of the brothers, who took two hundred dinar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> from the common inheritance to support himself when he went to another place <span class="gemarra-regular">to study Tora</span><span class="gemarra-regular">h</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> or to learn a trade, the brothers can say to him: If you are </span>here <span class="gemarra-regular">with us, you are entitled to sustenance </span>along with us. <span class="gemarra-regular">If you are not </span>here <span class="gemarra-regular">with us, you are not entitled to sustenance.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> shouldn’t they give him </span>his sustenance <span class="gemarra-regular">wherever he is? </span>The Gemara answers: This ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">supports </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav Huna, as Rav Huna says: The blessing of the house </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">in its abundance. </span>This means that the extent to which blessing permeates a home is proportionate to the number of people who live there, and when many people live together the expenses per capita decrease. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But shouldn’t they give him </span>his sustenance <span class="gemarra-regular">according to the blessing of the house, </span>i.e., the expenses he would incur even if he were in the house? The Gemara responds: <span class="gemarra-regular">Indeed, </span>they are required to provide for those expenses that he would incur in any event.
§ The mishna teaches: If one of the brothers <span class="gemarra-regular">became sick and sought treatment</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the </span>cost of the <span class="gemarra-regular">treatment is </span>paid <span class="gemarra-regular">from his own </span>resources. <span class="gemarra-regular">Ravin sent </span>a ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">in the name of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rabbi Ela: They taught </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he became ill through negligence. But </span>if he became ill <span class="gemarra-regular">through circumstances beyond his control, </span>the cost of <span class="gemarra-regular">the treatment is </span>paid <span class="gemarra-regular">from the middle</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., from the common inheritance. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What are</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the circumstances in </span>which it is considered <span class="gemarra-regular">negligence? </span>This is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Ḥanina, as Rabbi Ḥanina says: All </span>occurrences that befall man <span class="gemarra-regular">are in the hand of Heave</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> except for colds </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">obstacles [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">paḥim</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> from which one is able to protect himself, <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">is stated: “Colds and snares are on the path of the crooked; he who guards his soul shall keep far from them” </span>(Proverbs 22:5).
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> It was common practice for friends of a groom to give him gifts in order to help cover the expenses of the wedding feast. These gifts are known as gifts of groomsmen, and would be reciprocated in turn. While the groom and the groomsman were at times the recipient and the giver of the gifts, respectively, the gifts were at times provided by the father of the groomsman and received by the father of the groom. In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">brothers, some of whom brought gifts of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">groomsme</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">in their father’s lifetime, </span>which were provided by their father, when <span class="gemarra-regular">the gifts of groomsmen are reciprocated </span>after the father’s death, when one of the brothers gets married, <span class="gemarra-regular">they are reciprocated to the middle, </span>i.e., the gift is divided among the brothers. This is <span class="gemarra-regular">because gifts of groomsmen </span><span class="gemarra-regular">are </span>a legal debt owed to the father, <span class="gemarra-regular">collectible in </span><span class="gemarra-regular">court</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who sends his friend jugs of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">win</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">or jugs of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">oil</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> a reciprocal gift <span class="gemarra-regular">is not collectible in court, because they are </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">acts of kindness.</span>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">And</span> the Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises a contradiction </span>between the mishna’s ruling that the gifts of groomsmen are reciprocated to the middle, and the first clause of a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: If <span class="gemarra-regular">a father sent </span>his son with <span class="gemarra-regular">gifts of groomsmen, when they are reciprocated </span>when that son gets married, <span class="gemarra-regular">they are reciprocated to </span>that son. If <span class="gemarra-regular">his father was </span><span class="gemarra-regular">sen</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">gifts of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">groomsme</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> for the wedding of one of his sons, <span class="gemarra-regular">when they are reciprocated </span>from the father’s estate, <span class="gemarra-regular">they are reciprocated from the middle, </span>i.e., the cost of the gift is divided among the brothers. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Asi says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: When we learned the mishna as well, we learned </span>it as teaching the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to gifts of groomsmen that <span class="gemarra-regular">were sent to </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">father </span>for the wedding of one of his sons, not with regard to gifts of groomsmen sent by the father.
The Gemara objects: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">brothers, some of whom brought gifts of groomsmen. </span>The Gemara responds: Emend the text of the mishna and <span class="gemarra-regular">teach </span>it as saying: With regard to brothers, <span class="gemarra-regular">to some of whom </span>gifts of groomsmen were brought. The Gemara objects: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>the mishna explicitly <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> if <span class="gemarra-regular">the gifts of groomsmen are reciprocated. </span>The Gemara responds: <span class="gemarra-regular">This is </span>what the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">saying: When it is collected </span>from the brothers <span class="gemarra-regular">in return, it is collected from </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">middle.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Asi says: </span>Even if the text of the mishna is not emended, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult </span>and can be reconciled with the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">Here </span>in the mishna it is referring to where the father sent the gifts of groomsmen <span class="gemarra-regular">without specifyin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span> which son should be ascribed credit for bringing the gifts. <span class="gemarra-regular">There </span>in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, it is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the father <span class="gemarra-regular">specified </span>that the credit for the gifts of groomsmen should be ascribed to a specific son, who receives gifts in return, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is taught </span>in another <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: If <span class="gemarra-regular">his father sent gifts of groomsmen on his, </span>i.e., the son’s, behalf, then <span class="gemarra-regular">when </span>the gift <span class="gemarra-regular">is reciprocated, it is reciprocated to him, </span>i.e., to that specific son. If <span class="gemarra-regular">his father sent gifts of groomsmen without specification, </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">when </span>the gift <span class="gemarra-regular">is reciprocated, it is reciprocated to the middle.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Shmuel says: Here </span>in the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">we are dealing with a man </span><span class="gemarra-regular">whose married brother died childless [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">yavam</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> The son who brought the gifts of groomsmen died childless, his brother entered into levirate marriage with the widow, and the gifts of groomsmen were reciprocated at the wedding of the <span class="it-text">yavam</span>. Although the <span class="it-text">yavam</span> inherits the property of his brother, since the reciprocal gifts were not extant when his brother died, they do not belong solely to him; rather, they are divided among the brothers. This is because the <span class="it-text">yavam</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">does not take </span>in inheritance the property <span class="gemarra-regular">due </span>the deceased <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>he does the property the deceased already <span class="gemarra-regular">possessed.</span>
The Gemara asks: Is it possible to conclude <span class="gemarra-regular">by inference </span>from Shmuel’s statement <span class="gemarra-regular">that the other </span>side, i.e., a friend who had received gifts of groomsmen from the deceased, is obligated to <span class="gemarra-regular">repay </span>the gifts of groomsmen he received from the deceased? Why should this be so? <span class="gemarra-regular">Let him say: Give me my groomsma</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and I will rejoice with him. </span>Since the one who gave him the gifts is deceased, he is not obligated to reciprocate.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Isn’t it taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> (<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span>, <span class="it-text">Pesaḥim</span> 3:1) with regard to similar circumstances: In <span class="gemarra-regular">a place where </span>people <span class="gemarra-regular">are accustomed to return the betrothal </span>money when the betrothed man or woman dies, <span class="gemarra-regular">they return </span>it; in <span class="gemarra-regular">a place where </span>people <span class="gemarra-regular">are accustomed not to return </span>it, <span class="gemarra-regular">they do not return </span>it. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav Yosef bar Abba says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Mar Ukva says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel says: They taught </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">when </span>the woman <span class="gemarra-regular">dies, </span>in which case one follows the local custom. <span class="gemarra-regular">But if </span>the man <span class="gemarra-regular">dies, </span>all agree that <span class="gemarra-regular">they do not return </span>the money. <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>for this? Since <span class="gemarra-regular">she can say: </span>

Daf 145a

<span class="gemarra-regular">Give me my husband and I will rejoice with him, </span>i.e., it is not my fault that we are not getting married, she is not required to return the betrothal money. <span class="gemarra-regular">Here too, let him say: Give me my groomsman and I will rejoice with him</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef said: With what are we dealing here? </span>Shmuel’s statement is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the original recipient, in reciprocation, <span class="gemarra-regular">rejoiced with </span>the brother who brought the gifts of groomsmen during the <span class="gemarra-regular">seven days of </span>the wedding <span class="gemarra-regular">feast, but did not suffice to repay him before </span>the brother <span class="gemarra-regular">died. </span>Since it was the usual practice to send the gifts of groomsmen after the groomsman rejoiced with the betrothed man for seven days, he is obligated to reciprocate the gifts of groomsmen, and the <span class="it-text">yavam</span> cannot claim them for himself.
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Shall we say </span>that Shmuel’s statement that a betrothed woman can claim: <span class="gemarra-regular">Give me my husband and I will rejoice with him, is</span> a dispute between <span class="gemarra-italic">tanna’im</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who betrothed a woma</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> and then he divorces her or dies, if she is <span class="gemarra-regular">a virgin, </span>she <span class="gemarra-regular">collects two hundred </span>dinars in payment of her marriage contract. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>if she is <span class="gemarra-regular">a widow, </span>she collects <span class="gemarra-regular">one hundred dinars. </span>In <span class="gemarra-regular">a place where </span>people <span class="gemarra-regular">were accustomed to return the betrothal </span>money when the betrothed man or woman died, <span class="gemarra-regular">they return </span>it. In <span class="gemarra-regular">a place where </span>people <span class="gemarra-regular">were accustomed not to return the betrothal </span>money, <span class="gemarra-regular">they do not return </span>it. This is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of Rabbi Natan. Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi says: Actually they said: </span>In <span class="gemarra-regular">a place where </span>people <span class="gemarra-regular">were accustomed to return </span>it, <span class="gemarra-regular">they return </span>it; in <span class="gemarra-regular">a place where </span>people <span class="gemarra-regular">were accustomed not to return </span>it, <span class="gemarra-regular">they do not return </span>it.
The Gemara clarifies: The opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi is </span>identical to the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the first </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>i.e., Rabbi Natan. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, is it not </span>that the difference <span class="gemarra-regular">between them </span>concerns the validity of the claim: <span class="gemarra-regular">Give me my husband and I will rejoice with him?</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the statement in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is incomplete and this </span>is what <span class="gemarra-regular">it is teaching: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who betrothed a woman </span>and then the betrothal is terminated, if she is <span class="gemarra-regular">a virgin, </span>she <span class="gemarra-regular">collects two hundred </span>dinars in payment of her marriage contract, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>if she is <span class="gemarra-regular">a widow, </span>she collects <span class="gemarra-regular">one hundred dinars. In what </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">is this statement said? </span>It is said <span class="gemarra-regular">where he retracted, </span>i.e., he died or divorced her. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>with regard to where <span class="gemarra-regular">she died, </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is as follows: In <span class="gemarra-regular">a place where </span>people <span class="gemarra-regular">were accustomed to return </span>the betrothal money, <span class="gemarra-regular">they return </span>it; in <span class="gemarra-regular">a place where </span>people <span class="gemarra-regular">were accustomed not to return </span>the betrothal money, <span class="gemarra-regular">they do not return </span>it. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>this applies <span class="gemarra-regular">specifically </span>to <span class="gemarra-regular">where she died; but </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">he died, they do not return </span>it. <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>for this? It is because <span class="gemarra-regular">she can say: Give me my husband and I will rejoice with him. </span>This is the statement of Rabbi Natan.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi came to say: Actually they said: Whether he died or whether she died, </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">a place where </span>people <span class="gemarra-regular">were accustomed to return </span>it, <span class="gemarra-regular">they return </span>it; in <span class="gemarra-regular">a place where </span>people <span class="gemarra-regular">were accustomed not to return </span>it, <span class="gemarra-regular">they do not return </span>it, <span class="gemarra-regular">and she cannot say: Give me my husband and I will rejoice with him.</span>
The Gemara rejects this explanation: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, everyone </span>agrees that <span class="gemarra-regular">she can say: Give me my husband and I will rejoice with him, and </span>in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he died, everyone agrees </span>that she does not have to return the betrothal money. <span class="gemarra-regular">They disagree </span>in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where she died, and here </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>the question of whether <span class="gemarra-regular">betrothal </span>money <span class="gemarra-regular">is given as a sunk </span>cost, i.e., that it is not returned even if the betrothal is not consummated, that <span class="gemarra-regular">they disagree. Rabbi Natan holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">betrothal </span>money <span class="gemarra-regular">is not given as a sunk </span>cost, and in a place where people were accustomed to return it, they return it. <span class="gemarra-regular">And</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">betrothal </span>money <span class="gemarra-regular">is given as a sunk </span>cost.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But doesn’t </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">teach </span>that according to Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi, in <span class="gemarra-regular">a place where </span>people <span class="gemarra-regular">were accustomed to return </span>it, <span class="gemarra-regular">they return </span>it? This indicates that Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi does not hold that the betrothal money was given as a sunk cost. The Gemara replies: This is not referring to the betrothal money, which is not returned in any event. <span class="gemarra-regular">This is </span>what the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is saying: But </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">presents, </span>which the betrothed man sent his betrothed following the betrothal, <span class="gemarra-regular">certainly </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">a place where </span>people <span class="gemarra-regular">were accustomed to return </span>them, <span class="gemarra-regular">they return </span>them.
The Gemara notes: The dispute between <span class="gemarra-regular">these </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna’im</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>in the following <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">is like </span>the dispute between <span class="gemarra-regular">those </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna’im</span> just mentioned, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: In a case where the man <span class="gemarra-regular">betrothed </span>a woman <span class="gemarra-regular">with a talent </span>of silver, equivalent to six thousand dinars, if she was <span class="gemarra-regular">a virgin </span>she <span class="gemarra-regular">collects </span>in payment of her marriage contract <span class="gemarra-regular">two hundred </span>dinars over and above this amount, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>if she was <span class="gemarra-regular">a widow </span>she collects <span class="gemarra-regular">one hundred dinars </span>over and above this amount. This is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Yehuda says: A virgin collects two hundred </span>dinars <span class="gemarra-regular">and a widow one hundred dinars, and she returns the rest </span>of the betrothal money <span class="gemarra-regular">to him. Rabbi Yosei says: </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">he betrothed her with twenty, he gives her thirty halves; </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">he betrothed her with thirty, he gives her twenty halves, </span>as the Gemara will explain.
The Gemara clarifies the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">With what are we dealing? If we say </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">when she died, is she entitled </span>to receive payment of her <span class="gemarra-regular">marriage contract</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rather, </span>perhaps the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">where he died, </span>in which case <span class="gemarra-regular">why </span>does Rabbi Yehuda state that <span class="gemarra-regular">she returns the rest </span>of the betrothal money <span class="gemarra-regular">to him? Let her say: Give me my husband and I will rejoice with him. Rather, </span>perhaps the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is referring to the case <span class="gemarra-regular">of the wife, </span>i.e., the betrothed, <span class="gemarra-regular">of an Israelite, who committed adultery, </span>who cannot claim that she is available to marry her betrothed, as it is prohibited for her to engage in intercourse with him. The Gemara challenges: This is also difficult, as <span class="gemarra-regular">with what </span>circumstance is the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> dealing? <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>it is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>she committed adultery <span class="gemarra-regular">willingly, is she entitled </span>to receive payment of her <span class="gemarra-regular">marriage contract</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rather, </span>it is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">rape. </span>But in that case, she <span class="gemarra-regular">is permitted to him</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Why should she return the betrothal money?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to the wife, </span>i.e., the betrothed, <span class="gemarra-regular">of a priest, who was rape</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> and is prohibited from engaging in intercourse with her betrothed. She therefore cannot claim: Give me my husband and I will rejoice with him, yet she is entitled to receive payment of her marriage contract, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna’im</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">disagree with regard to </span>whether <span class="gemarra-regular">betrothal </span>money <span class="gemarra-regular">is given as a sunk </span>cost: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir holds that betrothal </span>money <span class="gemarra-regular">is given as a sunk </span>cost. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda holds </span>that it <span class="gemarra-regular">is not given as a sunk </span>cost. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Yosei is uncertain if </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">is given as a sunk </span>cost <span class="gemarra-regular">or not.</span>
The Gemara explains Rabbi Yosei’s opinion: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>since it is uncertain whether or not she is required to return the betrothal money, <span class="gemarra-regular">therefore, </span>she returns only half the money: If <span class="gemarra-regular">he betrothed her with twent</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span> <span class="it-text">sela</span>, which are equivalent to eighty dinars, she owes him forty dinars. Yet, if she is widowed or divorced, she is entitled to one hundred dinars in payment of her marriage contract, so he or his estate <span class="gemarra-regular">gives her thirty halves </span>of a <span class="it-text">sela</span>, which are equivalent to sixty dinars, so that she receives one hundred dinars in all. If <span class="gemarra-regular">he betrothed her with thirty </span><span class="it-text">sela</span>, which are equivalent to one hundred twenty dinars, she owes him sixty dinars. Since she is entitled to one hundred dinars in payment of her marriage contract, he <span class="gemarra-regular">gives her twenty halves </span>of a <span class="it-text">sela</span>, equivalent to forty dinars.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef bar Minyumi says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman says: In every place where they were accustomed to return </span>the betrothal money, <span class="gemarra-regular">they return </span>it. <span class="gemarra-regular">And the interpretation </span>of this statement is that it is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">Neharde’a. </span>The Gemara asks: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">the rest of Babylonia, what </span>is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba and Rav Yosef both say: </span>The <span class="gemarra-regular">presents are returned </span>and the <span class="gemarra-regular">betrothal </span>money <span class="gemarra-regular">is not returned. Rav Pappa said: The </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is that <span class="gemarra-regular">whether he died </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">whether she died or </span>whether <span class="gemarra-regular">he retracted </span>his agreement to the betrothal and divorced her, the <span class="gemarra-regular">presents are returne</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> and the <span class="gemarra-regular">betrothal </span>money <span class="gemarra-regular">is not returned. </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">she retracted </span>her agreement to the betrothal and requested a divorce, <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">betrothal </span>money <span class="gemarra-regular">is returned.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Ameimar said: </span>The <span class="gemarra-regular">betrothal </span>money <span class="gemarra-regular">is not returned</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> This is a rabbinic <span class="gemarra-regular">decree, lest </span>people <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">betrothal</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> takes effect with her sister. </span>If the betrothal money is returned, people are likely to think that the betrothal is retroactively nullified and that the man can betroth her sister, whereas in fact the betrothal was not retroactively nullified and he cannot betroth her. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi said: Her bill of divorce proves for her </span>that she was betrothed, so this concern is not in effect. The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">And this </span>statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav Ashi is a mistake, since there are </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">who heard about this, </span>i.e., the return of the betrothal money, <span class="gemarra-regular">but did not hear about that, </span>i.e., the bill of divorce.
§ The mishna teaches: If the gifts of groomsmen are reciprocated after the father’s death, they are reciprocated to the middle, <span class="gemarra-regular">because gifts of groomsmen</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> are </span>a legal debt owed to the father, <span class="gemarra-regular">collectible in court. The Sages taught </span>(<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span> 10:8): <span class="gemarra-regular">Five statements were said with regard to gifts of groomsmen: </span>They are <span class="gemarra-regular">collectible in court; and </span>they are <span class="gemarra-regular">reciprocated </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">at their </span>relevant <span class="gemarra-regular">time</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., at the time of the groomsman’s own wedding; <span class="gemarra-regular">and they are not subject to</span> the prohibition of <span class="gemarra-regular">interest, </span>i.e., it is permitted to reciprocate with a gift of greater value than the original gift; 

Daf 145b

<span class="gemarra-regular">and the Sabbatical </span>Year <span class="gemarra-regular">does not abrogate them</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and the firstborn does not take a double </span>portion <span class="gemarra-regular">of them.</span>
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> states that gifts of groomsmen <span class="gemarra-regular">are collectible in court. What is the reason </span>for this? It is that they are considered <span class="gemarra-regular">similar to a loan.</span> The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> states: <span class="gemarra-regular">And they are not subject to </span>the prohibition of <span class="gemarra-regular">interest. </span>The reason is <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>it was <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>with <span class="gemarra-regular">that in mind </span>that he gave him a larger gift. Rather, he did so on account of his joy at his friend’s wedding. The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> states: <span class="gemarra-regular">And the Sabbatical </span>Year <span class="gemarra-regular">does not abrogate them. </span>The reason is <span class="gemarra-regular">that one cannot read </span>the verse concerning the abrogation of debts during the occurrence of the Sabbatical Year: <span class="gemarra-regular">“He shall not exact </span>it of his neighbor and his brother, because the Lord’s release has been proclaimed” (Deuteronomy 15:2), <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>gifts of groomsmen. Since one cannot choose to exact the gifts until the time of one’s own wedding, they are not addressed by this verse.
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> states: <span class="gemarra-regular">And the firstborn does not take a double </span>portion from them. The reason is <span class="gemarra-regular">that they constitute potential </span>inheritance, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the firstborn does not take</span> in inheritance the property <span class="gemarra-regular">due </span>the deceased <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>he does the property the deceased <span class="gemarra-regular">possessed.</span>
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Kahana said: The principle with regard to </span>the reciprocation of <span class="gemarra-regular">gifts of groomsme</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> is: If the recipient <span class="gemarra-regular">was in town </span>when his groomsman wed, <span class="gemarra-regular">he should have come </span>to the wedding, and even if he did not come, he is obligated to send the gifts of groomsmen. If he was not in town, but <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span>was nearby and he <span class="gemarra-regular">heard the sound of the dru</span><span class="gemarra-regular">m</span> announcing the wedding, <span class="gemarra-regular">he should have come. </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span>was far away and <span class="gemarra-regular">did not hear the sound of the drum, </span>the betrothed man <span class="gemarra-regular">should have informed him. </span>If he did not inform him, the recipient <span class="gemarra-regular">has a grievance </span>against the betrothed man because he did not inform him about the wedding, but <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span>still <span class="gemarra-regular">repays </span>the gifts of groomsmen.
In this case, since he did not partake of the wedding feast, he is entitled to deduct a sum from the reciprocal gift. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And up to how much </span>can he deduct? <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said</span><span class="gemarra-regular">:</span> The <span class="gemarra-regular">members of a wedding </span>feast <span class="gemarra-regular">were accustomed </span>to deduct according to the following principle: If the gift of groomsmen that the reciprocal giver received was <span class="gemarra-regular">up to a dinar, </span>he now pays nothing, because what a person <span class="gemarra-regular">brings in his hand he consumes in his stomach. </span>If the gift of groomsmen was <span class="gemarra-regular">up to four </span>dinars, he now <span class="gemarra-regular">pays half</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> From that </span>sum <span class="gemarra-regular">onward, each person </span>deducts <span class="gemarra-regular">according to his prominence, </span>i.e., in accordance with the outlay that would have been required to honor the reciprocal giver properly, had he participated in the wedding feast.
