<span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>(<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span> 10:9): If one <span class="gemarra-regular">served </span>as groomsman <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>his friend <span class="gemarra-regular">at a public [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">pumbei</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> wedding, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>when the groomsman himself wed, he <span class="gemarra-regular">requested </span>that his friend reciprocate <span class="gemarra-regular">by serving </span>as a groomsman <span class="gemarra-regular">for him at a private </span>wedding, the friend <span class="gemarra-regular">can say to him: I </span>am willing to reciprocate and <span class="gemarra-regular">serve </span>as groomsman <span class="gemarra-regular">for you </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">at a public </span>wedding, where the rejoicing is greater, <span class="gemarra-regular">in the manner you served </span>as a groomsman <span class="gemarra-regular">for me. </span>If one <span class="gemarra-regular">served </span>as a groomsman <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>his friend <span class="gemarra-regular">when </span>he married <span class="gemarra-regular">a virgin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">requested </span>that his friend reciprocate <span class="gemarra-regular">by serving </span>as a groomsman <span class="gemarra-regular">for him when</span> he marries <span class="gemarra-regular">a widow, </span>the friend <span class="gemarra-regular">can say to him: I shall serve </span>as a groomsman <span class="gemarra-regular">for you </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">when </span>you marry <span class="gemarra-regular">a virgin, in the manner you served </span>as a groomsman <span class="gemarra-regular">for me.</span>
If one <span class="gemarra-regular">served </span>as a groomsman <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>his friend <span class="gemarra-regular">when </span>he married <span class="gemarra-regular">a second </span>wife, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">requested </span>that his friend reciprocate <span class="gemarra-regular">by serving </span>as a groomsman <span class="gemarra-regular">for him when </span>he marries <span class="gemarra-regular">a first </span>wife, the friend <span class="gemarra-regular">can say to him: When you marry another woman I will serve </span>as a groomsman <span class="gemarra-regular">for you. </span>If one <span class="gemarra-regular">served </span>as a groomsman <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>his friend <span class="gemarra-regular">when </span>he married <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>woman, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">requested </span>that his friend reciprocate <span class="gemarra-regular">by serving </span>as a groomsman <span class="gemarra-regular">for him when </span>he marries <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>women, the friend <span class="gemarra-regular">can say to him: I will serve </span>as a groomsman <span class="gemarra-regular">for you when </span>you marry <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>woman, <span class="gemarra-regular">in the manner you served </span>as a groomsman <span class="gemarra-regular">for me.</span>
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: There are different types of Torah scholars. There is a scholar who is <span class="gemarra-regular">wealthy </span>in figurative <span class="gemarra-regular">property </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">wealthy </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">public </span>renown; <span class="gemarra-regular">this is the master of homiletics</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> There is a scholar who is <span class="gemarra-regular">wealthy </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">coins </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">wealthy </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">houses; this is the master of dialectics</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> There is one who is <span class="gemarra-regular">wealthy </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">oil </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">wealthy </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">hidden </span>stores; <span class="gemarra-regular">this is the master of </span>halakhic <span class="gemarra-regular">traditions</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Everyone is dependent on the owner of wheat; </span>this is the master of <span class="gemarra-regular">Talmud</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> who understands the reasons behind the rulings and traditions.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Zeira says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: What </span>is the meaning of that <span class="gemarra-regular">which </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is written: “All the days of the poor are terrible; </span>and for the good-hearted it is always a feast” (Proverbs 15:15)? “All the days of the poor are terrible”; <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>is referring to the <span class="gemarra-regular">master of Talmud, </span>who is wearied by the difficulty of his Talmud study. <span class="gemarra-regular">“And for the good-hearted it is always a feast”</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> this </span>is referring to the <span class="gemarra-regular">master of Mishna, </span>who recites the <span class="it-text">mishnayot</span> by rote and is not wearied thereby.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava says: The opposite </span>is true. <span class="gemarra-regular">And this is </span>consistent with that <span class="gemarra-regular">which Rav Mesharshiyya says in the name of Rava: What is </span>the meaning of that <span class="gemarra-regular">which is written: “He who quarries stones shall be hurt by them; and he that chops wood shall be warmed thereby” </span>(Ecclesiastes 10:9). <span class="gemarra-regular">“He who quarries stones shall be hurt by them”; these are the masters of Mishna. </span>They exert themselves to memorize the <span class="it-text">mishnayot</span>, but since one cannot reach practical conclusions from the mishna, they are comparable to one who carries a heavy load without benefiting from it. <span class="gemarra-regular">“He that chops wood shall be warmed thereby”; these are the masters of Talmud, </span>who attain the benefit of their exertions in the form of practical conclusions.
The Gemara cites other interpretations of this verse. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ḥanina says: “All the days of the poor are terrible”; this </span>is referring to one <span class="gemarra-regular">who has a wicked wife. “And for the good-hearted it is always a feast”; this </span>is referring to one <span class="gemarra-regular">who has a good wife. Rabbi Yannai says: “All the days of the poor are terrible”; this </span>is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who is delicate [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">istenis</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> and overly sensitive, because he constantly encounters unpleasant situations. <span class="gemarra-regular">“And for the good-hearted it is always a feast”; this </span>is referring to one <span class="gemarra-regular">who is relaxed </span>and not particular with regard to his food or his surroundings.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: “All the days of the poor are terrible”; this </span>is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">an empathetic person, </span>because he is constantly affected by the suffering in the world. <span class="gemarra-regular">“And for the good-hearted it is always a feast”; this </span>is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">a cruel person, </span>who is not pained by the suffering of others. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi says: “All the days of the poor are terrible”; this </span>is referring to a person <span class="gemarra-regular">of impatient disposition.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> “And for the good-hearted it is always a feast”; this </span>is referring to a person <span class="gemarra-regular">of patient disposition. </span>

Daf 146a

<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi says: </span>Is it so that <span class="gemarra-regular">all the days of the poor are terrible? But aren’t there </span><span class="gemarra-italic">Shabbatot</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and Festivals, </span>when even the poor enjoy their meals and rest? Rather, explain this <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Shmuel, as Shmuel says: A change of regimen [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">veset</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> causes <span class="gemarra-regular">the onset of </span>intestinal <span class="gemarra-regular">disease, </span>and as a result the poor suffer even from a change for the good.
It <span class="gemarra-regular">is written in the book of ben Sira</span><span class="gemarra-regular">:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> All the days of the poor are terrible. Ben Sira says: The nights </span><span class="gemarra-regular">as well. His roof is at the lowest point of the roofs; the rain of roofs go onto his roof. His vineyard is at the height of the mountains; the soil of his vineyard goes onto other vineyards.</span>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who sends presents [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">sivlonot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">to his father-in-law’s </span><span class="gemarra-regular">hous</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> following his betrothal, even if <span class="gemarra-regular">he sent there </span>the sum of <span class="gemarra-regular">ten thousand dinars and </span>subsequently <span class="gemarra-regular">ate there a groom’s feast even </span>worth the value <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span>a single <span class="gemarra-regular">dinar, </span>if for any reason the marriage is not effected, the presents <span class="gemarra-regular">are not collected </span>in return by the formerly betrothed man. If he <span class="gemarra-regular">did not eat a groom’s feast there, </span>the presents <span class="gemarra-regular">are collected, </span>as they were not an unconditional gift. If he <span class="gemarra-regular">sent many </span><span class="gemarra-regular">present</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> with the stipulation <span class="gemarra-regular">that they return with her to her husband’s house, </span>i.e., to his own house, after the wedding, <span class="gemarra-regular">these are collected </span>if the marriage is not effected. If he sent <span class="gemarra-regular">a few presents for her to use while in her father’s house, they are not collected.</span>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna states that if the betrothed man ate food worth even a single dinar at his father-in-law’s house, the presents are not returned. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava says: </span>This applies <span class="gemarra-regular">specifically </span>to the value of <span class="gemarra-regular">a dinar, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>if he ate food worth <span class="gemarra-regular">less than </span>the value of <span class="gemarra-regular">a dinar, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>so. The Gemara asks: Isn’t that <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious, </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">we learned </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in the mishna with reference to the value of <span class="gemarra-regular">a dinar? </span>The Gemara answers: It is stated <span class="gemarra-regular">lest you say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the same is true even </span>in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">less than a dinar, and </span>the reason <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with reference to <span class="gemarra-regular">a dinar </span>is that it <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches the matter in the manner in which it </span>typically occurs, and one does not usually eat less than that. Rava therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>that the formulation of the mishna is precise; the mishna is not referring to the value of less than a dinar.
§ The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">We learned </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in the mishna with regard to a betrothed man who <span class="gemarra-regular">ate </span>at his father-in-law’s house. <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> if <span class="gemarra-regular">he drank </span>there? <span class="gemarra-regular">We learned </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in the mishna with regard to a case where <span class="gemarra-regular">he, </span>the betrothed, ate there. <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> if <span class="gemarra-regular">his agent </span>ate there? <span class="gemarra-regular">We learned </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in the mishna with regard to a case where the betrothed man ate <span class="gemarra-regular">there, </span>at his father-in-law’s house. <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> if his father-in-law <span class="gemarra-regular">sent him </span>a feast to his home?
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a proof concerning one these matters, <span class="gemarra-regular">as Rav Yehuda says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel says: </span>There was <span class="gemarra-regular">an incident involving one man who sent to his father-in-law’s house one hundred wagons </span>full <span class="gemarra-regular">of jars of wine and of jars of oil, and </span>one hundred wagons full <span class="gemarra-regular">of silver vessels, and </span>one hundred wagons full <span class="gemarra-regular">of gold vessels, and </span>one hundred wagons full <span class="gemarra-regular">of garments of fine wool [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">milat</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> And he rode </span>over <span class="gemarra-regular">in his </span>state of <span class="gemarra-regular">joy and went and stood by the entrance to his father-in-law’s house. And they brought out </span>to him <span class="gemarra-regular">a cup of hot </span>drink <span class="gemarra-regular">and he drank </span>it, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he </span>subsequently <span class="gemarra-regular">died.</span>
The question arose as to whether the presents must be returned to the betrothed’s heirs. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Aḥa Sar HaBir</span><span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> raised this </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> before the Sages in Usha, and they said: Presents that are typically consume</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> are not collected, and </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">that are not typically consumed are collected. </span>One can <span class="gemarra-regular">conclude from </span>this incident that <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>if the betrothed only <span class="gemarra-regular">drank, </span>some of the presents cannot be reclaimed.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Can you learn from this </span>incident that the presents cannot be claimed <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>if he ate or drank <span class="gemarra-regular">less than </span>the value of <span class="gemarra-regular">a dinar, </span>since a cup of hot drink is not worth a dinar? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi said: Who shall say to us that they did not grind a pearl worth one thousand dinars and serve it to him to drink? </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Can you learn from this </span>incident that <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">they sent </span>the feast <span class="gemarra-regular">to him </span>the presents cannot be claimed, as he drank at the entrance and did not enter inside? The Gemara rejects this conclusion: <span class="gemarra-regular">Perhaps the entire entrance of his father-in-law’s house is considered as his father-in-law’s house.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">A dilemma was raised before </span>the Sages: Rava states that if the betrothed man ate less than the value of a dinar at his father-in-law’s house, and the marriage is not effected, he can collect the presents he sent. <span class="gemarra-regular">What is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">whether he must divide </span>the value of the presents, and claim only part of the value, in proportion to the amount he ate? And <span class="gemarra-regular">what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">the enhancement of </span>the value of <span class="gemarra-regular">the presents</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> Does one say that <span class="gemarra-regular">since </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is that <span class="gemarra-regular">if they are </span>extant <span class="gemarra-regular">they are returned to him, </span>therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">they were enhanced under his ownership? Or perhaps, since </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is that <span class="gemarra-regular">if they are lost or stolen, </span>the betrothed woman’s family is <span class="gemarra-regular">required to repay him, </span>therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">they were enhanced under her ownership. </span>The Gemara concludes: These dilemmas <span class="gemarra-regular">shall stand </span>unresolved.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava raises a dilemma: What is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">presents that are typically consumed, but were not consumed? </span>The Gemara replies: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a proof: <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Aḥa Sar HaBira raised this </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> before the Sages at Usha, and they said: Presents that are typically consumed are not collected, and </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">that are not typically consumed are collected. What, is it not </span>referring to presents that are typically consumed <span class="gemarra-regular">even though they were not consumed? </span>The Gemara rejects this: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>the mishna is referring to presents <span class="gemarra-regular">that were </span>actually <span class="gemarra-regular">consumed.</span>
The Gemara replies: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a proof from the mishna: If he sent a <span class="gemarra-regular">few presents for her to use while she is in her father’s house, </span>they <span class="gemarra-regular">are not collected. </span>This indicates that they cannot be collected in any event, irrespective of whether they were used or not. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava interpreted </span>the mishna as referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to a snood or hairnet, </span>which are insignificant items that the betrothed man sends without any intention of later collecting them.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: </span>There was <span class="gemarra-regular">an incident involving one man who sent new wine, and new oil, and new linen garments to his father-in-law’s house at the </span>time of <span class="gemarra-italic">Shavuot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is this incident <span class="gemarra-regular">teaching us? </span>The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">If you wish, say </span>that it <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us the importance, </span>i.e., the greatness, <span class="gemarra-regular">of Eretz Yisrael, </span>where there is new wine, oil, and linen already available at the time of <span class="it-text">Shavuot</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if you wish, say </span>instead that it teaches <span class="gemarra-regular">that if </span>the betrothed man <span class="gemarra-regular">claims </span>that he sent these items at the time of <span class="it-text">Shavuot</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">his claim is </span>a plausible <span class="gemarra-regular">claim, </span>and there is no reason to question it.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: </span>There was <span class="gemarra-regular">an incident involving one man who was told </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">his wife, </span>i.e., his betrothed, <span class="gemarra-regular">was one whose sense of smell was impaired</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and he followed her into a ruin, </span>carrying a date with him, <span class="gemarra-regular">to check her </span>to see if she could correctly identify the smell. <span class="gemarra-regular">He said to her: I smell </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">scent of radish in the Galilee. </span>

Daf 146b

<span class="gemarra-regular">She said to him: Who will give us of the dates of Jericho that I shall eat them, </span>hinting that she smelled the date he had brought with him. <span class="gemarra-regular">The ruin collapsed upon her and she died. The Sages said: Since he went into </span>the ruin <span class="gemarra-regular">after her only to check her </span>sense of smell, and not for the purpose of consummating their marriage, if <span class="gemarra-regular">she dies, he does not inherit </span>from <span class="gemarra-regular">her</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as the marriage was not effected, and a man does not inherit from his betrothed.
§ The mishna teaches: If he sent <span class="gemarra-regular">a few presents for her to use while in her father’s house, </span>they are not collected. <span class="gemarra-regular">Ravin the Elder was sitting before Rav Papp</span><span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and he was sitting and saying: Whether she died, or whether he died, </span>or whether <span class="gemarra-regular">he retracted</span> his agreement to the betrothal and divorced her, the <span class="gemarra-regular">presents return </span>to the betrothed man or his heirs, but <span class="gemarra-regular">food and drink do not return. </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">she retracted </span>her agreement to the betrothal and requested a divorce, <span class="gemarra-regular">even a bundle of vegetables returns </span>to the betrothed man. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, said: </span>When the presents are returned, the court <span class="gemarra-regular">appraises for </span>the betrothed woman’s family the sum that they must repay for any meat he gave her, according <span class="gemarra-regular">to a reduced </span>assessment of the <span class="gemarra-regular">value of </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">mea</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> and not according to the price the betrothed man paid. <span class="gemarra-regular">How much </span>less is the <span class="gemarra-regular">reduced </span>assessment? <span class="gemarra-regular">Up to one-third </span>less than he paid.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a person on his </span><span class="gemarra-regular">death-be</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">who wrote </span>a deed granting <span class="gemarra-regular">all of his property to others, and he reserved </span>for himself <span class="gemarra-regular">any amount of land, his gift stands </span>even if he subsequently recovers. If <span class="gemarra-regular">he did not reserve </span>for himself <span class="gemarra-regular">any amount of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">land</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and he recovered, <span class="gemarra-regular">his gift does not stand, </span>as the gift was conditional upon his death, since is it evident that he did not intend to leave himself without means of support.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">Who </span>is the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> who <span class="gemarra-regular">taught that we follow </span>the principle of <span class="gemarra-regular">assessing </span>a person’s intentions, even when he did not expressly state them? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman said: This is </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon ben Menasya, as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> (<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span>, <span class="it-text">Ketubot</span> 5:9): In a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where one’s son went overseas and he heard that his son died, and </span>then he <span class="gemarra-regular">arose and wrote </span>a document granting <span class="gemarra-regular">all of his property to another, and then his son came </span>back, <span class="gemarra-regular">his gift </span>to the other people <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>a valid <span class="gemarra-regular">gift. Rabbi Shimon ben Menasya says: His gift is not </span>a valid <span class="gemarra-regular">gift, as had he known that his son </span>was <span class="gemarra-regular">alive he would not have written </span>a document granting <span class="gemarra-regular">them </span>his property.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Sheshet said: This is </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon Shezuri, as it is taught </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Gittin</span> 65b): <span class="gemarra-regular">Initially </span>the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">would say: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who was taken out in a colla</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> to be executed <span class="gemarra-regular">and said: Write a bill of divorce for my wife, these </span>people <span class="gemarra-regular">should write and give </span>her the document. Although he did not explicitly say the word give, this is understood to have been his intention, to release her from the necessity to perform levirate marriage or <span class="it-text">ḥalitza</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">They then said </span>that this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> applies <span class="gemarra-regular">even to one who sets sail and one who departs with a caravan </span>to a far-off place. A bill of divorce is given to his wife under these circumstances even if her husband said just: Write. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon Shezuri says: Even </span>in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who is dangerously il</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span> who gives that instruction, they write the bill of divorce and give it to his wife.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And what is the reason </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman does not interpret </span>the mishna as being <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon Shezuri? </span>The Gemara answers: Rav Naḥman holds that it <span class="gemarra-regular">is different there, as he said: Write </span>a bill of divorce, thereby partially stating his intention to divorce her, whereas in the case of the mishna here, he did not express his intention at all. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And what is the reason </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Sheshet does not interpret </span>the mishna as being <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon ben Menasya? </span>The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">An assessment </span>of a person’s intentions <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>clearly <span class="gemarra-regular">prove</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is different, </span>and it is possible that Rabbi Shimon ben Menasya does not apply this principle where the person’s intentions are less evident.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Who </span>is the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> who <span class="gemarra-regular">taught that which the Sages taught </span>(<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span>, <span class="it-text">Ketubot</span> 4:15): If one <span class="gemarra-regular">was ill and bedridden, and </span>those present <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: To whom </span>shall <span class="gemarra-regular">your property </span>be given? <span class="gemarra-regular">And he said to them: </span>

Daf 147a

Previously, I <span class="gemarra-regular">thought that I had a son. Now </span>that I have been informed <span class="gemarra-regular">that I do not have a son, my property </span>shall be given <span class="gemarra-regular">to so-and-so. </span>Or if he <span class="gemarra-regular">was ill and bedridden, and </span>those present <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: To whom </span>shall <span class="gemarra-regular">his property </span>be given? And <span class="gemarra-regular">he said to them: </span>Previously, I <span class="gemarra-regular">thought that my wife was pregnant. Now </span>that I have been informed <span class="gemarra-regular">that my wife is not pregnant, my property </span>shall be given <span class="gemarra-regular">to so-and-so. And </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">it </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">became known, </span>in either of those cases, <span class="gemarra-regular">that he had a son or that his wife was pregnant, his gift is not </span>a valid <span class="gemarra-regular">gift</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> since he clearly indicated that he bestowed the gift on that recipient only because he thought he had no heir.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Shall we say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">this is </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon ben Menasya and not </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis? </span>The Gemara rejects this: <span class="gemarra-regular">You </span>can <span class="gemarra-regular">even say </span>that this is the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis, </span>as the case where he said: I <span class="gemarra-regular">thought</span> that I had a son, <span class="gemarra-regular">is different, </span>since he stated the reason for his actions.
Since the difference between the cases is obvious, the Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">He who asked it, why did he ask it? </span>The Gemara replies: <span class="gemarra-regular">Lest you say </span>that when the bedridden man mentioned that he does not have a son, <span class="gemarra-regular">he is mentioning it </span>only as an expression of <span class="gemarra-regular">his sorrow, </span>since the matter of the disposal of his estate brings it to mind, but he is not mentioning this as the reason for the gift, the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>that the reference to his son indicates that had he known that he had a son, he would not have given his property to others.
§ Unlike the gifts of a healthy person, the gifts of a person on his deathbed do not require a formal act of acquisition. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Zeira says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: From where</span> is it derived <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> gift of a person on his deathbed is by Torah law</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> As it is stated </span>in the passage delineating the laws of inheritance: “If a man dies, and he does not have a son, <span class="gemarra-regular">then</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> you shall cause his inheritance to pass to his daughter” </span>(Numbers 27:8). The term “you shall cause…to pass” is superfluous, as the verse could have stated: His inheritance shall go to his daughter. One can therefore derive from this term that <span class="gemarra-regular">you have another </span>case of <span class="gemarra-regular">causing </span>property <span class="gemarra-regular">to pass </span>to another, <span class="gemarra-regular">which is comparable to this </span>case of inheritance, which does not require an act of acquisition. <span class="gemarra-regular">And what is this </span>case? <span class="gemarra-regular">This is </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">the gift of a person on his deathbed.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman </span>says that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba bar Avuh says: </span>The <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to the gift of a person on his deathbed is derived <span class="gemarra-regular">from here: </span>“And if he has no daughter, <span class="gemarra-regular">then you shall give his inheritance to his brothers” </span>(Numbers 27:9). The verse could have stated: His inheritance shall go to his brothers, as inheritance is transferred by itself, without any intervention. One can therefore derive from the term “you shall give” that <span class="gemarra-regular">you have another </span>case of <span class="gemarra-regular">giving that is comparable to this </span>case. <span class="gemarra-regular">And what is this </span>case? <span class="gemarra-regular">This is </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">the gift of a person on his deathbed.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman, what is the reason </span>that he <span class="gemarra-regular">did not say </span>that this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> can be derived <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the term <span class="gemarra-regular">“you shall cause…to pass”? </span>The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">He requires that </span>verse <span class="gemarra-regular">for that </span>which is taught <span class="gemarra-regular">by Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">says: With regard to all of </span>the heirs, the term <span class="gemarra-regular">giving was stated </span>in the Torah, <span class="gemarra-regular">and here, </span>with regard to the daughter, the term <span class="gemarra-regular">causing to pass was stated. </span>One can derive from this that <span class="gemarra-regular">there is no </span>heir <span class="gemarra-regular">who </span>can <span class="gemarra-regular">cause </span>one’s <span class="gemarra-regular">inheritance to pass from </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">tribe to </span>another <span class="gemarra-regular">tribe except </span>for the <span class="gemarra-regular">daughter, since her son and her husband inherit </span>from <span class="gemarra-regular">her, </span>and they may be of a different tribe.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Zeira, what is the reason </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">he did not say </span>that this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> can be derived <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the term <span class="gemarra-regular">“Then you shall give”? </span>The Gemara answers: Rabbi Zeira maintains that <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>usage <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>usual <span class="gemarra-regular">manner of the verse, </span>and one cannot derive anything from this term.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Menashya bar Yirmeya says: </span>The <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to the gift of a person on his deathbed is derived <span class="gemarra-regular">from here: “In those days Hezekiah became deathly ill, and Isaiah ben Amoz the prophet came to him, and said to him: So says the Lord: Instruct your household, for you will die, and you will not live” </span>(II Kings 20:1). This indicates that <span class="gemarra-regular">merely by </span>issuing <span class="gemarra-regular">an instruction, </span>a person on his deathbed can transfer ownership of his property.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rami bar Yeḥezkel says: </span>The <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to the gift of a person on his deathbed is derived <span class="gemarra-regular">from here: “And when Ahithophel saw that his counsel was not followed, he saddled his ass, </span>and he arose, <span class="gemarra-regular">and went to his home, to his city; and he instructed his household, and strangled himself” </span>(II Samuel 17:23). This indicates that <span class="gemarra-regular">merely by </span>issuing <span class="gemarra-regular">an instruction, </span>a person on his deathbed can transfer ownership of his property.
<span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught: </span>Before his death, when he saw that Absalom’s rebellion against King David had failed, <span class="gemarra-regular">Ahithophel instructe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> his sons </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">three matters:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Do not be </span>participants <span class="gemarra-regular">in a dispute. And do not rebel against the kingship of the house of David</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> And </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">the festival of </span><span class="gemarra-italic">Shavuot</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">a clear </span>day, <span class="gemarra-regular">sow wheat, </span>as it is a sign that the wheat crop will thrive. <span class="gemarra-regular">Mar Zutra said: It was stated </span>that the wheat crop will thrive if <span class="it-text">Shavuot</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">cloudy </span>day, not if it is a clear day. The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">of Neharde’a say in the name of Rabbi Ya’akov: </span>According to both opinions, <span class="gemarra-regular">a clear </span>day does <span class="gemarra-regular">not literally </span>mean <span class="gemarra-regular">a clear</span> day, <span class="gemarra-regular">nor </span>does <span class="gemarra-regular">a cloudy </span>day <span class="gemarra-regular">literally </span>mean <span class="gemarra-regular">a cloudy </span>day. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, even </span>if the day is <span class="gemarra-regular">cloudy but a north wind is blowing </span>the clouds away, <span class="gemarra-regular">this is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">a clear </span>day.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Abba said to Rav Ashi: We teach this </span>matter of signs concerning crops <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>the statement of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yitzḥak bar Avdimi, as Rav Yitzḥak bar Avdimi says: </span>At <span class="gemarra-regular">the conclusion of the final day of the festival </span>of <span class="it-text">Sukkot</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">everyone looked upon the smoke </span>rising from <span class="gemarra-regular">the arrangement </span>of wood on the altar. If the smoke <span class="gemarra-regular">inclined toward </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">nort</span><span class="gemarra-regular">h</span> due to a south wind, <span class="gemarra-regular">the poor </span>were <span class="gemarra-regular">glad and the homeowners </span>were <span class="gemarra-regular">sad, because </span>this was a sign that the <span class="gemarra-regular">year’s rainfall </span>would be <span class="gemarra-regular">plentiful, and </span>although the rain would produce an abundant crop, the <span class="gemarra-regular">produce </span>would <span class="gemarra-regular">decay </span>due to the humidity. The humidity would make it difficult to store the abundant harvest, forcing the homeowners to sell the produce quickly at a lower price.
If the smoke <span class="gemarra-regular">inclined toward </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">south </span>due to a north wind, <span class="gemarra-regular">the poor </span>were <span class="gemarra-regular">sad and the homeowners </span>were <span class="gemarra-regular">glad, because </span>this indicated that the <span class="gemarra-regular">year’s rainfall </span>would be <span class="gemarra-regular">sparse and </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">produce </span>would be meager and would <span class="gemarra-regular">store </span>well. If the smoke <span class="gemarra-regular">inclined toward </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">east </span>due to a west wind, <span class="gemarra-regular">everyone </span>was <span class="gemarra-regular">glad, </span>because this indicated that there would be sufficient rainfall to ensure a substantial crop, and at the same time, the produce would store well. If the smoke inclined <span class="gemarra-regular">toward </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">west </span>due to an east wind, <span class="gemarra-regular">everyone </span>was <span class="gemarra-regular">sad, </span>because the east wind does not bring rain, and this indicated that there would be a drought.
The Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises a contradiction </span>from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">An east </span>wind is <span class="gemarra-regular">always beneficial, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">a west </span>wind is <span class="gemarra-regular">always harmful. A north wind </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">beneficial to the wheat when it has reached one-third </span>of its growth <span class="gemarra-regular">and harmful to the olives when they are blossoming. And a south wind is harmful to the wheat when it has reached one-third </span>of its growth <span class="gemarra-regular">and beneficial to the olives when they are blossoming.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav Yosef says, and some say </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">Mar Zutra </span>who says this, <span class="gemarra-regular">and some say </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak</span> who says this: The following is <span class="gemarra-regular">your mnemonic </span>to remember which wind is beneficial to which crop: The <span class="gemarra-regular">Table </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">in the north </span>of the Sanctuary, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">Candelabrum </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">in the south. This </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">increases its own, and that </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">increases its own, </span>i.e., the Table, upon which the shewbread made from wheat is placed, is in the north, and the north wind is beneficial to the wheat. The Candelabrum, which is lit with olive oil, is in the south, and the south wind is beneficial to the olives. In any event, the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> contradicts the statement of Rav Yitzḥak bar Avdimi with regard to the effect of the western and eastern winds.
The Gemara answers: This is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult. This, </span>the east wind, is <span class="gemarra-regular">for us, </span>in Babylonia, <span class="gemarra-regular">and that, </span>the west wind, is <span class="gemarra-regular">for them, </span>in Eretz Yisrael. In Babylonia the east wind is beneficial, because water is plentiful there, and the dry east wind does not harm the crops. In Eretz Yisrael the east wind is harmful, because water is scarce, and the east wind ruins the crops, whereas the west wind brings the necessary rain.
It <span class="gemarra-regular">is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Abba Shaul says: </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">the festival of </span><span class="gemarra-italic">Shavuot</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">a clear </span>day, this is <span class="gemarra-regular">a good sign for the entire year. Rav Zevid said: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">this first day of Rosh HaShana, if </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">warm, the entire year </span>will be <span class="gemarra-regular">warm, </span>but <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">cold, the entire year </span>will be <span class="gemarra-regular">cold. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What difference is there </span>whether one knows this or not? 

Daf 147b

The Gemara answers: The difference is <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the prayer of the High Priest</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> who would pray on Yom Kippur for beneficial weather, and this knowledge enabled him to formulate his prayers accordingly.
The Gemara resumes the discussion with regard to the gifts of a person on his deathbed: <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rava </span>says that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman says: </span>The <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that the <span class="gemarra-regular">gift of a person on his deathbed </span>does not require an act of acquisition <span class="gemarra-regular">is merely by rabbinic law</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and it is instituted <span class="gemarra-regular">lest </span>he see that his will is not being carried out and <span class="gemarra-regular">he lose control of his mind </span>due to his grief, exacerbating his physical state.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And did Rav Naḥman </span>actually <span class="gemarra-regular">say this? But doesn’t Rav Naḥman say: Even though Shmuel says </span>that with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who sells a promissory note to another and then forgives </span>the debt, the debt <span class="gemarra-regular">is forgive</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> and the note is nullified, <span class="gemarra-regular">and even </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">heir </span>of the creditor can <span class="gemarra-regular">forgive </span>the debt, <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel concedes that if </span>the creditor <span class="gemarra-regular">gave </span>the promissory note <span class="gemarra-regular">as the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">gift of a person on his deathbed</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> his heir <span class="gemarra-regular">cannot forgive </span>the debt?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, if you say </span>that the gift of a person on his deathbed is valid <span class="gemarra-regular">by Torah law </span>without an act of acquisition, <span class="gemarra-regular">due to that </span>reason the heir <span class="gemarra-regular">cannot forgive </span>the debt, as the debt was acquired by another. <span class="gemarra-regular">But if you say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">it </span>is valid <span class="gemarra-regular">by rabbinic law</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> why </span>is the heir <span class="gemarra-regular">unable to forgive </span>the debt? The Gemara replies: Rav Naḥman maintains that although this gift <span class="gemarra-regular">is not </span>effective <span class="gemarra-regular">by Torah law, </span>nevertheless, the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">made it </span>a <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>the force <span class="gemarra-regular">of Torah law.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman says: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a person on his deathbed who says: So-and-so shall reside in this house</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> or who says: <span class="gemarra-regular">So-and-so shall eat </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">fruit of this palm tree, </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">has not said anything, </span>as one cannot give that which is not tangible, such as the right to use property, or the right to consume fruit that has not yet grown. His statement is ineffective <span class="gemarra-regular">until he says: Give this house to so-and-so and he shall reside there, </span>or: <span class="gemarra-regular">Give this palm tree to so-and-so and he shall eat its fruit.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">this to say that Rav Naḥman maintains </span>that only <span class="gemarra-regular">a matter that can be </span>conferred as a gift <span class="gemarra-regular">by a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> healthy person </span>with an act of acquisition <span class="gemarra-regular">can be </span>conferred as a gift <span class="gemarra-regular">by a person on his deathbed </span>by means of verbal instruction, but a matter <span class="gemarra-regular">that cannot be </span>conferred as a gift <span class="gemarra-regular">by a healthy person cannot be </span>conferred as a gift <span class="gemarra-regular">by a person on his deathbed</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> Consequently, a person on his deathbed cannot transfer ownership of an intangible right, just as a healthy person cannot do so. <span class="gemarra-regular">But doesn’t Rava say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman says: </span>

Daf 148a

With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a person on his deathbed who says: Give </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">loan </span>owed <span class="gemarra-regular">to me to so-and-s</span><span class="gemarra-regular">o</span> as a gift, the <span class="gemarra-regular">loan </span>owned to <span class="gemarra-regular">him </span>is acquired <span class="gemarra-regular">by so-and-so. And </span>this is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">despite </span>the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that this does not </span>apply <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a healthy person</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as one cannot transfer a loan to a third party without a promissory note. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa says: </span>In this case the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of transferring loans differs with regard to a person on his deathbed, <span class="gemarra-regular">since an heir inherits </span>loans without a promissory note, and the Sages accorded the gift of a person on his deathbed the halakhic status of an inheritance.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Aḥa, son of Rav Ika, said: A loan </span>without a promissory note <span class="gemarra-regular">can be </span>conferred as a gift <span class="gemarra-regular">by a healthy person. And </span>this is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>that which <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna </span>says that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says, as Rav Huna says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: </span>With regard to one who said to another: <span class="gemarra-regular">I </span>have <span class="gemarra-regular">one hundred dinars in your possession, give it to so-and-so, </span>if this was stated <span class="gemarra-regular">in the presence of </span>all <span class="gemarra-regular">three of the </span>parties, the third party <span class="gemarra-regular">acquires </span>the money without an act of acquisition and without the need for witnesses.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">A dilemma was raised before </span>the Sages: With regard to one who gave <span class="gemarra-regular">a palm tree to one </span>person <span class="gemarra-regular">and its fruit to another</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? <span class="gemarra-regular">Did </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">reserve the place of the fruit </span>on the tree for the second person in order to give him a tangible object, and therefore the second person acquires the fruit, <span class="gemarra-regular">or </span>did <span class="gemarra-regular">he not reserve </span>it, and the second person does not acquire the fruit? Furthermore, <span class="gemarra-regular">if you say </span>that giving the palm tree to one person and giving the fruit <span class="gemarra-regular">to another is not </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">reserving </span>the place of the fruit unless this is explicitly stipulated, then if he reserves the fruit <span class="gemarra-regular">for himself, </span>stating that the tree is given to another <span class="gemarra-regular">except for its fruit, what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman said: </span>Even <span class="gemarra-regular">if you say </span>that giving the <span class="gemarra-regular">palm tree to one </span>person <span class="gemarra-regular">and its fruit to another is not </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">reserving the place of the fruit </span>for the second person, if he gave the <span class="gemarra-regular">palm tree to one </span>person <span class="gemarra-regular">and reserved the fruit for himself, </span>he also <span class="gemarra-regular">reserved the place of the fruit </span>for himself. <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>for this distinction? The reason is that <span class="gemarra-regular">anything </span>that one reserves <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to himself, he reserves generously, </span>and therefore he reserves for himself not only the fruit itself, but also the place of the fruit.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Abba said to Rav Ashi: We learned </span>the aforementioned statement of Rav Naḥman <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>the statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Shimon ben Lakis</span><span class="gemarra-regular">h</span> concerning a different matter, <span class="gemarra-regular">as Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish says: </span>In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who sells a house to another and says to him: </span>I am selling the house <span class="gemarra-regular">on the condition that the upper story [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">deyota</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> remains <span class="gemarra-regular">mine, the upper story </span>remains <span class="gemarra-regular">his. </span>

Daf 148b

<span class="gemarra-regular">A dilemma was raised before </span>the Sages with regard to the statement of Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish: If one sold <span class="gemarra-regular">a house, </span>i.e., a lower story, <span class="gemarra-regular">to one </span>person <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>stated that the upper <span class="gemarra-regular">story </span>will be sold <span class="gemarra-regular">to one </span>other person, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? <span class="gemarra-regular">Is this </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">reserving </span>additional rights for the second person apart from the upper story, <span class="gemarra-regular">or not</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> If you say </span>that in a case where one sells his <span class="gemarra-regular">house to one and </span>the upper <span class="gemarra-regular">story to one, </span>his stipulation <span class="gemarra-regular">is not</span> considered <span class="gemarra-regular">reserving </span>rights for the second person, there is another dilemma. If one sold a house <span class="gemarra-regular">except for </span>the upper <span class="gemarra-regular">story, </span>reserving the upper story for himself, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? Is this considered reserving additional rights for himself?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman said: </span>Even <span class="gemarra-regular">if you say </span>that where one sells the <span class="gemarra-regular">house to one </span>person <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the upper <span class="gemarra-regular">story to one </span>other person, he <span class="gemarra-regular">is not </span>considered to be <span class="gemarra-regular">reserving </span>rights for the second person, if one sold a house <span class="gemarra-regular">except for </span>the upper <span class="gemarra-regular">story</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> he <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>considered to be <span class="gemarra-regular">reserving </span>additional rights for himself. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>this is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav Zevid, who says </span>that the reason the seller reserves additional rights is <span class="gemarra-regular">that if </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">wants to extend projections from </span>the upper story into the space of the courtyard, <span class="gemarra-regular">he may extend </span>them.
The Gemara concludes: <span class="gemarra-regular">Evidently, since he reserved </span>the upper <span class="gemarra-regular">story, he also reserved the place of the projections. Here too, </span>with regard to the one who gave a palm tree to another and reserved the fruit for himself, <span class="gemarra-regular">since he said </span>that the tree is given to another <span class="gemarra-regular">except for its fruit, he reserved the place of the fruit </span>for himself as well.
§ The mishna (146b) states that if a person on his deathbed granted all of his property to others but reserved for himself any amount of land, his gift is valid even if he recovers. If he did not reserve for himself any amount of land, his gift is not valid if he recovers. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef bar Minyumi says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman says: </span>In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a person on his deathbed who wrote </span>a deed granting <span class="gemarra-regular">all of his property to others, </span>the manner in which he divided his property <span class="gemarra-regular">is examined. If </span>it appears <span class="gemarra-regular">that he was </span>intending <span class="gemarra-regular">to divide </span>his entire estate among various recipients, then if <span class="gemarra-regular">he dies, all </span>the recipients <span class="gemarra-regular">acquire </span>their gifts. If he <span class="gemarra-regular">recovers, </span>he can <span class="gemarra-regular">retract all </span>of the gifts, in accordance with the ruling of the mishna.
But <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>it appears <span class="gemarra-regular">that he was reconsidering </span>the matter, initially intending to give away only a portion of his property, and then reconsidering and distributing the rest, then if <span class="gemarra-regular">he dies, all </span>of the recipients <span class="gemarra-regular">acquire </span>their gifts. If <span class="gemarra-regular">he recovers, he can </span><span class="gemarra-regular">retract only the last </span>gift, as the previous gifts were given with the intent to reserve part of the property for himself, and they are valid even if he recovers. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Perhaps </span>he was not reconsidering; rather, he initially intended to transfer ownership of all of his property, and <span class="gemarra-regular">he was considering </span>to whom to give each portion <span class="gemarra-regular">and then giving </span>it. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">The usual </span>way <span class="gemarra-regular">of a person on his deathbed is to consider </span>the matter <span class="gemarra-regular">carefully </span>first <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">then </span>to <span class="gemarra-regular">confer </span>his gifts. Therefore, if he pauses to consider in the interim, it appears that he did not initially intend to transfer ownership of his entire estate.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Aḥa bar Minyumi says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman says: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a person on his deathbed who wrote </span>a deed granting <span class="gemarra-regular">all of his </span>generally known <span class="gemarra-regular">property to others, and </span>he then <span class="gemarra-regular">recovered, he cannot retract </span>it, as <span class="gemarra-regular">we are concerned </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">perhaps he has propert</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in another provinc</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> that he reserved for himself, in which case the gift is valid even if he recovered.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>as for <span class="gemarra-regular">the mishna, which teaches: </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">he did not reserve </span>for himself <span class="gemarra-regular">any amount of land, </span>and he recovered, <span class="gemarra-regular">his gift is not valid, how can you find these </span>circumstances? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥama said: </span>The mishna is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he says: All my property </span>is given to so-and-so, in which case he clearly reserved nothing for himself. <span class="gemarra-regular">Mar bar Rav Ashi said: </span>The mishna is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where our presumption is that he does not have </span>property elsewhere.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">A dilemma was raised before </span>the Sages: With regard to the gift of a person on his deathbed, <span class="gemarra-regular">is a partial retraction </span>of the gift considered <span class="gemarra-regular">a retraction of the entire </span>gift, <span class="gemarra-regular">or </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>considered a retraction of the entire gift? The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear</span> a proof from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: If one gave <span class="gemarra-regular">all </span>of his property <span class="gemarra-regular">to the first </span>recipient <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>then he partially retracted his gift and gave <span class="gemarra-regular">part </span>of his property <span class="gemarra-regular">to the second </span>recipient, <span class="gemarra-regular">the second acquired </span>his gift, but <span class="gemarra-regular">the first did not acquire </span>anything. <span class="gemarra-regular">What, is it not </span>referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the giver <span class="gemarra-regular">died, </span>and the reason that the first recipient does not acquire anything is that a partial retraction is considered a retraction of the entire gift?
The Gemara rejects this explanation: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the giver <span class="gemarra-regular">recovered. </span>The first gift was invalidated, because he left nothing for himself, whereas the second gift remained valid, since he gave only part of his property. Had he died, the first recipient would have received the remainder, as the giver retracted only part of the first gift, which he gave to the second recipient.
The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">So too, it is reasonable </span>to understand the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> in this manner. <span class="gemarra-regular">From </span>the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that the last clause </span>of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches: </span>If he gave <span class="gemarra-regular">part </span>of his property <span class="gemarra-regular">to the first </span>recipient, <span class="gemarra-regular">and</span> then he gave <span class="gemarra-regular">all </span>of his property <span class="gemarra-regular">to the second </span>recipient, <span class="gemarra-regular">the first </span>recipient <span class="gemarra-regular">acquired </span>his gift, but <span class="gemarra-regular">the second did not acquire </span>anything. <span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, if you say </span>that the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the giver <span class="gemarra-regular">recovered, due to that </span>reason <span class="gemarra-regular">the second </span>recipient <span class="gemarra-regular">did not acquire </span>the gift. <span class="gemarra-regular">But if you say </span>that the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he died, both of them should acquire </span>their gifts.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yeimar said to Rav Ashi: And even </span>if the first clause of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to</span> a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he recovered, </span>one can prove that a partial retraction is considered a retraction of the entire gift. <span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, if you say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a partial retraction is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">a retraction of the entire </span>gift, <span class="gemarra-regular">this is </span>the reason <span class="gemarra-regular">that at least the second </span>recipient <span class="gemarra-regular">acquired </span>the gift, as the giver reserved part of his property for himself. <span class="gemarra-regular">But if you say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a partial retraction is not </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">a retraction of the entire </span>gift, the giver <span class="gemarra-regular">should</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> be </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">as one who was dividing </span>all of his property between the two recipients, <span class="gemarra-regular">and neither of them should acquire </span>their gifts.
The Gemara concludes: <span class="gemarra-regular">And the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is that <span class="gemarra-regular">a partial retraction is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> retraction of the entire </span>gift. <span class="gemarra-regular">You find </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that is stated in <span class="gemarra-regular">the first clause </span>of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">both </span>in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the giver <span class="gemarra-regular">died and </span>in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he recovered</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> You find </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that is stated in <span class="gemarra-regular">the last claus</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> only </span>in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he recovered.</span>
§ A series of <span class="gemarra-regular">dilemmas were raised before </span>the Sages: If a person on his deathbed <span class="gemarra-regular">consecrated all of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> his propert</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span> to the Temple treasury <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>subsequently <span class="gemarra-regular">recovered, what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? <span class="gemarra-regular">Do we say </span>that in <span class="gemarra-regular">any </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">that concerns consecrated </span>property the assumption is that he <span class="gemarra-regular">resolves to transfer </span>the property unconditionally, and therefore the consecration is valid even if he recovers? <span class="gemarra-regular">Or perhaps </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">any </span>matter <span class="gemarra-regular">that concerns himself </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">does not resolve to transfer </span>the property unconditionally.
Furthermore, if a person on his deathbed <span class="gemarra-regular">declared all of his property ownerless, what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? <span class="gemarra-regular">Do we say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">since </span>declaring his property ownerless is <span class="gemarra-regular">for</span> the benefit of <span class="gemarra-regular">the poor as well as the rich, </span>it involves the potential mitzva of providing for the poor, and therefore the assumption is that <span class="gemarra-regular">he resolves to transfer </span>the property, i.e., declare it ownerless, unconditionally? <span class="gemarra-regular">Or perhaps </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">any </span>matter <span class="gemarra-regular">that concerns himself he does not resolve to transfer </span>the property unconditionally.
Furthermore, if a person on his deathbed <span class="gemarra-regular">divided all of his property to </span>be distributed to <span class="gemarra-regular">the poor, what </span>is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? <span class="gemarra-regular">Do we say </span>that with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">charity </span>the assumption is that <span class="gemarra-regular">he certainly resolves to transfer </span>the property unconditionally? <span class="gemarra-regular">Or perhaps </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">any </span>matter <span class="gemarra-regular">that concerns himself he does not resolve to transfer </span>the property unconditionally. The Gemara concludes: These dilemmas <span class="gemarra-regular">shall stand </span>unresolved.
The Gemara presents <span class="gemarra-regular">another version </span>of this series of dilemmas: If a person on his deathbed <span class="gemarra-regular">consecrated all of his property </span>to the Temple treasury, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? If he <span class="gemarra-regular">declared all of his property ownerless, what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? If he <span class="gemarra-regular">divided all </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">his property to </span>be distributed to <span class="gemarra-regular">the poor, what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? These dilemmas <span class="gemarra-regular">shall stand </span>unresolved.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Sheshet says: </span>If one says: So-and-so <span class="gemarra-regular">shall take </span>my property, <span class="gemarra-regular">or: </span>So-and-so <span class="gemarra-regular">shall gain possession </span>of my property, <span class="gemarra-regular">or: </span>So-and-so <span class="gemarra-regular">shall take possessio</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> of my property, <span class="gemarra-regular">or: He shall acquire </span>my property, <span class="gemarra-regular">all of </span>these <span class="gemarra-regular">are terms </span>that denote the bestowal <span class="gemarra-regular">of gifts. </span>It <span class="gemarra-regular">was taught in a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">baraita</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: </span>If one says: So-and-so <span class="gemarra-regular">shall receive as an inheritance, or:</span> So-and-so <span class="gemarra-regular">shall inherit</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> these are <span class="gemarra-regular">also </span>valid terms denoting inheritance <span class="gemarra-regular">in</span> the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who is fit to inherit </span>from <span class="gemarra-regular">him. And this </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka, </span>who holds that one can bequeath all of his property to one of his sons using terms that denote inheritance, not only using terms that denote the bestowal of a gift.
A series of <span class="gemarra-regular">dilemmas were raised before </span>the Sages: 

Daf 149a

If a person on his deathbed says: So-and-so <span class="gemarra-regular">shall benefit from </span>my property, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? Is he <span class="gemarra-regular">saying that all </span>of the property <span class="gemarra-regular">shall be a gift? Or perhaps </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">saying </span>that the recipient <span class="gemarra-regular">shall derive some benefit from </span>the property. If he says: So-and-so <span class="gemarra-regular">shall be seen in </span>my property, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? If he says: So-and-so <span class="gemarra-regular">shall stand in </span>my property, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? If he says: So-and-so <span class="gemarra-regular">shall rely on </span>my property, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? The Gemara concludes: All these dilemmas <span class="gemarra-regular">shall stand </span>unresolved.
<span class="gemarra-regular">A dilemma was raised before </span>the Sages: If a person on his deathbed <span class="gemarra-regular">sold all of his property</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: If he recovers, he cannot retract </span>the sale. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>at <span class="gemarra-regular">times, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav said: If he recovers, he can retract </span>the sale. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>these statements <span class="gemarra-regular">do not disagree. This </span>statement, that he can retract the sale, applies in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where the dinars </span>he received as payment <span class="gemarra-regular">are </span>still <span class="gemarra-regular">extant</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., in his possession. <span class="gemarra-regular">That </span>statement, that he cannot retract the sale, applies in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he paid his debt with </span>those dinars.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">A dilemma was raised before </span>the Sages: In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a person on his deathbed who admitte</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> that he owed money to a certain person, where it was possible that he did not actually owe him money, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? Does his admission qualify as the gift of a person on his deathbed? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a proof, <span class="gemarra-regular">as Issur the convert had twelve thousand dinars </span>deposited in <span class="gemarra-regular">the house of Rava. Rav Mari</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> Issur’s <span class="gemarra-regular">son, whose conception was not in </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">sanctity </span>of the Jewish people, i.e., he was conceived before his father converted, <span class="gemarra-regular">but his birth was in </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">sanctity </span>of the Jewish people, i.e., he was born after his father converted, <span class="gemarra-regular">was </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">a study hall </span>elsewhere when his father was on his deathbed.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava </span>reasoned that he would acquire possession of the deposit for himself, as he <span class="gemarra-regular">said: How can Rav Mari acquire these dinars? If </span>he attempts to acquire the money <span class="gemarra-regular">as inheritance, he is not fit to inheri</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> from Issur. Since he was conceived before his father converted, he is therefore not halakhically considered his son. <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>he attempts to acquire it <span class="gemarra-regular">as a gift, the Sages equated </span>the halakhic status of the <span class="gemarra-regular">gift of a person on his deathbed with </span>that of <span class="gemarra-regular">inheritance. </span>Therefore, <span class="gemarra-regular">anywhere that </span>the property <span class="gemarra-regular">can be </span>acquired <span class="gemarra-regular">as inheritance, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">it can </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">be </span>acquired <span class="gemarra-regular">as a gift, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">anywhere that </span>the property <span class="gemarra-regular">cannot be </span>acquired <span class="gemarra-regular">as inheritance, it cannot be </span>acquired <span class="gemarra-regular">as a gift</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
