<span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>he attempts to acquire the dinars <span class="gemarra-regular">by pulling </span>them, which is a formal act of acquisition, he will not be able to do this, as the dinars <span class="gemarra-regular">are not with him.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> If </span>he attempts to acquire them <span class="gemarra-regular">by </span>means of symbolic <span class="gemarra-regular">exchange</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> a pro forma act of acquisition effecting the transfer of ownership of an article, <span class="gemarra-regular">money cannot be acquired by </span>means of symbolic <span class="gemarra-regular">exchange</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> If </span>he attempts to acquire them <span class="gemarra-regular">by</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> means of </span>the acquisition of <span class="gemarra-regular">land</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> Issur <span class="gemarra-regular">does not have </span>any <span class="gemarra-regular">land. If </span>he attempts to acquire them by means of verbal instruction made by his father <span class="gemarra-regular">in the presence of </span>all <span class="gemarra-regular">three </span>parties, i.e., the giver, the recipient, and the bailee, <span class="gemarra-regular">if he sends for me, </span>the bailee, <span class="gemarra-regular">I shall not go,</span> as without the presence of the bailee he cannot transfer ownership of the money.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ika, son of Rav Ami, objected to this: Why </span>is Rav Mari unable to acquire the money? <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>why not <span class="gemarra-regular">let Issur admi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that these dinars are </span>owned <span class="gemarra-regular">by</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rav Mari, and he shall transfer </span>ownership of <span class="gemarra-regular">them </span>to Rav Mari <span class="gemarra-regular">by </span>means of a document of <span class="gemarra-regular">admission? In the meantime, </span>a document of <span class="gemarra-regular">admission </span>stating that the dinars belonged to Rav Mari <span class="gemarra-regular">emerged from Issur’s house. Rava became angry, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">said: They are teaching people </span>legal <span class="gemarra-regular">claim</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and causing me loss. </span>In any event, this incident proves that the admission of a person on his deathbed is a valid means of transferring ownership. 

Daf 149b

§ The mishna teaches (146b): If a person on his deathbed <span class="gemarra-regular">reserved </span>for himself <span class="gemarra-regular">any amount of land, his gift stands </span>even if he subsequently recovers. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And how much </span>is meant by the term: <span class="gemarra-regular">Any amount</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rav Yehuda says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: </span>This means <span class="gemarra-regular">land </span>that is <span class="gemarra-regular">sufficient </span>to provide <span class="gemarra-regular">for his livelihood</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Since he reserved this land for himself, one can assume that he wished to transfer the rest of his property in any event. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav Yirmeya bar Abba says: </span>Even if he reserved for himself <span class="gemarra-regular">movable property </span>that is <span class="gemarra-regular">sufficient </span>to provide <span class="gemarra-regular">for his livelihood, </span>his gift is valid.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Zeira said: How meticulou</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> are <span class="gemarra-regular">the halakhic statements of the elders </span>Rav Yehuda and Rav Yirmeya. With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">land, what </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">the reason </span>that he must have reserved enough for his livelihood? The reason is <span class="gemarra-regular">that if he recovers </span>he will <span class="gemarra-regular">rely on that </span>land for his livelihood. With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">movable property as well, if he recovers </span>he will <span class="gemarra-regular">rely on it </span>for his livelihood.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef objects to </span>Rabbi Zeira’s statement: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is meticulous </span>about these statements? The statement of the <span class="gemarra-regular">one who says </span>the gift is valid even if he reserved for himself <span class="gemarra-regular">movable property </span>is difficult, as <span class="gemarra-regular">we learn </span>in the mishna that he must leave himself <span class="gemarra-regular">land. </span>The statement of the <span class="gemarra-regular">one who says </span>that he must leave himself an amount <span class="gemarra-regular">sufficient </span>to provide <span class="gemarra-regular">for his livelihood </span>is difficult, as <span class="gemarra-regular">we learn </span>in the mishna that his gift is valid if he reserved for himself <span class="gemarra-regular">any amount.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said to </span>Rav Yosef: <span class="gemarra-regular">And anywhere that </span>the term <span class="gemarra-regular">land is taught, </span>does it mean <span class="gemarra-regular">specifically land? But didn’t we learn </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Pe’a</span> 3:8): With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who writes, </span>i.e., gives via a document, <span class="gemarra-regular">all of his property to his </span>Canaanite <span class="gemarra-regular">slave</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the slave <span class="gemarra-regular">has been emancipated, </span>but if he <span class="gemarra-regular">reserved </span>for himself <span class="gemarra-regular">any amount of land</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> then he <span class="gemarra-regular">has not been emancipated, </span>as perhaps he reserved the slave for himself as well. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon says: He always </span>becomes <span class="gemarra-regular">a freeman </span>regardless of the wording of the document, even if the owner reserved land for himself, <span class="gemarra-regular">unless it says </span>in the document: <span class="gemarra-regular">All of my property is given to so-and-so my slave, except for one ten-thousandth of it</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as in that case it is possible that the master meant to include the slave in the portion that he is not giving away. Consequently, the slave is not emancipated. 

Daf 150a

<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav Dimi bar Yosef says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar says: </span>The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">deemed movable property </span>to be considered a significant <span class="gemarra-regular">reserving </span>of property for oneself <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>the emancipation of <span class="gemarra-regular">a slave</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> so that a slave is not emancipated when his owner gives him all of his other property. <span class="gemarra-regular">But they did not deem movable property </span>that one withheld from his sons and earmarked for his wife to be considered a significant <span class="gemarra-regular">reserving </span>of property <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>her <span class="gemarra-regular">marriage contract</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> If one granted all of his property to his sons but reserved any amount of land for his wife, she forfeits her marriage contract. By not protesting the gift, she has conceded that she will collect her marriage contract only from the land he reserved for her. Nevertheless, if he reserved only movable property for his wife, she does not forfeit her marriage contract. Rabbi Elazar’s ruling with regard to a slave indicates that the expression: Reserves any amount of land, does not necessarily exclude movable property.
Rav Yosef replies: <span class="gemarra-regular">There, </span>with regard to the slave, <span class="gemarra-regular">by right </span>the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">should not </span>have <span class="gemarra-regular">taught </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">land, </span>but it should have taught the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to all property. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span><span class="gemarra-regular">since </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">former clause </span>of the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>a <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to land, the mishna mentions land in the subsequent clause as well. The Gemara cites the former clause (<span class="it-text">Pe’a</span> 3:6): <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Akiva says: </span>The owner of <span class="gemarra-regular">any amount of land is obligated in </span><span class="gemarra-italic">pe’</span><span class="gemarra-italic">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and in first fruits</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>if the debtor possesses any amount of land the creditor <span class="gemarra-regular">can write a document that prevents the Sabbatical Year from abrogating an outstanding debt [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">prosbol</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">for i</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> so that his loans will not be canceled in the seventh year; <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">can acquire property that does not serve as a guarantee </span>along <span class="gemarra-regular">with it by </span>means of <span class="gemarra-regular">money, by a deed, or by taking possessio</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> of it. Rav Yosef concludes: <span class="gemarra-regular">Due to this </span>reason, the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">land.</span>
Abaye raises an objection to Rav Yosef’s statement that the term any amount should be understood literally: <span class="gemarra-regular">And anywhere that </span>the term: <span class="gemarra-regular">Any amount, is taught, </span>does the amount <span class="gemarra-regular">not have a measure? But didn’t we learn </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Ḥullin</span> 135a): <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Dosa ben Harkinas says: </span>When shearing <span class="gemarra-regular">five sheep, </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">sheared </span>wool of each sheep, with the wool weighing <span class="gemarra-regular">one hundred dinars and half </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">one hundred dinars</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., one hundred and fifty dinars, renders the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">obligated in </span>the mitzva to give <span class="gemarra-regular">the first sheared </span>wool to the priests. <span class="gemarra-regular">And the Rabbis say: Five sheep, </span>each of whose <span class="gemarra-regular">sheared </span>wool yields wool weighing <span class="gemarra-regular">any amount</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> And we say: And how much </span>is signified by the term: <span class="gemarra-regular">Any amount? Rav says: </span>A total weight of <span class="gemarra-regular">one hundred dinars and half </span>of one hundred dinars, <span class="gemarra-regular">provided that </span>the one hundred and fifty dinars <span class="gemarra-regular">are divided </span>equally <span class="gemarra-regular">between the five </span>sheep. This indicates that the term any amount can denote a certain minimal amount.
Rav Yosef replies: <span class="gemarra-regular">There, </span>with regard to the first sheared wool, <span class="gemarra-regular">by right </span>the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">should not </span>have <span class="gemarra-regular">taught </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">any amount. But since the first </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>Rabbi Dosa ben Harkinas, <span class="gemarra-regular">states a large measure, </span>the Rabbis <span class="gemarra-regular">also state </span>that they require <span class="gemarra-regular">a small measure, </span>and therefore they <span class="gemarra-regular">call </span>this measure <span class="gemarra-regular">any amount. </span>But with regard to the gift of a person on his deathbed, the term any amount should be understood literally.
§ It is <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious </span>that if one <span class="gemarra-regular">said: </span>I give <span class="gemarra-regular">my movable propert</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to so-and-so</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> then that person <span class="gemarra-regular">acquires all </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">his utensils, excluding </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">wheat and barley</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> If one said: I give <span class="gemarra-regular">all my movable propert</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to so-and-so, </span>then that person acquires <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">wheat and barley, and he acquires even the upper millstone, </span>since it is occasionally removed from its place. He acquires all the property that is not land or houses, <span class="gemarra-regular">except for the lower millstone, </span>which is never moved. If he said: I give <span class="gemarra-regular">everything that can be moved </span>to so-and-so, that person <span class="gemarra-regular">acquires even the lower millstone, </span>as it is possible to move it.
<span class="gemarra-regular">A dilemma was raised before </span>the Sages: Is the legal status of a Canaanite <span class="gemarra-regular">slave like </span>that of <span class="gemarra-regular">land, or </span>is his status <span class="gemarra-regular">like </span>that of <span class="gemarra-regular">movable property</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rav Aḥa, son of Rav Avya, said to Rav Ashi: Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a proof from a mishna (68a): A landowner <span class="gemarra-regular">who sells the city has sold </span>with it the <span class="gemarra-regular">houses, </span>and the <span class="gemarra-regular">ditches and caves, and </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">bathhouses, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">the olive presses and the irrigated fields, but not the movable property. But when </span>the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>to the buyer: I am selling <span class="gemarra-regular">it and everything </span><span class="gemarra-regular">that is in it, </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">there were animals or </span>Canaanite <span class="gemarra-regular">slaves in </span>the city, <span class="gemarra-regular">they are all sold. </span>Rav Aḥa, son of Rav Avya, explains the proof: <span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, if you say </span>that the legal status of a Canaanite slave <span class="gemarra-regular">is like </span>that of <span class="gemarra-regular">movable property, due to that </span>reason <span class="gemarra-regular">he is not sold in the first </span>case. <span class="gemarra-regular">But if you say </span>that the legal status of a Canaanite slave <span class="gemarra-regular">is like </span>that of <span class="gemarra-regular">land, why is he not sold </span>with the city?
Rav Ashi replied: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, what </span>do you say? Do you maintain that his legal status <span class="gemarra-regular">is like </span>that of <span class="gemarra-regular">movable property? </span>If there is no difference in legal status between Canaanite slaves and movable property, <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>is the reason that the mishna emphasizes in the second case that <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>the Canaanite slaves are sold? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, what have you to say </span>to explain this? One must explain that <span class="gemarra-regular">movable property that moves </span>by itself <span class="gemarra-regular">is different from movable property that does not move </span>by itself, and therefore one might have thought that although the sale includes movable property, Canaanite slaves are not included in the sale. In the same manner, <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">you say </span>that the legal status of a Canaanite slave <span class="gemarra-regular">is like </span>that of <span class="gemarra-regular">land, land that moves is different from land that does not move. </span>Therefore, the legal status of Canaanite slaves cannot be proved from this mishna.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Ravina said to Rav Ashi: Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a proof from a mishna (<span class="it-text">Pe’a</span> 3:8): With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who writes, </span>i.e., gives via a document, <span class="gemarra-regular">all of his property to his </span>Canaanite <span class="gemarra-regular">slave, </span>the slave <span class="gemarra-regular">has been emancipated, </span>but if he <span class="gemarra-regular">reserved </span>for himself <span class="gemarra-regular">any amount of land, </span>then he <span class="gemarra-regular">has not been emancipated, </span>as perhaps he reserved the slave for himself as well. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon says: He always </span>becomes <span class="gemarra-regular">a freeman </span>regardless of the wording of the document, even if the owner reserved land for himself, <span class="gemarra-regular">unless it says </span>in the document: <span class="gemarra-regular">All of my property is given to so-and-so my slave, except for one ten-thousandth of it.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav Dimi bar Yosef says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar says: </span>The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">deemed movable property </span>to be considered a significant <span class="gemarra-regular">reserving </span>of property for oneself <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to a slave, </span>so that the slave is not emancipated when the owner gives him all of his other property. <span class="gemarra-regular">But they did not deem movable property </span>that one withheld from his sons and earmarked for his wife to be considered a significant <span class="gemarra-regular">reserving </span>of property <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>her <span class="gemarra-regular">marriage contract. And Rava said to Rav Naḥman: What is the reason </span>for this? Rav Naḥman explained: A Canaanite <span class="gemarra-regular">slave is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">movable property, and </span>reserving <span class="gemarra-regular">movable property is</span> considered a significant <span class="gemarra-regular">reserving with regard to movable property. But a woman’s marriage contract is </span>a document concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">land, </span>since the payment of the marriage contract is collected from land, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>reserving <span class="gemarra-regular">movable property is not </span>considered a significant <span class="gemarra-regular">reserving with regard to land. </span>Rav Naḥman states that a Canaanite slave is considered movable property. 

Daf 150b

Rav Ashi <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Ravina: The reason the slave is not emancipated if the master reserved part of the property for himself is not that the slave is included in the property that the owner reserved for himself. Rather, <span class="gemarra-regular">we </span><span class="gemarra-regular">teach this </span><span class="it-text">halakha</span> as being <span class="gemarra-regular">due to </span>the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the document is <span class="gemarra-regular">not a bill </span>of manumission <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>completely <span class="gemarra-regular">sever</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> the bond between the slave and the master.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman says: </span>There are <span class="gemarra-regular">five </span>types of gifts to which specific <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> apply, but the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> do not apply <span class="gemarra-regular">until </span>the owners <span class="gemarra-regular">write </span>a deed granting <span class="gemarra-regular">all </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">their property</span> to another without reserving anything for themselves, <span class="gemarra-regular">and they are as follows: </span>The gift of <span class="gemarra-regular">a person on his deathbed</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> a gift to one’s Canaanite <span class="gemarra-regular">slave, </span>a gift to one’s <span class="gemarra-regular">wife, </span>a gift to one’s <span class="gemarra-regular">sons, </span>and the gift of <span class="gemarra-regular">a woman who shelters </span>her property from her prospective husband by transferring her property to another before her marriage. In this latter case the Sages instituted that if her husband dies or divorces her she can reclaim the property.
The Gemara explains each of these cases: In the case of a gift of <span class="gemarra-regular">a person on his deathbed, </span>this is <span class="gemarra-regular">as we learned </span>in the mishna (146b): With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a person on his deathbed who wrote </span>a deed granting <span class="gemarra-regular">all of his property to others, and he reserved </span>for himself <span class="gemarra-regular">any amount of land, his gift stands </span>even if he subsequently recovers. If <span class="gemarra-regular">he did not reserve </span>for himself <span class="gemarra-regular">any amount of land, </span>and he recovered, <span class="gemarra-regular">his gift does not stand, </span>as the gift was conditional upon his death, since evidently he did not intend to leave himself without means of support if he survived.
In the case of a gift to one’s <span class="gemarra-regular">slave, </span>this is <span class="gemarra-regular">as we learned </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Pe’a</span> 3:8): With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who writes </span>a deed granting <span class="gemarra-regular">all of his property to his </span>Canaanite <span class="gemarra-regular">slave, </span>the slave <span class="gemarra-regular">has been emancipated, </span>but if he <span class="gemarra-regular">reserved </span>for himself <span class="gemarra-regular">any amount of land, </span>then he <span class="gemarra-regular">has not been emancipated, </span>as perhaps he reserved the slave for himself as well.
In the case of a gift to one’s <span class="gemarra-regular">wife, </span>this is <span class="gemarra-regular">as Rav Yehuda says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel says: One who writes </span>a deed granting <span class="gemarra-regular">all of his property to his wif</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> renders her only a steward </span>of his property, i.e., he intends only to place her in charge of the property and she does not acquire it. According to Rav Naḥman, this applies only if he did not reserve any part of the property for himself.
In the case of a gift to one’s <span class="gemarra-regular">sons, </span>this is <span class="gemarra-regular">as we learned </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Pe’a</span> 3:7): With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who writes </span>a deed granting <span class="gemarra-regular">all of his property to his sons, and he writes </span>in the deed that he grants <span class="gemarra-regular">any amount of land to his wife, she forfeits </span>payment of <span class="gemarra-regular">her marriage contract</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> If he reserves any amount of land for himself, his wife does not forfeit payment of her marriage contract.
In the case of a gift of <span class="gemarra-regular">a woman who shelters </span>her property from her intended husband, this is <span class="gemarra-regular">as the Master says: </span>In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a woman who </span>wishes to <span class="gemarra-regular">shelter </span>her property from her prospective husband, <span class="gemarra-regular">she</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> must write </span>a deed granting <span class="gemarra-regular">all </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">her property </span>to another. If she reserves for herself any amount of property, she cannot reclaim the property if she is widowed or divorced.
The Gemara concludes: <span class="gemarra-regular">With regard to all of these </span>cases, reserving <span class="gemarra-regular">movable property is </span>considered a significant <span class="gemarra-regular">reserving </span>of property, <span class="gemarra-regular">except with regard to </span>a woman’s <span class="gemarra-regular">marriage contract. </span>If one grants all of his property to his sons except for any amount of land, which he gives to his wife, and he reserves for himself only movable property, his wife forfeits payment of her marriage contract, as nothing remains in the husband’s possession from which she is entitled to collect payment. This is <span class="gemarra-regular">because the Sages instituted </span>that the lien on the marriage contract is placed <span class="gemarra-regular">on land,</span> and <span class="gemarra-regular">the Sages did not institute </span>that the marriage contract can be collected <span class="gemarra-regular">from movable property.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Ameimar said: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">movable property that is </span>explicitly <span class="gemarra-regular">written in the marriage contract </span>as property from which the debt may be collected <span class="gemarra-regular">and is </span>still <span class="gemarra-regular">extant, </span>if the husband reserves this property for himself, this <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>considered a significant <span class="gemarra-regular">reserving </span>of property, and his wife does not forfeit payment of her marriage contract.
§ If one <span class="gemarra-regular">said: My property </span>shall go <span class="gemarra-regular">to so-and-so</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> anything that is referred to as property is included in the gift. A Canaanite <span class="gemarra-regular">slave is called property, as we learned </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Pe’a</span> 3:8): With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who writes, </span>i.e., gives via a document, <span class="gemarra-regular">all of his property to his </span>Canaanite <span class="gemarra-regular">slave, </span>the slave <span class="gemarra-regular">has been emancipated. Land is called property, as we learned </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Kiddushin</span> 26a): <span class="gemarra-regular">Property that serves as </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a guarantee, </span>i.e., land, <span class="gemarra-regular">can be acquired by </span>means of <span class="gemarra-regular">money, by </span>means of <span class="gemarra-regular">a deed,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> or by taking possession </span>of it. <span class="gemarra-regular">A cloak, </span>as well as other garments and movable property, <span class="gemarra-regular">is called property, as we learned </span>in that same mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>property <span class="gemarra-regular">that does not serve as a guarantee, </span>i.e., movable property, <span class="gemarra-regular">can be acquired only by pulling.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Money [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">zuzei</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is called property, as we learned </span>in that same mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>property <span class="gemarra-regular">that does not serve as a guarantee can be acquired </span>together <span class="gemarra-regular">with property that serves as a guarantee by </span>means of <span class="gemarra-regular">money, by </span>means of <span class="gemarra-regular">a deed, or by taking possession </span>of it. Money is among the types of property that can be acquired by means of the acquisition of land, <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>is evident from <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>incident <span class="gemarra-regular">involving Rav Pappa</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> who <span class="gemarra-regular">had twelve thousand dinars </span>loaned to the people of <span class="gemarra-regular">Bei Ḥozai. </span>Rav Pappa <span class="gemarra-regular">transferred </span>ownership of the money <span class="gemarra-regular">to Rav Shmuel bar Aḥa, </span>who was traveling to Bei Ḥozai, <span class="gemarra-regular">by means of </span>transferring ownership of <span class="gemarra-regular">the threshold of his house, </span>so that Rav Shmuel bar Aḥa could collect the money. <span class="gemarra-regular">When </span>Rav Shmuel bar Aḥa <span class="gemarra-regular">came </span>back with the money, Rav Pappa was so pleased that he <span class="gemarra-regular">went out as far as Tavakh to meet him.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">A deed is called property, as Rabba bar Yitzḥak says: There are two </span>types of <span class="gemarra-regular">deeds </span>with regard to the acquisition of land. If one <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>to the witnesses: <span class="gemarra-regular">Acquire this field on behalf of so-and-so and write the deed for hi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">m</span> as proof of the sale, the giver <span class="gemarra-regular">can retract the deed but he cannot retract the </span>transfer of ownership of the <span class="gemarra-regular">field </span>once the other party has taken possession of it. If one said: Acquire this field on behalf of so-and-so <span class="gemarra-regular">on the condition that you write the deed for him, </span>the giver <span class="gemarra-regular">can retract both the deed and </span>the transfer of <span class="gemarra-regular">the field, </span>as he stipulated that the acquisition of the field is dependent on the writing of the deed.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav Ḥiyya bar Avin </span>says that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna says: There are three </span>types of <span class="gemarra-regular">deeds. Two </span>are <span class="gemarra-regular">those that we stated </span>above, and <span class="gemarra-regular">the other </span>is as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">If the seller wrote the deed in advance </span>and kept it until the buyer would come and pay him. The Gemara adds parenthetically: This is <span class="gemarra-regular">like that </span><span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">that we learned </span>in a mishna (167b): 

Daf 151a

A scribe may <span class="gemarra-regular">write a deed </span>of sale <span class="gemarra-regular">for the seller </span>of property at the seller’s request, <span class="gemarra-regular">even if the buyer is not with him </span>when he presents his request, as the deed obligates only the seller. In this case, <span class="gemarra-regular">once this </span>one, the buyer, <span class="gemarra-regular">has taken possession of the land, the deed is acquired</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> wherever it is. And this is </span>as it is stated in the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">that we learned </span>(<span class="it-text">Kiddushin</span> 26a): <span class="gemarra-regular">Property that does not serve as a guarantee can be acquired </span>together <span class="gemarra-regular">with the property that serves as a guarantee by </span>means of <span class="gemarra-regular">money, by </span>means of <span class="gemarra-regular">a deed, or by taking possession </span>of it. One can learn from this that a deed is included in the term: Property that does not serve as a guarantee.
<span class="gemarra-regular">An animal is called property, as we learned </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Shekalim</span> 12a): In a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who consecrated his property, and on </span>the property <span class="gemarra-regular">there were animal</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> fit to </span>be sacrificed <span class="gemarra-regular">upon </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">altar, male </span>animals are sacrificed as <span class="gemarra-regular">burnt-offerings, and female </span>animals <span class="gemarra-regular">are sold for the purpose of </span>being sacrificed as <span class="gemarra-regular">peace-offerings. Birds are called property, as we learned </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Shekalim</span> 12a): In a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who consecrated his property,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and on </span>the property <span class="gemarra-regular">there were items that were fit to </span>be sacrificed <span class="gemarra-regular">upon </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">altar, </span>e.g., <span class="gemarra-regular">wines, oils, and birds</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> Rabbi Eliezer says: They are sold for the needs of that kind of item, i.e., to individuals who will use them as such.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Phylacteries are called property</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as we learned </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Arakhin</span> 23b): With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who consecrates his property, </span>the value of his <span class="gemarra-regular">phylacteries is assessed for hi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">m</span> and he redeems them by paying their value to the Temple treasury. <span class="gemarra-regular">A dilemma was raised before </span>the Sages: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a Torah scroll</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> what </span>is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? Is it considered property or not? Does one say that <span class="gemarra-regular">since it is not sold, as it is prohibited to sell </span>a Torah scroll, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is </span>therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">property? Or perhaps </span>one says that <span class="gemarra-regular">since it may be sold </span>in order to enable one <span class="gemarra-regular">to study Torah or to marry a woman, it is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">property. </span>The Gemara concludes: The dilemma <span class="gemarra-regular">shall stand </span>unresolved.
§ The Gemara presents <span class="gemarra-regular">a mnemonic</span> for the series of incidents stated below: <span class="gemarra-regular">Zutra, the mother, of Amram, from two sisters, Rav Tovi, and Rav Dimi and Rav Yosef.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">The mother of Rav Zutra bar Toviyya wrote </span>a deed granting <span class="gemarra-regular">her property to Rav Zutra bar Toviyya, </span>explaining that she was doing so <span class="gemarra-regular">because she wanted to get married to Rav Zevid</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and she did not want him to acquire her property. <span class="gemarra-regular">She married </span>Rav Zevid, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he divorced her. She came before Rav Beivai bar Abay</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> to claim her property from her son. Rav Beivai <span class="gemarra-regular">said: </span>She transferred her property <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>she wanted <span class="gemarra-regular">to get married, and she married. </span>Since her intentions were fulfilled, even though she subsequently was divorced, the gift is a valid gift.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, said to </span>Rav Beivai: Is it <span class="gemarra-regular">because you come from </span>a line of <span class="gemarra-regular">truncated [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">mula’ei</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] people</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> from the house of the High Priest Eli, whose descendants were condemned to premature death (see I Samuel 2:31), that <span class="gemarra-regular">you say truncated [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">mulyata</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] </span>and unsound <span class="gemarra-regular">matters? Even according to the one who says </span>that the deed of <span class="gemarra-regular">a woman who shelters </span>her property from her intended husband <span class="gemarra-regular">effects acquisition</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and the woman cannot reclaim the property, <span class="gemarra-regular">this matter </span>applies <span class="gemarra-regular">where she did not reveal her intentions </span>in transferring ownership of her property. <span class="gemarra-regular">But here, she revealed her intentions that </span>she transferred the property <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>she wanted <span class="gemarra-regular">to marry; and she married, but was divorced. </span>Therefore, since she is no longer married, she can reclaim the property.
<span class="gemarra-regular">The mother of Rami bar Ḥama wrote </span>a deed <span class="gemarra-regular">in the evening </span>granting <span class="gemarra-regular">her property to Rami bar Ḥama</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> In the morning</span> of the following day, <span class="gemarra-regular">she wrote </span>a deed granting her property <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>his brother, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ukva bar Ḥama. Rami bar Ḥama came before Rav Sheshet, </span>who <span class="gemarra-regular">established him </span>as the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">of the property, </span>as the deed transferring the property to him preceded the gift to his brother. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ukva bar Ḥama came before Rav Naḥman, </span>who <span class="gemarra-regular">established him </span>as the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">of the property.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Sheshet came before Rav Naḥman </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: What is the reason </span>that the <span class="gemarra-regular">Master established Rav Ukva bar Ḥama </span>as the owner of the property? <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">because she retracted </span>her gift, <span class="gemarra-regular">but didn’t she die? </span>Since the gift of a person on his deathbed is considered valid, Rami bar Ḥama already acquired the property in the evening. Rav Naḥman <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Rav Sheshet: <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>is what <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel says: </span>With regard to the gift of a person on his deathbed, in <span class="gemarra-regular">any </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he could retract </span>his gift <span class="gemarra-regular">if he were to recover</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., if he transferred ownership of all of his property, even if he does not recover, <span class="gemarra-regular">he can retract his gift.</span>
Rav Sheshet responded: <span class="gemarra-regular">Say that Shmuel said </span>that he can retract his gift if he wants to retain the property <span class="gemarra-regular">for himself, </span>but if he wants to retract his gift in order to give it <span class="gemarra-regular">to another, did he </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that he can do so? Rav Naḥman <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Rav Sheshet: <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel explicitly said </span>that he can retract his gift <span class="gemarra-regular">both </span>in order to retain the property <span class="gemarra-regular">for himself and </span>to grant it <span class="gemarra-regular">to another.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">The mother of Rav Amram the Piou</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> had a bundle [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">meloga</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of </span>promissory <span class="gemarra-regular">notes. When she was dying, she said: Let </span>these promissory notes <span class="gemarra-regular">be for Amram, my son. His brothers came before Rav Naḥman. They said to </span>Rav Naḥman: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>Rav Amram <span class="gemarra-regular">did not pul</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span> the bundle of documents, and since an act of acquisition was not performed he did not acquire them. Rav Naḥman <span class="gemarra-regular">said to them: </span>An act of acquisition was not required, because <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of a person on his deathbed is considered as written and as </span>though the documents were <span class="gemarra-regular">delivere</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> to the recipient.
<span class="gemarra-regular">The sister of Rav Tovi bar Rav Mattan</span><span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> wrote </span>a deed <span class="gemarra-regular">in the morning </span>granting <span class="gemarra-regular">her property to Rav Tovi bar Rav Mattana. In the evening </span>another brother, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Aḥadvoi bar Rav Mattana, came </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">cried to her. </span>Rav Aḥadvoi <span class="gemarra-regular">said to her: Now </span>people <span class="gemarra-regular">will say </span>that you gave your property to Rav Tovi because this <span class="gemarra-regular">Master, </span>Rav Tovi, is <span class="gemarra-regular">a Torah</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> scholar, and </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Master, </span>Rav Aḥadvoi, <span class="gemarra-regular">is not a Torah scholar. She wrote </span>a deed granting the property <span class="gemarra-regular">to him. </span>Rav Tovi <span class="gemarra-regular">came before Rav Naḥman. </span>Rav Naḥman <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Rav Tovi: <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>is what <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel says: </span>With regard to the gift of a person on his deathbed, in <span class="gemarra-regular">any </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he could retract </span>his gift <span class="gemarra-regular">if he were to recover, </span>even if he does not recover, <span class="gemarra-regular">he can retract his gift,</span> and therefore the property belongs to Rav Aḥadvoi.
<span class="gemarra-regular">The sister of Rav Dimi bar Yosef had a tract of </span>land in <span class="gemarra-regular">an orchard. Whenever she was sick </span>and thought that she was dying, <span class="gemarra-regular">she would transfer </span>ownership of the orchard <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>Rav Dimi, 

Daf 151b

<span class="gemarra-regular">and when she recovered she would retract </span>her gift. On <span class="gemarra-regular">one occasion she was sick. She sent </span>a message <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>Rav Dimi: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">acquire </span>my property. <span class="gemarra-regular">He sent </span>a message back to her: <span class="gemarra-regular">I do not want </span>to come. <span class="gemarra-regular">She sent </span>a message <span class="gemarra-regular">to him: Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">acquire </span>my property in <span class="gemarra-regular">any manner that you want. He went and reserved </span>for her part of the orchard, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">acquired </span>the rest of the property <span class="gemarra-regular">from he</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> with an act of acquisition. <span class="gemarra-regular">When she recovered she retracted </span>the gift.
<span class="gemarra-regular">She came before Rav Naḥman </span>to reclaim it. Rav Naḥman <span class="gemarra-regular">sent </span>a message <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>Rav Dimi: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>to court. Rav Dimi <span class="gemarra-regular">did not come. He said: What </span>reason is there for <span class="gemarra-regular">me to come? Didn’t </span>I <span class="gemarra-regular">reserve </span>part of the property for her, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>I <span class="gemarra-regular">acquired </span>the rest of the property <span class="gemarra-regular">from her </span>with an act of acquisition? Therefore, the acquisition is complete. Rav Naḥman <span class="gemarra-regular">sent </span>a message <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>Rav Dimi: <span class="gemarra-regular">If you do not come, I will strike you with a thorn [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">besileva</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that does not draw blood, </span>i.e., I will excommunicate you.
Inquiring into the matter, Rav Naḥman <span class="gemarra-regular">said to the witnesses: How did the act </span>of transferring the property take place? The witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Rav Naḥman: <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>is what <span class="gemarra-regular">she said: Woe, that woman is dying</span><span class="gemarra-regular">!</span> Rav Naḥman <span class="gemarra-regular">said to them: If so, this is </span>a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who issues directives </span>with regard to his property <span class="gemarra-regular">due to </span>his expectation of his imminent <span class="gemarra-regular">death</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> And one who issues directives due to </span>his expectation of his imminent <span class="gemarra-regular">death can retract </span>his gift even if he did not transfer all of his property, as he evidently granted the gift only because he expected to die.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">It was stated </span>that the <span class="it-text">amora’im</span> disagreed with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a gift of a person on his deathbed </span>that includes only <span class="gemarra-regular">a part </span>of his property. <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages said </span>the following <span class="gemarra-regular">before Rava in the name of Mar Zutra, son of Rav Naḥman, who said </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">in the name of Rav Naḥman: This </span>type of gift <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>in some respects <span class="gemarra-regular">like the gift of a healthy person, and </span>in other respects <span class="gemarra-regular">it is like </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">gift of a person on his deathbed. It is like the gift of a healthy person, as, if he recovers he cannot retract </span>it, as stated in the mishna. <span class="gemarra-regular">And it is like </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">gift of a person on his deathbed, as it does not require </span>an act of <span class="gemarra-regular">acquisition</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Rather, it is acquired by means of verbal instruction alone.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said to </span>the Sages: <span class="gemarra-regular">Did I not say to you: Do not hang empty pitchers [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">bukei</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> upon Rav Naḥman, </span>i.e., do not attribute incorrect statements to him? <span class="gemarra-regular">This is </span>what <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman says: </span>A gift of a person on his deathbed that includes only a part of his property <span class="gemarra-regular">is like the gift of a healthy person and requires </span>an act of <span class="gemarra-regular">acquisition. </span>If an act of acquisition is not performed, the acquisition of the gift is not effective even if the owner dies.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava raised an objection to Rav Naḥman </span>from the mishna (146b): If <span class="gemarra-regular">he reserved </span>for himself <span class="gemarra-regular">any amount of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">land, his gift stands. What, is it not </span>referring even to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the gift <span class="gemarra-regular">was not acquired from him </span>by means of an act of acquisition? <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>it is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the gift <span class="gemarra-regular">was acquired from him </span>by means of an act of acquisition. Rava asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If that is so, say the last clause </span>of the mishna: If <span class="gemarra-regular">he did not reserve </span>for himself <span class="gemarra-regular">any amount of land, </span>and he recovered, <span class="gemarra-regular">his gift does not stand. And if </span>the mishna is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the gift <span class="gemarra-regular">was acquired from him </span>by means of an act of acquisition, <span class="gemarra-regular">why does his gift not stand?</span>
Rav Naḥman <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Rava: <span class="gemarra-regular">This is </span>what <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel says: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a person on his deathbed who wrote </span>a deed granting <span class="gemarra-regular">all of his property to others </span>without reserving anything for himself, <span class="gemarra-regular">even though </span>the gift <span class="gemarra-regular">was acquired from his possession </span>by means of an act of acquisition, if <span class="gemarra-regular">he recovers, he can retract </span>his gift. The reason for this is that <span class="gemarra-regular">it is known that he was issuing directives </span>with regard to his property <span class="gemarra-regular">only due to </span>his expectation of his imminent <span class="gemarra-regular">death.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Mesharshiyya raised an objection to Rava: </span>There was <span class="gemarra-regular">an incident involving the mother of the sons of Rokhel, who was sick, and she said: My brooch [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">keveinati</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> shall be given to my daughter, and it is </span>valued <span class="gemarra-regular">at twelve hundred dinars. And </span>this woman subsequently <span class="gemarra-regular">died, and </span>the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">upheld her statement </span>even though the gift included only a part of her property and an act of acquisition was not performed. Rava replied: That incident is different, as the case <span class="gemarra-regular">there </span>is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to one who issues directives </span><span class="gemarra-regular">due to </span>his expectation of his imminent <span class="gemarra-regular">death.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Ravina raised an objection to Rava </span>from a mishna (<span class="it-text">Gittin</span> 13a): In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who says: Give this bill of divorce to my wife</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> or: </span>Give <span class="gemarra-regular">this bill of manumission to my slave</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>then he <span class="gemarra-regular">dies, one should not give it after </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">death. </span>But if one says: <span class="gemarra-regular">Give one hundred dinars to so-and-so, and </span>then he <span class="gemarra-regular">died</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> one does give </span>the recipient the money <span class="gemarra-regular">after </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">death. </span>This indicates that a gift of a person on his deathbed that includes only a part of his property does not require an act of acquisition.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And from where </span>can one learn <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the money <span class="gemarra-regular">was not acquired from him </span>by means of an act of acquisition? This is learned from the fact that this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> was juxtaposed to the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to a bill of divorce, indicating that this case is <span class="gemarra-regular">similar to a bill of divorce. Just as a bill of divorce is not subject to </span>the standard <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of an act of acquisition, <span class="gemarra-regular">so too, </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>case of the gift of one hundred dinars, the mishna is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the money <span class="gemarra-regular">was not acquired from him </span>by means of an act of acquisition. Rava replied: <span class="gemarra-regular">There, too, </span>the mishna is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to one who issues directives </span>with regard to his property <span class="gemarra-regular">due to </span>his imminent <span class="gemarra-regular">death.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, said: </span>The gift of <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span><span class="gemarra-regular">who issues directives </span>with regard to his property <span class="gemarra-regular">due to </span>his expectation of his imminent <span class="gemarra-regular">death generally requires </span>an act of <span class="gemarra-regular">acquisition</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> And when it is taught </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">these </span><span class="gemarra-italic">baraitot</span> that an act of acquisition is not required, the <span class="it-text">baraitot</span> are referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to one who divides all of his property </span>between different recipients, <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>case, the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">accorded </span>the gift the legal status of <span class="gemarra-regular">a gift of a person on his deathbed.</span>
The Gemara concludes: <span class="gemarra-regular">And the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is that <span class="gemarra-regular">a gift of a person on his deathbed </span>that includes only <span class="gemarra-regular">a part </span>of his property <span class="gemarra-regular">requires </span>an act of <span class="gemarra-regular">acquisition; </span>otherwise it is invalid <span class="gemarra-regular">even though he </span>subsequently <span class="gemarra-regular">died, </span>and the gift is inherited by his heirs instead. The gift of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who issues directives </span>with regard to his property <span class="gemarra-regular">due to </span>his expectation of his imminent <span class="gemarra-regular">death does not require </span>an act of <span class="gemarra-regular">acquisition. And this </span>applies only <span class="gemarra-regular">when </span>he subsequently <span class="gemarra-regular">died. </span>If he <span class="gemarra-regular">recovered, </span>he can <span class="gemarra-regular">retract </span>his gift <span class="gemarra-regular">even though it was acquired from him </span>by means of an act of acquisition. 

Daf 152a

§ <span class="gemarra-regular">It was stated </span>that the <span class="it-text">amora’im</span> disagreed with regard to a deed pertaining to the <span class="gemarra-regular">gift of a person on his deathbed in which </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">is written </span>that an act of <span class="gemarra-regular">acquisition </span>was also performed. In <span class="gemarra-regular">the study hall of Rav they say in the name of Rav: </span>The person on his deathbed <span class="gemarra-regular">caused </span>the recipient <span class="gemarra-regular">to mount two steeds, </span>i.e., he strengthened the validity of his gift in two different ways. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Shmuel said: I do not know what I should rule with regard to this </span>gift, as it may not be a valid gift.
The Gemara explains: In <span class="gemarra-regular">the study hall of Rav they say in the name of Rav </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">he caused him to mount two steeds. </span>On the one hand, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is like </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">gift of a healthy person, </span>but on the other hand, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is like </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">gift of a person on his deathbed. It is like </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">gift of a healthy person, as, if he recovers he cannot retract </span>the gift, because an act of acquisition was performed. <span class="gemarra-regular">It is like </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">gift of a person on his deathbed, as, if he said </span>that the <span class="gemarra-regular">loan </span>owed to <span class="gemarra-regular">him </span>should be given <span class="gemarra-regular">to so-and-so</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the <span class="gemarra-regular">loan </span>owed to <span class="gemarra-regular">him </span>is acquired <span class="gemarra-regular">by so-and-so, </span>whereas a healthy person cannot transfer his right to collect a debt except in the presence of all three parties.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Shmuel said: I do not know what I should rule with regard to this </span>gift. <span class="gemarra-regular">Perhaps</span> the fact that an act of acquisition was performed indicates that <span class="gemarra-regular">he resolved to transfer it </span>to him <span class="gemarra-regular">only with a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">deed. </span>The gift of a person on his deathbed takes effect only after he dies, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a deed is not </span>effective if it is delivered <span class="gemarra-regular">after </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">death </span>of the owner.
The Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises a contradiction between </span>this statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rav and </span>another statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav, and between </span>this statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Shmuel and </span>another statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Shmuel. </span>This is <span class="gemarra-regular">as Ravin sent in the name of Rabbi Abbahu: You should know that Rabbi Elazar sent </span>a ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">to the Diaspora, </span>i.e., Babylonia, <span class="gemarra-regular">in the name of our teacher</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> Rav: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a person on his deathbed who says: Write </span>a deed <span class="gemarra-regular">and give </span>with it <span class="gemarra-regular">one hundred dinar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to so-and-so, and </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">died </span>before the deed was written, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is not written and given </span>to that person. The reason for this is that <span class="gemarra-regular">perhaps he resolved to transfer </span>the gift to him <span class="gemarra-regular">only with </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">deed, and a deed </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is not </span>effective if it is delivered <span class="gemarra-regular">after </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">death </span>of the owner. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav Yehuda says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel says: The </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is that the deed <span class="gemarra-regular">is written and given </span>to the recipient.
The Gemara concludes: The first statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">difficult, </span>as it is apparently contradicted <span class="gemarra-regular">by </span>the other statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav, </span>and the first statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Shmuel is difficult, </span>as it is apparently contradicted <span class="gemarra-regular">by </span>the other statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Shmuel.</span>
The Gemara replies: The apparent contradiction <span class="gemarra-regular">between </span>the first statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav</span> and the other statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult. This </span>statement, that the gift is valid, is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the gift <span class="gemarra-regular">was acquired from </span>the person on his deathbed by means of an act of acquisition. <span class="gemarra-regular">That </span>other statement is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the gift <span class="gemarra-regular">was not acquired from him </span>by means of an act of acquisition, but only by verbal instruction, and therefore the deed is not written after his death. The apparent contradiction <span class="gemarra-regular">between </span>the first statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Shmuel</span> and the other statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Shmuel </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult, </span>as Shmuel’s statement that the deed is written after his death is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the giver was clearly <span class="gemarra-regular">enhancing the </span>legal <span class="gemarra-regular">power </span>of the recipient by providing him with a deed, and he was not making the gift contingent upon the delivery of a deed.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak was sitting behind Rava, and Rava was sitting before Rav Naḥman, </span>and Rava <span class="gemarra-regular">asked </span>Rav Naḥman: <span class="gemarra-regular">Did Shmuel </span>actually <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">perhaps </span>the fact that an act of acquisition was performed indicates that the person on his deathbed <span class="gemarra-regular">resolved to transfer </span>ownership of the gift <span class="gemarra-regular">only with </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">deed, and </span>therefore the gift is invalid, as <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">deed is not </span>effective if it is delivered <span class="gemarra-regular">after </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">death </span>of the owner? <span class="gemarra-regular">But doesn’t Rav Yehuda say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel says: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a person on his deathbed who wrote </span>a deed granting <span class="gemarra-regular">all of his property to others, even though </span>they <span class="gemarra-regular">performed an act of acquisition, </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">he recovers he can retract </span>his gift? 

Daf 152b

The reason for Shmuel’s ruling is that <span class="gemarra-regular">it is known that </span>an act of <span class="gemarra-regular">acquisition </span>was performed <span class="gemarra-regular">only due to </span>his expectation of imminent <span class="gemarra-regular">death. </span>This ruling indicates that if the giver does not recover, the recipient acquires the gift, and the performance of an act of acquisition does not indicate that the giver intended to transfer the property only after his death. Rav Naḥman <span class="gemarra-regular">indicated </span>the answer <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>Rava <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>a gesture of <span class="gemarra-regular">his hand</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>Rava <span class="gemarra-regular">was silent.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">When </span>Rav Naḥman <span class="gemarra-regular">arose </span>from his place, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said to Rava: What did he indicate to you </span>with that gesture? Rava <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>He indicated that the statement of Rav Yehuda is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the giver was clearly <span class="gemarra-regular">enhancing the </span>legal <span class="gemarra-regular">power </span>of the recipient by requiring an act of acquisition to be performed in addition to bestowing the gift.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is considered </span>an act of acquisition that <span class="gemarra-regular">enhances the </span>legal <span class="gemarra-regular">power </span>of the recipient? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥisda said: </span>An act of acquisition is clearly intended only to reinforce the legal power of the recipient when, for example, the following phrase is written in the deed: <span class="gemarra-regular">And we, </span>the witnesses, <span class="gemarra-regular">acquired </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">from him </span>by means of an act of acquisition <span class="gemarra-regular">in addition to this gift. </span>This indicates that the act of acquisition was not performed in order to effect the actual acquisition.
§ It is <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious </span>that if a person on his deathbed <span class="gemarra-regular">wrote </span>a deed of transfer granting his property <span class="gemarra-regular">to this </span>individual, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>he then <span class="gemarra-regular">wrote </span>a deed granting the same property <span class="gemarra-regular">to that </span>individual, i.e., a second recipient, <span class="gemarra-regular">this is </span>the case discussed by Rav Dimi. <span class="gemarra-regular">As when Rav Dimi came </span>from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia he <span class="gemarra-regular">said: </span>A later <span class="gemarra-regular">will [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">dayetikei</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> nullifies </span>an earlier <span class="gemarra-regular">will</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> The <span class="it-text">amora’im</span> disagree with regard to a case where one <span class="gemarra-regular">wrote </span>a deed of transfer <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">conferred possessio</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> of the property <span class="gemarra-regular">on this </span>individual, and then he <span class="gemarra-regular">wrote </span>a deed of transfer <span class="gemarra-regular">and conferred possession </span>of the same property <span class="gemarra-regular">on that </span>second individual. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: </span>The <span class="gemarra-regular">first </span>recipient <span class="gemarra-regular">acquires </span>the gift, <span class="gemarra-regular">and Shmuel says: </span>The <span class="gemarra-regular">second </span>recipient <span class="gemarra-regular">acquires </span>the gift.
The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says </span>that the <span class="gemarra-regular">first </span>recipient <span class="gemarra-regular">acquires </span>the gift. Since an additional act of conferring possession of the property was performed, the gift <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">like </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">gift of a healthy person, </span>which cannot be retracted. <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel says </span>that the <span class="gemarra-regular">second </span>recipient <span class="gemarra-regular">acquires </span>the gift because <span class="gemarra-regular">it is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">like </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">gift of a person on his deathbed, </span>which can be retracted.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But didn’t </span>Rav and Shmuel already <span class="gemarra-regular">disagree about this </span>matter <span class="gemarra-regular">once? With regard to </span>a deed pertaining to the <span class="gemarra-regular">gift of a person on his deathbed in which </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">is written </span>that an act of <span class="gemarra-regular">acquisition </span>was also performed, Rav maintained that the gift cannot be retracted, whereas Shmuel maintained that the acquisition was not effective. Why is it necessary to record another disagreement with regard to the same principle?
The Gemara replies: It <span class="gemarra-regular">is necessary </span>to cite both cases. This is <span class="gemarra-regular">because if it were stated </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to that </span>case, where an act of acquisition was recorded in the deed, one might say that only <span class="gemarra-regular">in that </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says </span>that the gift cannot be retracted, <span class="gemarra-regular">because an act of acquisition was </span>performed. <span class="gemarra-regular">But in this </span>case, <span class="gemarra-regular">where an act of acquisition was not </span>performed, one might <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">he concedes to Shmuel. And if it was stated </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to this </span>case, where he conferred possession of the property on the recipient through a deed alone, one might say that only <span class="gemarra-regular">in this </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel says </span>that he can retract the gift. <span class="gemarra-regular">But in the other </span>case, where an act of acquisition was recorded in the deed, one might <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that Shmuel <span class="gemarra-regular">concedes to Rav </span>that he cannot retract it. Therefore, it <span class="gemarra-regular">is necessary </span>to cite both cases.
<span class="gemarra-regular">In Sura they taught </span>the statements of Rav and Shmuel <span class="gemarra-regular">that way, </span>as stated above. <span class="gemarra-regular">In Pumbedita they taught </span>their statements <span class="gemarra-regular">like this</span><span class="gemarra-regular">:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rav Yirmeya bar Abba says: </span>After the death of Rav, the following question <span class="gemarra-regular">was sent from the study hall of Rav to Shmuel: Let our teacher teach us: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a person on his deathbed who wrote </span>a deed of transfer granting <span class="gemarra-regular">all </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">his property to others, and they performed an act of acquisition, what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? Shmuel <span class="gemarra-regular">sent to them </span>in reply: <span class="gemarra-regular">After </span>an act of <span class="gemarra-regular">acquisition </span>is performed, <span class="gemarra-regular">nothing </span>can effect a retraction of the gift. 

Daf 153a

Rav’s disciples <span class="gemarra-regular">understood from this </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">this statement </span>applies only when the person on his deathbed wishes to retract his gift and transfer it <span class="gemarra-regular">to another. But </span>if he recovers and wishes to retract the gift and retain it <span class="gemarra-regular">for himself, </span>Shmuel’s statement <span class="gemarra-regular">does not </span>apply. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥisda said to them: When Rav Huna came from Kufrei, he explained </span>that Shmuel’s statement applies <span class="gemarra-regular">both </span>to retaining the property <span class="gemarra-regular">for himself and </span>to transferring it <span class="gemarra-regular">to others.</span>
The Gemara relates: There was <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain </span>person on his deathbed who wrote a deed of transfer granting his property to another, and <span class="gemarra-regular">it was acquired from him </span>by means of an act of acquisition. He subsequently recovered and wanted to retract the gift, and <span class="gemarra-regular">he came before Rav Huna. </span>Rav Huna <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>to him: <span class="gemarra-regular">What can I do for you? </span>You cannot retract the gift, <span class="gemarra-regular">as you did not transfer </span>the gift <span class="gemarra-regular">in the manner that people </span>on their deathbed <span class="gemarra-regular">transfer </span>ownership of gifts, and you enhanced the legal power of the recipient by performing an act of acquisition.
§ The Gemara relates: There was a deed pertaining to <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain gift </span>of a person on his deathbed, <span class="gemarra-regular">in</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> which it was written </span>that the gift is given both <span class="gemarra-regular">in life and in death</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> In such a case, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: It is like </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">gift of a person on his deathbed, </span>and if he recovers he can retract it. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Shmuel says: It is like </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">gift of a healthy person, </span>and he cannot retract it.
The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: It is like </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">gift of a person on his deathbed. </span>This can be inferred <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that it is written in </span>the deed that the gift is given <span class="gemarra-regular">in death. </span>This means that the giver <span class="gemarra-regular">is saying to him </span>that the gift should take effect <span class="gemarra-regular">after </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">death, and that which is written </span>in the deed, that the gift is given <span class="gemarra-regular">in life, </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">merely </span>an auspicious <span class="gemarra-regular">omen, </span>expressing hope <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the giver <span class="gemarra-regular">will live.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Shmuel says: It is like </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">gift of a healthy person. </span>This can be inferred <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that it is written in </span>the deed that the gift is given <span class="gemarra-regular">in life. </span>This means that the giver <span class="gemarra-regular">is saying </span>that the gift takes effect <span class="gemarra-regular">during </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">life, </span>i.e., immediately. <span class="gemarra-regular">And that which he wrote, </span>that the gift is given <span class="gemarra-regular">in death, is like</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> one who says: From now and for evermore, </span>i.e., that the gift is not retractable. The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">of Neharde’a say: The </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: And if it was written in </span>the deed that the gift is given <span class="gemarra-regular">during life </span>and in death, the recipient <span class="gemarra-regular">acquires </span>the gift and it cannot be retracted, as this term indicates that the gift takes effect while the giver still lives.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Ameimar said: The </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is not in accordance with </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rava. Rav Ashi said to Ameimar: </span>Isn’t that <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious, as </span>the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">of Neharde’a say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav? </span>Ameimar replied: <span class="gemarra-regular">Lest you say </span>that with regard to the term: <span class="gemarra-regular">During life, Rav concede</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> that the giver intends for the gift to take effect immediately, Ameimar <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>that since the giver also mentioned death, he intended the gift as the gift of a person on his deathbed and he can retract it.
The Gemara relates: There was <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain </span>person who wrote in the deed that the gift is given in life and in death. When he recovered he wanted to retract the gift. He <span class="gemarra-regular">came before Rav Naḥman in Neharde’a. </span>Rav Naḥman <span class="gemarra-regular">sent him to </span>appear <span class="gemarra-regular">before Rabbi Yirmeya bar Abba in Shum Tamya. </span>Rav Naḥman <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>in explanation of his actions: <span class="gemarra-regular">Here, </span>Neharde’a, <span class="gemarra-regular">is the place of Shmuel. </span>Consequently, Shmuel’s rulings should be followed, and therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">how can we act in accordance </span><span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span>
