The Gemara relates: There was <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain </span>woman who wrote in the deed that the gift is given during life and in death. She <span class="gemarra-regular">came before Rava. Rava acted with regard to her </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with his halakhic </span>ruling, and he ruled that she cannot retract the gift. She did not accept the ruling, and <span class="gemarra-regular">she </span>constantly <span class="gemarra-regular">troubled him,</span> saying that he had not judged her case properly.
Rava <span class="gemarra-regular">said to Rav Pappa, his scribe, son of Rav Ḥanan: Go, write for her </span>a ruling in her favor, <span class="gemarra-regular">and write in </span>the ruling the phrase: He may <span class="gemarra-regular">hire </span>replacements <span class="gemarra-regular">at their </span>expense, <span class="gemarra-regular">or deceive them </span>to get them to return to work. This is a phrase from the mishna (<span class="it-text">Bava</span> <span class="it-text">Metzia</span> 75b) that discusses the ruling in the case of one who hired laborers to perform a task that cannot be delayed, and they quit. Rava intended this phrase to indicate to the court that the ruling was merely a ruse in order to persuade the woman to leave. The woman understood the ruse. <span class="gemarra-regular">She said: May his ship sink; you are deceiving me. Rava had his clothes immersed in water </span>so that the curse should be fulfilled in this alternative manner, <span class="gemarra-regular">but even so he was not saved from </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">sinking </span>of his ship.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If one <span class="gemarra-regular">did not write in </span>the deed that he was <span class="gemarra-regular">on his </span><span class="gemarra-regular">deathbed</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and he then recovered and wished to retract the gift, and <span class="gemarra-regular">he says: I was on my deathbed, </span>and since I recovered, I can retract the gift, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>the recipients <span class="gemarra-regular">say: You were </span><span class="gemarra-regular">healthy</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and the gift cannot be retracted, the giver <span class="gemarra-regular">must bring proof that he was on his deathbed </span>in order to retract the gift. This is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of Rabbi Meir. And the Rabbis say: The burden of proof rests upon the claimant, </span>and since the property is in the possession of the giver, the recipients must bring proof that they have the right to receive it.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> There was a deed pertaining to <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain gift </span>of a person on his deathbed, <span class="gemarra-regular">in</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> which it was written </span>that the gift was bestowed <span class="gemarra-regular">when </span>the giver <span class="gemarra-regular">was sick and lying in his bed, but </span>the continuation of the standard formula: <span class="gemarra-regular">And from his sickness he departed to his </span>eternal <span class="gemarra-regular">home, was not written in </span><span class="gemarra-regular">it</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> The giver’s heirs claimed that although he was ill when he wrote the deed, he later recovered, and his gift is not valid. 

Daf 153b

<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba said: He is dead</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and his grave proves </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span>died. It may therefore be assumed that he did not recover from his sickness, and his gift remains valid. <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said to him: And now, if </span>in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a ship </span>that sank, <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the fate of <span class="gemarra-regular">most of </span>the passengers of sunken ships is <span class="gemarra-regular">to perish, </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">stringencies of </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">living and </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">stringencies of </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">dead are applied to the</span><span class="gemarra-regular">m</span> due to the uncertainty as to whether they are alive or dead, in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">sick people, where </span>the fate of <span class="gemarra-regular">most sick people </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>return to <span class="gemarra-regular">life, all the more so </span>is it <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>clear that one should assume that he recovered from the illness and his gift is invalid?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, said: In accordance with whose </span>opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">is that </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of Rabba? </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Natan, as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: With regard to a case where one who gave his property to others claims that since he was on his deathbed at the time he can retract the gifts, and the recipients claim that he was healthy and cannot retract it, <span class="gemarra-regular">who removes </span>the property <span class="gemarra-regular">from whose possession? </span>The giver <span class="gemarra-regular">can remove </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the recipients’ <span class="gemarra-regular">possession without proof</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as the property was previously established to be in his possession, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>the recipients <span class="gemarra-regular">can remove </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the giver’s <span class="gemarra-regular">possession only with proof. </span>This is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of Rabbi Ya’akov.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Natan says: </span>The presumption is that the current situation reflects the situation at the time the gift was bestowed. Therefore, <span class="gemarra-regular">if he is </span>currently <span class="gemarra-regular">healthy, </span>the obligation <span class="gemarra-regular">is upon him to bring proof that he was on his deathbed </span>when he gave his property to others. <span class="gemarra-regular">If he is </span>currently <span class="gemarra-regular">on his deathbed, </span>the obligation <span class="gemarra-regular">is upon </span>the recipients <span class="gemarra-regular">to bring proof that he was healthy </span>then.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar says: And with regard to </span>a case of uncertain <span class="gemarra-regular">ritual impurity, </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> depends <span class="gemarra-regular">on </span>the same <span class="gemarra-regular">dispute. </span>This is <span class="gemarra-regular">as we learned </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Teharot</span> 6:7): The <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is that a case where it is uncertain if something or someone became impure in the public domain, the item or person is deemed pure. With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">an expanse of fields, in the summer, </span>when many people pass through the fields, it <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">the private domain with regard to </span>the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">Shabbat, but </span>it is considered <span class="gemarra-regular">the public domain with regard to </span>the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">ritual impurity</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and if one is uncertain as to whether he was rendered impure there, he is deemed pure.
<span class="gemarra-regular">In the rainy season, </span>when not many people pass through the fields, an expanse of fields is considered <span class="gemarra-regular">the private domain </span>both <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to this, </span>Shabbat, <span class="gemarra-regular">and with regard to that</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> ritual impurity. Therefore, if one is uncertain whether he was rendered impure there, he is deemed impure. If one does not know whether the day he entered the expanse of fields was considered part of the summer or the rainy season, and he is uncertain whether he was rendered impure there, Rabbi Ya’akov maintains that he retains the status of purity that he held before entering the fields. According to Rabbi Natan, it is presumed that he entered the fields during the same season in which he came to ask whether he was rendered impure.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava </span>disagrees with Rabbi Elazar and <span class="gemarra-regular">says: They taught </span>the ruling of the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>with regard to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where the rainy season has not </span>yet <span class="gemarra-regular">passed over </span>the fields after the possibility arose that the fields contained impurity. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">the rainy season has </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">passed over </span>the fields, it is considered <span class="gemarra-regular">the private domain </span>both <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to this, </span>Shabbat, <span class="gemarra-regular">and with regard to that, </span>ritual impurity. Even though the one who passed through the fields came to ask about his status in the summer, when the fields should be considered the public domain, he is nevertheless deemed impure even according to Rabbi Natan, and there is no parallel dispute with regard to uncertain ritual impurity.
§ The mishna teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">And the Rabbis say: The burden of proof rests upon the claimant, </span>and since the property is in the possession of the giver, the recipients must bring proof that they have the right to receive it. 

Daf 154a

The Gemara asks: With regard to the <span class="gemarra-regular">proof </span>that the recipients must bring, <span class="gemarra-regular">in what </span>manner is it brought? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna says: </span>The <span class="gemarra-regular">proof </span>is presented <span class="gemarra-regular">by </span>bringing <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses </span>who testify that the giver was healthy. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥisda and Rabba bar Rav Huna say: </span>The <span class="gemarra-regular">proof </span>is presented <span class="gemarra-regular">by </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">ratification of the deed, </span>i.e., the recipients are required only to ascertain that the signatures of the witnesses on the deed are authentic in order to prove that it is not forged.
The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna says </span>that the <span class="gemarra-regular">proof </span>is presented <span class="gemarra-regular">by </span>bringing <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses. </span>He maintains that Rabbi Meir and the Rabbis <span class="gemarra-regular">disagree with</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> regard to </span>the issue that is the subject of <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">dispute of Rabbi Ya’akov and Rabbi Natan </span>in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> (153b).
The Gemara notes <span class="gemarra-regular">a mnemonic </span>device that indicates which tannaitic opinions are correlated: <span class="gemarra-italic">Manniaḥ</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>which represents the letters <span class="it-text">mem</span>, <span class="it-text">nun</span>, <span class="it-text">yod</span>, <span class="it-text">ḥet</span>, stands for Meir, Natan, Ya’akov, and the Rabbis [<span class="it-text">ḥakhamim</span>]. This indicates that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir, </span>who says that the giver must bring proof that he was on his deathbed, holds <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Natan, </span>who maintains that one presumes that the current situation reflects the situation at the time the gift was bestowed. <span class="gemarra-regular">And the Rabbis, </span>who say that the recipients must bring proof that the giver was healthy, hold <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ya’akov</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥisda and Rabba bar Rav Huna say </span>that the <span class="gemarra-regular">proof </span>is presented <span class="gemarra-regular">by </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">ratification of the deed. </span>The Gemara explains: Rav Ḥisda and Rabba bar Rav Huna maintain that Rabbi Meir and the Rabbis <span class="gemarra-regular">disagree with regard to </span>whether when there is a debtor <span class="gemarra-regular">who </span><span class="gemarra-regular">admits that he wrote </span>a promissory <span class="gemarra-regular">note</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the creditor <span class="gemarra-regular">must ratify i</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> in court in order to collect payment. The same ruling would apply to a case where the person on his deathbed admits that he wrote the deed granting the gift. They explain <span class="gemarra-regular">that</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rabbi Meir holds </span>that when there is a debtor <span class="gemarra-regular">who admits that he wrote </span>a promissory <span class="gemarra-regular">note, </span>the creditor <span class="gemarra-regular">need not ratify it </span>in court in order to collect payment, and in this case the giver cannot invalidate the deed by claiming that he was on his deathbed. <span class="gemarra-regular">But the Rabbis hold </span>that even when there is a debtor <span class="gemarra-regular">who admits that he wrote </span>a promissory <span class="gemarra-regular">note, </span>the creditor <span class="gemarra-regular">must ratify it </span>in court in order to collect payment.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But didn’t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> they </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">disagree with regard to this </span>matter <span class="gemarra-regular">once? As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: With regard to witnesses who ratified their signatures but claimed that at the time they signed the document they were not fit to bear witness, their testimony is <span class="gemarra-regular">not deemed credible to invalidate </span>the document; this is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of Rabbi Meir. And the Rabbis say: </span>Their testimony is <span class="gemarra-regular">deemed credible</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
The Gemara answers: It <span class="gemarra-regular">is necessary </span>to state both cases, <span class="gemarra-regular">because if </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>case with regard to witnesses who disqualified their testimony <span class="gemarra-regular">was stated, </span>one might think that <span class="gemarra-regular">the Sages say </span>that their testimony is accepted only <span class="gemarra-regular">in that </span>case, <span class="gemarra-regular">due to </span>the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the testimony of <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses is powerfu</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and they can impair </span>the validity of the <span class="gemarra-regular">document, but here, </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">him, </span>the giver, <span class="gemarra-regular">who </span>admitted that he wrote the deed but it <span class="gemarra-regular">is not in his </span>power to impair the validity of the deed, <span class="gemarra-regular">I would say </span>that his claim is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>accepted.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>case, with regard to a debtor who admits that he wrote a promissory note, <span class="gemarra-regular">was stated, </span>one might think that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir says </span>that the giver cannot invalidate the deed only <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to this </span>case, <span class="gemarra-regular">but with regard to that </span>case, where the witnesses ratified their signatures, <span class="gemarra-regular">I would say </span>that Rabbi Meir <span class="gemarra-regular">concedes to the Rabbis </span>that witnesses can invalidate the deed. Therefore, it <span class="gemarra-regular">is necessary </span>to state the dispute in both cases.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabba also says: </span>With regard to the <span class="gemarra-regular">proof </span>that the recipients must present, it is presented <span class="gemarra-regular">by </span>bringing <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesse</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> who testify that the giver was healthy. <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said to him: What is the reason </span>for this? <span class="gemarra-regular">If we say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">due to </span>the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that in all </span>deeds of gift the following formulation <span class="gemarra-regular">is written: When he was walking on his feet in the marketplace, </span>which indicates that the gift was the gift of a healthy person, <span class="gemarra-regular">and in this </span>deed this <span class="gemarra-regular">was not written, </span>therefore one may <span class="gemarra-regular">conclude from </span>the deed that the giver <span class="gemarra-regular">was on his deathbed, </span>that is not correct. <span class="gemarra-regular">On the contrary, </span>one could say that <span class="gemarra-regular">due to </span>the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that in all </span>deeds concerning the gifts of a person on his deathbed the following <span class="gemarra-regular">is written: When he was sick and lying in his bed, and in this </span>deed this <span class="gemarra-regular">was not written, </span>therefore one may <span class="gemarra-regular">conclude from </span>the deed that the giver <span class="gemarra-regular">was healthy.</span>
Rabba replied: Since one <span class="gemarra-regular">can say this and </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">can say that, </span>nothing can be concluded from the formulation of the deed. Therefore, due to the uncertainty, <span class="gemarra-regular">establish the property in the possession of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">its </span>last known <span class="gemarra-regular">owner.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>this dispute with regard to the statement of the Rabbis is also the subject <span class="gemarra-regular">of a dispute </span>between other <span class="it-text">amora’im</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">as Rabbi Yoḥanan says: </span>The <span class="gemarra-regular">proof </span>is presented <span class="gemarra-regular">by </span>bringing <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses, and Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish says: </span>The <span class="gemarra-regular">proof </span>is presented <span class="gemarra-regular">by </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">ratification of the deed.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan raised an objection to Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish </span>from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: There was <span class="gemarra-regular">an incident in Bnei Brak involving one who sold </span>some <span class="gemarra-regular">of his father’s propert</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span> that he had inherited, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he died, and </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">members of </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">family came and contested </span>the sale, <span class="gemarra-regular">saying: He was a mino</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> at the time of </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">death, </span>and therefore the sale was not valid. <span class="gemarra-regular">And they came and asked Rabbi Akiva: What is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? Is it permitted to exhume the corpse in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to examine it </span>and ascertain whether or not the heir was a minor at the time of his death? Rabbi Akiva <span class="gemarra-regular">said to them: </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">not permitted </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">you to disgrace him</span> for the sake of a monetary claim. <span class="gemarra-regular">And furthermore, signs </span>indicating puberty <span class="gemarra-regular">are likely to chang</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> after death, </span>and therefore nothing can be proved by exhuming the body. 

Daf 154b

Rabbi Yoḥanan explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, according to my </span>explanation of the mishna, <span class="gemarra-regular">that I say </span>that the <span class="gemarra-regular">proof </span>must be presented <span class="gemarra-regular">by </span>bringing <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses, </span>I can explain the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">Since </span>Rabbi Akiva <span class="gemarra-regular">said to the buyers: Bring witnesses, and they did not find </span>witnesses, <span class="gemarra-regular">this is </span>the reason <span class="gemarra-regular">that they came and said to him: What is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? Is it permitted <span class="gemarra-regular">to examine him? But according to you, that you say </span>that the <span class="gemarra-regular">proof </span>is presented <span class="gemarra-regular">by ratification of the deed, why do they </span>need <span class="gemarra-regular">to examine him? Let them ratify their deed and they shall be established </span>as owners <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the property.</span>
Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish replies: <span class="gemarra-regular">Do you maintain </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the property stood in the possession of </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">members of </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">family and the buyers came and contested </span>their possession of the property? Rather, <span class="gemarra-regular">the property stood in the possession of </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">buyers</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">members of </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">family came and contested </span>the sale. Since they claimed that the deed was invalid, they could not prove their claim by ratifying the deed, but only by bringing witnesses or examining the body.
<span class="gemarra-regular">This, too, stands to reason, as </span>Rabbi Akiva <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>the claimants: <span class="gemarra-regular">You are not permitted to disgrace him, and they were silent. Granted, if you say </span>that the <span class="gemarra-regular">members of </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">family were contesting </span>the sale, <span class="gemarra-regular">due to that </span>reason <span class="gemarra-regular">they were silent, </span>as they accepted that they should not disgrace their relative. <span class="gemarra-regular">But if you say </span>that the <span class="gemarra-regular">buyers were contesting </span>the claim of the relatives, <span class="gemarra-regular">why were they silent? They should have said to </span>Rabbi Akiva: <span class="gemarra-regular">We gave him money, </span>and if our right to the property cannot be proven without disgracing him, <span class="gemarra-regular">let him be disgraced.</span>
The Gemara rejects this argument: <span class="gemarra-regular">If it is due to that</span> reason, i.e., this claim they could have said, <span class="gemarra-regular">there is no </span>conclusive <span class="gemarra-regular">argument. This is what </span>Rabbi Akiva <span class="gemarra-regular">said to them: One </span>reason to prohibit exhuming the body is <span class="gemarra-regular">that you are not permitted to disgrace him. And furthermore, if you should say: He took </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">money; let him be disgraced, </span>in any event nothing can be proved by exhuming the body, as <span class="gemarra-regular">signs </span>indicating puberty <span class="gemarra-regular">are likely to change after death.</span>
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a proof: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish aske</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rabbi Yoḥanan </span>about <span class="gemarra-regular">that which is taught in the Mishna of bar Kappara</span><span class="gemarra-regular">:</span> There was one <span class="gemarra-regular">who was continually enjoying </span>the profits from <span class="gemarra-regular">a field</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and it was the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption that it was his, and someone contested his </span>claim, <span class="gemarra-regular">saying: It is mine. And that </span>person, who was profiting from the field, <span class="gemarra-regular">produced a deed, </span>in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to say: </span>It is mine, <span class="gemarra-regular">as you sold </span>this field <span class="gemarra-regular">to me, or: </span>It is mine, <span class="gemarra-regular">as you gave me </span>this field <span class="gemarra-regular">as a gift. If </span>the one who protested his claim <span class="gemarra-regular">said: I do not recognize that deed </span>as one that I have <span class="gemarra-regular">ever </span>written, <span class="gemarra-regular">the deed </span>must <span class="gemarra-regular">be ratified through its signatures.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>the one who protested his claim <span class="gemarra-regular">said: This is a document of appeasement </span><span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">shtar </span><span class="gemarra-italic">p</span><span class="gemarra-italic">assim</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> a document written only so that the holder should appear wealthy, <span class="gemarra-regular">or a document of trust</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> which means <span class="gemarra-regular">that I sold </span>the field <span class="gemarra-regular">to you </span>and provided you with the deed, trusting you to provide payment, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>since <span class="gemarra-regular">you did not give me </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">money </span>the sale is void, then <span class="gemarra-regular">if there are witnesses, follow </span>the testimony of the <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses, and if not, follow the deed.</span>
Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish concludes: According to your explanation, the Rabbis maintain that even if the deed is ratified the claimant cannot take possession of the property without bringing witnesses. If so, <span class="gemarra-regular">shall we say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir, who says </span>that when there is a debtor <span class="gemarra-regular">who admits that he wrote </span>a promissory <span class="gemarra-regular">note, </span>the creditor <span class="gemarra-regular">is not required </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to ratify it </span>in court in order to collect payment, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis?</span>
Rabbi Yoḥanan <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>it is not so. <span class="gemarra-regular">As I say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">everyone agrees </span>that in the case of a debtor <span class="gemarra-regular">who admits that </span><span class="gemarra-regular">he wrote </span>a promissory <span class="gemarra-regular">note, </span>the creditor <span class="gemarra-regular">is not required to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> ratify it </span>in court in order to collect payment. Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish asked: <span class="gemarra-regular">But don’t they disagree, as we learned </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: With regard to witnesses who ratified their signatures but claimed that they were not fit to bear witness when they signed the deed, their testimony is <span class="gemarra-regular">not deemed credible to invalidate </span>the document; this is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of Rabbi Meir. And the Rabbis say: </span>Their testimony is <span class="gemarra-regular">deemed credible.</span>
Rabbi Yoḥanan <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish: Even <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>the testimony of <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses is powerful and they impair </span>the validity of the <span class="gemarra-regular">deed, </span>which they admit to have written, with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">him, </span>the giver, <span class="gemarra-regular">is it in his </span>power to impair the validity of a deed that he admits to have written? Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Rabbi Yoḥanan: <span class="gemarra-regular">But wasn’t it stated in your name </span>with regard to the aforementioned incident in Bnei Brak: The <span class="gemarra-regular">members of </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">family contested </span>the claim <span class="gemarra-regular">correctly, </span>even though they admitted that the deed was authentic? This means that the claimant is required to ratify the deed. Rabbi Yoḥanan <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish: <span class="gemarra-regular">That </span>statement <span class="gemarra-regular">was stated </span>in my name by Rabbi <span class="gemarra-regular">Elazar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> my disciple, but <span class="gemarra-regular">I never said that statement.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Zeira says: If Rabbi Yoḥanan denies </span>the statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Elazar, his disciple, will </span>Rabbi Yoḥanan also <span class="gemarra-regular">deny that </span>which he said to <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yannai, his teacher? </span>This is <span class="gemarra-regular">as Rabbi Yannai says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">says: </span>When there is a debtor <span class="gemarra-regular">who admits that he wrote </span>a promissory <span class="gemarra-regular">note, </span>the creditor <span class="gemarra-regular">is not required to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">ratify it </span>in court in order to collect the payment. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Yoḥanan said to </span>Rabbi Yannai: <span class="gemarra-regular">My teacher, is this not </span>the case discussed in <span class="gemarra-regular">our mishna, </span>which states to the contrary: <span class="gemarra-regular">And the Rabbis say: The burden of proof rests upon the claimant? </span>Rabbi Yoḥanan concludes: The <span class="gemarra-regular">proof </span>mentioned in this mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">is nothing other </span>than <span class="gemarra-regular">ratification of the deed. </span>This indicates that Rabbi Yoḥanan maintains that according to the opinion of the Rabbis, the recipient is required to ratify the deed. If so, why does he state that everyone agrees that the recipient is not required to ratify the deed?
Rabbi Zeira explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">Indeed, the statement of our teacher, </span>Rav <span class="gemarra-regular">Yosef, appears </span>to be correct, <span class="gemarra-regular">as our teacher </span>Rav <span class="gemarra-regular">Yosef says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel says: </span>The opinions here should be reversed. <span class="gemarra-regular">This, </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> taught by bar Kappara, according to which the deed does not require ratification, <span class="gemarra-regular">is the statement of the Rabbis. But Rabbi Meir says </span>that when there is a debtor <span class="gemarra-regular">who admits that he wrote </span>a promissory <span class="gemarra-regular">note, </span>the creditor <span class="gemarra-regular">is not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">required to ratify it </span>in court in order to collect payment. <span class="gemarra-regular">And what </span>is the meaning of Rabbi Yoḥanan’s statement that <span class="gemarra-regular">everyone agrees </span>that in this case, the recipient is not required to ratify the deed? Rabbi Yoḥanan means that this is the statement of the Rabbis, and a statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of the Rabbis that </span>is disputed only <span class="gemarra-regular">by Rabbi Meir is </span>tantamount to <span class="gemarra-regular">a statement </span>accepted <span class="gemarra-regular">by all.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But didn’t we learn the opposite </span>in the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">And the Rabbis say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the burden of proof rests upon the claimant? </span>This means that the recipient is required to ratify the deed. The Gemara replies: <span class="gemarra-regular">Reverse </span>the opinions in the mishna. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t it taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: With regard to witnesses who ratified their signatures but claimed that they were not fit to bear witness, their testimony is <span class="gemarra-regular">not deemed credible to invalidate </span>the document; this is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of Rabbi Meir. And the Rabbis say: </span>Their testimony is <span class="gemarra-regular">deemed credible. </span>This indicates that according to the Rabbis the document requires ratification. The Gemara answers: Here too, <span class="gemarra-regular">reverse </span>the opinions.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But doesn’t Rabbi Yoḥanan say </span>with regard to the proof that the recipient is required to bring, that the <span class="gemarra-regular">proof </span>is presented <span class="gemarra-regular">by </span>bringing <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesse</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> who testify that the giver was healthy, and not by ratifying the deed? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Reverse </span>the opinions of Rabbi Yoḥanan and Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish. Rabbi Yoḥanan maintains that the recipient is required to prove his claim only by ratifying the deed, whereas Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish maintains that the recipient is required to bring witnesses. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Shall we say </span>that we should <span class="gemarra-regular">also reverse the objection </span>that Rabbi Yoḥanan raised to Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish previously, and say that Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish raised the objection to Rabbi Yoḥanan? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>that is unnecessary.

<span class="gemarra-regular">This is what Rabbi Yoḥanan said to Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish: Granted, according to my </span>explanation of the mishna, <span class="gemarra-regular">that I say </span>that presenting <span class="gemarra-regular">proof through </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">ratification of the deed </span>is sufficient in order to enable the recipient to claim the gift, <span class="gemarra-regular">this is </span>the reason <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>with regard to the incident in Bnei Brak <span class="gemarra-regular">you find </span>the possibility <span class="gemarra-regular">that the buyers take possession of the propert</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span> by ratifying the deed. It is therefore possible that the buyers held the property, and the relatives were claiming it from them. <span class="gemarra-regular">But according to you, that you say </span>that the <span class="gemarra-regular">proof </span>must be presented <span class="gemarra-regular">by </span>bringing <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses, how can you find </span>circumstances in <span class="gemarra-regular">which the buyers take possession of the property, </span>since they have no proof?
Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Rabbi Yoḥanan: <span class="gemarra-regular">I concede to you with regard to </span>a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">members of </span>the deceased’s <span class="gemarra-regular">family contested </span>the legality of the buyers’ claim <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>their <span class="gemarra-regular">contesting </span>the legality of that claim <span class="gemarra-regular">is not </span>taken into consideration, since they are contesting the deed held by the buyers. It is therefore possible for the buyers to take possession of the property, as in this case <span class="gemarra-regular">what do </span>the relatives <span class="gemarra-regular">say? </span>They say that the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">was a minor. </span>But there is a <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses do not sign the document unless </span>the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">has become an adult</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> In the mishna, by contrast, there is no presumption that counters the giver’s claim that he was on his deathbed. The recipient is therefore required to bring proof that the giver was healthy.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">It was stated </span>that there was a dispute with regard to the following matter: <span class="gemarra-regular">From when, </span>i.e., from what age, <span class="gemarra-regular">can a minor</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> sell his </span>deceased <span class="gemarra-regular">father’s property</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rava </span>says that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman says: </span>From the time he is <span class="gemarra-regular">eighteen years old, and Rav Huna bar Ḥinnana </span>says that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman says: From </span>the time he is <span class="gemarra-regular">twenty years old. </span>The Gemara notes: <span class="gemarra-regular">And this </span>statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rava was not stated explicitly; rather, it was stated by inference.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Zeira raises an objection </span>from the aforementioned <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: There was <span class="gemarra-regular">an incident in Bnei Brak involving one who sold </span>some <span class="gemarra-regular">of his father’s property, </span>which he had inherited, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he died, and </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">members of </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">family came and contested </span>the sale, <span class="gemarra-regular">saying: He was a minor at the time of </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">death, </span>and therefore the sale was not valid. <span class="gemarra-regular">And they came and asked Rabbi Akiva: What is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? Is it permitted to exhume the corpse in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to examine it </span>and ascertain whether or not the heir was a minor at the time of his death? Rabbi Akiva <span class="gemarra-regular">said to them: </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">not permitted </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">you to disgrace him </span>for the sake of a monetary claim. <span class="gemarra-regular">And furthermore, signs </span>indicating puberty <span class="gemarra-regular">are likely to change after death, </span>and therefore nothing can be proved by exhuming the body. Rabbi Zeira explains the objection: <span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, according to the one who says </span>that the heir can sell the property once he is <span class="gemarra-regular">eighteen years old, </span>

Daf 155b

<span class="gemarra-regular">this is </span>the reason <span class="gemarra-regular">that they came and said to </span>Rabbi Akiva: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? Is it permitted <span class="gemarra-regular">to examine </span>the corpse? <span class="gemarra-regular">But if you say </span>that he can sell the property <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the time he is <span class="gemarra-regular">twenty </span>years <span class="gemarra-regular">old, </span>even <span class="gemarra-regular">if they examine him, what of it? But didn’t we learn </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Nidda</span> 47b): With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a twenty-</span>year<span class="gemarra-regular">-old </span>man <span class="gemarra-regular">who did not develop two </span>pubic <span class="gemarra-regular">hairs</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> proof must be brought that he is twenty </span>years <span class="gemarra-regular">old, </span>and then he is no longer considered a minor. <span class="gemarra-regular">And he is the sexually underdeveloped man, </span>who is excluded from the mitzva of levirate marriage. Therefore, if his married brother dies childless, <span class="gemarra-regular">he neither performs </span><span class="gemarra-italic">ḥalitza</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> nor enters into levirate marriag</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> with his widow. Since a twenty-year-old is considered an adult even if he has not developed signs of puberty, there is no reason to examine the body.
The Gemara replies: <span class="gemarra-regular">Wasn’t it stated with regard to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that </span>mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shmuel bar Rav Yitzḥak says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: And </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> only <span class="gemarra-regular">where he developed the signs of a sexually underdeveloped man? </span>Otherwise, a twenty-year-old who has not developed two pubic hairs is still considered a minor. The examination of the deceased could therefore be effective to see if he has other signs of being sexually underdeveloped. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: </span>The language of the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> also precise, as it teaches: And he is the sexually underdeveloped man. </span>The usage of the definitive article indicates that the mishna is referring to one who is clearly a sexually underdeveloped man. The Gemara affirms: One can <span class="gemarra-regular">conclude from </span>the mishna that the mishna is speaking of one who developed the signs of a sexually underdeveloped man.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And if he did not develop the signs of a sexually</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> underdeveloped man</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> until when </span>is he considered a minor if he does not develop two pubic hairs? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ḥiyya teaches </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: He is considered a minor <span class="gemarra-regular">until most of his years </span>have elapsed, i.e., until he is thirty-five years old. <span class="gemarra-regular">When </span>the case of one who had not developed pubic hair <span class="gemarra-regular">would come before Rabbi Ḥiyya, </span>he would offer the following advice: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>the person was <span class="gemarra-regular">thin, he </span>would <span class="gemarra-regular">say to </span>those appearing in court: Cause him <span class="gemarra-regular">to become fat, and if he was fat, he </span>would <span class="gemarra-regular">say to them: </span>Cause him <span class="gemarra-regular">to become thin. </span>This is <span class="gemarra-regular">because these signs </span>indicating puberty <span class="gemarra-regular">sometimes develop due to </span>excessive <span class="gemarra-regular">thinness, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">sometimes they develop due to corpulence</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">A dilemma was raised before </span>the Sages: <span class="gemarra-regular">During </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">time, </span>i.e., the year, when a minor comes of age with regard to selling his deceased father’s property, i.e., during his eighteenth or twentieth year, is this year considered <span class="gemarra-regular">as before </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">time</span> that he comes of age <span class="gemarra-regular">or </span>is it considered <span class="gemarra-regular">as after </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">time? </span>Does one come of age at the beginning or end of that year? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman says: During </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">time </span>is considered <span class="gemarra-regular">as before </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">time</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and he does not come of age until the year has elapsed. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava bar Rav Sheila </span>says that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman says: During </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">time </span>is considered <span class="gemarra-regular">as after </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">time, </span>and he is considered as having come of age during that year.
The Gemara notes: <span class="gemarra-regular">And this </span>statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rava was not stated explicitly; rather, it was stated by inference. As </span>there was <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain </span>person who was <span class="gemarra-regular">during </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">time, </span>i.e., the year, when one comes of age <span class="gemarra-regular">who went </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">sold </span>his father’s <span class="gemarra-regular">property, and </span>the case <span class="gemarra-regular">came before Rava. </span>Rava <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>the litigants: <span class="gemarra-regular">He did not do anything, </span>and the sale is not valid. <span class="gemarra-regular">One who observed </span>Rava’s ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">assumed </span>that he ruled in this manner <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>he maintained <span class="gemarra-regular">that during </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">time </span>when he comes of age is considered <span class="gemarra-regular">as before </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">time. But </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">is not so. </span>The reason for Rava’s ruling was that <span class="gemarra-regular">there, </span>Rava <span class="gemarra-regular">observed excessive mental incompetence in </span>the behavior of that individual, <span class="gemarra-regular">as he was emancipating his slaves</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Since Rava saw that he was mentally incompetent, he invalidated the sale.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Giddel bar Menashya sent </span>an inquiry <span class="gemarra-regular">to Rava: Let our teacher instruct us: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a girl </span>who is <span class="gemarra-regular">fourteen years and one day ol</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> who <span class="gemarra-regular">understand</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the nature of business </span>negotiations, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? Can she sell property that she inherited from her father? Rava <span class="gemarra-regular">sent </span>a reply <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>Giddel bar Menashya: <span class="gemarra-regular">If she understands the nature of business </span>negotiations <span class="gemarra-regular">her purchase is </span>a valid <span class="gemarra-regular">purchas</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and her sale is </span>a valid <span class="gemarra-regular">sale.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>Giddel <span class="gemarra-regular">could have sent </span>this question <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>Rava with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a boy. </span>Why did he not do so? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">The incident that </span><span class="gemarra-regular">took place, took place in this way. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But he could have sent </span>this question <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>Rava with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a girl </span>who is <span class="gemarra-regular">twelve years and one day old, </span>at which age a girl reaches her majority. Why did he not do so? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">The incident that took place, took place </span><span class="gemarra-regular">in this way.</span>
The Gemara notes: <span class="gemarra-regular">And this </span>statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rava was not stated explicitly; rather, it was stated by inference, as </span>it was inferred from the following incident. There was <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain </span>person who was <span class="gemarra-regular">under twenty </span>years <span class="gemarra-regular">old </span>and understood business negotiations <span class="gemarra-regular">who went </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">sold his father’s property, in accordance with </span>the ruling that Rava sent to <span class="gemarra-regular">Giddel bar Menashya, </span>and the case <span class="gemarra-regular">came before Rava. </span>The seller’s <span class="gemarra-regular">relatives said to </span>the one who sold the property: <span class="gemarra-regular">Go eat dates and throw </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">pits into Rava’s house, </span>in order to prove to Rava that their relative was not mentally competent. <span class="gemarra-regular">He did so. </span>Rava <span class="gemarra-regular">said to them: His sale </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>a valid <span class="gemarra-regular">sale.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">When they were writing for him a writ </span>containing the decision, <span class="gemarra-regular">the buyers said to </span>the seller, in order to prove that he was mentally competent: <span class="gemarra-regular">Go </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">say to Rava: The scroll of Esther, </span>which is a large scroll, is bought <span class="gemarra-regular">for a dinar. </span>Why then does <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>short <span class="gemarra-regular">writ </span>containing <span class="gemarra-regular">Master’s </span>ruling also cost <span class="gemarra-regular">a dinar, </span>which was the scribe’s fee? The seller <span class="gemarra-regular">went </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>Rava. Rava <span class="gemarra-regular">said to them: His sale </span>is a valid <span class="gemarra-regular">sale. The </span>boy’s <span class="gemarra-regular">relatives said to </span>Rava: <span class="gemarra-regular">The buyers taught him </span>to say that. Rava <span class="gemarra-regular">said to them: </span>Even so, when <span class="gemarra-regular">they explain </span>the matter <span class="gemarra-regular">to him he understands. Since, when they explain </span>a matter <span class="gemarra-regular">to him he understands, he knows </span>what he is doing. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the reason <span class="gemarra-regular">that he acted </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>manner, throwing the pits into Rava’s house, was because of <span class="gemarra-regular">excessive impudence that was in him, </span>not mental incompetence.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, says: And with regard to </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">testimony </span>of one who is not old enough to sell property that he inherits from his father, <span class="gemarra-regular">his testimony </span>is valid <span class="gemarra-regular">testimony. Mar Zutra said: We said </span>that his testimony is valid <span class="gemarra-regular">only with regard to movable property</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> but not with regard to land.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi said to Mar Zutra: </span>In <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>way <span class="gemarra-regular">is movable property different </span>from land? It is different <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>with regard to movable property <span class="gemarra-regular">his sale is </span>a valid <span class="gemarra-regular">sale. But if that is so, </span>consider <span class="gemarra-regular">that which we learned </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Gittin</span> 59a): <span class="gemarra-regular">A purchase </span>made <span class="gemarra-regular">by young children </span>is a valid <span class="gemarra-regular">purchase</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and a sale </span>made by them is a valid <span class="gemarra-regular">sale. </span>These <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> apply <span class="gemarra-regular">to</span> transactions involving <span class="gemarra-regular">movable property. </span>Is it possible <span class="gemarra-regular">that also </span>in the case of young children <span class="gemarra-regular">their testimony </span>is valid <span class="gemarra-regular">testimony? </span>Isn’t it an established <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that minors are disqualified from bearing witness? Mar Zutra <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Rav Ashi: <span class="gemarra-regular">There, </span>with regard to testimony, <span class="gemarra-regular">I require </span>the witnesses to be men, as the verse states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Then the two men shall stand”</span> (Deuteronomy 19:17), which is interpreted as referring to witnesses, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>this requirement is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>fulfilled in the case of young children.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Ameimar says: </span>With regard to one who is not old enough to sell property that he inherits from his father, if he gave a gift from the property, <span class="gemarra-regular">his gift </span>is a valid <span class="gemarra-regular">gift</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rav Ashi said to Ameimar: Now, if </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a sale, </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">which</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he receives money, you say </span>that the Sages instituted an ordinance <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">not</span> authorized to sell, <span class="gemarra-regular">lest he reduce </span>the price of the property and deplete his father’s estate, <span class="gemarra-regular">all the more so </span>in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a gift </span>he is not authorized to give a gift, <span class="gemarra-regular">as nothing at all comes into his </span>possession in exchange. Ameimar <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Rav Ashi: 

Daf 156a

<span class="gemarra-regular">And according to your reasoning, </span>that the money he receives in exchange for the property is a reason one could consider his sale valid, if <span class="gemarra-regular">he sold </span>property <span class="gemarra-regular">worth</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> five </span>dinars <span class="gemarra-regular">for six </span>dinars, would <span class="gemarra-regular">his sale also be </span>a valid <span class="gemarra-regular">sale?</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, the Sages maintain that a child’s inclination </span>is to be <span class="gemarra-regular">attracted to money. And if you say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">his sale is </span>a valid <span class="gemarra-regular">sale, </span>there may be <span class="gemarra-regular">times </span>that there are potential buyers <span class="gemarra-regular">who rattle the dinars </span>before <span class="gemarra-regular">him </span>in order to tempt him to sell, and <span class="gemarra-regular">he will go and sell all of his father’s property. </span>That is why the Sages ruled that all of his sales are not valid. <span class="gemarra-regular">But with regard to a gift, if he did not </span>derive <span class="gemarra-regular">benefit from </span>the recipient, <span class="gemarra-regular">he would not give him a gift. The Sages </span>therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">said: Let the gift </span>of an orphan <span class="gemarra-regular">be </span>a valid <span class="gemarra-regular">gift, so </span>that people <span class="gemarra-regular">will perform </span>beneficial <span class="gemarra-regular">matters for </span>the orphans, as the orphan can reciprocate by giving gifts.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel says: </span>Children who have reached the age of majority, i.e., a boy who is thirteen years old and a girl who is twelve years old, <span class="gemarra-regular">are examined </span>for signs indicating puberty if it is necessary to determine their adulthood <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>the purpose of <span class="gemarra-regular">betrothal</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for </span>the purpose of <span class="gemarra-regular">divorce, for </span>the purpose of <span class="gemarra-italic">ḥalitza</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, and </span>for the purpose of stating a girl’s <span class="gemarra-regular">refusa</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span> to remain married. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to sell from the property that </span>one inherited from <span class="gemarra-regular">his father, </span>the seller must be older, and one cannot sell this property <span class="gemarra-regular">until </span>the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">is twenty </span>years <span class="gemarra-regular">old.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But once I examined </span>the boy <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>the purpose of <span class="gemarra-regular">betrothal, why do I </span>need to examine him again <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>the purpose of <span class="gemarra-regular">divorce? </span>The Gemara answers: This <span class="gemarra-regular">is necessary only with regard to </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">levirate marriag</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> of a minor, <span class="gemarra-regular">as we learned </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Nidda</span> 45a): A boy who is <span class="gemarra-regular">nine years and one day old who engaged in intercours</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with his </span><span class="gemarra-italic">yevama</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., his brother’s widow, <span class="gemarra-regular">acquired her </span>as his wife by means of engaging in the act of intercourse. Although a minor cannot betroth a woman under ordinary circumstances, in the case of levirate marriage the act of intercourse of a nine-year-old with his <span class="it-text">yevama</span> effects acquisition. <span class="gemarra-regular">But he cannot give </span>her <span class="gemarra-regular">a bill of divorce until he reaches his majority. </span>It is therefore necessary to examine him at the time of the divorce.
The Gemara explains why it is necessary to mention examining a boy <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>the purpose of <span class="gemarra-italic">ḥalitza</span><span class="gemarra-regular">:</span> This is mentioned <span class="gemarra-regular">to the exclusion of that which Rabbi Yosei </span>says, <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>Rabbi Yosei <span class="gemarra-regular">says: “Man,” </span>i.e., an adult man, <span class="gemarra-regular">is written in the </span>Torah <span class="gemarra-regular">passage </span>with regard to <span class="it-text">ḥalitza</span>, as the verse states: “And if the man does not wish to take his brother’s wife” (Deuteronomy 25:7). <span class="gemarra-regular">But a woman, whether </span>she is <span class="gemarra-regular">an adult or a minor, </span>can be released by <span class="it-text">ḥalitza</span>, as the verse does not indicate her age. To counter this, Rav Naḥman <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us that a woman is juxtaposed to a ma</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> in this passage, indicating that the <span class="it-text">yevama</span> must also have reached adulthood, and the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">not in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei.</span>
The Gemara explains why it is necessary to mention examining a person <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>the purpose of stating her <span class="gemarra-regular">refusal</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> This is mentioned <span class="gemarra-regular">to the exclusion of that which Rabbi Yehuda </span>says, <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>Rabbi Yehuda <span class="gemarra-regular">says </span>that a girl whose mother or brother married her off while she was a minor can nullify her marriage by refusing to remain married, and she can state this refusal <span class="gemarra-regular">until </span>she reaches complete maturity, i.e., <span class="gemarra-regular">when </span>the area covered by <span class="gemarra-regular">black </span>pubic hairs <span class="gemarra-regular">is greater </span>than the skin of the genital area. Rav Naḥman therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us that </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">not in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda, </span>and once a girl has developed two pubic hairs she cannot state her refusal.
Rav Naḥman states: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to sell from the property that </span>one inherited from <span class="gemarra-regular">his father, </span>the seller must be older, and he cannot sell the property <span class="gemarra-regular">until he is twenty </span>years <span class="gemarra-regular">old. </span>This is mentioned <span class="gemarra-regular">to the exclusion of </span>the opinion of the <span class="gemarra-regular">one who says </span>that the seller can be <span class="gemarra-regular">eighteen </span>years <span class="gemarra-regular">old.</span>
The Gemara concludes: <span class="gemarra-regular">And the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is that with regard to the age when a minor can sell property inherited from his father, <span class="gemarra-regular">during </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">time, </span>i.e., during his twentieth year, is considered <span class="gemarra-regular">as before </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">time </span>when it is permitted, and he cannot sell until the end of his twentieth year. <span class="gemarra-regular">And the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the ruling that Rava sent to <span class="gemarra-regular">Giddel bar Menashe, </span>that a child who has reached his majority and understands the nature of business negotiations can sell land.
The Gemara continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">And the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the statement of <span class="gemarra-regular">Mar Zutra, </span>that one who is not fit to sell land is also not fit to bear witness with regard to land. <span class="gemarra-regular">And the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the statement of <span class="gemarra-regular">Ameimar, </span>that an orphan under the age of twenty can bestow gifts from the property he inherited from his father. <span class="gemarra-regular">And the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the statement that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman </span>says that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel says with regard to all </span>the matters that he mentioned.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who divides his property </span>between various recipients <span class="gemarra-regular">by </span>means of <span class="gemarra-regular">verbal </span>instruction, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar says: </span>Both in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>who is <span class="gemarra-regular">healthy and </span>in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>who is <span class="gemarra-regular">dangerously </span><span class="gemarra-regular">ill</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">Property that serves </span><span class="gemarra-regular">as a guarantee, </span>i.e., land, <span class="gemarra-regular">is acquired by </span>means of <span class="gemarra-regular">money, by a deed </span>of transfer, <span class="gemarra-regular">or by taking possession </span>of it. <span class="gemarra-regular">And that </span>which <span class="gemarra-regular">does not serve </span><span class="gemarra-regular">as a guarantee, </span>i.e., movable property, <span class="gemarra-regular">can be acquired only by pulling. </span>

Daf 156b

The Rabbis <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Rabbi Elazar: There was <span class="gemarra-regular">an incident involving the mother of the sons of Rokhel, who was sick, and </span>who <span class="gemarra-regular">said: My brooch shall be given to my daughter, and it is </span>valued <span class="gemarra-regular">at twelve hundred dinars. And </span>this woman subsequently <span class="gemarra-regular">died, and </span>the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">upheld her statement</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> This indicates that a person on his deathbed can gift property without an act of acquisition. Rabbi Elazar <span class="gemarra-regular">said to them: </span>That case was different; <span class="gemarra-regular">the sons of Rokhel should be buried by their mother, </span>i.e., he cursed them. It is not possible to bring a proof from this incident, as these sons were wicked people. Consequently, when ruling in this matter the Sages did not act in accordance with the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>, but allowed the mother of the sons of Rokhel to give this valuable piece of jewelry to their sister without an act of acquisition having been performed.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">It is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Eliezer said to the Rabbis: </span>There was <span class="gemarra-regular">an incident involving a certain </span>man <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Mero</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">who was in Jerusalem, and he had a lot of movable property. And he desired to give </span>the movable property <span class="gemarra-regular">as gifts </span>to various individuals, but they could not be acquired by pulling. The Rabbis <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: There is no remedy for </span>transferring the property <span class="gemarra-regular">unless he transfers </span>the movable property <span class="gemarra-regular">by means of </span>transferring the ownership of <span class="gemarra-regular">land.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">He went and acquired one </span>plot of <span class="gemarra-regular">rocky </span>land <span class="gemarra-regular">adjacent to Jerusalem, and </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">said: </span>I give <span class="gemarra-regular">the north </span>part <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span>this area <span class="gemarra-regular">to so-and-so, and with it one hundred sheep and one hundred barrels. And </span>I give <span class="gemarra-regular">the south </span>part <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span>the area <span class="gemarra-regular">to so-and-so, and with it one hundred sheep and one hundred barrels. And he died, and the Sages upheld his statement. </span>This indicates that a person on his deathbed cannot transfer property without an act of acquisition. The Rabbis <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Rabbi Eliezer: Do you bring <span class="gemarra-regular">proof from there? </span>The man <span class="gemarra-regular">of Meron was healthy </span>at the time. This was not the gift of a person on his deathbed, and it could not be acquired by verbal instruction.
§ The mishna teaches: Rabbi Elazar <span class="gemarra-regular">said to them: </span>That case was different; <span class="gemarra-regular">the sons of Rokhel should be buried by their mother. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">he was cursing them? Rav Yehuda says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel says: They were maintaining thorns in a vineyar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> and did not uproot them, <span class="gemarra-regular">and Rabbi Eliezer </span>conforms <span class="gemarra-regular">to his </span>line of <span class="gemarra-regular">reasoning</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as we learned </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Kilayim</span> 5:8): With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who maintains thorns in a vineyard</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rabbi Eliezer says: He has proscribed </span>the vineyard, rendering it forbidden due to the prohibition against diverse kinds. <span class="gemarra-regular">And the Rabbis say: Only </span>growing <span class="gemarra-regular">a matter, </span>i.e., a crop, <span class="gemarra-regular">the like of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">which </span>people usually <span class="gemarra-regular">maintain, proscribe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> a vineyard and renders it forbidden.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, </span>if it were <span class="gemarra-regular">saffron </span>that grew in the vineyard, it <span class="gemarra-regular">is useful </span>for seasoning and other uses, and therefore it proscribes the vineyard. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">thorns, for what are they useful? Rabbi Ḥanina said: What is the reasoning of Rabbi Eliezer? </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">because in Arabi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> they maintain thorns in the fields for their camels</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Rabbi Eliezer holds that since thorns are maintained in one place, they are considered useful everywhere.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Levi says: </span>An act of <span class="gemarra-regular">acquisition may be performed </span>in order to effect acquisition of property <span class="gemarra-regular">from a person on his deathbed even on Shabbat</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> even though transactions are not performed on Shabbat. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>this, that an act of acquisition must be performed, is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>stated in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to take into consideration the statement of Rabbi Elieze</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> that the gifts of any person on his deathbed require an act of acquisition. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>the reason for this is that if a person on his deathbed requests the performance of an act of acquisition, his request is fulfilled, <span class="gemarra-regular">lest </span>his anxiety upon seeing that his will is not being carried out cause him to <span class="gemarra-regular">lose control of his mind </span>due to his grief, exacerbating his poor physical state.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Eliezer says: On Shabbat, the </span>verbal <span class="gemarra-regular">statement </span>of a person on his deathbed <span class="gemarra-regular">stands, as </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">cannot write, </span>and the Sages instituted that he can effect the transaction verbally lest the inability to do so exacerbate his condition. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>a verbal instruction does <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>stand if stated <span class="gemarra-regular">on a weekday. Rabbi Yehoshua says: With regard to Shabbat, </span>the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">stated </span>that his verbal instruction is sufficient, even though writing is prohibited. One can infer <span class="gemarra-italic">a</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">fortiori</span> that the same applies <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to a weekday, </span>when writing is permitted.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Similarly, one can acquire </span>property <span class="gemarra-regular">on behalf of a minor</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> but one cannot acquire </span>property <span class="gemarra-regular">on behalf of an adult, </span>since he can perform the act of acquisition himself; this is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of Rabbi Eliezer. Rabbi Yehoshua says: </span>The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">stated </span>this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to a minor, </span>and one may infer <span class="gemarra-italic">a</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">fortiori</span> that this also applies <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to an adult</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> who is able to perform the act of acquisition himself.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Whose </span>opinion is ex-pressed in the <span class="gemarra-regular">mishna? </span>The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">This is </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda. </span>This is <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Eliezer says: </span>With regard to a person on his deathbed who distributes his property by verbal instruction, <span class="gemarra-regular">on a weekday, his statements stand, because he can write, but </span>his statement does <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>stand <span class="gemarra-regular">on Shabbat, </span>because he cannot write. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehoshua</span>

Daf 157a

<span class="gemarra-regular">says: With regard to weekdays </span>the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">stated </span>that the verbal instruction of person on his deathbed is valid, even though it is permitted to write. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>one may infer <span class="gemarra-italic">a</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">fortiori</span> that the same applies <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to Shabbat, </span>when writing is prohibited. <span class="gemarra-regular">Similarly, one can acquire </span>property <span class="gemarra-regular">on behalf of an adult, </span>as he is able to effect acquisition himself, <span class="gemarra-regular">but one cannot acquire </span>property <span class="gemarra-regular">on behalf of a minor; </span>this is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of Rabbi Eliezer. Rabbi Yehoshua says: </span>The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">stated </span>this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to an adult, </span>even though he can effect acquisition himself. One may infer <span class="gemarra-italic">a</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">fortiori</span> that this also applies <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to a minor, </span>who cannot effect acquisition himself.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda says that Rabbi Eliezer says: On Shabbat, </span>the verbal <span class="gemarra-regular">statement of </span>a person on his deathbed <span class="gemarra-regular">stands due to </span>the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that he cannot write. But </span>a verbal instruction does <span class="gemarra-regular">not stand </span><span class="gemarra-regular">on a weekday. Rabbi Yehoshua says: With regard to Shabbat </span>the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">stated </span>that his verbal instruction stands, even though writing is prohibited. One may infer <span class="gemarra-italic">a</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">fortiori</span> that the same applies <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to a weekday, </span>when writing is permitted. <span class="gemarra-regular">Similarly, one can acquire </span>property <span class="gemarra-regular">on behalf of a minor, but one cannot acquire </span>property <span class="gemarra-regular">on behalf of an adult, </span>since he can effect the acquisition himself; this is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of Rabbi Eliezer.
