Rabbi Yehoshua says: </span>The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">stated </span>this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to a minor, </span>and one may infer <span class="gemarra-italic">a</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">fortiori</span> that this also applies <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to an adult.</span>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">A house collapsed on </span>a son <span class="gemarra-regular">and upon his father, or upon </span>a certain person <span class="gemarra-regular">and upon those </span>from <span class="gemarra-regular">whom he stands to inherit, </span>and it is unknown who died first. If the son <span class="gemarra-regular">bore </span>the responsibility to pay the <span class="gemarra-regular">marriage contract of </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">wife and </span>to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">a creditor, </span>and the son had no money with which to pay them except that which he might inherit from his father, and <span class="gemarra-regular">the father’s heirs say: The son died first and afterward the father died, </span>and therefore the son did not inherit property from his father, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the creditors say: The father died first and afterward the son died, </span>resulting in the son’s inheriting his father’s property, enabling the creditors to collect payment from the property even after the son’s death, there is a dispute with regard to how to rule.
Since it cannot be determined who died first, <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Shammai say: They divide </span>the property between them so that the father’s heirs receive half of his property and the son’s creditors receive the other half. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Beit Hillel say: </span>The <span class="gemarra-regular">property </span>retains <span class="gemarra-regular">its </span>previous ownership <span class="gemarra-regular">status</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Since the last known owner of the property was the father, the property is given to the father’s heirs.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">We learned </span>in a mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">elsewhere </span>(175a): <span class="gemarra-regular">One who lends </span>money <span class="gemarra-regular">to another with </span>a promissory <span class="gemarra-regular">note can collect </span>the debt even <span class="gemarra-regular">from liened property </span>that has been sold. If one lends money only <span class="gemarra-regular">with witnesses, he can collect </span>the debt only <span class="gemarra-regular">from unsold property.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel raises a dilemma: </span>If the borrower wrote in the promissory note: The property <span class="gemarra-regular">that I will acquire </span>in the future shall be liened to this debt, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he </span>subsequently <span class="gemarra-regular">acquired </span>property, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? Is the property liened or not? The Gemara clarifies the dilemma: <span class="gemarra-regular">According to </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Meir, who says: A person can transfer </span>ownership of <span class="gemarra-regular">an entity that has not </span>yet <span class="gemarra-regular">come into the world, you should not raise the dilemma, as </span>the lender <span class="gemarra-regular">certainly acquires, </span>i.e., places a lien, on the property. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, when should you raise the dilemma? </span>Raise it <span class="gemarra-regular">according to </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of the Rabbis</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> who say: A person cannot transfer </span>ownership of <span class="gemarra-regular">an entity that has not </span>yet <span class="gemarra-regular">come into the world.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef said: Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>proof from a mishna (<span class="it-text">Ketubot</span> 110a): If one produces a promissory note against another, and the borrower produced a bill of sale dated after the promissory note that states that the lender sold him a field of his, Admon says that the borrower can say: Were I really indebted to you, you should have collected the loan when you sold me the field. <span class="gemarra-regular">And the Rabbis say: </span>This does not prove anything. It is possible that <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>lender <span class="gemarra-regular">was perspicacious, as he sold </span>the borrower <span class="gemarra-regular">the land </span>for a good reason, <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>now <span class="gemarra-regular">he can take </span>the field <span class="gemarra-regular">as collateral from him </span>in lieu of the outstanding loan. This mishna indicates that even property acquired by the borrower after the promissory note is written is liened.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said to </span>Rav Yosef: <span class="gemarra-regular">Do </span>you <span class="gemarra-regular">speak </span>of a case where the debt is collected <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the debtor? With regard to collecting the debt <span class="gemarra-regular">from him, </span>the debt is collected from any property currently in his possession, <span class="gemarra-regular">even from </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">cloak that is upon his shoulders</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> When the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">dilemma was raised to us, </span>it was with regard to a case where the borrower wrote: The property <span class="gemarra-regular">that I will acquire </span>shall be liened, and he subsequently <span class="gemarra-regular">acquired </span>property <span class="gemarra-regular">and sold </span>it to others. The dilemma also pertains to a case where the borrower wrote: The property <span class="gemarra-regular">that I will acquire </span>shall be liened, and he subsequently <span class="gemarra-regular">acquired </span>property <span class="gemarra-regular">and bequeathed </span>it to his heirs. In these cases, <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? Can the lender repossess the property from the buyer or heir?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥana said: Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a proof from the mishna: In a case where <span class="gemarra-regular">the house collapsed on </span>a son <span class="gemarra-regular">and upon his father, or upon </span>a certain person <span class="gemarra-regular">and upon those </span>from <span class="gemarra-regular">whom he stands to inherit, </span>and it is unknown who died first, the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> depends on the circumstances. If the son <span class="gemarra-regular">bore </span>the responsibility to pay the <span class="gemarra-regular">marriage contract of </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">wife and </span>to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">a creditor, </span>and the son had no money with which to pay them except that which he might inherit from his father, and <span class="gemarra-regular">the father’s heirs say: The son died first and afterward the father died, </span>and therefore the son did not inherit property from his father, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the creditors say: The father died first </span>and afterward the son died, there is a dispute with regard to how to rule. In this case, the creditors claim that the son inherited his father’s property, and therefore they have a lien upon the property.
The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">And if it enters your mind </span>to say that when the borrower writes: The property <span class="gemarra-regular">that I will acquire </span>shall be liened, and he <span class="gemarra-regular">acquires </span>property <span class="gemarra-regular">and sells </span>it to others, it is not liened, and that when he writes: The property <span class="gemarra-regular">that I will acquire </span>shall be liened, and he <span class="gemarra-regular">acquires </span>property <span class="gemarra-regular">and bequeaths </span>it to his heirs, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is not liened, </span>then the mishna is difficult. <span class="gemarra-regular">Although the father indeed died first, </span>this case <span class="gemarra-regular">is</span> comparable to one where the borrower writes: The property <span class="gemarra-regular">that I will acquire </span>shall be liened, as the son acquired the property after receiving the loan. This indicates that a lien can be placed upon property that one will acquire in the future.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman said to </span>the Sages: Rabbi <span class="gemarra-regular">Zeira, our colleague, interpreted </span>the mishna as follows: In this case, the creditors do not claim the property because it is liened. Rather, they claim it because it is <span class="gemarra-regular">a mitzva </span>incumbent <span class="gemarra-regular">upon the orphans to repay their father’s debt</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rav Ashi objects to this: </span>If the promissory note does not place a lien on the property, <span class="gemarra-regular">this is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">a loan by oral</span> agreement, <span class="gemarra-regular">and Rav and Shmuel both say: A loan by oral </span>agreement <span class="gemarra-regular">cannot be collected, neither from the heirs nor from the buyers. </span>

Daf 157b

<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>in accordance with <span class="gemarra-regular">whose </span>opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">is this </span>mishna? This mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir, who says: A person can transfer </span>ownership of <span class="gemarra-regular">an entity that has not </span>yet <span class="gemarra-regular">come into the world. </span>Similarly, Rabbi Meir maintains that one can place a lien on property that the borrower will subsequently acquire.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yaakov from Nehar Pekod says in the name of Ravina: Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>proof from a mishna (<span class="it-text">Shevi’it</span> 10:5): <span class="gemarra-regular">Promissory notes that are antedated</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., that are dated prior to the date on which the loan actually was given, <span class="gemarra-regular">are invalid. </span>This is because the promissory note places a lien on the borrower’s property. By dating the document earlier than the loan itself, the lender appears to have a lien on property that the borrower sold prior to taking out the loan, enabling the lender to fraudulently repossess it from the buyer. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>promissory notes <span class="gemarra-regular">that are postdate</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> are valid, </span>as this does not enable the lender to defraud a buyer.
The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">And if it enters your mind </span>to say that property that the borrower acquires after receiving the loan <span class="gemarra-regular">is not liened </span>even when he writes: The property <span class="gemarra-regular">that I will acquire </span>shall be liened, and he <span class="gemarra-regular">acquires </span>property <span class="gemarra-regular">and sells </span>it to others, or when he writes: The property <span class="gemarra-regular">that I will acquire </span>shall be liened, and he <span class="gemarra-regular">acquires </span>property <span class="gemarra-regular">and bequeaths </span>it to his heirs, <span class="gemarra-regular">why, </span>then, <span class="gemarra-regular">are </span><span class="gemarra-regular">postdated </span>promissory notes <span class="gemarra-regular">valid? </span>They should be invalid, as in some instances they enable the creditor to fraudulently repossess property that is not liened, e.g., if the borrower acquires property after receiving the loan but before the date on the promissory note, and he sells it after that date. This case <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>comparable to one where the borrower writes: The property <span class="gemarra-regular">that I will acquire </span>shall be liened.
The Gemara answers: In accordance with <span class="gemarra-regular">whose </span>opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">is this </span>mishna? This mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir, who says: A person can transfer </span>ownership of <span class="gemarra-regular">an entity that has not </span>yet <span class="gemarra-regular">come into the world.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Mesharshiyya says in the name of Rava: Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>proof from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: With regard to collecting a debt <span class="gemarra-regular">in</span> a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">enhancement of land, how </span>does it happen that the debt cannot be collected from liened property that has been sold? This question arises in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>a debtor <span class="gemarra-regular">sold a field to another and </span>the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">enhanced it, and a creditor came and repossessed it </span>from the buyer. <span class="gemarra-regular">When </span>the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">collects </span>the value of the land from the seller, he <span class="gemarra-regular">collects the principal </span>even <span class="gemarra-regular">from liened property </span>that was sold to others, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>he collects the value of <span class="gemarra-regular">the enhancement </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">from unsold property</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if it enters your mind </span>to say that property that the borrower acquires after receiving the loan <span class="gemarra-regular">is not liened </span>even when he writes: The property <span class="gemarra-regular">that I will acquire </span>shall be liened, and he <span class="gemarra-regular">acquires </span>property <span class="gemarra-regular">and sells </span>it to others, or when he writes: The property <span class="gemarra-regular">that I will acquire </span>shall be liened, and he <span class="gemarra-regular">acquires </span>property <span class="gemarra-regular">and bequeaths </span>it to his heirs, <span class="gemarra-regular">why does </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">creditor collect </span>his debt by repossessing the <span class="gemarra-regular">enhancement </span>from the buyer? Since the enhancement was not extant at the time of the loan, it is not liened.
The Gemara answers: In accordance with <span class="gemarra-regular">whose </span>opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> this </span>mishna? This mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir, who says: A person can transfer </span>ownership of <span class="gemarra-regular">an entity that has not </span>yet <span class="gemarra-regular">come into the world. </span>The dilemma of Shmuel is raised according to the opinion of the Rabbis.
The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">If you say </span>that when the borrower writes: The property <span class="gemarra-regular">that I will acquire </span>shall be liened, and he <span class="gemarra-regular">acquires </span>property <span class="gemarra-regular">and sells </span>it to others, it is not liened, and that when he writes: The property <span class="gemarra-regular">that I will acquire </span>shall be liened, and he <span class="gemarra-regular">acquires </span>property <span class="gemarra-regular">and bequeaths </span>it to his heirs, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is not liened, </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">it is not liened </span>and the following question will not arise. <span class="gemarra-regular">If you say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">it is liened, what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to one who <span class="gemarra-regular">borrowed </span>money from one lender <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">borrowed </span>money from another lender, stating in both cases that the property that he will acquire shall be liened, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">then </span><span class="gemarra-regular">acquired </span>land? Does <span class="gemarra-regular">the first </span>lender <span class="gemarra-regular">have a lien upon </span>the property <span class="gemarra-regular">or </span>does <span class="gemarra-regular">the last </span>lender <span class="gemarra-regular">have a lien upon </span>the property?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman said: This matter was raised before us, and </span>the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">sent </span>a response <span class="gemarra-regular">from there, </span>from Eretz Yisrael: <span class="gemarra-regular">The first </span>lender <span class="gemarra-regular">acquires </span>the property, since his lien came first. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna says: </span>The lenders <span class="gemarra-regular">divide </span>the property between them. <span class="gemarra-regular">And so teaches Rabba bar Avuh: </span>The lenders <span class="gemarra-regular">divide </span>the property between them. <span class="gemarra-regular">Ravina said: The first time Rav Ashi </span>taught this matter <span class="gemarra-regular">he said to us: The first </span>lender <span class="gemarra-regular">acquires </span>the property. <span class="gemarra-regular">The last time Rav Ash</span><span class="gemarra-regular">i</span> taught this matter <span class="gemarra-regular">he said to us: </span>The lenders <span class="gemarra-regular">divide </span>the property between them. <span class="gemarra-regular">And the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is that <span class="gemarra-regular">they divide </span>the property between them.
The Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises an objection </span>from the aforementioned <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: With regard to collecting a debt <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">enhancement of land, how </span>does it occur that the debt cannot be collected from liened property that has been sold? This question arises in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">sold a field to another, and </span>the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">enhanced it, and a creditor came and repossessed i</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> from the buyer. <span class="gemarra-regular">When </span>the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">collects </span>the value of the land from the seller, he <span class="gemarra-regular">collects the principal </span>even <span class="gemarra-regular">from liened property </span>that was sold to others, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>he collects the value of <span class="gemarra-regular">the enhancement </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">from unsold property. And if it is so </span>that in general, the property is divided between the creditors, then, since both the creditor and the buyer have a lien upon the enhancement of the property, the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">should </span>collect only <span class="gemarra-regular">half of </span>the value of <span class="gemarra-regular">the enhancement.</span>
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>does the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> mean, <span class="gemarra-regular">as well, </span>when <span class="gemarra-regular">it teaches </span>that the buyer <span class="gemarra-regular">collects </span>the enhancement? The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> means that he collects <span class="gemarra-regular">half of </span>the value of <span class="gemarra-regular">the enhancement. </span>

Daf 158a

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If <span class="gemarra-regular">the house collapsed upon </span>a husband <span class="gemarra-regular">and upon his wife</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and it is unknown who died first, if the wife did not have any children from her husband, then the following claims arise: <span class="gemarra-regular">The husband’s heirs say: </span>The <span class="gemarra-regular">wife died first </span>and was inherited by her husband, <span class="gemarra-regular">and afterward the husband died, </span>and therefore the husband’s heirs inherit both his and her property. The <span class="gemarra-regular">wife’s heirs say: </span>The <span class="gemarra-regular">husband died first and afterward </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">wife died, </span>and her heirs inherit the property that she brought with her to the marriage and the payment of her marriage contract.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Shammai say: They divide </span>the property under dispute between them. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Beit Hillel say: </span>The guaranteed <span class="gemarra-regular">property </span>that the wife brought with her to the marriage retains <span class="gemarra-regular">its </span>previous ownership <span class="gemarra-regular">status</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> The sum of the <span class="gemarra-regular">marriage contract </span>remains <span class="gemarra-regular">in the possession of the husband’s heirs, </span>since the marriage contract is collected from the husband’s property. <span class="gemarra-regular">Property that is brought into and taken out </span>of the marriage <span class="gemarra-regular">with her</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., usufruct property that remains in the wife’s possession during her marriage, remains <span class="gemarra-regular">in the possession of the heirs of the </span>woman’s <span class="gemarra-regular">father. </span>

Daf 158b

<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna teaches that according to Beit Hillel, the guaranteed property that the wife brought with her to the marriage retains its previous ownership status. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">In whose possession </span>does the guaranteed property remain? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: </span>It remains <span class="gemarra-regular">in the possession of the husband’s heirs, </span>since the husband is liable to compensate his wife for guaranteed property in the event of loss. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Elazar says</span><span class="gemarra-regular">:</span> It remains <span class="gemarra-regular">in the possession of the wife’s heirs, </span>as the property came from her father’s house and belongs to her.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish says in the name of bar Kappara: They divide </span>the property between them. <span class="gemarra-regular">And likewise bar Kappara teaches </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Since these </span>heirs <span class="gemarra-regular">come to inherit and those </span>heirs <span class="gemarra-regular">come to inherit, </span>and neither can prove his claim, <span class="gemarra-regular">they divide </span>the property between them.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If <span class="gemarra-regular">the house collapsed on </span>a son <span class="gemarra-regular">and upon his mother, </span>and it is unknown who died first, the following claims arise: The mother’s paternal family claims that the son died first, and therefore they inherit from the mother, and the son’s heirs claim that the mother died first and her son inherited from her, and therefore they inherit from the son. In this case, both <span class="gemarra-regular">these </span>Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">and those </span>Sages, Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel, <span class="gemarra-regular">concede that they divide </span>the property between them. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Akiva said: In this </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">I </span><span class="gemarra-regular">conced</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">that the property </span>retains <span class="gemarra-regular">its</span> previous ownership <span class="gemarra-regular">status</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">Ben Azzai said to </span>Rabbi Akiva: <span class="gemarra-regular">We are </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">troubled by </span>those cases where Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel <span class="gemarra-regular">are in disagreement. But </span>do <span class="gemarra-regular">you come to bring upon us a disagreement </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>case where they <span class="gemarra-regular">agree?</span>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna states that according to Rabbi Akiva, the property retains its previous ownership status. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">In whose possession </span>does the property remain? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ila says: </span>It remains <span class="gemarra-regular">in the possession of the mother’s heirs. Rabbi </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Zeira</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> when he was still in Babylonia, <span class="gemarra-regular">said: </span>It remains <span class="gemarra-regular">in the possession of the son’s </span><span class="gemarra-regular">heirs</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">When Rabbi Zeira ascended </span>to Eretz Yisrael, <span class="gemarra-regular">he adopted the opinion of Rabbi Ila, </span>whereas <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba, </span>in Babylonia, <span class="gemarra-regular">adopted the opinion </span>stated <span class="gemarra-regular">by Rabbi Zeira. Rabbi Zeira said: Conclude from </span>this incident <span class="gemarra-regular">that the air of Eretz Yisrael makes </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">wise, </span>as when I ascended to Eretz Yisrael I accepted the opinion of Rabbi Ila, who was also from Eretz Yisrael, whereas Rabba, who remained in Babylonia, accepted my former opinion.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And what is the reason </span>that the property remains in the possession of the mother’s heirs? <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye says: Since the inheritance was </span>initially <span class="gemarra-regular">in the possession of that tribe </span>of the mother, it is not removed from their possession in order to transfer it to the son’s heirs, who are from a different tribe.
The mishna teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">Ben Azzai said to </span>Rabbi Akiva: <span class="gemarra-regular">We are </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">troubled by </span>those cases where Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel <span class="gemarra-regular">are in disagreement. </span>But do you come to bring upon us a disagreement with regard to the case where they agree? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shamlai said: That is to say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">ben Azzai was a disciple-colleague of Rabbi Akiv</span><span class="gemarra-regular">a</span> and not just a disciple, <span class="gemarra-regular">since he said to him: </span>Do <span class="gemarra-regular">you come, </span>in the second person, rather than using the more formal third person.
§ The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">sent </span>a ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">from there, </span>Eretz Yisrael: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a son who borrowed </span>money based <span class="gemarra-regular">on </span>the security of <span class="gemarra-regular">his father’s property during his father’s lifetime, and </span>whose father subsequently <span class="gemarra-regular">died, his son repossesses </span>the property <span class="gemarra-regular">from the buyers. And this is the </span>most <span class="gemarra-regular">difficult </span><span class="it-text">halakha</span> to understand <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to monetary law. </span>The Gemara clarifies the ruling: If the son <span class="gemarra-regular">borrowed, what does he repossess? </span>He needs to repay a debt, not to collect payment. <span class="gemarra-regular">Moreover, what is the relevance of the buyers </span>in this matter? There is no mention of them in the premise. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, if </span>this matter <span class="gemarra-regular">was stated, </span>it is in <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>manner

Daf 159a

that <span class="gemarra-regular">it was stated: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a son who sold </span>some <span class="gemarra-regular">of his father’s propert</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> during his father’s lifetime, and </span>the son <span class="gemarra-regular">died, </span>the son’s <span class="gemarra-regular">son repossesses </span>the property <span class="gemarra-regular">from the buyers. And this is a difficult </span><span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to monetary law, </span>as the buyers <span class="gemarra-regular">can say to </span>the son’s son: Does <span class="gemarra-regular">your father sell </span>the property to us <span class="gemarra-regular">and you repossess </span>it?
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And what is the difficulty? Perhaps he can say: I come </span>to repossess the property <span class="gemarra-regular">on the basis of </span>the right of my <span class="gemarra-regular">father’s father </span>to the property, as I inherit directly from him. <span class="gemarra-regular">Know </span>that this is so, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is written: “In the place of your fathers shall be your sons; you shall make them into princes throughout the land” </span>(Psalms 45:17). The phrase “In the place of your fathers shall be your sons” indicates that a grandson inherits from his grandfather directly, and he does not inherit through his father.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, if </span>there is a <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to monetary law that poses <span class="gemarra-regular">a difficulty</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> this is the difficult </span><span class="it-text">halakha</span>: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a firstborn son who sold, during his father’s lifetime, </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">portion of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the firstborn </span>that he was set to inherit, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">died in his father’s lifetime, his son can repossess </span>the portion of the firstborn <span class="gemarra-regular">from the buyers. And this is a difficult </span><span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to monetary law, </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">his father sells </span>the property and <span class="gemarra-regular">he repossesses </span>it. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if you would say: Here too, he says: I come </span>to repossess the property <span class="gemarra-regular">on the basis of </span>the right of my <span class="gemarra-regular">father’s father </span>to the property, this is not a valid claim, as, <span class="gemarra-regular">if he comes </span>to repossess the property <span class="gemarra-regular">on the basis of </span>the right of his <span class="gemarra-regular">father’s father, what is the relevance of </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">portion of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the firstborn, </span>since he is not his grandfather’s firstborn?
The Gemara rejects this: <span class="gemarra-regular">And what is the difficulty? Perhaps he can say: I come </span>to repossess the property <span class="gemarra-regular">on the basis of </span>the right of my <span class="gemarra-regular">father’s father </span>to the property, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>yet I receive the portion of the firstborn, as <span class="gemarra-regular">I stand in </span>my <span class="gemarra-regular">father’s stead</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, if </span>there is a <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to monetary law that poses <span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> difficulty, this is the difficult </span><span class="it-text">halakha</span>: One <span class="gemarra-regular">knew testimony supporting </span>another, and his testimony was written <span class="gemarra-regular">in a document before he became a robber</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">he became a robber </span>and was disqualified from bearing witness. In this case, <span class="gemarra-regular">he may not testify as to </span>the legitimacy of <span class="gemarra-regular">his handwriting. But others may testify </span>that it is his handwriting on the document. The difficulty is that <span class="gemarra-regular">now </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">his </span>testimony <span class="gemarra-regular">is not deemed credible, </span>although he knows of the matter with certainty, is it logical that <span class="gemarra-regular">others are deemed credibl</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> and his signature is ratified according to their testimony? <span class="gemarra-regular">And this is a difficult </span><span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to monetary law.</span>
The Gemara rejects this: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the difficulty? Perhaps </span>this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the signature <span class="gemarra-regular">was </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">presumed by </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">court </span>to be <span class="gemarra-regular">his handwritin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span> before he was disqualified, and the witnesses testify merely that the document was already ratified.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, if </span>there is a <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to monetary law that poses <span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> difficulty, this is the difficult </span><span class="it-text">halakha</span>: One <span class="gemarra-regular">knew testimony supporting </span>another concerning the latter’s ownership of a plot of land, and his testimony was written <span class="gemarra-regular">in a document before </span>the land <span class="gemarra-regular">came into </span>the witness’s possession <span class="gemarra-regular">as an inheritance, </span>which caused the witness to become an interested party. In this case, the witness <span class="gemarra-regular">may not ratify his handwriting. But others may ratify his handwriting. </span>The Gemara rejects this: <span class="gemarra-regular">And what is the difficulty? Perhaps here too, </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the signature <span class="gemarra-regular">was </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">presumed by </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">court </span>to be <span class="gemarra-regular">his handwriting </span>before he became an interested party, and the witnesses testify merely that the document was already ratified.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, if </span>there is a <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to monetary law that poses <span class="gemarra-regular">a difficulty,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> this is the difficult </span><span class="it-text">halakha</span>: One <span class="gemarra-regular">knew testimony with regard to </span>another, and his testimony was written in a document <span class="gemarra-regular">before he became </span>that person’s <span class="gemarra-regular">son-in-law</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">he became his son-in-law. </span>In this case, the son-in-law <span class="gemarra-regular">may not testify as to his handwriting, </span>since one cannot bear witness for his relative. <span class="gemarra-regular">But others may testify </span>that it is his handwriting. Is it logical that <span class="gemarra-regular">his </span>testimony <span class="gemarra-regular">is not deemed credible, </span>yet <span class="gemarra-regular">others are deemed credible </span>and may ratify his signature?
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if you would say: Here too, </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the signature <span class="gemarra-regular">was </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">presumed by </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">court </span>to be <span class="gemarra-regular">his handwriting </span>before he became a relative, this is difficult. <span class="gemarra-regular">But doesn’t Rav Yosef bar Minyumi say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman says: </span>Others may testify as to the validity of his handwriting <span class="gemarra-regular">even though </span>the signature <span class="gemarra-regular">was not </span>previously <span class="gemarra-regular">presumed by </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">court </span>to be <span class="gemarra-regular">his handwriting</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span>
The Gemara rejects this: <span class="gemarra-regular">And what is the difficulty? Perhaps it is the King’s edict, </span>i.e., a divine decree, <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the testimony of a son-in-law <span class="gemarra-regular">is not deemed credible, and </span>yet the testimony of <span class="gemarra-regular">others is deemed credible, and </span>the reason he is disqualified is <span class="gemarra-regular">not that he is </span>suspected of <span class="gemarra-regular">lying. </span>This must be so, <span class="gemarra-regular">as if you</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> do not say so, </span>why are <span class="gemarra-regular">Moses and Aaron </span>disqualified from bearing witness <span class="gemarra-regular">for their father-in-law? </span>Could this be <span class="gemarra-regular">because their </span>testimony <span class="gemarra-regular">is not deemed credible? Rather, it is the King’s edict that </span>even Moses and Aaron <span class="gemarra-regular">shall not bear witness for </span>their relatives. <span class="gemarra-regular">Here too, it is the King’s edic</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that </span>a son-in-law <span class="gemarra-regular">shall not testify as to </span>the validity of <span class="gemarra-regular">his handwriting for his father-in-law.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>the difficulty is <span class="gemarra-regular">actually as we said initially, </span>with regard to the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that if a son sold some of his father’s property and then died, the son’s son repossesses the property from the buyers. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>with regard to the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>posed <span class="gemarra-regular">a difficulty for you: “In the place of your fathers shall be your sons” </span>(Psalms 45:17), which apparently indicates that a grandson inherits from his grandfather directly, this is not difficult. <span class="gemarra-regular">That </span>verse <span class="gemarra-regular">is written as a blessing</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> The verse does not indicate the halakhic status of the grandson’s inheritance, and the reason he can repossess the property is still difficult.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But can you say </span>that the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">is written as a blessing, </span>

Daf 159b

<span class="gemarra-regular">but with regard to the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> it does <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>indicate anything?
<span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t it taught </span>in the mishna (157a): <span class="gemarra-regular">A house collapsed on </span>a son <span class="gemarra-regular">and upon his father, or upon </span>a certain person <span class="gemarra-regular">and upon those </span>from <span class="gemarra-regular">whom he stands to inherit, </span>and it is unknown who died first. If the son <span class="gemarra-regular">bore</span> the responsibility to pay the <span class="gemarra-regular">marriage contract of </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">wife and </span>to pay <span class="gemarra-regular">a creditor, </span>and the son had no money with which to pay them except that which he might inherit from his father, and <span class="gemarra-regular">the father’s heirs say: The son died first and afterward the father died, </span>and therefore the son did not inherit property from his father, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the creditor says: The father died first and afterward the son died, </span>there is a dispute as to the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>. The son therefore inherited his father’s property, and his creditor has a lien upon the property, enabling him to collect payment from the property even after the son’s death.
<span class="gemarra-regular">What, is it not </span>correct to explain that <span class="gemarra-regular">the father’s heirs </span>are the son’s <span class="gemarra-regular">sons, </span>and the term: <span class="gemarra-regular">Those </span>from <span class="gemarra-regular">whom he stands to inherit, </span>is referring to the deceased son’s <span class="gemarra-regular">brothers</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> And if it enters your mind </span>to maintain that the grandson <span class="gemarra-regular">cannot say: I come </span>to repossess the property <span class="gemarra-regular">on the basis of </span>the right of my <span class="gemarra-regular">father’s father </span>to the property, <span class="gemarra-regular">as when it is written </span>in the verse in Psalms: <span class="gemarra-regular">“In the place of your fathers shall be your sons,” </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">is written as a blessing, </span>then the mishna is difficult. According to this understanding, grandsons inherit from their grandfather only through their father. If so, even <span class="gemarra-regular">if the son died </span>first <span class="gemarra-regular">and afterward the father died, what of it? Let the creditor say to </span>the son’s sons: It is <span class="gemarra-regular">their father’s inheritance </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">I am taking, </span>as the grandsons inherit from their grandfather only through their father.
The Gemara rejects this explanation: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, the father’s heirs are </span>the deceased son’s <span class="gemarra-regular">brothers, </span>who certainly inherit from their father directly, and the term: <span class="gemarra-regular">Those </span>from <span class="gemarra-regular">whom he stands to inherit, </span>is referring to the deceased son’s <span class="gemarra-regular">father’s brothers. </span>Therefore, one cannot derive from the mishna that a grandson inherits from his grandfather directly.
§ The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">raised a dilemma before Rav Sheshet: What is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to a son</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> inheriting from his mother </span>while he is <span class="gemarra-regular">in the grave, in order to bequeath </span>that inheritance <span class="gemarra-regular">to his paternal brothers? </span>If a son dies, and afterward his mother dies, does the deceased son inherit from his mother, and subsequently bequeath the inheritance to his paternal brothers, who are not related to the mother? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Sheshet said to them: You learned it </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: Consider <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>case of a <span class="gemarra-regular">father who was taken captive </span>and died in captivity, <span class="gemarra-regular">and his son died in the province,</span> i.e., at home, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>consider the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a son who was taken captive </span>and died, <span class="gemarra-regular">and his father died in the province. </span>Since it is not known who died first, <span class="gemarra-regular">the father’s heirs and the son’s heirs divide </span>the inheritance.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What are the circumstances </span>of the case? <span class="gemarra-regular">If we say </span>that the case <span class="gemarra-regular">is as </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches, </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is difficult. <span class="gemarra-regular">Who are the father’s heir</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and who are the son’s heirs? </span>The same individuals inherit from both of them. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, is it not </span>so that <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>is what the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is saying: </span>Consider the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a father who was taken captive </span>and died in captivity, <span class="gemarra-regular">and his daughter’s son die</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in the province, and </span>consider the case of the <span class="gemarra-regular">son of his daughter who was taken captive </span>and died, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the father of </span>the captive’s <span class="gemarra-regular">mother died in the province, and we do not know which of them died first. </span>If the father died first, his daughter’s son inherits from him, and the son’s paternal relatives subsequently inherit from the son. If the son died first, the father’s heirs inherit the father’s estate. Since it is unknown which of them died first, <span class="gemarra-regular">the father’s heirs and the son’s heirs divide </span>the inheritance.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if it is so </span>that a son inherits from his mother while in the grave, <span class="gemarra-regular">although the son indeed died first, he should inherit </span>from <span class="gemarra-regular">his mother’s father </span>while <span class="gemarra-regular">in his grave and bequeath </span>his inheritance <span class="gemarra-regular">to his paternal brothers, </span>and the son’s heirs should receive the entire inheritance. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, isn’t it </span>correct to <span class="gemarra-regular">conclude from </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">the son does not inherit from his mother </span>while <span class="gemarra-regular">in the grave in order to bequeath </span>that inheritance <span class="gemarra-regular">to his paternal brothers?</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Aḥa bar Minyumi said to Abaye: We learn </span>this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in the mishna (158b) <span class="gemarra-regular">as well: </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">the house collapsed on </span>a son <span class="gemarra-regular">and upon his mother, </span>both <span class="gemarra-regular">these </span>Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">and those </span>Sages, Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel, <span class="gemarra-regular">concede that </span>the son’s heirs and the mother’s heirs <span class="gemarra-regular">divide </span>the property between them. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if it is so </span>that a son inherits from his mother while in the grave, <span class="gemarra-regular">although </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">son indeed died first, he should inherit </span>from <span class="gemarra-regular">his mother </span>while <span class="gemarra-regular">in his grave and they should inherit </span>from him, i.e., he should bequeath his inheritance <span class="gemarra-regular">to his paternal brothers. Rather, isn’t it </span>correct to <span class="gemarra-regular">conclude from </span>that mishna that <span class="gemarra-regular">the son does not inherit from his mother </span>while <span class="gemarra-regular">in the grave in order to bequeath </span>that inheritance <span class="gemarra-regular">to his paternal brothers? </span>The Gemara affirms: <span class="gemarra-regular">Conclude from </span>the mishna that this is so.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And what is the reaso</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> that a son does not inherit from his mother while in the grave? <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye says: </span>The term <span class="gemarra-regular">transfer, </span>concerning the transfer of inheritance from one tribe to another, <span class="gemarra-regular">was stated with regard to </span>the inheritance of <span class="gemarra-regular">a son </span>(see Numbers 36:7), <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the term <span class="gemarra-regular">transfer was stated with regard to </span>the inheritance of <span class="gemarra-regular">a husband</span> (see 111b–113a and Numbers 36:9). <span class="gemarra-regular">Just as </span>in the case categorized as <span class="gemarra-regular">transfer that was stated with regard to </span>the inheritance of <span class="gemarra-regular">a husban</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the husband does not inherit </span>from <span class="gemarra-regular">his wife </span>while he is <span class="gemarra-regular">in the grav</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> in order to bequeath that inheritance to his heirs, <span class="gemarra-regular">so too, </span>in the case categorized as <span class="gemarra-regular">transfer that was stated with regard to </span>the inheritance of <span class="gemarra-regular">a son, the son does not inherit from his mother </span>while <span class="gemarra-regular">in the grav</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in order to bequeath </span>that inheritance <span class="gemarra-regular">to his paternal brothers.</span>
§ There was <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain </span>person <span class="gemarra-regular">who said to another: I am selling to you </span>all of <span class="gemarra-regular">the property </span>that I own <span class="gemarra-regular">of bar Sisin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> There was one </span>parcel of <span class="gemarra-regular">land that was called </span>the tract <span class="gemarra-regular">of the house of bar Sisin. </span>The seller <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>the buyer: <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>latter parcel of land <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>actually <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>the property <span class="gemarra-regular">of the house of bar Sisin, and it is </span>merely <span class="gemarra-regular">called: Of the house of bar Sisin, </span>and therefore it is not included in the sale.
The matter <span class="gemarra-regular">came before Rav Naḥman, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span><span class="gemarra-regular">placed </span>the land <span class="gemarra-regular">in the possession of the buyer. Rava said to Rav Naḥman: </span>Is <span class="gemarra-regular">this the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? </span>The <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is that <span class="gemarra-regular">the burden of proof rests upon the claimant, </span>which in this case is the buyer. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises a contradiction between </span>this statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rava </span>and another statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rava, and between </span>this statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav Naḥman </span>and another statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav Naḥman.</span>
The Gemara explains the contradictions. There was <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain </span>man <span class="gemarra-regular">who said to another: What do you want, </span>i.e., what are you doing, <span class="gemarra-regular">with this house </span>of mine? <span class="gemarra-regular">He said to </span>the claimant: <span class="gemarra-regular">I purchased it from you and I </span>worked and <span class="gemarra-regular">profited </span>from it for <span class="gemarra-regular">the years </span>necessary for establishing the <span class="gemarra-regular">presumption </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">ownership. </span>The claimant <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: I was </span>traveling <span class="gemarra-regular">among the settlements </span>in a distant location, and I was unaware that you were residing in my house, which is why I did not lodge a protest.
The one residing in the house <span class="gemarra-regular">came before Rav Naḥman </span>for a judgment. Rav Naḥman <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Go clarify your profiting</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., prove that you really resided there for three years, and then the case can be judged. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said to </span>Rav Naḥman: Is <span class="gemarra-regular">this the </span>correct <span class="gemarra-regular">judgment? </span>The <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is that <span class="gemarra-regular">the burden of proof rests upon the claimant. </span>Therefore, the claimant should have to prove that the possessor did not reside in the house. The first statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rava is difficult, </span>as it is contradicted <span class="gemarra-regular">by </span>the second statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rava</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>the first statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav Naḥman </span>is difficult, as it is contradicted <span class="gemarra-regular">by </span>the second statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav Naḥman. </span>In the first case, Rav Naḥman ruled in favor of the buyer, and Rava ruled in favor of the seller, whereas in the second case their rulings were reversed.
The Gemara answers: The apparent contradiction <span class="gemarra-regular">between </span>the first statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rava </span>and the second statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rava </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult. Here, </span>with regard to the property of bar Sisin, the <span class="gemarra-regular">seller stands in </span>possession of <span class="gemarra-regular">his property, </span>and the buyer claims the parcel of land from him. <span class="gemarra-regular">There, </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">buyer stands in </span>possession of <span class="gemarra-regular">his property, </span>since he dwells in the house, and the seller wishes to evict him.
The contradiction between one statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav Naḥman and </span>the other statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav Naḥman </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">not</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> difficult as well, </span>because there, <span class="gemarra-regular">since </span>the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>I am hereby selling you all of the property that I own <span class="gemarra-regular">of the house of bar Sisin, and </span>this parcel of land is <span class="gemarra-regular">called: Of the house of bar Sisin, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">incumbent on him to reveal that it </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">not of the house of bar Sisin. But here, </span>in the case where the claimant states that he had been in a distant location, it <span class="gemarra-regular">should not be </span>considered as any case <span class="gemarra-regular">other </span>than one <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the possessor is <span class="gemarra-regular">holding a document </span>as evidence that he purchased the house. <span class="gemarra-regular">Wouldn’t we </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">say to him: </span>First <span class="gemarra-regular">ratify your document, and </span>only then be <span class="gemarra-regular">established </span>as the owner of the <span class="gemarra-regular">property</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> In this case as well, since his presumptive ownership is in place of a document, he needs to clarify the matter by means of witnesses. 


Daf 160a

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In <span class="gemarra-regular">an ordinar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> document, its witnesses </span>are to sign <span class="gemarra-regular">inside it, </span>i.e., on the written side of the paper. In a folded and <span class="gemarra-regular">tied </span>document, <span class="gemarra-regular">its witnesses </span>are to sign <span class="gemarra-regular">on the back of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">it.</span>
With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">an ordinary </span>document <span class="gemarra-regular">whose witnesses </span><span class="gemarra-regular">wrote </span>their signatures <span class="gemarra-regular">on the back of it, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">tied </span>document <span class="gemarra-regular">whose witnesses wrote </span>their signatures <span class="gemarra-regular">inside of it, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">both of these </span>are <span class="gemarra-regular">not valid</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rabbi Ḥanina ben </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Gamliel says: A tied </span>document <span class="gemarra-regular">whose witnesses wrote </span>their signatures <span class="gemarra-regular">inside of it </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">valid, because one can transform it </span><span class="gemarra-regular">into an ordinary </span>document by untying it. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabban Shimon ben </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Gamliel says: Everything </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with regional custom</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">An ordinary document </span>is rendered valid <span class="gemarra-regular">by </span>its having at least <span class="gemarra-regular">two witnesses, and a tied </span>document is rendered valid <span class="gemarra-regular">by </span>its having at least <span class="gemarra-regular">three </span>witnesses. With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">an ordinary </span>document <span class="gemarra-regular">in which a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> single witness wrote </span>his signature, <span class="gemarra-regular">and a tied </span>document <span class="gemarra-regular">in</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> which </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">two witnesses wrote </span>their signatures, <span class="gemarra-regular">they are both</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not valid.</span>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">From where are these matters </span>derived? What biblical basis is there for the existence of these two types of documents? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ḥanina says: As the verse states: “They shall buy </span><span class="gemarra-regular">fields for money, and subscribe the deeds, and seal them, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and call witnesses” </span>(Jeremiah 32:44). When the verse states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“They shall buy fields for money, and subscribe the deeds</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,” </span>

Daf 160b

<span class="gemarra-regular">this</span> is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">an ordinary </span>document. When the verse states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And seal them,” this </span>is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">a tied </span>document. The next phrase, “and call witnesses [<span class="it-text">veha’ed</span> <span class="it-text">edim</span>],” which more literally would be translated: And have witnesses bear witness, is interpreted as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And have bear witness [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">veha’ed</span><span class="gemarra-regular">],” </span>this indicates the need for <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>witnesses, as the term “witness [<span class="it-text">ed</span>]” in the Torah generally refers to two witnesses. As to the word <span class="gemarra-regular">“witnesses [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">edim</span><span class="gemarra-regular">],” </span>this additional term indicates the need for <span class="gemarra-regular">three </span>witnesses. <span class="gemarra-regular">How so? </span>How can the verse call for both two witnesses and three witnesses? Rabbi Ḥanina explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">Two </span>witnesses are required <span class="gemarra-regular">for an</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> ordinary </span>document, and <span class="gemarra-regular">three </span>are required <span class="gemarra-regular">for a tied </span>document.
The Gemara questions this explanation: <span class="gemarra-regular">But I </span>can just as well <span class="gemarra-regular">reverse </span>it, requiring two witnesses for a tied document and three for an ordinary one. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Since </span>the tied document requires <span class="gemarra-regular">more </span>to be done <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to its ties, </span>it stands to reason that it requires <span class="gemarra-regular">more </span>to be done <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">its witnesses, </span>requiring three rather than two.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rafram says </span>that there is a different source for two kinds of documents, <span class="gemarra-regular">from</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> here: “So I took the deed of the purchase</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, that which was sealed, the terms and conditions, and that</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> which was open” </span>(Jeremiah 32:11). When the verse states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“So I took the deed of the purchase,” this </span>is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">an ordinary </span>document. When it states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“That </span><span class="gemarra-regular">which was sealed,” this </span>is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">a tied </span>document. When it states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And that which was open,” this</span> is referring to the <span class="gemarra-regular">ordinary, </span>unfolded part <span class="gemarra-regular">of a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">tied </span>document. 
Rafram continues: With regard to the phrase: <span class="gemarra-regular">“The terms and conditions,” these are the matters</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that </span>distinguish <span class="gemarra-regular">an ordinary </span>document <span class="gemarra-regular">from a tied </span>one. <span class="gemarra-regular">How</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> so? </span>What are the details that differentiate the two types of documents? <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>one, the ordinary document, has <span class="gemarra-regular">two witnesses</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, and that </span>one, the tied document, has <span class="gemarra-regular">three witnesses. </span>And in <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>one, the ordinary document, <span class="gemarra-regular">its witnesses </span>are signed <span class="gemarra-regular">inside it, </span>on the front side, while in <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>one, the tied document, <span class="gemarra-regular">its witnesses </span>are signed <span class="gemarra-regular">on the back</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of it.</span>
The Gemara questions this explanation: <span class="gemarra-regular">But</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> I </span>can just as well <span class="gemarra-regular">reverse </span>it, requiring two witnesses for a tied document and three for an ordinary one. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Since </span>the tied document requires <span class="gemarra-regular">more </span>to be done <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to its ties, </span>it stands to reason that it requires <span class="gemarra-regular">more </span>to be done <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span><span class="gemarra-regular">regard to its witnesses, </span>requiring three rather than two.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rami bar Yeḥezkel</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> said </span>that there is a different source for two sets of <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> for two types of documents <span class="gemarra-regular">from here: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">“At the mouth of two witnesses or at the mouth</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of three witnesses shall a matter be established” </span>(Deuteronomy 19:15). <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>witnesses’ <span class="gemarra-regular">testimony is established with two </span>witnesses, <span class="gemarra-regular">why </span>did the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">specify for you </span>that it is also established <span class="gemarra-regular">with three, </span>which is self-evident? Rather, this verse serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to tell you </span>that there is a requirement for <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">for an ordinary </span>document, and a requirement for <span class="gemarra-regular">three </span>witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">for a tied </span>document.
The Gemara questions this explanation: <span class="gemarra-regular">But I </span>can just as well <span class="gemarra-regular">reverse</span> it, requiring two witnesses for a tied document and three for an ordinary one. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Since </span>the tied document requires <span class="gemarra-regular">more </span>to be done <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to its</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> ties, </span>it stands to reason that it requires <span class="gemarra-regular">more </span>to be done <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to its witnesses, </span>requiring three rather than two.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And</span> is it so that <span class="gemarra-regular">these </span>verses <span class="gemarra-regular">are coming for this</span> purpose, to teach that there are two types of documents? But <span class="gemarra-regular">each and every one </span>of them <span class="gemarra-regular">comes for its</span> own <span class="gemarra-regular">purpose. </span>The first verse comes <span class="gemarra-regular">for that which is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: When the verse states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“They </span><span class="gemarra-regular">shall buy fields for money, and subscribe the deeds, and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">seal them, </span>and call witnesses” (Jeremiah 32:44), it is merely to <span class="gemarra-regular">teach us good advice, </span>that people should carefully document their purchases in order to provide permanent proof of purchase. When the verse states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“So I took the deed </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of the purchase” </span>(Jeremiah 32:11), <span class="gemarra-regular">this was </span>merely how that <span class="gemarra-regular">incident </span>occurred, and the phrase is not intended to teach any <span class="it-text">halakhot</span>. When the verse states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“At the mouth </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of two witnesses or at the mouth of three witnesses </span>shall a matter be established” (Deuteronomy 19:15), this is stated in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to juxtapose three </span>witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">with two </span>witnesses for several reasons, as delineated <span class="gemarra-regular">in the dispute between Rabbi Akiva </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and the Rabbis </span>(<span class="it-text">Makkot</span> 5b).
The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>the entire institution of the <span class="gemarra-regular">tied </span>document is <span class="gemarra-regular">rabbinic </span>in origin, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>all these <span class="gemarra-regular">verses </span>that were cited above by various <span class="it-text">amora’im</span> were intended as <span class="gemarra-regular">mere suppor</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> for the concept of a tied document, as opposed to actual sources.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And what is the reason</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">the Sages instituted </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">tied </span>document? The Gemara explains: There was <span class="gemarra-regular">a place where there were </span>many <span class="gemarra-regular">priests</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and they were very quick tempered, and they would </span>seek to <span class="gemarra-regular">divorce their wives </span>impetuously. The <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is that a priest may not marry a divorcée, even his own ex-wife. These priests, who acted impetuously, often regretted having divorced their wives. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>therefore, <span class="gemarra-regular">the Sages instituted an ordinance </span>that the bill of divorce for these people should be of the tied format, which is a long, drawn-out process, hoping that <span class="gemarra-regular">meanwhile, their composure would be regained </span>and they would reconsider their decision to divorce.
The Gemara asks: This <span class="gemarra-regular">works out well </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">bills of divorce, </span>but <span class="gemarra-regular">what can</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> be said </span>with regard to other <span class="gemarra-regular">documents? </span>Why is this procedure used for other documents as well? The Gemara answers: This was instituted <span class="gemarra-regular">so that you should not differentiate between</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> bills of divorc</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>other <span class="gemarra-regular">documents.</span>
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Where do the witnesses sign </span>on a tied document? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna says: </span>They sign <span class="gemarra-regular">between each tied </span>fold. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav Yirmeya bar Abba says: </span>They sign <span class="gemarra-regular">on the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">back of the written </span>side, taking care that the signatures are exactly <span class="gemarra-regular">opposite the writing, on the outside.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rami bar Ḥama said to Rav Ḥisda: According to Rav </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Huna, who says </span>that the witnesses sign <span class="gemarra-regular">between each tied </span>fold, it <span class="gemarra-regular">enters our mind </span>that he meant <span class="gemarra-regular">between each </span><span class="gemarra-regular">tied </span>fold <span class="gemarra-regular">on the inside </span>of the document. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>this is difficult, as there was <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain tied </span>document <span class="gemarra-regular">that</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> came before Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi, <span class="gemarra-regular">and Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi, not realizing it was tied, <span class="gemarra-regular">said: There is no date</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> on this </span>document, so it is not valid. Then, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon, son of Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi, <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi: <span class="gemarra-regular">Perhaps </span>the date is <span class="gemarra-regular">hidden between the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">tied </span>folds. Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">opened it and saw </span>that the date was in fact between the tied folds. <span class="gemarra-regular">And</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> if it is so </span>that the witnesses sign between each tied fold on the inside of the document, Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">should have </span>had two objections, and said: <span class="gemarra-regular">There is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> no date on this </span>document, <span class="gemarra-regular">and there are </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">no</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> witnesses </span>signed <span class="gemarra-regular">on this </span>document.
Rav Ḥisda <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: Do you maintain </span>that Rav Huna meant that the witnesses sign <span class="gemarra-regular">between the tied </span>folds <span class="gemarra-regular">on the inside? No, </span>he meant <span class="gemarra-regular">between the tied </span>folds <span class="gemarra-regular">on the outside </span>of the document.
The Gemara questions Rav Huna’s opinion: <span class="gemarra-regular">But let</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> us be concerned </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">perhaps </span>the party holding the document <span class="gemarra-regular">falsified </span>some information <span class="gemarra-regular">and wrote whatever he wanted. And </span>this is a concern, as there are already <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses signed </span>on the document. In an ordinary document the witnesses sign immediately following the text, so there is no possibility of adding to the text. A tied document has part of its text written in the folds, but also has a part written on the face of the document on the unfolded paper, before or after the text in the folded part. If the witnesses sign between the folds there is the possibility of writing additional text in the unfolded section.
The Gemara explains: The case is one <span class="gemarra-regular">where it is written in </span>the document: Everything is <span class="gemarra-regular">confirmed </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and established. </span>That is, every folded document must contain this formula at the end of the text, to prevent forgery, as any writing after this formula would be disregarded.
The Gemara questions this explanation: <span class="gemarra-regular">But let us be concerned </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">perhaps </span>the holder of the document <span class="gemarra-regular">wrote whatever he wanted and afterward wrote </span><span class="gemarra-regular">another </span>time: Everything is <span class="gemarra-regular">confirmed and established. </span>The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">We write </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>declaration of: Everything is <span class="gemarra-regular">confirmed and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">established</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> we do not write two </span>declarations of: Everything is <span class="gemarra-regular">confirmed and established. </span>Therefore, anything written after the first declaration would be rejected, even if followed by a repetition of the declaration.
The Gemara questions further: <span class="gemarra-regular">But let </span>there be <span class="gemarra-regular">a concern </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">perhaps </span>the holder of the document <span class="gemarra-regular">erased </span>the declaration: Everything is <span class="gemarra-regular">confirmed and established, and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">wrote whatever he wanted </span>over the erasure, <span class="gemarra-regular">and afterward wrote</span> the declaration: Everything is <span class="gemarra-regular">confirmed and established. </span>The Gemara responds: How could this happen? <span class="gemarra-regular">Doesn’t Rabbi Yoḥanan say: </span>A document that includes <span class="gemarra-regular">a suspended </span>correction of text inserted between lines of the document, which is <span class="gemarra-regular">verifie</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> at the end of the document, <span class="gemarra-regular">is valid; </span>

Daf 161a

but a document with a reference to words written over <span class="gemarra-regular">an erasur</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is not valid, even if it is verified </span>at the end of the document. At the end of a document, before the formula: Everything is confirmed and established, is written, any corrections made in the document are verified by adding to the text: On line so-and-so, such and such a word has been added, or some similar formulation. This may be done only for inserted corrections, not for erasures.
The Gemara clarifies this statement: <span class="gemarra-regular">And they said that an </span><span class="gemarra-regular">erasure </span>on a document renders the document <span class="gemarra-regular">not valid only </span>if it is <span class="gemarra-regular">in a place </span>on the document where the declaration: Everything is <span class="gemarra-regular">confirmed and established</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> should have been written, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>only if the erasure <span class="gemarra-regular">is the measure </span>of space in which the declaration: Everything is <span class="gemarra-regular">confirmed and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">established, </span>can be written. The only concern with erasures is that the crucial formula: Everything is confirmed and established, might have been erased, as this would allow for unlimited forgery.
