If the erasure is such that this formula could not possibly have been erased, the document is valid.
§ Rami bar Ḥama asked Rav Ḥisda: <span class="gemarra-regular">And according to Rav Yirmeya bar</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Abba, who says </span>that the witnesses sign <span class="gemarra-regular">on the back</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of the written </span>side, taking care that the signatures are exactly <span class="gemarra-regular">opposite the writing, on the outside let </span>there be <span class="gemarra-regular">a concern </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">perhaps </span>the party holding the document <span class="gemarra-regular">will</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> write whatever he wants on the inside, </span>i.e., the front of the document, adding to the text, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">have extra witnesses sign on the outside, and </span>he will <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>to anyone questioning the number of witnesses being more than the minimum: <span class="gemarra-regular">I did </span>this in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">increase </span>the number of <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses, </span>the more to publicize the matters written in the document.
Rav Ḥisda <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Do</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> you maintain </span>that the <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses sign in order, </span>that is, one under the other, starting from the top of the page on the back? This is not correct; rather, the <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses sign from bottom to top</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> The witnesses sign in a perpendicular direction relative to the text of the document. The first signature begins at the reverse side of the last line of the document, and it continues upward toward the first line. There is therefore no possibility of adding to the text of the document, as, if the text extended beyond the beginning of the signatures, it would be recognized as a forgery.
Rami bar Ḥama continues to question the method of signature prescribed by Rav Yirmeya bar Abba: <span class="gemarra-regular">But let </span>there be <span class="gemarra-regular">a concern </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">perhaps something </span><span class="gemarra-regular">detrimental </span>to the holder of the document <span class="gemarra-regular">happens </span>to appear <span class="gemarra-regular">in the final line </span>of the document, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he excises </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the final line, and </span>in doing so <span class="gemarra-regular">excises </span>the first name of the witness on the opposite side as well. For instance, if the witness’s name is Reuven, son of Ya’akov, he will excise <span class="gemarra-regular">Reuven along with </span>the final line of the document, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the document <span class="gemarra-regular">will be </span><span class="gemarra-regular">rendered valid with </span>the remaining part of the signature: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Son</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of Ya’akov, witness.” As we learned </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Gittin</span> 87b): If one signs: <span class="gemarra-regular">Son of so-and-</span><span class="gemarra-regular">so, witness, </span>without mentioning his own name, the document is <span class="gemarra-regular">valid.</span>
The Gemara answers: It is a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where it is written “</span><span class="gemarra-regular">Reuven, son of” on one line, </span>i.e., opposite the final line of the document, <span class="gemarra-regular">and “Ya’akov, witness,” above </span><span class="gemarra-regular">it</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> beginning from the penultimate line of the document and continuing upward in a perpendicular manner. That is, a tied document is valid only if the witnesses sign in this manner. In this case, if the final line of the document is excised, all that will remain of the signature will be: “Ya’akov, witness.”
Rami bar Ḥama continues to ask: <span class="gemarra-regular">But let </span>there be <span class="gemarra-regular">a concern </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">perhaps he will </span><span class="gemarra-regular">excise </span>the final line of the document, along with the words <span class="gemarra-regular">“Reuven, son of,” and </span>the document <span class="gemarra-regular">will be </span><span class="gemarra-regular">rendered valid with </span>the remaining part of the signature: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Ya</span><span class="gemarra-regular">’akov, witness.” As we learned </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Gittin</span> 87b): If someone signs just: <span class="gemarra-regular">So-and-so, witness, </span>the document is <span class="gemarra-regular">valid.</span>
The Gemara answers: It is a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the word <span class="gemarra-regular">witness is not written </span>after the witnesses’ names. That is, a tied document is valid only if the word witness does not appear after the signatures. It is only in such a case that the document cannot be materially changed by excising the final line without rendering the witnesses’ names disqualified.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> you wish, say </span>instead <span class="gemarra-regular">that actually </span>the witness <span class="gemarra-regular">did write</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> “witness” </span>after his signature, and the case is one <span class="gemarra-regular">where we know </span>for a fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that this signature, </span>which consists of the words “Ya’akov, witness,” 

Daf 161b

<span class="gemarra-regular">is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not Yaakov’s </span>signature. That is, it is known for a fact that there is no one living in the city where the document was written who is named Ya’akov and whose signature matches the signature on this document. Therefore, the court will recognize that the signature must have originally stated: “So-and-so, son of Ya’akov, witness,” and that the last line had been excised, and they will invalidate it.
Rami bar Ḥama challenges: <span class="gemarra-regular">But</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> perhaps </span>this witness <span class="gemarra-regular">signed using the name of his father</span> instead of his own name, as a gesture of respect toward his father. The Gemara answers: This is not done; <span class="gemarra-regular">a person does not discard his own name and sign</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> using </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">the name of his father.</span>
Rami bar Ḥama challenges further: <span class="gemarra-regular">But perhaps </span>the witness <span class="gemarra-regular">made </span>this name <span class="gemarra-regular">into a mere distinguishing mark </span>that he uses as his signature, <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>it is known that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav </span>used to <span class="gemarra-regular">draw</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a fis</span><span class="gemarra-regular">h</span> as his signature mark, rather than signing his name, and <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ḥanina </span>used to <span class="gemarra-regular">draw a palm </span><span class="gemarra-regular">branch </span>as his signature mark, and <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥisda </span>used to sign just the letter <span class="gemarra-italic">samekh</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Hoshaya </span>used to sign just the letter <span class="gemarra-italic">ayin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava bar Rav Huna</span> used to sign his name by drawing a ship’s <span class="gemarra-regular">mast [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">makhota</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">A person is not</span> so <span class="gemarra-regular">insolent </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">to use his father’s name as</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a distinguishing mark.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Mar Zutra</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> said: Why do you need all this? </span>Why go to such lengths to answer the question posed above? There is a simpler answer: <span class="gemarra-regular">Any tied </span>document <span class="gemarra-regular">whose witnesses do not</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> end on a single line </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">not valid. </span>The Gemara had previously assumed that the witnesses sign one after the other, beginning at the document’s bottom line and going upward toward the first line; this arrangement leaves open the possibility that the signature of the first witness could be truncated by an unscrupulous party. Mar Zutra explains that this is not so; rather, the signatures are written with each one beginning opposite the bottom line and heading upward toward the beginning of the document. Therefore, if a line of text is excised from the bottom of the document, the names of all the witnesses on the reverse side will be truncated, and the forgery will become apparent.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yitzḥak bar Yosef </span><span class="gemarra-regular">says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: </span>There are two <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> with regard to documents: For <span class="gemarra-regular">any erasure</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> in a document, the scribe <span class="gemarra-regular">must write </span>at the end of the document: <span class="gemarra-regular">And this is their verification</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> That is, he must list the erasures, stating that on line so-and-so there is an erasure and a correction stating such and such, for each erasure. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the second <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is that the scribe <span class="gemarra-regular">must review </span>some <span class="gemarra-regular">of the details of the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">documen</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in the final line </span>of the document. <span class="gemarra-regular">What is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the reason </span>for this second requirement? 

Daf 162a

<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Amram says: </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">because</span> one <span class="gemarra-regular">may not learn </span>any new details <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">final</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> lin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> of a document. There is a concern that the holder of the document may have written in an extra line of text to his advantage, between the text and the witnesses’ signatures. Therefore, any new information contained in the last line is disregarded. Since the final line is disregarded, it is necessary that the final line of a document contain only a review of what is already written in it.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman said to Rav Amram: From where do </span><span class="gemarra-regular">you </span>know <span class="gemarra-regular">this? </span>Rav Amram <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: As it</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> (<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span> 11:1): If one writing a document <span class="gemarra-regular">distanced the witnesses’ </span>signatures <span class="gemarra-regular">two lines from</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the text </span>of the document, leaving two lines blank, the document is <span class="gemarra-regular">not valid, </span>as it would be possible for the holder of the document to fill in false information in those lines. But if one distanced the signatures <span class="gemarra-regular">one</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> line </span>from the text, the document is <span class="gemarra-regular">valid.</span>
Rav Amram analyzes the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is different </span>in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>blank <span class="gemarra-regular">lines </span>that that the document is not valid? If you say that <span class="gemarra-regular">perhaps </span>the holder of the document will take advantage of those two blank lines, and <span class="gemarra-regular">forge </span>unverified information <span class="gemarra-regular">and write </span>it in those lines, then in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one line </span>left blank <span class="gemarra-regular">as</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> well, </span>he can <span class="gemarra-regular">forge </span>information <span class="gemarra-regular">and write </span>it in that line. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>must one <span class="gemarra-regular">not conclude from </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that one <span class="gemarra-regular">may not learn </span>any new details <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">final</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> line </span>of a document? Therefore, only when two lines are left blank is there a concern that false information would be added to the penultimate line. The Gemara affirms: <span class="gemarra-regular">Conclude</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from </span>this <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that it is so. 

Daf 162b

<span class="gemarra-regular">A dilemma was raised</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> before </span>the Sages: If the space of <span class="gemarra-regular">a line and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a hal</span><span class="gemarra-regular">f </span> is left blank, <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? The Gemara seeks a solution to the dilemma. <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>what was stated in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> cited earlier: If one writing a document <span class="gemarra-regular">distanced the witnesses’ </span>signatures <span class="gemarra-regular">two lines</span> from the text of the document, leaving two lines blank, the document is <span class="gemarra-regular">not valid. </span>One can infer: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if there is a gap of only <span class="gemarra-regular">a line and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a half, </span>the document is <span class="gemarra-regular">valid.</span>
The Gemara deflects this proof: <span class="gemarra-regular">Say the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">last clause </span>of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: If one writing a document distanced the witnesses’ signatures <span class="gemarra-regular">one line </span>from the text of the document, the document is <span class="gemarra-regular">valid. </span>One can infer: It is only when there is a gap of <span class="gemarra-regular">one line </span><span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the document <span class="gemarra-regular">is valid, but </span>if there is a gap of <span class="gemarra-regular">a line and a half </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">valid. </span>The Gemara states: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, no </span>inference is <span class="gemarra-regular">to be</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> learned from this </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span>.
<span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>halakhic conclusion <span class="gemarra-regular">was</span> reached <span class="gemarra-regular">about </span>this matter? <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a proof from a different source, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> (<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span> 11:10): If one writing a document <span class="gemarra-regular">distanced the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> witnesses’ </span>signatures <span class="gemarra-regular">two lines from the text </span>of the document, the document is <span class="gemarra-regular">not valid, </span>but if the gap is <span class="gemarra-regular">less than that, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">valid. </span>It is clear from the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that any gap less than two full lines does not invalidate the document.
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues: If <span class="gemarra-regular">there were four or five witnesses</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> signed on the document, and one of them was found</span> to be <span class="gemarra-regular">a relative </span>of one of the parties in the document, <span class="gemarra-regular">or </span>one of them was found to be otherwise <span class="gemarra-regular">disqualifie</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> from bearing witness, the <span class="gemarra-regular">testimony </span>on the document may be <span class="gemarra-regular">established via the other </span>witnesses.
The Gemara draws a further conclusion from this <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: This <span class="gemarra-regular">supports </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Ḥizkiyya, as Ḥizkiyya says: </span>If one <span class="gemarra-regular">filled in </span>the gap between the document and the signatures <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>signatures of <span class="gemarra-regular">relatives</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the document is <span class="gemarra-regular">valid.</span>
Ḥizkiyya continued: <span class="gemarra-regular">And do not be surprised </span>by this, <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>a similar situation is found with regard to the roofing of a <span class="it-text">sukka</span>. Empty <span class="gemarra-regular">space </span>in the roofing <span class="gemarra-regular">of a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">sukk</span><span class="gemarra-italic">a</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">disqualifies </span>the <span class="it-text">sukka</span> if the space extends for <span class="gemarra-regular">three </span>handbreadths, whereas materials that are <span class="gemarra-regular">unfit </span>to be used as <span class="gemarra-regular">roofing disqualify </span>the <span class="it-text">sukka</span> only if the unfit material extends for <span class="gemarra-regular">four </span>handbreadths. If a <span class="it-text">sukka</span> had a gap in its roofing of three handbreadths it is disqualified, but if the gap is filled in with unfit material the <span class="it-text">sukka</span> is valid, since it is less than four handbreadths. This is comparable to the situation with a document: If there is a significant gap between the text and the signatures the document is not valid, but if the gap is filled in with signatures of those disqualified from bearing witness it is valid.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">A dilemma was raised before </span>the Sages: With regard to the gap of <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>blank <span class="gemarra-regular">lines </span>between the text and the signatures, <span class="gemarra-regular">which </span>the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>invalidates the document, 

Daf 163a

does this refer to the size of lines <span class="gemarra-regular">with the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> space </span>between lines added? <span class="gemarra-regular">Or </span>is it <span class="gemarra-regular">perhaps </span>referring to lines of writing themselves, <span class="gemarra-regular">without their spaces?</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> bar Yitzḥak said: </span>It <span class="gemarra-regular">stands to reason that </span>it is referring to the lines <span class="gemarra-regular">with their spaces</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> As, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>it were to <span class="gemarra-regular">enter your mind </span>that it is referring to the lines <span class="gemarra-regular">without their spaces, for what is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> one line without its space fit</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> did not have to state that a document with a single blank line after the text, measured without counting spaces, is not forgeable; this is obvious. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>one may <span class="gemarra-regular">conclude </span><span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>this claim that the reference is to two lines <span class="gemarra-regular">with their spaces. </span>The Gemara affirms: <span class="gemarra-regular">Conclude from </span>this claim that it is so.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shabbtai</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> says in the name of Ḥizkiyya: </span>With regard to the gap of <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>blank <span class="gemarra-regular">lines </span>between the text and the signatures, <span class="gemarra-regular">which </span>the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>invalidates the document, the lines are measured <span class="gemarra-regular">by the handwriting of witnesses</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>by <span class="gemarra-regular">the handwriting of a scribe, </span>who is presumably skilled enough to write in a smaller script. <span class="gemarra-regular">What is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the reason </span>for this? <span class="gemarra-regular">Anyone who forges </span>a document, adding additional lines to the document, <span class="gemarra-regular">would not go to a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> scrib</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>ask him to <span class="gemarra-regular">forge </span>it; he would execute the forgery himself, or have another unscrupulous person who is not a professional scribe forge it. Therefore, in order to present a concern for possible forgery, a document must have two blank lines that are measured by the handwriting of an ordinary person, such as one of the witnesses.
The Gemara has established that the width of the gap required to invalidate the document is two lines with interlinear space. The Gemara clarifies: <span class="gemarra-regular">And how much </span>interlinear space is necessary to invalidate the document? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yitzḥak ben Elazar </span><span class="gemarra-regular">says: For example, </span>enough to write the Hebrew word <span class="gemarra-italic">lekh</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, and </span>then the Hebrew word <span class="gemarra-italic">lekha</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, this </span>word <span class="gemarra-regular">on </span><span class="gemarra-regular">top of that </span>one. These two words each consist of the two letters <span class="it-text">lamed</span> and final <span class="it-text">khaf</span>; the former has a projection that fully occupies the interlinear space above it, and the latter has a projection that fully occupies the interlinear space below it. Writing these words one under the other, then, would require an additional interlinear space above and below both lines. The Gemara concludes: <span class="gemarra-regular">Apparently, </span>Rav Yitzḥak ben Elazar <span class="gemarra-regular">maintains </span>that the empty space required to invalidate the document is the width of <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>written <span class="gemarra-regular">lines with four</span> interlinear <span class="gemarra-regular">spaces</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥiyya bar Ami states </span>a different opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">in the name of Ulla: For example, </span>enough to write a <span class="gemarra-italic">lamed</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> on </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">upper </span>line <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>a final <span class="gemarra-italic">khaf</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> on </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">lower </span>line. The Gemara concludes: <span class="gemarra-regular">Apparently</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>Ulla <span class="gemarra-regular">maintains </span>that the empty space required to invalidate the document is the width of <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>written <span class="gemarra-regular">lines with three</span> interlinear <span class="gemarra-regular">spaces, </span>one above the first line, one between the two lines, and one beneath the second line.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Abbahu states </span>a different opinion: <span class="gemarra-regular">For example, </span>enough to write the name <span class="gemarra-regular">Barukh ben </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Levi on one line. </span>Barukh contains a final <span class="it-text">khaf</span>, and Levi contains a <span class="it-text">lamed</span>. The Gemara concludes: <span class="gemarra-regular">Apparently, </span>Rabbi Abbahu <span class="gemarra-regular">maintains </span>that the empty space required to invalidate the document is the width of <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>written <span class="gemarra-regular">line with two </span>interlinear <span class="gemarra-regular">spaces, </span>one above the line and one beneath the line.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: They taught </span>in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that a gap of two lines invalidates the document n <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>if that space is <span class="gemarra-regular">between the witnesses’ </span>signatures <span class="gemarra-regular">and the text </span>of the document. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if there is a gap <span class="gemarra-regular">between the witnesses’ </span>signatures <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>a court’s <span class="gemarra-regular">ratificatio</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> of the document, which follows the witnesses’ signatures, then <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>if there is <span class="gemarra-regular">more </span>space than this, the document is <span class="gemarra-regular">valid.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">different </span>about the case where the gap is <span class="gemarra-regular">between the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses and the text, </span>that it invalidates the document? There is a concern that <span class="gemarra-regular">perhaps </span>the holder of the document <span class="gemarra-regular">may forge </span>additional lines <span class="gemarra-regular">and write whatever he wants, and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the witnesses </span>have already <span class="gemarra-regular">signed </span>at the bottom, giving the appearance that they attest to the added lines as well. But the same concern can be raised concerning a gap <span class="gemarra-regular">between the witnesses’ </span>signatures <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the court’s <span class="gemarra-regular">ratification as</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> well: </span>There, too, he can <span class="gemarra-regular">forge </span>additional lines <span class="gemarra-regular">and write</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> whatever he wants, and </span>have <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses sign it</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> with the court’s ratification giving the appearance that it attests to the added lines and signatures as well. Why is this document valid?
The Gemara explains: When is a gap between the witnesses’ signatures and the court’s ratification not problematic, according to Rav? Only <span class="gemarra-regular">when </span>someone <span class="gemarra-regular">inks i</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> the blank space with lines or dots, to prevent information from being added there. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, </span>the gap <span class="gemarra-regular">between the witnesses’ </span>signatures <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the text of <span class="gemarra-regular">the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> document </span>should <span class="gemarra-regular">also </span>be made irrelevant in this manner: <span class="gemarra-regular">Let</span> the scribe <span class="gemarra-regular">ink in [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">metayyet</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> the blank space. Why, then, was it taught categorically that the witnesses must sign within two lines of the text?
The Gemara answers: Inking in the gap between the text and the signatures of the witnesses will not help, as people might <span class="gemarra-regular">say, </span>i.e., the concern might be raised: <span class="gemarra-regular">The witnesses are signed </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">on the inking in</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> It is possible that the witnesses’ signatures were affixed only to attest that the inking was done in their presence and that the inking in is not a sign of duplicity, and their signatures do not relate to the actual text of the document. The Gemara asks: If so, raise the same concern when the gap <span class="gemarra-regular">between the witnesses’ </span>signatures <span class="gemarra-regular">and the </span>court’s <span class="gemarra-regular">ratification </span>is inked in; there too, people might <span class="gemarra-regular">say: The court’s </span>ratification <span class="gemarra-regular">is signed </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">for the inking in, </span>and not for the actual text of the document. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">A court does</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not sign on </span>mere <span class="gemarra-regular">inking in; </span>their ratification is always in reference to the entire document.
The Gemara raises another issue: <span class="gemarra-regular">And let </span>there be <span class="gemarra-regular">a concern </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">perhaps </span>the holder of the document will <span class="gemarra-regular">excise </span>the entire text that appears <span class="gemarra-regular">above </span>the signatures, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">erase the inked-in </span>part <span class="gemarra-regular">and writ</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> whatever</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he wants </span>in that erased area, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>have unscrupulous <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> sign </span>it. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>this would be a valid document, as <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: A document that comes </span>before the court for ratification in which <span class="gemarra-regular">its </span>content <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the signatures of <span class="gemarra-regular">its</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> witnesses are </span>both written <span class="gemarra-regular">over an erasure </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">valid. </span>The court ratification would then be assumed to be referring to this new, forged document. 

Daf 163b

 <span class="gemarra-regular">This works out well, </span>i.e., this concern does not apply,<span class="gemarra-regular"> according to Rav Kahana, who teaches in the name of Shmuel</span> that a document in which its content and its witnesses’ signatures are both written over an erasure is valid; according to him, all<span class="gemarra-regular"> is well. </span>It is Rav who says that an inked-in gap between the witnesses’ signatures and the court’s ratification is acceptable, and it is Shmuel who says that a document that is written and signed over an erasure is acceptable. <span class="gemarra-regular">But according to Rav Tavyumei,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">who teaches </span>this latter statement <span class="gemarra-regular">in the name of Rav, what can be said? </span>According to him, Rav said both statements, and taken together they pose a difficulty: The inked-in gap between the witnesses’ signatures and the ratification can easily be erased and a new document with signatures can be written over the erasure.
The Gemara answers: Rav <span class="gemarra-regular">maintains </span>that in<span class="gemarra-regular"> all cases like this, </span>where a document and its witnesses’ signatures are written over an erasure and there is a court ratification on a non-erased part of the paper, the later court <span class="gemarra-regular">ratifies </span>the document<span class="gemarra-regular"> not on the basis of the </span>previous court’s<span class="gemarra-regular"> ratification that is on it</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> but </span>only<span class="gemarra-regular"> on the basis of the </span>signatures of the<span class="gemarra-regular"> witnesses that are on it.</span> Therefore, the forging of a document in this manner is impossible, as the prior ratification of the court is disregarded, and the witnesses will attest to what they signed upon.
The Gemara cites another opinion:<span class="gemarra-regular"> And Rabbi Yoḥanan says: They taught </span>in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that a gap of one line does not invalidate the document <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>in the case where that space is <span class="gemarra-regular">between the witnesses’ </span>signatures <span class="gemarra-regular">and</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">the text</span> of the document. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if the gap is<span class="gemarra-regular"> between the</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses’ </span>signatures <span class="gemarra-regular">and</span> a court’s <span class="gemarra-regular">ratificatio</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> of the document, then a space of <span class="gemarra-regular">even one lin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> renders the document <span class="gemarra-regular">not valid.</span>
The Gemara asks:<span class="gemarra-regular"> What is different </span>about the case where there is a one-line gap <span class="gemarra-regular">between the witnesses’ </span>signatures <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the court’s<span class="gemarra-regular"> ratification </span>that you say it is not valid? The Gemara answers: There is a concern that <span class="gemarra-regular">perhaps </span>the holder of the document will<span class="gemarra-regular"> excise </span>the entire text of the document at <span class="gemarra-regular">the top </span>of the paper <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">write</span> a new, brief document, with <span class="gemarra-regular">its</span> text <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the signatures of<span class="gemarra-regular"> its witnesses on one line.</span> The court’s ratification will appear to verify the new, forged document. <span class="gemarra-regular">And</span> Rabbi Yoḥanan<span class="gemarra-regular"> holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a document that comes </span>before the court with<span class="gemarra-regular"> its</span> text<span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>the signatures of<span class="gemarra-regular"> its witnesses</span> appearing <span class="gemarra-regular">on one lin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is valid.</span>
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, </span>the same problem <span class="gemarra-regular">also</span> exists when there is a one-line gap <span class="gemarra-regular">between the witnesses’ </span>signatures <span class="gemarra-regular">and the text: </span>There should be a concern that <span class="gemarra-regular">perhaps </span>he will <span class="gemarra-regular">excise </span>the entire text of the document at<span class="gemarra-regular"> the top </span>of the paper <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">write whatever he wants </span>in a brief, one-line document. <span class="gemarra-regular">And the witnesses’ </span>signatures on the next line, which are there from the old document, will still be <span class="gemarra-regular">signed</span> there, appearing to attest to the veracity of the new, one-line document. The Gemara answers: Rabbi Yoḥanan <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a document that comes </span>before the court with<span class="gemarra-regular"> its </span>text <span class="gemarra-regular">on one line and </span>the signatures of <span class="gemarra-regular">its witnesses</span> appearing <span class="gemarra-regular">on another line</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., on the following line, is <span class="gemarra-regular">not valid</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">And let </span>there be<span class="gemarra-regular"> a concern </span>that<span class="gemarra-regular"> perhaps </span>the holder of the document will excise the entire document, leaving only the blank line and the signatures that follow it, and he will<span class="gemarra-regular"> write </span>a brief document in which<span class="gemarra-regular"> its </span>text <span class="gemarra-regular">and</span> the signatures of<span class="gemarra-regular"> its witnesses</span> are <span class="gemarra-regular">on one line, </span>followed by the original signatures that remained from the original document, <span class="gemarra-regular">and</span> he will <span class="gemarra-regular">say:</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">I did this </span>in order<span class="gemarra-regular"> to increase </span>the number of <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses, </span>the more to publicize the matter written in the document. The document is therefore still forgeable.
The Gemara answers: Rabbi Yoḥanan <span class="gemarra-regular">maintains </span>that in <span class="gemarra-regular">all cases like this, </span>where a document and its witnesses’ signatures are written on one line, followed by other signatures on subsequent lines, the court <span class="gemarra-regular">ratifies </span>the document<span class="gemarra-regular"> not on the basis of the </span>signatures of the<span class="gemarra-regular"> witnesses that</span> are <span class="gemarra-regular">on the bottom,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">but on the basis of the </span>signatures of the<span class="gemarra-regular"> witnesses that </span>are<span class="gemarra-regular"> on top, </span>on the same line as the text. Therefore, the forging of a document in this manner is impossible. The false signatures of the witnesses will be discovered when those witnesses attest to what they signed upon.
§ Having cited Rav’s statement, the Gemara discusses <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>matter <span class="gemarra-regular">itself.</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: A document that comes </span>before the court in which <span class="gemarra-regular">its </span>content <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the signatures of <span class="gemarra-regular">its witnesses are </span>both written <span class="gemarra-regular">over an erasure </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">valid.</span>

Daf 164a

<span class="gemarra-regular">And if you say: </span>There is a possibility of forgery with such a document, as the holder of the document can <span class="gemarra-regular">erase </span>the original writing on the paper, then write the text of the document and have witnesses sign on the part that had been erased, <span class="gemarra-regular">then</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">erase </span>the document text <span class="gemarra-regular">once again,</span> substituting for it a text that is more to his advantage, leaving the original signatures in place, this is not a valid argument. Paper that has been <span class="gemarra-regular">erased once is not similar </span>in appearance<span class="gemarra-regular"> to </span>paper that has been <span class="gemarra-regular">erased twice. </span>It will be seen that the signatures are on a place that had been erased once and that the text is written on a place that had been erased twice, and the forgery will be noticed.
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">But</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">let </span>there be <span class="gemarra-regular">a concern </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">perhaps </span>the holder of the document will <span class="gemarra-regular">initially, </span>after the entire original document, including the signatures, has been erased, but before the second one is written,<span class="gemarra-regular"> throw </span>some <span class="gemarra-regular">ink on the place </span>where the <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses </span>are to sign under the text of the second document, <span class="gemarra-regular">and</span> then <span class="gemarra-regular">erase</span> that ink. He will do this <span class="gemarra-regular">so that</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">when, </span>after the witnesses have signed,<span class="gemarra-regular"> he then erases </span>the document text and writes a false text, it will emerge that both <span class="gemarra-regular">this, </span>the new document’s text, <span class="gemarra-regular">and that,</span> the signatures, will be on paper that had been <span class="gemarra-regular">erased twice.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said </span>in response:<span class="gemarra-regular"> Rav holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses may not sign </span>a document written over <span class="gemarra-regular">an erasure unless </span>the paper<span class="gemarra-regular"> was erased in their presence, </span>i.e., unless they saw the paper after its old text had been erased, before the new text was written. They will then see that the place where they are to sign has been erased twice, while the place where the document is to be written has been erased only once. They will realize that this leaves open an opportunity of subsequent erasing and falsification, and they will refrain from signing.
The Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises an objection</span> to the opinion of Rav from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: A document in which <span class="gemarra-regular">its</span> text is <span class="gemarra-regular">on </span>a part of the <span class="gemarra-regular">paper </span>that has never had writing erased<span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>the signatures of<span class="gemarra-regular"> its witnesses </span>are <span class="gemarra-regular">on</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">an erasur</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> is<span class="gemarra-regular"> valid. </span>The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">But let us be concerned </span>that<span class="gemarra-regular"> perhaps </span>the holder of the document will<span class="gemarra-regular"> erase </span>the text <span class="gemarra-regular">and write </span>in its place <span class="gemarra-regular">whatever he wants, and it will </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">be </span>a document where both <span class="gemarra-regular">its </span>text <span class="gemarra-regular">and</span> the signatures of<span class="gemarra-regular"> its witnesses </span>are <span class="gemarra-regular">on an erasure. </span>Since Rav maintains that such a document is valid, it is easily forgeable in this manner.
The Gemara answers: Such a document is valid only in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where</span> the witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">write this: We, </span>the<span class="gemarra-regular"> witnesses</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> signed on an erasure, but the document </span>text <span class="gemarra-regular">was written on</span> a part of the <span class="gemarra-regular">paper </span>that never had writing erased. If the holder of the document then tries to erase the original text and write new text in its place, the forgery will be noticed.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Where </span>do the witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">write </span>this declaration? <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>they write it <span class="gemarra-regular">underneath </span>their signatures, the holder of the document can simply <span class="gemarra-regular">excise</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">it. </span>And<span class="gemarra-regular"> if</span> they write it<span class="gemarra-regular"> above </span>their signatures, the holder of the document can <span class="gemarra-regular">erase it </span>along with the text of the document. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">They write </span>the declaration <span class="gemarra-regular">between </span>the signature of one<span class="gemarra-regular"> witness and </span>the signature of the other<span class="gemarra-regular"> witness.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If that is so,</span> that the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is discussing a case in which the witnesses write a declaration about the circumstances of the document’s condition, <span class="gemarra-regular">say the latter clause </span>of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: A document in which <span class="gemarra-regular">its</span> text <span class="gemarra-regular">is on an erasure</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the signatures of<span class="gemarra-regular"> its witnesses are on</span> a part of <span class="gemarra-regular">the pape</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> that never had writing erased is <span class="gemarra-regular">not valid.</span> The Gemara presents its question: <span class="gemarra-regular">Why</span> is such a document <span class="gemarra-regular">not valid? Here, too,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">let</span> the witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">write</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">this:</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">We, </span>the<span class="gemarra-regular"> witnesses, signed on paper</span> that never had writing erased,<span class="gemarra-regular"> but the document </span>text was written<span class="gemarra-regular"> on</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">an erasure</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Now </span>in this case <span class="gemarra-regular">as well</span> it should be valid, as <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>can<span class="gemarra-regular"> you say </span>to argue that it is a forgeable document? If you say that the holder of the document, having <span class="gemarra-regular">erased </span>the original document, can <span class="gemarra-regular">erase</span> the writing <span class="gemarra-regular">once again </span>and write a new, false document, this is not a concern, as <span class="gemarra-regular">didn’t you say </span>that paper that has been <span class="gemarra-regular">erased once is not similar </span>in appearance<span class="gemarra-regular"> to </span>paper that has been <span class="gemarra-regular">erased twice? </span>It would therefore be noticeable that the document had been erased a second time, and the forgery would be noticeable. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">That statement </span>applies only <span class="gemarra-regular">when the witnesses are signed on an erasure, </span>and the appearance of that erasure can be compared with the appearance of a double erasure. But in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where the witnesses are signed not on an erasure but on paper</span> that has not had its writing erased, so that there is no contrast between a single erasure and a double erasure, the forgery would<span class="gemarra-regular"> not </span>be<span class="gemarra-regular"> known.</span>
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>let the court<span class="gemarra-regular"> bring another parchment, </span>write something on it <span class="gemarra-regular">and erase it, and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">compare </span>this single erasure with the erasure on the document in question. If the document were erased twice, a contrast would be seen between a single erasure and a double erasure. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">The erasure of this parchment is</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>necessarily <span class="gemarra-regular">similar to the erasure of that parchment. </span>A single erasure on one parchment might resemble a double erasure on a different parchment.
The Gemara continues to suggest: <span class="gemarra-regular">But let us accept, </span>i.e., verify, <span class="gemarra-regular">the signatures of the</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses </span>on the document <span class="gemarra-regular">in court,</span> after which they may safely be erased; <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>then<span class="gemarra-regular"> erase</span> the signatures <span class="gemarra-regular">and compare </span>that erasure to the erasure of the document text, to see if it was erased once or twice. In response to this question <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Hoshaya says:</span> That which is <span class="gemarra-regular">erased on the same day </span>that it was written<span class="gemarra-regular"> is not</span> necessarily <span class="gemarra-regular">similar to</span> that which was <span class="gemarra-regular">erased two days </span>ago, i.e., more than a day after it was written. An older erasure looks different from a new one, so the comparison might not show that there was a double erasure in the document.
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">But let us retain </span>the document for an extra day, at which point both erasures will be old and can be compared. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yirmeya said </span>in response: <span class="gemarra-regular">We are concerned for </span>the possibility of <span class="gemarra-regular">an erring court. </span>If such complicated procedures were used in order to declare a document valid, there would be a chance that a particular court would not apply them properly, and that court would end up ratifying a document that was not valid.
§ The mishna teaches that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ḥanina ben Gamliel says: A tied </span>document whose witnesses wrote their signatures inside of it is valid, because one can transform it into an ordinary document by untying it. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi</span> Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">raised an objection to the statement of Rabbi Ḥanina ben Gamliel:</span>

Daf 164b

<span class="gemarra-regular">But the date of this one,</span> a tied document, <span class="gemarra-regular">is not the same as the date of that one,</span> an ordinary document. In <span class="gemarra-regular">an ordinary</span> document, when the king has<span class="gemarra-regular"> reigned </span>for one<span class="gemarra-regular"> year</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> one<span class="gemarra-regular"> year is counted for him,</span> and when he has reigned for <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>years,<span class="gemarra-regular"> two</span> years <span class="gemarra-regular">are counted for him.</span> By contrast, in <span class="gemarra-regular">a tied </span>document, when the king has<span class="gemarra-regular"> reigned </span>for one<span class="gemarra-regular"> year,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>years<span class="gemarra-regular"> are counted for him,</span> and when he has reigned for<span class="gemarra-regular"> two </span>years,<span class="gemarra-regular"> three </span>years<span class="gemarra-regular"> are counted for him.</span> If a tied document is simply opened up and used as an ordinary document, then it will emerge that it is postdated by a year.
Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>there are<span class="gemarra-regular"> times </span>this can be problematic, as in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where</span> the debtor <span class="gemarra-regular">borrows</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">money</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">from</span> the creditor, and the details of the loan are written <span class="gemarra-regular">in a tied</span> document. <span class="gemarra-regular">And</span> the debtor <span class="gemarra-regular">chances upon</span> some <span class="gemarra-regular">money in the interim, </span>i.e., during the first year after the document was written, <span class="gemarra-regular">and</span> he<span class="gemarra-regular"> repays</span> the creditor, <span class="gemarra-regular">and says to him: Give me </span>back <span class="gemarra-regular">my </span>promissory<span class="gemarra-regular"> note, </span>as I have just repaid you. <span class="gemarra-regular">And</span> the creditor <span class="gemarra-regular">says to </span>the debtor:<span class="gemarra-regular"> I lost </span>the document and cannot give it to you. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>in lieu of returning the promissory note, the creditor <span class="gemarra-regular">writes a receipt </span>for the debtor, as protection against a second collection.
Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">And</span> then,<span class="gemarra-regular"> when</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">the</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">time for</span> repayment written in the promissory note <span class="gemarra-regular">arrives, </span>the creditor will <span class="gemarra-regular">make it</span> into <span class="gemarra-regular">an</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">ordinary</span> document by undoing its stitches and opening it up, <span class="gemarra-regular">and</span> he can then <span class="gemarra-regular">say</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">to</span> the debtor:<span class="gemarra-regular"> It is now that you borrowed this </span>money <span class="gemarra-regular">from me, </span>as attested in this promissory note, and the receipt you have in your possession is for a previous debt, as its date precedes the date on my document.
The Gemara answers: Rabbi Ḥanina ben Gamliel <span class="gemarra-regular">holds</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">one does not write a receipt </span>in such cases. If a creditor loses his promissory note, the debtor need not pay him at all, out of concern that the debt may one day be collected again when the promissory note is found. He is not required to pay the debt and accept only a receipt, which he will then have to guard permanently to protect himself against a second collection.
The Gemara asks with regard to the previous discussion: <span class="gemarra-regular">And was Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">expert in </span>the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">tied</span> documents? <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>wasn’t there<span class="gemarra-regular"> a certain tied</span> document <span class="gemarra-regular">that</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">came before</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>when <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi saw the date he <span class="gemarra-regular">said: This is</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">a postdated document. And </span>a Sage named <span class="gemarra-regular">Zuni</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">said to Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi:<span class="gemarra-regular"> Such is the custom of this nation; </span>when the king has <span class="gemarra-regular">reigned </span>for one<span class="gemarra-regular"> year, two </span>years <span class="gemarra-regular">are counted for him,</span> and when he has reigned for<span class="gemarra-regular"> two </span>years,<span class="gemarra-regular"> three </span>years<span class="gemarra-regular"> are counted for him. </span>The document is therefore not postdated. From this anecdote it is clear that Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi himself had not been familiar with this practice.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">After </span>Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">heard it from Zunin</span> he accepted the explanation <span class="gemarra-regular">and held</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>way himself, and that is what prompted him to raise his objection.
§ There was<span class="gemarra-regular"> a certain document on which was written,</span> as its date: <span class="gemarra-regular">In the year of so-and-so, Archon [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">Arkhan</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> a title for a ruler, without stating any particular year of his reign. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ḥanina said: Let it be investigated when </span>it was that this <span class="gemarra-regular">Archon rose to his </span>position of<span class="gemarra-regular"> archon,</span> i.e., find out the year he came to power, and the validity of the document is established from that year.
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">But perhaps </span>the writer of the document was using an Aramaic or Hebrew term, and intended to say <span class="gemarra-regular">that</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">the reign of</span> so-and-so had already <span class="gemarra-regular">extended</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">arikh</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> for several years. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Hoshaya says:</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">Such </span>is<span class="gemarra-regular"> the custom of this nation </span>where the document was written: In the<span class="gemarra-regular"> first year</span> of the king’s reign<span class="gemarra-regular"> they refer to him </span>with the title <span class="gemarra-regular">Archon; </span>in his<span class="gemarra-regular"> second </span>year<span class="gemarra-regular"> they refer to him </span>with the title <span class="gemarra-italic">Digon</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">But perhaps </span>the people <span class="gemarra-regular">deposed </span>the ruler<span class="gemarra-regular"> and</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">then</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">reinstated him, </span>and the document was written in the first year of his second reign. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yirmey</span><span class="gemarra-regular">a</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">said: </span>In <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>case, <span class="gemarra-regular">they </span>would<span class="gemarra-regular"> refer to him </span>with the title <span class="gemarra-regular">Archon</span><span class="gemarra-italic"> Digon</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
§ Apropos these Greek terms, the Gemara cites two <span class="it-text">baraitot </span>that mention them. <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>(<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span>, <span class="it-text">Nazir</span> 1:2) that if one said: <span class="gemarra-regular">I am hereby a nazirit</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">heina</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> or stated a similar expression with other comparable Greek terms, <span class="gemarra-regular">Sumakhos said </span>that his status depends on which term he used. If he used the word <span class="gemarra-italic">heina</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> he is a nazirite for <span class="gemarra-regular">one</span> term of naziriteship, i.e., thirty days; if he said <span class="gemarra-italic">digon</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> he is a nazirite for <span class="gemarra-regular">two</span> terms of thirty days each; if he said <span class="gemarra-italic">terigon</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>he is a nazirite for<span class="gemarra-regular"> three </span>terms; <span class="gemarra-italic">tetrigon</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>for<span class="gemarra-regular"> four </span>terms; <span class="gemarra-italic">pentigon</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>for<span class="gemarra-regular"> five </span>terms.
<span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught</span> in another <span class="it-text">baraita </span>(<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span>, <span class="it-text">Nega’im</span> 6:3): <span class="gemarra-regular">A round house</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> or one that is shaped like <span class="gemarra-regular">a</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">digon</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., it has two walls, one straight and one curved, or one that is shaped like <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">terigon</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., a triangle, or one that is shaped like <span class="gemarra-regular">a pentagon, does</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">not become susceptible to the ritual impurity of leprous spots. </span>If it is shaped like <span class="gemarra-regular">a</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">tetrigon</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>i.e., a quadrilateral, it <span class="gemarra-regular">becomes susceptible to the ritual impurity of leprous spots.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">From where are these matters </span>derived? The Gemara answers: It is <span class="gemarra-regular">as the Sages taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: The Torah <span class="gemarra-regular">states</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">above: </span>“If the plague be in the walls of the house” (Leviticus 14:37). The verse did not state: <span class="gemarra-regular">A wall, </span>but <span class="gemarra-regular">“walls,” </span>indicating that the house in question has at least <span class="gemarra-regular">two</span> walls. And where it <span class="gemarra-regular">states below: </span>“If the plague has spread in the walls of the house” (Leviticus 14:39), instead of stating: <span class="gemarra-regular">A wall, </span>the verse states<span class="gemarra-regular"> “walls,” </span>indicating another <span class="gemarra-regular">two</span> walls. There <span class="gemarra-regular">are </span>a total of <span class="gemarra-regular">four</span> walls mentioned<span class="gemarra-regular"> here </span>in order to indicate that a house can become impure through leprous spots only if it has four sides.
§ The Gemara relates: There was <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain tied </span>document <span class="gemarra-regular">that came before Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi, <span class="gemarra-regular">and Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi, not realizing it was a folded document, <span class="gemarra-regular">said: There is no date on this </span>document, so it is not valid.<span class="gemarra-regular"> Rabbi Shimon, son of</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi, <span class="gemarra-regular">said to</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi: <span class="gemarra-regular">Perhaps </span>the date is<span class="gemarra-regular"> hidden between its tied </span>folds. Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi<span class="gemarra-regular"> opened it and saw </span>that the date was in fact between the tied folds. <span class="gemarra-regular">Afterward,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi</span> Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">looked at</span> his son <span class="gemarra-regular">disapprovingly, </span>as he held that one should not write a tied document. His son <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: I did not write it; Rabbi Yehuda Ḥayyata wrote it. </span>Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">said to</span> his son: <span class="gemarra-regular">Turn away</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">from</span> uttering <span class="gemarra-regular">this</span> kind of <span class="gemarra-regular">malicious speech</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
Another<span class="gemarra-regular"> time,</span> Rabbi Shimon <span class="gemarra-regular">was sitting before</span> his father <span class="gemarra-regular">and reciting a section of the book of Psalms. Rabbi</span> Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>to him: <span class="gemarra-regular">How straight</span> and neat is<span class="gemarra-regular"> this writing</span> in this book from which you are reading. Rabbi Shimon <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: I did not write it; Yehuda Ḥayyata wrote it.</span> Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">told</span> his son: <span class="gemarra-regular">Turn away from </span>uttering <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>kind of <span class="gemarra-regular">malicious speech.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, there,</span> in the first episode,<span class="gemarra-regular"> there is malicious speech </span>involved, since Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi was displeased with the writer of the document, <span class="gemarra-regular">but here,</span> in the second episode, <span class="gemarra-regular">what malicious speech is there?</span> Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi was complimenting the writer of the book of Psalms, not criticizing him. The Gemara answers: It is <span class="gemarra-regular">because</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">of</span> what <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Dimi</span> teaches. <span class="gemarra-regular">As Rav Dimi, the brother of Rav Safra, teaches: A person should never speak the praises of another</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as out of the praise </span>spoken about<span class="gemarra-regular"> him </span>someone may<span class="gemarra-regular"> come to </span>speak to<span class="gemarra-regular"> his detriment.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Amram says</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says:</span> There are <span class="gemarra-regular">three sins</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">from which a person is not spared each day.</span> They are: Having<span class="gemarra-regular"> sinful thoughts</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and</span> committing sins concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">deliberation in prayer</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and</span> uttering <span class="gemarra-regular">malicious speech.</span> The Gemara asks: Can it<span class="gemarra-regular"> enter your mind</span> that a person cannot go through the day without uttering <span class="gemarra-regular">malicious speech?</span>

Daf 165a

The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather,</span> Rav was referring to uttering <span class="gemarra-regular">a hint, </span>i.e., words with a bare trace, <span class="gemarra-regular">of malicious speech</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda says</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says:</span> The<span class="gemarra-regular"> majority </span>of people suc-cumb to sin <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to robbery</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and a minority</span> of people succumb to sin <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to sexual matters,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and everyone</span> succumbs to sin <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">malicious speech.</span> The Gemara asks: Can it<span class="gemarra-regular"> enter your mind</span> that all people sin <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">malicious speech?</span> The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather,</span> Rav was referring to uttering <span class="gemarra-regular">a hint</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">of malicious speech.</span>
§ The mishna teaches, with regard to documents, that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: Everything </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with regional custom.</span> The Gemara wonders: <span class="gemarra-regular">And does the first</span><span class="gemarra-italic"> tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not accept</span> that one should follow the <span class="gemarra-regular">regional custom?</span> It is not reasonable that he would take issue with such a basic concept.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi said</span> in explanation: <span class="gemarra-regular">In a place where the custom </span>is to write<span class="gemarra-regular"> an ordinary</span> document, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">said to</span> a scribe:<span class="gemarra-regular"> Make an ordinary </span>document <span class="gemarra-regular">for me, and </span>the scribe <span class="gemarra-regular">went </span>and<span class="gemarra-regular"> made a tied </span>document <span class="gemarra-regular">for him, </span>it is assumed that he was <span class="gemarra-regular">particular</span> about wanting an ordinary document. Similarly, in a place where <span class="gemarra-regular">the custom </span>is to write <span class="gemarra-regular">a</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">tied</span> document, <span class="gemarra-regular">and</span> one <span class="gemarra-regular">said</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">to</span> a scribe: <span class="gemarra-regular">Make a tied</span> document <span class="gemarra-regular">for me,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and</span> the scribe <span class="gemarra-regular">went </span>and<span class="gemarra-regular"> made an ordinary</span> document <span class="gemarra-regular">for him,</span> it is assumed that he was <span class="gemarra-regular">particular</span> about wanting a tied document. In both of these cases, the document is considered to have been written without the consent of the one who requested it. If it is a bill of divorce it may not be used, as a bill of divorce must be written with the knowledge and consent of the husband.
<span class="gemarra-regular">When</span> the <span class="it-text">tanna’im</span> of the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">disagree </span>is<span class="gemarra-regular"> in a place where the custom </span>is to write <span class="gemarra-regular">both an</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">ordinary</span> document<span class="gemarra-regular"> and</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">a tied</span> document, <span class="gemarra-regular">and</span> one <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>a scribe: <span class="gemarra-regular">Make an ordinary </span>document <span class="gemarra-regular">for me,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the scribe <span class="gemarra-regular">went and made a tied </span>document <span class="gemarra-regular">for him.</span> In such a case, one<span class="gemarra-regular"> Sage, </span>the first <span class="it-text">tanna</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">holds</span> that the one requesting the document was <span class="gemarra-regular">particular</span> about wanting an ordinary document, and since the scribe wrote a tied document, it is considered to have been written without his consent. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>one<span class="gemarra-regular"> Sage, </span>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel, <span class="gemarra-regular">holds</span> that the one requesting the document was merely <span class="gemarra-regular">indicating </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">position</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the scribe, stating that if the scribe wanted to save himself the trouble of writing a tied document there would no objection.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said: </span>Concerning<span class="gemarra-regular"> Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel, and Rabbi Shimon, and Rabbi Elazar, they all hold</span> that when one gives instructions to an agent, he is merely <span class="gemarra-regular">indicating </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">position</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">to him,</span> as opposed to expressing an insistence on certain details.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel </span>holds this is the case, <span class="gemarra-regular">as</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">we have </span>just <span class="gemarra-regular">said. Rabbi Shimon </span>holds this as well, <span class="gemarra-regular">as</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">we learned</span> in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Kiddushin</span> 48a), as explained by the Gemara there, that the first <span class="it-text">tanna</span> rules that if a woman appoints an agent to accept her betrothal money and tells him that the man will be giving a golden dinar, or that he will be giving a silver dinar, and he in fact gives the other type of dinar, the betrothal is not valid, as in accepting the wrong dinar the agent did not follow the woman’s instructions exactly.
But <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon says: If he misled her to </span>her<span class="gemarra-regular"> advantage</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., he told her he was going to give a silver dinar and gave her a golden dinar, <span class="gemarra-regular">she is betrothed. </span>When the woman told the agent to receive the silver dinar she did not mean to insist that the dinar be silver as opposed to gold, but was only indicating her position, which is that she would have no objection to receiving only a silver dinar.
Abaye continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar</span> also holds this,<span class="gemarra-regular"> as we learned</span> in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Gittin</span> 65a): With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">the woman who, </span>when designating her agent for receipt of her bill of divorce, <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>to her agent: <span class="gemarra-regular">Receive my bill of divorce for m</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in such and such a place, and he received it for her in another place, </span>the divorce is <span class="gemarra-regular">invalid; and</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar deems </span>it<span class="gemarra-regular"> valid. </span>One <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage,</span> the first <span class="it-text">tanna</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">holds</span> that the woman is <span class="gemarra-regular">particular </span>that her instructions be followed, <span class="gemarra-regular">and</span> one <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage,</span> Rabbi Elazar, <span class="gemarra-regular">holds</span> that she was merely <span class="gemarra-regular">indicating </span>her <span class="gemarra-regular">position to </span>the agent, informing him of where she thought her husband would be.
§ The mishna teaches: With regard to<span class="gemarra-regular"> an ordinary </span>document <span class="gemarra-regular">in which</span> the signature of <span class="gemarra-regular">a single witness is written,</span> and a tied document in which the signatures of only two witnesses are written, they are both not valid. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">was</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary</span> for the mishna to teach that <span class="gemarra-regular">a</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">tied</span> document <span class="gemarra-regular">in which</span> the signatures of only <span class="gemarra-regular">two witnesses</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">are written</span> is<span class="gemarra-regular"> not valid, </span>as it might<span class="gemarra-regular"> enter your mind to say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">since</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">generally</span> a document is <span class="gemarra-regular">valid</span> with two signatures, <span class="gemarra-regular">here too </span>it is<span class="gemarra-regular"> valid;</span> therefore, the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>it is in fact <span class="gemarra-regular">not valid. But </span>why was it necessary to state that <span class="gemarra-regular">an ordinary </span>document <span class="gemarra-regular">in which</span> the signature of <span class="gemarra-regular">a single witness is written </span>is not valid; isn’t this<span class="gemarra-regular"> obvious?</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">said: </span>It<span class="gemarra-regular"> is necessary </span>to state this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>to teach <span class="gemarra-regular">that</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">even</span> if there is <span class="gemarra-regular">one witness</span> signed on the document <span class="gemarra-regular">in writing</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and, </span>in addition, <span class="gemarra-regular">one witness</span> testifies <span class="gemarra-regular">orall</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span> to the contents of the document, the document is not valid.
The Gemara relates:<span class="gemarra-regular"> Ameimar</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">deemed</span> a document <span class="gemarra-regular">vali</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">in</span> the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one witness</span> signed on the document <span class="gemarra-regular">in writing</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">one witness</span> testifying <span class="gemarra-regular">orally</span> to the contents of the document. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi said to Ameimar:</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">And what of</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">that</span> statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye, </span>which deemed such a document invalid? Ameimar <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him:</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">I did not hear</span> of it, as though <span class="gemarra-regular">to say:</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">I do not hold</span> like it; I disagree with Abaye.
Rav Ashi asks:<span class="gemarra-regular"> But </span>if you disagree, the <span class="gemarra-regular">difficulty</span>

Daf 165b

with <span class="gemarra-regular">the mishna</span> remains: Why does the mishna state that which is obvious, that a document with a single witness’s signature is not valid?
