The Gemara answers that the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us this:</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">That</span> the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>witnesses signed <span class="gemarra-regular">on a tied </span>document is <span class="gemarra-regular">similar to </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one witness</span> signed <span class="gemarra-regular">on</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">an ordinary</span> document: <span class="gemarra-regular">Just as</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">there,</span> in the case of a single witness signed on an ordinary document, <span class="gemarra-regular">the</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">disqualification</span> is<span class="gemarra-regular"> by Torah law</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> so too here, </span>in the case of two witnesses signed on a tied document, <span class="gemarra-regular">the disqualification</span> is<span class="gemarra-regular"> by Torah law.</span>
Ameimar added: <span class="gemarra-regular">Know </span>that the signature of one witness on a document and the oral testimony of one person about it can be combined into a single testimony,<span class="gemarra-regular"> as the colleagues </span>of the academy <span class="gemarra-regular">sent </span>a question <span class="gemarra-regular">from there, </span>i.e., Eretz Yisrael, <span class="gemarra-regular">to Rabbi Yirmey</span><span class="gemarra-regular">a</span> seeking clarification of a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>. The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> states that the first <span class="it-text">tanna</span> holds that the testimony of two witnesses to an event can be combined into a single testimony only if both of them witnessed the event together, while Rabbi Yehoshua ben Korḥa holds that the testimony can be combined even if they saw the event one after the other. Furthermore, the first <span class="it-text">tanna</span> holds that their testimony is accepted only if they both testify together. By contrast, Rabbi Natan holds that the testimony of one witness may be accepted today, and when the other witness comes the next day his testimony may be accepted, and the two testimonies may thereby be combined.
The dilemma they posed to Rabbi Yirmeya was this: In the case of a loan for which there is <span class="gemarra-regular">one witness in writing, </span>signed on a promissory note, <span class="gemarra-regular">and one </span>other <span class="gemarra-regular">witness </span>who testifies to the loan <span class="gemarra-regular">orally, what</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is</span> the <span class="it-text">halakha </span>with regard to the possibility <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the two of them <span class="gemarra-regular">will combine </span>to testify as two witnesses?
The dilemma is clarified:<span class="gemarra-regular"> According to </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of the first </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span> of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, who engages in a dispute <span class="gemarra-regular">with Rabbi Yehoshua ben Korḥa,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">you should not raise the dilemma,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">as</span> according to his opinion there are situations where <span class="gemarra-regular">even two</span> testimonies <span class="gemarra-regular">in writing or two oral </span>testimonies <span class="gemarra-regular">are not combined</span> into a single testimony. All the more so they are not combined when one is written and one is oral. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">when should you raise the dilemma?</span> Raise it<span class="gemarra-regular"> according to </span>the opinion<span class="gemarra-regular"> of Rabbi Yehoshua ben Korḥa.</span> The dilemma is: Is it only testimonies of <span class="gemarra-regular">two</span> witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">in writing or two</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">oral</span> witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">that are combined</span> into a single testimony, <span class="gemarra-regular">but we do not combine </span>testimony of <span class="gemarra-regular">one witness in writing and one orally?</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">Or perhaps</span> there <span class="gemarra-regular">is no difference </span>between these cases.
Rabbi Yirmeya humbly <span class="gemarra-regular">sent </span>back his response <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the colleagues of the academy:<span class="gemarra-regular"> I am not worthy</span> of being the recipient of the query <span class="gemarra-regular">that you sent to me.</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">But this</span> is how <span class="gemarra-regular">the opinion of your student, </span>i.e., himself,<span class="gemarra-regular"> leans:</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">That </span>the testimonies<span class="gemarra-regular"> should be combined</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> This exchange between Rabbi Yirmeya and his questioners indicates that Ameimar’s opinion is accepted.
Rav Ashi <span class="gemarra-regular">said to</span> Ameimar: <span class="gemarra-regular">We</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">teach</span> this entire incident with Rabbi Yirmeya differently, <span class="gemarra-regular">as follows: That the colleagues </span>of the academy <span class="gemarra-regular">sent </span>this question <span class="gemarra-regular">to Rabbi Yirmeya: </span>If there are<span class="gemarra-regular"> two </span>witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">who</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">testified,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">one</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">in this court and one in that court</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to the possibility <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the judges of one <span class="gemarra-regular">court</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">could come</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">to</span> the other <span class="gemarra-regular">court</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and</span> in this manner the two testimonies <span class="gemarra-regular">will be combined </span>to become a valid testimony of two witnesses?
The dilemma is clarified:<span class="gemarra-regular"> According to </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of the first </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span> of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, who also engages in a dispute <span class="gemarra-regular">with Rabbi Natan,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">you should not raise the dilemma,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">as</span> according to his opinion, testimonies that are not given concurrently <span class="gemarra-regular">are not combined</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">even in one court;</span> all the more so when they are given in two different courts. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">when should you raise the dilemma?</span> Raise it<span class="gemarra-regular"> according to </span>the opinion<span class="gemarra-regular"> of Rabbi Natan. </span>The dilemma is: Is it <span class="gemarra-regular">in one court that </span>the two separate testimonies <span class="gemarra-regular">are combined, but </span>when they are given <span class="gemarra-regular">in two </span>separate <span class="gemarra-regular">courts they are not combined? Or perhaps</span> there <span class="gemarra-regular">is no difference.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And</span> Rabbi Yirmeya <span class="gemarra-regular">sent</span> back his response <span class="gemarra-regular">to them: I am not worthy</span> of being the recipient of the query <span class="gemarra-regular">that you sent to me.</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">But this </span>is how <span class="gemarra-regular">the</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">opinion of your student leans: That they</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">should be combined.</span> According to this version of the exchange between Rabbi Yirmeya and his questioners there is no relevance to Ameimar’s statement.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Mar bar Ḥiyya said</span> yet a third version, that the dilemma the colleagues of the academy <span class="gemarra-regular">sent to </span>Rabbi Yirmeya is<span class="gemarra-regular"> as follows: </span>If there are <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">who testified in this court and then</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">testified in that court</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to the possibility <span class="gemarra-regular">that one </span>judge would <span class="gemarra-regular">come</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">from each court </span>to one location and relate the testimony he had heard to the other, <span class="gemarra-regular">and</span> in this manner the two testimonies <span class="gemarra-regular">will be combined?</span>
The dilemma is clarified:<span class="gemarra-regular"> According to </span>the opinion<span class="gemarra-regular"> of Rabbi Natan you should not raise the dilemma. Now</span> that he maintains that <span class="gemarra-regular">we combine</span> two individual <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is</span> it <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>to ask if <span class="gemarra-regular">judges</span> may be combined in this manner? They certainly can be combined. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">when should you raise the dilemma?</span> Raise it<span class="gemarra-regular"> according to </span>the opinion<span class="gemarra-regular"> of the first </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span> of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, who engages in a dispute <span class="gemarra-regular">with Rabbi Natan. </span>The dilemma is:<span class="gemarra-regular"> Is</span> it only testimony of <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses that we do not combine</span> into a single testimony, <span class="gemarra-regular">but we do combine judges</span> from two different courts? <span class="gemarra-regular">Or perhaps</span> there <span class="gemarra-regular">is no difference.</span>
Rabbi Yirmeya <span class="gemarra-regular">sent</span> back his response <span class="gemarra-regular">to them:</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">I am not worthy</span> of being the recipient of the query <span class="gemarra-regular">that you sent to me.</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">But this is</span> how <span class="gemarra-regular">the opinion of your student leans:</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">That they should be combined.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Ravina said</span> a fourth version, that the dilemma the colleagues of the academy <span class="gemarra-regular">sent to </span>Rabbi Yirmeya is<span class="gemarra-regular"> as follows: </span>If there were <span class="gemarra-regular">three </span>judges <span class="gemarra-regular">who</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">sat</span> as a court <span class="gemarra-regular">to ratify a document,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and,</span> after verifying the signatures of the witnesses, <span class="gemarra-regular">one of </span>the judges <span class="gemarra-regular">died, must they </span>mention this in their statement of ratification, to account for why the declaration is signed by only two judges, and<span class="gemarra-regular"> write: We were sitting in </span>a group of<span class="gemarra-regular"> three </span>judges,<span class="gemarra-regular"> and one of </span>the judges <span class="gemarra-regular">is no </span>longer alive? <span class="gemarra-regular">Or</span> perhaps they are <span class="gemarra-regular">not</span> required to write this.
Rabbi Yirmeya <span class="gemarra-regular">sent</span> back his response <span class="gemarra-regular">to them: I am not worthy</span> of being the recipient of the query <span class="gemarra-regular">that you sent to me. But this is</span> how<span class="gemarra-regular"> the opinion of your student leans:</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">That they are required to write: We were sitting in </span>a group of<span class="gemarra-regular"> three </span>judges,<span class="gemarra-regular"> and one of </span>the judges <span class="gemarra-regular">is no </span>longer alive.
The Gemara relates: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>it was<span class="gemarra-regular"> because of this</span> fitting answer, to whichever version of the dilemma that is adopted, that the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">brought</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yirmeya</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">into the study hall </span>after he had been expelled, as related earlier in this tractate (23b).
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If <span class="gemarra-regular">it is written in</span> a document that someone owes: <span class="gemarra-regular">One hundred dinars, which ar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> twenty </span><span class="gemarra-italic">sela</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> which is internally inconsistent since there are twenty-five <span class="it-text">sela</span> in a hundred dinars, the holder of the document <span class="gemarra-regular">has </span>the right to claim <span class="gemarra-regular">only</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">twenty</span> <span class="it-text">sela</span>, the lower of the two amounts. If it is written that he owes: <span class="gemarra-regular">One hundred dinars, which are thirty </span><span class="gemarra-italic">sela</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>the holder of the document<span class="gemarra-regular"> has </span>the right to claim <span class="gemarra-regular">only</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">one hundred</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">dinars,</span> again the lower of the two amounts.
If it is written that someone owes: <span class="gemarra-regular">Silver dinars that are,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and</span> the remainder of the text, where the number of dinars should be specified, <span class="gemarra-regular">was erased</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the amount must be <span class="gemarra-regular">no less than two</span> dinars, the lowest amount to which the plural word dinars can be referring. That is what the creditor can claim. Similarly, if it is written: <span class="gemarra-regular">Silver </span><span class="gemarra-italic">sela</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">that are, and</span> the remainder of the text <span class="gemarra-regular">was erased,</span> the amount must be <span class="gemarra-regular">no less than two</span> <span class="it-text">sela</span>. And if it is written: <span class="gemarra-regular">Darics</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">that are, and</span> the remainder of the text <span class="gemarra-regular">was erased,</span> the amount must be <span class="gemarra-regular">no less than two</span> darics.
If it is <span class="gemarra-regular">written in </span>the document<span class="gemarra-regular"> above, </span>in an earlier place in the document, that someone owes <span class="gemarra-regular">one hundred dinars,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and below,</span> toward the end of the document, it is written that the amount owed is <span class="gemarra-regular">two hundred </span>dinars, or if <span class="gemarra-regular">above </span>it is written <span class="gemarra-regular">two hundred</span> dinars <span class="gemarra-regular">and below one hundred dinars,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">everything follows the bottom</span> amount. <span class="gemarra-regular">If so,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">why</span> does one <span class="gemarra-regular">write </span>the information in <span class="gemarra-regular">the upper</span> part of the document at all? It is a safety measure, <span class="gemarra-regular">so </span>that<span class="gemarra-regular"> if one letter</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is erased</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">from</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">the</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">lower</span> part of the document, thereby rendering it illegible, the information <span class="gemarra-regular">can be learned from the upper</span> part of the document.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>(<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span> 11:2): If a document <span class="gemarra-regular">states </span>that someone owes <span class="gemarra-regular">silver</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> without specifying which silver coin, the amount must be <span class="gemarra-regular">no less than a</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">silver dinar. </span>If it states: <span class="gemarra-regular">Silver dinars, or: Dinars silver, </span>the amount must be <span class="gemarra-regular">no less than two silver dinars, </span>the lowest amount to which that phrase can refer. If it states: <span class="gemarra-regular">Silver, in dinars, </span>the amount must be <span class="gemarra-regular">no less than two golden dinars’ </span>worth of<span class="gemarra-regular"> silver.</span>
The Gemara analyzes the beginning of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">The Master says:</span> If a document states that someone owes <span class="gemarra-regular">silver,</span> without specifying which silver coin, the amount must be <span class="gemarra-regular">no less than a</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">silver dinar. </span>The Gemara asks:<span class="gemarra-regular"> But </span>why not<span class="gemarra-regular"> say </span>that the intention of the word silver is not to a coin at all, but to a small <span class="gemarra-regular">piece</span> of silver? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar said: </span>The case of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">where</span> the word <span class="gemarra-regular">coin is written</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">in</span> the document. The Gemara asks further: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>why not<span class="gemarra-regular"> say </span>that the intent is not a dinar, but smaller coins, such as <span class="gemarra-italic">perutot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa said: </span>The <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is stated <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to a place</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">where</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">silver</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">perutot</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> do not circulate.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught</span> in the continuation of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: If it is written in a document that someone owes <span class="gemarra-regular">gold,</span> the amount must be <span class="gemarra-regular">no less than a golden dinar. </span>If it is written: <span class="gemarra-regular">Golden dinars, or: Dinars golden, </span>the amount must be <span class="gemarra-regular">no less than two golden dinars. </span>If it is written: <span class="gemarra-regular">Gold, in dinars, </span>the amount must be <span class="gemarra-regular">no less than two silver dinars’ </span>worth of<span class="gemarra-regular"> gold.</span>
The Gemara analyzes the beginning of this section of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">The Master says:</span> If it is written in a document that someone owes <span class="gemarra-regular">gold,</span> the amount must be <span class="gemarra-regular">no less than a golden dinar. </span>The Gemara asks: But why not<span class="gemarra-regular"> say </span>that the intention of the word gold is not to a coin at all, but to a small <span class="gemarra-regular">piece</span> of gold? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar said: </span>The case of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">where</span> the word <span class="gemarra-regular">coin is written</span> in the document.

Daf 166a

The Gemara asks further: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>why not <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that the intent is not a dinar, but smaller coins, such as <span class="gemarra-italic">perutot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? </span>The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">People do not make </span><span class="gemarra-italic">perutot</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of gold.</span>
The Gemara continues its analysis of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, which states: If it is written: <span class="gemarra-regular">Gold, in dinars, </span>the amount must be <span class="gemarra-regular">no less than two silver dinars’ </span>worth of <span class="gemarra-regular">gold. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>why not <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that the document <span class="gemarra-regular">is speaking </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">two golden dinars’ </span>worth of <span class="gemarra-regular">pieces of gold? Abaye says: </span>This interpretation is also possible, but the guiding principle in all interpretations of ambiguities is that <span class="gemarra-regular">the holder of the document </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">at a disadvantage.</span>
The Gemara asks a question from <span class="gemarra-regular">the first clause </span>of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">which teaches </span>that if the document states: <span class="gemarra-regular">Silver in dinars, </span>the amount must be <span class="gemarra-regular">no less than two golden dinars’ </span>worth of <span class="gemarra-regular">silver. Why </span>is he entitled to so much? <span class="gemarra-regular">Say </span>that the document <span class="gemarra-regular">is speaking </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">silver </span>only, and means: <span class="gemarra-regular">Two silver dinars’ </span>worth of silver <span class="gemarra-regular">pieces. </span>This interpretation would be a lower value than the interpretation assigned to it by the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, and would be in keeping with the principle that the holder of the document is at a disadvantage.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi said </span>in reply that the text of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> should be emended: In <span class="gemarra-regular">the first clause </span>the case is <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the scribe <span class="gemarra-regular">wrote: </span>Silver in dinars, using the plural form <span class="gemarra-italic">dinarei</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>which refers specifically to golden dinars. In <span class="gemarra-regular">the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> latter clause, </span>the case is <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the scribe <span class="gemarra-regular">wrote: </span>Gold in dinars, using the plural form <span class="gemarra-italic">dinarin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> which denotes silver dinars specifically.
The Gemara supports its assertion that there is a difference between these two plural forms: <span class="gemarra-regular">And from where do you say that </span>there is <span class="gemarra-regular">a difference between </span>the words <span class="gemarra-italic">dinarei</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span><span class="gemarra-italic">dinarin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span>
This is <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is taught </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Karetot</span> 8a): In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a woman for whom there was uncertainty </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">five births</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and likewise a woman for whom there was <span class="gemarra-regular">uncertainty </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">five </span>irregular <span class="gemarra-regular">discharges </span>of blood from the uterus [<span class="it-text">ziva</span>], <span class="gemarra-regular">she brings one offering, and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">she may partake of </span>the meat of <span class="gemarra-regular">offerings. And the remaining </span>offerings <span class="gemarra-regular">are not an obligation for her</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> If she <span class="gemarra-regular">has in her </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">five definite births </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">five definite discharges of a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">zava</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, she brings one offering, and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">she may partake of </span>the meat of <span class="gemarra-regular">offerings. And the remaining </span>offerings <span class="gemarra-regular">are an obligation for her.</span>
That mishna continues: There was <span class="gemarra-regular">an incident where </span>the price of <span class="gemarra-regular">nests</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., pairs of birds, <span class="gemarra-regular">stood in Jerusalem at golden </span><span class="gemarra-italic">dinarei</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>as the great demand for birds for the offerings of a woman after childbirth and a <span class="it-text">zava</span> led to an increase in the price. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel said: </span>I take an oath by <span class="gemarra-regular">this abode </span>of the Divine Presence that <span class="gemarra-regular">I will not lie </span>down <span class="gemarra-regular">tonight until </span>the price of nests <span class="gemarra-regular">will be in</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">dinarin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>Ultimately, <span class="gemarra-regular">he entered the court and taught: A woman for whom there were five definite births </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">five definite discharges of a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">zava</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> brings one offering, and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">she may partake of </span>the meat of <span class="gemarra-regular">offerings. And the remaining </span>offerings <span class="gemarra-regular">are not an obligation for her. </span>

Daf 166b

The mishna concludes: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>as a result, the price of the <span class="gemarra-regular">nests stood that day at one-quarter </span>of a silver dinar, as the demand for nests decreased. It is clear in the mishna that the term <span class="it-text">dinarei</span> indicates a higher value than the term <span class="it-text">dinarin</span>.
§ The mishna teaches: If it is <span class="gemarra-regular">written </span>in the document <span class="gemarra-regular">above </span>that someone owes one hundred dinars, and below it is written two hundred dinars, or if above it is written two hundred and below one hundred, everything follows the bottom amount. If so, why does one write the information in the upper part of the document at all? It is a safety measure, so that if one letter is erased from the lower part of the document, thereby rendering it illegible, the information can be learned from the upper part of the document. <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> (<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span> 11:4): Information concerning what is written <span class="gemarra-regular">below may be learned from </span>what is written <span class="gemarra-regular">above </span>if the lower text is missing <span class="gemarra-regular">one letter, but not </span>if it is missing <span class="gemarra-regular">two letters. </span>In that case, in the event of a discrepancy between information written above and information written below, the document is not valid.
<span class="gemarra-regular">For example, </span>if the name of one party is written as <span class="gemarra-regular">Ḥanan </span>below and Ḥanani above, it may be derived <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the word <span class="gemarra-regular">Ḥanani </span>written above that the party is named Ḥanani. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>similarly, if a name is written <span class="gemarra-regular">Anan </span>below, it may be learned <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the name <span class="gemarra-regular">Anani </span>written above that the party is named Anani.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is different </span>about <span class="gemarra-regular">two letters </span>missing, that the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> teaches <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the name written below <span class="gemarra-regular">cannot </span>be corrected from the name written above? The Gemara suggests: It is out of concern that <span class="gemarra-regular">perhaps </span>it will <span class="gemarra-regular">occur </span>by chance that there is <span class="gemarra-regular">a four-letter name, and </span>the omission of two letters <span class="gemarra-regular">would be half of the name, </span>and for this reason the Sages extended this concern to all cases where two letters are missing. The Gemara challenges: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, </span>the same could be said when <span class="gemarra-regular">one letter </span>is missing <span class="gemarra-regular">as well, </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">perhaps </span>it will <span class="gemarra-regular">occur </span>by chance that there is <span class="gemarra-regular">a two-letter name, and </span>the omission of one letter <span class="gemarra-regular">would be half of the name.</span>
The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, this is the reason </span>that when <span class="gemarra-regular">two letters </span>are missing the name written below cannot be corrected from the name written above: The concern is that <span class="gemarra-regular">perhaps </span>it will <span class="gemarra-regular">occur </span>by chance that there is <span class="gemarra-regular">a three-letter name, and </span>the omission of two letters <span class="gemarra-regular">would be a majority of the name. </span>The Sages applied this concern to all cases where two letters are missing.
The Gemara continues to discuss discrepancies between the information written above and below in a document. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa said: </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious to me </span>that if a document states <span class="gemarra-regular">above </span>that one owes <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">sefel</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> a type of cup, <span class="gemarra-regular">and below </span>it states <span class="gemarra-italic">kefel</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> a type of garment, <span class="gemarra-regular">everything is determined by the </span>information written <span class="gemarra-regular">below. </span>In this case there is not a missing letter at the bottom but an altered letter. Therefore, the information written below is not corrected from the information written above.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa raises a dilemma: What </span>if it is stated <span class="gemarra-italic">kefel</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> above and </span><span class="gemarra-italic">sefel</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> below</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> The difference between the two words is that the former begins with <span class="it-text">kuf</span>, whereas the latter begins with <span class="it-text">samekh</span>. The orthographical difference between these two letters is a single stroke that extends downward, as the omission of the extension of this stroke would change <span class="it-text">kuf</span> into <span class="it-text">samekh</span>. Rav Pappa’s dilemma is: <span class="gemarra-regular">Are </span><span class="gemarra-regular">we concerned for </span>the possibility that <span class="gemarra-regular">a fly </span>landed on the stroke of the <span class="it-text">kuf</span>, removing the ink and changing it into <span class="it-text">samekh</span>? <span class="gemarra-regular">Or </span>are we <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>concerned with this possibility? The Gemara comments: The dilemma <span class="gemarra-regular">shall stand </span>unresolved.
§ The Gemara relates: There was <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain </span>document <span class="gemarra-regular">in which it was written </span>that the amount due was <span class="gemarra-regular">six hundre</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and a dinar, </span>without specifying to which denomination the six hundred amount referred. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Sherevya sent </span>this question <span class="gemarra-regular">before Abaye: </span>Does the holder of the document collect <span class="gemarra-regular">six hundred </span><span class="gemarra-italic">istira</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and a dinar? </span><span class="it-text">Istira</span> is another name for a <span class="it-text">sela</span>, which equals four dinars. <span class="gemarra-regular">Or </span>is he <span class="gemarra-regular">perhaps </span>entitled to collect only <span class="gemarra-regular">six hundred </span><span class="gemarra-italic">perutot</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and a dinar, </span>a <span class="it-text">peruta</span> being a small fraction of a dinar? Abaye <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Remove </span>the possibility of six hundred <span class="gemarra-italic">perutot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, since </span>people <span class="gemarra-regular">do not write </span>large numbers of <span class="it-text">perutot</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">in a document, as they </span>instead <span class="gemarra-regular">combine them </span>into larger denominations

Daf 167a

<span class="gemarra-regular">and change them </span>into a smaller number of <span class="gemarra-regular">dinars. </span>Therefore, <span class="gemarra-regular">what can you say? </span>The highest and lowest remaining possibilities are: <span class="gemarra-regular">Six hundred </span><span class="gemarra-italic">istira</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and a dinar, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">six hundred dinars and one </span>more <span class="gemarra-regular">dinar. </span>The guiding principle is that <span class="gemarra-regular">the holder of the document </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">at a disadvantage,</span> and the lesser of these two values is assumed.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">this one who needs to show his signatur</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in court </span>for the purpose of corroborating his signature on a document, he <span class="gemarra-regular">should not show </span>it by writing it <span class="gemarra-regular">at the end of the parchment, lest another, </span>unscrupulous, person <span class="gemarra-regular">find </span>the parchment <span class="gemarra-regular">and write </span>above the signature <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the signatory <span class="gemarra-regular">owes him money. And </span>such a document would be valid, as <span class="gemarra-regular">we learned</span> in a mishna (175b): If one <span class="gemarra-regular">presents to </span>a debtor a document in the <span class="gemarra-regular">handwriting of </span>the debtor stating <span class="gemarra-regular">that he owes </span>money <span class="gemarra-regular">to him, </span>but without witnesses signed on the document, the creditor <span class="gemarra-regular">can collect </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">from unsold property</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., property that is currently in the possession of the debtor.
The Gemara relates: There was <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain </span>Jewish <span class="gemarra-regular">tax collector who came before Abaye </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Let the Master show me his signature </span>on a piece of paper to keep in my records, <span class="gemarra-regular">as when rabbis come </span>to me and <span class="gemarra-regular">show me </span>a note with your signature on it, attesting to the fact that they are Torah scholars, <span class="gemarra-regular">I let them pass without</span> paying the <span class="gemarra-regular">tax. Abaye showed him </span>his signature <span class="gemarra-regular">at the top of the parchment, </span>though the unscrupulous tax collector kept <span class="gemarra-regular">pulling </span>the parchment away from Abaye so that the signature would be at the bottom. Abaye noticed this and <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: The Sages </span>have <span class="gemarra-regular">already anticipated </span>people such as <span class="gemarra-regular">you </span>and advised that one should never write his signature at the bottom of a paper.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said: </span>When writing a promissory note, one <span class="gemarra-regular">should not write </span>any number <span class="gemarra-regular">from three until ten at the end of a line, lest </span>someone <span class="gemarra-regular">commit forgery and write </span>an extension to the number, since it is at the end of the line. In Hebrew and Aramaic, the words for the numbers three through nine can be changed to thirty through ninety, respectively, by appending to them the suffix <span class="it-text">in</span>, written with the letters <span class="it-text">yod</span> and <span class="it-text">nun</span>. Ten can be changed to twenty in a similar manner. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if </span>by chance <span class="gemarra-regular">it occurs for him </span>that these numbers fall out at the end of a line, <span class="gemarra-regular">he should repeat his words two </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">three times, </span>stating and restating the agreement in question, as <span class="gemarra-regular">it is impossible that </span>the number will <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>eventually <span class="gemarra-regular">occur for him in the middle of a line. </span>When there is a contradiction, it is the final mention of the amount that is authoritative, as the mishna teaches.
The Gemara relates: There was <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain </span>bill of sale <span class="gemarra-regular">in which it was written </span>that the item sold was: In my garden, <span class="gemarra-regular">one-third of the orchard. </span>The purchaser <span class="gemarra-regular">went </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">erased the roof and the foot of the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">bei</span><span class="gemarra-italic">t</span> of the term: Of the orchard [<span class="it-text">befardeisa</span>], <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>thereby <span class="gemarra-regular">changed </span>the prefix <span class="it-text">beit</span> into a <span class="it-text">vav</span>, yielding: In my garden one-third, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the orchard [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ufardeisa</span><span class="gemarra-regular">], </span>indicating that the sale included one-third of the garden in addition to all of the orchard. The document <span class="gemarra-regular">came before Abaye, </span>who <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>the purchaser: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>that there is <span class="gemarra-regular">so much space around this </span><span class="gemarra-italic">vav</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? </span>Since the letter <span class="it-text">vav</span> is narrower than the letter <span class="it-text">beit</span>, a larger space between letters emerged as compared to the spacing of letters in the rest of the document. Abaye <span class="gemarra-regular">bound </span>the purchaser, i.e., he subjected him to physical coercion, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he admitte</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> to the forgery.
The Gemara relates: There was <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain </span>bill of sale <span class="gemarra-regular">in which it was written </span>that the item being sold was: <span class="gemarra-regular">The portions of Reuven and Shimon, brothers [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">aḥei</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]. </span>Reuven and Shimon happened to <span class="gemarra-regular">have a brother </span><span class="gemarra-regular">whose name </span>was <span class="gemarra-regular">Aḥai, </span>which, when writing without vowels, is spelled identically to <span class="it-text">aḥei</span>. The purchaser <span class="gemarra-regular">went </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">wrote </span>a conjunctive <span class="gemarra-italic">vav</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in </span>the document before the word <span class="it-text">aḥei</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">and changed </span>the wording into: The portions of Reuven and Shimon <span class="gemarra-regular">and Aḥai. </span>The document <span class="gemarra-regular">came before Abaye, </span>who <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>the purchaser: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>that it is <span class="gemarra-regular">so crowded around this </span><span class="gemarra-italic">vav</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? </span>By inserting the extra <span class="it-text">vav</span>, a smaller space between letters emerged as compared to the spacing of letters in the rest of the document. Abaye <span class="gemarra-regular">bound </span>the purchaser, i.e., he subjected him to physical coercion, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he admitted </span>the forgery.
The Gemara relates: There was <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain document upon which </span>the signatures of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava and Rav Aḥa bar Add</span><span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> were signed. </span>The one holding the document <span class="gemarra-regular">came before Rava, </span>who <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: This is my signature, but I never signed </span>any document <span class="gemarra-regular">before Rav Aḥa bar Adda</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Rava <span class="gemarra-regular">bound </span>the holder of the document, i.e., he subjected him to physical coercion, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he admitted </span>the forgery. Rava <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Granted, you </span>were able to <span class="gemarra-regular">forge my </span>signature, <span class="gemarra-regular">but how did you perform </span>a forgery of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Aḥa bar Adda’s </span>signature, <span class="gemarra-regular">since his hands shake</span> and as a result his signature is distinctive? The man <span class="gemarra-regular">said: I placed my hands on </span>the rope of <span class="gemarra-regular">a narrow footbridge [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">amitzra</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and was thereby able to duplicate Rav Aḥa’s signature. <span class="gemarra-regular">And some say</span> that the forgery was accomplished when the forger <span class="gemarra-regular">stood upon a </span>wobbly <span class="gemarra-regular">water skin [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">azarnuka</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and wrote </span>the signature.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> A scribe may <span class="gemarra-regular">write a bill of divorce for a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">ma</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> who requests one, <span class="gemarra-regular">even if his wife is not with him </span>to give her consent when he presents his request, as there is no possibility that he will misuse the document. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>a scribe may write <span class="gemarra-regular">a receipt for a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">woma</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> upon her request, attesting to the payment of her marriage contract, <span class="gemarra-regular">even if her husband is not with her </span>to give his consent. This is true <span class="gemarra-regular">provided that </span>the scribe <span class="gemarra-regular">recognizes </span>the parties requesting the document, to prevent misrepresentation. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>for both documents, <span class="gemarra-regular">the husband gives </span>the scribe his <span class="gemarra-regular">wages</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> 

Daf 167b

A scribe may <span class="gemarra-regular">write </span>a promissory <span class="gemarra-regular">note for a debto</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> who requests one, <span class="gemarra-regular">even if </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">creditor is not with him </span>when he requests the document, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>a scribe may <span class="gemarra-regular">not write </span>a promissory note <span class="gemarra-regular">for a creditor </span>who requests it <span class="gemarra-regular">unless </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">debtor is with him</span> and consents. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">the debtor </span>who <span class="gemarra-regular">gives </span>the scribe his <span class="gemarra-regular">wages.</span>
A scribe may <span class="gemarra-regular">write a bill</span> of sale <span class="gemarra-regular">for a selle</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> of a field who requests one <span class="gemarra-regular">even if the purchaser is not with him </span>when he presents his request, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>a scribe may <span class="gemarra-regular">not write </span>a bill of sale <span class="gemarra-regular">for a purchaser </span>who requests it <span class="gemarra-regular">unless the seller is with him </span>and consents. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">the purchaser </span>who <span class="gemarra-regular">gives </span>the scribe his <span class="gemarra-regular">wages</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
A scribe may <span class="gemarra-regular">not write documents of betrothal and </span>documents of <span class="gemarra-regular">marriag</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> except with the consent of both </span>parties, the groom and the bride. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">the groom </span>who <span class="gemarra-regular">gives</span> the scribe his <span class="gemarra-regular">wages</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
A scribe may <span class="gemarra-regular">not write contracts for sharecroppers and contractor</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> except with the consent of both</span> parties, i.e., the sharecropper or contractor and the one who hires him. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>sharecropper or <span class="gemarra-regular">contractor </span>who <span class="gemarra-regular">gives </span>the scribe his <span class="gemarra-regular">wages.</span>
A scribe may <span class="gemarra-regular">not write documents </span>testifying to <span class="gemarra-regular">arbitration </span>agreements <span class="gemarra-regular">or any </span>other <span class="gemarra-regular">court enactmen</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> except with the consent of both </span>parties to the litigation. <span class="gemarra-regular">And both </span>parties <span class="gemarra-regular">give </span>the scribe his <span class="gemarra-regular">wages.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: </span>The scribe <span class="gemarra-regular">writes two </span>documents <span class="gemarra-regular">for the two </span>parties, one <span class="gemarra-regular">for this </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">by himself, and </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">for that </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">by himself.</span>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is meant by: <span class="gemarra-regular">Provided that </span>the scribe <span class="gemarra-regular">recognizes </span>the parties requesting the document? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: </span>It means <span class="gemarra-regular">provided that he recognizes the man’s name in the </span>case of <span class="gemarra-regular">the bill of divorce and the woman’s name in </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">the receipt.</span>
The Gemara relates: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Safr</span><span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and Rav Aḥa bar Huna and Rav Huna bar Ḥinnana </span>were <span class="gemarra-regular">sitting, and Abay</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> was <span class="gemarra-regular">sitting near them. And </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">they were sitting, they raised a dilemma: </span>Did Rav mean that with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">the man’s name in the </span>case of <span class="gemarra-regular">bill of divorce bill, yes, </span>it must be known to the scribe, but <span class="gemarra-regular">the woman’s name </span>need <span class="gemarra-regular">not</span> be known to the scribe? And did he mean that with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">the woman’s name in </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">the receipt, yes, </span>it must be known to the scribe, but <span class="gemarra-regular">the man’s name </span>need <span class="gemarra-regular">not</span> be known to the scribe?
<span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if so, <span class="gemarra-regular">let </span>there be <span class="gemarra-regular">a concern </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">perhaps </span>the man who made the request <span class="gemarra-regular">writes the bill of divorce and </span>intends to <span class="gemarra-regular">go and give it to the wife of another </span>man with the same name.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>similarly, in the case of the receipt let there be a concern that there will be <span class="gemarra-regular">times </span>when the <span class="gemarra-regular">woman writes </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">receipt and </span>intends to <span class="gemarra-regular">give </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">to a man who is not her </span>husband, whose wife shares her name.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said to them: </span>You are not understanding Rav’s statement correctly. <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>is what <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: The man’s name in </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">the bill of divorce </span>must be known to the scribe, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the same is true of the woman’s name, </span>which must also be known to the scribe. And <span class="gemarra-regular">the woman’s name in </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">the receipt </span>must be known to the scribe, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the same is true of the man’s name, </span>which must also be known to the scribe.
They continued their line of questioning: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>even if both names are known to the scribe, <span class="gemarra-regular">let </span>there be <span class="gemarra-regular">a concern for </span>the possibility of <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>men with the same name, such as two men named <span class="gemarra-regular">Yosef ben Shimon, who live in one cit</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span> and whose wives share the same name as well, and <span class="gemarra-regular">perhaps </span>the man who made the request will <span class="gemarra-regular">write the bill of divorce and </span>intend to <span class="gemarra-regular">go and give it to the wife of the other </span>man who bears the same name as him. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Aḥa bar Huna said to them </span>in reply that <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>is what <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: </span>If there are <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>men named <span class="gemarra-regular">Yosef ben Shimon who live in one city </span>and are married to women who share the same name, <span class="gemarra-regular">they may divorce their wives only in the presence of one another.</span>
They continued to ask: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>even if the scribe knows the man’s name and the name of the man’s wife, <span class="gemarra-regular">let </span>there be <span class="gemarra-regular">a concern </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">perhaps </span>someone will <span class="gemarra-regular">go to another city and establish </span>a false <span class="gemarra-regular">name for himself as Yosef ben Shimon, and </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">will write the bill of divorce and give it to the wife of the other </span>man, whose name really is Yosef ben Shimon.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna bar Ḥinnana said to them </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>is what <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">anyone whose name has been established in a city </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">thirty days</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> there is <span class="gemarra-regular">no concern </span>harbored <span class="gemarra-regular">about him </span>that his name is false. It is assumed that this is his true name.
They continued to ask: <span class="gemarra-regular">What</span> if his name has <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>been <span class="gemarra-regular">established </span>for thirty days? How can a newcomer in a town have a bill of divorce drawn up for him? <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said: </span>It is sufficient <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>people <span class="gemarra-regular">call him </span>by the name he claims for himself <span class="gemarra-regular">and he respond</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> to that call. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Zevid said: A liar is careful about </span>upholding <span class="gemarra-regular">his lies, </span>and just because he responds to being called by a particular name does not prove he is telling the truth. A newcomer would therefore have to wait thirty days before requesting that a scribe write him a bill of divorce.
§ There was <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain receipt </span>of payment of a marriage contract <span class="gemarra-regular">upon which Rav Yirmeya bar Abba was signed </span>as a witness. <span class="gemarra-regular">That woman, </span>whose name matched the name on the receipt, <span class="gemarra-regular">came before </span>Rav Yirmeya, seeking to collect payment of her marriage contract. Rav Yirmeya recognized her name, but not her appearance. The woman <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: It was not I </span>whose name was on the receipt that you signed, but another woman with the same name; I have not collected payment of my marriage contract. Rav Yirmeya <span class="gemarra-regular">said: I, too, said to </span>the other witnesses signed on the document: The woman for whom we signed the receipt <span class="gemarra-regular">is not she. But they said to me: </span>It is in fact the same woman, but <span class="gemarra-regular">she has aged and her voice has matured </span>and changed, and that is why you do not recognize her.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">although the Sages said: </span>

Daf 168a

<span class="gemarra-regular">Once </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">has stated </span>his testimony <span class="gemarra-regular">he may</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not then state a revision, </span>this case of Rav Yirmeya is an exception, and he can retract his initial statement in which he supported the woman’s claim. The reason is that <span class="gemarra-regular">it is not the manner of a Torah scholar to be carefu</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span> about identifying women, for reasons of modesty.
The Gemara relates: There was <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain receipt </span>of payment for a marriage contract <span class="gemarra-regular">upon which Rav Yirmeya bar Abba was signed.</span> A woman whose name appeared on the receipt, who was seeking to collect payment of her marriage contract, <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> It was not I, </span>but another woman with the same name, who had this receipt written. <span class="gemarra-regular">He said to her: But it was you, </span>and you are lying now. <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said: Although </span>I said that <span class="gemarra-regular">it is not the manner of a Torah scholar to </span>be <span class="gemarra-regular">careful </span>about identifying women, <span class="gemarra-regular">once he is careful </span>about such an identification and states positively that he recognizes a particular woman, <span class="gemarra-regular">he is careful</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said: A Torah scholar who goes to betroth a woman should take an ignoramus with him </span>to establish a positive identity of the woman, <span class="gemarra-regular">lest </span>people <span class="gemarra-regular">exchange </span>another woman for <span class="gemarra-regular">her </span>when given to <span class="gemarra-regular">him </span>for marriage, taking advantage of his innocence.
§ The mishna teaches that <span class="gemarra-regular">the husband gives </span>the scribe’s <span class="gemarra-regular">wages </span>for writing a bill of divorce. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason</span> for this? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">As the verse states: </span>“When a man takes a wife and marries her, and it comes to pass, if she finds no favor in his eyes, because he has found some unseemly matter in her, <span class="gemarra-regular">he shall write </span>her a scroll of severance <span class="gemarra-regular">and give </span>it in her hand” (Deuteronomy 24:1). It is therefore the husband’s responsibility to have the bill of divorce written. The Gemara adds: <span class="gemarra-regular">But today, </span>the reason <span class="gemarra-regular">that we do not do so, </span>but instead have the woman pay the scribe, is that <span class="gemarra-regular">the Sages placed </span>the burden <span class="gemarra-regular">upon the woman</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> so that </span>the husband <span class="gemarra-regular">should not delay </span>the divorce by refusing to pay the scribe.
The mishna teaches: A scribe may <span class="gemarra-regular">write </span>a promissory <span class="gemarra-regular">note for a debtor </span>who requests one, <span class="gemarra-regular">even if </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">creditor is not with him, </span>and it is the debtor who gives the scribe his wages. The Gemara asks: Isn’t it <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious </span>that the debtor pays the wages? After all, he is the beneficiary of the loan. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>for the mishna to state this, as there are times when the loan is beneficial to the creditor as well, as <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a joint venture, </span>where the creditor receives a share of the profits engendered by the money provided to the borrower (see <span class="it-text">Bava</span> <span class="it-text">Metzia</span> 104a).
The mishna teaches: A scribe may <span class="gemarra-regular">write a bill </span>of sale <span class="gemarra-regular">for a seller </span>of property who requests one, <span class="gemarra-regular">even if the purchaser is not with him </span>when he presents his request, and it is the purchaser who provides the scribe’s wages. The Gemara asks: Isn’t it <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious </span>that the purchaser pays the wages? After all, he is the beneficiary of the sale. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>for the mishna to state this, as sometimes the sale is beneficial to the seller as well, as <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who sells a field because of its poor </span>quality, as he is anxious to be rid of it.
The mishna teaches: A scribe may <span class="gemarra-regular">not write documents of betrothal </span>and documents of marriage except with the consent of both the groom and the bride, and it is the groom who provides the scribe’s wages. The Gemara asks: Isn’t it <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious </span>that the groom pays the wages? After all, he is the one acquiring his betrothed. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>for the mishna to state this, to teach us <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>it applies <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>when the groom is <span class="gemarra-regular">a Torah scholar, </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">which </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">it gives his father-in-law satisfaction to bring him into his family </span>by having him marry his daughter. Even in such a case, where the bride’s family is a beneficiary, it is the groom who pays the wages.
The mishna teaches: A scribe may <span class="gemarra-regular">not write contracts for sharecroppers and contractors </span>except with the consent of both parties, i.e., the sharecropper or contractor and the one who hires him, and it is the sharecropper or contractor who provides the scribe’s wages. The Gemara asks: Isn’t it <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious </span>that the contractor pays the wages? After all, the contract details his rights to the field. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>for the mishna to state this, as sometimes the deal is detrimental to the contractor, as <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a fallow</span> field. It might have been thought that in this case the cost of the document is borne by the landowner.
The mishna teaches: A scribe may <span class="gemarra-regular">not write </span><span class="gemarra-regular">documents </span>testifying to <span class="gemarra-regular">arbitration </span>or any other court enactment <span class="gemarra-regular">except with the consent of both </span>parties to the litigation. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is meant by <span class="gemarra-regular">documents </span>testifying to <span class="gemarra-regular">arbitration? Here </span>in Babylonia the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">interpreted</span> it to mean <span class="gemarra-regular">documents recording the claim</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> of the two parties to the litigation. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yirmeya bar Abba says:</span> A document testifying to arbitration is one that records the procedure in which the composition of the court is chosen, as described in tractate <span class="it-text">Sanhedrin</span> (23a), whereby <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>litigant <span class="gemarra-regular">chooses one </span>judge <span class="gemarra-regular">and that </span>litigant <span class="gemarra-regular">chooses one </span>judge, and these two judges choose the third one.
§ The mishna teaches that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: </span>The scribe <span class="gemarra-regular">writes two</span> documents <span class="gemarra-regular">for the two </span>parties, one <span class="gemarra-regular">for this </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">by himself and </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">for that </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">by himself. </span>The Gemara analyzes the disagreement between Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel and the first <span class="it-text">tanna</span>, who did not call for two separate documents: <span class="gemarra-regular">Shall we say </span>that they <span class="gemarra-regular">disagree with regard to </span>the principle that the court <span class="gemarra-regular">coerces </span>people to prevent <span class="gemarra-regular">conduct</span> characteristic <span class="gemarra-regular">of Sodom, </span>i.e., selfish behavior? That is, the case is where one of the litigants does not want to contribute to the writing of a joint document, and insists that each litigant pay to have his own document written, which would entail an additional expenditure on the part of the other party.
The dispute is then as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">As </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage, </span>the first <span class="it-text">tanna</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that the court <span class="gemarra-regular">coerces </span>people to prevent this conduct, so the obstinate litigant is forced to pay his share of a joint document, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage, </span>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel, <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that the court does <span class="gemarra-regular">not</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> coerce </span>people to prevent this conduct, and a litigant can insist upon paying only for a document of his own.
The Gemara rejects this analysis: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, everyone </span>in the mishna holds that the court <span class="gemarra-regular">coerces </span>people to prevent conduct characteristic of Sodom, <span class="gemarra-regular">and here</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> this is the reason </span>for the ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel: </span>It is because the litigant demanding separate documents is not making a pointless, selfish request at all, <span class="gemarra-regular">as he says to </span>the other litigant: <span class="gemarra-regular">It is not amenable for me that your defense, </span>i.e., the record of your claims, <span class="gemarra-regular">should be together with my defense</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as you are to me like an ambushing lion, </span>i.e., our interests are in conflict.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In the case of a debtor <span class="gemarra-regular">who repaid part of his </span><span class="gemarra-regular">deb</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>with the agreement of the creditor <span class="gemarra-regular">deposited </span>the promissory <span class="gemarra-regular">note with a third party </span>serving as a trustee to ensure that the creditor would not collect the full amount, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the debtor <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>the trustee: <span class="gemarra-regular">If I have not given you </span>the balance <span class="gemarra-regular">from now until such and such a day, give </span>the creditor <span class="gemarra-regular">his </span>promissory <span class="gemarra-regular">note, </span>thereby enabling him to collect the full amount stated on the note, if the stipulated <span class="gemarra-regular">time arrived and </span>the debtor <span class="gemarra-regular">did not give </span>the balance to the trustee, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei says:</span> The trustee <span class="gemarra-regular">should give </span>the promissory note to the creditor, in accordance with the debtor’s stipulation. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda says: </span>The trustee <span class="gemarra-regular">should not give </span>it, as the stipulation is void.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">With regard to what </span>principle <span class="gemarra-regular">do </span>Rabbi Yosei and Rabbi Yehuda <span class="gemarra-regular">disagree? Rabbi Yosei holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a transaction with inconclusive</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> consent [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">asmakhta</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">effects acquisition. </span>In this case, the debtor willingly undertook a penalty if he would not repay the remainder of the debt on time. Yet, he did not think that he would miss the deadline and be held accountable to pay that penalty. Rabbi Yosei holds that he is nevertheless bound by his word. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Yehuda holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">an </span><span class="gemarra-italic">asmakhta</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> does not effect</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> acquisition, </span>i.e., it is not binding.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba bar Avuh says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: </span>The <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei. When </span>questioners <span class="gemarra-regular">came before Rabbi Ami, </span>inquiring of him what the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is in this matter, <span class="gemarra-regular">he said to them: But since </span>it is the case <span class="gemarra-regular">that Rabbi Yoḥanan taught us a first time and a second </span>time, i.e., repeatedly, that the <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei, what can I do </span>to contradict his words?
The Gemara concludes: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>in fact the <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">not in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei, </span>i.e., an <span class="it-text">asmakhta</span> is not binding.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In the case of a creditor <span class="gemarra-regular">whose promissory note</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> has become erased, </span>he should <span class="gemarra-regular">produce witnesses </span>who remember the details of the document to testify <span class="gemarra-regular">about it. And </span>they <span class="gemarra-regular">come before the court, and they ratify </span>his promissory note <span class="gemarra-regular">for him, </span>stating: The promissory <span class="gemarra-regular">note of so-and-so was erased, </span>and it stated that a loan for such and such an amount took place <span class="gemarra-regular">on such and such a date, </span>

Daf 168b

<span class="gemarra-regular">and so-and-so and so-and-so were its witnesses. </span>The ratification document is signed, and it may be used as a replacement for the erased document.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>(<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span>, <span class="it-text">Bava</span> <span class="it-text">Metzia</span> 1:16): <span class="gemarra-regular">What is </span>the text of <span class="gemarra-regular">the ratification </span>document <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span>an erased document? The court writes as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">We, so-and-so and so-and-so and so-and-so, were sitting as three </span>judges, and <span class="gemarra-regular">so-and-so, son of so-and-so, produced an erased document before us, </span>which was written <span class="gemarra-regular">on such and such a date, and so-and-so and so-and-so </span>were <span class="gemarra-regular">its witnesses. And if it is written in </span>this ratification document also: <span class="gemarra-regular">We engaged in </span>the investigation of <span class="gemarra-regular">the testimony of the witnesses and their testimony has been found </span>to be <span class="gemarra-regular">congruent, </span>the creditor can <span class="gemarra-regular">collect </span>his debt on the basis of this ratification document, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he does not need to bring </span>further <span class="gemarra-regular">proof. </span><span class="gemarra-regular">But if </span>this formula is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>written, the creditor <span class="gemarra-regular">needs to bring </span>further <span class="gemarra-regular">proof </span>of the loan in order to collect it.
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues with its discussion of damaged documents: If a promissory note was <span class="gemarra-regular">torn </span>intentionally it is <span class="gemarra-regular">not valid, </span>but if it <span class="gemarra-regular">became torn </span>accidentally it is <span class="gemarra-regular">valid. </span>In a case where it <span class="gemarra-regular">was erase</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> or smudged, if its imprint is recognizable, </span>i.e., if the words are still legible, though barely, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">valid.</span>
The Gemara seeks to clarify the terms in the second part of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">What are the circumstances, </span>i.e., what are the defining characteristics, of a document that was <span class="gemarra-regular">torn, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">what are the circumstances </span>of a document that <span class="gemarra-regular">became torn? Rav Yehuda says: </span>A document that was <span class="gemarra-regular">torn </span>means that it had <span class="gemarra-regular">a tear </span>created <span class="gemarra-regular">by the court, </span>because they wished to render it not valid due to payment of the loan or some other circumstance. A document that <span class="gemarra-regular">became torn </span>means it had <span class="gemarra-regular">a tear that </span>was <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>created <span class="gemarra-regular">by the court.</span>
The Gemara seeks further clarification: <span class="gemarra-regular">What are the circumstances, </span>i.e., what are the signs, of a document that had <span class="gemarra-regular">a tear </span>created <span class="gemarra-regular">by the court? Rav Yehuda says: </span>The document has a tear that ruins <span class="gemarra-regular">the place of the witnesses’</span> signatures <span class="gemarra-regular">and the place of the date and the place of the essential part </span>of a document. <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye says: </span>It has <span class="gemarra-regular">a tear </span>that goes both <span class="gemarra-regular">lengthwise and widthwise.</span>
§ The Gemara relates: There was once <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain </span>group of <span class="gemarra-regular">Arabs who came to Pumbedita </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">who would rob people’s land </span>and force the victims to surrender the deeds to their property to prevent subsequent legal action. <span class="gemarra-regular">The owners of </span>land who had not yet had fallen victim to these Arabs <span class="gemarra-regular">came before Abaye </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Let the Master look at our deeds </span>to our property <span class="gemarra-regular">and let the Master write us another deed for it, </span>so <span class="gemarra-regular">that if one </span>of the deeds <span class="gemarra-regular">is robbed we will have </span>the other <span class="gemarra-regular">one in our possession.</span>
Abaye <span class="gemarra-regular">said to them: What can I do for you? </span>I cannot comply with your request, <span class="gemarra-regular">as Rav Safra says: </span>One may <span class="gemarra-regular">not write</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> two deeds </span>of ownership <span class="gemarra-regular">for one field, lest </span>the owner of that land <span class="gemarra-regular">repossess property</span> once <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">go back and repossess </span>it once again. Generally, whenever real estate is sold there is a guarantee given to the purchaser in the event that the land is repossessed by the seller’s creditor or by someone else who proves that the land rightfully belongs to him. If the seller of the repossessed land has no money to honor the guarantee, the purchaser can repossess property from others who had purchased property from the same seller subsequent to the sale of the repossessed land. In order to do so, he would have to produce the bill of sale proving that he had purchased the repossessed property. If he has two such deeds, he would be able to collect payment twice. To eliminate this possibility, duplicate property deeds are not written.
The landowners <span class="gemarra-regular">kept badgering </span>Abaye to write the duplicate documents, until, in order to be rid of them, <span class="gemarra-regular">he said to his scribe: Go write </span>the document <span class="gemarra-regular">for them, </span>but first write on paper and then erase it, and then write the desired document over the erased text, so that the text of the document will be written <span class="gemarra-regular">over an erasure</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>the signatures of <span class="gemarra-regular">its witnesses </span>will be <span class="gemarra-regular">on </span>a part of <span class="gemarra-regular">the paper </span>where the writing had not been erased, a situation in <span class="gemarra-regular">which </span>the document is <span class="gemarra-regular">not valid.</span>
