<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Aḥa bar Minyumi said to Abaye: But perhaps </span>the first writing on the paper was not erased thoroughly, so <span class="gemarra-regular">its imprint is recognizable</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and it is taught </span>in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that in a case where the writing on a document <span class="gemarra-regular">was erased or smudged, if its imprint is recognizable, </span>the document is <span class="gemarra-regular">valid. </span>Abaye <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Did I say </span>that he should write <span class="gemarra-regular">a proper document </span>and then erase it? <span class="gemarra-regular">I said, </span>i.e., I intended, that he should <span class="gemarra-regular">merely </span>write letters of the <span class="gemarra-regular">alphabet [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">alef</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">beit</span><span class="gemarra-regular">], </span>not actual words.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: In a case where one <span class="gemarra-regular">came </span>to court <span class="gemarra-regular">and said: My promissory note was lost</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> even if witnesses said: We wrote and signed</span> such a promissory note <span class="gemarra-regular">and gave </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>this man, the court may <span class="gemarra-regular">not write </span>a new <span class="gemarra-regular">document for him. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">In what </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">is this statement said? In </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">documents </span>detailing <span class="gemarra-regular">loans.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> But </span>in a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">deeds of buying and selling </span>land, the court may <span class="gemarra-regular">write </span>a replacement document, <span class="gemarra-regular">excluding the </span>standard <span class="gemarra-regular">guarantee that </span>was <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the first document, which states that if the field is repossessed the seller will compensate the purchaser for his loss. 

Daf 169a

The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: </span>The court may <span class="gemarra-regular">not write </span>a replacement document <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">deeds of buying and selling </span>land. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says as well: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who gives a gift </span>of land <span class="gemarra-regular">to another, and </span>the recipient <span class="gemarra-regular">returned the deed </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to him, his gift </span>of land <span class="gemarra-regular">returns </span>to him as well. <span class="gemarra-regular">But the Rabbis say: His gift </span>of land <span class="gemarra-regular">remains </span>in the possession of the recipient.
The Gemara analyzes the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">The Master says </span>in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: With regard to deeds of buying and selling land, the court may write a replacement document, <span class="gemarra-regular">excluding the guarantee that </span>was <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the first document. <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>that the guarantee may not be written?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Safra says: </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>the court may <span class="gemarra-regular">not write two deeds </span>of sale <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>the same sale of <span class="gemarra-regular">one field</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> lest a creditor </span>of the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">go </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">repossess </span>the field sold <span class="gemarra-regular">to this </span>purchaser, <span class="gemarra-regular">and that </span>purchaser <span class="gemarra-regular">go and take out one </span>deed, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>in accordance with the guarantee clause of the sale, <span class="gemarra-regular">repossess </span>land from other <span class="gemarra-regular">purchasers </span>who purchased land from the same seller at a later date, <span class="gemarra-regular">and say to the creditor: Remain quiet [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">shof </span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> about this matter for a few years, <span class="gemarra-regular">while I become established in </span>the property I repossessed. <span class="gemarra-regular">And then, come </span>and claim your loan again, and then you will <span class="gemarra-regular">repossess </span>this property <span class="gemarra-regular">from me. And </span>then, after it is taken from him a second time, the purchaser will then <span class="gemarra-regular">take out the other </span>document of sale, the replacement that the court had written for him, <span class="gemarra-regular">and then go </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">repossess </span>land from <span class="gemarra-regular">other purchasers </span>who purchased land from the same seller. In short, a replacement document with a guarantee will enable double collection on that guarantee.
The Gemara asks with regard to Rav Safra’s scenario: How would it be possible for this to occur? <span class="gemarra-regular">But once </span>the creditor repossessed the land the first time as payment of the debt, <span class="gemarra-regular">we, </span>the court, <span class="gemarra-regular">tore the </span>promissory <span class="gemarra-regular">note of </span>the seller’s <span class="gemarra-regular">creditor; with</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> what </span>document could the creditor <span class="gemarra-regular">repossess </span>the purchaser’s land <span class="gemarra-regular">again?</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if you would say that we did not tear </span>the creditor’s promissory note in the course of the first collection, that cannot be. <span class="gemarra-regular">But doesn’t Rav Naḥman say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">any </span>document of <span class="gemarra-regular">authorization to repossess </span>liened property from its purchaser <span class="gemarra-regular">in which it is not written:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> We have torn the creditor’s </span>promissory <span class="gemarra-regular">note, is not </span>a valid document of <span class="gemarra-regular">authorization to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> repossess </span>liened property; <span class="gemarra-regular">and any document of authorization </span>used <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>seize a debtor’s property <span class="gemarra-regular">in which it is not written: We have torn the</span> creditor’s document of <span class="gemarra-regular">authorization to repossess </span>liened property, <span class="gemarra-regular">is not </span>a valid <span class="gemarra-regular">document of authorization; and any document of appraisal </span>of an article’s value <span class="gemarra-regular">in which it is not written</span><span class="gemarra-regular">:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> We have torn </span>the creditor’s <span class="gemarra-regular">document of authorization, is not </span>a valid <span class="gemarra-regular">document of appraisal.</span>
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>to explain Rav Safra’s case as follows: The concern is not that a creditor will repossess the field, but <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>someone will <span class="gemarra-regular">come </span>to repossess it <span class="gemarra-regular">based on </span>his claim to the land as the property of <span class="gemarra-regular">his ancestors</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> That is, he proved that the field had belonged to his ancestors, and by extension belongs to himself as their heir, and the one who sold the field was in fact a thief. It was for this reason that he repossessed the field from the purchaser, and the concern is that the purchaser will seek reimbursement, as stipulated in the guarantee, from other property sold subsequently by the seller. If the purchaser has two deeds of sale with guarantees, he can collect payment twice.
The Gemara presents another question pertaining to Rav Safra’s case. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Aḥa of Difti said to Ravina:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> And why did </span>Rav Safra have <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>include in his case that the purchaser will <span class="gemarra-regular">say to the creditor</span><span class="gemarra-regular">:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Remain quiet </span>about this matter for a few years <span class="gemarra-regular">while I become established in this land </span>I repossessed, and then come and claim your loan again? Why did he devise a case in which the seller’s creditor collects payment twice? Let the problem <span class="gemarra-regular">derive </span>from the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that since </span>the purchaser <span class="gemarra-regular">holds two deeds</span> he will be able to <span class="gemarra-regular">repossess </span>land based on his guarantee once <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">repossess </span>land <span class="gemarra-regular">again, </span>even if the creditor does not collect his debt twice.
Ravina answered: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, </span>if the purchaser attempts to repossess land twice based on a single repossession of the creditor, <span class="gemarra-regular">he will have </span>too <span class="gemarra-regular">many litigants </span>to deal with at once, and his dishonest dealings will be discovered.
The Gemara asks further: <span class="gemarra-regular">But let </span>the court <span class="gemarra-regular">write a proper bill </span>of sale, one that includes a guarantee, <span class="gemarra-regular">for this </span>purchaser, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">let </span>the court <span class="gemarra-regular">write a receipt for the seller, </span>stating: <span class="gemarra-regular">All documents that are issued with regard to </span>the purchase of <span class="gemarra-regular">this field are not valid, except for </span>the one <span class="gemarra-regular">issued on this</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> date, </span>referring to the replacement document written by the court. This will prevent double collection, as if the purchaser attempts to collect on his guarantee with a second document, the seller will foil this attempt by showing this receipt.
<span class="gemarra-regular">The Rabbis said before Rav Pappa </span>in response to this question, <span class="gemarra-regular">and some say </span>it was said <span class="gemarra-regular">before Rav Ashi: Is that to say </span>that the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> holds that in general the court does <span class="gemarra-regular">not write a receip</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> in such cases? 

Daf 169b

Rav Pappa or Rav Ashi <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>them: Do not draw this conclusion. It is possible that the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> holds that <span class="gemarra-regular">generally </span>the court <span class="gemarra-regular">writes a receipt </span>when a creditor has lost his promissory note. <span class="gemarra-regular">And here, this is the reason </span>that it does not write a receipt: <span class="gemarra-regular">As, perhaps </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the creditor, </span>i.e., the one from whom the property was stolen, will <span class="gemarra-regular">go and repossess </span>property <span class="gemarra-regular">from the purchaser </span>who bought the stolen land, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the purchaser, seeking reimbursement in accordance with the guarantee, will <span class="gemarra-regular">go and repossess </span>property from other <span class="gemarra-regular">purchasers </span>who had later bought property from the same seller. <span class="gemarra-regular">And the receipt </span>will not help, because it <span class="gemarra-regular">is not with the purchasers </span>who bought property from the seller, but is in the possession of the seller himself. The purchasers, who are the ones who will suffer from the double collection, have no protection; they will in fact not even be aware that they are the victims of a double collection.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Ultimately, don’t </span>these <span class="gemarra-regular">purchasers go back to the owner, </span>i.e., the seller, <span class="gemarra-regular">of the land </span>to demand reimbursement? At that point the seller will produce the receipt, exposing the double collection, and the entire process will be reversed, so that ultimately the purchaser who suffered from the unjust collection will obtain possession of his property.
The Gemara answers: While it is true that ultimately the deception will be discovered, <span class="gemarra-regular">in the interim, </span>between the time the land was unjustly repossessed from the purchaser and the time when the injustice is reversed, the one who repossessed the land <span class="gemarra-regular">seizes </span>the land <span class="gemarra-regular">and consumes </span>its <span class="gemarra-regular">produce</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., he enjoys the profits produced by the land, and it will be difficult to receive full reimbursement for this stolen produce.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Alternatively, </span>the reason the option of writing a receipt for the seller of the land is not pursued here is that there is a concern <span class="gemarra-regular">about one who purchases </span>land <span class="gemarra-regular">without a guarantee. </span>As such a purchaser knows that he has no recourse to be reimbursed from the seller if the land he bought is repossessed, he will never contact the seller and discover that the seller has a receipt and that he has been the victim of an unjust double collection.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, </span>the same concern should be taken into consideration in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">promissory notes as well. </span>And yet Rav Pappa, or Rav Ashi, said that the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> concedes that a receipt may be written for the debtor to enable the collection of a debt in the event of the loss of the promissory note. Why are the aforementioned concerns not applicable to the case of debt collection?
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">There, where </span>the debtor <span class="gemarra-regular">owes money, </span>when the creditor seeks to repossess sold land, the purchaser of that land <span class="gemarra-regular">will say </span>to himself: There is a possibility that the debtor <span class="gemarra-regular">appeased the creditor by </span>paying him <span class="gemarra-regular">money, </span>since debts are usually settled with money. I will therefore investigate the matter with the debtor before allowing the creditor to repossess my land. At that point the receipt, held by the debtor, will be discovered, and double collection will be prevented. <span class="gemarra-regular">Here, where he owes land, </span>as the issue is that the claim is based on reimbursement for having bought stolen land, the purchaser <span class="gemarra-regular">knows that </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>common for one <span class="gemarra-regular">who </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">owed land </span>to be <span class="gemarra-regular">appeased with money </span>in such cases. The purchaser will therefore allow his land to be repossessed and will seek reimbursement at a later time.
§ The Gemara returns to the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> and analyzes one of its statements. <span class="gemarra-regular">The Master says </span>in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: With regard to deeds of buying and selling land, the court may write a replacement document, <span class="gemarra-regular">excluding the guarante</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that </span>was <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the first document that if the field is repossessed the seller will compensate the purchaser for his loss. <span class="gemarra-regular">How do we write </span>a bill of sale in such a way that it does not include this guarantee? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman said </span>that the case is one in <span class="gemarra-regular">which </span>the court <span class="gemarra-regular">writes as follows: Our deed is not </span>intended <span class="gemarra-regular">to enable </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">collection </span>of reimbursement in event of repossession, <span class="gemarra-regular">neither </span>collection <span class="gemarra-regular">from liened </span>property that has been sold <span class="gemarra-regular">nor </span>collection <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span><span class="gemarra-regular">unsold </span>property; <span class="gemarra-regular">rather, </span>it is intended merely to ensure <span class="gemarra-regular">that the land is established in the possession of the purchaser.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rafram says: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>statement of Rav Naḥman serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to say </span>that the omission of the <span class="gemarra-regular">guarantee </span>of the sale from a document <span class="gemarra-regular">is a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">scribal error</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> That is, it is assumed that when one purchases land he expects to have his purchase guaranteed, and that if such a clause is not stated in the document it is presumed to be a mere scribal oversight, and a guarantee is in effect. Rav Naḥman said, in explaining the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, that <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">reason </span>a land purchase would not have a guarantee <span class="gemarra-regular">is that </span>the scribe <span class="gemarra-regular">wrote this for him, </span>i.e., he wrote that there is no guarantee, explicitly in the deed; <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>indicates that if the scribe <span class="gemarra-regular">did not write this </span>explicitly <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>the purchaser, but left out the subject of the guarantee altogether, the purchaser <span class="gemarra-regular">would </span>nevertheless have the guarantee and would be able to <span class="gemarra-regular">collect </span>reimbursement from the seller in the event of repossession.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi </span>disagrees and <span class="gemarra-regular">says: </span>The omission of the <span class="gemarra-regular">guarantee </span>of the sale from a document <span class="gemarra-regular">is not a scribal error. </span>Accordingly, if mention of a guarantee is omitted from a bill of sale, there is in fact no guarantee. <span class="gemarra-regular">And what </span>does the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> mean when it says: <span class="gemarra-regular">Excluding the guarantee that </span>was <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the first document? It means simply <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>in this case there was <span class="gemarra-regular">no </span>clause about a <span class="gemarra-regular">guarantee written in it </span>at all.
The Gemara relates: There was <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain woman who gave money to a certain man to </span>act as her agent and <span class="gemarra-regular">purchase land for her. </span>The agent <span class="gemarra-regular">went </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">purchased </span>land <span class="gemarra-regular">for her, </span>but he conducted the purchase in such a way that it was <span class="gemarra-regular">without a guarantee</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> The woman wanted to take action against the agent and <span class="gemarra-regular">came before Rav Naḥman </span>to ask what recourse she had.
Rav Naḥman <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>the agent: The principle with regard to an agent is that if he acts to the detriment of the one who appointed him, the one who appointed him can say: <span class="gemarra-regular">I sent you</span> to act <span class="gemarra-regular">for my benefi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and not to my detriment. </span>Therefore, the entire agency is null and void, thereby negating the purchase. Nevertheless, you agreed to purchase the land without a guarantee. Therefore, <span class="gemarra-regular">go </span>yourself and <span class="gemarra-regular">purchase </span>the land <span class="gemarra-regular">from him without a guarantee, and then sell it to </span>this woman <span class="gemarra-regular">with a guarantee </span>that you will reimburse her in the event the land is repossessed.
§ The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> teaches that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: </span>In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who gives a gift</span> of land <span class="gemarra-regular">to another, and </span>the recipient <span class="gemarra-regular">returned the deed to him, his gift</span> of land <span class="gemarra-regular">returns </span>to him as well. <span class="gemarra-regular">But the Rabbis say: His gift </span>of land <span class="gemarra-regular">remains </span>in the possession of the recipient. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>for the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel? Rav Asi says: It becomes as </span>if the giver <span class="gemarra-regular">said to</span> the recipient: <span class="gemarra-regular">This field is given to you </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">as long as the deed </span>remains <span class="gemarra-regular">in your possession. </span>Therefore, by returning the deed to the giver, the recipient is canceling the gift.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba objects </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to this: If that is so </span>that these are the conditions of the gift, then when the deed is <span class="gemarra-regular">stolen </span>from <span class="gemarra-regular">or lost </span>by the recipient, the gift should <span class="gemarra-regular">also </span>be canceled.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Rabba said </span>a different explanation: Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel and the Rabbis <span class="gemarra-regular">disagree</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> about </span>whether or not the <span class="gemarra-regular">letters, </span>i.e., the contents of a promissory note, <span class="gemarra-regular">are acquired by </span>merely <span class="gemarra-regular">transferring </span>the document from one holder of the document to another. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel holds </span>that the <span class="gemarra-regular">letters are</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> acquired by transferrin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span> the document. Therefore, if the recipient returns the bill of sale to the giver, the land returns to the giver as well. <span class="gemarra-regular">And the Rabbis hold </span>that the <span class="gemarra-regular">letters are not acquired </span><span class="gemarra-regular">by transferrin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span> the document.
<span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who comes </span>to court <span class="gemarra-regular">to be judged </span>over a claim that land that is in his possession belongs to another, if he claims ownership <span class="gemarra-regular">based on a deed, </span>i.e., a bill of sale, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>claims further that he is the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">based on presumptive ownership </span>of the land, as it was in his uncontested possession for three years, and he therefore does not need the deed as proof, his claim is <span class="gemarra-regular">judged based on</span> the <span class="gemarra-regular">deed. </span>This is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: </span>His claim is judged <span class="gemarra-regular">based </span><span class="gemarra-regular">on </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">presumptive ownership.</span>
The Gemara analyzes the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">With regard to what do </span>Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi and Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel <span class="gemarra-regular">disagree? When Rav Dimi came </span>from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia he <span class="gemarra-regular">said: They disagree </span>about whether or not <span class="gemarra-regular">letters are acquired by transferring </span>the document from one holder of the document to another. 

Daf 170a

The Gemara explains: This is a case where one party sold land to another, who then sold it to a third party by transferring the bill of sale to him. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel holds </span>that the <span class="gemarra-regular">letters </span><span class="gemarra-regular">are not acquired by transferring </span>possession of the document. Handing the bill to the third party is therefore not a valid act of acquisition. In in order to establish that the land is his, one must prove presumptive ownership by demonstrating that he has lived in the land uncontested for three years. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that the <span class="gemarra-regular">letters are acquired </span><span class="gemarra-regular">by transferring </span>possession of the document. Therefore, if the third party produces the bill of sale that had been transferred to him, this is sufficient proof that the land is his.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye </span>objected and <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Rav Dimi: <span class="gemarra-regular">If that is so, </span>that Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel holds that letters are not acquired by transferring possession of the bill of sale, this would be in <span class="gemarra-regular">disagreement with </span>what <span class="gemarra-regular">the Master, </span>Rabba, said earlier, that Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel maintains that letters are acquired by transferring possession of the bill of sale. Rav Dimi <span class="gemarra-regular">said</span> back <span class="gemarra-regular">to him: And let it be in disagreement. </span>I am not obligated to be in agreement with Rabba.
Abaye clarified his objection and <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> This is what I </span>meant to <span class="gemarra-regular">say to you. The </span><span class="gemarra-italic">baraita</span> (168b), which Rabba was explaining, <span class="gemarra-regular">can be explained only </span>the way the <span class="gemarra-regular">Master, </span>Rabba, <span class="gemarra-regular">explained </span>it. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if so, </span>i.e., if you do not agree with Rabba’s understanding of the opinion of Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel, there is <span class="gemarra-regular">a difficulty, </span>as there is a contradiction <span class="gemarra-regular">between </span>one statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel and </span>the other statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Abaye said </span>that the explanation of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> concerning one who appears before a court to be judged is as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">With what are we dealing here? </span>We are dealing with a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where one of </span>the witnesses signed on the bill <span class="gemarra-regular">was found to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">be a relative </span>to one of the parties, <span class="gemarra-regular">or </span>he was found to be <span class="gemarra-regular">disqualified </span>from bearing witness for another reason, and therefore the document is rendered invalid.
Abaye continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">And</span> the two opinions in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> disagree <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>the issue that is the subject of <span class="gemarra-regular">the dispute between Rabbi Meir and Rabbi Elazar. </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">holds in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar, who says: The witnesses of the transmission </span>of the document <span class="gemarra-regular">effect </span>the transaction, meaning that witnesses are not required to be signed on a document at all, provided that there are witnesses who saw the transfer of the document to the relevant party. It is therefore inconsequential that one of the witnesses that signed the document is disqualified. This is why Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi says that the claim is judged based on the deed, i.e., the deed is valid.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel holds in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir, who says: The signatory witnesses</span> on the document <span class="gemarra-regular">effect </span>the transaction, meaning that it is necessary for a document to have witnesses sign it. If there are no witnesses or if one or both of them are disqualified, the document is not valid even if its transmission is witnessed by qualified witnesses. This is why Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says that the claim is judged based on the claimant’s presumptive ownership; this is his only valid proof since the deed he possesses is not valid.
The Gemara objects to Abaye’s explanation: <span class="gemarra-regular">But doesn’t Rabbi Abba say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar concedes </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the case of a document whose <span class="gemarra-regular">falsification is inherent in i</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that it is not valid? </span>Rabbi Elazar said only that a document that has no witnesses signed on it at all is valid if its transmission was witnessed. If the document has disqualified witnesses, he agrees it is not valid.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Rabbi Avina said</span> a modification of Abaye’s explanation. <span class="gemarra-regular">All concede that if it is written in </span>the document: <span class="gemarra-regular">We, </span>the court, <span class="gemarra-regular">engaged in </span>an investigation of <span class="gemarra-regular">the testimony of the witnesses </span>and have determined that they signed the document, <span class="gemarra-regular">and their testimony was found </span>to be <span class="gemarra-regular">false, </span>the document <span class="gemarra-regular">is not valid, in accordance with</span> the statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Abba. They disagree only with regard to a document upon which there are no witnesses </span>signed <span class="gemarra-regular">at all. As Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">holds in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar, who says: The witnesses of the transmission </span>of the document <span class="gemarra-regular">effect </span>the transaction. Signatory witnesses are not necessary, and the deed can therefore be used as proof. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel holds in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir, who says: The signatory witnesses </span>on the document <span class="gemarra-regular">effect </span>the transaction, so the deed cannot be used. Therefore, the only valid proof would be based on his presumptive ownership.
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">And if you wish, say </span>instead: The case in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is one where the alleged purchaser has a bill of sale for the land, but the alleged seller, although he admits that the document was written with his consent, claims that the sale did not ultimately occur, and that the alleged purchaser took the document from him. And the <span class="it-text">tanna’im</span> in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">disagree, with regard to </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in the case of a debtor <span class="gemarra-regular">who admits that he wrote </span>a promissory <span class="gemarra-regular">note</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> whether the creditor <span class="gemarra-regular">is required to ratify it </span>in court in order to collect, and, by extension, in a case where a seller admits that he wrote a bill of sale, whether the purchaser must ratify it in court in order to establish its validity.
<span class="gemarra-regular">As, Rabbi</span> Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that in the case of a debtor <span class="gemarra-regular">who admits that he wrote </span>a promissory <span class="gemarra-regular">note, </span>the creditor <span class="gemarra-regular">is not required to ratify it </span>in court in order to collect what is owed to him. In this case as well, the purchaser can use the bill of sale as proof that he is the rightful owner of the property. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel holds </span>that in the case of a debtor who admits that he wrote a promissory note, the creditor <span class="gemarra-regular">is required to ratify it </span>in court in order to use it to collect the debt. In this case as well, since the purchaser is unable to ratify it, his only recourse to prove his ownership is showing that he lived in the land uncontested for three years.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But didn’t we hear the opposite concerning </span>Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi and Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel? <span class="gemarra-regular">As it is taught</span> in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> (<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span>, <span class="it-text">Bava</span> <span class="it-text">Metzia</span> 1:8) that if <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>people, the debtor and the creditor, <span class="gemarra-regular">are grasping </span>a promissory <span class="gemarra-regular">note</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and the <span class="gemarra-regular">creditor says: It is mine,</span> i.e., the debt has not yet been paid, <span class="gemarra-regular">and it fell from me, and you, </span>the debtor, <span class="gemarra-regular">found it, and </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">debtor says: It is </span>in fact <span class="gemarra-regular">yours, </span>i.e., I did borrow the money from you, <span class="gemarra-regular">but I paid you </span>and was given the promissory note, and it fell from me, and you found it, <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>promissory <span class="gemarra-regular">note must be ratified through its signatories, </span>even though the debtor admits it is a valid document. <span class="gemarra-regular">This is the statement of Rabbi</span> Yehuda HaNasi. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: They should divide </span>the amount written in the promissory note, i.e., the debtor must pay half of the recorded sum to the creditor.
The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">And we discussed</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it </span>once before and asked the following question about it: <span class="gemarra-regular">But doesn’t Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi agree to <span class="gemarra-regular">that which we learned </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Bava</span> <span class="it-text">Metzia</span> 2a), with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>people who came to court <span class="gemarra-regular">holding a garment, </span>where <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>one is <span class="gemarra-regular">saying: I found it, and that </span>one is <span class="gemarra-regular">saying: I found it; </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">takes an oath that he does not have </span>claim to <span class="gemarra-regular">less than half of it, and that </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">takes an oath that he does not have </span>claim to <span class="gemarra-regular">less than half of it, and they divide </span>it? Why does Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi not maintain that in a case where the debtor and creditor are grasping a promissory note, there too they should divide the money?
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>in response to this question <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman said: In </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a ratified </span>promissory note, <span class="gemarra-regular">everyone agrees that they should divide </span>it. <span class="gemarra-regular">Where they disagree </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the case of a note <span class="gemarra-regular">that is not ratified. </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that in the case of a debtor <span class="gemarra-regular">who admits that he wrote </span>a promissory <span class="gemarra-regular">note, </span>the creditor <span class="gemarra-regular">is required to ratify it </span>in court in order to collect the debt from him. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if he </span>successfully <span class="gemarra-regular">ratifies it, </span>the creditor <span class="gemarra-regular">collects half </span>of the recorded sum, since the two parties are contesting ownership of the document. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>successful in ratifying the note, it <span class="gemarra-regular">is merely a shard, </span>i.e., a worthless piece of paper.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel holds </span>that in the case of a debtor <span class="gemarra-regular">who admits that he wrote </span>a promissory <span class="gemarra-regular">note, </span>the creditor <span class="gemarra-regular">is not required to ratify it </span>in court in order to collect payment. Since the note is valid and fit for collection, <span class="gemarra-regular">they should divide </span>it, i.e., the creditor collects half the sum, as the ownership of the document is contested. The positions of Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi and Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel are therefore the reverse of what the Gemara proposed in its explanation of the first <span class="it-text">baraita</span>.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Reverse </span>the way the opinions of Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi and Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel are recorded in one of the two <span class="it-text">baraitot</span> so that they are consistent in both <span class="it-text">baraitot</span>.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if you wish, say </span>instead: <span class="gemarra-regular">Actually, do not reverse </span>their opinions. There is no contradiction between them, because the issue in the first <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is not whether or not a bill of sale must be ratified when the seller admits that he wrote it. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, here </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna’im</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">disagree with regard to verifying</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., they disagree about whether a litigant is required to verify all his claims in circumstances where his case is strong enough to have the court rule in his favor even if they were to disregard some of his claims. Generally, if one has evidence of presumptive ownership of a field he does not have to produce a bill of sale for it. Here, Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi holds that since the one occupying the land claims that he has a bill of sale, he must verify this claim by producing it. Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel holds that he is not required to produce it, as the claim of presumptive ownership suffices.
The Gemara explains: It is <span class="gemarra-regular">like this </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">where Rav Yitzḥak bar Yosef was owed money by Rabbi Abba. </span>The case <span class="gemarra-regular">came before Rabbi Yitzḥak Nappaḥa. </span>Rabbi Abba <span class="gemarra-regular">said: I </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">repaid you </span>the debt <span class="gemarra-regular">in the presence of so-and-so and so-and-so. Rabbi Yitzḥak</span> Nappaḥa <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Rabbi Abba: The witnesses you have named, <span class="gemarra-regular">so-and-so and so-and-so, must come</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and testify </span>that they saw you repay the loan. Rabbi Abba <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Rabbi Yitzḥak Nappaḥa: <span class="gemarra-regular">If they do not come, am I not deemed credible </span>to say that I repaid the loan? <span class="gemarra-regular">But don’t we maintain </span>that with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who lends </span>money <span class="gemarra-regular">to another in </span>the presence of <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the debtor <span class="gemarra-regular">need not repay him in </span>the presence of <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses, </span>as he is deemed credible to say he repaid the debt even with no supporting testimony?
Rabbi Yitzḥak Nappaḥa <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Rabbi Abba: <span class="gemarra-regular">With regard to this </span>issue, <span class="gemarra-regular">I hold like the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> said <span class="gemarra-regular">by </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the Master, </span>i.e., you yourself. <span class="gemarra-regular">As Rabbi Abba says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Adda bar Ahava said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says:</span> If <span class="gemarra-regular">one says to another, </span>i.e., if a debtor says to his creditor: <span class="gemarra-regular">I repaid you in the presence of so-and-so and so-and-so, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">required that so-and-so and so-and-so come </span>to court <span class="gemarra-regular">and testify </span>that they witnessed the repayment. Rabbi Abba <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Rabbi Yitzḥak Nappaḥa: <span class="gemarra-regular">But doesn’t Rav Giddel say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says </span>that the <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with the statement of Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel, </span>that it is not required that a litigant verify all his stated claims if his case is sufficiently strong without those claims? <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>moreover, <span class="gemarra-regular">even Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">did not</span>

Daf 170b

<span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that the litigant loses the case if he cannot produce verification of his extraneous claims, but <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>that he is told <span class="gemarra-regular">to verify </span>those claims if he can. Rabbi Yitzḥak Nappaḥa <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Rabbi Abba: <span class="gemarra-regular">I, too, am saying </span>only that you are required <span class="gemarra-regular">to verify </span>your claim if you can; if you cannot, you will not be required to pay.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In the case of a debtor <span class="gemarra-regular">who repaid part of his </span><span class="gemarra-regular">debt</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda says: </span>The creditor <span class="gemarra-regular">should exchange </span>the promissory note for a new one stating the current balance and tear up the first promissory note. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei says: </span>The creditor may keep the original promissory note, and he <span class="gemarra-regular">should write a receipt </span>for the payment he has received and give it to the debtor as proof of his partial payment of the sum recorded in the old note. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda said </span>with regard to this arrangement: It is <span class="gemarra-regular">found </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>debtor <span class="gemarra-regular">must </span>now <span class="gemarra-regular">guard his receipt against </span>being destroyed by <span class="gemarra-regular">mice</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as if he no longer has the receipt, he will have to pay the entire sum recorded in the promissory note. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei said to him: This </span>situation is <span class="gemarra-regular">fitting for </span><span class="gemarra-regular">him</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span> it is better that this procedure be followed, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the strength of </span>the claim of <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>creditor <span class="gemarra-regular">not be weakened.</span>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: </span>The <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">not in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda, nor </span>is it <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei. Rather, </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is that <span class="gemarra-regular">the court tears up the </span>original promissory <span class="gemarra-regular">note and writes a different </span>promissory <span class="gemarra-regular">note for </span>the creditor, listing the new sum owed, dated <span class="gemarra-regular">from the time </span>of the <span class="gemarra-regular">first </span>document.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman said to Rav Huna, and some say </span>it was <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yirmeya bar Abba </span>who said this <span class="gemarra-regular">to Rav Huna: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">If Rav would have heard this </span>following <span class="gemarra-italic">baraita</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that according to Rabbi Yehuda the proper procedure is that the <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses tear the </span>original promissory <span class="gemarra-regular">note and write another </span>promissory <span class="gemarra-regular">note for </span>the creditor listing the new sum owed, dated <span class="gemarra-regular">from the time </span>of the <span class="gemarra-regular">first </span>document, <span class="gemarra-regular">he would have retracte</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> his statement that the court tears the promissory note and writes a new one.
Rav Huna <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>Rav <span class="gemarra-regular">heard </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>nevertheless <span class="gemarra-regular">he did not retract </span>his statement. While Rabbi Yehuda says in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that the witnesses write a new promissory note, Rav maintains that this must be done specifically by a court. Why is this? 

Daf 171a

<span class="gemarra-regular">Granted,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a court </span>can write a new document, because the court <span class="gemarra-regular">has the power to confiscate money. </span>A creditor has the right to seize any property that the debtor had owned on the day the promissory note was written, even if that property was subsequently sold to others; the earlier the date on the note, the more properties it applies to. By dating the new document on the date of the original document the creditor is once again given the right to seize properties from those who had purchased land from the debtor in between the date of the original loan and the date the new promissory note is actually written. The court has such confiscatory power. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">who </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">performed their agency, </span>i.e., fulfilled their assigned role, the first time they wrote the promissory note, can <span class="gemarra-regular">they return and perform their agency </span>again by writing a second promissory note?
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>is it so that witnesses are <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>empowered to do so? <span class="gemarra-regular">But doesn’t Rav Yehuda say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: Witnesses </span>who were commissioned to write a deed for the transfer of property <span class="gemarra-regular">may write even te</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> deeds for one field</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> If the original deed is lost or destroyed, the witnesses may write a replacement deed for the purchaser, even if the deed is lost many times.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef says </span>an answer to this question: Rav Yehuda’s statement was concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">a deed of gift, </span>not a bill of sale. A gift of land has no guarantee; if it is repossessed from the recipient by the giver’s creditor to repay the giver’s debt, the recipient has no recourse and cannot collect any money from anyone. Therefore, in this case no one is jeopardized by the writing of many replacement deeds, which are intended only to serve as a proof that the recipient is actually entitled to the land.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabba says: </span>It is possible to say that Rav Yehuda’s statement applied even <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to a bill </span>of sale <span class="gemarra-regular">that does not have a guarantee in it. </span>In that case as well, there is no potential loss to any purchasers of land. By contrast, in the case of a promissory note, which can be used to repossess property from those who have purchased land from the debtor, witnesses do not have the authority to predate a document and thereby subject more purchasers to possible land seizures due to the predating of the document.
The Gemara cited an excerpt from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> earlier. It now cites it in full: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is the full text of the <span class="gemarra-italic">baraita</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? As it is taught: </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">one thousand dinars are owed by </span>a debtor, and the debt is recorded in a promissory note, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the debtor <span class="gemarra-regular">repaid five hundred dinars out of </span>the total, the <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses tear the </span>original promissory <span class="gemarra-regular">note and write another </span>promissory <span class="gemarra-regular">note for him, </span>dated <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">time of </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">first </span>note. This is <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">statement of Rabbi Yehuda. Rabbi Yosei says: This </span>original promissory <span class="gemarra-regular">note shall remain in its place, </span>in the custody of the creditor, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">write </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a receipt </span>for the five hundred dinars that were repaid. This receipt is given to the debtor to protect himself against a possible attempt by the creditor to use the promissory note to collect the entire one thousand dinars.
Rabbi Yosei continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>there are <span class="gemarra-regular">two reasons why </span>the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">they write a receipt, </span>as opposed to writing a new promissory note: <span class="gemarra-regular">One </span>reason is <span class="gemarra-regular">so that </span>the creditor <span class="gemarra-regular">can coerce </span>the debtor <span class="gemarra-regular">to repay him, </span>i.e., the psychological pressure for the debtor of knowing that the creditor has a promissory note with a larger amount listed than what he owes him will induce the debtor to repay the remainder promptly. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the other <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">so that he, </span>the creditor, <span class="gemarra-regular">should </span>be able to <span class="gemarra-regular">collect </span>liened property <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">first date, </span>that of the original document.
The Gemara asks with regard to Rabbi Yosei’s second reason: <span class="gemarra-regular">But doesn’t Rabbi Yehuda also say </span>that the new document must be dated <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">time of </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">first </span>document? The Gemara answers: Rabbi Yosei did not hear a full explanation of Rabbi Yehuda’s opinion; he heard only that Rabbi Yehuda prescribed writing a new promissory note recording the new balance. And <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>is what <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei is saying to Rabbi Yehuda: If you </span>mean to <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that the new promissory note is dated <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">time of </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">first </span>document, <span class="gemarra-regular">I disagree with you on one </span>count, as I hold a receipt should be written to pressure the debtor. <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>you mean to say that the second promissory note is dated <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">second date, </span>i.e., from when the second promissory note was written, <span class="gemarra-regular">I disagree with you on two </span>counts.
§ The Gemara discusses a related <span class="it-text">halakha</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> (<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span>, <span class="it-text">Makkot</span> 1:3): If there is a promissory <span class="gemarra-regular">note whose date is written as a Shabbat or as the tenth of Tishrei</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., Yom Kippur, it <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>assumed to be <span class="gemarra-regular">a postdated </span>promissory <span class="gemarra-regular">note</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as writing is forbidden on Shabbat and Yom Kippur, <span class="gemarra-regular">and it is </span>therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">valid. </span>This is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of Rabbi Yehuda. Rabbi Yosei deems </span>the promissory note <span class="gemarra-regular">invalid. Rabbi Yehuda said to </span>Rabbi Yosei: <span class="gemarra-regular">But didn’t </span>such <span class="gemarra-regular">an incident come before you in Tzippori, and you </span>yourself <span class="gemarra-regular">deemed </span>the promissory note <span class="gemarra-regular">valid? </span>Rabbi Yosei <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: When I deemed </span>the promissory note <span class="gemarra-regular">valid, </span>it was <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>a case like <span class="gemarra-regular">this, </span>where the date was a Shabbat or Yom Kippur, that <span class="gemarra-regular">I deemed </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">valid.</span>
The Gemara is puzzled by Rabbi Yosei’s response at the end of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">But Rabbi Yehuda was also speaking in </span>a case like <span class="gemarra-regular">this, </span>where the date was a Shabbat or Yom Kippur, and yet Rabbi Yosei’s opinion was that the promissory note is invalid.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Pedat says: All </span>parties to this dispute <span class="gemarra-regular">agree that if we engaged in </span>an investigation of <span class="gemarra-regular">the date of the document, and its date was found to be exactly on Shabbat or on the tenth of Tishrei, </span>that it is self-evident <span class="gemarra-regular">that it is a postdated </span>promissory <span class="gemarra-regular">note </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and is valid. </span>

Daf 171b

The two Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">disagree only with regard to </span>a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a postdated </span>promissory <span class="gemarra-regular">note in general, </span>i.e., one in which the fact that it is postdated is not readily discernible from the dating of the document, as opposed to one dated on Shabbat or Yom Kippur.
<span class="gemarra-regular">As Rabbi Yehuda </span>conforms <span class="gemarra-regular">to his </span>line of <span class="gemarra-regular">reasoning, as he says: </span>One does <span class="gemarra-regular">not write a receipt </span>for a debtor when he pays his debt; rather, the original document is torn, and in the case of partial repayment a new document is written, attesting to the balance due. <span class="gemarra-regular">And</span> consequently, <span class="gemarra-regular">no harm can emerge from </span>a postdated document. There is no concern that the date on the postdated document may have been recorded after the writing of a receipt.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Yosei </span>conforms <span class="gemarra-regular">to his </span>line of <span class="gemarra-regular">reasoning, as he says: </span>One <span class="gemarra-regular">writes a receipt </span>for a debtor when he pays his debt, in lieu of tearing the promissory note. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>consequently, <span class="gemarra-regular">harm can emerge from </span>a postdated promissory note. Harm can occur in a case such as the following: The loan was given on the first of Nisan. The debt was paid on the following day and, rather than tearing the promissory note, a receipt was written and dated on the second of Nisan. If the original note had been postdated to the third of Nisan or thereafter, the creditor could use it to collect his debt a second time, arguing that the debtor’s receipt is irrelevant, as its date is prior to the date in the promissory note.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, says: Even according to the one who says </span>that one <span class="gemarra-regular">writes a receipt </span>for the debtor when he pays, in lieu of tearing the promissory note, <span class="gemarra-regular">this statement </span>applies only <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to</span> a case where the debtor pays <span class="gemarra-regular">half, </span>i.e., a portion, of the debt. <span class="gemarra-regular">But with regard to </span>a case where the debtor comes to repay <span class="gemarra-regular">all of </span>the debt and the creditor has lost the promissory note and cannot tear it, all agree that one does <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>write a receipt. Rather, the debtor will not be required to repay the loan unless the creditor can produce the promissory note.
The Gemara rejects this opinion: <span class="gemarra-regular">But it is not so; we write </span>a receipt <span class="gemarra-regular">even in </span>a case where the debtor pays <span class="gemarra-regular">all of </span>the debt.
The Gemara proves its assertion: This is <span class="gemarra-regular">like that </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">where Rav Yitzḥak bar Yosef was owed money by Rabbi Abba. </span>Rav Yitzḥak bar Yosef <span class="gemarra-regular">came</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> before Rabbi Ḥanina bar Pappi, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Rabbi Abba: <span class="gemarra-regular">Give me my money. </span>Rabbi Abba <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>First <span class="gemarra-regular">give me my </span>promissory <span class="gemarra-regular">note, and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">take your money. </span>Rav Yitzḥak bar Yosef <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: I lost your </span>promissory <span class="gemarra-regular">note; </span>instead, <span class="gemarra-regular">I will write a receipt for you. </span>Rabbi Abba <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Isn’t </span>there the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav and Shmuel, who both say </span>that the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is that one does <span class="gemarra-regular">not write a receipt?</span>
Rabbi Ḥanina bar Pappi, the judge, thereupon <span class="gemarra-regular">said: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Who will give us </span>some <span class="gemarra-regular">of the dust of Rav and Shmuel, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">I will place it on my eyes, </span>so highly do I regard them. Nevertheless, <span class="gemarra-regular">isn’t </span>there the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan and Reish Lakish, who both say </span>that one <span class="gemarra-regular">writes a receipt?</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And similarly, when Ravin came </span>from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia, he said that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ilai </span><span class="gemarra-regular">says: </span>The <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is that one <span class="gemarra-regular">writes a receipt.</span>
The Gemara concludes: <span class="gemarra-regular">And it stands to reason that </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">writes a receipt. As, if </span>it would <span class="gemarra-regular">enter your mind that </span>one does <span class="gemarra-regular">not write a receipt, </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">if the </span>promissory <span class="gemarra-regular">note</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of this </span>creditor <span class="gemarra-regular">is lost, should this </span>debtor <span class="gemarra-regular">eat and rejoice? </span>Is it fair that he should keep money that he knows he owes the creditor?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye objects to this </span>line of reasoning: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, what </span>should the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> be, that one <span class="gemarra-regular">writes a receipt </span>when the creditor cannot find the promissory note? If <span class="gemarra-regular">the receipt of </span>the debtor <span class="gemarra-regular">is lost, should this </span>creditor <span class="gemarra-regular">eat and rejoice</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> Once the debtor has lost his receipt, there is nothing to prevent the creditor from collecting the debt a second time. This, too, is unfair. In either case, whether a receipt is written or not, an injustice could result. Why should it be preferred that the potential of suffering an injustice should be borne by the debtor rather than the creditor? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said to </span>Abaye: <span class="gemarra-regular">Yes, </span>it is preferable, because, as it is written: <span class="gemarra-regular">“The borrower is a servant to the lender” </span>(Proverbs 22:7). The debtor’s interests are subordinated to those of the creditor.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">We learned </span>in a mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">elsewhere </span>(<span class="it-text">Shevi’it</span> 10:5): <span class="gemarra-regular">Promissory notes that are antedate</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> are not valid, but </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">that are postdate</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> are valid.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Hamnuna says: They taught </span>this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">promissory notes, but </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">deeds of buying and selling </span>property, <span class="gemarra-regular">even postdate</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> documents <span class="gemarra-regular">are not valid. What is the reason </span>for this stringency in the case of bills of sale? If postdated documents were allowed, there could be <span class="gemarra-regular">times that </span>the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">sells land to </span>the purchaser <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the month of <span class="gemarra-regular">Nisan </span>of a particular year <span class="gemarra-regular">and writes </span>a postdated deed <span class="gemarra-regular">for him </span>stating that the sale took place <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the following <span class="gemarra-regular">Tishrei, and </span>some <span class="gemarra-regular">money happens to </span>reach the seller <span class="gemarra-regular">between </span>Nisan and Tishrei <span class="gemarra-regular">and he purchases </span>the land back <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the purchaser. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>then, <span class="gemarra-regular">when Tishrei arrives,</span> the purchaser <span class="gemarra-regular">takes out </span>the original bill of sale <span class="gemarra-regular">and says to </span>the seller: It is true that you purchased the field from me, but <span class="gemarra-regular">I then purchased it from you </span>again now, in Tishrei, as stated in this document.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, </span>a similar scenario could occur with <span class="gemarra-regular">promissory notes as well: </span>There could be <span class="gemarra-regular">times that one</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> borrows </span>money <span class="gemarra-regular">in Nisan and writes </span>a promissory <span class="gemarra-regular">note for </span>the creditor stating that the loan took place <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the following <span class="gemarra-regular">Tishrei, and </span>some <span class="gemarra-regular">money happens to </span>reach the debtor <span class="gemarra-regular">between </span>Nisan and Tishrei <span class="gemarra-regular">and he repays </span>his debt <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the creditor early <span class="gemarra-regular">and says to him: Give me my </span>promissory <span class="gemarra-regular">note. And </span>the creditor <span class="gemarra-regular">says to him: I lost </span>it, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he writes him a receipt </span>instead. <span class="gemarra-regular">And</span> then, <span class="gemarra-regular">when the time </span>written in the note <span class="gemarra-regular">arrives, </span>the creditor <span class="gemarra-regular">takes out </span>the supposedly lost promissory note <span class="gemarra-regular">and says to </span>the debtor: It is true that you repaid me previously, but <span class="gemarra-regular">it is now, </span>after you repaid that loan, <span class="gemarra-regular">that you borrowed from me these </span>dinars recorded in this document, which is dated in Tishrei.
The Gemara answers: Rav Hamnuna <span class="gemarra-regular">holds that </span>one does <span class="gemarra-regular">not write a receipt, </span>so that scenario cannot occur. Like Rabbi Yehuda, Rav Hamnuna maintains that if a creditor loses his promissory note the debtor does not have to repay the loan. Rabbi Yosei, who does allow the creditor to collect his debt in such a case and write a receipt for the debtor, is concerned about that scenario, and consequently he holds that postdated promissory notes are not valid.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yeimar said to Rav Kahana, and some say </span>it was <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yirmeya of Difti </span>who said this <span class="gemarra-regular">to Rav Kahana: And today, when we write postdated </span>promissory <span class="gemarra-regular">notes,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and we </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">write a receipt </span>in cases where the creditor loses his promissory note, <span class="gemarra-regular">why do we do this? </span>The combination of allowing postdated promissory notes and allowing the writing of a receipt instead of producing the promissory note would enable double collection of the loan to take place. Rav Kahana <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>The problem was rectified <span class="gemarra-regular">after Rabbi Abba told his </span>court <span class="gemarra-regular">scribe: When you write postdated </span>promissory <span class="gemarra-regular">notes, write as follows: We did not write this document on its date, </span>i.e., on the date written within the document; <span class="gemarra-regular">rather, we postdated it and wrote it. </span>Since it is clear from the text of the document that it was postdated, double collection of the loan is avoided.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi said to Rav Kahana: But</span> what about <span class="gemarra-regular">today, when we do not do this, </span>i.e., we do not follow Rabbi Abba’s instructions? How do we avoid double collection of the loan? Rav Kahana replied: The problem was rectified <span class="gemarra-regular">after Rav Safra said to his </span>court <span class="gemarra-regular">scribe: When you write these receipts </span>for debtors who pay debts without the original promissory note being torn, <span class="gemarra-regular">if you know the date </span>written <span class="gemarra-regular">in the </span>missing promissory <span class="gemarra-regular">note, write </span>it into the receipt. But <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>you do <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>know the date written in the promissory note, <span class="gemarra-regular">write </span>the receipt <span class="gemarra-regular">without specification</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., do not write any date at all in the receipt, so <span class="gemarra-regular">that</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> whenever </span>the creditor <span class="gemarra-regular">produce</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> the promissory note, the undated receipt <span class="gemarra-regular">can weaken it, </span>i.e., exempt the debtor from payment.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Ravina said to Rav Ashi, and some say </span>it was <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi </span>who said <span class="gemarra-regular">to Rav Kahana: </span>

Daf 172a

<span class="gemarra-regular">But today, when we do not do this </span>either when writing receipts, how can we avoid double collection of a loan? Rav Kahana <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: The Sages instituted </span>taking this precaution. <span class="gemarra-regular">One who does </span>what the Sages instituted <span class="gemarra-regular">does </span>it and protects himself from loss; and as for <span class="gemarra-regular">one who does not do </span>so, <span class="gemarra-regular">he has brought the loss upon himself, </span>and will suffer the consequences if the promissory note is found and presented in the future.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava bar Rav Sheila said to those who wrote deeds of acquisition, </span>i.e., deeds of sale or deeds of gifts for property they acquired: <span class="gemarra-regular">When you write deeds of acquisition </span>after the acquisition was performed, <span class="gemarra-regular">if you know the day on which you effected the acquisition</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> write </span>that date on the document. <span class="gemarra-regular">But if </span>you do <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>know the day on which you effected the acquisition, <span class="gemarra-regular">write the date on which you are currently </span>writing the document. You should follow this procedure, and not write an approximate or estimated date, <span class="gemarra-regular">so that </span>the document shall <span class="gemarra-regular">not appear as a falsehood.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav said to his scribe, and Rav Huna said similarly to his scribe: When you</span> are writing a document and you <span class="gemarra-regular">are situated in Shili, write </span>that the document was written <span class="gemarra-regular">in Shili, and </span>you should do so <span class="gemarra-regular">even if the matters were given over to you, </span>i.e., the transaction attested to in the document took place, <span class="gemarra-regular">in Hini</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> When you are situated in Hini, write </span>that the document was written <span class="gemarra-regular">in Hini, even if the matters were given over to you </span><span class="gemarra-regular">in Shili.</span>
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">this one who is holding </span>a promissory <span class="gemarra-regular">note of one hundred dinars</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and he says </span>to the court: <span class="gemarra-regular">Prepare </span>this note <span class="gemarra-regular">for me, </span>i.e., exchange it, for <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>notes <span class="gemarra-regular">of fifty </span>dinars <span class="gemarra-regular">each, </span>so that if the debtor pays half the debt I will be able to give him one document and keep the other, <span class="gemarra-regular">we do not prepare </span>the new notes for him.
<span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason? The Sages have performed a matter </span>here <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">beneficial to the creditor and </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">beneficial to the debtor </span>as well. It is <span class="gemarra-regular">beneficial to the creditor </span>to keep the promissory note with the larger sum <span class="gemarra-regular">so that </span>he can <span class="gemarra-regular">coerce </span>the debtor <span class="gemarra-regular">to repay him, </span>as there is a greater incentive to pay off a larger promissory note than a smaller one. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">beneficial to the debtor, so that </span>when he pays half the debt <span class="gemarra-regular">his </span>promissory <span class="gemarra-regular">note becomes vitiated, </span>and the remainder of the sum written in the vitiated promissory note can be collected only if the creditor takes an oath that he has not received the entire sum.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rava said</span> further: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">this one who is holding two </span>promissory <span class="gemarra-regular">notes, each of fifty dinars, </span>owed by the same person, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he says </span>to the court: <span class="gemarra-regular">Prepare </span>this note <span class="gemarra-regular">for me </span>into <span class="gemarra-regular">a single </span>note <span class="gemarra-regular">of one hundred </span>dinars, <span class="gemarra-regular">we do not prepare</span> the new note for him.
What is the reason? <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages have performed a matter </span>here <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">beneficial to the creditor and </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">beneficial to the debtor </span>as well. It is <span class="gemarra-regular">beneficial to the creditor </span>to keep the smaller notes, <span class="gemarra-regular">so that </span>if the debtor pays fifty dinars, <span class="gemarra-regular">his </span>promissory <span class="gemarra-regular">note will not become vitiated, </span>which would require the creditor to take an oath before collecting the remainder. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">beneficial to the debtor, so that </span>the creditor <span class="gemarra-regular">will not </span>be able to <span class="gemarra-regular">coerce him to repay </span>the debt quickly, as there is a greater incentive to repay a larger sum than a smaller one.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi says: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">this one who is holding </span>a promissory <span class="gemarra-regular">note of one hundred dinars, and he said </span>to the court: <span class="gemarra-regular">Prepare </span>this note <span class="gemarra-regular">for me </span>into <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>note <span class="gemarra-regular">of fifty </span>dinars, as the debtor has paid me half, <span class="gemarra-regular">we do not prepare </span>the new note for him.
<span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason? We say, </span>i.e., we are concerned, that the following may have happened: <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>debtor actually <span class="gemarra-regular">repaid </span>all one hundred dinars, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>when he did so he <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>the creditor: <span class="gemarra-regular">Give me</span> back <span class="gemarra-regular">my </span>promissory <span class="gemarra-regular">note. And </span>the creditor <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: I lost it.
