And </span>the creditor <span class="gemarra-regular">wrote a receipt for him </span>in lieu of handing over the promissory note. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>now, if we write a new promissory note of fifty dinars for the creditor, <span class="gemarra-regular">he will present this </span>note <span class="gemarra-regular">and say to </span>the debtor, who presents his receipt for a hundred dinars: <span class="gemarra-regular">That </span>receipt <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">a different </span>loan that you repaid.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In a case where there are <span class="gemarra-regular">two brothers, one poor and one rich, and their father left them a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">bathhous</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">or an olive press </span>as an inheritance, if the father had <span class="gemarra-regular">built </span>these facilities <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span><span class="gemarra-regular">profit</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., to charge others for using them, <span class="gemarra-regular">the profit </span>that accrues after the father’s death is <span class="gemarra-regular">shared </span><span class="gemarra-regular">equall</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span> by the two brothers. If the father had <span class="gemarra-regular">built them for himself </span>and for the members of his household to use, the poor brother, who has little use for these amenities, cannot force the rich brother to convert the facilities to commercial use; rather, <span class="gemarra-regular">the rich </span>brother can <span class="gemarra-regular">say to the poor </span>brother: Go <span class="gemarra-regular">take servants for yourself, and they will bathe in the bathhouse. </span>Or he can say: Go <span class="gemarra-regular">take olives for yourself, and come and make </span>them into oil <span class="gemarra-regular">in the olive press.</span>
If there are <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>people <span class="gemarra-regular">who were</span> living <span class="gemarra-regular">in one city</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> one named Yosef ben Shimon and the other </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">named Yosef ben Shimon, one cannot present a promissory note against the other, </span>as the purported debtor can claim: On the contrary, it is you who owed me money; you repaid me and I returned this note to you upon payment. <span class="gemarra-regular">Nor can another, </span>third person, <span class="gemarra-regular">present a promissory note against </span>either of <span class="gemarra-regular">them, </span>as each one can claim: It is not I but the other Yosef ben Shimon who owes you money.
If a document <span class="gemarra-regular">is found among one’s documents </span>stating: <span class="gemarra-regular">The promissory note against Yosef ben Shimon is repaid, </span>and both men named Yosef ben Shimon owed this man money, <span class="gemarra-regular">the promissory notes of both of them </span>are considered <span class="gemarra-regular">repaid, </span>as it cannot be determined which debt was repaid and which is outstanding.
<span class="gemarra-regular">What should </span>two people with the same name in a single city <span class="gemarra-regular">do </span>in order to conduct their business? <span class="gemarra-regular">They should triple </span>their names by writing three generations: Yosef ben Shimon ben so-and-so. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if they have </span>identical <span class="gemarra-regular">triple </span>names, i.e., not only their fathers but their grandfathers had identical names, <span class="gemarra-regular">they should write an indication </span>as to which one is referred to, such as: The short Yosef ben Shimon or the dark Yosef ben Shimon. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if they have </span>identical <span class="gemarra-regular">indications, they should write: </span>Yosef ben Shimon <span class="gemarra-regular">the priest, </span>if one of them is a priest.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> There was <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain </span>promissory <span class="gemarra-regular">note that was presented at the court of Rav Huna, in which it was written: I, so-and-so son of so-and-so, borrowed one hundred dinars from you. </span>No name was given as the creditor, but the one presenting the document claimed that the money was owed to him. 

Daf 172b

<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna said: </span>The term: <span class="gemarra-regular">From you</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> in the document do not identify anyone in particular, and can mean <span class="gemarra-regular">even: From the Exilarch</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> or even: From King Shapur</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥisda said to Rabba: Go out </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">investigate </span>this matter, <span class="gemarra-regular">as tonight Rav Huna will ask this </span>question <span class="gemarra-regular">of you.</span>
Rabba <span class="gemarra-regular">went out, examined </span>the matter, <span class="gemarra-regular">and discovered </span>a relevant source. <span class="gemarra-regular">As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: Concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">a bill of divorce in which there are </span>the signatures of <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses on </span>the document <span class="gemarra-regular">but there is no date </span>written <span class="gemarra-regular">on </span><span class="gemarra-regular">it, Abba Shaul says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">is written in it: I divorced her today</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> it is <span class="gemarra-regular">valid.</span>
Rabba concludes: <span class="gemarra-regular">Apparently, </span>the term: <span class="gemarra-regular">Today, indicates that day on which </span>the bill of divorce <span class="gemarra-regular">emerges </span>in the presence of the court. <span class="gemarra-regular">Here too, </span>the term: <span class="gemarra-regular">From you, </span>in a promissory note <span class="gemarra-regular">indicates that man from whose possession it emerges.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said to him: But </span>this is not a valid proof, as <span class="gemarra-regular">perhaps Abba Shaul holds in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Eliezer, who says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses of the transmission </span>of the bill of divorce <span class="gemarra-regular">effect </span>the divorce. <span class="gemarra-regular">But here, let </span>there be <span class="gemarra-regular">a concern for </span>the possibility of the promissory note <span class="gemarra-regular">falling</span> from its rightful owner and being found by the present holder of the document.
Rabba <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Abaye: <span class="gemarra-regular">We are not concerned </span><span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>the possibility of a promissory note <span class="gemarra-regular">falling </span>from its rightful owner and being found by another. <span class="gemarra-regular">And from where do you say, </span>i.e., from where can it be proven, <span class="gemarra-regular">that we are not concerned for </span>the possibility of a promissory note <span class="gemarra-regular">falling </span>and being found by another?
<span class="gemarra-regular">As we learned </span>in the mishna: If there are <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>people <span class="gemarra-regular">who were </span>living <span class="gemarra-regular">in one city,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> one named Yosef ben Shimon and the other </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">named Yosef ben Shimon, one cannot present a promissory note against the other, </span>as the purported debtor can claim: On the contrary, it is you who owed me money; you repaid me and I returned this note to you upon payment. <span class="gemarra-regular">Nor can another, </span>third person, <span class="gemarra-regular">present a promissory note against </span>either of <span class="gemarra-regular">them. This </span>indicates that one of <span class="gemarra-regular">them can </span>present a promissory note <span class="gemarra-regular">against others</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> But why </span>can they do so? <span class="gemarra-regular">Let </span>there be <span class="gemarra-regular">a concern for </span>the possibility of the promissory note <span class="gemarra-regular">falling </span>from one Yosef ben Shimon and being found by the other. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>must one <span class="gemarra-regular">not conclude from this </span>mishna that <span class="gemarra-regular">we are not concerned for </span>the possibility of the promissory note <span class="gemarra-regular">falling </span>from one Yosef ben Shimon and being found by the other?
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>why did <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye, </span>who is concerned for this possibility, not see a proof to the contrary from the mishna? He would counter: <span class="gemarra-regular">We are not concerned for </span>the possibility of a promissory note <span class="gemarra-regular">falling from one </span>particular person and being found by the other person with the same name, which is the case in the mishna, as that is extremely unlikely. <span class="gemarra-regular">We are concerned for </span>the possibility of a promissory note <span class="gemarra-regular">falling </span><span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>one of the general <span class="gemarra-regular">public </span>and being found by someone else. 

Daf 173a

The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>what of <span class="gemarra-regular">that which is taught </span>in another <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Just as </span>the two men named Yosef ben Shimon <span class="gemarra-regular">cannot produce a promissory note, this </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">against that </span>one, <span class="gemarra-regular">so they cannot produce </span>promissory notes <span class="gemarra-regular">against others, </span>as those others can claim: I did not borrow from you but from the other Yosef ben Shimon, and somehow the note he was holding is in your possession? This <span class="it-text">baraita</span> contradicts the mishna, from which it was inferred that one of the two men named Yosef ben Shimon can produce promissory notes to collect the debt from others. <span class="gemarra-regular">With regard to what </span>principle <span class="gemarra-regular">do </span>the mishna and <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">disagree?</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">They disagree with regard to </span>whether <span class="gemarra-regular">letters, </span>i.e., the content of a promissory note, <span class="gemarra-regular">are acquired by </span>merely <span class="gemarra-regular">transferrin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span> the document to a new owner. In other words, they disagree about whether or not a creditor can transfer his right to collect a debt to another by merely transferring the document to him.
<span class="gemarra-regular">The </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of our </span>mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">maintains </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">letters are acquired by transferring</span> the document. There is no concern that the promissory note was inadvertently transferred from one Yosef ben Shimon to the other by being lost and then found, as explained earlier. Nevertheless, there is still the possibility that one Yosef ben Shimon deliberately transferred the promissory note to the other, transferring the right of collection to him. According to this <span class="it-text">tanna</span>, the second Yosef ben Shimon is fully entitled to collect the debt by producing the promissory note. <span class="gemarra-regular">And the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">baraita</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">letters are not acquired by transferrin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span> the document, so that even if one Yosef ben Shimon transferred his promissory note to the other, the new holder of the document is not entitled to collect the debt.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if you wish, say that everyone, </span>i.e., both the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> of the mishna and the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, holds that <span class="gemarra-regular">letters are acquired by transferring </span>the document, <span class="gemarra-regular">and here they disagree with regard to </span>whether or not the new holder of the promissory note is <span class="gemarra-regular">required to bring proof </span>that the original creditor transferred it to him for collection, as opposed to his having received it for safekeeping or having found it by chance. <span class="gemarra-regular">The </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of our </span>mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that the present holder of the document is <span class="gemarra-regular">not required to bring proof </span>that the debt was transferred to him and therefore he can collect the debt through the promissory note in his possession. <span class="gemarra-regular">And the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">baraita</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> holds </span>that he is <span class="gemarra-regular">required to bring </span>such <span class="gemarra-regular">proof, </span>and in its absence he cannot collect the debt with the document he holds.
This is <span class="gemarra-regular">as it was stated: Letters are acquired by transferring </span>the document. <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye says: </span>The new holder of the document is <span class="gemarra-regular">required to bring proof </span>that he has in fact acquired the right to collect the debt. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rava says: He is not required to bring</span> such <span class="gemarra-regular">proof; </span>it is assumed that if he is holding the document it was transferred to him knowingly by the original creditor.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said: From where do I say </span>that he is required to bring proof? This is <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one of </span>several <span class="gemarra-regular">brothers, </span>heirs of an estate, <span class="gemarra-regular">who has a promissory note in his possessio</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> listing a debt owed to the deceased father, and he seeks to collect the debt for himself, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">upon him to bring proof </span>that the document was transferred to him legally by his father in his lifetime, or that it was bequeathed to him specifically and he did not appropriate it from the other brothers. Abaye concludes from this: <span class="gemarra-regular">What, is the same not true for </span>all <span class="gemarra-regular">others </span>in a similar situation? In other words, whenever someone holds a promissory note that did not initially belong to him he is required to prove that he acquired it legally.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rava said </span>in response: Proof is not generally required in such a case. But the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">brothers </span>who are heirs <span class="gemarra-regular">is different, as </span>it is common for brothers who are co-heirs to <span class="gemarra-regular">seize </span>property belonging to the estate <span class="gemarra-regular">from one another.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">There are </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">who say </span>there is a different version of this exchange between Abaye and Rava. According to this version, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: From where do I say </span>that no proof is required? <span class="gemarra-regular">As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one of </span>several <span class="gemarra-regular">brothers, </span>heirs of an estate, <span class="gemarra-regular">who has a promissory note in his possession </span>listing a debt owed to the deceased father, and he seeks to collect the debt for himself, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">upon him to bring proof </span>that the document was transferred to him legally by his father in his lifetime, or that it was bequeathed to him specifically and that he did not appropriate it from the other brothers. The implication is that <span class="gemarra-regular">it is </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">brothers </span>who must bring such proof, as it is common for brothers who are co-heirs to <span class="gemarra-regular">seize </span>property belonging to the estate <span class="gemarra-regular">from one another. But others </span>in a similar situation do <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>have to bring proof that they acquired the promissory note legally.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>how would <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye </span>counter this proof? He would say: There is no difference between <span class="gemarra-regular">brothers </span>and anyone else; they all have to bring proof. The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> specifies brothers because it <span class="gemarra-regular">was necessary for it </span>to mention that case, as it might <span class="gemarra-regular">enter your mind to say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">since </span>it is common for brothers who are co-heirs to <span class="gemarra-regular">seize </span>property belonging to the estate <span class="gemarra-regular">from one another, </span>one might <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">they are careful </span>to prevent such attempts. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>therefore, when brothers produce a promissory note, <span class="gemarra-regular">they are not required to bring proof </span>that they obtained it legally, as it is assumed that the other brothers would not have allowed the note to escape their possession otherwise. To counter this, the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>that brothers, too, must bring proof when they produce promissory notes.
§ The Gemara returns to discuss the case of two men with the same name. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>what about <span class="gemarra-regular">that which is taught </span>in another <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Just as </span>the two men named Yosef ben Shimon <span class="gemarra-regular">can produce a promissory note against others, so can they produce </span>promissory notes <span class="gemarra-regular">against one another. </span>This represents a third opinion, standing in opposition to both the mishna and the previous <span class="it-text">baraita</span>. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">With regard to what do </span>the mishna and first <span class="it-text">baraita</span> on the one hand, and this <span class="it-text">baraita</span> on the other, <span class="gemarra-regular">disagree?</span>
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">They disagree about </span>whether or not a scribe <span class="gemarra-regular">may write </span>a promissory <span class="gemarra-regular">note for a debtor even if </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">creditor is not with him.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">The </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of our </span>mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that a scribe <span class="gemarra-regular">may write</span> a promissory <span class="gemarra-regular">note for a debtor even if the creditor is not with him. </span>The Gemara explains: At <span class="gemarra-regular">times, </span>it could happen <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>one of the men named Yosef ben Shimon <span class="gemarra-regular">goes to a scribe and </span>to <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses and says to them: Write </span>a promissory <span class="gemarra-regular">note for me, as I wish to borrow </span>money <span class="gemarra-regular">from another Yosef ben Shimon. And </span>then, <span class="gemarra-regular">after they write </span>the document <span class="gemarra-regular">and sign </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">for him, </span>he will <span class="gemarra-regular">take it and say to </span>the other Yosef ben Shimon: <span class="gemarra-regular">Give me the hundred </span>dinars <span class="gemarra-regular">that you borrowed from me, </span>as attested to in this document. That is the reason why the mishna rules that two people of the same name cannot collect a debt through a promissory note from one another, thereby preventing this occurrence.
By contrast, <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of the </span>other <span class="gemarra-italic">baraita</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> holds </span>that a scribe <span class="gemarra-regular">may not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">write </span>a promissory <span class="gemarra-regular">note for a debtor unless </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">creditor is with him </span>and consents to the writing of the document. If one Yosef ben Shimon consents to the writing of the document before the other, they apparently trust one another, and there is no concern that the one holding the promissory note will defraud the other.
§ The mishna teaches: If a document is <span class="gemarra-regular">found </span><span class="gemarra-regular">among one’s documents </span>stating: The promissory <span class="gemarra-regular">note against Yosef ben Shimon is repaid, </span>and both men named Yosef ben Shimon owed this man money, <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>promissory <span class="gemarra-regular">notes of both of them are </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">repaid, </span>as it cannot be determined which debt was repaid and which is outstanding. The Gemara comments: The implication of the mishna is that <span class="gemarra-regular">the reason </span>this man cannot collect his debt is <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>this note <span class="gemarra-regular">was found </span>among his papers; <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>if it was <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>suddenly found, rather he was always aware of its existence, <span class="gemarra-regular">he could present </span>a promissory note against one of the men named Yosef ben Shimon and collect the debt from him. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But didn’t we learn </span>earlier in the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">Nor can another present a promissory note against </span>either of <span class="gemarra-regular">them?</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yirmeya said: </span>This later line in the mishna is stated <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>a promissory note in which the debtors Yosef ben Shimon are identified by having their names <span class="gemarra-regular">tripled, </span>i.e., through mentioning the name of their respective grandfathers, as is explained at the end of the mishna.
The Gemara questions this explanation: <span class="gemarra-regular">But let us see in whose name </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">receipt, </span>i.e., the note stating that Yosef ben Shimon’s debt has been repaid, <span class="gemarra-regular">is written. </span>Why is there uncertainty as to which Yosef ben Shimon is referred to in the document? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Hoshaya said: </span>The case is <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the debtors are identified by having their names <span class="gemarra-regular">tripled in the </span>promissory <span class="gemarra-regular">note, but </span>the names are <span class="gemarra-regular">not tripled in the receipt</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye stated </span>a different answer to this question, that the mishna is speaking about the debtor, not the creditor, and <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>is what <span class="gemarra-regular">it</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is saying: </span>If a receipt is <span class="gemarra-regular">found among the debtor’s document</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> stating: <span class="gemarra-regular">The </span>promissory <span class="gemarra-regular">note o</span><span class="gemarra-regular">f  Y</span><span class="gemarra-regular">osef ben Shimon </span>against me has been <span class="gemarra-regular">repaid, </span>and this debtor had borrowed money from both men named Yosef ben Shimon, <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>promissory <span class="gemarra-regular">notes of both of them are </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">repaid</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., they are not valid for collection, as it cannot be determined which debt was paid and which one is outstanding.
The mishna teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">What should </span>two people with the same name in a single city <span class="gemarra-regular">do </span>in order to conduct their business? <span class="gemarra-regular">They should triple </span>their names by writing three generations: Yosef ben Shimon ben so-and-so. If their grandfather’s names are identical and they have no prominent physical difference to indicate who is the one listed in the document, they write that the one referred to in the document is a priest, if that is the case. The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">taught </span>the following continuation of the mishna in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: And <span class="gemarra-regular">if both of them were priests, they should write </span>several <span class="gemarra-regular">generations </span>of ancestors, until a divergence in names is found that can serve as a means of identification.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who says to his son </span>before dying: One promissory <span class="gemarra-regular">note among </span>the promissory <span class="gemarra-regular">notes </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">my </span>possession <span class="gemarra-regular">is repaid, but I do not know which </span><span class="gemarra-regular">one</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>promissory <span class="gemarra-regular">notes of all of </span>those who owe him money <span class="gemarra-regular">are </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">repaid, </span>i.e., they are not valid for collection, as it cannot be determined which debt was repaid and which are outstanding. If there were <span class="gemarra-regular">found </span>among his papers <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>promissory notes owed <span class="gemarra-regular">by one </span>person, the one for <span class="gemarra-regular">the greater </span>amount <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">repaid, and </span>the one for <span class="gemarra-regular">the smaller </span>amount <span class="gemarra-regular">is not </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">repaid</span> and can be collected; the debtor is favored in the case of an uncertainty.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava says </span>that if a creditor says to a debtor who borrowed money twice from him: One promissory <span class="gemarra-regular">note </span>of the two that I have <span class="gemarra-regular">of yours in my possession is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">repaid</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> without specifying which one, the one for <span class="gemarra-regular">the greater </span>amount <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">repaid, and </span>the one for <span class="gemarra-regular">the smaller </span>amount <span class="gemarra-regular">is not </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">repaid, </span>and can be collected. If the creditor said instead: <span class="gemarra-regular">The debt of yours </span>that I have <span class="gemarra-regular">in my possession is repaid, all </span>the promissory <span class="gemarra-regular">notes </span>this creditor has from this debtor <span class="gemarra-regular">are </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">repaid, </span>as the term debt covers all the loans at once.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Ravina said to Rava: If that is so </span>that when one makes an ambiguous statement it is interpreted to his detriment, does the same <span class="it-text">halakha</span> apply to sales? If a seller of land writes a document for a purchaser stating: <span class="gemarra-regular">My field is </span>hereby <span class="gemarra-regular">sold to you</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> without specifying which of his two fields he is referring to, is it the <span class="gemarra-regular">larger field </span>that is <span class="gemarra-regular">sold to him? </span>And if he writes a document for the purchaser stating: The <span class="gemarra-regular">field that I have is sold to you, </span>is it so that <span class="gemarra-regular">all of his fields are sold to him, </span>as the Hebrew word for field can refer to several fields as well as a single field?
Rava explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">There, the holder of the document </span>of sale <span class="gemarra-regular">is at a disadvantage</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as it is he who seeks to take more property from the seller, and must accept the minimal meaning. Here too, in the case of the promissory notes, it is the holder of the document, the creditor, who seeks to collect more money from the debtor. Therefore, the creditor is at a disadvantage.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">One who lends </span>money <span class="gemarra-regular">to another with </span>the assurance of <span class="gemarra-regular">a guarantor</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> cannot collect </span>the debt <span class="gemarra-regular">from the guarantor. </span>

Daf 173b

<span class="gemarra-regular">But if </span>the creditor <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>the debtor: I am lending the money <span class="gemarra-regular">on the condition that I will collect </span>the debt <span class="gemarra-regular">from whomever I wish, </span>i.e., either the debtor or the guarantor, he <span class="gemarra-regular">can collect </span>the debt <span class="gemarra-regular">from the guarantor. </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: If the debtor has property </span>of his own, then <span class="gemarra-regular">whether </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>case, where the creditor stipulated this condition, <span class="gemarra-regular">or that </span>case, where he did not, he <span class="gemarra-regular">cannot collect </span>the debt <span class="gemarra-regular">from the guarantor.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And so Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel would say</span><span class="gemarra-regular">:</span> If there is <span class="gemarra-regular">a guarantor for a woman for her marriage contract</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> from whom the woman can collect payment of her marriage contract instead of collecting it from the husband, <span class="gemarra-regular">and her husband was divorcing her, </span>the husband <span class="gemarra-regular">must take a vow </span>prohibiting himself from deriving any <span class="gemarra-regular">benefit from her, </span>so that he can never remarry her. This precaution is taken <span class="gemarra-regular">lest </span>the couple <span class="gemarra-regular">collude [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">kenunya</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> to divorce in order to collect payment of the marriage contract <span class="gemarra-regular">from this </span>guarantor’s <span class="gemarra-regular">property, and </span>then the husband <span class="gemarra-regular">will remarry</span> his wife.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna teaches: One who lends money to another with a guarantor cannot collect the debt from the guarantor. The Gemara at first understands that the mishna is ruling that a guarantor’s commitment is limited to when the debtor dies or flees. <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>the guarantor’s commitment is limited? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba and Rav Yosef both say </span>that the guarantor can tell the creditor: <span class="gemarra-regular">You gave a man over to me, </span>to take responsibility for him if he dies or flees; <span class="gemarra-regular">I have given a man </span>back <span class="gemarra-regular">to you. </span>The debtor is here before you; take your money from him, and if he has nothing, suffer the loss yourself.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman objects to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">this: This is Persian law.</span>
The Gemara interjects: <span class="gemarra-regular">On the contrary, </span>the Persian courts <span class="gemarra-regular">go after the guarantor</span> directly, without even attempting to collect the debt from the debtor himself. Why, then, did Rav Naḥman say that excusing the guarantor from payment is Persian law?
The Gemara clarifies Rav Naḥman’s intent: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>Rav Naḥman meant to say that this kind of ruling would be appropriate for the members of <span class="gemarra-regular">a Persian court, who do not give a reason for their statements, </span>but issue rulings by whim. Rav Naḥman was saying that it is not fair or logical to excuse the guarantor and cause a loss to the creditor who was depending on him.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Rav Naḥman said: What </span>does the mishna mean when it says that the creditor <span class="gemarra-regular">cannot collect</span> the debt <span class="gemarra-regular">from the guarantor? </span>It means that he <span class="gemarra-regular">cannot claim </span>payment from the <span class="gemarra-regular">guarantor at the outset, </span>until after it is established that the debtor has no means to repay the debt. After the borrower defaults, the creditor can collect the debt from the guarantor.
<span class="gemarra-regular">This </span><span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is also taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: One <span class="gemarra-regular">who lends </span>money <span class="gemarra-regular">to another with </span>the assurance of <span class="gemarra-regular">a guarantor cannot claim </span>payment of the debt <span class="gemarra-regular">from the guarantor at the outset, </span>rather, he must first attempt to collect the debt from the debtor. <span class="gemarra-regular">But if </span>the creditor <span class="gemarra-regular">said to</span> the debtor: I am lending the money <span class="gemarra-regular">on the condition that I will collect </span>the debt <span class="gemarra-regular">from whomever I wish, </span>he can <span class="gemarra-regular">claim payment </span>of the debt <span class="gemarra-regular">from the guarantor at the outset, </span>bypassing the debtor.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna said: From where </span>is it derived <span class="gemarra-regular">that</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a guarantor becomes obligated </span>to repay a loan he has guaranteed? <span class="gemarra-regular">As it is written </span>that Judah reassured his father concerning the young Benjamin: <span class="gemarra-regular">“I will be his guarantor</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of my hand shall you request him” </span>(Genesis 43:9). This teaches that it is possible for one to act as a guarantor that an item will be returned to the giver.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥisda objects to this:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> This </span>incident involving Benjamin is not a case of a standard guarantor, but a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">an </span><span class="gemarra-regular">unconditional guarantee, as it is written, </span>also in the context of Benjamin, that Reuben said: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Deliver him into my hand, and I will bring him back to you” </span>(Genesis 42:37). One who undertakes unconditional responsibility for a loan has a different status than a standard guarantor, as will soon be elaborated. Therefore, a biblical source has yet to be adduced to teach that one can become a standard guarantor.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Rabbi Yitzḥak said </span>that the source is <span class="gemarra-regular">from here: “Take his garment that is surety for a stranger; and hold him in pledge that is surety for an alien woman” </span>(Proverbs 20:16). The verse advises a creditor to take the garment of the debtor’s guarantor as payment for the loan.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And it is stated: “My son, if you have become surety for your neighbor, if you have shaken your hands for a stranger, you have become ensnared by the words of your mouth, you have been caught by the words of your mouth. Do this now, my son, and save yourself, seeing that you have come into the hand of your neighbor: Go, humble yourself [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">hitrappes</span><span class="gemarra-regular">], and assemble your neighbors” </span>(Proverbs 6:1–3). This last part of the passage means: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>your neighbor’s <span class="gemarra-regular">money is in your possession, </span>as you owe it as a guarantor, <span class="gemarra-regular">open up [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">hatter</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] the palm [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">pissat</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of your hand </span>and repay him. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>money that you owe him, but rather “you have become ensnared by the words of your mouth” and owe him an apology for a personal slight, <span class="gemarra-regular">gather together many neighbors </span>through which to seek his forgiveness.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Ameimar said: </span>The issue of <span class="gemarra-regular">whether </span>or not <span class="gemarra-regular">a guarantor </span>in fact <span class="gemarra-regular">becomes obligated </span>to repay the loan he has guaranteed is <span class="gemarra-regular">a disput</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> between <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Yosei. According to Rabbi Yosei, who says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a transaction with inconclusive consent [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">asmakhta</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] effects acquisition, a guarantor becomes obligated </span>to repay the loan, whereas <span class="gemarra-regular">according to Rabbi Yehuda, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">who says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">an </span><span class="gemarra-italic">asmakhta</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> does not effect acquisition, a guarantor </span>does <span class="gemarra-regular">not become obligated </span>to repay the loan. Any obligation one undertakes that is dependent on the fulfillment of certain conditions that he does not expect will be fulfilled, in this case the debtor’s default on the loan, is considered an <span class="it-text">asmakhta</span>.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi said to Ameimar </span>that he was conflating these two issues: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">a daily occurrence, </span>i.e., it is taken for granted, <span class="gemarra-regular">that an </span><span class="gemarra-italic">asmakhta</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> does not effect acquisition, and </span>it is also taken for granted that <span class="gemarra-regular">a guarantor becomes obligated</span> to repay the loan he has guaranteed.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Rav Ashi said: Through that satisfaction that </span>the guarantor feels when the creditor <span class="gemarra-regular">trusts him </span>and loans the money based on his guarantee, the guarantor <span class="gemarra-regular">resolves </span>to <span class="gemarra-regular">obligate himsel</span><span class="gemarra-regular">f </span> to repay the loan. Guaranteeing a loan is unlike a usual case of an obligation undertaken that is dependent on the fulfillment of certain conditions that he does not expect will be fulfilled, in which the commitment is not considered a real one. Here, the one obligating himself experiences a sense of satisfaction when the money is loaned to the debtor, and due to that, fully commits to fulfill his obligation.
§ The mishna teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">But if </span>the creditor <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>to the debtor: I am lending the money <span class="gemarra-regular">on the condition that I will collect </span>the debt <span class="gemarra-regular">from whomever I wish,</span> he can collect the debt from the guarantor. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba bar bar Ḥana says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: They taught </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">only when the debtor has no property </span>of his own from which to repay the loan, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">the debtor has property </span>the creditor <span class="gemarra-regular">cannot collect </span>the debt <span class="gemarra-regular">from the guarantor.</span>
The Gemara questions this assertion: <span class="gemarra-regular">But from </span>the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that the latter clause </span>of the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: If the debtor has property</span> of his own, then whether in this case, where the creditor stipulated this condition, or that case, where he did not, he <span class="gemarra-regular">cannot collect </span>the debt <span class="gemarra-regular">from the guarantor, by inference </span>one can understand <span class="gemarra-regular">that the first </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> maintains </span>that there <span class="gemarra-regular">is no difference </span>if it is <span class="gemarra-regular">like this and </span>there <span class="gemarra-regular">is no difference </span>if it is <span class="gemarra-regular">like that. </span>Whether or not the debtor has property from which to repay the loan, the creditor can collect the debt from the guarantor.
The Gemara clarifies: The mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">is incomplete and this </span>is what <span class="gemarra-regular">it is teaching: One who lends </span>money <span class="gemarra-regular">to another with </span>the assurance of <span class="gemarra-regular">a guaranto</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> cannot collect </span>the debt <span class="gemarra-regular">from the guarantor </span>before first claiming the debt from the debtor. <span class="gemarra-regular">But if </span>the creditor <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>to the debtor: I am lending the money <span class="gemarra-regular">on the condition that I will collect </span>the debt <span class="gemarra-regular">from whomever I wish</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> he <span class="gemarra-regular">can collect </span>the debt <span class="gemarra-regular">from the guarantor.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> In what </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">is this statement said? When the debtor has no property </span>of his own from which to repay the debt; <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">the debtor has property, </span>the creditor <span class="gemarra-regular">cannot collect </span>the debt <span class="gemarra-regular">from the guarantor. </span>This is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to a standard guarantor, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">an unconditional guarantor,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> even if the debtor has property </span>of his own, the creditor <span class="gemarra-regular">can collect </span>the debt <span class="gemarra-regular">from the unconditional guarantor. </span>

Daf 174a

<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: If the debtor has property, </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">both this </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>case, i.e., whether the guarantor is a standard guarantor or an unconditional guarantor, the creditor <span class="gemarra-regular">cannot collect </span>the debt <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>either type of guarantor.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba bar Ḥana says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: Wherever Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel taught </span>a <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the corpus of <span class="gemarra-regular">our Mishna, </span>the <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with his </span>opinion, <span class="gemarra-regular">except for </span>the following three cases: The responsibility of the <span class="gemarra-regular">guarantor, and </span>the incident that occurred in the city of <span class="gemarra-regular">Tzaidan </span>(see <span class="it-text">Gittin</span> 74a), <span class="gemarra-regular">and</span> the dispute with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">evidence </span>in the <span class="gemarra-regular">final </span>disagreement (see <span class="it-text">Sanhedrin</span> 31a).
§ The Gemara discusses which expressions confer upon a person the status of a standard guarantor, and which confer the status of an unconditional guarantor. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna says </span>that if one says to a potential creditor: <span class="gemarra-regular">Lend </span>money to <span class="gemarra-regular">him and I </span>am <span class="gemarra-regular">a guarantor</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> or: <span class="gemarra-regular">Lend </span>money to <span class="gemarra-regular">him and I </span>will <span class="gemarra-regular">repay </span>the debt, or: <span class="gemarra-regular">Lend </span>money to <span class="gemarra-regular">him and I </span>am <span class="gemarra-regular">obligated </span>to repay the debt, or: <span class="gemarra-regular">Lend </span>money to <span class="gemarra-regular">him and I </span>will <span class="gemarra-regular">give </span>the money back to you, <span class="gemarra-regular">all these are expressions </span>that confer the status of a standard <span class="gemarra-regular">guarantee.</span>
If one says: <span class="gemarra-regular">Give </span>money <span class="gemarra-regular">to him and I </span>am <span class="gemarra-regular">an unconditional guarantor, </span>or: <span class="gemarra-regular">Give </span>money <span class="gemarra-regular">to him and I </span>will <span class="gemarra-regular">repay </span>the debt, or: <span class="gemarra-regular">Give </span>money <span class="gemarra-regular">to him and I </span>am <span class="gemarra-regular">obligated </span>to repay the debt, or: <span class="gemarra-regular">Give </span>money <span class="gemarra-regular">to him and I </span>will <span class="gemarra-regular">give</span> the money back to you, <span class="gemarra-regular">all these are expressions </span>that confer the status of <span class="gemarra-regular">an unconditional guarantee. </span>The usage of the word give, as opposed to lend, confers the status of an unconditional guarantor.
<span class="gemarra-regular">A dilemma was raised before </span>the Sages: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> if one says: <span class="gemarra-regular">Lend </span>money to <span class="gemarra-regular">him and I </span>am <span class="gemarra-regular">an unconditional guarantor? </span>On the one hand, the word lend is used, as opposed to give, but on the other hand, he explicitly states that he will be an unconditional guarantor. What is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> if one says: <span class="gemarra-regular">Give </span>money <span class="gemarra-regular">to him and I </span>am <span class="gemarra-regular">a guarantor? </span>On the one hand, the word give is used, as opposed to lend, but on the other hand, he states that he will be a guarantor.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yitzḥak says </span>in resolving this dilemma: When one employs <span class="gemarra-regular">the language of </span>a standard <span class="gemarra-regular">guarantee, </span>it is a standard <span class="gemarra-regular">guarantee, </span>even if he also used the word give. And when one employs <span class="gemarra-regular">the language of an unconditional guarantee, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">an unconditional guarantee, </span>even if he also used the word lend.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥisda says: All of </span>the expressions mentioned in this discussion <span class="gemarra-regular">are expressions of an unconditional guarantee, except for: Lend </span>money to <span class="gemarra-regular">him and I </span>am <span class="gemarra-regular">a guarantor.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava says: All </span>of the expressions mentioned in this discussion <span class="gemarra-regular">are expressions of </span>a standard <span class="gemarra-regular">guarantee, except for: Give </span>money <span class="gemarra-regular">to him and I </span>will <span class="gemarra-regular">give </span>the money back to you.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Mar bar Ameimar said to Rav Ashi: My father said the following: </span>If one says: <span class="gemarra-regular">Give </span>money <span class="gemarra-regular">to him and I </span>will <span class="gemarra-regular">give </span>the money back to you, this expression binds the guarantor to such an extent that <span class="gemarra-regular">the lender has no </span>claim <span class="gemarra-regular">against the debtor at all; </span>his only option is to collect the debt from the guarantor.
The Gemara rejects this last statement: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">is not so. </span>Rather, <span class="gemarra-regular">the debtor is not exempted from </span>dealing with the <span class="gemarra-regular">creditor unless </span>the guarantor <span class="gemarra-regular">takes </span>the money from the creditor <span class="gemarra-regular">and gives </span>it to the debtor <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>his own <span class="gemarra-regular">hand</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
§ The Gemara relates: There was once <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain judge who permitted a creditor to enter the debtor’s property </span>and collect it for his debt <span class="gemarra-regular">before lodging a claim against the debtor </span>himself. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥanin, son of Rav Yeiva, </span>overruled that judge and <span class="gemarra-regular">expelled </span>the creditor from the seized property.
When <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava </span>heard about this he <span class="gemarra-regular">said: Who </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">wise </span>enough <span class="gemarra-regular">to perfor</span><span class="gemarra-regular">m</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> such a matter, </span>i.e., to issue this ruling, <span class="gemarra-regular">if not Rav Ḥanin, son of Rav Yeiva? </span><span class="gemarra-regular">He holds that a person’s property is a guarantee for him, </span>i.e., it acts as a guarantor for the loan if the debtor does not repay it; <span class="gemarra-regular">and we learned </span>in the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">One who </span><span class="gemarra-regular">lends </span>money <span class="gemarra-regular">to another with </span>the assurance of <span class="gemarra-regular">a guarantor cannot collect </span>the debt <span class="gemarra-regular">from the guarantor. And we established </span>that the mishna means that he <span class="gemarra-regular">cannot collect </span>the debt <span class="gemarra-regular">from the guarantor at the outset, </span>before seeking payment from the debtor himself. So too, he cannot collect the debt by taking the debtor’s property without first seeking payment from the debtor himself.
§ The Gemara relates: There was once <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain guarantor for orphans </span>whose father borrowed money and died, and the orphans were minors, and this guarantor <span class="gemarra-regular">repaid </span>the debt <span class="gemarra-regular">to the creditor before informing the orphans </span>that he was repaying the debt for them. The guarantor now sought reimbursement from the orphans.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa said: Repaying a creditor </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">a mitzva</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and orphans </span>who are minors <span class="gemarra-regular">are not obligated in performing a mitzva</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> They therefore do not have to repay any debts owed by their deceased father until they reach the age of majority.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>that the orphans do not have to repay the guarantor until reaching majority, but for a different reason: <span class="gemarra-regular">Say </span>that perhaps the deceased <span class="gemarra-regular">gave bundles </span>of money <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>his creditor before his death, and therefore some or all of the debt has been paid. As long as they are minors, the heirs would not be aware of this payment, but upon reaching majority there is a chance that they may examine their father’s papers and discover that their father had done this. Therefore, payment is deferred until they reach majority. 

Daf 174b

The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is </span>the difference <span class="gemarra-regular">between </span>the opinion of Rav Pappa and that of Rav Huna, son of Yehoshua, as both agree that the orphans are exempt from repaying the debt until they reach majority?
The Gemara answers: The difference <span class="gemarra-regular">between them </span>is in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where the one who owed</span> the money, i.e., the deceased, <span class="gemarra-regular">admits </span>explicitly just before his death that he did not yet repay any of his loan. <span class="gemarra-regular">Alternatively, </span>there is a difference between them in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the court <span class="gemarra-regular">excommunicated </span>the deceased for not cooperating with the court in repaying his debt, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he died </span>while still <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>a state of <span class="gemarra-regular">excommunication, </span>which demonstrates that the debt had not been repaid prior to his death. In both of these cases Rav Pappa would exempt the minor orphans from payment, as minors are not obligated to perform mitzvot, while Rav Huna, son of Yehoshua, would require them to repay the debt immediately, as there is no possibility that their father had repaid the debt.
The Sages of Eretz Yisrael <span class="gemarra-regular">sent </span>a ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">from there </span>to Babylonia: In a case where the court had <span class="gemarra-regular">excommunicated </span>a debtor for not cooperating in repaying his debt, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the debtor <span class="gemarra-regular">died </span>while still <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>a state of <span class="gemarra-regular">excommunication, the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, </span>and the orphans must repay the debt immediately.
The Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises an objection </span>from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> (<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span> 11:15): <span class="gemarra-regular">A guarantor </span>for a debt <span class="gemarra-regular">who has the promissory note </span>for that debt <span class="gemarra-regular">in his possession</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> indicating that he has repaid the debt, and now seeks reimbursement from the debtor, <span class="gemarra-regular">cannot collect </span>if the debtor has died and the obligation for the debt has fallen to his minor heirs. <span class="gemarra-regular">But if it is written </span>by the creditor <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the promissory note: <span class="gemarra-regular">I received </span>repayment <span class="gemarra-regular">from you, </span>the guarantor, then the guarantor <span class="gemarra-regular">can collect </span>the debt from the minor heirs.
The Gemara explains the objection: <span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, according to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, you find </span>a case where the minor heirs would be required to repay the debt, such as <span class="gemarra-regular">when the one who owed </span>the money, i.e., the deceased, <span class="gemarra-regular">admits </span>explicitly just before his death that he did not yet repay the loan. <span class="gemarra-regular">But according to</span> the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa, </span>who maintains that minor heirs never have to repay their father’s debts, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">difficult. </span>What is the case discussed in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>?
The Gemara answers: It is <span class="gemarra-regular">different there, </span>as it is <span class="gemarra-regular">for this</span> reason that the creditor <span class="gemarra-regular">troubled himself and wrote for </span>the guarantor: <span class="gemarra-regular">I received </span>repayment from you. Once the creditor writes this in the promissory note, it attains the status of a promissory note of the guarantor held directly against the debtor, and even Rav Pappa agrees that a debt that is recorded in a promissory note can be collected from the deceased’s property immediately, even from the minor heirs.
The Gemara relates: There was <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain guarantor </span>who had guaranteed a loan given <span class="gemarra-regular">by a gentile, who repaid the gentile </span>creditor <span class="gemarra-regular">before </span>the gentile creditor <span class="gemarra-regular">claimed </span>repayment <span class="gemarra-regular">from the orphans </span>who survived the debtor. The guarantor now sought reimbursement from the orphans. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Mordekhai said to Rav Ashi: This is </span>what <span class="gemarra-regular">Avimi of Hagronya said in the name of Rava: Even according to the one who says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">we are concerned for </span>the possibility that the deceased may have given <span class="gemarra-regular">bundles </span>of money to the creditor before his death, <span class="gemarra-regular">this statement </span>applies only in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a Jewish </span>creditor. <span class="gemarra-regular">But</span> in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a gentile </span>creditor, <span class="gemarra-regular">since </span>according to gentile law he is entitled to <span class="gemarra-regular">go </span>directly <span class="gemarra-regular">to a guarantor, we are not concerned for </span>the possibility that the deceased may have given <span class="gemarra-regular">bundles </span>of money. The debtor would not repay the gentile before the loan is due, as the latter has the right to collect directly from the guarantor, and would thereby receive double payment.
Rav Ashi <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Rav Mordekhai: <span class="gemarra-regular">On the contrary,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> even according to the one who says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">we are not concerned for </span>the possibility that the deceased may have given <span class="gemarra-regular">bundles </span>of money, <span class="gemarra-regular">this statement </span>applies only in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a Jewish </span>creditor. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a gentile </span>creditor, <span class="gemarra-regular">since </span>according to gentile <span class="gemarra-regular">law they</span> are entitled to <span class="gemarra-regular">go </span>directly <span class="gemarra-regular">to a guarantor, no </span>guarantor <span class="gemarra-regular">would accept </span>upon himself to guarantee such a loan <span class="gemarra-regular">if the debtor had not given bundles </span>of money as collateral to the gentile creditor <span class="gemarra-regular">from the outset.</span>
§ The mishna teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">And so Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel would say: </span>If there is <span class="gemarra-regular">a guarantor for a woman for her marriage contract, </span>and her husband is divorcing her, the husband must take a vow prohibiting himself from deriving any benefit from her so that he can never remarry her. The Gemara relates an incident pertaining to this ruling: Someone named <span class="gemarra-regular">Moshe bar Atzari was </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a guarantor for the marriage contract of his daughter-in-law, </span>guaranteeing the money promised by his son in the event of death or divorce. <span class="gemarra-regular">His son, </span>named <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna, was a young Torah scholar, and was in financial straits. Abaye said: Is there no one who will go advise Rav Huna</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that he should divorce his wife, and she will go and collect her marriage contract from </span>Rav Huna’s <span class="gemarra-regular">father, and then </span>Rav Huna should <span class="gemarra-regular">remarry her?</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said to </span>Abaye: <span class="gemarra-regular">But didn’t we learn </span>in the mishna that when a husband divorces his wife in such circumstances he <span class="gemarra-regular">must take a vow </span>prohibiting himself from deriving any <span class="gemarra-regular">benefit </span>from <span class="gemarra-regular">her, </span>thereby precluding the possibility of remarriage? <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said to him: Is that to say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">everyone who divorces </span>his wife <span class="gemarra-regular">divorces </span>her <span class="gemarra-regular">in a court? </span>Rav Huna could be advised to divorce his wife outside the court, in which case he could do so without being forced to take the prescribed vow.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Ultimately, it was revealed that </span>this Rav Huna <span class="gemarra-regular">was a priest, </span>who may not marry a divorcée, even his own ex-wife. Abaye’s suggestion was therefore not an option for him. Upon hearing this, <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said: This </span>is in accordance with the adage <span class="gemarra-regular">that people say: Poverty follows the poor.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But did Abaye </span>really <span class="gemarra-regular">say this? </span>Would he really encourage giving such advice? <span class="gemarra-regular">But doesn’t Abaye </span>himself <span class="gemarra-regular">say: Who is a cunning, wicked person</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> This </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">one who provides advice to sell property in accordance with </span>the ruling of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel. </span>As taught elsewhere (<span class="it-text">Ketubot</span> 95b), if one says: My property is hereby bequeathed to you, and after you die it will pass to so-and-so, Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel rules that the first recipient can sell the property, which would thereby deprive the second recipient from receiving it. Abaye said that giving advice to someone to pursue such action, though it is legally sound, is considered wicked. Here as well, why would he give advice to Rav Huna to divorce his wife only in order to force his father to pay the marriage contract?
The Gemara answers: When dealing with one’s <span class="gemarra-regular">son </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">is different</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> It is not considered wickedness to force a father to give money to his own son. Moreover, when dealing with <span class="gemarra-regular">a Torah scholar </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">is different. </span>It is not considered wickedness to procure money for a Torah scholar, because the money enables him to pursue his studies.
The Gemara asks another question with regard to this incident: <span class="gemarra-regular">But wasn’t </span>Moshe bar Atzari <span class="gemarra-regular">a guarantor? And we maintain, </span>as the Gemara will soon note, that <span class="gemarra-regular">a guarantor for a marriage contract does not become obligated </span>to pay. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">He was an unconditional guarantor.</span>
The Gemara objects: <span class="gemarra-regular">This works out well according to the one who says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">an unconditional guarantor for a marriage contract becomes obligated</span> to pay it <span class="gemarra-regular">even if the husband has no property </span>of his own at the time of the marriage. According to this opinion all is <span class="gemarra-regular">well. But according to the one who says: If </span>the husband <span class="gemarra-regular">has </span>his own property the unconditional guarantor <span class="gemarra-regular">becomes obligated </span>to pay, but <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>the husband <span class="gemarra-regular">does not have </span>his own property <span class="gemarra-regular">he does not become obligated, what is there to say? </span>Rav Huna obviously did not have any property of his own. Why, then, was his father held responsible for paying his marriage contract according to this latter opinion?
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">If you wish, say </span>that Rav Huna <span class="gemarra-regular">had </span>property when he got married, so that his father’s guarantee took effect, <span class="gemarra-regular">but it became blighted, </span>i.e., it was ruined or lost in the interim. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if you wish, say </span>instead: <span class="gemarra-regular">A father, vis-à-vis his son, </span>sincerely <span class="gemarra-regular">obligates himself </span>to guarantee his marriage contract, even when the son has no property of his own.
The Gemara elaborates on the issue under discussion. This is <span class="gemarra-regular">as it was stated: Everyone agrees </span>that a standard <span class="gemarra-regular">guarantor for a marriage contract does not become obligated </span>to pay the marriage contract, and <span class="gemarra-regular">everyone agrees </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">an unconditional guarantor for a creditor, </span>i.e., for a loan, <span class="gemarra-regular">becomes obligated </span>to repay the loan. With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">an unconditional guarantor for a marriage contract and </span>a standard <span class="gemarra-regular">guarantor for a creditor, </span>the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">disagree. </span>One <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">if the debtor</span> or husband <span class="gemarra-regular">has </span>his own <span class="gemarra-regular">property, </span>these guarantors <span class="gemarra-regular">become obligated </span>for the guarantees they have undertaken, but <span class="gemarra-regular">if he does not have </span>his own property the guarantor <span class="gemarra-regular">does not become obligated. And </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">whether </span>the debtor or husband <span class="gemarra-regular">has</span> property <span class="gemarra-regular">or does not have </span>property, the guarantor <span class="gemarra-regular">becomes obligated </span>to pay it.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is that <span class="gemarra-regular">a guarantor becomes obligated </span>to pay, <span class="gemarra-regular">whether </span>the debtor <span class="gemarra-regular">has </span>his own property <span class="gemarra-regular">or does not have </span>property. This is <span class="gemarra-regular">to the exclusion of a guarantor for a marriage contract, </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">which </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">even if the husband has </span>his own property <span class="gemarra-regular">he does not become obligated </span>to pay. <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>for this? The intention of the guarantor <span class="gemarra-regular">is to perform </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">mitzva </span>of facilitating a marriage by encouraging the woman to consent to the marriage as a result of his involvement, but he does not truly intend to obligate himself. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>furthermore, in contrast to a guarantor for a loan, where the creditor stands to suffer a loss if he is not repaid, the woman <span class="gemarra-regular">does not </span>suffer any concrete <span class="gemarra-regular">loss, </span>as the husband does not borrow money from the woman. Therefore, the level of commitment of the guarantor in this case is lower. Accordingly, the Sages instituted that the guarantor does not become responsible for payment of the marriage contract from his own property.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a person on his deathbed who consecrated all his propert</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span> to the Temple treasury, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">says: So-and-so has one hundred dinars in my possession, </span>i.e., I owe one hundred dinars to so-and-so, is <span class="gemarra-regular">deemed credible, </span>and the money is to be repaid to that person. The reason for this is that there is <span class="gemarra-regular">a presumption</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">a person does not collude against </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">Temple </span>treasury. He would not lie about owing money to someone, thereby causing a loss to the Temple treasury.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman objects to this </span>ruling: <span class="gemarra-regular">And does a person collude against his children? </span>Of course not. Yet, <span class="gemarra-regular">as Rav and Shmuel both say </span>that in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a person on his deathbed who says: So-and-so has one hundred dinars in my possession</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> only if <span class="gemarra-regular">he says</span> explicitly: <span class="gemarra-regular">Give </span>him the money, the children <span class="gemarra-regular">give </span>it, but if <span class="gemarra-regular">he did not say </span>explicitly: <span class="gemarra-regular">Give </span>him the money, the children do <span class="gemarra-regular">not give </span>it. The person on his deathbed is not assumed to be telling the truth about owing the money unless he explicitly instructs that the money be given. <span class="gemarra-regular">Apparently, </span>then, it is assumed that <span class="gemarra-regular">a person is prone </span>to make false statements so as <span class="gemarra-regular">not to make his sons </span>appear <span class="gemarra-regular">sated, </span>i.e., wealthy. A person on his deathbed may falsely claim that he is in debt in order to dispel the notion that his children are wealthy heirs. 

Daf 175a

<span class="gemarra-regular">Here, too, </span>with regard to the Temple treasury, apply the same principle and say: <span class="gemarra-regular">A person is prone </span>to make false statements so as <span class="gemarra-regular">not to make himself </span>appear <span class="gemarra-regular">sated. </span>It is therefore possible that the money was not owed, and payment should not be made from the consecrated property.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">When </span>does <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna say </span>that payment should be made <span class="gemarra-regular">there, </span>in the case of a person on his deathbed who consecrated all his property? In a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the creditor, to whom the deceased admitted owing money, <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>a promissory <span class="gemarra-regular">note </span>corroborating the deceased’s admission.
The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">By inference, </span>the statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rav and Shmuel, </span>where the money is not given to the creditor unless the person on his deathbed explicitly requests that it be given, is applicable in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the creditor <span class="gemarra-regular">does not hold </span>a promissory <span class="gemarra-regular">note </span>corroborating the admission. The Gemara asks: If so, how can it be that if the deceased <span class="gemarra-regular">says: Give </span>him the money, the children <span class="gemarra-regular">give </span>it to him, i.e., it is collected from the estate left to the heirs, as <span class="gemarra-regular">it is a loan</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> by oral </span>contract, <span class="gemarra-regular">and as Rav and Shmuel both say: One does not collect a loan by oral </span>contract <span class="gemarra-regular">from heirs nor from purchasers </span>who bought land from the debtor after the loan was granted?
The Gemara gives a different answer to this question. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Rav Naḥman said: </span>Both <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">and that</span> case are discussing <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the creditor <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>a promissory <span class="gemarra-regular">note </span>corroborating the deceased’s admission. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>yet it is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult. </span>In <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>ruling of Rav Huna, the case is <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the creditor’s promissory note has been <span class="gemarra-regular">ratified</span> by the court, and in <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>ruling of Rav and Shmuel, the case is <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the creditor’s promissory note has <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>been <span class="gemarra-regular">ratified </span>by the court. Therefore, in the latter case, if the person on his deathbed <span class="gemarra-regular">says: Give </span>him the money, he <span class="gemarra-regular">has </span>in effect <span class="gemarra-regular">ratified </span>the creditor’s promissory <span class="gemarra-regular">note, </span>and if he did <span class="gemarra-regular">not say: Give </span>him the money, he has <span class="gemarra-regular">not ratified </span>the creditor’s promissory <span class="gemarra-regular">note.</span>
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba says </span>that in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a person on his deathbed who says: So-and-so has one hundred dinars in my possession, and the orphans </span>who inherited his property subsequently <span class="gemarra-regular">said</span><span class="gemarra-regular">:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> We repaid </span>the debt, <span class="gemarra-regular">they are deemed credible. </span>But if the father said: <span class="gemarra-regular">Give one hundred dinars to so-and-so, </span>as I owe it to him, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>subsequently <span class="gemarra-regular">the orphans said: We repaid </span>him the money, <span class="gemarra-regular">they are not deemed credible.</span>
The Gemara objects: <span class="gemarra-regular">Isn’t it the opposite [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">kelappei layya</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> The opposite is </span>more <span class="gemarra-regular">reasonable. </span>If the father <span class="gemarra-regular">says: Give one hundred dinars </span>to so-and-so, <span class="gemarra-regular">since their father stated the matter assertively, </span>as he gave an explicit directive, <span class="gemarra-regular">it could be said that </span>the heirs <span class="gemarra-regular">repaid </span>the money. But if he said: <span class="gemarra-regular">So-and-so has one hundred dinars in my possession, since </span>the orphans’ <span class="gemarra-regular">father did not state the matter assertively, it could be said that </span>the heirs <span class="gemarra-regular">did not repay </span>the creditor.
