The Gemara reformulates Rabba’s statement: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, if </span>Rabba’s statement <span class="gemarra-regular">was stated, it was stated as follows: </span>In a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a person on his deathbed who says: So-and-so has one hundred dinars in my possession, and the orphans </span>subsequently <span class="gemarra-regular">said: </span>After his admission, <span class="gemarra-regular">Father retracted </span>his words <span class="gemarra-regular">and said to us: I repaid </span>the debt, <span class="gemarra-regular">they are deemed credible. What is the reason </span>for this? At first the father had forgotten, but subsequently <span class="gemarra-regular">he remembered </span>repaying the debt. But if the father says assertively: <span class="gemarra-regular">Give one hundred dinars to so-and-so, and the orphans </span>subsequently <span class="gemarra-regular">said: </span>Afterward <span class="gemarra-regular">Father retracted </span>his words <span class="gemarra-regular">and said: I repaid </span>the debt, <span class="gemarra-regular">they are not deemed credible. </span>The reason is <span class="gemarra-regular">that if it is so that </span>the father <span class="gemarra-regular">repaid </span>the debt or was uncertain about the matter, <span class="gemarra-regular">he would not say </span>with such assertiveness: <span class="gemarra-regular">Give </span>the money to him.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava raises a dilemma: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a person on his deathbed who, </span>upon hearing someone’s monetary claim against him, <span class="gemarra-regular">admitte</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> owing the money to him, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? Is it <span class="gemarra-regular">required </span>for him <span class="gemarra-regular">to say </span>to two people: <span class="gemarra-regular">You are my witnesses, </span>as is usually necessary in order to prove that an admission is stated in earnest and not in jest? <span class="gemarra-regular">Or </span>is it perhaps <span class="gemarra-regular">not required </span>for him <span class="gemarra-regular">to say: You are my witnesses, </span>since he is a person on his deathbed, whose instructions are generally binding? Is it <span class="gemarra-regular">required that he say </span>to two people: <span class="gemarra-regular">Write </span>my admission in a document, as is usually required, <span class="gemarra-regular">or </span>is it <span class="gemarra-regular">not required </span>for him <span class="gemarra-regular">to say: Write </span>my admission in a document? The issue in question here is: Does <span class="gemarra-regular">a person </span>sometimes <span class="gemarra-regular">jest at the time of death, </span>i.e., while on his deathbed, <span class="gemarra-regular">or </span>can it be assumed that <span class="gemarra-regular">a person </span>does <span class="gemarra-regular">not jest at the time of death?</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">After </span>Rava <span class="gemarra-regular">raised the dilemma, he </span><span class="gemarra-regular">then resolved it, </span>and ruled: <span class="gemarra-regular">A person </span>does <span class="gemarra-regular">not jest at the time of death, and </span>therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">the statements of a person on his deathbed are considered as </span>if they were <span class="gemarra-regular">written </span>in a document <span class="gemarra-regular">and transmitte</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> to the relevant party.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">One who lends </span>money <span class="gemarra-regular">to another by means of </span>a promissory <span class="gemarra-regular">note can collect </span>the debt <span class="gemarra-regular">from liened property </span>that had been sold to others by the debtor after the loan was granted. One who lends money <span class="gemarra-regular">by means of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> without recording the loan in a promissory note, <span class="gemarra-regular">can collect </span>the debt only <span class="gemarra-regular">from unsold property. </span>

Daf 175b

If one <span class="gemarra-regular">presents to </span>a debtor a document in the <span class="gemarra-regular">handwriting of </span>the debtor stating <span class="gemarra-regular">that he owes </span>money <span class="gemarra-regular">to him, </span>but without witnesses signed on the document, the creditor <span class="gemarra-regular">can collect </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">from unsold property.</span>
In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a guarantor whose </span>commitment <span class="gemarra-regular">emerged after the signing of </span>the promissory <span class="gemarra-regular">note</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the creditor <span class="gemarra-regular">can collect </span>the sum only <span class="gemarra-regular">from unsold property </span>of the guarantor.
The mishna relates: <span class="gemarra-regular">An incident </span>occurred where such a case <span class="gemarra-regular">came before Rabbi Yishmael</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and he said: </span>The creditor can <span class="gemarra-regular">collect </span>the sum <span class="gemarra-regular">from unsold property </span>of the guarantor, but not from liened property that he has sold to others. <span class="gemarra-regular">Ben Nanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> said to </span>Rabbi Yishmael: The creditor <span class="gemarra-regular">cannot collect </span>the sum from the guarantor at all, <span class="gemarra-regular">not from liened property </span>that has been sold, <span class="gemarra-regular">nor from unsold property.</span>
Rabbi Yishmael <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Why </span>not? Ben Nannas <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">one was strangling someone in the marketplace</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> demanding repayment of a loan, <span class="gemarra-regular">and another </span>person <span class="gemarra-regular">found him </span>doing so and <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>the attacker: <span class="gemarra-regular">Leave him </span>alone <span class="gemarra-regular">and I will give you </span>the money he owes, the person who intervened is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from paying, <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>the creditor <span class="gemarra-regular">did not loan </span>the money in the first place <span class="gemarra-regular">based on his trust </span>of the one who intervened. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, who is a guarantor who is obligated </span>to repay the loan he has guaranteed? One who tells the creditor before the loan takes place: <span class="gemarra-regular">Lend </span>money to <span class="gemarra-regular">him, and I will give you </span>the repayment, <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>in that case the creditor <span class="gemarra-regular">did loan </span>the money <span class="gemarra-regular">based on his trust </span>of the guarantor.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Yishmael </span>thereupon <span class="gemarra-regular">said: One who wants to become wise should engage in </span>the study of <span class="gemarra-regular">monetary law</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as there is no greater discipline in the Torah, and it is like a flowing spring. And, </span>he added, <span class="gemarra-regular">one who wants to engage in </span>the study of <span class="gemarra-regular">monetary law should attend to, </span>i.e., become a disciple of, <span class="gemarra-regular">Shimon ben Nannas.</span>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">Ulla says: By Torah law, </span>a creditor, <span class="gemarra-regular">whether </span>in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a loan with </span>a promissory <span class="gemarra-regular">note or </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a loan by oral </span>contract, can <span class="gemarra-regular">collect </span>the debt <span class="gemarra-regular">from liened property </span>that has been sold by the debtor subsequent to his receiving the loan. <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>for this? The property of a debtor at the time of the loan, even an oral loan, is <span class="gemarra-regular">liened by Torah </span><span class="gemarra-regular">law</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">And what is the reason </span>the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>that one who gives <span class="gemarra-regular">a loan by oral </span>contract can <span class="gemarra-regular">collect </span>the debt <span class="gemarra-regular">only from unsold </span>property? <span class="gemarra-regular">Because of the loss </span>that would be incurred <span class="gemarra-regular">by purchasers </span>of land if the seller’s creditors could seize the land they have purchased.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, a loan with </span>a promissory <span class="gemarra-regular">note </span>should <span class="gemarra-regular">also </span>not be collected from purchasers of property, as this would cause them a loss. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">There, </span>in the case of a loan recorded in a promissory note, the purchasers, who neglected to investigate the financial status of the seller before purchasing land from him, <span class="gemarra-regular">brought the loss upon themselves. </span>By contrast, loans by oral contract are often impossible to discover, even with a thorough investigation.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabba says: By Torah law, </span>a creditor, <span class="gemarra-regular">whether </span>in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a loan with </span>a promissory <span class="gemarra-regular">note or </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a loan by oral </span>contract, can <span class="gemarra-regular">collect </span>the debt <span class="gemarra-regular">only from </span>the debtor’s <span class="gemarra-regular">unsold property. What is the reason </span>for this? The property of a debtor is <span class="gemarra-regular">not liened by Torah law. And what is the reason </span>the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>that one who gives <span class="gemarra-regular">a loan </span><span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>a promissory <span class="gemarra-regular">note can collect </span>the debt <span class="gemarra-regular">from liened property </span>that has been sold? <span class="gemarra-regular">So as not to lock the door in the face of </span>potential <span class="gemarra-regular">borrowers. </span>If one could not collect a debt by taking liened property that has been sold, people would be hesitant to put their money at risk by lending it.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If that is so, </span>that there is a desire to encourage people to lend money by granting greater power of collection to creditors, <span class="gemarra-regular">a loan by oral </span>contract should <span class="gemarra-regular">also </span>be collectible from liened property that has been sold. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">There, </span>in the case of a loan by oral contract, <span class="gemarra-regular">it has no publicity </span>associated with it, so that purchasers often cannot find out about it, even after a thorough investigation, and it would be an unfair burden on them to have the property purchased by them seized in such cases.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And did Rabba </span>really <span class="gemarra-regular">say this? But doesn’t Rabba say, </span>in the case of a firstborn son, that if he and his brothers <span class="gemarra-regular">collected </span>a debt from <span class="gemarra-regular">land, he has </span>the right to receive a double portion of that payment, but if <span class="gemarra-regular">they collected </span>a debt from <span class="gemarra-regular">money, he does not have </span>the right to a double portion? A firstborn son is entitled to a double share of inheritance of any property that was owned by his father at the time of his death, but not to profits or income that accrue to the estate after his death. If a debt owed to the father is collected from land after his death, Rabba said that the firstborn is entitled to a double portion, indicating that the land was considered in the father’s possession even before he died, which indicates that Rabba holds that the property of a debtor is liened to a creditor by Torah law.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if you would say: </span>The opinions as they were cited earlier are attributed incorrectly, and it is necessary to <span class="gemarra-regular">reverse </span>the two opinions, and exchange the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba for </span>that of <span class="gemarra-regular">Ulla, and</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">of Ulla for </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabba, </span>there is a difficulty: <span class="gemarra-regular">But doesn’t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Ulla say </span>elsewhere: <span class="gemarra-regular">By Torah law </span>the <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of a creditor is </span>to collect his debt only <span class="gemarra-regular">from inferior-quality land</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span>
The Gemara resolves the contradiction between Rabba’s two statements: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Rabba was stating an explanation for </span>the opinion of the <span class="gemarra-regular">people of the West, </span>Eretz Yisrael, cited earlier (125a), <span class="gemarra-regular">but he himself does not hold accordingly, </span>as he holds that a firstborn son is not entitled to a double portion of a debt collected from land.
The Gemara continues to discuss the issue of the extent of liens on a debtor’s property. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav and Shmuel both say: </span>In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a loan by oral </span>contract, the creditor <span class="gemarra-regular">can collect </span>the debt only from the one who took the loan, but <span class="gemarra-regular">not from the heirs </span>of the debtor after his death, <span class="gemarra-regular">and not from purchasers </span>of his property. <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>for this? They maintain that the property of a debtor is <span class="gemarra-regular">not liened by Torah law.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan and Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish both say: </span>In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a loan by oral </span>contract, the creditor <span class="gemarra-regular">can collect </span>the debt <span class="gemarra-regular">both from the heirs </span>of the debtor after his death <span class="gemarra-regular">and from the purchaser</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> of his property. <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>for this? They maintain that the property of a debtor is <span class="gemarra-regular">liened by Torah law.</span>
The Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises an objection </span>to the opinion of Rav and Shmuel from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> (<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span>, <span class="it-text">Bava</span> <span class="it-text">Kamma</span> 6:2): If <span class="gemarra-regular">one was digging a pit in the public domain</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and an ox fell on him and killed him </span>as he was in the pit, the owner of the ox is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt </span>from paying for the damage caused, as it is the one who dug the pit who is at fault. <span class="gemarra-regular">Moreover, if </span>it occurred <span class="gemarra-regular">that the ox died </span>as a result of the fall, <span class="gemarra-regular">the heirs of the owner of the pit are liable to pay the value of the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">ox to its owner. </span>Compensation for damages is comparable to a loan by oral contract, and yet the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> states that the heirs of the culpable party must pay it.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ela says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says:</span> The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is discussing a case <span class="gemarra-regular">in which </span>the one who dug the pit <span class="gemarra-regular">stood trial </span>for the damage before he died, and once judgment is rendered by a court, the resulting financial liability is comparable to a loan with a promissory note.
The Gemara objects: <span class="gemarra-regular">But it is taught </span>in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">killed him </span>by falling on him. How then can one say that he stood trial? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Adda bar Ahava says: </span>The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> does not mean that the ox killed him instantly, but <span class="gemarra-regular">that it rendered him one who has a wound that will cause him to die within twelve months [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">tereifa</span><span class="gemarra-regular">], </span>and there was enough time before his death to try him and deem him liable to pay for damages.
The Gemara objects that there is a different version of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> according to which this interpretation is not possible: <span class="gemarra-regular">But doesn’t Rav Naḥman say</span> that a certain <span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> taught </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> with a different formulation, stating that the one who dug the pit <span class="gemarra-regular">died </span>from the impact of the ox <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the ox in effect <span class="gemarra-regular">buried him </span>in the ground at the bottom of the pit? In this scenario it would be impossible to take the one who dug the pit to court to stand trial. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">There, </span>according to that second version, it is discussing a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where judges sat at the opening of the pit and deemed liable </span>the one who dug the pit to pay for the damage before he died. 

Daf 176a

<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa said: The </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is that when a creditor gives <span class="gemarra-regular">a loan by oral </span>contract, he can <span class="gemarra-regular">collect </span>the debt <span class="gemarra-regular">from the heir</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> of the debtor after his death, <span class="gemarra-regular">but he cannot collect </span>the debt <span class="gemarra-regular">from the purchaser</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> of the debtor’s property. He can <span class="gemarra-regular">collect </span>the debt <span class="gemarra-regular">from the heirs so as not to lock the door in the face of </span>potential <span class="gemarra-regular">borrowers. But he cannot collect </span>the debt <span class="gemarra-regular">from the purchasers, as </span>a loan by oral contract <span class="gemarra-regular">has no publicity </span>associated with it.
§ The mishna teaches: If one <span class="gemarra-regular">presents to </span>a debtor a document in the <span class="gemarra-regular">handwriting of</span> the debtor stating <span class="gemarra-regular">that he owes </span>money <span class="gemarra-regular">to him, </span>but without witnesses signed on the document, the creditor <span class="gemarra-regular">can collect </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">from unsold property. Rabba bar Natan asked Rabbi Yoḥanan: </span>If the document in the <span class="gemarra-regular">handwriting of </span>the debtor <span class="gemarra-regular">was ratified in court </span>at a later time, <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? Would it then be possible to collect the debt from liened property that has been sold? Rabbi Yoḥanan <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him </span>in reply: <span class="gemarra-regular">Even if </span>the document in the <span class="gemarra-regular">handwriting of </span>the debtor <span class="gemarra-regular">was ratified in court, </span>the creditor <span class="gemarra-regular">can collect </span>the debt <span class="gemarra-regular">only from unsold property.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rami bar Ḥama raises an objection</span> from a mishna (<span class="it-text">Gittin</span> 86a), which states: There are <span class="gemarra-regular">three </span>types of <span class="gemarra-regular">bills of divorce </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">are not valid </span><span class="it-text">ab</span> <span class="it-text">initio</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span><span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>the woman <span class="gemarra-regular">marries </span>another man on the basis of one of these bills of divorce the lineage of <span class="gemarra-regular">the offspring </span>from this marriage <span class="gemarra-regular">is unflawed. </span>In other words, she is not considered to be a married woman who engaged in sexual intercourse with another man, which would impair the lineage of their child. <span class="gemarra-regular">And they are these: </span>A bill of divorce that the husband <span class="gemarra-regular">wrote in his handwritin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> but there are no </span>signatures of <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses in </span>the document at all; a bill of divorce where <span class="gemarra-regular">there are </span>the signatures of <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses in </span>the document <span class="gemarra-regular">but there is no date </span>written <span class="gemarra-regular">in it</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span> and a bill of divorce where <span class="gemarra-regular">there is a date </span>written <span class="gemarra-regular">in it, but it contains only one witness. These are </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">three bills of divorce </span>that are <span class="gemarra-regular">not valid </span>with regard to which the Sages said: <span class="gemarra-regular">And if she marries, </span>the lineage of <span class="gemarra-regular">the offspring is unflawed.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar says: Even though there are no </span>signatures of <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses in </span>the document, <span class="gemarra-regular">but he handed it to her in the presence of </span>two <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> it is <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">valid </span>bill of divorce. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>on the basis of this bill of divorce the woman can <span class="gemarra-regular">collect </span>the amount written to her in her marriage contract even <span class="gemarra-regular">from liened propert</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span> that has been sold. This indicates that even when no witnesses signed the document, the debt listed therein can be collected from liened property that has been sold, as long as witnesses saw the document being transferred to the creditor. All the more so a debt listed in a document in the handwriting of the debtor that has been ratified by a court should be eligible for collection from liened property that has been sold.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">There </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">is different, as </span>the husband <span class="gemarra-regular">obligated himself </span>and his property immediately <span class="gemarra-regular">from the time of </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">writin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span> of the document, as he knew at that time that the document would be transferred in the presence of witnesses. By contrast, in the case of the mishna here, the document in the handwriting of the debtor was written without the intent of ratifying it. It was only at a later date, as an afterthought, that it was ratified, and the terms of the obligation of the debt cannot be changed at that time.
§ The mishna teaches: In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a guarantor whose</span> commitment <span class="gemarra-regular">emerged, </span>i.e., was written, <span class="gemarra-regular">after the signing of </span>the promissory <span class="gemarra-regular">note</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the creditor can collect the debt only from unsold property of the guarantor. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav says: </span>If the guarantor’s commitment is written <span class="gemarra-regular">before the signing of the document, </span>the creditor can <span class="gemarra-regular">collect </span>the debt from the guarantor <span class="gemarra-regular">from liened property </span>that has been sold; if it is written <span class="gemarra-regular">after the signing of the document, </span>the creditor can <span class="gemarra-regular">collect </span>the debt only <span class="gemarra-regular">from unsold property.</span>
At other <span class="gemarra-regular">times, Rav said: Even </span>if the guarantee is written <span class="gemarra-regular">before the signing of the document, </span>the creditor can <span class="gemarra-regular">collect </span>the debt <span class="gemarra-regular">only from unsold property.</span>
The Gemara asks: There is <span class="gemarra-regular">a difficulty </span>resulting from the contradiction between one statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav to </span>the other statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav, </span>as they seem to contradict one another with regard to a guarantee that is written before the signing of the document. The Gemara answers: This is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult. This </span>case, where Rav says the creditor can collect the debt only from unsold property, is <span class="gemarra-regular">where it was written in </span>the document as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">So-and-so </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">a guarantor, </span>as this formulation is an independent statement, and the witnesses signing the document do not necessarily relate to that statement. And <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>case, where Rav says the creditor can collect the debt from liened property that has been sold, is <span class="gemarra-regular">where it was written in </span>the document as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">And so-and-so </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">a guarantor. </span>The usage of the conjunctive: And, causes this clause to be an integral part of the document, so that the signatures of the witnesses relate to it as well.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Yoḥanan says: </span>In <span class="gemarra-regular">both this </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">and that </span>case, the creditor can <span class="gemarra-regular">collect </span>the debt <span class="gemarra-regular">only from unsold property. </span>The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>according to the opinion of Rabbi Yoḥanan, this is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">even if it is written in </span>the document: <span class="gemarra-regular">And so-and-so </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">a guarantor.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava raises an objection </span>from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> (<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span>, <span class="it-text">Gittin</span> 9:9): In a case where <span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses are signed on a greeting </span>written <span class="gemarra-regular">in a bill of divorce</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the bill of divorce is <span class="gemarra-regular">not valid, </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">we are concerned </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">perhaps </span>the witnesses <span class="gemarra-regular">signed on the greeting </span>alone, i.e., they did not intend to testify to the divorce, but only to verify that the greeting was written.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Abbahu said </span>concerning this <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">It was explained to me </span>personally <span class="gemarra-regular">by Rabbi Yoḥanan </span>himself that it is only when the wording of the greeting begins: <span class="gemarra-regular">Send a greeting </span>to so-and-so, that the bill of divorce is <span class="gemarra-regular">not valid, </span>as this is an independent statement and it is possible that the signatures relate to it alone. But if the wording is: <span class="gemarra-regular">And send a greeting </span>to so-and-so, the usage of the conjunctive: And, causes this clause to be an integral part of the document, and the bill of divorce is <span class="gemarra-regular">valid. </span>This indicates that Rabbi Yoḥanan himself maintains that when the conjunction is used the signatures relate to the entire document.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Here too, </span>when did Rabbi Yoḥanan say that the creditor can collect the debt only from the guarantor’s unsold property? <span class="gemarra-regular">Where it was written: So-and-so </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">a guarantor. </span>If the conjunction is used, he can collect the debt even from liened property that has been sold.
The Gemara objects: But <span class="gemarra-regular">if so, this is </span>identical to the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav, </span>whereas Rabbi Yoḥanan was presented as disagreeing with Rav. The Gemara answers: That presentation was inaccurate. <span class="gemarra-regular">Say </span>instead: <span class="gemarra-regular">And so Rabbi Yoḥanan says </span>as Rav did.
§ The mishna relates: <span class="gemarra-regular">An incident </span>occurred where such a case <span class="gemarra-regular">came before Rabbi Yishmael, </span>and he said: The creditor can collect the debt from unsold property of the guarantor, but not from liened property that the guarantor has sold to others. Ben Nannas said to Rabbi Yishmael: The creditor cannot collect the debt from the guarantor at all, not from liened property that has been sold, nor from unsold property. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba bar bar Ḥana says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: Although Rabbi Yishmael praised Ben Nannas </span>after hearing his dissenting opinion (see 175b), the <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is actually <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>Rabbi Yishmael’s opinion as he stated it initially, i.e., that in the case of a guarantee that is written after the signatures, the creditor can collect the debt only from unsold property of the guarantor, but not from liened property that has been sold.
<span class="gemarra-regular">A dilemma was raised before </span>the Sages: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>would <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yishmael say to me about </span>the case of the debtor who was being <span class="gemarra-regular">strangled, </span>as depicted by ben Nannas? Perhaps he would agree in that case, since the guarantee was given under duress, that it is not valid. The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear, as Rabbi Yaakov says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: Rabbi Yishmael disagreed </span>with ben Nannas <span class="gemarra-regular">also in </span>the case of the debtor being <span class="gemarra-regular">strangled.</span>
The Gemara asks: And is the <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in accordance with </span>Rabbi Yishmael’s opinion even in the case of the debtor being strangled, <span class="gemarra-regular">or </span>is the <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not in accordance with his </span>opinion in that case? <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear, as</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> when Ravin came </span>he said that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: Rabbi Yishmael disagreed </span>with ben Nannas <span class="gemarra-regular">also in </span>the case of the debtor being <span class="gemarra-regular">strangled, and </span>the <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>Rabbi Yishmael’s opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">also in </span>the case of the debtor being <span class="gemarra-regular">strangled.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel says: </span>If the debtor was being <span class="gemarra-regular">strangled, and </span>in addition <span class="gemarra-regular">an act of acquisition was performed with </span>the guarantor, the guarantor <span class="gemarra-regular">becomes obligated </span>to repay the debt. The Gemara deduces: <span class="gemarra-regular">By inference </span>it emerges <span class="gemarra-regular">that a guarantor generally does not require an act of acquisition </span>to become obligated to pay. <span class="gemarra-regular">And</span> this <span class="gemarra-regular">disagrees with </span>a statement of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman, as Rav Naḥman says: </span>

Daf 176b

<span class="gemarra-regular">It is </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">a guarantor </span>who undertakes a loan guarantee <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the presence of <span class="gemarra-regular">a court who does not require an act of acquisition; this </span>indicates that <span class="gemarra-regular">generally, </span>a guarantor <span class="gemarra-regular">requires an act of acquisition </span>in order to be obligated to pay.
The Gemara concludes: <span class="gemarra-regular">And the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is that <span class="gemarra-regular">a guarantor </span>who accepts responsibility for the loan <span class="gemarra-regular">at the time of the giving of the money does not require an act of acquisition; </span>but if he accepts responsibility <span class="gemarra-regular">after the giving of the money</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> he <span class="gemarra-regular">requires an act of acquisition. </span>Moreover, <span class="gemarra-regular">a guarantor </span>who undertakes a loan guarantee <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the presence of a <span class="gemarra-regular">cour</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> does not require an act of acquisition, as </span>in return <span class="gemarra-regular">for that gratification that </span>he experiences in that the court <span class="gemarra-regular">trusts him, he resolves to obligate himself</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
